column2: CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery never had any doubt that the drive of his British Eighth Army would reach Tripoli. In his order of the day issued just before the attack was launched Jan. 12 from Buerat el Hsun, he said frankly that his aim was to complete the campaign that would mean the death knell for Premier Mussolini's empire.

The heavy burden imposed on paper and glass as replacement materials for packages formerly made of tin and other critical items was emphasized yesterday at the judging of some 8,000 entries in the All-America Packaging Competition, sponsored by Modern Packaging, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Humphrey O. Clarke, Third Secretary of the British Embassy, and Mrs. Clarke have come from Washington to the Pierre.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 23 -- The Allies have overwhelmed the Japanese throughout the Sanananda sector of New Guinea and now control the entire Papuan peninsula, the High Command announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet midday communique as recorded here by the Soviet radio monitor:

It is reported from a trustworthy source that the leaders of the Fighting French and of the liberated French in Africa -- presumably General Charles de Gaulle, General d'Astier de la Vigerie and General Georges Catroux on the one side and General Henri Honore Giraud on the Other -- are now conferring and that British-American pressure is being brought to bear upon them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Board of War Communications established priorities today, effective Feb. 15, for all telegraph, cable and radio telegraph carriers, giving first call to messages of the War, Navy and State Departments.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- The Red Army is throwing a half-moon are around Voroshilovgrad with one tip only ten miles east of that industrial capital of the Donets Basin, Soviet communiques indicated today.

A revision of duties allocated to members of the Board of Superintendents, which will place the Bureau of Supplies, recently under attack by the Commissioner of Investigation, under supervision of the board, was announced, yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The scheduled work week in war industries went over the forty-eight-hour mark in November through an increase of 0.7 per cent over October in average weekly hours, Secretary Perkins reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Japanese power on Guadalcanal has been irreparably broken and now probably consists of no more than 4,000 enemy soldiers of whom half are disorganized stragglers, it was stated here today by Lieut. Col. Lewis B. Puller, veteran Marine Corps officer, who left Henderson Field in a plane on Jan. 1.

Grocery lists in hand, a group of city housewives have started working for the government in a special wartime volunteer service by compiling homely statistics on the kinds and amounts of food they buy.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Operating virtually around the clock, British and United States airmen hammered many targets in Germany, Northern France and Belgium and in Norwegian waters during last night and by daylight today.

Only $1,862,000 of new municipal financing will come up for award next week, compared with this week's total of $28,559,075, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The largest issue will be $675,000 of East Chicago (Ind.) Sanitary District sewage disposal plant bonds due from 1945 to 1969, which is scheduled to be sold on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Standardized grade labeling, plans for which were announced by OPA some time ago for packed fruits and vegetables, was put into effect for the first time today in a maximum price regulation which, at the same time, set dollars-and-cents maximums for canned grapefruit juice at the packer level.

No Army or Navy wife or mother need ever feel lonely or at a loss, because she belongs to the biggest ready-made club imaginable, organized to help her in her new job as "the woman behind the man behind the gun."

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Lee Savold, Paterson, N.J., heavyweight, knocked out Nate Bolden of Chicago in the third round of their scheduled ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium tonight after flooring Bolden twice.

Led by Bill Sheron with 22 points, St. Francis Prep's basketball team registered its seventh straight Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. victory and continued in the lead by routing Brooklyn Cathedral Prep, 57 to 31, on the atter's court yesterday. The victors held a 25-15 lead at the half.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Factories' wartime experience, particularly with women workers, indicates "non-rotation or very infrequent rotation" between day and night shifts is most efficient, a State Labor Department physician said today.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation, working under wartime handicaps, approved thirty-eight world track and field records in 1942, ten established by athletes from the United States.

As a Baltimore basketball fan, who often visits Madison Square Garden while on business trips to New York, I would like to point out that the games there this season differ from those of past years on one count. We are seeing very few standout ball-handlers.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 22 (AP) -- New Jersey's highest law tribunal, the Court of Errors and Appeals, criticized today the practice of some banks of furnishing credit ratings for the customers.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as recorded here by the Soviet radio monitor:
You are entitled to the thanks of all good citizens for your intelligent and forthright opposition to the appointment of Mr. Flynn as Minister to Australia.
The Rabbinical Assembly of America, consisting of 335 rabbis throughout the United States, reaffirmed yesterday its loyalty to the Zionist cause.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Republican minority of the Ways and Means Committee, declaring that the taxpayers of the country are entitled to know as soon as possible what their increased tax burden will be and the form in which it will be paid, called today for immediate hearings on prospective legislation, including some form or pay-as-you-go collection of personal income levies.
War scars the earth and scars men's souls, but sometimes it yields to some men the choice of how they shall die. It extended this grim gift to Major Eric Knight and he accepted it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A globe-girdling network of mobile drydocks for repairing United Nations vessels and possibly converting some from one type to another is planned by the Navy.
SARASOTA, Fla., Jan. 22 (AP) -- There will be some big league Spring training in Florida after all.

Kitchen cabinets designed to match other furniture in the house will make this room as attractive as the living room in the home of the future, H. Creston Doner, director of the department of design of the Libby-Owens-Ford Glass Company, told decorators yesterday.

Almost without exception those who have come out of occupied Europe in recent months tell the same story. They say that the thoughts of people inside the conquered countries are quite different from the thoughts of people outside. They say that in France there is far less interest in French politics than is currently manifest in the United States.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Jan. 22 -- Dr. Charles A. Luce, for fifty-two years a practicing physician here and president of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Amityville for thirty-two years, shot and killed himself with a rifle yesterday in a bedroom in the Luce homestead at Albany Avenue and Broadway, where he also maintained his office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An agreement was reached between the United States and Mexico through an exchange of notes in Mexico City today providing for the inducting of nationals of either country resident within the territory of the other into the armed forces of the country of their residence.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, at a rally in Town Hall yesterday, opened a nation-wide Women's Week in behalf of the fight against poliomyelitis, urging that women, particularly at this time, volunteer in the campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan upheld today the contention of the State Parole Board that its action in releasing or not releasing a prisoner who has completed his minimum sentence is an administrative function, not reviewable by the courts if done according to law.

MIAMI, Jan. 22 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor ratified today the agreement for arbitration of jurisdictional disputes formulated by the joint A.F. of L.-Congress of Industrial Organizations peace committee on Dec. 2.

The New York State Bar Association endorsed the Ruml pay-as-you-go Federal income tax plan yesterday at its sixty-sixth annual meeting, at which speakers assailed the growth of bureaucracy and attempts to advance social reforms under the guise of war necessity.

Organization of a national association of salesmen for manufacturers and wholesalers representing all industries is in a formative stage, it was learned yesterday. Purpose of the group will be to help manufacturers maintain their markets and increase their war work as well as keep employment of its members at as high a level as possible for the duration.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 -- The University of Pittsburgh is in the market for a high-class football coach, and Clark Daniel Shaughnessy, former Stanford mentor and widely known exponent of the T formation, is a leading candidate the job.

Employment dropped 8.5 per cent, payrolls 5.8 per cent and man-hours 6.1 per cent in the construction industries of New York State from the middle of November to mid-December, according to a report issued by the State Department of Labor yesterday.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman, announced yesterday the resignation of Mrs. Ruth Pratt as a member of the Republican National Committee. He said that Mrs. Charles W. Weis Jr. of Rochester, vice chairman of the Monroe County Republican Committee and president of the National Federation of Republican Women's Clubs, has been recommended as Mrs. Pratt's successor.

Earl Bryant, 21 years old, a gunner's mate with a Navy citation for bravery under fire, was indicted yesterday for murder in the first degree by the Richmond County grand jury at St. George, S.I., for the killing of Frederick Vaughn Jr., 22, a radio technician of Irvington, N.J.

Ray Robinson, Harlem's unbeaten welterweight, will have one more ring engagement before he enters the Army. He was matched yesterday by Mike Jacobs for a ten-round battle against Sergeant Jackie Wilson, California, in the Garden on Feb. 19.

In a recent letter to you, Morton Bartlett asked how the statement that "skiing probably has done more to improve the physical welfare of American youth in recent years than any other sport" can be justified. He attributed that quoted statement of mine either to over-enthusiasm or exaggeration, and contended that swimming has made a much greater contribution (and not "probably").

When news comes that the Marines are leaving Guadalcanal for a well-earned rest we know that this is not because they asked to be relieved of their assignment. They have been on Guadalcanal since Aug. 7, and at no time have they asked relief from any duty or respite from any risk.
WASHANGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- J.A. Krug, a former official of the Tennessee Valley Authority, was named Power Director today with responsibility for electricity, gas, water and communications.

Recordings of the newest popular tunes are being made by "bootleg bands" in defiance of the ban by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and are receiving wide distribution through department stores, it became known yesterday.
Martha Punt will not be buried in potter's field, for the people of San Juan Hill yesterday were able to raise $138 to give the slain 12-year-old schoolgirl a fitting funeral service and burial.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- The War Production Board has told the village of Larchmont it will have to wait until the end of the war to blow three special air raid sirens recently purchased at the insistence of the Office of Civilian Defense.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The corner business property at Third and Washington Streets, Hoboken, N.J., occupied by a drug store for the last eighteen years, has been sold for cash by the Elleau estate to H. Braunstein. The C.B. Snyder Realty Company was the broker and Lehlbach Ormond and S. Davidson were the attorneys.

Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. expressed regret in General Sessions yesterday that he could not impose a more severe term on John Martin, 26 years old, a Negro on whom he imposed a total of twelve and one-half to twenty-five years in State prison for the rape and robbery of one of ten white and Negro women residents of Washington Heights between October and December last.

Lou Little and other prominent coaches have snarled at the athletic directors because of the decrease in competitive sports. Neither their name-calling nor their praises of competition have clarified the so-called controversy regarding competitive athletics and physical education programs.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 22--Bolstered by American and British reinforcements, French troops have halted a twin-pronged German thrust along a mountain range running southwestward from Pont du Fahs, General Henri Honore Giraud reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Mexico has purchased about 6,000,000 bushels of wheat from the United States and Canada in recent weeks and the controversy over shipping Canadian grain to Mexico has been cleared up, trade sources here have been informed.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The Hudson County Tax Board, in a report to Governor Edison today, disclaimed responsibility for the exodus of many large corporations from this city to other parts of the State, declaring it would have violated the law if it had continued to give corporations preferred rates on their intangible personal properties.

The German High Command acknowledged openly for the first time yesterday that its army before Stalingrad had been trapped by the great Russian offensive and was fighting for its life against far superior forces, which on Thursday broke through the German lines from the west to a depth of several kilometers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- That there is no conflict between the views of General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, and the policy of the United States of refusing recognition to any French provisional regime that might compromise the freedom of the French to decide their own political future was indicated today by Adrien Tixier, chief of the Fighting French delegation in this country.
If you have a little space, I don't like to pass without comment the seven letters in today's TIMES disagreeing with my piece in your Magazine last Sunday entitled "We Shall Hate or We Shall Fail."

Resentment against the New Deal bureaucracy, which he said was the major factor in substantial gains in the Republican membership of the House of Representatives at the last election, has increased since November and is still growing, Harrison E. Spangler, recently elected chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared yesterday.

ONE of the most surprising track crowds of the last decade was not the gathering of 90,000 faithful Germans who appeared at the Olympic Stadium for the preliminary trials of the hammer throw, of all things, one Summer morning almost seven years ago. Instead it was a far smaller but far more genuine outpouring of 2,500 fans at the first half of the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships last Saturday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22--British Eighth Army forces were almost at the gates of Tripoli yesterday after a day of skirmishing in the sand flats immediately south and east of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House Appropriations Committee started a bi-partisan program today to widen its functions so that it could go directly into government establishments to ascertain where economies can be made. This action was taken as it was revealed by the joint Congressional economy committee that six Federal agencies would increase their personnel by more than 130,000 by next July.

HAVANA, Jan. 22 -- Faced with the prospect of grinding only 3,200,000 short tons of sugar this year, the Cane Planters Association last night issued a manifesto to the public criticizing the United States policy toward Cuba's industry which, it pointed out, was the basis of the island's economy.

Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, reiterated yesterday a denial of the OWI that its agents had sought to force the inclusion of Communists in an Italian-American Victory Committee as charged by friends and associates of the assassinated anti-Fascist and anti-Communist Carlo Tresca.

STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Merchants of this Fairfield County municipality and those in the neighboring towns of Greenwich and Westport will conform with Governor Raymond D. Baldwin's recent request for fuel oil conservation by remaining closed, with few exceptions, for two consecutive days a week for the duration of the fuel crisis.

The second half of the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships will be held at Columbia's South Field, 115th Street and Broadway, today. Pincus Sober, chairman of the games committee, emphasized yesterday that fans should not confuse the location with the Lions' uptown Baker Field.

The Andrew Jackson High School swimming team won the dual meet championship of the P.S.A.L. by defeating Brooklyn Tech in the Textile pool yesterday, 41 to 26. The triumph was the ninth successive one of the season for Jackson and the twenty-fifth in a row over a period of three years.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 -- British naval torpedo planes operating from Malta sank one Axis supply ship and damaged two others in raids Wednesday night.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A British communique:

Efforts of the State Board of Mediation to decrease strikes and increase the use of arbitration to settle disputes between labor and management were successful to a considerable extent during 1942, the first year of the war, according to the board's annual report, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A large transport seaplane carrying a crew of nine men and ten naval officers as passengers was reported by the Navy at 5:50 this evening to be "more than twenty-four hours overdue on a flight from Pearl Harbor to San Francisco."

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Developments in Washington overshadowed all other factors as a price-making influence in the grain markets today. Announcement that the House Agricultural Committee had approved unanimously a bill that would force the inclusion of all costs of farm labor in computing parity prices on agricultural products and a report that the government was not contemplating placing a ceiling price on wheat started a general short-covering movement on the Board of Trade.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 23 (UP) -- A headquarters spokesman said that at Rabaul anti-aircraft and searchlight batteries had been particularly active recently and that in yesterday's attack the big bombers had to dive down through heavy fire and concentrated light beams to get at the targets.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Navy Department announced today ninety-five casualties, including eighteen dead, thirty-seven wounded and forty missing.

At informal exercises yesterday afternoon in Earl Hall, sixty-three graduates of the School of Engineering of Columbia University received their Bachelor of Science degrees after completing courses of study that were accelerated by the war.

In a beautifully played first-round match that was see-saw right down to the end of the fifth game, Henry P. Esquerre of the University Club defeated F.B. Chase of the Yale Club last night in the Class C tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association at the Harvard Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Military Affairs Committee of the Senate began a movement today to start investigations of nominations submitted by Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Director, and look into the entire manpower situation.

There will be an increase in the price of wine in this area as a result of the Office of Defense Transportation's recent directive requisitioning the wine industry's tank cars, J. Campbell Moore, president of the American Wine Association, said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 (AP) --Clark Daniel Shaughnessy confirmed tonight that he has been negotiating with the University of Pittsburgh and said he expected developments to reach a definite stage over the week-end.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza, impresario of the Metropolitan Opera for a quarter century, who died in Ferrera, Italy, on Sept. 2, 1940, left a gross estate of $266,735, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court here by the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York as an ancillary executor.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The bodies of forty-two children and six teachers, victims of the Nazi bombing of a London school Wednes'day, Will share"a common grave, officials-announced today as the death toll at the school was set with probable finality at fortyeight.

The audience assembled for the performance of "Tannhaeuser" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House had reason to admire the art as well as the courage of Marjorie Lawrence. She then appeared for the first time in an opera performance in this city since her attack of infantile paralysis of nearly two years ago.

The first College course in the country to train women for duties with the Waacs, Waves and Spars will be introduced at the City College School of Business for the Spring semester beginning next month, it was revealed yesterday by Mrs. Ruth C. Wright, dean of women at the college.

A flag for 487 members of the Police Department who have entered the armed services was dedicated yesterday in the line-up room of Police Headquarters by Mayor La Guardia, while department officials, the wives and families of the men and a number of invited guests looked on.

Continuing with his enormous task of playing all of Chopin's piano music, Alexander Brailowsky gave the second of his cycle of six recitals at the Town Hall last night. The large audience responded enthusiastically to the pianist's imaginative interpretations of another batch in the sheaf of more than 170 compositions that he is covering in the series.
Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House this afternoon. The evening opera will be "Aida."

Stimulated by the favorable action taken on legislation to revise the parity computation formula by the House Agricultural Committee, the cotton futures market yesterday turned strong and ascended to its best levels in more than six months.

In September, 1930, the New York Legislature put on the statute books what was to become known popularly as the Old-Age Pension Law. The act made possible the granting of aid from public funds to needy, aged people. There were requirements as to age, residence for a specified time in State and county, citizenship and need.

Since the first flashes of the rescue were received many weeks ago the story of the ordeal of Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and his seven companions has been growing in size. The newspaper interviews and Captain Rickenbacker's nationwide broadcast were supplemented yesterday by a signed Life article.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- The war Department said today that the Distinguished Service Cross has been awarded to nine officers and one enlisted man for extraordinary heroism in action in the Southwest Pacific and North African campaigns.

A 16-year-old Negro, who, it was charged, invaded Brooklyn from Harlem and attacked and robbed another youth and fought off with a knife a patrolman, was held in $26,000 bail after a hearing yesterday in Brooklyn Adolescent Court before Magistrate John F.X. Masterson.

Justinian Cardinal Seredi, the Roman Catholic Prince Primate of Hungary, declared in a recent speech in the presence of the Papal Nuncio that "Christ's teachings do not acknowledge difference between men and men and do not know prerogatives which would entitle a man or a nation to oppress another man or nation on racial or national basis."

George A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co. of Illinois, meat packers, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Chicago that operations had been conducted on a profitable basis since the beginning of the current fiscal year on Nov. 1, 1942.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at Misurata, Libya, Jan. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The most disappointed man in this village today was its Italian prefect. He turned out in all his ribbons and medals expecting to turn the place over to at least a colonel.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Important announcements may be expected soon regarding the establishment of machinery for the operation of Allied strategy in the coming year. Conferences of far-reaching importance have been going on by transatlantic telephone and more direct means in the last few days regarding many phases of unified strategy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Special directives similar to the one giving to the program of William M. Jeffers, rubber director, a priority rating increased to 55 per cent of its objective, will be extended soon to the high-octane gasoline and to the naval escort vessel programs, according to reports among officials of the War Production Board today.

War workers who park their cars near bowling alleys to roll a few frames on their way home from the plant will not run afoul of the pleasure-driving ban, as long as the visit to the alley does not add to their mileage, according to an Office of Price Administration decision made public yesterday.

A plan intended to relieve the acute shortage of fuel oil in some parts of the New York metropolitan area and to give immediate aid to consumers who are actually suffering for lack of oil heat was presented last evening to officials of the Office of Price Administration and the Petroleum Administration for War by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.
Communique 63 from French General Headquarters in North Africa as broadcast this morning by Radio Maroc in French and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 22 -- Disclosures of the existence in Argentina of a vast spy ring, which, under orders of the German Embassy in Buenos Aires, operated throughout South America, were made in a memorandum submitted by the United States today to the Emergency Advisory Committee for Political Defense of the Continent in Montevideo.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- A war-winning strategy for the United Nations in 1943 is believed by London observers to be in the stage of final settlement at this moment, with formation of a four-power "A.B.C.R." Supreme War Council as one of its main bases.
STOCKHOLM, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The ousting of prominent Quisling leaders from their posts in a purge of the Nasjonal Samling [Nazi] party was reported today in stories reaching here from Norway.
BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Perhaps because most of its regular members have been either specialists or the larger firms of Wall Street, the New York Curb Exchange has suffered no great proportional loss in regular member firms in the great drying-up which set in in 1930.

Although celery is cheaper than it was last week by 6 cents, and mushrooms by 4, most vegetables are slightly more expensive. One reason for this, according to a recent report from the United States Department of Agriculture, is the decrease in supplies. Transportation difficulties are responsible for the decrease, in the opinion of certain well-informed persons.

Retail trade here was active this week and was benefited by cold weather which spurred a strong demand for seasonal merchandise. Percentage comparisons with a year ago were more favorable, and estimates yesterday indicated that volume was about equal to the 1942 week.

Christopher Morley, for whom life invariably calls up letters, and letters life, favors this column with the following communication. We believe it needs no explanatory note for faithful readers of the news.

Alexander Ellis, 45 years old, a former seaman whose nervous system was "shattered," his lawyer told Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions yesterday, when his vessel was torpedoed and sunk by an Axis submarine off Iceland, got off with a suspended sentence for killing a pet dog last September in the apartment next to his at 212 East Fifty-fourth Street.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- The tightening of control over civilian workers in Canada was announced this morning by Humphrey Mitchell, Minister of Labor, with a view to better organization of manpower in industry and agriculture.

On Nov. 12, 1938, the business manager of Local B-9 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A.F. of L. affiliate, filed charges of unfair labor practices with the National Labor Relations Board against the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company of South Bend.

A substantial enlargement of the power and prestige of the City Council was forecast at City Hall yesterday as a result of the decision of the Court of Appeals on Thursday, holding that legitimate expenses of Council investigations must be paid by the city, despite refusal by the Board of Estimate to appropriate necessary funds.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Distribution of kerosene under State supervision to emergency cases began today in New Haven and Hartford as 32,000 barrels arrived by train and barge, but Connecticut continued to face a drastic shortage of the fuel used by thousands of families for cooking and heating their homes.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- With Commissioner Robert C. Mealy dissenting, the Securities and Exchange Commission held today that it had jurisdiction under the Public Utility Holding Company Act to hear and determine unliquidated claims in dissolution proceedings before it.

LONDON, Jan. 22--The last important defenses of Tripoli were reported in British hands tonight, and the main remnants of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's fugitive Africa Corps were believed to have escaped into Tunisia.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22 -- In announcing the exchange of notes today between the United States and Mexico, on the reciprocity of treatment for nationals residing in either country, Ezequiel Padilla, Foreign Minister, stated this evening "that many Mexicans in the United States Army were already fighting abroad."

The exhibition of work by artists of the United Nations now in America, arranged by the National Association of Women Artists, is being held at the Argent Gallery, 42 West Fifty-seventh Street, through Jan. 30. The name of the gallery was omitted in a review of the show on Tuesday.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The noon communique:
Twentieth Century-Fox has purchased the screen rights to "The Russian People," the Theatre Guild's fourth offering of the season, for $30,000, it was learned yesterday from a spokesman for Fox.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- As the first of a series of milk-marketing economy measures, designed to reduce the spread between producers and consumers and to conserve manpower and critical war materials, the Department of Agriculture ordered tonight the ban after Feb. 1 of the sale of milk in containers of less than quart size.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 22 -- State's Attorney Lorin W. Wallis applied today to Judge Ernest Inglis in Superior Court for bench warrants to arrest State Representative Fred W. Buckley and six other Norwalk residents on charges of violating the absentee ballot law in the Nov. 3 election.

A polka military ball was given by the Kosciuszko Foundation last night in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria under the patronage of men and women prominent in diplomatic, military and social circles. Its theme and decorations centered on the gallant role being played by Poland in the war.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins dismissed yesterday four suits brought by minority stockholders of four large oil companies who charged waste of assets of the companies in connection with their participation in licensing agreements for the hydrogenation process.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 Mayor La Guardia's request for broadened tax powers for New York City seemed likely today to be granted on a temporary basis again. Governor Dewey's special committee on local city taxing powers indicated that it had to work on the problem from a long-range point of view.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Three investigators of the "paving block" episode involving Edward J. Flynn, President Roosevelt's nominee to be Minister to Australia, agreed today in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that there was evidence of wrong practices.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The rationing of milk was advocated by a representative of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, in suggesting a program intended to reduce milk prices, to regional officials of the Office of Price Administration as they conducted a hearing at the Essex House here today on a proposal by Arthur F. Foran, State Milk Control Director, for a cent a quart increase in the price to the consumer.

A "Service of Thanksgiving to God" for the birth of Princess Margriet Francisca of the Netherlands will be held tomorrow at 4 P.M. in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue, near Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- David Karro of Arlington, Va., conceived an idea poking around among Indians' effects in the Smithsonian Institution. He built a pick-back papoose pack for Mrs. Karro to carry their 10-months-old child while she does the shopping.

"Navy Church Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in this area in response to the invitation of Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, Commandant of the Third Naval District, and the Navy Chaplain Corps to participate in "Navy Church Week-end" the celebration of which began last evening and be continued this morning in the synagogues.
An introduction to trout fishing at the age of three years proved a significant start for Ken Reid, executive secretary of the Izaak Walton League.

Coming events often cast their shadows before them, and one such shadow is now visible over Scandinavia because of the possibility of a new Allied landing in Northern Norway. Whether such a landing is contemplated or not is, of course, the secret of the Allied High Command.

Trial of the first-degree murder indictment against Louis Caridad, 24 years old, of 228 Smith Street, Brooklyn, and Charles Farley, 26, of 90-05 175th Street, Jamaica, Queens, for the hold-up slaying of Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno in Brooklyn was set yesterday by Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein for March 8, two and one-half years after the first arraignment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture announced today that government loan rates on longer staple varieties of cotton grown in 1943 would be higher than on similar grades last year, while rates on shorter staple length will be lower.

In contrast to the heavy volume of the preceding period, new securities offered here this week for public subscription were limited to three small issues of municipal bonds aggregating $492,000, compared with four flotations amounting to $127,573,000 the week before, one of which was for $90,000,000 of Canadian bonds.

The Manhattan Beach Coast Guard beat Camp Upton, 46-34, last night in the first of a series of service basketball games to be played in the Rockefeller Center gymnasium. About 900 were present, many of them service men, on the first occasion that the Radio City gymnasium was open to the general public.

Discovery of the reason why metals coated with oxygen emit a stream of electrons more readily than uncoated metals, solving a mystery that has puzzled scientists for forty years and promising better electronic tubes for radio, television and countless tasks in industrial operations, was reported yesterday before a meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- To assure householders in the thirty-State rationed area of their minimum fuel oil needs, the OPA today advanced by one week the date when No. 4 ration coupons may be used and rescinded the recent 10 per cent increase in heating allotments in Kentucky and parts of five Middle Western States where Winter has been milder than usual.

HONOLULU, Jan. 22 -- The progress of the Pacific war depends on carrier-based aircraft, Captain Ralph A. Ofstie, aviation officer on Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's staff, said in an address yesterday to the Honolulu Chamber of Commerce. He acknowledged, however, the need for coordination among all arms, citing the Guadalcanal operations as an example.

The Procter Gamble Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on Dec. 31 a consolidated net profit of $10,194,515, after Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions. After allowing for dividend requirements on the 8 and 5 per cent preferred stocks, the profit is equal to $1.54 a share on the common.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--The War Production Board today moved to conserve available supplies of dyestuffs and organic pigments through issuance of a stringent order effecting far-reaching controls over use of such products in civilian clothing and other consumer products.

"HAPPINESS," says Kathleen Coyle in her autobiographical "The Magical Realm,"* "is a state. It is immeasurable. It cannot be counted out like time in an hourglass. It is irrecoverable in its forms. All you ever know is that you have had it."

Out front, before 8 o'clock last night, the Metropolitan Opera House audience filtered into its seats. Behind the curtain stagehands, satyrs, angels, graces and nymphs, fluttered, pirouetted or stood in whispering groups. Then a hush fell on the cavernous, dimlit setting for the opening scene in "Tannhaeuser."

TRENTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The right of a local school board to suspend or repeal a salary schedule calling for periodic pay increases for teachers was upheld today by the Court of Errors and Appeals, New Jersey's highest law tribunal, in a decision of major import throughout the State's public school system.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Globe the attraction will be "Margin for Error," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen version of the Clare Boothe play. Milton Berle, Joan Bennett, Carl Esmond and Howard Freeman head the film's cast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Typical points raised by the imminent issue of War Ration Book 2 were discussed today by the Office of Price Administration in one of its frequent "question-and-answer" statements. The statement reads:

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The important rail junction and German air base of Salsk, 100 miles southeast of Rostov, fell to the swiftly advancing Russian Army of the Caucasus today, and Soviet troops also were fast encircling Voroshilovgrad, capital of the Donets Basin north of Rostov, according to the Soviet Monitor's recording of two Moscow communiques tonight.

MANY people are asking, not unreasonably, why publishers use their paper on new and untried books while they have not enough to keep in print half of their standard works and classics which are in continual demand.

THE bold idea of putting girls in United States Army, Navy and Coast Guard uniforms to release men for combat duty is working out so well that officers who at first made disparaging remarks about petticoat armies are now demanding more and more women to serve with them.

Most amusing and instructive was the dissertation in Thursday's Topics, of THE TIMES. That Roget's Thesaurus should go onto a prescribed list of subversive books suggests -- not the scrubwoman you have invented -- but the Gremlins themselves as having had a hand or many hands in drawing up that list and then exclaiming -- "So there! We can't write -- or read books -- so we'll ban a few of 'em; why not!"

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- The men that 409 new second lieutenants, first "speed-up" graduating class of the United States Military Academy, left behind when they went to war last Tuesday began building a fresh crop of Rosy O'Donnells, Blondy Saunderses and Tom Trapnells with their first sports week-end today.

The Berlin radio said last night that the Nazi armies encircled at Stalingrad were fighting "to the last cartridge and last hand grenade" to tie down huge Russian forces and make them "employ large amounts of materials."

NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 (AP) -- British bomber and fighter planes carried destruction to targets in the Prome district of Central Burma yesterday and pounded Donbaik, in Western Burma, in a series of widespread raids, a British communique said today.

THE DANCE OBSERVER magazine last week brought together Beatrice Seckler, Lee Sherman, Marie Marchowsky and Welland Lathrop for its third set of sponsored recitals, and showed once again in tangible fashion how the dance can be not only kept alive through the war period but actually advanced.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- Although the island of Malta has long since passed from a state of semi-siege to a limited offensive role, the British occupation of Tripoli means that the island will now have an abundance of the supplies needed to make it a base for an all-out air campaign against Axis bases and ships in the Central Mediterranean.

THE copyright division of the Library of Congress, which in a manner of speaking gives the final word on potential theatrical activity, reports once more the diminishing quantity of same. For in the calendar year 1942 it allowed copyrights on only 4,299 scripts in English or other languages, that number being a large drop from 1941.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 23 -- The Dartmouth hockey team staved off a last-period Yale rally to win its opening Pentagonal League contest tonight, 4 -- 3.
THIS is a birdseye view of the woman of 1943 -- how she lives and how she looks. And what she does about her looks.

The training division of the War Shipping Administration in New York announced yesterday that 800 future merchant marine officers would be graduated Thursday from the United States Maritime Service Candidate Officer's Training School at Fort Trumbull, Conn.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 23 (UP) -- The United States Government, although appreciative of Argentina's action in arresting Axis espionage agents, deemed it in the interests of the American republics to furnish memoranda -- originally provided to Argentina -- to the Montevideo Committee for Political Defense of the Hemisphere, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General, carried to the Supreme Court today his attempt to restrain James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and the union from enforcing a ban against making recordings.

The other night I attended the movies and saw a short entitled "You, John Jones." This short is pointed and poignant. For its material it simply reaches out into a world which is full, unfortunately, of such heart-rending episodes as it depicts.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 23 -- The high tide of power politics still swirls through the streets of this easy-going, sun-splashed city, transforming it from a gay, provincial capital to a feverish battle-ground of political and racial factions on which the future of France -- perhaps of all Western Europe -- is being fashioned.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers, which has a membership of 19,916, and includes all the leaders in the electrical arts, will begin its annual Winter conference here tomorrow morning at the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street. Sixteen hundred electrical engineers from all parts of the country are expected to attend the six days of sessions, at which recent developments in electricity will be reported by authorities.

WITH 1,500,000 fighting men overseas, and other millions on their way or ready to go, Uncle Sam has gone Baedeker. The Special Service Division, Services of Supply, has compiled and published for the War and Navy Departments a series of pocket guides to foreign countries which are distributed among all departing soldiers, sailors or marines.
YOU published last Sunday a letter from Leslie Ingersoll, questioning the location of short-wave "freedom stations" discussed in my article of Jan. 3.

GOODNESS in a character, that is, strength and kindness and understanding, is something that most novelists shy away from and with good reason. For the description of these qualities is a difficult thing to achieve.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Best showings were made by accessories, housewares and home furnishings, linens and domestics, millinery and shoes. Suits and furs were good.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The University of Pittsburgh tonight reportedly had offered a long-term contract and a high salary to induce Clark D. Shaughnessy, the T formation wizard, to come to Pitt to stage a gridiron revival.

Dr. Robert A. Hingson and Dr. Waldo B. Edwards of the United States Public Health Service announced last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association that they had successfully used "continuous caudal analgesia" to banish the pain of childbirth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Petroleum Administration for War today informed the Office of Price Administration that no change was necessary at present in the value of Period 4 fuel-oil coupons in seventeen Eastern States and the District of Columbia.
TORONTO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Brilliantly led by Syl Apps, the Maple Leafs defeated Chicago, 5 -- 3, tonight before 11,272 fans to move into second place in the National Hockey League, ahead of Detroit.
BACHELOR'S BREW -- That famous sociological type -- the "white collar girl" -- has a practical prescription for her household appurtenances. They must be pretty, efficient and compact.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Rear Admiral Robert H. English, commander of the Pacific Fleet's submarine force, 55-year-old hero of submarine patrol duty in the first World War, was one of the nineteen men on the seaplane still missing on its flight from Pearl Harbor to San Francisco, the Navy disclosed tonight.

CAIRO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Some of General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's soldiers scarcely paused at Tripoli today. They thundered on to the west in pursuit of Marshal Rommel's Africa Corps, beating along the coastal road to the refuge of the Mareth Line, sixty-five miles inside Tunisia and 165 miles from Tripoli.

BERNE, Switerland, Jan. 23. -- The dreaded spotted typhus has claimed a noticeably large number of victims in comparison with prewar figures since the outbreak of hostilities in the so-called endemic countries of North Africa and Russia and it theatens to reach proportions of continental importance unless the military-economic stability of Europe is re-established soon.

While his father and 4-year-old brother slept, John Herbert, 3, went to the kitchen of their home, 1203 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday afternoon and accidentally or playfully turned on the gas jets. John was found dead by the police.

WHILE travel restrictions have cut down on the number of week-end skiers journeying to the Laurentians, those timing their arrival and departure for days other than Sundays have had no transportation difficulties.

In the long valleys between the mountain ridges of Northeastern Pennsylvania thousands of hard coal miners who had staged an unauthorized walkout on Dec. 30, last week trudged back to mine shafts and breaker houses. For nearly a month they had defied John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.

This sport of motor boating is not the young upstart some folk imagine. It is actually hoary with age. The American Power Boat Association is beginning to reach back into antiquity. The ruling and governing body of the sport will hold its fortieth annual meeting on Feb. 1 at the Hotel Lexington. President John A. Remon of Washington will bang the moderator's gavel at 8:30 P.M.

A detailed semi-annual financial report of the National Maritime Union, made public last week in accordance with the organization's policy of "keeping open books," showed income from all sources of $429,170, an increase of $50,016 over the previous half year.

Bonds held the center of speculative interest yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with dealings the second largest for a Saturday this year and the rail average at the best level since Oct. 14, 1937. The stock market drifted on reduced volume, closing mixed and virtually unchanged.

THE art of the Persian miniature makes no more pretension to reality than do the Arabian Nights tales. It cares little for photographic representation and rejects the idea of perspective altogether. If a rug is worth snowing at all, an Iranian painter does not skimp by revealing just the edge or a narrow rhomboid.

Calling attention to the shortage of physicians and surgeons in this country, Earl G. Harrison, Commissioner of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, revealed last night that his office had been instructed to expedite the citizenship petitions of all alien practicing physicians and surgeons.

Possibility that home delivery of milk might have to be ended was voiced yesterday by F.J. Andre, president of Sheffield Farm Company, who said that Secretary of Ariculture Claude R. Wickard's five-point directive to all handlers and distributors of milk fell short of solving the problem faced by dealers in the New York area.

A SIGNIFICANT and distinguished addition to the English Men of Letters series is Edmund Blunden's "Thomas Hardy." It is obvious that no fitter pen could have been chosen for the task. Mr. Blunden is both an excellent poet and prose writer, a man of keen perception, peculiarly attuned to the native qualities of Hardy's mind and heart.

When is a meet record not a meet record? That question faced the A.A.U. fathers yesterday at the end of the second portion of the metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at Columbia's South Field when the Fordham relay team surpassed the indoor mark in keeping the one-mile relay title.

THE age of Elizabeth was one of the most fruitful and rewarding in English literature. Messrs. Lamson and Smith have contrived a volume that takes full advantages of its riches. The very format of the book is an invitation to learning.

How the eighteen community centers supported by the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities have turned their resources toward aiding in the war is described in a survey made public yesterday.

A tax program similar in some respects to the much publicized Ruml plan is now being operated successfully in Canada, James L. Ilsley, Canadian Finance Minister, said last night at the annual meeting of the Canadian Society of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Long recognized as a Summer resort, this quaint Adirondack village is rapidly earning a reputation for its Winter sports facilities. To a skier, the facilities that abound in this region, combined with the heavy annual snowfall -- the average is 130 inches -- make for ideal conditions.

New Orleans selling weakened the cotton futures market at the close yesterday, eradicating the moderate gains attained in the preceding session. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended a very quiet session with net losses of 6 to 7 points, near the day's low levels.
As a result of the war the private independent schools in this country are undergoing vast changes in their curriculum. Courses are being revised to meet the present-day war demands.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Jan. 23 -- The hay wagon that was to have brought guests to a dinner party this evening of Mr. and Mrs. Myron J. Sutliff at their home on Cedar Swamp Road here came a cropper as it was starting from the Sutliff property to pick up its passengers. Its three occupants were hurt.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Fire swept the Rittenhouse Hotel tonight as 183 guests made their way to safety through blinding smoke, many of them fleeing down firemen's ladders.

Beginning Tuesday, all the neighbors may come in and hear accused pleasure drivers try to explain to local rationing boards why they should not be penalized by the confiscation of some or all of their gasoline coupons.

THE column by Mr. Dowries in Sunday's TIMES concerning the formation of an Army symphony orchestra aroused an enthusiastic response among the serious musicians in our Air Force band, and his comprehensive presentation of the case crystallized for us a feeling that has been widespread among symphonic musicians in the service for some time.

Since 1919 those who paid a Federal income tax have been able to do so in quarterly installments. The system has been a boon to all taxpayers, but until this year those who paid a New York State income tax had to pay at least half the sum on April 15, a fourth within two months and the remainder within six months.

PHIL EVARTS had been a brigand, tougher than his tough neighbors, had taken what he wanted and had built up the Hatchet ranch until it dominated the whole region. But now Phil Evarts was dead, leaving a daughter, Celia, and a weak brother in whose hands the ranch had begun to disintegrate.

Colummbia College will admit only high school graduates for the Spring semester and thereafter, despite a trend among colleges to allow students to enter without completing their senior year, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

RETAIL trade now gives some indications of falling behind the high totals of last year. This trend is noted particularly here in the East where the ban on automobile driving and the steps being taken to conserve fuel oil are probably major influences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A new method by which packers of most canned and packaged foods can determine new maximum prices when they change the nature or size of their containers was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

FEATURED in the windows of almost every antique shop this season are china figurines, one of the most picturesque forms of ceramics. Because of war conditions abroad, there are at present a great many Europeans in New York who know antiques, and to them English and Continental china and earthenware have always had a strong appeal.

LONDON, Jan, 23 (Canadian Press) -- A penalty goal by Denis Compton five minutes before the close gave Arsenal a 1-0 victory over Brentford before a crowd of 23,000 in today's soccer football feature.

THE educator in quest of a compass pointing to the new schools which the new world destined to emerge from this greatest of wars must hunger and thirst after, will without much prodding turn hopefully to Professor Kotschnig's book.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- As questions about a manpower inquiry continued to loom large on Capitol Hill, Senator Bankhead agreed today to quash one incipient legislative fight over what committee should have investigative powers by withdrawing his resolution to refer the problem to the Appropriations Committee.

CAMOUFLAGE -- the art of concealment and deception -- is practiced on every battlefront today, from the jungles of New Guinea to the frozen steppes of Russia. Gun emplacements, air fields, tanks, even the soldier himself, are camouflaged. And behind the lines the camoufleur performs his sleight of hand to change the appearance of munitions plants and large city areas.

INVISIBLE DRYER -- Invisible infrared waves are now used to dry textiles that come from the dyeing and finishing bath, George Fisher reported at the last meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. The waves are not hot in themselves, but they generate heat in anything that they strike.

A VERY satisfactory but little known group of iris are the Spurias. They bloom in mid-June and closely resemble the bulbous Dutch iris in form, excepting that they are much larger and are borne on tall robust stalks. Among the best of these are: Mr. Whitney, white with yellow signal; Sunny Day, large gleaming yellow; Hazy Hills, gray-blue falls and standards, and Fairy Wand, bluish falls and standards tinged with yellow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Because of the demand for physicians and nurses in the armed services, and because the reconstruction period abroad will call heavily on American medical personnel, medical services for the duration of the war and for several years afterward will be "rationed," Dr. George Baehr, chief of the medical division of the OCD, said today.

Since the United Nations are fighting to insure a happier life and freedom from want for the peoples of the world, one of the chief tasks immediately after the war should be the building of "more and better homes on a scale infinitely vaster than ever in the past," Walter Nash, Minister from New Zealand, declared yesterday.

With the opening of the Spring semester next week, high schools and colleges report that a record number of students are flocking to technical and vocational courses, anxious to take work that will be of immediate value in the war effort.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Red Army has recaptured Armavir, which controls the Maikop oil fields in the Caucasus, and on the Voronezh front to the north has occupied Volokonovka, railway junction seventy-eight miles northeast of Kharkov and fifty miles east of Belgorod, two highly important Nazi bases, a special communique announced tonight.

AS is its annual custom, the Cooperative Analysis of Broadcasting, Inc., which is responsible for what are known to the trade as the Crossley ratings, has come up with its findings for the past year; and very interesting reading they make, too, as you may see by a glance at the Jan. 18 issue of Broadcasting Magazine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- To assure to farmers and other commercial vehicle operators continued mileage, the Office of Price Administration, at the request of the Office of Defense Transportation, made provisions today for the issuance of temporary gasoline rations after Jan. 31.

From the bombproof shelters in which the executives of our big corporations are hiding, squawks about the new proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission arise like a faint, sweet whisper on the evening air. Everybody is afraid to stick out his neck far enough to make a noise like a businessman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Representative Martin of Massachusetts, House Republican leader, came out today for establishment of a standing House Aviation Committee to promote American dominance of the world's airways after the war and expressed belief that most Republicans on the Military and Naval Committees would support the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- A spokesman for the Navy Department said today that combined quotas of the armed services will be filled through single induction centers under Selective Service, beginning on Feb. 1. Barney Ross, former world lightweight and welterweight champion, will receive the Edward J. Neil Trophy in absentia when the award is made on Feb. 17 at the annual dinner of the Boxing Writers' Association of New York in Ruppert's Brewery.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Major Vidkun Quisling, the Norwegian Nazi puppet Premier, has built himself a $60,000 "northern Berchtesgaden" near Oslo, where he now lives under protection of 150 guards who man machine gun posts twenty-four hours a day, it was revealed tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- A police complaint that charged George Engelbrecht of 41 Hunterdon Street here with possession Of $1,000 worth of tools and plywood that allegedly had been stolen from the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, Kearny, N.J., where Engelbrecht is employed as a carpenter, was dismissed here today by Police Judge William M. Untermann, after the company's representatives had failed to identify the articles.

George M. EUGENE, Ore., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Mrs. Martha Virginia Brinson James, 21, wife of Ensign Richard F. James, was slain early today on board the Southern Pacific's San Francisco-bound West Coast Limited. A widespread search was on tonight for a dark husky man described as the slayer.

A pre-meteorology school has been established at the University of North Carolina under the guidance of the Army Air Corps. The school will open March 1 and will have an enrollment of 250 students for a six months' course. As privates in the Army, the students will receive $50 a month pay, plus $2.75 a day for board and lodging, in addition to their tuition and Army uniforms.

Duke Ellington now has joined Paul Whiteman, Benny Goodman and "Fats" Waller in the ranks of jazz notables who have given concerts at Carnegie Hall. He and his band played there last night and a crowd of 3,000 turned out to cheer him, to enjoy his music and to contribute to Russian War Relief, the beneficiary of the event.

The things that happen to them, like a divorce when neither party to it really wants a divorce, an attempted suicide, the acid quarrels of feuding ladies and so on, are naturally more diverting when you are not mixed up in them yourself.

In 1941 the United States Steel Corporation paid out $600,000,000 in salaries and wages, compared with $60,000,000 in dividends. The employes of the corporation, in short, got ten times as much out of it that year as the stockholders did. In 1941 the General Motors Corporation paid out $670,000,000 in salaries and wages and $172,000,000 in dividends.

After playing second fiddle to midyear examinations during the past ten days, collegiate basketball activity will be resumed on a broad scale this week and several, leading New York City quintets will start the second half of their schedules for the current campaign.

Last week the Houdry Process Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced the successful development of methods for the production of gasoline compared with which the ordinary kind sold by filling stations is a feeble milk-and-water concoction.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Ten Japanese have been killed on Guadalcanal for every American soldier lost, and their air losses in the Solomons have been seven to our one, Major Gen. A.A. Vandegrift of the United States Marine Corps said today.

IN the old cattle-ranching days of the late 1870's Tracy Coleman was sent from Texas to take over the Horsehead ranch away up north in "The Basin," surrounded by high hills. When he got there he found a run-down ranch and a hostile crew, what was left of it.

Maxwell Anderson, playwright and author of "The Eve of St. Mark," now playing at the Cort Theatre, announced last night that he would leave for England as soon as he "can get space on a boat," and subsequently try to get "as close to the North African front as possible" to gather material for a play about American Negro soldiers, which he announced in November.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- The Diario Oficial has published several decrees which specify the new taxes that were applied as of yesterday on several consumers articles as well as corporations.

THE nameless one who tells this story of the tall Kentucky hunter, his grandfather's grandfather, always planted appleseeds in the springtime. "A chore for Johnny Appleseed" he calls it, and thereby hangs this tale of gratitude to that strange half-mythical figure who has such a firm hold on America's imagination.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 -- A settlement has been reached between the government and the delegates of the steel workers who have been on strike for the past twelve days, but official announcement of the terms has been delayed until tomorrow afternoon so as to provide an opportunity for consultation with the local unions.

HENRY J. KAISER, the West's twentieth-century Paul Bunyan, performs his prodigious industrial feats with three Big Blue Oxen. His lead ox is Imagination. Hitched with it are two stalwart beasts, Organization and Perspiration, which show more than a plodding gait as they are driven about damming rivers, converting swampland, cow pastures and even mountains into shipyards, and orange groves into steel mills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A Congressional movement to curb the regulatory powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission is developing in both the Senate and the House as a result of what several members regard as the SEC's tendency to exceed the powers that Congress intended to grant it in imposing rules upon corporations.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Newark Bears, hard hit by the draft and the loss of star players to the parent Yankees, announced today the purchase of two pitchers and an infielder.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., may or may not be the garden spot of the Army, but one of the nearest approximations to a garden in the Field Artillery Replacement Center has been the lawn in front of the orderly room of Battery A, Twelfth Battalion, Fourth Regiment.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 23 -Iraq's decision to abandon neutrality and declare war on the Axis brought home to the Arab world sharply the way the rising tide of Allied victories is affecting the destinies of Near and Middle Eastern countries and their fighting Moslem peoples.

Two of the harshest sections of the regulations issued by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, were the provisions that determinations of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and the War Labor Board "shall be final and shall not be subject to review by the Tax Court of the United States or by any court in any civil proceedings."

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Wheat prices on the Board of Trade broke about a cent a bushel today from the high point of an early advance, following the announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation's wheat holdings were being offered for sale at parity price.

A COUPLE of strollers on Jacobs Beach, that glistening sidewalk strand below Mike Jacobs's office on the Rialto, were discussing the self-eliminating lightweight tournament which has been going nowhere with great rapidity ever since it was conceived.

A LITERARY phenomenon of our times that will no doubt not fail to be reckoned with when peace and the pursuits of peace are once again paramount with us is the stocktaking that has been going on among the American and the British or British off-shoot nations since the start of war.
The letter from Edward McKernon published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 17 certainly requires rebuttal and denial as to the facts in the case of the Portsmouth Peace Conference of 1905.

RESTRICTIONS in the use of paper, long anticipated by the book publishing industry, the only questions in recent weeks having been when and how much, were put into effect a few days ago by the War Production Board.

GROWING numbers of women are on the production lines of war industries, but there has been no comparable increase in the number of women bosses to date. Only a few of the ablest workers in slacks are moving up from the ranks to positions of greater importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended its hearings today on the nomination of Edward J. Flynn to be Minister to Australia after Mayor La Guardia of New York, in a snappy, nine-minute appearance, had disqualified himself as too politically prejudiced against Mr. Flynn to discuss his qualifications for a diplomatic post.

A FEW people exist in this world who thought last season's dramatic reportage of life in the Yiddish theatre, "Cafe Crown," a too-colorful exaggeration of the facts. To these chilly skeptics particularly is this truthful tale of what now goes on in a local playhouse dedicated.

Although the country does not yet fully realize it, the United States, under the stress of war, is undergoing a most important industrial change. By the aid of war contracts and other assistance from the Federal Government, the large companies in virtually every industry are assuming greater importance, while the small units are being forced gradually out of business or assuming a lesser role.

NOTWITHSTANDING wartime restrictions, the ban on pleasure driving and other things, the local after-dark entrepreneurs continue to evince an impulse to action. The latest of these is Harry Finkelstein.

WHEN Nazi Germany, in adopting religious persecution as part of its scheme of aggression, put the clock back, it began to dawn on many of us that human liberty is something for which men and women must constantly work. Ceaseless effort for its maintenance is necessary.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Lifted to the forefront of popular acclaim by the fall of Tripoli and the successful conclusion of his desert campaign, General Sir Harold Alexander, Commander in Chief of Allied forces in the Middle East, is regarded by many here as the logical man to command the next full-blown offensive of the Allied nations, wherever it may fall.

A curb on the growth of bureaucracy in both Federal and State Governments, which, he said, tended to substitute government of men for government of laws, was urged last night by Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio in a speech at the dinner of the New York State Bar Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE job of the "Dark Duet," Michael Kane and Ernest Guelvada, is the elimination of Nazi agents who cannot be reached by due process of law. To put it bluntly, these two men deal in assassination. They act under orders from an unspecified branch of the British Government.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: It's none to early to prune grape vines; unless the ground is frozen solid when this task is done they are likely to bleed badly. . . . Flower bulbs stored for Winter -- such as dahlias, gladioli, cannas and tuberous-rooted begonias -- are looked over now to see if they are still plump and sound; if they are getting soft or shriveling, they need more moisture.

Restrictions on motoring are taking a big bite out of the paying traffic on the five toll bridges within the city, it was apparent yesterday when the annual report of the Triborough Bridge Authority was made public.

The need for increasing Germany's production to keep pace with the extension of the war and the enormous consumption of materials by the German war machine justify the impression that the six Winter months will not suffice for the accumulation of the stocks of materials necessary for decisive Axis operations in 1943, it is disclosed in several confidential reports that reached this country recently and were compiled by an authoritative neutral source.

Intimations in official quarters last week that the Office of Civilian Supply, now part of the WPB, may be set up as a separate consumer agency aroused speculation in retail circles last week as to whether a "positive" approach to problems of civilian goods production and distribution was in the making.

With nineteen "name" bands alternating throughout the evening to provide dance music, with stagei and screen stars making personal j appearances, and a special enter-I tainment recalling in song, dance and commentary distinctive events in the period of years between j 1917-43, the President's Birthday Party will take place next Satur-I day night in the grand ballroom J suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Prices of wheat turned downward today on the Board of Trade, after having shown moderate strength early.

Faber Faber have bought the English rights to Christopher Morley's current novel, "Thorofare" (Harcourt, Brace).... A biography of the distinguished Negro scientist George Washington Carver, who died recently at his home at Tuskegee Institute, will be out in April under the Doubleday, Doran imprint.

MORE and more, the organization of war work demands trained skill: even as civilian volunteers, Marjorie Barstow Greenbie points out in the introduction to this book, amateurs are discouraged. What, then, can amateurs do to win the war?

SOPHIE BARTON was having a hard time being "gentled" by her Aunt Lydia. It was hard enough for a girl brought up on a Wyoming ranch in 1892 to hem curtains and wear frilly aprons, but with a cattleman's war going on right under her nose and a spy loose, cutting fences and shooting steers, it was intolerable.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau as recorded by the Soviet Monitor:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Officials in the New York City offices of the War Production Board read with amazement today newspaper stories reporting that the Washington office of the WPB had deferred "for the duration" an application by the Larchmont War Council for a priority to buy copper wire with which to connect the village's new air-raid sirens to power lines.
The final list of foods available to users of Federal surplus food stamps, from Feb. 1 to March 31, was announced yesterday by the Food Distribution Administration of the Department of Agriculture.

Alexander Woollcott, who had perhaps come closer than any other modern American to carrying his chosen vocation of "Town Crier" into the twentieth century, was fatally stricken last night before his microphone at the Columbia Broadcasting Company, 485 Madison Avenue.

There is a particularly interesting story behind an advertisement printed in THE TIMES today. It is concerned with a request from the President of the United States and a generous response to that request, in circumstances which are unusual.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Science Service) -- Among the 601 patents granted here this week was one covering dehydrated foods now being shipped in immense quantities to our armed forces and to our overseas allies. These foods are prepared by putting raw vegetables and meat into the drier, separately.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Pennsylvania gained undisputed leadership in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by defeating Yale at the Palestra tonight, 42 -- 30, before 2,500 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial activity continued at a high level in December and the first of January, with prices of farm products and retail foods advancing further, while prices of most other commodities showed little change.

Florida racing, up to now confined to the Winter months, may be conducted during April, May and June if present plans of legislators in the Peninsula State are carried out at the forthcoming session of the Florida Legislature. Ralph Davis, executive secretary to Spessard Holland, Governor of Florida, yesterday said over the telephone:

Women of Canada not only are enlisted in large numbers in several branches of the armed services but also are contributing largely to industrial production and directing the work of civilian rationing, it was learned yesterday from leaders of government and national organizations who visited this city en route to Washington.

A COVER received from St. Johns by H.L. Lindquist has postage prepaid with Newfoundland's first 1943 stamp -- a 30-cent rose on which the Memorial University College is illustrated. Advanced scientific and technical subjects and the liberal arts are taught at this non-sectarian institution, which was established in 1925 "in memory of Newfoundland's fallen" in World War I.

FLORENCE HUTTER MASON is trying to write a novel, and some unknown person is adding cryptic and vaguely menacing quotations to the manuscript. It may be a practical joke, but Mrs. Mason thinks not. She is so worried that her nephew, Sylvanus Hutter, begs Henry Gamadge to come to Underhill, the ancestral home of the Hutters, to find out who is responsible.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Perhaps the most important appeal on behalf of Jewish and other refugees from the Nazi terror since the recent wave of brutality that shocked a world that thought itself beyond being shocked in this particular, was issued today by the Archbishops of Canterbury, York and Wales on behalf of the whole Anglican Episcopate.

THE spotlit news of the week concerned two of our museums. Great significance attaches to the announcement that the Whitney is to be merged with the Metropolitan, an announcement made at the conclusion of the latter institution's annual meeting on Monday.

Independent meat packers in the Eastern territory will be forced to close unless their price ceilings are raised, according to a memorandum submitted to Mayor La Guardia by the Eastern Independent Meat Packers Committee, and made public yesterday by Nathan Sweedler, its counsel.

At least one event where the entries equal or exceed that of the pre-war rationing period is the fifth annual New York Journal-American's bowling tournament for women, starting Jan. 30 at the Bowlmor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Because a homing pigeon's ceiling is about 10,000 feet, the Army Signal Corps has developed a cage with an automatic opening device which allows the birds to be dropped from scout planes flying at tremendous heights.

AFRICAN MIGRANT: The Federal Communications Commission announced last week it had definitely located the radio station, "Brazzaville Two," which tries to stir up dissension among the Allies in North Africa. The location: not Brazzaville, French Equatorial Africa, but near Vichy, France.

OUR insight into Mohammed's religious personality would be incomplete without knowledge of his personal life, for he led the life of an ordinary Arab of his time. One of the most interesting personalities in his entourage was his second wife, Aishah, whom the Prophet married after the death of his devoted first wife, Khadijah.

Your editorial of Jan. 10, "A Soldier Speaks," compels continuing thought, for the guery of Lieut. Col. Evans F. Carlson, in his address over the graves of members of his unit who fell at Guadalcanal, is not one readily answered. "It is not given us to know the process by which certain of us are chosen for sacrifice, while others remain."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 -- Only four horses -- two of them coupled as an entry -- started in the Ponchatoula Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, but three of them thrilled upward of 8,000 fans by hitting the wire heads apart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The United States war effort has already been saved "millions of tons of shipping and hundreds of millions of dollars" as the result of reciprocal lend-lease aid from Allies, Edward R. Stettinius, American Lend-Lease Administrator, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The way was cleared by the Office of Price Administration today for dealers and others to furnish new passenger cars to the Army Air Forces' Ground Observer Corps for official use by airplane spotters.

THERE were always strange doings on Halfaday Creek, the small mining camp away up in the Yukon just across the Alaska border which was a haven for outlaws -- so long as they gave up outlawry while staying there.
