Ten years ago next Saturday Adolf Hitler became Chancellor of the German Reich to begin a decade unparalleled in European history since the days of Napoleon. The anniversaries of Hitler's accession to power have usually been marked by great parades of heiling Nazis and by triumphant speeches.

I read with a great deal of interest an article titled "Facts Behind 'Yankee Doodle Dandy'" in your columns of Jan. 10. Perhaps it would be of interest to readers of THE TIMES to know some other facts about the efforts that were made to bring the story of George M. Cohan to the screen.

An international organization with regional units, each unit responsible for keeping the peace in an allotted area, was proposed for maintaining peace after the war by Dr. Alexander Loudon, Ambassador from the Netherlands, in an address yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Seven "unconventional" types of motor transportation have been developed by the Office of Defense Transportation for heavy urban passenger traffic to "substantial practicability" for use if the present public and private urban transport facilities should break down as the result of industrial expansion and war-imposed restrictions on the use of private cars and other transportation facilities.

Cold weather spurred retail trade here this week, bringing an active demand for seasonal merchandise. Comparison with a year ago was on a more favorable basis and estimates yesterday indicated that sales last week were about even with those of last year, against declines of 4 to 7 per cent in the two previous weeks.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Manhattan scored its seventh basketball victory of the season against a single setback as it improved upon its previous triumphs over Niagara by recording a 49-33 decision tonight before 6,722 spectators.

LOVE in the R.A.F. is again the theme of Miss Shann's new novel. Cherry had enlisted for special duty as a Waaf and was a competent plotter. The work was hard, and that pleased Cherry, because she had gone into it to try to forget Simon, who was married to her friend Denise.

FROM Switzerland by way of Portugal comes information that last October Norway issued a series of stamps in honor of Johan Herman Wessel to mark a national celebration of the second centenary of his birth. An eighteenth-century man of letters, Wessel wrote parodies that burlesqued the heavy Scandinavian tragedies of his time, altering the course of Norwegian literature.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A British communique:

THE Empire Theatre celebrates its fiftieth anniversary on Monday night, Jan. 25. For half a century this distinguished theatre has been entertaining the citizens of New York City. Although fifty years is a remarkable record for any theatre in New York City, the Empire's proud reason to celebrate this anniversary lies in the richness of its theatrical history.

AMONG the best things that have come to gardens through the inspired magic of the hybridizers are the modern lilacs. As sweet as lilacs always were and just as hardy, these newer hybrid lilacs bloom younger and offer tremendous plumes on small bushes.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The general strategy underlying the Royal Air Force's bombing of Germany and German-occupied territory can be summed up as a long-term policy of blockade.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- British and French troops have rolled a German tank column back at least four miles in the Robaa area of Central Tunisia, it was announced today as other Allied forces mopped up German parachutists seeking to widen the fifty-mile alley of escape left to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's forces fleeing into Tunisia.

IN the first chapter of "Bridle-Wise" Ken Langdon pinch-hits his school baseball team to victory; in the second he is promised a horse of his own, a good enough beginning for any boy's story, but the significant thing here is that Ken is lame. Child of wise parents, he has never learned self-pity nor inactivity, and his paralyzed leg and crutches have never kept him from enjoying life thoroughly.

A FEW moments before he is to go to the electric chair Jerry Taylor, condemned murderer, confides to Thatcher Colt the name of another murderer, a man who kills for sport. This man's name is Dr. Baldwin, and he has, according to Taylor, discovered an undetectable method of meting out death.

Increasingly skeptical over the country's post-war ability to absorb the full output of vastly expanded plant facilities, more and more industrial companies are beginning to set aside reserves to cover the scrapping of excess capacity, accountants reported here yesterday.
" AND what the people," Milton wrote, "but a herd confus'd, a miscellaneous rabble?" So Robert Wilder finds them and so he offers them in type.

AMONG radio's forgotten men are those in the small orchestral units, ranging from perhaps only an organist to a trio or quartet, who at odd hours of the day or night fill in fifteen minutes on program schedules already overburdened with the popular offerings of full-sized aggregations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In its seventh annual report to Congress for the fiscal year ended June 30 last the National Labor Relations Board said yesterday that "an increasing acceptance" of the Wagner Act by employers was indicated by the nature of cases which had come before it during the year.
Confusion caused by the stampede for furniture during the markets here and in Chicago led many factories to accept orders they will be unable to fill, trade observers reported yesterday.

The Intensification of the nationwide fight on infantile paralysis with expansion of facilities for study and treatment of the disease is outlined in the fourth annual report, made public yesterday of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis issued by Basil O' Connor, president of the foundation.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Princeton's hockey team trounced the Harrington Park A. C., 9 -- 3, on Baker rink tonight on a contest featured by thirteen penalties and three fights. It was the Tigers' second triumph in four starts.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- American Flying Fortresses blasted at German submarine pens at Lorient and Brest today and American-made Mustangs of the Royal Air Force struck at Nazi inland transportation in double daylight blows at German-occupied Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Work Projects Administration will wind up in every State by May 1 all operations except the micro-filming of its final accounts, Deputy Commissioner George H. Field said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Two government officials this week spoke optimistically of the military situation. The Under-Secretary of War, Mr. Patterson, said that, except for the submarine sinkings, "the over-all picture is bright." The Director of the Office of War Information, Mr. Davis, said that, with the same exception, the situation is "pretty encouraging."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- The country's newest horse racing plant, highly-successful Garden State Park in the Philadelphia-Camden area, came out today with a richer stake program for next Summer in the face of the ban on pleasure driving.

Sir John Squire has written an agreeable little library, of which one book is called "Flowers of Speech." The last we heard of him, and we never can hear too often, he was busy trying to pull up certain weeds of speech. He reproaches The Times of London with using "loaned" instead of "lent."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Much of the credit for the British Eighth Army's unprecedented 1,400-mile advance from El Alamein to Tripoli was due to Lieut. Gen. Sir W.G. Lindsell, declared War Secretary Sir James Grigg in a British broadcast today, according to the British Information Services.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The probability that Nazi Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps, retreating west of Tripoli, will make a stand in the French-built system of fortifications in the southeastern corner of Tunisia was noted here today by a Fighting French spokesman.

LONDON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- British bombers raiding Western Germany last night were over Cologne, it was reported today, but the attack there was believed comparatively light. The R.A.F. planes were said to have been engaged chiefly in reconnaissance.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Plans for recovering the ration books of persons being inducted into the Army and returning them to the inductees' rationing boards were disclosed today by James Kerney Jr., State director of the Office of Price Administration. He said the plans were worked out by officials in Washington in cooperation with the Army.

Local communities should exercise greater initiative and effort in dealing with wartime tasks on the civilian front, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, yesterday. Other rabbis commented on various aspects of the war.

Half of the turned-in tires examined so far under the government's idle tire purchase plan are usable only as scrap and are being paid for at scrap prices, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Price Administration, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Treasury Department favors "early enactment of legislation designed to put the payment of income taxes on a current or more nearly current basis" and will be ready to give its advice on the subject to Congressional committees whenever it is asked to do so, Randolph Paul, Treasury general counsel and chief tax expert, said today.

A BEAUTIFUL girl with tragedy in her eyes attracts the attention of Bryan Sloane at a cocktail party, and he hastens to make her acquaintance. Her name is Paula Storm. She and Bryan meet again and fall in love with each other, but she tells him that their love is hopeless for a reason which she refuses to disclose.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The government put 235,000,000 bushels of its stock of wheat on the market today in a move to keep prices from advancing above the parity level.

The National Maritime Union sent a protest last week to Vice Admiral R.R. Waesche, commandant of the United States Coast Guard, against the holding of secret hearings before the Merchant Marine Inspection Service on charges brought by N.M.U. seamen against Captain G. Strand, master of the freighter Harry Luckenbach.

My most interesting house plants are Coleus. The leaves are so diversified and colorful that they add cheer to any room. From the smallest plant one can make continuous cuttings. I root them first in water and, when the roots appear, which is in about a week or ten days, I plant them in ordinary soil and they multiply rapidly.

IN the preface to her book about the siege and surrender of Warsaw Mrs. Langer writes that in "the horrible process" of war "in which so many die new human beings are born. For no one who has been through war will ever be quite the same person again."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- Tripoli fell at 5 A.M. today. Advance forces of the British Eighth Army swept away the last German rearguard parties during the night and moved into the ancient capital before dawn.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A British communique:

TRANSPORTATION difficulties have obliged the Metropolitan Opera to curtail its annual Spring tour and, though there is still lively hope for carrying on, the tour may have to be abandoned altogether. The cities definitely eliminated are Boston, which the company has visited regularly for ten years and sporadically for many years before that, and Baltimore, where the company has played for the last sixteen seasons.

MOTION picture industry leaders are already planning a post-war conquest of the European film market. Robert T. Kane, chief of Twentieth Century-Fox's British production, now here for studio executive conferences, disclosed this week ambitious plans that are under way.

MR. LERMAN has already given us one full-bodied biography from the Renaissance in his "Leonardo da Vinci"; now he has delved into a rich fund of knowledge for another, a life of Leonardo's rival and peer in sculpture.

THOUGH many things have changed in Moscow since the outbreak of the war, two institutions remain intact -- the ballet and the ballet school. For the ballet is so important a part of Russian life that dancers, whether men or women, are not mobilized; and to carry on the cherished traditions of the ballet children from as far afield as Vladivostok and Transcaucasia are gathered and trained by the State in the art of dancing.

NEXT Saturday Franklin D. Roosevelt will be 61 years old. No man in the world has a harder job. No one is carrying a heavier burden or bearing graver responsibilities. Yet when I asked him the other day if he ever lay awake at night and worried, he smiled; shook his head, and replied: "Never."
A great deal of sports equipment is being produced, but only a small fraction of it is reaching the civilian population not engaged in war work.

The annual meeting of the New York Women's League for Animals will take place Thursday afternoon at the residence of Mrs. M. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street. Harry I. Caesar, president of Dogs for Defense, Inc., will speak on the work of dogs in the war, and Miss Alice Carroll, lecturer on humane education, will describe the work she does for the league in the New York public schools.

CANADA is experiencing a boom in books. The only difficulty seems to be to get enough books to satisfy the public. Sales for November and December are double those of a year ago. Then, too, the public is buying better books as well as more books.

THE ways of the dictator are as old, almost, as human society. In each new incarnation he may add an item or two to his bag of tricks, but the basic principles upon which he operates, first by his own will, and later by the necessity of circumstances which he has produced, remain the same.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- What was regarded as a broad hint was given by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today in support of reports that the United Nations have reached a new unity among themselves for more intensive and better integrated prosecution of the war on the military and political fronts.

TO many right thinking people, it is only the fact that Sonja Henie brings her ice show to town which makes New York at all habitable by Winter. Usually the revue arrives during the particularly grim period on or near the January thaw, when the better part of the world is trudging around on half-torn rubbers and is sneezing besides.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 23 -- Since the great Pacific offensive began in the Solomons on Aug. 7, United States convoys have been fueling, feeding and equipping United Nations forces along the vast South Seas supply lines with complete success, Captain Richard Boush Coffman, Senior Convoy Commander in the Pacific, declared here today.

AMONG the 1928 fictional successes was the late Major P.C. Wren's "Beau Ideal," last of a trilogy including "Beau Geste" and "Beau Sabreur," describing the military and romantic adventures of the Geste brothers.

A central office will be set up jointly by the Office of Price Administration, the Petroleum Administration for War, and the city through which any householder out of fuel oil may obtain supplies immediately, according to plans announced yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- The Coast Guard cutter Natsek, with an estimated crew of thirty aboard, has been several weeks overdue in the North Atlantic and must be presumed lost, the Navy announced today. The Natsek, of 225 gross tons, is the fourth Coast Guard ship to be lost in this war.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23 -- Leading in every department of play after the first nine minutes, the Naval Academy basketball team today registered a 47-to-27 victory over the Rutgers University quintet.

ALTHOUGH Captain Duncan Maclain is totally blind, his other senses tell him things that have escaped the eyes even of trained investigators. In the case with which this story deals he is investigating the death of another blind man who fell or was thrown from an eight-floor balcony to the lobby floor of the building which had once been his office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Butter and cheese will probably be rationed in the Spring, according to talk at the Office of Price Administration here.

Despite a recent Appeals Court decision barring employes from intervening in a contempt proceeding brought by the National Labor Relations Board against a company for back payment of wages, employers cannot feel certain today that payment of such back pay to the board will automatically protect them from future separate actions by employes who might claim such payments were insufficient, Sol A. Herzog, trade association counsel, pointed out yesterday.

Manufacturers were faced with the problem of extricating themselves last week from heavy commitments accepted from visiting retail buyers, most of whom have now left the markets, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Another ship has been hit by bombs at Rabaul, New Britain, where earlier this week Allied planes sent four vessels, totaling 24,000 tons, to the bottom, the Allied High Command reported today. Near hits were scored on a second ship north of Rabaul.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 23 -- Straight-talking Rogers Hornsby had a few unkind words today for those who would bury baseball without even the benefit of a funeral.
ACE-SHOWING responses to opening two-bids have been growing in favor among New York players during the last two years, and it is possible that nearly half of the local experts now use them.

PLANT material commonly used for the back of garden borders often achieves but one effect -- height. But liatris, commonly known as gayfeather or Blazing Star, offers much more. Its long, slender spikes of bloom, borne on stems three to six feet in height, depending on variety selected, give distinction and character to any planting.

IN her most recent story of nurses and their loves and troubles, Miss Hancock sets the scene in the slums of an up-State New York town. Some of the boys go into the Army, leaving their mothers sobbing in broken English while Miss Mary tries to console them.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 -- The loss by the Axis of Tripoli, southern apex of the strategic triangle of Tripolitania, Tunisia and Sicily, came as a stunning blow to the Italian man in the street, who is unaware how it could have happened.

Adrian Gips, a director of the Holland-America Line and chairman of the Netherland Shipping Committee at 61 Broadway, announced yesterday that the organization would use a "country retreat" on Long Island as a recreation center for Dutch seamen.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Russian advances on the Caucasus front were reported this afternoon to have brought the Red Army to the approaches of a big, inhabited locality. Dozens of other places were overrun. The drive is moving westward along the mountains toward the Black Sea, which now is a little more than 100 miles from Lieut. Gen. Maslennikoff's left wing.

READERS who have not enough fancy to tell from the label what sort of goings-on are inside this book will miss something first class and A No. 1. For here two good farmers from the region of the little blue lakes of up-State New York tell each other how things were when they were boys about fifty years ago, and anybody who wants to can sit down and enjoy the talk.

Despite a recent Appeals Court decision barring employes from intervening in a contempt proceeding brought by the National Labor Relations Board against a company for back payment of wages, employers cannot feel certain today that payment of such back pay to the board will automatically protect them from future separate actions by employes who might claim such payments were insufficient, Sol A. Herzog, trade association counsel, pointed out yesterday.

Manufacturers were faced with the problem of extricating themselves last week from heavy commitments accepted from visiting retail buyers, most of whom have now left the markets, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Another ship has been hit by bombs at Rabaul, New Britain, where earlier this week Allied planes sent four vessels, totaling 24,000 tons, to the bottom, the Allied High Command reported today. Near hits were scored on a second ship north of Rabaul.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Jan. 23 -- Straight-talking Rogers Hornsby had a few unkind words today for those who would bury baseball without even the benefit of a funeral.
ACE-SHOWING responses to opening two-bids have been growing in favor among New York players during the last two years, and it is possible that nearly half of the local experts now use them.

HERE is another fragment of the cipher diary of William Byrd of Westover in Virginia, Esq're, as his bookplate on the title page qualifies him. The first lot, published in 1941, is the daily record of a man in his thirties -- 1709-1712.

THE idea upon which David Rame builds this neat and exciting novel is not entirely without precedent. During the last war, or shortly thereafter, some one -- Robert W. Chambers, at a reasonable venture -- wrote a novel about a surprising German plan for the invasion of France.

Adrian Gips, a director of the Holland-America Line and chairman of the Netherland Shipping Committee at 61 Broadway, announced yesterday that the organization would use a "country retreat" on Long Island as a recreation center for Dutch seamen.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Russian advances on the Caucasus front were reported this afternoon to have brought the Red Army to the approaches of a big, inhabited locality. Dozens of other places were overrun. The drive is moving westward along the mountains toward the Black Sea, which now is a little more than 100 miles from Lieut. Gen. Maslennikoff's left wing.

READERS who have not enough fancy to tell from the label what sort of goings-on are inside this book will miss something first class and A No. 1. For here two good farmers from the region of the little blue lakes of up-State New York tell each other how things were when they were boys about fifty years ago, and anybody who wants to can sit down and enjoy the talk.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Eight survivors of an American merchant ship sunk in the Caribbean last October lived on sharks that they fought with their bare hands and killed with knives, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Highly authoritative Allied war spokesmen joined recently in emphasizing that all the United Nations' successes in foreign fields have only questionable value until the problem of Axis submarines is solved.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Extension of the powers of the censors to matters of opinion as well as to questions involving national security drew criticism today from the Council of the Empire Press Union in its annual report.

To be or not to be, that is the question suddenly thrust upon the standard American law school. In answering the famous soliloquy legal educators and university administrators should, it seems, propose another question: What kind of social order shall be established when the devastating battles have been fought and won? How can we make the most of victory?

Eugene Rogers, 18-year-old Columbia freshman, who last night was swimming for the New York A.C., won the 220-yard New York State A.A.U. free-style championship in the Winged Foot 75-foot pool by defeating the defending titleholder, Mike Priano, Flatbush Boys Club, in the feature of the eight aquatic events.

Point rationing will be simplified for housewives, to judge by a series of charts now available. The Office of Price Administration has compiled a work sheet with special tabulations for canned vegetables, canned or bottled fruits, soups, baby foods, and vegetable juices; frozen fruits and vegetables, and dried and dehydrated foods.

FOR many years there has been need for an up-to-date volume on Congress combining liveliness with authority. This need Roland Young, a former secretary of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, has now supplied. His book is short, entertaining, realistic and informative.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- A Pan American-Grace Airways transport plane, carrying six Americans among its fifteen passengers and crew members, crashed near Ocona, Peru, yesterday, it was reported without confirmation today.

WHO are the real rulers of Britain? "The law which constitutes the form of government," wrote Saint-Simon nearly a century and a half ago, "is less important as it touches the happiness of a people -- far less -- than the law which constitutes property. It is the law of property which determines the real character of a people."

Phil Terranova, Bronx featherweight, last night scored a technical knockout over Curley St. Angelo, a neighborhood rival, in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn. Referee George Walsh halted the battle after 2:15 of the fifth to save St. Angelo, who had been staggered in the second round and hammered steadily thereafter. Terranova weighed 125 pounds and St. Angelo 128 1/2.

IN purchasing seed for the 1943 Victory Garden of home-grown vegetables, the well-informed amateur does not select just beans, peas, corn and squash at random. He knows that improved and tested varieties are worth growing and he sees to it that he gets seeds which give larger yields, better quality and are often disease free or at least disease resistant.

A CORVETTE would roll on rough grass, according to this lively and entertaining chronicle by an amateur yachtsman who joined up after Dunkerque and spent two years as a watch officer on one of these tiny but invaluable fighting ships.

Although fifteen other major league clubs say they will not send out 1943 player contracts until baseball's advisory council, consisting of Commissioner K.M. Landis and the two league presidents, has received a blanket ruling from Washington, the Giants revealed yesterday they had decided to act without further delay on the basis of rulings they received a few weeks ago.

Thomas Jefferson's two hundredth birthday, which falls on April 13, naturally sets one to speculating as to the conditions under which great reputations survive through the generations. Something of every man's thought goes out of fashion with the age in which he lives.

The impact of the war upon the American bar and law schools and the danger that "lay bootleggers of law" may "muscle in" to the profession while lawyers generally are preoccupied with the war were stressed by speakers yesterday at the sixty-sixth annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan 23 -- The attack on Adolf Hitler's "Festung Europa" -- European fortress -- was slowly taking shape this week as the United Nations took the offensive in the air of Western Europe, on the snow-covered steppes of Russia and on the sandy wastes of Libya.

AT the annual meeting of the Horticultural Society of New York the following officers were re-elected: Henry F. duPont, president; William A. Delano, Mrs. Samuel Seabury and Mrs. Harold I. Pratt, vice presidents; Clarence L. Hay, secretary; Fred T. Bonham, treasurer.
MONTREAL, Jan. 23 -- Elmer Lach pulled the Montreal Canadiens into a 5-5 deadlock with the New York Rangers tonight, scoring the tying goal with only 15 seconds left.

The home of /Vrs. Robert C. Ream of 770 Park Avenue will be the setting Tuesday afternoon for a tea and package party to benefit the Bargain Box, a thrift shop at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street Each guest is requested to bring a bundle of rummage to be sold later at the shop, which through the proceeds of sales made there contributes to the support of eight philanthropic organizations.

Nothing can better illustrate the close military cooperation and global strategy of the United Nations against their common enemy than the latest figures on lend-lease aid to Russia. According to these figures, the United States sent to Russia up to Jan. 1 of this year nearly 2,600 planes, 3,200 tanks and 81,000 other military motor vehicles, besides large quantities of food, which is more than has been sent to any other country, including England.

The Metropolitan Opera Company presented Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" yesterday afternoon, its second production of the work this season. Bruno Walter was again the conductor, and most of the singers were the same as at the Jan. 9 performance.

Formation of the new Food Industry War Committee, perhaps the most representative group of food traders to be organized in this country, has aroused considerable optimism among trade factors who are looking forward hopefully to its first executive session in Chicago tomorrow.

AS one might gather from the title, this book is a discourse (informal) on a very glorious -- and much misunderstood -- calling. Or rather it is three discourses, for the author has split his subject into sections, headed "To the Layman," "To the Student" and "To Fellow-Architects."

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Reports reaching here from various parts of the State show that Governor Dewey is using the State police to investigate prospective officeholders, according to reports to them by their friends, neighbors and business associates.

A PROGRAM of Verdi's music, including a hitherto unknown score of very definite political import, has been arranged by Mr. Toscanini for the NBC Symphony concert of Jan. 31. This program is remindful of Verdi's political position in his country's history, as it is of Toscanini's attitude toward the present war and the part he has always taken in defense of liberty and against aggression.

MIAMI, Jan. 23 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today received a letter from Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, thanking the federation for its cooperation in war construction and war manufacturing activities. The letter said:

AT the theatre recently I made one valuable discovery: that firemen are not actors. Just before the opening act curtain a gentleman in blue uniform stepped from between the curtains. Raising a paper in front of his eyes and completely covering his mouth, he proceeded to read.
Captain Harold A. Sweet of Pan American Airways reported yesterday the completion of a mission that bolstered the morale of American fighting men halfway around the world.

THE Nationa Orchestral Association's annual Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series will consist 'of two concerts this season, .with the same works being performed at each. They will be Schubert's Mass in G minor and a Requiem by Guy R0Partz

DETROIT, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., described today as "regrettable" Captain E.V. Rickenbacker's assertion here that labor's absenteeism and strikes were seriously hampering the war effort.

Patrolman Pasquale Venturelli, 31 years old, was killed at 10 o'clock last night when he was thrown from the running board of a stolen car, containing three youths, after it had crashed into a tree at West Caroll Street and William Avenue, City Island, the Bronx.

With Spring just around the corner comparatively little preparation is in evidence for the early outdoor dog shows in this section of the Atlantic seaboard. In recent years the late Spring and early Summer period has been the most popular time of the year for these events, with the calendar so crowded that there haven't been enough week-ends to fill the demand.

Art teachers should not go into war factories to make a living or help win the war because they can make themselves indispensable in the wartime educational structure, Jay Deiss of the Graphics and Publications Information Service, United States Office of Education, told the Committee on Art in American Education and Society yesterday morning at the organization's first annual meeting at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The award of letters of commendation to ten officers and two enlisted men was announced today by the Navy.

How many non-resident sportsmen will be fishing and hunting in New York during this year is still a matter of conjecture. But according to the statistics just announced by the Conservation Department, most of those who purchased licenses were interested in fresh water fishing.
For even an amateur observer no day can be outwardly so dull, as hasty judgment may deem it, as to fail to provide at least one "salient," or feature of outstanding interest.

The nation's war effort is greatly hindered by that fact that "we have too many political time-servers where we ought to have high-minded statesmen," declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The day-and-night offensive by American and British bombers against Lorient followed warnings by Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee and A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, that German submarine attacks on Allied supply lines constitute one of the gravest threats of 1943 to the United Nations, it was emphasized here today.

Reports from London say that the British capital is living in high hopes that out of the present conversations between the United Nations will come something approaching an interallied War Council which will unify their strategy for a supreme bid for victory in 1943 through an invasion of the European Continent.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- A few more portents of the political storm that is likely to arise over the Beveridge report appeared today.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 23 (Religious News Service) -- The anti-Quisling New Year's message issued by the Provisional Church Council of Norway was read in more than 1,000 churches, according to reports reaching here.

On Friday, stock market averages went to the highest of the year; they had advanced 3 1/8 points during the present month and some 11 points since last August, but were still well below the figure reached in the years before Pearl Harbor.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- How ski sport has become the way of life in a community was vividly shown at Old Forge-Thendara today. This Central Adirondack territory was known not so long ago for its attractions as a Summer resort and depended on its ice and lumber industries for income during Winter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- With the Ways and Means Committee scheduled to meet not later than Thursday to determine when it will tackle the problems of the 1943 tax bill and pay-as-you-go taxation, the proposal to enact a Federal sales tax was revived tonight by Representative Wesley E. Disney of Oklahoma as a means of raising part of the $16,000,000,000 in new revenue called for by President Roosevelt.

Commercial credit and collection conditions in Latin-American markets during the last half of 1942 continued the upward trend in progress since July, 1940, according to the latest in the series of semi-annual surveys released today by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Dick Werner, Paterson, N.J., flash, and Miss Carmelita Landry of Fitchburg, Mass., national and North American champion, won the principal titles today in the Middle Atlantic speed-skating championships.
LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau, broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Navy Communique 260:

LONDON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The United States Army Air Forces' deadly raiding combination of Flying Fortress bombers and Lightning fighters has scored a decisive victory on the African front by downing or damaging thirty-five Axis planes without a single loss in a battle over Bizerte, it was announced tonight.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- The dramatic bombing of Tokyo last April by American bombers was related with new details tonight as one of the navigators on the special mission visited Chicago today.

Local rationing boards all along the East Coast face a major problem, beginning Wednesday, in what to do about users of fuel oil for heating who have neither converted to coal-burning equipment nor proved the impossibility of doing so.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Oats developed considerable strength late last week on the Board of Trade following an announcement that the Canadian Wheat Board would not issue additional permits for the exportation of oats to the United States owing to the large number of permits already issued and shortage of freight cars to move the grain.

Stirrup pumps will go on sale in many stores throughout the city on Feb. 1, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. The retail outlets that will sell this equipment at the cost price of $1.91, plus city sales tax, will be revealed in the Mayor's broadcast next Sunday and will include a number of large department stores.

Art teachers dedicated themselves to the war yesterday at the second and last day's session of the first annual meeting of the Committee on Art in American Education and Society at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 25 -- Russian troops, sweeping forward in the Caucasus, have captured Peschanokopskoe, only fifty miles northeast of Tikhoretsk, key railway junction of the vital Novorossiisk-Stalingrad and Rostov-Baku railroads, the Soviet midnight communique said, it was reported by the Soviet Monitor here.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- An unprecedented sense of crisis permeates the German press today and the entire country may be said to have been transported into a state of apprehension and alarm over the military situation on the Russian front.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Decidedly unfavorable weather conditions resulted last week in a marked reduction in the number of hogs received at leading markets, and with an insistent demand for lard and meats the only trading reported in many items was at ceiling prices, with supplies inadequate.

Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, and Delos Walker, vice president of R.H. Macy Co., will open a new information center for the Red Cross in the drug department on the street floor of Macy's at 11 o'clock this morning.

VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 24 -- Handshakes in the street, faded Maltese and Allied flags flying from improvised staffs atop ruined buildings and bands playing marked the jubilation here at the news yesterday of the taking of Tripoli.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Alternate severely cold and mild weather prevailed last week in the Winter wheat belt, and there were reports of freezing and thawing from parts of the Southwest where the crop is not protected by snow, but experts said the complaints were not as numerous as usual.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- The Winter sailing regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club today was marred by lack of wind. Half a score of craft labored around the harbor and managed to finish two races, such as they were. Then Clint Bell, chairman of the race committee, figured that there was a limit to patience and called it a day.
Attorney General Nathanial L. Goldstein announced yesterday the appointment of Orrin G. Judd, a partner in the law firm of Davies, Auerbach, Cornell Hardy, as Solicitor General.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Reports that the government might set ceiling prices on cash wheat and futures, similar to the action taken earlier in the month in regard to corn, served last week to check speculative and milling interest in the market, and prices fluctuated erratically.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 18 -- At least 80 per cent, perhaps 100 per cent, of the oil received by Great Britain is of Venezuelan origin, it has been learned here through a reliable source.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24 -- Two big cargo ships glided into the waters of Los Angeles harbor today within an hour as employes of two shipyards staged gala launching ceremonies. The two were the Cape Mendocino, launched at 11 A.M., and the Samuel H. Langley, launched an hour later.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Outside interest in grain futures has decreased recently as the result of scattered liquidation by speculators who are said to have evened up their market position because of expectations of early additional government restrictions on trading.

" War, serious as it is, is only a phase of another and far-reaching event of our day," Supreme Court Justice Michael F. Walsh told the fifty-one graduates of Manhattan College at commencement yesterday. "At this moment of your graduation a world revolution is in progress and Christendom itself is passing through a most serious crisis."

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared yesterday in his annual report as president of Columbia University that "the time has plainly come when the business of the whole world is our business, and when, if we neglect that vital fact, we are doing our nation the greatest possible damage.
The German radio last night reported that the Nazis were building a new type of submarine operating with compressed oxygen. The broadcast was recorded by The Associated Press.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

WITH ALLIED FORCES, On the Central Tunisian Front, Jan. 24 -- American troops are strengthening their positions in the Ousseltia area and continuing their attacks against Axis forces holding the foothills and mountain passes astride the road to Kairouan, German stronghold twenty-five miles southeast of the present battleground.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (ONA) -- Belgian circles reported today that twenty Belgian patriots had raided a German arsenal at Lutre, in Belgium, removing large quantities of ammunition and explosives, putting two big locomotives out of action and destroying two compressors and a huge crane.

An easier flow of coffee from roasters to wholesalers, made possible by a change in rationing procedure, was reported yesterday by E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Price Administration. Mr. Ferguson said that wholesalers who had not been able to obtain their full allowable inventories could now get relief.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Nearly half the members of the Bergen County Bar Association are exchanging their white collars during the nights for the work-clothes used in war factories where they have taken jobs.

Many people are turning to religion these days and their hopes are well grounded, said the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers in his sermon yesterday in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The phrase "German imperialism" occurred with significant frequency in a speech by Alexander Shcherbakoff, Chief of the Information Bureau, Thursday evening. The Russians regard the predatory attack made on their land as a continuation of the German policy that, because of the pertinacity with which it has been pursued, has become almost traditional.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Vice President Wallace told American soldiers, sailors and marines today that the two essential bases of the peace for which they were fighting could be found in the Bible and in the history of this democracy, which he described as the only form of government fully in harmony with the principles of the Scriptures.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- Establishment of ceiling prices on corn has effectively checked the advancing tendency shown in that grain recently, but it has brought about a great deal of confusion, part of which may not be in evidence for some time to come, according to leading cash grain handlers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Black Hawks rallied to beat the Bruins, National Hockey League leaders, 4 -- 3, tonight and score their first victory in seven games. A crowd of 14,991 saw the Chicago Stadium game.

Price variations and volume in the cotton market continued slight last week as traders awaited developments on agricultural legislation scheduled for Congressional action. For the second successive week the list of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the period irregular, the net changes showing an advance of 7 points to a decline of 6 points.
That streamlined revival of "Sailor, Beware" is coming to the Forrest Theatre the week of Feb. 8. Charles Robinson, co-author of the comedy, will attend to the staging.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Such varied issues as the national manpower emergency, a House fight over creation of a permanent civil and commercial aviation committee, and the plight of some 1,000 yacht owners who have not yet been paid by the government for their requisitioned vessels will be taken up when Congress gets back to work tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Unified responsibility for supplying labor for war production on farms was given to Secretary Wickard today under a directive issued by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, the Office of War Information said.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Decorations for 120 United States airmen, including the award of the Silver Star to Brig. Gen. Haywood S. Hansell of San Antonio, Texas, were announced today by Eighth United States Army Air Force headquarters.

Your recent difficulties in procuring butter, lard and prepared shortenings may have led you to wonder how much fat you require in the daily course of your meals. Answer to your question, which must be stated in general rather than exact terms, is given by Miss Lillian Anderson in the latest issue of Nutrition Notes, a publication of the Community Service Society.

A ceremony will be held on the stage of the Empire Theatre tonight after the performance of "Life With Father" to commemorate the fiftieth birthday of the theatre. The Players are sponsoring the event and will present a bronze plaque and pay tribute to thirty-six actors and actresses who have appeared at the Empire during its half century of existence.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Because of the operation of numerous controls, subsidies and rebates, the course of grain prices in Great Britain is difficult to trace in detail but the Board of Trade's review of commodity prices for the past year gives some picture of the movement of prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A Federal retail sales tax as a war emergency measure was recommended today in a study made public by the Brookings Institution, which estimated that a 10 per cent tax on all retail sales, except housing, medical care and education, would raise $5,000,000,000.

A dinner dance and waltzing party will be given Feb. 6 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis as a benefit for Belgians in Britain, a division of Bundles for Britain. A waltz contest will be a special feature of the entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Reports received by the Office of Price Administration from the area in New York State where ration banking has been under the test of actual operation since Oct. 28 indicate that merchants, wholesalers and banks quickly master the mechanics of banking ration stamps, coupons and certificates much as they handle cash and currency in ordinary checking accounts, according to the OPA.

St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, celebrated yesterday the 133d anniversary of its founding with special morning and afternoon services in which two bishops, four choirs and thirty parish organizations participated.

IT must come as a shock to baseball followers to read that Shanty Hogan, the old-time catcher, is arising at 5:30 every morning and dashing cheerfully off to his job in a shipyard. In the old days it frequently was more of a task to get him to bed at that hour. Shanty was a convivial and friendly soul by nature, a trencherman by preference.

The New York metropolitan milk pool, in which 54,887 dairy farmers of six States will share, had a net farm value of $13,671,377 in December, representing an increase of $661,162 over the pool of December, 1941, although the month's deliveries were 9 per cent less.

Appointment of a chief probation officer in the Children's Court, a position unfilled since 1939, was among recommendations made yesterday to the Mayor's Committee on the Wartime Care of Children by the Women's City Club of New York.

Five works by young American composers were presented yesterday afternoon by the League of Composers at the New York Public Library. Four of the composers represented are already in the armed forces, and Richard Franko Goldman, the fifth, has been accepted as a volunteer officer candidate in the Army.
Realty activity in Manhattan reported over the week-end included sales of six tenements on the lower East Side by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- Creation of an American Jewish Assembly, organized along democratic lines, to provide a representative forum for expression of ideas and opinions designed to help the status of Jews in the post-war world and implement rights of Jewish people in regard to Palestine, was voted today by representatives of thirty-two national Jewish organizations.

It takes sixteen men and women on the war production line to supply one man in our fighting forces. These workers are still massing in a great national migration toward our "boom towns." Inevitably this movement involves overcrowding, maladjustment, confusion, lowering of health standards and the temptations of many cheap and demoralizing forms of entertainment.

With the first-run theatres in the midtown area holding over their current attractions, only two film openings are scheduled for this week. On Thursday the Palace will bring in "Truck Busters," postponed from last week. This is a Warner melodrama featuring Richard Travis and Virginia Christine.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Clark D. Shaughnessy, famed exponent of the T formation, said tonight he would decide "within the next few days" whether to accept the position as football coach at the University of Pittsburgh. He made arrangements to leave for College Park, Md., later this evening, by train.

Upon the merits of the suggestion made by Mrs. Roosevelt and others that the voting age should be reduced to 18, I do not desire to comment. It is a matter of surprise, however, that educated and intelligent Americans appear to be proceeding on the theory that Congress has something to do with it.

Because we are facing tremendous realities, we must be real in our religion, Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Episcopal Mission of the Advent, 7 West 128th Street. He told the Negro congregation that these are times in which all mankind needs the full help and blessing of the church, and he called for a "faithfulness" in carrying out the life and work of the church.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, gave two answers tonight to critics of the War Department on the ground of planning too large an Army. They forgot, he said, that we neded to raise enough soldiers to give the United Nations superiority over tremendous Axis hordes, and that we must train men for a long war -- one which he said did not seem likely to end this year.

It's a far cry from hardware to eye shadow -- but the newest arrival on the shelves of a distinguished Manhattan housewares store is a dazzling series of South American beauty preparations, complete from lipstick to eye make-up.

Reviewing a book of fiction the other day, in which the central character had some almost unbelievable adventures, John Chamberlain wrote in this newspaper: "If such things happen to copyreaders, then what am I doing reviewing books?

A very distinguished recital of songs and song cycles by Robert Schumann was given by Lotte Lehmann yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The capacity of the hall had been bought out by an exceptionally attentive and appreciative audience days in advance of the event.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis listed yesterday nine grants totaling $83,180 to institutions of New York City and New York State to further the fight against infantile paralysis. All were made during the foundation's fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1942.

The will of God is his blueprint of creation but the building has to be done through men who accept responsibility for some part of the structure itself, declared the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

Vegetarians here have been assured by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard that the OPA is giving consideration to a special rationing plan for them, it was announced yesterday by Symon Gould, secretary of the Vegetarian Society of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- -- Forty-five additional industrial plants have received the joint Army-Navy "E" production award for outstanding performance on war orders. The companies are:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 -- Jane Withers, who at the age of 17 has appeared in thirty film comedy roles, will play her first dramatic part in Samuel Goldwyn's "The North Star." She has been cast as a young Russian peasant who is murdered by the Nazis while trying to defend her home village.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- The Red Wings regained second place in the National Hockey League tonight by blanking the Rangers, 7 to 0, for Goalie Johnny Mowers's fourth shut-out of the season. Carl Liscombe fired home three goals.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 24 (Reuter) -- The government has been gravely concerned with the growing seriousness of the food situation in this country, a press communique said today. It is aware that wheat, in particular, is extremely short in many areas and that, while there is, at present, generally speaking, the same stringency with respect to other grains, prices have risen considerably above low pre-war levels.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Twenty-six priests of Maryknoll Seminary, most of whom were freed recently from Japanese internment camps, left today for missions in South and Central America after a departure ceremony in the chapel attended by relatives and friends and a group of prominent diplomats, business men and clergymen of Latin America.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The German High Command today continued its grudging admissions of Axis reversals in Russia, acknowledging a further withdrawal in the Caucasus and a major Soviet break-through at Stalingrad, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded here.

A capacity audience last night at the Shubert Theatre saw the sixty-first annual benefit in behalf of the Actors' Fund of America. The fare was a variety of theatrical entertainment comprising some of Broadway's outstanding talent.

Wendell L. Willkie expressed hope yesterday that reports from London and Washington that a Grand Allied Strategy Board was in process of formation would prove to be correct. He added that all Americans should support the creation of such a board, consisting of representatives of the United States, Great Britain, Russia, China and the other Allied nations.

Services climaxing the celebration of "Navy Week-End" were held in many churches yesterday, stressing the Navy's devotion to the ideals and principles of religion as expressed through the work of its chaplains on shore, at sea and wherever officers and men of the fleet are fighting for their country.

Christians on the Continent of Europe are experiencing the ordeals and persecutions that for 300 years marked the path of the early church, and when we view the present situation we realize how immortal is the Word of God, how history repeats itself, declared the Rev. Ernest R. Palen in his sermon yesterday in the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.

The guides to Latin America that have been taking shape at Duell, Sloan Pearce under the sponsorship of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs are now in sight. There will be two volumes, the first scheduled to be released Feb. 25 and the second in April.

Support of all American war projects was pledged yesterday by 700 delegates, representing eighty Zionist districts and groups in this city, who met at their annual conference at the Park Central Hotel.

It was a fighting army brilliantly led that drove Marshal Rommel headlong across 1,300 miles of North Africa and captured Tripoli. But it should not be forgotten how much the long arm of Allied naval power contributed to the victory. Toward the end the Axis forces could not maintain their communication with home bases except over a limited area.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 19 (Delayed) -- Neither the war nor politics is interfering with the work of the Theosophical Society, whose headquarters in the Madras suburb of Adyar THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent visited this afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- Bills carrying out the major part of Thomas E. Dewey's program for his first session of the Legislature have been completed and are scheduled for introduction at tomorrow night's session.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Apparently preparing the Germans for news of a disastrous defeat on the Eastern Front, the Voelkischer Beobachter recalled today the conditions of 1918, "when the weakness of the Germans on the home front forced Germany to capitulate." It declared that sacrifices at Stalingrad have "obliged all the people to stand up under all difficulties. A lost war is a lost future."

The internal revenue regulations provide for the reporting of income from annuities by those filing Federal income tax returns. Because of the nature of annuity income, special treatment is required in preparation of the return.

WINDSOR, Ont., Jan. 24 -- Army leaders and "big business" have "almost complete control" over American war production and they must share the responsibility for any production and supply blunders, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said here today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 -- Raw steel output throughout the country last week advanced half a point to 100 per cent of rated capacity. This good showing is said to be due to a better balance in furnace repairs as well as a lack of a serious scrap situation at the present time.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Paul Feng, former Shanghai newspaper man, reached here today after a sixty-five-day escape trek from Shanghai and reported that between twenty-five and thirty Japanese officers were killed Nov. 26 when American fighter planes machine-gunned a ship in the Yangtze.

The Delaware Hudson Company and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $6,592,365 for 1942 in a preliminary annual report, compared with $4,336,480 in 1941. Net income for the fourth quarter of 1942 was $2,557,374, against $666,661 in the 1941 period.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 24 -- The first mass demonstration approving Chile's rupture with the Axis is due to take place on Wednesday, when a majority of the political parties, labor organizations and intellectual groups will parade the central streets.

Daggett Ramsdell, manufacturers of toilet preparations and a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company, who recently leased the entire building at 719-23 Greenwich Street, near Charles Street, have extended the lease for an additional five years.

Events tonight: "Louise," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Yehudi Menuhin, violin recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Glanna Bernhard, soprano, and Antony Zungolo, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Josef Gingold, violin, and Liza Elman, piano, Y.M.H.A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, 8:45.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The handle of an oar from one of the Alabama's lifeboats, picked up after the Confederate privateer was sunk by the Kearsarge in the English Channel on June 19, 1864, has been given by the Navy authorities here to the Naval Academy Museum at Annapolis, Md.

In the first month of "what promises to be a momentous year" Canadian business conditions are being adjusted in ever-increasing degree to the imperative demands of wartime economy, according to the January review of business conditions of the Bank of Montreal.

Miss Betty Shields, 15-year-old Pelham High School sophomore, took the metropolitan junior 100-yard back-stroke swimming championship in the London Terrace pool yesterday and helped as the Women's Swimming Association A team gained the metropolitan senior 400-yard free style relay crown.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- With Governor Dewey required to submit his budget to the Legislature a week from tomorrow, the Governor's office announced today that the traditional "budget school" for reporters and newspaper editorial writers will be held on Saturday.
OTTAWA, Jan. 24 -- An international planning project aimed at

Inez Lauritano, young New York violinist, gave her fifth New York recital last night at Town Hall. Arpad Sandor was her accompanist and her program was confined to four works, Beethoven's Sonata for Violin and Piano, Op. 30, No. 2; Lalo's Symphonie Espagnole, the adagio and fuga from Bach's Sonata in G minor for violin alone and Sarasate's "Carmen" Fantasy.

Demand that Attorney General Francis D. Biddle order an investigation of the murder of Carlo Tresca, Italian anti-fascist leader and enemy of the Communists, was made yesterday by the national conference of the Social Democratic Federation at 7 East Fifteenth Street.

The Lighthouse helps the blind to see by training them through their other senses to self-reliance and self-support. This institution, which is maintained by the New York Association for the Blind, has been carrying on its beneficent work since 1905. It is now making its annual appeal to the public, an appeal that has never failed.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 0.1 per cent to 110.2.

IN the first two years of the Second World War the nine small destroyers that made up the British flotilla of F boats, His Majesty's Ships Faulknor, Firedrake, Fury, Fortune, Foxhound, Foresight. Fearless, Forester add Fame, steamed more than 1,000,000 miles on active duty. In Firedrake they were oiling ship that Sunday morning when Neville Chamberlain announced over the radio that a state of war existed.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Alessandro Pavolini, Italian Minister for Popular Culture, made a broadcast speech last night to explain the loss of Tripoli to the Italian people.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Cale Young Rice, 70, a well-known poet, was found dead in bed, with a bullet wound below the heart, at his apartment home here early today, according to Coroner M. Rodger Daugherty, who said Mr. Rice apparently shot himself sometime during the night.
MADRAS, India, Jan. 18 (Delayed) -- C.R. Rajagopalachari is a disappointed man. That means something in Indian politics.

The season's first performance of "Il Trovatore" will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera Association on Friday evening, Feb. 5, it was announced yesterday with the release of the repertoire for the eleventh week of the season. Cesare Sodero will conduct the work and Giovanni Martinelli will make his first appearance of the season in the role of Manrico.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 24 -- The British Eighth Army was "well west of Tripoli" and 300 miles from Tunis today. The occupation of Tripoli was a vital success in the British drive westward, but now it is only a highlight of that drive.

Earlier in the campaign, when the Manhattan College basketball team took the measure of Niagara immediately after Taps Gallagher's squad had upset St. John's, followers of the court sport sat up and took notice. This was no run-of-the-mine victory, and the Jasper stock soared.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 24 (AP) -- An ex-Army sergeant at 15? Sure, it's so. He's Johnny Maras, back at his home here with a discharge in his pocket and mad enough about it to chew nails.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The stock markets, although again losing last week some of the business momentum which launched them so auspiciously on the new year, have shed little of their inherent strength. It has been demonstrated frequently in the past year that reactions from buoyancy become smaller and smaller and of shorter duration.

Class night, traditionally the last opportunity for venting satire and regrets upon faculty members and fellow students, will be omitted at Hunter College this semester because most seniors are busy in war work and have had no time for rehearsals, it was learned yesterday.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Ont., Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The proposed terms of the latest plan for settlement of strikes in the Canadian steel industry were made public today at a mass meeting of 4,000 members of the Algoma local of the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.), along with the announcement of plans for a secret ballot of the union employes on acceptance or rejection of the plan.

A U.S. MOTOR TORPEDO BOAT BASE, Somewhere in the Solomons, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- United States torpedo boats have sunk or damaged an estimated 250,000 tons of enemy vessels, including a battleship, two cruisers and thirteen destroyers since they went into action on the Solomons front a little more than three months ago, authorities said today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

Much of the criticism of American policy in North Africa arises from confused thinking and failure to understand the real meaning of such terms as "Vichyite," "Collaborationists," "Anti-British," "Fascist," etc.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 24 -- The police unearthed tonight new details on the slaying of Mrs. Martha Virginia Brinson James, 21-year-old bride of a Navy officer, whose throat was cut in her berth, lower 13, of a train speeding toward San Francisco.
This is Boxing Week in New York for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, and it will be ushered in tonight at the St. Nicholas Palace with a departure from custom.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Despite labor turnover and other difficulties and shortages due to the war, the Beckman Hospital "has served faithfully and has maintained the highest professional care," Howard S. Cullman, president, declared in the annual report, made public yesterday.

The growing meat shortage in New York City was discussed at a conference at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia and local OPA representatives yesterday afternoon after the Mayor had announced that he would soon submit findings and remedial recommendations to local and national OPA authorities, and after he had broadcast that "everybody is violating the OPA regulations" and ceiling prices.

It was Christmas in January yesterday for Burt Lewis, a blue-eyed Californian, who is a machinist's mate, second class, in the Navy. The lucky youth, who hails from Los Angeles, was one of a group of young sailors who attended the first birthday party of the USO club at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, operated by the Jewish Welfare Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Enlargement of the Red Cross's volunteer hospital and recreation corps to bring artists into an arts and skills unit to teach handicrafts to convalescents in Army and Navy hospitals was announced today by Mrs. Dwight Davis, National Director of Volunteer Special Services.

Equal status for women and men in the armed services was advocated yesterday at the conclusion of the mid-year meeting of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc., at national headquarters, 1819 Broadway.

Standard Brands, Inc., has reorganized its pharmaceutical division and is entering the drug field with consumer-advertised items. The first step in the program will be the introduction of Stams, new multi-vitamin and mineral tablet, with what the company describes as "the most intensive advertising and sales promotion campaign in the history of the drug industry."

The Third Avenue Seventh Day Adventist Church of Jersey City has purchased from the Home Owners Loan Corporation the two-family dwelling on a plot 75 by 111 feet at 103-05 Orient Avenue, Jersey City, N.J. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker and David W. Smith the co-broker in the sale.

Sister Susie is shedding pounds for patriotism. Perhaps she still whacks a typewriter or pushes a pencil in a comfortably sedentary office in the daytime. But shipyards and welding shops are beckoning; Commando and Ranger training courses have stimulated enthusiasm, and the feminine contingent, en masse, has decided to get tough too -- physically -- for whatever ordeals war may yet impose.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Eighteen metal-working machinery manufacturers have reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that their combined net profit after all charges rose from $22,000,000 in 1940 to $28,000,000 in 1941.
Mayor La Guardia warned users of soft coal yesterday that they will not be permitted to blacken the sky and besoot the city now that the anthracite miners have gone back to work.

SOMEWHERE IN THE ATLANTIC, Jan. 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- German sailors manning a blockade-running cargo ship disguised as Norwegian ran up the Nazi swatika and scuttled their vessel last November under the guns of an American naval task force in the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In the first blanket exemption of its kind, the War Labor Board authorized nonprofit hospitals throughout the country today to make wage or salary adjustments for their employes without board approval.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- More drastic rationing of food than most Americans ever contemplated is in store for civilians, even if history's most ambitious food production goals are attained in 1943, Secretary Wickard indicated today in his annual report to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The American attacks on Munda, site of a Japanese airfield on New Georgia Island, only about 200 miles from Guadalcanal, were stepped up to four withering bomber raids in less than twenty-four hours yesterday (Solomons time), the Navy reported.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 -- Encouraged by what appeared to be a more liberal attitude toward prices on the part of Prentiss Brown, the new Price Administrator, heavy trade buying for price fixations and speculative support carried cotton futures into the highest ground of the season on the Cotton Exchange here last week.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- Here is a description of the desert fighting as the British forces neared Tripoli. It may appear late when it reaches readers, but this is what it was to us in the vanguard.

In a move to conserve electric power and manpower, the Queens Midtown Tunnel will be closed to traffic daily between midnight and 6 A.M., beginning next Monday, the New York City Tunnel Authority announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The important announcement concerning United Nations strategy, recently foreshadowed, has failed as yet to materialize. Yet there is no diminution of optimism in circles that are sensitive to the fluctuations of diplomacy.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortresses attacked the Japanese base of Rabaul, on New Britain Island, for the fourth straight day yesterday, setting large fires raging on airdromes, the noon Allied communique announced today.

All available merchandise was bought heavily in the wholesale markets last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Following a period of brisk buying in the medium-priced coat and suit market, it was found that manufacturers would probably be unable to ship more than 70 per cent of the orders booked.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 24 -- General Douglas MacArthur said tonight that widespread use of air power both offensively and defensively was the "outstanding military lesson" learned in the victorious Allied campaign in Papua and that it pointed the way to the ultimate defeat of Japan.

The home front must be on the alert "lest all the worth-while things for which our soldiers, sailors and marines are fighting may be lost through treachery in their rear," Rear Admiral John J. Brady, Chaplain Corps, U.S.N. (retired), and vicar delegate of the third subvicariate of the Military Ordinariate of the United States, warned a congregation of 3,000, including 500 Navy officers and enlisted men, at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Local spokesmen for the Office of Price Administration withheld comment yesterday on Mayor La Guardia's proposal in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall that the Federal prohibition against sliced bread be modified to permit those grocers with slicing machines to slice bread on condition that they ask no price increase.

According to various reports during the last few days, the United Nations have been conducting momentous discussions for a new unity among themselves for a more intensive and better integrated prosecution of the war on the military and political fronts. That is highly encouraging news.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Cooking lessons "while you wait" have been started in several of London's hospitals for their women clinic patients.

The start of grade labeling in the food field will exercise an important influence on the industry's advertising campaigns, according to agency executives. Efforts will be made to acquaint the public with the fact that despite similar gradings one product may still be considerably better in quality and flavor than another.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.2 on Jan. 12. This compared with 112.7 a fortnight and a month before, 108.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

LONDON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force dealt the German war machine two smashing blows last night, blasting the U-boat base at Lorient in the fourth Allied attack there within ten days and unloading cargoes of bombs on the heart of industrial Western Germany, apparently including targets in the Ruhr.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and one of the group of lawyers who drew up the present rules governing the operations of The Associated Press, defended it against the Federal Government's charges of monopoly in an address broadcast last night over WINS.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Rubber Director William M. Jeffers said today he would have to be overruled by "a higher authority" before he would abandon his insistence on top priorities for ma terials needed to complete synthetic rubber plants.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Police today questioned a Negro cook about the slaying in lower berth 13.

Declaring that "anti-Semitism and other bigotry" were slowly making themselves felt in this city, Edward Corsi, former Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, called upon seventy publishers and editors of foreign language newspapers to form a united front for tolerance among all peoples in this country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 -- Paramount announced today that its proposed film "Girls' Town" will reach the screen as a musical and not as straight comedy as originally intended. It will be based on the war-industry conditions at Emporium, Pa., where there are twenty women to each man.

Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested in a talk last night at the University Club, to some 200 members and guests of the executive committee of the National Association of Investment Companies, that they might well consider investing in venture capital.

The Estate of Mrs. Margaret P. Daly, widow of Marcus Daly, Montana copper mine operator, was appraised at a net of $12,685,641 in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The appraisal papers shorted that Mrs. Daly gave away in the quarter-century before her death a total of $3,800,000, not including gifts to charitable organizations, which were not listed.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -A special Russian communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Increased vigilance and ever-closer collaboration in defense of the Western Hemisphere against the Axis powers was urged by Dr. Alberto Guani, Vice President-elect and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Uruguay at the twenty-third plenary session here today of the Inter-American Defense Board.

The elimination of G.S. Gavan of the Princeton Club, third seeded player, by Dr. J.J. Cunningham of the Montclair Athletic Club featured yesterday's play in the Class C tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association as the quarter-final bracket was filled at the Harvard Club.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP) -- By a happy coincidence, General Douglas MacArthur and Australia will celebrate their birthdays together tomorrow.

Within a few hours after the new Fuel Oil Emergency Committee was set up with offices in the Empire State Building to handle appeals for oil for cold homes, its staff received emergency calls for fuel from 400 residents. A prompt check disclosed that 369 were bona fide cases of dwellings either without fuel oil or with tanks so low they would be exhausted before the end of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The health of American troops in North Africa is excellent, Major Gen. James C. Magee said today, despite the prevalence of "almost every disease you can think of" among the native population there.
TORONTO, Jan. 25 (Canadian Press) -- A routine meeting of the National Hockey League's board of governors adjourned suddenly today after President Frank Calder suffered a heart attack.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The Peoples Light and Power Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a voluntary plan for recapitalization by one of three methods or by a combination of the three.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The Under-Secretary of War, Mr. Patterson, is not in the least impressed -- he is even impatient-with the arguments of those who think the plan for an American Army of 7,500,000 men, officers not included, puts out of balance the global military equation by making this item too large in proportion to others with which it must be meshed.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor opposed today the recent request of the Office of Price Administration for a rescinding by the Interstate Commerce Commission of last year's railroad rate increases.

The annual statement of the Continental Motors Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, announced yesterday, disclosed a net profit for the year ended on Oct. 31 of $5,472,884 after all charges, including normal and excess profits taxes and $250,000 reserve for post-war adjustments.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Governor Dewey appealed today for public support of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, proclaiming the current week as Infantile Paralysis Campaign Week.

Sentimental and nostalgic citizens of New York paid tribute last night to the Empire Theatre, which opened for the first time just fifty years ago with the premier performance of "The Girl I Left Behind Me."

St. Timothy's League, composed of New York alumnae of St. Timothy's School in Catonsville, Md., has taken over the performance of Sidney Kingsley's new play, "The Patriots," on the night of Feb. 3 at the National Theatre to aid the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary.

Directors of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation and Vultee Aircraft, Inc., at a meeting in Los Angeles yesterday, recommended a merger of the two companies, according to a statement released here. The stockholders will vote on the proposal at the annual meeting of the respective companies on March 17.
