SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 25 -- Wool supplies are ample in this country to meet civilian requirements said C.B. Wardlaw, president of the National Wool Growers Association which opened its seventy-eighth annual meeting here today.

A fund of $260,000 raised during the last year through a self-imposed tax on each garment produced by the New York coat and suit manufacturers affiliated with the National Suit and Coat Industry Recovery Board was allocated last night to refugee relief and other philanthropic organizations at a meeting of the fund's board of trustees at the Hotel Astor.

ALGIERS, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Marcel B. Peyrouton, Governor General of Algeria, told an audience of officials and prominent residents of Algiers today that "we shall act" against any attempt to divide the population of Algiers to the detriment of the Allies.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- A firm tone marked the opening of the stock markets today, with home railway issues and junior stocks providing gains of note. Southern Deferred gained seven-eighths, London, Midland and Scottish and Great Western gaining a half.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Legislation providing for participation of the 20,000,000 policy holders of the Prudential Insurance Company of America in elections of members of the company's board of directors was offered for introduction today in the New Jersey Legislature.

Like a breath of the free and invigorating North Country come the announcements, made in Washington and Ottawa, that a joint economic committee representing the United States and Canada is studying post-war collaboration in the region tapped by the new Alaska Highway.

The annual St. Valentine's Kettledrum and card party for the benefit of the Samaritan Home for the Aged will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 8 in the ballroom of the Colony Club. Mrs. Gilbert S.B. Darlington and Mrs. George Hull are co-chairmen of the benefit committee and their aides include Mrs. Edward Fales Coward, Mrs. John Gerdes, Mrs. Cochran Supplee and Miss Margaret Remsen.

High officials of the city, the Army and the Navy were among the thousand persons who attended a memorial service for P. E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in charge of the New York City office, heId yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Aenue and Twelfth treet.

A basketball game that would bring together the whiners of the N.C.A.A. and National Invitation Tournament late in March, certainly one of the most attractive court contests of any season, if arranged, is in the making.

Civilian supply of viscose rayon yarn, already pinched by war demands, may be seriously curtailed for the balance of this year as the result of a serious bottleneck that threatens delay in completion of newly placed ordnance contracts for vitally needed fragmentation- bomb parachutes, it was reported here yesterday by cloth weavers.

An arbitration award granting to 1,200 employes of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company an 8-cent-an-hour wage increase has been made by the Rev. John P. Boland, former chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board, the Transport Workers Union announced yesterday.

Greater New York's three public libraries are asking the city for more money for books. The New York Public Library asks a raise from $50,000 to $250,000; the Queens Borough Public Library from $25,000 to $85,000; the Brooklyn Public Library from $35,000 to $250,000.

AN R.A.F. BASE ON THE BURMA BORDER, Jan. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Operating in relays from this jungle air field, squadrons of R.A.F. fighter planes made a six-hour attack today on Prome, important Japanese supply center on the Irrawaddy River.
LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 25 (AP) -A joint British Headquarters-R.A.F. communique:

For men in large camps bordering overburdened villages, and for those in small cantonments from Trinidad to Alaska, the women's division of the Jewish Welfare Board-USO has devised a novel service program, which is being recommended to other groups throughout the country by the Women's Interests Section of the War Department.

The worst mother is better than the best institution when it is a matter of child care, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at the opening of the first information and counseling service to be set up by the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Niagara Falls Power Company asked a State Supreme Court justice today to set aside a Public Service Commission rate for power furnished to seventeen Niagara frontier war production plants and stop the State agency from interfering with a rate ordered by the Federal Power Commission.
Mrs. Dennis Mullane, a Staten Island housewife, failed to give the right answer to a question in a radio quiz program Saturday night and had to take the consequences.

With the assertion that "it would be against my interests," William C. Kunz, 40-year-old former leader of the Bronx unit of the German-American Bund, refused yesterday to testify as a government witness. His testimony was sought at trial before Federal Judge John Bright of the government's action to annul the naturalization certificates of Kunz and nineteen other ex-Bundists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Justice Department's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press was challenged anew today in Congress, where Representative Harness, Republican, of Indiana, introduced a resolution calling for an investigation.

Captain Robert S. Holt, Army Air Forces combat intelligence officer and president of Finlay, Holt Co., Ltd., of this city, has died of wounds received on Jan. 8 in action in the Southwest Pacific area, according to a report to his family by the War Department.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 25 -- The board of trustees of the University of Pittsburgh, by unanimous vote tonight authorized the appointment of Clark D. Shaughnessy as head football coach at Pitt with the rank of "full professor."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Chief operating officers of nearly 200 railroads throughout the country were put on formal notice today that their engineers, firemen, conductors, trainmen and switchmen demand a 30 per cent wage increase, a minimum raise of $3 a day.

Two hundred thousand South Africans are in the armies of the United Nations and, under the leadership of Premier Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts the people of South Africa are determined to help see the war through to victory, Ralph W. Close, Minister to the United States of the Union of South Africa, declared yesterday in an exposition of his country's part in the conflict.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- To promote a better understanding between United States and Canadian women, eight members of the Canadian Women's Committee on International Relations exchanged interviews today with Mrs. Ellen S. Woodward of the Social Security Board, Secretary Perkins and Mrs. Roosevelt.

While her husband, Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., was presiding yesterday at a General Sessions trial two floors above in the Criminal Courts Building, Mrs. Mary C. Schurman was chosen foreman of a jury in another part for the perjury trial of two men before Judge Owen W. Bohan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Proposing a post-war selective service system "in reverse" to operate as a job placement agency, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, promised tonight that the Army would "do its best to see no man is mustered out of military ranks into a breadline."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A $100,000,000 farm subsidy program designed to stimulate production of protein crops vital to the war effort was announced today by Secretary Wickard.

Anticipating a heavy oversubscription for the new issue of one-year 7/8 of 1 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness, on which the books have been closed and on which subscriptions are to be paid for next Monday, these certificates went to a substantial premium in the over-the-counter market yesterday.

There will be no lack of medical care for those among the public who need it, in spite of the large scale drafting of physicians and surgeons by the armed services, Dr. J. Stanley Kenney, the incoming president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, said last night in his inaugural address at the Academy of Medicine.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- British submarines operating in the Mediterranean are playing havoc with Axis supply shipping. An Admiralty communique tonight announced the sinking of four more enemy cargo vessels as well as that of one of the escorting ships.

Police Commissioner Valentine requested yesterday a budget allowance of $70,914,583 for the Police Department in the fiscal year 1943-44. This represents an increase of $3,398,837 over the total allowed for the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 26 -- The Red Army, rolling westward on a 500-mile front, has expelled all the Germans from Voronezh, upper Don citadel, and reached a point forty miles from Tikhoretsk, key Caucasus rail junction below Rostov, Moscow reported today, and Premier Joseph Stalin has ordered his troops to hurl back the invaders "over the boundaries of our motherland."
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Russian midday communique:

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Political history was made in the State tonight as the Republican party, long heralded as the friend of the power interests, introduced as a party measure a bill preserving to the people of the State the right of license in the State's water-power resources and charging the present principal lessee of water power four times the present payment for public waters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Congress was informed today that lend-lease aid by the United States from March, 1941, through December, 1942, totaled $8,253,000,000, and that our Allies have bought with their own funds $6,000,900,000 worth of munitions and other essential supplies in this country.

Miss Gwendolyn Handy has been appointed chairman of a junior committee organized in the interests of the Forty-first annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, which will be given in a patriotically designed setting on Feb. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Even in war, when death is knocking at such a multitude of doors, the loss of a trusted public man in the flower of his age and his powers is lamentable. Jay Moffat, United States Minister to Canada, spent more than half his life in the public service. He entered diplomacy nearly twenty-six years ago.

In a news dispatch in THE TIMES I find the following quotation as part of a statement by Representative Shafer of Michigan in connection with his resolution for an investigation of the background of the case against The Associated Press: " * * confront the United States with a most serious assault upon all the freedoms granted to its people."

A new issue of $2,750,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by the New York Housing Authority for award on Feb. 4. The issue will be dated Feb. 15, 1943, and will be payable on Aug. 16, 1943.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- A broad commission house demand for rye futures that uncovered stop loss orders sent prices up 2 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, with May equaling the top price of the season, and July and September went into new ground.

The annual report of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation for 1942 shows net assets of $25,252,289 at the year-end, equivalent to about $146 per share of first preferred stock, comparing with $155.54 a share at the end of 1941.

Wherever on the battlefronts of total war American soldiers fight or wait for their call to fight they carry with them the wise little pocket guides which the War and Navy Departments published. Their authors were anonymous, for nobody was seeking credit. In some cases a number of distinguished writers collaborated.

THE safest place to talk to Frank Frisch is on the baseball field when the only music he can hear is the ringing sound produced by bat meeting ball. At least it is music to his ears when it is a Pittsburgh Pirate bat connecting with a ball. Mr. Frisch did not hear much of that type of music last season.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan 25 -- While British advance forces continued to pursue German rear-guard elements toward the Libyan-Tunisian border Allied air forces opened up on Axis airfields, harbors and shipping throughout the central Mediterranean area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Thirty years ago George Graff of New York City sat down with Chauncey Olcott, the romantic Irish tenor, and Ernest R. Ball, the song writer, to compose "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling." Next Monday, according to expectations, the United States Supreme Court will decide who shall henceforth reap the revenue from the famous ballad.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- Although about $50,000,000 represents the total of capital investments by American organizations and individuals in the past two decades in Palestine's economic development, these funds have actually stimulated and guided investments from other sources so effectively as to make this country a potent supply base in a broader plane for the United Nations' war effort.

The convictions against Edward O. Dormann, former sheriff of Rockland County, and two co-defendants accused of operating a short-lived lottery last Spring, were reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn and a new trial was ordered.

At this late hour we hardly need any German testimonials to British steadfastness in a dark hour. Still, it will do no harm to quote what a writer in the Fuehrer's own newspaper has just said. England, he reminds his German readers, stood up under defeat, and even catastrophe.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

The news yesterday and during the past week clearly shows that the war has reached another crisis -- but this time it is an Axis crisis. The Russian victories, which continue to grow in actual and potential importance, and week-end reports from London and Washington of strategic conversations "on the highest levels" among the United Nations, demonstrate that the course of the war -- and perhaps its duration -- is now being determined.

Sir Owen Dixon, Australian Minister to the United States, in his first public address in New York, said last night it should not be a matter of surprise if Australia awaits with impatience the time when Allied strategy and Allied resources allow a major offensive against Japan.

Preparatory to the first national advertising campaign of the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Association, funds are being raised among members for a study of customer attitudes, according to E. Carl Sorby, vice president of George D. Roper Corporation, Rockford, Ill., who is chairman of the group's advertising and sales promotion committee.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- A new system to simplify the management of sterling accounts held by residents of the United States by amalgamating three types of accounts was announced today by the British Treasury.

It is unlikely that the Nazis ever got much oil from Maikop. The Russians removed the equipment and wrecked the wells. But the oil of Maikop was a symbol of what the Germans hoped to get and what Hitler promised them he would get. Now the Russian drive through the Caucasus is about to erase even that symbol.

A stoppage of the dress industry, largest single industry in the city, affecting 85,000 workers, will begin this morning as a result of the breakdown of negotiations yesterday for a wage readjustment begun last September between the Dress Makers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and five employer associations representing manufacturers, jobbers and contractors.

William J. Fallon, convicted as the "bag man" in the Judge Martin T. Manton case, died yesterday in the Bretton Hall Hotel at Eighty-sixth Street and Broadway of a heart attack. He had lived there the last month with his wife, Mrs. Esther Fallon.

The field for the Mel Sheppard 600 at the Millrose A.A. games in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6 is now complete, Director Fred Schmertz said yesterday at the first of the weekly luncheons of the Track Writers Association at the Hotel Paramount.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25 -- More than fifty local unions and metal trades councils, reported to represent about 300,000 West Coast workers, have sent letters in the last week to President Roosevelt and members of Congress threatening to withdraw their "no strike" pledge if the National Labor Relations Board persists in pushing its "unfair" labor practices case against the three Henry J. Kaiser shipyards in the Portland (Ore.) industrial area, it was disclosed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- While popular resentment over the manner in which the public was informed of events leading to the fall of Tripoli continues to mount in Italy, the Ministry of Propaganda continued today its all-out efforts to make bad news serve a good end by heightening internal determination to fight on to victory.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 25 -- A mixed force of American infantry and tanks swept into Maknassy, thirty-five miles from the Gulf of Gabes, shot up German positions and captured eighty prisoners in a bold exploit that emphatically answered an enemy challenge to "come out and fight," it was announced today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- C.K. Sie, Chinese Minister to Switzerland, who was appointed more than six months ago to be the first modern Chinese envoy to the Vatican, left Berne today for that post. He was accompanied by R.H. Wang, formerly of the embassy in Vichy, who will be his first secretary.

The Isaac Don Levine biography of Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell, postponed from last Fall, will be published by Duell, Sloan Pearce Feb. 26. The author had the cooperation of General Mitchell's family in the preparation of the study.

Out of the stillness of his Forty-second Street hideout yesterday President Ed Barrow of the Yankees emerged noisily to take issue with Joe Cronin, manager of the Red Sox, on the matter of which team will win the 1943 pennant in the American League.
Berlin acknowledged yesterday the loss of Voronezh and Velikiye Luki, strategic bases long in dispute.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25 -- The world champion Cardinals, their pockets abulge with ready spending money, learned today they will do their Spring training in Cairo, Ill., where they can live in an eighty-six-year-old hotel, take steamboat rides on the Mississippi or go anywhere in a taxi for ten cents.

Gianna Bernhard, Czech soprano who has sung in operas and operettas in Europe, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. She was accompanied by Ernst Wolf. Her program included three Schubert songs, Faure's "Apres un reve," two songs in English and three arias.

A few of the annual meetings of conservation groups including the annual North American Wildlife Conference have recently been set. An outline of the program of the conference has been received, although some of the reports and speakers to be heard are yet to be announced.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- The first official news of the German "clean-up offensive" in Yugoslavia from Axis sources was given tonight in the following German order:

More than 1,000 students at Columbia, New York and Fordham Universities and City College, it was estimated yesterday, will be subject to the War Deaprtment's order calling up the Army's enlisted reserves in the colleges.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- Forty thousand persons have been ordered to evacuate the Old Harbor district of Marseille at the instigation of the German military authority, which has established in that city a base for its "troops of operation."

The United States faces a manpower shortage which, though vastly less difficult than that of our enemies, will tax both the capacity and the flexibility of our labor supply, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of The Guaranty Survey.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gave approval today to a plan for the transfer of the foreign servicing business of the Electric Bond and Share Company System from Ebasco Services, Inc., to American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- Stops to eliminate delinquences under the Selective Service Act have been approved by the national headquarters, Brig. Gen. Ames Brown, State director, said today in explanation of the plan which was adopted at a recent conference of United States attorneys and officers of the F.B.I. within the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A Treasury-sponsored bill to increase the public debt limit from its present all-time high of $125 billions to $210 billions entered competition today with the new tax legislation for first consideration by the House Ways and Means Committee.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden is facing a series of tough questions on this Government's attitude toward the recent appointment of Marcel B. Peyrouton as Governor General of Algeria when the House of Commons reconvenes.

Events today: Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor; Fritz Kreisler, soloist; Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Clarence Adler, pianist, assisted by the National Ochestral Association Alumni Orchestra, conducted by Leon Barzin Mozart piano concertos, Town Hall, 8:45; Margaret Aue Butler, 'cello; Romolo De Spirito, tenor, and Walter Hautzig, pianist, Towa Hall, 3; Eunice Eaton, piano recital, New York Times Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Navy announced today forty-six more casualties in Navy forces, including three dead, two wounded and forty-one missing.

Two designers shared the honors at the Saks Fifth Avenue millinery showing yesterday afternoon. They represented the old and the new world in training. Mme. du Plessix, Russian born, had her schooling in the couture of Paris; Josephi, an American, got his start in the field of fashion by trimming windows in Pittsburgh, then he branched into millinery and had a quick success that he has maintained.

Plans for presenting a "united front" of the outer apparel industries here in opposition to MPR 287 as unworkable in its present form and as constituting a threat to the survival of these industries were formulated yesterday at a special meeting of garment manufacturers held in the Democratic Club.

Saturday night will mark the thirty-ninth and final performance of "The Russian People" at the Guild Theatre. Spurred on by glowing reports of its success in the Soviet Union, the Theatre Guild outbid competitors and acquired the Konstantin Simonoff play, assigning Clifford Odets to prepare the American acting version and Harold Clurman to stage it in Boris Aronson's scenery.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Sentiment for stringent measures to persuade Argentina to break with the Axis or suffer the economic consequences inherent in having herself cut off from trading contact with the United Nations is building up among foreign traders, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The bulk of the Army's enlisted reservists in colleges throughout the country will be ordered to active duty in the near future, War Department officials said today.

Red, white and blue national emblems of the United States, Great Britain and Canada formed a patriotic decor for a gala entertainment, entitled "A Night in an English Music Hall," held last night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Canadian Club of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Frenchmen barricaded themselves inside their homes in the Old Harbor district of Marseille tonight and began fighting German troops who called up tanks and artillery, reports from Switzerland said.
In a three-point program the National Boxing Association, through its president, Abe J. Greene, yesterday recommended steps calculated to avoid confusion in the lightweight championship situation.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 5 per cent for the week ended Jan. 23, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a decrease of 8 per cent.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The Russians announced a further important advance in the Kuban area of the Caucasus this morning and the successful, development of offensives below Rostov and north of the Donets basin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The East coast fuel situation remains acute despite increased production of coal and use of emergency distribution methods, Secretary Ickes reported today.

License Commissioner Paul Moss testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck that in 1938 he had ordered "all tip sheets" banned from newsstands, but that his orders were not fully carried out at that time.

Joseph Platzker, assistant commissioner of the Department of Housing and Buildings, and chairman of the Mayor's committee to provide homes for the 613 families in Kingsbridge which are being moved to make way for the Waves and the Spars, reported last night that 427 payments already have been allocated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- The talk by Mr. Jeffers at Baltimore today brought from the Office of War Information here two hours later this statement:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- American fliers, playing an ever-increasing part in the stepped-up Allied air offensive against Burma, made a devastating daylight attack yesterday on Rangoon, chief port of entry for Japanese supplies, it was announced today.

The unorthodox January rally movement received added impetus yesterday from the so-called blue-chip issues as spots in the high-priced investment group added 2 or more points. There was still considerable trading in the low-priced shares, although the pace in them was considerably lessened.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Proposed control over the distribution of manpower between military and civilian war effort, and through it the size of the Army, was projected today by the Senate Committee on Appropriations. Under the committee's program the controls would be exercised through limitations on appropriations where it deemed that curbs should be applied.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP) -- Dan Chappell, attorney for the Horsemen's Protective Association, returned from Washington today with word that reopening of Florida's racing season is "virtually hopeless."

In the early days of Lend-Lease the achievements of the United States were not impressive. For a period of some months our contribution to the common pool of the nations fighting in defense of freedom consisted mainly of exports of food, of which we then had an abundance.

Several amendments have been made to Food Administrator Wickard's bread order, extending its provisions and clarifying its scope, John F. Conaboy, New York Area Supervisor of the Food Distribution Administration, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 -- While Governor Dewey's modifications of the State income tax were introduced in the Legislature tonight, it became known definitely that the Governor is committed to budgetary reserves, designed to preserve a cushion for State finances in the event of a falling off in revenues in the future, rather than embarking on the use of surplus funds for additional tax reduction now.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 -- Probable governmental action for elimination of 'frills" in the wholesale distribution field under wartime conditions was outlined today by Dr. Walter F. Crowder, chief, business structure and operations unit of the Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Navy Department Communique 261: ...

Two thousand soldiers, sailors and air force men representing virtually every one of the United Nations danced with registered hostesses last night in the cavernous Arcadia Ballroom, at Fifty-third Street and Broadway, as guests of the management.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- American Army troops in an offensive on Guadalcanal have captured Kokumbona, coast village seven miles west of Henderson Field, and six important elevations, also west of the airfield, and continued mopping up pockets of enemy resistance, the Navy reported today.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25 -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, demanded here today that "the Army and the Navy and these loafers" be kept out of war plants to permit the managers of the plants to "get out the production we need."

The Treasury, according to its general counsel, Randolph Paul, flavors "early enactment of legislation designed to put the payment of income taxes on a current or more nearly current basis," and is ready to give its advice on the subject to Congressional committees whenever it is asked to do so.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -With the evacuation of the Voronezh bridgehead, and Stalingrad rapidly deteriorating into a forlorn hope for the Germans, official warnings to the civilian population that the military crisis along the Russian front calls for mobilization of the nation's last reserves became still more outspoken today.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- Marseille was warned by city-wide loudspeakers that looters would be shot in the Old Harbor area, according to the Vichy radio. The radio said the Nazis explained their evacuation order on "military and security" grounds.

LONDON, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- Negotiations are progressing between the Yugoslav Government and Russia to bring together the two antagonistic anti-Axis factions operating in Yugoslavia, it was reported reliably today.

A special service in observance of the tenth anniversary of the induction of the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming as rector of the parish of Trinity Episcopal Church was held yesterday in the church, Broadway and Wall Street, with Bishop William T. Manning giving his personal greetings as well as those of the diocese.

The considerations that determined the board of directors of The Associated Press to deny membership in that news gathering organization in twelve instances were cited yesterday in Federal court. They were given in a reply to "requests for admissions" filed by the government in its anti-trust action to force the press association to make available membership to all who apply for it.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 25 (U.P.) -- The communique of Nov. 18 said Japanese planes sank two American trawlers along the coast of New Guinea and front dispatches later told of an American general who stood on the deck of one of them and blazed away at twenty-three Zero fighters with a Springfield rifle.
The skiing world has gone to war in a big way.

TRENTON, Jan. 25 -- South Jersey Republican Senators who are unfriendly to Governor Charles Edison delayed action at today's session of the Legislature when the Judiciary Committee reported for confirmation only reappointments. None of these nominations was acted upon, however.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- Japan's capture of the rich rubber supplies of the Far East has played havoc with the United States' supplies of rubber and curbed the driving of consumers, but it has meant little to her as a source of revenue, according to word brought here today by foreign traders.

The theft of ration coupons for 11,467,392 gallons of gasoline from the Long Island City office of OPA over the week-end convinced Federal and local authorities last night that professional bootleggers had moved into the field of gasoline rationing.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at Tripoli, Libya, Jan. 23 (Delayed) -- The Union Jack flies from the tallest building in this city.

ON THE CENTRAL TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- Today I saw American planes bomb a German strong-point in the critical Ousselat Valley and American artillery shell it -- and the Germans broke and ran. The result was that three enemy machine-gun nests were smashed, an 88-mm, gun was left behind and a battery of three was put out of action.

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The German radio announced today that British commandos had attempted to raid Lervik, on the coast of Norway. The announcement said the raid was carried out by sabotage troops in seven motor torpedo boats which were turned back by the defenses.

Apparently unconvinced that higher parity prices will be sanctioned, cotton traders became cautious yesterday, operating on both sides of the futures market, while awaiting decisive action on agricultural bills now pending before Congress.

Shipments of fresh vegetables arriving in the wholesale market yesterday were a little larger than usual and as a result prices dropped. The increase in supplies -- they had been conspicuously light the end of last week -- will be noticeable in retail stores today and tariffs should be correspondingly lower.

Yehudi Menuhin reached his majority several years ago, but he seems to have come of age as an artist this season. His playing at Carnegie Hall last night was the best that this reviewer has heard him do in more than a decade. The erstwhile prodigy has achieved maturity.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25 (AP) -- A soda-fountain girl, Mona Mervyn, today told the jury trying Errol Flynn on statutory rape charges that one of the complaining witnesses, Betty Hansen, informed her she hoped to meet Flynn and get into the movies with his help.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25 -- Six men and four wholesale meat companies with which they are connected, who were accused of violating OPA price ceilings in complaints filed last week, pleaded not guilty when they were arraigned before United States Commissioner William J. Bartholomew in Newark today.

The Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia in 1942 increased its holdings of United States Government bonds by $20,154,000, a sum which exceeded the total increase in company assets during the same period, M.A. Linton, president, reported yesterday to policy holders.

Young women members of Junior Leagues throughout the country were urged yesterday to "step out of the 'leisure class' and become gainfully employed war workers" if by doing so they could "best aid the war."

CINCINNATI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- Joe Choynski, the "California Terror" whose vinegar-hardened fists once carried his 162 pounds to a twenty-round draw with big Jim Jeffries at 230, died yesterday, one of the last great figures of the bare-knuckle era of fistiana. He was 74.

Without being overoptimistic furniture retailers as a Whole should plan on volume this year being equal to or slightly better than in 1940, Charles S. Shaughnessy, merchandise councillor in charge of furniture at R.H. Macy Co., declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives of New York in the Advertising Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- An increase from 8 to 10 cents in the Hudson Manhattan Railroad's fare between Jersey City and Hoboken, N.J., and Hudson Terminal was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Examiner R.N. Trezise.
A Finnish communique broadcast by the Lahti radio and recorded by the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service.

PESHAWAR, India, Jan. 25 (Reuter) -- The Turkish press delegation today visited "the nearest point to Turkey in India" -- the Khyber Pass. The delegation, driving through this historic military and commercial highway between India and Afghanistan, appeared impressed by the impregnability of the fortifications.

May 1, in answer to Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, present another side of the local tax picture. Without going into a detailed analysis of State-city fiscal relationships, the fact is that New York City in many instances pays more to the State than all the other communities combined.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- The Moscow press was dominated today by Premier Joseph Stalin's congratulatory order to the Red Army, signed for the first time in his capacity as supreme commander, and by the announcement of the clearing of Voronezh and neighboring territory east of the Upper Don, where the enemy had been lodged since last July.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Distinguished Flying Crosses were awarded today to three United States airmen of the Eighth Army Air Force.

The manager and three women and a man, employes of the motion picture theatre at 5 Chatham Square, in Chinatown, were arraigned yesterday in the Bowery Court in a test case accused of having violated the lottery law in charging admission to bingo games in the theatre last Friday and Saturday.

Retail liquor dealers were warned that their supplies would be reduced this year by about 50 per cent of the amount available in 1942, but were told by various speakers at a meeting yesterday of the Metropolitan Package Stores Association at the Hotel Park Central that a normal consumer demand could be met through sound distribution.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,245, as against 1,782 in the preceding week and 1,522 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 339, which compared with 785 last Tuesday.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Enroute to cover the biggest story of his career, Edouard Baudry, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation war correspondent, was killed by anti-aircraft fire over Spanish Morocco when the plane in which he was riding with other correspondents became lost in bad weather.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Forty winners of the second annual science-talent search among high school seniors who will come here to compete for $11,000 in Westinghouse Science Scholarships were named today by the Science Clubs of America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:If reports from Washington are to be credited, it now transpires that the much-discussed Petrillo case is not a threat to our American way of life by a petty dictator acting in the guise of a labor union leader, but a difference between Mr. Petrillo and the heads of the National Broadcasters Association as to the politeness of their respective manner of approach.
Net sales of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for 1942 increased to $142,168,850 from the $101,957,987 volume of 1941, according to the annual report issued yesterday by L.B. Neumiller, president.
Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, who had been staying at 277 Park Avenue, has returned to Washington.

As the deadline next Tuesday for draft delinquents draws near, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City's Director of Selective Service, revealed yesterday that an average of from six to eight men daily have presented themselves at each of the 280 local boards here during the last week to make themselves available henceforth for military service if called.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A British communique:

Harry Hansen said yesterday in his reminiscences of Alexander Woollcott that toward the end of his life Woollcott developed an enthusiasm for a fellow-Vermonter, Wolcott Balestier, who died in 1892, the year in which his sister Caroline Starr Balestier became the wife of Rudyard Kipling.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 26 -- The resignation of Fred A. Howland at the age of 78 from official connection with the National Life Insurance Company after forty years with the company, twenty-one years as president and six years as chairman of the board, and the election of four new vice presidents were announced at the ninety-third annual meeting of the directors here today.

Four specific recommendations were submitted yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., to members of the committee named recently by Mayor La Guardia to make a study of Labor Relations in the city's transit system.

In spite of the obstacles in the first full year of our participation in the war, newspaper advertising did well last year in comparison with other years, an analysis of Media Records' figures show. Linage last year, which was down 5.4 per cent from 1941, compared favorably with all the years back to 1931. The 1942 linage, however, was still one-third below that of 1928 and 1929.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- A Casablanca dispatch of The United Press has revived speculation whether a new drive was under way to take Finland out of the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- Local newspapers arriving here from France contain announcements regarding the free distribution of evaporated milk for young children. The wording of such announcements has become familiar to the French, but there is a notable omission -- no mention is made of the fact that the milk was brought by the American Red Cross as a gift from the American people.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- American nurses, including members of the Roosevelt Hospital unit from New York City, are now on this front after a four-and-a-half-day train trip across North Africa and a more or less perilous convoy journey along roads occasionally raked by German and Italian planes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The meeting at Casablanca of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill was regarded in official circles here as a council of war designed to clear the way for Allied unity and a common strategy on all fronts, and to plan a continuing offensive whose object is, not the negotiated peace for which the Axis has at times angled and may angle again, but "unconditional surrender" of the enemy.

Criticism of the policy of the Office of War Information in seeking to bring about the organization of Italian-American Victory Councils in New York and other cities, with the inclusion of Communists and persons formerly pro-Fascist in their sympathies, is expressed in an editorial to appear in Nazione Unite, official organ of the Mazzini Society, and released for publication yesterday by A. Tarchiani, national secretary of the society.

The Fighting Frenchmen who are today helping patrol the streets of Tripoli are not necessarily all of one political party. They do all belong to the party which never accepted the surrender of Bordeaux, never for one moment dreamed of ending this war until they were dead or until the soil of France had been purged of the last living Nazi.

While fifty more families moved yesterday, from five of the thirteen buildings in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx to make room for the Waves and Spars who will train in near-by Hunter College, five of the tenants appeared in Bronx Municipal Court to contest dispossess proceedings brought by a landlord for nonpayment of rent for this month.

Emphasizing that "tremendous" strides are being made in the improvement and production of aircraft, the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, at a meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, honored five men who have played an important part in the creation of America's new strength in the air.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Seven modern patriotic murals are on display above the Fifth Avenue show windows of B. Altman Co., with the announced purpose of acting as "a constant reminder to each passer-by that this is every American's war -- to encourage the further purchase of war bonds and stamps."

In a war without limits and without precedents, the reporters covering the action in North Africa cannot have been much surprised to be summoned to Casablanca and whisked into a tropical garden where they found the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, demanded tonight the resignation of the president and directors of the Marine Maintenance Corporation of Bayonne, N.J., following the company's indictment on charges of collecting $600,000 in overcharges and fraudulent fees.

Coal gas fumes, rising from the cellar of a four-story apartment house at 650 Crown Street, Brooklyn, affected forty persons, including men, women and children, early yesterday, and drove many of the building's 100 occupants, suffering from dizziness and nausea, to open windows and the street.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 26 -- Annapolis, the repository of the nation's naval traditions, reflects in its quiet classrooms and enormous dormitories the news of the far-flung war at sea.

Although the war has posed many new problems for medical science it has also provided opportunities for greater progress in this field, leaders in several branches of medical work declared yesterday at a forum on "Medicine in Wartime" at Town Hall.

International studies, designed to prepare students to become specialists in one foreign country or region of the world, has been approved as a major course at Barnard College, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday. The newly planned curriculum constitutes an interdepartmental major under the direction of a faculty committee.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 26 -- Because of the requirements of international law, British administrators will make few changes in the government of Libya, either for reasons of discipline or reform. Italian law will remain the basis for the civil government and some Italian administrators even will be allowed to carry on their duties.
If Mrs. Dennis Mullane, Staten Island housewife, had kept up with her mail yesterday she could truthfully have set down, "Your 60,000 letters received, but contents not noted."

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Domestic railway issues were today the only ray of sunshine in a generally quiet stock market. After a quiet opening Great Western gained 1/4 and Southern deferred 1/8. Gilt-edge stocks were dull, old Consols falling 1/4 and local loans 1/8.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 -- The final session today of the general assembly of the Council of State Governments, attended by twelve Governors and several hundred other representatives of the States, unanimously adopted the report of its manpower committee, which urged the Federal Government to stop trying to go it alone and to accept State and local cooperation in solving war manpower problems.
Cooperative Distributors, who have been in East Sixteenth Street for some time, have leased a large store and basement at 13 Astor Place through the Chelsea Management Corporation, brokers.

The Army's announcement that enlisted reservists soon will be called for active duty from the colleges doesn't necessarily mean that intercollegiate athletics will be halted or even greatly curtailed in the near future.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- British, American and Allied fighters and bombers were over France and Belgium today in fairly extensive sweeps, chiefly blasting Nazi-used railways and other traffic lines. The attacks continued most of the afternoon and watchers on the Channel coasts of England saw many planes roaring out and back.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- Education groups appear to have lost, for the time being, their fight to have the amount of money allocated as State aid for schools pegged at the same amount as was given last year.

Two men who once worked in the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's plant at Long Island City testified in Federal court yesterday that Franz Wunschel, German-American Bund member, had counseled the workers there to "lay down on the job."

Dining out will be recognized as an uplift for morale in the new rationing program for restaurants and hotels, and patrons of these establishments will not be required to surrender ration stamps to get food, Archie M. Palmer, associate director of the food rationing division of the OPA, said here yesterday.

In the first million-share session of the new year on the New York Stock Exchange, the stock market yesterday consolidated and extended moderately its rally which has swept prices up to the best levels since late October of 1941. The additions were limited and not as wide as in recent sessions of the January movement, and the continued unresponsiveness of the railroad issues restricted buying in many of the pivotal groups.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Germans executed several prominent Jews before surrendering Tripoli to the triumphant British Eighth Army, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The last fortnight brought many intimations of a new Roosevelt-Churchill conference, but the actual fact of President Roosevelt's sensational flight to North Africa was a military secret until its official announcement tonight.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Leningrad is still under the spell of its recently won freedom. Your correspondent spoke by telephone to a friend in that city last night to ask him how Leningrad had celebrated the breaking of the blockade. He said there had been patriotic dancing to tunes broadcast all night in the streets, that nobody had slept a wink and that street cars kept running till morning.

In computing deductions for depreciation, in Federal income tax returns, the "useful life" of a property is considered as its term of use for the purpose designated. The regulations say that complete exhaustion of a property is not required in estimating the annual depreciation, but if it possesses salvage value at the end of the useful life, this value must be taken into account in determining the depreciation value.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 26 -- The location, number and relative strength of Allied assaults on the Nazi fortress of Europe this year was the prime topic of discussion during the "unconditional surrender" meeting between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and military, naval and air staff chiefs.

The Shoestring Opera Company, by its very name, disarms those who come upon it. The company's first production, Offenbach's "The Tales of Hoffmann," presented at the Hunter College Auditorium last night, was equally disarming. Without pretension and with the most limited of means, the company put on a pleasant show, modestly conceived and carried through with a not unplaesant blend of professionalism and semi-professionalism.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 26--Residents of the Swedish frontier area tonight reported having heard thunderous explosions throughout the day from the direction of Trondheim on the Norwegian coast.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Signator hung up his second victory in two starts at the Fair Grounds today when he took the $2,500 added Lake Providence Handicap over a muddy track.

Pursued by a series of injuries which have handicapped his Rangers all of this season, Manager Lester Patrick yesterday suffered the loss of Jimmy Franks, his goalie. However, the graying hockey executive for Madison Square Garden, after frantic calls to minor leagues, announced the engagement of Billy Beveridge of the Cleveland Barons, as a replacement.
MOSCOW, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The gross value of United States manufactured products in 1942 was $121,000,000,000, according to latest Commerce Department estimates, more than double the $57,000,000,000 reported by the census of manufactures in 1939 and exceeding by 30 per cent the $94,000,000,000 for 1941, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Rye was again the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today. A small dip early was followed by an advance of around 1/2 cent a bushel over the finish of the previous day to a new seasonal high, but the bulge brought in liberal profit-taking, and a reaction of 1 1/2 cents from the top followed.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 24 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Details of probably the most important gathering of leaders of two great nations in history were disclosed in the most informal press conference ever held.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Fear that some race horse owners and handlers might reach the down-and-out stage because of the collapsed Florida racing season brought plans today for the relief of any in need.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Franciscus Johannes Winter, a 40-year-old German spy who came to Great Britain in the guise of a refugee, was executed today in Wandsworth Prison, the Home Office announced.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill today concluded a momentous ten-day conference in which they planned Allied offensives of 1943 aimed at what the President called the "unconditional surrender" of the Axis powers.

Reporting on operations of the New York Life Insurance Company in 1942, George L. Harrison, president, declared yesterday in the company's ninety-eighth annual statement that assets had passed the three-billion-dollar mark last year, increasing $154,000,000 to $3,142,000,000 on Dec. 31, 1942.

Nostalgic charm and present-day chic were skillfully mingled in the "Spring Song" collection of hats shown yesterday during luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Braagaard of 17 West Fifty-seventh Street was the creator of these hats, which would add sparkle and grace to the simplest of duration clothes.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 26 -- The Marine Maintenance Corporation of Bayonne, N.J., and its president and the former treasurer were charged today with defrauding the government of $600,000 in overcharges and false fees for the repair of ships plying between this country, Africa and Russia, in an indictment returned by the Federal grand jury here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan plans to make a separate peace proposal to China not later than September, 1943, according to information received by the Korean National Front Federation and the Sino-Korean People's League and made public today by their Washington representative, Kilsook Haan.

Fears in Washington that any "sensible action" on the reinforcing-bar situation might "discredit the scrap drive" have forced steel producers into a ridiculous and embarrassing situation, according to O.W. Irwin of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chairman of the Concrete Reinforcing Bar Producers Committee.

The Belmont Park, Empire City and Saratoga race tracks yesterday received from the State Racing Commission their allotment of dates for the 1943 season. Last month Jamaica and Aqueduct gained approval for their schedules and now nothing remains except the problem of getting the racegoers to the ovals.

Assistant District Attorney Edmund C. Rowan of Queens was accidentally killed yesterday afternoon when he discharged a .32-caliber pistol he was cleaning in the basement of his home at 110-50 213th Street, Queens Village. A bullet passed through his heart.

The President's visit to Casablanca is a bold and brilliant stroke of leadership. Its immediate results are a new unity on the part of our French allies and "complete agreement" between the British and American war staffs on the campaigns which will be undertaken in every theatre of war in close association with our friends, the Russians and the Chinese.

After a notable career "Watch on the Rhine," the Drama Critics Circle prize play of the 1940-41 season, will reach the end of its travels in Wilmington on Feb. 6. The tour began on the Coast Sept. 14 of last year with Lucile Watson, Paul Lukas and Mady Christians occuping the featured roles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Japan, racing to step up her war production for the day when the United Nations turn exclusive attention to the Far Eastern theatre of war, is making heavy going of her attempts to tie recently conquered areas into her program, according to information that foreign traders have gleaned from neutral sources and offered to the government for study.

Graduation exercises of the High School of Music and Art, at 135th Street and Convent Avenue, were held yesterday at the school, with five of the 155 graduates absent because they had enlisted in the armed forces.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Jan. 26 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur awarded an Oak Leaf Cluster in lieu of the Distinguished Service Cross today to Brig. Gen. Hanford MacNider of Mason City, Iowa, for "extraordinary heroism in action near Cape Endaiadere, New Guinea, Nov. 23."
Marriage as an institution certainly shows no sign of dying out because of the war, but the conflict has indirectly imposed some startling changes on weddings as social gatherings.

"Star Spangled Rhythm" enters its fifth week today at the Paramount. . . . "China Girl" will start a second and final week today at the Roxy. . . . Beginning third weeks today are "Shadow of a Doubt," at the Rivoli, and "Commandos Strike at Dawn," at Loew's Criterion.

According to preliminary figures at hand, power output by the nation's power and light industry last week reached the second highest level in the history of the industry. The high production record -- 3,975, 873,000 kilowatt-hours -- occurred in the week ended Dec. 19, 1942, and last week's production is expected to come pretty close to that level.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

A solemn pledge to the armed forces that New York City will raise its quota of $12,920,700 toward the national goal of $125,000,000 when the 1943 Red Cross War Fund drive opens on March 1 was signed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and borough leaders of the campaign and turned over to representatives of the Army and Navy at a colorful ceremony in Times Square.

Priorities permitting, an interior decorating and renovating session is in prospect for the Woman's Court, in the ancient Jefferson Market edifice at Sixth Avenue and Tenth Street. Recommendations to that effect, framed by a committee of six magistrates, have been submitted by Commissioner of Public Works Irving V.A. Huie to the director of the budget, who has referred them -- favorably -- to the city priorities and allocations board for consideration.
A broadcast by the German-controlled Lyon radio to the French public, reported to the Office of War Information in Washington, was quoted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- His trip to North Africa makes President Roosevelt the "travelingest" President in history, putting him far in front of the late William Howard Taft, who had held the record.

The problem of street traffic congestion in the city in normal times "can be solved only by a joint attack involving regulation, cooperation of and informed public, new construction and legislation," the Regional Plan Association declares in a report of a two-year study, containing a program for improved post-war conditions in midtown and downtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- Martial law continued to be applied today in the old harbor section of Marseille, from which 40,000 persons have been evicted on German order. No one is permitted to enter the vacated buildings, and looters have been warned their fate will be death.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Edward J. Flynn resigned today as a Democratic National Committeeman from New York and this step apparently cleared the way for a close but favorable vote by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on his nomination to be Minister to Australia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Captain E.V. Rickenbacker, American ace of the first World War and hero of a notable venture in this one, urged today an educational program which would turn high schools exclusively to the task of producing soldiers and war workers and postpone education in the liberal arts until after the war.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 26 -Captain William Hays Davidow of the Army Air Forces has been killed in an airplane accident in Africa, the War Department has notified his mother, Mrs. Irwin Friend, of 44 Graham Road, Scarsdale. There were no further details.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- Feb. 15 is the tentative date set by the authorities of "New France" for the "total liquidation of the Jewish problem," according to information reaching international relief organizations in Geneva.

A plan for the removal of the parterre boxes, known the world over as the "diamond horseshoe," has been discussed by the directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association. If and when the boxes are eliminated, the plan calls for replacing them with plush seats fastened to each other and set in tiers as in the orchestra and the balconies.

Arthur Bartley, United States manager for Ducks Unlimited, was a busy fellow yesterday preparing to start on a transcontinental trip to raise funds to carry on his organization's work in Canada, but he stopped long enough to answer a question or two.
LONDON, Wednesday, Jan. 27 (AP)--The Soviet midnight communique:

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Russian troops have killed or captured all but 12,000 German troops of the huge forces trapped at Stalingrad and have freed the three main railways radiating westward for the continuing offensive that has carried the Red Army forward 245 miles, Moscow announced tonight in a special communique recorded by the Soviet monitor here.

Wendell Willkie, in a broadcast over WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System immediately following announcement of the President's trip, said that he felt the visit to an actual battlefield would give Mr. Roosevelt a closer understanding of the war, but expressed disappointment that Premier Joseph Stalin and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had not participated in the conferences.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- Under the new price control technique for the food trade providing definite margins and fixed dollars and cents ceilings, consideration will be given to higher costs resulting from volume declines, rationing, lowered labor efficiency and other war-time factors, A. C. Hoffman, director of the food price division, Office of Price Administration, declared here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- To determine the eligibility of high school students to obtain the 750 State scholarships awarded annually by the Board of Regents a new type of comprehensive examination has been approved by the board, Dr. George M. Wiley, associate commissioner of education, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Senate was in recess. Its Military Affairs Committee heard reports on the size of the armed forces. An agriculture subcommittee heard Donald Nelson, WPB chairman, discuss the synthetic rubber program.
BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings outscored the Bruins tonight by a 5-3 margin to gain their first regular scheduled National Hockey League triumph on Boston ice since Dec. 7, 1937.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26 -- Russian dive bombers and torpedo-carrying planes have destroyed a German convoy in the Barents Sea off the Arctic coast, sinking nine transports and a patrol vessel totaling 51,000 tons, it was announced today.

Fifteen metal sports trophies! were thro back into the ring, to be melted into war scrap, at victory rally last night under the auspices of the 'Vev York City l Salvage Committee, at the Federation Settlement Auditoritml, 115 East 106th Street.
We have read with great interest the article. "The Nazi Rot in Denmark" in your Jan. 23 issue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 26 -- The German High Command's communique today admitted that the remnants of the German Sixth Army and the Rumanian units engaged at Stalingrad had been massed in a small sector, where a last stand was about to be attempted.

The United States Steel Corporation was able to apply a tax credit of $6,200,000 to its fourth quarter earnings in 1942 by reason of ultraconservative tax provisions in the first nine months of the year, the use during the year of a $10,000,000 post-war credit by application of the money to debt retirement, and a year-end charge of $16,500,000 against operations to defray part of pension accruals for past services, which is a tax deduction.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill left England to meet President Roosevelt the evening of Jan. 12 in the same Liberator, with the same crew, commanded by Captain William Vanderkloot of Florida, of the Ferry Command, that took him to Cairo and Moscow in August.

VILLUPPURAM, Madras Presidency, India, Jan. 20 (Delayed) -- It was only on coming to Madras Presidency that the writer became fully aware of a fundamental clash of interests that profoundly affects the religious, social and political life of Southern India.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Possession of five cans of foodstuffs will be allowed each person, without penalty, when canned goods are rationed in the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- American ground forces on Guadalcanal have consolidated their occupation of the former Japanese stronghold of Kokumbona, with the capture of considerable booty, the Navy Department reported today, while our air forces there dispersed a large attacking force before it could strike at Guadalcanal.

The leasing of several large suites in El Dorado at 300 Central Park West featured apartment renting activity yesterday. Seven-room apartments were taken by Hayward Singer, John B. Taub and Dr. Joseph Weiss and six-room suites by Benjamin L. Engel and Abraham Tepper.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The magnitude and complexity of the task of getting two great nations to act as one in war and politics were indicated today by the mixups, muddles and paradoxes that developed over so relatively simple a matter as telling the world about the Churchill-Roosevelt meeting at Casablanca, Morocco.

John M. Rainey, former First Deputy Commissioner of Licenses, took issue yesterday with testimony given by License Commissioner Paul Moss that the latter's orders in 1938 for the banning of "all tip sheets" from newsstands had not been fully carried out.

Three pleasing young artists were presented in debut recitals yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by the New York Madrigal Society. They were Romolo De Spirito, Italian-American tenor; Waiter Hautzig, Vienna-born pianist, and Margaret Aue Butler, American 'cellist.

The Museum of Modern Art, supplementing its big architectural exhibition, "Brazil Builds," has installed in a narrow corridor gallery on the ground floor a show of about fifty photographs by Genevieve Naylor, entitled "Faces and Places in Brazil." This is excellent background material for the other show.

Interpreting continued Allied military successes as the precursor of an earlier-than-expected peace, commission houses assumed yesterday a bearish outlook in regard to cotton, on the theory that cessation of hostilities would bring a temporary slackening in demand for the commodity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Delegations from the Ohio and Michigan Legislatures visited Washington today with further proposals to change the two States from Eastern to Central War Time if such would not constitute an impediment to the war effort, but evidently received cold comfort from Federal authorities.

In Balzac's novel, "La Peau de Chagrin," a miraculous bit of wild ass's skin seems to grant its owner's every wish, but only at the price of a certain shrinkage for every wish fulfilled. The last wish is never gratified, for the skin has shrunk to nothing and its owner dies.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- In the first burst of enthusiasm for any positive action about North Africa there is bound to be a plethora of exuberant exclamations in London at the announcement of the Casablanca conference.

LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army swept closer today to the Mareth Line in Tunisia, where German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's retreating and weary forces were reported to be bracing for what the Axis itself said was an impending multi-bladed Allied assault.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Production experts of the women's garment industry will confer here Thursday and Friday with representatives of the Office of Price Administration to go over industry cost problems which have arisen under Regulation No. 287 which sets prices for women's, girls' and children's outerwear garments, OPA announced today.

Voronezh is a hinge. On that hinge, midway on the long Russian front, the German swung last year's offensive. But the Russians never permitted the Germans to tear the hinge loose. They clung desperately to their defenses just beyond the city, thus preventing extension of the German drive northward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -Senator Chandler of Kentucky said today that the United States planned to have 10,420,000 men and women in uniform by the end of this year, including 2,220,000 in the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

W. Gibson Carey Jr. and Herbert C. Davidson were elected yesterday trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. Mr. Carey is president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company and Mr. Davidson is a vice president of Consolidated Edison.

An Army-Navy mile relay, never before witnessed at Madison Square Garden, has been arranged by Fred Schmertz, director of the Millrose Games, it was announced yesterday. As a matter of fact, indoor track being comparatively new at West Point, this will mark the first participation of an Army track team in the Millrose carnival, which will be held at the Garden on the night of Feb. 6.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 -- Film rights to the recent non-fiction best seller, "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," by Cornelia Otis Skinner and Emily Kimbrough, which details their comic adventures on a European trip in the Nineteen Twenties, has been acquired by Paramount.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The 119 municipal and cooperative electric distribution systems using TVA current in the Tennessee Valley sold almost 2,500,000,000 kilowatt-hours of power for a combined net income of nearly $5,000,000 during the fiscal year ended on last June 30, the Tennessee Valley Authority announced today.

Uncertainty as to effects of war contract renegotiation, doubt with respect to income taxes to be paid by such companiees and discouragement by government agencies of physical inventories in war plants where they interfere with output, were listed yesterday by the American Institute of Accountants as among major factors which have created serious problems in connection with preparation of corporate financial Statements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A far-reaching plan to "rationalize" a vast segment of American industry -- to end duplication of effort and other practices described as wasteful -- is in the final stages of consideration in the War Production Board, high officials disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A bill to extend to June, 1914, all the provisions of the lend-lease act were introduced in the House today by Representative Bloom, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. The House referred the bill to that committee for action.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 26 -- Marcel B. Peyrouton's assumption of power as Governor General of Algeria has not been followed by the widespread "shake-up" among office-holders for which democratic elements here hoped, but he has faithfully followed the Allied policy in urging the unity of all Frenchmen.

At last some information has trickled through neutral channels concerning the discussions that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Pierre Laval had in Berlin toward the end of December, with Count Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, in the background. The Vichy Premier was roughly handled, abused and borne down with insolent words.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- The destruction of the British aircraft carrier Avenger in an Axis torpedo attack near Gibraltar in November was described today by an American Coast Guard boatswain's mate who participated earlier in a night landing on the North African coast while hostile searchlights swept the sea and Allied ships exchanged gunfire with shore batteries.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America sold yesterday from its investment portfolio, through competitive bidding, a block of $3,000,000 Toledo, Ohio, waterworks extension first mortgage revenue bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1938, to a syndicate headed by Braun, Bosworth Co. The block consists of $2,834,000 2 3/4 per cent bonds, due Dec. 1, 1948 to 1969, and $166,000 2 1/2s, due Dec. 1, 1970.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Navy communique 262:

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- American soldiers in Northern Ireland, celebrating the first anniversary of their arrival here, today heard a message from President Roosevelt saying that talk of defense now was past and that henceforth we would think of "determined, unrelenting, smashing attack."

Pointing out that the British were doing their share in the conduct of the war, Captain Arthur Marsden of the Royal Navy, a Member of Parliament, declared yesterday that "the British are producing more per head in war production than any other country in the world."

Willie Pep, Hartford boxer who is recognized here as the world featherweight champion, will appear before the State Athletic Commission today for a final physical check-up for his scheduled ten-round bout Friday night against Allie Stolz, Newark lightweight, in Madison Square Garden.

A charge of keeping and maintaining a house for prostitution against Pearl Davis, better known as Polly Adler, was dismissed by Magistrate Thomas H. Cullen in Woman's Court yesterday after the court ruled that police had failed to establish a case.
"THE trouble with the Norwegian people is that they have been debrutalized!"

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 26 (AP) -- United States infantry crept through rocky, shrub-spotted hills east of here yesterday morning and occupied an important pass that snakes its way around mountain peaks called Djebel er Rihana and Djebel al Halfa and leads to the coastal plain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs voted today to investigate the charge made in Baltimore yesterday by William M. Jeffers, rubber director, that "Army and Navy loafers" and "expediters" were interfering with war production.

While the Mayor's meat board was taking further statements yesterday on the condition of meat supply in New York City a group representing packers, kosher and non-kosher retailers and union meat cutters met in the offices of Nathan Sweedler, attorney, 225 Broadway, and drafted a telegram to Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, saying that at least three independent packers in this area faced the necessity of closing if they could not get relief.

PRICETON, N.J., Jan. 26 -Congress is expected in the near future to start an investigation of lend-lease operations. It must decide whether to renew the historic measure under which the United States became the "arsenal of democracy."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Marine Corps will make an official announcement on the Women's Reserve it is planning the middle of February and will introduce afterward at a press conference the woman selected as Reserve Director, it was revealed today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, according to the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 20: an increase of $508,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $584,000,000 in United States Government deposits; an increase of $173,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, and a decrease of $103,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Blame for a "black market" in meat was put on the Office of Price Administration today by Representative Donald L. O'Toole of New York, who called upon the House to make an investigation. He introduced a resolution providing for an inquiry to determine if packer influences in OPA handed the meat industry over to the packing industries, was responsible for the "present meat mess" in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- A more abundant life, more jobs and more happiness are in prospect after the war if the United States will only face the facts and take appropriate action, Vice President Wallace told the youth of this country in a radio address today.

As the newly organized Fuel Oil Emergency Committee acted yesterday to relieve the situation of 393 families without fuel, Bronx rationing authorities heard complaints against three motorists, including two selectees, accused of violating the pleasure-driving prohibition.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 26 -- When top executives regard industrial accident figures with the same seriousness that they do profit sheets, both profits and production will soar, leaders in business, agriculture, labor and safety were told here today.

Events tonight: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 o'clock; Donald Ashton Mandell, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Alice Anderson, song recital, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45; Emile Baume, piano, and Joseph Rogatchewsky, tenor, 451 Madison Avenue; 9; Archibald Mansfield, piano recital, International Center, Y.W.C.A., 341 East Seventeenth Street, 8:30; Louis Persinger, violinist, assisted by Barbara Holmquist, pianist, Juilliard School of Music Concert Hall, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Donald Nelson told the Senate Agriculture Committee that 55 per cent of the synthetic rubber program, for which Mr. Jeffers has been waging a vigorous fight in the face of Army and Navy opposition, would be "carried through as rapidly as possible."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Employment of women to increase the manpower reserves of the transportation industries has moved forward perceptibly in recent months, Otto S. Beyer, director of the division of transport personnel of the Office of Defense Transportation, said today.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 26 (AP) -- Pan American-Grace Airways confirmed today a government report that fourteen persons burned to death and only one, John A. Howard, 26 years old, survived the crash of a Pan American-Grace airliner near Chaparra, about 350 miles south of here, last Friday. Mr. Howard was injured.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach vetoed today a $2,700 appropriation made Jan. 18 by the Westchester Board of Supervisors for the County Home Bureau to use in teaching nutrition, canning and home economics.

ALBANY, Ore., Jan. 26 (AP) -- The slayer of Mrs. Martha V.B. James in lower 13 of a West Coast Limited sleeping car was right-handed and probably escaped from the berth with little blood on his clothing, investigators reported today.

The establishment of a bureau to investigate and where possible to rectify neighborhood shortages of foods was completed yesterday by John F. Conaboy, area supervisor of the Food Distributors Administration.

Combined net earnings of the Massachusetts Bonding and Insurance Company were $1,755,230 after Federal income taxes, equal to $10.97 a share on 160,000 shares outstanding, according to the annual report for 1942 issued for release today by T.J. Falvey, president.
LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The London newspapers hailed the "unconditional surrender" meeting at Casablanca today as an augury of better times to come in the war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 26 -- Closing the 1942 session of the Finnish Riksdag today, President Risto Ryti expressed his warm hope that the traditional friendly relations between the United States and Finland would become as good and confident as they used to be.

MIAMI, Jan. 26 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor opposed compulsory national service legislation today on the ground that it would retard rather than increase war production, according to a statement by William Green, president.

Another clash between the New Deal wing of the Democratic party and the faction headed by James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, appeared yesterday to be a likely sequel to the formal announcement in Washington that the resignation of Edward J. Flynn as a member of the Democratic National Committee from New York had been accepted by Postmaster General Frank Walker, new Democratic National Chairman.
