PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26 -- A tip to all baseball players to start their spring training now was passed along today by Bill Benswanger, in ordering his Pittsburgh Pirates to start weight-reducing exercises at once -- seven weeks before the formal workouts start.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 26 (U.P.) -- At least fifty Japanese were killed when a Royal Indian Navy patrol vessel sank an enemy coastal craft northwest of Akyab, Burma, and British fliers inflicted considerable casualties on the enemy in low-level attacks against a Japanese motor convoy, it was announced today.
The Roosevelt-Churchill conference in North Africa kept the Axis guessing and, as usual, the guesses were mostly inaccurate.

A new formula for fixing lumber ceilings on a regional basis will be worked out at a series of industry meetings around the country during March, Peter A. Stone, price executive of the lumber branch, Office of Price Administration, announced here yesterday.

In 1941 Congress raised the legal public debt limit from $49,000,000,000 to $65,000,000,000. In 1942 it raised it again to $125,000,000,000. Now the Treasury has asked Congress raise it to $210,000,000,000. This is one inevitable consequence of the war which we are fighting to preserve our freedom.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Jan. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two officers of a tank destroyer unit are back with their own troops today after they separately made perilous two-day treks through the mountains dodging German patrols.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Axis reports said tonight that American troops were massing in force for an attempt to cut off Marshal Rommel coastal line of retreat in Tunisian.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 25 -- Plans for vast expansion of research and promotion by the National Cotton Council which would boost its annual budget of about $350,000 to a point several times that figure were announced here today by Oscar Johnston, president, at the group's annual meeting.

Dr. Vannevar Bush, Director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, the general staff of America's mobilized brain power charged with task of translating new ideas into new weapons in the shortest possible time, told a gathering of electrical engineers at the Hotel Commodore last night that there was no foundation to the charges that the men who lead our Army and Navy are not open to new ideas.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 24 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt took time out from his ten-day conference to decorate Brig. Gen. William H. Wilbur personally with the Congressional Medal of Honor -- the highest American decoration -- for his part in the landings in French Morocco.

Demonstrations by audiences are not new experiences to Fritz Kreisler, but the welcome he received when he stepped on the stage of Carnegie Hall last night to play with the Philadelphia Orchestra must have been heartening to him.

According to a dispatch to this newspaper yesterday, sentiment is building up in Washington in both foreign trade and official circles for an Allied boycott against Argentina to persuade that country to break with the Axis. There is talk of "drastic" and "aggressive" measures which, if carried out, would bring about a collapse of Argentina's internal economy and would exclude her from the lucrative post-war rehabilitation markets.

Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, who once confessed with complete candor that he would "rather be lucky than good," may have to call on more than his share of luck if he is to stage a successful comeback during the uncertain campaign of 1943.

Formation of a joint council composed of members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and the National Association of Manufacturers from every State in the Union, to bring about a new order of cooperation among government, business, labor and agriculture, was advocated yesterday by Louis Ruthenburg, president of Servel, Inc., and also president of the Indiana State Chamber of Commerce.

Two players from Jackson Heights, C.A. Keyser and Arthur Arguedas, reached the semi-finals in the twelfth annual Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class C singles championship tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday.
Small buildings were involved in most of the Manhattan deals reported by brokers yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- An increase in daily war spending from 12,000,000 to 14,000,000 was explained today by Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a statement to the House of Commons, moving two further votes of credit for 1,000,000,000 and for 900,000,000.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 26 (UP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin said tonight that the Southwestern Pacific area was too crucial a war theater to be left to a force of "caretakers" and he urged that adequate naval and air strength be sent here to avenge the men of Corregidor.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP) -- A Soviet special communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Carlyle H. Wash, commanding general of the Second Air Support Command with headquarters at Colorado Springs, Col., and former commander of the Third Air Force here, was killed today with nine others, seven of them officers, in the crash of an Army transport plane seven miles from Flomaton, Ala., while on a flight from Drew Field here.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 21 (Delayed)--President Roosevelt inspected American troops in French Morocco today, surprising them by his presence and leaving their faces wreathed in smiles.

Latin-American nations will join in local celebrations of the President's Birthday Ball on Saturday for the first time, it was announced yesterday by A. Ramon Ruiz, chairman of the Latin-American Participation.

The wallflower became the belle of the ball. That, figuratively speaking, is the American history of the soy bean. Though the metaphor may sound high-flown, it accurately described the lowly vegetable that a couple of decades ago was considered fit for fodder only, and that is now found, in one form or another, on the best of dinner tables.

A loan exhibition of paintings by nineteenth century artists (for the most part French) will open with a preview at 4 o'clock this afternoon at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It has been arranged as a benefit for L'Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes, which is affiliated with the New School for Social Research in Twelfth Street.
A dinner dance and gin rummy party will be given Feb. 4 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador Hotel. The admission charge will include a package of rummage.

Between 15,000 and 20,000 dressmakers, members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, quit their jobs yesterday in what the union called a "spontaneous" stoppage to enforce demands for wage readjustments after the breakdown of negotiations with employers on Monday.

In the grounds of the City Hall in Belfast yesterday the Governor of Northern Ireland unveiled a memorial stone to commemorate the first anniversary of the landing of American troops in Ulster. The stone and the inscription are simple. The event is memorable and deserves lasting physical record.

Persons with colds were urged yesterday by Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins to go to bed and call a doctor. He reported a sharp rise in pneumonia cases and deaths in this city in the last few weeks.

A jury last night convicted a 16-year-old schoolboy, a tramp and a young mechanic, all Negroes, of first-degree murder in the stabbing of Stanley Kilbucz, 19, a war worker, of 35 Union Street, Holyoke, Mass. He died after a hold-up in Harlem on the night of July 18.
A One-Way Conversation With Conzelman "IN the very near future," said Jimmy Conzelman, pushing back his shaggy gray locks, "you'll have to treat me with the proper respect due a man of my station."

There must be literally millions of people in the United States who are now discussing the post-war world and the position of the United States in it. Some, no doubt, still feel that it will be possible to return to isolationism, but even they are discussing the problem and the need of making this country so strong that it can stand alone.

LONDON, Jan. 26--One hundred and eighty men and seventy women have been shot in connection with the round-up of what the Germans term "subversive elements" and evacuation of the Old Harbor area of Marseille, according to Swiss reports.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- House leaders deliberated today on the advisability of creating a committee to handle exclusively the postwar problem of the development of air transport. Tonight it seemed likely that the proponents of a standing committee on aviation would lose because of the opposition of other committees fighting to retain their prerogatives.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A bill directing the Board of Regents to formulate a comprehensive program for the physical rehabilitation and professional and vocational training of disabled war veterans was introduced today by Assemblyman Devany of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- From 10 o'clock tonight onward for twenty-four hours, the overseas broadcasting service of the Office of War Information and the British Broadcasting Corporation are to be busy making the Casablanca announcement known to the entire world.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 26 -- Following is the text of the official communique on the conference of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill:

OSSINING, Jan. 27 -- In the first case of its kind since the State adopted the electric chair for capital punishment fifty-four years ago, Irving Nitzberg, 33 years old, who served two separate terms in the Sing Sing death house for months, was released from prison today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Thomas Holcomb, commandant of the Marines, announced today the establishment of a women's reserve. The women are to relieve trained marines for combat duty. General Holcomb said that the reserve was still in the "planning stage" and applications would not be received before Feb. 15.

The great labor groups of the United States -- A.F. of L., C.I.O. and the railway workers -- should join in a united effort to preserve the gains they have made under the New Deal, A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen, said last night in an address at the ninth annual meeting of the Newspaper Guild of New York, held in the Capitol Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Direct allocation of all high tenacity viscose rayon yarns of 250 or coarser denier was ordered today by the War Production Board to implement its program for the production of 50,000,000 pounds of high-tenacity rayon yarns for use in tires.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Generals de Gaulle and Giraud will exchange military and economic missions soon, it was announced today, and a highly-placed source said that the two leaders would be left to work out their political differences without Anglo-American intervention.

A campaign for aid by the Save the Children Federation got under way yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin, where citations at the eleventh annual meeting were presented to fourteen men and women for advancing the child welfare program of the federation in recent years.

Twenty-five hundred maintenance men, employed at eight shops on the IRT division of the city's unified transit system, stopped work yesterday for periods ranging from one to two hours, in protest against alleged discriminatory and inadequate pay adjustments recently granted by the Board of Transportation.

Trials for four events in the P.S.A.L. indoor swimming championships were held yesterday in the Columbia University pool and Andrew Jackson, Curtis and Richmond Hill established themselves as title contenders. Each school qualified three men, while Bayside. the defending team, placed two.

Leading men's clothing manufacturers reported yesterday that they have been receiving reports of spotty business from their representatives and customers, but declared that the over-all business being done has shown some improvement since the first of the year.

An agreement between a single manufacturer and a single dealer granting exclusive right to sell garments of the manufacturer at retail does not constitute a monopoly under the State anti-monopoly law, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday in dismissing a suit brought in the Bronx by Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., against Ohrbach's, Inc., Siegel Brothers Kiki Maid Koats, Inc., and Leeds Ltd. Coats Company, Inc.

PONDICHERRY, French India, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- Miss Margaret Woodrow Wilson, daughter of the late President, told this correspondent today that she was happier than ever before and did not want to return to the United States. For four years she had been a sadhak or follower of Sri Aurobindo, India's most prominent mystic, in his asram here.

Mark Starr, education director of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, was nominated yesterday by the Board of Superintendents for the $7,500 post of adult education director in the New York City school system. This is a new position established by the Board of Education to coordinate all the work in the adult education field.

Increasing use of chicken, turkey and other poultry as a substitute for beef, lamb, pork and other scarce meats has resulted in a substantial reduction of poultry stocks held in storage in the New York area, figures compiled by the Department of Agriculture disclosed yesterday.

A recommendation that all probation departments serving eight courts in New York City be combined into one integrated and central agency under the jurisdiction of the Appellate Divisions of the First and Second Supreme Court Departments was offered yesterday by the Joint Committee on Probation in New York City, of which Samuel Seabury is chairman.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Payment of $2,098,512 in preferred stock dividends by the American Car and Foundry Company will be permitted under an order signed today by Henry T. Kays, vice chancellor.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Chancellor W.W. Harrington today ordered consolidation of two suits brought by the Missouri-Kansas Pipeline (Mokan) Company and others against the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation and the Columbia Gasoline and Electric Corporation and ordered a hearing to be held on Feb. 13 on a proposed settlement of the suits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Northern and Western corn and wheat farmers will get a lion's share of $595,500,000 in benefit payments to be distributed among growers for complying with last year's Federal crop-control programs.

Secretary Wickard of the Department of Agriculture has approved a new school lunch program where-by the Federal Government will provide funds to help pay for food used in providing the lunches instead of providing the food for them, the New York office of the Food Distribution Administration announced last night.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 27 -- An official charge that the Japanese Army was using poison gas, the first since the United States and Britain threatened to retaliate if earlier attacks in China were repeated, was made by the Chinese High Command today.

Allie Stolz, Newark lightweight, yesterday passed the physical test ordered by the State Athletic Commission for his ten-round bout tomorrow night against Willie Pep, world featherweight champion, in Madison Square Garden. But, not so much can be said about Pep.

ALBANY, Ore., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Robert L. Folkes, 20-year-old Negro, was charged today with the murder of Mrs. Martha Virginia Brinson James, bride of Ensign Richard F. James, in Lower Berth 13 on the Southern Pacific's West Coast Limited in the early-morning darkness last Saturday.

Organization of a joint information office of the trucking industry, with the approval of the Office of Defense Transportation, was announced yesterday as a means of eliminating trips by half-filled trucks and "deadhead" return trips.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- There were signs today that the British people were prepared to accept the Churchill-Roosevelt conference with the knowledge that they cannot and will not know what was decided and will have to wait until the pudding has been eaten before they can pass judgment.

MIAMI, Jan. 27 -- While the Anglo-American Trade Union Committee was discussing plans to increase war production, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor issued an appeal to workers to help reduce absenteeism.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 27 -- Official circles in Algiers were preoccupied today with the North African aspects of the Roosevelt-Churchill conference at Casablanca.

After opening strong and approaching the high levels for the current movement, the cotton futures market settled yesterday into a tight trading web in the vicinity of the previous close and ended an erratic session mixed, 3 points higher to 4 points lower than Tuesday's final prices, with the distant positions weakest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 27 -- The probability of one film company immortalizing in pictures the life of the star of a rival company looms with the announcement today by Charles Koerner, vice president of RKO, that his company is planning to produce a film based on the life of Marie Dressler with Kate Smith portraying the late M-G-M star.

ON THE TUNISIAN WAR FRONT, Jan. 22 (Delayed) -- While General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel is moving northward, pursued by the British Eighth Army but still full of fight, I have visited most of the strong points on the Southern Tunisian front, where American armored, infantry and artillery units are waiting to repel an expected shock while battling enemy forces already here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A charge that Japan's black dragon society launched a nation-wide movement to alienate the loyalty of American Negroes was made today in a sedition indictment returned by a Federal grand jury at East St. Louis, Ill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Considerable additional wheat probably will be shipped to Mexico from the United States in the next two weeks as the result of an extension of the government's 25-cents-a-bushel subsidy on exports to certain Latin-American countries, grain men said today.

The United States Pipe and Foundry Company, in a preliminary statement for the year 1942, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $1,655,646 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and $1,200,000 reserve for contingencies.

The largest organization expenditure for community projects to date was announced yesterday at the third day's session of the annual board of directors meeting of the Association of Junior Leagues of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Robert E. Dingman of Larchmont, secretary of the association's ways and means department, made the announcement in conjunction with the financial report for the last year.

The technical education program recently started at 200 colleges by the Army and Navy will not tolerate "country-club attitudes on the campus," Dr. Joseph. W. Barker, special assistant to the Secretary of the Navy, informed a conference on technical manpower in the war effort yesterday morning. Dr. Barker, on leave from his post as dean of the faculty of engineering, Columbia University, discussed the Navy's program.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Attorney General Watson won a round in his campaign against the closed shop in Florida when Judge Miles W. Lewis signed an order in Circuit Court here today directing the Moore Pipe and Sprinkler Company of Jacksonville to cancel its closed-shop contract with a steamfitters and plumbers local (A.F.L.).
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The swift Mosquito planes of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command raided Copenhagen this afternoon in the first British air attack on the Danish capital, the Air Ministry reported.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- An easy undertone developed today in the grain markets, with houses with Eastern connections on the selling side of wheat and rye, which found support less aggressive than recently.

The New York Central Railroad Company reported yesterday for 1942 after charges and taxes a net income of $49,062,283, equal to $7.61 each on the 6,447,413 capital shares outstanding. The net compared with $26,245,562, or $4.07 a share, in 1941. Gross revenues were $593,666,196, against $447,789,655.

Dealing with large groups of women should present no difficulties to the first four Waves officers assigned to organize the training school for Waves and Spars on the Bronx campus of Hunter College. In civilian life three of them supervised girls in academic institutions, while the fourth, a lawyer, spent three years untangling civil cases for both men and women.

William S. Bennet in a letter published in THE TIMES of Jan. 25 states that "educated and intelligent Americans appear to be proceeding on the theory that Congress has something to do" with reducing the voting age from 21 to 18.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 -- A junction of Col. Gen. Konstantin Rokossovsky's Red armies of the Don with Lieut. Gen. Vassily Ivanovitch Chuikoff's Stalingrad garrison has effected the liquidation of the entire German force outside the city and is squeezing the remnants into two pockets less than two miles deep.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Stephen Lawford Childs, former counselor of the British Embassy in charge of press relations, has been killed in an airplane crash in Iran, according to cables received by the embassy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- William Benton, vice president of the University of Chicago, will assume the additional post of chairman of the board of directors of Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., on Jan. 28, when title to the Britannica company, recently given to the university by Sears, Roebuck Co., is transferred.

Retail lumber dealers need not fear the loss of business as a result of the expected post-war expansion of prefabrication, if they will prepare now to participate in this new industry, F. Vaux Wilson, vice-president of the Homasote Company, declared yesterday at the annual convention of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An offer to acquire all assets of the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company in exchange for shares of its own common stock was made public yesterday by the General Motors Corporation, which already owns 103,450 shares, or 71.9 per cent, of the preferred stock; 715,260 shares, or 32.5 per cent, of the Class B common stock, and 800,000 shares, or all of the common stock of the truck corporation.

Concurrent with the report of its 1942 operating results, the Hercules Powder Company announced yesterday the retirement of Gould Grant Rheuby from his positions as vice president, director and member of the finance committee. He had served the company since April 1, 1913, only three months after it had commenced business.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 27 -- American troops are now consolidating the positions that they won from the Germans on a ridge on the east side of the Ousselat Valley. The positions include an S-shaped pass through which the Kairouan-Ousseltia road runs.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Amid gathering signs that a final offensive to drive the Axis out of North Africa may be near, Allied Headquarters in North Africa disclosed today the recapture of several Central Tunisian positions with which the enemy had sought to form a line to protect the flank of Marshal Rommel's retreat into Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Navy announced today forty-nine casualties, including one dead, one wounded and forty-seven missing.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27 -- The fine legal question whether an administrative agency of the Federal Government has the power to grant absolution to the perpetrator of a libel by transferring responsibility has arisen as the result of the recent revisions of the proxy rules issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 27 -- The Reds sold Paul Derringer, dean of their great pitching staff, to the Cubs tonight in a straight cash deal. General Manager Warren C. Giles announced the transaction, which left Cincinnati with only eight pitchers on its roster.

Prepare for disappointments, heartaches and backaches, as well as blistered hands, in your first season of victory gardening, Thomas Little, superintendent for Colonel Robert H. Montgomery of Cos Cob, Conn., said yesterday at the second of a weekly series of lectures on "Planning Victory Gardens.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- The Adam, Meldrum Anderson State bank today filed in State Supreme Court a plan for retirement of certificates of withheld deposits under which 25 per cent of the amount of the certificates will be paid in cash and 45 per cent in merchandise of the A.M. A. department store at retail prices.

Switzerland stands today an island in a Nazi ocean. Hitler could occupy the country at any time if he cared to pay the price in soldiers and ammunition. He can freeze its inhabitants by denying them coal. He can reduce them to penury by shutting off their exports and imports. By all material tests they are in his power.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 27 -- The Churchill-Roosevelt meeting caused satisfaction to Brazilians because it united the French factions. Today's newspaper editorials viewed the new harmony as forecasting the resurrection of France.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27 (AP) -- Carlos Davila, former President of Chile and Ambassador to the United States from 1927 to 1931, told the University of Rochester's Latin-American Conference today that his country delayed breaking with the Axis only because "it thought by so doing it served the democratic cause better."
MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The capture of seventeen more district centers, railway stations and other inhabited localities was announced by the Soviet High Command early today.

John Grosvenor Thorndike, 22 years old, the son of Mrs. Grosvenor Farwell of 1075 Park Avenue and the late John Richard Thorndike of Boston, shot and killed himself early yesterday morning in his mother's apartment. Young Thorndike, who became the father of a daughter in December, had been under a psychiatrist's care for a nervous condition, according to members of the family.
MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The mid-day communique of the Soviet Information Bureau:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13 to 10 today to recommend to the Senate the confirmation of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia, but the Roosevelt Administration's margin of victory was so small that opponents expressed renewed hope that they could defeat Mr. Flynn on the Senate floor.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A communique:
Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Tuttle gave a dinner at the Grosvenor last night in advance of the opening concert of the Chamber Music Club, Washington Square Chapter, held in the Crystal Room of the hotel.

Dr. Ernst Sedgwick (Putzi) Hanfstaengl has been giving our government information on Hitlerism for several months. This was revealed by Washington to aid in the psychological deflation of Adolf Hitler on the eve of the Jan. 30 Berlin celebration of the tenth anniversary of his seizure of power.

The Philadelphia Museum of Art has announced plans for the assembling at the museum of original documents and letters by artists, the body of material brought together to be known as the Archives of American Art.

Public libraries in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens have asked for larger budget oppropriations for 1943-1944 than they received in 1942-1943, according to requests submitted yesterday to Acting Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Bankhead of Alabama carried his plan for an Appropriations Committee investigation of the size of the United States Army one step further today when he organized a subcommittee which, he said, would conduct hearings and "draw the purse strings" if it decided the Army was getting too large.

The election of three residentiary canons of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the first time the cathedral has had three, as provided by its constitution, and its first canon since 1929, was announced yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.

Manhattan rolled up its highest score of the season when it defeated the Wagner five, 67 to 23, on the Jasper court last night. The winners registered their ninth triumph in ten starts. Captain Dick Murphy was the high scorer with 16 points.

Mrs. Dennis Mullane, Staten Island mother of a 17-year-old marine, who has been trying to open a deluge of mail since Monday, got some relief yesterday when the National Broadcasting Company assigned a staff of fifteen clerks to open the 130,000 letters she had received up to last night because she failed to answer a question on a quiz program Saturday night.

Undaunted by yesterday's snowfall, Branch Rickey will play the role of intrepid explorer today when he heads a delegation of baseball scribes as well as his own imposing office staff on an expedition up the Hudson to inspect the Dodgers' 1943 training base at Bear Mountain and West Point.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 27 -- Mgr. Martin J. O'Connor of Scranton, was consecrated as titular Bishop of Thespiae and Auxiliary Bishop of the Scranton Diocese today in the presence of several thousand people who filled St. Peter's Cathedral to overflowing.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in England, Jan. 27 -- In an attack on Germany proper for the first time by the United States Army Air Forces, big Flying Fortresses and Liberator bombers in considerable strength subjected the important Nazi naval bases of Wilhelmshaven and Emden to heavy poundings in daylight today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The grand strategy discussed by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill at Casablanca faced no greater problem than the one existing in the fact that at this time, more than a year after the active entry of the United States into the war, not one convoy-escort vessel of the approved transocean type has been put into service.

Barbers and beauty shop operators who protested yesterday to the linen suppliers that they could not get along without towels were told that restaurants might have to do without napkins and table-cloths when the present supply wears out.

The parking problem, subject of a study just made public by the Regional Plan Association, is one which existed before the OPA inspectors began to haunt our streets and which will exist after the inspectors have turned their attention to other things. The present enforced lull in unnecessary traffic is a good time to study it, though the association could not have foreseen this event when it began work.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- German troops wiped out all resistance in the Old Harbor area of Marseille after killing at least 300 French men and women who revolted against a Nazi order to evacuate the section, European reports said today.
More than 150 day employes of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, stopped work for two hours yesterday afternoon as the result of a labor dispute.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Notice was received today by Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy Director of Civilian Protection for Westchester County, that the War Production Board had capitulated and granted a priority to Larchmont for the purchase of ninety-seven feet of copper wire needed for installation of two air raid sirens in the village.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- More confidence that the Legislature would enact a reapportionment bill was manifest today after conferences among party and legislative leaders. Word was circulated that, after the State budget was disposed of, Governor Dewey would send in a special message urging action on the measure, and that the Republican majorities in both houses would accept his demands on the subject.

Rationing of tobacco products, particularly cigarettes and smoking tobacco, were cited as a possibility before the end of the year at the regional meeting yesterday of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors at the Hotel Commodore. Harley Jefferson, head of the tobacco section of the WPB, and Joseph Kolodny, executive secretary of the association, both referred to the possibility.

After a two-week recess, basketball will make a unique return to Madison Square Garden tonight, when a major triple-header, involving five college teams and one service quintet, will be played there for the first time in the history of the cage sport.

The wartime necessities of airplane production have caused engineers, manufacturers, operators, meteorologists, metallurgists, physiologists and other professions involved in making bigger and faster planes to go farther and do a larger job. This was pointed out yesterday at the eleventh annual meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The long-proposed establishment of a bipartisan committee of Congress to represent the legislative branch in a program of cooperation with the executive branch in solving non-military problems of the war appeared today to have been blocked after a brief hearing before a special Senate Military Affairs subcommittee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- Lend-lease food shipments to Russia in December -- for the first time -- were larger than the combined shipments to the United Kingdom and other British destinations, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard disclosed today at the closing sessions of the three-day war council of the National American Wholesale Grocers Association.

The newest of the college baseball leagues, the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference, which began play for the Edward G. Barrow Trophy last Spring, is going to carry on in 1943 with a full schedule.

"Truck Busters," a Warner Brothers action drama, will open this morning at the Palace. Richard Travis, Virginia Christine, Ruth Ford and Richard Fraser head the cast. The second-run feature, "The Black Swan," is the associate attraction on the double bill program.

Frederick F. Greenman announced yesterday that he had resigned as Republican leader of the Seventh Manhattan Assembly District to accept a commission as major in the Judge Advocate General's department of the Army and would leave Feb. 2 on his first assignment at Ann Arbor, Mich. Mr. Greenman was an officer of artillery in the first World War.

The steadily mounting death rate this Winter from automobile accidents, particularly during wartime dimouts from sunset to midnight, led yesterday to Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran sending a communication to all the other magistrates of the city urging them to be "rough" in their sentences on all speeders and red-light traffic violators.

The War Labor Board in Washington intervened yesterday in the dress stoppage in this city, as another 10,000 men and women joined the no-work movement designed to force a wage increase for the entire industry, and asked the workers to return to their jobs immediately as a condition of the board's assumption of jurisdiction in the dispute.

Alice Anderson, soprano, making her New York debut last night, gave the first of two evenings of vocal chamber music at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. She had the assistance of six instrumentalists, and three of her selections were solo cantatas.

Fuel oil stocks declined further last week, but gasoline supplies showed another sharp gain, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the week gasoline stocks were 87,102,000 barrels, an increase of 2,147,000 over the 84,955,000 a week earlier. A year ago the supplies amounted to 99,345,000 barrels.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Fire that swept the three upper stories of a six-story apartment house at 552 Riverside Drive early yesterday caused the death of one man and injuries to seven others, six of them firemen.
Edward J. Flynn made it known yesterday that he had resigned as chairman of the Executive Committee of the Bronx County Democratic Committee, a post he had held for twenty-two years.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- News of the conference of Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Franklin D. Roosevelt at Casablanca and its results had little effect today on the stock markets here, but the tone of the markets was cheerful. Gilt-edge issues were steady at overnight levels and home rails were firm with further gains in a few stocks.

A new system of air raid alarms, described as imperfect but better than the method now in use, was promulgated yesterday by the War Department, the Eastern Defense Command and the Office of Civilian Defense. It goes into effect at 12:01 A.M. Feb. 17.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
Boon to meat-hungry households is a buillon so highly concentrated that six ounces will make forty-eight cups.

The Central Needle Trades High School held yesterday afternoon its first January graduation exercises in the school's auditorium, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. In former years the exercises had been held in June, but a fifteen-year custom was droopped because of need of the specially trained students.

"Tinker's Dam," a fantasy by Andrew Hawke, will be presented tonight and through Sunday, Feb. 14, by the Blackfriars' Guild at the Blackfriars' Theatre, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street. The play has been directed by Dennis Gurney. The cast includes Lawrence Fletcher, Dorothy Steele, Gerald Buckley, Peggy Wynne, Eileen Heckert, John Huntington, H.E. Currier, Robert Hayward, James Ganon, Dort Clark, Alix Taran and Patsy O'Shea.

The delicate pastel quality of Spring is captured in the newest lipstick color of the season -- a shade described as "wonderful" rose. It is a deep carnation pink with just a bit of blue in its make-up and provides the perfect sort of glow to wear under a new hat or above a crisp jabot.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

News that the supply of scrap steel is now .ample in all steel centers and, that surpluses exist in some places does not indicate that there will be any let-down in efi forts,to collect new scrap. On the contrary, it is necessary for constant recoveries to be made to :keep the supply situation healthy, and a few months of lagging efforts might make redoubled efforts imperative in the Fall months.

An exchange of letters between Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, chief of the United States Wildlife Service, and Captain Roy D. Craft, managing editor of The Kodiak Bear, Fort Greely, Alaska, brings to the front their views on conservation of our Alaskan game as well as the question of hunting licenses for service men there.

The anti-trust division of the Department of Justice filed yesterday in Federal court 127 questions The Associated Press is asked to answer in the government's monopoly suit against the non-profit news gathering organization.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Don Hutson, Green Bay's nimble-fingered end, who holds more records than any other football player, gained another today when he was named the National Football League's most valuable player for the second consecutive year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, and William M. Jeffers, rubber director, clashed tonight over the question whether the OWI was in order when it rebuked Mr. Jeffers for denouncing "Army and Navy loafers" in the government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Prompt Congressional action on a bill to increase the public debt limit from the present $125,000,000,000 to $210,000,000,000 was scheduled today so the road might be cleared for consideration of pay-as-you-go income tax collections.

Real dangers from inflation will not menace this country until the return of peace, according to the eighteenth annual report of the Massachusetts Investors Trust, largest institution of its kind in the country. At that time, said the trustees, "it may reasonably be presumed that consumers will be eager to increase their purchases of the many varieties of goods which they have been without during these war years."
LONDON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- American war planes on a reconnaissance mission flew over Wake Island Monday and probably destroyed two of eight Zeros that arose to attack them, the Navy Department announced today. None of our planes was lost.

In your editorial "Shadow in the North" you say: "She [Sweden] has been forced to increase her shipments of iron ore to Germany, on which the German armament industry is largely dependent because of its special qualities."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 459 more American soldiers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands and Formosa. The list includes 327 officers and 129 enlisted men of the Army, and three officers of the Army Nurse Corps.

The Big Ten will have strong representation in the thirty-sixth annual Millrose A.A. games, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 6. Five colleges in the group have accepted bids to take part in the competition, Fred Schwartz, chairman of the games committee, announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 27 -- Beyond admitting that the revelation of the meeting place confounded German assumptions, Berlin comment on the Casablanca conference of American and British leaders is preponderantly caustic.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied Commander in Chief in this theatre, relaxed the censorship of political news from North Africa today.

Couples who participate in war marriages should not assume the role of parenthood in "these uncertain and anxious times," the Very Rev. George A. Robertshaw, dean of the Cathedral of the incarnation, Garden City, declared yesterday.

The Women's Division of the Greater New York Federation of Churches will hold a conference on "Minority Groups: The Unfinished Business of Democracy" today at 10 A.M. in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Apartment rentals reported in Manhattan yesterday included numerous new contracts for suites in buildings on the East Side.
The following summary of of the new air raid warning signal system and blackout procedure that will go into effect Feb. 17, 1943, in the Eastern Military Area, was issued yesterday:

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 27 -- The Casablanca meeting has had a stunning effect on the Italian public. For the second time in a week Italians have had evidence that the Propaganda Ministry knows nothing or, knowing, will not tell. Both demonstrations came from North Africa.

One set of unhappy individuals in this war against the Axis gets nothing but brickbats from all sides. They are the censors. The war correspondents consider them as their sworn enemies, and the tales of their supposed ineptitude and stupidity are part of the legendary history of the war.

It has been a particularly good week for the bourgeoisie, or, as people call it in this country, the middle classes. Vice President Wallace said the other day that we must make it our goal to build "an America where all can become members of the middle class."

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 27 (AP) -- The Illinois-Iowa Power Company filed suit in United States District Court here today against its former parent, North American Light and Power Company, a Delaware corporation, asking a return of more than $20,000,000 and an accounting of certain transactions.

ALGIERS, Jan. 27 (AP) -- The announcement that Generals-Giraud and de Gaulle have decided to establish "diplomatic relations" and will hold further negotiations was one of the most favorable developments in North Africa today in the wake of the Roosevelt-Churchill conference.

Divorcing the meeting at Casablanca from the drama that invested it, its paramount importance lies in the fact that it was a war council -- the first held on the battlefield itself, the first, indeed, which could be held on ground liberated from the control of the enemy and within sight of the main objective of the conflict.

Warm Springs may not be much more than a whistle stop on the A.B. C. Railroad, but it is a junction point for those who suffer from infantile paralysis and for those who assist with cash the appeal for funds now being made.
The Savoy Opera Guild, which has occupied the tiny Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village since April 15, 1941, will end its tenancy with the final four performances of "The Gondoliers."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Jan. 28 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur announced today that Allied casualties in the victorious Papuan land campaign in New Guinea, including numerous cases from natural illness, were less than half those of Japanese.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 27 -- Safety on the job and at home was lifted from the realm of impersonal statistics into the field of individual concern for some 120,000 war plan workers in the Minneapolis area today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 27 -- The story of how a German submarine emerged to shell a seventy-ton British West Indies sailboat without giving the crew time to crowd into lifeboats was told today by twenty-two survivors who arrived at La Guaira.
Following is press comment on the Casablanca conference as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker went on record today as favoring establishment of a separate House committee on civilian and commercial aviation.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuter) -- Immediate fusion of British diplomatic and consular services into a single Foreign Service was announced in a White Paper issued today. Britain in this follows the lead given by the United States.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 27 (UP) -- Bombers of the Tenth United States Army Air Force struck anew yesterday at Rangoon and Mandalay in Burma, it was announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Russian troops have captured 3,350 more German survivors of the 220,000-man Nazi army trapped at Stalingrad, leaving about 5,000 doomed troops on the Volga, while in the continuing offensive to the west another Red Army salient has been driven to a point sixty miles from Rostov and eighty miles from Kursk, two big Nazi bases, Moscow said tonight in a regular communique recorded here by the Soviet radio monitor.

LONDON, Jan. 27 (UP) -- The German High Command said today that the Russian Winter offensive had spread "to new areas" and acknowledged that Nazi forces were attempting to build a new defense line west of Voronezh, which was liberated completely by Soviet forces Monday.

Events today: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Bruno Walter conducting, Rudolf Serkin, pianist, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Tales of Hoffmann," the Shoestring Opera Company, Hunter College Auditorium, 8:30; Frances Pelton-Jones, harpsichord, and Christopher Hayes, tenor, Hotel Plaza, 3:30; Anne Judson, contralto, Hotel Ansonia, 8:30.

The air raid signal system is cleared up, as it should have been long ago, by regulations announced today by the Eastern Defense Command and First Army. The new system, effective for the sixteen Eastern seaboard States and the District of Columbia, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull denounced at his press conference today critics who had abused the Government and officials for the policy being followed in French North Africa when the conference of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill was in progress.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Most women members of Congress today seconded the "unconditional surrender" fighting aim of the war conference at Casablanca.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 27 (AP) -- A United States Headquarters communique:
LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Two women sobbed in the crowded church, but only two, at the joint funeral today of thirty-nine children and five teachers killed in Lewisham school by Nazi bombing last week.

IT was natural for Al Baggett to choose the air force when he went into the Army. His basketball players at West Texas State were higher off the ground than any others and the stratosphere came more easily to Captain Al. So he turned his coaching portfolio over to Gus Miller, thus changing entirely the displacement quotient at West Texas State.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Army and Princeton played two extra five-minute periods to reach a decision today in a fast basketball game staged in the big field house. The Tiger five finally won by 47 to 41. It was Army's third defeat in a row and the fourth in five starts.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The German Gestapo, presumably seeking to solidify the eastern reaches of Nazi-occupied Europe against possible future extensions of the powerful Red Army offensives, has begun a wholesale manhunt to round up Polish manpower, which already during the last few days is known to have affected 75,000 civilians, it was announced this evening by Premier Wladislaw Sikorski of Poland in his first press conference here since his return from the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 27 -- The announcement of the Casablanca conference was broadcast last night by all local stations. By some error the broadcast for Argentina began in Portuguese but this was corrected after a few minutes and the rest followed in Spanish.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The turning point in General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's Africa campaign was his tank victory Nov. 2 at Tel el-Aqqaqir, behind the Alamein line in Egypt, the British War Office said today in an illustrated booklet.
There are two points in Wendell Willkie's criticism of the results of the President's trip to Africa which raise some interesting questions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (U.P.) -- The $5,000-a-year Department of Agriculture job of Gardner Jackson, who has been accused of alleged "un-American activities" has been "abolished" for reasons of economy, department officials revealed tonight.

MOSCOW, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, and Lacy Baggallay, British Charge d'Affaires, called at the Kremlin today and handed Premier Joseph Stalin a joint note from President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill.

Credit men must insist upon full disclosure by business firms of all pending tax liabilities in their financial statements because of the new and complex relief provisions governing excess profits contained in the Revenue Act of 1942, George D. Fish of George D. Fish Co., tax consultants, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Downtown Textile Credit Group in the Ark-wright Club.

The consultations of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill in Casablanca were hailed yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, as "one of the greatest happenings in the history of the modern world" and the forerunner of a unified world for prosperity and peace.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 27 -- Approval of Chile's break with the Axis powers was expressed tonight by one of the largest mass demonstrations ever held here. Crowds estimated at 100,000 marched to the Presidential Palace, to be addressed by President Juan Antonio Rios and Cabinet members.

The stock market's first reaction yesterday to the announced results of the war conference in North Africa was one of disappointment, but, after word had filtered through from Washington that there would be subsequent chapters of the historic meeting, prices rebounded and most losses were reduced substantially or eliminated.

The publishing firm of W.W. Norton is currently attempting to regiment its authors. Disregarding the sacred right of every author to spell the way he pleases, to devise his own punctuation, to number his pages in any corner he decides upon, to spend as long as he likes correcting proofs, the firm has prepared a manual on style and is appealing to its authors to follow it for the common good.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The distinguished conferees at Casablanca had four major objectives, and the best information that could be obtained in Washington today is that they accomplished two, made progress on another and none to speak of on the fourth. The President, the Prime Minister of Great Britain and their staffs are confidently believed to have:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Within thirty days the country's railroads, which now are carrying 770,000 barrels of petroleum daily to the Eastern seaboard region, will increase the movement to 900,000 barrels, and a goal of l,000,000 barrels a day is not "too far fetched," John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, told a Senate committee today.
Mrs. Fleming Newbold of Washington is at the Pierre.

The three-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 166-8 Jewett Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Personal Credit Plan, Inc., to Stanbert, Inc., for investment. The sale was subject to a $37,000 mortgage held by the Provident Institution for Savings.

Foreign manufacturing enterprises can never keep pace with those in this country and American exporters will always have new post-war products to promote in other countries, L.C. Booz, vice president and general manager of the United States Rubber Export Company, Ltd., declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Export Advertising Association at the Hotel Belmont-Plaza.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 27 -- Profiteering, political apathy -- worse than any factional strife -- distrust of the Americans and lack of faith in an ultimate United Nations victory are rife in French Morocco, where the political and economic situation parallels that of Algeria, but is intensified by the dictatorial character of Governor General Charles Nogues's regime.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (AP) -- Errol Flynn, unsmiling and serious, made denial in Superior Court today that he was guilty of any misconduct with Peggy La Rue Satterlee, who accuses him of twice raping her.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 27 -- The report from London, as yet unconfirmed, that Vice Admiral Sir Percy Noble, head of the British Admiralty delegation in Washington, is to head a new United Nations anti-submarine organization emphasizes again the seriousness of the war of attrition at sea.

After the war night flying and more modern equipment will make possible passenger flights to Buenos Aires in forty-eight hours, now requiring three and a half days, and air trips to Lima in one day, half the time now required, Harold J. Roig, president of Pan American-Grace Airways, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- One of the hottest controversies in years found Senate supporters and opponents of President Roosevelt's nomination of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia almost deadlocked tonight on the basis of membership polls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The White House disclosed tonight that President Roosevelt had paid his respects to President Edwin J. Barclay of Liberia and reviewed a large detachment of American Negro troops there while en route home from his war council meeting with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at Casablanca.

With rumors of an early peace still heard, the cotton futures market continued yesterday its reactionary movement. Under a very thin volume active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange underwent moderate price variations and closed with net losses of six to ten points as commission-house liquidation outweighed limited trade buying.

OTTAWA, Jan. 28 -- By extending the present system of pay-asyou-earn, which has been operating since last September, Canada will adopt in some measure the Ruml plan of personal income tax payment, it was announced today when the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone, read the government's declaration of policy at the opening of the new session of Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Further gains in prices for agricultural commodities, principally grains and livestock, dominated the commodity markets during the week ended on Jan. 23. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 items in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent to 101.7 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- As the Senate Military Affairs Committee and the Appropriations Committee's subcommittee extended their manpower inquiries today, the possibility of still another manpower investigation loomed up as Senator Pepper announced that he would push his resolution calling for such a study by the Education and Labor Committee.

An appeal was made yesterday afternoon to Mayor La Guardia to intervene in a strike of fourteen truck drivers of the Suburban Fuel Oil Service, Inc., of Mount Vernon, which services many homes and apartment houses in the upper Bronx and lower Westchester County.
Any method of accounting which reflects correctly income and expenditures may be used in making out Federal income tax returns.

Bargain night at Madison Square Garden, where 15,494 persons were privileged to witness three basketball games last night, turned out nicely for all the local teams involved. St. John's, St. Francis and Long Island University, in the order named, were the victors as the court sport returned to the Eighth Avenue area following a two-week lay-off.

Federal income tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while holdings of United States Government securities decreased $88,456,000 during the week to the lowest figure of the year.

Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt De Cicco, Cathleen Vanderbilt Arostegui and Countess Gladys Vanderbilt Szechenyi must pay the $800,000 taxes levied against a $6,000,000 trust of which they were named principal beneficiaries under the will of Mrs. Alice G. Vanderbilt, Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- British bombers dropped hundreds of tons of high explosives and many thousands of incendiaries on the important German industrial city of Duesseldorf last night, the Air Ministry announced today. It was the third big raid against the Nazis within twenty-four hours, the previous ones being the daylight attack yesterday by United States planes on Wilhelmshaven and Emden and the British raid on the Diesel engine plant at Copenhagen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey reported today from the South Pacific that at no time had merchant seamen refused to unload ships at Guadalcanal Island, as charged in a report that a House committee has undertaken to investigate.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Santo Micelli, 28 years old, and Henry Schwartz, 24, were sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions after he had described them as members of one of the most dangerous gangs of hijackers in America.

Three years may not be a long time for most girls, but for 15-year-old Marianne Benjamin it has meant the difference between a life of soul-crushing fear and one of happy, carefree freedom. For in that time she has developed from a shy, furtive refugee into a smiling, joyful schoolgirl.

The winners of the George Ruppert fishing contest have been announced and the "most outstanding angling achievement of 1942," carrying with it a $1,000 prize, is credited to Mrs. Annie Zitzman of Geauga Lake, Ohio.

The 30,000 dressmakers, members of the Dress Makers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers, who stopped work for two days to enforce a demand for wage increases, returned to their jobs yesterday in compliance with the request of the War Labor Board, telegraphed the day before, that they do so immediately as a condition of the board's acceptance of jurisdiction in the dispute.

Japan intends to respect her neutrality pact with Russia and assumes the Soviet Government will reciprocate, Foreign Minister Masayuki Tani declared yesterday, according to versions of his speech to Parliament broadcast by Axis radios.

The Treasury released yesterday detailed figures on the nation-wide December Victory Fund Drive which brought in $12,937,000,000, of which $7,865,000,000, or 60.8 per cent, was raised from sources other than commerical banks. Perhaps the most important disclosure yesterday was that 17 per cent of the total was furnished by business and industrial concerns.

Activities of the orchestra of the New Friends of Music will not be suspended because of war conditions, as at first believed necessary. The group will resume its concerts with a tour of the East and Middle West, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 28 -The will of Grenville Winthrop of Lenox, who died in New York City on the 19th, was filed in probate court today by Judge Charles L. Hibbard and disposes of an estate of $4,500,000.

The National Association of Tobacco Distributors went on record yesterday as favoring the percentage mark-up method of price control by the OPA instead of a price ceiling. The size of the mark-up, it was indicated at the closing session of the regional meeting of the association at the Hotel Commodore, will be developed in negotiations with the proper government agencies.

The snow fell just as hard yesterday down in the lower East Side as elsewhere in the city, but it had a hard time holding its own at 36 Attorney Street. Throughout the day friends, neighbors, school teachers and officials wore a track to the home of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schlier to pay tribute to the Schliers' 18-year-old daughter, Gertrude.

The stock market closed yesterday on a rallying note, a pattern which has been followed generally this month, after a session given over previously to irregular movements. Strong buying entered the rail, oil and specialty sections in the final hour when business was the heaviest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- At least $56,000,000,000 worth of goods and services a year are necessary to keep the civilian economy of this country operating efficiently, according to estimates compiled today by the War Production Board's office of civilian supply for the information of James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

What will life be like after the war when it is reorganized globally? Sometimes the global visions seem to anticipate a world in which everybody will spend all of his time flying around the globe. Needless to say, it will be nothing of the kind.

How a radio wave, directing a slight change in gun elevation, resulted in "damage beyond repair" to the 35,000-ton French battleship Jean Bart during the North African invasion, by a salvo from an American battleship at a range of twenty-six miles, was revealed yesterday at the annual Winter conference of the Institute of Radio Engineers, by Rear Admiral Stanford C. Hooper, general consultant to the Navy for radio, radar (radio location) and underwater sound equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -Assistant Secretary Robert A. Lovett of the War Department today branded as "vicious, reckless and completely untrue," a rumor that "50 per cent of personnel in Army planes en route to our fronts are killed in transit."

A postwar controlled economy on raw materials in which synthetic and natural rubber would find wide industrial applications was predicted yesterday by A.A. Garthwaite, president of the Lee Rubber and Tire Company at the company's annual meeting held here.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) -Errol Flynn's defense rested its case today with the stipulation by Jerry Giesler, counsel, that he may ask that the jury visit the yacht where the prosecution says that the film actor attacked one of his two girl accusers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate elected Wall Doxey as Sergeant-at-Arms, received favorable committee report on nomination of Edward J. Flynn, approved a resolution authorizing $15,000 for Puerto Rican investigation and adjourned at 12:38 P.M. until noon Monday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 -- The news of the Casablanca parleys became publicly known through last night's British broadcast of the joint communique, which was repeated several times and printed prominently in the press today. As is the practice here, the press has not rushed to comment on the conference but there is no doubt that a deep impression was made on the public.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 28 -Officially China shares in the general enthusiasm over the Casablanca conference. When questioned concerning China's reactions today, Dr. T.V. Soong, Minister of Foreign Affairs, made the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Navy announced today 138 casualties, including six dead, four wounded and 128 missing. This brings to 22,091 the total of Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard casualties reported to next-of-kin since Dec. 7, 1941.

Random House announced yesterday that the response to the recently published "The Wisdom of China and India," edited by Lin Yutang, has prompted the firm to advance its plans for two similar volumes designed along the same lines.

The fashionable Cavendish Club at 14 East Sixty-second Street and a midtown Hungarian singing society were disclosed yesterday as the latest objectives in a police drive to clean up suspected gambling places in the midtown area.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 29 (AP) -The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and reported here by the Soviet radio monitor:

Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota declared yesterday that the first concern of the government in the post-war period should be to encourage free enterprize through which industry by its inventiveness, management, mass production and distribution could make its greatest contribution to the standard of living of the people of America and the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Reports that lend-lease authorities and representatives of the War Production Board are working out specifications for construction of textiles to be shipped to tropical and to cold climates were current here today.

Local Draft Board 17, at 412 Sixth Avenue, last night continued in classification 1A the last three of twenty-eight foreign-born followers of Frank Buchman, organizer of "Moral Rearmament," who claimed deferment from military service because of occupation in evangelism, which they considered a field necessary to the national defense.

By preaching the doctrine of regular saving, thrift institutions can give powerful aid in maintaining the American system of free enterprise in the postwar era, Eugene E. Agger, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, told stockholders of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York yesterday at the tenth annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Naval circles said today that they had no confirmation from their own sources of reports yesterday that a big German naval formation had been seen entering Wilhelmshaven yesterday while United States fliers were making a daylight raid there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- The story of the marines who captured and held Guadalcanal was told today by the man who led the heroic leathernecks in the first major United States offensive of the war, Major Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler was reported tonight to have given up on his "intuition" and turned the direction of the war back to his General Staff. Observers here believed Herr Hitler was haunted by memories of the 1918 collapse and would proclaim martial law to prevent possible uprisings on the home front.

ON THE TUNISIAN WAR FRONT, Jan. 28 -- Yesterday I saw exclusively American combat teams of artillery, infantry and tanks working in perfect unison. Before the day was over they had taken from the Germans heights commanding a vital pass to Kairouan and the sea.

The growing ranks of war workers will have to be increased through the employment of additional women, Charles P. Taft, Assistant Director, Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, declared last night at a meeting here of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America.
Mr. and Mrs. Franklin T. Clark have come from Philadelphia to the Hotel La Salle.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Army opened its ranks today to enlistment by American-born Japanese who, under a policy laid down by Secretary Stimson, will be trained for action in special units.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- The Dewey Administration appears ready to grant to Mayor La Guardia's Administration the right to increase the sales tax from 1 per cent to the old rate of 2 per cent so as to give the city some relief from its fiscal worries.

Mrs. Edward M. Weld was elected second vice president of the New York Women's League for Animals yesterday afternoon at the organization's annual meeting, held in the home of Mrs. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street. She succeeds the late Miss Rosa Anne Grosvenor, from whom a bequest of $20,000 to the league was announced.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 -- Two hundred and seventy-five members of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers tonight defied an order of Federal conciliators and Army officials to end their outlaw strike at the Avonmore plant of the National Roll and Foundry Company near Apollo.

MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Mutiny has broken out in the German pockets of death at Stalingrad and officers and men are surrendering by the hundred as Russian assault forces close in for the kill, front dispatches said tonight.

Sixty outstanding physicians of four United Nations -- Norway, Great Britain, Canada and the United States -- held an all-day conference at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, yesterday and pooled their knowledge of "combat fatigue" -- the term that, they agreed, best describes the condition of many merchant seamen after being torpedoed or after a long stretch of service in submarine-infested waters.
LONDON, Jan. 28 -- A new government order will come into force Feb. 22 whereby the number of part-time war workers, both men and women, but particularly women, will be increased.

Bill Sullivan was a second-class seaman on the Lexington when a bomb dropped near his gun crew. "Three of us were wounded and seventeen were killed," Bill reported. "They wrapped me in a blanket and lowered me over the side." No boats, no rafts -- just the sea.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 28 (AP) -The formation of one huge Allied Mediterranean theatre command, bristling with troops pointed toward Greece, Italy and France, appeared in sight today as a result of a Mediterranean war conference held here among American and British military chieftains.

Most vegetables are on the upgrade so far as price is concerned, with the notable exception of broccoli, which dropped about 8 cents since last Friday, and spinach, which is down 2. Among the best purchases, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, are kale and sweet potatoes, carrots and parsnips.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A joint system of drafting men for the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard will go into effect on Monday.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses gave assurance yesterday that constructive plans would be ready to "combat unemployment intelligently" in New York when the nation will face an idle postwar population greater than that at "the depths of the last depression."

Interest throughout the nation in Victory gardening is "astounding," H.W. Hochbaum, chairman of the United States Department of Agriculture Committee on Victory Gardens said yesterday in the opening address at a two-day conference of national leaders on home food production, held in the rooms of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue.

John S. McCook was elected and installed last night as president of the New York Young Republican Club at its annual meeting, in the Harvard Club, 27 V4est Forty-fourth Street. His father, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, was one of the founders and served as the club's first president when it was organized thirty-one years ago.

Natural tones of beige and gray are sponsored on the basic ensemble color card for Spring, as they require little dye, it was announced yesterday by the color coordination committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 28 -The life story of Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, which, since the famous aviator's rescue at sea, has been the most sought after property in years, will be produced as a film by Winfield R. Sheehan, the former Fox production chief.

A new issue of $25,000,000 of New York City revenue bills was sold yesterday by allotment by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick on an 0.55 per cent basis. All the bills are dated Jan. 29 with $10,000,000 maturing on April 22 and $15,000,000 on April 29.

Only two days after the death of John Burns, Ben Tillett vanishes from the scene. He was 82. He had lasted long in no easy life. At 8 he was graduated from school and began working in a brickyard. Before he was 12 he ran away from two stepmothers. He was ship boy on a fishing smack, seaman in the Royal Navy and the merchant service.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Jan. 28 -Responding to the government's appeal for increased production of butter, eggs and other dairy products, Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell, heiress to the fortune of the late James B. Duke, tobacco manufacturer, is converting Duke Farms, her 2,300-acre estate in Hillsborough Township, near here, into a general livestock farm, it was announced today by George A. Lefevre, new manager of the farm.

Purchases now of goods for delivery in the post-war period would be a vital factor in siphoning off some of the $18,000,000,000 in excess purchasing power which will be available this year, Dr. Rolf Nugent, credit adviser to the price administrator, declared yesterday, at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

Reversing the trend of the three preceding weeks, the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City sharply increased i their total earning assets in the week ended on Wednesday, adding substantially to their loans and to their investments, according to figures on banks released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Seven hundred and fifty maintenance men employed in shops of the Independent division of the city's unified transit system quit work for two hours yesterday, following the example of their 2,500 co-workers on the I.R.T. division, who staged work stoppages on Wednesday in protest against allegedly inadequate and discriminatory wage adjustments recently made by the Board of Transportation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Fifty-three seamen were missing tonight as a result of the sinking of four United States merchant ships in a convoy off the northern coast of South America early is month, survivors reported on arrival here.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -Robert Folkes, 20-year-old Negro dining-car cook, has made a new and coherent confession that he slashed the throat of a naval officer's bride when she attempted to eject him from a lower 13 berth of a Pullman car, police announced today.

In line with the advertising trend in most industries, leading distillers will devote the major portions of their 1943 campaign to the war effort. Carstairs Brothers Distilling Company, Inc., and Fleischman Distilling Corporation yesterday announced plans which tie in very closely with the war program.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 28 -- A successful attack by Mitchell bombers of the United States Twelfth Air Force on two Italian destroyers in the Mediterranean featured yesterday's air activity in the Tunisian theatre of war. This activity was on a large scale after two days of bad flying weather.

New York City, which, according to the trade, uses 10 per cent of the nation's total linen laundering services, faces more than just a possible shortage of restaurant, beauty parlor and barber shop supplies, it developed yesterday.

A snowstorm that threatened to be the worst since February, 1934, when two heavy storms almost completely paralyzed travel on the Eastern seaboard, struck the city and much of the North Atlantic Coast area yesterday.

"The Patriots," a new play by Sergeant Sidney Kingsley, U.S.A., will open tonight at the National under the auspices of the Playwrights Company and Rowland Stebbins. The play deals with the ten years in Thomas Jefferson's life before he became President.

Asking no commendation, and without fanfare of any kind, hundreds, if not thousands, of women who are classified as "enemy aliens" are giving their time and services to the city's defense activities, it was found yesterday.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- The President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Great Britain were just a couple of symbols -- "A-1" and "B-1" -- for the ten days they conferred here. A-1, the President, lived at a villa called "No. 2" and B-1 stayed at a place called "No. 3."

Leo Durocher, manager of the Dodgers, edged a trifle closer to Army life yesterday, although for the present he seems lodged in a job for which perhaps he might be more eminently fitted than anything else he might try.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- American troops were reported to have narrowed General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's escape corridor to thirty-three miles and a combined Giraud and de Gaulle French column threatened the southern end of his protective Mareth Line today, as indications grew that the Allies were beginning a major offensive in Tunisia.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Unfortunate Yugoslavia, after experiencing a shattering military defeat and partitioning among the Germans, Italians, Hungarians and Bulgarians, followed by savage slaughter and waves of brutality, is now being ravaged by a widespread bitter civil war.

The most imposing record in modern boxing history will be in jeopardy at Madison Square Garden tonight when Willie Pep, featherweight champion of the world, tackles Allie Stolz, Newark lightweight, in an over-the-weight clash of ten rounds.

We salute the three Democratic members of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations who were independent enough to vote against the President's nomination of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia and we trust that they will find other equally independent Democrats ready to stand beside them when the nomination reaches the floor next week.

Of General William Francis Bartlett of Massachusetts, mentioned in an editorial on Jan. 20 as "always getting hit," his comrade-in-arms, the late General Simon G. Griffin, wrote: "General Bartlett was one of those unfortunates who could never go into action without being wounded."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 28 (AP) -- A story of how Barney Ross, United States Marines hero and former boxing champion, knocked out a native champion in Samoa and was amazed when a native chief offered him his daughter in marriage as a reward was told here today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 28 -On the eve of the tenth anniversary of his appointment by President von Hindenburg as Chancellor of the Reich, Adolf Hitler today decreed the mobilization of the entire civilian population of Germany for the nation's defense.
UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The noon communique:
