WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Ways and Means Committee, responding to the impact of public demand for pay-as-you-go income taxation, voted today to begin hearings Tuesday to work out a system at the earliest possible date.
An unseeded player from Jackson Heights won the Class C championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night.

In establishing its proposed method for the regional pricing of lumber at retail, the Office of Price Administration should take into consideration the declining volume of business, the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association recommended yesterday in a resolution passed at the closing session of its annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

News from the South Seas continues to be good. The Japanese stronghold of Rabaul is under constant and damaging bombardment. The Papuan peninsula of New Guinea has been cleared of the last Japanese remnants. And on Guadalcanal enemy troops have been retiring for a week before a strong American attack.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 29 -- The Red Army was developing its threat to Kursk, one of the starting points of Germany's 1942 offensive, today after capturing the railway junction of Kastornoe, eighty-three miles to the east, while in the Caucasus the Russians were menacing Tikhoretsk and Kropotkin after outflanking those two railway junctions below Rostov.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 28 (U.P.) -- Finland, exhausted from two wars only fifteen months apart, is carefully sounding out the possibilities of a protective pact with Sweden, realizing that major reorientation of her policy would almost certainty involve German economic and military reprisals, diplomatic quarters reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Max Bentley made four goals and three assists for 7 points tonight, tying a National Hockey League record, as the Black Hawks crushed the Rangers, 10 -- 1, before 7,500 in the Chicago Stadium.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 -- A crowd of close to 3,000 today saw the longest-priced winner of the season at the Fair Grounds and an unusual daily double situation. Colonial Miss, owned by Stinson Hall, drove to victory in the opening dash for 3-year-old maidens to return a straight price of $318.60 for $2.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Friday, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt conferred with President Getulio Vargas of Brazil at Natal, on the Eastern coast of the South American nation, while he was en route home from Casablanca, it was announced officially today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- As the first wartime labor-control legislation to receive official action since the opening of the new Congress, the long-controverted bill designed to subject unions to the provisions and penalties of the Anti-racketeering Act of 1934, was reported to the House by the Judiciary Committee today.

At the annual meeting of the Travelers Insurance Company held on Wednesday in Hartford, Conn., L. Edmund Zacher, president, said the companies in the Travelers group had increased their holdings of United States Government bonds in a slightly larger amount than the assets of the companies had increased last year.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Jan. 28 (AP) -- To seven officers of the United States Army Air Forces who flew on more than fifty missions were awarded Distinguished Flying Crosses today "for extraordinary achievement."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- American war planes in action last year shot down approximately three planes for each loss of one of themselves, plus another enemy plane probably destroyed, it was shown today in an official compilation made public by the War Department.

Seven hundred and fifty members of the Hotel Association of New York City were told last night at its sixty-third annual dinner at the Hotel Astor that upon them will fall part of the responsibility of seeing to it that the city's millions who take their meals in public eating places fare no better than the millions who depend upon the success of metropolitan housewives in exchanging their ration cards for food.

Group insurance policies in the savings bank life insurance system of this State will be offered now to business and industrial organizations, it was announced yesterday by Edward A. Richards, president of the Savings Banks Life Insurance Fund, who is president of the East New York Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

The Federal Government through the War Production Board yesterday took over 196 automobiles and trucks belonging to the Lasky Motor Car Corporation of 90 Montrose Avenue, Brooklyn, on the ground the company had failed to care for the new vehicles, which previously had been "frozen" from sale on the open market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Administration leaders conceded today that the vote on confirmation of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia would be close, with a number of Democratic Senators joining Republicans in opposing President Roosevelt's choice.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- In one of the few cases of its kind on record, the Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today at the request of a State public utilities agency to investigate contracts for managerial service between a holding company and six of its subsidiaries.
Apartment-house owners have recently been grossly abused and have been the victims not only of literary attack but also of legal restrictions and of terrifically increased operating costs.

Deposits of the 300 largest banks in the United States on Dec. 31 last, aggregated $60,362,277,400, an increase of nearly $12,000,000,000, or 24 per cent, during 1942, according to the annual "roll-call" of commercial banks, released yesterday by American Banker, a daily banking publication.

The tentative report of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, issued for release today, shows for the year 1942 net income of $11,977,500 after all operating charges and estimated Federal income taxes, but before any provision for special reserves.

"Silk, Blood and Sun" is the feature attraction on the all-Mexican film program, which has its premiere today at the World Theatre. The drama of the bullring, which is equipped with English titles, stars Jorge Negrete, Gloria Marin and the matador Pepe Ortiz. Also on the program is "The Boxer," a short comedy starring the Mexican comedian Cantinflas, and a short featuring Carmen Amaya in a repertoire of dances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 23 were up 2 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 1 per cent for the preceding week.

It takes time to execute plans made at a conference that had to cover so much ground, known and unknown, as the meeting at Casablanca. Months elapsed between the decision last Summer to invade North Africa and the landing of the expeditionary forces, and this operation, difficult and daring as it was, involved fewer hazards and incomparably less force than will be required for the invasion of Europe.

Eight of the nine judges of General Sessions issued a statement last evening opposing the plan of the Joint Committee on Probation in New York City to merge all the court probation units of the city. The committee, appointed by Mayor La Guardia in November, 1941, is headed by Samuel Seabury.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 30 -Amid charges that Washington agencies had failed to give proper recognition to West Coast problems relating to food and labor shortages, California took steps today to set up its own food-labor commission to investigate the needs and try to find a solution.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 28 (AP) -The Bears of the International League announced today the resigning of Bill Meyer as manager. The contract was on the club's usual one-year basis.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- After a quiet opening today the stock markets improved and gilt-edge securities showed many issues gaining a turn. Home rails continued their upward trend under the influence of possibilities of dividends which should be due soon.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- Apparently as agile as her cetacean namesake, the British submarine Porpoise has returned safely to base after fourteen months in the Mediterranean, during which she not only sank at least four ships and survived eighty-seven depth charges but also helped to supply Malta and earned a flag never before flown by an undersea craft.

A far-reaching plan to "rationalize" a large segment of American industry is reported to be in the final stages of consideration in the War Production Board. The purpose of the plan is to end duplication of effort and the "wasteful" use of critical machines, manpower and transportation, so that an entire industry can "function as a single manufacturer."
I read with a great deal of interest the dispatch from Washington wherein an official of the I.C.C. urged a 10-cent Jersey fare rate in spite of a plea by the OPA.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- A delegation representing all parties and both Houses of Parliament had a long conference with Ministers today to urge that Britain should take immediately what steps she can for the relief of persecuted Jews in enemy-occupied countries.

Promising the completion by his company this year of "a ship a day, every day, including Saturdays and Sundays," Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, yesterday revealed record-breaking performances in virtually every phase except net profits in 1942, and forecast still greater marks for 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- A concerted drive by organized labor for wage increases above the 15 per cent ceiling of the National War Labor Board's Little Steel formula appeared to be developing here today, carrying with it, according to the views of many, a threat to the success of the economic stabilization program established by President Roosevelt.

Women are still women in or out of uniform, and out of office hours at least, members of the Waves, Waacs, Spars or any other initialed United States auxiliary organization would rather look at a lipstick than a tank model or the latest anti-aircraft gun.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 -- Officials of Sears, Roebuck Co. today denied reports that the company was offering to take over distribution of farm equipment in areas where smart manufacturers now have allotments but no outlets.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 -- The Temple Gold Medal, top honor of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, has been awarded to Raphael Soyer, New York artist, for his painting "Waiting Room," in the academy's 138th annual exhibition.

The status of the Negro and the search for "a scientific approach to race prejudice" were presented as important aspects of "the current challenge to democracy" at a conference held yesterday under the auspices of the women's division of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

The amiable folk of Father Carey's Blackfriars' Guild are discussing the soul in "Tinker's Dam," the second show of their current season and the one which went on last night on Fifty-seventh Street, west of where the snowplows ended.

Net assets of the Massachusetts Investors Second Fund, an open-end investment company of the management type, rose almost $1,000,000 last year, due in part to an increase in shares outstanding, which advanced from 905,872 to 930,227, and in part to market appreciation of the portfolio.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Bank clearings of the major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday increased 6.2 per cent over the corresponding week last year, but were slightly below the preceding week's total, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The War Production Board is preparing to give full cooperation to families who want to escape the limitations of point rationing of canned goods by preserving their own food this Summer when there is expected to be an abundance of fresh fruit and vegetables, it was learned yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 -- Determined to bring to a head organized labor's demand for participation on every level in the war production machinery, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor made public today its proposed program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -The Agriculture Department issued an order today limiting the animal protein content of pet foods to 8 per cent, effective Jan. 29.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 28 -- An informed French political source predicted today General Georges Catroux would be named General Charles de Gaulle's representative in High Commissioner Henri Honore Giraud's government soon as the result of the consultation of the two leaders at Casablanca, Morocco.

HEADQUARTERS HAWAIIN AIR FORCE, Jan. 28 -- The crews of the big United States Army four-motored B-24 bombers saw one Zero crash flaming into the water off Wake Island and saw four others spinning downward smoking.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 28 -- Political persecution goes farther in many respects in Morocco than in Algeria.

Despite heavy sinkings during the past year American marine insurance companies expect to show only a small loss on their overall operations since the 140 companies involved in the war risk "pool" of underwriters began its operations in June, 1939, the American Institute of Marine Underwriters announced yesterday. During that time, they have written approximately $17,061,000,000 of war risk insurance on shipping.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 28 -Carl Hubbell, the Giants' well-known "meal ticket," is ready to be punched for another baseball season undaunted by the perils of training in frosty latitudes.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- In addition to the capture of Kastornoe and the threatened encirclement of Tikhoretsk and Kropotkin, these developments were reported in two communiques broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here tonight:

]VL Raymond Riley, president of the Orange First National Bank of Orange, N. J., has been elected president of the Essex County, N. J., Bankers Association. He succeeds Carlos D. Kelly, ace president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The way was opened today for baseball players -- except the top-paid man on each club -- to put in the annual bid for a salary rise without regard for government pay ceilings.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 28 -- As a means of promoting unity of all Lutheran groups in the United States a resolution was adopted today by the National Lutheran Council, representing eight church groups and two-thirds of the 5,000,000 Lutherans in the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- In a review of the war's progress on all fronts at a press conference today, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson disclosed that American casualties to date in Tunisia had totaled 1,258 dead, wounded and missing.

Your editorial "A Special Exemptions" in THE TIMES this morning inquires whether I believe members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union are to be excused from sacrifices made necessary by the war and whether I further believe that "they are to enjoy just as high a standard of living, and have just as high a command of civilian goods, as if there were no war at all."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the arrest of a man and woman, former employes of the Bureau of Publications of the State Labor Department, which is in the State Building at 80 Centre Street, in a series of frauds in the last two years against thirty-two banks in the city.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, AUSTRALIA, Friday, Jan. 29 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's every-busy air arm has struck the Japanese in ten places, the noon communique reported today.

A new front of "human decency," stripped of ideologies, was urged for post-war America yesterday by former President Herbert Hoover. Mr. Hoover, as chairman of the board of Boys Clubs of America, spoke before 200 officers, directors and friends of Boys Clubs in Brooklyn who met at the Hotel Bossert to honor four youthful victory volunteers of borough clubs.

Ensign Phillip G. Nolan, who sang carols on Christmas Day in an open lifeboat in the Atlantic and observed the advent of the New Year by drinking a carefully rationed cup of water before retiring to his strip of boat planking, returned to New York yesterday.

Many national groups will celebrate President Roosevelt's sixty-first birthday tomorrow, according to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, under whose auspices the annual celebration is conducted.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 28 -- The first American bombing attacks yesterday on German objectives were directed significantly enough at important German submarine bases and were coupled with Royal Air Force bombings of Nazi U-boat lairs of the coast of France.

THE longest sports streak since Joe DiMaggio hit safely in fifty-six straight games will be tested for durability and additional length tonight. This streak is the personal property of another hitter, although he does not swing a bat. If he did, Major Gen. John J. Phelan of the Boxing Commission would have conniption fits on the spot.
LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported in the weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today declined 1,320,000, and it was the fourth consecutive week to show a loss.
The evening of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert, Bruno Walter conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall, was one of magnificent music-making.

Because of the tremendous success the Army and Navy have had with the use of dried blood plasma, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has been called upon to increase the donations of blood given through it from 5,000 pints to 7,500 pints a week, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Earle Boothe, director of the chapter's blood donor service.

ALBANY, Jan. 28 -- Fifteen bills embodying the legislative program recommended by John H. Amen, special prosecutor, who investigated charges of official corruption and racketeering in Kings County, will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, their sponsor, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- In a news dispatch carried by The Associated Press, and prominently displayed in this and other newspapers Wednesday morning, an account was given of a "far-reaching plan" evolved by the War Production Board "to 'rationalize' a vast segment of American industry, to end duplication and other practices described as wasteful."

Skiers need not go far for their outdoor activity the next few days, deep snow at points accessible to the metropolitan enthusiast having made slope and trail running at such popular centers as Bear Mountain Park, the Catskills, Poconos and Berkshires superb.

LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- General Bader, commander of the German forces occupying Yugoslavia, has issued a proclamation virtually making hostages of the people in four Serbian districts in a new warning to the populace against aiding General Draja Mikhailovitch, the Yugoslav government in exile said today.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The stock markets here were quiet today. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged in price and home rails held their recent gains.

Smuggling of 8,000 carats of industrial diamonds from this country to Europe, where the Axis is sorely in need of them, was charged yesterday to Werner F. Trinler, a Swiss citizen, 36 years old, who was described as a skiing instructor at Great Barrington, Mass.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- General Charles de Gaulle departed from his first meeting with President Roosevelt at Casablanca convinced that the Chief Executive of the United States is "a very great and intelligent statesman whose thinking is on a high plane," it was asserted here today by Major Claude de Boislambert, of General de Gaulle's staff, who accompanied the Fighting French leader to the African conferences.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- An Army plane carrying seven officers and two noncommissioned officers has been missing over the Caribbean since Sunday, the War Department announced today.
I want to applaud the intrepid stand taken by Miss Maureen Orcutt in her recent "Women in Sports" column in THE TIMES concerning the continuance of women's golf.

It has been easy to understand why American-born Japanese -- the so-called Nisei -- had to be removed from Pacific coastal areas and also why there has been hesitation about enlisting them in the Army. In this country they have almost always been segregated. In spite of the fact that they are taller and more robust than their parents, they still look Japanese.

Grover B. Hill, assistant secretary of agriculture, told members of the New York Cotton Exchange, at a national cotton conference forum in the Hotel Biltmore last night, that the end of the war would reduce cotton consumption sharply and bring to the industry world-wide problems so critical that "we may need an international agreement among the principal cotton growing nations."

Net profits of the First Boston Corporation last year were $491,256 or $1.09 on each of 450,000 shares in the hands of the public, against 56 cents in 1941, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Last year the corporation bought 50,000 shares of its own capital stock at an average price of $10 a share.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Fred K. Hoehler has arrived in Algeria to serve as Director of Relief in North Africa for former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Director of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, the State Department announced today.

You have evidently not forgotten the Chinese front, judging from the fact that you devoted no less than one-third of the editorial "The Grand Alliance," in the Tuesday issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, to express the tardiness of the lend-lease aid to China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The American Federation of Labor came to the support today of the War Labor Board's wage policy, target for an outburst of labor criticism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- An increase of one-half of 1 per cent in the cost of living between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15 was shown today in a report issued by Secretary Perkins that brought the rise for the first year of United States participation in the war to 9 per cent.

One hundred and fifty members of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., employed at the Jamaica car inspection barns on the IND division of the city subway system, staged an all-day sit-down strike yesterday because a non-union worker who had been transferred to Manhattan at their insistence was sent back to the Jamaica shops by the Board of Transportation.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A bill to enlarge the geographical boundaries within which Australia's militia and conscripted soldiery may serve was introduced in the House of Representatives today by Prime Minister John Curtin and drew immediate criticism as not far reaching enough in its effects.

Eight Staten Island speeders, already hit in their pocketbooks by fines imposed in Magistrates Court, also have been tapped in their gasoline ration books, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday.

The annual report of Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., announced yesterday, shows a net income for 1942 of $1,206,186 after reserves of $250,000 for general contingencies land $1,450,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes, less post-war refund.

Satisfied that the government has given them another "green light" in the form of a ruling which permits ball clubs to negotiate salary terms in pretty much the same manner as in the past, the Yankees yesterday mailed contracts to thirty players around whom Manager Joe McCarthy hopes to build another American League flag winner.

LIFE with the Yankees will not be the same any more. Lefty Gomez has departed and the stadium will be a more quiet and more somber place. Its sparkle has transferred to the Boston Braves, who now can boast a two-man vaudeville show in the Singular Senor and the Singular Stengel.
David Lamb, retired Commissioner of the Salvation Army, is having the time of his life right now because he can "gossip a little."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29 -- A streamlined version of Princeton University's traditional commencement program began today with the holding of class day exercises for 311 members of the class of '43 who will be graduated tomorrow, five months ahead of normal schedule, in the institution's first midwinter commencement.

The only thing that will break Germany is "an overwhelming preponderance" of Allied air power, which may be achieved in 1944, and, "barring an accident," there will be no end of the war this year, in the opinion of Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Total non-agricultural employment increased by 423,000 between mid-November and mid-December, reaching a high record of 38,956,000 and reflecting a gain of 2,868,000 in the first year of war, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A major war-production controversy has been settled through a White House decision allowing top priority ratings for materials needed to carry out this year 43.6 per cent of the original rubber production program outlined in the Baruch report, it was reported authoritatively here tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- A jury in Common Pleas Court awarded to John O'Donnell, head of the Washington Bureau of The New York Daily News, damages of $50,000 today in his libel suit against The Philadelphia Record.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- West Coast Japanese-Americans are leaving the War Relocation Authority's ten centers at the rate of seventy-five a day, most entering domestic employment, a WRA spokesman disclosed today.
Recently there appeared in THE TIMES a story headed "Major leagues to set precedent with intersectional games on two holidays."

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- With the capture of the important railway junction of Kastornoe, Col. Gen. Philip I. Golikoff's right wing has widened its front and advanced more than half way from Voronezh to Tim, where Col. Gen. Baron von Weichs opened the Wehrmacht's 1942 offensive against Southern Russia.

In October we heard that American troops had landed in Liberia; in December that the United States had made an agreement with that country to defend it. It was natural that President Roosevelt should visit and review the Negro soldiers in the Negro Republic.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The H. F. Company of New York bought for investment from the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., the two and four story modern industrial plant at 88 Llewellyn Avenue, northwest corner of Fulton Street, Bloomfield, N.J. The property is 100 by 230 feet, and the sale includes a one-family dwelling at 106 North Fulton Street and a parking lot, 106 by 100 feet, at 81-87 Llewellyn Avenue, opposite the factory.

Despite the apparent liberality of the most recent limitation order on the production of paper, converters of a number of items are appealing to the government for increased quotas to take care of sharply expanded demand, it was learned here yesterday.

A fund of $1,021,500, representing the first contributions of ship-owners and operators, throughout the nation to the United Seamen's Service, was presented yesterday to John E. Bierwirth, president of the New York Trust Company and treasurer of the service, by Emmet J. McCormack, vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines and chairman of its shipping division.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29 -- Because of heavy military and lend-lease demands on production the nation is rapidly approaching a "balancing point" between military requirements and minimum civilian needs, David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation, declared today in an address before the Kentucky Publishers Association.

Last week the New York Curb Exchange saw eleven of its tickers installed in the offices of member and associate member firms. This, with the exception of a slight bulge in October of last year, when the net gain for the month was six machines, is the first reversal of the downward trend since the month after the start of the war in 1939, when hasty optimists installed fifty-six tickers.

The war continues to make itself felt in the art world. The prizewinning paintings and a selection of others from the competition held by Life Magazine for men in the armed forces will be placed oh exhibition Monday at the American-British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The government either owned or held farmer loans on agricultural commodities valued at $2,172,000,000 on Jan. 1, the Commodity Credit Corporation reported today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Aggressive buying of rye futures headed by houses with Eastern connections, regarded as reinstating sold-out lines, combined with short covering and stop-loss buying, ran prices of that grain up 1 5/8 cents a bushel today to the highest marks of the season on the Board of Trade.

Cornelius Warmerdam will be in the Millrose A.A. track and field meet in Madison Square Garden next Saturday. The entry of the greatest pole vaulter in the world, the only man who has cleared fifteen feet, was announced yesterday after the San Francisco Olympic Club record-holder had assured himself of transportation.

A photograph showing an Army bombardier cadet seated before almost 900 pounds of food that, it was said, he would eat during a twelve weeks training course at San Angelo, Texas, aroused skepticism here yesterday.

Andrew Jackson High of Queens, scoring 17 points, last night won the city P.S.A.L. senior team title at the annual individual championships in the Columbia University pool. Jackson recently captured the P.S.A.L. dual meet championship. Last year Richmond Hill nosed out Jackson to take the crown in the individual meet.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Clark D. Shaughnessy, new football coach at the University of Pittsburgh, expressed the opinion today that, despite manpower difficulties, the wartime future of college football is not too dismal.

The stock market pushed upward yesterday to the highest level since October, 1941, as prices rose fractions to 2 points or more in the broadest and most active session of the year to date. Stimulated by the war news and the previous day's statement by the president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation that the steel industry had solved its production knots, pivotal industrial issues assumed control of the share list.

Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., took issue yesterday with what he termed the "arbitrary and dictatorial attitude" of David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, "in justifying the strike of his union against the dress industry."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Navy announced today 138 casualties in Navy forces, including two wounded and 136 missing.
Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Brown, who have been at Hampshire House for several days, will return today to Newport, R.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. (AP) -- Most of the Enlisted Reserve Corps students in colleges of the United States will be called to active duty at the end of the current semester, the War Department stated today.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 29 -- Strong objection is being voiced by the Toronto Stock Exchange as well as every other Stock Exchange brokers' association in Canada, to the proposed extradition treaty between Canada and the United States.

Religious and social agencies should give adequate birth control advice to young homemakers, the Rev. Dr. L. Foster Wood, secretary of the Commission on Marriage and the Home, Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared yesterday at the Closing session of the two-day annual meeting of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America in the Hotel Waldorf -- Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- An independent "people's government" with its own Chamber of Deputies is now established in Bihac, Northern Bosnia, and its armies have liberated 30,000 square miles of territory from Axis domination, according to information made available here by sympathizers with the Yugoslav partisan movement.

President Roosevelt celebrates his sixty-first birthday today at the close of one of the most brilliant episodes of his career: a journey which brought the breath of his democratic enthusiasm into three continents; a conference which, however little we may know about its strategic decisions, dramatized the fact that the psychological initiative in this war has passed to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Navy communique 265:

George Kondolf, who last was represented on Broadway as sponsor of "Morning Star" (1940), and Rita Hassan have formed a partnership to produce "Marianne" in mid-March or early April. The musical comedy, which has a libretto by Sylvia Regan (she also wrote "Morning Star"), music by Abe Ellstein and lyrics by Lothar and Bea Metzl, originally was announced as the property of Nat Karson and Miss Hassan,

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Officials of the National Institute of Diaper Services, appealing the industry's fuel-oil ration today before the Office of Civilian Supply in the War Production Board, were requested to prepare a city-by-city survey of the essentiality of the service.

Flying records of every sort have gone by the boards since Pearl Harbor. Some of them, made in the routine of wartime necessity, are astounding. The other night Captain R.O.D. Sullivan taxied the camouflaged, oil-stained American Clipper of Pan American Airways through the mists of Long Island Sound and signed his log at the terminal without realizing the significance of the flight he had just concluded.
The house at 8-19 Parsons Boulevard, Malba, Queens, has been sold by Elizabeth C. White to Ralph K. Fisher. Its assessed valuation is $8,800.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- American bombers operating out of Henderson air field on Guadalcanal Island sank or damaged an important amount of Japanese shipping, including two destroyers, two cargo ships and a tanker in a renewal of brisk aerial warfare in the Solomon Islands on Wednesday and Thursday (Solomon time), the Navy announced today.

Greater New York commercial organizations, competing in the annual State-wide accident prevention campaign of Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., scored the highest marks during the final quarter of last year, it was announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Princeton fought Dartmouth's undefeated hockey team to a standstill for nearly two periods, but faltered late in a Pentagonal League game to succumb, 4 to 1, on Baker Rink tonight. It was Dartmouth's seventh straight victory.

The preliminary report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for 1942, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $11,012,167 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $7.34 a share on the corporation's outstanding $6 preferred stock on which dividend arrears amounted to $26.25 a share at the end of the year.

School teachers must be protected against wanton assaults, Presiding Justice Bernard A. Kozicke declared yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions in sentencing a 300-pound Negro mother to thirty days in the workhouse for assaulting her 12-year-old son's teacher.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The American Meat Institute has called a meeting of Packers for tomorrow to explore the possibility of increasing supplies for lend-lease shipment, but the small salable live supplies arriving here recently offered scant encouragement. The government recently notified packers of the failure of supplies to reach lend-lease requirements and asked their cooperation.

Retail trade here was moving along nicely this week until the snowstorm on Thursday greatly reduced volume on that important selling day. As a result, department store volume for the week will probably show a decrease of about 12 per cent under the corresponding week of 1942.

Because more men in the armed services of the United States are going overseas daily, John P. Stevens, vice president of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, urged yesterday that special efforts be made this year to attain the $13,000,000 goal set for the Red Cross drive in the metropolitan area.
A "desperate" shortage of seamen for the wartime merchant marine is steadily growing worse despite the government's expanded training program, it was disclosed yesterday.
BOSTON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- A system of priorities on kerosene deliveries was ordered in New England today, under the first emergency order issued by the Office of Price Administration.

The largest single share of British Government advertising for the first ten months of 1942 was received by provincial daily papers, according to Samuel W. Meek, vice president in charge of J. Walter Thompson Company international operations.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

AT SEA OFF GUADALCANAL, Jan. 20 (Delayed) -- The work of reducing the Japanese population of Guadalcanal goes on methodically if not apace. Most of the decimation is being done by shellfire. Our soldiers are not moving up until the Japanese lines are well worked over by artillery.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- American-built Boston bombers of the Royal Air Force joined the offensive against U-boats today when they struck effectively at the railway line running across France to the German submarine base at Brest. Their target was the vital 300-foot-high viaduct at Morlaix in Brittany over which the main line runs to Brest.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The failure of Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia to attend the Casablanca conference of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill and of any unified Allied board of strategy to evolve from the meeting, while disappointing to many, brought emphasis today upon the point that, while the United States and Britain are fighting a global war, that is not the case of the Soviet Union.

"Lucky Jordan," the Paramount melodrama starring Alan Ladd, which goes into a second week today at the Rialto, set a house record for its first week with an attendance of 34,000 persons and a gross business of approximately $16,000, it has been reported by the management. The picture topped the marks set over a similar period by the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fight films. No figures for the latter were available.

Asserting that the perpetuation of our economic system is dependent on a constant flow of fresh capital, the First National Bank of Boston in the current issue of its New England Letter, reminds that the real sources of this fund are savings, and that confidence in the future is necessary so individuals may practice thrift and business men will be willing to assume the risk of directing their investments into productive channels.

The Chilean Government has arrested the Japanese Minister in retaliation for Tokyo's arrest of the Chilean Minister in Japan, Radio Agricultura of Santiago said last night in a Chilean domestic broadcast recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

Influenced by the complete approval given to the Pace bill, providing for higher parity prices through the inclusion of farm labor costs in the computation formula, by the House Agricultural Committee, and also by the 25-point rise in the parity figure as of Jan. 15, the cotton futures market closed yesterday 6 to 10 points above Thursday's final prices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Reflecting an unprecedented demand for food, farm product prices made further gains this month to reach the highest level since 1920, the Agriculture Department reported today.

An indictment charging Vincent Sollami and Joseph Palmer with first-degree murder in connection with the midday shooting of Detective Joseph Miccio on a downtown street corner in Brooklyn on Dec. 7, was handed up yesterday by a Kings County grand jury.

OTTAWA, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press) -- J.A. MacKinnon, Trade Minister, announced today that wheat marketing in Western Canada during the crop year starting next Aug. 1 would be limited to fourteen bushels from an authorized acre and that the government-guaranteed price would remain unchanged at 90 cents a bushel, basis No. 1 Northern, at Fort William.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission closed today a three-year-old case by permitting Morgan Stanley Co. of New York City to reduce voluntarily its fee for underwriting a bond issue of the Consumers Power Company from $50,802 to $16,160.

Foppish Dino Alfieri, Italian Ambassador to Germany, has been horsewhipped by a German officer who, returning wounded from the African front, found his wife in the fascist envoy's arms, the secret German radio station Gustave Siegfried I said yesterday, according to The United Press.

Paul Draper and Larry Adler joined forces last night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of Russian War Relief in another of their unique programs of tap and harmonica virtuosity, and once again filled the hall with both people and applause.

Because of "unsettled and unpredictable conditions existing in the business world" and particularly in the real estate market in New York today, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, in a ruling yesterday directed the successor reorganization managers of the New York Title and Mortgage Company to abandon the plan of reorganization of the company which was tentatively approved in 1939.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Maurice R. Franks, editor of The Railroad Workers Journal and business agent for the Railroad Yardmasters Union, denounced the National Labor Relations Act today in an address before 300 employers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced maximum margins which may be authorized for newly established manufacturers of women's, girls' and children's coats, dresses and other outer wear garments, ranging from 27 to 36 per cent over direct costs of material and labor.

Today's events: "Faust," 2 P.M., and "The Barber of Seville," 8:15, Metropolitan Opera House; Victory concert, with Camilla Wicks, violin, and Abram Chasins, piano, as participants, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Dargomyzhsky's "Russalka" in concert form, Russian Opera Company, Town Hall, 8:30; American Peoples Chorus, New York Times Hall, 9.

The first Federal price-ceiling prosecution of wholesale meat dealers to be completed here resulted yesterday in pleas of guilty by two partners and four employes of the Bronx Meat Company of 631 Brook Avenue, the Bronx, and 449 West Thirteenth Street.

Dedicated to the armed forces of the United Nations and set in a patriotic decor befitting its traditions maintained for more than a century in wartime and peace, the anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- Speculation on whether Adolf Hitler would address Germany tomorrow on his tenth anniversary as leader of the Reich was definitely disposed of with the announcement today that Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Propaganda Minister, would broadcast a proclamation by the Reichsfuehrer at 4 P.M. [11 A.M. New York time.]

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Forty-eight Red Army officers now engaged in Russia's great Winter offensives today received the military orders of Kutozoff and Suvoroff, the highest honors of the Soviet, for successful offensive operations.

The Little Red Schoolhouse officially known as Public School 2 in Richmond Valley, S.I., which sits atop a hill of Weimar Street, one of the last two-classroom schools in the city which had been ordered closed at the end of the term as an economy measure, received a new lease of life yesterday.

M.A. Sunstrom, vice president and controller of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has rented an apartment in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, according to H. Stanley Hillyer, Inc. Through the same broker, R.A. Mehrtens, sales manager of General Motors Corporation, leased an apartment in 20 Fifth Avenue.

Joseph (Socks) Lanza, the former labor union racketeer "czar" in Fulton Fish Market, and four of his "strong-arm men," all of whom had pleaded guilty in General Sessions on Jan. 12 while being tried for extorting $120 weekly for years from Local 202 of the teamsters' union, were sentenced to prison yesterday by Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions.
MOSCOW, Jan. 29 (AP) -- A special Soviet communique:
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The State today called a rebuttal witness at Errol Flynn's trial on rape charges in an effort to disprove defense contentions regarding a bedroom door lock.

Appreciation of the concerts given since last March at East Coast naval bases under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund was expressed by Captain Paul P. Blackburn, director of Naval Reserve for the Third Naval District, at the luncheon of the fund yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 -- Asserting that national unity was essential to winning the war, Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, assailed "New Deal bureaucracy" tonight as an obstacle to victory, and called upon the American people "to weed out of government those who would change our free system into some form of National Socialism."

The Erie Railroad Company reported yesterday for 1942 a net income of $14,339,524 after charges and taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on the 5 per cent preferred stock, to $5.06 a share on the common stock and certificates of beneficial interest.

Despite aerial bombardments that at one time became so severe that air raid wardens ran out of pins to chart bomb craters and it was possible to tell the time of the day or night by the regularity of the attacks, the German and Italian air forces were unable to break the morale of the defenders of the British island of Malta, Philip Pullicino, son of the Maltese Attorney General, said here yesterday.

Vice President Wallace is one of the most interesting and original of our public men. He is the first philosopher and idealist to preside over the Senate chamber since Mr. Jefferson left it; and Mr. Jefferson was a letter writer, not a speaker. The integrity of Mr. Wallace's character and convictions is recognized even by those who dissent most strongly from the latter.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Madge Bellamy, actress in the silent movies, who is charged with assault with a deadly weapon, wept in court today when A. Stanwood Murphy, lumberman, testified that he "ducked" when three shots were fired at him outside the Pacific Union Club.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt and Getulio Vargas conferred at length through the day and evening yesterday aboard a United States destroyer anchored in the Potengi River harbor at Natal, the easternmost stronghold of the hemisphere, it was learned from new details disclosed today when President Vargas returned here by plane from the meeting.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- Details of the formation of the Yugoslav partisan army are given in a new book published by the State Publishing House entitled "Yugoslavia in the Fire of Partisan Warfare," written by I. Klakhovitch, a young Yugoslav who participated in the Spanish civil war and now resides in Moscow.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Jan. 29 -- Australian concern over the possibility of a Japanese attack on the Australian mainland mounted tremendously today with the release by the Australian Government of the fullest details so far revealed of the recently increased Japanese strength and military activity in the islands immediately to the north of this country.
While reports of Federal liquor rationing, to begin by mid-year and continue for the duration, persist, local spokesmen for the liquor industry yesterday took differing views of this possibility.

There are several items on fish and game that soon will be under consideration by Connecticut legislators from the changing of the name of the State's Board of Fisheries and Game to a recommendation to pay bounties on crows.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A bill which would automatically increase farm prices by including all labor costs, including that performed by farmers and their families, in the parity, or "fair exchange," formula, was unanimously approved today by the House Agricultural Committee.

A friend who manages to combine stoicism with good humor points out how much easier life has been made by our war hardships. If we had no war and no gasoline rationing this last snowstorm would have confronted him with a bad job in his suburban home two miles from the station.

Governmental salary restrictions are going to give baseball an informal secret society this year known as the "ceiling club" and composed of the highest-paid players from the sixteen major-league teams.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 30 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's forces are pursuing strong Japanese patrols toward Salamaua, 140 miles northwest of Buna, in New Guinea, after repulsing an attack west of Mubo, an Allied headquarters communique announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29 -- Irene Manning and Dennis Morgan, who have the romantic singing leads in Warner Brothers' "The Desert Song," not yet released, will be co-starred in the studio's forthcoming musical, "Mississippi Belle," for which Cole Porter is here writing music and lyrics, it was announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique as recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Activation of eleven air depot control area commands in the Air Service Command of the Army Air Forces was announced today.

Hats are versatile and accommodating this Spring. They oblige by clinging firmly to the head (a happy aid to the carry-your-bundles campaign), this in the majority of cases without grace of elastic. Hats are built to fit -- they have shaped calots, bandeaux and head-gripping tabs variously fashioned in "boomerang" swirls or tongues, or they descend on the hair with deep cloche brims.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP) -- George L. Oles, grocer and former Youngstown in mayor whose newspaper advertisements amuse his customers, was charged today with violating price ceilings set by the Office of Price Administration.

The strike of fourteen truck drivers employed by the Suburban Fuel Oil Service, Inc., of Mount Vernon that had impeded fuel deliveries to householders and apartment houses in the upper Bronx and lower Westchester County since last Wednesday morning, was settled yesterday.

To develop among the youth of the parish an abiding interest in the life of the church, the Rev. Henry W. Snyder Jr., the new pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street, has instituted a "Children's Service," held the first Sunday of each month.
ATLANTA, Jan. 29 -- New and troublesome problems arose today as the result of the adoption by the State yesterday of the plan to shift the State out of the Eastern time zone into the Central zone.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- Four announcements were made by the Italian Government this afternoon. They were:

LONDON, Jan. 29 (U.P.) -- Coming in the midst of reports of possible martial law in Germany and new labor mobilization decrees, Adolf Hitler's apparent decision not to speak tomorrow aroused much speculation in London. Many observers believe Herr Hitler will speak, entering the hall while Dr. Goebbels is speaking and touching off a burst of applause.
BUFFALO, Jan. 29 -- A Cape Cod cottage was dedicated today in Lafayette Square as part of a campaign to recruit at least 30,000 women to relieve the labor shortage in the Buffalo area.

In making out the Federal income tax return, expenses deductible in arriving at net profit (or loss) from business or profession are the normal current costs of running a business or producing income. The regulations state that such expenses must be distinguished from those incurred for the convenience, comfort or economy of the individual pursuing the business or in the nature of loans, gifts, capital investments and the like.

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- It is now known that Lazar Kaganovitch, brilliant transport expert, member of the Politbureau and in the early days of the revolution associated with the Red Army's formation, has been working with General I.V. Tulyeneff, in command of the Caucasus front.
LONDON, Jan. 29 -- This year is going to see the end of all sorts of little luxuries that helped make woman's wartime existence tolerable.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Tearing huge gaps in Axis puppet ranks west of Voronezh, the Red Army has killed, routed or trapped seven German divisions in three days and run its captive toll to nearly 100,000 prisoners since mid-January, Moscow announced tonight in a special communique recorded here by the Soviet monitor.

According to complaints of small shoe retailers in various sections of the country, some shoe manufacturers are not lying up to the mandatory provision of WPB Regulation M217 which provides that each manufacturer must care for each of his customers on a pro rata basis, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Approval by the Ways and Means Committee of the Treasury bill to increase the public debt limit from the present $125,000,000,000 to $210,000,000,000 was blocked today by what was called "a revolt against government by directive."

There are millions of school children in the nation whose "idle time" might be devoted to Victory gardens to help offset wartime food shortages, Dr. Walter H. Gaumitz of the United States Office of Education declared yesterday.

Russian troops are moving in strong force against the German flank on the Voronezh front and are trying to break through Axis defenses in the Western Caucasus, the Nazi High Command reported yesterday, according to broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

The first Carey-Thomas Award, an honor designed to pay tribute to "good publishing," has been won by Farrar Rinehart, New York publishers, for sponsorship of the Rivers of America series, it was announced yesterday by Publishers Weekly.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Moon Maiden, flying the red, white and blue silks of Stephen Messena, scored her third triumph in five Fair Grounds attempts today by leading six other veterans home in the six-furlong feature. The 5-year-old daughter of Challenger II-Star Chase came up from third place to win by two lengths.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Declaring that lend-lease operations are "a military instrument" essential to victory, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., lend-lease administrator, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that "total cooperation among nations in the waging of the war" is the only principle "on which a war of alliance can be successfully waged."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 29 (AP) President Getulio Vargas announced tonight that a complete accord on the war effort had been reached between the United States and Brazil as a result of his conferences with President Roosevelt at Natal.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 29 (AP) -- Miss Flora Reilly, daughter of the Rutgers swimming coach, Jimmie Reilly, won the women's New Jersey A.A.U. 100-yard back-stroke championship tonight in 1:16.6.

NILES, Ohio, Jan. 29 -- Prosperity and full employment in the United States after the war can be brought about only by the encouragement and full development of private enterprise, protected by a "reasonable" tariff barrier, Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight, in an address on the 100th anniversary of the birth of President McKinley.

An audience of 3,500 high school students attended the junior performance of Mozart's "The Magic Flute," presented under the sponsorship of the Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. To avoid congesting traffic the children present did not come from a given area, as heretofore at these annual events, but included groups from Connecticut, New Jersey, Long Island, Westchester and this city.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- While the men are fighting to stamp out a world conflagration, women living near wooded areas are helping to keep fires from burning over one of the country's vital wartime resources, live timber, says A.G. Hamel of Milwaukee, assistant regional forester of the United States Forest Service.

The tendency of most basketball writers to glorify the spectacular athletes seems to have permeated the minds of most New York City sports followers. Last week one of your readers rebelled against this type of player and expressed his concern over the lack of standout ball-handlers like Red Holzman, former City College ace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- President Roosevelt and President Getulio Vargas of Brazil in their conference in Brazil yesterday surveyed the future safety of the Western Hemisphere and declared their determination to assure that "the coasts of West Africa and Dakar" shall "never again under any circumstances be allowed to become a blockade or invasion threat against the two Americas."

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 29 -- Pushing steadily westward despite exceptionally bad weather, the British Eighth Army yesterday reached the neighborhood of Zuara, sixty-seven miles west of Tripoli and about thirty miles from the Tunisian border.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Over the whole field of war production, Britain's output was about 50 per cent greater in 1942 than in 1941, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said today. He asserted Britain had every reason to be pleased with the way things were going, but warned against any slackening during 1943.

THIS column is going to start a book-of-the-month club for peace planners. Its choice for February is "Germany's Master Plan"* by Joseph Borkin and Charles A. Welsh, which comes to us with an introduction by Thurman Arnold. According to Borkin and Welsh, German industry planned to enslave the world through cartelization.

Alexander Brailowsky was heard in the third recital of his current Chopin cycle last night in Town Hall. The pianist provided his audience with a series of masterly performances that brought ovations after each of the thirty works presented.

Doubleday, Doran and the Garden City Publishing Company announced yesterday the signing of contracts with Ely Culbertson for two books dealing with his plan "for permanent peace." The first, to be published within the next few weeks by Garden City, will be a summary of the World Federation plan.

With startling ease the amazing Willie Pep, world featherweight champion, fashioned his fifty-ninth ring victory last night at Madison Square Garden in an unbroken string that started with his first professional fight back in July, 1940.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Brig. Gen. W.T. Larson, chief of the Anti-Submarine Command of the United States Army Air Forces, said in an interview today that he was "thoroughly optimistic" over the outcome of the warfare against U-boats which is being waged by air and sea.

With only one and a half business days remaining in which to buy 1943 license tags for automobiles in daily use, lines of motorists crowded the main office of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau at 80 Centre Street yesterday for the first time during this renewal period.

War bonds and stamps will be received tomorrow in the 7,000 churches affiliated with the Northern Baptist convention. The bonds and stamps will be held for the building of churches in suburban communities after the war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Captain Henry Nelson, skipper of the liner President Coolidge, which struck a mine and sank while being used as a troopship in the South Pacific, disclosed in an interview that he had had a Navy court-martial and had been cleared in connection with the ship's loss.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Active demand for spot foreign wools is the feature of the market here this week, with the medium grades wanted most and hard to find. The disappearance of spot offerings has quickened calls upon importers for wools from abroad, especially in Australia and Montevideo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The International Wheat Council took steps today to set up a 100,000,000-bushel pool of wheat for relief use in Europe, Africa and Asia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Selective Service Bureau broadened its list of "essential occupations" in the communications service today to include about 120 types of jobs.

Expressing the hope that legislation soon would be enacted to carry out recent proposals of the joint committee on probation, Mayor La Guardia yesterday replied to criticism directed Thursday against the committee's report by eight judges of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senator Byrd of Virginia said today that he would oppose confirmation of Edward J. Flynn's nomination as Minister to Australia because it "will not be helpful to our war effort and will be resented by our ally, Australia, even though this (Australian) government cannot express its displeasure."

CATSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Reduced tolls and restrictions on motoring due to the war have reduced traffic and revenue on the Rip Van Winkle, the Mid-Hudson and the Bear Mountain Bridges during 1942, according to the annual report of the State Bridge Authority.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Britain has Supplied United States Army forces here with 300,000 suits of British army battle dress, provided adequate storage places for the troops' foodstuffs and furnished them with potatoes and fresh vegetables under "reverse lend-lease," according to Major Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, quartermaster general of the United States Army, today.

The Office of Price Administration understands that there is enough fuel oil available in the seventeen-State East Coast shortage area to redeem every ration coupon that has been issued to consumers in the area, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Celebrating capital crowds who cannot drive for pleasure set out on foot tonight to have fun and further the cause of those who cannot walk -- infantile paralysis victims.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) -- Members of the Senate and House Civil Service Committees agreed tentatively today with Federal personnel officers on the terms of legislation raising government salaries for the duration of the war.

A tortured humanity writhing under the scourge of the most extensive and the most savage war in history will contemplate this day with mingled fury and regret, but also with a sense of triumph and a new dedication to final victory over the powers of darkness. Ten years ago today a demoniacal demagogue named Adolf Hitler came to power in Germany and thereby unleashed forces which are now drenching the world with blood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The location of the Japanese command post captured Wednesday by the Americans on Guadalcanal was not specified in the communique, but a Navy spokesman said that it probably was somewhere in the four-mile strip of coastal country between Kokumbona and Tassafaronga.
LONDON, Jan. 29 (UP) -- Despite Axis firing squads, sabotage of ammunition dumps, railroads and factories is growing in Greece, sources in London said today.

While City dwellers were digging out from the heaviest snowfall in this area since 1934, the army of metropolitan ski enthusiasts looked forward to some of the finest local sport in many years. The city's public parks and many side streets felt the impact of wooden runners, while some of the more ambitious enthusiasts skied their way to railroad stations in the suburban areas, where walking was really a task.
As church opposition to the Nazi ideology grows in Europe, the cleavage between State and church in Axis nations becomes more evident.

Of interest to housekeepers plagued by the current scarcity of fats are tests that have just been conducted by the General Electric Consumers Institute. The purpose of these experiments was to determine the most acceptable method of stretching a small supply of butter, and, to that end, tasters were blindfolded and asked to give their opinions of four "spreads."

Sam Boston, leading betting commissioner whose two partners were slain last August by a former partner, was arrested last night with a new associate in his luxuriously furnished thirteenth-floor apartment at 240 Central Park South, where, the police charged, he was taking bets over the telephone on the Pep-Stolz boxing match at Madison Square Garden.

New State and municipal bond and note issues amounting to $8,928,000 will come up for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $5,062,000, according to Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new offerings for the year, thus far, amounts to $31,505,578, due to the heavy financing done early this month.

Winning a minor economic revolution while members of a City Council are engaged in a favorite political dodge would be considered a man-sized job, but it has been done by a woman. She is Senora Graciela de Schnake, wife of Dr. Oscar Schnake, Chilean Ambassador to Mexico, who arrived here from South America last week, and who, competent authorities insist, is the only woman ever to rule one of the world's capital cities as Mayor.

The Judiciary Committee has favorably reported the Hobbs bill to the House. The bill would make labor unions clearly subject to the provisions of the Anti-Racketeering Act of 1934, as they ought to be, like everybody else. It would remove the immunity which the Supreme Court less than a year ago ruled that the present act confers on union members.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 29 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa, made it clear today that there would be nothing beyond military and economic liaison between French North Africa and the followers of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, and that political union of all Frenchmen outside the motherland was impossible at present.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 29 -- Yesterday's issue of the popular Swedish weekly illustrated magazine, Se, was seized by the police because it contained a map showing how no fewer than twenty-five official and semi-official branch offices of the German Legation here were within a stone's throw of important Swedish offices.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Don Hutson, the artful end whose name is etched seventeen times in the National Football League's record book, hopes the fans will understand why he plans to retire from pro football although family men are needed more than ever by the Green Bay Packers and the rest of the league.

Besides developing an ever-increasing number of items useful to the war effort, the application of soluble plastic resins to textiles and other articles promises to bring many new products for post-war world commerce, C. W. Patton of the plastics division of the Carbide and Carbon Chemicals Corporation declared last night at a meeting of the American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists in the Downtown Athletic Club.

To a layman, certain significant changes have occurred in education over recent years. Whereas the teacher was mostly interested professionally in pedagogic methods and curricular content, the present crisis compels the educator not only to adjust policies according to the trend of the times and state of society but also to the experimental dictates of ineducable lay boards.

What a triumph it would have been for the Axis Powers if American merchant seamen, landing desperately needed supplies for the marines on Guadalcanal, had refused because of "union rules" to work cargo on Saturday afternoon and Sunday! It never seemed a likely story.
I should like to refute some statements concerning swimming that were made without basis by "R.P." in his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday.

The market for new investments here improved slightly this week, two issues of municipal bonds aggregating $1,500,000 being offered for public subscription, against three last week totaling $492,000. In the corresponding week of 1942, two loans, one for a railroad and the other a State issue, amounting to $6,150,000 were marketed.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 -- Twenty-five German soldiers were injured, several seriously, by the explosion of a bomb in Lyon early this morning. Two French passersby were shot dead when they failed to stand in their tracks when ordered by the commander of the detachment, immediately following the explosion.

Mounded snow the color and consistency of brown sugar ran off in icy water yesterday as the warm sun smiled on the city and environs. Pedestrians stepped through it gingerly at cross-walks or getting into or off buses that stopped four and five feet from the curbs where the snow was still four feet high.

A large dinner dance was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School in Greene County, Va., an institution for children of needy families in the mountain districts of the State. Mrs. F. Graham Cootes was chairman and Mrs. George Gordon Battle, honorary chairman.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Fifteen hundred of the world's most enthusiastic dancers, including accomplished "hepcats" from half a dozen United Nations, celebrated President Roosevelt's birthday with a bang tonight at Covent Garden.

The British National Maritime Board has approved wage increases for officers and seamen serving on British merchant ships, effective tomorrow, according to information received at the New York office of the International Transport Workers Federation.

A delegation of Red Cross workers and city department heads will call on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning and formally request him to proclaim the month of March as Red Cross War Fund Month in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Open hearings, described as "intended to be neither a smear nor a whitewash," will be conducted this week by a Congressional committee anxious to learn just what William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, meant when he charged that Army and Navy "loafers" and "so-called expediters" were holding up the country's synthetic rubber program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Navy announced today 160 casualties in Navy forces, including five dead, two wounded and 153 missing.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 30 -- Bombers of the Twelfth United States Army Air Force struck a smashing blow yesterday at General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's desperate efforts to prepare his armies to meet the next Allied land offensive when they successfully attacked a large convoy in the Mediterranean.

FASTER and faster every month, here in New York harbor, America's sons and munitions of war move out in great masses overseas. On Army trucks, on ferries, tugs and Navy speed boats I have gone by waters swarming with fighting craft and cargo vessels to closely guarded piersheds roaring with war activities all day long and through the night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The Seventy-eighth Congress is decidedly investigation-minded. Although only a little more than three weeks old, it already has embarked upon an inquiry program that has record-breaking possibilities.

THE wearer of the wedding dress is Tessa Devlin, who, up to a few months before our story opens, has believed herself to be Tessa Shaw, daughter of a medical missionary in India. But when Dr. Shaw died he left a letter and a diary informing Tessa that she was really the daughter of Thomas Devlin, a wealthy mining man of New York.

THE democratic world warring against Nazi Germany has today almost forgotten the first heroes of the anti-Nazi cause -- the German underground. Nearly ten years have passed since they first organized their ranks to preserve, in Hitler's anarchy, the flame of democracy which their trade unions held aloft for decades.

MY best thanks to R.L. Duffus for his very cordial review of "Wide Is the Gate." In course of the discussion, he implies a question, and the answer to it may be of interest to readers, as well as to him. Referring to Lanny Budd, protagonist of the series of novels, he says:

An old-time "last-minute" rush for automobile license plates before the deadline for using 1942 tags without the 1943 date-line strip expires tomorrow midnight developed yesterday at offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau throughout the State.

AT 6:15 A.M. Deborah's mother leaves home for her war job in a Jersey plant, so her father gets Debbie dressed and fed and delivered to nursery school. "I just couldn't manage her hair this morning," he apologized as they arrived the other day a few minute late.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Contributors to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis were thanked by President Roosevelt for a happy birthday in a message broadcast from the White House tonight by Mrs. Roosevelt.

Wherever the statute of New York State demands that compensation insurance rates be both adequate and reasonable, there can be only one rate, in the opinion of Henry D. Sayer, general manager of the Compensation Insurance Rating Board, expressed in his annual report for 1942.
IT is almost a habit with most bridge players to play an ace when a singleton is led from dummy in a case such as this:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Now that Lieut. Gen. Eisenhower, chief of both the military and political affairs of the United States in North and West Africa, has lifted the censorship and permitted American correspondents to describe the civil conditions there, a paradox has arisen here.

WHEN Alexander Woollcott died a week ago last night, amid circumstances that no one would have described with greater dramatic relish than he, radio lost a first-rate performer. For one reason or another he had appeared only intermittently on the air in recent years, and on at least one occasion he allowed it to be understood that he did not think a great deal of the so-called art of the microphone.

State Senator John J. Crawford, father of the law under which New York racing functioned from 1934 to the enactment of the mutuel measure in 1940, was in town yesterday to further his present measure recently proposed in Albany and declared that the "New York State Racing Commission, the Massachusetts Racing Associations and the New Jersey Racing Associations were interested in the bill."

I DON'T see how I can debate the issues Mr. Sinclair raises. If his books didn't make me understand what Lanny saw in Irma, his explanation can't. If his characters don't seem to me to grow up, he can't grow them up in a relatively brief letter.

MILLIONS laughed when mileage rationing came to Wistful Vista not long ago, but few realized who helped to put those funny words into the mouths of Fibber McGee and Molly. It's no secret, however, that the Office of War Information's Domestic Radio Bureau was responsible for Mr. McGee's rather hilarious transition from a persecuted holder of an "A" gasoline card into a patriotic advocate of rubber conservation.

OLD FORGE, N.Y. -- The picturesque Central Adirondack area embracing Old Forge, Inlet, Webb, Thendara, Indian Lake and Long Lake, long famous as a Summer playground with its attractive Fulton Chain of Lakes and imposing mountain ranges, is now firmly established as a Winter sports area, with emphasis on skiing.
May I express my point of view in connection with Harold Callender's article which appeared in the Dec. 24 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the title "Poles Rift Bared by Sikorski's Visit."
LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau as recorded by the Soviet Monitor:

IN an article last Sunday you expressed the desire to know "what percentage of a cross-section of the country's 30,000,000 radio-equipped homes" listen to certain sustaining programs. "Since the sampling is done by telephone," you continued, The scientific basis of the Crossley is not altogether clear to this department.

Dr. Alfred Taylor of the University of Texas announces in Science that he has succeeded in obtaining a powerful tumor-producing principle from tumors, injecting this under the skin of mice and thus starting tumors which grew more rapidly than transplants. This is the first time that tumor stuff from a mammal has been used to generate a tumor in a similar mammal.

The Winter track and field season, away to a staggered start in the recent Metropolitan A.A.U. championships, will really get off the mark Saturday night when the Millrose A.A. conducts its thirty-sixth invitation meet in Madison Square Garden.

ARTHUR HARTMANN writes us in rejoinder to an article which appeared in this place in a recent issue, concerning the present artistic status of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and its experiences in late seasons under various "guest" leaders.

A radio transmitter is now being used to make molded wood and plastic airplanes for the United States. This new development, although still in the experimental stage, is being used by the Duramold division of the Fairchild Engine and Aviation Corporation to transform trees into airplanes.

Gounod's "Faust" received its third presentation of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performance marked the return of John Charles Thomas, who made his first appearance of the season with the company as the Valentin of the cast.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30 -- Argentina is in danger of finding herself materially as well as morally isolated. Economic problems created by the war have a tendency to grow more acute as time passes, and Argentina, which has been drawing heavily upon her reserves during the last year, can hardly expect the next twelve months to be as prosperous as those just ended.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 30 -- For "extreme gallantry under fire during the ninth United States Army Air Forces heavy bomber attack on Naravino Bay, Greece, on Oct. 3, 1942," Henry T. Gorrel, United Press war correspondent today received the Air Medal.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 30 -- Strongly entrenched in the rugged hills in the north and busily digging in along the Mareth Line in the south, an experienced and well-equipped German army is preparing to sell Tunisia yard by yard to the Allied armies gathering for the campaign that will open the great struggle for control of the Mediterranean.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler was reported off somewhere "with his soldiers" when the R.A.F.'s fast Mosquito bombers struck, precisely at 11 A.M., Berlin time, as the be-medaled Marshal Goering was ready to talk at the Air Ministry in the heart of Berlin.

FIRST you were told that limitations had been placed on the kinds of soup that could be canned, that varieties had been reduced to a fraction of those available before the war. Then you were informed that restrictions had been put on the volume, that this year's production would be three-quarters of the 1942 pack.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Two Russian communiques, broadcast by Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor, indicated today that the Red Army was tightening its net in the Caucasus south of Rostov and also rapidly extending its gains west of Voronezh in the direction of Kursk and Kharkov.

THE traveler aboard a train today finds his mind not on scenic splendors nor relaxation but on the Army. He may forget home problems or temporarily divert his thoughts from business, but he cannot escape Uncle Sam's men.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- The shift to non-food items by grocers seeking to maintain sales volume in the face of wartime shortages of staples was emphasized here last week, as wholesalers eagerly sought new lines ranging from corn plasters to straw hats.
