War is exploding many myths that grew up in peacetime to confuse the minds of men. One of these myths was that only a planned and regimented economy on the Nazi-Fascist or Communist model could provide work for everybody and banish the specter that haunted our industrial age -- the specter of unemployment.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Despite the obvious need for unity on the part of the patriot population in its resistance against the Axis and Axis-puppet governments, the peoples of occupied Yugoslavia remain bitterly split into two main factions, which are continuously engaged in civil warfare deliberately facilitated by the cynical divide-and-conquer policy of the Germans and Italians.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 -- Requested, Ben Whitaker's comeback colt, established himself as a threat for the New Orleans Handicap when he easily won the mile and-a-sixteenth Chalmette Handicap before 7,000 fans at the Fair Grounds today.

IN a fashion as effortless and buoyant as the flight of thistledown, Elizabeth Orton Jones has written the tale of Twig, a little girl who lived on the fourth floor of a high sort of building in the city and whose father drove a Yellow taxi.

BACK in 1935, it will be remembered, Benito Mussolini began boasting a bit more than usual. His so-called glorious legions were overrunning Abyssinia; his late son, fresh from air raids on native villages, was reporting the effect produced by Italian bombs on massed humans as resembling the opening of the petals of a beautiful rose; there'd been some happy correspondence with Berlin.

Despite the demands of war and the urgent need for technical training of men and women, American colleges and universities are determined to uphold the liberal arts tradition in the field of higher education.

ONE of the principal reasons behind the plan to remove the Metropolitan Opera's "Diamond Horseshoe" after the war is that more customers can be accommodated in the space if it is transformed into a regular balcony.
President Roosevelt's war leadership, as exemplified by the Casablanca conference, was praised by rabbis in sermons here yesterday, on his sixty-first birthday.

A panel of five women will discuss underlying reasons for the reluctance of many women to take part in the war effort, and methods of bringing them into fuller participation, at a meeting tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Women's City Club.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 30 -- Steel mills in the Great Lakes area got away to a flying start on 1943 war production by consuming upward of 7,500,000 tons of iron ore this month, according to statistics compiled by shipping companies here. If is possible, according to observers, that the record of 7,759,366 tons, established last month, will be eclipsed when final figures are tabulated.

AN operatic workshop, directed by Dr. Herbert Graf and Nicholas Goldschmidt, will be conducted by the Department of Music of Columbia University next season at the Brander Matthews Theatre, as a laboratory for singers, teachers, composers, librettists and directors.

THE Trianon Room of the Ambassador and its adjoining Circular Lounge will be the settings for a rummage dinner dance and gin rummy party to be given Thursday night in aid of Friends of Greece, Inc. Subscribers to the party are being asked to bring with them, as part of the admission charge, a package of rummage for resale at the newly opened Thrift Shop at the sponsoring organization's headquarters, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The Office of Price Administration made it clear yesterday by word and action that there would be no relaxation in enforcement of the ban on pleasure driving.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Neither the Fuehrer's proclamation today nor the accompanying speeches by Goering and Goebbels contributed any alleviation to the dark and pessimistic atmosphere created deliberately in Germany by Nazi propaganda, with the apparent aim of steeling the Germans for further reverses and more hardships.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, Inc., announced yesterday the election of its first group of officers since the organization was incorporated as a permanent community fund-raising body.
The first attempt to do an overall job of training for industry by integrating courses offered earlier by various government agencies was undertaken here last week by the War Manpower Commission.

The Concertante for Piano and String Orchestra by Stanley Bate, young English composer-pianist now living in this city, received its first American concert performance by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Reports that the Argentine Government was curbing the influence of pro-Allied newspapers in Buenos Aires by denying newsprint to publications friendly to the United Nations' cause drew little substantiation from government sources here today.

THE war in which this nation has now been engaged for more than a year is making greater demands upon transportation than any conflict in our history. That fact is spectacularly illustrated by the vast distances which American troops and supplies have to traverse to reach such far-away stations and combat areas as Australia, the Solomon Islands, North Africa.

SOLDIER'S RATION -- Studies that show the energy costs in a soldier's life are discussed by Professor George R. Cowgill in The Yale Review. Because of mechanized warfare, a traveling kitchen is not always practicable. A ration has been devised that is "concentrated, readily digested, nutritively complete, easily eaten and packaged in a way that permits rough handling in the field."

Smetana: The Moldau. National Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Hans Kindler. (Victor DM-921, two twelve-inch records.) This is the second in Smetana's symphonic cycle, "Ma Vlast" (My Country). Czechs would probably complain about Victor's insistence on calling it "The Moldau" on its title page; they prefer to use the Czech name of the river in question, Vltava, rather than the German.

SEATTLE, Jan. 30 -- An intensive drive for greater safety in war plants and streets here was started today with the visit of William A. Irvin, former president of the United States Steel Corporation and chairman of the War Production Fund for Conservation of Manpower.
THE Army and Navy need 36,000 more nurses this year. Where can they be found? When they are found, will there be enough other nurses to fill civilian needs?

WHAT was passed by the censors concerning American radio affairs behind scenes in this war was told here last week at the Winter conference of the Institute of Radio Engineers. The meeting was international -- there was a pick-up from London and more than 100 broadcasters of two nations carried the annual institute ceremonies.

UP to two weeks ago almost every major company was rushing preparations on a film dramatization of recent events in North Africa. Now the enthusiasm to keep pace with the war headlines has cooled off considerably, due, it is stated, to the fear on the part of Washington that film subjects which in any way touch the French political and military situation would cause diplomatic embarrassment.

In a twelve-hour tournament, which came down to the last bout and final touch for a decision, the Bloomfield High School trio of Dick Heeren, Fred Seufert and Cyrus Nucci came through to victory in the tenth annual interscholastic fencing tournament sponsored by Washington Square College of N.Y.U. on the trips of the East Building last night.
MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- The Russians reported today that their forces west of Voronezh were striking new heavy blows and had overrun forty more localities, taking 600 additional German prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- Permanent adoption by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the device for special offerings of securities on stock exchanges is expected within the next six months, following the submission of studies of the operation of the device on the New York Stock Exchange.
IT was of the African Congo that Vachel Lindsay was thinking when he wrote his wild, exciting lines:
IT is a far cry and a longer distance from a ski run in New Hampshire to a bomber run over a Nazi submarine base in occupied France. But the two occasionally tie in together.

MEN prefer red roses; that is proved conclusively by nation-wide florists' polls. The enthusiastic male also grows white, pink and yellow roses of superlative loveliness, but his real passion, his heart's delight, is the masculine quality of sheer vitality, the exotic perfume which characterizes man's first choice among all flowers.

High up in the snow fastnesses of Camp Hale in the Colorado Rockies, thousands of Uncle Sam's "Fighting Mountaineers" are being rigorously trained to prepare them for one of the most dangerous and difficult kinds of combat.

CHILDREN who find fun and magic in a merry-go-round, as most of them do, will enjoy Margery Bianco's and Marjory Colleson's picture story book, which tells in genuinely childlike fashion of a little girl named Penny, who loved the merry-go-round in the park, spent her precious nickel to ride on it every Saturday and always chose the prancing white horse, who seemed to nod his head and say he was waiting for her.
LONDON, Jan. 30--Excerpts from Marshal Hermann Goering's speech yesterday follow:

EXPLORATIONS, journeyings to far lands, voyages over strange seas, all these make sun instant appeal to the 7 to 10 year old, whose horizon is expanding, and who, while he still craves the element of wonder and strangeness, is pleased to find his heroes pursuing adventure against a background of history.

Because mail, and particularly air mail, is so important to men in American expeditionary forces, I thought your readers might be interested in the little-known fact that Benjamin Franklin was the first person ever to receive an air mail letter.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- Governor Dewey announced today that the State had undertaken a rush job to provide vital parts for an aviation gasoline plant being built in Texas, with the work being done at the machine shop of the State Barge Canal System in Syracuse.

The manning and training divisions of the War Shipping Administration are working on a reorganization of their programs to relieve a serious shortage in available manpower for the merchant marine, it was disclosed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The State Department's document, "Peace and War," covering the diplomacy of 1931 to 1941, was praised highly by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in a message to Secretary Hull and which was given out by the State Department tonight.

THE war isn't over, by a long shot -- by several million long-drawn shots, perhaps -- and this is no time for kidding ourselves into thinking the end is nigh. But some of the motion-picture people, with a foresight that works in spans of years, are even now looking forward to the day of ultimate peace and are making their plans according to the way they see things shaping up.

The dramatic announcement last week of the President's visit to North Africa made it clear that there were two main purposes behind the historic conference held at Casablanca. The first, and plainly the more important, was to discuss military plans for the invasion of the Continent of Europe.

Private Harold Mullane, the 17-year-old Marine whose Staten Island home was deluged with pennies as a result of an appeal on an NBC radio broadcast after his mother had failed to answer a question on a quiz program, appeared in person on the same program last night to accept the gifts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President Roosevelt made a short stop on the island of Trinidad in the British West Indies during his flight north from Brazil to the United States and received an enthusiastic reception from the populace, according to a dispatch from Port-of-Spain, the capital of Trinidad, received at the White House late today.

Moscow's snowbound streets echo with the steady rumble of trucks, and observers see in the starlight that they are Dodges and Studebakers from America. To the Russian in the street these trucks represent lend-lease. He doesn't exactly know how they got there, doesn't hear of the difficulties involved, but he recognizes that they are as much a part of the contemporary scene as felt boots and posters of shivering Germans.

MR. BORLAND'S poems, which have been very popular and will become more popular, are a direct speech to the American who is known as Mister, brother or friend. Is this speech becoming the typical popular poetry of America?

THREE items of fine printing and bookmaking from the Huntington Library have to do with California in the middle of the nineteenth century. "Glances at California, 1827 to 1853" comprises the Diaries and Letters of William Rich Hutton, surveyor, with a brief memoir and notes by Willard O. Waters (S2); "California, 1847 -- 1852," reproduced from the originals by William Rich Hutton ($5), and "The Butterfield Overland Mail," by Waterman L. Ormsby.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Theoretically guests in this area, the armed forces have captured the spotlight and are doing The entertaining. Attendance of civilians at periodical graduations from the Army Air Forces Training School at Miami Beach runs into thousands, and spectators throng the Recreation Pier and Flamingo Park for shows staged by service men.

Merchandising authorities sought last week to analyze the factors in what has become one of the most complicated Spring buying situations in many years, with prime attention centering on the actual percentage of deliveries manufacturers will be able to make on the large orders which retailers have placed for suits, coats, dresses and other apparel items.

Twenty-seven enemy aliens, among them an associate of two of the Nazi Saboteurs landed from a German submarine last June, were arrested in New York and vicinity during the week-end, it was revealed yesterday at the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

FOUR persons tell this story and play the leading parts in it. One is Mark McPherson, the detective from Police Headquarters who has been assigned to the case of the murder of Laura Hunt. The other three are persons who have known the murdered woman more or less intimately.

Sam Boston, betting commissioner, who was arrested Friday night in his apartment at 240 Central Park South, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Magistrate Rothenberg in Weekend Court on betting charges and was held in $7,500 bail for a hearing on Feb. 10 in Jefferson Market Court.
Lieutenant Robert L. Shedden of the Army Air Forces, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Shedden of 64 East Ninetieth Street, was killed in action over Western Europe on Jan. 22.

Fourteen supplemental interrogatories directed to The Chicago Tribune and Robert R. McCormick, its publisher, who are among the defendants in the anti-trust suit of the government against The Associated Press, non-profit news gathering organization, and its members, were filed yesterday here in the Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Senator McKellar of Tennessee announced his opposition tonight to President Roosevelt's nomination of Edward J. Flynn as Minister to Australia, a development generally regarded as foreshadowing Senate rejection of the appointment if it is not withdrawn before consideration begins Monday.

FROM real estate men in many areas comes an interesting report. It is confirmed by a survey here in the Northeast. In spite of gasoline and rubber shortages, there is an unusual demand for small acreage homes along main roads served by bus lines or near railroads.
LONDON -- The German "New Order" in Belgium is now well under way. Its victims are divided into two groups; peoples of "Germanic" blood and persons of "non-Germanic" stock.

CHUNGKING, Jan. 30 -- No statement thus far received from the Casablanca conference has changed the strategic situation for China, as nothing that has happened since the Burma Road was cut last Spring has made any material difference.

BETTY HUTTON is the little blond cherub with the bobbing curls, the round eyes and the hot little heart, who turns lady-Tarzan when she gives a song, who tosses the furniture around, plays acrobatic end-man if there are more than three people on the stage, and jerks her dainty head out of joint whenever the script calls for it.

Friday's sitdown strike of 121 transit workers employed in the Jamaica inspection barn of the Eighth Avenue Subway System, in Kew Gardens, Queens, and work stoppages last Wednesday and Thursday in IRT shops, were assailed yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, as "acts of distinct sabotage."

The New York City meat market is "entirely disorganized," "all branches of the industry admit ignoring the ceiling prices and other OPA regulations," prices charged are often "exorbitant," and "New York City is not getting sufficient meat for home consumption," according to the findings of Mayor La Guardia's committee to study the problems of the meat industry, released by the Mayor at City Hall yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Views on how the war is affecting the American people and what kind of problems the country is facing were voiced today by speakers at the National Institute on War and Post-War Issues sponsored by the American Library Association and attended by more than 200 of the country's leading librarians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A critical manpower situation will confront the nation in the months ahead as it mobilizes to raise, equip and feed armed forces totaling more than 10,000,000 men while carrying on a vital program of lend-lease aid to our Allies and maintaining its own civilian economy at a lean, but sound, level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Adolf Hitler's proclamation, broadcast from Berlin today, which concentrated upon Russia and apparently sought to discount Britain and the United States as enemies, was interpreted by practiced observers here as another attempt to "sell" to the Western World the idea that Germany was the only barrier against the conquest of Europe by bolshevism.

RIVERMEN who work in the lower Mississippi River trade are pretty prone to speak contemptuously of any other river. They can get away with that talk with some men on some rivers, but not with the men who steamboat on the great river which enters the Mississippi some fifteen miles above St. Louis.

More than 18,000 pounds of Russian dandelion have been harvested from experimental plantings made in the Summer of 1942, to determine the feasibility of producing rubber from the roots. Last Summer the Forest Service planted 130 acres in Minnesota, Michigan, Wisconsin and Montant with Russian dandelion.

The British Mosquito bombers that swept down over Berlin just as Reich Marshal Hermann Goering was to begin his speech yesterday are the world's fastest bombers and one of the fastest types of planes in any category, says the British Information Service.

THE curtain is up on the last act of the Whitney Museum's brave and fine and stirring drama, which began more than a decade ago. The final curtain falls at the end of next month, and then the Metropolitan will take on the task of "absorbing" the Whitney's collection of American art, built up through the years.

On his return flight from Morocco, President Roosevelt stopped off for another important meeting. Last Thursday morning his giant flying boat skimmed gently into the Potengi River at the seaport of Natal, on the "hump" of the Brazilian coast nearest Africa. Here, on an American destroyer, surrounded by patrol craft and under an umbrella of planes, he held affectionate reunion with "my old friend," Getulio Vargas, President of Brazil.

ALEXEI NIKOLAYEVITCH TOLSTOY, considered by many to be Soviet Russia's greatest living writer, now 60, has been awarded the Red Banner for distinguished work in the Soviet Union's cause. Recently Tolstoy delivered a penetrating and candid speech to the Academy of Science, surveying twenty-five years of progress of Soviet literature.

THERE are not many authors of good literary standing who would admit that "being clever and ambitious" and "seeking the most comfortable short cut to success," they had in their previous books "managed to dazzle" their readers "into taking easy brilliance of expression for depth of thought, sincerity of heart."
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Displaying an audacity unsurpassed in the war, Royal Air Force bombers struck at Berlin twice today in the first British daylight attacks on the strongly defended enemy capital.

Luxurious furnishings that once graced the spacious salons and first, second and third class staterooms of the giant French liner Normandie will soon be standard equipment for the dormitories of officers and enlisted personnel of the Waves at Hunter College and the newly acquired apartment house at Eighteenth and G Streets, N.W., in Washington, it was revealed here yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. Jack Dean, chief of the Navy Salvage Section of Supplies and Accounts.

American labor law has long abandoned the notion that organized labor's quarrel with management is private warfare unconnected with governmental concern except to keep the peace. The national labor policy has fallen, however, into three basic errors of approach.

Reports from a number of Northern gardeners that the new Golden Spider-plant or Cleome has given a poor performance indicate improper handling. The entire group of cleomes, including the popular C. spinosa and also C. serrulata (which should, because of an even more pronounced airy grace, be as popular in the North) require handling different from that given ordinary annuals if they are to provide a long and satisfying display.

MEMBERS of the war activities committee of the Smith College Club of New York, of which Mrs. Frederick H. Cone is chairman, have announced that the club workroom to aid the war effort will be opened tomorrow for two sessions daily -- from 10 o'clock in the morning until 1 o'clock in the afternoon and from 2 until 5 o'clock in the afternoon, every day except Saturday and Sunday.

As time goes on, it becomes more and more clear that the most difficult of all tasks of the over-all war direction is to assure that the production of thousands of different weapons and parts of weapons is properly balanced and synchronized. To produce a single item, like an airplane, motors, bombsights, machine-guns, ammunition, propellers, wheels, tires, frames must all be turned out in the proper proportions to each other.

For the most part the response registered in the discussion of Acting Deputy Coordinator of Fisheries Charles Jackson's suggestion that sportsmen "fish for food" instead of for fun has brought identical reaction.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- In a broadcast of greetings to President Roosevelt on his sixty-first birthday today Major Gen. Russel P. Hartle, in temporary command of the United States Army forces in Europe, reiterated the President's own promise that the enemy "asked for it and is going to get it."

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Adolf Hitler failed to appear today at a gloomy party celebrating the tenth anniversary of his accession to power, and British bombs twice upset the broadcast explanations of Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels as to why the German Armies were meeting reverses in Russia.

New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. It is the increased need for care of children in "temporary shelters" -- voluntary agencies which receive children in case of accident, illness or some other family crisis. Dr. Keliher says that volunteers are urgently needed to help with these youngsters.

CONSERVATION -- The much-discussed bugaboo of all-out food rationing stares us sternly in the face. Housewives bravely attack the intricacies of the point system. To get the most out of food, kitchen equipment -- made of irreplaceable metal -- must be maintained and conserved in good order. The prosaic frying pan, the plain, garden-variety of double boiler play a stellar role, these days, in the drama of keeping America strong.

A GARDEN information program will be sponsored by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden at 10:30 A.M. on Tuesday. A discussion of Victory Garden plans will be featured, and gardeners are invited to submit their problems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Congress, under the gun of public insistence, is ready, and waiting, quite impatiently, to vote for a program that will put taxation of incomes on a pay-as-you-go basis.

One of the most colorful of house plants is the Jerusalem Cherry, with its bright red berries, but its life in a heated living room is short. One may lengthen its bloom by keeping it in as cool a place as possible and giving it plenty of air and moisture.

TORONTO, Jan. 30 -- Toronto suffered a 5-3 defeat at the hands of the National Hockey League-leading Boston Bruins at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and it turned into a double mishap when the great Toronto center, Syl Apps, was carried off the ice with a broken leg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The continuing surge of the Russian forces across their frost-bitten southern front is fast approaching the point that will decide whether the German armies will lose this Winter only what they gained in last Summer's enemy offensive or whether their reversal will become in fact a defeat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The new baseball you will see bouncing and soaring around the parks this year probably will be a fugitive from the fairway with a hide of horse but the heart of a golf ball.

MR. GELBER'S tough-minded little book redresses the balance of much of discussion of peace programs which has been disturbed by an undue emphasis on tender-minded projects for millennial changes in our institutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The tenth anniversary of the accession of the Nazis to power in Germany was signalized today by the State Department in the publication of a White Book that presents in detail the Nazi viewpoint, structure and program, particularly through the use of Germans and organized German minorities abroad for the furtherance of Nazi interests.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Jan. 31--Maikop, center of the only oil resources captured by Adolf Hitler in his 1942 drive for precious Caucasus motor fuel, has been recaptured by the Red Army, the Russians announced early today in a special communique.

Deposits ranging from 1 to 3 cents on milk bottles and higher deposits on cases, cans and dispensers will be required by the milk industry of the nation beginning tomorrow in accordance with wartime conservation directive No. 11 recently issued by the Director of Food Distribution of the Department of Agriculture.

I believe the men and women who have given so freely of time and money to make life brighter for the men in our fighting services will derive a real encouragement from a letter the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has just received from a private first class now stationed somewhere in the remote Yukon Territory.
Columbia played host to the athletes of Manhattan and its own Midshipmen's School on South Field yesterday in a triangular track and field meet, then proceeded to take four of the eight events.

Fears that the impending "omnibus" type of separate ceiling regulation for wholesalers of dry goods and apparel may force such distributors to amend their sales policies during 1943 at the expense of large department stores and chains whose volume they previously sought avidly, were expressed last week by textile distributors.

THIS graceful and moving little novel reminds one again of something often observed before, that no amount of industrious research in libraries is an adequate substitute for the kind of knowledge a writer absorbs by early association and, as it were, through the pores of his skin.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Two hundred and fifty Japanese have been killed in the Mubo area, near Salamaua, New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique announced today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The professor punctuated his phrases with chalk-jabs on the blackboard. "T equals the thickness of the beam at the shearing unit desired," he said. His fingers drummed out diagram and formula, involving T's and V's and S's.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- The outflanking of particularly powerful German fortifications on the lower Don River and the capture of two localities there were announced today as reports emphasized the severity of the fighting on the eastern approaches to Rostov. Substantial losses were inflicted on counterattacking infantry forces.

President Roosevelt's order of Oct. 3, 1942, which developed by regulation into a limitation upon the payment of salaries of $25,000, after taxes, indicates that its final form was not originally intended and was probably deemed not legally enforceable.

SOME years ago, after an unexpectedly brief tussle with certain of the more obscure phases of the Muscovite muse, Jed Harris let it be known through the usual channels that he had combed the last cossack from his hair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (Science Service) -- Coffee without caffein, which many have come to like during recent years, can be better and more quickly manufactured by a new process in which organic solvents are eliminated and only hot water is used.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 30 -- A world swimming record that Johnny Weissmuller wrote into the books back in 1927, and since then an elusive target for every freestyle ace, vanished today in the wake of a superb performance by Alan Ford, sensational Yale freshman.
ANY one with ten fingers and an ounce of ingenuity can learn to do her own hair. And with time and hairdressers at a premium -- and March 15 drawing on apace -- it is a good idea.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 29 -- A series of moves designed to consolidate and improve Army organization were announced today. Defense Minister M.F. Jones revealed that the better situation in the Pacific had made possible the release of a number of senior officers from their posts for advanced training at Army schools and their replacement by junior officers, who thus gain valuable experience.

Prices hit the best levels in a year and a quarter yesterday as the New York Stock Exchange ended its first month of 1943. The market, which traded 612,010 shares of 758 issues, was the largest and broadest Saturday session since Dec. 27, 1941.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York will observe tomorrow the one hundredth anniversary of the issuance of its first policy, issued on Feb. 1, 1843, on the life of Thomas N. Ayres, who had been appointed the company's first representative.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala, after assailing war workers who expect special privileges yet refuse to accept responsibilities like other citizens, yesterday sentenced a man who demanded that a patrolman "get a trolley car out my way because I'm a defense worker" to either a week in jail or a $30 fine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The accident rate for Army planes in the United States is lower now than in the ten-year period between 1930 and 1940, the War Department stated today. Figures were made public in a letter from Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, to Senator Maybank, who had written that he had received many communications calling attention to fatal air accidents and asked the War Department for data.

Although the wholesale markets were relatively quiet this week, a summary of the month's buying activities indicated that orders placed far exceed that of any other year, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Adolf Hitler's restive National Socialist Germany got off to a poor start with the celebration of its tenth birthday this morning when the British in an "impromptu" visit to the capital delayed the first of the day's two main speeches -- one by Reich Marshal Hermann Goering -- for exactly an hour while they gave Berlin some unexpected birthday presents delivered by Mosquito bombers.

CARROLL LANE FENTON has written a number of highly satisfying books about the out-of-doors for the younger children ("Holiday Shore," "Along the Hill" and others). Now he and Mrs. Fenton have made for older boys and girls and for adults a splendidly informing book about the mountains in North America, with special emphasis on the Western ranges.

The Aetna Life Insurance Company and its affiliated companies reported yesterday for 1942 a total premium income of $209,278,373, an increase of $16,167,506 over 1941. Each company in the group showed an increase. Holdings of United States Government bonds by the group on Dec. 31 were $289,054,601, an increase of $49,852,585 during the year.

Just and durable peace on a world basis can be achieved and safeguarded only if the United Nations concept is permanently maintained and remains effective in peacetime, Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States, asserted in an address relayed from Washington to the ninth Opera Victory Rally, which was broadcast over the Blue Network, during the second intermission of the performance of Gounod's "Faust," yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Value of oil rationing coupons for the fourth period in six Northeastern States was slashed again today by the OPA to eight gallons apiece for householders against the previous nine. This means that residents of Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Southern New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will be able to obtain only 160 gallons after midnight tonight on the twenty coupons for the period.

Criminal prosecutions instead of punitive suspensions or "S" orders for firms or individuals accused of violations of War Production Board regulations is planned as the WPB enforcement policy in the future, according to Fraser M. Horn, local WPB regional attorney.
LONDON, Jan. 30 (Reuter) -- Results of today's football matches in the British Isles:
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, Jan. 30 -- The day the Russians heard about the Casablanca meeting of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill they read in their newspapers that more than 10,000 Axis troops had just been captured by the Red Army.

ENGINEERING drawing is the medium through which the engineer expresses his conceptions of machines and other structures in such a manner that his ideas may be readily transformed into useful and economical devices, precisely as he conceived them.
The RAF yesterday gave Berlin its first daylight bombing since the war began. The occasion was symbolic. It was the tenth anniversary of Hitler's assumption of the Chancelorship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The blow-off in Baltimore last Tuesday by "Big Bill" Jeffers, who demanded that Army and Navy "loafers" and so-called "expediters" be kicked out of war plants, focused attention on what, to the rubber director and many others, was a painful fact: one year has passed since the Japanese captured most of the world's rubber supply, and not one ounce of synthetic rubber has been produced under the government synthetic rubber program.

This year's Westminster Kennel Club show will be unusual in various ways. The sixty-seventh annual exhibition will be held in Madison Square Garden Thursday and Friday, Feb. 11 and 12, and although it will be the third time it has been given while the nation has been at war, this is the first time the United States has used dogs with its armed forces.

PT boats are doing gallant work in the Pacific. A report from Guadalcanal tells how these frail plywood craft tear in to loose their torpedoes against battleships, cruisers and destroyers alike. They are credited with having sunk 250,000 tons of enemy shipping in the Guadalcanal area alone -- a hundred times what a fleet of fifty of them would weigh.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 30 -- Plans for intensifying the war against enemy submarines in the South Atlantic were considered here today by United States and Brazilian officers and officials as a result of the conferences this week between President Roosevelt and President Getulio Vargas at Natal.

Private citizens and clerical employes of the company were pressed into service yesterday by J. Henry Esser, president of the Suburban Fuel Oil Service, Inc., of Mount Vernon, to deliver fuel oil in five and ten gallon cans to heatless homes and apartment houses in the upper Bronx and Westchester County when striking truck drivers repudiated an arbitration agreement reached the day before in the offices of the State Mediation Board.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Breaking the official silence about the Ford Motor Company's Willow Run bomber plant, the War Production Board said today:

The report of the Continental Baking Company and its subsidiaries for 1942, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $3,554,508, after Federal income taxes. This is equivalent to $1.46 a share on the outstanding common stock, after preferred dividend requirements.

A FIRST-DAY cover received from Ciudad Trujillo by H. L. Lindquist, philatelic publisher, bears as postage 3-centavos orange, 4c rose and 13c magenta stamps issued by Dominican Republic to commemorate last year's election of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina as President. The series includes also a 1-peso blue.

Long before the war scientists tested both men and airplanes in chambers which made it possible to simulate the conditions that prevail at high altitudes. In an address before the annual meeting of the American Society of Refrigerating Engineers, J.G. Bergdoll Jr., chief engineer for the York Ice Machinery Corporation, disclosed that the steel "strato-chambers" make it possible for engineers to reproduce conditions that prevail eight miles up, which means in the stratosphere.

A big audience listened with contagious enthusiasm last night in Town Hall to what was so accurately described as "the first concert performance of Dargomyzhsky's 'Russalka' in the United States," by Michel Kachouk's Russian Opera Company.
Income from miscellaneous sources, including net profit or loss from partnerships, fiduciary income and other income, must be shown in the Federal income tax returns in item 10, Form 1040.

FOUR shrewd and amusing stories, two short, two of novelette length, make up Mrs. Miller's new book. The law and the police, of which the author had always been fond in a literary way, are important in three of them.

BUCKHILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 30 -- Possessing its best snow conditions in several years, a thick blanket of fourteen inches, the Poconos of Northeastern Pennsylvania today provided superb skiing for a large number of enthusiasts.

MR. BRENNAN is a frequent and highly successful contributor to the popular magazines; the discipline of that hard school has served him well in his new novel. "Memo to a Firing Squad," a tale of international triple-crossing in Lisbon, moves with the compelling rhythm of a machine gun.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The American Foreign Service Journal declared in an editorial today that the State Department had complete confidence in Robert D. Murphy, the American Minister in North Africa, and others in charge there, and that its aim was to cooperate in every possible way with the military authorities there.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration granted today to operators of bituminous mines in Western Pennsylvania an average price increase of about 23 cents a ton.

A CONCERT, a puppet production and an auction of painting for the sale of war bonds will take place this evening at 8:30 o'clock, at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre, Fifty-eighth Street and Sixth Avenue. The event is sponsored by The Group Collective, Moi Solotaroff, director, on behalf of the New York State War Savings Staff of the United States Treasury.

Good main floor and basement trade was reported last week in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coats and suits were active, with dresses fair.
INVITED by Frederic Melcher, editor of the book trade journal Publishers' Weekly, to award a decoration or two for "good publishing" during the past year, a jury has considered and voted.

GREENVILLE, Pa., Jan. 30 -- Use of student activities as apprenticeships in community service and leadership for college men and women is advocated by Dr. William F. Zimmerman, who will be inaugurated as the eleventh president of Thiel College here Tuesday.

Dr. Jose Carrasco, owner of El Diario of La Paz, the oldest newspaper in Bolivia, declared yesterday in an interview that oil wells in his country were not being worked extensively because of a shortage of capital and engineers.

THE New York Eye and Ear Infirmary will be the beneficiary of the performance of Sidney Kingsley's new play, "The Patriots," on Wednesday night at the National Theatre which has been taken over by members of St. Timothy's League to aid the institution.

Several hundred high school students were told yesterday that soon after the close of this war there would be a tremendous boom in aviation that would see most of them riding around in airplanes much as their parents rode automobiles until recently.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 23 Anne O'Hare McCormick gives an authoritative picture of European Nazi-occupied countries where entire populations now exist in a state of semi-starvation. She cites Mr. Hoover's statement that food production is secondary only to military operations in determining the outcome of the war; and that it is foolish to talk of feeding 300,000,000 or 400,000,000 people after the war unless agricultural production in this country is enormously increased.
IN THE NEW YORK TIMES I read an article by William Schuman which intrigued me. It spoke of a new technique in the organization of choruses and a new approach to choral performance.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Admiral Karl Doenitz, Commander in Chief of the German submarine fleet, has been appointed Commander in Chief of the German Naval Forces. He succeeds Grand Admiral Erich Raeder, who has been created Admiral Inspector of the German War Fleet.

Accurate predictions of a student's success in the study of life sciences such as medicine, dentistry and nursing for which zoology is basic, has been made possible through a series of tests developed at the University of Arizona.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Establishment of a "high command" to cope with domestic problems is being considered by President Roosevelt's advisers, and the proposal may be submitted to him for a decision as soon as he clears away some of his more pressing war tasks, it was learned tonight.

THE general pattern of this book is a familiar one. It runs like this: Young man, down and out, answers blind ad, gets a job that promises good pay for very little work, and runs into a lot of trouble. It is a pattern that admits of endless variations, and Mr. Coxe has provided some that make one forget that the pattern is a little shopworn.

SEVERAL hundred uniformed members of the American Women's Voluntary Services will occupy special seats on the platform at the benefit recital to be given tonight at Carnegie Hall by Helen Traubel, Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera.

Willie Pep won perhaps his greatest battle in Madison Square Garden last Friday night when he hammered out a ten-round decision over Allie Stolz in one-sided fashion. He collected his greatest purse for the effort -- $22,000. But, he wound up in disfavor with the New York State Athletic Commission that made him the 126-pound champion even over the objections of his native Connecticut.

That's what always happens to the January thaw. It gets frozen in, or snowed under, or blown right back where it came from. And those who said, "Maybe the Winters are getting warmer," try to control their chattering teeth while they swallow their impetuous words.

PROFESSOR LASKI in his article in last Sunday's TIMES Magazine painted a fanciful picture of British political life. It is the sort of argument which might be put forward in an English bye-election by a political party which had nothing constructive of its own to offer and realized that its only chance of winning the seat lay in reviving ancient prejudices and arousing fears for the future.

Light snow and freezing rain, which put a glazed finish on snow mounds, sidewalks and streets, is expected to give way today to moderate weather while Sanitation Department snow removers concentrate on the much-neglected side streets.

WITH evergreens, particularly with the broad-leaved ones, such as rhododendrons, laurel and the rest of the acid-soil tribe, the danger period for Winter injury lies ahead. The high winds of late February and March; late Winter thaws, followed by sudden drops in temperature, and sleet storms are all possible causes of injury.

In an effort to stabilize post-war industrial conditions through a unified procurement policy, the government is currently working out a single, uniform cancellation clause to be used by all procurement agencies, each of which at the present time has its own particular clause, it was learned here last week.

AMERICAN book production for 1942, as was expected early in the year, shows a definite decrease from 1941. The Annual Summary Number of Publishers' Weekly gives the number of books published last year as 9,525, as against 11,112 for 1941.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Major Joseph Triner, former president of the National Boxing Association and chairman of the Illinois State Athletic Commission, believes boxing will have a tremendous boom after the war, with new talent coming from the armed forces.

WITH the death on Jan. 19 of Grace M. Schirmer, in her eighty-seventh year, the musical world of New York lost a very remarkable personality, Mrs. Schirmer was the widow of Gustave Schirmer, the second of a dynasty of music publishers to bear that name.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- For the present there is a deadlock between General Charles de Gaulle, leader of Fighting France, and General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa.

OTTAWA, Jan. 30 -- Up in the back regions of Quebec Province a power development is nearing completion that rivals Boulder Dam both in guaranteed power and speed of construction. For many months it has been a "hush-hush" war mystery not to be written about.

The suit of the Office of Price Administration here for $750,000 triple damages against A.D. Juilliard Co., Inc., of 40 West Fortieth Street, for alleged violation of ceiling prices, was settled yesterday with the announcement that the government had received a check for $410,219 and that the company had signed a consent decree under which it agreed not to violate the provisions of the maximum price regulation covering woolen and worsted civilian fabrics.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 30 (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in French North and West Africa, indicated today that he regarded the political situation in North Africa as closely linked to the military position "but not under any circumstances more important."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- The study of the liberal arts, although curtailed for the duration, "will gain new life and vigor in meeting the challenge of total war," Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan, said today at Princeton University's first mid-Winter commencement exercises.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -Pennsylvania's five defeated the Army at the Palestra tonight, 39 -- 28. It was the eighth straight for the Red and Blue, the only setback being in the opening game against Aberdeen Proving Grounds.

SHERIFF JESSE RODEN of Deer Lick, Ky., is a backwoodsman, and he uses the skills that backwoodsmen have in tracking down criminals, just as he would use them in tracking game. Much of his life has been spent in the woods with dog and gun and he has become expert in reading the signs that show what creatures have passed and what they have been doing.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP) -- The story of a man and woman who lived through fifty-one days in a lifeboat while all of their fifteen companions died was told here today by a young British maritime officer, survivor of an Axis torpedoing.

IT seems that Sir Henry Merrivale ("H.M." to his friends) once played rugger for Cambridge. In order to convince his friend Paul Ferrars what a great player he was, H.M. puts on a demonstration and fractures his big toe.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Resistance to "collaboration" is a hydra. For every head lopped off, two spring up.

Any consumer, industrial, commercial or private who, being without oil, as a result faces a serious threat to health or property, may buy up to fifty gallons of fuel oil even if he is without coupons valid currently, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive, announced yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- Success capped the performances of a majority of the Army indoor sports squads operating on their home front today against intercollegiate rivals.

THAT the propaganda broadcasts of the United Nations have Joe Goebbels, the Reich clown, in a fine frenzy is testified to this morning by firsthand evidence from Czechoslovakia. It takes the form of a copy of the May 30 issue of Lidove Noviny, once Prague's leading daily but now a Nazi organ, which was obtained by the short-wave department of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

At every one of them, despite the silk hats and bouquets, there are men who stand with crossed fingers, sweaty brows and a tight feeling around the collar.

ONCE again Hilda Vaughan uses the Wales she knows and loves for the background of her novel and once again she has written a story distinguished for its poetic expression and sensitive exploration of the human heart.

MR. HATCH splits his new book in the middle, the first story being about a singing Cinderella and the second about a show girl with dramatic ambitions. The first is less entertaining than the second, unless the reader happens to be a devotee of swing.

Sister Elizabeth Kenny of Australia, whose method of treating infantile paralysis cases has won widespread acclaim, was the guest of honor yesterday at a party given by the City Council in its chamber at City Hall to celebrate President Roosevelt's sixty-first birthday.

Prices of cotton for future delivery declined yesterday 5 to 17 points on the New York Cotton Exchange. Buying support failed to follow up the expected increase in parity prices of agricultural products and commission houses took profits.

Play in the invitation squash racquets double tournament for the Lockett Trophy came down to the semi-final round yesterday on the courts of the University Club.
Sidney Kingsley, Pulitzer Prize playwright, has gone back to the beginnings of American democracy for "The Patriots," a play about Thomas Jefferson.

IN spite of the sharp increases brought about by scare buying a year ago, January trade volume has managed to keep ahead of last year's figures on a country-wide basis. The gain is small, but in general merchandise it matches the price rise over twelve months and therefore means that about the same physical volume of goods is moving.

QUIESCENT for the past fortnight, except for several promises of future activities, the New York night club impresarios are once again busying themselves with more immediate projects. JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 30 -- In a complex political manoeuvre that may have far-reaching effects on the feud between Governor Charles Edison and Mayor Frank Hague, the Governor announced today an alliance with Mayor Bernard N. McFeely of Hoboken, who for many years has been the leader of one of the major wings in the Hague Democratic organization.

SHORTLY before the close of his long career, Sir Isaac Newton is said to have summed up his achievements in these words: "I seem to have been only like a boy playing on the seashore, and diverting myself in now and then finding a smoother pebble or a prettier shell than ordinary, whilst the great ocean of truth lay all undiscovered before me."

A $50,000,000 post-war construction program for the Bronx was announced yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons. Studies and plans now under way contemplate a comprehensive modern arterial highway system, asphalt plant, and trunk and relieving sewers in many sections.

Friendship between the United States and China has increased steadily in the last hundred years, and at present it is as strong, if not stronger, than it ever has been in the past, Dr. Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, former Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday at the forty-seventh annual luncheon of the Cornell Women's Club of New York held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Yachtsmen, new and old, and every other kind of pleasure boatman who is training for war service will probably flock in droves into the free instruction classes in visual signaling which will begin Tuesday night under the auspices of the New York Power Squadron, H.B. Oakes, heading the committee, has designated Room 218 at 45 Broadway for the session, and the hours from 7 to 9 o'clock will be devoted to learning about maritime communications.

DIMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH wrote his String Quartet, 0p. 49, in 1938, which places it in the period of the Fifth symphony and piano Quintet. As far as is known, it is his only quartet. The Stuyvesant String Quartet, which has just recorded it (Columbia X-231, two twelve-inch records) has given as many as thirty-five performances of the work in a single season.

BITUMINOUS -- Soft coal -- just to console those householders who are reduced to the necessity of burning it in their furnaces -- needn't be sooty. Install a stoker, if you can, the bituminous coal experts advise, and water the coal (yes, actually sprinkle it generously with water) before you add it to the fire.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 30 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval of France now has his own Elite Guards. They wear khaki shirts with a black armband, like the Germans. The formal organization of this "French militia" was announced in Vichy today when the service d'Ordre Legionnaire received that name.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 30 -- William Phillips, President Roosevelt's special Ambassador, has stepped into India like a Daniel into the lions' den and, so far, neither the British nor the Indian lions have done him any harm. They are hardly likely to harm him, either, since both desperately want the understanding and sympathy of the United States in a situation where much sincerity and strong arguments are found on both sides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The War Production Board announced today that it has completed mailing Controlled Materials Plan inventory report forms to the more than 30,000 Production Requirements Plan units, many of which will begin operations under the CMP on April 1, when this new plan goes into effect.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied commander in chief in this area, emphasized today that in political as well as military matters the British and American staffs here were in complete accord.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Six additional Japanese ships, including a destroyer, have been sunk and a seventh damaged by United States submarines operating in Pacific and Far Eastern waters, the Navy Department announced in a communique tonight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30 -- Princeton's good basketball team made things perfect tonight for the crowd here for the Tigers' first wartime graduation when it upset Dartmouth and gained a victory in its Eastern Intercollegiate League debut, 44 to 39.

Industries in the New York area continued their drive to get in scrap of all kinds for war production by turning over 54,925,450 pounds during the first month of 1943, it was announced yesterday by Rolland J. Hamilton of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Equipment Company, chairman of the Industrial Salvage Committee here.

A VERY modernized Japanese, speaking flawless English, an authority on transportation problems, was once being entertained at luncheon by the editors of an American magazine. The Japanese seemed to think so entirely in contemporary terms that one of the hosts ventured to put a half jocular question:

IN his preface Mr. Klein states that he "has attempted to fill the need for a reference and instruction book, with supplementary descriptive literature, concerning the processes, methods and materials employed in the aircraft industry."

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- There are many indications that this fourth year of war -- the present conditions and future plans taken together -- means for education in Great Britain something which, if it cannot be called the beginning of the end of social revolution, may be called the end of the beginning.

A new plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company has been drafted, but so far has been submitted only to the first and refunding committee and to certain junior interests, according to a joint statement issued yesterday by a committee headed by J.W. Stedman and the Alleghany Corporation, in which the Robert R. Young interests are the controlling factors.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Despite the invasion of the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command and the Coast Guard, which have taken over all of the luxury hotels along the Boardwalk, Atlantic City is still busily playing host to its numerous visitors, for whom, according to a recent survey, there are still 10,000 rooms available.

SEPARATE plantings of vegetables, flowers and herbs are a comparatively modern design in horticulture. The earliest gardens of this country were planned with the European idea of getting the greatest possible use out of space available.

President Roosevelt's sixty-first birthday was observed yesterday all over the United States with parties and other celebrations marking the culmination of this year's drive for funds and the March of Dimes for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Two hundred members of the Norwegian Seamen's Association, an affiliate of the International Transport Workers Federation, voted last week to refuse to register in the Norwegian seamen's pool here after tomorrow unless a satisfactory arrangement is made with their government regarding maintenance pay in port.

CERTAIN crabbed members of human society, looking over the crude beginnings of animal social life as described by Professor Hooton, may find a scornful excuse for mankind's misdeeds, saying: "Well, what can you expect of man, seeing that he is but a little way removed from these low origins?"
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The text of Adolf Hitler's proclamation to the German people, a broadcast from Berlin and recorded here today, follows:

CHICAGOANS not long ago were amazed by the spectacle of huge lines of people who streamed for blocks across a drawbridge over the winding Chicago River. It was slushy underfoot; the sky was heavy with snow clouds; a bitter wind swept through the huddled ranks that started many of them dancing.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 30 -- Barbara Ann Headford, 11-year-old daughter of an ordnance plant worker, is getting her long-awaited puppy tomorrow, but it took a letter to President Roosevelt and the interest of Brig. Gen. R.E. Hardy of the Ordnance Department to swing the deal.

SUMMER squash, while not too highly advocated by the nutrition experts, has several good points to recommend it for the home garden. It grows very rapidly, yields heavily in proportion to the space occupied, if bush varieties are used, and makes an easily prepared dish which many persons find most acceptable.
Mayor La Guardia, the city's most eminent and faithful fire buff, told a group of firemen yesterday that he doesn't like fires, but goes to them out of a sense of duty.

Back home after the most disastrous road trip in the history of the team, the Rangers will seek to prove that they are not as bad as the records indicate when they tackle the Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Although overtime pay has appreciably increased salaries which the goverment can offer to secretaries, stenographers and typists, the Civil Service Commission says that demands for such workers are greater than the supply.

S.J. PERELMAN is no Peter Bell. A primrose by a river's brim would never be just a yellow primrose to him. It would always be something more. Likely enough in no time at all it would become a gigantic yellow sunflower, malevolently gnashing its teeth at him, and you too.

The President and Prime Minister and their combined staffs, having completed their plans for the offensive campaigns of 1943, have now separated in order to put them into active and concerted execution.

LARGE-FLOWERING hybrid clematis, herbaceous perennials of the buttercup and anemone family, are among the most effective climbers that the amateur horticulturist can grow to add distinction to his garden.

NOVICES in the literary craft sometimes ask editors to give them a start by sending them books for review. They believe, in their innocence, that this kind of work can be undertaken successfully by a prentice hand.

The United States Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service reported from overseas that at 10:25 o'clock yesterday morning, Eastern wartime, German propagandists in Berlin sent out a Morse code message to German newspaper editors ordering them to use the following headlines on Reichsfuehrer Hitler's proclamation:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Gingerly at first, then with growing gusto, Vice President Wallace, members of Congress and officials sampled fricasseed muskrat today and smacked their lips. They met in a Capitol dining room to see if it was true what they say in one part of Dixie that the Louisiana swamprat is good for more than his fur.

THE current exhibition of oils and water-colors by Lyonel Feininger -- all executed since his seventieth anniversary show two years ago -- includes some of the best work of the artist's long career. Most of the paintings are highly characteristic, but here and there an example reveals that this young-old painter is still innovating, still courageously experimenting.

LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP) -- A new Allied command set-up in North Africa, which would leave General Eisenhower as supreme commander with a group of British "specialists" working under him, was forecast today by The News Chronicle's North African correspondent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Bowling, the occasional or steady pastime of 12,000,000 Americans, is due for some hard blows before the war is much older.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 -- Wheat and rye parted company today on the Board of Trade, the former advancing 5/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel and closing at the top, while rye turned reactionary and lost 1/2 to 5/8 cent after being off 1 cent at the extreme.

At last we have a modern, attractive book, authoratively written, on our own native shrubs. The author of "Ornamental American Shrubs" is a biologist in the United States Department of Agriculture. As such he has worked on the problem of using native plants for soil conservation in all parts of the country.

THE conflict between good and evil is, of course, an old subject in fiction. Mr. Herbert Whiting gives us a new variation on the theme in "The Listeners," a first novel of unusual quality. Evil has definite and active powers of communication; the presence of Eve Massingley all but disrupted the Massingley household, which but for her would have been blissfully happy.

THE author has done something which too few writers of technical and semi-technical books can bring themselves to do. Instead of remembering always that he must impress the reader with his own great knowledge, Mr. Goad has sat down to tell about Diesel engines, and he has done a very good job.
LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique: During Jan. 30, troops of the

LOUIS D'ANGELO'S twenty-fifth anniversary as a singer at the Metropolitan Opera will be observed with ceremony at a forthcoming production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville." That opera has been chosen because it contains the role that the Italian-American baritone likes best of all the 300 parts in his repertoire -- that of Dr. Bartolo. He will sing it at the performance. And his colleagues are preparing a "surprise" for the occasion.

REPORTS that Paramount and Vera Zorina had reached a parting of the ways were confirmed the other day by the dancer-actress. She said the parting was amicable, that she is considering film offers from other studios and that she also desires to do a play on Broadway.

WHAT with wartime Washington overcrowded as it is, the National Folk Festival Association has decided not to attempt to hold its annual session there this Spring, as it has done for the past five years, but to move it to Philadelphia instead.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- In a recapitulation of Wednesday's heavy daylight raid on Wilhelmshaven and Emden, Germany, by United States Flying Fortresses and Liberators, the headquarters of the United States Army Eighth Air Force announced today that a re-examination of the results showed twenty-two German fighter planes had been destroyed for a loss of three American bombers.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Montreal had to be content with a 3-to-3 deadlock tonight in a National Hockey League game with the Red Wings, the invaders coming back to even the count after the Canadiens had held a 3-to-0 advantage.
LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The Daily Express said today in its leading editorial that President Roosevelt had "won an enduring and an endearing place in the hearts of all free and progressive peoples."

Branch Rickey, still shedding snow from his recent polar expedition to Bear Mountain, saw another of his Dodger mainstays swept away for the duration when word was received from Louisville yesterday that Harold (Peewee) Reese, brilliant young shortstop, had enlisted in the Navy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ONE of the outstanding features of the tenth annual Brotherhood Week program of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, to be held Feb. 19 to 28, will be a concert of rare choral and instrumental music on Feb. 23 at the Town Hall.

A canine vaccine, described as a new single-injection method of protecting dogs against distemper, "their worst enemy," is announced by Dr. E. Fanslau, director of the veterinary division of the Winthrop Chemical Company. About $1,000,000 has been spent in research to achieve this result.

Assailing "reactionary interests" who, "under a false plea of economy, are urging the curtailment or abolition of the Farm Security Administration program," Courtenay Dinwiddie, general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, issued a report yesterday commending the services of the FSA in helping low income families to independence, making it possible for their children to get an education, to have an adequate diet and receive medical care.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 31 -- German tanks, infantry and artillery brushed aside a small French force defending Faid Pass, on the road between Sfax and Sbeitla in Central Tunisia, yesterday and advanced about six and a half miles beyond the pass.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Awarding nine Air Medals and two Oak Leaf Clusters to United States airmen today, Brig. Gen. Frank O.'D. Hunter, Chief of the Eighth United States Army Air Force Fighter Command, predicted the end of the German air force as a fighting group this year.

Beginning today, no truck will be permitted to run out from metropolitan New York or Northern New Jersey with less than capacity load unless it has "rolling papers" certifying that the trucking industry's clearance office has been unable to assemble a full cargo.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 31 -- A premature touch of Spring skiing came to the popular Poconos of Northeastern Pennsylvania today, brilliant sunshine drenching the slopes and trails which were blanketed with twelve to fourteen inches of settled powder snow.

Idle for more than two weeks, the Columbia basketball team swings back into action tonight on its home court, clashing with Dartmouth, defending champion in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. Although upset by Princeton on Saturday night, the Indians from Hanover are favored to down the Lions.

SEATTLE, Jan. 31 -- At least twenty-eight persons were burned to death and several more were believed to have perished today in a fire which swept through a sanitarium for invalids just outside Seattle.

Last February the Supreme Court handed down a decision declaring that certain union members, though clearly guilty of threats and violence to obtain money, were nevertheless immune from the present Federal Anti-Racketeering Act. Chief Justice Stone described the facts of the case as follows:

When the telephone rings at WAlker 5-5038, it means a housewife is complaining about the meat shortage. Since the Food Distribution Administration opened a bureau at 145 Hudson Street two days ago as a service to women trying to cope with food shortages, inquiries have poured in from the far corners of Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Many new and vital materials will be available for the needs of industrial America after the war, Lammot du Pont, chairman of the board of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of Wilmington, Del., declared today in a special address to American fighting forces overseas.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Navigation was much easier afloat than on land today. There was no snow, not even ice on the water, so the dinghy sailors carried on happily at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Arthur Knapp was the winner with his boat Popcorn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Conflicting influences tended last week to slow trading in cash wheat and futures, and prices held within relatively narrow limits. Support was in evidence around $1.39 a bushel for the May delivery on the Board of Trade, and above $1.40 there appeared to be plenty for sale.

Every day of the war brings a greater drain on the registered nurse personnel of the city, Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich, vice chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, said in a statement issued yesterday.
According to the opinion of seafaring people from the skipper down to the messboy there is only one thing that will lick the submarines, and that is speed and more speed.

Helen Traubel, the Metropolitan soprano, was heard in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. Now that Kirsten Flagstad has departed from this country, no other woman vocalist appearing before the public on this side of the Atlantic can rival Miss Traubel in volume and expansiveness of tone.

Hitler's ten years of power have made a decade of mourning for Jews throughout the world. Each year, as the Nazi persecution spread from Germany across the map of Europe, the burden of relieving misery and suffering fell more heavily on the Jews of America.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Because a 72-year-old retired Chicago merchant, who was a major in the last war, adhered to his lifelong practice of keeping himself in top physical condition, he is in service in the current conflict as an able-bodied seaman.

The recent epidemic of galoshes, snow plows and sniffles is sufficient reminder of the fact that Winter is still with us. The peak-season period for the common cold is about to begin, according to the statistics of the Department of Health) and wind-roughened skins are seen on every hand.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- Dick Werner of Paterson, N.J., and Miss Carmelita Landry of Fitchburg, Mass., who have swept just about all competition in the East this Winter, triumphed again today in the New York State speed-skating championships.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Canadiens executed a lightning assault of three goals in thirty-seven seconds against the National Hockey League's leading net-minder, Johnny Mowers, to beat the second-place Red Wings, 4 to 3, before 12,318 tonight.

A warning against the "one-class church" was uttered yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, as guest speaker at the silver jubilee celebration of the Fort George Presbyterian Church, West 186th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

The great milk bottle mystery, or what happens to 500,000,000 glass containers a year that are not returned to the milk companies, may be cleared up, leaders in the industry said last night, by the government's bottle-deposit order that becomes effective throughout the nation today.

There was drama at the Nazis' celebration of the tenth anniversary of their rule -- high drama surpassing anything that these past masters of showmanship had ever staged or seen before. But it was drama in reverse -- drama provided by their enemies who now direct the play.

Flotation of the largest Canadian loan since 1930 lifted the total of new bonds offered here in January for public subscription to $160,901,000 for thirteen issues, the largest figure for any month since April, when $261,352,000 in twenty-six issues reached the market.

"The Barber Had Two Sons," a drama about Nazi-conquered Norway, will open tonight at the Playhouse under the production auspices of Jess Smith. Heading the cast is Blanche Yurka. Others in the drama include Richard Powers, Tutta Rolf, Walter Brooke, Wolfgang Zilzer, Fairfax Burgher, Edit Angold, J. Arthur Young, Anthony Blair, Anita Vengay, Maurice Minnick, Alfred Zeisler and Richard O'Connor.
SOMEWHERE IN TUNISIA, Jan. 29 (Delayed), (Canadian Press) -- The Germans have brought new monster tanks called Tigers to Tunisia, evidently in an effort to bolster the morale of Axis troops here.

ON MANOUVRES IN LOUISIANA, Jan. 31 -- Out of the myriad of United States Army units none can be found with greater incentive, or determination, to achieve distinction in coming warfare than the 302d Engineer Combat Battalion, of "New York's Own" Seventy-seventh Division, which is on manouvres in this State.

Undoubtedly, the striking event of last week was the unexpected visit to the African front by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, and their conference with the rival leaders of the French troops. Beyond surprise by the public at the incident, and beyond the accompanying assurance that plans were being made for attack on the Nazi strongholds in Central and Western Europe, no fresh information was imparted.

Post-war reconversion problems that credit and financial executives must anticipate were outlined by the committee on post-war credits of the National Association of Credit Men, in the ten-point agenda released today for a series of study meetings to be held during the coming weeks by its 120 local affiliated associations throughout the country.
William C. Foster, in 24 W 55th St; Eleanor Dallale, in 39 W 55th St; Mrs. G.N. Colin, in 301 E 21st St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

At a time when the streets of Eastern cities have come to resemble wide open spaces, parking problems may seem to be a somewhat academic business. But it is a good moment to catch our breath and look ahead. The Eno Foundation for Highway Traffic Control has published a study of vehicular parking which is based on broad research.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Hamburg was the Royal Air Force's target last night and a force of heavy bombers bored through gales, electric storms and icing clouds to reach it.

The Bruins showed the Rangers no mercy in their National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. Jumping at the hapless Blue Shirts for two goals within the first minute of play, the Boston skaters went on to bury the last-place New Yorkers under a one-sided score, 7 -- 2.

Dr. Alberto Guani, Uruguayan Foreign Minister and Vice President-elect, arrived early yesterday morning from Canada, where he spent three days as official guest of the government. He was greeted here by diplomatic officials, who included the Uruguayan Consul General, Santiago Rivas Costa, while a police escort stood at attention.

In its first change of ownership in more than seventy-five years the property 159-61 Mercer Street has been sold by the estate of Seligman H. Strouse to the Mayflower Show Case Company. It consists a five-story building on a lot 44 by 100 feet and is assessed at $19,000, of which $14,500 is land value. Jerome Tanenbaum was the broker in the sale.

Three masterpieces of the instrumental ensemble literature were expertly presented by the Kolisch Quartet, assisted by Josefa Rosanka, pianist, at the concert of the New Friends of music, given late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The stock markets failed to respond as expected to the big news of last week. Rumors of pending important developments from the meeting of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill caused a tense atmosphere but the results of the Casablanca conference produced little stimulus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Edward J. Flynn announced tonight that he was asking President Roosevelt to withdraw his nomination as Minister to Australia and National Ambassador to the Southern Pacific area.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Only organized labor can provide jobs for demobilized soldiers, R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), declared tonight in a formal reply to the speech that Captain E.V. Rickenbacker made here Jan. 22.

Cliff Sutter and Joe McGuire of the Greenwich Country Club annexed top honors in the Lockett Trophy invitation doubles squash racquets tournament, completed yesterday at the university Club. They defeated Germain Glidden, former national amateur singles titleholder, and Joe Holmes of the Englewood Field Club, 15 -- 3, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 10, in the final.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- David J. Lewis, chairman of the National Mediation Board, announced today that he planned to retire to private life tomorrow at the expiration of his term. Mr. Lewis, former Maryland Representative in Congress, wrote to President Roosevelt that he would not seek reappointment to the board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Export-Import Bank of Washington, of which Jesse H. Jones is chairman and Warren Lee Pierson is president, has reported that at the close of 1942 it had undivided profits of $20,790,553. For the calendar year of 1942 the bank had earnings of $7,544,080.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The "Congress plan" to create an over-all civilian Office of War Mobilization, headed by a director and four administrators, who would have an edge of power over the military authorities, will be reintroduced tomorrow in the Senate with the formal backing of ten Senators, Democrats and Republicans, Senators Kilgore and Pepper, its original sponsors, announced tonight.

The enterprising supporters of the New Opera Company do not like the sight of talent hanging around unused, and they make it their business to do something toward employing it when they can. The company completed its season some weeks ago, and its current business is the Broadway run of "Rosalinda."

After forty-three years as rector of St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church at 120 West Sixty-ninth Street, the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Seagle announced yesterday from his pulpit that he had tendered his resignation and had been elected rector emeritus. He was 74 years old on Dec. 24.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- General Henri Honore Giraud in a telegram to President Roosevelt today expressed the gratitude which he said Overseas France felt for "the decisive help of the United States." France now, he said, "can accomplish the mission that is hers and free Metropolitan France."
