SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Jan. 31 -- A pile of charred wreckage lying in a canyon at the foot of a steep cliff near Boonville, about 115 miles north of San Francisco, today marked flight's end for the big Navy seaplane missing for ten days on a hop from Pearl Harbor to San Francisco.

A plan for obtaining maximum transportation between New York and New Jersey is needed in connection with the conservation of gasoline and rubber, Commissioner Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port Planning Committee, Port of New York Authority, said yesterday in a report on an analysis of essential interstate traffic in the metropolitan area.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A communique:
CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Mine operators are expected to make "strong representations" this Spring for higher prices for Lake Superior iron ore, the magazine Steel said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- General Vittorio Ambrosio, Chief of the Army Staff and former commander of the Second Italian Army in the Balkans, has been named to be chief of the Italian General Staff by Premier Benito Mussolini, according to a communique issued at Rome today, after Marshal Ugo Cavallero had resigned the post, according to the announcement, "of his own demand."
Taxable real estate in Manhattan, including real estate of utilities, is tentatively assessed on the rolls for 1943-44 at a total of $7,264,715,985, showing a decrease of $90,501,550 from last year.

IN Charlestown, Mass., customers who patronize the Snappy Dress Shoppe probably do not often take time out to ponder the fact that an event of the first magnitude in the history of their country and the world took place on the same site 152 years ago. It was the birth in 1791 of Samuel Finley Breese Morse, Yankee aristocrat, inventor of the electromagnetic telegraph, distinguished painter, versatile jack of many other trades.

Recommendations for a five-point program to stabilize and control the supply, distribution and price of meat in New York and the nation at large were made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia's fact-finding committee, which on Friday reported that the meat industry was in an unorganized and chaotic condition, with chiseling widespread, prices too high and black market practices on the increase.

Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., as special agents, have notified holders of City of Porto Alegre (United States of Brazil) forty-year, 7 per cent sinking-fund gold bonds external loan of 1928 that funds have been deposited sufficient to pay 13.975 per cent of the face amount of the coupons due on Aug. 1,1940, amounting to $4.89 1/8 for each $35 coupon and 2.44 9-16 for each $17.50 coupon.

I am not sure there is profit in discussing the feelings of the recent combatants after the peace conference at Shimonoseki, which ended the first Sino-Japanese War, or yet the talks at Portsmouth, N.H., which, under the auspices of President Theodore Roosevelt, terminated the Russo-Japanese conflict.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Netherland churches have combined once more to protest against the mounting tide of executions in German-occupied Netherlands, Reichscommissar Arthur Seyss-Inquart announced in a broadcast today in which he declared that, nevertheless, the execution of Netherlanders accused of hampering the German war effort would continue unabated and might even be expected to increase.

Coffee retailers and wholesalers who were unable, because of supply shortage and uneven distribution of coffee stocks, to build up their inventories to the full amount allowed them at the start of rationing, now may obtain ration certificates to replenish their stocks, it was announced yesterday by E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive of the Office of Pride Administration.

Luigi Antonini, president of the Italian-American Labor Council, issued a statement yesterday absolving Alan Cranston, chief of the Foreign Language Division of the Office of War Information, and Lee Falk, an official of the division, of charges that they have sought to promote the inclusion of Communists in the formation of an Italian-American Victory Council in this city.

Rear Admiral Robert H. English, commander of the Pacific Fleet's submarine force, won official commendation for his conduct of submarine operations in the Pacific. His death is regarded as a severe blow to the naval service, for his wide knowledge of submarine warfare was expected to prove invaluable to those entrusted with perfecting this country's defense against U-boat depredations in both the Atlantic and the Pacific.

A special feature of the Metropolitan Opera season's twelfth week, starting next Monday night, Feb. 8, will be the opening of the Tuesday night uncut cycle of Wagner's "Ring" with a performance of "Das Rheingold" in which Friedrich Schorr will sing Wotan for the last time.

The note of desperation running through Hitler's tenth anniversary proclamation -- "in this war there will be neither victor nor vanquished, but only those who survive those who are destroyed" -- echoed in the speeches of Goering and Goebbels. Private reports from Berlin sound an even louder note of urgent alarm.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The grim tone of the bomb-accompanied pronouncements by Marshal Goering and Dr. Goebbels was considered by politeal quarters here today as the most significant feature of yesterday's Nazi party celebration in Berlin.

"Italia tradita" -- "Italy betrayed" -- were words written in his own handwriting by Arturo Toscanini into the score of Verdi's "Hymn of the Nations," composed for orchestra, chorus and solo voices, heard for the first time in America under his conductorship at the NBC Symphony concert given yesterday afternoon in Studio H-8 in Radio City, and from there broadcast to the Americas and to the world.

The item in newspapers of Jan. 24 that labor unions will demand higher wages on the ground that the cost of living has increased is disturbing. It is a logical result of the many promises which have been made to organized labor, but there is no power to give labor the standards of living which those demanding higher wages aim to provide by this process.

While the British Eighth Army was fighting its way westward across Libya and Tunisia, an American contingent was constantly with that army, sharing the heat, the cold, the dust, the privations and the shellfire. It was the American Field Service, the volunteer ambulance corps, which for many months has been working with the British and the Fighting French.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in North Africa, Jan. 31 -- The last-minute rescue by British destroyers that had sunk a submarine carrying five American airmen to an Italian prison camp was described today by Fighter Pilot J.C. Lentz, 25 years old, of Paris, Texas, one of three survivors flown here.

The Petroleum Corporation of America, an investment company, had, on Dec. 31, net assets equivalent to $7.12 a share, according to its report. Taking into account, however, the value of the one-fifth share of Consolidated Oil Corporation common which was distributed to shareholders on May 15, last, the net asset value was $8.49.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 31 -- Two distinguished naval spokesmen -- Vice Admiral Sir Alban Curteis, senior British naval officer in the Western Atlantic, and Rear Admiral Jules James, commandant of the United States naval operating base here -- emphasized the need for continued vigilance in Bermuda at the annual dinner of the Speaker of the Assembly Friday night.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, Nazi Germany's wily submarine warfare wizard, assumed command of the German Navy today with the prompt declaration that every ounce of German sea power was to be thrown into the submarine war against the Allies.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, back from a two-week aerial tour of the Pacific that took him to the Guadalcanal battlefront and subjected him to two air raids, met the press here today full of confidence that the Americans have proved themselves masters of the Japanese, and that resistance on Guadalcanal will end in thirty days.

The home must accept the greatest part of the blame for juvenile delinquency, Mgr. Bryan J. McEntagert, National Director of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Former President Herbert Hoover praised the American theatre for its contribution to the war last night in a brief speech to members of the Lambs at their clubhouse, 128 West Forty-fourth Street, where he was guest of John Golden, theatrical producer and Shepherd of the club, at the midwinter gambol.

Although the volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the first month of the year was slightly below that of December, the total for January was the largest for any corresponding month since 1939. The volume, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 18,032,142 shares, compared with 19,312,762 shares in the previous month and with 12,993,875 shares in January of 1942.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- I should dislike to start another wartime argument -- but there are indications that men are better housekeepers than women. And especially is this so when it comes to mass-scale housekeeping of the sort necessary on a troop transport.

The current $2,000,000 campaign of the United Yugoslav Relief Fund has been formally endorsed by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, it was announced yesterday by the fund's national headquarters at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street. The fund had previously been approved by the President's War Relief Control Board.

MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP) -- About three weeks ago two giant Flying Clippers, escorted by Army bombers, took off from the near-by Dinner Key seaplane base bearing President Roosevelt and his party to the Casablanca meeting with Prime Minister Churchill.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 110.2 to 110.3. The farm products index rose .8 per cent, because increases in the prices of oranges, apples, grains and potatoes exceeded the decline in lamb.

Two widely divergent official pronouncements have just been made on German bonds -- whether they are worthless, or whether they eventually will have some value -- and investors in the United States holding more than $800,000,000 of these obligations, stand to profit, oddly enough, on either view.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Owners and representatives of the Western Association, one of the oldest Class C baseball leagues in the country, voted unanimously at a meeting today to suspend operations during "the present national emergency."

Taxable real estate and special franchises in New York City are valued at $16,058,686,836 on the tentative assessment rolls for 1943-1944, indicating a decrease of $53,287,619 from the final figure of $16,111,974,455 for 1942-43.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The men who bombed Berlin by daylight for the first time in history told about it today in tones suggesting a teatime conversation about the weather.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The midday communique of the Soviet Information Bureau as recorded by the Soviet Monitor:

The National Association of Manufacturers in a statement released for publication today recommends the public recording of several types of patent license agreements, including those of an international character. At the same time, the association stated that it was opposed to any legislation which would hamper legitimate patent agreements either within the United States or between United States citizens and foreigners.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 31 -- Carmen Miranda will be starred by Twentieth Century-Fox in a Technicolor musical, "Mexico City," which, according to the studio announcement, will be produced in collaboration with the Mexican Government and with considerable footage filmed below the border.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Extension of the service of Red Cross volunteer nurse's aides to Army general and station hospitals has been requested by Major Gen. James C. Magee, Army Surgeon General, and will be put into effect, it was announced today by Mrs. Walter Lippmann, national director of the Volunteer Nurse's Aide Corps.

ANOTHER of the fabled heroes of the misty and glamorous past moved on last week when Joe Choynski died. But his memory will be ever green and the stories about him legion. The Californian was that fighting freak of a bygone era, a scholar, a scientific boxer and a gentleman, in days when pugilism had few who could boast such qualities.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- A thirty-five-mile advance toward Krasnodar from Kropotkin, indicated by last night's announcement of the capture of Ladojskaya on the Kuban River, the complete clearing of the Maikop oil fields by a two-pronged advance from the Black Sea and the fall of Tikhoretsk have reduced the German hold on Russia south of the Don River to a dangerous narrow salient with one flank uncomfortably against the Black and Azov Seas.

The seven colleges that make up the heptagonal group will all be represented in Saturday's Millrose A.A. games in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday. They are Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth and Penn.

Artists cannot work when the light goes out. The darkness of the depression which touched bottom in 1933 almost extinguished art in this country, especially that which was just in the bud. It was then that Edward Bruce lighted a beam which for years to come will cast its reflection on some of our most vigorous painting and sculpture.

Among the many problems perplexing housewives nowadays, the most teasing, perhaps, is one that might be termed "How to serve meat when you can't get it." For, unfortunately, supplies continue to be scant, and the good old standbys, such as steaks and chops and roasts, are decidedly among the missing.

Sacrificing her desire to meet the President upon his return to Washington, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night kept a promise to talk about "our coming, victory over the Axis" before 2,000 persons, including 400 standees, who filled every corner of Cooper Union.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Year-end figures in connection with Britain's war nursery scheme show that a quarter of a million children under 5 are now getting daytime care in nurseries and play centers while their mothers are at work in munition plants, shipyards and other industries.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The Black Hawks blew a 3-1 lead in a furious last period tonight and Toronto skated off with a 3-3 tie in a National Hockey League game in the Chicago Stadium before 14,769 spectators.

The American Institute of Graphic Arts plans an exhibit of books produced by lithography and has invited publishers and lithographers to submit books for inclusion. Selection of books for the exhibit will be made on the basis of technical excellence, physical attractiveness, suitability to purpose and the success with which the planner and producer have fulfilled the intentions of the publisher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Army Air Forces were accused today of "reactionary policies and discriminatory practices" against Negroes in a statement by William H Hastie, former Federal judge and law-school dean, explaining his resignation as civilian aide to Secretary Stimson.
A net increase in the total value of Richmond taxable real estate of $3,158,735 is reported on the 1943-44 tentative assessment rolls made public yesterday by the City Tax Commissiou.

The Dessoff Choirs, Paul Boepple conductor, who never give hackneyed programs, and whose concerts cannot be replaced by any others in the musical life of this city, repeated their admirable custom when they gave a concert by composers of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries last night in Town Hall.

The inclusion in the peace treaty of a program under international supervision to facilitate the voluntary settlement elsewhere of nationals who are forced by economic conditions to emigrate from war-devastated countries was recommended yesterday in a statement of principle adopted at the annual meeting of the American Jewish Committee, held at the Hotel Astor.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- Mobilization of the German adult population for total warfare is being pushed with all the official force behind the decrees of Fritz Sauckel, the Reich Commissioner for the Mobilization of Manpower, dispatches from Berlin say.

PANAMA, Jan. 31 -- The War Minister of Colombia, Dr. Alejandro Galvis, left Albrook Field today for Bogota after six days' intensive study of Canal Zone defenses and troop training as a guest of Lieut. Gen. George Brett, commander of the Caribbean Defense Command:

Ice fishermen in Westchester continue to prove a sturdy as well as a patient lot. Although their numbers have been reduced this year, nevertheless this Winter form of fishing is being carried on by some of its ardent adherents.

A service flag with one gold star and seventy-six blue stars was dedicated to "God and country in proud tribute to the young men and women serving in the armed forces" at the service yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Increases aggregating $17,688,201 on taxable real estate, including real estate of utility companies in Brooklyn, are shown by the tentative assessment rolls for 1943-44, made public yesterday by the City Tax Commission. Brooklyn's taxable real estate of all kinds is valued tentatively at $3,598,611,892, including $3,344,047,662 for ordinary real estate, $254,564,230 for utility holdings.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 -- Cotton futures were timid most of last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange. Delays in legislative action on farm matters in Washington tended to restrict activity and make fluctuations narrow. New-crop positions fell behind again and premiums in the spot month increased nearly $1 a bale.

There will be no more air raid or blackout drills in the city until after Feb. 17, the effective date of the new alert system recently set up by the Army for the eastern defense area, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Virtually complete destruction of Adolf Hitler's proud Stalingrad siege forces of 330,000 men, with the smashing of two crack Nazi armies, the killing of 100,000 troops in the last twenty days and the capture of a field marshal general and sixteen generals was announced by Russia late tonight in a triumphant special communique.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 31 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's eloquent silence and the clumsy justifications and threats of propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels and Reich Marshal Hermann Goering made a deep impression in Sweden, where comments such as "the Nazis' swan song" and "acknowledgment of Germany's doom" were frequently heard in the course of the day.

In a rough-and-tumble contest that saw two ten-minute misconduct and one match penalty handed out to the visitors, the second-place New York Rovers beat the Philadelphia Falcons, 5 -- 1, in the feature clash of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League twin bill at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Near-by deliveries of oats sold last week on the Board of Trade here at the highest prices of the season and cash oats went to a twenty-three-year peak with the exception of a short period in 1928. Reports that the Canadian Wheat Board would not issue additional permits for the exportation of oats to this country because of transportation difficulties imparted considerable strength to the market.
As an active participant of the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-5, I would like to draw attention to some inaccuracies contained in the letter of Stanley Washburn printed Jan. 24.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 -- The flow of orders to steel mills last week was not as heavy as in the corresponding December period, but many mills reported volume still equal to or in excess of production. It had been thought in some quarters that fresh business would taper off more than it has owing to the changeover period preceding the Controlled Materials Plan.

Stuart Gracey, American baritone, has a good time singing, and he tries to make his public feel the same way. At his Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon he succeeded. The large audience seemed to be delighted; it could scarcely hold back its applause before the end of some numbers.

The industrial situation is coming into more satisfactory shape and the proportion of the country's effort devoted to war purposes still is growing, the National City Bank of New York reports in its current monthly review of economic conditions.

Milton L. Hanauer, former State champion, took the lead at 5 1/2 -- 1/2 in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club last night. He defeated Alvin C. Cass, one-time champion of the Crescent A.C., Brooklyn.

National advertisers who have been worrying about the proposed, zoning of distribution to conserve transportation facilities are beginning to believe that such a program is losing favor in Washington. As government agencies probe deeper into each industry, they are finding less transportation saving than expected under a zoning plan, and numerous obstacles in the way of an equitable scheme are cropping up.
A special German communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The industrial situation is coming into more satisfactory shape and the proportion of the country's effort devoted to war purposes still is growing, the National City Bank of New York reports in its current monthly review of economic conditions.

National advertisers who have been worrying about the proposed, zoning of distribution to conserve transportation facilities are beginning to believe that such a program is losing favor in Washington. As government agencies probe deeper into each industry, they are finding less transportation saving than expected under a zoning plan, and numerous obstacles in the way of an equitable scheme are cropping up.
A special German communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Jan.31 -- West of Kastornoe the Russians, beating down attempts of the Germans to stem them on the Kursk railway, advanced further in the direction of the junction at Marmiji. From Novi Oskol another group is pushing northward toward Kastornoe, reaching Chernyanka, seventy-two miles away, yesterday.

Trading in cotton futures continued last week to be cautious as final action on agricultural legislation failed to materialize. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts had net declines of 4 to 25 points, or 20 cents to $1.25 a bale, for the period, with the new-crop months losing most.

The urgency of immediate economic relief as a war weapon as well as a means of promoting an enduring peace after the war was stressed by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, director of foreign relief and rehabilitation, in an address at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Commodore last night.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval's "French Militia" is now well under way, with brown shirts and black armbands. He notified the Government Council of this fact in Vichy yesterday and today the Journal Officiel publishes details regarding the new authorization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- President Roosevelt returned tonight to the White House, thus safely completing his history-making journey to North Africa, where with Prime Minister Winston Churchill he planned the future course of the war to end with the "unconditional surrender" of the Axis.

The re-election of Herbert W. Haldenstein as president of the New York Jewish Federation's Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, located at 121 West 105th Street, Manhattan, was announced yesterday at the seventy-third annual meeting of the home.
Only three new films are scheduled to have Broadway premieres this week. These are:

Birth control was condemned yesterday by delegates to the monthly meeting of the New York regional division of the National Federation of Catholic College Students. Ten metropolitan Catholic colleges were represented at the conference held at St. John's University, Brooklyn.

Officials of the Laundry Workers Joint Board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers declared yesterday that 30,000 laundry employes in New York, Westchester and Long Island might lose their livelihood if the order of the Petroleum Administrator for War reducing by 40 per cent fuel oil rationing for other than heating were made effective.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Part of the mystery in regard to the limited receipts of hogs at leading markets recently is said to have been dissipated last week, following reports that country butchers had resorted to killing hogs and cattle bought in their neighborhoods to take care of the demand for fresh meat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Twelve regional offices and 131 district offices, empowered to take action on the spot, have been established under the new decentralization plan of the Smaller War Plants Division of the War Production Board, it was announced today by Lou E. Holland, deputy chairman of WPB attached to the division.

Brisk wholesale buying in the three weeks just ended has resulted in the broadest sell-out of merchandise in twenty years, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The de Gaullist ranks have been further increased by the arrival here of another prominent Frenchman, Rene Massigli. He was once the French Ambassador to Turkey and has just escaped from France, it was revealed today. M. Massigli, who is 53 years old, is bitterly anti-Nazi.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- The floors of the dormitories at Smith College and at near-by Mount Holyoke College have become "decks" and the nautical language of the sea fills the quiet campuses of these women's colleges as the Waves learn the ways of the Navy.

When the Germans tell us that during the month they have sunk a certain number of ships totaling so many hundred thousand tons, what do they mean? Tonnage may be gross net, deadweight or displacement, and all are different. Unless we know what the Germans are measuring the figures given out are misleading.

The Board of Transportation has been criticized by its own impartial grievance committee for alleged failure to handle effectively some of the labor relations problems on the city's unified transit lines the last year, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Petroleum Administration for War announced today that vehicles carrying "certificates of war necessity" or "T" ration stickers would be permitted hereafter to use credit cards at service stations and to obtain gasoline at stations operating on a twenty-four-hour basis.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Navy reported today eighty-seven casualties in Navy forces, including eight dead, eight wounded and seventy-one missing.

For the first time in its young but kaleidoscopic history, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been rebuffed by the Supreme Court of the United States. In a four-to-three decision, with Justice Frankfurter handing down the opinion, the court set aside a SEC order holding that stock in the Federal Water Service Corporation purchased by its directors and officers could not share on the same basis with stock held by others in a proposed reorganization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 -- Jimmy Rogers, youngest son of the late Will Rogers, who appeared in several Hal Roach pictures, was signed by Harry Sherman today to a seven-year contract which gives him the romantic lead in the Hopalong Cassidy series.

NATURALLY, all who could get into service enlisted in the Navy. The sea is in their blood and deep is their love for the impact of the waves against the sides of their ships and for the tangy scent of the salty sprays. They are America's yachtsmen, an unsung group of heroes who are doing a magnificent job in patrolling the waters from Iceland to Guadalcanal.

The Radio City Music Hall expects to sell the millionth admission ticket to "Random Harvest" tomorrow. Attendance at the film through Sunday night totaled 964,271. "Random Harvest" will begin the eighth week of its run on Thursday, this being only two weeks behind the record ten-week engagement of "Mrs. Miniver."
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The stock markets opened for the week quietly but with a firm tone under the lead of gilt edge issues, with both the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan and old Consols recording gains of 1-16.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- One of the letters quoted by the Fighting French spokesman said, in part:

LEON MARCHAL once served Vichy in North Africa, but "only in hopes of erecting barriers against German penetration in the French overseas empire." Later on M. Marchal moved to Washington to become counselor to the French Embassy. When Pierre Laval returned to power in the Spring of 1942, M. Marchal openly broke with Vichy.
A High, Command communiqu broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ON THE WESTERN BURMA FRONT, Jan. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- British and Indian troops, undaunted by tremendous natural hazards and stronger Japanese resistance than was expected, are gradually advancing in the Arakan hill tracts of the Mayu range. At the moment two of the three fronts are fluid.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's airmen carried the fight to the vital Japanese air base at Rabaul, New Britain, in a slashing attack yesterday that left more than twenty-two fires blazing, while intensive Allied patrol activity in the jungles around Mubo-Wau kept the enemy worried.

N.Y.U., Manhattan and Columbia will be prominently represented in the thirty-sixth annual Millrose games, which will launch the indoor track season at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. The Violets will present, among others, their freshman sprint sensation, Ed Conwell, who starred in the recent metropolitan championships.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Clarence Edinger, 46-year-old salesman from Chicago, won the top prize of $4,000 and a medal in the twenty-ninth renewal of the Petersen individual bowling tourney which ended early today.

One of the most impressive openings of a piano program that has been offered here for some time was Artur Rubinstein's performance of Cesar Franck's "Prelude, Chorale and Fugue" at the beginning of his recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The heads of the war government, as a series of recent incidents proves anew, still fail to realize that they must set an example if their steady calls for sacrifice are to be heeded to the extent and in the spirit that is necessary. They continue to disregard what was said in the Sermon on the Mount, reported identically by Matthew and Luke with the variation of only the fourteenth word:
A High Command communiqu broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

ANKARA, Turkey, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Selim Sarper, director-general for the press, said last night that Prime Minister Churchill had not asked Turkey to enter the war and that Turkey had not undertaken any such agreement.

Pressure from Army buyers to switch cotton looms from civilian fabrics to raincoat sheetings, now urgently needed to replenish supplies depleted by North African activities, may be eased considerably as a result of cancellation and deferment of some bandolier cloth contracts by ordnance divisions, it was reported here yesterday by textile mill agents.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 1 -- American tanks and infantry battered at the strong German positions in Faid Pass yesterday while another American column struck along the road from Sidi bou Zid to Maknassy, farther south in Central Tunisia, and a light armored formation raced around the enemy posts in an attempt to cut off the German forces at Sened, nineteen miles southwest of Maknassy.

Not long after the announcement that he had won a first prize in the George Ruppert fishing contest, Sylvester Cavanaro of Riverhead, L.I., was discussing the outlook for Long Island's salt water anglers.

Governor Dewey has made an admirable beginning in his first budget. For the new fiscal year to begin April 1, 1943, he recommends expenditures of $369,600,000. This would mean a reduction of $11,900,000 on the basis of the "customary comparison" with the appropriations of the previous year, but the reduction is reduced to $7,000,000 by comparisons Mr. Dewey considers "more proper."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Under a pledge of secrecy, President Roosevelt gave to eleven Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders today an elaboration of the 1943 offensive war plans of the United Nations that were mapped at the Casablanca conferences between the President, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and military leaders of the United States, Britain and France.

Dr. Alberto Guani, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Vice President-elect of Uruguay, now visiting this country, declared in a speech here last night that "no country can consider itself independent of the lot and fate of the other countries that form the international community."

The sleep-inducing power of Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was cited yesterday by a former German-American Bund member, as he parried a question whether he thought the work "un-American." The question came up at trial before Federal Judge John Bright of the government's suit to denaturalize twenty German-born bundists, who are alleged to have obtained United States citizenship through false oaths of allegiance.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Liquor Authority, in its annual report tonight to Governor Dewey and the Legislature, stated that the trend in New York State has definitely changed from dry to wet, and that not a single town voted last November to join the ranks of dry communities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Three new bombing forays by American airplanes against advanced Japanese bases and one air stroke against Guadalcanal by the enemy were reported in a communique issued here today by the Navy Department.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Postal carriers will distribute the War Manpower Commission's forms for voluntary registration of women over 18 for war work, the Postoffice Department stated today.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company issued yesterday its ninth annual compilation of prices and yields of State and municipal bonds, covering 200 communities. It is shown that while prices are generally higher than one year ago, only about 10 per cent of the bonds listed have bettered the highs established in 1940.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 (Reuter) -- Thousands of Chinese who left Honan Province because of one of the most devastating famines in modern Chinese history have perished in their quest for food.

Despondent because his friend, Anthony Usati, 15 years old, had just been buried, a victim of pneumonia, Joseph Compono, 14, one of a family of fourteen children, hanged himself yesterday in the basement of the Compono home at 2516 Tilden Avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Roosevelt formally withdrew today the nomination of Edward J. Flynn to be Minister to Australia.

While plans are still only in the discussion stage, there is a good possibility that the War Production Board may ease some of its material and manufacturing restrictions enough to permit the production of a limited number of victory models in lines in which civilian output has been banned entirely, it was learned here yesterday.
Leases aggregating $60,000 per annum in the building at 61 Broadway were reported yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., for Harry Forsyth, trustee.

GUADALCANAL, Jan. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Japanese dive and horizontal bombers raided the American Army's front line positions on Guadalcanal today, while Army and Marine fighter planes engaged in bitter duel with Zeros high above the bloody island.

The Dixie Clipper of Pan-American Airways, which carried President Roosevelt on the Casablanca trip, arrived at its home terminal here yesterday and a few minutes later the American Clipper, which made part of the trip, arrived.

In this great debate which is now under way, about the need of hating all the Germans with all our blood pressure and all our facial muscles, the negative seems to be well ahead. We trust we are not too frivolous on a big subject if we say that the overwhelming sense of the American people on this issue is to make hate slowly.

In one of the first formal interpretations of the inventory control order, the War Production Board has informed furniture retailers that they may, with specific authorization, exchange merchandise horizontally among themselves, even though each of the dealers concerned is frozen with respect to allowable purchases.

The workers of Great Britain need little urging for contributions to Russian war relief, because they know that "the day they stopped being blitzed was the day the Russians started putting up real defenses," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday at a luncheon of the New York Junior League in its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- There follows the text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature, accompanying his budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1, 1943:

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 2 -- The Soviet Army is forty-five miles from the Caucasian gateway of Rostov and only sixty-five miles east of Kursk, one of the main German bastions in Southern Russia, Moscow announced early today in a communique recorded by the Soviet monitor here.

KANEOHE NAVAL AIR STATION, Hawaii, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- Secretary Knox presented awards here today to seven officers and eleven enlisted men of the Navy aerial patrol wings, which he characterized as the "modern cavalry of the sea."
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communiqu as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The man with what is probably the longest shopping list in New York is Lieutenant Herbert Schwab, supply officer at the new training school for Waves and Spars on the Bronx campus of Hunter College, whose job it is to order furniture and food for 6,000 women.

Mayor La Guardia promised yesterday that he would issue a proclamation on March 1 naming the month of March "Red Cross War Fund Month." The Red Cross will open its annual drive on March 1, seeking to raise a national quota of $125,000,000, of which $12,920,700 is to be raised in this city.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Russian mid-day communiqu recorded by the Soviet monitor:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 1 -- Eleven parachutists dropped behind the Allied lines in civilian clothes were shot as spies at Biskra, Algeria, on Saturday, after having been condemned to death by a French court-martial.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 29 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt's reassurance that the Allies' object in the Pacific is to prevent Japan forever from dominating that ocean and that their aim is the unconditional surrender of all the Axis powers will be, in this country, a particularly welcome outcome of the Casablanca conference.

The annual exhibition of work in all media by members of the Studio Club of the Y.W.C.A., 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, will open this afternoon at 4:30 with a tea in honor of the judges -Isabel Bishop, Grace Cornell and Kenneth Thompson. The exhibition will continue through Feb. 24.

The threatened refusal of Norwegian seamen to register in the Norwegian seamen's pool because of lowered maintenance pay was called off yesterday after the Norwegian Government had expressed its willingness to negotiate the matter.

Thirty business men began yesterday a nineteen-day course in naval organization, procedure and operations at the Naval Reserve Midshipman's School at Columbia University. The men, many of whose companies hold Navy contracts, were invited to take the course by Under-Secretary James V. Forrestal.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 1 -- The State Legislature today gave final approval to one bill repealing the State's fifty-year-old poll tax and to another establishing a permanent registration system in Tennessee. The Senate passed Governor Prentice Cooper's poll-tax repealer 22 to 10, five minutes after it had approved the permanent registration measure, 19 to 13.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- General Ivan V. Tulinefff'c armies are making rapid progress toward Krasnodar, the Kuban region's capital and the chief collection point for the wealth of this abundant land. Here, too, are oil refineries.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- Lieutenant Robert Cox of the King's Royal Rifle Corps has rejoined his battalion somewhere in Tripolitania, it was revealed today. This apparently routine action was the latest chapter in the story of six Americans who, as Quentin Reynolds said of the Eagle Squadron, "didn't wait to be stabbed in the back."

There was an overflow gathering at Helen Cookman's, 48 East Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon at a preview of her Spring and Summer offerings in wool and cotton. Many of the familiar faces one used to see at the openings of the Paris couture were there, and Marjorie Howard, who for many years lived in and wrote from Paris, was the announcer.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, chancellor of Stanford University, received tonight the William Freeman Snow Medal for distinguished service to humanity at the annual national dinner meeting of the American Social Hygiene Association.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- Leo Durocher came here today to keep a date with draft board physicians and said he was "Ready, willing and able to go any time Uncle Sam wants me."

Representative A. Willis Robertson, in a letter to a colleague, Representative C. Jasper Bell, commenting on my proposal that a supplemental tax be placed on certain increases in individual income, suggested that I outline my plan "for arriving at what is the war profit of an individual."

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- Reports that are believed here to have originated with the Axis-controlled Belgrade newspaper, Novo Vreme, and have been circulating for some time abroad say that a member of the Soviet Legation staff in Belgrade did not leave Yugoslavia in 1941 but is cooperating with the partisan movement there.

A "covenant of cooperation" with Federal agencies and continued voluntary rationing of cigars covering medium and higher-price brands as well as the low-price product was announced yesterday by the Cigar Manufacturers Association, representing nearly 75 per cent of the annual dollar volume of the American cigar industry.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 1 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's attempt to justify German underestimation of the Russian Army by saying that during the Winter war in Finland the Russians had "bluffed" the world, has met with energetic opposition in Finland.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 (AP) -- More than 1,000 enemy troops have been killed or wounded in heavy fighting still in progress along the Burma-Yunnan border, the Chinese High Command asserted tonight.

Higher meat prices here were predicted yesterday by Louis Lotstein and Nathan Sweedler, representing the independent meat packers of this city, on the eve of going to Washington to lay the plight of the independent packers and butchers before Federal authorities.

The Board of Transportation revoked yesterday an order it had issued some time ago calling for docking the pay of any employe engaging in a work stoppage as part of the campaign of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., to increase wages on the city's transit system. Two thousand employes took part in such stoppages last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A spokesman for the Fighting French delegation in the United States made public today two letters from members of the de Gaullist underground movement in North Africa saying that pro-Allied Frenchmen there were held in prison and in concentration camps. He drew attention to dispatches from American correspondents within the last week that said that many of these political prisoners were still incarcerated.

A ceremony to mark the first induction of 2,000 of the personnel of the newly constituted United States Citizens Service Corps in Manhattan was announced yesterday for Feb. 14 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman, and Mrs. Homer L. Sweetser, co-chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Volunteer Office.

Instead of conserving scarce workshirt fabrics, sizable quantities of which have been removed from the civilian market to satisfy war-aid needs, the inclusion of unshrunk utility fabrics in the WPB's proposed standard "victory" line may shift war workers' demands into larger sizes and thus defeat the chief purpose of the regulation, it was declared yesterday by textile suppliers.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- One Netherlander has been executed for murder and sabotage and seventeen others have been condemned to death for distributing anti-German pamphlets, the Netherlands News Agency said today.

Confirmation by rail issues of the powerful upturn of the new year gave new encouragement yesterday to the stock market as pivotal groups showed gains of a point and more. The pattern off the session was almost an exact replica of the majority of the January business days, with profit-taking slightly unsettling the list in the morning, only to be overcome by support in the final hour.

In a bid to provide insurance against possible loss of Manager Leo Durocher now that Peewee Reese has entered the armed service, Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, yesterday announced the purchase of Steve Mesner from the Reds for about the waiver price, $7,500.

The Pierpont Morgan Library at 29 East Thirty-sixth Street is, as the metaphorists would say, wreathed in smiles just now. Belle da Costa Greene, the director, has produced from the receptacles where such things are kept quantities of eighteenth and nineteenth century English caricatures, her express desire being "to make people laugh for a little while and forget. . . ."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 - Thurman Arnold, closing the argument for the Federal Government in its charge that the Pullman interests exercised a monopoly in restraint of trade in their dealings in the sleeping car business, charged today that the defendants had obtained a "corner in every single angle" of the field.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The Tobacco Products Export Corporation was criticized by the Securities and Exchange Commission today for failing to give its security holders more than "the most cursory information respecting its affairs."

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Regarded in Fighting French circles as one of the most powerful reinforcements that the movement has had, Rene Massigli, former French Ambassador to Turkey, who has just arrived here, parried like the veteran diplomat that he is all questions on the North African political situation today.
In listing contributions and gifts in the Federal income tax return to obtain allowable deductions, such contributions and gifts must fall within the limitations governed by law.

After the first sigh of relief at the President's safe return various thoughts run through one's mind: the mechanical marvels which permit a man to go so far and get so much done in three weeks; the question of risk and the undoubted fact that there is no invention which can take the place of conferences held face to face.

Confidence increased in garment circles here yesterday that the OPA would grant a tolerance in figuring minimum allowable costs under MPR-287, following the conference in Washington last week. Production men and trade association executives, participating in the conference, had urged a tolerance of 5 to 10 per cent, some on minimum allowable costs and some on the selling price.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran broke into song yesterday as he announced that in the two months since he created the Bowery Court in the new Criminal Courts Building most of the "bottle babies," or inebriates, of that old thoroughfare had taken to war work, with 100 joining the Army and with only 5 per cent of the 300 that had been arraigned in the court becoming "backsliders."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The WPB, through its program vice chairman Ferdinand Eberstadt, announced today that substantial simplification of the Controlled Materials Plan has been worked out by the board and will go into effect immediately.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Sales of war bonds reached an all-time high last month, totaling $1,240,444,000, the Treasury reported today.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- The capture of Field Marshal General Friedrich von Paulus and many other generals of the German Sixth Army and Fourth Tank Group on the seventieth day of their encirclement at Stalingrad was celebrated today when 38-year-old Col. Gen. Constantine Rokassovsky, who began the war as a colonel, and Lieut. Gen. Vassily Ivanovitch Chulkoff, commander of the heroic Seventy-second Army, took the salute as their armies paraded.
The six-story apartment house on a plot 66.8 by 102 feet at 247-53 West Seventy-first Street has been sold by the Mountbern Realty Corporation to an investing client of Peace Mayer, brokers.

Spain has adopted an attitude of tolerance toward refugees from France, Dr. Joseph Schwartz of 125 West Seventy-sixth Street, European chairman of the American Jewish joint distribution committee, declared yesterday upon his arrival from Europe aboard a Clipper plane.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation today reported for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1942, consolidated profit for the corporation and its subsidiaries of $2,550,257 after all charges. This compares with $4,234,599 in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1941.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Tokyo radio quoted Admiral Shigetaro Shimada, Navy Minister, as telling the Diet today that Japanese planes sank two battleships and three cruisers off the most southerly point of the Solomons last Friday and Saturday.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Lieutenant G. J. Oxrider of Dayton, Ohio, pilot of a Flying Fortress that was returning to its British base from a raid with but one of its four engines functioning, was about to crash-land the big bomber in a field when he discovered that the open space was a football ground filled with children.

Spokesmen for the petroleum industry, Federal rationing authorities and consumers hailed yesterday's mild weather and sunny skies as checking the rush on fuel oil stocks throughout the New York metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Edward E. Conroy, Western-born veteran of twenty years with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was shifted today from his post as F.B.I. chieftain in New Jersey to roy as special agent in charge of New York F.B.I. office.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Methods of obtaining greatest value in new clothes and of converting east-off garments into sweaters, coats and dresses were demonstrated this afternoon at a wartime clothes clinic conducted by the consumer education section of the Westchester County War Council, the Westchester County Recreation Commission and Bonwit Teller, Inc.

The recently organized joint information office of the trucking industry, which hopes to eliminate "deadheads" and partly loaded trucks on trips to and from New York, opened its new quarters at 90 West Street yesterday morning, with Harold A. Connor in charge as manager.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. (AP) -- communiqu:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- With nothing more than "pitiful" assistance arriving from the United States, China is on the verge of economic collapse, Mme. Wellington Koo, the wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Great Britain, said today in an address to workers of the United War Chest.

A bill has been introduced in Congress authorizing increasing the debt limit to 210 billions. The figure is based upon the requirements of the war. Nobody has ventured to suggest any method of repayment, or even how it may be reduced.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust reported yesterday that at the close of 1942 it had a net asset value of $108,263,234, equal to $16.89 each on 6,410,211 shares of $1 par stock, compared with $91,438,269, or $15.58 a share the year before, when 5,870,592 shares were outstanding.

TRENTON, Feb. -- A bill to revise the election laws, introduced by Assemblyman Lester E. Mahr of Essex County, was discussed at length today in caucuses of the Republican majorities in both Senate and House but no agreement was reached on action.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Dewey submitted to the Legislature tonight his first State budget, totaling $369,600,000, compared with appropriations of $381,500,000 made last year, and an expenditure rate which ran several millions less.

Mr. Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, presented in your columns a useful commentary upon the present plight of the members of his union, and the facts given as well as suggested are surely worthy of consideration.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- Rene Birr, aged 20; Auguste Sonntag, aged 18; Eugen Boeglin, aged 30, and Adolf Murbach, aged 40, have been sentenced to death by the high court for the Reich, which for the occasion was transferred to Strasbourg.

The President has written the best possible end to the story of the Flynn appointment by withdrawing the nomination from the Senate. An Administration poll had shown that if the question came to a vote Mr. Flynn would be rejected. The fight was over. There was no good reason for the President to push on to the bitter end and meet with the inevitable rebuff.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Roosevelt will be called upon in a day or two to untangle the snarl which today made the National (railway) Mediation Board a one-man body, unable to function, although it is tied up in the Executive order outlining the procedure to be followed in the handling of the demand for wage increases which the Rail Mediation Board was unable to adjudicate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (U.P.) -- The National Lawyers Guild today accused the Dies Committee on Un-American activities of being the "secret weapon" with which Adolf Hitler "hopes to soften up our nation for military conquest."

Official announcement was made yesterday that Gertrude Lawrence and "Lady in the Dark" would return here for a bargain price engagement, starting Sunday night, Feb. 28, at the Broadway Theatre. The tremendous business the Moss Hart-Kurt Weill-Ira Gershwin musical has been doing in Chicago resulted in extending the visit there for a fifth week.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (Reuter) -- A Ministry of Information communique:

Walter Nash, New Zealand's Minister to the United States, in an address at Town Hall yesterday, said that while his country realized that the United Nations first must concentrate against Germany, "we want to see a blitz against Japan that will knock her out of the war the moment such a blitz becomes a strategic possibility."

In a special report on the labor situation in the New York Federal Reserve District, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in the February issue of its survey of business and credit conditions that, although New York City is still an area of labor surplus, most of the important industrial centers of this district have reached about as high a level of employment as they can attain with the local labor supply.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- Scattered liquidation made its appearance in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and with a lack of aggressive support prices declined quickly with rye in the lead. The latter developed independent weakness as the result of selling induced by the announcement late last week that the government did not contemplate purchasing rye for shipment to Russia, and prices at one time were off 1 3/4 cents.

A thirty-count indictment against Arnold R. Hanson and Sven Wellmer Hanson, securities dealers, and John W. Hession, former columnist, on charges of violating provisions of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1933 and conspiracy in a case involving market activity in Wisconsin Central Railway bonds, was handed up to Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday in Federal Court.

A Finnish general staff officer made a published protest yesterday against Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's assertion in his Nazi anniversary speech Saturday that Russia's war on Finland had been "perhaps the cleverest and greatest camouflage in world history."

Carl Van Doren appears on the Viking Spring list with further secret history of the American Revolution. "Mutiny in January," a work due to be published in April, is the story of the uprising of soldiers of the Pennsylvania line who had mutinied and set themselves up at Princeton, N.J.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 1 -- Pop Schwer is leaving for St. Louis in April. Although this may not seem epochal news to war-driven America, it is something to Chungking. For Pop, once known as "Red Face" in honor of his enthusiastic complexion, is a key citizen of venerable standing in Free China's war capital.

Withdrawal of Edward J. Flynn's nomination as Minister to Australia yesterday raised the possibility that he might recall also his resignations as Democratic National Committeeman from New York and as Bronx Democratic leader, but the prevailing belief in political circles here last night was that he would not do so.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The nomination of Josh Lee, defeated Democratic Senator from Oklahoma, as a member of the Civil Aeronautics Board was confirmed today by the Senate, 46 to 31, after his successor, Senator Moore, a Republican, had opposed him as "a lame duck favorite of the White House."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1 -- Dental examinations were being used today to identify the nineteen bodies recovered from the wreckage of the Navy transport plane which crashed into a Mendocino County cliff during a storm on Jan. 21 and was destroyed by fire.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced yesterday that it has forwarded a vigorous protest against the new proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission to each member of the Senate and House of Representatives in Washington.

Cyrus Crane Willmore, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will be the guest of the members of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at a luncheon at the Hotel Bossert Feb. 8. He will be welcomed by Borough President John Cashmore.

Emil K. Ellis, counsel to the City Council committee that investigated the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, its former president, filed an application yesterday in Supreme Court for summary judgment in his suit against the city for fees and expenses in connection with the two-year inquiry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Robert Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told a joint subcommittee of the House Military and Naval Affairs Committees today that William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, who recently accused the Army, Navy and "loafers" of disrupting production, had attempted to push through first priorities for his own projects that would have delayed the high-octane aviation gasoline program four months and caused a loss of production of 15,000 airplanes.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 10 per cent for the week ended Jan. 30, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The snowstorm on Thursday was a major factor in the showing for the week.
CHUNGKING, Feb. 1 (Reuter) -- A Chinese communiqu:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP -- President Roosevelt was reported tonight to have given the conference of Congressional leaders at the White House a rough estimate of 7,500,000 men as the maximum-sized Army needed to carry the war to a successful conclusion.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 1 -- New methods of measuring changes in nerve cells, solving for the first time the long-standing mystery how the nervous system transmits messages to the brain and enables the body to keep alive, were described here tonight at Rutgers University by Professor D.W. Bronk of the University of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Congressional leaders of both parties, giving a resume of the Casablanca war council meeting; his visitors included Secretary Hull, Under-Secretary Welles and Admiral Stark.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Power Authority, in its annual report to the Legislature tonight, hailed the construction of the Massena power line now being used for war purposes as paving the way for public control of power transmission from the Niagara River-St. Lawrence area after the war.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 1 (AP) -- A former Chilean military attache in Germany and Italy who returned here only last week predicted today that Germany would lose the war, that Italy would be shaken by revolt and that a second front would be established in Europe in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The secret service appealed to the public today for aid in suppressing a racket which thrived during WPA days -- the theft and forging of Federal checks. Issuance of thousands of government allowance and allotment checks to dependents of service men, officials warned, may provide a lucrative field for the unscrupulous unless the public is on guard.

Columbia's awe of the Dartmouth basketball team was proved justified last night as the Lion quintet, outclassed, bowed to the Hanover Indians, 66 -- 44, before a capacity crowd of 1,500 in the Columbia gym, where the home team suffered its first setback in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Johnny Simmons, 22-year-old defense worker from Stamford, Conn., captured the two-mile intercity race of champions which featured the nineteenth annual Silver Skates competition staged by the News Welfare Association at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 14,797 witnessed the program. Proceeds went to the USO.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Stern realities of war, as experienced by American forces, especially in the last days of Bataan and Corregidor, have at least partially dictated line, color and fabric in a revised wardrobe for Army nurses, previewed today under the auspices of the War Department in the Archives Building auditorium.

For a few brief moments yesterday at Stillman's Gymnasium Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh's former holder of the world welterweight title, turned from the serious business of training for a fight to comedy. He clowned with Fred Allen, stage, screen and radio comedian, before the largest gathering of gymnasium patrons that has assembled in the rambling Eighth Avenue plant in five years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Much concern over the possibility that other States may follow the lead of Ohio, Georgia and Michigan and dispense with war time and expressed by spokesmen for the War Production Board here today. Michigan and Ohio last week turned their clocks back to standard time because of general dissatisfaction with the war plan of time saving.

One of the largest dwellings in Lawrence, L.I., the former home of Susanna W. Carvalho and known as Villa Pombal, has been purchased by two nurses and will be remodeled for use as a private hospital. The property was sold by Roy E. Pardee of Islip and Mrs. S.C. Crehore of Plainfield, N.J., executors of the Carvalho estate.

When a city cook can't get a steak or a half-dozen chops or a roast, she buys a chicken or some eggs, some beans (for baking) or some cheese. She buys anything, in fact, but fish. Why this should be so, a representative of the Fish and Wild Life Service said yesterday in discussing the matter, is something of a mystery.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 1 -- The United Nations' northernmost foothold in New Guinea is at stake in a battle that has developed for Wau as a result of a Japanese attack launched at the end of last week. In the center of the New Guinea goldfields, Wau is the site of an airdrome thirty-five airline miles inland from the Japanese-held port of Salamaua and not much farther from Lae.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 2 -- The mystery of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's movements since he bade President Roosevelt au revoir after the Casablanca conference was dispelled early this morning by an announcement that was as important as it was dramatic and unexpected.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- Fuller details came to hand today regarding the organization of Chief of Government Pierre Laval's "French Militia," which seems to be the latest hope of bolstering the Vichy regime.

Aided by a fifth Sunday, as against four in January of last year, advertising linage of eight New York newspapers last month rose 14.6 per cent over the like 1942 period, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

Arturo Toscanini, beaten by Mussolini's blackguards in 1931 because he had disobeyed their master's order to play the Fascist hymn, took a neat and subtle revenge Sunday. In the book written by Boito, the famous librettist of "Otello" and "Falstaff," for Verdi's "Hymn of Nations" the conductor substituted for "Italy, My Country," "Italy Betrayed."

From out the great West has come "The Barber Had Two Sons" to set up shop -- though it may be briefly -- at Mr. Brady's Playhouse and to push back into the darkness the Broadway theatre that lately had been playing happily in the light.

Recognition of the college basketball player in the metropolitan area who is most valuable to his team will be given for the first time this season by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association, it was decided yesterday at a luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant.

In addition to twenty-two Axis divisions that have already been moved into the Soviet-German front to replace those wiped out at Stalingrad, nine more are on the way, the Moscow radio said last night in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

In addition to twenty-two Axis divisions that have already been moved into the Soviet-German front to replace those wiped out at Stalingrad, nine more are on the way, the Moscow radio said last night in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A bill preparing to set in motion Congress' idea of how the war procurement program should be conducted was introduced today in the Senate. It would create the Office of War Mobilization, headed by a director.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Axis troops trapped at Stalingrad continued to fight at the insistence of Adolf Hitler after many German generals there had concluded that further resistance was "senseless and criminal," Major Gen. Moritz von Dreber told Russian officers who captured him.

After a two weeks' aerial tour of the Pacific, Secretary Knox reports that the situation in Guadalcanal is well under control, that the Americans have proved themselves masters of the Japanese, and that we are now ready to strike harder blows at them than heretofore.

Selective service inductees at Grand Central Palace yesterday were permitted to express their preference for the Navy, Marine Corps or the Coast Guard instead of the Army. For the first time in history the three branches of the country's armed forces that always had filled their ranks by volunteer enlistments were drafting men.

The Earl of Gosford, captain of D Company of the New York City Patrol Corps, explained yesterday that he sought this form of active duty "because a man can't feel really happy unless he's doing a bit more than is expected of him."

Merchant seamen who help get the convoys through showed yesterday what they could do in a peaceful pursuit by opening an exhibition of their paintings, drawings and prints at 24 West Fortieth Street, under the sponsorship of the United Seamen's Service.

A new issue of $14,212,000 of temporary loan notes was announced yesterday by the Baltimore Housing Authority, Maryland, for award on Feb. 9. The issue will be dated March 1, and will mature on May 17, 1944, with the rate of interest to be named by the bidders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- To the accompaniment of applause from both sides of the House, Representative Dies, Democrat, of Texas, called on Congress today to purge the government of "irresponsible, unrepresentative, crackpot and radical bureaucrats" by withholding funds from the agencies employing them.

The Work Projects Administration here announced yesterday that 5,800 men and women had been dropped from the rolls, out of 17,444 employed last week, leaving 11,644. President Roosevelt recently ordered dissolution of the WPA by Feb. 1 "or as soon thereafter as feasible."
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 2 (AP) -- communiqu:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 -- Advance forces of the British Eighth Army occupied Zuara yesterday and moved westward toward the Tunisia border. There is now only one town, Pisida, between the British and the frontier.

Moderate replacement buying in the distant positions yesterday imparted strength to the cotton futures market in late dealings and brought the list of active contracts to final net gains of 4 to 9 points, near the best levels of the quiet session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- An eight-wheeled contraption called the "War Wagon Trailer," latest innovation in passenger travel, has been demonstrated to officials of the Office of Defense Transportation and the War and Navy Departments.

Two hundred men and women attending a meeting in regional headquarters of the Office of Price Administration in the Empire State Building last night received their first instructions regarding the mechanics of point rationing, which they will pass on to housewives throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Because of the circumstances under which the case was put to the Supreme Court, the tribunal today refused to discuss whether it had jurisdiction to pass upon the validity of the Connecticut Birth Control Law.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address today by Premier Mussolini, broadcast by the Rome radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, according to the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 27: An increase of $580,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and a decrease of $231,000,000 in United States Government deposits; increases of $124,900,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $77,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Labor Board today vetoed a wage increase of l0 cents an hour negotiated by an employer and a union and reduced from 4 cents an hour to 3 cents another wage increase also negotiated by a labor organization.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of the Allied Air Forces, Southwest Pacific Area, has awarded medals for gallantry in action to eight officers and eleven enlisted men.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 1 -- Pennsylvania, rarely associated with the "northlands" by metropolitan skiers, has always been a land of snow and ice but it remained for Winter sports enthusiasts to teach Pennsylvanians what an asset the State's outdoor facilities can be during the cold months.

HONOLULU, Feb. 1 (AP) -- "Hey, Joe," called the young lieutenant as Joe Cronin, manager of the Boston Red Sox, entered, "that girl sure was sore. You know, the one we brought out Sunday afternoon to dance with you. And then you never danced with her, even once."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission holding that preferred stock of a company purchased by its directors and officers while reorganization plans were under consideration should not be treated in the reorganization on a parity with other preferred stock.
Walt Disney disclosed yesterday upon his arrival from Hollywood that he is planning to produce a film cartoon to "explode the Hitlerian or any one else's theory of racial superiority."

A German broadcast, recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York, reported the German High Command had announced that the southern group of the Sixth Army in Stalingrad has been overpowered "by the superior power of the enemy" after more than two months of "heroic defense."

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Walter A. Futter, president of New York Machine Shops, Inc., who leased an apartment in 280-90 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agent, and Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

Herbert Agar, president of Freedom House, will deliver the baccalaureate address at the commencement exercises of 687 Hunter College graduates today at 8 P.M. in the college assembly hall, Sixty-ninth Street and Park Avenue. His topic will be "Our Place in the United Nations."

The Chauncey Real Estate Company, of Brooklyn, headed by Joseph W. Catharine, is celebrating this week the 100th anniversary of its founding in 1843 by Daniel, David and Michael Chauncey, contractors and builders.
ALLIED HEADQUATER IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

The president and three members of the Harry M. Sullivan Association of Woodside, a political and social organization that used to conduct lottery games at a Woodside hail, were indicted yesterday by the Queens grand jury on lottery charges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The order issued today by the Bureau of Selective Service to its local beards affects men between the ages of 18 and 37 in twenty-nine occupations "non-deferrable regardless of the activity in which they are found," or employed in nineteen manufacturing, eight wholesale and retail trades, and nine service activities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Treasury and Postoffice Departments together purpose to spend about 9 per cent less in the next fiscal year, with much of the cut due to curtailment of foreign air mail service.

The discovery that the discredited filibuster was still a potent weapon in the hands of an unrepresentative minority of the Senate in connection with the recent defeat of the bill seeking to abolish the poll tax was particularly alarming at this time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- The War Manpower Commission was told today by an advisory committee that Local 513 of the Boilermakers Union had discriminated against Negroes in quest of employment at the Richmond Shipyards on the Bay, with the result that "a supply of labor which is desperately needed" had been withheld.

The Rev. William F. Clark, spiritual father of the Jesuit community at Fordham University, observed yesterday his fiftieth anniversary in the clergy by attending ceremonies at the university church on the Bronx campus, at which five younger members of the community made their final vows. Following the services, an informal reception was held at Keating Hall.

New York City's assessed real estate valuations are down about three and a half billion dollars from the high point reached in 1930, but, as taxpayers learned yesterday, they have dropped only $53,287,619 since last year. At this rate it would take nearly seventy years to get them down another three and a half billion.

MADRAS, India, Jan. 27 -- (Delayed) -- The northern part of the Madras Presidency, which is inhabited by the Telugus, is different from the Tamil region in the south and both in turn differ greatly from the western part, with its Malayalams on the Malabar coast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Railway Labor Executives Association, representing nineteen standard railroad unions with a claimed membership of 1,500,000, issued a statement today asserting that their treatment at the hands of government authorities was such that they had decided they were regarded as not being employed in an industry essential to winning the war and, as a result, many railroad workers were considering leaving their posts for other industries.
A High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

Sackett Graduate Scholarships, awarded annually to students who do "the best work in the course on the law of libel and in other courses" at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, have been given this year to Seymour Ethan, Dwight Bentel and Miss Grace Darin, Dean Carl W. Ackerman announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Japanese began trying to retake Guadalcanal immediately after the American invasion started on Aug. 7, when United States marines moved in under support of naval guns and planes.

A friend who prides himself on being a realist and an expert in truth from the inside and the low-down now thinks he has the inside story and the low-down about Casablanca. It was not a meeting to plan grand strategy or global policy.

The presentation of evidence on which the government has asked the denaturalization of Fritz Kuhn and nineteen others who were active in the German-American Bund was completed yesterday. It closed with testimony that one of the group had extolled Adolf Hitler and defended the sneak attack on Pearl Harbor.

Jeanette Savran, young American pianist, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Hall last night under the auspices of the Atwater Kent Foundation, can play like a whirlwind virtuoso and like a sensitive poet, and she seems to shuttle between the two styles.

It is good to hear a pianist who plays like a genuine artist with something to say, and like a man; a young man with blood in his veins and the vitality and enthusiasm that properly pertain to his years. This was the case when Rudolf Firkusny gave a recital of compositions by Beethoven, Schumann, Martinu, Chopin and Smetana, before a highly representative audience, warm in its approval, last night in Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today he believed that all the country's estimated 1,700 colleges and universities could be fitted into the war and post-war training program.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- A Russian communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet Monitor:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sullivan of Waterloo, Iowa, whose five sons were reported missing in action after the sinking of the cruiser Juneau off the Solomon Islands in November, have come to Washington.

The Irish Free State Government, after long consideration, has established its own central bank. Until this week the Bank of Ireland, a privately owned institution, has issued Eire's currency on behalf of the government, in cooperation with seven other privately owned Irish banks.

TRENTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- New Jersey farmers continued to reap a golden harvest from their Winter produce in the month ended Jan. 15, the Federal-State Crop Reporting Service said today, with animal growers enjowing an unprecedented boom.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 2 -- Hope that the good will of the United Nations would save Finland from the consequences of German defeat was expressed today by President Risto Ryti of Finland.

Replacement of John H. Delaney as chairman of the Board of Transportation by a man more in sympathy with organized labor would result in a tremendous improvement of labor relations on the city's transit system, Harry M. Sacher, counsel for the Transport Workers Union, asserted yesterday.
