Although the city's payroll is running almost $3,000,000 below estimates and there is need for some adjustments in salaries to meet rising living costs, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and Thomas J. Patterson, acting budget director, recommended in a report to the City Council yesterday that the question of pay increases be left for the 1943-44 budget, now in preparation.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and its subsidiaries had a net profit in 1942 of $10,305,705, equal after preferred dividend requirements, to $5.66 a share on the common stock, according to the annual statement announced yesterday.

The one-story factory on a plot of four acres of land at 401-33 Kingsland Avenue, Harrison, N.J., has been sold by the. General Cable Corporation to the Allcraft Corrugated Company for $100,000. It is assessed for $177,000.

The opportunity for a limited number of seniors from accredited secondary schools who are between the ages of 17 and 18 to apply for enlistment as officer candidates in the Marine Corps was announced yesterday by Major Frank V. McKinless, in charge of Marine officer procurement, 33 Pine Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- The National Power and Light Company proposed today to the Securities and Exchange Commission the sale of its entire interest in the West Tennessee Gas Company, a Florida corporation, to the Equitable Securities Corporation of Tennessee for $712,500 in cash plus interest at the rate of 3 per cent annually from June 30, 1942, to date of closing.

New business of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company during 1942 reached a new high of $417,857,642, which includes an increase of $223,357,746 of group business on old cases as a result of increased employment due to the war, according to the seventy-eighth annual statement announced yesterday by Frazar B. Wilde, president. In 1941 total new business was $222,574,922, which included $109,380,152 of group business from old cases.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- The Legislature today asked Governor Dewey to issue a proclamation designating March 9 as "John Ericsson Day" in honor of his invention, construction and launching at Greenpoint, New York, of the Union gunboat Monitor.

The public libraries of Greater New York serve in both peace and war. Especially in these days do they have an important function, and it may truly be said that their books constitute an irreplaceable means of aiding our war efforts.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Cyrus S. Eaton of Otis Co. today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission "to require competitive bidding" on a proposed new issue of $14,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent Series D Erie Railrad bonds "before the conventional excuse is made that a private sale has already been concluded and that competition therefore is not practicable."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Treasury, through its general counsel, Randolph Paul, urged the Ways and Means Committee today to write a pay-as-you-go income tax bill which could be enacted in time for a collection-at-source system to become operative not later than July 1.

As the last German resistance at Stalingrad nears its end the Russian armies of the Caucasus continue to drive the Nazis there into what appears to be a similar trap. More than 200,000 German troops are now herded into the Kuban plain, with all the equipment accumulated in a long campaign.

The Navy Department will open the ranks of the Waves and Spars, women's Naval and Coast Guard auxiliaries, to Negro recruits as the result of recent conferences with officers of these services, Councilman Adam Clayton Powell Jr. informed the City Council yesterday as it approved a resolution condemning racial discrimination in these units.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Rationing of canned foods under the point system, which was forecast several weeks ago, will begin March 1, the Office of Price Administration stated today.

Cotton textile manufacturers are greatly disturbed over proposed application of the renegotiation statute to their government business which, because of the rigid rules surrounding it, would not warrant "as a purely business proposition" the preference it is receiving in current industry output, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared here yesterday.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland has accepted the chairmanship of the United Palestine Appeal, central agency of American Jews for the defense and rebuilding of the Jewish settlement in Palestine, the organization announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 2 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, General Charles Nogues and Pierre Boisson have arrived in Algiers in the last twenty-four hours for a third meeting of the Imperial Council of the French Provisional Government, which is expected to start tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (Reuter) -- Miss Diana Wynyard, 37-year-old stage and film actress, is to be married here tomorrow to Carol Reed, who directed the "Kipps" film, in which she appeared. Both are Londoners. Mr. Reed, who is 36, directed the film "Young Mr. Pitt."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The WPB's requirements committee today "cut the pie" of America's supply of steel, copper and aluminum to be delivered to the nation's war producers during the second quarter of this year.

" Counterattack," a new Soviet drama by Janet and Philip Stevenson (Mr. and Mrs. S.) from the central theme of a Russian play by Ilya Vershihin and Mikhail Ruderman, will open tonight at the Windsor under the auspices of Lee Sabinson, a newcomer in the Broadway managerial field.

Although heavy government buying may deprive the home decorator of many familiar staples this Spring -- and more next Fall -- it results occasionally in the appearance of a new drapery fabric. An especially fine broadcloth with a soft silky sheen, prized as a draw curtain material but too expensive to produce in peacetime, is now available in small lots from a factory where it is being manufactured for parachutes.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Feb. 2 -- One of the longest school vacations forced upon any community in the metropolitan New York area due to the shortage of its rationed fuel oil supplies was authorized today for the Belleville High School, which will be closed from next Friday afternoon until March 1.
A third death so far this year from diphtheria was reported in New York City last week, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday. In all of 1942, there were only seven diphtheria deaths.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- The value of securities registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission during 1942 fell to its lowest point since 1935, the January statistical bulletin of the SEC disclosed today.

Warning against speculative excesses in raw furs, Louis F. White, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, last night declared "it is entirely up to the fur garment manufacturer to stop the steady skyrocketing of prices for raw skins," He spoke at the annual meeting of the association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Interest on indebtedness is generally an allowable deduction in arriving at net income for Federal income tax purposes. Deductible interest includes both interest paid in connection with one's business or profession and interest paid on personal indebtedness.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Bill Cowley's hat trick performance of three goals enabled the Bruins to defeat the Black Hawks by 5 -- 3 and increase their National Hockey League lead to six points over Detroit tonight before a 10,314 crowd at the Boston Garden.
American Airlines, Inc., has leased for its main executive offices four floors and some ground-floor space in the Pershing Square Building, at 100 East Forty-second Street, for a long term.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Quota restrictions on withdrawals of fuel oils and kerosene from refinery and terminal supply points were lifted today until further notice by the Petroleum Administrator for War, while limitations on withdrawals of gasoline stocks were continued in effect.

Men's wear stores, which since the beginning of Fall have been experimenting with offerings of women's coats, are now planning fairly extensive advertising campaigns for them during the Spring season, retail executives reported yesterday.
WASqGTON, Feb. 2 -- Here is the log of President Ro0sevelt's 16,965-mile train, plane and automobile trip to Africa and South America for war conferences:

How the arts may be used to help injured war veterans is illustrated in an exhibition called "The Arts in Therapy," which the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open to the public this morning and later will circulate through the country.

Helene Garnell, who was responsible for the millinery showing at the luncheon hour in the Ritz-Carlton's Oval Room yesterday, is a good showman. She made no attempt to overdramatize her hats, but presented them in a simple setting. The frocks worn by the manikins were of simple gray. A new note, however, was the fact that their legs were painted a matching gray.

Dr. Alberto Guani, vice president-elect of Uruguay, declared last night at the Hotel Roosevelt that "we cannot now think of future boundaries; what now interests us is the abolition of political slavery in the post-war world."

In a little red brick building at 139 East Thirty-sixth Street, the Red Cross began yesterday the job of recruiting 125 Manhattan and Bronx nurses a month for service with the Army and Navy, as part of the national campaign to add 36,000 more nurses to the armed forces this year.
Sir Owen Dixon, the Australian Minister at Washington, has been joined at the Ritz-Carlton by Lady Dixon.

Officially opening the new Brooklyn Terminal Market in Canarsie yesterday, Mayor La Guardia warned that, because of war demands, there must be no waste of food. He said "the trimmings we discard just wouldn't be tolerated in other countries."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Representative Charles Wolverton of New Jersey said in a statement today that he would demand that the chairman and the assistant solicitor of the Securities and Exchange Commission be called before a Congressional committee "to explain their philosophy."

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Representatives of New York's firemen and policemen met today with Senator Hammond and Assemblyman Ostertag to ask changes in their bill authorizing the city and other municipalities to appoint temporary firemen and policemen

By a unanimous vote the City Council approved yesterday a resolution calling on Mayor La Guardia to appoint a special committee to study the growth of juvenile delinquency within the city and to make recommendations for combating it. Before the vote was taken the Council was informed by Majority Leader Joseph T. Sharkey that the Mayor had agreed to appoint such a committee promptly.

LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The first activity by advance elements of the British Eighth Army that crossed the border into Tunisia last week was reported tonight from Algiers, indicating that General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's forces might be getting ready to strike at Marshal Rommel from the south.

The Erie Railroad Company is negotiating for the sale of $14,000,000 of first consolidated mortgage bonds. All details of the issue have not yet been worked out, but it is understood that the sale will be handled privately by a banking group.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- New Britain Island, one of the big bases from which the Japanese could be loosing their latest announced offensive in the Solomons, has been raided by United Nations planes, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique disclosed today.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- In a desert valley through which camel caravans wind, American tanks and other armored Titans appeared today to fight a battle for the rail station of Sened, near Maknassy, on their way westward.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- Cornell opened its Farm and Home Week today with wartime problems stressed in lectures, round tables and discussions by the faculty of the State College of Agriculture, home economics and veterinary medicine.

If industry wants to avoid collectivism "by default," it must start preparing now to provide jobs for 55,000,000 people in the post-war era and goods and services worth $140,000,000,000, C. Scott Fletcher, director of field development of the Committee for Economic Development, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York.

It is regrettable that the representatives of the Army, the Navy and the rubber program should be forced to air their differences in public. The spectacle of the Under-Secretary of War and the Rubber Director contradicting each other before a Congressional committee does not increase the confidence of the country in the management of the war.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Hollywood the new attraction will be "Air Force," a Warner Brothers action drama detailing the wartime adventures of a Flying Fortress and its crew. . . . "Immortal Sergeant," a film version of the book by John Brophy dealing with warfare in the Libyan desert, will be the newcomer at the Roxy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 - President Roosevelt said today that he had kept in constant touch with the White House, even while riding in an airplane, during his twenty-two-day transatlantic trip.

Greg Rice, the country's greatest distance runner, who has won so many consecutive races he isn't certain of the exact count, will start in the two-mile event in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. The world record-holder, inactive since he stepped into a hole while training outdoors last October, announced at the track writers' luncheon at the Paramount Hotel yesterday that he had turned in his entry to Fred Schmertz.

The heads of 25,000 New York corporations have been requested to appoint company chairmen for the Red Cross War Fund campaign that will begin on March 1, it was announced yesterday by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the local commerce and industry division of the fund.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- American bombers based in India blew up a large warehouse at Rangoon, vital Japanese supply port in Burma, and left fires raging in the dock area yesterday, the Tenth United States Army Air Force reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt's sixty-first birthday party was held Saturday in a Pan American clipper plane, flying 8,000 feet above Haiti, he told his press conference today.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday found both Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh battler who formerly held the world welterweight championship, and Beau Jack, Georgian, who is recognized here as world lightweight titleholder, in tip-top condition for their ten-round, non-title battle to be held Friday night in Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Navy Communique 268:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- A bill authorizing the construction of floating drydocks to accompany the United States and other Allied navies to combat areas was passed by the House today by voice vote.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- At least ten acres of the German submarine base and naval arsenal at Lorient, France, have been smashed up by the hundreds of tons of explosives rained down in recent British and American raids, the Air Minister reported today on the basis of Royal Air Force reconnaissance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- American workers and industrialists have every reason to feel proud of "the truly amazing" war-output record they established last year, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board Chairman, said today in giving out figures showing a 500 per cent rise in munitions production in the months since Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt held a press conference and saw Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, United States Minister to New Zealand, George S. Messersmith, United States Ambassador to Mexico, and Edward J. Flynn.

The women's division of the British War Relief Society has collected $198,756 in its current campaign, Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the division, announced yesterday at a meeting of many of the 1,240 volunteer workers in the Hotel Plaza.

Further new high levels were reached yesterday by the stock market, but prices wavered somewhat in the afternoon to produce a mixed closing. Although a long list of specialties was sought by active traders, the railroad issues continued to improve and consolidate their position in reflection of the previous strength in the industrial section.
The four five-story apartment houses at 13, 15, 17 and 19 West 106th Street, near Central Park West, have been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman, operator, from a client of Solomon Ginsberg, attorney.

When Winston Churchill flew from Casablanca via Cairo to Turkey to meet Ismet Inonu, successor of Ataturk, he landed on a modern airfield. But Adana itself, like most places in the Near East, is old and haunted by history. The people in the eastern basin of the Mediterranean are connected with the past by a line that is never quite erased in their thoughts or in their policy.

Frederick L. Bauer, 40 years old, who was dismissed from the police force on Jan. 18 on his plea in General Sessions of guilty on the theft of about $7,500 of the funds of the Patrolmen's Progressive Association when he was its financial secretary. was sentenced yesterday to Sing Sing for fifteen to thirty months by Judge Saul S. Streit.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 2 -- United Nations air strength in the South Pacific has increased greatly in the past three months, according to Major Gen. Millard F. Harmon, U.S.A., as quoted by an official New Zealand Government war correspondent in a delayed dispatch from Guadalcanal. General Harmon said the increased strength was due to development of airfields and other facilities.

Western Kentucky, with a perfect string of fourteen victories, and New York University, its record unmarred in eleven starts, will go into action tonight at Madison Square Garden, but not against each other. The Southerners are slated to clash with C.C.N.Y. and the Violets with the Terriers of St. Francis College, the first game starting at 8:15 P.M.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Reports of a revival in the demand for flour, combined with a little buying of wheat futures attributed to mills, sent the market for wheat upward in the late trading today on the Board of Trade, and the close was at the top, with gains of 1/8 to 1/4 cent a bushel.

ED DIDDLE has a slow Southern drawl, a quick, active mind, an acute sense of humor and an unbeaten basketball team. He will have all four of these items in Madison Square Garden tonight, but the only one the crowd will be able to observe will be his Western Kentucky State quintet, which figures to make City College its fifteenth straight victim without having to open the throttle too far.

Brooks Atkinson, our envoy in Cathay, has found an original and a marrowy character in Chungking. Pop Schwer, sometime of St. Louis, sometime chief engineer of an American gunboat on the Yangtze, for twenty years resident in Chungking, philosopher and friend, is the man.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The stock markets have maintained their firmness today under the news of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's conference with President Ismet Inonu of Turkey and the subsequent activities of Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Turkey, although there was no marked improvement in prices.

The latest report of Representative Dies, made on the floor of Congress, cannot wholly commend itself to those who have an old-fashioned, one-hundred-per-cent fondness for orderly procedure, the rules of evidence and the democratic process. Mr. Dies objects vigorously to "a vicious assault upon members of the House" which was made last May by a magazine with which he is out of sympathy.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2- John W. Douglas of Northampton, Mass., was voted the outstanding member of the class of 1943 at Princeton University in a poll of the seniors taken before their graduation Saturday, according to the results announced today.
ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Legislators who studied Governor Dewey's budget message think he is marking out a course of conservatism in finance.

Enactment of local legislation fixing uniform closing hours for retail grocery and butcher stores, of which there are 100,000 in the city, was suggested yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in a letter to the City Council. He said such a measure had been requested by many retail associations.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 2 -- Large war industries in the Portland area, which are turning out Liberty ships, naval vessels, aircraft parts and other war items never publicly told, were lined up today in a countrywide accident-prevention campaign headed by William A. Irvin, national chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., began a serious hunt among its personnel yesterday for ungremial Gremlins and issued a pamphlet to its thousands of workers aloft and earthbound, to cast these Gremlins out.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2 -- The Federal Assembly of Railroad Workers was preparing today its reply to a strongly worded letter that President Manuel Avila Camacho had addressed to Jose Ibarra, secretary general of the Workers Syndicate, in which he made a last appeal for cooperation to render more efficient the national railroad network.

Henry G. Riter 3d, new chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., will be the principal speaker at the seventeenth annual dinner of the New York Security Dealers Association, to be held tomorrow night in the Waldorf Astoria.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 -- Michele Morgan has been chosen by Universal to star in "Two Tickets for London," mystery yarn by Roy William Neill, with a screen play by Tom Reed. The picture will be produced and directed by Edwin. L. Marin. Miss Morgan had previously been announced for "One Hundred Girls and a Man," a story now in abeyance.

Cotton prices held fairly steady yesterday in dull trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts, reflecting minor buying support from commission houses in the distant positions and equally insignificant liquidation in the near months, ended the session mixed, 3 points lower to 4 points higher than Monday's final prices.

Drastic write-downs have completely changed the picture of the General Investment Corporation since it became the Foundation Industrial Engineering Company, Inc. The merger of the investment trust and the Foundation Company of Delaware on Oct. 14 last was accomplished by a write-down of capital from $2,700,007 to $86,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Japanese have launched a desperate effort to recapture control of the entire Solomons area, with the result that the United States and the enemy have both suffered losses in air and naval actions, the Navy Department announced tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The general tendency in Britain to look ahead to the economic problems of postwar society was reflected in the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Processors of meats made a determined attack today on prices of hogs although receipts here and at the nation's other principal markets were not considered excessive. Buyers for the major killers refused to make purchases until asking prices had been shaved off 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt was in excellent spirits when he received the newspaper correspondents at his press conference today and gave them an extended report on his African trip and the conference with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at Casablanca.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In order to allow for marital and dependency exemptions and other deductions granted under the income tax law the Treasury has drawn up a tentative schedule of weekly exemptions to expedite the operation of its proposed 19 per cent income tax withholding system.

The Japanese Domei Agency said in a transmission intended for the United States yesterday that Premier Hideki Tojo had told the House of Representatives that Japan was now a "have" power "far richer than Britain or the United States."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Colonel Douglas C. Mackeachie, 42, general purchasing agent for the European theatre of operations, and Lieut. Col. Russell R. Brunner, 32, Air Corps pilot, are missing in action, the War Department reported today. No details were disclosed.

For the hours they have contributed to war relief work since Pearl Harbor, 1,000 merit pins and service chevrons were awarded yesterday to volunteer workers of the English-Speaking Union of the United States, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 -- Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, addressing the Advertising Club of Los Angeles today, minced no words in telling his hearers what he thought should be done at once to help the nation's fighting men.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, estimated yesterday that, altogether, 800,000 men here between the ages of 18 and 38 years must have their cases considered carefully to determine whether they were eligible for military service under the terms of the new order from the War Manpower Commission, aimed at the drafting of fathers not engaged in occupations officially listed as essential to the war effort.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Appealing to British farmers for increased land cultivation during 1943, which, he said, is Britain's most urgent and most immediate task, Robert S. Hudson, Minister of Agriculture, hinted today at things to come when he told a meeting of farmers at Maidstone that they could not expect the same help from the Army this year that they had had in the past two.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- According to confidential figures assembled by the General Staff, Intelligence Section, of one of the United Nations and based on German insurance statistics smuggled out of the Reich, as well as expert estimates here, more than 4,000,000 Nazi soldiers are now believed to have been killed, captured or permanently crippled so far in this war.

The surprise meeting between the Turkish President and Prime Minister Churchill, coming right after the Casablanca conference and with the United States as an invisible participant, is another dramatic demonstration that the United Nations have seized not only the military but also the political initiative, and that the two combined are now drawing a noose around Hitler's neck.

Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox told the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Foreign Press Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night that he had been greatly encouraged by what he had just seen of "the tide of our united power rolling relentlessly in the South Pacific," but that the Navy still lacks enough equipment to overcome the Germane submarines in the Atlantic, which he called "our most menacing danger now."

Following the withdrawal by Luigi Antonini, president of the Italia-American Labor Council, of his charges against officials of the Foreign Language Division of the Office of War Information alleging efforts on their part to force the inclusion of Communists and former Fascists in the formation of Italian-American Victory Councils, the Mazzini Society, which had joined in the charges, yesterday issued a similar statement.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 2 (AP) -- Reuben D. Silliman, East Orange lawyer, filed in Federal court today an answer denying charges of fraud made by the government in a civil suit to recover $881,298 on assets of more than $3,000,000 returned after the first World War to a German business man.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Major George A. Spiegelberg told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that as a result of the lend-lease program all United States forces in the United Kingdom had spent only about $1,000,000 for purchases from British commercial sources since June.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Just how it happened nobody seemed to know, but when they visited Parliament with a group of less glamorous stagehands today to protest a move to open theatres on Sundays, about 100 chorus girls were shunted for their meeting into Room No. 14, which has earned the adjective "famous" because Cabinet members and other high government officials have often used it in the past.

Buyers registered in the New York market in January set an all-time record of 6,752, increasing 2.7 per cent over the previous high set in January, 1942, when 6,574 listing were made. Buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 717, compared with the 1,245 in the preceding week and 1,132 for the corresponding period a year ago.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Feb. 2 -- John (Jake the Barber) Factor, Chicago promoter and speculator, today was sentenced to serve ten years in a Federal penitentiary and to pay a $10,000 fine for his role in a million-dollar whisky warehouse receipts swindle.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--French funds blocked or frozen in this country, to the amount of $1,594,000,000, are ready for requisition by a French government that is established de jure; that is, by the free will expression of the French people.

Cartels are preparing "to pick up their old arrangements now that victory is assured," Thurman W. Arnold, assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, declared last night at the annual dinner of the New York Credit Men's Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

It was spaghetti day down at the Salvation Army day nursery yesterday. Children, their faces smeared with tomato sauce, their clothes saved by jumpers and bibs, were seated around pint-sized tables, gorging on the food they knew and liked best.

A feud between two lower East Side Italian families which, according to Assistant District Attorney Louis A. Pagnucco, began more than twenty-two years ago and thus far has three killings attributed to it, came to light in General Sessions yesterday at the arraignment of Angelo Ficarella, 52 years old, of 100 Baruch Place on a first-degree manslaughter indictment in the fatal stabbing of John Grespo, 42, of 3 Baruch Place, last July 12.

The regional office of the War Manpower Commission announced last night that all New York City offices of its United States Employment Service would remain open until 9 P.M., starting today, to handle applications for war jobs or war training.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 -- The horsemen of Maryland want racing continued and their thoroughbreds kept in trim during the war, so they came out today in favor of purses based on the size of pari-mutuel play, even "as small as $5" if need be.

Members of the Council on Books in Wartime, meeting yesterday at luncheon at the Hotel Ambassador, heard a message from Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, which expressed a "healthy respect for the part books can play in a full war-information program."

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- Canada has been building cargo ships during the past year at a rate that exceeds even that of the United States when allowance is made for the 12-to-1 difference in population, according to figures given to Parliament last evening by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 2 -- Dick Rondeau of Providence, captain and star center of the Dartmouth hockey team, has been named coach of the team as well, it was announced today by William H. McCarter, director of athletics at Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- President Roosevelt broadly implied today that the United States and Great Britain had reached agreement at the Casablanca conferences on an invasion of the European Continent in 1943.

Fifteen hundred women crowded into the ballroom of the Essex House on Central Park South last night to hear Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt discuss the part that the women of Great Britain are playing in the war. She was the principal speaker at a meeting sponsored jointly by the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. Women's Committee on Civilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- War Manpower Commission sources said tonight it was "a safe bet" that eventually all professional athletes, including baseball players, would face the problem of shifting to an essential industry or being classified 1-A, regardless of dependents.

To replace nurses serving with the armed forces, 2,300 more volunteer nurse's aides will be needed in the city by May 1, it was announced yesterday by the American Red Cross and the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 31 reported on a National Institute on War and Post-War Issues, sponsored, in Chicago, by the American Library Association. This institute was attended by more than 200 of the country's leading librarians whose views were said to be the "result of their contacts with patrons of their respective libraries throughout the country."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- The Navy announced today ninety-eight casualties in Navy forces. including twenty-three dead, twenty-nine wounded and forty-six missing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The government warned hundreds of thousands of workers today to expect no further draft deferments, regardless of their number of dependents, unless they found more essential jobs.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 2 (U.P.) -- A $100,000 damage suit against Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings for alleged defamation of character in her book, "Cross Creek," was on file in Circuit Court tonight.
" These are great days for the fish," laughed the visitor, "they must be having a grand time thinking of all you fellows who can't go out."

Musical instruments and athletic equipment are urgently needed for shipment to prisoner-of-war camps in enemy countries, it was disclosed yesterday at the national headquarters of the Young Men's Christian Association, 347 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 3 -- The Red Army has completed the destruction of 330,000 trapped troops at Stalingrad, the flower of Adolf Hitler's army, Moscow announced last night in a special bulletin. This raised the Russians' announced toll of Axis casualties on the Volga since last Fall to more than 500,000 in dead and captured alone.
U.S. NAVAL AIR STATION, Quonset Point, R.I., Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- Quonset has become a name to conjure with in the naval service.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, warned yesterday that substitution of the word "buildings" for "dwellings" in a proposed resolution of the City Planning Commission concerning site plans for large residential developments might make it possible for unscrupulous persons to erect factories, slaughterhouses or other objectionable structures within such developments.

Recently arrived from an herb; farm just north of the city limits is a bedtime brew that is "as soothing as a mother's lullaby," to quote the label. The bits of red and green and blue that may be seen through the clear glass jar proclaim the presence of no less than fourteen herbs, among them fennel and lady slipper, sassafras and elder flowers.

Women in colleges can contribute a greater ultimate good to their country by finishing their courses than by leaving to join the Waves, Waacs or Spars, both Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Waacs, and Lieut. Comdr. Mildred McAfee, head of the Waves, agreed yesterday at a "Women and the War" program in Town Hall.

Courses to train students for post-war reconstruction work in Greece will be given by the Finch Junior College and the newly founded Finch School of Adult Education, Mrs. Jessica G. Cosgrave, president and founder of the college, announced yesterday.

The old four-story brownstone house at 2077 Fifth Avenue will be sold at auction at the offices of the Collector of Internal Revenue at 11 A.M. today unless Homer Collyer, recluse, who lives with his brother Langley at 2078 Fifth Avenue, pays up by that time the $1,900 in income tax arrears, plus interest, that the government says has piled up against him in the last twelve years.

A vivid picture of Leningrad during the siege was given yesterday by a young Russian, who, as a guerrilla fighter in that area, witnessed not only the valiant Russian resistance but also the German atrocities, some of which he and his comrades avenged in silent nocturnal raids on the enemy.

Miss Jean Stark, daughter of James Harrington Stark of Darien, Conn., and this city, has chosen her attendants for her marriage on Saturday to John P. Colmore, son of the Right Rev. Charles B. Colmore, Episcopal Bishop of Puerto Rico, and Mrs. Colmore.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 2 -- Adolf Heinz Beckerle, German Minister in Sofia, has been recalled at the demand of the Bulgarian Government, according to reports reaching here.

LONDON, Feb. 2--Returning westward after his successful meeting with President Ismet Inonu of Turkey on Turkish soil, Prime Minister Winston Churchill broke his journey at Nicosia, the ancient capital of Cyprus, where he addressed assembled notables.

The city's surface transportation facilities and occasionally its rapid transit lines are experiencing great difficulty in meeting expanded needs because of shortages of equipment and inability to get repair parts and materials, officials of the Board of Transportation agreed yesterday after the existing service had been condemned at a meeting of the City Council.

Among those who signed leases for residential quarters reported yesterday by brokers was Diosa Costello, singer and dancer, who rented a three-room suite in the Hotel Wellington, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

Fears that their initial stocks of Fall merchandise may be curbed have been expressed by Eastern retailers because of the restrictions of the Inventory Limitation Order L-219, it was learned here yesterday.

Manhattan College's basketball team turned in a workmanlike job in beating a highly rated Providence quintet, 65 -- 47, in a Jasper gymnasium filled to the rafters with a crowd of 1,100 last night. It was the eleventh triumph for the once-beaten wearers of the green, who were playing a team that had tasted defeat only once in ten previous games.

A few casualties from war areas overseas have started to arrive at the Halloran General Hospital, Willowbrook, S.I., it became known yesterday. However, the hospital that the Army took over recently is as yet only partly built, and of its 1,000 beds fewer than 200 are occupied.

ALGIERS, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- The eleven men freed today are pro-Allied sympathizers and most are followers of General Charles de Gaulle, the Fighting French leader. Several aided the Allied occupation of North Africa.

The Rangers will oppose the Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. And since the class will be the last one on local ice for ten days, a better than fair crowd is expected to turn out to see the last-place Blue Shirts do battle against the Windy City sextet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Warnings that the maldistribution of canned goods would not end with the introduction of a rationing program scheduled to begin March 1 unless more consideration were given to local buying habits by the Office of Price Administration were given to the agency by individual canners this week.
BANGALORE, Mysore State, India, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- Christianity's greatest problem in India is the caste system, Mgr. Leo Kierkels, Apostolic Delegate, told your correspondent this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made a plea in the House of Commons today for patience regarding the North African political situation. He declared there was no difference between the British and American Governments on any issues there but that "deep cleavages" between Frenchmen, whose problem it was primarily, could not be "easily bridged."

Improvement of labor relations on the city's transit system and establishment of labor-management committees to stimulate inventiveness and economies in material would increase employe efficiency enormously, representatives of the Transport Workers Union contended yesterday at a hearing before a special committee named by Mayor La Guardia to investigate the labor relations.

Macmillan announces the publication of "Merchant Ships, 1942," a volume designed to help seamen distinguish friend from foe on the high seas. Although it has been published annually in England since 1932, this is the first American edition.

The female of the species is a creature of inconsistency. She observes enthusiastic economy in her purchases and use of food and furnishings for her home, but buys beauty aids indiscriminately, uses them not wisely, but too well, and considers the process her inalienable right.

The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, in its eighty-fifth annual statement issued yesterday by M.J. Cleary, president, disclosed a new high record in assets and insurance in force at the close of 1942.

Two floors and a penthouse in 333-39 West Fifty-second Street have been leased by the Amertype Recordgraph Corporation, a subsidiary of the American Type Founders Company, from the Adanfa Construction Company. The quarters contain about 10,000 square feet of space and will be used for offices and the assembling of sound recording instruments.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Harry C. McCaffrey, 39 years old, president of the McCaffrey Construction Company of 109 Houston Street, Newark, was found dead this morning in the yard of his home in Ridge Road here. He was clad only in a pajama coat.

Within striking distance of the weights at which they aimed when their preparatory campaigns got under way, Fritzie Zivic, former world welterweight champion, and Beau Jack, Georgian, who is recognized as world lightweight title-holder, yesterday concluded hard training for their ten-round match tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

Three natives of Germany whom the government is seeking to deprive of acquired United States citizenship on allegations of fraud testified yesterday in their own behalf before Federal Judge John Bright. Each protested his loyalty to this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- American and Japanese airplanes and warships are locked in clashes over a widespread area of the Solomons and are sparring fiercely for position in the fight to control the crucial South Seas area, a Navy spokesman reported today.

Probably it is Margaret Webster who is the heroine of "Counterattack," which opened last evening at the Windsor Theatre. For she has taken what must have been a not very good play and by her direction has built it into a rather tense melodrama.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 -- Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein, accompanied by "several high-ranking German officers," arrived in Sofia this afternoon for "prolonged talks" with the Bulgarian General Staff, according to a report received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Captain Howard M. Cone Jr. of Douglaston, L.I., and Captain Otis V. Bryan, two veteran commercial airline pilots, who flew President Roosevelt on his war conference trip to Africa and South America, told reporters today that the President was aft excellent passenger, a good air sailor, and a man well schooled in geography, who could distinguish territory by its landmarks without reference to navigational charts.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's conference with President Ismet Inonu of Turkey, combined with the constant German nervousness voiced in official Berlin propaganda about the possibilities of a United Nations attack in the Dodecanese Islands as preliminary to the potential opening of a second front in the Balkans, has focused public attention on the necessity of cleaning up the dreary Yugoslav situation as soon as possible.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Red Army has driven to a point only twenty-two miles north of Kursk, German bastion in Southern Russia, has cut off another Nazi escape corridor in the Caucasus below Rostov and has captured the important railway junction of Kupyansk, only sixty-three miles southeast of Kharkov, Ukraine capital, a special Russian communique recorded by the Soviet monitor here said tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Business was quiet on the stock markets today, with prices generally easier. There was little movement in gilt-edge stocks, and both home and foreign railway issues eased.

The Erie Railroad Company has sold a new fifteen-year issue of $14,000,000 of first consolidated mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, series D, due on Feb. 1, 1958, to Morgan Stanley Co. and associates, it was announced yesterday. The deal is subject to authorization by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the issuance and sale of the bonds.

Work-a-day problems of eating well in the midst of rationing and shortages were brought to the River Club at Fifty-second Street and the East River yesterday by Commisioner Daniel P. Woolley of the Department of Markets.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 3 -- American infantry and artillery have dug in east of Sened and the railroad station to the south, it was announced today, although some of the forces that raided the town and captured a number of German prisoners and about twenty tanks were drawn off after an enemy counter-attack had been repulsed.

The clarity, brilliancy and taste that characterize the playing of Robert Casadesus were fully in evidence when he gave a piano recital before a crowded house, with many seated on the stage, last night in Carnegie Hall. The music of Rameau and Scarlatti is well calculated to bring his qualities into play.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks, sponsor of a series of bills affecting labor conditions on the New York City transit system, amended today his principal measure, designed to bar a closed shop on the system, so that it no longer would act to prevent Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, from acting as a union negotiator.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 The first big ballet to reflect moods of the war is in rehearsal here for presentation around May 1. The music is by Oransicy and the choreographer is Leonid Jacobson, who is using his own version of a Russian fairy tale for this Bolshoi Theatre production, which promises to be one of the most gorgeous and ambitious ballets in many years.

The business property at 826-36 Third Avenue, at the southwest corner of Fifty-first Street, known as a center of antique shops, has been sold by the Dry Dock Savings Institution to Morris H. Harris, of Essex House, through Ira Kavanau, broker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Pending completion of a "priority list" of standardized heavyweight undergarments considered to be most essential for civilian use next Winter, the Office of Price Administration has advised the industry's advisory committee that a manufacturer is permitted to agree to sell knit underwear to a customer under an open-price type of contract.

Representatives of twenty-three leading department stores and specialty shops assembled at the headquarters of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York at 130 West Forty-second Street yesterday afternoon and drew lots to see which combat area and function of the Red Cross each would portray in a display window when the drive for funds begins here March 1.

Sir Ganga Singh, Maharaja of Bikaner, who died this week at Bombay, was the intelligent and vigorous ruler of a strange country. It is largely covered with loose sandhills. You might almost say that water won't run. Two streams straggle and die. Wells have to be very deep.

The names of fifty-six former students of New York City high schools who have won decorations or citations for extraordinary war service were made public yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools. Many of those cited on the roll of honor are nationally known heroes.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 3 -- Passage of an amendment to the town zoning ordinance last night by the Montclair Commission opens the gates to considerable garden apartment construction in Montclair. The amendment also permits conversion, in certain areas, of one-family homes to multi-family use.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Full use of the manpower and facilities of State prisons in the war effort was urged today by the Prison Association of New York in its ninety-eighth annual report to the Legislature as one of eleven major problems requiring immediate consideration at Albany.

Accidentally pushed off the platform at the Main Street, Flushing, Queens, terminal of the IRT as a train was starting for Manhattan at 7:10 A.M. yesterday, Carl Scheide, 32 years old, of 13-31 126th Street, College Point, Queens, found himself between two cars and "rode the rods" through a tunnel and across the top level of the Roosevelt Avenue bridge over the Flushing Creek to the Willets Point Boulevard station in Corona.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Striking fiercely at factories that are helping the Nazis' U-boat warfare, British-based Allied airmen last night made a twenty-minute "thunderbolt" raid on Cologne. They dropped one hundred two-ton bombs at the rate of one every twelve seconds as well as hundreds of other high explosives and thousands of incendiaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The House (Dies) committee to investigate un-American activities won a vote of confidence from the rules committee today despite a charge by Representative Folger of North Carolina that the Dies group was too interested in publicity and concentrated on Russia rather than Germany and Japan.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 3 (AP) -- New Jersey residents want "honest, courageous and intelligent" candidates nominated in this year's primary elections, Governor Charles Edison said tonight, they must see to it that tickets are not picked "in the City Hall, Jersey City, or by "a handful of men in a smoke-filled hotel room in Atlantic City."

The Metropolitan Opera has installed a loudspeaker system connecting from the box-office to the main lobby. Every ten minutes during the day a member of the box-office staff addresses the crowd waiting to purchase tickets.

An appeal to women of the United Nations to intensify their war efforts, issued yesterday through the Greek Office of Information at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, disclosed that Greek women in the homeland and throughout the United States had seized the opportunity nearest at hand to make their force felt in the war.

MOTOR TORPEDO BOAT SQUADRONS' TRAINING CENTER, Portsmouth, R.I., Jan. 27 (Delayed) -- The PT boats, coated with snow and ice, streaked across the sullen, slate-gray waters of Narragansett Bay today as student officers and men of the mosquito fleet learned how to sting the Japanese.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A special Russian communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Since the red light hasn't been turned on yet, professional baseball and football have decided to go right on about their business of getting ready for the 1943 seasons until such time as new and expanded War Manpower Commission rulings put on the brakes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Opposition in the House of Representatives against "government by directive" took another form today when the Rules Committee, by a majority vote, sent to the floor for action a resolution to set up a special five-member committee empowered to make formal inquiry into any action, rule, procedure, regulation, order or directive taken or promulgated by any agency of the government where complaint is made on these grounds.

Adoption of an accelerated program by medical schools has made possible the graduation of 5,000 more doctors than would have been supplied under a normal academic program, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, reported yesterday.

United States law enforcement officials are concerned seriously over the drive of the Toronto Stock Exchange, thus far successful, to prevent ratification of a new extradition treaty between Canada and this country. The new treaty, ratified by the Senate last July, would plug holes in the old 1905 document and close the Dominion as a refuge for fake stock salesmen, mail-fraud operators and other swindlers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 3 -- Having occupied a desert point called Zelten, the British Eighth Army's main body is now within twenty miles of the Tunisian border. Although the British are in contact with the enemy, they are fighting only skirmishes with German rearguard elements and there is still nothing to indicate any serious enemy resistance short of the Mareth Line, seventy miles beyond the Tunisian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Switching of tires among passenger cars operated by a Federal, State, local or foreign governmental agency is permitted by an amendment to the tire-rationing regulations issued today by the Office of Price Administration.

Bud Abbott and Lew Costello, who were voted the nation's best box office attraction by theatre owners in a number of film industry trade paper polls, were crowned officially yesterday as the nation's "No. 1 Box Office Stars" by Mayor La Guardia, at a luncheon given in their honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Starlight Roof.

As a result of exhaustive tests made by soldiers under simulated combat conditions, Army specifications may be changed to conserve wool used in barrack blankets and vital cotton linters used for mattresses, according to Colonel Max R. Wainer of the Quartermaster Corps and a director of the quartermaster board at Camp Lee, Va., where the tests were made.

ALGIERS, Feb. 3 (AP) -- In the first North African move to break all possible economic ties with the Axis, the Official Gazette published today a blacklist, based on information of the United States State Department, of all firms in, Spain and other countries charged with trading with Germany.
MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Today's communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Coffee rations for consumers will be slashed by one-sixth when coffee stamp No. 25 becomes valid next Monday. The new stamp will provide for a single pound of coffee in six weeks instead of a pound every five weeks.

Tonight at the Biltmore, Alfred de Liagre Jr. will present "Ask My Friend Sandy," a farce comedy by Stanley Young, with Roland Young, last seen here in "Spring Thaw" (1938), starred. In featured roles are Norman Lloyd and Mary Sargent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Taking cognizance of complaints among minority groups concerning alleged Federal inaction on discrimination in war employment, President Roosevelt directed Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman, today to call a conference to consider revising and strengthening the powers of the President's Fair Employment Practices Committee.

Lend-lease aid to Poland for the post-war restoration of its health and medical services was indicated yesterday by Lieut. Col. Antoni Jurasz, medical director of the Paderewski Memorial Hospital in Edinburgh and dean of the Polish Medical School at the University of Edinburgh.

Trailing by eight points twelve minutes before the end, the New York University basketball team rallied to eke out a 45-44 victory, their twelfth straight, over a scrappy, resourceful St. Francis College quintet at Madison Square Garden last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- Asserting that the rate of fatalities from accidents in the San Francisco metropolitan area was 26 per cent higher last year than the national average for cities of more than 100,000 population, representatives of the National Safety Council began discussing with business and industrial leaders here today the formation of a local council to direct accident prevention work.

A conspiracy to traffic in securities stolen and then transported here from Miami was charged yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to Frank L. Miller, lawyer; Albert J. Contento, alias Al Howard, former night-club operator, and six other men.

I enjoyed reading Professor Walter Russell Bowie's rebuttal of Rex Stout's article of Jan. 17, "We Shall Hate, or We Shall Fail." Yet to this reader the issue was not resolved by Dr. Bowie's remarks. There is ever a need for good hatred, despite the fact, which Dr. Bowie labored in fine heat, that charity and love are greater moral qualities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- There recently appeared in the war administration what Rubber Director Jeffers told a House committee is needed most: "A fellow at the top who can say 'yes' or 'no' and mean it." The "fellow" is James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

Emphasizing that hospitals, war industries and the armed services all are suffering from a shortage of trained nurses, Colonel George Baehr, chief medical officer of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared yesterday that Congressional action will be sought for the creation of a Victory Nurse Corps.

An over-all increase in electric generating capacity of more than 30 per cent to meet the accelerated demands of war production was reported yesterday by the North American Company, one of the nation's largest utility holding company systems.

Unless the American people formulate a foreign policy that will give the people of Europe "something firm, definite and final to believe in," revolutions resulting in communism or fascism will be ignited in Europe as soon as the present war ends, Dr. Herbert Agar, president of Freedom House, told 644 Hunter College graduates at commencement exercises in the college auditorium last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 3 -- Warner Brothers, who, in filming Irving Berlin's "This Is the Army" will add a fictional story to the soldier show, has assigned Joan Leslie to the romantic lead in this part of the picture. Miss Leslie, now working at RKO in Fred Astaire's "The Sky's the Limit," will fill a role in the Army film previously mentioned as a possibility for Ginger Rogers.

Girls of 'teen age picked up in this area by service men outnumber professional prostitutes by a ratio of 4 to 1 as spreaders of venereal diseases among our armed forces, a conference on wartime control of venereal disease was informed yesterday by representatives of the Army, Navy and the United States Public Health Service.
Apropos Professor Bowie's article and the previous one by Rex Stout, here is an extract from a letter to me from an Army air cadet:

Rear Admiral Ben Moreell and Frank W. Barnes, construction manager for the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, were the recipients last night of awards from the Moles, an organization of heavy construction engineers, at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt that was attended by 1,000 persons.

Fishermen who may be watching for signs to indicate whether new rules will be made to permit them to travel by automobile to distant fishing spots will find nothing exceptional in the stand recently taken in New Hampshire.

LESTER PATRICK and Frank Boucher were surprisingly cheerful. They certainly had no right to look so beaming and unalarmed. The expectation was that they'd have the harried appearance of stock market plungers of 1929. The New York Ranger stock, to be specific, had hit a new all-time low.

A temporary surplus of trained ordinary seamen is creating a "backlog" of waiting men who are becoming restless because they have no ships, but officials of the War Shipping Administration in charge of training and manning are making every effort to meet the unexpected development by readjusting its facilities, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Pacific War Council at its weekly meeting today with President Roosevelt learned that he and Prime Minister Winston Churchill during their conference at Casablanca had "pretty well settled" the question of where to strike against the Axis in Europe.

The last remnants of the great German garrison at Stalingrad have surrendered, and the Russians are coming back into the ruins of the city that now lies like a skeleton on the battered banks above the unconquered Volga. Stalingrad is the scene of the costliest and most stubborn struggle in this war.

MADRID, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Spanish press dispatches from Paris reported today that the whole French black market was engaged in frantic liquidation as the result of the spreading idea that the war would end soon.

The current control on trade with Argentina are "adequate" and, although the Department of State may find it desirable to institute a boycott against that country, foreign traders should "take care of their own knitting," exporters asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A charge that Adolf Hitler murdered the only woman he ever loved because she fell in love with her Jewish singing teacher was made by Ernst (Putzi) Hanfstaengl, former Nazi foreign press chief, in an article published in the Cosmopolitan magazine.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3 (AP) -- The naval officer credited with driving Axis submarines out of the Atlantic-Gulf-Caribbean area was transferred today to an undisclosed post but one where the U-boat is still a definite menace. He is Rear Admiral James L. Kauffman, commandant of the Seventh Naval District and commander of the Gulf sea frontier.

The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday a consolidated net profit of $11,929,867 for 1942, equivalent to $5.41 a share on 2,205,667 capital shares, comparing with $17,102,350, or $7.75 a share, in the preceding year. The figures are subject to year-end audit.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 3 -- Dartmouth launched Captain Dick Rondeau's hockey coaching career successfully tonight on Davis Rink by downing Princeton, 4 -- 0, in a Pentagonal League game for its twenty-eighth straight victory. It was Goalie Al Barrett's first shutout of the year, and although Ned Kelly, the losers' net-minder, let four get by him, he was the game's individual star, as he consistently stopped Indian surges.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The troops that Adolf Hitler has left along the battlefront from Kharkov to Novorissiisk can be estimated tentatively as follows: Rostov and its defense perimeter, 250,000 men; remnants of the Caucasus army south or Rostov, 70,000 to 80,000; on the front before Kharkov, 250,000.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- On both the southern and southwestern fronts the Red Army's advance in the last forty-eight hours has been more rapid than for some time, despite stiffening resistance, while General Ivan V. Tulineff's Caucasus Army is not yet in sight of its final objectives -- the complete clearance of the Kuban and the West Caucasus.

Preliminary heats for the sixty-yard dash and high hurdles in the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night were needed yesterday, it was announced by Fred Schmertz, meet director. Thirty-two men will start in the sprint and sixteen in the hurdles.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Members of the House of Commons and House of Lords decided at a joint meeting tonight to draft a resolution proposing that Britain give sanctuary to Jews from Nazi-occupied countries.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3 -- The German Propaganda Ministry has decreed three days of national mourning for the "Stalingrad defenders," whose annihilation was announced to the German public in a special communique broadcast this afternoon.
In raising the bogey of bolshevism once more, Berlin's Propaganda Minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, writing in the latest issue of the weekly magazine the Reich, tries to frighten the British with it.

A new issue of $311,000 city of Camden, Ark., waterwork revenue bonds will be offered on Feb. 10 by the Arkansas Municipal Water Company of Little Rock. The issue will be dated Nov. 2, 1942, and will consist of $124,000 3 1/4s, due Jan. 1, 1944 to 1960, and $187,000 2 1/2s, due Jan. 1, 1961 to 1978.

The stock market suffered yesterday its first reversal in a week, but the losses failed to undermine the stability of the list. The major weakness was confined to the morning hours, and the unevenness was straightened out to some extent by a mild rally in the final period under the leadership of the steel group.
Events tonight: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

Well over 30,000 persons, most of them employed in non-essential industries, swamped the seven offices of the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday in search of war jobs in response to the "war-work-or-fight" order issued by the commission on Tuesday.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Lord Snell, Deputy Leader of the House of Lords, assured Lord Marley today that the government was trying a variety of schemes designed to reconcile a housewife's duties with her obligations as a citizen of a nation engaged in total war.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- The American Air Force fought the Germans today over the expanding battlefield in Southern Tunisia as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel succeeded in getting some of his prize armored units into the fighting in this sector.

KENVIL, N.J., Feb. 3 -- After the explosion in which fifty-two persons lost their lives at the Hercules Powder Company plant here in September, 1940, America had hardly enough powder to keep an army of 100,000 men in the field, Major Gen. Charles T. Harris Jr., commanding general at the Aberdeen Proving Ground, disclosed today at exercises marking the presentation of the Army-Navy "E" to the powder concern for its achievements in production.

Industry should immediately initiate and put before Congress a three-year post-war program designed to correlate production with consumption, Arthur Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, said yesterday. One of several speakers at the "Road Ahead Conference" of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Biltmore, Mr. Whiteside declared years of prosperity are ahead for the country if the necessary steps are taken to strike a balance between production and consumption.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Navy announced today seventy-five casualties in Navy forces, including seven dead, twenty-six wounded and forty-two missing, bringing to 22,639 the total of Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard casualties reported to next of kin since Dec. 7, 1941.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Major Al Key of Meridian, Miss., endurance flier of 1935, today received the Distinguished Service Cross, second only to the Congressional Medal of Honor, for "extraordinary heroism" in a bomber mission over Europe.

A ten-year campaign sponsored by educational leaders representing Protestant, Catholic and Jewish groups has proved successful in eliminating from the public, private and parochial school textbooks of the United States virtually all passages regarded as biased from the standpoint of race or religion, it was learned yesterday.

The three-story building containing stores and lofts on a lot 25 by 79 feet at 1015 East Tremont Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Bronx Savings Bank to a client of Morris D. Dubin. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., was the broker and the seller was represented by George K. Shields.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Feb. 3 -- Every new development of the war has created a new job for the Army engineer, until this historic home of the Corps of Engineers has become in 1943 half laboratory and half training ground, teaching to thousands of men the basic essentials of construction, destruction and reproduction.

From Rio de Janeiro, where it was "boiling," to the snows of New York they clippered, arriving here Tuesday clutching only a few costumes and their press book pasted with triumphant notices. Yesterday Theodora Roosevelt and her partner, Alexander Iolas, took time out at the home of her mother, Mrs. Archibald Roosevelt, 225 East Seventy-fourth Street, to explain why they went to Brazil for a six-week dance tour -- and remained eight months.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 3 -- On the ground that the Federal District Court lacked jurisdiction Judge James Alger Fee refused today to stop the National Labor Relations Board hearing of its unfair labor practices case against Henry J. Kaiser's three shipyards at Portland and Vancouver, Wash.

The property known as Glen Cairn Arms at 201 West State Street, Trenton, N.J., has been sold by the Glentrent Corporation to an investing client of Abraham Richter. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., was the broker.

The retirement of Lester F. Scott as national executive of the Camp Fire Girls after twenty-seven years as an official of the organization was announced yesterday. His resignation will take effect on March 31. He will be succeeded as national executive by Miss Martha F. Allen, now assistant executive.

Neither the rationing of gasoline nor the shortage of tires can stop the Victory Book Campaign from its appointed rounds. Going into action in the area between Ninety-sixth and 110th Streets between Central Park and Riverside Drive, the V Book Committee of Bundles for America collected 4,000 volumes.

Holding its opponent scoreless in the first quarter and yielding only four points through the second and third periods, Andrew Jackson High's five, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, scored its sixth straight South Queens success yesterday afternoon by humbling John Adams, 46 to 12.

Directors of the United States Rubber Company authorized yesterday a $2 dividend payable to preferred shareholders on March 26. The only dividend paid on this stock in 1942 was $4 a share distributed on Dec. 18. Prior to this stockholders received $2 on Dec. 19, 1941.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Fourteen Negroes received commissions today as officers of the United States Army and won the plaudits of Major Gen. Russell P. Hartle, deputy commander of the American Forces in the United Kingdom.

The 10 per cent reduction in the use of paper by magazines this year has brought in such a flood of orders for space to leading publications that many are booked solidly through the balance of the year and have been forced to turn down business, reports in the advertising field indicated yesterday.

Imagine a family of four living in a medium-income neighborhood in this city. There is the man of the house, an office worker, who leads a moderately active life and eats luncheon away from home. There is his wife -- she, too, is moderately active -- and there are two children, a boy of 14 and a girl of 10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Representative Halleck of Indiana asked the House today to authorize an investigation of the War Production Board's regulation curbing the use of printing paper, arguing that this "could threaten the press of the nation."

The largest union contract ever negotiated for white collar employes was signed yesterday between the United Office and Professional Workers of America, C.I.O., and the Prudential Insurance Company at the union's office, 8 West Fortieth Street. It affects 18,000 employes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Internal revenue collections of $16,774,416,290 for 1942 were almost double the $8,689,097,890 return for 1941, as reported today by the Treasury Department.

WITH U.S. FORCES, on Guadalcanal, Jan. 26 (Delayed) -- A group of shabby Japanese, arms raised in surrender, walked toward the American lines. Leading the way was Private Akiyoshi Hasamoto, 23-year-old veteran of the Japanese campaigns in China, Borneo and the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- American merchant marine losses in dead and missing during the first year of the war totaled more than 3,200, or 3.8 per cent of the number of merchant sailors, as compared with a rate of three-fourths of 1 per cent for the armed services, Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said today.

The War Department quietly issued a circular order a week ago renewing a forty-two-year-old prohibition of hard liquor in the military establishments of the United States, it was made known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Bankhead of Alabama declared today that nearly 1,000,000 men must be released from the Army and Navy to avert an acute shortage of food, while in the House, Representative Kilday of Texas called new manpower orders a threat to "the preservation of the family in American life."

CHICAGO, Feb. 3 -- Liquidation developed today in rye on the Board of Trade and prices slid more than 1 cent a bushel below yesterday's finish to the lowest level on the current downturn. The market showed a loss of 3 1/2 cents from the high of late last week, just before the government denied a report that it contemplated buying rye for shipment to Russia.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3 -- Pennsylvania, after trailing the Naval Academy basketball team until the last seven minutes of play today, staged a rally that gave the Philadelphians a 48-to-47 victory over the Midshipmen.

Taking strong exception to the pessimistic tone adopted by several rival club executives in the wake of the WMC's recent ruling on nondeferrable occupations, Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, declared yesterday in a 600-word statement to the press that he could see no reason why baseball men should not "take a more encouraging view of baseball's future than that expressed by some of our clubs."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 3 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a memorandum to his staff saying that "We are fighting a tough war and everything we do must be directed toward winning that war," warned today that he would not tolerate irresponsible talk against any of our allies, excessive drinking, sloppy dress and disorderly barracks.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman said tonight that 823,000 Serbs had been killed since Axis forces had moved in, and that a new wave of terror was sweeping Yugoslavia, the Germans threatening to "annihilate the entire population" unless resistance ceased.

Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie appeared in Harlem Municipal Court on Tuesday as a witness in a property damage suit, testifying in behalf of the plaintiff, the Level Transportation Company, a taxicab concern, to whom Justice Mario G. Di Pirro awarded a judgment for $77.95.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 3 -- Nine young priests of Maryknoll Seminary, who left here in the Summer of 1941 for missions in Free China, recently have reached the society's mission house at Kweilin, China, along with four other priests and a brother from Maryknoll who were interned with them for months in Stanley Prison in Hong Kong, it was announced today at the headquarters of the missioners.

The Federal Government yesterday took possession of an old brownstone house at 2077 Fifth Avenue after a representative of the Collector of Internal Revenue had waited more than an hour beyond the scheduled time of the auction sale of the property in the hope that Homer Collyer or his brother Langley would appear to pay an income tax claim and make seizure of the parcel unnecessary.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- A series of amendments to the Ostertag-Hammond Bill which would authorize New York City and other localities of the State to appoint temporary firemen and policemen during the war was agreed on today by representatives of members of the city police and fire forces and sponsors of the legislation.
A Broad Channel fisherman, cruising in Jamaica Bay, rescued two Navy fliers when their plane crashed in the bay yesterday afternoon.

Construction shortly after the end of the war of a new railroad terminal, particularly for the Long Island Railroad, on the site of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory was suggested yesterday by John Howes Burton, well known sponsor of civic improvements.

I'VE known John Hersey for some time. But I've known him as a person I used to meet and say hello to in the elevator in the Time-Life Building. Occasionally we used to compare notes on armchair strategy, for we were both writing about the war, with occasional help from so-called experts. Hersey, who was born in China, had his theories of naval warfare in the Far East.

" Tarzan Triumphs," the first film in that series to be produced by Sol Lesser for RKO, will open at the Palace this morning. Johnny Weissmuller, who heretofore has appeared as the jungle character for Metro, continues in the title role.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- This country will reach the brink of starvation if the armed forces persist in putting more than 11,000,000 men in uniform, Senator Bankhead of Alabama said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Representative McLean of New Jersey, at the Ways and Means Committee hearing today, asked Randolph Paul how far he thought "a real American" would go in accepting further paycheck deductions.

Members of the executive committee of the Bronx County Democratic Committee started yesterday a movement to get Edward J. Flynn to continue as chairman and county leader. Sponsors of the movement asserted that it would have the support of a majority of the committee members and possibly of all of them if Mr. Flynn should be willing to continue in the post.

" Keeping Victory Crops Growing" was the topic yesterday of T.H. Everett, horticulturist at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, in the third of the series of weekly lectures on "Planning of Victory Gardens," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and the Botanical Garden, in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway's president, Carl Elbridge Newton, today threatened legal action against the Erie Railroad's directors unless the Erie bought its financing "to benefit its stockholders rather than to benefit any selected seller of financing."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Thursday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Braving unfavorable weather to support the United Nations forces in the growing battle of the Solomons, General Douglas MacArthur's bombers raided New Britain Island, one plane attacking a Japanese warship, the High Command announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 3 -- Eleven of fourteen persons arrested Dec. 29 in the political upheaval that followed the assassination of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan have been released from prison, according to informed French political sources.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The regional office of the War Labor Board, acting on reports that eleven rayon manufacturing firms of Paterson had raised the wages of their employes without obtaining the approval of the WPB, sent warnings today to the companies and to officials of the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O.

Until this week there were eight American States in which a citizen could not vote unless he had paid his poll tax. Now, by legislative act, Tennessee is off this list. Only Virginia, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Arkansas and Texas remain. The Tennessee law required a payment of but fifty cents.

The testimony of the representatives of the Treasury on the pay-as-you-go proposal is disappointing. The Treasury faces this year the greatest problem of income tax collection in its history. Yet its representatives have no well-thought-out plan to present. Their proposals seem improvised and floundering.

Albert G. Milbank, attorney and president of the Milbank Memorial Fund, yesterday was appointed chairman of a new health committee of the Community Service Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, to study the society's program for the control of preventable diseases in New York City.

Despite allocation of hides, tanners were reported yesterday to be operating at near capacity. Operations on leathers for military and lend-lease purposes continue at a high rate. Tanners said that their output of such leather had been made somewhat easier by color restrictions ordered by WPB for civilian shoe uppers.
