ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 3 -- Canadian troops, eager to get into front-line action, are established in this war theatre, prepared to learn the lessons of actual battle.

Benjamin Siegel, 48 years old, owner of a chain of gasoline stations in Brooklyn, was released in $2,500 bail in the Homicide Court yesterday for a hearing Feb. 24 on suspicion of being one of two men whose car last Monday afternoon fatally injured an unidentified man on the Bowery, near Broome Street, whom they then carried away and abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Two attempts to upset the War Labor Board's formula limiting wage increases, designed to meet rising living costs up to 15 per cent of January, 1941, levels, were started here today.
CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 3 (U.P.) -- Government leaders told the House of Representatives today that the Japanese were massing strong forces at Rabaul and other island bases fringing Australia.

Procter Gamble Company last year continued to be the largest spender for advertising in magazines, radio and farm papers, according to the annual compilation to be published today by Printer's link. The expenditures of 399 advertisers who spent more than $100,000 in the three media amounted to $256,221,479 last year as against $252,590,053 in 1941, a rise of 4.2 per cent.

With 500 more combat planes to operate out of air bases already established in Eastern China, Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, head of the American Air Forces in China, believes he can "run every Jap out of China and short circuit Japanese shipping between Japan and the Solomons," Colonel Robert L. Scott, leader of General Chennault's fighter group, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Three officials of the Army and Navy accused William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, today of incorrect statements before a Congressional committee investigating his charges that Army and Navy "loafers" were delaying production of war material.
A special German communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Camp programs for children and youths must be adapted next season to changed conditions and ought "to serve the nation," leaders in this field declared yesterday at the opening of a four-day conference sponsored jointly by the New York section of the American Camping Association and the eighth annual "camp pow-wow."

Thomas F. McLaughlin, assistant to the president of the Crucible Steel Company, has subleased a penthouse apartment of eleven rooms and four baths in 1175 Park Avenue from George S. Pollitz Jr., vice president of the Seneca Textile Corporation, who has rented a large unfurnished duplex terraced apartment of seven rooms and four baths in the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Paul D. Miller, attorney and member of the Down Town Association, has been elected president of the Goodwill Industries, a social service organization for the employment and rehabilitation of physically handicapped persons, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3 -- The full dimensions of the triumph of Russian arms at Stalingrad have hardly yet dawned on the Moscow public, from whose thoughts the Volga city's name has rarely been absent since the middle of last year. The victory is being celebrated with the quiet dignity with which the Soviet people both bear sufferings and express their relief in wartime.

Premier Hideki Tojo told the Japanese House of Peers in Tokyo yesterday that he "felt cold water run down my back" when a Japanese convoy was detected en route to Malaya two days before the attack on Pearl Harbor.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Full employment of everybody after the war is the government's intention, declared Hugh Dalton, President of the Board of Trade, today in winding up the debate in the House of Commons on the British economic policy.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- The meeting of Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain and President Ismet Inonu of Turkey and the joint talks of British and Turkish staff chiefs were described this morning by Sir Hughe M. Knatchbull-Hugessen, the British Ambassador to Turkey, at his press conference.

President Roosevelt has expressed his thanks to newspapers and radio for the way they kept the secret of his trip to Casablanca. Once more, therefore, in the space of less than three months it has been shown that a secret is best kept when a great many people know about it.

Small retailers feel that a positive approach to civilian production and essential manpower recruiting could benefit both the war and civilian economy, the National Retail Dry Goods Association declared yesterday in filing with the Senate Small Business Committee a suggested outline of the functions of an independent office of civilian supply, or civilian supply administrator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Still insisting upon a doubling up of 1942 and 1943 income tax payments to put the country on a pay-as-you-go basis, the Treasury disclosed today that "very serious consideration" had been given to a compromise under which the 1942 "liability" would be met at lower than present rates.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Calling the present Anglo-American aid to Russia "parsimonious," Lord Beaverbrook delivered an impassioned plea in the House of Lords today for a vastly increased flow of material to the decisive Eastern battlefront.

Four apartment houses at 56 to 62 La Salle Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, have been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman for a syndicate from Lypkind Brothers. They occupy a plot 100 by 102 feet and recently were remodeled by the Dry Dock Savings Institution into sixty-four apartments of two and a half rooms each.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- About 30,000 barrels of gasoline are being saved daily as the result of wholehearted public support of the ban on non-essential driving in the Eastern States, Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 3 -- The Association of American Colleges announced today the organization of a commission on wartime placement of college faculties to seek a solution for the problem of faculty members who face the loss of their teaching jobs under the wartime curtailment of higher education.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 3 -- Behind the businesslike reports of the Twelfth United States Army Air Force bombing operations lies another story -- the story of the men who "keep 'em flying" when it is more than a phrase.

Although expenses keep increasing, it is a real challenge to continue meeting deficits, Mrs. Joseph A. Glazier, president of the New York Diet Kitchen Association (Children's Health Center), said yesterday at the association's seventieth annual meeting.
Three large foreign banks reported yesterday their 1942 earnings. Two of these institutions showed gains over 1941, and the third would have done so, had it not been for a sharp increase in taxes.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The rescue of Brig. Gen. N.F. Twining, Colonel Glen C. Jamison and thirteen others after they had been adrift six nights and five days on two small life rafts in the Coral Sea was disclosed today by the Thirteenth Air Force.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 3 -Paced by Scotty Hamilton, allI America forward and captain, the Z West. Virginia quintet defeated Army, 50 -- 35, in a thrilling basketball game today.

Four young soldiers from New York City and a lieutenant from Texas, wearing the colors of Fort Monmouth, provided plenty of excitement for Columbia's basketball team in the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night. Columbia won by 49 to 45, but two minutes from the end the score was tied at 45 -- all.
Places for 5,000 students are available in thirty-three schools offering courses under the war industries training program of the Board of Education, it was learned yesterday.

According to present indications, the next nation-wide Victory Fund Drive to sell upward of $10,000,000,000 of new securities will be held early in the Spring. In the meanwhile, the market for government securities is very firm. Apparently the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System is continuing to resell some of the large blocks of securities that it took on recently.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine for Jan. 31 Professor Walter Russell Bowie, replying to my recent article about hating Germans, fails to reply at all. Instead, he constructs a straw man of hideous form and repulsive feature, furiously tears it to bits, and seems to be under the impression that he has answered something.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Railroad representatives told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they would comply with an "admonition" to use revenues from increased rates and fares for betterment of their plants and retirement of debts.

TORONTO, Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -- T.A. Richardson, president of the Toronto Stock Exchange, asserted tonight that the new extradition treaty between Canada and the United States which is scheduled to come before Parliament soon was not likely to be adopted as drafted because of restrictions which it would place on legitimate financing in the United States by Canadian companies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 -- Film rights to "Valley of Decision," novel by Marcia Davenport, have been bought by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a reported sum of $60,000 and it will be a starring vehicle for Greer Garson, according to a studio announcement.

George Herrick, 48-year-old gambling figure, and two co-defendants pleaded guilty yesterday to gambling charges before Magistrate William Hoppin in Yorkville Court. All will be sentenced next Wednesday.

Restaurant patrons may soon be drinking demi-tasses with their evening meals instead of full cups of coffee, Miss Elsa Curtis, executive director of the New York State Restaurant Association, Predicted yesterday. The Office of Price Administration is expected shortly to cut restaurant allocations of coffee in the same proportions that civilian rations have been reduced because of dwindling stocks.

Eggs, unlike most foods, dropped again in price this week. Grade A whites are cheaper by 4 cents and Grade B mixed by 3. One reason for this is, of course, that supplies continue to be abundant and demand is comparatively light. Listed below are averages of prices prevailing in representative city stores, as quoted by the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets:

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES in Central Tunisia, Feb. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- A battle between an American artillery column and two German fighters during which two American machine-gunners fought on with jammed guns was described today by Captain Wilson C. McNamara, 30, of 41 Rugar Street, Plattsburg, N.Y.
Elsa Jordan, a dancer from Salt Lake City, made her local debut last night in a recital at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall.

HONOLULU, Feb. 4 -- Territorial Senator Sanji Abe, an American citizen of Japanese extraction who had been in custodial detention by the Army since last September, has submitted his resignation from the Hawaiian Senate to Governor Ingram Stainback.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Beatrice Houdini, who spent ten years trying to reach her husband, Harry Houdini, in the spirit world, renounced today her long-cherished faith in communication after death, and added that she was skeptical about any form of life hereafter.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- "Cousin Louis" brought his two girl cousins a large bunch of bananas from Africa, where he had been on business. The girl cousins thought it would be a good idea to pass them on to the children injured and in hospital after the recent daylight bombing attack on a London school and asked their mother to take them along.

A short circuit shortly before 2 P.M. yesterday blew the cover of a manhole twelve feet into the air at Park Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street with a loud explosion, blew out the main electric panel in the basement of 470 Park Avenue with another explosion, causing a fire and started another fire in the basement of 58 East Fifty-eighth Street.

In the presence of thirty-five members attending the Eastern Saddle Horse Breeders Association's annual meeting and luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Miss Dorothy Hopkins Ritterbush of Bernardsville, N.J., received the organization's trophy for junior equestrians.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A special Russian communique broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded hers by the Soviet monitor:

The decision of the railroads to accept the suggestion made by the Interstate Commerce Commission that they use the revenues resulting from the increases in rates granted last year for debt retirement and property improvements was not unexpected.
In increasing numbers American painters and sculptors are turning their art to war purposes or are giving it up temporarily to work in war factories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today that the United States would draw upon a pool of 6,400,000 persons this year to meet demands of the armed forces and war industry.

New Orleans buying provided the only feature of an otherwise dull session on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Under this support and a moderate amount of switching from the old-crop to the new-crop months, the market rose from early losses of as much as 8 points to close unchanged to 7 points higher than Wednesday's final prices, with strength again most pronounced in the distant positions.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussions, Federal income tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

By voluntarily concentrating available cotton spinning equipment on a limited range of all-purpose yarns that can be utilized in the greatest number of simplified lines of finished products, textile manufacturers will seek to maintain total civilian supply for 1943 at approximately last year's high level, it was learned yesterday in the Worth Street textile market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- After nearly five hours of spirited debate in the Senate today, the Military Affairs Committee succeeded in capturing jurisdiction over the proposed bill to create a civilian Office of War Mobilization. The vote, which disregarded party lines, was 39 to 28.

Less than two weeks have passed since the formation of the Arts and Skills Project of the American Red Cross Hospital Recreation Corps, rallying volunteers to entertain and instruct convalescent service men. But already a Greater New York unit of this service has been formed, and the first group of these volunteers is scheduled to begin work in Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, within the next week, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Except for continued gains in primary market prices for fresh fruits, vegetables and for livestock, there was little change in commodity markets during the last week of January. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices of nearly 900 series rose 0.1 per cent to 101.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, during the first full year since the declaration of war by the United States, helped meet the nation's critical needs for war materials with a record-breaking production, Lewis H. Brown, president, declared in the annual report released to stockholders last night.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- An accusation by the War Labor Board that it had granted wage increases in violation of the President's stabilization order was denied today by the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association, but, the association added, employes deserve rises.

Mr. Churchill's unexpected appearance in Turkey and Cyprus was not just drama. He arrived on Turkish soil without the knowledge of the Nazi spies in Ankara, but the wide and deliberate publicity given to the military character of the conference with the Turkish leaders shows that the intention was to point a finger to the Balkan peninsula as a possible route of invasion.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Erie Railroad's president, Robert E. Woodruff, declared tonight that competitive bidding on the $14,000,000 bond issue awarded to Morgan Stanley Co. of New York "would have caused needless delay and risk."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A bitter dispute over recognition of Local 277, State, county and municipal workers of America, C.I.O., as the bargaining agent for city employes ended today with the announcement by Parks and Public Property Director Ralph A. Villani that he would negotiate with the union.

Neither industry nor labor nor agriculture alone can provide prosperity when peace returns to this country, but government, in cooperation with private enterprise, can assure the stability of our economic life, Colonel David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared yesterday.

The American General Corporation on Dec. 31, last, had net assets of $15,451,588, equivalent to $92.82 a share on the convertible preferred stock and to $5.08 a share on the common, according to a report issued yesterday. Comparable figures a year earlier were $83.23 on the preferred stock and $3.97 on the common.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The nation's Class I railroads had a net operating income of $1,480,940,760 in 1942, the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today, 48.3 per cent more than the $998,286,708 earned in 1941.

Approximately 15,000 persons employed in industries characterized by the War Manpower Commission as non-essential registered for war jobs yesterday in the seven offices of the commission's United States Employment Service in this city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs here today were less than 60 per cent of the number expected, and prices bounded upward around 25 cents a hundredweight at the opening of the market. The top was again $15.50, but later prices lost 10 to 20 cents of the early gain. Cattle and sheep were strong to 25 cents higher than yesterday.

Reassurance that the Lend-Lease Administration is anxious to maintain the normal channels of export trade was given foreign traders yesterday by Philip Young, Deputy Lend-Lease Administrator, at a meeting sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, at the Hotel Commodore.

For all except three minutes of last night's basketball game in Fordham's Rose Hill gym, the Ram ran shoulder to shoulder with West Virginia, but the visitors made the last three minutes pay off. In the end, the Mountaineers were on top by 52 to 46.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt approves the plan announced by the War Department to create a combat team for the Army composed of loyal American citizens of Japanese descent.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Dewey has ordered an investigation into practices of the State in ordering office supplies, following a memorandum to him by one of his staff, showing that twenty-nine employes were involved in one recent order for twelve bottles of mucilage, costing a total of seventy cents for the dozen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Here are textual highlights from the statement read to the Ways and Means Committee today by Beardsley Ruml, in support of his skip-a-year, pay-as-you-go income tax plan:

A seven-room apartment in 1050 Park Avenue has been leased by Horace M. Marston, formerly of Pittsburgh, Pa., a representative of the American-Jewish Committee, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker. Warren Marks Associates were co-brokers.
Thousands of Chinese-Americans now in the United States armed forces have been granted a special three-day furlough to celebrate the old Chinese New Year 4,640, which is today.
Still another use for the nurse's aide was found yesterday, when four of these volunteer war workers took up their duties as assistants to Army doctors in physical examinations of Waac applicants.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Frederick Thiry, 3-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thiry, got ahold of some matches while his mother was shopping at a nearby store this afternoon and set fire to the Thiry apartment, causing the death of his brother, John, 19 months, and injuries to himself, his two-months-old sister, Mary, and his mother.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- Messina, Sicily, vital link with the Italian mainland, was battered again yesterday by American heavy bombers. The planes raided the rail ferry terminal, a drydock, oil storage installations and the port power station.
The relay phase of the Millrose A.A. games to be held in Madison Square Garden tomorrow night has attracted an entry unmatched in the history of this indoor track fixture.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A small arsenal ,.was uncovered by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents 'in one of thirty raids tonight in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, New Jersey FBi .Chief E. E. Conroy said. Tile weapons were found at the seashorezh0rt/e of an enemy alien Mr. Conroy did! not identify.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The total of alien residents of the United States has declined 641,396 since the first registration two years ago and now makes up the smallest percentage of the population in history, Earl G. Harrison, Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, reported to Congress today.
In connection with the dimouts in New York and the increased number of accidents, there is an idea which is so simple it is almost pointless at first blush.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Consolidated net income of the Universal Corporation, parent of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., amounted to $2,806,952 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1942, after taxes and all charges, according to the report announced yesterday by J. Cheever Cowdin, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A threatened attack on the United States last year was warded off and the enemy was defeated over the ocean with only thirty minutes' advance notice of the invasion, Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, told the House Interstate Committee today.
As the rains slowly end in Tunisia the North Africa fighting is flaring into furious action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Recent successive triumphs by the United Nations over the Axis powers must not lull the American people into a false hope that the end of the war is nearing, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, cautioned today.

A two-alarm fire swept the Shubert Theatrical Warehouse, a four-story building at 508 West Thirty-eighth Street, late yesterday afternoon, destroying a large quantity of scenery owned by Lee and J.J. Shubert, theatrical producers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Department store sales for the week ended Jan. 30 were unchanged from the same period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This followed a gain of 1 per cent in the week ended Jan. 23. Sales in the latest four-week period rose 2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Congressional Medal of Honor was conferred by President Roosevelt today on Major Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift of the Marine Corps for "outstanding and heroic accomplishment" against Japanese forces in the Solomon Islands.

The sharp expansion of New York transactions in the week ended on Wednesday swelled the volume of bank clearings for this city and the country at large to the highest level for any week during the past twelve years, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

The 909th Air Force Engineers of Mitchel Field will hold a camouflage exhibition of paintings depicting protective concealment as practiced by the United States Army, at Macy's. The exhibition opens this evening with a private view on the fifth floor and to the public on Saturday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4 -- Owing mainly to substantial increases in originating shipments and in the production of bituminous coal, business in the Pittsburgh district last week reached the highest level in the past year, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

President Roosevelt, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson and other national leaders joined yesterday in congratulating the United Service Organizations on their second anniversary and John D. Rockefeller Jr., honorary chairman, told 1,000 of his "fellow-workers" at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor that their activities will brighten the lives of five to ten million fighting men before the war is over.

The New York City Housing Authority awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,750,000 of temporary loan notes to a syndicate comprising the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, the National City Bank, the New York Trust Company and Brown Brothers Harriman Co.

Private camp organizations were urged yesterday to help the war program outlined by the Department of Agriculture, especially in recruiting a part of the 3,500,000 additional farm workers this season, in a discussion at the annual conference of the New York section of the American Camping Association held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- When formal meat rationing starts on April 1, the allowance for civilians will be slightly less than two pounds a week, it was stated tonight. Officials of the Department of Agriculture and of the Office of Price Administration declined official comment on the reports.

As the result of a three-year effort by a group of New York business men to strengthen democracy through restoring religion in education, more than 100,000 children in the city's public schools are being instructed weekly in the faith of their fathers -- Catholic, Jewish and Protestant -- a group of church leaders was told last night at a dinner in Town Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Dissolution and liquidation of the North American Gas and Electric Company was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the corporate simplification section of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Mrs. Lillian Rosenlicht, befurred, bejeweled and matronly, was accused yesterday in Special sessions of being the operator of "caravan" women's poker games in apartments of women acquaintances on the upper West Side through which she averaged $15,000 yearly for at least two years.

BUFFALO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Wiliam C. Rose, director of operations of the War Manpower Commission, said today that an acute manpower shortage is in prospect, even with full employment of women workers.

A somewhat melancholy note crept into the tenth annual Butler's Staff Ball last night at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street. The attendance was about half the attendance of other years and 20 per cent of the members are in the armed services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., warned Congress today that the Treasury's proposals for putting the country's income taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis would impose "intolerable" burdens of double taxation and violate the long-established principle of levying according to ability to pay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Merchant shipyards in the United States delivered in January 106 vessels aggregating 1,008,400 deadweight tons. This was the second month in a row in which production passed the million-ton mark.

About 1,500 independent food merchants, meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the New York State Food Merchants Association, denounced the plan now under consideration by the Office of Price Administration to establish different food price ceilings for different classes of retailers.

Mixed trends again held sway yesterday in the stock market, with another technical reaction straightened out in late trading by rallying tendencies. Prospective purchasers stood aside in the morning when realizing was in force, but once the limited offerings failed to injure values seriously, buying power reasserted itself.

Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht approved yesterday as fair and reasonable a settlement offer of $75,000 made by Phoenix Securities Corporation in a suit brought by minority stockholders of the Happiness Candy Stores, Inc. Payment would be made to the Happiness company.

Mme. Wellington, Koo, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Great Britain, issued a statement here yesterday in which she sought to clarify a statement she made in a Philadelphia speech on Monday that "China is nearer collapse on the economic front than at any other time during the course of the war.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Senator Wicks of Kingston introduced a bill today directing the Board of Transportation in New York City to grant a 15 per cent wage increase, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1943, to workers in the operating division of the municipal transit system.

A charge of attempted extortion was lodged yesterday against Elmer Fisher, 20 years old, of 870 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, who was accused of having threatened his uncle with violence unless the latter gave him $1,500.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Navy communique 271:

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Round-the-clock bombing of Germany by United States and British airmen proceeded with unflagging vigor last night and today. By daylight today Flying Fortresses hammered targets in Northwestern Germany after Royal Air Force bombers under cover of darkness had blasted objectives at Hamburg, the Nazis' chief U-boat production center.

Mrs. Christine Sullivan Palma, wife of Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Richmond, was questioned for more than an hour yesterday afternoon by the Richmond County grand jury at St. George, that is investigating charges of violation of the city charter against the borough president and other officials who have not been named.

The Soldier's Medal for exceptional heroism in saving the life of a fellow-soldier while his division was on manoeuvres in Louisiana was awarded yesterday to Staff Sergeant Robert Purcell in a ceremony and review of a contingent of the 518th Military Police Battalion on Governors Island.

Leo Golden, 38 years old, who described himself as a "wool broker," was held in $10,000 bail yesterday in the Felony Court for a hearing Feb. 16 on his not-guilty plea to defrauding Mrs. Lucie Newman, 61, of a total of $5,800 since September, 1941, on his promise to "use my influence" to bring many members of her family into this country from Lyon, France, and Cuba.

A concentrated attack on the whole question of crime prevention and social adjustment as war, post-war and social problems was announced yesterday by the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs as its fiftieth anniversary project.

" The First Film Carnival of Winter Sports," a feature-length compilation of sports subjects, will start an engagement today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse. Included in the program are "The Ski Chase," "The Art of Skiing," "Conquests of the Alps," "Love on Skis," "Frosty Frolics" and "Skiing on Your Feet."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes today accused Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities of "irresponsibility" and said Mr. Dies "hasn't said anything new for two or three years."

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Slicing steadily at the Axis lifeline across the Mediterranean, over which the enemy sends vital materials to his forces in Africa, British submarines, operating off the Tunisian coast, have destroyed one anti-submarine vessel and nine other ships, most of them small cargo carriers, within the last few days, the Admiralty announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Paul V. McNutt said tonight that the War Manpower Commission would take control of the hiring of labor in shortage areas, a step expected to freeze millions of persons to war industries or other tasks deemed essential.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Another over-the-weight bout will feature the boxing card at Madison Square Garden tonight, and another crowd of capacity proportions is expected to witness it. Beau Jack, Augusta, Ga., Negro who holds the lightweight championship of the world, will oppose Fritzie Zivic, former welterweight king, in a ten-round battle that promises to attract a gathering of 20,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Juvenile delinquency is increasing, particularly among girls, according to comparative figures for 1942 and 1941 read today by Miss Elsa Castendyk, director, social service division of the Children's Bureau, Department of Labor, at a White House meeting of the bureau's commission on Children in Wartime.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Failure of the United States to accept its responsibilities a generation ago helped the rise of the aggressors, said Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, today in an address at commencement exercises of the University of Maryland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, is prepared to transfer six divisions of WPB from the jurisdiction of Ferdinand Eberstadt, vice chairman in charge of materials, to Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman for production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Captain John L. McCrea has been relieved as naval aide to President Roosevelt, at his own request, so that he may go to sea in command of one of "the biggest and most powerful" ships in the Navy, the White House announced today.

The sale by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of a large property in the Fifty-ninth Street shopping zone was announced yesterday. John F. Burns of Pelham Manor has bought 142 to 158 East Fifty-ninth Street, running through to 141-55 East Fifty-eighth Street, and having an "L" at 731-33 Lexington Avenue.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A delirious merchant seaman who landed here two days ago, his life practically baked out of him after spending seventy-six days drifting in an open boat on the torrid South Atlantic, was identified today as William Colborn, 32 years old, of Liverpool.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 4 -- A profound party division on the issue of Argentine neutrality was brought to light today by an open letter addressed to Senator Gilberto Suarez Lago, chairman of the dominant National Democratic party, by National Democratic Deputy Justo V. Rocha, chairman of the Chamber Foreign Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The statement regarding North Africa made in the House of Commons yesterday by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, gave satisfaction to official circles here today, since it supplied further and more specific evidence than any hitherto publicly known that the British government was now in accord with American policy in that region.

The Berlin radio said last night that Soviet "Commandos" had gained a foothold on the Taman Peninsula leading to the Kerch Strait after storming ashore early yesterday under cover of the guns of the Russian Black Sea Fleet.

More than a majority of the members of the executive committee of the Bronx County Committee was reported yesterday to have signed a petition requesting Edward J. Flynn to continue as chairman of the committee and county leader.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Feb. 4 (AP) -- At least three of the five men who survived the crash of the Harold Giliam plane a month ago in the wilderness south of here are still alive, according to a message sent from a searching plane to Coast Guard headquarters today. Miss Susan Batzer, 23, of Camas, Wash., was fatally injured in the crash.

The Board of Transportation disclosed yesterday that it is studying the possibility of widespread employment of women on the city's unified transit system to replace men lost to the service by military draft or transfer to more lucrative private employment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Because of lowered income tax exemptions, many housewives who employ domestic servants may become acquainted for the first time this year with the government's annual information return.

INTERNATIONAL intrigue, espionage, an occasional quiet murder committed out of patriotism or for reasons of state have provided staple fare for literary diversion for generations. Long before the Nazis launched what Curt Reis calls their "total espionage," spy fiction had its uncrowned king, E. Phillips Oppenheim, and innumerable aspiring heirs to the throne.

An order directing the New York Butchers Dressed Meat Company to show cause on Feb. 8 why it should not be permanently restrained from practices alleged to violate Office of Price Administration rules for the sale of beef carcasses and wholesale cuts was signed yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an increase of 3,225,000 in note circulation.

Threats of suits against the Erie Railroad Company's directors clouded the financial skies last night as a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co. prepared to market today $14,000,000 of the road's 3 1/2 per cent Series D bonds due on Feb. 1, 1958.

The publication of "The Dickens Digest" by Whittlesey House on Monday will mark the centennial appearance of "Martin Chuzzlewit." "Chuzzlewit" began appearing in monthly installments in January, 1843. Because some of the American scenes were rather unfavorable to this country, which he had just visited, it was criticized as a one sided picture of American life.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Barring action by the Federal Government, the thirty-day horse racing meet at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, starting Feb. 22, apparently had clear sailing today. The Arkansas Senate, after a full-dress debate, defeated by a vote of 19 to 11 a bill to outlaw horse and dog racing and make betting on races a felony.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, speaking for 750,000 members of trades unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor in New York and vicinity, called last night for revision of the Little Steel formula to permit wage increases "commensurate with the rise in the cost of living."

Challenging the premise of the Office of Price Administration and the Petroleum Administrator for War that a balance had been reached between fuel oil supplies and coupon demand on the East Coast, spokesmen for the petroleum industry said last night that each oil company would have to "consult its own legal department whether to obey the new PAW amendment or the OPA's non-discrimination order."

Further cuts in service to customers were seen probable as the result of the manpower shortage, ODT and tire and gasoline regulations, at the closing session yesterday of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

The Wakeland Realty Corporation has bought three apartment houses in the Bronx from Samuel Weiner. They are 1089 Tiffany Street, with twenty-four apartments and four stores; 747 Southern Boulevard, with twenty apartments and five stores, and 960 Rogers Place, with twenty-five apartments.

Mrs. Rose Bornholz, mother of six boys serving in the armed forces, of 1530 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, made the first contribution yesterday to the American Red Cross War Fund Campaign at the official opening of the Bronx campaign headquarters at 374 East 149th Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Buying of wheat futures to remove hedges against sales of flour, including one order from an Eastern chain baking interest said to have aggregated 200,000 barrels, resulted today in imparting a strong tone to the market on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The armament program of the United States cost between June, 1940, and December, 1942, $25,000,000,000 less than it would have cost if prices had been permitted to rise at the rate they did in the first World War, the Office of Price Administration asserted today in its third quarterly report.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- In indirect support of our forces in the Solomons, Catalina flying boats harassed the Japanese airdrome at Buin, on the southern tip of Bougainville Island, for three hours in a night raid early yesterday, starting seven fires. Four were believed to be burning planes.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 5 -- The Red Army has cut off German troops in the Western Caucasus from Rostov by two swift smashes toward the Sea of Azov and has broken through the first line of powerful new Nazi fortifications rimming Rostov, Moscow announced today in a midnight communique recorded here by the Soviet monitor.
Goering speaking, on that tenth Hitler anniversary last Saturday: "It was the Fuehrer who, against all the weaklings who whined around him, with all his strength held the front in the east alone."

Howard Huston of the American Cyanamid Company has been appointed temporary chairman of the progress committee of the Advertising Study, which has been set up to appraise advertising as an instrument of American economic development, it was announced yesterday from the group's headquarters, 60 East Forty-second Street.

Deposits in mutual savings banks in the United States rose $131,278,410 in 1942 to a new high record of $10,620,957,953, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks announced yesterday. At the same time these banks increased their holdings of government securities by about $725,000,000, or by five and one-half times the increase in their deposits.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- General Charles de Gaulle, head of the Fighting French, said tonight that France's effort against the enemy grew stronger daily "in spite of all the efforts that have been made to divide and confuse her."
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- Not only the existence of a fifth column in France but its systematic development is indicated by various measures taken recently in Vichy.

The arguments presented by Quentin Reynolds in his letter to THE TIMES outlining some of the difficulties arising from the inexorable demands of a war economy, while logical, are based on a false premise.

If they were fighting with words instead of fists, Fritzie Zivic would have Beau Jack cut and bleeding in the opening minute. Before the first round had been completed he would have him colder than a refrigerator car. Fritzie is one of those voluble oh-boy-will-I-murder-him type of talkers and the Beau is a shy youngster who lets his actions speak louder than his words.

Shipments of high-grade dresses have been held up since last Monday by manufacturers of the couturier type because of difficulties in figuring costs under MPR-287. Specialty stores here reported yesterday their shipments have been affected since Feb. 1 and it was indicated that this has been the case with specialty shops throughout the country.

The open market committee of the Federal Reserve System made net sales of $254,709,000 of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday from the holdings of the twelve central banks of the Reserve System, it was disclosed yesterday.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 4 -- Disregarding her rank as a topnotch performer of the landlubber's favorite sport, Miss Helen Jacobs has cast aside her tennis racket to learn the ways of the Navy. Trim in her attire of apprentice seaman at the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Smith College, Miss Jacobs said yesterday that she felt the same in her uniform as she had on the center court at Wimbledon, England.

America's devotion to the thoroughbred dog as a companion, guard and an integral part of the country's armed forces is indicated by the handsome entry received for the sixty-seventh annual all-breed exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club at Madison Square Garden next Thursday and Friday.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- One of the major problems in wartime Britain, as in the United States, has been the increase in juvenile delinquency. Latest figures show that the battle against it is being won.

Within the last year fourteen women in the New York area have given up jobs in private industry to take on full-time paid union work with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America. In addition, about 17 per cent of the union's national staff now are women, as against 2 per cent a year ago, Miss Ruth Young, executive secretary, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Large steel companies, the armed forces and the War Production Board were jointly blamed today by a special Senate investigating committee for a steel shortage which it said had come "very close to being a stumbling block" of the war effort.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Accidents of all types in 1942 cost the lives of 93,000 Americans and injured 9,300,000 others, causing an economic loss to the country of $3,700,000,000, the National Safety Council reported today.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The first battle estimates of Germany's giant new Mark VI tank failed to impress military observers here, who said tonight that the weapon probably was of greater value defensively than for aggressive operations.
Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia, said last night in a radio talk that the days of mourning and grief in Germany suggest the possibility that Reichsfuehrer Hitler may be dead.

The government's financing program is producing a new army of investors and a new kind of responsibility, according to Harry G. Riter 3d, chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4 -- Mobilization of Germany's civilian reserves began in earnest today with official notification to the retail trade, arts and crafts professions and hotel and eating establishments to release all dispensable labor for national emergency service.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America announced yesterday the election of John L. Cameron to the board of directors and as a vice president of the company. He has been second vice president and associate actuary.

The eight-story Marie Antoinette Hotel at the northwest corner of Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street has been purchased by Benjamin Winter, operator, from the Franklin Savings Bank. The property occupies a plot 112.10 by 140.8 feet and is assessed at $665,000.

" For Your Pleasure," a variety show starring Veloz and Yolanda, dancers, will open tonight at the Mansfield. It will be presented by George M. Gatts. Others headlined are Susan Miller, singer; the Golden Gate Quartet, Bill Gary, tap dancer; Jerry Shelton, accordionist; Al and Lee Reiser, pianists, and Vicente Gomez, guitarist.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Rayon yarn producers must pass along to buyers a substantial portion of savings experienced when certain operations in processing yarn are eliminated, the Office of Price Administration ruled today. The OPA established specific ceiling prices for sales of yarn which has not been wound on cones or reeled in skeins.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Secretary Wickard declared today that American food was "almost surely" keeping Russia in the war.

In this newspaper yesterday a delayed dispatch dated Jan. 26 from Guadalcanal said that Japanese soldiers had been surrendering almost every day since Jan. 16. Private Hasamoto, veteran of China, Borneo and the Philippines, member of a crack regiment, led a number of his fellows into camp.

Plans for enlisting all branches of the food industry in the most comprehensive coordinated advertising campaign in its history as a contribution to the war effort were drawn up yesterday at a meeting sponsored by the Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 -- Immediate closing of the Bay Meadows race track, with abandonment of a fifty-day meeting which had been scheduled to start on Feb. 20, was announced tonight by William P. Kyne, general manager of the course.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Dull conditions continued today in all sections of the stock markets. Home rails sagged, Great Western losing 1/4 to 60 1/4; London, Midland Scottish, 3/8 to 28 3/8, and Southern deferred, 1/8 to 24 1/4.

During the past ten years, while Hitler has been busily spreading his devil's work of bigotry, American educators, clergymen and public-minded citizens have been quietly conducting a campaign to eliminate offensive racial and religious passages from the textbooks of this country's public, private and parochial schools.

Your newspaper reported Jan. 26 a speech by Mayor La Guardia to a meeting in Harlem at which he made a number of statements which entirely misrepresent both the problems facing families during wartime and the efforts of school and social agencies to alleviate some of these problems.
MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 4 -- The immediate Axis reaction to last week-end's conferences between British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Ismet Inonu of Turkey and their high staff officers came when THE NEW YORK TIMES radio monitors picked up a Paris broadcast stating that Reich Ambassador Franz von Papen would soon be recalled from Ankara.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Veiled in secrecy, the air-sea engagements in the South Pacific are continuing, with the American and Japanese adversaries apparently still feinting and parrying for advantageous positions in what may prove to be a history-making battle for control of the Solomon Islands.

The music that Bruno Walter interpreted with much "innigkeit" last night at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert in Carnegie Hall was very much of another time and another world than this one. Therein lay its great virtue and, in the case of Dvorak's G major symphony, too seldom played, its abiding charm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Production of enough synthetic rubber to avert the rubber supply crisis expected to arise in October and November, when stocks of natural rubber dwindle to the danger point, has been assured by the assignment of priorities to complete plants capable of producing 55 per cent of Buna S rubber called for by the Bernard M. Baruch rubber report, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, said today.

It appeared as if the New York Rangers were on the way to their first National Hockey League triumph of 1943 in their clash with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night, and at the same time it seemed the desperate Blueshirts were about to register their first shut-out of the entire season, for with only eight minutes left they enjoyed a 1-to-0 advantage.
The National Federation for Constitutional Liberties announced yesterday that 1,250 persons had signed a statement sponsored by the organization asking Congress to abolish the Dies Committee.

A. Wells Peck, president of Peck Peck, has purchased for investment the five-story business building at 581-83 Fifth Avenue from the Greenwich Savings Bank in a deal negotiated by the Charles F. Noyes Company, who will manage the property for the new owner.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4 -- A fighter umbrella, which some day will see Allied ships safely through the Mediterranean, is already in operation, according to Air Chief Marshal Sir William Sholto Douglas, who succeeds Air Marshal Sir Arthur William Tedder in the Middle East.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Private Billy McHale of Philadelphia was the envy of every buck private in Uncle Sam's Army today. He beat the blazes out of a sergeant and nobody even mentioned the guardhouse.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Germany and her allies have lost more than 1,000,000 men since Russia sprang her big Winter offensive last Nov. 19 at Stalingrad, and the continuing successes have surprised even the Soviet High Command, an informed source said tonight.

With Leo Durocher due to confer with his mentor and employer, Branch Rickey, in Brooklyn today, baseball's diversified interests are about to revert to a familiar topic: Who will manage the Dodgers for 1943?

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 4 -- Attacking at dawn, British troops drove the Germans off a hill in the Djebel Mansour area yesterday, then repulsed an enemy counter-attack. Fighting still continued in that sector seven miles southeast of Bou Arada, but elsewhere the Tunisian land front was quiet.

Harold Kimball, president of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, with headquarters in White Plains, is highly encouraged by the membership drive that his organization is making these days to enroll sportsmen.

Declaring that "you cannot defend yourself unless you are prepared to defend others," Sir Norman Angell, Nobel Prize winner and author of the recent book, "Let the People Know," made a plea for international cooperation in the post-war world at the closing Book and Play Luncheon yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Biltmore.

Appeals by fifteen followers of Dr. Frank Buchman, founder of the Oxford or Moral Rearmament group movement, from their 1-A draft classification by Local Board 17, at 412 Sixth Avenue, were denied last night by Appeals Board No. 4 at 29 Broadway, of which Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Attorney, is chairman.

The notable collection of modern art formed by A.E. Gallatin has found a new, and this time permanent, home. According to an announcement just received, the collection has been transferred to the Philadelphia Museum.

Ski conditions, generally speaking, remain good in the north country, according to reports received yesterday. Rising temperatures created a wet and granular surface at many points and what action the weather man takes within the next twenty-four hours will decide the type of sport available at several centers.

Blue and white festoons, symbolic of the national emblem of Greece, adorned the Trianon Room of the Ambassador last night for a gala dinner dance and gin rummy party given for the benefit of Friends of Greece, Inc. Many dinner parties were given, and the adjoining Circular Lounge was the setting for card playing.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Governor Dewey today spiked reports, which have been current in the liquor trade for some time, that he was contemplating setting up a system of State package stores to replace the present system of privately owned, State-licensed stores.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis granted today an application by Samuel Nuzzo, ousted business agent of Local 17 of the International I-Iod Carriers, Build-! ing and Common Laborers Union of America, for a certificate of reasonable doubt that iermits his release on bail from the Rockland County jail pending an appeal from his Jan. 7 conviction at Newburgh on thirty-two counts of theft and forgery.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Navy announced today 54 casualties in Navy forces, including eight dead, thirty-two wounded and fourteen missing, for a total reported to next of kin since Dec. 7, 1941, of 6,454 dead, 4,007 wounded and 12,211 missing.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 4 (AP) -- For extreme gallantry in landing their unarmed troop-carrier planes under enemy air attack, two American transport pilots received Distinguished Service Crosses from Major Gen. James H. Doolittle in a brief ceremony today.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- Ralph Coghlan, chief editorial writer of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, and his two co-defendants were cleared tonight of charges of conspiring to steal a broken-down cannon from the Capitol grounds and deposit it on the nation's scrap heap.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in the South Pacific, Feb. 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- A night bombing attack by Japanese aircraft against American warships, the first such foray of the war, was carried out Friday night, Jan. 29, in the Solomon Islands area.
TORONTO, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Red Wings strengthened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League tonight defeating the third-place Maple leafs, 3 -- 2, before 12,000 fans.
Taxes are deductible, in general, in arriving at net income for Federal tax purposes.

There is a town on the river Don, west of Stalingrad; in the town is a certain house, and in the house a certain plain room, with four bare walls, a table and four chairs. A Russian Marshal, a Russian Colonel General, a German Marshal and an interpreter sat in this room the other day, and a photographer took their pictures.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 4 -- Twenty-seven Communist Deputies arrested by the French Government since the opening of the war have been released unconditionally by General Henri Honore Giraud in another step in the provisional government's program for ending the political abuses that have characterized Vichy rule in North Africa.

It becomes increasingly difficult to avoid the suspicion that the chief reason the Treasury opposes the Ruml plan is that some one else thought of it first. The Treasury now, belatedly, says that it wants to get the taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis. But not by the Ruml plan!

R.R. Ely, acting for the director of the War Manpower Commission, yesterday limited the recent WMC nondeferment order as applied to "custom furrier." The limitation was announced in a telegram to Avery T. Salter, executive secretary of the National Federation of the Fur Industry.

President Ryti of Finland opened the 1943 session of the Riksdag with words which can only be construed as an attempt at reconciliation with the United Nations. "Civilized nations," he said, "can never sink so low as not to acknowledge the rights of a nation to fight for its life and freedom."

OTTAWA, Feb. 4 -- The Canadian Government has set up a fourteen-man advisory committee on economic and financial policy and organization arising from the war and to make recommendations for meeting post-war problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt, as Commander in Chief of the American armed forces, sent a message of congratulation today to Joseph Stalin as supreme commander of the armed forces of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the "brilliant victory" of the Russian armies at Stalingrad.
The six-story apartment house, containing forty-eight apartments, at 1425 Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to Seraben, Ltd., for cash above a purchase-money mortgage of $145,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor to Major Gen. Alexander Vandegrift; his visitors included H.F. Arthur Schoenfeld, United States Minister to Finland; Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, Basil O'Connor and Herbert H. Lehman.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 4 -- Street demonstrations against sham window shows in Berlin shops, which actually had nothing to sell and consequently had their windows smashed by irritated passers-by, were cautiously reported tonight by the Berlin correspondent of the Stockholms Tidningen.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Police were holding two suspects tonight for questioning in the murder of Miss Elizabeth Traxler, about 35 years old, whose bruised and lacerated body was found early today near an old barn at 203 Van-Houten Street.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 5 -- Breaking two Spaulding pool records in the process, the Yale swimming team took an undisputed hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League as it downed Dartmouth today, 41 to 34.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The armed forces expect to call up 4,228,906 men and women in 1943, increasing its strength to 11,213,040, Senator Reynolds, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, disclosed today.

Branch Rickey's eloquent statement following Paul V. McNutt's ruling on nondeferrable occupations is the best declaration made by any baseball official regarding the future of the national pastime during the current war.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Governor Dewey said today that he was preparing a program to relieve the critical farm labor shortage and provide all the manpower necessary for the planting and harvesting of crops in the State.

In the last week the New York Curb Exchange has hired five girls as pages, and they have taken their places behind trading post counters on the floor. From the depths of this experience, the new employes already have produced several suggestions for improving the Curb's trading and reporting system.

With the volume of business still small pending settlement of the parity price issue, the cotton futures market was featureless again yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active months opened slightly below the previous close, held virtually unchanged for most of the session and then closed with net losses of 3 to 5 points, the low levels, through increased liquidation of the March in late dealings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 5 -- George Sanders will go to Columbia on loan from Twentieth Century-Fox to play the lead in "Appointment in Berlin," a story which was prepared by the B.P. Shulberg unit and now, with the latter's resignation from the company, will be assigned to another producer.

Carmine Galante, 35-year-old exconvict picked up on Jan. 13 and held as a material witness in the killing of Carlo Tresca, anti-Fascist editor, was brought before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday on a writ of habeas Corpus obtained by his attorney to "find out why he is being held incomunicado."
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company of America announced yesterday a dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock.

Another clue to the state of the public mind in Germany is to be found in the scrupulous care with which the High Command is holding back news of the fact that the American aerial bombardment of the Reich has started.

The questions asked by women who attended conferences at the New York State College of Home Economics during Cornell's Farm and Home Week -- this lasted from Tuesday through Thursday -- sounded strange to one who, like the writer, had come from a crowded city.

The Board of Education submitted to Acting Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday its request for $141,209,407 for 1943-44, or $301,130 less than was appropriated for 1942-43. The Department of Sanitation asked for $31,932,511, an increase of $1,168,666.

The German High Command reported yesterday that strong Russian attacks had been repelled in the area of the mouth of the Don. This was the first admission by Berlin that the fighting in South Russia had moved into the area of Rostov.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Axis war prisoners may be used in this country next Summer to help produce the food which Allied fighting men will need to crush the enemy.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The Municipal budget showing total appropriations of $39,110,052, a reduction of $408,337 compared with last year, was introduced and approved on first reading by the City Commission today. A public hearing is scheduled for 11 A.M. Feb. 24, prior to adoption of the proposed schedule.
