AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt settled today the long-standing controversy among Federal agencies as to jurisdiction over railway wage disputes by requiring that while the emergency boards named by National Railway Labor-Panel had authority to make recommendations, James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, could direct changes if the recommendations did not conform to the Federal wage stabilization policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Formal orders setting forth in detail the WPB reorganization under which he transferred seven divisions from the jurisdiction of Ferdinand Eberstadt, vice chairman in charge of materials, to Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman in charge of production, ald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.

The German American, a monthly publication sponsored by the German American Emergency Conference, has presented with its February issue a special supplement showing the text and pictures of leaflets circulated by the Soviet Army among German soldiers on the Russian front.
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 6 -- Two Russian communiques recorded here by the Soviet monitor early today continued to tell of sweeping Red Army gains all along the 1941 German defense line in Russia.
Plans for physical reconstruction of Greek cities and towns destroyed or damaged by the Axis are now being drawn up at Columbia University's School of Architecture, it was learned yesterday.

Fear that the end of the war will see a "great influx" of needy and unemployed into New York City was expressed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who put up to the Federal Government prevention of that possibility.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Fifty-eight civilian electrical technicians who were rushed to Hawaii to help repair propulsion equipment of the battleships California and West Virginia, sunk in Pearl Harbor by the Japanese, will receive Navy "E" pins in recognition of their services.
The St. John's basketball team led all the way to beat Hofstra College, 47 -- 38, in DeGray Gymnasium last night. It was the eleventh victory in twelve starts for the Redmen.

Premier Hideki Tojo, seeking to justify his demand for new authoritarian powers to solidify his absolute control of the Japanese war economy, told a committee of the Japanese House of Representatives in Tokyo yesterday that he was not a dictator because he Was exercising his power as Premier under "the glorious light of the emperor."

Captain Eddie Rickenbacker last night cabled his "heartiest congratulations" to Captain Joseph Jacob Foss, 27-year-old flier on duty in the Solomons, who has tied Captain Rickenbacker's World War I record by shooting down twenty-six enemy planes, The United Press reported in New York.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 5 -- Pierre Boisson, Governor General of French West Africa, has pledged 100,000 well-trained Senegalese soldiers to the cause of the United Nations and has promised 200,000 more if officers and non-commissioned officers can be found to lead them.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY IN TUNISIA, Feb. 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieutenant Quentin Roosevelt, 23 years old, of Oyster Bay, L.I., told today how two trapped American infantry companies, supported by a timely artillery fire, fought their way with eighty prisoners through a ring of two enemy battalions and broke up plans for an Axis counter-attack to recapture the fertile Ousseltia Valley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -R.B. White, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that a continuation of year-old rail rate increases is necessary if the carriers are to continue their present standard of service in the war drive.

MYSORE, India, Jan. 31 (Delayed) -- This great State of Mysore in Southern India is proof that Indians can govern themselves with efficiency and enlightenment. It is not only the most advanced princely State; it is more advanced than any province of British India with the possible exception of Punjab.

Boy Scout Sunday, Youth Sunday and Interracial Sunday all will be observed tomorrow. "Boy Scout Week," opening tomorrow, will mark the thirty-third anniversary of the scouting movement. At many Scout services to be held by churches of different faiths and synagogues the boys will recommit themselves to the twelfth Scout law, which is: "A Scout is reverent.

Retail trade was active here this week, with volume recovering sharply from the slump noted last week. Department store sales were estimated as 3 to 4 per cent above the comparative week last year. A larger increase was held likely for specialty shop volume.
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has sold the following five properties in Brooklyn:

Stimulated by a strong upturn in the steel section, the stock market returned yesterday to its forward movement. In reversing the backward trend of the two previous sessions, prices were enlarged from fractions to a point and more in slightly better volume.

ROBERT NEUMANN, who was once a citizen of Vienna, was a successful author in Germany. His books sold well at home and they were translated into twenty languages. Then the Nazi blight descended upon his native land. His works were burned and he himself was forced to seek refuge in England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- President Roosevelt today discounted speculation that he and Prime Minister Churchill had decided upon a unified commander for Allied operations against the Axis in North Africa.

One good way to define a fascist, with a small f, is to say that a fascist is the kind of man that Alexander Hamilton was not. The distinction between fascist with a small f and a capital F is important.

A new procedure in pleasure-driving cases, under which persons not officially connected with the Office of Price Administration sit in judgment on accused motorists, had its first workout yesterday when seven cases were heard here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- Award of the Air Medal to seventeen Army Air Force officers and men for participating in hazardous, long-distance flights was announced today by the War Department.

ADVANCE BASE, SOUTH PACIFIC, Feb. 5 (AP) -- In two attacks by torpedo planes, one of them a spectacular night assault, against a United States task force in the Solomon Islands a week ago, the Japanese lost at least seventeen of their Mitsubishi twin-engine aircraft.

A half century ago last October the Art Students League took up residence in the American Fine Arts Building, which has remained its headquarters ever since. The milestone is to be celebrated, and tomorrow, with a preview, the league will open there a large exhibition called "Fifty Years on Fifty-seventh Street."

The regulations which have just been issued by Mr. McNutt as Manpower Chairman, governing conditions of employment in thirty-two areas officially classified as suffering from a "critical labor shortage," specify that persons engaged or most recently engaged in essential activities can be employed only by an employer for work in another essential activity.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.
Although fishing tackle stores are far from humming with activity these days, nevertheless one department head was found who emitted some traces of optimism.

The record of Dr. James Albert Cooper's efforts to escape military service is "literally reeking with hypocrisy and bad faith," Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director, wrote yesterday to Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national Selective Service chief, who stayed Dr. Cooper's induction by ordering that the file of his case be forwarded to Washington.

"Snapphanar" ("Feudists"), a Swedish importation, will have its American premiere today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Edvard Persson is starred in the historical romance, which is set in the seventeenth century during the war between Sweden and Denmark.

Candy supplies available to civilians are averaging not more than half last year's quantities due to restrictions on materials and priorities granted military orders and the orders for war plants, William C. Kimberly, secretary of the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate, said yesterday.

The secret life of Agnete Louise Wilfred, an imaginative young lady of 18, was revealed yesterday with her arraignment on a Federal charge of having impersonated a lieutenant of the United States Navy. Previously Miss Wilfred had been known to her fellow-employes and friends as "Shadow" and looked upon as a mysterious sort of person.

Nazi attempts to coerce the church in occupied countries have served to strengthen resistance among churchmen and people generally to National Socialism. Protests by church leaders in Norway, Denmark, Holland and Belgium exemplify the spirit of opposition evident in many of the conquered nations.

A contest to oust the present management of the United Corporation appeared yesterday with the disclosure that a group is soliciting proxies from the more than 100,000 stockholders of the utility-holding concern to elect new directors at the annual meeting scheduled for March 3 in Wilmington, Del.
Casualty losses and thefts are allowable deductions in computing net income for Federal income tax purposes.

The armed forces got further material yesterday from the families of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Di Blasio of 107 Humphrey Street, Englewood, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Aumann of 517 Adams Avenue, Elizabeth, N.J., but the supply is now exhausted.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Community Gas and Power Company and its subsidiary, American Gas and Power Company, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a voluntary plan proposing dissolution of Community and the break-up of the Community system in compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the holding company act.

The Rev. Dr. J. Wilson Sutton will conduct his first service on Sunday, March 7, as rector of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, near Broadway, where he will succeed the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Seagle, rector for the last forty-two years.
MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Saturday, Feb. 6 -- The triumphal entry that Premier Mussolini failed to get at Alexandria, Egypt, was reserved, it is now revealed, for Winston Churchill at Tripoli. But by his words and conduct the British Prime Minister left no doubt that he visited the conquered city only to say hello and thanks to the men of the British. Eighth Army and the Allied Air Forces.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 -- The Nazis are demanding from Norway the same mobilization of manpower as that enacted in Germany, it is now reliably reported from Oslo tonight.

Two six-story apartment houses at 605 and 611 West 156th Street have been sold by O'Brien Estates, Inc., John J. O'Brien, president, which erected them thirty-two years ago. They occupy plots of 100 by 100 feet each and contain 352 rooms, renting for about $50,000 a year.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Sullivan, whose five sons have been reported missing in action in the Pacific, observed their twenty-ninth wedding anniversary today by urging war workers to build more war tools for the men who fight the country's battles.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 5 -- Describing it as "a fiendish crime which must be cleared up," Chief of Police James Walker today directed all members of his department to work on their off time in an effort to trace the murderer of Miss Elizabeth Traxler, 26 years old, whose bruised and lacerated body was found early yesterday near an old barn at 203 Van Houten Street.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 5 -- The Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Smith College is gradually being transformed into a women's world, as one by one the male officers are released for active service. Captain Herbert W. Underwood, commanding officer of the school, said today that women officers might soon total 90 per cent of the personnel at this Waves station.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 5 -- As soon as hidden arms and ammunition are uncovered in France and taken to town halls "for safety," they are removed again by "Communists," who, adding insult to injury, sort out those of no military value and leave them on the doorstep.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Employer members of the War Labor Board in a minority opinion, criticized the board majority for "virtually abdicating its plain responsibilities" when it sent back for further negotiation a dispute involving four Great Lakes ore carriers and the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.

There are people very high in the German war councils who realize that Germany has lost the war. Signs of this are faint and puzzling as yet, tremors on top of the pyramid rather than a sag in the structure itself. The cracks that appear on the periphery of the Nazi "sphere" are not much in evidence within the Reich.

The Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, representing sixty leading capital stock casualty insurance companies, announced yesterday the formation of a permanent aviation advisory committee to handle insurance matters affecting aviation interests in recognition of the increasing use of aircraft and growing demands for insurance coverage which may be anticipated.
Leo Durocher, as trim and debonair as ever, breezed into New York yesterday and pronounced himself ready to meet whatever the future held for him. What the future holds for him seems complex.

Congress begins to be troubled in its mind. Its more progressive members recognize that its existing organization is not remotely adequate to the demands of total war. A few moderate proposals have been introduced to provide for better staffing, for more expert advice, for the merging of this committee with that, and for at least the beginnings of liaison between one committee and another.
Isn't it about time we quit counting our chickens before they are hatched and crossing bridges before we come to them?

The Celotex Corporation yesterday inaugurated an extensive advertising campaign, urging the public to earmark its war bonds for the purchases of new homes in the post-war period. At the same time the campaign will emphasize the new laboratory developments of Celotex, which will be available in the post-war period, such as Celo-Roof, which combines sheathing, insulation and roofing in one composite material, and other products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- mediation panel chairman who recommended that the War Labor Board deny union maintenance and dues checkoff to the C.I.O. United Auto Workers at the West Allis, Wis., plant of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company was accused of bias by a union spokesman at a hearing today.

The Federal wages and hours law does not apply to maintenance employes of buildings occupied by tenants engaged in interstate commerce unless the tenants are actually engaged in the "production of goods for commerce" on the premises, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled yesterday, confirming a recommendation of Official Referee Jacob Marks in a case involving a seventeen-story building at 2-8 West Forty-sixth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 5 -- The Germans made the most out of the two months' grace in which no major battles were fought on the Tunisian front, and when the Allies launch a major offensive many of the advantages held by them last November will belong to the enemy.

Every year since its foundation the Juilliard School of Music has presented some sort of a memorial in tribute to Augustus D. Juilliard, to whom it owes its existence. This year the memorial took the form of a concert by the orchestra of the Juilliard Graduate School, under Albert Stoessel, presented last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the United Hospital Fund.

I have enjoyed reading the references in Lincoln Werden's "Wood Field and Stream" column recently concerning the "fish for food" suggestion made by Charles Jackson of Washington, D.C., acting deputy coordinator of fisheries.

The major orchestras in New York would be seriously affected if the War Manpower Commission ruled that men under 38, now classed as 3-A in the draft, must find jobs in war industries or enter the armed services, according to a survey made here yesterday.

Directors of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, comparing with four quarterly dividends of 31 1/4 cents a share each declared in 1942. They also voted to set aside a reserve for post-war adjustments, but did not make the figure public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Representative Marcantonio introduced a bill in the House today which would give broader powers to the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices to prevent discrimination in employment because of race, color, creed or national origin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (U.P.) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the civilian labor force dropped to 52,400,000 last month, a wartime low, largely because of the entrance of men into the armed services.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Each major faction of Yugoslavia's divided Patriot armies is accusing the other of collaboration with the Axis to assure its own ascendancy. A previous dispatch presented the Chetniks' tale of how the dispute began; the following is the version of the Partisans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The War Department's Corps of Engineers is building that part of war housing located on or near military depots, posts, airfields and industries, but it is undecided whether recreational or other additional facilities will be added by the Army or the National Housing Agency.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Following is a series of Office of War Information questions and answers concerning rationing of processed foods:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Secrecy continued today to cloak the movements of American and Japanese forces in the South Pacific.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- General Georges Catroux, Fighting French Delegate General to Syria, will visit Algiers in the near future before returning to the Levant, it was revealed here today. He has been mentioned as a possible member of General Charles de Gaulle's mission to collaborate with General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner in French North Africa, but as recently as yesterday it had been indicated that he was going directly back to Syria.

Roosevelt Dudley of East New York Vocational established a new vocational high school indoor meet record for the running high jump when he turned in a performance of 5 feet 9 1/8 inches at the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School gymnasium in Brooklyn yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- If the worst comes Americans will have enough wool garments to remain comfortable and healthy and there is no indication that rationing of clothing will have to take place, according to Meyer Kestnbaum, president of Hart, Schaffner Marx, men's clothing manufacturers stated today.

The shortage of nurses and the reduction in the number of physicians on hospital staffs are leading to subtle changes in hospital procedure in which the patient still gets the best of care but with the gradual elimination of all "frills," it was learned yesterday.

The lend-lease program is working out far better than Congress ever expected it would work, James W. Wadsworth Jr., Representative from New York, told members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club.
The recent article in THE TIMES pointing out that admirers of Jimmy Collins consider him deserving of a place in baseball's Hall of Fame prompts me to write.

Five Bronx youths who ran away from their homes and lived on the earnings of one of the group, described as a "pool shark," found their bid for unrestrained freedom ended yesterday when they appeared in Bronx Magistrate's Court and received a stern warning on the dangers of bad company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Senator Truman, chairman, said today at the close of a public hearing that the Special Defense Committee would explore further the concrete barge construction program at, the MacEvoy Shipbuilding Corporation yards in Savannah, Ga.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A recommendation that if the United States adopts a "bedrock" civilian economy it limit the sale of distilled spirits to 1 per cent of the 1941 consumption, with buying permitted for medicinal uses only, has been made to James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, by the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply.

AT SEA OFF GUADALCANAL, Jan. 24 (delayed) -- A South Pacific task force early this morning drove in close to and bombarded the newly established Japanese supply base on the southeastern tip of Kolombangara Island, which is only thirteen miles from Munda airfield on New Georgia Island just across Kula Gulf.

One way to realize what the effect of pay-as-you-go taxes would be is to consider the probable situation when the war ends. Hundreds of thousands of persons now in high-paid munitions jobs would find themselves out of those jobs. This year, let us say, a man who never made more than $40 a week before is getting $100 a week in a munitions factory.

The truth was proved again last night in the Metropolitan Opera House that the mainspring of a performance is a conductor. And since Cesare Sodero was in the conductor's chair, and very authoritative and dramatic in his reading of the score, another truth, even more important, was driven home on this occasion, which is, that "Il Trovatore" is a most romantic and thrilling opera.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

A basic principle of rationing is that when two alternative methods are available the simpler one should always be adopted unless, on grounds of equity, the more complex has overwhelming evidence in its favor. This principle is pertinent in connection with meat.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Edward Henry Crockett, 31-year-old Associated Press war correspondent assigned to the British Mediterranean Fleet, was fatally wounded in the torpedoing of a British naval vessel and died at sea, the Admiralty disclosed today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Indictments against eleven present and former officials of the Ohio Fuel Gas Company, the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries were quashed today by Common Pleas Judge Robert P. Duncan.
BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow of the Boston wool market:
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Vice Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten declared today that the war could be won only when soldiers have taken physical possession of enemy-held territory.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Major Gen. Holland M. Smith, 61, commanding general of the Fleet Marine Force in the San Diego area, was released on $500 bail today after detention by the police on charges of hit-and-run driving, drunken driving and a misdemeanor hit-and-run accident.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Buying of wheat futures attributed to mills gave the market for that grain a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade, but profit-taking above $1.40 a bushel for May and the development of independent weakness in rye caused a sell-off of around 1 cent a bushel from the top.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Mounting costs of the war at sea brought a request from President Roosevelt today for an additional $4,000,000,000 in cash and $210,000,000 in contract authorizations for the Navy.

Feeding the 2,500,000 young Americans who will attend our Summer camps through July and August presents a major problem for counselors this year, Frances Foley Gannon, Director of Consumer Service, Department of Markets, in this city, said yesterday at the afternoon session of Camp Conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Feb. 6 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur hurled his aerial might against Japanese shipping over a wide area of the South Pacific today. In one attack on Amboina, west of Dutch New Guinea, four-motored Liberators bombed 20,000 tons of ships, destroying or seriously damaging the three vessels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Direct intercession by President Roosevelt to prevent inclusion in the $210,000,000,000 national debt limit bill of the Gearhart "rider" to repeal the executive order holding salaries to a maximum of $25,000 net was impending tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Britain is building better and faster merchant ships, according to J.R. Hobhouse, chairman of the General Council of British Shipping.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 5 -- Representatives of the University of Connecticut, the United States Employment Service, the Women's Land Army and the Farm Security Administration issued a call today for New York and New England women workers to help win the food phase of the war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The Office of Price Administration today amended Maximum Price Regulation No. 287 to permit manufacturers of women's and children's outerwear garments to meet minimum costs they must put into dresses, suits, coats, skirts and blouses in order to sell them in designated price lines.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Carrying out their greatest triple-threat raid, strong forces of four-motored British bombers roared over three countries, Italy, France and Germany, last night, battering the Fiat works at Turin and Italy's chief naval base at Spezia, the Nazis' U-boat lair at Lorient and industrial targets in the Ruhr Valley.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews assumed command of the United States forces in the European theatre today and declared strongly for an all-out intensification of air warfare against Germany, indicating at the same time that the major part of his job would be preparing the reinforcements expected here.

Although Japan did not ratify the Geneva agreement of 1929 affecting prisoners of war, Allied soldiers and sailors captured by the Japanese are being "reasonably well treated," according to Howard Wilson, head of military and naval welfare service field directors, North Atlantic Area of the American Red Cross.

The Indian girl's swift emigration from the quiet tribal life of her reservation to the speeded-up living of industrial war centers envisions the end of the American Indian's isolation from normal American community life. Such is the opinion of Miss Bertha M. Eckert, secretary for Indian work of the National Y.W.C.A., who has just returned to New York after a three months tour through the Dakotas, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Illinois.

A series of exhibits entitled, "This Is Our War," principally designed to emphasize the nation's war aims, will open on Lincoln's Birthday on Friday in the Plaza of Rockefeller Center, the Office of War Information at Washington announced yesterday.

The sixty-family apartment house at 17-25 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, has been bought by the Essbee Company. The seller was the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee for the mortgage participation certificate holders of the Fidelity Union Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Intimating a weakness that his hale-and-hearty appearance belied, Connie Mack asked for help tonight in blowing out the eighty candles on his birthday cake.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 5 -- Assuming "the entire burden for the conduct of political and military operations in this delicate phase of the conflict," Premier Mussolini tonight ousted twelve of the most important members of his government, including his son-in-law, Count Ciano, whose Foreign Affairs portfolio he took.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5 (AP) -- United States bombers scored direct hits on a strategic railroad bridge over the Irrawaddy near Mandalay in Burma yesterday, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The War Manpower Commission's plan to draft fathers of families unless they switch from "nonessential" jobs to more essential occupations encountered strenuous opposition today in the House, where members of the Military Committee moved to block it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Gardening will supplement golf playing at several country clubs in Westchester County next Summer, the Westchester Victory Garden Council said today in announcing arrangements for a 20 per cent increase in the county's 18,870 victory gardens of last year.

Without doubt All the artists connected with "For Your Pleasure" are impeccable, and probably it is sheer boorishness to suggest they do not, as a collective unit, belong on Broadway. But the disagreeable fact remains that the variety show put together by Veloz and Yolanda is not a good one, for it lacks the change in pace a vaudeville bill should have and, above all, it lacks a bit of comedy.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Too many salesmen now on the job were trained too long ago, S.D. Chamberlain said here today. Mr. Chamberlain, field manager for the Kendall Company, is a pioneer in the development of sales training methods and the use of specialized aptitude tests not only in selection of salesmen, but also in their development.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 5 -- Twenty-six German planes were shot out of Tunisian skies by the machine guns of American planes and twenty-six more were damaged yesterday.

IT was just a year ago that Fred Schmertz, the director of the Millrose Games, received a letter. He fingered it nervously, hesitated over it and tried to make up his mind. The missive was from Jack Ryder, track coach at Boston College and the Boston A.A. In it Ryder modestly offered him Gilbert Dodds for either the mile or the two-mile event.

Thousands of Chinese and hundreds of other interested spectators thronged the narrow, quaint Mott, Pell, Doyers and Bayard Streets yesterday in a gay and noisy celebration of the Chinese New Year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Rubber Director William M. Jeffers is asking State Governors to cancel all horse-race meetings at tracks whose locations make it necessary to travel to them by automobile.

The 909th Engineers of Mitchell Field, L.I., opened last night a series of demonstrations at Macy's department store designed to acquaint metropolitan New Yorkers with the techniques and the importance of camouflage in modern warfare.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Rugged Jacob La Motta, belting his foe through the ropes for a count of nine in the eighth round, handed Ray (Sugar) Robinson his first defeat in 130 fights by scoring a ten-round decision tonight before a record crowd of 18,930 spectators at Olympia Stadium.
Commander Gene Tunney considers a standardized system of calisthenics for all members of the armed forces superior to competitive sports because it saves unnecessary expense and valuable time.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Feb. 5 -- If there is any remotely practical idea, however fantastic, for the development of communications in the future, it more than likely will be found somewhere within the five laboratories or in one of the sheds on the snow-covered hills of this Army Signal Corps establishment.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 -- Consolidation of twelve insurance companies into one, the Guaranty Union Life Insurance Company, has been ordered by Superior Judge Ruben S. Schmidt on the basis of a petition filed by Anthony Caminetti Jr., State Insurance Commissioner.

The letter of Charles Upson Clark, published Feb. 2, is somewhat inaccurate. No one anywhere, as far as I know, has suggested that all of the functionaries in North Africa be shipped back to Vichy. That would be most absurd, so it is unnecessary for Mr. Clark or anybody else to labor that question.

Questioning the wisdom of a huge Federal Government advertising fund to be used to help explain the problems of the home front, Gardner Cowles Jr., publisher of The Des Moines Register and Tribune and director of the Domestic Division of the Office of War Information, appealed here last night for the aid of the advertising field to help win the war.

Railroad financing featured the market for new investments here this week, with the first flotation of mortgage bonds by that industry since last October. This issue, put out by the Erie Railroad and the sole loan of the week, amounted to $14,000,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 5 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French Africa, appointed a "War Committee" to replace the Imperial Council as a temporary administration in French North Africa at the conclusion of a council meeting today.

Some 100 American composers will have works broadcast by WNYC during the municipal station's fourth annual American Music Festival to be held daily from Lincoln's Birthday, Feb. 12, through Washington's Birthday, Feb. 22.

WITH THE AMERICAN FORCES ON GUADALCANAL, Jan. 21 (UP) (Delayed) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox experienced conditions on Guadalcanal at first-hand today, jolting over the muddy, rural roads and inspecting forward positions under fire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The House refused today to write in the Treasury Appropriation Bill a restriction against paying the salaries of about forty government employes classified by Chairman Dies of the House committee investigating un-American activities as "crackpot" or "radical" bureaucrats.

Assets of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company rose $44,379,888 last year to $810,336,717. The gain was largely invested in government bonds, which exceeded $95,000,000 at the year-end. Net earnings rose $2,183,942 to $15,759,213 and policies increased in value by $29,701,327, so that insurance in force at the end of 1942 aggregated $2,055,144,876 for 532,915 policies, not counting more than 40,000 annuity policies.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- There has been so much optimistic speculation about the results of the meeting at Casablanca between General Henri Giraud, High Commissioner of French Africa, and General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, that it may be useful now to recapitulate what actually did happen when President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill brought together the two French leaders.

Aggregate market value and average price of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange on Jan. 30 reached the highest levels since Sept. 1, 1941. The former was $41,410,585,043, against $38,811,728,666 on Dec. 31, 1942, and the latter was $28,16, against $26.39.
Both appointees, outstanding in the field of religion, authors of note and organizational workers as well as members of Phi Beta Kappa, will begin their terms at Union Theological Seminary on July 1.

After seven months of trying to find out how to obtain war contracts and getting nowhere, the American Contractors War Advisory Committee, formed by the officers of twenty-four employer associations in the building trades for the purpose of studying contract procedure, has made a direct appeal to the President, Philip Wolf, chairman of the group, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Members of a House naval subcommittee said today that accounts of union seamen refusing to unload ships at Guadalcanal were untrue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- A representative of the National Symphony Orchestra said today that while the long-range outlook for that organization under wartime manpower needs and regulations was not particularly encouraging, it did not see in the War Manpower Commission's order any immediate threat to the orchestra's future.
Beau Jack overwhelmed Fritzie Zivic last night in their ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 -- The "black market" in beef has brought back the cattle rustler, whose dark deeds in the old days of the open range have been the subject of many a story of Western life.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission held today that it does not regard annual reports of corporations to be a part of the material for solicitation of proxies under the present proxy rules unless the issuer specifically requests that the material be so treated.
UTICA, N. Y., Feb. 5 (AP) -- Rinks from Brookline, Mass., and Mount Hope won first-round matches tonight in Allen Medal play of the Grand National curling tournament.

Further aid to non-citizens who wish to acquire "official status as Americans" was pledged yesterday by government officials and representatives of national service and welfare organizations attending the annual conference of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship held at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 5 -- Since nothing can prevent Chinese from celebrating the traditional New Year according to the lunar calendar the National Government is turning the occasion this year into a three-day celebration of the new American and British treaties abolishing extraterritoriality.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Helena Rubinstein Gourielli received $55,557.26 as president and director of Helena Rubinstein Inc., of New York, according to the 1942 report of the corporation made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The gold medal for distinguished services to advertising was awarded to Chester J. La Roche, chairman of the board of Young Rubicam, Inc., at the annual Advertising Awards dinner, sponsored by Advertising and Selling Magazine, last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Operations of the Sun Oil Company and its subsidiaries in the year ended on Dec. 31 resulted in a net income of $8,671,050 after Federal taxes and other deductions.

Charles Blandford, administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Market, has prepared a request to Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, Federal Food Administrator, for authority to order the elimination of competition in the distribution and collection of milk here.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Adolf Hitler's lust for conquest has already cost the world more than $400,000,000,000, the Commerce Department estimated today, and the cost may exceed $500,000,000,000, or half a trillion, if he is not brought to his knees for another year.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Tragic Ending, Coldstream Farm 5-year-old, won the mile and a sixteenth St. Martinville purse at the Fair Grounds today by three lengths after taking the lead at the head of the stretch. The winner toured the distance in 1:48 3-5 and returned 5 to 1.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A Superior Court jury trying Errol Flynn on three morals charges involving two young girls was ordered locked up for the night when it failed to reach an agreement at 9:54 P.M. (Pacific war time), tonight, nearly eleven hours after receiving the case.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5 -- Rene Ristelhueber, former Vichy Minister to Canada, and members of his staff have offered their services to General Henri Honore Giraud, High Commissioner for French North Africa, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King intimated in the House of Commons today after reading a statement on the status of the former envoy and the legation here.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The stock markets remained quiet today. Gilt-edged stocks and home rails were unchanged.

Mayor La Guardia's special committee for the study of labor relations on the city's unified transit system conferred yesterday with the three members of the impartial grievance committee set up in the Board of Transportation a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Three big labor groups, the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the railroad brotherhoods, together with the National Farmers Union, representing "an estimated 13,000,000" organized workers and working farmers, have joined in a common legislative front to fight anti-labor legislation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 5 (Reuter) -- Russian forces under Col. Gen. Andrey I. Yeremenko have captured Bataisk, ten miles south of Rostov, according to an unofficial Soviet, report tonight. Bataisk, the last big station before Rostov, is at the junction of the Salsk-Rostov and Mozdok-Rostov railways.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (UP) -- Andre Marty, former Communist member of the French Chamber of Deputies, said today that a vast underground organization was laying the groundwork in France for a national uprising to coincide with the Allied invasion of Europe.

Fans who have been talking in fractions of seconds for weeks and weighing the capabilities of bright new stars against established heroes with an avidity that only track addicts can muster will have something concrete to work on tonight when the thirty-sixth Millrose A.A. games open the indoor season in Madison Square Garden.

The "biggest bargain" ever offered in a department store basement will be found at midnight, Feb. 16, at Gimbel's, it was announced yesterday. For the first time in its history of 101 years, the store will be open at that hour -- to admit what promises to be its most frenzied customers -- with probably the most money to spend.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

THERE has been no Shakespearean revival so far this season, but unless something goes wrong between now and mid-March that sad state will be remedied by George Coulouris. For Mr. Coulouris plans to revive "Richard III," playing the title role and directing, with rehearsals to begin the week after this, and a New York opening to follow in the usual four weeks.

For at least the sixth time since Americans landed on Guadalcanal six months ago today, the Japanese last week were apparently staking a major effort on regaining the positions they had lost in the strategic Solomons. Secrecy hid what was in progress. In Washington Secretary of the Navy Knox yesterday described the action as in a "preliminary stage."
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Oscar Mayers, spokesman for Miami slaughterers, reported today that all slaughter houses in the Miami area have been closed down because of price ceilings on beef.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Fourteen months after Pearl Harbor the attitude of official Washington toward the objectives of the country at war reveals no fundamental differences. When President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, after their Casablanca conference, named "unconditional surrender" of the Axis powers as a basic condition of peace there was no dissent here.

IN 1943 almost every gardener is going to have a Victory Garden whether or not he has ever before grown vegetables. The government has asked the amateur growers of the country to band themselves into a home front for food production and it begins to look as though there would be a 100 per cent response.

AFTER a recent series of many committee meetings, final plans are being completed for the concert to be given at Carnegie Hall on the night of Feb. 16 for the benefit of the Grenfell Association of America. The program will be presented by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, with Marjorie Lawrence and Friedrich Schorr as soloists.

The Manhattan College basketball team spurted in the third period to beat Fort Monmouth, 45 -- 22, in the Jasper gymnasium last night. Leading by only 18 -- 15 at the end of the first half, during which the score had been tied four times, the Manhattan lads broke the game wide open after the intermission to lead by 31 -- 19 and go on to an easy triumph.

The difference between a springy, rubber-like substance and a hard plastic or a tough fiber, either synthetic or natural, lies in the tendency of the molecules either to contract or to form crystals, Dr. H. Mark, Professor of Organic Chemistry at the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, explains in a Sigma Xi lecture.

I wonder if you remember meeting me at a table in an Automat on Broadway in the Spring of 1935. We chatted, and you generously collected a cup of coffee for me. I gave you an English penny, whose size astonished you, and you told me, in an access of frankness, that on the whole you thought our government better than yours.

I HOPE Mr. Freed, the author of the letter on choral singing in last Sunday's TIMES, was present at the recent concert of the Dessoff Choirs. He might have learned the reason for some of the practices of the Collegiate Chorale which he criticized, and observed a confutation of much of his discourse on a "trained" and "led" chorus.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Ray Getliffe tonight led the Canadiens to an 8-3 triumph over the Boston Bruins, leaders of the National Hockey League, before 10,046 fans at the Forum. Getliffe shot five goals and assisted in a sixth to help the Canadiens move within three points of the fourth-place Chicago Black Hawks.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 -- William Ziegler Jr.'s Wait a Bit, one of the lightweights in the field but a colt that moves up remarkably in mud, emerged victorious from a three-way nose finish in the six-furlong Gentilly Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A sweeping indictment of the President's $109,000,000,000 budget, in which it will be charged that non-military items are concealed among the war expenditures and that some expected expenditures, which will send the budget over the $109,000,000,000 figure, are not mentioned at all, is being prepared by the Byrd committee.

THOUGH there is a growing scarcity of seeds of vegetable and field crops, there has been no easing of the strictness with which high seed standards have been maintained by the Department of Agriculture.

TWO major studios, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Twentieth Century-Fox, in producing pictures with all-Negro casts, are following the desires of Washington in making such films at this time. Decisions to produce the pictures, it is stated, followed official expression that the Administration felt that its program for increased employment of Negro citizens in certain heretofore restricted fields of industry would be helped by a general distribution of important pictures in which Negroes played a major part.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Pennsylvania maintained its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League when it drove to a 42-35 triumph over Cornell tonight. It was the tenth straight victory for the Quakers and their third straight in circuit play.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Portuguese Premier, remained in his capital today, despite reports from Axis news sources indicating he had left for an unspecified destination to meet Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spanish Government chief.

Calling attention to Brazil's "active and fruitful collaboration in the activities of Pan-Americanism," Carlos Martins, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States emphasized yesterday that his country will cooperate in the common protection of the continent and collaborate "in the organization of a lasting peace based on justice, on mutual assistance."

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 6 (AP) -- United States heavy bombers have wrecked Japanese communications between North and South Burma so completely that the enemy has been compelled to rearrange his defensive forces while an effort is made at repair.

Dogs are serving honorably now with our armed forces, but they are still playing their amiable and useful part in civilian life. And we have a reminder of that fact in the Westminster Kennel Club's annual show this week. Exactly what the year's list of ten top dogs of pure breed will be can't yet be told. But grouped on these pages are that number of long-time favorites.

" 'A FIREPLACE, Father?' exclaimed Gustaf. 'You didn't expect that!' " Thus, asking so little of comfort, of the bare necessities of life, the Larssons, who had come thousands of weary miles, rejoiced at last in their new home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Science Service) -- Chlorine, the element of a thousand uses in war and peace, can be made as a by-product of the potash industry through a process patented here by a Bureau of Plant Industry chemist, Donald L. Reed. Mr. Reed has assigned rights in his patent, No. 2,309,919, royalty-free to the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An effort will be made next week by Senators Kilgore and Pepper to salvage their bill to establish a Civilian Office of War Mobilization, but informed Senate circles predicted today that its chances of emerging intact from the Military Affairs Committee were slight.

TORONTO, Feb. 6 -- The downward spiral of Toronto hockey fortunes, started when Sylvanus Apps was sidelined for the season with a leg fracture, was halted tonight as the Maple Leafs shaded the New York Rangers, 3-2, in a thrill- fraught National Hockey League fixture before 10,788 fans in Maple Leaf Gardens.

SEVEN prospective heirs are waiting for old Josiah Sloan to die. He has informed them that they, together with three others, are to divide his estate, and he has invited them to live in his house for the short time that the doctors have allotted him.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- British undersea craft have sunk four more Axis vessels seeking to supply Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel and left another probably in a sinking condition, it was announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Fearful of a possible United Nations landing on the Balkan peninsula to establish bridgeheads for the opening of a second front on the Continent, Axis forces under German leadership have begun a widespread campaign to stamp out patriot resistance in Yugoslavia and to wipe out both the Chetnik organization of General Draja Mikhailovitch and the Partisan movement based on the small Bosnian town of Bihac.

Although the Quartermaster Corps has indicated that it has not yet crystallized its buying program for the last half of 1943 or for 1944, wool goods and clothing manufacturers expressed the conviction last week that government buying has reached a peak and will be on the down grade at the end of the fiscal year, June 30.

The appointment of Admiral Karl Doenitz to command Hitler's fleet serves further notice that Germany plans a supreme effort in ruthless submarine warfare. Doenitz, accepting his commission, confirms this fact with a pledge to concentrate the full strength of the German Navy on "inexorable" use of this weapon.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Chile has acquired copper and steel plants in the United States, to be operated in this country, and their capacity will be sufficient to meet Chilean needs of those metals, it was announced today by Rodolfo Jaramillo, new Minister of Economy.

THE baseball clans are gathering these days for some vitally important league meetings. The magnates will get their last chance to laugh tonight when the Baseball Writers Association lampoons them unmercifully at the scribes' twentieth annual dinner. Then they will be deadly serious for the next few days.

THE recent season has given us few opportunities to hear new music; it has given us instead the second performance of a work excelling the latest novelties in scope and value. It was gratifying to discover that the repetition of E.J. Moeran's violin concerto gave us no reason to modify the very favorable opinion one had formed when this delectable piece was first heard at the Promenade concerts.

THERE are a number of women in this country who are neither Waves, Waacs, lathe hands nor nurses' aides. These are the women who write in the proper space on the census blank: "Occupation, housewife."

Dean Robert G. Caldwell of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today expressed the hope that the nation's liberal arts colleges would emerge with more balanced programs at the end of the war and that the liberal tradition would be preserved.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 6 -- Major Gen. Louis H. Brereton has succeeded Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews as commander of United States forces in the Middle East, it was disclosed today, but he will simply carry on the job that he has been doing superbly since the Ninth United States Army Air Force was formed last Summer.

The high tide of German conquest was still receding last week across the frozen Kuban steppes and the snow-covered Ukraine fields, leaving hehind it the flotsam and jetsam of a great retreat. The Nazi armies on the southern Russian front had experienced what Secretary Stimson described as "one of the worst military defeats ever suffered by Germany" -- and the retreat after two and a half months had not ended.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at City Hall the appointment of Leo Arnstein as Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, to succeed the late William Hodson, who was killed last month in an airplane crash while en route to North Africa on a mission for former Governor Lehman, Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation.
Joseph Stalin is fighting his own war, Russia's war, the war which he foresaw -- perhaps before anyone else -- and for which he prepared his country.

PHILHARMONIC HALL in Leningrad is a formal eighteenth-century building -- it was the St. Petersburg court assembly rooms -- with plain white walls, glittering chandeliers and an open stage backed by organ pipes. It was here, some years ago, that a small audience of Leningrad's inveterate concertgoers assembled to listen to a pianoforte recital by Dmitri Shostakovich.

PERHAPS no one has played a more important part in raising the American theatre from the lowly estate it floundered in twenty-five years ago than George Jean Nathan. He has fought long and hard for originality, honesty and dignity in the native drama and with equal strength he sought to combat the strangle hold that Puritanism, academicism and crass commercialism once exercised upon it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- O. John Rogge was named by Attorney General Biddle today to direct the prosecution of the sedition conspiracy case in place of William Power Maloney, whose work in the case has drawn protests from Senator Wheeler and others.

Amid other news of the war, it may be that the significance of the Alcan Highway under completion from Edmonton, Alberta, to Fairbanks, Alaska, has still to be appreciated fully on both sides of the border. Under the circumstances I take the liberty of enclosing some correspondence which may help to clarify the situation.
A CLIPPING from a newspaper on my desk disturbs my peace of mind, keeps me from doing my daily work. It demands action of some kind. I do not know what to do about it, except write this article.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Organized labor's many-pronged attack on the War Labor Board's "Little Steel" wage-stabilization formula is well in its stride and promises to continue for some time, bringing with it a reopening of last year's discussion on methods of averting a possible inflationary spiral.

MAY 1, as a visitor from the provinces, express my deep satisfaction with two plays I saw last week? I expected to be pleased with Mr. Anderson's "The Eve of St. Mark" because I had read it, but I could not be aware, of course, of the impression which "The Patriots" would make on me.
Unprecedented changes are being made in the curricula of the nation's forty-two social work schools to bring them in line with the new types of training demanded by total war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The shake-up in the Italian Cabinet was declared at the State Department today to be mere window-dressing by the Fascist ruling clique that should deceive no one and should lead to no relaxation in the war effort.

Deliveries from wholesale markets will probably be delayed even further by the Manpower Commission's new edict adding to labor difficulties in certain lines, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Uncle Sam in the year since Pearl Harbor has become the greatest real estate operator in the world. Since Dec. 7, 1941, he has done a land and building business aggregating more than $250,000,000 -- and to an extent and pace evoking strong criticism from certain quarters, notably from Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Congressional-Departmental Economy Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 -- William Jeffers, national Rubber Administrator, gave notice today that the Bay Meadows race track would be permitted to go ahead after all, with its fifty-day meeting starting Feb. 20, but the patrons will go to the course by stage coach.

The Blood Transfusion Service in Great Britain promises to throw light on the relations and perhaps the origins of the races of Northern Europe, and this because blood is divided before transfusion into four groups, A, B, AB and O, on the basis of "antigens" which damage red corpuscles in other groups.

" THE GREEK HISTORIANS," the complete and unabridged historical works of Herodotus, Thucydides, Xenophon and Arrian, was edited by Francis R.B. Godolphin, Associate Professor of Classics, Princeton University. Random House has brought out these two sturdy cloth-bound volumes ($5) in the accepted translations of Rawlinson, Jowett, Dakyns and Chinnock.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 6 -- Premier Mussolini's new government got off to a poor start today when because of an "oversight" or the press of other matters the decree naming the "crisis cabinet" failed to get the signature of King Victor Emmanuel.

After following the discussion of whether we must hate or not in order to win the war and win the peace, as led by Rex Stout and countered by Professor Bowie, it seems to me the clarifying distinction has not yet been made.

It is an old story about the retired professor of classical languages who spent the last years of his life translating "Hamlet" into ancient Greek. He thought it a great pity that this greatest single masterpiece in all literature should be exposed to the vicissitudes of a living, changing tongue like English.

Edsel Ford's recent vindication of those of us who have passed the median age will find warm support from the "forty-and-upward" group of men and women to whom he refers. At the present moment we seem to be regarded as unfit for anything more active than the role of a claque for the younger set who now occupy the stage.

SANFORD, Fla. -- Many Easterners not kept at home by their work are leaving their empty fuel tanks behind and flying, like wild ducks, to the sun. This group is composed largely of elderly retired couples or invalids, but there are also families of men on oversea duty, and young wives who take their small children away from inadequately heated houses.

FOR many years British radio comedy was one of those things no Englishman would attempt to defend. Then the American Army came to Britain. A half million American boys missed their radio comedy programs.

Efforts of the textile industry to sustain last year's high rate of essential civilian output for 1943, now receiving practical assistance by the WPB, will require greater leeway from other government agencies, notably the OPA, if it is to succeed in its objective, textile leaders declared here last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations called upon the Federal Government today to revise its wage policy upward and make provision for a guaranteed work-week of forty hours, but it reaffirmed its support of national wage stabilization as a necessary war measure and its willingness to submit its pay increase disputes to the War Labor Board for final determination without resort to strike action.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, today appealed for cancellation of this year's Kentucky Derby, scheduled for May 1. Because of increasingly heavy demands on railroads and intercity buses for troop movements and other necessary passenger traffic, "it would be better from a transportation standpoint if the Kentucky Derby were not run this year," Mr. Eastman said.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Parliament prepared today to weigh human resentment against international law as the question was raised whether Nazi airmen killed while raiding Great Britain should be buried with military honors.

EFFECTIVE economy is enlightened economy. It's the kind the Bureau of Home Economics demonstrates in a series of posters that are tellingly titled "Get the Good From Your Food." The pictures on this page are taken from these posters.

Reports from Philadelphia that the Securities and Exchange Commission is seriously concerned over the possibility of a rising market for securities and is considering steps to check one if it appears, shocked and amazed Wall Street circles yesterday.

MOST Americans possess an impression, and an unpleasant impression, of the phantom Vichy regime that emerged from the wreckage and collapse of France in the tragic Summer days of 1940 and that lost the last semblance of independent sovereignty when Hitler ordered the occupation of all France last November.

THOMAS JEFFERSON was one of the most unusual and enigmatic figures in all American history. A large landowner, he spent his life fighting the doctrine that the new country should have an aristocratic ruling class.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The War Labor Board reported today that there were 1,363 strikes during 1942, involving 569,801 workers and causing a loss of 2,095,294 man days in war industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The U-boat menace is the greatest threat the Allies are facing in the Atlantic and the Navy is straining every effort to meet it, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said at his press conference today. He reiterated that Adolf Hitler was counting on submarines for his major effort at sea.

THE call for Block Service Leaders to be the good neighbors of New York City is prying thousands of inactive women out of their ivory towers and adding another volunteer job to the lives of women who are already doing so much.

WOMEN interested in furthering the work of the American Flying Services Foundation are active in the sale of tickets for the national amateur figure skating championships to be held on March 8 at the Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the New York Skating Club for the benefit of the foundation.

Three new recordings of the Johnny Mercer-Harold Arlen tune, That Old Black Magic from the film, "Star-Spangled Rhythm," are at hand. The best of the three is by Freddie Slack and his orchestra, with a warm vocal by Margaret Whiting (Capitol).

A Festival of Jewish Arts was presented by Jacob Weinberg, pianist-composer, last night in Town Hall. Assisting artists included Maria Van Delden, soprano; Edgar Mills, baritone; Vladimir Graffman, violin; Youry Bilstin, 'cello; Irene Jacobi and Walter Taussig, pianists; Alexander Richardson, organ, and the Jewish Choral Society, directed by A.W. Binder.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- Although the blockade around Free China is severe it listens to reason. Believe it or not, the Japanese are only human and the Chinese realistic.

Behind the headlines that herald the air supremacy of the United Nations on the battlefronts of the world is a story of industrial resourcefulness. From the plants and laboratories of makers of refrigerators, automobiles, heat controls industrial instruments, railroad cars and petroleum have come outstanding contributions to the super-planes which are expected to wrest victory from the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Three weeks from Monday the rationing of canned goods will get under way, and on April 1 meat rationing will go into effect. Therewith American shoppers and consumers will enter upon a new era, both as to what they buy and how they buy it.

As the new Spring term gets under way this week, small liberal arts colleges and universities in every section of the country face one of the most difficult periods in the history of American education. Enrollment losses ranging up to 50 per cent or more are recorded on campuses in every section of the land.

IF it is fitting to celebrate the hundredth anniversary of the birth or death of a famous writer, does not the centenary of the foundation of a great publishing house equally deserve recognition? In February, 1843, there came into existence a firm which has left is mark upon English literature.

Concern over a post-war world in which the American people might not be able to get back the liberties and privileges that they have relinquished willingly to aid the war was expressed last night by four speakers at the annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

ENGLISH caricature constitutes the current exhibition theme at the Pierpont Morgan Library. An attractive display has been arranged. The walls there have seldom been so gay with color. More closely examined, true enough, much of the color is flamboyant and crude, for that goes with comic art of the period covered (eighteenth and nineteenth centuries).

Bread is no longer sliced because of a shortage of manpower and the saving of an infinitesimal amount of electricity. Both manpower and electricity are wasted in the making of tea balls. Twenty-five tea balls containing two ounces of tea are put into a box capable of holding a quarter pound.

IN Madrid on the night of Feb. 8, 1843, an Italian soprano sang the title role in the opera "Norma" and in the early hours of the next morning gave birth to her seventh child. The name of that child was Adelina Patti.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Wayne L. Morse, speaking for public members of the War Labor Board, said last night that the "Little Steel" wage formula would be maintained regardless of pressure from organized labor for further wage increases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- A first list of 281 institutions approved for training of men and women for the armed forces was made public today by the Joint Committee for the Selection of Non-Federal Educational Institutions.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- To the Fighting French here, General Giraud's assumption of the title of "French civil and military commander in chief" and his new policy in North Africa, while welcome in one or two particulars, are regarded as generally unfortunate in that the steps were taken without any previous discussion or agreement with General de Gaulle.

IT used to be said that the preacher's boy was likely to turn out wild. In this story it is the daughter of grimly religious New Englanders who wants to be a little wild flower. All the stories she had ever heard of her Uncle Joel, the black sheep of the family, made her want to be like him.

New Utrecht's athletes regained some of the Brooklyn school's past glory in track and field yesterday, when the Green and White squad scored 30 points to win the team title in the fortieth annual city P.S.A.L. senior high indoor championships at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The War Production Board, of which Donald M. Nelson is chairman, has always been beset with internal controversies over persons and policies. But this week a jurisdictional dispute involving officials of higher rank than ever before same to general attention when Mr. Nelson took six divisions From the province of Ferdinand Eberstadt, vice chairman in charge of program, and assigned them to Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman in charge of production.

The French militia that Pierre Level has organized is being recruited to fight on the side of the Germans against an Allied invasion, it was indicated last night by a Berlin broadcast of a dispatch from Vichy recorded by The Associated Press.
" IN my life" -- so begins this autobiography -- "I have learned all the tricks except how not to be a damn fool." The exception is adequately and interestingly disproved in the succeeding 400 pages.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 6 -- The creation of a North African theatre of operations under the command of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was announced by Allied Headquarters today. General Eisenhower retains his old position as Commander in Chief of the Allied forces while taking over the vastly more ambitious post of commanding general of the North African theatre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- President Roosevelt appealed to the House Ways and Means Committee today to vote out the bill to increase the national debt limit to $210,000,000,000 without the Gearhart "rider" to repeal his Executive Order holding salaries to a maximum of $25,000 net a year.

HOLLYWOOD. SHOULD William Saroyan ever feel need of a champion in the movies -- a ridiculous thought, since he has proven a most voluble defender of his own best interests -- he could find no stouter supporter than Clarence Brown.

Training for physical fitness in a world at war requires the elimination of 25 per cent of the recreational activities of peacetime, directors of private camps declared yesterday at the closing session of the camping conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The newest chapter of the Battle of the Solomons, now being written behind a screen of close official secrecy, conforms to the consistent official opinion that the Japanese must meet the issue of the South Pacific in the waters around this tropical archipelago.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 (AP) -- American bombers again pounded the Myitnge Bridge near Mandalay, a vital link of Japanese communications in Burma, as the enemy attempted to repair damage from previous raids, a Tenth United States Air Force communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Sufficient alcoholic liquor is on hand in the United States to meet normal consumption "for several years," Joseph L. Weiner, OCS director, asserted today, adding that the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply had made no recommendations that production or distribution be limited to 1 per cent of 1941 consumption or any other recommendation on the subject.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 6 -- Federal Judge Ramon F. Vasquez appointed today a trustee or special administrator to run Critica, leading Argentine afternoon newspaper and one of the stanchest defenders of the democratic cause, until litigation affecting its ownership is settled.

Available manpower for the crews of War Shipping Administration vessels of Panama and Honduras registry is to be concentrated in a central pool controlled by the recruitment and manning organization of the War Shipping Administration, according to an announcement by Captain Granville Conway, Atlantic Coast director of the WSA.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 6 -- Playing with deliberation, the Pennsylvania State College basketball team flashed too much finesse for the Naval Academy players today, turning back the Midshipmen, 33 to 21.

In wartime, when big brothers go into the Army and Navy, and big sisters into the Waacs and the Waves, younger boys and girls grow up faster. One sign of more rapid maturity has moved the executives of Camp Fire Girls to extend the junior program to include 7-year-olds as well as girls of 8 and 9.
The American Women's Voluntary Services announced yesterday its readiness to send for all useless automobiles whose owners are willing to donate them to its salvage department.

IT would be hard to estimate too highly the work of reconstruction which has been done on the famous Crosby Brown collection of musical instruments at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, or the imagination and scholarship with which a newly arranged exhibition of these instruments, officially opening today, is placed before the public.

A course in practical gardening will be given at Columbia University beginning Feb. 15 and continuing to March 15, under the sponsorship of the Columbia University Committee for War Relief. The proceeds from tuition fees, which will be $10 for the course, will go to the "seeds for Britain" section of the British War Relief Society, Inc.

Guiomar Novaes, Brazilian pianist, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss Novaes, who had just recovered from an attack of influenza, presented a program, the first half of which, containing the Chopin sonata in B flat minor, the Handel "Chaconne" in G, Mozart's A minor Rondo and Schumann's "Papillons," made heavy demands on her strength.

SOME adults can go up to a group of children and in no time at all say or do exactly the right thing to set the conversational ball rolling. The rest of us wait for the children to make the openings -- as they may or may not -- or wade in with such heavy-footed advances as, "How old are you?"

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 6 -- A draft of the new Venezuelan petroleum law, long promised by President Isaias Medina Angarita, was handed to representatives of foreign oil companies at the Presidential Palace yesterday by President Medina himself, assisted by Minister of Development Eugenio Mendoza Jr.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 3 (Delayed) -- There is one highly important and large section of India that does not want to see the British quit India under the present circumstances and that is made up of the Moslems who follow Mohammed Ali Jinnah in his demand for Pakistan [a separate Moslem State].

TWO stimulating shows at once are current this month at Henry Kleemann's Gallery -- one of aquatints in color, by Georges Rouault, and the other of outstanding drawings by a half dozen contemporary American, artists.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Army's basketball forces gained a satisfying victory today when they turned back Maryland, 44 to 40. Just a week before this Maryland team had visited Annapolis and left on the long end of a 63-to-54 score.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- British naval sources, professing lack of sympathy with recent emphasis in Britain and the United States on the seriousness of the submarine menace, said tonight that current destruction of U-boats was at the highest rate since the war began while Allied sinkings were not "above normal."

Spokesmen for both management and labor in the city's commercial laundry business appealed to Mayor La Guardia yesterday for aid in obtaining relief from government restrictions on their use of fuel oil, declaring that the city might be without laundry service by the end of the month unless such relief is granted.

Sidney Blumenthal Co., Inc., manufacturer of textiles, and subsidiaries had in the year ended on Dec. 31, 1942, a net profit of $1,250,208 after all charges, including Federal, State and local taxes totaling $520,111, according to the annual report announced yesterday by H.H. Schell, president.

The personnel of the first of the twelve "Little War Labor Boards" being established throughout the country to help relieve pressure on the National War Labor Board was announced here yesterday by the Office of War Information. The board is for the area including New York State and Northern New Jersey counties and will be known as Regional Board No. 2.

THE young man on the railway train headed for Philadelphia believes that he is Jeffrey Bruno, a writer for the pulp magazines, but the papers in his wallet indicate that he is John Blake, an insurance man. John Blake, according to the newspapers, is wanted by the police for the murder of old Rufus Carrington, and the newspaper picture of John Blake is quite evidently a portrait of Jeffrey Bruno.
THE major ran his hand over his cue-ball pate. "God must have loved the common woman," he paraphrased, "because he made so many of them." "But why," he implored, "why must they all write to me?"

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Feb. 6 -- government plan to switch a portion of the armed forces to industry was revealed by Prime Minister Peter Fraser today. The method of carrying out the plan would provide a maximum degree of flexibility, Mr. Fraser said, enabling the continuance of a maximum degree of strength and quick mobilization should the threat to New Zealand again become serious.

AS in previous years, the World Almanac is indispensable for almost anybody who wants to look up almost anything. Here are collected in easily accessible form essential data which otherwise could be uncovered only after considerable delving into many and varied sources.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 6 -- A German counter-attack, sprung in the face of weather so bad that aerial activity over Tunisia was virtually suspended, has forced Allied troops to relinquish their hold on the strategic height of Djebel Mansour, twenty miles southwest of Pont du Fahs, officials disclosed today.

The congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, has invited Yugoslavs here to join with them in a special service of Christian unity this afternoon.

IT was a week in which, if he chose, the diligent gallery-goer could run the gamut from the naturalistic to the abstract. Since such treks can sometimes prove profitable, making clearer to us the principles involved, I have brought together for discussion here today six new one-man shows, each of which illustrates a phase in the sequence.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- A Chicago flier told today how he and his fellow crewmen on an American bomber sank an Axis ship carrying tanks and an estimated 1,000 troops near Bizerte in Tunisia and then made it back to their home station after being shot down in the Mediterranean by anti-aircraft fire.

Among track experts, the thirty- sixth annual Millrose games, which opened the major indoor campaign at Madison Square Garden last night, offered three "best bets" and a reasonably "good thing." The consensus was that Greg Rice, Cornelius Warmerdam and Gil Dodds could not miss in their specialties and that Jim Herbert was rightfully favored in the Mel Shop-pard 600.

" THE WHOLE HEART" is a first novel by Helen Howe, who comes of a writing family including Quincy and Mark De Wolfe Howe. Now everybody in the family has written a book. Miss Howe has written and acted many monologues and character sketches, here and abroad, so it is not a long leap to a novel written in the form of letters and diary, tuned to the motif of character study.

The 1943 program of the American Civil Liberties Union, made public yesterday, has as its keynote President Roosevelt's declaration that "we will not under any threat, or in the face of danger, surrender the guarantees of liberty our forefathers framed for us in the Bill of Rights."

A LARGE subscription has been reported for the card party in aid of St. Peter's Hospital in Brooklyn, which will take place next Saturday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event has been arranged by members of the hospital's Ladies Auxiliary of which Mrs. Leo J. Guilfoyle is president.

A SIGHTSEEING bus is about to start for the little Mexican town of Los Altos. Janet Martin, a school teacher from the United States, is one of the passengers. Another is a plump little man named Doan, who tells everybody that he is a detective.

Voted the "most muscular man in America" last year in a nationwide contest, Dan Lurie, 19 years old, of 1729 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, has been rejected by the Army because of a "slight heart murmur."

STORIES of animals who talk among themselves as they busily carry on their lives in field or forest or even among men are very popular with children from the days when Peter Rabbit is their favorite hero on through "The Wonderful Adventures of Nils," the "Jungle Book," and stories by Mukerji, Henry Williamson and Theodore Waldeck.

MOSCOW, Feb. 6 -- In two and a half months the powerful Red Army offensives have driven forward 140 to 375 miles on three of the main fronts in Southern Russia and the Caucasus. The Russians are displaying greater power than ever before and are clearly outmanoeuvring and outgeneraling the vaunted armies of Adolf Hitler.

THE return of Winfield R. Sheehan, former production chief of the old Fox Film Company, to active film production parallels in some respects the re-emergence of Jesse L. Lasky as a first-rank producer. Both men were at one time among the most powerful of the Hollywood hierarchy and both in recent years experienced professional reverses.
