An attempt by the firemen of the city to drop the V system under which they work eight extra hours a week without pay has been frustrated as the result of a threat by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh to institute 24-hour duty, similar to the system that obtained during the last war.

GEOGRAPHY is an easy lesson when learned through folk tales, and in these which Harold Courlander has collected from native storytellers the mountains and plains, the little houses and the laughing people of Haiti stand out almost as if painted for us, and Lucy Crockett's impressionistic decorations are evocative, too.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The visit of President Roosevelt, on his way home from Africa, to President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, at Natal, is being hailed as a dramatic symbol of the collaboration between Latin America and the other members of the United Nations in the war effort.

In the expectation that the list of nonessential industries will be extended to include many in the large group which have not yet been classified at all, most companies not actually doing war work prepared last week for the loss of substantial numbers of their employes.
There are some folk who believe that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service will find some means of bringing back off-shore fishing and at least stimulating interest in fresh water angling.
MOSCOW, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

If the Treasury and some of the members of the House Ways and Means Committee could be brought face to face with the absolute necessity for withholding a substantial rate of tax at the source of payment, a way would be found by which the taxpayer could be placed on a current basis.

INFORMATION has reached this country about the death in France of the Russian novelist and publicist, Michael Ossorgin, whose "Quiet Street" was published by the Dial Press and distributed by the Book-of-the-Month Club in 1930.

/. and Instrumental /Vfusic ' . 1[ will be presented Feb. 23 at Town Plall,-under the au-qpices of the National Conference i of Christians and Jews. Participants will include Maria IVfaximowitch, soprano; Felix Salrnond, I I'cello; Marcel Grandjany, harp;I Vivian Fine, piano; the Columbia l University Choir, under Lowell P. r Beveridge; a sextet from Lhe Blessed Martin Choral Group, and the Temple Emanu-E1 choir, under Lazare Saminsky.

Dogs of peace and K-9s of war will be on exhibition in Madison Square Garden Thursday and Friday in the sixty-seventh annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club. The former will compete during the two days in breed classes and groups events and the six survivors will battle for the best in show honors.

ONE may be proud of both the United States Marines on Guadalcanal and the young men who write about them. Here is the third book describing the fighting on that island, and it does not suffer by that fact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, a unit of the C.I.O., was certified by the National Labor Relations Board today as the exclusive bargaining agent for 24,387 production and maintenance workers at the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation at Portland, Me.

MRS. STUYVESANT WAINWRIGHT, Mrs. Beverly Chew Smith and Mrs. Edwin H. Armstrong are members of the Motor Transport Division of the American Women's Voluntary Services, which will give a gala all-star benefit the night of Feb. 21 at the Alvin Theatre.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Red Army has slammed the door on the Germans in the Caucasus by a lightning thrust to the Sea of Azov at Yeisk, a special Russian communique, recorded here by the Soviet monitor, announced tonight.

ONE of the most important railroad terminals in the nation is Union Station at Washington. A vital transportation nerve center, its load is increasing daily and the efficiency with which it is handled is an outstanding tribute to the skill of American railroad men.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- With deliberate absenteeism on the part of mine workers showing an increase, Britain's acute coal problem became worse during the four-week period up to Jan. 23, when the coal output was nearly 70,000 tons lower than that of the previous month, according to figures just given out by government officials.

Out on the high plains the snows are beginning to wear thin. On the ridges and south slopes brown buffalo grass shows through; and in the broad swales where the sun beats strongest there is the thick stubble of bluestem and wheat grass which will be greening in another six weeks. The uplands are pasture; the swales are hay land. And there are millions of acres of upland and swale.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- What seemed the nearest thing to a frank peace feeler to come from an official German source in more than two years was a sentence from an article in the weekly magazine Das Reich by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, which was broadcast to the world from Berlin this week.

Managers, trustees and shareholders of investment trusts that are too small to be operated profitably are growing heartily sick of them. Accordingly, a movement to combine "orphan trusts" for more efficient operation is making progress, both in corporation circles and in the councils of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ABERDEEN, Scotland, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, British Minister of Aircraft Production, said today that totalitarianism, even in defeat, might leave its imprint upon the world unless the United Nations planned a cooperative world economy of plenty before the war ended.

THIS is an official biography of America's oldest going concern among symphony orchestras. Mr. Erskine is the third official biographer in the orchestra's first hundred years, and because he is the latest, with the advantage of newly revealed sources of information, his is the completest.

A protest against "unseemly and discriminatory" treatment of Belgian seamen in American ports was forwarded last week to Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, by Omer B. Becu, American representative of the International Transport Workers Federation.

MAYBE you happened to notice in the papers the other day a comment by Colonel Le Roy P. Hunt of the United States Marines. Colonel Hunt led the first troops that landed on the beaches of Guadalcanal, and this interview with him, these months later, was on the nature of the fighting which took place there.

A daily saving of enough gasoline to fly 1,000 two-engined bombers from England to Berlin and return has resulted from the pleasure-driving ban that the Office of Price Administration imposed throughout the East Coast one month ago today, Russell H. Potter, acting district manager of the New York OPA office, declared last night.

A pianist-composer, the captain of a merchant ship, Wendell L. Willkie and a motion-picture studio are on the latest Honor Roll of Race Relations, announced yesterday by Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick of the New York Public Library.

IT is clear to even the least perceptive, by now, that America is a "have not" nation for the duration, lacking sufficient supplies of several key materials, and it is equally clear that losses of battles and territories have been responsible in large measure for our plight.

One of the duties of American colleges and universities is to keep alive the liberal arts and the cultural heritage of the past, Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the New York City branch of the American Association of University Women, in the Hotel Pierre.

DISTINGUISHED persons of the Allied Nations are expected at the formal opening of the new recreational room of the Maple Leaf Club for service men of the United Nations at 601 Fifth Avenue on the afternoon of Feb. 15.

BLACKMAIL and murder form a familiar sequence and a natural one, for no one likes to be blackmailed, nor does any one like to admit that he is being blackmailed lest some dereliction of his own be exposed. So it is in the case with which this story deals.

IN reviewing the first great attempt to prove that Shakespeare could not and did not write his own plays, W.J. Rolfe maintained for a time an air of respectful courtesy worthy of Bacon and the Bard of Avon, not to mention sedate Victorian scholarship; but he finally broke down with an anecdote of an American boy in Paris who felt himself outraged by the opinions of his Gallic playmates.

Two persons were beaten and shot, two others were beaten and a fifth was attacked with a pistol and an axe by a Brooklyn patrolman who ran amok early yesterday while on a tour of duty in the South Brooklyn section of the borough.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 6 -- The provisional French regime here has moved decisively during the past week to smooth out the political situation in North Africa and hush criticism of itself as a reactionary instrument tending toward fascism in its attitude toward civil liberties.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 6 -- The immediate political effects of the Casablanca conference of Generals Henri Honore Giraud and Charles de Gaulle already are visible in North Africa.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 -- After deliberating for thirteen hours, a jury of nine women and three men brought in a verdict today acquitting Errol Flynn, the film actor, of three counts of statutory rape which the State alleged he had committed against two 'teen-age girls.

Every one is familiar with Galax leaves in combination with violets, under a dish of strawberries and in other arrangements. Some florists of imagination have used it with fruits and vegetables with unexpectedly stunning effects. However, two uses of Galax have up to now been almost completely overlooked.

An amendment to the National Labor Relations Act empowering the NLRB to review the reasonableness of union admission requirements is urged by Professor Ralph A. Newman of the St. John's University School of Law, and a trial examiner for the board, in the current issue of the Columbia Law Review.

ALL through the preliminary tour of this play I kept hearing, from people who had met him, about Ludwig Fulda. He had lectured in America in 1906 and again in 1913 and covered, evidently, the same ground which his play was to traverse, after his death, thirty years later.

THIS book is recommended reading for New Yorkers. Mr. Rodgers writes from five years' experience as a member of the City Planning Commission. How many of us know just what the Planning Commission's functions are?

ABANDONING the forum for the factory, a number of clubwomen are now taking their places on assembly lines, in the laboratories and in offices of war plants. Most of them are married, with households to manage for husbands and growing children, and the financial reward was not their chief reason for joining up.

Beau Jack, who was Sidney Walker in his caddie days before he became world lightweight boxing champion, and Fritzie Zivic, hardy Pittsburgh ring veteran who formerly held the world welterweight title, will meet again if Promoter Mike Jacobs has his way.

RICHARD CROCKER of Tammany Hall is a strange person, it might seem, for two serious-minded historians to quote appreciatively, yet Thomas C. Cochran and William Miller have unearthed a saying by the cynical sachem which well sets forth the essence of their interesting and excellent book.

For the forthcoming city-wide Red Cross War Fund drive nearly 100,000 women are being mobilized into what is described as "the largest corps of its kind ever mustered in New York City for humanitarian purposes," according to Red Cross officials.

The meeting at Casablanca to which the Prime Minister of Great Britain and the President flew with their staffs again drives home the enormous potentialities of the airplane. Out of the war a type of cargo and passenger plane is evolving which will far surpass in range and carrying capacity the craft in which the Prime Minister and the President winged across land and sea.

THE unostentatious store with the plain lettering on the window, "Actors Thrift Shop," at 164 West Forty-eighth Street, is a year old -- and doing a good business. One principle has guided the venture: the proceeds are used to purchase wardrobes for unemployed actors when they go job-hunting in their profession.

MOST amateur gardeners think first of the flower or the vegetable they plan to raise. They should instead think of the soil in which they expect to grow their plants, for here may lie the difference between success and failure.

RUBBER DIRECTOR JEFFERS sees no reason why the boys should come home to a country where business is "flat as a flounder" and last week the National Retail Dry Goods Association submitted a program on behalf of small retailers to the Senate Small Business Committee calling for an independent office of civilian supply.
INFORMATION came from Rio de Janeiro last week that Brazil would release five commemoratives within a few months and in July a regular postage series to replace the group currently in use.

THE leg man is a low form of life. He gathers facts on police news but seldom writes them. He telephones them to a rewrite man and the rewrite man organizes them into the size and form decreed by the city editor.

MAP reading and coding are explainably attractive volunteer courses -- they are mysterious enough to sound important. But why 200 women will travel from ten blocks to twenty miles to attend classes dealing in base plugs, flatirons, window sashes and kitchen sinks deserves some explanation.

A precedent was established by Justice Charles Marks in the Third District Court of Manhattan last week when he awarded a judgment of $466.50 to Gertrud Strauss, 65-41 Saunders Street, Forest Hills, L.I., against the United States Lines as a refund for a passage from Hamburg.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations pledged its support today to the New York Transport Workers Union in its campaign for "a living wage" for the 32,000 employes on New York City's city-owned transit system and called upon Mayor La Guardia to submit the dispute "to advisory arbitration by an impartial tribunal to be designated by the Mayor."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- The railroads completed testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission today in opposition to a proposal to reduce freight rates and passenger fares.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- Holding that a boom market would be "highly undesirable," the staff of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has drawn up a comprehensive plan, involving concerted and drastic action by the Congress and several Federal agencies, to ward off such an eventuality.
WITHOUT boast but with pardonable pride the Writers War Board has issued a report on its activities and accomplishments since Dec. 9, 1941. It is an impressive score sheet.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- Mill interests and cash houses bought wheat futures off and on during today's session on the Board of Trade and gave the market a firm undertone, but the support was not sufficient to maintain the full advance and the finish was at a gain of 1/8 cent.
LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- A special Russian communique recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The cotton futures market weakened yesterday as reports of Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's recommendation that cotton farmers capitalize to the fullest extent their acreage allotment for cotton were confirmed. Liquidation induced by this news left the market with final net losses of 5 to 10 points and at the lowest prices in two weeks.

PANAMA CITY, ever the facilities of HP5G on 11.78 megacycles, is providing surcease for members of the hot stove league worried about baseball's future. Most Sunday afternoons it broadcasts games between teams in the Canal Zone and, though the announcer may be no Red Barber, it is not unwelcome to hear talk of Texas Leaguers and sacrifice flies.

One year after a CDVO Rehousing Section was organized by the New York City Welfare Department as a Disaster Squad, it was called upon for its first big test -- an apartment house fire at 552 Riverside Drive on Jan. 27. Five of the feminine volunteers were summoned, arriving at 1:16 A.M.

Now that Sister Kenny's method of treating infantile paralysis has been officially adopted by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, we hope that the Medical College of Virginia's plan for the creation in Richmond of an Institute of Physical Therapy will be realized.

IN the accumulating symposium that acquaints the campus of the college with the mysteries of the Orient there is a place for a volume dealing with those Indian princes, hundreds of them, who dwell in palaces that are purdah to the public and, decked with a priceless regalia, reign over the poverty around them, it is alleged, as pariahs of privilege, beyond the pale of polite or impolite progress. Clearly their case should be stated.

RECORDINGS of the latest radio programs are being dropped by parachute to American troops in isolated spots of the world, it was revealed last week by Major Irving Fogel, commanding officer in New York of the United States Army Special Services Division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Reflecting a large wartime demand for food and an increase of 22 per cent in prices, the gross income of American farmers for 1942 climbed to the record figure of $18,700,000,000, the Department of Agriculture said today.

The stringent automobile headlight dimout rules in force for the last five months were amended yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine "with the full approval of the Army" in the hope of reducing the heavy toll of traffic fatalities caused by inadequate light for both motorists and pedestrians.

Four Russian women who sail as seamen in the Soviet merchant marine visited the National Maritime Union headquarters near the Chelsea waterfront last week to encourage American "seawomen" in their campaign to win permission from the government to return to their maritime jobs.

SMOKE SCREENS -- The movements of United Nations' forces are being concealed by chemical smoke screens made from a chlorinated compound which is a popular non-inflammable dry-cleaning fluid. Less and less of this chlorinated compound -- perchlorethylene -- has been available for civilian use, because large quantities are needed to make smoke-screen chemicals for all the armed forces, and because its related compound -- trichlorethylene -- is used to clean metals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- About 20,000 workers will be needed in the new synthetic rubber industry when it is in full operation, but difficulty is being met in obtaining them, the War Manpower Commission announced today.

THE jury has disagreed, and Viola Ross will have to endure once more the ordeal of being tried for her life on the charge of having murdered her husband. But Richard Arnold, the one juror who has refused to join the others in a verdict of guilty, is determined that this shall not happen.

FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD Ann Jackman and her younger brother, Philip, got their first taste of life in the Hudson Bay country in "Adventure North." Now in this new story, hardened by a season's homebuilding under primitive conditions, they find more adventure during their first frozen Winter in the fur country.

AUSTRALIA'S Acting Trade Commissioner in New York, J.U. Garside, has received the 1-penny and 1 3/2p stamps on which a portrait of Britain's Queen Elizabeth replaces that of King George VI. The 1p, in a brownish shade of plum, is decorated at the top with kurrajong leaves and flowers.

ABOARD A NEW UNITED STATES BATTLESHIP AT SEA, Jan. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Shorn of her paint and polish, rusted and rugged, one of the mightiest of United States battleships pushed through surging seas of the North Atlantic today in battle practice before joining the Fleet.

Some 4,000 members of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association are scheduled to catechize local and Washington OPA authorities as well as New York City Health and Market officials here today on the obscurities of food rationing.

Oils, mail orders and low-priced motor shares were strong and steels and whiskies were weak on an irregular New York Stock Exchange market yesterday. The close was mixed and volume was 500,250 shares, against 612,010 on the previous Saturday.

DESIGNED as a patriotic wartime party, the forty-first annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club will be held Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. A patriotic entertainment and pageant of the United Nations will be a dramatic feature of the event, net proceeds from which will advance the projects of the club's war service committee.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Dispatches from the front and Axis sources indicated tonight that the Allied offensive to throw the Axis out of Africa was shaping up as a nutcracker push by the British from both ends of the Tunisian battle line, with American forces holding the center.

QUEBEC -- The historic Cote de Beaupre region, some twenty miles from Quebec, will be the scene of activities for ski experts in the district next Sunday, when senior and junior cross-country ski races are run off, for the Beaupre Coast championships.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Gunners of the Flying Fortresses that made heavy daylight bombing attacks over Northwestern Germany on Thursday shot down twenty-five Nazi fighters, headquarters here of the United States Army Air Forces reported today after a final check-up.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Brazil joined the United Nations today as a full partner against the Axis in a move that places this country at war against Japan as well as Germany and Italy.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Russian strategy, which Marshal Timoshenko calls "blitz-grinding," finally is beginning to pay big dividends. Essentially it is the simple theory that in order to beat Hitler the destruction of his production capacity is not enough; the primary necessity is to kill Germans.

The Times of London and The Lancet report the case of a soldier who was court-martialed for having fired a rifle at a corporal. In defense the man pleaded that he had been injured in the head before the shooting and could remember nothing. Because there were no witnesses, the court accepted expert testimony, based on a brain-wave record that was abnormal.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Studded with stars from the New York City area, Niagara's slick squad attained an amazing 56-to-48 victory tonight and toppled highly-rated New York University from intercollegiate basketball's unbeaten ranks.

BEATRICE KEAN SEYMOUR is a writer whose work has always been distinguished by integrity. She has never followed fashion trends, but, apparently, has been guided by an inner compulsion forcing her along the harder road of individuality.

THE Jade Plant is well known to fanciers of house plants as one of the most satisfactory of the many succulents that will thrive in sunny window. It is also extremely popular for use in dish-gardens. Very few home gardeners, however, have ever had the good fortune to bring this plant to the blooming stage.

PASADENA, Calif. SNATCHING the cloak of heroics off the shoulders of mythology and fable, Emil Ludwig, famed historian of this day, takes issue with Homer, the even more celebrated historian of the past.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 6 -- Dartmouth's undefeated hockey team moved another step toward its second Pentagonal League title with a thrilling 7-4 victory over powerful Harvard in the Davis Rink tonight. It was the Green's twenty-ninth straight triumph.

The nature of this total and global war brings it about that while the United Nations are able to hail gratifying victories on some fronts, there are stalemates and touch-and-go battles on others, and there are also cries of distress and urgent appeals for help from some of our allies exposed to an immediate menace.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 6 (U.P.) -- Brazilian police accused a former police official and a lawyer today of having received "millions of cruzeiros to free German spies" and facilitate their escape to Uruguay and Argentina.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- How to mobilize a 7,500,000-man Army, simultaneously find the men to operate a two-ocean Navy and at the same time obtain the men and women necessary to keep all essential civilian war activities going is a problem which the country's manpower mobilization agencies have been facing for many months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The War Production Board issued a controlled materials plan regulation today to govern sales of aluminum, copper and steel by warehouses and distributors. The new controls become effective for copper on Feb. 15 and for aluminum and steel on March 31.
The International League, only minor circuit to play its full schedule during the 1918 war year, yesterday adopted a 154- game program at its annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

Defeats suffered by Adolf Hitler's legions on the frozen steppes of Southern Russia increased in magnitude last week. Vast reaches of Russian land, bought with hundreds of thousands of German lives in the Summer and Fall campaigns, were being blasted from the Wehrmacht's grasp.

THIS book is perhaps the most important effort thus far on the part of North Americans in the rather testy business of appealing to and understanding the Latin-American temperament. There are many reasons for this -- negative as well as positive. One of the most obvious positive ones is that it shows the Latins that we are concretely interested in their culture.

City College will begin the second half of its ninety-sixth academic year tomorrow with a drop of only 10 per cent in the day session, despite the anticipated large decrease in enrollment in colleges all over the country as a result of the drafting of 18-year-olds and the calling up of students in the Enlisted Reserve Corps, it was announced yesterday by President Harry N. Wright.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 6 -- Following up its surprising victory of last week over Dartmouth's defending champions, Princeton defeated Columbia, 39 to 25, tonight to remain unbeaten in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League.

HERE are two episodes in the career of young Dr. Kildare, miracle worker extraordinary and favorite pupil of Dr. Gillespie. Kildare is only an interne, nominally subject to the rules of the hospital to which he is attached, but those rules mean nothing to him when he considers it expedient to disobey them.

LONDON, JAN. [DELAYED]. THE other day we had a date with an anonymity, an old friend just back from the North African battlefront. He is anonymous on account of being the officer commanding Film and Photographic Unit, Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- An interdepartmental committee of five members to serve as an advisory and coordinating agency in all matters pertaining to the investigation and disposition of complaints of subversive activity on the part of employes of the executive branch of the government was established within the Department of Justice by President Roosevelt today by an executive order.

NOT content with reconstructing in their pristine glory many of the lovely old houses, colonial Williamsburg is now intent upon resurrecting from yellowed diaries, letters and records the memories of the long-dead citizens who lived in them, and of preserving not only their portraits but their manners and mores in a series of official publications.

Washington and Lincoln, whose birthdays are to be celebrated this month, and the heroes of the present war exemplify the true strength of democracy, which will insure its ultimate victory over fascism, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday. Boy Scout Sabbath, marking the thirty-third anniversary of the scouting movement, was observed in various synagogues.

ADOLF BUSCH is a violinist who has little use for the excesses of hero worship that fall to the lot of the virtuoso. A solo violinist of no mean accomplishments, he would probably prefer to devote most of his time to playing in ensemble -- whether in chamber music of small or large units or in Orchestral groups.

IF United Nations heroes of the present war were all given their due, this book would be of encyclopedic proportions. Anything less than their due must necessarily be disappointing, so that one must not look for anything approaching completeness in Mr. Wells's short record of nearly 200 valorous soldiers, sailors and civilians.

After three days of negotiations an agreement on maintenance pay for seamen in the Norwegian manning pool was reached here Friday night by representatives of the Norwegian Seamen's Association, an affiliate of the International Transport Workers Federation, with the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission in this city.

CITATIONS for America's second army -- the one in overalls -- are pouring into Washington these days along with those of the nation's fighting men. The accomplishments they relate are not as spectacular as the exploits of warriors like the Kellys, Powerses and Doolittles.

About sixty members of the New York City staff of John J. Bennett Jr., when he was State Attorney General, gave a testimonial luncheon to him yesterday at the Pearl Street Restaurant, near Broadway. John F.X. McGohey, who was Mr. Bennett's first assistant, presented a silver service set and a pair of silver candelabra to the former chief of the State Law Department as the gift of his staff.

RUSSELL PATTERSON'S second production at the Riobamba will open this Thursday, with Benny Fields as the star. The DiGatanos -- Adam and Jane -- will do the dancing, and Nat Brandywynne and Chavez's rhumba band will supply the music.

A German who admitted that Henrich Heinck, executed Nazi saboteur, had lived in his home for two years prior to Heinck's return to Germany, was one of twenty-four enemy aliens arrested during the week end, E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced yesterday.

ALTHOUGH Friday is Lincoln's Birthday and offers a holiday to banks, schools and a few offices, it will not be generally observed as in years past. Time was when both Lincoln's Birthday and Washington's were prime excuses for the short, gay trip on cruise ship, de luxe train or via motor car.

WHEN Adolf Hitler became Chancellor of Germany ten years ago philatelists little dreamed what profound changes his rise to power portended in their special world. During the decade about 20,000 major and minor varieties of stamps, have been issued, and it is estimated that about half of them were due to events arising from the efforts of Hitler, Mussolini and Japan to create "new orders."

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 -- With 675 dogs on the benches, six more than a year ago, the Maryland Kennel Club started the 1943 bench-show season auspiciously this afternoon in the spacious main hall of the Fifth Regiment Armory.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Navy communique 273:

The likelihood that a broad consumer rationing program is now in the cards and may be launched before the end of Summer is receiving increasing attention from retailers. Rumors regarding the scope of possible action, which may be hastened by expanding lend-lease needs and manpower pressures, were more numerous last week and comment in well-informed quarters was that OPA is busy on numerous ration plans in preparation for any eventualities which may develop.

THREE weeks before this country was plunged into war Lincoln's eloquent letter to General Hooker, placing him in command of the Army of the Potomac, was being sold with spectacular success in Philadelphia.

WE have here both a history of America and a tract for the times. Over the course of fifteen years Charles and Mary Beard have told the story of the American people in three massive volumes under the title "The Rise of American Civilization."

IT has been a long time since this column has made any reference to Tolstoy's "War and Peace." It ventures to do so again, having come upon a recent issue (Dec. 19) of The Times Literary Supplement (London) which devotes a long article and an editorial, both of them excellent, to that greatest of all novels.

Once the Japanese have been driven out of Kiska and Attu in the Aleutian Islands, Alaska may become the most effective base for the bombing of Japan, Thomas Riggs, former Governor of Alaska and Commissioner of the International Boundary Commission, yesterday told 1,000 members of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

THIS book is, as the superscription on the jacket describes it, simply a life of the poet Yeats, a work outlining the main facts of his life, his activities, his friendships. It is written in a plain, straightforward manner, without much discussion of the poetry or much effort at interpreting it.

The first actual test of a postwar delivery plan for major consumer items will get under way this week in Hartford when the Hartford Electric Lighting Company starts a campaign for such a program. For the last month the utility has been educating dealers in the program, and as word of the plan has spread it has attracted considerable interest among both business men and the public.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- Arsenal gained the championship of the English Football League's southern section today by blanking Crystal Palace, 9 -- 0. The Gunners also won last year when the tourney was confined to London and district teams. Arsenal now will compete for the league cup.

Before his appointment as commander of the United States Army Air Forces in the Middle East -- the position he now vacates to take charge of all American troops in that theatre -- General Brereton had seen fighting in the Philippines, Java and India.

ODD, how history manages things. Who would have thought in the dim primordial past of five years ago that one day Donald Duck would be giving the retort perfect to Herr Doktor Goebbels? Not Mr. D. and hardly, one suspects, Dr. Goebbels; and least of all, Walt Disney, who has a paternal interest in "the duck" and a more vehement interest in the Nazi mouthpiece.

Paint, always a panacea for the ills a house is heir to, is a vital factor in the business of conservation. A flawless film of paint would probably protect a piece of wood against moisture forever, and moisture is the most common cause of deterioration of wood.

A GREAT jubilation has lately overcome "That Brewster Boy" and the radio agencies responsible for him. In two years Joey Brewster, the Henry Aldrich of CBS, has leaped to the top of the heap of radio shows emanating from Chicago.

Retail trade was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were active, with a brisk demand reported for dresses, coats, suits and furs.
Baseball's current off-season, one of the most eventful the game has known in many Winters, will rush to its climax this week with the clans from all sections converging on New York.

Scores of war production programs require the same vital and scarce materials. All the programs are essential, but there are not enough materials to go around. To the directors of each program, theirs is the most pressing need; the result is that irresistible forces are encountering immovable bodies.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Dump a general in the drink, storm toss him for six nights and five days, starve him and up he comes smiling with sound recommendations for the safety and comfort of others who are similarly marooned.
THE average player, when he is declarer, often overlooks opportunities to trade one trick for two by giving up a trick "unnecessarily."

J.B. PRIESTLEY, who is a master craftsman at spinning a yarn, has turned his talents to writing a tale of espionage. But "Blackout in Gretley" is more than a spy-hunting story. It is Priestley's ardent declaration of the things that England is fighting for.

The destruction last week of what remained of the German Army at Stalingrad wrote the end to a story that will live for generations. For savage attack and grim resistance there has been no such siege in this great war, not even at Leningrad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Clark of Idaho, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Subcommittee investigating the ban on phonograph recordings and radio transcriptions by the American Federation of Musicians indicated today that hearings would be resumed unless a settlement offer was made soon by James C. Petrillo, president of the union.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Public relations officials at the Greenville Army air base stated today that fourteen men were killed when two Army medium bombers crashed on a farm twelve miles south of Newberry, S.C., yesterday afternoon.

IT wasn't that Thursty was really mean or spiteful, but like a good many of us, especially those glorying in the tightknit ties of the gang age, he had an instinctive distrust of any one who was "different." And certainly Ernst, the German refugee who entered the second form at the beginning of the Fall, was that.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Feb. 7 -- In the biggest single day's air battle to date in the Southwest Pacific, twenty-six Japanese planes were destroyed and fifteen damaged over Wau, New Guinea, yesterday.

A drive by the Third Naval District to enlist 1,200 women in the Navy and Coast Guard auxiliaries by March 1 will be opened on Waves and Spars Day tomorrow in connection with the commissioning of the new Women's Reserve Naval Training School on the Bronx campus of Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Losses, "surface and air," thus far suffered by the United States and Japanese forces in actions of recent days in the Solomon Islands area have been "moderate," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today at a press conference.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia Sunday, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

A sixty-family apartment house at 19 to 25 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to the Essbee Company through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization. The property is known as Kensico Gardens and is assessed at $361,600.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 7 -- Mexico's oil industry has been hard hit by the war, which has greatly curtailed exports, Efrain Buenrostro, general manager of Pemex (Petroleos Mexicanos), the government controlled company now holding the oil monopoly in this country, told the writer yesterday.

The National Conference has asked for an immediate release of "The Patriots" for production throughout the country. It is expected permission will be given by Sergeant Sidney Kingsley, author, and the Playwrights' Company and Rowland Stebbins, producers, at a meeting to be held this week.

IN SOUTHERN INDIA, Feb. 1 (Delayed) -- There is one spot in Southern India where the American flag flies. But it is an important spot, for here airplanes are made as well as repaired under American supervision. This is the famed aircraft company that has been taken all the way across China, patiently set up in one place after another, only to be bombed or occupied by the Japanese.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 7 -- Germany and Japan must be made partners with the United Nations in post-war reconstruction and relief plans or there will be another conflict, Charles P. Taft, assistant national director of defense, health and welfare services, said today in an address at the first mid-year commencement of Swarthmore College.

Shortage of manpower is beginning to pinch the banking industry. Many banks have reached the point where they are giving serious consideration to the possibilities of shortening banking hours and of eliminating many extra services provided for their customers.

Nathan Milstein afforded his audience many examples of masterly violin playing at his recital last night in Town Hall. His program was of a range and quality to necessitate this. It included the unaccompanied Partita in E major o Bach and three of the unaccompanied Caprices of Paganini.

Babe Ruth celebrated his forty-ninth birthday yesterday by lending a hand to the war effort. The Babe, nowhere near the 80 years, achieved recently by another great baseball figure, Connie Mack, is nevertheless too old for the armed forces, but he is doing what he can.

Total shipments of all types of hosiery during December, amounting to 12,441,207 dozen pairs, showed a gain of 503,694, or 4.2 per cent, over the like month in 1941, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Simple "duration" clothes have brought about an increased desire among American women for costume jewelry which manufacturers are striving hard to satisfy. Priorities brought perplexities, but the designers have rallied valiantly and have evolved various ingenious creations from non-priority materials.

Another crowded calendar is in store for college basketball this week. For a starter, tonight's schedule offers a double-header at Madison Square Garden and an important road game for N.Y.U. The twin bill will send L.I.U. against Duquesne and St. John's against St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, while the Violets will attempt to regain their winning ways at Syracuse.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Red Hamill, Chicago left winger who reports tomorrow in Toronto for his military service medical examination, was a participant in the lustiest fight Chicago Stadium hockey spectators have witnessed this season as the Black Hawks routed the New York Rangers, 8 -- 4, in a National League game tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- After many months of short rations, France will face famine in June and July. The peasant will be able to draw on his stores though they are growing smaller each season. The manual worker will still be able to eat, if his extra food coupons are honored, but those not engaged in productive occupation -- productive for Germany as well as for France -- will know starvation.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 7 -- The results of the Casablanca conference have been felt on the battlelines during the past week. The reorganization that followed the meeting is believed by authorities to have strengthened the defensive organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- John A. Lyons, State Commissioner of Correction, said today that there were no present plans for the opening of Green Haven Prison, new $8,000,000 State institution in Dutchess County, at any time in the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The House will consider this week the Smith bill to put a curb on so-called "government-by-directive" and a proposal to renew the life of the Dies Committee on Un-American Activities for another two years.

The Institute of International Education, 2 West Forty-fifth Street, announced yesterday the award of seventeen grants for research at universities and libraries in Latin America this year. The institute, of which Dr. Stephen Duggan is director, said the appointments were made on the recommendation of a prominent group of American educators interested in the other American republics.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 7 -- Just a week from the day that the Turkish Premier, with President Ismet Inonu and other high Turkish statesmen and staff chiefs, met British Prime Minister Churchill and his mission at the Yenice rendezvous, Shukru Saracoglu went to the Soviet Embassy last night as guest of honor of the Soviet Ambassador, Sergei A. Vinogradoff, at a large formal dinner attended by the United States and British Ambassadors.

RUFUS W. HOOKER, M.D., comes from Memphis, Tenn. He is a cheerful, practical, confident sort of person in his early sixties. He has practiced his profession of medicine successfully in Mexico, Memphis and on the high seas of much of the world. Today he achieves a new and probably unique distinction. His medical memoirs are published, and they are definitely something new and different in doctor books!

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 7 (AP) -- British troops have dug in near the mountain of Djebel Mansour, twenty miles southwest of Pont du Fahs, and checked a German advance that drove them from the height after they had captured it in a stiff fight last Wednesday.
Only three new films are slated for Broadway premieres this week.

The latest shake-up in the Italian Cabinet is not one of the periodic "changes of the guard" by which Mussolini kept the ambitious hierarchs of the Fascist party running up and down stairs, and so prevented any from standing at the top long enough to usurp his own power.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Will the Administration assume responsibility in time to avert a strike of 450,000 bituminous miners on April 1?

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- There is much searching among market observers for an answer to the question why the stock markets remain so extremely lethargic at a time when the war news grows better and better. One terse comment is that what goes up must come down -- the markets having experienced a prolonged rise, are now descending to a level more in keeping with actualities.

The report from London last week that Germany was estimated to have lost 4,000,000 men, killed, captured or permanently crippled, since the war began, is another indication that the Reich is approaching months comparable in crisis to those of 1918.

As part of a nation-wide celebration of Boy Scouts Sunday the ninth annual religious observance of the day was held yesterday afternoon by 4,000 Catholic Scouts, representing every section of the Archdiocese of New York, in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Plans for a nurses' recruiting project by the American Legion Auxiliary to speed up the training of more women as nurses, with scholarship awards amounting to $50,000, were announced here today by Mrs. Alfred J. Mathebat of Alameda,Calif., president of the auxiliary.

Arthur Krock's quotation from the New Testament, in criticism of the President's most recent appointments, calls to mind a still more applicable quotation to be found in the Koran: "A ruler who appoints any man to office when there is in his dominions another man better qualified for it sins against God and against the State."

Thousands of persons wise in the ways of the city flocked yesterday to the lower East Side, normally crowded with Sunday bargain hunters, eager to buy shoes of every description before sales were frozen.

There is one thing about the campaign in the Solomons that should not be overlooked or underestimated. Whatever the outcome of the present battle, it has already constituted a strategic success in that it bought us time and thus enabled us to hold India and a point from which to strike back at Japan.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The muscular arms of John Koruda, who handles beef carcasses in a Jersey City meat packing plant, helped bridge a four-foot space between two windows here today to rescue four persons trapped in blazing rooms on the third floor of a boarding house at 266 Montgomery Street.

The Rovers tasted defeat at the hands of the Coast Guard Cutters twice at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The New Yorkers dropped a 4-2 decision in the afternoon and bowed by 5 -- 4 before 8,000 fans at night. Both contests featured Eastern Amateur Hockey League twin bills.

It is a mistake to think that Pilate sat in judgment on Jesus, for the truth is, as demonstrated by Christ's influence throughout the centuries, that it was Jesus who sat in judgment on Pilate, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon in the Riverside Church.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- There was little change last week in the provision markets, supplies of hogs continuing to run far below the expectations of the trade and the government, while the demand continued active. Supplies are said to be inadequate for domestic needs after taking care of government and lend-lease requirements.

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY in Tunisia, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Sergeant Dan L. Mullis, a 21-year-old Georgian, told today of his capture by Germans who forced him to drive an American truck in a German advance through the Ousselat Valley and of his subsequent escape with other prisoners when they were machine-gunned by French forces who failed to recognize them.

Appointment of area committees, composed of representatives of management and labor, to assist and advise the regional office of the War Manpower Commission and its area directors on all manpower problems affecting the respective areas, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the WMC.

The thirteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, starting Feb. 15, will see the Winter's first performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere." It also marks the return of Gladys Swarthout, who will appear in the title role of Bizet's "Carmen."

Under usual conditions it is clearly not sound practice for Congress to attach irrelevant riders to bills that the President is virtually forced to sign. For the effect of such a practice is to abridge, if not to nullify, the President's veto power. To that extent it by-passes the intent of the Constitution.

The Piedmont Baseball League yesterday gave up hopes of operating with eight clubs this year and settled for six, with Roanoke replacing Greensboro. Both Charlotte and Winston-Salem retained their franchises, but suspended operations for the duration.

Dusolina Giannini, long known here as one of the Metropolitan Opera's fine voices, was the feature of the concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, singing Schumann's Lenau Lieder, Opus 90. The rest of the concert, continuing the chamber music cycles of Haydn and Schumann, was given by the Roth Quartet, including Feri Roth and Samuel Siegel, violins; Julius Shaier, viola, and Oliver Edel, cello.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Employes of the Carbon Limestone Company of Hillsville, Pa., won a wage increase in excess of the "Little Steel" formula from the War Labor Board yesterday. They are represented by a unit of the United Mine Workers.

With almost incredible speed and striking power, the Russian armies continue to smash into and through the German lines. There is promise that the German disaster at Stalingrad will be repeated on an even larger scale, and on several stages at once, in the Caucasus and in the whole Donets basin.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Roosevelt urged today that the Boy Scout movement be "maintained at its full strength and effectiveness as a practical contribution to the war effort."

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Louis Weitzenkorn, 49 years old, author of "Five Star Final" and other plays, and a former newspaper man, was found dead of burns and suffocation today in the kitchen of his apartment.

Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that "pressure groups" were seeking, by the use of misleading statistics, to create in the public mind the impression of widespread and growing juvenile delinquency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard issued an order today which, he explained, was designed to reserve about 38 per cent of the expected production of cheese for military, lend-lease and other war requirements.

The American Labor Conference on International Affairs, including representatives of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the railway brotherhoods, has been formed to study problem of the conduct of the war and the future peace from the point of view of organized labor, William Green, president of the A.F. of L., announced yesterday.

City College will have complete educational responsibility for the 500 soldier-students whom the Army will send to study at the college's School of Technology about April 1, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, revealed yesterday.

The object of the Ruml plan is to gather taxes before men have spent the money. To require quarterly income tax returns means an enormous addition to the labor spent on them -- four times as much as at present -- by individuals or their agents and by the government.

New Yorkers will have to get used to soiled shirts next month unless the 40 per cent reduction in fuel oil rations for industrial use is rescinded for the laundries, Bert T. Geltz, president of the Family Laundry Owners Association, declared yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 7 -- Striking in the dark of night, combat engineers attached to the United States armored forces have been blowing up bridges in enemy territory that are vital to communications and the transfer of supplies from Col. Gen. Dietloll von Arnims northern enemy forces to those of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel.

In THE TIMES of Jan. 31 there was a letter revealing that Benjamin Franklin was said to have received the first air-mail letter. Being an admirer of Franklin, I would like to point out another interesting incident which took place at that time.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 7 -- Lieut. Comdr. David White of Detroit, submarine commander back from a short excursion into Japanese waters, during which his submarine sank two enemy cargo ships and hit two others, but did not wait to see them sink, said today, "The Pacific used to be a pretty big ocean to us, but now it's like our own back yard."

An appeal for 1,000 women volunteers needed immediately to serve in the aircraft warning service was issued yesterday by the New York Air Defense Wing of the First Fighter Command. It was explained that the War Department has decided to move Waacs from this type of work in areas where adequate volunteer personnel is believed available.

From present indications advertising volume this year will be charted by the availability of media rather than by the budgets of advertisers, according to agency executives. Prior to the limitations on paper output a sellers market in advertising had not been seriously expected but now it has developed in magazines and will eventually extend to other media.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Smarting from the previous night's 8-3 setback, the Bruins turned savagely on the Canadiens and protected their National Hockey League lead by scoring a 7-1 victory tonight before a crowd of 10,000 at the Boston Garden.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 -- "Country Lawyer," Bellamy Partridge's biography of his father, Samuel Seldon Partridge, the film rights to which Warner Brothers acquired from Paramount two years ago, will be a starring vehicle for Walter Huston, according to a studio announcement.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- A special Soviet communique announced tonight that the entire southern bank of the Don had been cleared of German resistance and implied that only the 1,400-foot river stood between the victorious Red Army and Rostov as artillery dueled across the stream in the opening of a new battle for the city.

A draft of labor for war industries and farms similar to the draft for the armed forces, and the keeping of civilian service records for each individual civilian similar to the service records kept in the armed services were advocated last night by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, World War ace, in an address before the annual dinner of the Baseball Writers Association at the Commodore Hotel.

Fitting tribute has been paid by Secretary Knox to one of the branches of the naval air service which has received comparatively little recognition. This is the service of the patrol wings, the airmen who fly, for the most part, the big Consolidated PBY boats, night and day, over stormy waters in both Atlantic and Pacific.

Business and professional groups of the special gifts committee of the Archbishop's committee of the laity for the 1943 Catholic Charities Appeal were set up yesterday by John A. Coleman, executive chairman. Alfred E. Smith is chairman of the committee.

Elsbeth Ball, contralto, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, for which she had arranged a program containing operatic arias by Purcell, Handel, Meyerbeer and Massenet and songs in German, French, Italian and English.

The return to power of Edward J. Flynn as political leader of the Bronx was apparently assured last night with the announcement by City Councilman Louis Cohen, secretary of the Bronx County Democratic executive committee, that Representative Charles E. Buckley would resign today as leader of the Eighth Assembly District to permit the election of Mr. Flynn to succeed him.

BEEKMAN, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Green Haven Prison, which was completed in the Fall of 1941 at a cost of $8,000,000 and was to have been opened last July to receive an overflow of prisoners from Sing Sing, has never been occupied and is now in the hands of a crew of twenty-one maintenance men.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- For the first time since the war started the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Kingsley Wood, in the course of last week's debate in Parliament on finance, made what the City considers the most comprehensive, understanding and sympathetic statement on the country's economic and financial problems.

With the transfer of the National Consumers League headquarters office from New York to Cleveland came the announcement yesterday that Miss Elizabeth S. Magee was appointed general secretary of the league.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The text of the statement issued today by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, announcing the rationing of shoes, follows:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has asked the cooperation of Governor Herbert R. O'Conor of Maryland, chairman of the Conference of State Governments, in furthering State planning programs during the war emergency and subsequent readjustment period, the Governor announced tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7 -- Calling industrial accidents the "silent saboteur" of the war effort, William A. Irvin, chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, arrived here today to promote a program aimed at reducing such casualties through education.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Feb. 7 -- With perfection the order of the day, Toni Matt, former national combined downhill and slalom champion, won the famed Gibson Trophy slalom ski race on Cranmore Mountain today.

Democracy's debt to Thomas Jefferson is the theme of the essay competition that the Board of Education, the Catholic school systems and private schools, in cooperation with THE NEW YORK TIMES, are launching in city secondary and seventh and eighth year elementary schools today.

A stricter sense of trusteeship, if America is to be saved from the perils of financial inflation and moral deflation, was demanded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The population of France is more unified than ever by hatred of the Germans, according to a letter smuggled out of France that reached here recently. The first part of the letter, dated in September, was written from the occupied zone; the second, dated a month later, was written from the then unoccupied zone.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Shoe rationing for the American people at the rate of three pairs a year went into effect at 3 P.M. today. Advance warning was purposely withheld to prevent "hoarding," according to the announcement issued at the White House by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had asked John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, to prepare a comprehensive summary and statement of wages paid to the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit system, in order to offset misrepresentations and to inform the public of the true situation.

Winston Churchill, puffing his inevitable cigar, is back in London. Axis leaders will hardly breathe more easily because of his safe return. Every flight the Prime Minister has made to other lands has had the effect of a sudden and unexpected attack against the enemy.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Ab Jenkins's Mormon Meteor III is going to a museum, but Salt Lake City's racing Mayor still has hopes of being able to drive the huge automobile to more world speed records.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 7 -- Robert Murphy and Harold Macmillan, American and British Ministers in North Africa, jointly backed the recent actions of General Henri Honore Giraud's regime as moves in "the right direction" and declared that the Allies were eager to create "a healthy political atmosphere."

A close study of corporation reports for 1942 is being made by the Controllers Institute of America to observe to what extent controllers are being required to attach their names to the financial statements, Arthur R. Tucker, managing director, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- A survey by mortgage experts has indicated that 15 per cent of outstanding loans will be retired in full this year, more than in any other year of the nation's history, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America announced today.

Red Cross booths will be set up in the lobbies of ten motion-picture theatres in the metropolitan area today with Red Cross attendants on hand to make blood donor appointments for patrons and employes, it was announced yesterday.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 110.3 to 110.5. Changes in the prices of agricultural commodities were almost entirely responsible for the 0.2 per cent rise. Advances in the prices of oranges, corn, tobacco, and potatoes more than offset declines in eggs, apples, wheat, and lambs, resulting in a 0.5 per cent rise in the farm products index.
The Rome radio said last night that Count Ciano, son-in-law of Premier Mussolini, had been appointed Ambassador to the Vatican, according to an Italian broadcast recorded in London by Reuter.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 -- The beautiful fawn Afghan hound, Champion Rudiki of Prides Hill, owned by Mrs. Marion Foster-Florsheim of New York City and handled in the ring by Mrs. Thomas E. Gately, this evening was awarded the title of best dog in the thirtieth annual show of the Maryland Kennel Club in the Fifth Regiment Armory.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., distributor of drugs, wines and liquors, had a consolidated net profit of $2,172,099 for the six months ended with December, the first half of its fiscal year, after interest and $4,905,721 provision for Federal taxes, before applying $93,285 post-war credit, according to unaudited figures issued yesterday by W.J. Murray Jr., president.

Japanese miners afflicted with tuberculosis continue to work, apparently without being required to undergo treatment, until the advanced stage of the disease causes their deaths, it was indicated yesterday in a Tokyo broadcast directed to Japanese areas.

Arnaldo Estrella, Brazilian pianist, who has come here as the winner of the Columbia Concerts Award, made his North American debut yesterday afternoon before a large and enthusiastic audience at Carnegie Hall, where he was soloist with the Philharmonic Orchestra under Bruno Walter, playing the First Tchaikovsky concerto in B flat minor.

Acting on legislation affecting education now pending in Albany, the law committee of the Board of education has approved seven bills and disapproved seventeen, James Marshall, chairman, announced yesterday. All bills dealing with mandatory legislation were disapproved.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7 -- Steel ingot output last week throughout the country was maintained at 99.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that this level may be slightly bettered this week. Scrap supplies are noticeably easier owing to milder weather and every attempt is being made to produce a maximum amount of steel with present facilities.

Dr. Will Durant has reported to Simon Schuster on the progress of his long-term project, "The Story of Civilization." He is working on the third volume of the series, "Caesar and Christ," planning the fourth and thinking about the fifth.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the Associated Press:

Ken Terajima, the Japanese Minister of Communications, told the budget committee of the Diet in Tokyo Saturday that the Japanese merchant marine was being maintained at about the same tonnage that existed at the time the war with the United States started, the Tokyo radio said last night in a broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 (AP) -- American Red Cross relief supplies are now being distributed to the civilian population of Tripoli.

Trading in cotton futures diminished appreciably last week and prices held fairly steady as no new developments appeared in the legislative picture. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the period 4 points lower to 9 points higher than at the end of the preceding week, which had registered net declines of 4 to 25 points.

When Federal soldiers returning from the Civil War sang praises of the peanuts they had found in Southern climes they emphasized flavor. They didn't know that the lowly "nut," which is really a member of the pea family, was a highly nutritious food.

A memorial sermon for Edward Henry Crockett, Associated Press correspondent who was fatally wounded while on duty with the British Mediterranean Fleet, was preached yesterday by the Rev. Franklin P. Cole, pastor, at the morning service at the Church in the Gardens, Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Ceiling prices on cash corn and futures have resulted in materially curtailing trading in futures, and few men in the grain trade feel that it will be possible to raise the price level materially unless the Congressional farm bloc is able to obtain legislation restricting ceilings to parity levels without including benefit payments.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- The wheat market continues to hold within narrow price limits, and for the third straight week the bulk of trading on the Board of Trade was confined last week to a range of about $1.39 to $1.40 a bushel for May.

The Canadian dollar was steady last week, hovering around the best levels of the movement which started an upward spiral beginning about six weeks ago. However, these "peak" values caused a falling off in the buying and a modest decline (1/16 cent) at the closing price of 90.12 cents. The week's highest of 90.25 cents was made on Wednesday and Thursday, add the lowest, 89.94 cents, on Friday.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Replies to a questionnaire on what type of homes the women of Britain will want to live in when peace comes show that the housewives of this country are predominantly conservative in their demands.
An all-out assault on the food "black market," profiteers and hoarders in New York City was launched here yesterday by the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association.
I have been intensely interested in the letters of your readers which have followed Rex Stout's article, "We Shall Hate or We Shall Fail," and Dr. Walter Bowie's reply to it, "Hate Is Moral Poison."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill and General Sir Alan Brooke, chief of the British Imperial Staff, have discussed the coming struggle for Tunisia and future offensive operations in the North African theatre in two conferences with General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief, during a twenty-seven hour stay here.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Aerial hostilities in the Western European theatre slackened considerably over the week-end, being confined to a small-scale Royal Air Force bombing raid on Western Germany and mine-laying activities in enemy waters last night, light sweeps by British fighter pilots over Northern France and Belgium during daylight today and minor German attacks on scattered parts of England this afternoon and tonight.

It is perhaps a symptom of our unhappy time that the essay is in partial disrepute as a iterary form. It will have to await a more leisurely, less purposeful era before it will enjoy a full return to popularity.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 7 -- Hate songs promise to become official march music for Germany's newly mobilized civilian brigades and early patterns indicate that the "strafe"-motif is about to be revived in an assortment of variations.

The problem confronting mankind in its present crisis is essentially one of fidelity to absolute moral principles and of the acceptance of some common higher authority, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker asserted yesterday in his sermon in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Red Wings slammed home three goals in less than eight minutes of the second period to defeat the Maple Leafs, 5 to 3, in a National Hockey League game tonight before an overflow crowd of 13,649. The victory increased Detroit's second-place lead over Toronto to two and a half games.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill returned to 10 Downing Street and to his family and his domestic cares of office today after one of the most dramatic journeys he has yet made, and plunged at once into conferences with his Cabinet.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 5 (Delayed) -- At 9 in the morning teacher starts in (a little sleepy because she played bridge last night). She sits down primly at the desk before the Chinese lesson she wrote out yesterday and the ordeal begins.

There is an ever-expanding market for college women in war work, Dr. Margaret B. Pickel, director of the War Work Information Bureau for Women College Graduates, with headquarters at Columbia University, reported yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 -- The war planes of Malta which the Axis air forces in Sicily once tried vainly to pin down, are now pinning down their erstwhile tormentors. Better tactics, better weapons and better nerves are helping the British to do to Sicily what the Nazis could not do to Malta, but the object remains the same -- control of the Central Mediterranean skies and the lifeline of the Germans in Africa.

Mrs. Carl T. Hogan has accepted the chairmanship of the State and county employes division of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City and will direct solicitation of funds from 15,000 State and county employes here when the campaign begins March 1, it was announced yesterday by John H. Callen, chairman of the employes' gifts committee.

A program of compositions for percussion instruments was presented by an ensemble of twelve players, under the direction of John Cage, with Ruth Stuber Jeanne, marimba, as assisting artist, last night at the Museum of Modern Art, under the joint auspices of the League of Composers and the museum.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 5 (delayed) -- Bombay has been conquered by the industrialist. Where Calcutta is dominated by the great British managing agents, this second largest city of India is under control of the Parsees and Hindus, who have proved that in a stern, bitter struggle for business domination, which is such an important feature of the India situation, Indians can hold their own.

Determined to shelve its woes and worries for a few hours at least, baseball went on what might well prove to be its last grand bender for the duration last night when 1,300 guests -- a record high for the event -- jammed the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore clear into the balcony to attend the twentieth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A communique:
Valentines should be, above all, sentimental. Not just a bottle of perfume or a dozen roses -- but something special and thoughtful.

One race may not be sufficient, but two glittering performances on the same program call for superlatives, and these are precisely what little Hugh Short, the Georgetown junior, got at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The average American has much to learn about the most elementary of all human questions -- what to eat.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 1,036 American soldiers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

Steadfast Christian faith bolstered by fellowship with all Christians will bring ultimate victory to the Yugoslav people despite every effort of their enemies, the Rev. Mr. John A. Bell, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street, said yesterday afternoon at a special service dedicated to Yugoslavs here and in their native land.

Americans must feel shame at the figures for accidental death and injury made public by the National Safety Council. That accidents should cost 93;000 lives and 9,300,000 injuries in 1942, the first full year of war, is equivalent to a major victory for the enemy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 7 -- "A successful Allied invasion of Norway would be a catastrophe for Germany," writes the well-known German military expert, Rear Admiral Richard Gadow in today's Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung.

The Scophony Corporation of America has been formed by General Precision Equipment Corporation, formerly General Theatres Equipment Corporation, and Television Productions, Inc., subsidiary of Paramount Pictures, in association with Scophony, Ltd., of London, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A special Soviet communique broadcast by Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet Monitor:
The Gouverneur Hospital Social Service and Tuberculosis Committee appeals to your readers for used clothing for our city poor.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.5 on Jan. 26. This compared with 113.2 a fortnight before, 112.7 a month before, 108.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

PHOENICIA, N.Y., Feb. 7 -News of interest to metropolitan skiers was furnished today by Jimmy Simpson, member of an old Catskill family which has been responsible for the gain in skiing enthusiasm in Ulster and Greene Counties.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 -- The view from the air shows great stretches between the Delta and the Tunisia border area where the British Eighth Army prepares to continue its victorious offensive and offers impressive proof of an effort that never slackens.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- Less apprehension over an increase in the cotton acreage as proposed by Secretary Wickard in an effort to increase production of cottonseed oil, as Texas advices hinted that 90 per cent of that State's farm hands would not be draft-exempt because the State grew little cotton over an inch staple, accounted last week for moderate recoveries in the distant or new crop positions on the Cotton Exchange here.

War contracts totaling nearly $1,000,000,000 were placed in the New York area during November and December as a consequence of the War Manpower Commission's program of stressing placement of contracts of surplus labor communities, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the commission.

A seasonal lull in wholesale trading developed in most of the markets last week following a month of record buying, according to a summary of the week's activity prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- United States forces have strongly flanked the Japanese strongholds in the Cape Esperance area of Guadalcanal by occupying Titi, five and one-half miles west of the cape, the Navy announced today. Titi is one-half mile west of Marovovo, on the northwest coast of the island.

The campaign to save paper has spread to the theatres. Beginning today only one theatre program will be issued to every two customers. The Playbill, which serves every legitimate theatre on Broadway, carries a notice to this effect in the issues published today.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- James McC. Mitchell, newly elected president of the State Bar Association, made public today the appointment of three important committees, as follows:

CLEVELAND, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Steel markets are fairly steady, "demand and delivery showing little change, with billets and large bar rounds tightest of all carbon steel products and shipments on alloy grades much more extended than on carbon steels," the magazine Steel reported today.

IF Branch Rickey is suffering from badly bruised sensibilities this morning there is no need for surprise. The Deacon of the Dodgers had the harpoon firmly, planted in his hide last night at the Baseball Writers Dinner. For twenty years the scribes have been making merry at the expense of baseball, its chief characters and themselves.
America's war spirit swept into a room at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. A couple from Waterloo, Iowa, talked quietly of their life, now that tragedy has changed it.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A British communique:

The spirit of Jeremiah who did not fear to speak the bitter, unpalatable truth regardless of the punishments to which he laid himself open and which he suffered, must guide the church today if it it to play the role assigned to it by tragic events, declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Whole-hearted cooperation of the retail shoe industry in the United States was pledged yesterday to the government toward compliance with its rationing plan for shoes, by Harold F. Volk, president of the National Shoe Retailers Association.
MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Cash interests were on both sides of the market for oats on the Board of Trade last week, but the bulges brought in hedging sales from the Northwest and reports that additional purchases of Canadian grain had been made.

Men in every age who believe in God know that there are conditions He will not allow to continue, but it is also God's mercy that in the most frightfully destructive disasters He never completely wipes out what He has given to mankind, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, the president, said yesterday in his sermon in the James Memorial Chapel, Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.
Sales of properties in downtown Manhattan for cash featured realty activity reported over the weekend.

Carl Pilnick, former champion of the City College Chess Club, gained third place in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall C.C. yesterday when he defeated John W. Barnhart of Bronxville. The point gave Pilnick a score of 4 1/2-2 1/2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Nominations for the most popular election in Hollywood, the annual "Oscar" awards made by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, were disclosed tonight by Walter Wanger, the president.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 7 -- With three German fighters on his tail things looked black indeed for Second Lieutenant Robert E. Gibson of Rockville Centre, Long Island, N.Y., it was revealed today.
What effect the war will have upon our fishing resources along the Atlantic seaboard is still a matter to be determined.

Declaring that "we cannot hope to build an earthly paradise" when victory comes, the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of Rochester, yesterday urged the establishment of Christian democracy as the goal of victory. "In the term 'Christian democracy,'" he said, "it is not democracy that is of most importance, but it is Christian."

LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique reported the capture of a number of populated places north of Kursk, apparently in the same general area as the advance that carried to Fatezh. The communique was recorded here by the Soviet monitor.
