WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (U.P.) -- Its executive board announced tonight that the Congress of Industrial Organizations would initiate conferences in every war industry in an effort to eliminate absenteeism and other obstacles to all-out production.

DUBLIN, Feb. 7 (Reuter) -- Members of the Eire Government do not disguise the fact that they view the prospect of a general election this year with considerable distaste, Sean Lemass, Minister for Supplies, said at Edenderry today.

Last Tuesday, average prices of both stocks and bonds, after a week of continuous recovery, reached the highest of 1942 and of 1943 to date. To duplicate the average of both railway and industrial shares, that day, one would have to go back to September, 1941.

Because of the war's demands upon artists and students of art, the Art Students League is "in great danger" of being compelled to close its doors before the close of the year, Stewart Klonis, its president, yesterday told several hundred invited guests at a preview exhibition at the league headquarters, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Increasing academic pressure and the inability of a war-reduced staff to maintain financial solvency has forced The Daily Princetonian to suspend publication for the second time within twenty-five years, Eugene Holland Jr., chairman of Princeton's undergraduate newspaper, announced today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Sixty Japanese were killed yesterday in skirmishes in New Guinea, the Allied command announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (Delayed) -- Officers who question the crews of Flying Fortresses after their European forays said today that they believe the gunners of these planes destroy more enemy planes than official records show.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek, a slight bespectacled European Gandhi with a philosophy of passive resistance that worked against the Austro-Hungarian Empire and later against what he considered the Serb-dominated Yugoslav Government, is the main symbol of resistance against the Axis and for the independence of the Croats, according to word from Zagreb.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Two rules which must be followed by producers who state the retail price of their own products in advertisements were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP) -District Attorney Thomas Whelan said today "the facts and circumstances" did not seem to justify issuance of a complaint against Major Gen. Holland M. Smith, who was booked Friday on a drunk-driving, hit-run charge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) --Representative William L. Dawson, only Negro member of Congress, told the House today that William Pickens, Negro Treasury employe accused by the Dies committee of Communist affiliations, "is not and never has been a Communist."

Total resources of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, Newark, N.J., rose $38,634,854 last year, bringing the total assets of $834,552,067 on Dec. 31 to the highest point in the company's history, John R. Hardin, president, said yesterday in the ninety-eighth annual statement.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the extension of exemption under Rule U-70 (A) (7) under the Holding Company Act to March 1, 1944.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today made the positive statement that the commission has no intention of exercising its authority to close the country's stock exchanges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Roosevelt nominated several brigadier generals and colonels for promotion.

"In a few hours,", came the ingratiating voice of the Mayor over the radio on Sunday, "the OPA will announce the freezing of another commodity, beginning tomorrow morning. * * * So look to tomorrow morning's paper for the announcement, which may come as a surprise .

The War Production Board and the British Board of Trade have apparently entered into some form of "secret agreement" to restrict the importation of certain British cotton fabrics not controlled under General Imports Order M-63, it was reported in importing circles yesterday.

A loan exhibition of French posters, poster design and etchings was opened at the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies at 451 Madison Avenue yesterday. The admission fee, beginning today, will be 55 cents, tax included. The gallery will be open weekdays from 11 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., until the end of the month.

Columbia's basketball team, set for two Eastern Intercollegiate League contests this week, will be host to the Harvard quintet tonight at the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The Lions are hopeful that this engagement will give them a good start for Friday night's clash with the pace-setting Pennsylvania five.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 -- Arthur H. Rosson, associate director in the C.B. De Mille unit, left here today for Southern Mexico and Guatemala with a detachment to film jungle and animal scenes for the Paramount picture "The Story of Dr. Wassell," in which Gary Cooper will be starred.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Flying Fortress "Thumper" took two enemy cannon shells which hit the bomb bay and blew off part of the ship's nose in a recent raid, but went on to blast its target, then fight off a swarm of fighters all the way back to England where it crash-landed.

Edward J. Flynn announced yesterday at a press conference in the offices of the Democratic National Committee at the Hotel Biltmore that he would seek re-designation as Democratic national committeeman from New York and that he would accept re-election today as chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Executive Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The presence in Washington of the American Minister to Finland and the President's press conference statement that he expects Mr. Schoenfeld to return to his post at Helsinki in due course have again attracted attention to the problem of the relations of the United States with Soviet Russia, of which problem the situation of Finland is a part.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Admiral Harold R. Stark, commander of United States naval forces in European waters, who has just returned from conferences at Washington, asserted today that the U-boat menace was the most serious problem before the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 3, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Decreases of $334,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $309,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $207,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $116,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Jan. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Second Lieutenant Samuel Corder Turner, 27, U.S.M.C., of Murtaugh, Idaho, had a premonition before going into battle on Tanambogo Island, north of Guadalcanal, that he was going to be killed.

OTTAWA, Feb. 8 -- Introduction of a bill to provide a billion dollars during the fiscal year to pay for arms, ammunition, raw materials and foodstuffs to others of the United Nations not in a position to pay cash in Canadian dollars was announced in the House of Commons today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley.

In all the nine and a fraction years that college basketball has beeen played at Madison Square Garden there never was a more spectacular individual performance than the one Harry Boykoff gave last night as St. John's routed St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 76 -- 46.

One of the proposals put forward by the Treasury to place income taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis would call upon them to pay their taxes both on 1942 income and on 1943 income this year. One concession made is that rates on 1942 income be put back to the rates that prevailed on 1941 income.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 -- Senate Republicans turned thumbs down today on a proposal that the primary elections be shifted from September to May. The question was considered at a majority caucus prior to the afternoon session of the Legislature and it was reported that only four of the eighteen members favored the change.

WITH BRITISH FORCES on the Mayu Peninsula, Feb. 4 (U.P.) -- (Delayed) -- After a bitter all-day battle Indian troops today hammered back stubbornly resisting Japanese troops before Donbaik, approximately twenty miles northwest of Akyab, major objective of the British offensive in Western Burma.
There's another baby, the seventh in nine years, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mittel, at 27-37 First Street, Astoria, Queens, and he has been named Adolf Hitler.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Governor Stassen of Minnesota assumed today the presidency of the International Council of Religious Education. In his address he called upon newspaper men, radio artists, advertising men and laymen in other fields to put their professional talents to work for the church.

New items to replace the traditional staples in the notion field which have gone to war featured the National Notion and Novelty Exhibit which opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Buyer attendance was larger than a year ago, being reported as 220 against 180 in 1942.

The Madison Square Boys Club had announced on formal stationery that its Kennel Club would hold its twenty-first annual pet show yesterday afternoon. As befited the club's new modernistic building at 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, the affair had dog, in more ways than one.

Three pairs of shoes a year is no deprivation, and especially when one thinks how much worse it might be. It is like the man who kept hitting himself on the head with a hammer because it felt so good when he stopped.

A Supreme Court award of $407,854 against the Long Island Lighting Company and the Nassau and Suffolk Lighting Company in connection with intercompany sales of gas by the three corporations that constitute what is known as the Long Island lighting system was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn and the complaint was dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Sentiment for increased lend-lease aid to China mounted in Congress today as the House Foreign Affairs Committee heard Secretary Stimson and Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, stress the need for continuing the mutual aid agreements for another year.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The six clubs of the Interstate Baseball League agreed today to play a 1943 schedule of 140 game and left the door open to enlargement of the circuit to eight teams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A country-wide emergency ceiling over the prices of milk distributors and handlers may pay to farmers for fluid milk intended for resale was decided upon today by the Office of Price Administration, with the intention of preventing "further rises in the cost to the public of this essential food."
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP) -- An unidentified plane caught in a raging blizzard crashed tonight into famous Whiteface Mountain and burst into flames.

A combination of trade buying in the near months and commission-house purchases in the distant positions yesterday brought moderate increases in cotton prices despite spot-month liquidation and hedging. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed 2 to 7 points above Saturday's final quotations, with the new-crop options strongest.

In a decision aimed at having more direct control over the merchandising of its products after the war, Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company will drop its forty wholesale distributors at the end of this year, and will ship directly to retailers from the mill or mill warehouses, William D. Gardner, vice president in charge of sales, announced yesterday.

Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, chairman of the European executive council of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, reported yesterday on a nineteen-month visit to Portugal, Spain, unoccupied France, Switzerland and England, from which he returned last week.

A sudden thrust by American troops across the western tip of Guadalcanal Island has left the Japanese encircled on their last base at Cape Esperance. The American advance over jungle trails and mountains is the longest yet made in this campaign. It carried our fighters some twenty miles from Tassafafonga to Titi, on the opposite shore of the island, a distance equaling all our other gains since the Marines captured Henderson Field .
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Navy released the story of a Coast Guard cutter and three storms today.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The lone traitor among Netherland generals, Hendrik Alexander Seyffardt, died Saturday after having been shot before his home in The Hague, on Friday, and tonight the Netherland news agency Aneta said the Germans were planning "drastic reprisals" against the population.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Complete harmony prevailed among Federal departments concerned in the restoration of control of civilian functions to the Territorial government in Hawaii, Secretary Ickes said today.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (Reuter) -- The horrors of life in Norway under the Gestapo are described in an official Norwegian report issued today by Terje Wold, Norwegian Minister of Justice in the exiled government here, who writes:

LONDON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- Benito Mussolini's appointment of his son-in-law, Count Ciano, as Ambassador to the Vatican led today to widespread conjecture that Italy would make peace moves through the Pope.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The "National War Service Act of 1943," introduced jointly in both houses of Congress today by Senator Austin of Vermont and Representative Wadsworth of New York, would authorize President Roosevelt to prescribe regulations under which every man between 18 and 65 and every woman between 18 and 50 may be directed to war work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal District Court cannot allow payments to trustees in railroad reorganization proceedings without first enabling the Interstate Commerce Commission to put a ceiling on the amount.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The House virtually agreed today to a five-man committee investigation of subversive personnel on the government payroll, which stemmed from a spirited debate involving most members, and which reached such a din at times that the maintenance of order was almost impossible.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Wiley Blount Rutledge Jr. to the Supreme Court.
STALINGRAD, Feb. 8 -- This city, once a vast industrial center whose name will always be a symbol of the triumph of men over metal, is a heap of ruins and rubble. Everywhere there is devastation.

Peaceful and close collaboration between Poland and Russia as the first condition for a Central European Federation to assure peace was proposed yesterday by Professor Waclaw Lednicki of Cracow and Brussels Universities, now visiting professor at Harvard, who spoke at a "Poland Day" program in Town Hall.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill swung into day and night conferences today with his military and political advisers in a drive to put into action decisions reached at the historic North African talks with President Roosevelt from which he returned yesterday.
"I guess this guy was pampered too much by his mother," said the detective wearily. "Of course there were no notes, so you can't be sure."

THE open season on the male animal is continuing. The literary huntresses, from Mary McCarthy and Nancy Hale on down to Helen Howe, have had little pity, and the hides they have nailed to their walls are pretty well riddled with buckshot. Now comes an Australian novelist, Hiss Kylie Tennant, with one of the most effective shotguns of all.
Gross earnings of the Industrial Rayon Corporation for the year 1942 were the largest on record, Hiram S. Rivitz, president, declared in the annual statement to stockholders issued for release today.

Your recent editorial "Ten Years of Hitler" turned my thoughts again to how the German people will be dealt with after their unconditional surrender. You say Hitlerism is much more of a menace than Hitler himself, and that therefore to eliminate Hitler and his regime is not enough.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Russian midday communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:

With a jocular warning that "the first three years are the hardest," Mayor La Guardia visited the New York Red Cross nurse-recruiting center for the Army and Navy at 139 East Thirty-sixth Street yesterday morning and swore in the first five nurses accepted by the Army from among those recruited at the station.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Commission houses with Eastern connections became heavy sellers of rye futures on the Board of Trade today, after the market had shown moderate strength in the early trading, with the finish at the bottom at losses of 1 to 2 1/8 cents, the nearby deliveries leading the decline.
LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

A German broadcast, recorded yesterday by The United Press in New York, said Soviet forces continued fierce attacks with strong tank support on the Middle Donets front and in the sector west of Stary Oskol, but were "repelled in heavy fighting," according to the German communique.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The stock markets began the week with business on the small side. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged and the only movement of note was in home railway securities with gains of a quarter by London Midland and Scottish and Southern deferred and a loss of a similar amount by Great Western.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- Responding to a request for help from the Colombian authorities, Colonel Byron F. Johnson of the Marine Corps, United States naval attache here, today flew doctors and medical supplies 600 miles across the Andes Mountains to Uribia, on the Guajira Peninsula of Colombia, where a serious outbreak of malaria has developed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Former President Hoover warned today that the country must plan for three to five years more of war and urged a revision of manpower and military policies in order to make available 1,000,000 additional workers on farms, in metal mines, and for the drilling of oil wells during the next year.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The board of management and the board of directors of the New York League of Women Voters discussed reapportionment tonight prior to their visit to the Capitol, where they conducted a question and answer program. Later they attended the legislative session. Mrs. Robert Gordon of New York City, chairman of the committee on public administration, presided.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- J. Henry Esser, president of the Suburban Fuel Oil Service, Inc., undertook in the City Court here today to lay the foundation for criminal conspiracy proceedings against five of fourteen truck drivers of his concern who went on strike on Jan. 27.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 8 -- William Mr. Jeffers, Rubber Director, predicted tonight that the synthetic rubber program, despite some delays, would hit its full stride in 1944 and would compete with natural rubber.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- General Georges Catroux, representing General Charles de Gaulle, arrived here today to confer with General Henri Honore Giraud on means of furthering collaboration between the Fighting French and French North Africa.

Specially selected clothes of attractive design, good fabrics and careful workmanship marked the opening yesterday afternoon of Gimbe] new Specialty Corner. In this newly painted but not overdecorated shop on the third floor one may find anything from trim suits to dinner gowns, with a top price of about $40.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- A group of United States correspondents has just finished an intensive short course in high altitude flying at a United States training camp somewhere in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Government motion pictures and magazines, ostensibly produced to further the war effort, were being used to promote a fourth term for President Roosevelt, it was charged in the Senate today by Senator Holman, Oregon Republican.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- India's Communists, whose headquarters are here in Bombay feel that they, too, have a great future when the country gains its independence, P.C. Joshi, Young Communist party leader, told the writer this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Both Japanese and American air and surface forces are continuing operations in the Southwest Pacific in the general vicinity of the Solomon Islands, a Navy spokesman indicated today.
ALLIED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Allied bombers have wrecked the Japanese-occupied town of Dobo in the Aroe Islands, the High Command reported today.

The entire second floor, comprising about 22,000 square feet, in the Finkenberg warehouse buildings at 112-18 Willow Avenue, the Bronx, has been leased to the Federal Government for storage and warehouse purposes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Selection of twelve additional industrial plants to receive the Army-Navy production award in recognition of outstanding performances on war work was announced today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

The stock market failed again yesterday to produce a clear indication of the duration of the corrective phase in evidence recently. Prices drifted in an irregular manner, with emphasis on the down side, and closed mixed. Business dropped to the smallest in three weeks. Transfers on the Stock Exchange were 727,160 shares, against 875,470 on Friday.

Not so long ago Ned Schafer was an active figure in New Jersey's off-shore fishing family and a partisan member of the Neptune Sportsmen's Club. In fact, Schafer had looked forward to again being on the club's winning team in the Atlantic Coast tournament, but coastal restrictions and the cancellation of this event shattered that idea.
MANISTIQUE, Mich., Feb. 8 --Mr. and Mrs. Max Lieberman could put almost an army of their own into the field against the Axis. They have seven sons in service.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 -- If German sources are to be believed at least 300,000 skilled workers from France are now serving in armament plants in the Reich. In any case that is the implication contained by an announcement issued by D.N.B., official German news agency, to the effect that 100,000 French prisoners of war have been released in exchange.

ATLANTA, Feb. 8 -- The keynote of today's sessions of the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems was described as the need for cooperation between labor and capital and of harmony among these two and agriculture.

A RETURNING traveler from Britain brought word the other day that the British abandoned sports pretty generally in the panic right after Dunkerque but since have resumed their athletics on a wide scale. They found relaxation in sports to be the proper tonic for intense work with greater productivity resulting thereby.
Fred C. Moffatt, former president of the New York Curb Exchange, yesterday was re-elected chairman of the board of governors of the Exchange at its thirty-third annual election.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 8 -- Having successfully avoided an open break in the party ranks, which many competent observers did not hesitate today to term a counter-revolution, Premier Mussolini's move in naming Count Ciano, his son-in-law, to the post of Ambassador to the Vatican, has aroused much interest in diplomatic quarters here.

Elimination of most of the "squeeze" and use of intermediate price lines as the result of amendment No. 3 to MPR 287 were cited yesterday as greatly helping the garment industry at meetings here of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers.
Federal income tax regulations permit deductions under certain circumstances for expenses paid during the taxable year for medical care of the taxpayer, his wife or dependent.

WASHIHGTON, Feb. 8 -- The War Production Board confirmed Congressional apprehension today that another slash in the use of newsprint was contemplated, but promised that no such order would be issued before March 31, if then.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- A new struggle is forecast between the Norwegian school teachers and the Nazis following the publication today of "new order" school textbooks in a fresh drive to "re-educate" Norway's children on Nazi lines.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The text of a statement issued by Herbert Hoover today after he had testified before a subcommittee of the Senate investigating manpower facilities follows:

A suggestion that housewives get out the family washtub and accustom themselves again to washing their husbands' shirts and other home laundry to help conserve fuel oil was advanced yesterday by officials of the War Production Board and the Petroleum Administration for War at a joint press conference in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Here to study religious needs of the A.E.F. in the British Isles, Francis P. Matthews of Omaha, Neb., Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus and chairman of the executive committee of the National Catholic Community Service, declared tonight he felt that American servicemen here and in Northern Ireland lacked adequate facilities in which they could combine the atmosphere of their own religion and their own country.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 8 -- Carrying through attacks despite interception attempts by a swarm of Messerschmitt-109s and Junkers-88s, United States heavy bombers raided Naples yesterday and caused heavy damage to shipping and harbor installations.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Sixty Japanese planes attacked the Kwangsi Province capitalof Kweilin in three waves today, loosing both explosive and incendiary bombs and machine-gunning the outskirts, the Chinese Central News Agency announced.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Following is the text of the new Manpower Bill introduced in the Congress today:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger, commander of the Third Army, is in line for transfer to another assignment, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The fall of Kursk, one of the principal bastions of the German 1941-42 Winter line, in a smashing Soviet offensive was announced tonight in a special Russian communique, marking a victory approaching in importance the Russian triumph at Stalingrad. The Germans had been in Kursk since Nov. 11, 1941.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 8 -- A French High Command communique announced today that French troops had occupied an important height "in the region of the high valley of the Kebir River." The site of the operations was not more specifically defined.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 8 -- The wife of General Henri Honore Giraud and the wife of General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret were recently arrested by the Germans, Robert D. Murphy, United States civil affairs officer on the staff of Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, revealed here today.

Seven thousand City College students, buying books on their first day of school, noisily ignored an orderly and official book exchange designed to serve students anxious to get rid of their old texts and purchase new ones.

Jacob (Kuppy) Migden, 26-year-old hanger-on of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, who, it is charged, pointed the erring finger in the mistaken-identity murder of Irving Penn on July 25, 1939, went on trial yesterday in Bronx County Court, charged with first degree murder. Eight men jurors were chosen.

The steel industry began the new year by turning out 3.98 per cent more steel than in January, 1942, the previous January high mark, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Thus 1942, the biggest year in the history of the industry to date, was already being eclipsed.

As the sale of shoes stopped yesterday throughout the nation in preparation for the beginning of rationed sales today, Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown warned in Washington that it might not be possible to maintain the ration of three pairs a year for each person and urged men and women to buy shoes only when absolutely necessary.

Several newspaper editors in Hudson County, N.J., who refused to give the source of printed statements criticizing Bayonne officials must name the "messenger" or "vehicle of transmission" that put the statements in their hands, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Southern Pacific Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to substitute promissory notes for $6,095,567 of its obligations to conform to the letter of the excess-profits tax law in obtaining tax deductions.

Ever since the prohibitive tin order was issued a year ago, designers in the grocery industry have been busy perfecting wartime uniforms for perishable stuff that formerly appeared in cans. You are probably familiar with some of their innovations -- glass jars for fruits and vegetables, for example, and paper cartons for soups that are prepared in dehydrated form.

With the reverberations of Sunday's hilarious and record-smashing dinner of the New York baseball writer, still ringing in their ears, major league club owners and officials spent most of yesterday digging themselves out of the shelters where they had sought refuge from the barbs of the merry scribes.
The current Japanese operations in the Solomons area merely reflect a far wider and intensive scale of enemy activity throughout the whole South Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Administration of the inventory limitation order L-219 will soon be centered in New York City, according to an announcement here today by Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., Director of the WPB Consumer Goods Bureau.

CAMDEN, Me., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, was given the Indian name "Ow-du-sees-ul" -- meaning "Princess of Many Trails" -- in a Penobscot tribal induction ceremony today after the nation's First Lady had sponsored the first of a series of wooden barges to be launched at the Camden Shipbuilding and Marine Railways Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Red Army's capture of Kursk has imperiled the entire German defensive line in Russia. The railroad city had been in German hands since Nov. 11, 1941, having fallen to the Nazis only four and a half months after they had launched their drive into Russia.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 -- Key industrial leaders of Southern California met today with delegates of the National Safety Council's war production fund to conserve manpower to initiate plans for a permanent accident prevention program here.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The death of Major Gen. Harry Willans, first Director-General of Welfare and Education in the British Army, in a flying accident in the Middle East was announced today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 9 -- General Douglas MacArthur and Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the United States War Production Board, broke into the British Who's Who this year for the first time, joining the select company that still includes Adolf Hitler, publication of the 1943 edition revealed today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 8 (AP) -- A jury of eleven men and one woman was chosen today to try the president and fifteen other officers of the Mantle Club on fraud charges resulting from financial operations of the self-styled "Fraternal and Social Society."

John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, announced yesterday that he would introduce two resolutions at a meeting of the Board of Estimate on Thursday requiring the city to protect the rights of officers or employes of the city who may want to work in war factories after hours or seek agricultural employment during their Summer vacations.

Citing two cuts in the price of eggs within the last ten days, A.F. Guckenberger, manager of the New York State Food Merchants Association, suggested yesterday that Mayor La Guardia's comment on Sunday concerning a boycott against high prices of eggs seemed tardy.

HONOLULU, T.H., Feb. 8 -- In separate proclamations of approximately same wording Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding general of the Hawaiian Department and military Governor of Hawaii, and Governor Ingrain Stain-back today announced the return to civilian authority of all functions of the territorial government except three directly involved in the defense of the islands, which have been under the Army's control since Dec. 7, 1941.

A twenty-acre farm with a seven-room dwelling at Hortentown, Putnam County, N.Y., near the Taconic State Parkway, has been sold for Frank Knapp, former postmaster at Beacon, to Mrs. Rose Walker of Larchmont. The property has been owned by the Knapp family for nearly seventy years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Harold D. Smith, Director of the Budget and fiscal adviser to President Roosevelt, urged today the enactment and installation of a pay-as-you-go income tax collection system by April 1.

Five books are on the February list of the Trade Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, selected as those new titles "coordinating imaginative or purposeful design with sound execution" of book format or typography.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 8 -- Striking at one of the bulwarks of Axis air power in the Mediterranean, Flying Fortresses and Marauders of the United States Army Twelfth Air Force made two "very successful" attacks on the important enemy air base at Cagliari, Sardinia, yesterday afternoon -- the first attack by the Twelfth Air Force on that locality.
Members of symphony orchestras are not subject to the "work-or-fight" order of the War Manpower Commission, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the WMC, announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8 -- The Maryland Racing Commission announced today it had laid plans for a joint Spring racing season at Pimlico, within the Baltimore city limits, with days divided among Bowie, Havre de Grace and the host track.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- New York University's basketball forces got back on the victory path before 1,500 fans tonight as they defeated Syracuse in a driving finish, 55 -- 51.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The War Department announced today thirty-four citations for award of the Silver Star for gallantry in action to officers and enlisted men in the Southwest Pacific area. Their names and home addresses were as follows:
Mr. and Mrs. Francklyn Paris have arrived from Pittsburgh and are at the Biltmore.

The case for the adoption of the National War Service Bill which was introduced in Congress yesterday rests on the imperative necessities of total war. Manpower is the first of these necessities. Up to the present point we have been toying with the problem of how to provide it on an adequate scale.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8 -- Harry R. Bridges, Australian-born leader of West Coast longshoremen, met today his first rebuff from a Federal court in his fight against deportation.

The problem of tea supply during the next two or three months will be the most critical since the beginning of the war, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, warns in announcing results of the bureau's fourth quarterly survey of tea stocks.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Plumes of flame seared the sky over Lorient to a height of 7,000 feet last night as the Royal Air Force made its heaviest attack yet on the Nazis' main Atlantic submarine base there.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Navy announced fifty-three casualties today, including fifteen dead, twenty-two wounded and sixteen missing.

The annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for 1942, made public yesterday by James Wilson, president, showed after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges a net profit of $2,532,866. This was equal to $1.16 each on 2,178,250 capital shares outstanding and compared with a net of $2,320,263, or $1.06 a share, in 1941.

On a wind-swept platform at the Todd Erie Basin shipyards, not far from the New York Navy Yard where less than a year ago their five sons stood at attention as the light cruiser Juneau was commissioned, a mother and father pleaded with thousands of war workers yesterday to speed production so that "many more sons will come home to their mothers."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 8 -- The first class of midshipmen to be commissioned at the Mount Holyoke unit of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School, Women's Reserve, will leave tomorrow for assignment to active duty. The group of 236 officer candidates have completed the necessary two-month indoctrination course and will be commissioned either as ensigns or lieutenants (j.g.).

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent for the week ended Feb. 6 over the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Scheduled to open this evening at the Morosco, "The Moon Vine" will make its debut there on Thursday night instead. The decision to postpone Patricia Coleman's comedy was made after Sunday night's preview. As the play had no out-of-town tryout Producer Jack Kirkland felt that the production should practice a bit more.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -Income payments to individuals soared to $113,824,000,000 last year, 23 per cent greater than in 1941, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones reported today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 8 (AP) -Prime Minister Churchill became known on his recent visit to this headquarters as "the man who came to dinner -- twice."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The fate of the Kentucky Derby, scheduled for May 1, remained in doubt tonight, with sponsors of the historic horse race reported working on some plan to make it a "street car" affair in an effort to soften the objection of Joseph B. Eastman, defense transportation director.

Johnny Greco, hard-hitting lightweight, now a private in the Canadian Army, will box Cleo Shans, California contender for the 135-pound title, in the principal bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 26. In another ten-round match Sal Bartolo, Boston featherweight, and Pedro Hernandez of Brooklyn will be rivals.

His was an honorable heritage and worthily he continued it. His father, dean of the Cornell Medical School, had been a pupil of Stonewall Jackson's at the Virginia Military Institute and at 17 Jackson's drillmaster. His grandfather, Bishop and Lieutenant General, another Bishop called "a man whom noble men might love and meaner men might fear.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., Feb. 8 -- For four days late in January four fishermen-shipbuilders of Newfoundland drifted 150 miles to sea in a small, newly-launched wooden vessel while northerly gales at sub-zero temperature swept the ocean and ashore piled up snowdrifts which blocked train service across the island for a week.

Arrangements have been completed by which the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company would supply the East Ohio Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, with 50,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily, it was learned yesterday.

Manufacturers, in their advertising to dealers, are beginning to cite reasons why they continue to advertise even though their products are temporarily in limited supply. Two examples of this were furnished yesterday by John Morrell Co., makers of Red Heart dog food, and Duffy-Mott Company, Inc., which produce canned apple sauce and bottled apple juice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- After about March 1 persons will be able to get their automobile tires recapped without any restrictions, it was learned tonight from an OPA spokesman.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Charles W. Vreeland, 38, an insurance agent; his wife, the former Miss Mary Dean of Cleveland, and their daughter, Joan, 12, were burned to death early today in their log cabin in East Hartford, where they had been snowbound for several days.

Frauds said to have cost the government $250,000 were attributed yesterday to George Kramer of 30 Riverside Drive, when he pleaded guilty in Federal court to charges of having obtained two loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration, on the basis of fraudulent applications. Judge Vincent L. Leibell sentenced the defendant to eighteen months' imprisonment.

The Henry J. Kaiser Company has requested the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower commission here to recruit 2,000 electricians, electrician trainees and electrician helpers for the company's shipyards in Portland, Ore., Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the commission, announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A death-knell for intercollegiate football "as we have known it" for the duration was rung by Denny Myers, Boston College head coach for the past two seasons, today when he was sworn in as a senior grade lieutenant in the physical training division of the Navy's aviation branch.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (U.P.) -- Intensified Allied efforts on the sea and in the air are gaining headway in the struggle against the U-boats, but a long hard battle is inevitable before it can be conquered, and fluctuations must be expected, Sir Archibald Sinclair, British Air Secretary, said in an interview tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 8 -- Advance forces of the British Eighth Army, having occupied Pisida, ten miles east of the Tunisian border, were operating yesterday around the border itself. Some enemy armored cars were met and dispersed in a brief skirmish some distance from the coast, but aside from that patrol activity the ground front remained quiet.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Westchester County began today a new attempt to compel motorists to pay part of the county's $65,000,000 park and parkway debt as the Board of Supervisors sent to the State Legislature a proposed bill that would empower the county to levy 10-cent tolls on Westchester parkways.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- The boom in babies is baffling the Blue Cross, an organization of hospital plans which opened its three-day Winter conference today. The rapidly rising birth rate is crowding the maternity wards of hospitals to such an extent that the Blue Cross urges three-cornered cooperation to relieve the congestion.

Reports of a further severe cut in newsprint consumption were considered here by executives in the industry as somewhat exaggerated. It is believed that the WPB would like to make additional reductions in newsprint, possibly as high as 20 per cent, but that Canada, which supplies 75 per cent of the newsprint used in this country, is strongly opposed to horizontal reductions.

There once was an old gentleman who had a great many devoted nephews, and the more prosperous made their uncle an allowance. Soon after Jan. 1 every year each well-to-do nephew figured up how much money he had made during the preceding year and paid his uncle a certain percentage of this income as each of the following quarters came around.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Turkey's somewhat less cautious attitude toward the United Nations, as revealed in the visit of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in the continuing diplomatic activity at Ankara and in Turkish press comments on the war, is not regarded by informed observers here as justifying the inference drawn in some quarters that Turkey intends to join the ranks of the Allies.

A quarterdeck voice boomed: "Hoist the colors." A chill breeze beat out the folds of the American flag as it climbed the pole in the center of the campus. The band from the U.S.S. Prairie State broke into "The Star-Spangled Banner" and the Gothic buildings of Hunter College in the Bronx became yesterday "for the duration" the property of the Waves and Spars.

W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association, has filed a memorandum with Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, characterizing the revival of the Regional Agricultural Credit Corporation by the Department of Agriculture for the purpose of putting out $225,000,000 additional farm credit as not only inflationary but constituting an attack on private lending institutions.

SAN MIGUEL, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP) -- The 15-year-old son of an Army officer, using a .22-caliber rifle he received as a Christmas present, early today shot and killed an Army private who was attacking his mother, Captain Frank H. Jacobs, Camp Roberts provost marshal, announced.

A concert and supper dance in behalf of the War Relief Fund of the Federation of French Veterans will be held under the patronage of many prominent society women next Sunday night in the main ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania. Leon Rothier, chairman of the concert committee, has enlisted for the program the aid of well-known artists in the musical world.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- William S. Street is the new general manager of Marshall Field Co.'s Chicago and suburban stores, Hughston M. McBain, president, announced today. Mr. Street has been president and general manager of the company's second largest retail store, Frederick Nelson, in Seattle.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Acting on the basis of the recent Herlands report of "inefficiency and waste" in the purchase of school supplies by the New York City boards of education, the La Guardia Administration sponsored here tonight a bill to put control of all school purchases in the hands of the city Department of Purchase.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Sales of wholesalers advanced 5 per cent in December over December, 1941, the Census Bureau reported today, with dollar value of sales rising 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Development of production of riboflavin, or vitamin B2, from its sole-known natural source, milk, is being speeded so that it will soon be available for use in "fortifying" bread, Ollie W. Reed, chief of the Bureau of Dairy Industry, Department of Agriculture, predicted today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

The Japanese radio in a broadcast to Japanese areas yesterday bemoaned the fact that the fighting in the Solomon Islands and New Guinea has become "a succession of pathetic and tragic incidents" for Japanese troops, and complained that America and Britain "are trying to swallow us up in one breath in air and transportation battles by depending upon their vast production power."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Seeking greater uniformity in basic prices of gasoline and heating oil to eliminate discrimination from maximum price formulas previously used, the Office of Price Administration today broadened the application of base-period reference prices to include all tank-wagon sellers in the nation.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Shoe rationing drew varied reactions from New England shoe manufacturers and workers today.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Conservatives fearful that Labor element in the national government will use the party truce for favoring their own domestic ends gave the government's catering bill a rough ride in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A minimum wartime work week of forty-eight hours was decreed tonight by President Roosevelt. Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman, announced that it would apply immediately to thirty-two labor shortage areas, not including New York City.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 9 -- Several Swiss Jews interned in occupied France when the German authorities ordered the application of the Nuremberg laws have been allowed to return to this country. Jews of other neutral countries, such as Spain and Portugal, have also been liberated.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that Great Britain was dipping into her food reserves, but he added that he thought "we are going to get through pretty well on the lines we are now running on in the way of food."

PASSAIC, N.J., Feb. 9 (AP) -- A general alarm fire that burned for four hours destroyed the interior of the large three-story John Rafner furniture store on Main Street, directly across from the Erie Railroad station here tonight. The flames, first detected at 6:19 P.M. were not brought under control until after 10 o'clock.

Sports equipment for servicemen in the many camps and training stations throughout the country is the aim of a fund to be realized on boxing and administered by sports executives, if a plan advanced by Promoter Mike Jacobs meets with success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Refusing to modify its "Little Steel" formula, the War Labor Board denied a wage increase to 180,000 employes of the "Big Four" meat packing companies today and thus presaged a showtown between the Administration and John L. Lewis.

Joseph Platzker, chairman of a committee set up by Mayor La Guardia to aid 613 families in thirteen Bronx buildings taken over by the Navy to provide quarters for Waves and Spars, announced yesterday in closing his office that "if the city had not set up this committee, it would have been a racketeer's paradise."

Caution, heightened by uncertainty over what was to be the nature of last night's address by Economic Stabilizer James F. Byrnes, pervaded trading in cotton futures yesterday, restricting sales and confining price variations to a 7-point range.

In a move designed to channel cotton yarn output into critical war products, the War Production Board will shortly "freeze" output of spindles producing coarse counts ordinarily used in a number of civilian products, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street textile market.

Columbia University announced yesterday that 600 students chosen by the Navy would begin not later than July 1 their studies at the university under the war-training plan of the Army, the Navy and the War Manpower Commission. Columbia was one of the 281 institutions selected by the Joint Committee for the Selection of Non-Federal Educational Institutions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Agreement has been reached by individuals and organizations supporting the Austin-Wadsworth War Service Bill on the recommendation of an amendment to the measure respecting the freedom of any person assigned to work under the program to join or not to join a labor union.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The entire German line in Southern Russia appeared to be caving in tonight as the Russians, in a special communique recorded here by the Soviet monitor, announced the capture of Belgorod with a smashing Red Army blow that further imperiled Kharkov, chief Nazi base east of the Dnieper River.

Living quarters for 2,000 new Waves will be ready for occupancy by the end of this week, Lieutenant Herbert S. Schwab, supply officer at the new Wave training center on the former Hunter College campus in the Bronx, announced yesterday.

Although the official major league schedules are not likely to be ready for publication much before March 1, the Dodgers beat the gun on their local rivals yesterday by announcing a cluster of their more attractive home dates at Ebbets Field for 1943.

Since the government cut the production of ice cream in an effort to conserve butter fat, enterprising manufacturers have started to explore the possibilities of sherbets. Some results of their investigations, which are still continuing, may be seen in any number of drug stores and confectioneries about the city.

Continuance of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program is an "essential element in the winning of the war," and is necessary "as a factor in reconstruction planning," the National Foreign Trade Council declared yesterday in a special statement urging the extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act beyond its present expiration date -- June 12, 1943.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Backing its education committee's recommendation that the educational structure of the future should be based on a state system developed to provide free and full secondary education for all, the London County Council, after a somewhat stormy debate, passed the measure today.

The preponderance of informed opinion in this country contradicts Captain E.V. Rickenbacker's recent statement that even high schools should postpone liberal or general education until after the war. Dr. Charles Maxwell McConn, dean of the New York University Washington Square College of Arts and Science, declared yesterday.

Olga Coelho, Brazilian soprano and guitarist, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, does not believe in stiff formality on the concert stage. Nor is her singing the kind that thrives on formality. Her metier is the folksong, not only of her own country and other South American lands but of nations across the seas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- American control of the air must prevail after the war, instead of the Administration's "freedom of the air" policy, Representative Clare Boothe Luce told the House today, if United States aviation was to ensure the peace and prevent a third World War.

Diversion of idle stocks to war use was reported yesterday by the WPB redistribution division, which provided information on sources of supply in 887 cases out of 980 inquiries made during January by war contractors needing critical items of steel, copper, chemicals, kapok, airplane bolts, plant equipment, etc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 9 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Linda Darnell will be starred in "Highway to Algiers," a story with a background of contemporary fighting in North Africa, by Steve Fisher, who with Georges Kissel is preparing a screen play.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- President Roosevelt's executive order establishing a national forty-eight-hour work week read as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- German raiders in small numbers fanned out over Southeast England early today. Their bombs hit two schools and a church, demolished cottages and killed a dozen persons in several communities. The schools were hit before most pupils had arrived for morning classes and only two children were among the dead.

James Monroe High School's basketball team gained a 25-to-24 victory over DeWitt Clinton on the losers' court yesterday and moved into first place in the Bronx P.S.A.L. race. Grey, who was high scorer with 15 points, caged a foul shot to break the 24-24 tie.
Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway have arrived from their home in Bethesda, Yd., and are at the WaldorfAstoria, accompanied by Mme. Ragni Ostgaard and Colonel Nicolai Ostgaard.

Wherever we go we are met by urgent appeals to become nurses' aides and serve without compensation. The hospitals, we are told, are faced with an appalling shortage of trained personnel. It is therefore most disconcerting to a working or professional woman of limited means to find that her initial expenditure must equal or exceed a week's salary.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 9 -- Fifty school teachers at Rankin, a suburb, began a "sit-down" strike today to enforce demands for pay increases denied them by the borough school board.

If the advertising campaign being conducted in the metropolitan New York area to ferret out idle machine tools proves a success, it may be followed in other industrial sections of the country, it was announced yesterday by Herbert I. Segal, chairman of the New York chapter of the Machinery Dealers National Association, which is conducting the drive.

A plan to merge Universal Corporation and its principal subsidiary, Universal Pictures Company, Inc., is in preparation to simplify the corporate and financial structure of the motion-picture organization, J. Cheever Cowdin, chairman of both companies, said yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 9 -- The trustees of Vassar College have adopted without a dissenting vote a plan for completing the program of studies for the A.B. degree in three years of forty weeks each. The present course comprises four years of about thirty weeks each.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 9 -- A verdict on the case of Frank Jacson, alias Jacques Mornard, who has been charged with the killing of Leon Trotsky, will be rendered within a fortnight, it was announced today.

The continued threat of inflation overshadows all other dangers in banking, Louis S. Headley, president of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, told 900 bankers yesterday at the opening session of the three-day midwinter conference of the trust division in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

This is an anecdote, copyrighted, with all rights reserved, about three patriotic United Nations citizens, an American, an Englishman and a Fighting Frenchman, who made an appointment to meet on the first floor of a certain apartment house for an important discussion.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- As a step to halt any rush of consumers to buy clothing on the theory that it would follow shoes in the list of rationed articles, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, asserted in a joint statement today that there was no shortage of clothing and therefore no need of rationing.

New Yorkers appeared to have accepted government rationing of footwear with outward calm yesterday as shoe stores reopened for business under the limitation imposed by the recent order of the Office of Price Administration restricting individuals to three pairs of shoes a year.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A pair of third-period goals by Bill Cowley, the National Hockey League's leading point-maker, gave the Bruins a 3-1 victory over the Maple Leafs in the third of Boston's four Red Cross benefit games tonight before a crowd of 14,101 at the Boston Garden.
Reynal Hitchcock announces for late Spring publication a selection of the major addresses and papers of Vice President Henry A. Wallace.

The Federal income tax law requires that gains or losses be reported by a person whose income is affected frequently by transactions in property held for profit or investment or used in the taxpayer's business but not a part of the stock in trade.

The end of the war probably will bring the greatest demand for new homes and living units in the history of the nation, Cyrus Crane Willmore, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, told the members of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards at their installation dinner meeting last night in Essex House, Newark.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has approved the naming of a destroyer, now under construction, "The Sullivans" in honor of the five brothers who are listed as missing from the cruiser Juneau, which was lost in action in the Solomon Islands war area in November.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- Cevat Acikalin, Ambassador to Moscow, is due to arrive here on the Taurus express from Syria after a plane flight from Cairo, Egypt, to assist in the Turkish-Russian conversations aimed at a rapproachment leading up to a joint declaration setting forth common aims during and after the war in the Turkish-Russian spheres of interest.

BOMBAY, Feb. 7 (Delayed) -- This city is a good antidote for the belief that the All-India Congress movement has been forgotten or seriously undermined because the government has suppressed the civil disobedience campaign and arrested the Congress leaders.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 878, as against 717 in the preceding week, and 1,318 in the like period of 1942, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 439, which compared with, 318 last Tuesday.

A second-half scoring spree, paced by Ken Germann and Bruce Gehrke, brought the Columbia basketball team a 54-43 victory over Harvard in an Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter at the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.

The case load of scarlet fever rose sharply in New York City last week, 298 new cases being reported, Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, said yesterday. So far this year, there have been 1,203 cases of this children's disease in the city, in contrast to 836 cases at this time last year, and 881 in 1941.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The principal business of the child is to grow and to learn, Dr. George E. Stoddard, commissioner of education, told about 200 women at a luncheon of the legislative conference of the League of Women Voters, which ended its session today.

The 1,132 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $72,880,365,437 par value as of Jan. 31, had a total market value of $71,038,674,932, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Dec. 31, there were 1,136 issues, aggregating $72,992,873,380 par value, which had a total market value of $70,583,644,622.

The recent news item telling of the deservedly long sentence imposed upon "Socks" Lanza brought back vividly to mind the evidence which was uncovered over ten years ago when Judge Seabury investigated the District Attorney's office of New York County.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A record total of $56,382,000,000 in retail sales was reached in 1942, the Department of Commerce reported today. Sales in 1942 were 45 per cent higher than the 1935-39 base period, and 4 per cent more than the 1941 total.

While the running portion of the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor championships previously had been incorporated into the annual New York Athletic Club track meet at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 20, not until yesterday did it become known what would be done about the field events.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The White House made public a Presidential executive order establishing a minimum 48-hour work week for all employes in wartime.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened one of the season's major exhibitions with a preview yesterday. It is called "Americans 1943: Realists and Magic Realists" and will continue until March 21.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Robert P. Patterson and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretaries of War and Navy, joined today in announcing a broad general rule that "the margin of profit which a company makes on its expanded war sales may be limited to one-half or one-third of the margin of profit on peacetime sales."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Charles E. Wilson, War Production Board vice chairman in charge of production, assured industry today that orders involving production of critical common components to be used in the first half of 1943 will receive prompt consideration, even though they were not placed prior to the Feb. 6 deadline.

Feminine feet will go shod in sturdy oxfords and medium-heeled pumps for the duration of the war. Leading manufacturers and designers of footwear made this prediction yesterday on the first day of resumed buying since the rationing recess.

The regional War Labor Board for New York and Northern New Jersey held yesterday its first formal meeting and announced that eighteen disputes were before the board, in addition to 800 applications for approval of voluntary wage increases.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet special communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Alexander Uninsky, Russian pianist, made his North American debut in a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. That Mr. Uninsky was enthusiastically received by the large audience was the result of the virtuosity of his performances, for his attainments as an expert technician outshone his talents as interpreter.

Mrs. William Armour, chairman of the Women's Campaign Committee of the Special Campaign for the British War Relief Society, announced a grand total of $243,857 yesterday at the third report meeting in the Hotel Plaza. The campaign is aiming at $250,000 and closes Feb. 16.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- A large formation of American four-motored Liberator bombers, braving bad weather to make one of he longest raids of the Southwestern Pacific war, yesterday attacked the Japanese harbor and airdrome at Kendari, on the island of Celebes, causing "extensive damage," General Douglas MacArthur's command announced today.
ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The State War Council gave its approval today to the new blackout warning signal system set up by the Army, to go into effect Feb. 17.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- A barrel-chested young man in the uniform of a German air force officer "invaded" the American Red Cross Rainbow Corner tonight. He carried a rifle, bayonet and a revolver filled with blank cartridges.
Sophie presented the most outstanding of her themes yesterday afternoon when she exhibited her first wholesale collection at Saks Fifth Avenue.

The stock market returned yesterday to the forward side as traders resumed purchases on the premise that the period of readjustment had served its purpose. Additions of fractions to more than a point were registered in a wide variety of issues on the New York Stock Exchange, with the industrial section out in front.

President Getulio Vargas of Brazil informed General Henri Honore Giraud the other day that he had decided to send a military mission to North Africa. The French High Commissioner promptly assured him of a hearty welcome to Brazilian officers.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The recapture of Kursk, which had been one of the major Nazi positions, was described as follows today by a correspondent of the Communist newspaper Pravda:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A total of 750,000 refugees have found new homes in Palestine, North and South America and elsewhere as a result of large-scale rescue efforts supported by American Jews in the ten years since Adolf Hitler came to power, the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine informed President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee on Political Refugees in a memorandum today.

College students should be deferred if the proposed bill to draft women 18 to 50 years old for war work is enacted, Miss Virginia C. Gildersleeve, dean of Barnard College, declared yesterday at the opening assembly of the new semester in Barnard Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP) -Secretary Knox recommended today that the United States start immediate negotiations for complete post-war control of sufficient island aerial and naval bases in the Pacific Ocean to prevent Japan from entering on "another war of aggression in the future."
The two four-story apartment houses at 3-5 and 7-9 Park Avenue, Mount Vernon, have been sold by the Jon-Mar Realty Corporation to an investing client of Nehring Brothers, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Ways and Means Committee fell further behind schedule today in its consideration of pay-as-you-go income tax plans when it engaged in controversy over complaints that its jurisdiction and prerogatives had been invaded by the executive branch of the government.

Dr. Charles F. Bolduan, president of the New York Diabetes Association, Inc., made public yesterday a food rationing plan for diabetics, worked out by the association's committee on food rationing at the request of the City Department of Health to meet the growing problem of assuring an adequate supply of the proper types of foods required to maintain diabetics in good health.

The latest German experiment in Norway consists of a set of textbooks for the schools prepared by Nazi hacks. Norwegian children will be told how their nation was "saved" by Germany. The conquest which enslaved their parents was as simple and benign as that.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Navy reported today that a Navy Cross has been awarded posthumously to Lieut. Comdr. John M. Bermingham, of 2058 Watson Avenue, New York City. His widow, Mrs. Grace Bermingham, now lives at 8409 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens, L.I.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) -- "You can have the good old days," said George Ade, as he opened another birthday message. "I'm perfectly contented to be living in the present, even with rationing and the war."

Urging continuance of the voluntary system of war savings, Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the New York State War Savings Staff, asserted yesterday that a compulsory system would discourage bond buying and provide far less money for the war.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

A fashion show that breathed the spirit of today was presented yesterday morning by Lord Taylor. These were eloquent clothes, dealing with the requirements of women from morning the night. They told of the simplicity required by women who are busy fulfilling wartime tasks, and, on the other hand, illustrated the charm of dress that they appreciate when their activities are over and they can turn their minds to relaxation and pleasure.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- A compulsory "back-to-the-farm movement to help fill a rural labor gap which threatens this year's food production was indicated by James F. Byrnes tonight.

As a wartime measure, all seniors in the city's high schools and vocational schools will receive Red Cross first aid training during the new term starting this week, it was announced yesterday by the North Atlantic area headquarters of the American Red Cross, 300 Fourth Avenue.

After more than seven years since the passage of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, calling for stringent regulation and integration of public utility holding companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission has still to effect its so-called "death sentence" program against a major holding company system.

ESTALINGRAD, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- Field Marshal General Friedrich von Paulus, commander of the German Army destroyed at Stalingrad, may be held responsible for atrocities perpetrated by the Nazis during the siege of this ruined Volga city, it was made known today.

The fall of Kursk is one of the great Russian victories of the war. Recapture of this key city opens a broad new corridor for the entire Russian offensive. It is the first breach in the German Winter Wall that stretches from the Baltic to the Black Sea and the fall of the city necessarily imperils the whole structure of German defense in South Russia.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- There was a little more activity today in the stock markets than there had been recently. Home rail junior stocks improved with rises up to 1/4. Argentine rails, however, lost further ground, Buenos Aires Western losing 1/2 and Buenos Aires Great Southern and Central Argentine declining 1/4 each. Several prior-charge railway issues declined from 1/2 to 1 point.

Every American heart must have thrilled yesterday at the news that the battle of Guadalcanal was over and that the victory is ours. "All resistance apparently has ceased," according to Secretary Knox, and Japanese Imperial Headquarters confirms that its troops had been "withdrawn" from the island after "their mission had been fulfilled."

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- Belgorod, as important an outpost of Kharkov's defenses in the northeast as Russian-held Kupyansk in the southeast, was threatened today by Red Army successes just north of it in the capture of a series of strong positions.

The necessity for preventing inflation in this country is second only to the necessity of winning the military war, concludes a survey on inflation included in the annual report of the Atlas Corporation for 1942, released yesterday over the signature of Floyd B. Odlum, president.

MOSCOW, Feb, 9 (U.P.) -- The Communist party organ Pravda today cited Premier Joseph Stalin's May 1 statement as proof that the Soviet Government had no territorial designs on Europe or Asia or any wish to interfere in the domestic affairs of a liberated Europe.

Immediate arbitration of the wage demands of the 32,000 employes of the city's transit lines, members of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, was demanded at a rally held under the union's auspices in Madison Square Garden last night and attended by 20,000 persons affiliated with labor organizations in many fields.
MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique.

Assets of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company increased $44,379,888 last year, bringing the total on Dec. 31 to $810,336,717, Bertrand J. Perry, president, announced yesterday in the annual report to policyholders. The increase is represented chiefly by holdings in United States Government bonds, which now exceed $95,000,000.
The Baltimore, Md., Housing Authority awarded yesterday $14,212,000 of temporary loan notes dated March 1, 1943, and payable on May 17, 1944.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Stock corporations formed last month numbered 708, an increase of thirty-five over December, 1942, Secretary of State Curran reported today. Capitalization for 290 of the total number was $6,705,940, the other 418 issuing stock without par value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Max Swiren, an attorney for two government stabilization agencies, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the effort to have it eliminate rate, fare and charge increases granted common carriers a year ago was "a crucial battle in the campaign to curb inflation."

The first performance of the special Wagner cycle, which is now an annual observance, was given last night in the Metropolitan Opera, but not in the afternoon, as in previous seasons. The performance was attended by a very large audience, despite the fact that "Rheingold" is by no means the most dramatic popular opera of the "Ring" cycle.
The Tokyo radio, recorded by The Associated Press in New York, broadcast the following English-language version of the Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The largest number of United States bombers ever sent against Rangoon in a single day blasted the decks and railroad facilities of the important Burma port yesterday, only a few hours after Royal Air Force bombers had dropped nearly thirty tone of bombs on the city, a communique from United States headquarters said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, said tonight that "until further notice" the executive order establishing the 48-hour week would apply only to thirty-two "labor shortage" areas listed by him.
Following is the text of the radio address last night of James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway paid tribute yesterday to the merchant seamen of their country who are maintaining Norway's "front line" at sea. Boarding a neat motor freighter lying at a Brooklyn pier after a war-route voyage, the royal couple had luncheon and later talked with men in the crew and seamen from other Norwegian ships in the harbor.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 9 -- Striking at the bottleneck of Italo-Sicilian communications, American Liberators bombed the ferry terminal at Messina, Sicily, yesterday. The ferry brings trains across the narrow straits.

Ceremonial masks such as may be seen in distant countries by persons in the armed forces may be seen also by New Yorkers when the Museum of Costume Art at 630 Fifth Avenue opens today an exhibition of masks collected by Kenneth MacGowan.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 9 -Dorothy Heyward, resident dramatist at the Dock Street Theatre, announced the winners today in the Dubose Heyward memorial award for playwriting, divided this year for the first time between two playwrights.
The semi-final brackets were completed in the metropolitan squash racquets doubles championship last night at the University Club.

Following an all-day session that carried them well past their dinner hour, the club owners of the National League yesterday arrived at what they hopefully considered a final solution to the vexing problem of the long-impoverished Phils, chronic occupants of the circuit's cellar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- In order to still rumors which have obtained wide circulation, the War Production Board stated today that the best available figures on the print paper situation indicated that a second cut in use of not more than 10 per cent, effective April 1, would be sufficient to meet the shortage caused by the war.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 9 -- The evacuation of the coastal population of the Low Countries to inland points has been virtually completed and former well-known seaside resorts have been razed to make room for coast defenses, says a report from The Hague to the Essener National Zeitung.

Problems arising from the school activity program were discussed at the February membership meeting of the Teachers Alliance held last night at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Two hundred teachers attended.
Do not withdraw funds from an account in a savings institution in order to buy war savings bonds! That is the message being preached by the Treasury, savings institutions and economists.

Two thousand persons in the financial district attended the Victory Book rally held yesterday during the noon hour on the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets. Sponsored by the 1943 Victory Book Campaign Committee for Greater New York, the rally was designed to spur the collection of books for the armed forces.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- The Legislalature is considering what means can be taken to limit the effect of the recent Federal Supreme Court decision that divorces obtained in any State were legal in New York or any other State, even if only one party was represented in the out-of-State action.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Lord Beaverbrook called, the attenion of the House of Lords today to a change in Great Britain's constitutional structure that is occurring "almost unnoticed" and has given that chamber greater influence and power than at any time in the past thirty years.

ABOARD THE U.S. SUBMARINE-WAHOO, at a Pacific Base, Feb. 9 -- An engagement with a Japanese destroyer in a finger-like bay of Mushu Island, north of New Guinea, followed by a running torpedo and gun battle with a four-ship convoy the next day, gave this new submarine of the Pacific Fleet the right to wear a broom tied to her periscope when she came into port.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, head of the F.B.I., asked all policemen today to assume an extra burden in behalf of boys and girls in an effort to destroy "a trend of immorality which threatens the future of America's homes."

In rationing shoes Government officials avoided the error that they made in so many previous cases of rationing. They did not warn the country in advance that a shortage existed. They did not predict that rationing would be put into force at some future period. Such warnings and forecasts inevitably bring about the very condition they seek to prevent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- By an overwhelming voice vote House Democrats and Republicans joined today in adopting the Cannon resolution to investigate charges of radicalism in the Federal Government personnel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (U.P.) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, favors the 48-hour work week, but is opposed to any additional hours u.nless absolutely necessary, an A. F. L. spokesman said tonight in commenting,on President Roosevelt's executive order.

Anent the reported five-cans-per-person allowance when the new rationing program starts, is it possible that the government, in seeking to thwart the greed of a small number of hoarders, will persist in penalizing a vast' number of persons for just such thrift as it has so vigorously encouraged, in order that savings of money thus effected might be put into stamps and bonds?
