LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Holding his first press conference in many months, General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, said today that it would be futile for him and General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, to make an agreement unless a basis in political harmony between Fighting France and the North African regime had first been achieved.

Charge account receivables at the end of December were 22 per cent under those at the close of 1941, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. Installment account receivables were sharply lower, showing a drop of 41 per cent at the end of the year.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 9 -- Marcel Peyrouton, Governor General of Algeria, created a Permanent Council of War Economy today to tackle the complex Algerian economic situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- In connection with hints from Switzerland today of a possible Italian peace feeler via the Vatican, political and military specialists consulted here take the view that the Fascisti, who so lightly led Italy into war, could not now get her out if they tried; for all signs indicate that Italy is practically a prisoner of Germany and in a sense one of the occupied countries.

Women are being urged to buy only what they need in clothes as well as in foods to avoid the necessity for rationing. But they also want to and are urged to look pretty. How to reconcile this conflict was suggested in an unusual fashion show of "style stretchers" presented by International Fashions at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

Previously known to the world only as typical South Sea islands, the Solomon Islands, a land of coral reefs and jungles populated by 500 whites and 150,000 native blacks, came into the war news on Jan. 24, 1942, when the Japanese seized them in the course of their efforts to encircle Australia and cut off the American supply routes to the South Pacific.

From the spectacular advances of the Russian armies toward the west to the synchronizing and cumulative signs that the Axis governments have lost hope of victory and are beginning to manoeuvre to avoid defeat, every new development in the war emphasizes the rising demand for clearer understandings, military and political, between the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union.

Adolf Hitler Mittel, infant son of Joseph and Bertha Mittel of 27-37 First Street, Astoria, Queens, is going to get a new name. His dad, who had insisted on the present name, admitted as much in the little four-room apartment the family occupy.

MADRID, Spain, Feb. 9 (AP) -- The Spanish Government denied today a report it said had been published in Sweden and Britain that strong forces of German troops had been concentrated on the Spanish frontier and that an ultimatum had been delivered by Germany demanding the right of passage through Spain and occupation, of the Spanish Mediterranean coast.

Fred C. Moffatt, chairman of the New York Curb Exchange, was designated yesterday president pro tem. He succeeds himself, for he has held the post since July 1 last when George P. Rea, first paid president of the institution, resigned to go into educational work.

ALBANY, Feb. 9 -- Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic minority leader, appeared today as the sponsor of the first program bill submitted by the American Labor party. The bill, sent up by the State Committee of the Labor party, would make the State and all its agencies the enforcement officers for Federal price-fixing regulations for protection of the consumer.

"The Siege of Leningrad," a Soviet importation, which was previously titled "Leningrad Fights," will have its American premiere this morning at the Stanley Theatre. The feature-length documentary, which treats of the defense of the long-besieged city, was produced by Lenfilm Newsreel Studios of Leningrad and is distributed here by Artkino Pictures, Inc. Edward R. Murrow narrates the English commentary.

American importers must obtain special approval from the War Production Board for shipments of civilian textiles accumulated by British mills prior to their concentration of output on war-essential needs for the United Nations, M. Stanley Brown, United States representative for the Manchester Cotton Board, declared yesterday in commenting on reports in import circles that such shipments had been halted abruptly.

Japan's Imperial Headquarters was quoted by Axis broadcasts yesterday as announcing that Japanese forces had evacuated Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons, ending a six-month campaign, The Associated Press reported. Thus Tokyo admitted defeat of its effort to prevent complete American occupation of Guadalcanal.

Sincere attention to the specific problems of the Slavic peoples of Europe now and after the peace were pleaded for yesterday by Marcia Davenport, as "vitally important for the American people if they are to understand the world that is to come after this war."

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- Canada's wartime control is proving an outstanding success, Donald Gordon, Dominion Price Director, said tonight. He addressed 600 business men at the annual dinner of the Better Business Bureau of Chicago.

LONDON, Feb. 9 (UR) -- Reports from Sweden today continued to tell of R.A.F. operations against Denmark yesterday and of Swedish anti-aircraft guns opening up last night against a "number of foreign planes" flying at high altitude. There was no confirmation here of any R.A.F. operations in the Scandinavian area during the past twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- When the Senate Appropriations Committee, acting on the resolution of Senator Holman, Oregon Republican, inspects the new Office of War Information magazine, "Victory," to determine whether its cost is a "nonessential" or "wasteful" expenditure of public funds, the members will find a product that is interesting in many ways.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9 -- The intra-party feud between Governor Charles Edison and Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City over control of the Democratic organization in New Jersey became a "battle of banquets" today as party leaders in each of the State's twenty-one counties received dinner invitations from both of the warring camps.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Office of Defense Transportation called on cities and States today to revise traffic signals and regulations to meet the reduced volume of traffic caused by war restrictions so as to save rubber, gasoline and time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- American manufacturing industries, which have now been directed to go to a forty-eight-hour work week basis, worked their 15,434,000 employes an average of forty-four hours during November, according to official figures of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -- Harry Bridges, who is attending to labor union matters in New York and Washington, issued a statement through the national headquarters office of the Harry Bridges Victory Committee here today expressing disappointment over the Federal District Court's denial of his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.
PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 6 (Delayed) -- Forty-four officers and men of the Pacific Fleet received awards here today from Vice Admiral William L. Calhoun, Commander of the fleet's service force.

Soviet troops have launched attacks "still more violent than before" at decisive points on the southern Russian front, the German High Command said yesterday, and Axis troops are fighting "bitter defensive battles," according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Knox told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that statements attributed to Walter Winchell while on naval duty by Representative Hoffman of Michigan were "not considered as scandalous conduct tending to the destruction of good morals."

Executives of companies in the Iron and Steel Institute and in steel warehouse groups in this State and New Jersey joined yesterday with officials of the industrial salvage section of the War Production Board to speed the collection of 1,422,000 tons of scrap metal for the manufacture of steel for war purposes during the first half of this year.

DURING his first four years in the National Football League Don Hutson made the all-league team only twice, but he became a sure-fire certainty for his second four seasons. It is more than a coincidence that the period of his greatest effectiveness began with the arrival at the Green Bay Packer camp of Larry Craig.

ATLANTA, Feb. 9 -- "The remedy of our social and economic ills is not of a technological but of a religious nature," asserted the Most Rev. Gerald P. O'Hara, Bishop of Savannah-Atlanta, tonight at the closing session of the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems.

Philadelphia's association of merchant tailors has been discussing a subject of public, concern. OPA has forbidden double-breasted suits to be accompanied with a vest. Let the prohibition be removed, the merchant tailors say. In the words of their chairman, "a gentleman needs a vest."

A flat warning that the Army intends to force high-cost war plants to manufacture more efficiently and price their goods more cheaply or have their contracts canceled was sounded yesterday by Colonel Albert J. Browning, director of the purchases division, Services of Supply.
The time is now.
The United States Fish and Wildlife Service believes that one way of arousing interest in the so-called coarse fishes is to demonstrate that they are extremely palatable.

In its drive to procure 600,000 typewriters for the Army and Navy, the War Production Board will concentrate for the next sixty days on schools and on State and city governments, William G. Turquand, chief of the office equipment and machinery section, used equipment branch, announced last night at a meeting of the Office Machine Dealers Association of New York in the Hotel New Yorker.

Mrs. Nehamah Baranow, 35 years old, died in Kings County Hospital last night, her skull fractured and the fingers of her right hand crushed, about seven hours after she was found unconscious in an automatic elevator in the seventy-four-family apartment house where she lived at 260 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

The Blue Network, a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, acknowledged yesterday that it had tightened its censorship over the Sunday night broadcasts of Walter Winchell and Drew Pearson, two commercially sponsored commentators.

Anthony Albanese, 31 years old, who was one of Joseph (Socks) Lanza's gangsters several years ago when that racketeer labor union leader was terrorizing the waterfront with his extortion demands, was sentenced by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions yesterday to serve seven and one-half to fifteen years in State prison.

TRENTON, Feb. 9 -- The refusal of Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, to authorize an increase of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk in New Jersey was criticized sharply today by State Milk Control Director Arthur F. Foran.

The possibility of a "peace of power" after the war, with a truce guaranteed only by the armed might of the United Nations, was seen yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, in an address before 1,000 students at the first freshman chapel of the semester.

STALINGRAD, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- From where I am writing outside a dugout built in a narrow gully about sixty feet above the frozen Volga there is nothing to indicate that this is part of Stalin-grad. But less than 100 yards away is the underground headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Vassily Ivanovitch Chuikoff's Sixty-second Army, whence the long defense of Stalingrad was directed.

Testifying yesterday before a committee of Congress, Secretary Knox expressed the opinion that we shall have to maintain adequate defenses in the Pacific after the war and that this will require the establishment of air and naval bases to keep Japan disarmed "for a long time to come."

The Office of Price Administration launched an intensive investigation of meat and butter price ceilings in New York yesterday, shifting from the negative to the positive aspect of compliance and making no reference to the dire penalty clause in OPA regulations.

THE TIMES this morning reports an interesting speech of Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, in the course of which he made the statement that America's front-line soldiers "do not want and will not accept regimentation of their lives or planned economy."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 9 -- American air power struck heavily at vital Axis air bases, shipping and docks in widespread and successful air assaults over Tunisia yesterday. Eighteen enemy fighters were shot down, increasing the Axis losses since the opening of the North African campaign to 625 aircraft.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 9 -- War industry absenteeism, reported to be as high as 20 per cent in one week at a large local plant, put Maryland's Spring horse racing season in jeopardy today.

The engagement of "Counselor-at-Law," suspended since Monday because of Paul Muni's illness, is expected to be resumed "before the end of the week, perhaps even tomorrow night." This announcement, based on a report from Mr. Muni's physicians, was made by Producer John Golden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Target practice does not come within the scope of war activities for which it is appropriate to use an automobile to get to and from the rifle range, in the informal opinion of the Office of Price Administration, it was learned today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 9 -- Senators Chavez, Bone, Taft and Ellender arrived here by airplane from Miami today and about an hour later held a press conference to state the aims and procedure of their investigation into Puerto Rico's food shortage and unemployment, including the question whether the island's misery has been augmented by any inefficient management or lavish expenditures by the administration of Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- Appearing together for the first time, Colonel Oveta C. Hobby of the Waacs, Lieut Comdr. Mildred McAfee of the Waves and Lieut. Comdr. Dorothy Stratton of the Spars were honor guests today at a luncheon of the Boston Advertising Club.

Spokesmen for the laundry industry lost no time in advancing arguments yesterday to emphasize the adverse effects on health and cleanliness as well as on winning the war to be expected from any general compliance by housewives with the "back-to-the-washtub" movement advocated by PAW and WPB representatives in the interest of wartime conservation of fuel oil.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The long and hard-fought battle for the island of Guadalcanal in the Solomons apparently has ended, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said here today. His declaration, made at a press conference, was the first authoritative statement of a United States victory that has been indicated by the Navy communiques for the past two or three weeks.

Edward J. Flynn regained yesterday one of the three political offices he resigned while his nomination as Minister to Australia was before the United States Senate. He appeared assured of reelection to a second, but said he did not want the third, the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee.

Reporting on operations of the Warner Swasey Company, machine tool manufacturers, Charles J. Stilwell, president, informed stockholders yesterday that in 1942 its shipments of turret lathes, tools and parts rose in value to $51,626,436 from $34,903,703 in 1941 and $9,237,082 in 1939, the first year of the war.

As part of a program to enlarge recreational facilities of the city park system to meet wartime needs, Park Commissioner Robert Moses has requested that the allowance for the hire of playground directors be doubled in the new city budget for the fiscal year 1943-44, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing before Thomas J. Patterson, acting Budget Director.

Two million soldiers and sailors lost their lives in action or died from wounds or by drowning in 1942 in the war, according to statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the company announced yesterday. Military deaths last year were probably greater in total than for the preceding two years and four months of the war, the statisticians' report said.

A new health code for day nurseries, which are caring for an increasing number of children as mothers enter industry, was adopted yesterday by the city Board of Health. The code, which will not be enforced for a few weeks so as to give the agencies concerned a chance to learn the regulations, will affect 350 nurseries.
A special meeting of the membership of The Associated Press yesterday ratified an amendment to the by-laws changing the financial requirements for admission of new members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -The Appropriations Committee delivered to the House today a $2,621,104,379 Independent Offices Supply Bill, $6,448,206 under President Roosevelt's budget estimates and $212,906,193 under appropriations for the same purposes for the current fiscal year.

The advertising profession is currently worried over the possibility that advertising and publicity men may be classified as nonessential in some future list issued by the War Manpower Commission. A few rumors have been floating around this week that possibly in one of the early lists to be issued some advertising and publicity jobs may be classified as nonessential, but as yet there is no official word on the subject.

MOSCOW, Feb. 9 -- The storming of Kursk was a complicated operation. Apart from the Axis reserves held in this old Russian city, which is situated in a pleasant forested country, reinforcements had reached General Schneider's garrison from Lgov and Orel, several battalion from the former and from the latter a tank division acting as infantry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- When President Roosevelt tonight ordered a forty-eight-hour minimum work week, wherever the War Manpower Commission deemed it necessary, it was termed part of "the fullest mobilization" of America to carry out this year's war plans calling for a tremendous invasion of Europe.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
A bill sponsored by the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, which recommends a new license period for hunting, fishing and trapping, has been introduced in the Assembly at Albany.

George W. Sutherland, who served the War Production Board as a $1-a-year man since last June and set up its salvage section for the New York-Northern New Jersey region, has stepped down as regional salvage manager, it was learned yesterday.

The number of aliens of enemy nationalities rounded up in this area as dangerous to the safety of this country has just been raised to 2,398 with apprehension of ten Germans, E.E. Conroy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden informed the House of Commons today that there were 3,965 persons under detention in Algeria, but that that figure included many offenders against criminal laws as well as political prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Vice President Wallace, whose thinking was described by Representative Clare Boothe Luce as "globaloney" in a House speech yesterday, issued a statement of reply today and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt simultaneously aligned herself on his side.

J. Basil Maguire and Clifford Sutter of the Greenwich Country Club, defending title holders, took their place in the final round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets doubles championship last night at the University Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Government and industry officials told educators today to marshal college womanpower into war jobs. The educators in turn asked government and industry for "financial assistance," such as scholarships, to do the job.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet special communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 10 -- A "vast Nazi conspiracy," in which Brazilian soldiers were trained to prepare to assist the invaders in the event of an Axis attack, has been crushed, the government announced today.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court set aside today an intangible property assessment of $11,604,815 levied for 1939 by Hillsborough Township, Somerset County, against the Duke Power Company, a public utility operating in the Carolinas but maintaining a registered office in the New Jersey township in that year. The office has since been moved to Jersey City and later to Flemington.

Tonight's opening, postponed from Tuesday, will be "The Moon Vine," a comedy by Patricia Coleman which Jack Kirkland will bring to the Morosco Theatre. With action taking place in Louisiana early in the present century, its cast will include Haila Stoddard, Philip Bourneuf, Arthur Franz, Will Geer, Vera Allen and Grace Coppin.

The tragedy and courage surrounding the fall of Bataan and Corregidor were revived on Governors Island yesterday afternoon when Mrs. Jonathan M. Wainwright 4th received for her husband the Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Service Medal.
Properties in Manhattan that had been repossessed by lending institutions formed the bulk of realty deals reported yesterday. They include several tenements on the lower East Side.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 10 -- A plan which promises to solve the twin problems of housing and transportation plaguing most industrial war plant areas is being worked out by the United Aircraft Corporation.

Drastic revision of a proposed local law to enforce early closing hours for retail stores, as suggested by Mayor La Guardia, was forecast yesterday after a public hearing before the welfare committee of the City Council at City Hall.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- Disintegration of the German front between Orel and the Donets Basin is enabling the Russians to increase the pace of their advance in several sectors and to broaden their front northward in the direction of Orel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Reports that departmental rivalries existing here between the Board of Economic Warfare and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, agencies operating under Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, are finding echoes among their representatives in Brazil and causing embarrassment to American interests there, were heard widely here today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in South Pacific, Feb. 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- United States planes have sunk at least two Japanese destroyers and possibly five more in landing the first blows of a sparring match possibly foreshadowing one of the biggest air-sea battles yet fought in this area.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- Princeton defeated Yale, 41 to 33, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight and tied Penn for first place. Both the Tigers and the Quakers have won three circuit contests and lost none.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- On the basis of an investigation disclosing "very little reduction" in the use of cars by Federal agencies since gasoline rationing went into effect, the Senate will be asked to take steps to bring about closer supervision of use of government cars, Senator Byrd stated today.

The ninety-ninth annual report of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, addressed primarily to policyholders in the armed forces and to their families, was made public yesterday. It revealed that at the end of 1942 the company held United States Government bonds with a value of $122,682,000, compared with $62,446,000 five years ago.

A banking group headed by Blair Co., Inc., and John Nuveen Co. won the award yesterday of a new issue of $7,000,000 Seattle, Wash., municipal light and power system revenue bonds, due in varying amounts from Jan. 1, 1954 to 1970. The bankers bid 97.85, naming the interest rate as 2 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A Congressional storm blew up today over the appearance of "Victory," the new magazine of the Office of War Information. In the Senate a full investigation of all "government propaganda ventures" was promised by Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures, while in the House the OWI publication was both assailed and defended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Operators representing a sizable major proportion of the Southern Appalachian bituminous tonnage today met the terms of John L. Lewis, president of the U.M.W., for a six-day work week, and the rest of the field was reported ready to sign within twenty-four hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Captain G. Herbert Walker Jr., New York broker now stationed at the Army Air Field at Dayton, Ohio, and William Cox, New York lumberman, were disclosed today as heads of a syndicate which reportedly has the "inside" track in attempts to purchase the Phils from the National League.

Dogs of war are in the ascendancy at the sixty-seventh annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opens today. The historic fixture is held this year for the benefit of Dogs for Defense, the organization which is collecting suitable animals of the middle-sized and larger breeds for sentry and guard duty with the armed forces.
ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Senator Frederic R. Coudert and Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell introduced today a bill to revise the present stock transfer tax rates.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A spokesman for the India Office said today that Mohandas K. Gandhi's latest fast was apt to give rise to a situation fraught with gravity at a time when India was menaced by Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Retail sales of independent stores in thirty-four States increased 8 per cent last December over December of 1941 and 27 per cent over last November, J.C. Capt, Director of the Census, reported today. For the year 1942 dollar volume was 4 per cent above that of 1941.

The North American Company, second largest utility holding company in the country, with assets in excess of $1,000,000,000, yesterday petitioned the Supreme Court of the United States for a "showdown" on the constitutionality of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Navy communique:

All the news indicates that the opposing armies are closing in for the battle of Tunisia. The last Axis troops have been driven out of Libya by British land, sea and air action, supported by American bombers. General Alexander, commander of the British forces in the Middle East, states that "the Eighth Army is advancing."

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 11 -- The main Japanese force has been thrown back six miles at Wau, New Guinea, the Allied High Command announced today. This engagement marked a step-up in the tempo of the ground war on the approaches to Salamaua, which is thirty-five miles northeast of Wau. Yesterday's communique had told of the slaying of 100 Japanese in patrol offensives by the Allies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Legislation designed to carry the controversy in the Ways and Means Committee over "government by directive" to a show-down by repealing the Presidential executive order holding salaries to a maximum of $25,000 net was introduced in the House today by Representative Disney of Oklahoma, a member of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Edward R. Stettinius, lend-lease administrator, said today that American lend-lease aid now was being supplied to this country's Allies "at an annual rate in excess of $10,000,000,000."
It seems to me that the time has come for some one to state a few plain facts about the grimness of the food situation in the United States. The following things are perfectly apparent:

Unity between film producers and distributors on the one hand and theatre owners on the other was the keynote of speeches by former Mayor James J. Walker and William F. Rodgers, vice president of Loew's, Inc., at a luncheon given in connection with the twenty-third annual installation of officers yesterday of the Motion Picture Associates in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The loyal willingness of James F. Byrnes to guide the President out of the wilderness of his acts and policies has often been demonstrated on the floor of the Senate. When war came, and to the fires of Mr. Byrnes's personal devotion the fuel of fealty to the Commander in Chief of the armed forces was added, the heat of his uncritical zeal attained incandescence.

BOMBAY, Feb. 10 (AP) -- With India apprehensively alert, Mohandas K. Gandhi started a twenty-one-day hunger strike today, to subsist on citrus fruit juice mixed with water, but not to "fast unto death" as he threatened on previous abstentions. His fast is in protest against his confinement behind barbed wire in the palace of the Aga Khan at Poona.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Excerpts from the correspondence between M.K. Gandhi and the Viceroy of India follow:

Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and Vicente Lombardo Toledane, president of the Latin-American Confederation of Labor, appealed last night for closest unity of the trade union movements of the anti-Axis countries and specifically urged the inclusion of the trade unions of Soviet Russia in a great world labor federation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (AP) -- While the average work week in the steel industry is close to 40 hours now, the primary steel production departments are already on a 48-hour week, an industry spokesman said today in commenting on the government's 48-hour work week ruling.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 10 -- The forty-eight-hour work week order will have little effect here, according to officials.

High officers of the uniformed force and the detective division conferred at Police Headquarters yesterday after a stained hammer was found by a postman in a mail box two blocks from 260 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, where Mrs. Nehamah Baranow was beaten to death in a self-service elevator Tuesday afternoon.

The Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines and its subsidiaries reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year ended on Dec. 31 net income of $3,575,471, which compared with $2,816,177 net in 1941.

Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, former New York vice overlord, yesterday lost his plea for suspension of two remaining sentences of ten to fifteen years each, so that he would be eligible for parole soon on the ten to twenty-year sentence he is now serving in Great Meadows Prison.

STALINGRAD, Feb. 8 (Delayed) -- Last Friday in a bare-walled room flooded with the Winter sunlight and before a relief map of Stalingrad, Lieut. Gen. Mikhail Malinin, 43, chief of staff to Col. Gen. Konstantin Rokossovsky, commander of the Don group of Russian armies, outlined to the Allied correspondents on the visit here the great operations that smashed the Nazi plans to take this Volga city.

The smallest squad of Yankees to receive contracts in recent years soon will be perusing terms for 1943. This was revealed yesterday when President Ed Barrow announced he had mailed thirty of the forms to veterans and rookies scattered throughout the country.

Two hundred and fifty manufacturers of various forms of lower-priced footgear, who expressed fears that the coupon system of shoe rationing would force them out of business, were reassured last night by Julius Ritter, a regional official of the Office of Price Administration, at a meeting held by the National Association of Slipper Manufacturers at the Hotel McAlpin.

Times have changed considerably. The ardent swain of yester-year purchased three, maybe five, pounds of rich candies snugly set amid foil and lace in a quilted satin heart, and in addition, a fat milk chocolate heart inscribed in bas relief, "To my valentine." So armed, he considered himself well equipped to meet the day at hand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The American Management Association was urged today by Glenn E. Brockway, assistant director of the Bureau of Placement, War Manpower Commission, to name a liaison committee to work with the WMC in the formation of policies for improving the administration and organization of the United States Employment Service.

Edward L. Bernays, co-chairman of the Victory Book Campaign Committee, announced yesterday the gift of 1,000 copies of "Problems of Lasting Peace," by Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson. The donation was made by the Hoover Library on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University.

Yesterday we printed a dispatch about George Ade, the fabulist, with a portrait of him that seems to mark him as a member of the class of '42, Purdue University, though he pretends to be 77. As befits a County Chairman he is at Miami Beach. He wears a stick and a New York suit of clothes.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Now that Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's forces have withdrawn into Tunisia, the Germans have succeeded in massing one-fifth of their air force's entire single-engine fighter strength in that sector, an authoritative Royal Air Force source disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The newest German propaganda offensive is a planned and concentrated effort to make the world believe that Adolf Hitler and his regime constitute a barrier to save the world from Russian bolshevism, Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The sweeping Russian victories over the Axis, the loss of the Italian empire in Africa and the bombing of Italy's cities are bringing increasingly into the open in the fascist press long-harbored doubts of the people about the eventual outcome of the war.

After having been closed throughout the holidays for structural alterations, "Piccadilly Arcade in New York" at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, the British War Relief Society's reproduction of the famous London original, is to reopen next Tuesday morning.

The annual report of the Detroit Edison Company for 1942, made public yesterday by Alfred C. Marshall, president, showed after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, a consolidated net income of $7,837,720, compared with a net of $12,443,156 in 1941.

Reporters who have talked to the Germans captured in the graveyard of Stalingrad note the sharp contrast between the temper of the officers and the ordinary soldiers. All these men have experienced the hell they have created for others in their savage drive over Europe. They are sorry specimens, the broken and ragged remnants of the arrogant armies that rolled over Poland and France and Greece in the first fine rapture of conquest and destruction.

Time was when women could smarten up a sober costume by investing in a bright variety of accessories. But even these -- metal jewelry and colored shoes, to name but two -- are dwindling fast and an air of chic is not achieved as automatically as of yore.

As a further step in diversification of his realty holdings, Commander Vincent Astor has bought through his realty advisers one of the best-known business properties in Hartford, Conn., at the northwest corner of Main and Asylum Streets.

Men and women in the armed services who like a quiet retreat in which to enjoy mystery stories or Shakespeare's sonnets, will have a room devoted to their exclusive use beginning next Wednesday in the central building of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Dr. George T. Palmer, first deputy health commissioner, will retire from the city Health Department next Saturday on a pension after nine years' service, he announced yesterday. Dr. Palmer, who is not a physician but an experienced public health worker, will become a field consultant for the American Public Health Association.

There they are, five in a row, Cossack father, mother, two daughters, youngest son, all of them under arms against Hitler, making their contribution all of them to what has just happened to Hitler in the great bend of the Don and in the North Caucasus, and perhaps around Stalingrad.

The Brooklyn Museum will open today a series of new galleries in which its permanent collection of Colonial and Folk Art of Latin America has been installed. The galleries will be used in connection with the museum's Latin-American course for teachers, beginning on Feb. 18 and continuing on Thursday afternoons through June 3.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, "put his cards on the table" today in explaining to a joint meeting of the Senate and House Military Affairs Committee why the Army was asking 8,200,000 men in 1943 and several committee members afterward declared themselves agreeable to following recommendations of the military leadership.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Governor Charles Edison declared in a radio speech tonight, the third in a series of discussions of State problems, that he would not hesitate to invite a liberal Republican to seek the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination this Fall if there was no one available in his own party with the desired qualifications. The address was broadcast by stations WAAT, WTTM and WFPG.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Flooded by questions relating to administration of President Roosevelt's executive order decreeing a minimum wartime work week of forty-eight hours, the War Manpower Commission issued its first rulings today.

Oil supplies for civilian consumption on the Atlantic Coast increased slightly last week, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. The new index of the institute, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oils, stood at the close of the week at 34.6, compared with 34.5 a week earlier.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- American air forces based on Guadalcanal pressed new attacks against Japanese installations in the lower reaches of the Solomon Islands yesterday, coincident with ground operations that broke the last vestige of organized Japanese resistance on Guadalcanal itself.
BOMBAY, Feb. 10 -- The Government of India today issued this statement in regard to M.K. Gandhi's hunger strike:

The holiday outlook for metropolitan skiers is encouraging, only a few inches of snow being needed for Bear Mountain Park and some of the Catskill points to make the picture for the Lincoln holiday week-end one of the most attractive in years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- The House passed today, 201 to 56, a bill approving a merger of the Western Union Telegraph Company and Postal Telegraph, Inc., after protests that the consolidation would establish a "communications monopoly."

Although the opposing team was in command most of the game, the Manhattan College basketball team rallied to defeat Hofstra College, 41 -- 35, last night on the victor's court. Hofstra, paced by the spectacular Johnny Mills, held a 20 -- 18 edge at half-time.

Adult civic and educational leaders were advised yesterday by Dr. Elbert K. Fretwell, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, to become "adjustable" to the changes wrought by the war so that they might be able to lead youth to greater service in the future.

A discussion by a judge, jury and opposing lawyers replaced legal argument yesterday in a unique trial in General Sessions Court in which a man was accused of attempting to kill five of his six children and himself by turning on the gas last Oct. 10.

LIEUTENANT JOHN ALOYSIUS HASSETT is a rather handsome figure in his naval uniform. One look at his solid 180 pounds, his square jaw and his firm eyes and the impression grows that he's just the type warrior you would rather have on your side than fighting against you.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission decided today to limit the State's Spring racing season to fifteen days at Pimlico, all the races to be under Pimlico management.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Prime Minister Churchill answered many questions in the House of Commons today, dealing with larger aspects of the war without once giving away information that would be valuable to the enemy, to members of Parliament or to anybody else.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- From pictures taken by Royal Air Force reconnaissance planes after British bombers had done their work over Turin, the Ministry of Economic Warfare has assessed the damage done to the Italian war effort. Hitherto the information given to the public has consisted chiefly of the number of buildings hit and acres laid waste, but today the Ministry made it possible to translate those figures into industrial percentages.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Praising the voluntary cooperation of newspapers and broadcasters as "magnificent," Byron Price, Director of Censorship, presented slightly amended codes for press and radio today.

John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, yesterday branded as "false and alarmist" statements made by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., and by officers of the Transport Workers Union, intimating that the safety of operation and equipment on the city subway lines was being impaired because of failure to grant general wage rises or to submit the wage issue to arbitration.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Oxford, where modern Industrialism has contended with ancient buildings and the ways of a university town for the past twenty years with mediaevalism fighting a losing battle, received a great addition to the amenities of both city and university by an announcement today that negotiations had been completed whereby Wytham Abbey, a large estate on the outskirts of the city, eventually will pass to the university.
BUFFALO, Feb. 10 -- Steel mills, foundries and other heavy war industries in this area expect that the forty-eight hour work week will solve their situation in regard to manpower.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The Kentucky Derby, run annually without interruption since 1875, will not become a war casualty.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Mice are probably carriers of the virus that causes infantile paralysis in human beings, Dr. William A. Holla, Health Commissioner of Westchester County, said today in announcing the results of investigations conducted independently by two scientists as a result of the outbreak of five cases of infantile paralysis in a small area of this city last Autumn.

Sharp declines in retail sales of distilled spirits in New York and a number of other States during recent months were reported yesterday by Allied Liquor Industries, Inc. Based on "scattered reports" from the official liquor authorities in the States, the industry research organization's information indicated that sales since November have dropped off an average of about 30 per cent from last year's levels during the same period.

The forty-eight-hour week order announced by Mr. Byrnes, signed by the President and elaborated by Mr. McNutt, has two declared purposes. The first is to achieve "the fullest mobilization of our manpower" to carry out "one of the greatest military operations ever planned in history."

ALBANY, Feb. 10 (AP) -- January collections of State taxes amounted to $47,412,246, a decline of $11,256,851 from the same month last year. The falling off of automobile registrations contributed chiefly to the decrease.

DONALD HOUGH, author of "Snow Above Town,"* is like Mayor La Guardia in one respect: when he makes a mistake, he makes a beaut. But Mr. Hough capitalizes on his errors, and the bigger they are the better for his readers.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The stock markets were quiet again today, but the undertone was distinctly firmer than it was yesterday. Gilt edge stocks were dull. War loan 3 1/2 per cents at 105 5-16, 2 1/2 per cent consols at 82 9-16, and local loans at 97 5/8 were all 1-16 lower. Home rails, however, came in for renewed buying, especially stocks on which increased dividends are expected.
A penthouse apartment in 12 East Eighty-eighth Street has been leased by Henry L. Schultz, Standard Oil executive, through Pease Elliman and Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

The steel industry produced 11,543,000 net tons of plates for sale in 1942, an increase of 90 per cent over the previous record output of 6,199,575 tons in 1941, and six times the peace-time output of 1,919,835 net tons in 1938, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A speech that may have a broader significance than its immediate occasion was broadcast tonight by Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski to the crews of the Polish Navy on the anniversary of the day when Poland gained access to the sea after the First World War.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- War Manpower Commissioner Paul V. McNutt tonight said he was "ready and willing" to meet at any time with professional sports leaders to discuss the feasibility of their continued wartime operations.

A few tire dealers have jumped the gun on the Office of Price Administration's easing of the recapping restrictions, the OPA regional office declared yesterday in warning that motorists must present certificates for recapping of their own tires until about March 1 and for purchase of recapped tires at all times.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The following questions and answers on President Roosevelt's forty-eight-hour week order were issued today by the War Manpower Commission:

Plastics, synthetic materials for thousands of uses, are not available in sufficient quantities to meet both war and essential civilian needs, Dr. Ralph Ball of the organic plastics and resins section of the War Production Board declares in The Chemical and Engineering News of the American Chemical Society.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- Two Army photographers who flew with the American heavy bombers on Monday's raid at Messina could not resist the temptation to shoot bullets instead of film at Nazi fighters that attacked their formation.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Governor Dewey today received a letter from William M. Jeffers, Federal Rubber Director, asking him and the Governors of all States where race tracks are operated to help prevent the opening of all suburban tracks until the end of the war or until the tire problem is solved.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, rejected in the House off Commons today a suggestion for a fast cargo-warship as designed by W.S. Burns.

The borough of Manhattan has received by far the largest quota in New York City's drive to raise $12,920,700 here toward the national goal of $125,000,000 for the American Red Cross, it was disclosed yesterday when John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund for New York City, revealed the borough quotas for the campaign.

The sharp rise in industrial advertising last year, most of which was institutional, is graphically illustrated by the fact that the industrial classification was the only one to show a rise in each of ninety-eight markets, whereas total advertising registered a decline in ninety of the ninety-eight markets.

Taking cognizance of the effect of Japanese occupation of the Philippines upon issues of Philippine bonds, Supreme Court Justice Banjamin F. Schreiber granted permission yesterday to the Chase National Bank, as trustee, to deviate from the terms of a bond issue of the Manila Electric Railroad and Lighting Corporation.

With her muse attuned to the somber pitch of war, Jan Garthwaite, 15 years old, of Madera, Calif., has won for the second time the first prize in the annual poetry contest of the Camp Fire Girls, open to the 321,000 members of the organization, it was announced yesterday at national headquarters, 88 Lexington Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Nearly 250,000 babies were born in this State in 1942, according to the annual report of the State Department of Health, making the largest total in history, with the exception of 1917. Both these years marked the start of our participation in world wars.

Except for a flurry of liquidation at the opening, the cotton futures market yesterday ignored the anti-inflationary character of Tuesday night's speech by James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, who said the Administration was opposed to upward revision of the parity prices.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

At 9 A.M. today, the Westminster Kennel Club will open its sixty-seventh annual dog show in Madison Square Garden, with judging to be started an hour later in fifteen rings on the main arena floor. The exhibition will continue through tomorrow night, the final events being for best in show and best American-bred. There will be three judging sessions each day, at 10 A.M., 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The President's only announced appointment was with the Under-Secretary of State, Sumner Welles.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- Although some of its units may be sent elsewhere and many of its veterans may be returned to Britain or the Dominions, the British Eighth Army will remain a fighting force after Africa falls and will be available for an invasion of Europe where and when the high command thinks best.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Defects found in the existing mortgage moratorium law were corrected today in amendments to the Republican program bill, extending the life of the law to July 1, 1944, offered by the Senate majority leader, Joe R. Hanley.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 10 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortresses have rained high fragmentation bombs on twenty to twenty-five planes parked on enemy airfields near the old Moslem shrine of Kairouan, in Central Tunisia, it was announced tonight.

Marking the first monthly decline since the latter part of 1938, sales of thirty-one leading mail order and chain store companies showed a decrease of 1.5 per cent during January in comparison with the same month of 1942, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The first Salvation Army boys' club in New York City will be opened, probably next month, at Bushwick and Gates Avenues, Brooklyn, the organization announced yesterday. The club, to be called the Salvation Army Red Shield Boys Club, was made possible by a gift of $17,500 from the Charles Hayden Foundation.
Individuals and communities were urged yesterday to take advantage of the War Department courses in training for civilian protection.

The distribution of War Ration Book 2, which covers processed fruits, vegetables, soups, fruit and vegetable juices and sauces, will take place in the city's schools from 3 to 7 P.M. on Feb. 23, 24, and 25, with 35,000 teachers and aides acting as registrars, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 10 -- Several shots were fired this morning at Minister of Justice and Public Instruction Guillermo Rothe as he left his house to go to his office. All the bullets missed their mark and Senor Rothe suffered only a cut on a finger from flying glass.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 10 -- General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, announced today that the British Eighth Army, after its sweep of Libya, was advancing into Tunisia, and he declared he was confident that the short Mareth Line of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel could be easily flanked.
HAVANA, Feb. 10 -- The inhabitants of the city of Camaguey went on a general strike today in protest against the failure of government authorities to provide water for the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The "four freedoms" have been depicted in sculpture at President Roosevelt's suggestion By Walter Russell, New York artist, and plans are being made to send small-scale models of the original to all Allied nations and to public places in the larger cities of this country.

With the recent appointment of Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, U-boat expert, as Commander in Chief of the German Navy, the German submarine campaign may be said to be entering a new and unlimited phase, roughly comparable with the intensive unrestricted warfare of 1917-18.

The forty-eight plans for industrial buildings estimated to cost $4,309,705 were filed last month in this State outside of New York City, according to the State Labor Department, which reports that continued expansion of war plants to the exclusion of other industrial construction may be expected this year.

Legislation to curb racketeering and to make public the financial records of officially recognized trade unions was recommended last night by William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, in a lecture at the McMillin Academic Theatre under the sponsorship of the Columbia University Institute of Arts and Science.

Shoe rationing will help cure the foot ills that gasoline and tire rationing inflicted on part of the motoring public, Dr. Benjamin Kauth, director of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York, predicted yesterday.

Seventy-four chairmen and vice chairmen of business and professional committees for the special gifts solicitation of the Archbishop's Committee of the Laity's 1943 Catholic Charities Appeal will meet today with their executive chairmen, John A. Coleman, in the Empire State Club at 5 P.M. to open their drive formally.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A policy providing for the prompt transfer of idle machine tools to plants urgently needing them has been established by the War Production Board following consultations with the War and Navy Departments and the Defense Plant Corporation.

Concerned over the issuance by two carriers of tariffs which are claimed to discriminate in favor of forwarders and against shippers, the Shippers Conference of Greater New York yesterday voted to request the chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission for either an amendment or withdrawal of the rates by the carriers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle announced today the indictment of nine persons, charging bribery, false claims and fraud conspiracy involving an estimated $1,418,617 in alleged overpayments on Army and Navy munitions contracts with Triumph Explosives, Inc., at Elkton, Md.

The Lincoln Medal, awarded annually by the students of Abraham Lincoln High School to the citizen who has rendered the most distinguished service to New York City, was presented yesterday to Paul Robeson, Negro singer and actor, at special exercises in the auditorium of the school building, Ocean Parkway and West Avenue, Brooklyn.

TEANECK, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Eero Koskinen, 16 years old, of 524 Linden Avenue, Teaneck, crippled by infantile paralysis at the age of 5, left Teaneck High School today at the request of the Navy Department because his outstanding ability in model plane building is needed to aid the war effort.

Kay Francis and Mitzi Mayfair, newly returned members of a four-girl "Feminine Theatrical Task Force," yesterday described the hardships and dangers of wartime trouping on a 37,500-mile tour of United States Army stations in North Africa, England, Ireland and Bermuda.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Selling of grain futures induced by a bearish interpretation placed by traders on last night's radio address by James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, in which he expressed continued opposition to revising the parity price formula to include the cost of farm labor, caused a moderate decline in prices in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

Many public buildings in the city have been using fuel oil faster than their rations call for, and some of them may have to be closed, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. He described the situation in city-owned or city-used buildings as "not only bad, but critical."

Despite assurances from officials of the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration that there are adequate stocks of men's clothing, manufacturers warned yesterday that their facilities and piece goods supplies could not stand a heavy demand for fill-in lots from clothiers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 10 -- This Winter's production of the German armaments industry, originally earmarked for the German Summer offensive, will be made available immediately and thrown into the scales in an attempt to tip the balance of the struggle on the eastern front in favor of the Reich, says the Social Demokraten Berlin correspondent in a dispatch today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 10 -- Coinciding with the time limit today for the delivery of all firearms in France, the Vichy government warned against train-wrecking with the admission that "several attempts have been made recently." Such acts, it adds, "are the work of terrorist groups, which obviously operate on instructions emanating from abroad."

The city and the nation have yet to feel the real pinch of war, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at ceremonies in the Council Chamber at City Hall, where 300 CDVO volunteers took the oath as members of the Citizens Service Corps.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- A further cut of $11,500,000 in the State income tax, to be accomplished by increasing the reduction of 25 per cent made last year to one of 33 1-3 per cent this year, was demanded today by the Democratic minorities in both houses of the Legislature.
DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Reaction in the Detroit area to the decree of a forty-eight-hour week was generally favorable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Pay-as-you-go taxes for farmers, following the skip-a-year pattern of the plan of Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was urged on the Ways and Means Committee today on behalf of the National Grange, with 800,000 members in thirty-seven States.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Colonel Julia O. Flikke, superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps, is being retired for disability by the Army Medical Department.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 -- Civilian employes in war industries of Oregon and Washington were "frozen" in their jobs at midnight last night as the West Coast grappled with labor shortages and related problems.

Three pairs of shoes for a man are sufficient, but it is quite a different problem with growing boys. These youngsters are active and can usually wear out shoes three times as fast as their elders. Particularly is this true of city children who play on pavements and sidewalks.

Dollar volume of retail food stores last week showed an increase of about 10 per cent above the levels prevailing in the similar period last year, it was reported in the trade yesterday. However, because of rationing and wartime shortages, it was said, tonnage volume declined about 7 per cent from the levels of the same week in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Senate Agricultural Committee today ordered an investigation into the production, transportation and distribution of food, saying in a resolution that a threatened food shortage had been aggravated by executive department policies "directly contrary to the will of the people."

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, indicated tonight that the order for a forty-eight-hour minimum work week in thirty-two "critical labor shortage areas" might soon be extended to many other regions.

A saga of the high seas, in which a German raider used a flying boat marked "U.S. Navy" as a scouting and bombing plane and a Nazi prison ship hoisted a Norwegian flag in a vain effort to evade Allied cruisers, was recited here yesterday at the office of the Norwegian Information Services.

A mere matter of 315 shares of stock -- worth about $10 a share -- was all that stood in the way of the deal by which the National League could sell the Phils. The Associated Press reported yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- A plan for the mobilization of all protective forces in New Jersey in the event of an emergency was set up today by Governor Charles Edison in an Executive Order and municipal authorities were called upon to cooperate fully.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

An avalanche of favorable war developments plus the speeding-up of domestic support for the United Nations in increasing the industrial work week, produced yesterday an all-out bullish background for the stock market. Aided by the strongest demand since the final session of last year, prices were pushed up to the best levels of the rallying drive, or since October, 1941.

Following the heaviest buying of women's Spring apparel in twenty years in the wholesale markets here, leading resident buyers are turning back reorders from retailers as manufacturers are unable to accept additional business at this time, it was reported here yesterday.

The Ward Baking Company continued its recovery last year despite adverse sales factors, according to a report for 1942 issued yesterday. This showed a net profit of $1,241,333, equal to $4.85 a share for the preferred stock, against a profit of $150,821 in 1941 and a loss of $46,745 in 1940.

Beau Jack, Georgia's ex-caddy who is recognized here as the world lightweight champion, and Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh ring veteran who formerly held the welterweight title, yesterday were signed for a return bout in Madison Square Garden on March 5.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Mobile Red Army forces and ski troops, eating up the miles in a swift assault on Kharkov from two directions, have stormed into Chuguyev, only twenty-two miles southeast of the big Ukrainian city, a special Russian communique, recorded here by the Soviet monitor, announced tonight.

" Andy Hardy's Double Life," the latest release in Metro's series, will have its local premiere today at Loew's State. Mickey Rooney, Lewis Stone, Cecille Parker, Ann Rutherford and Sara Haden again appear in the comedy's leading roles.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Senate and House approved unanimously tonight a concurrent resolution petitioning Congress to end Puerto Rico's colonial regime and define a permanent political status through popular vote.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- In their most widely spread raids since the Battle of Britain, German planes bombed and machine-gunned twenty towns today, hitting a school, churches, houses, stores and a restaurant and killing a number of persons and injuring many others.

The Treasury, charged with the responsibility of foreign-owned funds in this country, has issued already enough rulings on the subject to fill a sizable loose-leaf ledger. Yesterday four more rulings were issued through the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- Nos. 2583 to 2586 -- designed to liberalize some of the restrictions and to save banks the trouble of making out additional reports.

To combat the typhus fever outbreak in Palestine, the national board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, yesterday cabled $6,000 to its emergency committee in Palestine. This action of the two-day war council at the Park Central Hotel extended its work in the health field in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Officials of the war shipping administration estimated today that 19,000 licensed officers and 80,000 seamen would be required to man the 2,300 new merchant vessels now under construction by the Maritime Commission. These figures are in addition to requirements of the existing merchant fleet.

Soviet pressure on the great bastion of Kharkov is increasing in accordance with an "obvious plan to encircle the town from north and south" and a Russian spearhead has breached the "elastic" German defenses, reaching Belgorod, the German Transocean agency reported last night, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and London.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- Philip Morris Co., Ltd., manufacturers of tobacco products, have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 105,176 shares of common stock, $10 par value, and indicating the likelihood of the subsequent sale of $6,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures due on March 1, 1963.

AN ADVANCE BASE, in South Pacific, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A new drive in the South Pacific was promised today following the success of America's first great offensive by land, sea and air in the Solomons. A Navy spokesman said the Japanese had been completely eliminated from Guadalcanal after losses of 30,000 to 50,000 men, 1,100 planes and seventy-two ships during the last six months in the Solomons.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The German-controlled Paris radio said today that "important" Allied forces had launched a new attack on Axis troops at Faid Pass but had been repulsed with losses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The House voted, 302 to 94, today to continue for two years the Dies Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A British communique:

The Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club held its forty-first annual ball last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Designed as a patriotic wartime party, the event was given in tribute to the armed forces, with 1,000 men and women in the various branches of service as guests of honor for the occasion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10 -- Robert Young, now on loan from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will be costarred with Betty Grable in "Sweet Rosie O'Grady," technicolor musical to go before Twentieth Century-Fox cameras on Feb. 22, with William Perlberg producing and Irving Cummings directing.

New York's biggest stock brokerage business again has vindicated the faith of its senior partner in chain-store methods for securities, it was said yesterday on the basis of a report by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.
LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Demands that the government prepare immediately for a great commercial British Empire air service after the war was made in the House of Lords today.

Eighty-two years ago yesterday Mr. Lincoln left his Springfield for Washington. His inaugural, moderate in tone and meant to be mollifying, was received in the South as a sort of proclamation of war. His first Cabinet, containing four of his rivals in the Chicago convention and one man who had been of political service to him, seemed not too promising.

The Bank of Canada, the Dominion's central bank, made a net profit of $9,097,478 in 1942, according to the annual report of G.F. Towers, governor, released here yesterday. After deducting dividends at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent, amounting to $225,000 on the bank's stock, which is held by the Canadian Minister of Finance, there remained $8,872,478, compared with $5,588,386 at the end of 1941.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The War Manpower Commission listed today these 102 cities in which labor shortages are expected within six months:

Suit was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Philip A. Hines, former first deputy city clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, to compel the city to grant him a pension, which was refused on Jan. 14 by the Board of Estimate.

Earl Girard, an employe of the Sheffield Milk Company, who lives on the second floor of a five-story studio apartment building at 72 West Fifty-second Street, was readying himself for bed about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, when, in the bathroom of his apartment, he heard faint whines apparently issuing from the wall.

There is no necessity of adopting the Ruml plan or any complicated system of withholding the income tax. Introduce at once a measure to provide that any one paying his income tax in advance gets 1 per cent rebate for each month paid in advance.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 11 -- The

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 11 -- Seventy-five girl workers at the Vought-Sikorsky plant of the United Aircraft Corporation in Stratford decided late today, at the urging of union officials, to return to work while efforts are made to iron out a dispute over the company's ban on "sweater girls."

"Saludos Amigos," a feature-length Walt Disney cartoon in technicolor, will have its local premiere today at the Globe. The picture represents impressions gained by Disney and a group of his artists, writers and musicians during a three-month tour of Argentina, Chile, Bolivia and Peru in the Summer of 1941.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- There is definite confirmation here of the arrest of General d'Harcourt, retired, who was vice president of the French Legion of War Veterans and chairman of the board of Air France, the company operating the few remaining French air routes.

The Pennsylvania Avenue Court House in Brooklyn, which houses both Magistrate's and Municipal Courts, will definitely have to shut down and about ten other courts will have to curtail their activities because they have burned their fuel oil rations too fast, City Fuel Oil Administrator Edwin A. Salmon declared yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Ignoring previous talk of purses as low as $5, the Maryland Jockey Club president said today that the minimum purse during Pimlico's officially approved fifteen-day Spring meeting would be $1,000.

Consolidated net profit of the Container Corporation of America and its subsidiary companies for 1942 amounted to $2,401,748 after all charges, equal to $3.07 a share on 781,253 capital shares outstanding, according to the preliminary statement announced yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 12 -- The Japanese have been "decisively defeated" in the Wau sector of New Guinea on the approaches to enemy-held Salamaua in a twelve-day encounter that cost them nearly 1,000 dead and many more wounded, the Allied command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary Morgenthau disclosed today that the next large financing operation of the Treasury Department would come in April and that it would seek to get "at least as much as and probably more than" the record-breaking $12,906,000,000 obtained from individual and corporate investors in the December Victory Loan drive.

Carrie Munn divided her Spring collection into four sections at her preview yesterday for her clientele and the press in the shop at 640 Madison Avenue. Daytime, afternoon, informal evening and full evening dress composed the well-designed groups, especially appealing to those women who buy fine custom-made clothes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 11 -- Wendell L. Willkie called upon the Republican party tonight to lead in the renewal of reciprocal trade treaties and lend-lease as a basis for a post-war economic world structure, and said that "the real solution" of the mounting national debt lay not in "continuously mounting deficit," but in "expansion and development within and without our borders."

CLEVELAND, Feb. 11 -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company is filing with the Interstate Commerce Commission a formal protest over the privately negotiated sale of $14,000,000 of bonds of the Erie Railroad Company to Morgan Stanley Co. of New York, investment bankers, and is petitioning to intervene in the Erie's application to the commission for approval of this sale.
The sale of five two-family houses marked realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday.

The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of a George Washington's Birthday card party to be held on the afternoon of Feb. 23 in the ballroom of the Hotel Bossert in Brooklyn. Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard of Brooklyn heads the arrangements committee for the event.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Prices moved today within narrow limits on the stock markets. Gilt-edge issues were dull. War Loan 3 1/2 per cents were down another 1-16 following yesterday's decline. Prices of home rails slipped, exceptions being London, Midland Scottish, which gained 2 1/2s, Metropolitan, which rose 5s.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The House moved in two new directions today toward reclaiming some of the power it delegated to the executive department, and halting alleged abuses of the powers, by adopting resolutions to set up a new investigating committee and giving subpoena powers to the Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Dissatisfaction of Senators from farm States with the Administration's agricultural policies was emphasized today by some members of Congress, who, in commenting favorably on Louis Bromfields' letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES, called for increased parity prices and adequate labor supplies.

An investment purchase in the downtown wholesale jewelry district was announced yesterday by the Irving R. Raber Company, brokers, who sold the five-story commercial building at 181 Canal Street for the 1-2 Realty Corporation. Assessed at $23,000 the property is 20.10 by 75 feet and was sold for cash over an existing mortgage of $12,050. Sidney H. Aarons was attorney for the seller mid Dreyer Traub represented the buyer.

Spokesmen for farmers, including key figures of the Washington "farm bloc," met yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania to register their complaints, only to be told by a representative of the Department of Agriculture that in the milk industry the near future would bring drastic plans for economy -- mostly in distribution -- "involving producers, handlers, consumers and labor."

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The Red Army, in its smashing semi-encirclement of Kharkov, has cut the Ukraine bastion's main railway to the south and the Crimea by capturing the key rail junction of Lozovaya, the Moscow radio announced tonight in a special communiqu recorded here by the Soviet monitor.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- A bomb explosion killed three persons in the Cawnpore railroad station last night only a few hours after Mohandas K. Gandhi, 73-year-old Nationalist leader, began a three-week hunger strike in protest against his detention by the British, Indian dispatches reported tonight.

A large furnished duplex terrace apartment has been leased by Alfred Nathan Jr., an executive of the Nathan Manufacturing Company, in John Murray House, 220 Madison Avenue. Warren Marks Associates were the brokers.
MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- An order directing the Federal Water and Gas Corporation to divest itself of interest in a large share of its holding company system, including several of its principal subsidiaries, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Washington was an aristocrat. And yet he and Lincoln, a man of the common people, are equally revered today. Which goes to show that the American people honor courage and nobility in any station.

Following the introduction of the Coudert-Mitchell bill in Albany for a reduction in the taxes on transfers of securities, the New York Board of Trade yesterday petitioned Governor Dewey for the elimination or reduction of these taxes.

Wholesale liquor dealers have petitioned the War Manpower Commission urging special consideration for certain "key employes" in their industry who have been declared non-essential, it was learned yesterday. Unless such workers as the head shipping clerk, chief warehouseman, and clerks in charge of bonded accounts can be maintained in their positions, it was asserted, the industry will find operations extremely difficult, if not impossible.

In 1931 a large and very comprehensive exhibition of retrospective work by Henri Matisse was presented by the Museum of Modern Art. This week the famous modernist's son, Pierre Matisse, opened at his gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, a show somewhat similar in scope, though on a very much smaller scale because of limited wall space.

The police got nowhere yesterday in their investigation into the murder of Mrs. Nehamah Baranow, whose skull was fractured by hammer blows at noon Tuesday in a self-service elevator in her home at 260 Ocean Parkway, in Brooklyn. Twelve men picked up in various parts of the city were questioned, but all were freed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- The Navy told today how a gun crew aboard an unescorted merchant vessel poured such a withering fire on seven persistently attacking German torpedo bombers that the assailants had to retire, damaged and defeated.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 11 -- Secretary of Economy Francisco Gaxiola in a published statement criticizes the "unpatriotic" attitude of the Syndicate of Railroad Workers in resisting since last November the government's demands to accept a program for reorganization of Mexico's railways.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- The Reichsbank's statement for 1942, just out, reports that the war has been good for business. With increasing war production, it says, the national income rose by loops and bounds, which in turn increased tax revenues and swelled saving accounts.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 12 (AP) -The text of the Russian midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Contending that the pro-Nazi un-American character of the German-American Bund had been proved conclusively by testimony, documents and photographs, Howard F. Corcoran, Acting United States Attorney, asked Federal Judge John Bright yesterday to annul the United States citizenship of Fritz Kuhn and nineteen other former Bundists.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Dr. H. Reydon, new Nazi-sponsored propaganda Minister in the Netherlands, and his wife were reported shot in The Hague yesterday, but there were conflicting reports as to whether both were killed.

Final details of the food industry's extensive program to promote six campaigns outlined by the government will be worked out at a meeting on Feb. 19 at the New York Times Hall, it was learned yesterday. Leading food manufacturers and their agencies will meet with representatives of the Office of War Information, the Grocery Manufacturers of America and the Advertising Council.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Royal Air Force planes made widespread raids on military targets in Japanese-occupied Burma yesterday, including a 200-mile sweep of the Irrawaddy River valley, and topped these off with a night attack on the Heho airdrome by American-made Liberators, a British communique announced today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Plans for a permanent accident prevention program in war industries here were formulated today at a conference attended by officers of the National Safety Council, San Diego Safety Engineers and William A. Irvin, national chairman of the War Production Fund to conserve manpower.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Grain markets moved upward today on the Board of Trade as a result of buying induced by an announcement that House and Senate bills designed to produce more money for farmers would be called up for debate soon.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday gained 26.4 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago, but declined 19.1 per cent from the previous week when the turnover reached a peak for the last twelve years, according to the report yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Impetus was given the study of utilization of women in the manpower shortage by the statement here that current estimates indicate the number of women in the national labor force will increase to 18,400,000 by December of this year, a gain of 3,400,000 over a fourteen-month period.

Army officers of the Second Service Command and civilian defense officials of New York, New Jersey and Delaware, meeting yesterday at Army headquarters at 90 Church Street, agreed upon the use of radio announcements and blasts from the pocket whistles of air raid wardens as the most effective means of sounding the "all clear" signal after hostile air raids affecting these three States.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange soared last month to the highest figure since June 30, 1939, or to 579,394 shares, not counting short interests of 34,117 shares in the accounts of odd-lot dealers. On Dec. 31 last the short interest was 501,833 shares, with 18,323 in odd-lot dealers' accounts.

Salom Rizk, author of "Syrian Yankee," published last month by Doubleday, Doran, will be guest speaker tonight on the Lincoln's Birthday program of the American Common, 40 East Fortieth Street.
