Will Irwin, vice chairman of the Common Council for American Unity, under whose aegis the American Common programs are presented, will preside at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A joint order outlining the working relationships between the Commodity Credit Corporation and the Board of Economic Warfare in handling the government's foreign food development, procurement and importation programs was issued today under the joint signatures of Vice President Wallace, chairman of BEW, and Secretary Wickard.

Braving a beating rainstorm, a group of women authors arrived as scheduled at Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday noon with a score of copies of their latest books to donate to the Victory Book Campaign. Miss Ilka Chase had a bulging shopping bag slung over one shoulder and her French poodle, Jingle, dangling precariously from the other arm.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 12 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, disclosing that nearly half a million Allied troops were now in Africa at the great bridgehead to Europe and that the Casablanca parleys had produced an immense and detailed Allied offensive pattern for the next nine months, solemnly proclaimed yesterday the Allied resolve to make the Nazis "burn and bleed" on other fronts as they had already over the length of Russia.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 11 -- Having pushed along the coastal road despite firm enemy opposition, advance forces of the British Eighth Army yesterday were well across the Tunisian border and fought an artillery duel with German armored elements east of Ben Gardane.
The more the Administration's wage policy and new forty-eight-hour order are studied the more ill-fitted they seem to solve either the problem of manpower or the problem of inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Sharp increases in primary market prices for fruits and vegetables and continued advances in grains brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehenseive index of nearly 900 items for the week ended on Feb. 6 up 0.2 per cent to a new wartime high.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (U.P.) -- Most of the men inducted into the armed forces within two or three months will be married men with families because "there will be no one else left to induct," Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, draft director, declared today.

The stock market held yesterday to an even keel with accelerated activity again present in the low-priced issues. The observance today of the Lincoln Day holiday, to be followed by tomorrow's abbreviated session, tended to restrict business in the standard stocks, and, while a few showed gains of major proportions the average additions were minor.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 11 -- "The Russian forces on the Eastern Front now have attained objectives from which the Germans may expect an attack anywhere from Leningrad to the Black Sea. The gravity of the situation cannot be ignored any longer. It calls for yet one more all-out effort on the home and battle fronts."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation and total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $244,164,000 during the week.

The annual report of the United Corporation for 1942, released yesterday by George Howard, president, shows for the year a net income of $3,553,145, compared with $6,811,213 in 1941. Total income of the holding company for the year fell to $4,335,071 from $7,454,714 the year before.

All leading domestic security and commodity exchanges will be closed today except the Savannah naval stores market and various livestock markets. Banks in New York State and in twenty-seven other States will be closed. The Canadian and London markets will be open. All markets in the United States that normally do business on Saturdays will reopen tomorrow, as will the banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Georgetown won its fourteenth game in sixteen starts tonight as Denny Kraus, one of this district's all-time court greats, slipped through a maze of Fordham players with only seconds to score, clinching a 52-t0-49 victory for the Hoyas.

The uncertainty still reigning in the parity price issue stalled activity on the New York Cotton Exchange again yesterday. Price fluctuations and volume were small and the market closed with net losses of only 1 to 3 points through some pre-holiday liquidation.

No revolution was expressed or implied in the program that John Barbirolli, returning as guest conductor, presented last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. Both the Americas were represented -- South America, in the instance of Brazil, with Villa-Lobos's suite, "Descobrimento do Brasil," and North America with Deems Taylor's Variations for Orchestra, "Marco Takes a Walk."

Thomas A. Edison's contribution to the efficiency of the Navy and the administration of his son, Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey as Secretary of the Navy, were praised yesterday by Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen, who is attached to the office of James Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Following are questions and answers issued today by the Office of Price Administration to explain how shoe rationing affects consumers:

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Governor Dewey issued a proclamation today setting the week of Feb. 14 as Bill of Rights Week. He followed the action of the Board of Regents in ordering observance in the schools, in accordance with the McCaffrey law passed several years ago.

The first report meeting of the special gifts committee of the 1943 Appeal of Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York heard Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary for charities to Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, declare that "totalitarianism under whatever title cannot write a real and lasting peace."

WASHINTGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt will report to the country by radio at 9:30 o'clock, E.W.T., tomorrow night on his Casablanca war conferences with Prime Minister Churchill, the White House stated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The refusal of Germany to consent to the repatriation of American officials and civilians, who were seized in France when diplomatic relations were severed and then taken to Germany, unless military members of the German Armistice Commission in North Africa are released, was denounced by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, today as one of the cheapest efforts at international blackmail he had ever known.

Sixteen of the thirty shows on Broadway have scheduled Lincoln's Birthday matinees. The plays today are: "The Three Sisters," a Stage Relief Fund benefit; "Angel Street," "Arsenic and Old Lace," "Ask My Friend Sandy," "Counselor-at-Law," with Paul Muni, now recovered from an attack of sciatica; "Counterattack," "Janie," "Junior Miss," "The Doughgirls," "The Moon Vine," which opened last night, and "The Patriots."

It would be a far happier world could the report this morning note that "The Moon Vine" is as good as its best intentions. For in her first play to reach town, Patricia Coleman has found an idea that is away from the ordinary, well-trodden track of Broadway comedy, and a number of agreeable players do their best to make it engaging.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 11 -- Recently deserters from the German forces in the Tunis-Bizerte area have begun to appear in our lines, and some persons here see significance in this as an indication that cracks are appearing in the enemy armor.

Charles T. Upjohn, New York realty man, has been reappointed manager of the New York Branch of the Office of Decentralization Service, which is opening an office in 63 Vesey Street, to find homes for Federal employes here under the ninth transfer of employes of certain Washington offices to this city.

It seems reasonably certain that the Treasury Department will approve a modification of the Ruml plan provided there is only a partial cancellation of the liability for the 1942 tax instead of full cancellation. The strain on the taxpayer will not be eased, however, but increased if in enacting a pay-as-you-go plan we require him to pay out in cash in any one year too large a portion of his income.

Reversing a Supreme Court decision, the Appellate Division denied bail yesterday to Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, associate of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, pending Shapiro's trial on charges of extortion. At the same time the court dismissed Shapiro's appeal for reduction of the $100,000 bail which had been fixed by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein.
CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Government approval of plans to hold the 1943 Kentucky Derby elated Colonel Matt Winn today -- and thousands of turf fans throughout the nation beamed, too.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 11 -- Paul Lukas, now in New York following his tour with "Watch on the Rhine" is coming here in two weeks to portray the part of the Nazi Commissioner of Police of Prague in "Hostages" at Paramount.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 11 -- The strongest possible team of Allied commanders, including what General Dwight D. Eisenhower called "the three stars of the British Empire," has been formed under the direct command of General Eisenhower for the final drive against the Axis forces in Tunisia. The Britons are General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham and Air Marshal Sir Arthur Tedder.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The possibility that the United Nations may attempt to open a second front on the European Continent by an air and sea campaign against Eastern Europe, followed by the establishment of a bridgehead on the Balkan Peninsula, has already touched off a wave of diplomatic activity regarding the potentially affected area and a mass of conjectures and unconfirmed tales is beginning to issue from traditionally rumor-ridden Eastern Europe.

War relief organizations have benefited to the extent of $1,500 as the result of a settlement out of court made by Mayor La Guardia in a libel suit he brought last November against Street Smith Publications, Inc., publisher of the magazine Pic, the Mayor disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The nation should prepare for heavy American casualties, "perhaps in the very near future," Secretary of War Stimson said today in a discussion of developing plans for driving the Axis from Africa.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY in Tunisia, Feb. 11 -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel is showing fight at last. In the biggest action since his belated stand at El Agheila, Libya, he has thrown tanks, infantry and artillery against forward forces of the British Eighth Army in the marshy frontier area of Tunisia.

Speaking last night on home ground in Indiana, Wendell Willkie had some useful things to say to a Republican audience about the folly of Republican tariff policy in recent years. He underscored his remarks by quoting from a Republican oracle on tariff matters, President McKinley. McKinley believed in "protectionism," but McKinley saw also the need of reciprocity in a world in which distance was being annihilated by invention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The swamps, jungles and hills of Guadalcanal, for which American forces fought the Japanese from last Aug. 7 to Feb. 9 now have become "a highly useful forward base" from which to press forward attacks on Japan, Secretary Knox said in a press conference here today.

The Thomas Negro Composers Study Group, a mixed chorus directed by Blanche K. Thomas, its founder, gave a program "depicting the musical progress of the Negro," last night in The New York Times Hall. The group was assisted by the Wide-Awake Choral of Hempstead, L.I.; the Rev. Edler G. Hawkins, narrator; Samuel Heyward, violin and guitar; Marjorie Johnson, soprano; Henry King, tenor, and Robert A. Woodland, reciter.

TORONTO, Feb. 11 (By The Canadian Press) -- The Dionne quintuplets will pay their first visit to the United States May 9 when they will christen five ships to be launched at Superior, Wis., Premier Gordon Conant informed the Ontario Legislature today.

The Detroit Edison Company was cut loose completely from the North American Company system yesterday when directors of North American declared a common stock dividend in the form of shares of the Detroit utility.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill's comment yesterday on the German submarine war put that campaign in its proper perspective, though there was some danger that his remarks might be too optimistically interpreted.
"There is no opposition to racing in Washington," declared Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, yesterday, "and the only point at issue is one of transport."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -Reports from Lisbon, published to-I day, of a growing conviction in[ Spain that the Axis cannot win the [ war are borne out by the latest] information, believed completely ! authentic, available here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Relief to New York's independent meat packers losing sales because of "uncontrolled rise" in live stock prices is being sought by Representative Winifred Stanley of New York. Miss Stanley will consult with Representative John Taber of New York on inviting Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, to discuss the situation with the Republican delegation, of which Representative Taber is "dean."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- General Ribbon Mills, Inc., of Catasauqua, Pa., was fined $15,000 yesterday for violations of the Wage-Hour Law and ordered to make restitution of $50,000 to 1,500 women employes by Federal Judge J. Cullen Ganey who denounced the company's practices as "medieval and disgraceful."

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 11 -- American and British generals have concluded ten days of conferences in India and in China, where they consulted Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek on ways to press home the battle to Japan.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill in his speech in the House of Commons today dismissed the political situation in French North Africa by saying that he was more interested in the safety of the armies and the success of operations, "which will soon again be advancing to an important climax."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission concluded three days of hearings today on the question whether to eliminate emergency increases in freight rates, passenger fares and charges which it granted to common carriers a year ago.

A new champion of champions will be crowned tonight in the final of the sixty-seventh annual all-breed dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opened yesterday morning in Madison Square Garden. The sole surviving group winner of last year went down to defeat in the opening sessions, while last year's best-in-show winner was not entered.

FOR a man who was not supposed to have Larry MacPhail's flair for the unusual, the flamboyant and the rambunctious, Branch Rickey has stirred up sufficient excitement in Brooklyn to date to satisfy even the most rabid Dodger fan.

Magistrate Raphael P. Koenig remarked in Yorkville court yesterday afternoon that if a gambling charge against a bookkeeper of the Cavendish Club at 14 East 62d Street is upheld then police would be in a position to lock up every social club and every home where friendly card games are played.

Mr. Krock thinks it isn't cricket for a government magazine to publish articles which speak of Mr. Roosevelt in 1932 "swept into office by a nation weary of reactionaries." And elsewhere the opposition to President Roosevelt is labeled Toryism.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11 -- Governor Baldwin put the State officially behind the President's forty-eight-hour work week order today by directing compliance by all the nearly 13,000 State employes with the Presidential ruling.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- All labor contracts calling for a work week of less than 48 hours are abrogated in the thirty-two labor shortage areas affected by President Roosevelt's extension of the work week, it was explained at the War Manpower Commission today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Pres:

Anticipating the points rationing program for foods which begins on March 1, retail grocers have generally abandoned their individual rationing and are now offering most canned goods items to consumers on a "first come, first served" basis, it was learned in the trade yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The newsprint situation and handling of war news were the chief problems as a group of editors met tonight to discuss the wartime future of American newspapers.

Because the supply of pulpwood appears to be the chief obstacle to the uninterrupted production of paper in this country, a move was started here yesterday to bring about an increase in farm production of pulpwood. In normal times such output is negligible but sponsors of the plan in the paper field contend that through a coordinated effort, farm output of pulpwood can be boosted sharply.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The noon communique:

German troops have scored "considerable defensive successes" on the southern front in Russia, where heavy fighting continues, checking the Soviet advance and increasing the weight of their counter-attacks, Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press said yesterday.

Immediate expansion and improvement of the social security system, both as a war measure and as economically sound from the viewpoint of post-war reconstruction, was urged last night by Senator James E. Murray of Montana and Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board.
Torpedoed and shipwrecked seamen will be able to get shoes even though they do not have Ration Book No. 1, under an arrangement announced yesterday by the United Seamen's Service at 39 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Spokesmen for the C.I.O. urged the Ways and Means Committee today to put the country's income-tax payers on a pay-as-you-go basis, but assailed the formula of Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., as "a rich man's scheme" that would provide "a real cash-in-hand windfall" for the wealthy.

Rapidly declining excess reserves forced member banks of the Federal Reserve System to sell huge amounts of Treasury bills to the twelve central banks of the system in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly figures released yesterday. The Federal open market committee, acting for the central banks, bought $398,389,000 of these bills in the week, the largest volume thus purchased in a single week in the history of the Federal Reserve System.

The establishment of maximum prices for all hard coal delivered to consumers in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens, effective next Monday, was announced yesterday in an order signed by Sylvan L. Joseph, regional OPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Charles E. Hughes Jr., son of the retired Chief Justice, argued today before the Supreme Court that the Federal Communications Commission had exceeded its authority in imposing restrictions on chain broadcasting which regulate contracts between radio stations and the networks.

A jail term of nine months and a fine of $2,500 were imposed yesterday on the first person to be convicted by a jury of dealing in "black market" gasoline ration coupons. The defendant, John Klinger, 56 years old, was found guilty in Federal Court last week of selling two C books of coupons for $30 to a plainclothes policeman.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Senator Barkley and other administration Senators criticized the War Production Board today on the ground of failure to cooperate with the Smaller War Plants Corporation.
Some of the finer points of what does or does not constitute essential driving were brought out yesterday as the result of hearings in Manhattan and the Bronx before OPA examiners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- First intimation that the Government has worked out a special construction of cotton cloth for industrial use as distinct from consumer uses, came today with the announcement that the Office of Price Administration has fixed ceiling prices for the cloth, a 64x60 construction, in which the filling yarn is heavier than in the regular 64x60's and is also made stronger by use of warp twist yarns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Thurman Arnold, familiarly known as the "trust buster" of the Department of Justice, was named by President Roosevelt today as an associate justice of the Circuit Court for the District of Columbia, to take the place of Wiley B. Rutledge, recently confirmed by the Senate for a Supreme Court seat.

The shoe trade expressed confidence yesterday that thousands of pairs of play and occasional footwear would be released to the public without the use of rationing stamps within the next few weeks. Retailers claimed that huge stocks of these types are on their shelves and that large numbers on order have not been shipped by manufacturers.

The Chase National Bank and the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, bidding jointly, won the award yesterday of a new issue of $600,000 Erie County, N.Y., home relief bonds. The issue is due serially from March 1, 1944 to 1946.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- British and French troops were reported tonight by a field correspondent in the Mateur area to have set the long-dormant northern front in Tunisia into action with a continuing attack that had advanced them about eight miles.

DICTATORS, conquerors and men of destiny march across the bodies of the slain to the ruffle of drums and the blare of trumpets. Their injured pride may launch a war; their ambition and megalomania may destroy nations and convulse civilization; their stubborn rationalization of their own obsessions and prejudices into so-called political systems may cause the slaughter of millions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt named Dr. William M. Leiserson of Ohio today to the National (Railway) Mediation Board for the term expiring Feb. 1, 1946, and former Senator Harry H. Schwartz of Wyoming to the term expiring Feb. 1, 1944.

The Little Steel wage formula, reaffirmed this week in the packers' case by the National War Labor Board, must be modified, the American Labor party declared yesterday in a statement sent to President Roosevelt, Chairman William H. Davis of the War Labor Board, OPA Administrator Prentiss Brown and members of Congress from this State.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell of Manhattan introduced a bill today to permit deferment of actual compliance with the Multiple Dwellings law in cases where the owners are unable to obtain the materials needed to make the required changes in their buildings.

The partial lifting of military rule in Hawaii reflects the improvement of our position in the whole Pacific area. Since the disaster of Pearl Harbor, Hawaii has been living the life of a military garrison. It is to the credit of its people that they have accepted severe restrictions cheerfully and without complaint.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement to the House of Commons today follows:

Today's events: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Fredell Lack, violin, Town Hall, 8:30; Roth Quartet, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Salmaggi Opera Company, Mecca Auditorium, 8:30.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 11 -- Minimum royalties of 16 2-3 per cent on all crude oil asphalt by-products are payable to the Venezuelan Government under new petroleum laws, the draft of which will be submitted to Congress shortly. The draft is now under intense study of oil companies, it was learned today.
The 134th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln will be celebrated here today with patriotic rallies, dinners, meetings and other observances.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 11 -- Some French forces in Tunisia are being withdrawn to be rearmed by the Allies, according to an order of the day from General Alphonse P. Juin, field commander of French forces in North Africa.

The stage is set for great action. In Mr. Churchill's ringing speech yesterday, in Secretary Stimson's statement that the nation should "get ready for very heavy casualties, perhaps in the very near future," in the announcement that General Eisenhower has been raised to the rank of full general and placed in supreme command of the Allied forces in North Africa, we see the decisions reached at Casablanca moving swiftly toward fulfillment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The War Manpower Commission indicated today that 102 additional labor shortage areas may soon be added to the thirty-two where President Roosevelt's forty-eight-hour work week has been ordered. Meanwhile, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said the forty-eight-hour decree "will have a tendency to cause more inflation."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary of War Stimson has said that any effort by "civilians" to reduce the planned size of the Army would be a "rash thing." General Marshall, the Chief of Staff, has satisfied the two Kentuckians -- Senator Chandler and Representative May -- who are chairmen of the Congressional Military Committees, that the 1943 goal of 7 1/2 million men, without officers, is necessary to accomplish our war aims.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The United States, in three civil suits filed today, asked damages of about $3,000,000 from nine persons indicted on charges alleging fraudulent activities in war contracts with Triumph Explosives, Inc. of Elkton, Md.

Adolf Hitler's newspaper, the Voelkischer Beobachter, commented yesterday shortly after Prime Minister Churchill's address that an Allied attack on Continental Europe now "appears very possible" and predicted that the drive would come in Western France, where Germany maintains "important submarine bases."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Plans of the Office of War Information to issue a second publication for distribution overseas, this one to be entitled "U.S.A.," were disclosed tonight as Elmer Davis gave notice that he did not intend to discontinue the picture magazine "Victory."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Ceiling prices aimed at making butter available to consumers in New York at 57 cents a pound for Grade AA, or "93-score," butter were fixed by the Office of Price Administration today in assuming tighter control over prices at manufacturing and wholesale levels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Charges that "a quiz-mania" born of "bureaucratic zeals" had so saddled business and individuals with needless and costly inquisitions as to be an obstacle to full use of the country's resources for the war effort, were made today by the Joint Congressional-Departmental (Byrd) Committee.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Lieut. for it recessed this evening.

As a means of expediting the issuance of the new War Ration Book No. 2, which is to be used in the purchase of processed foods and meat, the regional headquarters of the Office of Price Administration suggested yesterday that consumers clip copies of the new Consumer Declaration Form from newspapers and fill them in.

Joseph A. Palma, Borough President of Richmond, and unnamed borough officials were cleared yesterday by the Richmond County grand jury of violation of the City Charter. The evidence was turned over to District Attorney Farrell M. Kane last May by John Harlan Amen, then special prosecutor investigating the city-wide paving racket.

The American farmer is meeting the growing demands of the war for foodstuffs and other farm products much more efficiently than in World War I despite the decreased available labor force, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

Well, folks, you may breathe more easily. Andy Hardy is finally on his way to become a freshman at Wainwright College, and a new girl has swum into his ken. Such -- and only such -- is the progress accomplished in "Andy Hardy's Double Life," thirteenth in the Metro family series, which came to Loew's State yesterday.
MONTREAL, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The Canadiens tonight defeated Chicago, 5 to 3, in a National Hockey League game. Montreal thus advanced to within a game and a half of the fourth-place Black Hawks.

KATONAH, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- The Norwegian Government in Exile opened today a fifty-one-acre vacation center for Norwegian seamen, utilizing the grounds and nine buildings formerly occupied by the Brookwood Labor College in the wooded hills a mile north of this village.

DETROIT, Feb. 11 -- Close on the heels of the Presidential order calling for a forty-eight-hour week in the Detroit area, the United States Employment Service, through its director, John L. Craig, issued today an appeal for women to take jobs in order to relieve the manpower shortage.

Declaring that the job undertaken by the American Red Cross on behalf of service men and their families is the greatest in the history of that organization, Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund campaign for New York City, outlined yesterday three ways New Yorkers can help in this undertaking.

Baseball's latest razzle-dazzle concerning the new ownership of the orphaned Phils was still spinning merrily yesterday with every one -- the National League, perhaps, most of all -- showing an extraordinary interest in finding the answer.

Until the United States Fish and Wildlife Service measures the results of the wartime period on our fishing resources, salt water fishermen are likely to present their own interpretations of what the "lull" or "rest" means to the fish.

Precise and continuing cooperation between air and ground forces on a level of efficiency never achieved by the Germans was the chief reason for the British Eighth Army's amazing victories over Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in the Middle East, Wing Commander Michael Thomas Judd of the Royal Air Force asserted here yesterday.

Lawrence B. Lehrer, 25 years old, of 430 Riverside Drive was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years on his recent conviction of the theft of somewhere between $12,000 and $80,000 from the Yeckes Brothers Corporation, produce dealers in Washington Market, by which he had been employed as credit manager up to last April, when he was inducted into the Army.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussions, Federal income-tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

HANNOVER, N.H., Feb. 11 -- Some forty-four youngsters from eight colleges were on hand tonight for the renewal tomorrow of the oldest college Winter sports meet the country owns, the thirty-fourth Dartmouth Outing Club carnival. This year, because of war restrictions, the meet is combined with the senior Intercollegiate Ski Union championships and the team winner will boast a double title.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 6 were 19 per cent higher than for the same period of last year. In the previous week sales were unchanged from the same week a year ago. For the latest four-week period the increase was 5 per cent.

Liberal supplies of new cabbage from Florida and Texas are reported by the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets and prices are quoted as reasonable. Among the most abundant vegetables, and of course, the cheapest, are yellow onions, sweet potatoes, carrots and yellow turnips.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- President Roosevelt nominated Dwight D. Eisenhower to be a full general, nominated W.M. Leiserson and H.H. Schwartz to the National Mediation Board, requested an appropriation of $100,000,000 for agricultural incentive payments, and talked with Eric A. Johnston.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- Desire De Fauw has been appointed musical director and conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for the season of 1943-44, Edward L. Ryerson, president of the Orchestra Association, announced today. He added that the vote of members and trustees had been unanimous.
On the eve of Lincoln's birthday we citizens of the Americas may well reflect what he would have done if the destiny of this hemisphere were in his hands today.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an increase in government securities of 5,775,000. Private deposits improved over 1,000,000.

Transportation difficulties due to gasoline rationing have changed salvage procedures, according to the New York City salvage committee. Intensive campaigns with house-to-house canvassing have given way to the neighborhood method.

Seven midshipmen from the New York Naval Reserve graduating class, chosen from among 1,270 classmates, the largest group of officers to be sworn in at one time in the history of the Navy, received swords yesterday for outstanding leadership and ability in a ceremony at the New York Yacht Club.

OMAHA, Feb. 12 -- Former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas urged tonight "a coalition of real Democrats and the Republican party" as a guarantee that Vice President Wallace "and his fellow-travelers will not lead us down the same disastrous primrose path in which Hitler has led his people."

THE biggest social event of the New York basketball season will be staged in Madison Square Garden tonight when Notre Dame plays N.Y.U. It matters not what the records of the two clubs are for this annual state occasion. The Irish could have been swamped by P.S. 9 and the Violet could have been passed dizzy by a fast-moving quintet from the Home for the Aged and Infirm.

A Soviet opera dealing with the Cossacks and the defense of their homeland on the Don against the invasion of the Germans will have its American premiere in New York in May or June, according to plans being formulated under the sponsorship of a committee of prominent New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Official assurances that the government had no plan for rationing clothing in the immediate future were given today by Federal officials.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 12 -- Charles Brunel, an ardent de Gaullist, has been chosen to head Marcel B. Peyrouton's newly created Permanent Council of War Economy. This appointment -- the first of a recognized follower of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, to a high office -- has done as much as anything else to ease the political situation here.

If major league baseball needs only 400 players to operate successfully, as mentioned by Robert Manning in his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday, I think he was 100 per cent correct in advocating that the sport be classed as an essential activity immediately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Marine Corps moved today to enroll women in the new Women's Reserve, of which Mrs. Ruth Cheney Streeter, 47, of Morristown, N.J., a licensed pilot, is to be director, with the rank of major.

The Army and Navy rely on the schools to provide a sound basic education for those who are ultimately to make up the military and naval forces, representatives of the War and Navy Departments declared yesterday at a regional meeting of the National Vocational Guidance Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle said today that a Federal grand jury at Kansas City, Mo., has indicted the Baker-Lockwood Manufacturing Company, Inc., of North Kansas City, and four persons on a charge of conspiring to defraud on contracts involving more than $7,000,000 for aircraft accessories used at the Armys Wright Field near Dayton, Ohio.

The four-story building on a plot 28 by 80 feet at 228 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Joseph Huber to Rudolph H. Haber, a client of Philip Wolfson, attorney. Sale was for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $3,750. Smith Reiher represented the seller.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Resuming its around-the-clock offensive, the Royal Air Force bombed the German naval base of Wilhelmshaven last night and carried out many attacks during daylight today over Northwestern Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Northern France. The night and day attacks across the North Sea struck new blows in the antisubmarine warfare.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Crime decreased 29.9 per cent in New York last year, the Correction Department said today, asserting that wartime restrictions on foreign trade partly accounted for a drop in traffic in illicit drugs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Greatly expanded plans to inform the world of the position and progress of the United States in the war are under consideration by the Office of War Information and may be announced within a week.

Legal action to invalidate all existing eligible lists for elementary school teachers was taken yesterday in a taxpayer's suit filed against the Board of Education. This move seeks to throw out the names of 3,000 men and women now for the most part serving as substitute teachers, many of whom have been on the eligible lists since 1930.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 - Talking as man to man with a group of American airmen and ground staff members, Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, United States Army air chief, collected information on the performance of United States bombers and armament during a recent visit in the Mid East.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- The dog fight which four dinghies have been waging through the mid-Winter series of frostbite racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club apparently narrowed to two of these craft in the holiday program today which marked the next-to-last event of the series.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 12 -- The part played by "that slightly forgotten army, the infantry" in the defense of Malta was stressed by Major Gen. Ronald Scobie, operational chief on the island, in the course of a talk with war correspondents here last night.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- Confidence continues to be the keynote of the German mood and the national temper is firm and resolved, says Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, in his weekly diagnosis of the nation's frame of mind, which was broadcast today.

NORTH BAY, Ont., Feb. 12 -- The Dionne quintuplets were left speechless for a time today over the prospects of a trip, possibly by boat, to Superior, Wis., in May to sponsor five ships being built under lend-lease arrangements for Britain.
Russian offensives over virtually the entire eastern front were reported yesterday by the German High Command in a communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press.

Elsa Kuhn, wife of Fritz Kuhn, former national "Fuehrer" of the German-American Bund, has been taken into custody in the course of a round-up of alien enemies, and their son, Walter, also has been apprehended, it was learned last night.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 13 -- The Japanese retreat is continuing northeast of Wau on the approaches to the New Guinea port of Salamaua, the Allied command announced today in a communique which also said that 225 more enemy troops had been killed or found dead in Papua.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The War Labor Board by ruling today that a company cannot abandon a union shop established by a prior contract, created two classifications of employes in a plant, those covered by the union shop and those coming under a maintenance of membership provision.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- War agencies announced the following developments today:

The controversy over the effectiveness of dimout regulations now in effect along America's coastal areas has been heightened by a disclosure that the power division of the War Production Board is giving serious consideration to dimming out bright lights on a nationwide basis.

Steps are under way to organize a national federation of the women's apparel industries, with the twin objectives of obtaining recognition for the industries from government and to emphasize the importance of them to the public, it was revealed yesterday by I. Ginsberg of I. Ginsberg Brother, temporary chairman of the organizing committee, and Murray Norman of Starr-Norman, Inc.

MOSCOW, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -BattleI front dispatches reported today I that Red Army collimns under Col. I Gen. Nikolai Vatutin were drivingI on Kharkov from yelyaevka, fir-! ty miles to the south; Andreevka, twenty-three miles southeast; Chuguyev, twenty-two miles east by southeast, and Begoroa, ortyfive miles north.

Hoping to evolve some kind of program to avert the threat of serious production decreases in the milk industry, the National Milk Producers Cooperative Federation yesterday met in the Hotel Pennsylvania with representatives from twenty-three States in attendance.

American motor truck operators "as a group are entitled to quite as much praise" for their fine performance in the present emergency as has been accorded the nation's railroads, Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, asserted here yesterday.

TORONTO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Gold-mining stocks reduced early losses in the last hour of trading today on the Toronto Stock Exchange, but other groups continued soft and losses were showing at the close for all four index groupings. Volume was down to about 350,000 shares.

Champion Pitter Patter of Piperscroft, imported black miniature poodle owned by Mrs. P.H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J., and handled by Walter Morris, was adjudged best in the sixty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club last night at the final session in the two-day competition given at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of Dogs for Defense, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Senator Smith of South Carolina, chairman of the Agriculture Committee, predicted today that his impending inquiry into Administration farm policies will "blow the lid off, so the public will know the desperate outlook for war food production."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Secretary Ickes, Solid Fuels Coordinator for War, called upon the bituminous and anthracite industries today to advance the date Of their projected wage negotiations. He acted, he said, "to protect the nation's fuel supply and without in any sense assuming jurisdiction in a matter of collective bargaining."

The Vatican radio, in an English broadcast yesterday deplored ideologies that encourage "the policy of expansionism at any cost" or the "morbid urge to control all peoples for the benefit of one State."

"Race Relations Sunday" will be observed tomorrow. "More than 50,000 churches in all the States of the nation and in the Hawaiian Islands are expected to participate in this year's activities, which will include special services, study groups, interracial pulpit, choir and other exchanges," it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. George E. Haynes, executive secretary of the race relations department of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

GUADALCANAL, Feb. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- United States bomber and torpedo planes sank three Japanese destroyers and damaged at least four others in two attacks on task forces desperately evacuating Japanese officers and technical personnel from Guadalcanal the first week in February, the Navy disclosed today.

As Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman has set some sensible wartime standards for State traffic departments and cities of more than 10,000 population. Aimed at the conservation of fuel and tires, these proposed changes in the control of traffic both by automatic signals and by manpower are in line with the thinking of most traffic experts, who have been urging a revision of peacetime practice to meet wartime conditions.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- James A. Hamilton, president of the American Hospital Association, prophesied today that rationing of nursing service would be necessary unless an increase of 50,000 students for nursing schools were obtained. A rationing plan probably would include the banning of special-duty nurses, home nurses and nurses employed by industry in non-nursing jobs, he said.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 12 -- "Completing" his political shake-up of last week, Premier Mussolini ousted six under-secretaries in three ministries of his "new" Cabinet today and named new men to their positions. All are reported to have been ousted because of opposition to the "new policy" under which the Premier "shoulders entire responsibility for the conduct of operations in this delicate phase of the conflict."

The annual report of the Boston Edison Company for 1942, issued yesterday, shows net profit of $5,688,106, equal to $2.30 a share, comparing with $6,006,126, or $2.43 a share, earned in the preceding year. As a result of the sale of radio station WEEI to the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., there was a net capital gain after tax of $430,803, amounting to 17 cents a share.
Mr. and Mrs. Ogden White of Alamatuck Farm, Far Hills, N.J., have arrived at Hampshire House from Washington, where they are making their home.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique:

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Suspension of allegedly unprofitable train service is not warranted during the present emergency, the State Public Utility Commission ruled today, when the discontinuance of trains would require the use of motor trucks for transportation of goods now carried by rail.

The pamphlet report of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for 1942, made public yesterday, announces the largest sales volume in the company's history, in the amount of $498,313,857, against $480,109,939 in 1941, while net sales and other operating revenues set a new high mark of $523,463,385, about 4 per cent greater than the $503,352,294 reported the year before.

In Russia the German retreat is as plainly marked as an ebbing tide on a sandy shore. There is no similar map of the air front in the Mediterranean. Yet the change in the Mediterranean skies has been as radical and definite as the change in the Russian battle line.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Dr. Bertram C. Eskell of London, in charge of the British medical volunteer movement, who leased an apartment at 655 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Police Sergeant James Mannion, 59 years old and thirty-one years on the force, was passing the corner of Second Avenue and Forty-third Street at 11:30 last night, on foot patrol, when he saw a young man, a stranger to him, behind the bar of Rogerson's Bar and Grill, 803 Second Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UP) - Fighter-escorted American bombers started large fires and shot down one enemy plane in two destructive raids on Japanese-occupied-islands in the Solomons yesterday (Solomons time), the Navy reported today.

I live in what is technically known as the suburbs -- and the gasoline rationing being what it is, I have ample opportunity to study life on the rails, and especially that phase of it using the subway.

Fordham University officials revealed yesterday that Fordham College will become a center for the Army Specialized Training Program. The school will begin to receive Army men for basic and advanced technical subjects "sometime in the near future, probably. in April," the announcement said.

County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz of Brooklyn was accused last night of "cacography, cacology and cacophony" in his proposal to remove adolescent cases from the Magistrates' Courts and place them under the supervision of a Youth Court, administered by county judges.

Katharine Hepburn ends another successful Broadway engagement this evening when the Philip Barry play, "Without Love," closes at the St James Theatre after playing 110 performances. The play has not reached the end of its possible public, but has reached the end of Miss Hepburn's contract; she must return to the Coast.

MONTREAL, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The St. Lawrence Paper Mills Company, Ltd., reported today for 1942 a net profit of $514, 998, equal to $3.74 a share on the outstanding preferred stock, compared to $545,629, or $3.98 a share in 1941.

The Rev. Dr. John Knox, Professor of New Testament and Homiletics in the Divinity School of the University of Chicago, has accepted a call to the faculty of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, this city, and will begin his duties here when the seminary reopens this Autumn, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, the president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Republicans, comprising ten of the twenty-five members of the Ways and Means Committee moved today in favor of putting on salaries ceilings with the same dates and controls as the law and Administration policy now apply to wages.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 -- Sir Owen Dixon, Australian Minister to the United States, in a Lincoln birthday address tonight eulogized the Civil War President as an upholder of "the common law which protects the citizen against the state and gives to all equal political rights."

"Lucky Jordan" today starts its fourth and final week at the Rialto ..."Snapphanar," the Swedish importation at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, begins a second week today... "Fantasia" will go into a twelfth week at the Little Carnegie Playhouse on Tuesday... "Now, Voyager" and a revival of the French film, "Amphytrion," will be shown today through Monday at the park Theatre.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Private industry must develop a plan for finding employment for 8,000,000 to 9,000,000 more persons after the war-than were employed in 1940, Marion B. Folsom, treasurer of Eastman Kodak Company, told a large luncheon meeting of the American Management Association's conference on manpower utilization here today.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Rumanian Government has communicated to United Nations officials that it is prepared to cooperate in transferring 70,000 Rumanian Jews from Trans-Dniestria to any refuge selected by the Allies, according to neutral sources here.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes asserted tonight that there had been "a revolt in Congress against the despicable tactics" of Chairman Martin Dies of the Committee on Un-American Activities.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- This is being written from Eight Ball Hill, behind which for seven weeks the boys from Brooklyn have been holding the position closest to Tunis in the American sector officially known as "Medjez East."

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 12 -- So far as can be ascertained, Australians will pay heavier war taxes than wage earners in any other of the United Nations under the schedule that Treasurer J.B. Chifely introduced yesterday, which represents a 30 per cent increase in income tax, the greater part of which again falls on the higher and middle incomes.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 12 - Wellingtons of the Royal Air Force are playing a large, hitherto unrecognized, part in the air offensive against German communications that is a prelude to the approaching, battle for Tunisia.

Shivering tenants in thirty-one Bronx and Washington Heights apartment houses, caught in the middle of a labor dispute that left them heatless and without hot water for the last three days, were rescued from an arctic atmosphere when an agreement was reached at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon between the operators of the buildings and the union involved calling off the strike begun last Wednesday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Criticizing the recent executive order for a forty-eight-hour week with provisions for time and a half pay for overtime as "unfair to the small employer," Senator Reed said today he would call up his own longer work week measure in the Senate within two weeks and that he considers its chances enhanced by the recent developments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The latest and most emphatic assertion of the claim of the Soviet Union to Bessarabia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania on the ground that they are legally a part of Russia is contained in an editorial in Pravda, which was circulated in English translation today by the Soviet Embassy in its information bulletin.

Warning that there was a critical shortage of farm labor in New York, Governor Dewey declared last night that the State had a plan to meet the emergency and keep up food production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Roane Waring, National Commander of the American Legion, urged on Congress today a pay-as-you-go income tax system which would embrace the skip-a-year feature of the Beardsley Ruml plan. A method should be adopted by which taxpayers should be "required to pay no more than one year's taxes in any one year," he telegraphed to the Ways and Means Committee.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Red Army of the Ukraine was reported officially tonight to have captured Krasnoarmeisk, a main rail junction twenty-five miles northwest of Stalino, thus threatening to trap some 500,000 Axis troops already hard pressed by other Russian units attacking in the Donets Basin and Rostov areas to the east.

Mal Clark of White Plains, who, among other things, attempts to keep tabs on the sportsmen's views in his and surrounding vicinities, has noticed more discussion and "more interest in the approaching trout season."

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The Japanese have made a series of sharp counter-attacks in the region of Donbaik and Rathedaung, above Akyab, in Northwestern Burma, but all have been thrown back by the British, a communiqu of the Indian Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Election of a President of Finland in Helsinki on Monday is expected clarify somewhat, though not to resolve, Finland's anomalous position as a democratic country that finds herself, much to her embarrassment, in the Axis camp.

WITH BRITISH COMMANDO TROOPS, on the Tunisian Front, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- Crack British Commando troops, supported by French soldiers, carried out a bold, successful raid on the Bizerte corner of Tunisia last night and prowled behind the enemy lines for hours, while British infantry carried out a simultaneous attack on the right flank, killing 200 Italians and capturing twenty Italians and several German officers.

The council on Books in Wartime has issued a second list of sixteen titles pertinent to the war and recommended for widespread distribution and reading. "This Time for Keeps," by John MacCormac (Viking), which was published yesterday, is on the list.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 12 -- President Roosevelt declared tonight that great Allied operations designed to drive the enemy into the Mediterranean Sea were imminent in Tunisia and would be followed by "actual invasions of the Continent of Europe."

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Home railway issues provided the feature in today's stock market operations. On the announcement of a dividend of 2 1/2 per cent on London, Midland Scottish stock, that issue jumped u1 as the dividend exceeded the market's expectations. Under this lead other home rail stocks naturally were firm, with Great Western gaining 1/2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today that it has acquired the short story, "The Last Night" by Storm Jameson, published three weeks ago in a national magazine. The story, dealing with a phase of the invasion of Czechoslovakia, is the first purchase by a studio of war material in which Nazi characters are shown with an awareness of ultimate defeat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Army today struck a heavy blow at football and other major college sports when it ruled that students under its new specialized training program at colleges and universities could not participate in inter-collegiate athletics.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 12 -- The union-management committee at the Vought-Sikorsky aircraft plant at Stratford conferred today on the question whether the management should remove the ban on the wearing of sweaters by women employes, but the committee got nowhere.

Bishop William T. Manning, head of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, made public last night a letter to the church press protesting against the "ecclesiastical intrusion" of the Archbishop of Canterbury (William Temple) in the controversy now going on in the Episcopal Church in this country over a proposed organic union with the Presbyterian Church.

Although West Side, Night and Week End Magistrates Courts were moved out of the West Side court house last December, after Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran had dubbed it "Pneumonia Hall," the old structure at 314 West Fifty-fourth Street has been burning fuel oil since Jan. 1 so much faster than its ration allowed that the two Municipal Courts which still use the building soon will have to move, too.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Lord Nuffield, Britain's largest philanthropist, announced today that he was founding a charitable trust to be known as the Nuffield Foundation and was handing over to its trustees shares in the Nuffield automobile manufacturing organization to the value of u10,000,000 as a capital fund.

MONTREAL, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The toll of the crash of a Royal Air Force Ferry Command bomber in Newfoundland Tuesday night increased to nineteen last night with the death of one of the injured, Ferry Command officials announced today.

The seven colleges that will compete in the metropolitan intercollegiate championships, to be held this year in conjunction with the New York A.C. track and field meet in Madison Square Garden next Saturday, will be represented by 265 individuals and seventeen relay teams, according to a tabulation made yesterday.

A number of wineries are discontinuing their low-priced brands in favor of new labels at higher prices, retail liquor dealers reported yesterday. Unable to replace stocks of the attractively priced items, the retailers generally asserted dissatisfaction in view of the consumer resistance to the higher liquor costs which was first noted following the imposition of increased Federal taxes.

The linings situation is becoming increasingly tight and promises to become a "bottleneck in the production of the large volume of Spring ready-to-wear orders which manufacturers have on their books. Actual shortages have not yet developed to any marked extent, but estimates yesterday indicated that the available supply of linings for Spring garments may run well under last year.

Gains ranging up to 25 and 30 per cent in sales over Lincoln's Birthday last year were reported by local stores yesterday as shopping spurted in response to contradictory reports from Washington on clothing rationing. Favorable weather also was a substantial factor in rolling up the largest holiday sales totals in many years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, left today for a tour of six South American countries emphasizing the importance to this country of economic development in Latin America.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 (AP) -- In the most exciting contest of the Fair Grounds meeting, Emerson Woodward's Valdina Orphan nosed out Harold Clark's Riverland and set a new track record in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Natchitoches Handicap today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 6 were 755,386 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 20,804 cars, or 2.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 28,576 cars, or 3.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 45,190 cars, or 6.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Air raid wardens in various sectors throughout the city have already held drills in preparation for their duties during alerts held after next Wednesday, when the new Army regulations become effective, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

The President's address last night was a report to the American people on the first great council of war to be held since the United Nations took the offensive. Like Mr. Churchill, who made a similar report to his own people on the preceding day, the President predicts with ringing confidence that before the year is over the decisions reached at Casablanca will be made known to the world "in actions rather than words."

Tentative plans were laid at a meeting of friends of China here yesterday for a series of nationwide appearances by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, who is expected soon to leave a New York hospital where she has been under treatment, according to The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) -- The problem of printing the news in a country at war was examined today by more than 200 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, meeting with government information and censorship officials.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 12 (AP) -- Secretary Knox declared tonight that the United States henceforth must maintain powerful sea and air forces and must have for them a system of bases stretching around the world.

New York City marked with traditional services yesterday the 134th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln. While war plants remained on full schedules for the day, exchanges, schools, courts and banks and a number of business houses closed.

Municipal Court Justice James W. Donoghue, class of 1914; Henry M. Gould, 1912, and George L. Cohen, 1909, received Alumni Service Medals for outstanding college service at the annual luncheon meeting of the City College Associate Alumni yesterday at the Hotel Edison.

Mr. Byrnes's remark that "paying more for extra work does not make for inflation" would be correct under one interpretation. It is correct that paying more for proportionately extra production does not make for inflation. This could be achieved through properly controlled piecework and other incentive payment systems.

Once again comes Arthur Dove, perennial harbinger of Spring. On a calendar count his annual one-man shows at An American Place, 509 Madison Avenue, may not always, as is the case this time, just precede the gusty advent of March.

The announcement by Colonel Matt Winn that the Kentucky Derby will be held On May 1 comes as good news to all racing fans, even though thousands who have been looking forward to their annual trip to Churchill Downs probably will be compelled to forego that pleasure because of the attendance restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- A third Congressional investigation of the Office of War Information's new magazine, "Victory," was in prospect today as Representative Taber of New York demanded that the House Appropriations Committee use its new inquisitorial powers to investigate the costs and purposes of "Victory" and other government publications.
Apartment houses and commercial properties changed hands in scattered trading reported yesterday in Manhattan. Four of the properties were sold by savings banks.
Fighting off Columbia's terrific closing spurt amid a bedlam of excitement, Pennsylvania defeated Columbia, 58 -- 55, in the Morningside Heights gym last night.

Today's events: "Boris Godunoff," 2 P.M., and "Il Trovatore," 8:30, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, 11 A.M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Ellen Ballon, piano, Town Hall, 3; Carl Friedberg, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Lotte Lehmann, oprano, McMillin Theatre, 8:30; Charles Libove, violin, The Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, 8:15.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 12 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill met the Finnish Minister to Ankara, Baron Yrjoe Koskinen, during his recent visit to Turkey and is believed to have received from him Finland's estimate of the possibilities of peace with Russia, advices from Helsinki said tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- An Army sentry at Port Newark fired a shot through a rear tire of a Public Service bus at 11:15 o'clock last night after the driver allegedly had disobeyed the soldier's command to halt. At the time the bus was carrying sixty workers to the plant of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at the port.

The possibility that Barnard College may be taken over by the Army or the Navy at any time was revealed yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve to Barnard alumnae at the annual Alumnae Day luncheon in Hewitt Hall.
PYOTE, Texas, Feb. 12 (AP) -- America's most honored unit of fighting airmen, the Nineteenth Bomb Group, broke up today for a new war assignment with every member officially proclaimed a hero.

In THE TIMES of Feb. 10 there appeared an interesting interview with George Ade, marking the seventy-seventh birthday of the noted humorist. He is reported to have compared his boyhood days in Indiana unfavorably with present times, saying "people used to be pretty primitive in those days.
One lend-lease program sponsored by sportsmen is apparently working smoothly and bringing the desired results. It has to do with ducks, and the organization responsible for it is Ducks Unlimited.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (U.P.) -Housewives were warned today by the Department of Agriculture that to transfer commercially canned foods into glass jars was a dangerous practice which might result in fatal food poisoning.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -Far from indicating a decrease in measures of persecution of the church in Germany, the present silence on that subject confirms reports of increased severity, according to an article appearing in a Reformed Church magazine just out.

Still in search of their first victory of 1943, the Rangers are confident that their quest will be ended tonight when they tackle the Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. Since they lost the services of their star play-maker, Syl Apps, the Leafs have been performing badly, and the Blueshirts are hopeful of capitalizing on their rivals' decline, just as the other teams in the loop have been doing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -The crash of an Army plane from Bolling Field, Washington, during unfavorable weather near Petersburg, Va., killed a lieutenant colonel and two enlisted men today, field officials announced.

Laurence Stillman, who is old Able's nephew and principal heir, does not tell Anthony why the body is not to be buried or removed, but Anthony learns in due time.

BACK in the old rowdy days, when the world was considerably younger, Jimmy Durante sang a shrill song to the effect that while he could do without Broadway, could Broadway do without him. Of recent days the answer to that one seemed to be yes, but last week either one side or the other obviously weakened for the good of all concerned.

GOOD fiction is scarce and likely to he scarcer as the war goes on. As a result a number of novels and stories that had their prospects wrecked through the unfortunate timing of their original publication are now being given a second chance.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Arsenal today gained a 1-0 victory over Tottenham before a crowd of 30,590, the largest to attend a league football game in London this season.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 13 -- The American conquest of Guadalcanal was officially described today as a "complete rout and utter defeat of a Japanese Army which executed a nonorderly withdrawal." The description came from Commander Ralph E. Wilson, a naval officer on the staff of Major Gen. Alexander M. Patch, commander of American troops on Guadalcanal. He spoke to amplify a report on the island campaign by General Patch.

To meet the demand for technically trained teachers and professors, colleges and universities throughout the United States are retraining their faculty members, offering them an opportunity to enter much needed fields.

EASTPORT, L.I., Feb. 13 -- A human chain composed of eight soldiers from near-by Camp Upton spanned eighty feet of icebound Eastport Pond here today and saved the lives of a 10-year-old boy and an Army private, the first link in the chain, who had fallen through the ice in the first attempt to rescue the boy.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force fell with destructive force on the Japanese in Burma yesterday and last night, bombing and strafing communications and other military targets up and down the country, a British communique said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Marine Corps Women's Reserve will start recruiting 18,000 enlisted women and 1,000 officers on Monday, Major Ruth Cheney Streeter, director, said at her first press conference today. With the three other members of the new reserve, she made her first appearance in trim uniform of forest green, with chin strap and muffler of brilliant red.

Retail trade gains were marked here last week, as the shoe rationing order touched off a broader demand for women's apparel and men's clothing. Volume on Lincoln's Birthday was particularly heavy. Reports of prospective rationing of clothing, which were later denied, stimulated heavy purchases of apparel.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 13 -In today's sports program involving six varsity events and four plebe contests, Army started in great style with a smashing victory over the Princeton trackmen, scoring two slams and piling up a total of 67 2-3 points to 14 2-3 for the Tigers.

Thomas Jefferson High's quintet cleared one more barrier in its big for the Section 1, Brooklyn, P.S.A.L. championship, when it routed Eastern District High, 37 to 19, at Madison Square Garden yesterday. A crowd of 6,000 watched the battle, curtain-raiser of the fifth scholastic quintuple-header of the season at the Eighth Avenue arena.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- How the General Maximum Price Regulation broke an inflationary rise in clothing prices is shown in an accompanying chart.

TWO of the group shows of the week brought together recent paintings by contemporary Americans. Both exhibitions are lively and varied. At the Montross Gallery are contrasting and quite arresting landscapes by Whitney Hoyt and Alan Brown, the former represented by a mountain vista lost in blue distance and the latter by a direct staccato piece and also by a large and accomplished still-life.

A double-barreled track meet will be on tap in Madison Square Garden Saturday night. It will be the seventy-fifth anniversary indoor meet of the New York A.C., and in addition to its own invitation events the Winged Foot win play host to the metropolitan intercollegiate championships, otherwise left homeless this year because of the war.

The outstanding feature of the fourth Young People's concert of the season, presented yesterday morning by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, was the performance of the first movement of Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole," by Kenneth Gordon, 13-year-old violinist, who made his debut as a concert soloist.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Official London has been pleasantly surprised at the comparative calm that has prevailed in India since Mohandas K. Gandhi began his latest fast in furtherance of his campaign to compel the British to "quit India."

One week from today the Eastern Dog Club will open its thirty-first annual show in Mechanics Building, Boston. This two-day competition will be the second of the important all-breed exhibitions of the year and, following Westminster so closely, usually attracts the stars who have made canine history in Madison Square Garden.

MOST people, including beginning gardeners, think of a lump of earth as an inert mass. The green-thumb gardener knows instinctively that soil is a living, sentient thing, but only the soil microbiologist, who sees with the eyes of a microscope, is fully aware of the enormous population and intense activity of the subterranean world.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 13 (AP) -An indictment charging the nation's largest food chain, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, with conspiracy to "monopolize a substantial part of trade and commerce in food and food products" was quashed today by Federal Judge W. H. Atwell after he had sustained a defense demurrer.

CARD parties continue as a popular means of augmenting the funds of various wartime enterprises and charitable organizations. Members of the Eighth Division of the American Women's Voluntary Services have arranged a card party in behalf of that organization for Tuesday afternoon in the Penthouse of the New Weston.
