BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- A surprise triumph by Frank Dixon in the George L. Hunter Trophy race, providing the New York University freshman with the first one-mile victory of his career in big-time competition, tonight highlighted the fifty-fourth annual Boston A.A. indoor games witnessed by 13,232 track fans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A supplemental list of fifty-one schools, colleges and universities has been approved by the Manpower Commission for use by the War and Navy departments for specialized war training programs. The institutions were selected by a committee composed of three representatives each from the Army, Navy and MWC.

Swiftly, inexorably, the Russian armies continue to drive toward the west. One supposedly impregnable Nazi stronghold after another falls before their assault, and the heroic defense of Stalingrad is being matched by the gallant conquest of Kursk, of Belgorod, of many other places, to which the Nazi keypoints of Rostov and Kharkov will soon be joined.

MIAMI GARDENS ON VIEW MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Members of the Miami Beach Garden Club have set aside every Sunday as a day on which different Miami Beach private flower gardens will be opened for inspection by service men, stationed here for training, and their wives.

GROUCHO MARX, the one who had the mustache, is coming to the airwaves next month with his own show via the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System (WABC). It will be a variety offering which also is expected to include the talents of Virginia O'Brien, the young lady who popularized "dead-pan singing"; Donald Dickson and Robert Armbruster's Orchestra.

Illuminating gas, seeping slowly through a leak in an underground main, asphyxiated yesterday three employes of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company and overcame a fourth employe and two members of rescue parties who descended into a gas-filled manhole at the corner of Quentin Road and McDonald Avenue in the Flatbush section to save four repairmen.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb 13 -- American and British troops in Tunisia are an expeditionary force in the process of becoming an army.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 13 -- About half a century ago a score of individual steel manufacturers in the United States decided to invade foreign markets. They agreed that if they combined into one solid group, directed by one head, their chance of selling would be better.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Rev. Charles V. Poling, 32 years old, who was pastor of the First Reformed Church, Schenectady, until he entered service as an Army chaplain in May, is missing in North Africa, according to word received today by his father, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, pastor of Baptist Temple.

The remainder of the art objects and furnishings, including valuable silverware and carpets, from the residence of Mrs. E. John Heidsieck in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., were sold at auction yesterday for $32,975. Total receipts for the entire sale, conducted in two sessions at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, were $48.142.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, composed principally of Indian business men, appealed today to the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, to release Mohandas K. Gandhi "unconditionally."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -Today the Germans have a stranglehold on the French press. This could be guessed from the general tenor of the newspapers, but there is confirmation now of the fact that in the past week, without notice, the Germans placed agents in every editorial room and every printing plant.

MISS MOATS went to Russia for Collier'svia Japan, China and the Burma Road, arriving in the Soviet capital six weeks before the German invasion and remaining in Russia during the critical early months of the German onslaught.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 13 -- During the battle for Buna stacks of empty yellow tin cans grew larger day by day at the field hospital and advance first aid stations in the American sectors. The cans were containers for blood plasma that had been drained into the veins of wounded American soldiers.

Yesterday's sloppy mixture of rain and snow, which was converted into an ankle-deep slush in the afternoon, is expected to prove hazardous today, as subfreezing temperatures are forecast. Moderately cold and moderately windy weather with temperatures between 25 and 30 degrees are predicted.

ON its Spring tour, starting March 14, the Orchestra of the New Friends of Music will be conducted by Otto Klemperer. Cities to be visited during the tour of the East and Middle West include New Bedford, Mass.; Binghamton and Albany, N.Y.; Sandusky and East Liverpool, Ohio, and Danville, Va.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt was urged today by Representative Joseph C. Baldwin, Republican, of New York to present to Congress immediately his legislative program for implementing the Atlantic Charter. He was speaking before the local branch of the Foreign Policy Association.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -Billy Cant, Pennsylvania's diving star, suffered his first setback of the season today as the Red and Blue was overwhelmed by Princeton's well-balanced swimming team, 62 -- 13.

THE reader, recently grown accustomed to ponderous novels of a thousand pages, may think this book by Gale Wilhelm curiously small and thin. So it is, in mere physical size -- no more than a neat fit for a woman's handbag or a man's coat pocket. It is not, by that token, either brief or slight in emotional impact.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 13 (U.P.) -Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell, a reluctant witness before the Chavez Committee of the United Sates Senate, agreed today to prepare a comprehensive, detailed report on Puerto Rico -- "covering whatever the committee wanted."

ALBANY, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senator Desmond of Newburgh said today that five bills were being prepared to strengthen the civil service merit system, including one to require investigation of statements by job applicants.

Murder has been done, and Kirk Murray has been tried, found guilty and sentenced to death. In a few weeks his wife will be a widow unless she can discover the person who really killed Mia Mercer. The only clues are a matchbook cover and four names with telephone numbers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -Production of soft coal rose to a two-year high record last week, according to Harold L. Ickes, Fuel Coordinator.

Confusion marked the wholesale markets here last week as manufacturers and retailers sought to adjust themselves to the revival of scare buying of clothing which followed the shoe-rationing order, and to contradictory reports on further rationing, manpower shortages and rumored freezing of apparel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 13 -- A "Sergeant York school" for instruction of semi-literate and unschooled soldiers from backwoods areas such as produced the first World War hero has been organized at the Army Air Forces basic training center here, it was announced today by Colonel Robert P. Glassburn, commanding officer.

ROBERT LYND was lunching recently with three other men, all of them eminent in the world of letters, and never has he heard disagreement expressed about the work of authors whose fame is Supposed to have been established for all time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Under the President's Executive Order calling for a forty-eight-hour work week the eight-hour day and the five-day week will vanish generally from the American scene with some exceptions, mainly for small employers, according to a spokesman for the War Manpower Commission.

ANOTHER consumer buying boom has been touched off, it was plainly evident in the week, as a result of the awkward handling of rationing in canned foods and shoes and the cumulative effect of the Washington statements about "bedrock" and minimum civilian requirements.

Activity in the apparel and piece goods markets was unprecedented last week because of scare buying inspired by the shoe-rationing order, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

BASEBALL contracts either are in the mails or in a process of preparation. In ordinary years they were the seeds from which the holdouts blossomed. It always was a bumper crop, too, although those horticultural experts, the magnates, never were able to appreciate either the bud or the flower.

THOUSANDS of soldiers at this Army post recently were invited to join the Waacs and/or otherwise participate in National Women at War Week. The invitation came from the screens of the four War Department theatres on the post, via a trailer inserted by one of the newsreel companies in its regular footage.

The Japanese announced yesterday that they had lost nineteen warships and ten merchantmen in a half year of campaigning in waters off New Guinea and the Solomons and made the wholly unconfirmed claim that ninety-eight Allied warships and thirty-three cargo carriers had been destroyed in those seas from Aug. 7 to Feb. 7.

A new health service for Netherlands seamen, a completely equipped polyclinic occupying fourteen rooms at 61 Broadway, will begin to operate on March 1, it was announced yesterday by Adrian Gips, chairman of the Netherland Shipping Committee. Treatment and service in the clinic will be free to all men sailing in Netherlands vessels.

The Boxing Writers Association of New York will pay tribute to Barney Ross Wednesday night and through him, to the ringmen of the past and present, prominent and obscure, who have responded to the call to the flag.

HUNDREDS of thousands of young men and women are annually privileged to receive the benefits of an education in the liberal arts and in the humanities in the colleges of our nation. The present international crisis has brought about a threat to the study of music and to some of the teachers of music in these institutions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (Science Service) -- When we are able to travel by sleeper plane again, we shall find a new seating arrangement that will make for greater convenience and comfort, as well as greater privacy in preparing to retire, thanks to a seating arrangement on which United States patent No. 2-310,573 has just been issued to a Los Angeles aircraft designer, Edward F. Burton.

In our Magazine today certain extracts from Jefferson's writings are printed. Each one contains some principle or principles that the mere mention of his name calls up in any informed mind. Most persons are, of course, familiar with the Declaration of Independence.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -- The Geneva office of the World Council of Churches has just issued an eleven-point memorandum on the agreements and disagreements existing between the churches and members of the Ecumenical Council "for the purpose of clarifying issues for further discussion in preparation for the elaboration of a just and durable peace."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- A group of Representatives demanded today an inquiry into the government's motives in curtailing the use of paper by newspapers, magazines and other publications.

In response to urgent appeals from Washington, the National Retail Dry Goods Association moved promptly yesterday to head off a clothing buyers' rush believed to have been started by public statements of Donald M. Nelson, WPB director, variously construed as a forecast of clothing rationing. Mr. Nelson has finally asserted there is no need to ration clothing.

AN AIR FORCE REST CAMP, Tunisia, Feb. 13 -- When pilots of the Twelfth United States Army Air Force line up along the bar in the evening before dinner, one feels that one has done all this and seen them all before. Then one remembers that those fellows wore the light blue of the Royal Air Force and that we drank in a little pub along the road from Lille to Roubaix.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The tenderest of holidays found the American service men in Britain strictly on their own when it came to composing valentine messages. Yanks who had expected to rely on old-fashioned "canned" sentiments were disappointed because the cable companies failed to augment the regular list of censored expeditionary force messages for the occasion.

The National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, representing a large part of the nation's dairy industry, yesterday called upon the Federal Government to "abandon the prematurely conceived and short-sighted policy of freezing producer prices of milk at the January price level."

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Trading in wheat futures was quiet today and prices held within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade. A small early upturn disclosed orders to sell May at $1.40 1/2 a bushel in the hands of commission houses, and professional traders turned to the selling side and found support only fair.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- "Grave losses" to the war program would result if Detroit abandoned Eastern War Time status, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, warned today in a letter urging the City Council not to follow the rest of Michigan in setting clocks back an hour on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -The War Department reported today the names of 110 United States soldiers missing in action.

Several months ago, at a time when the differences in economic and religious views between Americans and the Soviet Government seemed perhaps a damper on complete cooperation on our part, THE NEW YORK TIMES was good enough to print a letter from me urging that, as Russia had again become our ally, as in World War I, it was vital for our own sake that we should render her all possible support.

MR. HOLLING, whose beautiful and original "Paddle-to-the-Sea" was received with enthusiasm by boys and girls and their elders when it appeared about a year ago, has again painted in words and pictures a colorful picture of a section of this country and its development during a stirring and picturesque period.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Allied troops ambushed a patrol of sixty Japanese marines in the Wandumi area of New Guinea yesterday, wiping out thirty-two of them in the first action involving enemy marines in this area, the Allied Command reported today.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 13 -Anthracite operators agreed today to start negotiations with the United Mine Workers for a new contract before March 22, the time limit suggested by Harold Ickes, Solid Fuels Coordinator, so that there would be no interruption of production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Reports were current here tonight that Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, had decided to dismiss Ferdinand E. Eberstadt, vice chairman, who has charge of allocating raw materials to war factories.
MONTREAL, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Two goals by Elmer Lach powered the Canadiens to a 5 -- 2 victory over Detroit in a National Hockey League game at the Forum tonight.

WOMEN in the U.S.S.R. are accorded equal rights with men in all spheres of economic, state, cultural, social and political life. . . . To defend the Fatherland is the sacred duty of every citizen of the U.S.S.R. -- From the Constitution of the U.S.S.R.

Employers in the city may have wondered where their receptionists and stenographers were yesterday morning. There was only one place they could have been. Bloomingdale's had advertised that every customer who bought a bond was entitled to buy two pairs of nylon stockings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, rebuked by Bishop William T. Manning of New York for writing a note commenting on the proposed organic union of Protestant Episcopal and Presbyterian churches in this country, was stoutly defended here today by Bishop Edward L. Parsons, retired, as being entitled to hold keen interest in church unity in the United States and throughout the world.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- Young George Platter of Buffalo cared little for the depth charges that nearly knocked him out of his bunk aboard a submarine in Japanese controlled waters one recent morning. Only 21, he had just undergone an emergency operation for appendicitis performed on him by First Class Pharmacists' Mate Thomas A. Moore of Chino Valley, Ariz., who is but a year older than his patient.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, was assisted by the women's chorus of the Sarah Lawrence College (William Schuman, director) when it performed Debussy's setting of Rossetti's "Blessed Damozel" yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

The 158th meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers will be held here this week, beginning tomorrow, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. More than 2,500 of the institute's 15,164 members are expected to attend.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The size of the average British family must be increased considerably after the war to maintain the population near its present level, but at the same time there should be an improved social order that will provide better standards of living and better educational opportunities generally, Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, said today.

Making a plea for cooperation and understanding among religious and racial minority groups in this country, Dr. Willard Johnson, assistant to the president, National Conference of Christians and Jews, warned against the growth of "hate movements" after the war.

THOMAS J. HAMILTON went to Spain in August, 1939, shortly after England had underlined her then appeasement policy by the haste with which she recognized a regime brought into power through military insurrection and Axis aid. His orders -- he was on the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES -- were to write what he saw with complete impartiality.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- To the late Lieutenant Clark A. Hood Jr., 30 years old, of Nocona, Texas, went official Navy recognition today for his heroism in delivering the first bomb attack against Japanese ships in Kiska Harbor in the Aleutian Islands.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Kharkov, Germany's defense hub for the entire Eastern Ukraine, was within reach of Russian artillery from three sides and all its main railway communications were cut by Red Army advances pounding into the suburbs, two communiques recorded by the Soviet radio monitor indicated tonight.

The Household Finance Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net income of $5,231,041 in 1942, or $5.99 each on 722,506 shares of capital stock, according to a report issued yesterday. For 1941 the net profit was $5,362,942, equivalent to $6.11 a share on 730,407 common shares.

Alexander Kipnis, Russian-born basso of the Metropolitan, who became an American citizen a good many years ago, brought his authority and knowledge of the traditions to his first appearance here in the title role of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" at the Opera House yesterday afternoon.

AT a luncheon of the Musicians Emergency Fund in the St. Regis Hotel a report by Mrs. Lytle Hull, president of the New Opera Company, dealing with the company's activities was read by Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, executive director of the fund and general manager of the New Opera, who said that the opera company was a direct outgrowth of the fund, since experience there had taught how few were the opportunities for talented young artists.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 13 -The Naval Academy and University of Virginia fives battled on even terms for most of their game today, with the midshipmen driving in the last seven minutes of play to win by 50 to 41.

Thousands of self-styled subway alumni, who trooped into Madison Square Garden last night to cheer the Notre Dame basketball team against N.Y.U., left the arena hoarse. For the Irish quintet, putting on the pressure early, subjected the Violets to one of the most severe setbacks ever inflicted upon them. It was no contest.

TORONTO, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Chicago dropped a 3-2 verdict to Toronto tonight before 11,360 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens, thereby imperilling its prospects of overhauling the Stanley Cup champions in the drive for the National Hockey League's third spot.

A torpedoed merchant seaman, who took command of a party of twenty-one castaways crowded on a life raft and, disdaining to rest or sleep, brought them to safety after four days and nights, was rewarded yesterday with the Merchant Marine's highest honor, the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Harvard rallied in the second half tonight behind Captain George Burditt, playing his farewell game, and defeated Princeton, 36 to 32, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest. It was Princeton's first defeat in four circuit games.
OTTAWA, Feb. 13 -- Canada spent during January nearly $6,000,000 a day for war and the prospects are that her 11,500,000 population will have to face this year a budget of over $5,000,000,000.

FROM the Director General of Posts and Telegraphs, at Helsinki, information mailed in Finland several months ago reached New York last week. Finland placed in circulation on Oct. 10 two stamps to commemorate the 300th anniversary of "la typographie" and "la litterature" of that nation.

Over in England there is talk of detailing a fleet of jeeps, with American soldiers at the wheel, to help with the Spring plowing. Not a bad idea, from any angle. Farmers over here have been itching to get their hands on a jeep to plow their gardens, bring in the cows from the back pasture, mow the front lawns and tote the eggs and milk to town.

Crowded shoe departments and an active demand for suits, coats and dresses featured retail trade last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

THE last few weeks have seen a group of war plays burst like shrapnel over Broadway. For the most part they opened, spoke their pieces and departed rather hurriedly, as though pursued by the furies. Roughly 70 per cent of the office positions vacated here in 1942 by men leaving for the armed services were filled by women, while relatively few replacements were made by hiring men over 45 years old, according to a survey just completed by the New York chapter of the National Office Management Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13 -Scoring three goals in the opening period, Yale's hockey team tonight downed Princeton by 4 -- 2 for its second Pentagonal League victory in four starts. It was the fifth defeat in six circuit games for the Tigers.
EL PASO, Texas -- Down in the sagebrush hills and the mesquite thickets of the great Southwest even the tourists are substituting war work this Winter for their usual campfire camaraderie.

FAMILY treasures donated by many persons of prominence will be placed on sale Tuesday at the reopening of the British War Relief Society's Piccadilly Arcade, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, as a means to aid the organization's civilian relief program in England.

FIGHTING GASOLINE -- Now that the Standard Oil Company and Houdry have told us all about their high-octane gasoline, the Universal Oil Products Company announces one of its own. It is made by grafting two carbon atoms into the structure of certain hydrocarbon compounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The war against inflation was at a crucial stage this week.

SIX short stories, each a little over fifty pages long, make up Faith Baldwin's new book, "Washington, U.S.A." All of them are concerned with the wartime activities of young women and young men in Washington.

In place of a porterhouse there may be a slice of flank; instead of a rib roast, a piece of chuck or shank or neck.

LILIES OF THE VALLEY have always been noted not only for their charming, fragrant May-blooming flowers but also for their thrifty qualities, including a preference for shaded locations. WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- No "holiday" in the production of industrial alcohol by the beverage spirits industry to permit replenishment of distilled spirits stocks is planned at present, WPB announced today. UTICA, Feb. 13 -- More than sixteen feet of snow have fallen at Old Forge thus far this year, according to Roy Studor, super intendent of the United States Meteorological Station.

SAN FRANCISCO; Feb. 13 -Harry Bridges says the Federal District Court decision this week rebuffing him in his fight against deportation will not take him and his supporters "off the beam" in their war efforts. In this he follows a tack which he has consistently pursued ever since Pearl Harbor.

THE service men's recreation committee of the Smith College Club of New York will give a Valentine party for officers in the armed forces of the United Nations on Tuesday evening in the club's headquarters at the Hotel Weylin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -With each editor sworn to secrecy, members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors learned today about the war on the foreign and home fronts direct from leaders of the Army and Navy.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- Collaboration between Western Europe and the United States, making possible a post-war approach to the problem of freedom from want from a world-wide angle, was advocated tonight by Maximilian Paul Leon Steenberghe, chairman of the Mission as the Kingdom of the Netherlands, as the key to enduring universal prosperity.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Mathew Smith, secretary of the Mechanics Educational Society of America, was ordered today to appear before the first session of the regional War Labor Board Monday to explain his statements that members of his independent union were striking at war plants here in protest against lack of representation on the WLB.

PUBLIC education in point rationing will be carried on at Y.W.C.A. branches throughout the city where booths will be set up. Here trained women will be on hand to help those wrestling with the new regulations.

DOWN the Mississippi again this Spring and Summer will float the Gordon C. Greene, well-known to vacationists who have shipped on the leisurely river boat in past years. The first cruise leaves Cincinnati April 10, the trip to New Orleans and return taking twenty days.

IT is always a treat to discover a plant, hitherto not much used, that will grow and bloom successfully in a dry, sunny spot that has been something of a problem in the home garden. From the long list of sedums, commonly known as stonecrops, flowers or attractive foliage may be found for such a location.

BERNARD SHAW'S remark that "Sullivan has been gaining ground and Gilbert losing it since they died" has offended the sensibilities of many a loyal Savoyard. One of them, James G. WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Bomber production at the huge Willow Run bomber plant owned by the government and run by the Ford Motor Company is meeting the current War Department schedule but the present output is only "a small fraction" of the plant's ultimate potential, the Office of War Information said today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- The work American women are doing in the war effort, the opportunities open to women today, and the social problems arising out of the war emergency will be the topics of discussion at Vassar College next week-end, Feb. 19 to 21, in a three-day conference under the auspices of the college's political association.

ALLIED HEAQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 13 -- British infantry and guns have knocked back an attack by German troops, probably supported by tanks, in the familiar battle grounds on the hills east of the Ousselat Valley, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Damage was inflicted by American bombers on Japanese bases in the Central Solomon Islands area in a series of four attacks yesterday (Solomons time) the Navy announced today.

The latest move to modify the Presidential executive order limiting salaries to $25,000, after deducting income taxes, is contained in a bill introduced last Wednesday in the House of Representatives by Representative Disney of Oklahoma.

Twenty-four hours after receiving the full impact of the Army ban on soldier-students participating in intercollegiate athletics, college sports leaders yesterday generally were clinging to the hope that a way will be found to continue their activities at least on a small scale in 1943.

Believing that colleges for women are very much in the war, Hunter College has revised its course of study. In so doing we have tried to be as practical and realistic as possible. Most girls should, we think, remain on the campus at least until the end of the sophomore year if only because comparatively few of them will be more than 18 then.

A total of 114 registrations by freshmen in the largest entering class for February in the day classes at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, 85 Livingston Street, has brought the total of all registrants to 656, according to Dean Ernest J. Streubel, who announced yesterday they would attend classes through the Summer.

A dispatch to this newspaper from A.C. Sedgwick at Cairo reveals a factory more than 1,500 miles long spread out behind General Montgomery's veterans. All the way back to Alexandria the roadside workshops are busy refitting damaged equipment, repacking captured supplies and reconditioning newly arrived materiel, so the Eighth Army may continue its advance.

FOR many years American gardens have stressed flowers. Therefore today's trend toward the practical, with larger and larger areas devoted to vegetables and fruits, is -- quite aside from the present emergency -- a wholesome manifestation.

THOSE collectors who are fond of the music of Sibelius have two of his symphonies at their disposal among the new recordings of the month. The First in E minor is played by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra directed by John Barbirolli (Columbia M-532, five 12-inch records).

Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill reported last week to their nations on the "unconditional surrender" conference held for ten days in January at Casablanca. From these reports there emerged a blueprint for Allied strategy in 1943.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 13 -Wherever farmers congregate, the big topic of conversation today is the shortage of farm hands. From Waterville, Me., to Visalia, Calif., seven out of every ten farmers consider the labor shortage the most difficult thing about running a farm this year.

From London comes word that "new issues of Fighting French stamps, both provisional and definitive, may be expected from Madagascar, Reunion and French Somaliland in the near future."

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday followed the trend that has prevailed for two weeks. Routine fixations by the trade were offset by near-month liquidation and transferals from old-crop to new-crop months. The list of active contracts closed mixed, 1 point lower to 5 points higher than on Thursday, after having fluctuated narrowly in the dull two-hour session.

DORIS HUMPHREY, who writes as well as she dances, has been gracious enough to reply to the implied query in these columns a few weeks ago about her possible reasons for presenting and (except for Jose Limon's "Chaconne") composing a whole evening's program to music of Bach.

HE'S going up the barracks steps, that guy whose shoulders bear the bright gold bars. He's entering the door. Inside some one yells, "Atten-HUT!" Instantly the gent with the bars snaps to rigid position, heels together, chin well in. After a few moments he glances around uneasily to find every one else at attention, too, including three shivering, stoical privates who stand stark naked.

In line with intensified emphasis on post-war planning some manufacturers of industrial equipment will now accept orders for post-war delivery, chiefly to give customers a priority rating in what is expected to be a period of chaotic purchasing, it was learned last week.

THIS unpretentious little volume, the work of an Englishman who has traveled a good deal in Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco, comes opportunely from the press. It is cut of date only in that the author could not foresee the landing of the American forces and the arrival of Rommel and his British pursuers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Senators generally today saw little chance of an immediate United Nations agreement on any detailed post-war program, although some expressed hope for a settlement soon on "basic principles."

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY IN TUNISIA, Feb. 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- Copies of a German propaganda newspaper entitled Adler im Sueden, or Eagle in the South, which furnishes political and military dispatches from Berlin to German air and naval forces in North Africa and the Mediterranean, have fallen into the hands of American Army officers.

THE White House Guards, in their khaki uniforms and with white accessories and gleaming bayonets, may not be as colorful and glamorous as the centuries-old guards at Buckingham Palace, with their scarlet jackets and bearskins, but commanding officers of this yearling outfit will match them with any military police force in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Thirteen rationing programs, ten of them covering items of everyday importance to the average American, are now in operation through the United States. A year ago the number of rationed commodities totaled two. They were tires and automobiles.

SYRACUSE, Feb. 13 -- New York State is urged to revert to Eastern standard time, because wartime "is causing hardship and economic loss to farm people," a resolution adopted today by the Onondaga County Farm Bureau, declared.

It has been praised by kings, premiers, first ladies, politicians, naval men, newspaper critics, prep school boys, the carriage trade and our hired help.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Office of War Information, directed by Elmer Davis, has encountered serious criticism for the first time since it supplanted and absorbed the Office of Facts and Figures, of which Archibald MacLeish was the director, just eight months ago today. That is a long honeymoon period for an Administration agency.

Clare Boothe Luce, Republican Representative from Connecticut, whose "globaloney" slap at Vice President Wallace caused some uproar in Washington, explained last night what she really meant when she talked of America's future in the air after the war.

A few weeks ago the art world was startled to learn that the Whitney Museum of American Art, in Eighth Street, would go out of existence, its extensive collection -formed over a period of years -absorbed by the Metropolitan. Housed in what will be known as the Whitney Wing, this art is to be merged with the Metropolitan's own growing collection of contemporary American art acquired through the Hearn Fund.

Now that the first excitement over the Allied expedition to North Africa and the political complications resulting therefrom has abated, and the various parties and personalities involved are settling down to coping with the larger tasks in hand, there is a noticeable improvement in both the atmosphere and the trend of events in that Allied base for the projected European invasion.

IN this third of his annual reviews of the war Professor Edgar McInnis has undertaken to compress within a few hundred pages the salient events of one of the most crowded and bewildering years in human history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- News from Turkey, Spain and Italy this week supplies accumulating evidence of the continuing and widening repercussions of the Allied display of might in North Africa which, coupled with the Russian offensive and the expectation of an Allied landing in Southeastern Europe, has shaken the shores of the Mediterranean like an earthquake.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Diverse pay-as-you-go income-tax proposals, presented during nearly two weeks of open hearings, were ready tonight for consideration in executive session by the Ways and Means Committee. Two compromises of the Ruml plan apparently vie for the committee's favor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The island of Guadalcanal became in the past week an American outpost, with Japanese resistance broken throughout its malarial swamps and rain-soaked hills. But there is great danger that the victory now accomplished will be overemphasized in relation to its importance in our war with Japan.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 13 -With a superbly balanced team performance, the skiers of New Hampshire came from behind today to nose out Dartmouth and take the title in both the Intercollegiate Ski Union championship meet and the thirty-fourth annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival.

Craig S. Vincent, Atlantic Coast representative of the recruitment and manning organization of the War Shipping Administration, announced last night that its field representatives would step up the campaign to bring back to the sea thousands of former seamen now in shore jobs, and that applicants would be interviewed this week at offices of the United States Employment Service in the metropolitan area.

In a second-semester expansion of wartime instruction, several new war courses have been added to the curriculum of the College of New Rochelle. Offered for college credit, these courses have been added to the non-credit defense courses to be continued from last semester.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- So immense are the Red Army's achievements in its Winter campaign that one tends to lose sight of the part played by the individual Russian soldier in its accomplishment. Yet it is on his stanchness and matchless courage that the victory is being built and upon him depends how far the Red Army can continue its advance as Winter relinquishes its grasp in South Russia.

GUADALCANAL, Feb. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two old Hollywood friends, Commander Gene Markey, writer-producer, and Lieutenant Robert Montgomery, film star, had a reunion today far from cinemaland's bright lights and sound stages.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null denied yesterday a petition of theatre brokers in this city to have him declare unconstitutional the State law which limits theatre ticket premiums to 75 cents a ticket.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -The Federal Government and the C.I.O. appealed to war workers today to put a halt to absenteeism, saying that the "I'll-take-a-dayoff" practice had doubled since the start of the war.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- The entire German position in the Donets basin was crumbling tonight. Two of the region's most important cities, Slavyansk, with its salt deposits and chemical works, and Voroshilovgrad, with huge gas generating plants, were isolated by rail.

A complete breakdown of negotiations in London between the Greek Government and representatives of the Greek seafarers for a new collective agreement was reported here yesterday by the New York office of the Greek Seamen's Union.

The Horticultural Society of New York will have its monthly flower show and lecture on Wednesday at 2:30 P.M. in the rooms of the society, 598 Madison Avenue. T.H. Everett will speak on "Growing Vegetables."

An overwhelming majority of Americans are in favor or immediate planning for the post-war era rather than waiting until the war is won, the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday. WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Temporary provisions to fit the sugar and coffee rationing regulations into the new rationing programs for restaurants, hotels and other "institutional users" were announced today by the Office of Price Administration, effective yesterday.

He mentioned the British Association for the Advancement of Science's studies of 1919 which directed attention to the possibilities of (1) a dead language, for example, Latin; (2) a national language, like English, or, (3) an artificial language, like Esperanto or Ido.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Ten Republicans and five Democrats of the Ways and Means Committee forced the reporting to the House today of the Disney bill to repeal President Roosevelt's order holding annual salaries to a maximum of $25,000 net and establish ceilings at Pearl Harbor day levels by statute in its place.

FACTS stranger than any fiction would dare to be form the basis of Victoria Wolf's novel "Spell of Egypt"; the facts concerning the discovery of the tomb of Tut-ankh-Amen. For the purposes of her narrative the author turns the tomb into that of an imaginary Pharaoh whom she calls Tutenophis and describes as a son-in-law of Akh-en-aten.

QUEBEC -- After a succession of heavy blizzards, Canada's ancient capital, Quebec, is covered by a veritable mountain of snow piled high along the main thoroughfares. On Grande Allee, the most exclusive of residential streets, narrow paths have been cut as access to residences, with the snow rising three or four feet on each side.

Chamberlain, chairman of the Department of Sociology an Anthropology announced yesterday.

The central character, played by Miss Hayes, is Harriet Beecher Stowe, whom Lincoln called "the little lady who made this great war," and the play's action concerns her mature life.

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Feb. 13 (U.P.) -- One of two Army fighter planes missing since Thursday on a flight from Providence, R.I., to Groton, Conn., has been found in fifty-eight feet of water at the south end of Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island, the Army announced here today.

THE Philadelphia Opera Company, a small, compact company, now in its fifth season, is an organization which will bear watching. All the singers, chorus and orchestra are Americans. NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- While awaiting a showdown between members of the farm bloc, who have expressed renewed determination to force a higher price parity for basic farm products, and the Administration, which has called for no increase in farm prices and firm opposition to any increase in parities, the cotton market here stood almost motionless last week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Rookie Wingy Johnston, who has been hugging the bench most of the season, tonight made two quick goals during the closing minutes of the last period and gave the Black Hawks a 3-2 National Hockey League victory over the front-running Boston Bruins before a crowd of 14,921 at the Chicago Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- A detailed explanation of why lend-lease aid to China has lagged, with transportation difficulties given as the principal cause, was offered by J. Franklin Ray, Chief of the Chinese branch, Office of Lend-Lease Administration, in a report to the House Foreign Affairs Committee, made public today.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 14 -- Balloting in the Presidential election, which had been going on every Saturday and Sunday since Jan. 16, ended at 6 P.M. today. Although the official results are not available, it is a foregone conclusion that President Higinio Morinigo has been returned for the 1943-48 term, as he was the only candidate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- American aircraft manufacturers turned out $5,000,000,000 worth of airplanes, engines and propellers during 1942, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce reported tonight. The dollar-volume of deliveries meanwhile mounted to $1,750,000,000, an increase of 186 per cent over 1941.

Secretary Knox's recommendations for insular air and naval bases in the Pacific afford a timely reminder of the shortsightedness and lack of vision of our representatives at the Paris Peace Conference of 1898, as a result of which Spain ceded to the United States the Philippines and Guam, retaining her other Pacific possessions, including the Carolines, Ladrones (Marianas) and Marshall Islands.

In his radio speech last week Mr. Byrnes made a great point of adhering to the "Little Steel" wage formula. "There must be no further increases in wages beyond the Little Steel formula," he said, "except in limited and special cases to correct patently gross inequities and to rectify plainly substandard wages."

The German radio broadcast a report last night that all night clubs in Paris, with the exception of the four largest ones, including the Tabarin and the Casino de Paris, had been closed for the week Feb. 14-21, The Associated Press reported.

Speedier action by the Board of Transportation on grievances presented by employes of the city's unified transit lines, taken in the light of "human relationships" rather than court decisions and legal technicalities, is recommended by the board's impartial grievance committee in its first annual report, made available yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A personal Valentine arrived today at the home of Pharmacist's Mate Wheeler B. Lipes Jr., credited with performing the first appendectomy aboard a submerged United States submarine.

A double check on violations of the 57-cents-a-pound price ceiling on butter was promised yesterday as Mayor La Guardia announced that the city would prosecute all overcharge cases that come to the attention of the Department of Markets.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, Southwest Pacific Area, Feb. 13 (AP) -- For acts of gallantry ten officers and men of the Thirty-second Division have received Silver Stars.
The German news agency told of the Russian victories in a broadcast recorded by Reuter in London as follows:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 14 -- The American aerial offensive against German communications, which may be regarded as the first stage of the final Allied battle for Tunisia, continued with marked success yesterday when six enemy transport planes were sent flaming into the sea and the airfield at El Aouina, near Tunis, was heavily bombed by Marauders.

An intellectual belief in God is insufficient; He should be a power emotionally experienced, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon, "On Feeling That God Is Real," in the Riverside Church.

Federal income taxpayers are urged to read carefully all the instructions accompanying the income tax forms before preparing their returns. If they need help in computing their tax liabilities they can get it without cost by consulting the nearest collector of internal revenue, deputy collector or internal revenue agent in charge.

Beginning with a series of Nazi defeats in Russia, last week brought news of the Japanese withdrawal from long-contested Guadalcanal and continuance of the shake-up of Italian Ministerial personnel. Probably Germany had insisted on the ousting of the very numerous officers who were sick of Nazi domination and wished an end of it.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Anthony Callipare of Rochester and Miss Laverne Dahm of Cleveland shared honors today at the Great Lakes speed skating championships by winning, respectively, the senior men's and women's all-events titles.

DAWSON CREEK, B.C., Feb. 14 (AP) -- A raging fire punctuated by powerful explosions killed three persons, left six missing, from 125 to 150 injured and wiped out an entire block of this northern railhead town last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Postoffice Department disclosed today that it plans to employ a large number of women, but probably not as letter carriers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, emphasizing that he was speaking only for himself, declared in an interview here today that he was opposed to overtime pay for the forty-eight-hour week during the war.

The New York Rovers, matching all three of the Hub team's goals in the third period, snapped out of a four-game losing streak yesterday afternoon by downing the Boston Olympics, 6 to 3, in the star battle of an Eastern Amateur Hockey League twin bill at Madison Square Garden.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 14 -- On the eve of the Finnish Presidential election tomorrow reports from Helsinki presage a close race between the incumbent, Risto Ryti, and Field Marshal Baron Karl Gustav Mannerheim. Among the "dark horses" -- which are the rule rather than the exception in Finnish Presidential elections -- there is much talk of General Rudolf Walden.

Every home on the 2,985 blocks of the Borough of Manhattan will be visited in an intensive block canvass through which 25,000 volunteer workers will endeavor to raise at least $1,000,000 of New York City's quota of $12,920,700 when the Red Cross War Fund drive opens next month, it was announced yesterday.

A 19-year-old English boy who was injured aboard a Swedish ship died in a hospital here on June 23. The boy's mother, a resident of Grimsby, England, wrote to Mayor La Guardia asking him to find out "what his accident was, if he died peacefully, and where and what kind of a burial he had."

The new wave of consumer scare buying in some sections of the country, which was set off by the shoe-rationing order, was reflected in the wholesale markets by a greater anxiety among retailers over the growing difficulty in placing reorders, according to a summary of the week's activity prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Two games were played yesterday in the tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club. Alvin C. Cass won from Walter Goldwater and Joseph Richman defeated John W. Barnhart.

A ruling just issued by the New York headquarters of Region 2, Office of Price Administration, says parents may use automobiles to take their children to dancing and music schools where lessons are given as a part of, or consist of, a regular and recognized course of study.

The Philip Carey Manufacturing Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, maker of roofing materials and insulation, has purchased a thirty-five-acre tract in Perth Amboy, N.J., from the city of Perth Amboy. The property fronts on Raritan Bay and adjoins the Pardee Tile Works, at Ninth Street and Victory Bridge, which was purchased in June, 1941, by the Ohio concern through the Louis Schlesinger Company, broker in the purchase of the additional property.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- This Adirondack village, which pioneered in Winter sports back in 1904, is enjoying a sustained period of the finest snow conditions in twenty years. From the first week in December, Lake Placid has had frequent snowfalls and continuous freezing weather, thus providing enthusiasts with superb skiing ever since.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Office of Price Administration today issued a manual containing digests of interpretations of knotty problems relating to regulations covering maximum fees charged for services.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Following the continuance of inactive and somewhat heavy conditions in the stock markets in the early part of last week, a definite brightening in sentiment and some increase in business occurred at the week-end.

It begins to appear as if only a ceiling on individual scoring will stop Harry (Big Boy) Boykoff, the St. John's superman. As basketball players go, Harry, the 6-foot 9-inch sophomore sensation, does not rank as the greatest. Defensively he has some shortcomings, but in the offensive department of the sport few men in this section, or anywhere else, approach the big fellow.

Immediate expansion of the social security system on a comprehensive basis that would include everybody and provide benefits not offered under the present Social Security Act was urged yesterday by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, as a means of implementing the war objective of freedom from want and as an essential element of post-war reconstruction.

William B. Given Jr., president of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company, has submitted to stockholders the report of the company for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1942. It shows a net profit of $2,991,459, or $3.22 a share on 769,092 shares of common stock, after preferred dividends.

The Salvation Army estimated yesterday that it would need $768,500 for operations in metropolitan New York in the fiscal year 1943-44, in addition to the amounts raised from its various income-producing activities. The announcement was made by Commissioner Ernest I. Pugmire, commanding the Eastern territory, in a publication issued by the 1943 Salvation Army campaign.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mayor La Guardia will be among the speakers at a memorial service to be held at 4 P.M. tomorrow for William Hodson, former Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, in the Hunter College assembly hall, 116 East Sixty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Colder weather in the Winter-wheat belt is causing a little apprehension about the crop, as the cold wave was preceded by higher temperatures that removed some of the snow covering in many sections. However, the cold was preceded by heavy snow in parts of Nebraska and Northern Kansas that will afford some protection.

A special feature of the fourteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, starting Monday, Feb. 22, will be the season's only performance of Wagner's "Siegfried." The performance of this music drama on Tuesday, Feb. 23, will mark the farewell appearance of Friedrich Schorr, who will be heard in the role of the Wanderer.
Carlo Tresca, militant anti-Fascist editor, mysteriously slain by a gunman on Jan. 11, was eulogized yesterday at a memorial meeting held in the Rand School at 7 East Fifteenth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 14 -- Paramount has announced for early Summer production "The Man in Half Moon Street," an English play by Barrie Lyndon, which the company has owned for several years, and "The Uninvited," the Dorothy MacArdle novel purchased in the Fall for a reported $25,000.

Mayor La Guardia entered the phrase-making lists yesterday in competition with Mrs. Claire Boothe Luce, Republican Representative from Connecticut, who recently described the global thinking of Vice President Henry A. Wallace as "globaloney."

The great D minor symphony of Cesar Franck topped an unusually fine program given in an extraordinarily fine way yesterday afternoon by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under John Barbirolli. The other numbers which delighted an audience that filled the hall were Nicolai's Overture to "The Merry Wives of Windsor," Abram Chasins's "Parade," Respighi's symphonic poem, "The Fountains of Rome," and Weinberger's "Schwanda" polka and fugue.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Feb. 14 -- The government has decided to sell at auction the agricultural machinery left by Costa Rica's Japanese colony, the members of which were arrested when war was declared and are now interned in the United States.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Masculine opposition to women in industry is collapsing, Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor, said today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Indication that the OPA was not out of step with the merchandise trend when it rationed leather shoes is indicated in the current business report of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- On a goal in the last four minutes by Carl Liscombe, the Detroit Red Wings tightened their hold on second place in the National Hockey League by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 2 to 1, before 9,839 spectators tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 14 -- Antoine Gardel, who held a similar position under General Maxime Weygand, former Commander in Chief in Africa, has been named director of the Algerian regime's press and information service.

Four goals down, with less than half the game over, the New York Rangers staged a thrilling rally to tie the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Investments in housing properties formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan reported over the week-end.

Sales approaching boom proportions in the boys' wear field are reported in trade circles, with current business placed at an average of 30 to 40 per cent above a year ago, and retailers anticipate further gains during the first half of the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors adopted resolutions today calling for "a world guarantee of freedom of the press" after the war and opposing efforts to put any press association "under the power of Congress to regulate commerce."

Director of Economic Stabilization Byrnes announced recently that farm workers now in war jobs should return to the farms "even if the compensation is less. If they refuse to go, then draft deferments should be canceled."

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Ceiling prices imposed on corn recently have resulted in limiting speculative interest in the market to such an extent that business has become more or less routine. Sales of futures on the Board of Trade now average around 1,500,000 bushels daily, part of which represents small buying and selling by cash interests.

A report on relief and rehabilitation for thousands of rabbis and Jewish scholars and their families in lands suffering from the war was made public yesterday by "Vaad Hahatala," an emergency committee here aiding stranded refugee Yeshiva scholars and rabbis and religious leaders.

Adolf Busch, violin, and Rudolf Serkin, piano, were the participants at the concert presented by the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program was devoted to three sonatas, comprising the examples in the form for piano and violin by Bach in E major and by Schumann in D minor, and Bach's unaccompanied violin sonata in C major.
Three new films are scheduled to open at Broadway theatres this week. They are:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Sunday Star says regulations are to be relaxed to permit any person needing a new automobile to buy, without a ration certificate, convertibles with soft tops, cars costing more than $1,500 and 1941 models of any type and price.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- A Berlin dispatch said tonight that a violent explosion occurred yesterday at noon at the Friedrichstrasse railway station, one of the most important in the German capital.
CASCADE, Idaho, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Five of a crew of eight Army airmen marooned for sixteen days near Loon Lake, northeast of here, were rescued today by Penn Stohr, civilian flier.

Did you ever see a ration gremlin? They breed in sewers called black markets. Scientists have likened them to a species of tropical fly, in that they possess a peculiar bite, by which they instill a poison in their victims. The victim, in turn, becomes a carrier and pollutes almost all with whom he comes in contact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (U.P.) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight announced its opposition to a bill which would require confirmation by the Senate of Federal employes earning $4,500 or more a year.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- More than 2,000 looked on today when Harry Morse of the Brattleboro Outing Club annexed the Nelson Memorial Trophy ski jump under wartime conditions. Morse won the prize, given for the best point award on a single jump, but failed to take the Class A honors as he fell on his first jump.

The fall of Rostov underlines beyond any Russian victory to date the extent and decisiveness of the German defeat in the east. More than Stalingrad, Rostov in the eyes of military experts is the keystone on which the Winter campaign hinges. For the second time the Nazis have failed to hold this pivotal position.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The House Committee on Small Business reported today it had received testimony presenting "a shocking picture of bureaucratic buck-passing, incompetent and listless administration and almost traitorous activities on the part of certain interests to protect their companies at the expense of the war effort."
MOSCOW, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communiqu:

Petite and slim in her blue uniform, Mrs. S.F. Chen of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, who is the city's only Chinese nurse, spoke eagerly and proudly yesterday of her profession and of her desire to help those in need.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Victorious Russian troops captured Rostov today, seizing the gateway to the Caucasus and the vital southern hinge of the entire German defensive line after a stubborn battle as the Nazis' pell-mell retreat continued, the Soviet Union announced tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 14 -- As Mohandas K. Ghandi completed today the fifth day of his fast, it was evident that his move would probably misfire. His fast, intended to effect his release from prison, has stirred many elements of the Hindu community, but it has not aroused the country nor induced the British to weaken in the slightest.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 -- A heavy influx of new steel orders, an operating rate approaching maximum output, an easier scrap situation and the threat of coal stoppage, in case a wage impasse results, featured news of the steel industry last week.

We now know why the Japanese cleared out of Guadalcanal. They were not beaten. Oh, no. For Japan the six-month campaign was a brilliant success. We have it on the word of Tokyo. The 20,000 troops on the island were merely "decoys" engaging the American forces while a "strategic advance to new bases" was under way, "permitting positive offensive operations against the enemy."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 14 -- General Christo Loukoff, founder of the Nazi Bulgarian Legion and protagonist of immediate Bulgarian participation in the war against Russia, who was shot and killed by fore men last night in Sofia, had been very active recently organizing "Bulgarian Phalanxes," which he hoped eventually would receive King Boris's permission to participate in the fighting on the Eastern Front.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Designation of three shipyards and twenty industrial plants to receive their first high honor awards for meritorious production was announced today by the Maritime Commission.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 110.5 to 110.7. The rise was mainly due to the fuel and lighting group, which advanced 1.2 per cent as a result of upward adjustment of bituminous coal prices by the Office of Price Administration.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 14 -- An inexpensive, simple home-foods dehydrator has been developed by agricultural engineers at the University of Tennessee in cooperation with the Tennessee Valley Authority and will be ready for the market within about two weeks.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 14 -- With the German eastern front crumbling along a wide sector and important key points being rapidly vacated, a report from neutral quarters tonight states that Reichsfuehrer Hitler is preparing to relinquish his active Supreme Command and place it in the hands of his Field Marshals, under the leadership of Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein.

Champion H. M. S. Kiddie Boots' Son, bred, owned and shown in the ring by Mrs. Don Smith of Pawtucket, R. I., last evening won the best-in-breed award at the thirty-fifth annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of New York at the Capitol Hotel.

Revenues of the city's general fund will be $32,000,000 lower in 1943-44 than the amount to be collected in the current fiscal year, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick estimated in a report made public yesterday. The report, prepared under the terms of the City Charter, will be submitted to the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The North African Economic Board announced today that 60,000 tons of supplies for civilian consumption had reached North Africa from the United States and Britain, each country sending equal amounts.

The House Ways and Means Committee has closed public hearings on the pay-as-you-go income tax proposal, and will now consider it in executive session. But the outlook for the adoption of a sensible plan is not promising. For the testimony of the Treasury and other witnesses has befogged what ought to be a very clear and simple question.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 14 -- Despite heavy clouds and generally bad weather conditions, United States heavy bombers raided the harbor of Naples yesterday and attacked the Crotone airdrome in the "sole" of Italy, it was announced today. Clouds obscured the results at Naples, but at Crotone several fires were started at the airdrome. Barracks and warehouses were hit.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- United States forces, now securely entrenched on Guadalcanal since the recent complete defeat and withdrawal of the Japanese, are continuing to make good use of Henderson Field as a base for air attacks against enemy strongholds in the Solomons, the Navy indicated tonight in a communique.
Proposed salary changes for staff members of the four city colleges will come up today at a hearing of the Board of Higher Education at Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Red Army's recapture of Rostov, southern anchor of a German chain of strong points that Adolf Hitler had boasted were impregnable, will force the Germans to fall back to the Dnieper River, in the opinion of military men here.
LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Two veteran French officers, one from the forces of the Fighting French leader, General Charles de Gaulle, and the other from General Giraud's army, declared today that French soldiers drew no distinc tion between the two leaders and aimed only "to beat the Germans and liberate France."

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Developments in the two weeks between Governor Dewey's submission of the State budget and the public hearing to be held on it tomorrow in the Assembly Chamber have tended to bolster the belief that the Governor has underestimated his prospective surplus by at least $25,000,000, or 50 per cent.

A vanguard of 145 city secondary schools had mailed in their entries to the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Essay Contest up to yesterday. The competition opened a week ago, and will come to a climax at the New York Times Hall with the announcement of winners and presentation of prizes on the Jefferson bicentennial, April 13.

The city's first air raid drill under the new Army signal regulations will be held at 9 P.M. Thursday, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from his desk at City Hall. The Army regulations, which become effective Wednesday, prescribe the siren signals for such an alarm but leave to the local authorities the decision as to the "all clear" signal.

Congress took testimony last week on manpower problems and the size of the Army, and the indications were that the debate about the land Strength the United States should raise and maintain would coincide with the start of the Spring offensives which the Casablanca conference clearly forecast.

Wartime confinement to the home is bound to produce a number of bodily ailments, and some mental ones, too. Among these, easily discernible in perhaps nine households out of ten, is a loss of balance brought on by intemperance in crossword puzzles.

The National Consumer-Retail Council, 8 West Fortieth Street, has issued two leaflets designed to help retailers and consumers adjust themselves to the labor shortage, Roger Wolcott, managing director of the organization, announced yesterday.

Possibly in any other year the fact that a woman angler gained top honors in the Field and Stream fishing contest would be more surprising than it is. But now, accustomed to having women actively participating in war work and as members of the various armed services, sportsmen will take the news in stride.
LONDON, Monday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Just as there are Saints and weather calendars there are also candy calendars. A hundred years ago rock candy and taffy were about all that could be obtained at a price within the means of children. The industrial age brought new ideas to candy manufacturers.
The Japanese-controlled Bangkok radio said yesterday that Premier Luang Bipul Songgram of Thailand had resigned, The Associated Press reported.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The largest non-combat vehicle in the service of the United States Army has been designed by Major Sidney Hedley Bingham, who started with the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in 1915 and is now on war leave from his post as assistant superintendent of New York's combined transit system.

The war has entered the field of feminine fripperies, which are suddenly taking on an almost sensible appearance. There is, for instance, the new set of spice-and-roses bath accessories that come packed in a decorative box that on being emptied turns out to be a convenient tissue dispenser.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 14 -- Spokesmen for business and industry, as well as Governor Tugwell, were heard by the Chavez Committee during the opening hearing here yesterday. The Senatorial group from the United States is seeking concrete proposals for ameliorating the insular economic plight.

The use of all United Service Organization centers and facilities is open to all members of women's units and auxiliaries of the armed forces, such as the Waacs, the Waves, the Spars, Wafs and Army and Navy nurses, according to a statement of policy issued yesterday on Work with Women and Girls.

Mrs. Margaret Duncan, 21 years old, of 113-31 Farmers Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, was taken to her home from Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, yesterday after recovering from hysteria and shock following an attack by a Negro Saturday night.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- In the closest session of sailing dinghy races during the twelve years of competition, Jack Sutphen, with his boat Rum Dum, wound up today by capturing the Winter series at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He won by a percentage of five one-thousandths.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Beginning tomorrow the weight of zinc used by newspapers, magazines, photo-engravers and all other makers of photo-engraving, must be reduced to 50 per cent of the amount used in the corresponding period of 1941.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Drastic reallocation of civilian workers, particularly the excessive number of governmental civilian employes, is the only way to avoid a critical manpower shortage, Senator Burton of Ohio said today at the seventeenth annual national conference on medical service.

The first induction of Manhattan civilian defense volunteers into the United States Citizens Service Corps was held yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where 2,000 members of various volunteer groups took an oath of allegiance to the service.

Reversing the downward trend that prevailed through 1942, newspaper advertising linage for January in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records showed an increase of 5.8 per cent over January, 1942. Increases were registered in all classifications except financial.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 14 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler cannot afford to lose one battle in Tunisia. So narrow is the eastern seacoast corridor that the Germans hold between Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's position south of the Mareth Line and the Tunis-Bizerte area that the loss of one battle would split the German forces.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 15 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force made two smashing attacks important U-boat base at Lorient, Lorient, France, Saturday night, dropping more than 1,000 tons of bombs and starting a tremendous conflagration in the harbor area.
Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, preaching at solemn mass there yesterday, cautioned Catholics against being "selfish" with their religion.

In your issue of Feb. 11 Hanson W. Baldwin writes: "Nor was it possible to replace overnight these slow cargo carriers with fast ones, or to base a new and vast merchant ship construction program on a new fast design."
The Germans had to capture Rostov twice. The Russians have twice regained it.

Citations for distinguished service in the war were awarded last night to Herbert H. Lehman, director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, and Bernard M. Baruch, banker and philanthropist, at the sixty-ninth annual dinner-meeting of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's Hebrew association in the association building, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second street. Neither was present at the dinner.

The Catholic Book Club's February selection is Ernest Lothar's "Beneath Another Sun," published by Doubleday, Doran. One of the February selections of the Religious Book Club (Protestant) is "The World's Great Catholic Literature," edited by Dr. George N. Shuster of Hunter College.

AT SEA OFF GUADALCANAL, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- The day may soon be here when United Nations anti-aircraft gunners will have more than an even chance of knocking down any enemy planes that come within range of their guns.

Bernard L. Patterson Jr. has been appointed Brooklyn and Queens sales supervisor for Anheuser-Busch, Inc., package goods division. He has been a member of the Budweiser sales staff for the last two years.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- A third member of Anton A. Mussert's Nazi-sponsored Netherland Cabinet has been slain by members of a well-organized underground group known as "The Black Hand" who have pledged to wipe out Mr. Mussert's entire government, it was reported tonight.

With the Congressional decision in the parity revision bill still in the balance, little interest on either side of the market was evidenced last week by traders in cotton futures. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts, except for the July position, which lost 2 points, registered net gains of 2 to 9 points for the week in small volume.

" Ask My Friend Sandy," the Stanley Young comedy that opened at the Biltmore on Feb. 4, closed after Saturday night's performance. The comedy starred Roland Young and had Norman Lloyd and Mary Sargent in the featured roles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Creation of a special committee to study post-war economic problems will be proposed in a resolution to be introduced in the Senate tomorrow by Chairman George of the Finance Committee.

President Roosevelt sent a message to Marjorie Lawrence at the testimonial dinner given last night in her honor by the Town Hall Club in the clubrooms in West Forty-third Street. The President greeted the Metropolitan Opera star, who is winning her fight over infantile paralysis, as "an old veteran to a young recruit" and he urged her to "carry on."

In a sermon on the observance of Race Relations Sunday at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, the pastor, asserted that from a Christian point of view there are no areas on earth where a person is excluded from any relationship in the common life of men and women because of color or other characteristics of the so-called racial strains.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Feb. 15 (AP) -- More than thirty heavy Allied bombers gave Rabaul, New Britain, a terrific pounding yesterday, the Allied command reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Samuel Okin of New York, stormy petrel of the stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company, holding company system, shouted charges in a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today that the proposed sale by National Power and Light Company of its assets in West Tennessee Gas Company was "a rotten, fraudulent deal."
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A German broadcast recorded by Reuter said tonight that the Russians had breached the German defense lines in the Kharkov area after several hours of battle.

There is no longer any doubt that the Germans are now retreating in the East along the entire line. It is not voluntary retreat, and the Russians have been too fast for all German attempts to disengage themselves from the enemy. As a result the retreat is a far more costly business than it would have been last Fall, and the mounting German blood toll marks the cost of Hitler's military blunders.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -Irving Eisenberg, one of the three men appointed to the Hudson County Common Pleas Bench by Governor Edison, has long been active in anti-Hague circles and served as assistant Hudson County prosecutor from 1929 to 1934 under the former Republican prosecutor John F. Drewen.

ON THE CENTRAL TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 15 -- American tanks smashed against heavy German tank concentrations nine miles west of Faid Pass today in an attempt to relieve surrounded American infantry after the biggest tank-against-tank battle of the Tunisian campaign yesterday, in which the losses on both sides were heavy.

Deliveries of Army and Navy aircraft by Consolidated Aircraft Corporation and Vultee Aircraft, Inc., in 1942 were more than three times those of 1941, in the case of each company, according to the annual reports signed by Tom M. Girdler, chairman, and Harry Woodhead, president, issued yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15 -- New Jersey women who want to do their bit in the war should "take the nearest and hardest job that will release a man for active duty," Mary Brewster White of Washington, manager of women's campaigns for the War Manpower Commission, told 100 women today at the opening session of the Woman Power Council at the L. Bamberger Co. store.
A German High Command communique, broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- A proposal that the judiciary law be amended so that workers in New York City war industries need not appear in person to ask to be excused from jury duty was one of twenty-six recommendations made by the State Judicial Council tonight in its ninth annual report to the Legislature.

In trained and equipped divisions -- one of the best yardsticks of land strength -- there is not much doubt that the Axis today has a positive numerical superiority over the combined land armies of the United Nations.

The local Regional Office of Price Administration announced last night that the new maximum ceiling price of 57 cents a pound for the best grade of premium butter would go into effect at 12:01 this morning in all retail stores in an area comprising New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland and the District of Columbia.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (ONA) -German officialdom in the eastern occupied territories and satellite countries is panicky, according to the report of a neutral traveler who has just come from there.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 15 -- "Government regulation of business does not at present constitute a threat to American free enterprise," Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co. of New York, declared here today. He said "such regulation is essential if a serious inflation is to be prevented.

An appeal to the people of Italy for "immediate and general action of extreme civil disobedience" in the government, armed services, industrial plants, railways, educational institutions and all essential branches of activity is being distributed in Italy by the Italian Socialist party, the Mazzini group, "Justice and Liberty," and the followers of the old "Partito Popolari," the Catholic party, headed by Don Luigi Sturzo, now an exile in the United States.

"We are united and intend to remain united after the war, because we know what will happen to us if we don't," declared Sir Godfrey Haggard, British Consul General for the United States, at a United Nations luncheon at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South, yesterday.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, as of last Wednesday, were only ,$85,000,000, lowest since September, 1937. Since last Wednesday the Treasury had made substantial withdrawals from its war loan accounts in these banks last Thursday and Saturday, and again yesterday, with another previously announced withdrawal due today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that food available to civilians in 1943 should provide "a reasonably adequate diet per capita," although there may be a necessity for the rationing of additional scarce commodities.
