ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 -- Mrs. Roosevelt spent an hour today telling 3,000 University of Missouri students and Columbians at Columbia, Mo., about the changing world which youth will face after the war and then spent thirty minutes more answering questions.

Point rationing may prove a blessing in disguise to American housewives, eight girl seniors in the home economics department of the New York University School of Education have decided after three weeks of experimentation while living in the University's model apartment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- The policy of the War Manpower Commission, particularly as it pertains to training of physicians, engineers and scientific and technical workers, is on a "catch-as-catch-can" basis which will meet the country's needs only if the war is ended soon, Edward C. Elliott, president of Purdue University and chief of the WMC division on professional and technical employment and training, said today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's promise Friday night of great and decisive actions against Japan was welcomed by the Chinese press over the week-end with expressions of hope that the final offensive would not be long delayed.

Events today: "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera, 7:30 P.M.; Philadelphia Orchestra, with Marjorie Lawrence and Friedrich Schorr as soloists, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Jan Peerce, tenor, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30; Juilliard Graduate School, student recital, Recital Hall, 120 Claremont Avenue, 5.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Navy communique 281:

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- On the basis of cheerful war news the stock market opened the week with a firm tone, a feature being renewed buying of home railway issues. Distribution of South African vesting money, which began today, had little effect on government stocks, all remaining steady.

In a nerve-tingling contest before 12,095 persons at Madison Square Garden last night, Manhattan College's basketball team upset St. John's, 42 -- 38, limiting Harry Boykoff to 11 points while subjecting the favored Redmen to their second defeat of the campaign.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Four companies, a trade association and five individuals were accused in a criminal information filed here in Federal Court today of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in the manufacture and sale of computer gasoline pumps and mechanisms.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Hugh Fulton of New York City was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Scare buying of clothing tapered of in retail stores here yesterday, reflecting both the extremely cold weather, which kept many customers home, and a normal reaction after the heavy purchasing noted late last week, according to reports by local merchants.

After the fall of France in 1940 few Americans could have foreseen the day when the pride of the French Navy would ride at anchor in New York Harbor. Yet this is what New Yorkers on the Staten Island ferry have seen for the past several days -- the mighty battleship Richelieu with her guns at rest under the Tricolor of the Republic.
ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Governor Dewey made tonight his first major Cabinet appointments since he took office, bringing to a temporary end the wait of the Republican State organization for patronage.
What part sports fishermen might play in any contemplated fish-for-food drive of the U.S. Wildlife Service is suggested by Bill Baxter of Beach Haven, N.J.
A double dose of misfortune struck the harassed New York Rangers hockey club yesterday in the wake of the tie game the squad played Sunday night against the Toronto Maple Leafs.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The Navy, which has come t0 the rescue many times in the past and on much more important occasions, has solved a difficult situation at Columbia College by agreeing to allow the freshman and sophomore classes to hold a joint dance Feb. 27 in John Jay Hall, where part of the Naval Reserve midshipmen's school is quartered.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -William Dudley Pelley, former leader of the Silver Shirts of America, failed today to obtain a supreme court review of his conviction on a charge of criminal sedition.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Rumanian Government would seem to tied to Germany whether it wills or not. Any peace feelers emitted in neutral capitals are pretty well balanced by the presence of numerous German troops and Gestapo men in the country.

When President Roosevelt said in his annual message to Congress that "we are flying as much lend-lease material into China as ever traversed the Burma Road," there was a lifting of eyebrows in many places. Considering the difficulties of air transport, could the President be speaking seriously?
MELBOURNE, Feb. 15 -- There has been a big boom in boxing and large-scale amateur activities in cricket and football, but organized sports in Australia generally have been reduced sharply by the war.

With routine price-fixing offset by hedging and near-month liquidation, cotton prices held yesterday within a trading range of 4 to 6 points under moderate volume. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed at the day's high levels, 1 to 7 points above Saturday's final prices.

WHITE PLAINS N.Y., Feb. 15 -- Thirty-three persons, including two doctors, a dentist, a Sing Sing convict and two former convicts, have volunteered to submit to tests here by Dr. William A. Holla, Westchester County health commissioner, to prove a theory that mice transmit infantile paralysis to human beings, Dr. Holla said this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, former Atlantic City Republican leader, on a charge of evading Federal income taxes for 1936 and 1937.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Three general officers of the United States and British Armies en route from North Africa have conferred at Pernambuco with Brazil's Air Minister Joachim Salgado Jr., the official news agency announced today.

Zero weather failed to keep a sizable audience of enthusiasts from Carnegie Hall last night to hear Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association in a program consisting almost entirely of contemporary music. Assisting artists were Roman Totenberg, violinist, and the WQXR Quartet, which is made up of Mr. Totenberg, Daniel Guilet, Ralph Hersh and Avron Twerdowsky.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Criticism of Governor Dewey's estimates of his prospective budget surplus, on the grounds that the excess would be far larger than he indicated, was the dominant note in the hearing on the State budget today in the Assembly Chamber.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- Permission was refused today to the Engineers Public Service Company by the Securities and Exchange Commission to use part of the proceeds from the sale of the principal assets of the Western Public Service Company, a subsidiary, to acquire and retire not more than 35,000 shares of its own preferred stock.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 15 -Universal announced today that Patric Knowles and Evelyn Ankers will be co-starred in a musical under the title "I Want to Sing." Felix Feist has been engaged to direct.

"Random Harvest" will enter its ] tenth week at the Radio City Music Hall n Thursday, thereby equaling the all-tin, e long-run-record for the theatre set by 'r. s. Miniver" last .Summer. From its openingon Dec. 17 through Sunday night, "Random Harvest" was seen by 1,234,9.74 persons as against an attendance of 1,281,712 persons recorded by "Mrs. Miniver" over a similar period.

The American [eat Institute disclosed yesterday that it has called to the attention of a large number of advertisers that the government has not requested "meatless days," although the phrase is constantly used in various ads and radio commercials.

FORTWORTH, Texas, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Rogers Hornsby, general manager of the Fort Worth Cats, blasted today at managements of six Texas League clubs that, he said, "talk about manpower but have their eye on money."

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States at the end of January amounted to $119,682,000, an increase of $1,643,000 on the month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey. This was the second consecutive monthly rise.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb 15 -- S.M. McAshan Jr., head of the United States Purchasing Commission here, confirmed today the report that he had resigned. He arrived yesterday from the United States to wind up his affairs and will return home soon, he said.

If you are puzzled about rationing problems, or would like help in budgeting your household money, or would like to know more about clothes conservation and repair, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office suggests that you go to your nearest Consumer Service Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Thirty-six additional industrial plants and one construction project were selected to receive the Army-Navy "E" award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work, Under-Secretaries Patterson and Forrestal announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -Several Latin-American diplomatic representatives in France, removed by the German authorities from Vichy to Mont-Dore, have now been transferred to Baden-Baden, in Germany, where they have joined the North American diplomatic group, made up of United States diplomats, newspaper correspondents and Red Cross workers formerly in Vichy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -Representative Fred Bradley, Republican, of Michigan, today introduced a resolution calling for a Congressional investigation to find out if any agency or officer of the government has plans to curtail the production of newsprint, or the dissemination of news, not necessitated by the "proper conduct of the war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during January totaled 915,479 bales of lint and 110,578 bales of linters, compared with 935,511 of lint and 108,113 of linters during December last, and 947,539 of lint and 116,279 of linters during January last year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Recommendation that all shoes priced at not more than $3 a pair retail be sold until June 15 without a rationing certificate has been telegraphed to the OPA by the National Shoe Travelers Association, Norman N. Souther, secretary of the group, made known today.

Is it not about time to call a halt on the national name-calling contest which is going on? The latest diatribe uttered by a former Republican Presidential candidate is almost nauseating. This from the representative of a great political party who was able to carry only two States of the forty-eight has no comparison in the history of bitter partisanship, and all this in a time of war.

Mayor La Guardia's little Sunday talks to his good people of New York must not be explained as purely a phenomenon of the radio age. It will be noted that the Mayor speaks to his flock over the radio, but they in turn do not address him by short wave.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Accepting pleas of nolo contendere, Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney levied here today fines totaling $77,500 against nine companies charged with conspiracy to fix prices on Navy orders for $50,000,000 worth of cable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The highest court in the land gave to James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians today the legal right to continue their national ban on the recording of music for radio, juke boxes and other public reproduction. The ruling prevents the union from being enjoined under the anti-trust laws.

Isidore Spector, 45 years old, who is serving three years in Federal prison for selling narcotics, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court to serve five to ten years in Sing Sing Prison for a killing in Rockaway twenty years ago.
LONDON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Reports that German troops were being moved from the Russian front to reinforce Axis positions in other countries were denied by the Russians tonight for the second time.

The estate known as Plaisance, once owned by the late Mrs. Marius de Brabant, on Little Neck Road, Centerport, L. I., has been sold by her daughter, Mrs. Rodney W. Williams, to a client of J. RalphI Bloomer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Wiley Blount Rutledge Jr. was sworn in today as an associate justice of the Supreme Court and within half an hour the court issued two unexpected orders aimed at speedy disposition of important cases affecting civil liberties.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15 -- Governor Charles Edison aimed another blow today at Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City in their two-year battle for control of the Democratic party when he sent to the Senate the nominations of six men for Hudson County judgeships.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Don Hutson, the Green Bay Packers' record-wrecker, set eight new marks in pass receiving alone last season, official statistics of the National Football League showed today.

Facts linking three men arrested here with ration coupons good for 2,000,000 gallons of gasoline, stolen from a Chicago branch of the OPA were said by New York City police yesterday to have been uncovered over the week-end. The suspects, a garage operator, a filling station proprietor and a clerk, were released in bail of $2,000 each by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter for action by a Federal grand jury.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- a national industry advisory committee of producers, converters and jobbers of cotton and rayon finished pieced goods has been named today by Office of Price Administration.
HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Cubans and Americans today observed the forty-fifth anniversary of the sinking of the Maine in Havana harbor with ceremonies at the Maine Monument.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 -Tyrus Raymond Cobb spoke up today for the sport that brought him fame. He appealed to the government "to continue professional baseball if possible during these war times as a matter of morale for the people, military and civilians alike."

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 15 (AP) -Fighters and bombers of the Tenth United States Army Air Force have carried out destructive raids against Japanese installations and rolling stock in Burma in the past two days, destroying or damaging an estimated 140 freight cars and leaving fires blazing among enemy barracks and storage dumps, a communique reported today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Grain prices held within very narrow limits today on the Chicago Board of Trade, with commission house and professional trade the smallest in some weeks. Brokers attributed this to uncertainty in regard to possible developments on proposed farm legislation in Washington.

Among the many ceremonies of Lincoln Day, one may have escaped general notice. It was the first of its kind, but will not, in all probability, be the last, and will some day be recalled as a historic occasion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -Directors of the Army and Naval aviation physical training programs declared tonight the two services would continue competitive sports during the war.

"Carmen" is a warm opera for an icy night, and it rejoiced a large audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last night as the thirteenth week of the season began. Gladys Swarthout, American mezzo-soprano, returned to the company after an absence of about two years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 15 -- After Field Marshal Baron Karl Gustaf Mannerheim, at the last moment, had virtually announced that he was not running for the office, President Risto Ryti of Finland scored a strong victory today when he was re-elected by the Presidential electors on the first ballot.

Agreement with most proposed salary legislation and amendments to the by-laws of the Board of Higher Education was expressed yesterday by representatives of four teachers' groups at a public hearing in Hunter College.

Declaring that bureaucracy in government will increase as long as business monopolies are permitted to expand, Senator James E. Murray yesterday outlined the five objectives which the Senate committee on small business has "resolved to attain."

The report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for 1942, filed yesterday in the Federal Court by the trustees in reorganization of the A.G. system, shows a consolidated balance of income for the year of $8,660,673, compared with $8,440,141 in 1941.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Two Waacs who arrived in London during the week-end were interviewed today before they reported for duty with the Eighth United States Army Air Force in Britain. They are Captain Zelma F. Hanson of Los Angeles, a former government employe whose two sons are in the services, and Lieutenant Dorothy Swart of Elsa, Texas, a former secretary.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -All French youths between the ages of 20 and 22 are to be conscripted for labor service, according to information from Vichy today. The inevitable conclusion is that many of them will be sent to Germany.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Miss Peggy Kirk, a Rollins College senior from Findlay, Ohio, scored a neat 78 today to win the medal in the annual Palm Beach women's golf championship.

The new Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens, designed to accommodate 1,500 patients, was commissioned formally yesterday morning by Captain Reynolds Hayden, Third Naval District Medical Officer, at a brief ceremony on the wind-swept grounds along Linden Boulevard.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Earl of Fitzwilliam died today at his home, Wentworth Woodhouse, near Rotherham, Yorkshire, at the age of 70.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Extension of Social Security coverage to the armed forces as well as to millions of others now outside the program will be recommended by the Social Security Board.

Mrs. Elizabeth E. Kelly, 39 years old, 40-17 Twenty-third Street, Long Island City; Mrs. Marie C. Nelson, 40, of 56-66 Fifty-ninth Street, Maspeth, and Mrs. Alice V. Greitz, 38, of 117 North Oxford Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court to conspiracy to receive criminally part of $80,000 worth of merchandise stolen from the Long Island City terminal of the Railway Express Agency.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 15 -German operations in the Donets Basin are being carried out in conformity with the new strategy of shortening the entire Eastern Front, it was asserted in Berlin today. Spokesmen for the High Command declared that the "evacuation" of Rostov and Voroshilovgrad represented first steps in carrying out that policy.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Frederick C. Crawford, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared today that rehabilitation of the post-war world "will require the investment of astronomical sums of capital" and "private capital can do the job and will, if permitted."

The careful plan for the murder of Philip Orlovsky, former "czar" of the Cutters Union and witness against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter in the garment industry investigation, which resulted in the mistaken-identity slaying of Irving Penn, was outlined yesterday in Bronx County Court by Edward Breslin, Assistant District Attorney, in his Opening statement in the first-degree murder trial of Jacob (Kuppy) Migden, 33-year-old Lepke hireling.

Although Garry Davis, son of the orchestra leader Meyer Davis, proved to be a capable pinch hitter (according to the Vinton Freedley office) for the ailing Danny Kaye at both performances on Sunday, the engagement of "Let's Face It" has been halted until Thursday night.

HYDERABAD, India, Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- This State, which is larger than England and Scotland together, cares little whether Mohandas K. Gandhi fasts or not. It is a good object-lesson in the importance of the princely States, which have about a third of the population and nearly half the territory of India.
"Tell it to the marines!" and three hundred women did just that yesterday.

The Tribunal of American Rabbinate, Beth Din of America, after a meeting of its executive council yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, made public a statement on post-war adjustments, taking issue with a declaration of principles made by ninety Reform Jewish rabbis in Philadelphia on Dec. 7.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 15 -According to a news bulletin from Washington, Representative James M. Curley, venerable Boston political scientist, has spoken aloud: "I have been informed that with 500 bombing and fighter planes and a reasonable amount of other war material, Chinese success over the Japanese would be possible in six months."

Business in the stock market bounded forward yesterday to within striking distance of the 2,000,000-share mark as prices pushed to new peaks for the current movement. Enlargements in values were not great, although key issues in some groups turned in gains of a point and more

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -Inquiry into plane construction at the Curtiss-Wright plant at Columbus and the Willow Run plant, near Detroit, was ordered today by Chairman Truman of the Senate war investigating committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The labor members of the War Labor Board charged today that the board's majority which adhered to the "Little Steel" formula and denied a general wage increase to 180,000 employes of the "Big Four"" meat packing companies had made a "gratuitous and unwarranted surrender of the prerogatives that Congress and the President granted to it" in the Stabilization Act of Oct. 2, 1942, and the executive order of Oct. 3, 1942.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- The midnight Soviet communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The issue of post-war economic planning was placed formally before Congress today, when identical resolutions were introduced in the Senate and House calling for formation of special committees to start making plans for reconstruction days.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers battered the Japanese base of Rabaul, New Britain Island, yesterday morning for the second successive day, dumping more than thirty-eight tons of explosive bombs and over 1,500 incendiaries, the Allied Command announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -President Roosevelt requested Congress for $65,000,000 for programs to alleviate the farm labor shortage.

New York State was criticized yesterday for building prisons of the "fortress' type in the face of progressive trends toward the greater use of medium-security institutions, and for alleged failure to take care of youthful offenders properly.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP) -The carriage trade will begin flocking to the Bay Meadows racing strip on the San Francisco peninsula next Saturday.

Columbia's basketball team will face the strong Princeton quintet at the Morningside Heights gymnasium tonight without the services of Captain Les Martens. Although Martens, chief playmaker of the Lions, was discharged from St. Luke's Hospital on Saturday after suffering a mild attack of appendicitis, he is confined to his home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Secretary Morgenthau expressed sympathy today with rural bankers' complaints of government competition stemming from Secretary Wickard's announcement on Jan. 21 that between $200,000,000 and $225,000,000 in Federal funds would be made available in loans to farmers for war production uses.
(Makes one eight-inch square or two eight-inch layers)

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Wholesale grocers were advised by the Office of Price Administration today that they should, in their own interests, fill unstintingly the orders they receive from retail stores during the retail stocking-up period from Feb. 21 to Feb. 28, inclusive.
MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- The Russians have lost no time in exploiting the Rostov victory and the enemy's remaining positions in the Donets basin are being squeezed more tightly.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 15 -- A curfew affecting boys and girls under the age of 16 was adopted this afternoon by the Riverhead town Board after a public hearing. It will become operative on March 1.

Buying was brisk at the opening of the New York Gift Show in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, and trading on many hard-to-get items was limited only by the manufacturers' ability to take orders. Budgets of smaller retailers, who made up most of the attendance, appeared to be up 10 to 15 per cent over last year.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 16 --Russian forces, driving to trap the entire German Army in the Rostov-Donets Basin region, have stormed and captured the railroad town of Kuteynikov, about fifty miles from the Sea of Azov, said the Red Army's midnight communique, heard here today in a Moscow broadcast.

"Jefferson, the Road to Glory, 1743-1776," will be published by Coward-McCann on April 13 as part of the observation of the Jefferson Bicentennial this year. The period covered in the biography includes Jefferson's formative years, and Coward-McCann reports that considerable new research has been made on Jefferson's boyhood, youth and family background.

Necessity for retailers to use correct descriptions of Regulation W in their credit and collection letters to consumers was emphasized yesterday by James M. Malloy, credit manager of Abraham Straus, Brooklyn, and president of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York.

Extremely low temperatures and strong winds striking the seaboard at a period when fuel was at a low ebb caused suffering yesterday that was worse than on Feb. 9, 1934, which was the coldest day in New York's recorded weather history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -The War Department announced today that Lieut. Col. Benjamin R. Farrar had been wounded in action in the Southwest Pacific area. His father, W.M. Farrar lives in Millburn, N.J.

Following its annual meeting, which was held last night, the National Academy has scheduled for this afternoon the preview of the 117th annual exhibition, installed in the galleries at 1083 Fifth Avenue (between Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets). The exhibition, which opens to the public tomorrow, will continue until March 9.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Texas League representatives who inquired about the possibilities for listing baseball among occupations whose workers can't be draft-deferred have been told simply that the sport isn't on the non-deferable roll as yet.

Ray Robinson, Harlem's contender for the welterweight title, and Sergeant Jackie Wilson of California, who is stationed at Mitchel Field, yesterday were pronounced in excellent physical condition by Dr. Vincent Nardiello of the State Athletic Commission following an official examination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Condemning nonessential driving of government automobiles, a joint Congressional committee recommended today the removal and prosecution of any Federal official who uses or authorizes the use of a government car "for other than official purposes."

Transfer of the fifteen-story apartment house at 694:-693 West End Avenue at the southeast corner of Ninety-fourth Street by the Guaranty Trust Company to Mary Simons of Brooklyn was recorded yesterday in the Register's office. The sale was made subject to a purchase money mortgage of $342,500. The building is on a plot 72.5 by 100 feet

Widespread support for maintenance of the field offices of the Department of Commerce was noted last week as foreign-trade organizations and other industrial groups urged continuance of the agencies. The offices, located in twelve large cities and eighteen smaller areas throughout the United States, are scheduled for "liquidation" because the Bureau of the Budget has eliminated an appropriation of $430,000 from its 1944 estimates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The President and the Secretary of State can point, if they choose, to the French warships, now safely at anchor in American waters, as the most striking symbol of the practical wisdom of their Vichy and North African policy that has yet appeared.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A.A. Berle, Assistant Secretary of State, assured Congress today that this nation's post-war interests in international air commerce were being safeguarded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -An effort to prevent Petroleum Administrator Ickes from ordering the construction of another pipeline from Texas to the Chicago area was started today by nine Senators as others criticized government "bungling," which, they said, had failed to avert a fuel shortage in New England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -Further evidence that the Japanese are concentrating powerful air defense forces in the Shortland Island area of the Solomons was contained in a Navy communique today reporting that a force of twenty-five to thirty enemy planes intercepted an American attack on shipping in that sector Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Passage of the Equal Rights Amendment would be "the most fitting tribute that we, members of Congress, can pay" to Susan B. Anthony, Representative Byrne of New York told the House today on the 123d anniversary of the suffrage leader's birth.

A master plan devised by the United States Bureau of Mines to assure this country a sufficient supply of aluminum from domestic materials was described here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP) -Directors of the Pacific Coast Baseball League voted today at their annual meeting to continue the Shaughnessy play-offs for the 1943 season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Sharply criticizing the many duplicating investigations carried out by various Senate committees, Senator Lucas of Illinois today told his colleagues, in effect, that they should not throw stones at "bureaucrats" as long as their own house is made of glass.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15 -- Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, surgeon general of the Navy, predicted today that one-third of the United States physicians who went into the armed services would not return to civilian practice after the war.

The article in Pravda demanding post-war Russian possession of the Baltic States and Bessarabia lends color to the rumor that last May the British were ready to sign a secret treaty -- like those with Italy and Rumania in the last war -- along those lines, but that our State Department interposed objection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, once Public Enemy No. 1 and head of a $1,000,000 racket ring, and two associates lost today their last judicial possibility of escape from the electric chair when the Supreme Court denied a review of their trial for the murder of Joseph Rosen.

For the first time in seventeen years, Hunter College students, 6,500 strong, came together under one roof yesterday. Two thousand and two hundred Bronx students, transferred to the main building in Sixty-eighth Street to make room for the Waves and the Spars, and an incoming freshman class used the building for the first time.

The great battleship Richelieu and three other French men of war, symbols of an unconquered France ready to re-enter the fray, have reached New York and other Atlantic ports to be repaired and fitted with fighting equipment. They had been harbor-bound in Dakar for two years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -A compact fishing kit is to become standard equipment on all lifeboats of Navy and merchant marine vessels of 3,000 tons or more, the Navy announced today.

Jennie Sheeran will have completed tomorrow forty-five years as a general domestic in the same home. Mrs. H.F. Smaltz of 161-12 86th Avenue, Jamaica, has several alternate plans for marking the day, occasioned by the fact that Jennie has a way of doing somewhat as she pleases, and no one plan can be made with the certainty that it will work out.
BOMBAY, India, Feb. 15 (AP) -- A United States Air Force Headquarters communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (U.P.) -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce, Republican, of Connecticut, blushed a little and giggled today when A.A. Berle, Assistant Secretary of State, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee there had been "a lot of loose talk" on the subject of post-war aviation.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in the South Pacific, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The Japanese Navy, after apparently extensive aerial scouting of the strong United States Pacific Fleet, refused battle in the final phases of the fight for Guadalcanal.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 15 -- A veteran German armored division smashed through the American positions in the Faid-Sened sector of the central Tunisian front yesterday in the opening of a serious and initially successful enemy offensive.

The Nazi-controlled Budapest radio told the people of Hungary today that anti-Axis "rebels" in occupied Croatia were counter-attacking "at many points," according to broadcasts recorded by the United States Foreign Intelligence Service.

Mr. Petrillo is distinguished from his fellow labor leaders by greater audacity and imagination. He realizes clearly the enormous powers of private dictatorship that the present state of the law, the beneficent attitude of the Administration, and the timorousness and vacillation of Congress have placed in his hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: decreases of $237,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $142,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $835,000,000 in United States Government deposits and an increase of $414,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

The weekly liberal magazine, The Nation, has been transferred to a non-profit membership corporation and is appealing to its subscribers for at least $25,000 to meet operating deficits, Frieda Kirchwey, its editor, announced yesterday. All of the stock in the Nation, Inc., owned by Miss Kirchwey, has been turned over to the new organization, Nation Associates, Inc.

Opposition by "selfish trade interests and isolationists in Congress" to renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, which expires June 12, must be stopped, Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan American Society, said yesterday at a luncheon honoring the Latin-American consular corps in New York and in celebration of the thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the society.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 15 -Patrolman John J. Barrett, 42 years old, described by his superiors as a "model policeman," shot and killed his wife, Marie, 35, and their daughter Edith, 9, and then wounded himself fataly early today in their home at 162 Clark Street.

Sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company and its Canadian subsidiary rose last year to the highest volume on record, but taxes reduced earnings to the lowest level since 1932, the annual report for 1942 disclosed yesterday.

Fears that the impending OPA ceilings on standardized "priority" styles of heavyweight knit underwear may be based on 1941 cost calculations, which have become outdated, were expressed yesterday by mill representatives. Since the time individual mills submitted their cost data to the agency in January, 1942, it was said, shortage of labor, fuel oil and materials have caused considerable irregularity in production schedules which are reflected in higher than normal costs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee, said in a nationwide broadcast tonight that any change-over from the existing delayed income tax collection system to a pay-as-you-go basis "undoubtedly" would be followed by still higher taxes. To assume that current payments would mean the paying of less taxes, he said, would be day-dreaming.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 15 -The fourteenth Indian Legislative Assembly and Council of State today took up the question of Mohandas K. Gandhi's fast with many sympathizers pleading for his unconditional release and warning that his death would lead to grave consequences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Department of Agriculture acted today to insure equitable distribution of available supplies of tea for domestic consumption. The move was necessary, Secretary Wickard said, because of wartime limitations on ocean shipping and short world supplies of tea.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15 -United Democracy, an organization of Democrats seeking to revitalize the party in New Jersey, came into being at Hotel Hildebrecht here tonight at a dinner attended by 225 men and women from all sections of the State and addressed by Governor Charles Edison and Senator John E. Toolan of Middlesex County.

Scholars leaned forward attentively yesterday to hear eighth-grade students from the Corpus Christi School, 529 West 121st Street, discuss ways of eliminating religious and race prejudice in the United States, at a reception sponsored by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.
The 1943 Swiss Industries Fair will be held in the permanent Fair buildings at Basle from May 1 to 11, where seventeen general groups are to feature the following displays:

More than 1,000 persons, including many members of the clergy, attended a funeral service yesterday for Mother Rose O'Hara of the Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart, who was principal of the Mother Cabrini High School, in the school's chapel at 701 Fort Washington Avenue. Among the congregation were 550 girl students of the school.

Seven local housing authorities in various parts of the country announced yesterday new bond issues aggregating $24,914,000 for award, through competitive bidding, on March 2. Each issue must be bid for separately and the interest rate specified. The new financing is as follows:

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 15 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of Allied forces in the North African theatre of operations, visiting the front for the first time since he became a full general, asserted: "It is part of my policy to regroup American forces in Tunisia in units at least as large as divisions."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- A House Appropriations subcommittee refused today, 6 to 1, to approve President Roosevelt's request for $100,000,000 for incentive payments to farmers for more production of essential food items.

On the corner of a broad street on the West Side is a store that fulfills three functions -- that of bakery, confectionery and restaurant. Two glassed-in counters, one filled with pastries and the other with candies, line the walls on either side of the entrance, and in the rear of the shop is a mirrored room, where meals are served from noon until after midnight.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- The State Senate passed unanimously tonight and sent to the Assembly the Dewey program bill which would more than quadruple the rental paid by the Niagara Falls Power Company for the water which it diverts for power purposes from the Niagara River.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Prentiss Brown, the Price Administrator, said today he was opposed to allowing "any general price increases" to businesses forced to pay overtime wages under the forty-eight-hour work week order. Mr. Brown also suggested that Congress require workers to invest the overtime pay in war bonds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission charged the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of Rochester, N.Y., today with "deceptive and misleading" advertisements which represent its orthogon type of spectacle lenses as superior to other types commonly used.

In Tunisia the Germans stand in a narrow coastal strip with their backs against the sea. As Frank Kluckhohn pointed out in a dispatch to this newspaper yesterday, a single lost battle on their present line might cost the Axis the whole African campaign. To prevent their forces from being split and separately destroyed they must have elbow room in which to manoeuvre.

Charles Baker, executive director of the Infants and Children's Coat Association, yesterday sent a communication to Jack Stevens, chief of the closure section of the WPB, urging that the WPB either grant enough steel for the manufacture of zippers or prohibit the use of zippers entirely.

I hope a great many people will read and appreciate the very fine letter of Thomas W. Lamont which you printed on Sunday. I was born and educated in England, I have lived in the United States for 55 years and have been a citizen for 40 years; I hope a good citizen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today that the basic work week, in some areas, may have to be raised beyond forty-eight hours a week, possibly to fifty-two, depending upon war needs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Thoroughbreds will be running at Narragansett Park April 10 under terms of a decision reached today by Governor J. Howard McGrath authorizing the scheduled race meeting because the Pawtucket track "is not a suburban track."

Relief costs to be met out of the city treasury during the next fiscal year will be $14,341,008 less than for the current year, Leo Arnstein, Commissioner of Welfare, estimated yesterday in submitting the new departmental budget request to Thomas J. Patterson, acting Budget Director.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 -- The plan for dissolution of the National Power and Light Company was amended today to provide for the further retirement of securities and the expansion of the plant of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, a $229,000,000 subsidiary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today relaxed its restrictions on the evictions of tenants from housing accommodations which landlords propose to sell.

Organization of the New York Labor War Chest, which will seek to raise at least $800,000 toward the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the fund, which on March 1 will open its campaign to obtain $12,920,700 in this city.

With 400 children, each representing a school in the city, gathered in the great hall of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street, Bill of Rights Week was opened officially here yesterday. All the students received copies of the historic document for display in their schools.

Although Gil Dodds has failed twice in a row, the Boston A.A. man will be the dominating figure in the Baxter Mile, feature of the annual New York Athletic Club meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. This opinion was expressed yesterday by Jim Rafferty, the veteran distance runner, who will be in the field that will oppose Dodds.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,182, which compared with 878 in the preceding week and 933 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Philip Orlofsky, 50-year-old former czar of the Cutters Union whom gangsters had ordered slain after he testified against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter in the garment industry investigation, told yesterday in Bronx County Court how he missed his rendezvous with death by leaving his home an hour earlier than usual on the morning of July, 25, 1939, to get shaved.
The new air raid warning system will go into effect today. Procedure under the new signals was described yesterday as follows:

Three hours after the Russians reported the capture of Kharkov the Berlin radio last night declared that "operations for the systematic evacuation of Kharkov, in accordance with plans, are about to be concluded," according to broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

More is involved in the present wage demands of the railroad employes than the $750,000,000 yearly increase in pay that is being sought. The question of inflation is included. If the wage rise should be granted, the inflationary trend might receive such an impetus that it could not be stopped until its full course had been run.

Rejection by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Agriculture of the subsidy payment plan proposed by the President and the Department of Agriculture as a reward to growers of essential products, and as a brake on price advances, excited yesterday covering of short positions and commission-house buying on the New York Cotton Exchange, raising values to the best levels in three weeks.

HYDERABAD, India, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- Like Cleopatra, this writer has just swallowed some pearls. A correspondent's coverage of India would not be complete without a brief study and description of the ancient systems of medicine still used by perhaps nine of ten natives of this country.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Disclosing the fourth attack in two weeks on one of his leading cohorts, Anton A. Mussert, chief of the Netherland Nazi party, announced today the formation of an armed guard to protect Nazi leaders, the German-controlled Netherland radio reported.

The diversion of contributions by the public from child welfare agencies to wartime organizations was decried yesterday by leaders in the field of child care. Child welfare is the community's priority, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, head of the Bureau of Child Hygiene, told members of the Women's National Republican Club, meeting in their headquarters, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle reported today the appointment of Charles B. Rugg, Boston lawyer, as a special assistant to represent the government in prosecution of an anti-trust suit against The Associated Press.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- The Motion Picture All-Industry Conference attended by the presidents of the several companies and studio executive members of the Association of Motion Picture Producers opened today at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

ALGIERS, Feb. 16 -- There was no sign of Pere Le Moko in Kasbah this morning as scores of gaunt ragged Arab children, a product of one of the world's worst slums, hungrily drank milk furnished by the American Red Cross from battered tin cups.

Police Commissioner Valentine called a session of 150 of his higher ranking aides -- from the rank of captain up -- yesterday to discuss changes in the air raid warning system, and took the occasion to read a stern lecture on the necessity for increased police vigilance to prevent crimes of violence and gambling.

Despite reports of increasing child delinquency in the city since the start of the war, and despite past teaching emphasis in the schools on the horrors of war, the school children of this city are adjusting themselves "very well" to the present conflict, according to Dr. Caroline B. Zachry of the Board of Education's Bureau of Child Guidance.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 16 -- By an order published today, signed by General Henri Honore Giraud, civil and military Commander in Chief, Jews will be admitted into combatant units in the French Army in future.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16 -- New taxation, including a measure bringing Palestine almost into line with Great Britain and the United States in income levies, has been prepared for enactment by the Palestine Administration as a further move to place this country's wartime financing on a broader basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -Claude R. Wickard, Food Administrator, and Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown have signed a "memorandum of understanding" dividing authority on food rationing, it was disclosed tonight.

William Hodson, who was killed in an airplane crash while on his way to direct relief in North Africa, gave his life for his country "just as certainly as the American marines who died on Guadalcanal of the soldiers in the Philippines," former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, director of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, declared yesterday at a memorial service at Hunter College.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- The death of Captain Richard Sanders Scott, 38, of the Army Air Forces, reported missing since Dec. 7 in North Africa has been confirmed to his family in Wellesley. He was buried at Oran, Algeria.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Formal application for a fifteen-day victory race meeting from March 9 to 27 was filed with Secretary Albin Tauzier of the Louisiana State Racing Commission today by Anthony Pelleteri, vice president of the Fair Grounds Breeders and Racing Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt pictured himself today as an economizer, the watchdog of the Treasury, and he indicated that those on Capitol Hill who would eliminate appropriations for post-war planning were spendthrifts.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 17 -- Kharkov, Russia's fourth city and anchor of the Germans' southern line, fell to a triumphant Russian army yesterday while to the southeast, on the Sea of Azov coast, the Red Army swept within seventeen miles of Taganrog, making a gain of eighteen miles west of recaptured Rostov.

Operations last year of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $9,914,548 after all charges, according to the annual statement for the year ended on Dec. 31, issued yesterday.

Cooperation extended during the past year to various branches of the armed forces in connection with procurement of various types of parachute fabrics was outlined yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., by Irene Blunt, secretary-treasurer of the group.

Two hundred and fifty thousand Victory gardens should be planted in this city in the Spring to insure an adequate food supply next Fall and Winter, Mrs. Vernon Lamson, chairman of the Victory garden department of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Secretary of Navy Frank Knox said today he assumed that the French warships recently arrived in this country would operate as French ships under French command, although no plans have as yet been made.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- There was very little activity today in the stock markets, and the tendency in all sections was for stocks to ease a little where changes ocsured. Gilt-edge issues generally were 1-16 lower, there being no signs of reinvestment of the South African vested loan money, release of which was begun yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16 (AP) Mohandas K. Gandhi, in the seventh day of his scheduled three weeks' fast, was growing constantly weaker today. There was anxiety among his followers that death might claim him this time.

Schools throughout this State are observing Bill of Rights Week, which ends Saturday, with special assembly exercises, discussions relating to the meaning of the Bill of Rights, showing of motion pictures, pageants, bulletin board displays and exhibitions of original posters by pupils.

Spotty action characterized the stock market yesterday, but prices closed firm after the list had weathered considerable profit-taking. Although volume on the Stock Exchange again crossed the million-share line, the tempo of trading was more subdued than for the 1,835,840 shares on Monday, which was the heaviest turnover in more than a year.

The increased volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange has brought more work for brokerage house staffs, but the overtime labor has not been without its compensations for the back-office crews. They have been treated to the delectable sight of partners striving mightily in the back offices for the first time in years and pitying themselves vocally.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company reported today $6,134,260 net profit on operating revenues of $37,305,279 in 1942, against $7,056, 585 on $35,343,035 in the preceding year.

Nine artists, all more or less well known to the local art world, have formed an organization with this rather curious name, New York Artists Painters. Their first show opened this week on the thirteenth floor at 444 Madison Avenue.

Victor Herwitz was accused in papers filed in Supreme Court yesterday of "conspiring," while he was assistant district attorney, with certain officials of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union to obtain control of the local so that he could be appointed its counsel.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- President Roosevelt had a series of callers and held a press conference.

Mrs. Skinker Matthews gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests included Mrs. William J. Hutchinson, Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips and Mrs. J. Fred Pierson. Another luncheon there was given by Baroness de Kerchove of Carlton House for Mrs. Andrew Fraser, Mrs. Reginald Marlowe and Mme. Blanche Vesnitch.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The government's announcement in the House of Commons today that it was ready to accept the Beveridge blueprint for social security in postwar Britain in "principle," but would have to reject some vital parts of the plan and would not make any final commitments now, left the Labor party cold.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- A United Nations Olympic Games, in which the contestants will be fighting men of all countries now engaged in the war with the Axis from this sector of the world front, is being planned for the Spring and Summer, it was learned today.

James G. Blaine has resigned as chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York so that he can devote more time to his duties as president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and chairman of the board of directors of the Greater New York Fund, it became known last night.
MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique: During the night of Feb. 15-16

Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the Commerce and Industry Committee, announced yesterday that the Red Cross War Fund of New York City would award the A.R.C. Citation for Patriotic Performance to New York business and industrial concerns that make corporate gifts and contributions from 90 per cent or more of both their executives and their employes to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund, in the drive which will begin on March 1.

BOSTON, Feb. 16 -- New sea weapons for use in the war against the Axis were shown today to newspaper correspondents at naval, shipping and aircraft engine plants. The new engines of war included the latest type of escort vessels, landing barges and other fighting ships which are believed by the Navy to be the most effective in fighting the submarine menace.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 -- After three weeks' filming of actual prison scenes at the Illinois State Penitentiary in Joliet for "Life of Touhy," based on the exploits of the gangster Roger Touhy, Twentieth Century-Fox is revising the script to produce it on a more important scale than originally intended.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Joltin' Joe DiMaggio trades a $35,000 or better baseball job tomorrow for the $50 monthly pay of a buck private.
CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Chicago will raise funds to replace the United States heavy cruiser of that name sunk by the Japanese off Guadalcanal, the Chicago branch of the War Savings Staff announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Small plants should have at least $25,000,000,000 to $35,000,000,000 worth of war production work this year, Colonel Robert W. Johnson, new vice chairman of the War Production Board which has charge of spreading work to smaller war plants, said today.

A 72-year-old artist whose paintings were never exhibited in a one-man show until last Spring has been honored by election to associate membership in the National Academy of Design, one of the oldest organizations of artists in the country.
Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to Russia, and Mrs. Davies have come to Hampshire House from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The toughest supply problems yet encountered in the North African theatre may have been in part the reason German troops were able to break through American lines for eighteen to twenty miles in Tunisia. This became apparent today with the study of supply lines that United States forces must maintain through the barren country there.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- It often has been said that Britain's two prime public recreations are beer and sports, and the government has tacitly reaffirmed this maxim so far during the war.

A realistic approach to an important new element of transportation, air cargo, may be expected as a result of the acceptance of a fund for research in this field by Wayne University. The study will be under the direction of Dr. Spencer A. Larson, associate professor of Marketing and also principal economist in the Wholesale and Retail Policy Section of the War Production Board.

The rapidly rising incidence of measles among New York children suggests that this may be another "measles year," Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. There were 228 new cases of measles in the city last week, contrasted with 133 the preceding week, ninety-one the week before that and sixty-five in the week ended Jan. 23.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. today began conferences with Federal Reserve Board officials on plans for the next Victory Loan drive in April -- when more of the campaign will be concentrated on the nation's smaller communities.

Manager Leo Durocher of the Dodgers has been placed in Class 1-A in the draft, subject immediately to induction into the armed forces, it became known late yesterday. His Selective Service Board, No. 133, at 129 Montague Street, Brooklyn, made the transfer from 3-A upon receipt of word from St. Louis that Durocher had passed his physical examination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Office of Price Administration instructed its regional administrators today to move immediately to make price adjustments in connection with the recent "freeze" of milk prices at producers' levels.

AN AMERICAN BOMBER STATION, England, Feb. 16 (AP) -- American Flying Fortresses and Liberators that pounded the U-boat base at St. Nazaire in broad daylight today bumped into a daredevil German flying circus and a thick curtain of anti-aircraft fire as they started back from dropping their explosives dead on the target.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Overnight developments in Washington were construed today by the grain trade as favorable for a higher range of prices and, paced by aggressive buying by commission houses with Eastern connections, wheat and rye advanced around 2 cents a bushel.

MADRID, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York conferred today with General Francisco Franco and later announced he would leave tomorrow for Rome, traveling by Italian commercial airline under a safe-conduct granted by the Italian Government.

The intense cold that descended on New York and the Eastern seaboard last Sunday night gave way slowly yesterday. The mercury, which started upward past the zero point at 10 P.M. on Monday had gained 21 points by 10 o'clock last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Employers of fewer than eight persons will be exempted from the order for a minimum forty-eight hour work week, it was said today, by regulations signed by the War Manpower Commission chairman, Paul V. McNutt.

The Berlin radio, in a broadcast recorded by The Associated Press, said last night that several Allied divisions were concentrated in the Ben Gardane area of Southern Tunisia and predicted a big Allied push there in the next few days.
The twelve-story apartment house on a plot 100.5 by 90 feet at 405 Park Avenue has been sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of Stroock Stroock Lavan, attorneys.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- An indication of future Finnish foreign policy was seen today in the manifesto issued just after the re-election of President Ryti in which the largest Finnish party, the Social Democratic, urged that Finland maintain friendly relations with the United States and meanwhile be ready to withdraw from the war whenever her independence was assured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- United States cash exports reached a value of $3,158,000,000 in 1942, or slightly in excess of the average of the three pre-war years of 1936-38, the Commerce Department announced today, The 1942 volume, it added, excluded shipments to our armed forces abroad and lend-lease shipments, while in the earlier war years a considerable increase in purchases by foreign governmental purchasing commissions mainly accounted for the high level of cash exports.

The largest crowd in the history of the event is scheduled to assemble tonight at Ruppert's Brewery, where the Boxing Writers Association of New York will hold its fifth annual dinner and award the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque for outstanding service to boxing during 1942, to Corporal Barney Ross of the Marine Corps.

Since it is clearly a matter of great importance to Americans to know what the rest of the world thinks about them, I believe a point mentioned by one of your Washington correspondents, Lewis Wood, in a dispatch describing the plans of the Office of War Information to send information to the four corners of the globe, is of more than technical interest.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Navy communique 282:

The second floor, comprising about 15,000 square feet of space, in 203 East Eighteenth Street has been leased by Viewtone, Inc., for the manufacture and sale of radio and electrical devices, and a floor, in 121-23 East Twenty-fourth Street has been rented by Charles C. Cuker for the manufacture of precision instruments and precision parts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 -- Joe DiMaggio, who already has passed, his preliminary Army examination, revealed today that he had not received a 1943 contract from the Yankees, but said he "would only have sent it back anyway."

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- The Republican majorities in both houses of the Legislature moved today to enact the major parts of Governor Dewey's legislative program. All indications are that they intend to adopt it as speedily as possible and pave the way for early adjournment.
On March 1, as you are well aware, the point-rationing of processed foods becomes effective. Here are the steps leading up to it:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Conferees of the Senate and the House agreed today on terms of a bill to permit the merger of Postal Telegraph, Inc., and the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The Consolidated Edison Company and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company warned yesterday that they had reached the bottom of their fuel oil supplies essential for the production of gas. They appealed to the millions of householders to conserve gas by every means, including cold baths, less baking and less use of the kitchen range for household heating.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Representative Luce and Representative Fulbright of Arkansas exchanged caustic words on the House floor today over post-war freedom of the airways.

The venereal disease rate in the armed services of the United States throughout the world is 40 per 1,000 per year, probably the lowest military rate in our history, it was learned yesterday from official sources.

Life insurance written in January was 39.9 per cent under that in the same month a year ago, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reported yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce. While the decline was the largest for any month in several years, it was pointed out that last years figure was unusually high, having exceeded the January, 1941, total by 66.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -The War Department made public today the names of ninety-seven soldiers killed and ninety-seven wounded in action. Included were casualties in the African, Alaskan, European, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Illegal markets for meat, resulting from scarcities and heavy demand from consumers, are spreading rapidly and threaten the packing industry and the food supplies of the Army and the Navy, Thomas E. Wilson, chairman of Wilson Co., packers, said today to stockholders at their annual meeting here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -Secretary Wickard told a Senate Agriculture Subcommittee today that a "black market" in beef threatened to disrupt the country's war food program. Informed by Senator Aiken of Vermont at an inquiry into war food production of reports that beefsteak was selling as high as $1.75 a pound in a New York "black market," Mr. Wickard said he preferred to leave the problem to the Office of Price Administration, but added:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, dismissed Ferdinand Eberstadt, WPB vice chairman, today and promoted Charles E. Wilson, former president of the General Electric Corporation, to be executive vice chairman of WPB, in complete charge of all programs, including the war production scheduling problem.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 16 -- The "battle of supply," on which the ultimate victory in Tunisia rests, is being convincingly won by the Allied navies and air forces, which have escorted several million tons of shipping into North African ports since the opening of the campaign, Admiral of the Fleet Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, Allied naval Commander in Chief in the North African-Mediterranean theatre of operations, has revealed.
The Treasury, through its war savings staffs covering the nation, is urging that the millions of war savings stamp albums now outstanding be filled as soon as possible and converted into war bonds.

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating an hour, returned a first-degree murder verdict yesterday against John Regan, 33 years old, a previously convicted slayer, for killing Francis McGovern, 27, a fellow-longshoreman, in a West Fiftieth Street cider stube Sept. 8.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- A census is about to be taken in France of all men between 21 and 31 years to ascertain whether they are "engaged in work useful for the needs of the country." If not, they will be assigned compulsory labor, presumably in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The essence of his anti-racketeering bill is to eliminate "just the rough stuff," Representative Hobbs of Alabama declared today before the rules committee, which is considering a rule to expedite consideration of the measure on the floor.

Vice Admiral Raymond Fenard, chief of the French naval mission in the United States, said Monday in announcing the arrival of the Richelieu and three other modern warships of the French fleet that plans for assigning the ships to war duty with other United Nations craft were indefinite, but he indicated that they would protect the route to French North Africa.

" Star Spangled Rhythm" today enters its eighth and final week at the Paramount, thus becoming the only film in the theatre's sixteen-year history to play so long an engagement. "Road to Morocco" is the runner-up with a seven-week stand made there last November and December.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 16 -- T. James Tumulty, who for several years was one of the most conspicuous critics of the administration of Mayor Frank Hague, was named an assistant corporation counsel at $4,000 a year today by the City Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 -- A plan for the merger of the Northern Power Company into the Superior Water, Light and Power Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by these two subsidiaries of American Power and Light Company, a part of the Electric Bond and Share Company system.
High Command communique broadcast from -- Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WILSON, N.C., Feb. 16 (AP) -- The government's anti-trust case against the Atlantic Commission Company, a subsidiary of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and twenty-eight other defendants operating in the potato industry collapsed in the Federal District Court today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Allied medium bombers, continuing heavy assaults on Japanese position in the Southwestern Pacific, scored "excellent result" yesterday in raids against the twin enemy bases of Lae and Salamaua on the north coast of New Guinea, the Allied command announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting is in progress on the Yunnan border and the Kwantung and Hupeh fronts, a Chinese communique said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- The first tank-car train of oil to be shipped to the East from the Norris City, Ill., terminus of the 24-inch, Texas-Illinois pipeline will be loaded and dispatched Friday, Harold L. Ickes, petroleum administrator, said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) - Prentiss Brown, the new Price Administrator, declared tonight he wanted to "flatly and vigorously" deny any impression that he favored appeasement on price controls and asserted that there should be no surrender to those seeking to break farm parity prices and wage stabilization policies.

An official summary of extensive air and naval operations in the Solomons area from Jan. 29 through Feb. 7 reveals at least part of what happened during the Japanese evacuation of Guadalcanal. No ships met in battle except some torpedo boats and destroyers. Those lost on both sides went down under air attack.

Three hundred students, half the number the Navy will send to Columbia University by July 1 for specialized training, will study at the School of Engineering, Associate Dean James K. Finch disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- For heroism in recuing fliers forced down in Greenland, Lieut. Col. Bernt Balchen of New York City, Arctic explorer, and seven other officers and enlisted men of the Army have received the award of the Soldier's Medal.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Surging across the Channel today for the second successive daylight raid this week over enemy-occupied France, Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force hammered St. Nazaire, now being used by the Nazis as a big U-boat base second in importance only to that at Lorient.
A gentleman from Georgia wearing a captain's bars dropped in for a chat that was devoted entirely to fishing and hunting.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 -- The British Eighth Army, having brought up sufficient forces to crack the enemy resistance at Ben Gardane, some twenty miles within the Tunisian frontier, discovered just before striking the Axis troops that they had followed about the same procedures that characterized the long retreat from El Alamein, Egypt.

As a result of the vigilance of the Fifth Avenue Association in cooperating with the Army, every store window in the Fifth Avenue shopping district now complies with dimout regulations. Captain William J. Pedrick, executive vice president of the association, reported yesterday at the thirty-sixth annual meeting and election in the Hotel Biltmore.

The red pompoms and sky-blue collars of the French Navy were conspicuous over the week-end in the military parade that is getting to be as characteristic of wartime Broadway as the bright lights used to be. Always a vestibule to the playhouses of the town, Broadway has now become the vestibule to the war theatres.

Fordham and City College clash for the twenty-ninth time tonight. The oldest of metropolitan college basketball rivals come together in the feature game of the doubleheader in Madison Square Garden. The opener, starting at 8:15, pairs N.Y.U. against Temple.

During the last few days a number of bills and resolutions looking forward to the post-war world have been introduced in Congress. Senator Gillette of Iowa has proposed that the President be urged by Congress to negotiate "a post-war charter" in order to give substance to the declaration of the Atlantic Charter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- A program for style simplification and for industry concentration upon more utilitarian types of garments is under consideration by the special industry advisory committee for the knitted outerwear industry, which met here today with War Production Board representatives.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 16 -- Four hundred of the 1,400 first day shift workers at the plant of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation walked out today. They were joined later by 150 of the second day shift of 900, who failed to report for work on that shift.

ED KENNEDY has been at Columbia University so long that about the only things on the campus antedating him are Nicholas Murray Butler and the original charter from the King of England. For thirty-three years he has been coach of the Lion swimming team and, as President Roosevelt remarked in his latest speech, "a great deal of water has flowed over the dam since then.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Colonel Charles Henry Barth, hitherto attached to the General Staff Corps, has been assigned as the Chief of Staff of the United States Army in the European theatre, it was announced today.
The offensive, or hitting, power of American and British land strength is to a considerable extent dissipated and limited by the strategic exigencies of this global war.

The performance of "Walkuere," second in Wagner's special cycle of operas uncut, now taking place on Tuesday nights at the Metropolitan, was threatened yesterday evening when at the end of the second act the voice of Mr. Huehn, the Wotan of the occasion, frogged and the baritone feared that he could not finish the final act.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The Ways and Means Committee moved today toward a compromise on the problem of putting income taxpayers on a current basis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Miss Antoinette Kleinman, Second Lieutenant in the Army Nurse Corps now on duty in North Africa, finds a new incentive in her chosen work in the "challenge every day to keep men fit for field duty."

Edward L. Bernays, co-chairman of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, has announced the names of a group of industries setting aside collection days for their employes. Those cooperating include Bendix Aviation Corporation, Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Chrysler Corporation, North American Aviation, Inc.; R.G. LeTourneau Co., Curtiss-Wright Corporation, Boeing Aircraft Corporation and Railway Express Agency.

Mrs. Halstead G. Freeman and Mrs. Carman H. Messmore, chairmen of the British War Relief Society's Piccadilly Arcade at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, jointly gave a luncheon yesterday at the Snack Bar there for staff members before the auction of family treasures which featured the observance of Celebrities Day marking the reopening of the shop.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission borrowing of $5,000,000 from four banks on 2 3/4 per cent serial notes payable over five years. The funds will be used for general corporate purposes. The Bankers Trust Company, the Manufacturers Trust Company and the First National Bank of Chicago each have a $1,500,000 share in the loan, while the Bank of New York has the remaining $500,000.

Mayor La Guardia requested the City Council yesterday to join him in urging the Legislature to enact bills introduced by Senator Frederic R. Coudert Jr. and Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat transferring the Bureau of Supplies of the Board of Education to the City Purchasing Department in line with recent recommendations of William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation.

It remained for a real estate specialist to scoop the social science professors in one of the most interesting recent surveys of the American people. To be sure, the study covers a very small portion of the United States -- namely, 613 families in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle announced today that a Federal grand jury at Baltimore had indicted twelve persons on charges of mail fraud involving Army and Navy munitions contracts with Triumph Explosives, Inc., of Elkton, Md.

Heads of the State's race tracks have had a preliminary meeting with officials representing Governor Dewey, and there will be subsequent meetings this week, in addition to that of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, scheduled today.

New ceiling prices on from 800 to 1,000 food items, superseding the March, 1942, levels, will be announced during the coming month, it was disclosed yesterday by Milton Rich, acting chief of the food unit of the New York Regional Office of Price Administration, at a meeting of the Super-Markets Institute at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Feb. 17, 1943 Air-sea clashes resulting from American moves to reinforce Guadalcanal and Japanese moves to evacuate it occurred chronologically as follows:

The art and the personality of Marjorie Lawrence capped an evening of great beauty at Carnegie Hall last night at the benefit performance given for the Grenfell Association of America by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) -Representative McCormack, majority leader of the House, today denounced former president Hoover's recent, warning against hasty prosecution of the war as "honest but misguided" advice leading down "the road to defeat."

Eharkov, captured by the Nazis on Oct. 25, 1941, is the principal center of the economic life of the Ukraine and the hub of six major railways radiating in all directions. Known as the Russian Pittsburgh, its steel furnaces before the German occupation surpassed the combined output of Japan, Italy and Poland.

Possibility of a black market in the shoe trade has loomed since the Office of Price Administration's rationing order was released the week-end before last, it was learned in the trade yesterday. Officials of the agency, it was reported, fully realize the dangers of illegal trading and admit that they have not the facilities to police the order beyond the regulation which requires dealers to surrender their customers' ration stamps to get new goods.

Dresses that have the double appeal of price and good looks are of interest to women today. The major part of the showing that Milgrim's staged on its fourth floor yesterday afternoon met these two standards. They were young (what woman does not like a dress that has the youth appeal?) and fell into the moderate price brackets.

The Bendel showing of Spring millinery, held yesterday morning, started with the announcement that there were no backward looks in the creating of the styles, no thumbing of costume books, but rather that the inspiration was of today and that brow and crown lines were keyed to present-day living.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 16 -- Following upon a Rumanian order calling for "early evacuation from Bucharest and other large towns" of all "non-essential civilians, women and children" to avoid undue congestion at a moment when developments might make further demands on the population, similar measures were ordered several days ago in Eastern Hungary, where developments are being "closely watched."
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The establishment of food rationing on a regional rather than a national basis was urged yesterday by food retailers at a "rationing clinic" sponsored by Supermarket Merchandising at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The proposal was one of a series of resolutions adopted by the meeting of nearly 100 supermarket operators of the East Coast area.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commander of all American forces in the Middle East, announced today the appointment of Colonel Hugo P. Rush of New Providence, Pa., as chief of the United States Army Air Force's Ninth Bomber Command, succeeding Brig. Gen. Patrick W. Timberlake.

Producers of infants' and children's wear were assured last night that the way is still open for easing of restrictions upon use of textile fabrics in their field, but were advised to collect all possible pertinent data for presentation to the WPB.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Feb. 16 -- Expansion of the Fort Worth Citizens Association to embrace a campaign against all types of industrial and home accidents was planned today under the direction of William A.
