Irvin, national chairman of the war production fund to conserve manpower and former president of the United States Steel Corporation.

Award of a new issue of $600,000 of airport bonds of St. Louis, Mo., was made yesterday to a syndicate comprising the 1VIilwaukee Company, the Illinois Company of Chicago, A.G. Becker Co., Inc., and Barr Brothers Co., Inc. The bankers bid 100.643, naming the interest rate as 1 1/8 per cent.

Staving off a determined last-minute rally by the Tigers, Columbia upset Princeton, 61 -- 59, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League encounter at Morningside Heights last night. Five minutes before the end the Lions held a ten-point lead, but the closing seconds found them desperately protecting a mere two-point margin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce "wholeheartedly" approved continuance of the Lend-Lease Administration today and expressed the hope that "conversations between Mme. Chiang Kai-shek and the Administration'' would meet the wants of China, which, she said, had received "next to nothing."

Twenty-five out of thirty-eight departments of New York stores showed gains in newspaper advertising over last year in January, according to an analysis of linage figures released yesterday by Media Records, Inc. Total linage for the month was up 15.4 per cent to 2,867,015.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell of Puerto Rico today invited members of the House Insular Affairs Committee considering a bill which would end his tenure to go to the island and get first-hand information of the political situation there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee moved today to put the enforcement of the War Manpower Commission's "work or fight" order squarely up to local Selective Service boards where unnecessary absenteeism in Navy shipyards was found responsible for delay in shipbuilding.

" High Tor," the historic Hudson River summit that was the scene of one of Maxwell Anderson's plays, will be preserved as a scenic landmark "for all time," Miss Margaret H. Gillmore, chairman of a committee to save the peak from commercial uses, announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Hudson River Conservation Society.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The heavy cruiser Chicago and an unnamed destroyer succumbed to Japanese air attacks, but American forces sank or damaged fifteen enemy ships in a running series of air-naval engagements in the Solomon Islands area between Jan. 29 and Feb. 4, the Navy announced here today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Farmer Sam Breadon, who raises world champion Cardinals, is virtually shutting down baseball's biggest incubator business, but lack of players, not lack of profits, is the reason for his curtailment of minor-league operations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 16 -- Squadrons of American medium tanks drove the advance guard of one of Germany's finest armored divisions back to the region of Sidi bou Zid yesterday afternoon in a victorious tank battle that checked, at least temporarily, the progress of the northern arm of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's offensive on the central Tunisian front.

The fiftieth anniversary of William B. Joyce's association with the insurance industry will be marked by a luncheon to be given in his honor at the Bankers Club today, with Louis H. Pink, former State Superintendent of Insurance, serving as chairman of the committee on arrangements.

ON THE Upper Peninsula of Michigan, by the cold waters of Lake Superior, there are iron mines and logging camps, small towns and cut-over forests, hunting, fishing and farming. There Winters are long and hard and life lacks many of the amenities to be found in great cities. Robert Traver wouldn't live anywhere else. He finds cities ruthless, impersonal, hectic and depressing; and will have none of them.
The Biltmore Theatre, partly owned by George Abbott, will receive his presentation of "Kiss and Tell" on the evening of St. Patrick's Day.

Concentration of the pulp and paper industry into a limited number of nucleus plants would make only a "most limited" contribution to the war effort, E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared yesterday at a meeting of the fine paper division of the National Paper Trade Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Edwin C. Conover, vice president of Trans-Films, Inc., has rented a penthouse in 17 East Eighty-ninth Street through Douglas L. Elliman Co. William V. Goldie, lawyer, leased through the same brokers an apartment in 1215 Fifth Avenue.

A violent explosion on the top floor of a three-story building at 88 Columbus Avenue, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets, shattered windows for a block in either direction at 2:15 A.M. today, driving guests in the Hotel Empire near by from their rooms and injuring at least one person.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- For nearly two hours today Senators, Representatives and Capitol attaches viewed the showing of Army morale-building films but they watched in vain for "the cleverly organized campaign material" which had convinced Senator Holman of Oregon, at a preview that President Roosevelt would seek a fourth term.

By what process of reasoning can the OPA justify its order permitting students engaged in the study of dancing to use automobiles in getting to the studios? In other words, the business of learning how to dance now comes under the head of essential driving, according to the announcement in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The usual human factors make up a goodly part of the situation in the War Production Board that exploded today when Chairman Nelson asked for the resignation of Vice Chairman Eberstadt and assigned full control of production to Vice Chairman Wilson.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Representatives of 350,000 members of the five operating railroad brotherhoods and of the country's principal railroad managements began direct conference negotiations today on the unions' demands for a wage increase.

President Risto Ryti, under whose government Finland entered into a "defensive war" against Russia simultaneously with Hitler's treacherous assault on the latter, has been re-elected by an overwhelming vote. But the re-election took place under circumstances which hold out the hope that Finland might become the first country to detach itself from Hitler and arrange a separate peace.

Need for sound and equitable termination clauses in government contracts for war production was emphasized yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager-on-leave of the National Association of Credit Men, at the luncheon session of the wartime credit managers' conference sponsored by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Further evidence of air-minded Britons' growling anxiety over post-war competi tion in commercial aviation was seen today in a speech by Sir Frederick Ogilvie, one-time Professor of Political Economy and former director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, at University College in London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 -- The House Rules Committee approved today a resolution creating a permanent twenty-one-member aviation committee, overriding protests by committees charged with Jurisdiction in that field.

Preliminary plans for an "Easter Parade" luncheon and fashion show, to be given April 13 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop, were drawn up yesterday at a meeting of committees at the home of Mrs. Herman L. Hoops of 830 Park Avenue.

As a result of operations in 1942 the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York not only will maintain last year's dividend scale in 1943 but has increased by $4,104,000 -- to $35,538,350 -- the surplus reserve available for investment and mortality fluctuations and other contingencies, according to a report on the company's 10Oth year.

Less than two minutes after the start of the Fordham-City College basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night the Beavers were on top by an 8-0 margin. So quickly and so unexpectedly did Nat Holman's lads electrify both the crowd and the opposition that to all appearances a major upset was in the making.

The major works of Ludwig van Beethoven, including the sixteen string quartets and the Grosse-Fuge, the ten sonatas for violin and piano and the trios and Lieder, will be presented next season by the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. These works will constitute the entire program material of the organization for the season, according to announcement by I.A. Hirschmann, its founder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- To halt the rush of buyers to food stores, sales of canned meats and fish were frozen as of midnight tonight by the Office of Price Administration pending the establishment of the rationing program for meat products, which is expected about April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that perishable foods held in cold storage warehouses and meat packing plants on Feb. 1 showed quite significant reductions from a month earlier for all commodities except pork and lard.

Arnaldo Estrella, the Brazilian pianist, winner of the Columbia Concerts Award, followed his recent appearance as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with a recital which attracted a large audience yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. With the orchestra Mr. Estrella had performed a dramatic concerto in the virtuoso style.

Led by Gil Eaton, who scored 21 points, the St. Francis College basketball team humbled Brooklyn College on the latter's court last night, 50 to 25. The visitors had things their way from the start, and at the half were in front, 36 to 13.

Prices of cotton futures improved slightly yesterday as price-fixing in the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange easily absorbed fairly heavy liquidation. Business was done within a trading range of 8 to 10 points during the session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A Senate judiciary subcommittee reported favorably to the full committee today on the Equal Rights Amendment, which is backed by nineteen national and several hundred State and local women's organizations.

The City Defense Recreation Center at 99 Park Avenue, the Stage Door Canteen in Forty-fourth Street west of Broadway and the National Catholic Community Service clubhouse at 17 East Fifty-first Street (one of the largest affiliated units of the United Service Organizations here) all sent word yesterday to crews of French warships here that they were welcome to use their entertainment facilities.

Alexander Borovsky, Russian pianist, played an exacting program at Carnegie Hall last night after an absence of ten years. A large audience, including many of his compatriots, was enthusiastic in its appreciation of the brilliant playing.

Suits, suits, suits -- this was the theme on which Macy's played some twenty-four variations at a style showing yesterday. Even to the initiate it was interesting to see what versatility designers have exercised in the making of the darlings of the season and to observe what the inventive talents of Amy Fagan, Macy's stylist, can do in dressing up even the simplest little numbers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 17 -- German armored forces storming down from Faid four days ago came uncomfortably close to capturing General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied commander, it was revealed today.

Possibility of a shortage of waste paper within ninety days, as a result of its increased use by paper mills as a substitute for wood pulp, was hinted yesterday at meetings of the American Paper and Pulp Association, holding its annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Elizabeth Niehaus, in 136 E 67th St; Auguste Bonavita, in 1158 5th Ave; James R. Henry, Hardwick Moseley, Dr. Maxwell L. Gelfand, John E. Shinitz, in 60 Gramercy Park; Herbert Emory Greene, Anne Campbell Greene, Manuel Quintana, Frank M. Trager, in 245 E 72d St; Herbert G. Bristol, in 102 E 22d St; Irving A. Insley, in 24 W 55th St; Thomas H. Corpe, in 17 W 54th St -- Douglas Gibbons Co, brokers.

Advice to housewives considering doing the family wash in case of a tie-up of commercial laundries was offered yesterday by the Home Economics Department of Teachers College, Columbia University, where four professors have given special attention to the subject.

Two officers and two members of the Harry M. Sullivan Association of Woodside, Queens, accused of conducting bingo games in violation of the State lottery laws, were acquitted yesterday by a jury of nine men and three women before Judge Thomas Downs in Queens County Court.

The psychological growth of German youth after the last war "should be an object lesson to us, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared yesterday in decrying today's emphasis in this country on "military exercises" for young persons.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 17 -- The prices of foods are three times the levels of August, 1939. Rents have been stabilized by law and clothing and shoes are fixed at prices about fifty per cent higher than before the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve System board of governors, told the Senate Banking Committee today that the United States is doing a "very bad" job of war financing by comparison with other countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The House passed the 1944 fiscal supply bill for independent agencies today, carrying $2,616,972,913, after it had voted by rollcall, 224 to 157, to trim $3,831,460 from the Administrative fund of the Federal Home Land Bank Administration.

Consolidated net profit of the Crucible Steel Company of America and subsidiaries for 1942 was $4,864,781, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $7.26 a share on the common stock, comparing with $7,439,480, or $12.95 a share, in 1941.

This week's only Broadway opening takes place this evening when Eddie Dowling brings in "This Rock," a comedy by Walter Livingston Faust, a New York business man who writes plays as an avocation. Billie Burke returns to the New York stage after a twelve-year absence to star in the production, and those featured are Nicholas Joy, Zachary Scott, Jane Sterling and Alastair Kyle.

The American steel industry has invested nearly $1,205,000,000 of its own funds to increase productive capacity and improve its equipment since 1938, the year in which Hitler moved into Czechoslovakia and Austria, according to a compilation by the American Iron and Steel Institute made public yesterday.

As a cushion for post-war unemployment, the possibilities of which are "even more frightening than the war itself," Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged a "gigantic public works program" which would include the construction of highways on a national and "even a hemispheric basis."

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Three major appointments were made in the State Tax Department today by Gov. Dewey, the principal one being the naming of Clifford J. Fletcher, Republican City Chairman of Utica, as Motor Vehicle Commissioner, succeeding John Splain of Queens, who resigned earlier in the day.
Intent on moving into first place in the National Hockey League race, the Red Wings will seek to hand one more defeat to the Rangers when the teams clash at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Mayor La Guardia warned a class of new policemen yesterday to "shoot first and be quick on the trigger" in their encounters with armed criminals but to be cautious in their treatment of peaceful citizens. He spoke at special exercises in the line-up room at Manhattan Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Sales of independent retailers increased 4 per cent in January over the corresponding month of 1942, according to preliminary data released today by J.C. Capt, director of the census. January sales were 37 per cent below those recorded for the preceding month.

The Locust Manor Branch of the Queens Public Libraries, at 116-06 Merrick Road, will close tonight at 7 o'clock instead of 9 o'clock and there is the possibility that the Baisley Park Branch at 116-03 Sutphin Boulevard and the Long Island City Branch at 27-01 49th Avenue may have to close evenings in the near future unless some arrangement can be made for better police protection in the area, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- British submarines in the Central Mediterranean have delivered another heavy blow against Axis supply lines to North African armies, destroying six more enemy vessels, damaging a seventh and probably sinking another, an Admiralty communique disclosed tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- In the stock markets today the debate in the House of Commons on the Beveridge social security scheme tended to improve insurance shares. Prudential A rose 1/2 to 21 1/2 and B 2 shillings to 95. Pearl gained 3/8 at 13 and Brittanic 1/4 at 13.

Business volume of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation last year fell more than 50 per cent below the record 1941 peak, but retrenchment resulted in combined net earnings of $14,405,982, against $17,324,310 in 1941, according to a report yesterday by Henry Ittleson, chairman, and Arthur O. Dietz, president.

LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Distinguished Flying Crosses were awarded to four American airmen, Air Medals to 209 and Oak Leaf Clusters to thirty-one in a list made public by United States Army Headquarters today. Captain Billy B. Southworth Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, pilot and son of the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, was among those receiving Air Medals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 17 -- The presidents of Harvard, Yale and Princeton -- the Big Three -- announced today in a joint statement that because of wartime conditions they believed "that the continued maintenance of 'athletics as usual' at these three institutions is no longer feasible."
LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- An Army proposal to reduce pre-medical training from the present three-year average to fifteen months is against the best interests of Army and civilian medical services and is unnecessary, the executive council of the Association of American Medical Colleges declared today.

In a setting which emphasized the place of boxing as a component part of basic service training, Corporal Barney Ross of the United States Marine Corps last night was honored as the representative of boxing who did the most through 1942 to advance the ring sport.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The question of bathing facilities for Prime Minister Winston Churchill occupied the House of Commons briefly today when Ellis Smith, Laborite, hinted that aircraft mechanics who, he believed, might better have been employed elsewhere had, in his opinion, frittered away their time outfitting a certain nameless plane as a luxury liner.

Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, told 1,270 new ensigns at graduation exercises of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School in Riverside Church yesterday morning that the most serious problem they and the nation now faced was German submarine warfare.

Will some one in Washington explain to the millions of so-called white-collar workers how they will meet the proposed income taxes? These millions, representing the backbone of the country, few of whom have profited one penny from the war, are facing a real problem -- nay, even a crisis.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Columbia's athletes ended the four-year reign of Princeton as champions of the annual Polar Bear track and field meet and drew even with the Tigers in the number of victories on Goldie Field today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A United States submarine probably sank a Japanese cruiser in a recent attack in Pacific waters, the Navy reported here tonight in a summary of seven successful attacks by our undersea raiders. No details of the torpedoing of the enemy cruiser were given, but a communique bringing submarine reports up to date stated, "One cruiser damaged and probably sunk."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- With the arrest today of Richard Oliver, 37 years old, on draft evasion charges, the New Jersey division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was concerned with another Negro cult believed to be Japanese-inspired.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- An assertion that thousands of persons will go hungry this year and next unless the government acts immediately to solve manpower and related problems affecting the distribution and processing of foods for civilians was made today by a "war committee" of the food industry.
LONDON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Conditions in the wool goods markets reveal that all talk of clothing rationing is absurd and that civilian supplies of wool clothing next Fall will be as plentiful as they are today, according to wool growers, weavers, clothing manufacturers and retailers who were canvassed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A program designed to increase pig iron production by an estimated fifty tons per blast furnace daily through improvement in the quality and uniformity of coke was announced today by Secretary Ickes as Solid Fuels Coordinator.

The nation's supply of gasoline was increased further last week, but stocks of both light and heavy fuel oil dropped again, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. On the East Coast, the institute's index of these three oil products on Feb. 13 stood at 36.5, compared with 34.6 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, when the sharp downward trend started.

Seventy-five young women were graduated from the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing last night at the school's sixtieth annual commencement exercises, held in the Blumenthal auditorium of the hospital at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 17 -- Targets on Sicily and in Southern Italy have been attacked again by Royal Air Force planes with satisfactory results.

Home Owners Loan Corporation The United States Savings and Loan League has joined other banking organizations to urge Congress to authorize the prompt liquidation of the Home Owners Loan Corporation. At present the Dirksen bill would require the HOLC to sell its mortgages.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 17 -- It was revealed today that three weeks ago three Parisian journalists were arrested for an attack on Pierre Laval and his son-in-law, Count Rene de Chambrun, in a weekly publication, The Pillory. Only the author of the article is still held.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of China's Generalissimo and champion of the demands of her country for more material assistance in fighting the Japanese, was welcomed to Washington today by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -The War Department's hotel acquisition program, including the purchase of the Greenbrier at White Sulphur Springs W.Va., and the Stevens Hotel in Chicago, won the approval of a Congressional committee today.

Mayor La Guardia, whose intervention helped the city's laundries win from the government restoration of part of their fuel oil ration cut, is now planning to go to bat for himself, it was learned last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Negotiations between representatives of the railroads and the Big Five operating brotherhoods over the union's demands for a 30 per cent wage increase, with a minimum daily increase of $3, broke down today, both sides saying they could not come to any agreement and there was no need to prolong the discussion.

Merchandise inventories of New York and Brooklyn department stores at the end of January were 11 per cent higher than for the corresponding period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17 -- Penn took a stronger lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race and Yale sank more firmly into the cellar bottom tonight when the Quakers beat the Elis, 56-35. It was Penn's thirteenth straight victory, its fifth league success in five games and Yale's sixth league defeat in six contests.

DALLAS, Feb. 17 -- Business and industrial leaders and public officials laid plans today to reduce in the Dallas area the manpower loss to war plants and other industries through accidents. The step was taken in response to proposals of William A. Irvin, national chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower.

James A. Farley returned yesterday afternoon from a five-week trip which took him to Mexico on business for the Coca-Cola Export Sales Company, of which he is chairman of the board, and enabled him to visit political friends in the South on his way back.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Criminal Court of Appeals reversed today convictions of three defendants in Oklahoma's 1940 communism trials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced today fifty-eight casualties, including eight dead, thirty-eight wounded and twelve missing.
Alice Mary, Countess of Gainsborough, who has been staying in this country for two years, is expected to arrive today from Washington, and will be at Essex House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Eight high school students from New York, two from Connecticut and two from New Jersey are among forty boys and girls from sixteen States who have been selected as finalists in the annual science talent search sponsored by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
Six hundred enthusiastic Waves and Spars trainees "docked" here yesterday to begin their six-week "boot" training at the Naval Training School at Hunter College in the Bronx.
A new survey of the city's air raid defenses will be conducted tonight when, at 9 o'clock, the first test of the new air raid warning system will be staged.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- The first issue of callable bonds in the history of New York State's borrowings was announced today by State Controller Frank C. Moore. He revealed that the State will put into effect a new policy in financing long-term improvements, in announcing that $12,000,000 of grade crossing bonds, with the new call provisions, will be sold at the Controller's office in Albany at 1 P.M. on Feb. 25th.

The twenty-first annual exhibition of "Fifty Books of the Year," organized by the American Institute of Graphic Arts, was opened last night at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, where the display will be on view in Room 322 through March 14.

H.F. Sinclair, president of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, criticized the oil industry yesterday for failure to proceed more rapidly with the joint use of facilities and the release of unneeded manpower as directed in the order issued on Sept. 25 by Deputy Petroleum Administrator Ralph K. Davies.

"The Crystal Ball," a comedy romance starring Paulette Goddard and Ray Milland, will have its local premiere today at the Capitol. Featured in the United Artists release, which was directed by Elliott Nugent, are William Bendix, Virginia Field, Cecil Kellaway and Gladys George.

Even if war risk premiums were omitted from the calculation, the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company still would have had last year the largest premium income in its 100-year history, according to a report yesterday by William D. Winter, president.
The appearance on Feb. 10 of Mr. Hodges' letter entitled "Penalty Seen for Thrift" and the editorial "Psychology of Rationing" seems to be an interesting coincidence.

In the first attempt in the New York district to enforce gasoline rationing rules by speedometer readings, the Office of Price Administration sought yesterday to revoke, for the duration of the war, all gasoline allotments to Emanuel Diamond, vice president of Elco Insulation, Inc., 345 East Twenty-third Street.

Our editorial on tonnage tried to make the point that ships are designed to carry loads of some kind and that gross, net, deadweight and displacement tonnage are all intended to throw light on size or carrying capacity. Gross tonnage, for example, expresses internal capacity in units of 100 cubic feet, a volume arbitrarily allotted to a ton of 2,240 pounds.

The Norman Dines, who live on an eight-acre estate overlooking a lake in Katonah in Northern Westchester, weren't certain yesterday but had the uneasy feeling that they have touched off an epochal reversal in the relationship between householders and home help.

In peacetime any vessel may steam freely through the English Channel, the Strait of Gibraltar or the coastal waters of any nation. But never has the airplane enjoyed what international lawyers call "the right of free passage" through the atmosphere. All the men who flew around the world obtained the right to traverse the countries on their courses only after their governments had begun the necessary diplomatic negotiations.
Anything made of metal appears somewhat in the nature of an anachronism at the moment -- yet glistening golden metal is the stuff in which a bright new make-up is encased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Commissioner Elmer Layden of the National Football League said he found "definite encouragement" for the continuance of professional football in talks today with Manpower Commissioner Paul V. McNutt and Transportation Director Joseph B. Eastman.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 17 (U.P.) -- Rome dispatches reported today that Virginio Gayda said in his newspaper Giornale d'Italia, that Italy could under certain circumstances consider making a separate peace with Britain or the United States, but never with Russia.

Since withholding taxes promise to become a greater factor for the duration, credit men should insist now that business firms set up special bank accounts for such funds to prevent mingling of tax moneys with business assets, Irving Baron of Irving Baron Co., accountants, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Uptown Credit Group, affiliate of the National Federation of Textiles, in the National Republican Club.

Three Pulitzer Prize poets, William Rose Benet, recipient of the award in 1942; Robert P. Tristram Coffin, winner in 1936, and John Gould Fletcher, winner of 1939, have written poems in honor of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Red Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 -Warner Brothers will star Sydney Greenstreet in a picture to be titled "The Fat Man," the nickname of the character he played in his first picture, "The Maltese Falcon." In the new film, to be produced by Jerry Wald, the one-time stage actor will play the part of a former college professor who turns detective to break up a San Francisco spy ring.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 17 -- Sledgehammer blows dealt by the Twenty-first and Tenth German Armored Divisions drove American tank units twenty-two miles from the region of Sidi bou Zid to the outskirts of Sbeitla yesterday.

A nationally known company, with headquarters in Chicago, is now making a highly concentrated beef extract -- a product that is not on the roster of point-rationed foods and that may conveniently pinch hit for the tinned soups and the fresh meats that are to be included on the list.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 18 -- Triumphant Russian troops, sweeping over the snow-covered flatlands beyond Kharkov, have captured Bogodukhov, thirty-five miles northwest of the city, and they have taken the key railroad city of Slavyansk in a new threat to the Germans in the entire Donets Basin-Ukraine theatre, communiques announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt conferred with the Minister from New Zealand, President Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth and members of the Pacific War Council.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Quoting reports from Stockholm that Virginio Gayda, Italian editor, was suggesting peace feelers to the United States and Great Britain, Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said today that the enemy was opening a "talk offensive" and this was the "first open appeal" from an Axis spokesman.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The battle over the Beveridge report continued inside and outside the House of Commons today. Outside, the War Cabinet decided that the government would not yield an inch. Inside, the clamor grew after Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, attempting to damp the fires by arguing the need for making haste slowly to give the plan a solid financial foundation, merely kindled them.

Willie Pep, Hartford boxer who holds the world featherweight championship, and Sammy Angott, former world lightweight titleholder, will be the principals in the first ring battle waged here in the interests of the Service Boxing Equipment Fund. Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. announced yesterday that they will meet March 19 in Madison Square Garden.

Jacob (Kuppy) Migden, 32-year-old hireling of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, interrupted his first-degree murder trial yesterday in Bronx County Court and pleaded guilty to attempted assault in the first degree in the mistaken-identity murder of Irving Penn on July 25, 1939. As a second offender the minimum punishment Migden can get is five to ten years.

The $75,000-a-year head of a medical instrument manufacturing concern, his wife, a son and a daughter have been apprehended here and interned as enemy aliens, it became known yesterday. The apprehension of the group, as well as of seven other Germans, was announced by E. E. Conroy of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 17 -- The cooperation of the United States and Brazil in solving the coffee problem, in rubber, mining and railway development and in other endeavors will be continued as part of the Good Neighbor policy, according to Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in an interview today.

The speedy capture of three suspects in the hold-up of twenty-five persons late Tuesday night in the clubrooms of the Manhattan Democratic Club at 138 Second Avenue brought praise yesterday for their captors, Detectives George McGuire, John S. Brennan and John Gannon of the Fifth Street Station, from Magistrate Raphael Koenig in the Felony Court.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Lean, brusque Joseph Paul DiMaggio laid aside the baseball honors of years today to take on the khaki of Uncle Sam's Army for the duration.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Secretary Wickard's $225,000,000 agricultural lending project to spur production for the Food-for-Freedom program was assailed by Senators, farmers and small bankers today as a threat to the Treasury's coming war-financing program.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 17 -Fighter planes of newest design, capable of more than 400 miles an hour, performed successfully yesterday before a group of fifty Navy officials from Washington and reporters on an inspection tour of the Pratt Whitney Aircraft Division, United Aircraft Corporation, at East Hartford.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee, dealing with wartime salary limitations, read as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- Excerpts from letters written by Baldwin B. Bane, director of the corporation finance division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to officers of corporations seeking clarification of the SEC's new proxy rules were made public today by the commission.
The German High Command said yesterday that heavy fighting was continuing in and near Kharkov, according to a communique broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 16 (Delayed) -- Members of the Chavez committee of the United States Senate had as witnesses today several officials of government agencies, including Antonio Luchetti, director of the Puerto Rican Water Resources Authority, which acts for the Federal Works Agency in operation of the Porto Rico Railway, Light and Power Company and the Mayaguez Light, Power and Ice Company.

It is not hard to see where Mona Lisa might fit into the OWI. A reporter asked an inopportune question and was referred by the President to Mona Lisa of the famous enigmatic smile. Some f one else asked where could lona Lisa be found and was told she was working for the Office of War Information.

The second Town Hall Music Forum of the season, presented last night, featured compositions by Aaron Copland. Two of the composer's works, "Music for the Theatre" and "Music for Movies," Suite No. 1, were performed by a chamber orchestra conducted by Daniel Saidenberg, and the more recent of his two piano sonatas was played by Leonard Bernstein.

Blood will tell, according to a homely saying. It has been telling some exciting stories of soldiers and sailors in North Africa and the Pacific who were snatched from the jaws of death with plasma collected by the Red Cross from generous blood donors all over the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Lou E. Holland, who was superseded as chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation and outranked as a member of the War Production Board's high command Jan. 19 when Colonel Robert Johnson was appointed, resigned today from three other war agency posts, thus severing all connections with the war effort here.

The preliminary report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for 1942, released yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income of $9,534,442 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, compared with one of $7,366,240 in 1941.
As a cure for ailments of varying kinds, Maine's Development Commission offers a treatment supplied by the great outdoors.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians lost a round today in the government's renewed effort to break the ban on commercial recordings when Judge Barnes in District Court denied a defense motion to dismiss the anti-trust suit.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Japanese have landed considerable forces in Kwangchowwan, French leased territory on China's far southern coast, the Chinese High Command announced tonight, indicating that the invaders were preparing for extensive operations in China's southern province of Kwangtung.

The Brooklyn Museum will open today an exhibition of Chinese rubbings in the Special Exhibitions gallery on the first floor. Although most of the rubbings are in black and white, there are many in colored silk on white paper. The stones from which they were taken date from the Han Dynasty to the present century.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- A suggestion for purchase by the Government of live animals and for the registration of every person who sells controlled meat as a means to combat the black market and keep small packers in business appeared to be gaining support today in the small business committee of the House.
The Nationwide Fire Prevention and Equipment Company has leased the entire building at 214 East Forty-fifth Street through Huberth Huberth, brokers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade again today, moving up quickly after a small dip early. The upturn carried the deferred futures of corn to the ceiling level and all deliveries of wheat into new seasonal high ground.
SAINT LUCIA., B.W.I., Feb. 17 (AP) -- A large British West Indian schooner has been sunk by a submarine off the north coast of South America.

IF a ticket taker at Madison Square Garden tonight suddenly keels over in a dead faint, please don't give it a second thought. The swoon will be caused by the spectacle of three men entering the arena on the same single ducat, a violent violation of all rules of common sense, sound business and popular practice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Miller G. White, assistant chief of staff in charge of Army personnel, testified today that enactment of legislation to put draft quotas on a State-wide basis and give deferment priorities to married men with dependents might force the Army to induct illiterates, men with venereal diseases and other "undesirables" now being accepted only in limited numbers.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- The defeated Japanese force in the hills of New Guinea is still retreating toward the village of Mubo, twelve miles southwest of the enemy-held port of Salamaua, the Allied Command announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- British bombers and fighters in an attack described by qualified observers as the most extensive night sweep of the war hammered last night at the great U-boat lairs at Lorient, in the tenth raid this month, and ranged hundreds of miles into Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Northern France.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 -- The four-engined plane that crashed in Zaragoza on Feb. 9 was stated today in United States Embassy circles to have been a Consolidated bomber being used as a transport.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The prospects of the next British harvest are greater than last year's "best ever," Agriculture Minister Robert Hudson said today, but he warned that the manpower problem was crucial.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Contesting a government move to strip him of his citizenship, a former German-American Bund member testified in Federal Court today that he was willing now to fight against Germany.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Working hours of factory employes in the State increased in 1942 from 41.6 a week in January to 44.3 in December, the State Labor Department revealed today. Hours for employes in war industries in the metals and machinery group ranged from 45.0 to 51.7 during December; average hours for the group as a whole jumped to 47.9 in October and to 48.6 in December.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Big-time college sports are headed for a state of suspended animation for the duration, Army officials plainly indicated tonight.
LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Admiral Sir Henry John Studholme Brownrigg, hero of Jutland, is reported missing.

The stock market was tested yesterday for its weak spots, but when spasmodic profit-taking failed to bring out any selling of force on the Stock Exchange, prices resumed their upward course. The cautionary signals sounded on the previous day by many brokers were well taken by traders.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- The Navy board for production awards has withdrawn the Army-Navy E conferred upon the John A. Roebling's Sons Company and directed that the pennant emblematic of the award be hauled down and that employes refrain from wearing the lapel insignia.

The budget requests of city departments and agencies for 1943-44 amount to $783,535,879, or $5,595,420 more than the appropriation for 1942-43, Thomas J. Patterson, acting Budget Director, disclosed yesterday. The requests for appropriations to be met from the real estate tax levy and the revenue of the general fund amount to $650,570,611, an increase of $16,383,244 over the $634,187,367 appropriated from the two sources in 1942-43.
Miss Dorothy Kerfoot of the Foils Club won the women's All-Eastern intermediate foil championship at the Fencers Club last night.

Postponed this year with the approval of President Roosevelt, so that there might be no interference with the United Nations drive held last month by the motion picture industry, more than 7,000 theatres in all parts of the country will conduct a "March of Dimes," beginning today and running through Feb. 24, for the benefit of the National Foundation of Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- In consequence of the major defeats inflicted by the Soviet troops against the Nazis in Russia, two arguments in favor of the planned size of our 1943 Army -- 7 1/2 million men, to which the complement of officers must be added -- are being more strongly pressed in military circles.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- A new report of a Soviet protest against alleged pro-Axis activities on the part of General Draja Mikhailovitch, Yugoslav Minister of War, circulated here tonight as Russian armies continued their westward pressure, which is so fraught with possible significance for the entire Balkans.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, sitting in Brooklyn Federal Court, dismissed yesterday an application for a writ of habeas corpus sought by Angelo Trulio, 36 years old, of 397 Stockholm Street, Brooklyn, to get out of the Army. Trulio, former national handball champion, sought a discharge on the ground that he suffered from epilepsy.

An ingenious extortion racket in which the mails are being used to defraud the relatives of dead service men who allegedly have incurred "debts" is being investigated by the Postoffice Inspection Service, it became known here yesterday.
A German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the Associated Press:

BUFFALO, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Nine years of "nearly total blindness" are over for Thaddeus Mankiewicz, 47-year-old broom maker employed by the Buffalo Association for the Blind, according to Miss Edna Stainton, executive secretary of the association.

Pointing out that 95,000 block service leaders will be required to carry out the program launched here under Civilian Defense auspices, James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, in a speech ever WABC yesterday, advised the public as to what the block leaders should and should not do.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 17 -The two-day wildcat strike at the plant of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation here was called off this evening after the War Labor Board had given notice that it would send an arbitrator to adjust a series of grievances held by members of Local 441, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, C.I.O.

In a compromise between the nation's war needs and the city's health and sanitary requirements, the government assured yesterday to the New York laundries enough heavy fuel oil to operate on a 50 per cent of normal basis for the next six weeks, thus preventing a threatened general shutdown of laundries here.

Guadalcanal is worth strategically every effort the Japanese made to retake it and all that the United States might expend to hold it, Major Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, who led the marines in capturing the island outpost, declared here yesterday. He returned only recently from the South Pacific.

With Leo Durocher another full stride nearer toward donning a military uniform, but not yet actually in one, Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, was still insisting yesterday that up to now he has not made a single move to find a successor to Lippy Leo.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Declaring that the enemy's fighter and anti-aircraft defenses were already "stretched thin and badly overworked," Major Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commanding the United States Army Eighth Air Force, declared tonight that the way to break them was for American fliers to continue bombing by day and leave it to Great Britain's Royal Air Force to make Nazi nights uneasy.

Despite the fact that an additional 10 per cent cut in printing papers is reportedly scheduled for April, some magazines have already begun to receive cancellations of space contracted for in recent weeks, reports yesterday indicated.

An appeal "to the free women of the world" from the Secret Organization of Greek Women to "strike with all the force of your heart against barbarism," and to "prepare a new world of freedom and justice," was made public yesterday by Basil Vlavianos, publisher of the National Herald, Greek daily newspaper, in the columns of which the appeal recently appeared.

Mayor La Guardia gave his approval last night to plans of the Greater New York Victory Garden Council for 250,000 vegetable and fruit gardens within the city limits this Spring, but, talking as a "typical city farmer," the Mayor warned all potential gardeners that they must be realistic and face the fact that crop growing entails "real elbow work."

Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee has put forward a "compromise" proposal for getting the taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis. Under it half of the taxes due on 1942 or 1943 income, one or the other, would be canceled. The taxpayer would be asked to pay taxes this year on his total income in one of the two years, and half of it in the other.

In the evolution of the American system of railroading the phrase "basic daily rate" does not have the same meaning as it formerly did, particularly with respect to the rules involving working conditions of engine and train service employes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 -- A draft board which has supervision over a district heavily populated with navy yard employes stated today that draft-eligible war workers who were found to be habitually absent from their employment would be reclassified and receive 1-A status.

The half-stilled rumors about imperialistic manoeuvring for position in North Africa open a most disquieting prospect. An issue is being precipitated on which the United Nations can violently disagree. That issue is: Why cannot post-war peace organization be discussed and determined now, before commitments are made to obstruct broader plans and arouse suspicions of insincerity?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The American setback in Tunisia is viewed in military circles here as a local retreat necessitated by an overwhelming German attack made in order to widen the corridor that Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps must use to effect a junction with the main German forces in Tunisia.

Even horse meat would taste good now to Miss Rita Beauregard. For the last ten months she has eaten goat and camel meat, stewed and broiled. Take her word for it, they are tough and not too palatable.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh announced yesterday that the city's 175,000 air raid wardens have been enlisted to serve final notice on owners or lessees of 300,000 homes and other buildings that not later than March 1 they must comply fully with the local law requiring installation of such protective firefighting equipment as stirrup pumps, water buckets and other prescribed apparatus.

The proposed Army of the United States, which will probably be the ultimate Army -- the Army with which we shall fight and win this war -- is to total about 8,200,000 officers and men by the end of 1943, according to present Army plans. This represents an increase of about 2,500,000 this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to limit all individual income, from whatever source, to no more than $25,000 a year for a single person and $50,000 for a married couple during "the war period."

A quick turnover of an East Side property was disclosed yesterday with the announcement by Henry Goelet, operator, that he had resold the twelve-story store and loft building at 114-16 East Twenty-fifth Street, between Fourth and Lexington Avenues, to an investor represented by Omnia Properties, Inc., broker in the sale.

The discovery and opening up of a rich new vanadium field in explorations by the United States Geological Survey in Sublette Ridge, Southwestern Wyoming, that will make the United States self-sufficient in this highly strategic mineral, was reported yesterday before the annual meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. The report was presented by Dr. W.W. Rubey of the survey.

A trained medical attendant for every merchant ship flying the American flag is the goal of a new school established at the Sheepshead Bay Training Station of the War Shipping Administration, it was disclosed here yesterday by the agency's division of training.
MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- Kharkov's victors are pursuing the remnants of the city's defeated German garrison westward.

Adolf Hitler is not with the German armies fleeing in disorder from the recaptured city of Kharkov. No one knows where he is. The voice is silent that has risen in paeans of self-adulation whenever there were victories to boast of. He is silent because nothing he could say would drown out the words of triumph he spoke when his troops entered the Ukrainian capital in October, 1941.

Elimination of retail "frills" such as gift wrapping and merchandise returns is progressing remarkably well in the suburbs and in outlying sections of the city, Samuel Kalp, business specialist in the New York district office of the Office of Price Administration, declared last night at an open meeting for retailers held in connection with the New York Gift Show in the Hotel New Yorker.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- According to the annual report of the Department of Mental Hygiene submitted to the Legislature today there were 90,781 resident patients at the end of June in the twenty-six institutions over which the department has jurisdiction.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 17 -Fifty-six lawyers who have been working for the last two months on the night shift at the Watson Elevator Company's plant here and nineteen others who had been in training for jobs at the war production factory were dismissed today because of a forced decrease in the production schedule.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Two of the bills on Governor Dewey's program designed to ease the rural labor shortage by authorizing Saturday school sessions and release of pupils over 14 years of age for Spring and Fall work went to him for signature today after winning unanimous approval in the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Navy Communique 284:

Despite the growing difficulty in finding suitable items for use as premiums, there has been no diminution in the desire to offer them except in connection with the sale of rationed goods such as coffee. In fact, there has been an increase recently in the number of premium users in fields that are still highly competitive, such as soaps and cereals, according to Howard W. Dunk, executive secre-retary of the Premium Advertising Association of America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt had luncheon with Elmer Davis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- President Roosevelt set up some time ago a Committee on Records of War Administration in the Administrative Management Division of the Bureau of the Budget to record the administrative history of this war while it is in the making.

With Herbert H. Lehman, director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, emphasizing in a message that "it is more vital than ever that voluntary organizations rendering essential services be maintained," the women's division of the United Jewish Appeal opened yesterday its 1943 War Emergency Campaign with a rally at the Hotel Biltmore.

The story of how three suspected members of an organized gang of blackmailers in this city and Washington, posing as detectives, had attempted to extort $10,000 in the last two weeks from a prominent American fiscal representative here for the British Government in the war, came to light yesterday in the Felony Court at the arraignment of two of the suspects.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The enemy countries must surrender their war criminals "who are alive and available" immediately any armistice is reached, Viscount Simon, the Lord Chancellor, declared in a speech today at a luncheon at St. Stephen's Club.

RADBURN, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Feeling that the Federal Government has not gone far enough toward eliminating duplicate delivery service to conserve rubber, gasoline and manpower, eleven families living on Addison Place here have dispensed with the services of all save one of the six milk companies that had been serving them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- American forces in the Southwest Pacific have grown to such size that the War Department, acting on recommendation by General Douglas MacArthur, today created the Sixth Army, embracing most of the troops in Australia and New Guinea.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Governor Dewey signed today the bill permitting a possible $5,000,000 slash in State income taxes through additional deductions and repeated his pledge for a simplification of the tax structure next year, after further study.

Meetings of wholesalers and retailers of women's outer apparel to discuss MPR No. 330 will be held under OPA auspices today, tomorrow and Tuesday at 3 P.M. on the 42d floor of the Empire State Building. The new regulation, which becomes effective next Wednesday, is the retail and wholesaler version of MPR 287 for manufacturers, and eliminates the alternative pricing arrangements under the GMPR.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -The United States has earmarked 200,000,000 bushels of wheat, or about one-fifth of its present supplies, for feeding hungry peoples in lands the Allies hope to wrest from the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- To Brig. Gen. Laverne G. Saunders of Aberdeen S.D., former West Point football star, has been awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and Silver Star for extraordinary achievement and gallantry against the Japanese in aerial combat over the Solomons, the War Department said tonight.

A special French revival program composed of fifty-six films, representative of the outstanding Gallic screen offerings of the last ten years, will begin today at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse and continue through April 15. Each program includes two features and will play two-day engagements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Antagonism between the armed services and the War Production Board boiled up again today as the services awaited a drastic new order enlarging the civilian agency's control over arms production.

LONDON, Feb. l8 -- A proposal for the reestablishment of pre-war independent nations of central and eastern Europe with advance settlement of their frontier questions and wholesale exchange of minority populations to end once for all internal problems of that portion of the continent was made today by President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia in an interview with this correspondent.

SEATTLE, Feb. 18 -- A four-motored Boeing bomber's crash into a packing plant in Seattle's South End today killed at least fourteen persons and spread flaming destruction through the four-story building.

Wearing his overcoat in the chilly Yorkville Court, Magistrate Raphael Murphy yesterday ordered a complaint drawn charging that Rudolph Muhson, bookkeeper of the Cavendish Club at 14 East Sixty-second Street, had permitted and maintained gambling games at the bridge club.

New York City, all New Jersey and suburbs in the metropolitan district were blacked out for a half hour in the moonlight last night in what was probably the most successful air raid warning drill of the war.

Bank clearings in the twenty-three major cities of the country for the five-day week ended on Wednesday amounted to $7,220,458,000, or 14.7 per cent more than the $6,297,177,000 for the corresponding 1942 period, also a holiday week, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A smash-up of the Office of Price Administration and the "most dangerous domestic situation in this country's history" will follow any serious break-through in either farm prices or wages, Prentiss M. Brown, price administrator, declared here yesterday.

The Bell System in 1942 installed $345,000,000 worth of new telephone plant, installed or moved 5,500,000 telephones and handled a record number of telephone conversations -- averaging 87,000,000 a day -- it was disclosed yesterday in the annual 1942 report to stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

HOUSTON, Feb. 18 -- Spurred by an admonition from William A. Irvin, national chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, Houston business and industrial leaders swung into action today to speed up war production by reducing industrial accidents.

The most promising Washington's Birthday week-end in more than a decade is expected to attract a wartime record throng to the North Country for skiing today. Usually the time of the year when Spring skiing is tempting devotees the snow centers from the Pennsylvania Poconos to the Canadian Laurentians now boast conditions comparable to the best this Winter has had to offer.

Three goals in 49 seconds were scored against the Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. And these three goals, coming as they did with the Blue Shirts handicapped by having a man in the penalty box, enabled Detroit to register a 5-to-4 triumph.

Sergei Prokofieff's cantata, "Alexander Nevsky," will receive its American premiere by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, Sunday, March 7, at Radio City. The work is considered especially timely, since it deals with the defeat and expulsion from Russia of the Germanic invaders by the national hero, Alexander Nevsky.

Price movements were erratic on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Early in the day the six active options pushed to gains of 9 to 12 points, with the March contract at its highest level since May 9, but later profit-taking in the distant positions sent their prices below the previous close.

The five members of Local Draft Board 115 of the Bronx are scheduled to report in a body tomorrow to the Red Cross blood donor center at 2 East Thirty-seventh Street and contribute a pint of blood each for processing into dried plasma for the use of the armed forces.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- In his speech at the Berlin Sportpalast tonight, as broadcast by the German radio, Dr. Joseph Goebbel, Propaganda Minister, said in part:

Under fire from consumers and agencies of State and Federal Governments, the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., agreed yesterday to revamp the system under which it provides its operating subsidiaries with management, legal and other services.

Headed by crack quartets from Georgetown, Villanova and Seton Hall, twenty-eight college teams and ten school combinations will take part in the relay portion of the New York Athletic Club's annual meet tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by Paul Pilgrim, veteran Winged Foot athletic director.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, told the German people last night that they faced sacrifices as yet unimaginable, but he asserted there would be a Spring offensive against Russia and a Summer submarine offensive against Allied shipping. And he said that any Allied attempt to invade Europe would be repelled.

BEN GARDANE, Tunisia, Feb. 18 -- Two French captains, acting for the French civil authority, remained here through the Axis occupation and evacuation and kept the French flag flying above the town's picturesque white-walled fort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Challenging President Roosevelt's leadership in post-war economic planning, Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, insisted today that Congress must take the initiative in this field.

Most retail stores in the metropolitan district may be without any butter at all within a week, due to a blocking of trade channels by the latest Office of Price Administration order fixing a maximum retail price of 57 cents a pound for Grade AA -- 93 score -- butter, C.B. Rader, business manager of the New York Mercantile Exchange, said last night.
LAYTONVILLE, Calif., Feb. 18 (AP) -- Dolph Camilli indicated today he might reconsider his decision to quit baseball if he were offered managership of the Dodgers.

The President's letter to Chairman Doughton is an extraordinary document, whether his argument is regarded from an economic or from a constitutional point of view. From an economic standpoint the letter is unfortunate. The President's disparaging reference to "the coupon clipper," for example, could scarcely be more ill-timed.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- Announcements of dividends on railway shares disappointed the stock markets here and caused a setback in home rails.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Russian midday communique as recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:

" The Three Sisters" will end its New York run Saturday, April 3, after having played 122 performances in fifteen weeks on Broadway. It will then go on the road, opening a two-week engagement at the Shubert, Boston, on April 5. Later it will visit Buffalo, Toronto, Detroit, Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Chicago, according to present plans.

On Oct. 20 last, Mainbocher began to select the fabrics for the collection of Spring and Summer styles that were shown in his salon in 6 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon and that laid its accent on beauty.

During the current year "practically no new road building equipment will be available to State governments, and probably none for the duration of the war," Louis Levinson head of the maintenance and machinery section of the governmental division of the War Production Board, told yesterday's session of the Association of Highway Officials of the North Atlantic States at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Sergeant Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn bombardier who rode the wings of freedom high over the waters of the Pacific dealing destruction to America's enemies, has fallen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger is regarded by his fellow officers as one of the Army's most learned students of strategy and military history and as a tactician of first rank. Ruthless in matters of discipline, he is none the less admired and respected as "a soldier's soldier.''

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Viscount Simon, Lord Chancellor, asserting today that war criminals would no escape this time as they did in World War I, said that while the British Government was prepared to discuss the setting up of international courts in addition to the United Nations commission for the investigation of war crimes, he felt that trial by military tribunals would prove the better system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -The War Department announced today the names of 540 American soldiers wounded in action in the North African, European, Asiatic, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas. It is said that some of the wounded men have recovered and have returned to duty.

While little organized opposition may arise to an expanded social security program, especially in the light of the Beveridge report, a fresh consideration should be given to the method of financing this expansion.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 -- Official and other reports today indicated Russian progress in three principal operational regions, the Donets Basin and the Kharkov and Kursk areas. The fall of Slavyansk was more than the capture of another large town, for it marked the failure of a determined German attempt to pierce northwestward through the Russian positions and shake them loose from their menacing grip on Kramatorsk and Krasnoarmeisk by attacking them in the rear.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 18 -- The resignation of three members of the Viceroy's Council represents India's greatest political crisis in many years. It is an important victory for Mohandas K. Gandhi, whatever is thought of his fast, and the writer understands these members deplored and resented it.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Tunisia, Feb. 17 (Delayed) -- Concentrated heavy fire from tanks set fire to Sbeitla yesterday when the enemy attacked it. The attack was repulsed.

The land on which the Trebuhs Building at 234-36 West: Fortyfourth Street stands has been sold by Commander Vincent Astor to an investor. The building, a tenstory structure occupied by Sardi's Restaurant and the Shubert theatrical offices, covers the entire plot of 56.7 by 100.5 feet between the Forty-fourth Street Theatre and The New York Times Hall.

Food wholesalers are urging the Office of Price Administration to make the use of ration banking mandatory for retailers whose sales volume exceeds a gross monthly total of $2,500, instead of the $5,000 optional limit now provided, It was learned yesterday.

Russian storm troops continue to advance from conquered Kharkov. With that key city in Soviet hands, there is apparently only one course open to the German High Command. That is full retreat under adverse conditions before an enemy attacking on a 700-mile front.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The American forces that held the center section of the United Nations' line in Tunisia, from which they are reported to have been pushed back in spots to the Algerian border, have suffered a "sharp reverse" at the hands of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's veterans, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Because of many delays which have beset the synthetic rubber production program, the output this year is now expected to total only 241,000 long tons, instead of the 354,000 envisaged in his first progress report Nov. 30, William M. Jeffers, Federal Rubber Director, said today in a second report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Representative Clarence F. Lea asserted in an interview today that Representative Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce was raising "fictitious issues" in so far as she suggested the possibility of internationalization of the airways.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Feb. 18 -- The 1943 Pittsburgh Award, given annually for achievement in chemistry by the Pittsburgh section of the American Chemical Society, was presented at a dinner tonight to Dr. Charles Glenn King, visiting professor of Columbia University and scientific director of the Nutrition Foundation, with headquarters in New York City.

The New York Athletic Club will play host to the National A.A.U. men's swimming championships to be held on April 2 and 3, it was announced yesterday. Also revealed was the fact that the women's title competition has been split in three parts and will be held in New York, Los Angeles and Portland, Ore.

Today's events: "Boris Godunoff," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Alexander Brailowsky, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; New York Little Symphony, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45; James Friskin, piano, Juilliard Recital Hall, 8:15: Ray Lev, piano, and Dorothy Minty, violin, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, 8:30; Greenwich House Music School Orchestra, Greenwich House auditorium, 27 Barrow Street, 8:30.

THERE will be two fighters who can hit in the Madison Square Garden ring tonight to the delight of a near capacity crowd of 20,000 and there will be another fighter who can hit in the Army tonight to the immense admiration of a crowd of 60,000,000.

As a solution to the current furniture problem, Lord Taylor opened yesterday an antique section operated on the auction principle. Dubbed an "automatic reduction shop," antiques and objets d'art ranging in price from $5 to $5,000 are being displayed in the eighth floor home furnishings department in true gallery fashion.
Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, left by plane for California yesterday on a mission during which he expects to touch all the bases.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 -- Fowler V. Harper, deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said tonight that the manpower gain from the forty-eight-hour minimum work week would be less than one-sixth of the needs for additional labor in 1943.

It is because the drama of this war is too big for any single theatre, too complex for the ordinary mind, that it explains and interprets itself best in human symbols. And it is because Mme. Chiang Kai-shek in her small and charming person is so large a symbol that her appearance before the Congress yesterday brought home to us as nothing else could the great historic facts her presence here expresses.

The German High Command announced yesterday, two days late, that Kharkov had been evacuated after systematic destruction of war-important installations, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

The railway labor organizations always have devoted considerable effort _to obtaining working rules designed to require the employment of additional men in the performance of railroad operations. A review of the various departments into which railroad operations are subdivided shows that they have had much success.

Severe cold weather in Southern States during the early part of the week caused great damage to crops of green vegetables, the Department of Agriculture reports. As a result, supplies in Manhattan are considerably lighter than they were last Friday, and prices are high.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The First Lady of China smiled, spoke and conquered. But Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's victory when she captivated and united both Houses of Congress today was more than a personal triumph or a victory for China.

A permanent society to commemorate the principles of the Bill of Rights, with emphasis on freedom of religion, speech, press and assembly, was started yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where a committee of thirteen was approved to effect the organization.
OTTAWA, Feb. 18 -- Warning that the war would not end this year and that "the situation at this moment is serious" came in the House of Commons today from Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

With its machine shops at the end of 1942 devoting more than 80 per cent of their entire production capacity to war work and its container factories turning out many types of war supplies and equipment, the American Can Company in its annual report submitted for release today, explained its participation in the war program of agriculture and industry.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -Sharp increases in hogs and cattle brought the number of livestock on farms on Jan. 1 to a record level and to the highest value in history, the Department of Agriculture said today in its annual livestock inventory report.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department announced today that Merchant Marine casualties reported to next of kin between Dec. 22, 1942, and Jan. 31, 1943, inclusive, numbered eighteen dead and 388 missing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Congressional groups took steps today in the war manpower situation which were aimed at checking the drafting of men for the armed forces.

Criticism of the plan of Sir William Beveridge for all-inclusive social insurance, now under discussion in Great Britain, and predictions that a similar plan probably will be introduced in this country soon were contained in the report made yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, at the annual meeting of the board of directors.

Gloomy war news from the Tunisian front had a depressing effect yesterday on the stock market and prices had their widest losses of the year. Declines ranged from 1 to 2 points generally, although some of the higher-priced issues were pushed back even more.

By day, Walter Livingston Faust is an executive downtown, but his heart is in the right place, which is the theatre. While good intentions count, even on Broadway, it seemed last evening at the Longacre that Mr. Faust is not yet the most facile of the Times Square playwrights.

Off-the-course betting, well known in England and France, but never legal in this country, became a matter of sharp issue yesterday in statements issued by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations of the U.S., Inc., and State Senator John J. Crawford.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussion, Federal income-tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House voted $75,000 today to finance continuation of the Dies committee to investigate un-American activities, and approved resolutions providing funds for two other investigations. The roll-call on the Dies fund was 278 to 64.

Some of the Navy's newest combat fighters intended for air and sea service were exhibited and explained Wednesday to the group of officials and newspaper correspondents on the third and last day of their inspection tour of Northeastern naval, shipping and aircraft engine plants.

Was it necessary for Judge Thomas Downs in the Queens County Court to go all the way to Schenectady for a case in point? A jury day before yesterday took only six minutes to acquit four persons accused of violating the anti-lottery laws by sponsoring a bingo game.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -- Openly charging the "Ciano government" [Count Ciano, former Foreign Minister] with a "lack of understanding of the problems of the war that led to actions that might have been described in other times as outright sabotage," the ultra-Fascist newspaper Regime Fascista of Roberto Farinacci, commenting on the recent Cabinet shake-up, today accused the ousted Ministry with "wilfully complicating matters.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 18 (AP) -- American fighter planes in raids Tuesday against Japanese supply lines in North Burma set fires in one town and strafed trucks loaded with equipment, a communique of the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Feb. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Returning from a mission Jan. 7, Sergeant Meyer Levin's bombing plane crashed into the sea forty miles south of Port Moresby during a storm.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 19 -- Russian troops threatened the Germans with a new and imminent defeat today in a drive that had taken them within thirty-three miles of the great anchor point of Orel from the east, while other forces smashed in from southeast and south.
New York University's track forces, strongly favored to dethrone Fordham as the metropolitan intercollegiate indoor champion, will carry 28 points into Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Practical, casual and pretty are the watchwords for the Spring collection B. Altman showed to the press yesterday morning. Seven leading suit styles opened the show, all of the softer dressmaker type. These included two navy suits -- one in cardigan style with a flowered print blouse tied with a big bow at the neck, and one with a hip-bone length cutaway jacket and trouser pleat skirt.

A recent letter to you about tea balls contained a number of misleading statements. Tea balls are made by machines which cannot possibly be used for any other purpose. No skilled manpower is involved. The machine divides each pound of tea into equal parts, each of which is the correct quantity for one cup of tea.
POONA, India, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi suffered a relapse today, the ninth day of his protest fast. His heartbeat became slower and his toxic condition increased.

A new issue of $2,500,000 of tax anticipation notes was announced yesterday by the city of San Francisco, for award on Feb. 23. The notes will be dated May 10, 1943, with the interest rate to be named by the bidders.

Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad in January were estimated yesterday by M.W. Clement, president, at $75,756,000, compared with $55,348,172 in January 1942. Freight business last month amounted to $50,535,000, an increase of 22.5 per cent over January last year, while passenger revenues were $17,825,000, an increase of 73.8 per cent.

Unfamiliar scores, for the greater part by living composers, made the program arranged by John Barbirolli for the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall. Fritz Kreisler appeared as soloist with the orchestra, concluding the occasion with a stunning performance of the Viotti A minor violin concerto.

Previous estimates of a production of 15,000,000 tons of paper and paperboard in this country this year must be scaled down to 13,500,000 to 14,000,000 tons, Oliver M. Porter, executive director of the United States Pulp Producers Association, asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry at the Hotel Commodore.

Governor Charles Edison began fulfillment of the second major pledge of his public career several days ago when some two hundred New Jersey Democrats met under his leadership in Trenton and founded United Democracy, a State-wide organization of Edison followers whose immediate concern is the election of a candidate for Governor this year.
