WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Following are the texts of the addresses of Madame Chiang Kai-shek today in the House and the Senate:

After a lapse of three years, Ernest Fiene returns to the local exhibition world with a one-man show, at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, which will continue through March 6. Elsewhere at the same galleries may be seen the exhibition of work by George Grosz, which will remain until Feb. 27.

Since the schools from which the new War Ration Book No. 2 will be distributed next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday are not provided with consumer declaration forms, persons applying for the new books must clip and fill in the consumer declaration blanks that are being published in the newspapers, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, warned yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Allied planes have bombed two Japanese cargo ships, a schooner and four launches, the Allied High Command announced today.

The Paumonok Handicap, Jamaica's sprint stake which has opened the metropolitan season for a generation, has been moved back this year to April 10, and the meeting will begin with the Experimental Handicap as the feature on April 8, it was announced yesterday by President Edward P. Kilroe.

Age limits without due allowance for exceptions, in many instances within my knowledge, have proved a disservice to both employer and employe. They are even a handicap to the war effort. In adhering strictly to set standards government and private industry, incidentally, evade a social obligation.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 7 (Delayed) -- When Gunner Joseph Edward Hartman of Birmingham, Ala., regained consciousness after the Japanese Zero had dived into his Flying Fortress and broken it in two, everything was so quiet he wondered what had happened.

Princess Diane Eristavi, president of the Metropolitan Headquarters of Bundles for America, gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon at her home, 850 Park Avenue, for members of the volunteer staff who have been aiding in the management of the organization's headquarters and shop at 648 Madison Avenue for the last four months.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The Secretary of State for India, L.S. Amery, declined today to recommend to the Viceroy of India that Mohandas K. Gandhi be allowed to make contact with certain outsiders.

A bout long awaited by boxing followers will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when Ray Robinson, fast-punching Harlem welterweight, engages Sergeant Jackie Wilson, Los Angeles fighter now in the Army. The rivals, campaigning generally in fields far apart, have built up formidable records, and many efforts were made to bring them together before Mike Jacobs finally succeeded in pairing them for this ten-rounder.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The Canadiens poured four goals past Bert Gardiner in the third period to score a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the Black Hawks tonight. A crowd of 8,890 was on hand in the Chicago Stadium.

Admiral Rene Godfroy is still a problem to the British Admiralty, but that problem will be settled during the next forty-eight hours, according to a most reliable authority. Admiral Godfroy is in command of the French squadron -- one old battleship, three cruisers, a few destroyers and submarines -- that has lain at anchor off Alexandria, Egypt, for thirty-one months.
In regard to certain parts of your editorials of Feb. 9 and 12, which refer to the forty and forty-eight hour week, and the time-and-a-half for the extra eight hours, I want to tell you something.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- A new light was shed today on the assassination of Admiral Jean Francois Darlan and the subsequent political developments in North Africa. The relator was Rene Capitant, who has just arrived at General Charles de Gaulle's headquarters from Algiers.

Eighteen new tenants have sgned leases in Tudor City, the Fred 7. French Management Company reported yesterday. They are Peggy Wallace, 1Virs. Carolyn B. Wolf, 0ren 1V[. Stephens, iV[ajor John G. Taylor, 1Vfrs. Antoinette M. 7ischer, Thomas N. Scoville, Sterling H. Albert, Albert Whittell Jr., Joseph G. 7erraTa, Ao. Angela Roberts, Eileen 7arrell, Katherine 7innegan, Litlian 7. Cowman, Allan Reagan, Winston Wells, Sallee Hoenig, Percy Mayas and Robert L. Sjostrom.

LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The vote today on final division on the amendment demanding immediate government action for implementation of the Beveridge report by the immediate creation of a Ministry of Social Security was 335 votes for the government to 119 against it.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 18 -- Forward elements of the British Eighth Army yesterday entered Medenine, about sixty miles inside Tunisia. They encountered almost no opposition.

A drastic shake-up in the personnel of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was announced yesterday by Marshall Field, president and chairman of the board of directors. Among the seventeen musicians dropped from the roster for next season is Michel Piastro, concertmaster of the orchestra since 1931, who joined its membership at the invitation of Arturo Toscanini.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, addressing sessions of the House of Representatives and the Senate today, challenged "the prevailing opinion" that the defeat of the Japanese was of "relative unimportance," while the smashing of Hitler was our "first concern."

OTTAWA, Feb. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada decreased $38,813,000 to $27,789,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the bank's weekly statement. Notes in circulation increased $2,605,000 to $684,064,000.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 18 -- The Japanese have made a limited aviation come-back but have not displayed superior or decisive air strength in the Southwest Pacific in recent weeks. This conclusion is to be drawn from communiques dealing with air warfare issued by the Southwest Pacific command during the last month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Sweeping authority over every major division of the War Production Board was reposed today in Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman, by Donald M. Nelson, chairman. Mr. Wilson was designated to fill the post of executive vice chairman created Tuesday when Mr. Nelson ousted Ferdinand Eberstadt, vice chairman in charge of programming, in a clash over operating policy.

" The moment Japan goes down, her overseas empire goes into liquidation; then we must find the solution for the islands and Korea," Hugh Byas, author of "The Japanese Enemy" and "Government By Assassination" and former Tokyo correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared at a luncheon of the China Society of America yesterday at the Bankers Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb.18 -- Secretary Knox disclosed today that Lieut. Comdr. Walter Winchell had been put on the inactive list, and Mr. Winchell promptly declared that he now would be able to continue his fight against "the undercover menace."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The National League has sold the last-place Phils -- presumably to William D. Cox, New York lumberman. Identity of the new owner will be disclosed officially within a week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- An interdepartmental letter of the Office of War Information, giving official figures on the cost, circulation and advertising plans of "Victory," the OWI's new magazine, confirms the fact that the publication goes to United States troops in England, and possibly in Hawaii and Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- American dive-bombers with an escort of fighters pounded the Japanese air field at Munda, on New Georgia Island, for the sixty-eighth time on Wednesday (Solomons time), the Navy Department reported here today.

Clarification of the nation's labor laws "so that millions of innocent men and women will have the same protection from our government as do the racketeers" was advocated yesterday by Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, aviation executive and hero of the United States Army mission in the Pacific, at the annual meeting of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A fragment of a rare Greek statue, carved, it is believed, only some twenty years before the famous Parthenon marbles, has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and placed on exhibition in the main entrance hall.

' Japan is now getting at lesmt 33,000,000 barrels of petroleum a year, which exceeds by 8,000,000 barrels its greatest peacetime yearly consumption, it was reported yesterday before the closing sessions of the 158th meeting of the American Institute of IVining and Metallurgical Engineers, at the Engineering Soeieties Building, i29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
The rules and scoring of contract bridge, a game played by millions of Americans, are being changed today with the publication of a 1943 code of laws. The revisions are the first since 1935.

LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Large increases were reported in the statement of the Bank of England issued today, for the week ended yesterday. Private deposits improved 10,240,000 and government securities showed an increase of 9,990,000.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Julius Amberg, special assistant to the Secretary of War, told 250 New York alumni of Colgate University last night that the reversal suffered by American troops in Tunisia underscored the necessity for a large Army capable of achieving victory on all fronts.

The American people will have a "limited" domestic food supply in 1943, but "no one need go hungry" and "the worst that can happen is that we may have to change our food habits some," M. Clifford Townsend, food production director of the Department of Agriculture, declared last night.

A visit by the late Alexander Woollcott to the farm home of Moss Hart started the train of thought that led Mr. Hart and George S. Kaufman to write their play, "The Man Who Came to Dinner," Mr. Hart testified yesterday in Federal court.

Warning that a large part of the population of Belgium, and possibly of other conquered European countries, may die of starvation before the end of the war unless they get help from abroad, a group of forty-three Protestant leaders issued a joint statement last night urging this country to make immediate shipments of dried milk and vitamins for children, nursing and expectant mothers and invalids, but for no other persons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Prices in primary markets advanced 0.1 per cent during the second week of February as a result of further gains in quotations for agricultural commodities and their products, and the all-commodity index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics now stands at 102.1 per cent of the 1926 average, 6 per cent higher than at this time last year.
While the United States is engaged in a fight for its life, and the Government becomes more and more concerned about a shortage of manpower --
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique as recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 18 -- After five days of swift and sure progress, the pace of the enemy offensive in Southern Tunisia slackened today, with Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's advance guard of big gray Mark IV tanks having captured the towns of Feriana, Kasserine and Sbeitla, and with American and French forces preparing to stand on new positions in mountain ranges west of those places.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Secretary Morgenthau told a press conference today that President Roosevelt's proposal to Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee calling for a "special war super-tax" on incomes, including incomes from tax-exempt securities, meant that such a tax should be applied to tax-exempt State and local securities, but not to wholly exempt Federal securities.

The shoe rationing order, which has been in effect about ten days, has caused a temporary boom in retail shoe sales and has brought many special problems to retailers and manufacturers, those familiar with the trade agreed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 18 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman's coming visit to the Vatican continues to arouse increasing interest in church circles throughout Italy, although the Italian press still ignores it.

Unemployment insurance benefits totaling $3,595,101 were paid to 56,600 unemployed workers in New York State in January, it was announced at Albany yesterday by Michael J. Murphy, Acting Industrial Commissioner, an increase of 20 per cent over December and a decline of 45 per cent from the amount paid in January, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Allotment periods for all rationed foods are set at two months each for restaurants, boarding houses, hotels and other institutions under rationing regulations set up by the Office of Price Administration for commercial and institutional users.

The 400 voluntary health and welfare agencies in this city face a greater responsibility than ever before because of the war, Arthur A. Ballantine, president of the Greater New York Fund, said yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the organization in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank, 33 Liberty Street.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Plans for the post-war world at this stage should be based on the hope of providing new adjustments in our social and economic framework "to meet the conditions of a changed and mechanized world to the end that we may continue free," Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, declared last night in an address made at the thirty-second annual meeting of the New York Academy of Public Education.

Thursday, April 1, has been selected as the date for New York basketball's Red Cross benefit game, it was announced yesterday by A.J. Ditman, headquarters representative of the organization's National Sports Committee. The entire receipts will go to the Red Cross.

For the first time in six weeks both the member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City and in the nation as a whole gained excess reserves in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday in the weekly figures reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

One of the most encouraging aspects of production for war has been the teamwork within the factors of American industry to expedite any desired program. The Civil Aeronautics Administration is completing a program which exemplifies to what unexpected fields this cooperation can be extended.

Spiking reports current in some export circles that steamship companies are refusing to accept certain unprofitable cargoes, however highly rated under the priority schedules, A.A. Alexander of the Office of Supervision of Cargo Clearance, War Shipping Administration, yesterday asserted that freight rates have no bearing on exporters' ability to obtain space.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and subsidiaries had a net income in 1942 of $22,108,102 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, according to the company's annual report, released yesterday by Charles Y. Freeman, chairman.

A sizable integrated newspaper advertising campaign on behalf of War Bonds and Stamps will be started in eight Manhattan newspapers about March 15, Nevil Ford, New York State Administrator of the United States Treasury War Savings Staff, announced yesterday.

James Vander Wyde, 22 years old, of 228 West Sixteenth Street, was sentenced to two and one-half to five years in State prison yesterday by Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions on his guilty plea to a second degree assault charge that grew out of his fatal attack on a man in Greenwich Village last March 21.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 18 -- Several hundred Brazilian business men applauded lustily today the declaration made by Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, that the end of the war would remove the threat of invasion from Africa.

Following the compromise by which the government allowed New York laundries enough heavy fuel oil to operate on a 50 per cent of normal basis for the next six weeks, averting a threatened shutdown, laundries which had closed early this week because of lack of fuel announced yesterday they would reopen immediately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Department store sales for the week ended Feb. 13 were 45 per cent higher than for the same period of last year. This followed a gain of 19 per cent in the week ended Feb. 6. Sales for the latest four-week period were up 16 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson announced today the establishment of a new Waac training center at Fort Devens, Mass., and said the value of the Waacs to the Army was demonstrated by present plans to expand the organization as quickly as possible to its authorized total strength of 150,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The business community of this country, and particularly that section of it known as "big business," would be wise to prepare its case against a charge that will surely be made in the 1944 campaign. The outlines of this accusation already are beginning to emerge in New Deal circles -- that business, and particularly big business, is responsible for the errors, confusions and controversies of the War Production Board.

Emphasizing the need for increased aircraft production in the United States to supplement British aircraft production, J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, hailed yesterday President Roosevelt's establishment of the six-day work week in key war production areas as an important step in the right direction.

A former Tennessee legislator and an ex-Walkathon promoter, who had attracted the attention of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, came up yesterday in separate parts of Federal court. Each had been linked to a long series of worthless checks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (U.P.) -- One Army officer was dead and seventeen other officers, enlisted men and civilians were missing in the crash of a huge Army transport at sea about a mile from an unnamed Pacific base, the War Department disclosed tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 18 -- The Japanese have begun attacks in seven widely separated areas, from the lake country north of Shanghai to the jungles of Yunnan in the southwest, apparently with the hope of ending Chinese resistance, the Chinese announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- A House naval subcommittee reported today that the American shipbuilding industry, "almost criminally neglected" after the first World War, could produce up to 20,000,000 tons of shipping this year if "undue and unnecessary" delays were corrected.

Although war contracts in the New York area have been increased from $141,000,000 to about $846,000,000 within the last year, the area is still considered the most distressed labor point in the country, Lieut. Col. Chester Mueller, chief of the production service branch of the New York Ordnance District, told about 300 members of the Commerce and Industry Association yesterday at a meeting at 233 Broadway.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to be at a new high record, while holdings of United States Government securities increased $76,208,000 during the week.
The award for the outstanding conservation accomplishment given by Field and Stream each year has been bestowed upon Frederic Walcott, former Senator from Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- If a plant, company or industry fails to effect a saving in manpower by establishing the forty-eight-hour week in accordance with President Roosevelt's recent executive order, the edict will not apply, according to reports current here today after it became known that Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, had signed the regulations implementing the order.

The Treasury made known lateI yesterday that it will withdrawI $195,240,000 on next Tuesday and a like amount on next Thursday from government war loan ac-] counts with commercial banks in the New York Federal Reserve District. For the entire country, withdrawals will afnount to $344,533,000 on each day.

It's safe to say that the Marines -- on land, at sea and in the air -would have been proud yesterday of the director of their new women's reserve. If fine tradition can be swallowed like a pill, then Major Ruth Cheney Streeter has done it.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

AN ADVANCED SOUTH SEAS BASE, Feb. 11 (Delayed) -- Final investment of Guadalcanal by the Army and some units of Marines came as anti-climax to men who did the fighting, especially the Navy forces, which have suffered the major losses.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Associate memberships in the Westchester League of Women Voters were offered today to men particularly those so active in the war that they have no time to participate personally in guiding local government.

In a game featured by fast, rough play and many fouls, the St. John's basketball team last night snapped the Manhattan Beach Coast Guard's winning streak at sixteen games by outscoring the Guardsmen, 52-45, on the De Gray gymnasium court in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The sooner professional baseball is prohibited the better. By this I mean baseball conducted for profit in wartime. Why should John Shane write a letter to THE TIMES, as he did last week, and Branch Rickey give interviews in the interest of preserving the income of a few hundred stockholders, or "sport" promoters, during a national emergency?

Adoption of a plan worked out on Jan. 22 for the reorganization of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., "to meet wartime requirements" and election of new officers of the trade association, which represents 220 American aviation manufacturing companies, was announced here yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- A bill to speed up slum clearance and housing redevelopment, particularly in New York City, was sponsored in the Legislature today by Senator Hampton of Utica and Assemblyman Mitchell of New York, Republicans.

With construction halted on the huge government-financed detinning plant in Long Island City, Queens, the problem of fast-growing tin-can stock piles within the city limits yesterday confronted municipal and War Production Board officials.

During the rush hours conditions in the subways are deplorable. Is it not possible for transportation and industry to work out a stagger system? If all the department stores were to open later, thousands of people would be affected. If the large insurance companies should change their hours, thousands of people would benefit.

A total of $21,589,300 of new State and municipal bonds is scheduled for award next week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. This figure compared with this week's total of $8,316,650, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $21,217,274.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A slight improvement for the second consecutive week in the East Coast oil supply was reported today by Secretary Ickes in his weekly petroleum bulletin.

Aviation and the war effort have suffered a loss in the death of Edmund T. Allen, director of flight and aerodynamics for the Boeing Aircraft Company. "Eddie" Allen exemplified to the highest degree the evolution of the test pilot that has gone hand in hand with the evolution of the airplane itself.

Housewives can defeat food racketeers and drive black markets out of existence by conducting a "benevolent boycott" against food prices that are too high, Commissioner of Markets Daniel P. Woolley declared yesterday at the dedication of the city's first cooperative food and rationing information center at the enclosed municipal retail market, Second Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 19 -- Numan Menemencioglu, Turkish Foreign Minister, paid an unprecedented hour-long visit to Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador, yesterday afternoon at Istanbul's American Embassy building, bringing to a climax a week-long series of important Turko-Allied conversations that are believed to be leading up to the long-awaited Russo-Turkish rapprochement.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Colonel Edson Raff disclosed today that German gains this week in Central Tunisia were made in part of an area of 10,000 square miles that a handful of American soldiers and some other Allied units had held for more than two months by sheer dash and bluff instead of numbers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A serious problem has recently been created for the War Production Board by the slow rate at which the railroads availed themselves of the new equipment allocations in the first weeks of this year, but orders are now coming in more rapidly, it was learned today.

Plans for an intensive campaign of consumer advertising in daily newspapers and national magazines as well as trade journals is contemplated on behalf of the newly formed Cooperative Olive Products Association of Fresno, Calif., which has just completed negotiations with H.J. Heinz Company for sales and distribution of a new olive oil.

Tabulations contained in the yearbook of the New York Stock Exchange, issued yesterday, revealed that 133 of the institution's 834 common stock issues have paid dividends without a break for twenty-five years or more, that 109 have paid for thirty years or more, seventy-one for forty years or more, thirty-six for fifty years or more, twenty-five for sixty years or more, and thirteen of the lot for seventy years or more.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (Reuter) -- The Rome radio said last night that the Riom tribunal has decided to release on parole former French Air Minister Guy La Chambre and former Controller of the War Ministry Pierre Jacomet, but that the French Government ordered them to be kept in prison at Bourrasol.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Since the beginning of the Soviet aid program, the United States has shipped more than 2,900,000 tons of war supplies to the Soviet Union, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, said today.

Out of thirty-three Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church who have replied directly or indirectly to a questionnaire, twenty-five approve the basic principles of the proposed union with the Presbyterian Church in the United States, three oppose and five are noncommittal, it was announced yesterday by The Witness, a weekly publication devoted to Episcopal news and comment.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Prices of wheat moved upward today on the Board of Trade as a result of scattered buying here and in Minneapolis which was attributed to mills, but the markets fell just short of reaching the seasonal high levels established yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- In order to provide the town of Linz, Austria, where Adolf Hitler went to school, with an art collection, the Germans have looted a number of old masters from the Netherlands, it was learned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Branch Rickey, out West to round up some of the Brooklyn Dodgers' doubtful hirelings, and professing no present concern over a club manager, predicted tonight that a full baseball season was ahead despite the war.

Federal income taxpayers are allowed deductions in connection with the cost of operation of an automobile used for business, including the cost of gasoline, oil, repairs, garage rent, amounts paid for insurance and other necessary expenses.

The Pulitzer Building, at 63 Park Row, with all its ghostly newspaper memories of old New York, was the scene yesterday of the formal opening on the second floor of the new headquarters of Local Draft Board 1, largest in the United States and the one with the most diversified registration.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Official announcement that William D. Cox, 33-year-old New York sportsman, has purchased the Phils is expected to be made here tomorrow.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Direct hits were scored on four Japanese cargo ships by Allied heavy bombers in a raid before dawn yesterday on the Buin naval base in the Northern Solomons, the Allied Command announced today.

The German communique said yesterday that renewed Russian attacks had been repelled in the Kharkov area, southeast of Orel and on the Donets front, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- George A. Casey, president of the National Independent Meat Packers Association, accused Secretary Wickard today of endangering public health by failing to provide relief for meat packers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Eastern sectional championships of the United States Figure Skating Association turned into a home-town triumph tonight for comely Ann Robinson of the New Haven Skating Club, Connecticut's only entry.
Canadian Army men will join with leading amateurs of the United States in the National Red Cross squash racquets tournament starting this morning on the courts of the University Club.

Today's events: "Louise," 2 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Jan Kiepura, tenor, Town Hall, 3; Helen Teschner Tas, violin, and Lukas Foss, piano, in Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Hubert Dilworth, baritone, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:45; Stell Anderson, piano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "La Gioconda," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30; operatic ensemble of the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, the Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, 8:15.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- The job of preserving the for-hire trucking system of New England was placed squarely in the lap of the industry at a meeting held here this afternoon. The alternative to voluntary action on the part of the trucking industry, it was said, is more stringent government regulation.

Mishel Piastro, concert master of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and one of fourteen men discharged from the orchestra, denounced the management yesterday as well as Dr. Artur Rodzinski, the conductor.

Two out of every seven who live in this city use one or more of the services that depend on the Greater New York Fund for financial help, Arthur A. Ballantine, president of the organization, declared last night in an address broadcast over Station WJZ, in which he reported on the activities of the fund during last year and urged support of its 1943 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt gave pledges today that the United States would rush -- "as fast as the Lord will let us" -- additional military materiel to China to transform that country into a base for offensive operations against the Japanese homeland. His promise drew from Mme. Chiang Kai-shek the remark that the Lord helps those who help themselves.

Some Treasury officials, as well as other critics of the Ruml plan, cannot get it out of their heads that somehow or other the Government is being cheated out of a year's taxes by it. Under cross-examination they admit that the Government's income would keep coming in just the same this year, next year, and so on.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The informal remarks of President Roosevelt in presenting newspaper correspondents today to Madame Chiang Kai-shek and Madame Chiang's talk were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that, despite opposition from farm State members of Congress and those who urge stress on supplying of weapons to our Allies, he was determined to build up the armed forces to the projected total of 11,000,000 by the end of 1943.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Mal Stevens, the old Yale blue, tonight suggested appointment of a national physical fitness coordinator who, he said, "might eliminate the strife between advocates of contact and non-contact training programs for the armed forces."

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Foreign correspondents in China will come under the newly promulgated newspaper man's law, official quarters said today, but it was indicated that although technically they will be covered by the law, in practice they will be treated as a separate class.

Retail trade continued notably active this week, with apparel sections again contributing substantial sales increases. Department store volume was estimated as running around 20 per cent ahead of the comparative 1942 week, a figure only slightly smaller than for the preceding week. Specialty shop gains were heavier, but were believed to have ranged under the 53 per cent rise reported for these apparel stores last week.

Nazi persecution of religion and the Jews in Germany and the occupied countries has been condemned by the churchmen of neutral Sweden in no uncertain terms, while church leaders of Switzerland have expressed uncompromising opposition to anti-Semitism.

New Yorkers last night and early today saw a partial lunar eclipse, in which more than three-quarters of the moon's surface was obscured in a celestial blackout by the earth's shadow. Despite somewhat cloudy weather, the eclipse was plainly visible in Manhattan. Weather conditions permitting, it was seen throughout the United States.

Four men were arrested yesterday by detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad and charged with the theft of 40,471 ration coupons from the Long Island City office of the OPA. The coupons, negotiable for 11,000,000 gallons of gasoline, were removed from a safe in the Chatham-Phenix Building, 29-28 Forty-first Avenue, during the last weekend of January.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The noon communique:

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The stock markets here were quiet today with the approach of the weekend. The government's showing that it had a majority for its policy of deferring action on the Beveridge social security plan strengthened both industrial and insurance shares.

The Japanese House of Representatives approved without discussion Thursday twenty-six bills, one of which greatly increases Premier Hideki Tojo's powers over war production, the German radio reported yesterday in a broadcast recorded by The Associated Press.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 19 -- Paramount will produce a picture with a contemporary Turkish background, "Date Line-Istanbul," dealing with Nazi spy activities. The screen play is being written by Joan Alison and Murray Burnett, authors of "Casablanca," now at Paramount under a recently signed term contract. The film will be produced by Walter MacEwen.

The casualty rate among American war correspondents since Pearl Harbor has been three to four times greater than that of the United States Army, according to an article published yesterday by Editor Publisher, trade paper of the newspaper industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- J.K. Galbraith, deputy price administrator, told Senate investigators today that a directive freezing fluid milk prices at January levels would be modified to permit increases in some areas.

Consolidated net income of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries for 1942 was $5,052,955 after $800,000 reserve for inventory price decline or other contingencies, according to a report issued yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 -- Outflanking of Taganrog by the capture of Matvyeev-Kurgan, progress of a double-headed assault on the Germans bridgehead in the Caucasus, overrunning of more regions in the eastern Donets Basin and important progress against the Orel salient were the main points of today's official news.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19 (AP) -- The part play by Assemblyman David Young 3d of Towaco, Morris County, in litigation instituted against the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation in the United States District Court of Delaware and the Delaware Chancery Court was "to conceal, if possible, the real parties in interest," Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine said today.

POONA, India, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi grew steadily weaker today near the halfway mark in his fast against detention in the palace of the Aga Khan and an attending physician declared it would "be a miracle" if the Indian leader survived the twenty-one-day ordeal.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- The Burlington Mills Corporation of Greensboro, N.C., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement for $6,500,000 of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock with a par value of $100 a share.

The proposed Youth Court for Kings County discussed by Judge Leibowitz as reported in THE TIMES of Feb. 10 deserves consideration from even a broader point of view than that from which it is contemplated. The proposed goals, "eradication of a stigma of felony from young offenders and subsequent rehabilitation of the defendants, are surely commendable.
BOSTON, Fed. 19 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow:

JERUSALEM, Feb. 19 -- After over three years of harassed wartime traveling over thousands of miles of land and sea, 859 children and 369 grown-ups had the happiest day of their lives yesterday when they arrived in Palestine at the termination of their prolonged odyssey.

Not many pianists in late seasons have interpreted Chopin as lyrically and poetically as Alexander Brailowsky in his recital, fifth of a series of six that he is giving of Chopin's music, last night in Town Hall. Mr. Brailowsky began with the Prelude in C sharp minor -- the late one which stands apart from all the others in its mood and its quality of free improvisation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- While people connected with the livestock and meat packing industry show little concern over what they consider to be an overrated "black market" in meat, they do, however, express some concern over the future outlook from the civilian point of view.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 19 -- German boys who are being mobilized recieve only six weeks' training and parallel to their military instruction they are being drilled in Nazi ideology so "they may fight with greater fury," according to advices received here from Berlin through private channels.
MY friend Tommy Miller, aged 8, is disgusted with the way I drive a car. When I come to a curve I slow down, but Tommy wants me to keep going straight.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- From a population and technological viewpoint, it is too late for the United States to rule the world, while the Soviet Union, with a "little political luck" will be the strongest single power in the world, Dr. Frank W. Notestein, of the Office of Population Research, told the midwinter meeting of the American Philosophical Society today.
MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

After exhibiting moderate strength early in the session, the cotton futures market weakened yesterday under late liquidation in the new-crop months and closed with prices unchanged to 4 points lower than Thursday's final quotations, the day's low levels.

James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company, ended his service as chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office yesterday, to the accompaniment of lavish praise from Mayor La Guardia for his year of labor as unpaid head of the organization.

While his seeing-eye dog watched with obvious intentness, David Margolis, a Brooklyn attorney who has been blind for five years, carefully felt his way along the aisle of a Kings County Court room yesterday and stood before the bench as Judge Nathan R. Sobel assigned him as counsel for a grand larceny defendant too poor to engage an attorney.

The world production of crude petroleum and its substitutes last year amounted to 2,207,800,000 barrels, compared with 2,379,420,000 in 1941, a decline of 171,620,000, according to an estimate by V.R. Garfias, R.V. Whetsel and J.W. Ristori of the foreign oil department of the Cities Service Company.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Criminal and civil action against black market operators is planned by the Office of Price Administration in an effort to halt illegal traffic in meat in the Midwest.

For the first time this year, no new issues of bonds were offered here this week for public subscription. Absence of flotations contrasted with four issues aggregating $15,518,000 last week and with three small municipal loans amounting to $2,400,000 a year ago at this time.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

With the arrival of new contingents of Waves, Waacs and Spars in the city, swelling the number of uniformed women, the work of outfitting them has grown into a sizable business for women s apparel shops. Although enlisted women and officers coming from training centers across the country already have received regulation outfits, they are shopping for replacements in a dozen or so, stores.

Lunch counters, restaurants, hotels and other eating places may not open canned meat or fish that they have in stock to make sandwiches and salads for customers, the legal division of the regional office of Price Administration declared yesterday in an "interpretation" of the OPA freezing order covering canned meats and fish.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 19 -- The University of New Hampshire's formidable array of skiers got off to a commanding lead in defense of its honors in the Middlebury Carnival today, rolling up an imposing score of 196.88 points for the first two events.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Cornell's basketball team held Princeton to a two-point lead at half-time tonight, but the Tigers surged back in the second half to win going away, 52 -- 36. It was the Nassau five's fourth victory in six starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate League and strengthened its hold on third place behind Penn and Dartmouth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Office of Price Administration has authorized an allocation system in an effort to obtain fairer distribution of beef, pork, lamb, mutton and veal in the San Francisco and Los Angeles areas and in Rhode Island.

One of the things which Mr. Tolischus did in the course of his habitation enforced in a Japanese cell was quite a bit of reading. He asked for the Bible and Shakespeare, but only got the former. Our correspondent read the Bible from cover to cover, and many passages more than once.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A Congressional Medal of Honor has been awarded to Lieut. Col. Pierpoint M. Hamilton of New York for "conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity" during the invasion of North Africa.

The importance of proper maintenance of the American family and in particular adequate protection for mothers were stressed yesterday by leaders in the fields of medicine and social welfare and cooperating organizations in welfare and public health.

The three fake detectives who were trapped in a scheme to extort $10,000 from an American fiscal representative of the British Government in Washington two weeks ago found themselves in new difficulties yesterday as a grand jury accused them of trying to bribe the detectives who arrested them.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools of New York City, attacked tonight the Coudert-Moffat bill transferring the purchase of school supplies from the Board of Education to the city Department of Purchase as "an attempt to undermine the independence and integrity of the school system."

A sentence to die in the electric chair in the week beginning March 29 was imposed by Judge John J. Freschi in General Sessions yesterday on John Regan, 33 years old, an ex-convict, in the shooting of Francis McGovern, a fellow-longshoreman, on the night of last Sept. 8, in a cider stube at 415 West Fiftieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Modification of the national 35-mile-an-hour speed limit to permit trucks to rush "emergency" war-vital freight is probable in the near future, it was reported, today.

The Red Cross is the "truest example of steadfast, wholehearted Americanism," former Mayor James J. Walker declared yesterday at a luncheon of executives in the New York dress industry at the Hotel Astor, in support of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City.
BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York postponed his departure by plane for Vatican City today because of rain and windstorms.
WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in Tunisia, Feb. 17 (Delayed) -- Jerry threw his Sunday punch at us with men, guns and tanks, and that, in part, is the story of the American retreat in Tunisia.

Andrew Jackson High, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, clinched the South Queens title in winning its ninth straight loop game, and Forest Hills High clinched the North Queens crown yesterday. Jackson, in winning in South Queens for the fourth time, routed Far Rockaway, 52 -- 25. Bobby Gale and Harry Johnson made 17 and 16 points, respectively, for the Old Hickories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- With flashing charm Mme. Chiang Kaishek laid the burdens of China on the desk of the President today. The jewelled wings she wore as no American wears an aviation pin, upward tilting and on-the-wing, twinkled as she sat on the edge of a chair which dwarfed her and in which, when rocking, she thrice threatened to pitch backward.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- American armored forces stabilized their new line on the Tunisian mountains near the Algerian frontier today while the violent drive by Marshal Rommel that had carried him more than sixty miles slacked off to mere skirmishing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Mareth Line in southeastern Tunisia, against which the British Eighth Army seems to be moving, was demilitarized by removal of its guns on Italian demands after the collapse of France and has been hastily re-equipped by the Germans since the Allied landings in North Africa last November, according to information here.

Judging from recent Washington dispatches, a considerable difference of opinion exists among high-ranking officers concerning the future of college athletics under the Army's new specialized training program.

Elissa Landi will enact the leading role, that of a woman lecturer, in "Apology," the Lee Strasberg production of the Charles Schnee play. Miss Landi has been a stranger to the Broadway stage since 1938, when she was seen in "Empress of Destiny."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, disclosed today "an alarming break-down" in the moral standards of juveniles, especially among girls.

Most banks and financial markets in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday. Some banks in Kentucky and North Carolina will remain open, as will banks in a few war industry areas in the Middle West.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The Royal Air Force delivered a heavy cargo of blockbusters on the Wilhelmshaven U-boat base and shipyards last night, while other British squadrons shot up shipping along the Netherland and French coasts and inland communications across France and Belgium.

The approach of an extended week-end holiday, due to the observance on Monday of Washington's Birthday, plus the sharp decline in prices on Thursday, invited yesterday further selling in the stock market. Sales did not appear at all urgent to brokers, who again were cautious in their comments on the present status of values.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked the third United States Circuit Court of Appeals to postpone the hearing of two appeals from its order to the Columbia Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiary, the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Company, to break their control over the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, until after the Federal District Court of Delaware acts upon a voluntary plan for liquidation of the subsidiary.
In your editorial "Hitler and the Generals" you are echoing General Chuikoff's, and perhaps others', conclusion that "the great strategic mistake of the Germans was putting Hitler in command."

What principles of good nutrition should guide a wartime cook in planning menus? What procedures should she follow in marketing? What practices should she observe in preparing meals? These were the questions the writer put to three women, all of whom have a better-than-average knowledge of food.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Turning down the Communist party's application for affiliation, the Labor party national executive, in a statement today, declared that an amalgamation would defer, if not destroy, labor's hopes of great social changes after the war.

The fifteen-story and six-story apartment buildings at 545 and 555 Edgecombe Avenue, comprising the Washington Heights blockfront between 159th and 160th Streets overlooking the Polo Grounds, have been sold by the Schwarzler estate to an investing client of Darling McDonald, brokers.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Jockey Leon Haas suffered a broken collar bone and the Greentree Stable's 6-year-old gelding Gramps was fatally hurt today in a spectacular spill that marked the seventh race at the Fair Grounds.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19 -- Claiming rank as the second largest labor union in the country, exceeded only by the United Auto Workers (C.I.O.), the United Steel Workers of America (C.I.O.) reported its membership today as 725,625 and its assets as $1,774,900, including $1,415,000 cash.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 19 -- British forces occupied the defended village of Foum Tatahouine yesterday, encountering little opposition, and later pushed on westward despite muddy roads, occupying positions some miles beyond Foum Tatahouine.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- A powerful Russian army is driving southwestward from Kharkov toward the Dnieper River on a forty-five-mile front, menacing the key German bases of Poltava and Krasnograd, while a second force thrusts northwestward on Konotop, a special Russian communique revealed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt, seeking to end a jam of cases before the National Railway Labor panel, added eight members to the nine-man board today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 19 -- By announcing over the radio this morning that Japan had begun a full-sized campaign to take China and occupy Chungking, the Japanese Voice of Experience has aroused the curiosity of lovers of truth in the capital of Free China.

Forty-one of the forty-five "wet" State Legislatures, which convened in the first two weeks of January, are considering a total of 566 proposed liquor law amendments, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by Allied Liquor Industries, Inc.

Asserting that most of the postwar plans so far projected have been designed to further special interests of Democratic politicians, Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State, urged Republican women yesterday to work for a program that would assure "constructive peace."

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The mystery of how to saw a woman in half appeared in Chancery Court today without an explanation of how it's done. It was made plain, however, that any one could read all about it in various books.

Oliver Wendell Holmes is so intimately identified with the "Autocrat of the Breakfast Table" and poems that every schoolboy knows that only physicians remember him as the man who, independently of the Hungarian, Ignatz Semmelweiss, discovered the contagious nature of childbirth fever.

Dean Alfange, former American Labor party nominee for Governor, called last night for a major political realignment in the United States, based on realities instead of on habit, expediency or the accident of geography.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Federal price control will be extended within two to three months over fresh vegetables, one of the few remaining foodstuffs in the family's budget which has not been brought under price curbs, the Office of Price Administration said today.

The ability of government to work well depends primarily upon the capacity of those who do the work. Today the government has an enormous job to do; and the importance of its labors will not decrease with the end of war.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Conversations directed toward settling differences between Russia and the Yugoslav government-in-exile over General Draja Mikhailovitch have been opened between representatives in London, it was learned reliably tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A wave of defeatism and fears for the future appeared today to be gripping Nazi satellites and Quislings as the Soviet offensive continued to roll back Adolf Hitler's Eastern armies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- The Metropolitan Opera Association, Inc., complete with singers, conductors, orchestra and ballet, will play its first Chicago engagement in thirty-three years when it opens a two-week season of fourteen performances at the Civic Opera House Monday evening, March 22.

Foregoing their customary Saturday off, more than 100,000 of the city's garment workers will report at their various shops today to participated in a "million-dollar day" by contributing the day's pay to war aid and community relief, it was announced yesterday by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Families in the Hudson River Valley, in New Jersey and all over New England are adopting in increasing numbers the Western practice of treating meats and other perishable foods almost like jewels -- locking them in rented vaults in commercial refrigerator plants where they keep fresh indefinitely.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commander of the United States Army Armored Forces, said in an interview today that since American and German tank losses in the Tunisian fighting were about equal the Germans were losing the war there.

MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (delayed) -- Although the blockade of Leningrad was broken a month ago today, the city's trials are by no means over. From a range of twelve miles heavy artillery mounted on armored trains is hurling ten-inch shrapnel shells on the city and the Luftwaffe, whose crack pilots still are kept in the north, are making frequent attempts to break through the immensely powerful barrage.

Mine. Chiang Kai-shek made an extraordinary impression on Congress. The gentlemen who have produced and sampled a lot of oratory say that as a speaker the First Lady of China stands first among the distinguished foreigners who have addressed the House. But it was not only her eloquence that evoked the storm of applause when she struck out at the "prevailing opinion" that the defeat of Japan is secondary to the defeat of Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Holding that a necessity for revising a dormant government corporation into a new $225,000,000 loan program to spur agricultural production had not been established, Senator Byrd, as chairman of the Congressional Departmental Economy Committee, instructed A.G. Black, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, today to submit legislative recommendations that would consolidate and simplify the twenty farm-lending agencies already in operation.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Colonel Edson Raff, stocky 35-year-old commander of the first United States paratroops to see action in this war, related the story today of how a fluke hoodwinked the defenders when American forces landed in North Africa last Fall and how it worked to the advantage of the invaders.

New York City had its second test blackout within twenty-four hours last night and the result, from early reports, seemed better than on Thursday. There seemed to be less confusion on the second blue signal, the alarm that caused most of the errors on Thursday.

" The Amazing Mrs. Holliday," a topical drama starring Deanna Durbin, will have its local premiere today at the Rivoli. Edmond O'Brien, Barry Fitzgerald, Harry Davenport, Frieda Inescort, Arthur Treacher and Grant Mitchell appear in featured roles.

All indications are that the garment trades will make a very early start on preparations for the Fall season. Unless rationing intervenes, the present oversold situation of Spring suits, coats and dresses will probably be cleaned up by May 1 at the latest and manufacturers will lose no time in beginning Fall production.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Senator Taft said today that a ten-day investigation of conditions in Puerto Rico by a Senate subcommittee disclosed "confusion, overlapping and duplication" of governmental agencies, both Federal and insular.
The case the President presents for his executive order limiting net salaries to $25,000 is as weak on economic as on legal grounds.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 19 -- A Chinese High Command communique said today that all the Japanese drives in Central, Southern and Southwestern China had been slowed down or thrown into reverse, although costly fighting continued in some areas.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Major John L. Griffith, commissioner of athletics for the Western Conference, said today a group of college presidents had advised Army officials to take a stand against participation in intercollegiate athletics.

THE track merry-go-round will spin dizzily in Madison Square Garden tonight when the New York Athletic Club stages its renewal of the oldest indoor meet in America and, therefore, in the entire world. The spiked shoe addicts will whirl around the boards and the objective of every man in every race will be to snatch the brass ring of victory in transit.

Representatives of the administrative, teaching and employe divisions of the Board of Education, appearing yesterday before the City Council committee on State legislation, urged rejection of a pending resolution designed to help transfer to the Department of Purchase the power, now held by the supply bureaus of the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education, to buy all school supplies, including textbooks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Ways and Means Committee, being unable to agree today upon any one of four pay-as-you-go taxation plans, turned the question over to a special subcommittee charged with drafting a compromise bill embodying the principles of pay-as-you-go and collection of taxes at the source.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The rapidity with which the Commodity Credit Corporation's feed wheat stocks have dwindled in recent weeks was a surprise to grain men. Only a few weeks ago the corporation said it still had 25,000,000 bushels available for sale to livestock feeders at 85 per cent of the parity price of corn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 19The Connecticut premire of the technicolor motion picture, "Stratford, the Home of the Lees," on the afternoon of Feb. 26 at the Greenwich High School will be under the auspices of the Women's Division of the War Savings Staff, United States Treasury, and the Greenwich committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc.

A racket in which with the stroke of a hammer a used postage stamp could be raised in apparent philatelic value from $6.50 to $600 has been uncovered here by Federal investigators, it was disclosed yesterday. Four stamp dealers and a printer have been arrested and are awaiting grand jury action.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The pamphlet report of the Sun Oil Company for 1942, made public yesterday, shows current assets on Dec. 31, last, of $94,438,801 and current liabilities of $44,098,975, compared with $67,759,209 and $31,728,108, respectively, on Dec. 31, 1941.
Just how many men are required on the "home front" to support one man in uniform is one of the debatable statistics of this and other wars to which no good answer is readily available.

The recording and transcription companies and the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, have reached an impasse on the union's proposed plan to end the controversy over recordings and any settlement of the seven-month-old dispute appears delayed indefinitely, it was learned yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The lights went out all over Hackensack during the blackout last night -- all but those on the porch of the home of John Borg, publisher of The Bergen Evening Record -- and the local Civilian Defense Council is $50 richer today as a result.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins reported today that the actual work-week in durable goods industries averaged 46.2 hours in December, which she interpreted as at least a forty-eight-hour schedule.

ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Government-ordered limitation on newsprint usage constitutes "a governor on the power of the press" at a time when "never before has so much depended upon the unselfish and enlightened use" of this power, Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, declared here today.

Eugene Rogers, an 18-year-old freshman from Bayside, won two events for Columbia, one in pool-record time, last night, but his team was beaten by Navy, 47 -- 28, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming meet at Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Quotas of wool allocated for the production of essential civilian goods were doubled today by the War Production Board in a move aimed at assuring an adequate supply of wool clothing for civilians next Fall and Winter.

Mild weather and shipments of oil somewhat eased the fuel oil crisis of the utilities yesterday. Closed laundries reopened on a 50 per cent basis. At the same time, wails went up because of priorities and other limitations on diaper services.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 19 -- A fire followed by violent explosions last Sunday completely destroyed the Frederikshavn branch of the famous diesel engine factory and machine shop Burmeister Wain, whose main plant in Copenhagen was badly mauled by the British Royal Air Force on Jan. 27.

The Book-of-the-Month Club has announced for its May choice "The Fifth Seal," by Mark Aldanov, a Scribner publication. Mr. Aldanov, a Russian by birth, lived for many years in Paris, and came to this country two years ago. His novel deals with political intrigue in Paris in the Thirties.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Governor Dewey asked the Federal Government to take steps to relieve the plight of small business concerns today in the New York City area which are suffering from lack of business and idle facilities. He pledged his cooperation and the full facilities of the State government.

Ray Robinson came back to Madison Square Garden and his winning ways last night in a ten-round bout with Sergeant Jackie Wilson of Mitchel Field and California, a contest waged in the interests of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

The New York A.C., the organization that ran America's first track meet back in 1868, will commemorate that occasion tonight with its seventy-fifth anniversary indoor games in Madison Square Garden. The event will be notable also because the Winged Foot is playing host to the metropolitan intercollegiate championship meet.

Judge Robert A. Inch, in Brooklyn Federal court, approved yesterday a settlement of $250,000 for 575 claimants seeking damages for the perilous journey from Seville, Spain, to New York aboard the Spanish ship Navemar, which carried 1,200 passengers when there were accommodations for only 15.

" Brotherhood Week" will have its annual observance in the churches beginning tomorrow, having begun last evening in the synagogues. A statement issued yesterday from the office of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, 381 Fourth Avenue, the sponsoring organization, said that "this year's observance will be more comprehensive than ever before," the reason being the war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The President held a press conference and received a number of callers.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 -- Interviews with executives of management and leaders of labor, together with an inspection of the Ford-operated Willow Run bomber plant, convinced members of the Truman Committee today that shortage of manpower and changes in design were responsible for deficiency in production.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of ninety-three soldiers missing in action on various fronts. Among them, with next of kin, were the following:
LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A special Russian communique recorded tonight by the Soviet monitor:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 19 -- Allied planes have intensified their systematic campaign of bombing and strafing German supply lines as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel sought to consolidate positions won in his four-day offensive in Southern Tunisia.
With the opening of the trout season in New York State some six weeks off, most of the sportsmen are finding themselves too busy these days to plan their customary Spring trips.

A group of teen-age girls living in the East Eighties gets into some kind of a "scrap" every afternoon after school. They use brooms -- even fingernails -- but they come out unharmed, while Uncle Sam benefits by many thousands more pounds of metal, rubber, grease and other kinds of hand-me-downs for the war machine.

The four-story apartment building at 42-43 147th Street, in Flushing, Queens, assessed for $58,000 and accommodating twenty families, has been sold by Herman Rohde to Molly Hirsch through Fred M. Doscher, broker. Michael Hertzoff represented the buyer and the Lawyers Title Corporation insured the title.

In the editorial "The A B C of Pay-as-You-Go" you point out that under one Treasury proposal "persons with $100,000 incomes would be asked to pay 22 per cent more than their entire incomes," while under another proposal the same class of taxpayers "would still have to pay 104 per cent of their whole income in taxes for the next five years."

In a recent public health meeting held in this city it was stated that the Army's present rate for venereal disease is now forty per thousand annually, the lowest in our military history. Good as the record is, the experts pointed out that it is not good enough. It is said to be three and one-half times higher than for civilians, and the civilian rate has always made State and Federal health departments shudder.

The New York Little Symphony, under Joseph Barone, its founder-conductor, gave a concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall before an enthusiastic capacity audience. In line with its purpose of creating opportunities for outstanding young American soloists, conductors and composers, the organization presented Lukas Foss, composer-conductor-pianist, and Merrill Miller, baritone, as assisting artists at this event.

Accelerated interest in sewing at home has brought a nation-wide increase of approximately 40 per cent in the sale of yard goods, patterns and notions in the last year. Thousands of more women are expected to raise the enrollment in the make-it-yourself school during "Sew and Save Week," which begins today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTER IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 19 (AP) -- A French High Command communique:
NORRIS CITY, Ill., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A train of tank cars pulled out tonight for the Atlantic seaboard with the first oil brought from Texas through "Big Inch," the world's largest oil pipe line.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 19 -- All day today among Hindus, Moslems and Britons in India's capital one finds the belief that Mohandas K. Gandhi is sinking. That amazing little old man may yet fool his friends and foes, but doctors' bulletins and other reports from Poona seem to leave little room for hope.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The City of New York and other interested official and trade groups from that city today filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking that if railroads are permitted to maintain their present increased rates or any increased rates, "they should be required as an expressed condition of so doing to readjust them promptly to reflect the long-established port differentials."
Service to men of many faiths is being rendered by the War Prisoners Aid of the Y. 1VLC. A. in prison camps throughout the world, according to executives of the organization.

With the exception of the detective, all the persons who play their parts in this tale of murder are connected in one way or another with Southwest University in Los Angeles. Most of them are students in the Drama Department, and at least one is majoring in psychology.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 20 -- Winning all but two events, the Dartmouth swimming team scored its fourth victory in five meets when it defeated Army, 51 -- 24, in the Spaulding Pool tonight. It was the Green's third Eastern Intercollegiate League triumph.

One hundred pacifists who firmly believe that an immediate peace is both practical and desirable got together yesterday at the Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street, for the sixth annual United Pacifist Conference.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 -- Trading in soy bean futures on the Board of Trade ceased today by direction of the directors of the Exchange following an analysis of the order issued this week by Secretary of Agriculture Claude M. Wickard which prohibited the purchase or acceptance of a delivery of soy beans except by processors, manufacturers or seed dealers.

THEY don't use any gasoline or rubber and they can more than double, with full legal consent, the speed of thirty-five miles an hour. You may have seen them of a Winter's day skimming across smooth reaches of the North Shrewsbury River, the Hudson, Lakes Hopatcong and Greenwood and various other tight-frozen waters near New York.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force, flying again by the light of a full moon and with a large bomber complement of the Royal Canadian Air Force, dealt the second successive night blow on Wilhelmshaven last night, loosing destruction upon U-boat lairs and shipyards of the Reich port in a thirty-minute saturation raid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The concern of the United States in the Indian situation was manifested today through a conference held by Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, in which it figured.

Vast changes have been made in the New York City curriculum to modernize the existing course of studies and get them attuned to the new world conditions. Almost every subject in the school system has undergone careful consideration and serious analysis at the hands of a recently appointed curriculum council.

FOR the past three years an experiment in the peoples' drama has been carried on by a group in Greenwich Village. With a persistence not usually associated with this kind of enterprise these people have turned their stage into a community weapon in order to make social comment on conditions needing recognition and solution. They present and work under the title of People's Plays.

Net profits of Sterling Drug, Inc., for 1942 were $7,086,354 after all charges and taxes, equal to $4.04 a share on 1,750,667 shares, according to a report issued yesterday. This compared with $8,651,386, or $4.96 a share on 1,740,868 shares in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Life in the United States, when and if total war requires civilians to sacrifice all but absolute essentials, will be a fairly drab affair, according to preliminary estimates which the Office of Civilian Supply in the War Production Board has prepared for James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization.

No one can say as yet whether the gardens we have next year will be pre-Victory or post-Victory. But one thing is certain: we shall still need gardens, and many who are in a position to know believe we shall be even more in need of them next year than this.
THROUGH a dozen channels, in a dozen tongues or more, organizations of women across the country are helping the OPA with the point-rationing program.

The fifty-fifth National A.A.U. track and field championships, which always strike a high note in the Winter's competition, will be held in Madison Square Garden on Saturday, with their luster undimmed despite the war. There will be fewer athletes than usual, but the meet will not suffer in quality.

THE team of Cornell and McClintic has scored again. Once more the actress-manager and her director husband have a hit -- Chekhov's drab picture of Russian life, "The Three Sisters," which needs superb acting and adroit directing. Miss Cornell and her company provide the first, Mr. McClintic has seen to the second.

A NEW type of antique, which is gaining a following among both collectors and interior decorators comes from south of the Rio Grande. Furniture, textiles, pottery, lacquer work and varied handcrafts of Mexico and our other sister republics are attracting new attention.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Office of War Information reported today that announced casualties of the armed forces had reached a total of 65,380 killed, wounded, taken prisoner, missing and interned in neutral countries.

The annual report of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for 1942, issued yesterday, shows total assets at a new high record of $5,994,915,577, comparing with $5,648,047,196 a year before, with unassigned funds of $369,769,190, against $340,894,196. Life insurance in force at the close of the year was $26,867,676,154, also a high record, comparing with $25,433,226,148 a year before.

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- Interest centers today on the southern part of the active front. The Russians report the capture of several big localities west of Seversk and Grivensk, which had been reached on a broad front during the previous day's fighting.
TORONTO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs defeated the Bruins, 4 -- 2, tonight before 13,483 fans in the Boston team's last appearance here in the current National Hockey League season.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 20 -- The Duke University basketball team defeated Navy, 58 to 48, today in a fast-moving game that saw the score tied eight times and the lead switching rapidly, particularly in the second period.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Feb. 20 (AP) -- President Ramon S. Castillo said in an interview today that Argentina would continue to remain neutral in the world struggle during the remaining year of his administration, and later as well in the event of the election of Senate President Robustiano Patron Costas, whom he has indorsed as his successor.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 20 -- Bermuda's imports last year are estimated at 2,401,225, compared with 2,422,106 in 1941 in a pamphlet on the colony's economy system by Professor W. Henry Richardson, the government's economic adviser.

MANY worth-while volumes remain obscure and unread for want of a "loudspeaker" to vaunt their virtues; not great books, but gentle, imaginative emanations of the spirit fashioned to bring pleasure to those properly attuned.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 20 -- In Vichy, Chief of Government Pierre Laval has created a new National Council that will continue to exist "until the promulgation of a new constitution" as set forth in the first decree of the "new order" dating back to July, 1940, said a Vichy announcement today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Attu, the westernmost of the Aleutians, is believed to have been used by the enemy as a seaplane base for reconnaissance flights and weather observation. In a sense it is an outpost of Kiska, and last September the Japanese entirely abandoned it in the interest of strengthening their base at Kiska.

THE National Conference of Christians and Jews has honored me with the task of devising and directing a musical program which will embody the idea of interfaith amity -- this to be a feature of the celebration of the tenth anniversary of Brotherhood Week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Services of Supply of the United States Army, declared at a press conference today that, in the light of his observations on his recent overseas inspection trip, he was "surer than ever that this is now a war of transportation."

WE may as well face it now as later: the brook and the river have met and our young friend Andy Hardy has gone rolling onward down the stream of life. We wouldn't be so morbid as to wave him a mournful farewell; we may yet see more of Andy beyond the current "Andy Hardy's Double Life."

The doubters ask what assurance is there, if we are patient and wait for the end of the war, that we shall really get a better world. What guarantees have we against another failure like that which followed upon the last World War?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A possible "solution" of the Ways and Means Committee's stalemate on pay-as-you-go taxation will be offered for consideration Monday by Representative Knutson of Minnesota, second ranking minority member of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The dismissal of Ferdinand Eberstadt as the War Production Board's program vice chairman in charge of allocating raw materials to war factories was more than a mere skirmish in the "battle of Washington" this week.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Asking whether America will fail its leaders and spokesmen as the country failed President Wilson after the first World War, Dr. Guy Stanton Ford, editor of The American Historical Review, told the American Philosophical Society today that he thought the chances of sabotaging effective participation of the United States in world reconstruction were greater than the defeat of a similar program in 1918.

By way of Lisbon comes news of a series issued by Bulgaria to aid war victims. "For Those Crippled From War" is inscribed on each stamp, and the same wording is on an attached tag. Every tag carries a special tax, and the stamp sells for its postal value plus the amount mentioned on the tag.

THE most violent chapters in the recorded history of this country concern the conflict between the Indians and the white invaders of their territory. The native, or 100 per cent, Americans resented the intrusion of the foreigners and the introduction of European ideas and ways of living to their as yet unspoiled continent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb 20 -- After General Winter, a new general -- purely German, this one -- is worrying the German people. His name is "General Unrest;" literally so, since in Germany he is General Walther von Unruh.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 20 -- Wendell Willkie is considering seeking the Republican Presidential nomination again in 1944, and he would be supported by at least the majority of the Indiana delegation as this State's favorite son.

SHOE rationing is having a sobering influence on people's taste in footwear and a beneficial effect on their feet. So is walking -- a practice which many city dwellers are indulging in for the first time in their feet.

THERE lately arrived in this office a letter that quite clearly had been born in sadness and considerable melancholy. Its author said that recently he had spent a fair length of time in New York and in the evenings had wandered often to the theatre.

This country's war planes, the Liberator, Flying Fortress, Warhawk, Thunderbolt, Avenger, Corsair and Spitfire, as well as the enemy's Junkers 87 (Stuka) Messerschmitt and Zero, are now as familiar to forty-seven men and women as once were the makes of automobiles.

ROY HARRIS has dedicated his new Fifth symphony to The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics "as a tribute to their strength in war, their staunch idealism for world peace, their ability to cope with stark materialistic problems of world order without losing a passionate belief in the fundamental importance of the arts."
A CERTAIN amount of hitting and grabbing and general free-for-all turns up in the normal course of events among young children -- with some more than with others.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The War Production Board reduced to $200 today the amount of construction which can be done without specific permission by industries which it classed as "not essential to the war program." Newspapers and manufacturers of sporting goods, furniture and cosmetics are included.
