Answers to some of the most pressing point rationing questions raised by the public in thousands of letters, telephone calls and personal visits to Washington authorities and to Office of Price Administration field offices and local boards were released here yesterday by the local Regional OPA office shortly before the one-week "freeze" of retail sales of processed foods started at midnight.

Last week a special Moscow communique announced the Red Army's greatest strategic success so far in this war. General Philip Golikoff, after drawing Kharkov's German defenders off balance by feints, had launched the main blow that routed the Nazis in a matter of hours.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared in an address here today that absenteeism was "eating up the heart of production," but that it cannot be cured by "calling each other names."
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- A drastic shortage in German aircraft has resulted in the inability of the Nazis to back up their U-boat campaign from the air, the British Air Ministry reported today.

Word received from the Office of Price Administration in Washington at the National Headquarters of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign in the Empire State Building reveals the willingness of the OPA to have citizens leave books for service men at the place where they go for War Ration Book No. 2.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission granted special temporary authority today to the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company to operate a radio-telegraph circuit between the United States and Algeria for a three-month period, but imposed two conditions.

Honesty paid dividends yester- day to a boy and a girl chosen by school principals and welfare agencies as the "most truthful" in the city. The affair was supported by the Hearns American Legion Post and Councilmanic President Newbold Morris was on hand at the Hotel Roosevelt to bestow his blessing.

The ancient committee system of Congress is visibly breaking down under the unparalleled burdens of total war. Instead of creating a single central over-all committee to coordinate its other committees and to frame a single coherent policy, Congress has been forming new special committees to do what many of its existing committees are already supposed to do.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- Fourteen men were held in total bail of $48,500 for the Federal Grand Jury tonight after F.B.I. agents made simultaneous raids in five New England States and smashed a lottery ring with an alleged annual "take" of $2,600,000 from small fry bettors.

NEW DELHI, Feb. 20 -- As Mr. Gandhi's condition continued to weaken, political, industrial and religious leaders met here today to endorse a resolution appealing to the Viceroy for his unconditional release. The resolution, which was actually presented to Lord Linlithgow last night in order not to lose time, stated that his release would be "in the interest of the future of India and international good will," while his death would cause a "serious situation."

Seven prominent newspaper men from Montevideo, Uruguay, and two from Lima, Peru, arrived in New York yesterday after a tour through the Southern States, the West Coast and the Northern industrial centers.

Tomorrow the nation celebrates the anniversary of George Washington's birth. This year the occasion holds a special meaning, since we have soldiers, marines and seamen round the world fighting to preserve the liberty Washington won for us.

FAT is "winning the war," and so is scrap, along with Henry Kaiser, sulfa drugs and the Associated Merchants of Slippery Rock -- all of them are winning the war. So, too, is a microscopic section of the Army whose responsibility it is to select, sort, test and assign every one of the 5,000,000 soldiers who represent America's bid for victory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- President Roosevelt announced today his "unqualified opposition" to the McKellar bill, which would require Presidential nomination and Senate confirmation of all Federal employes receiving more than $4,500 a year, and urged that the bill "not be enacted into law."

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 -- The British Government reiterated today its position that the responsibility for Mohandas K. Gandhi's hunger strike rested solely with him and that any decision to end it must be made by the Indian Nationalist leader himself.

A TALL, lank, sandy-haired man of 35 sits in Philadelphia, in a three-story house newly built in a field a quarter of a mile from what is now Independence Square. He has rented for thirty-five shillings a week a furnished parlor and bedroom. Here he has set up a desk made from his own design by a cabinetmaker of the town; and with a quill pen he is busily writing a paper headed "A Declaration."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The United States Navy, unlike the Army, will permit students in its college training program to engage in intercollegiate athletics -- if they can find the necessary time and have the necessary stamina.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Notre Dame tried to win one for the coach tonight -- but failed in overtime.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Long overdue, Gil Dodds, Boston's entrant in the mile sweepstakes, sped to an easy triumph in the Baxter Mile, feature race of the seventy-fifth anniversary indoor games of the New York Athletic Club, before a crowd of 13,000 at Madison Square Garden last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Invoking the "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission today directed the Republic Service Corporation to cut four electric subsidiaries and one water subsidiary from its system and to recapitalize its corporate structure so that its common stock shall have no participation.

FRANK SHAUGHNESSY was thumbing through the baseball rule book and shaking his head. As the president of the International League Shag is the final court of appeals for his circuit and it is his task to uphold his umpires or slap them down. He does the former with extreme pleasure and the latter only with regret.

THE growing of tree fruits in the home garden is not as widely practiced as it deserves to be. It is, of course, a different phase of gardening from growing flowers and vegetables, but in this very fact lies its attraction.

THOUGH he now discusses the news six times a week at 7 P.M. for Station WOV, which most commentators would deem a tolerably busy existence, Hans Jacob is practically loafing. By comparison, that is, with what used to be his schedule.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 20 -- Most of the talking about the farm-labor shortage and other wartime agricultural problems is done for, rather than by, the farmer. He is inclined to be rather close-mouthed about the whole thing, unless he has a personal problem that he thinks the county agent or the war-board chairman or somebody else in authority can do something about.

IN the former mansion of the late Frank J. Sturgis at 17 East Fifty-first Street, the Cathedral Canteen is maintaining a "home away from home" for an average of 5,000 soldiers, sailors, marines and merchant mariners every week. With some thirty personalized types of service now available to the boys in uniform, the canteen is arranging several special entertainments and recreational undertakings for the near future.

THE acute shortage in blueberries for general markets the past Summer, due to the large amount required by the Army and Navy, has awakened the gardener's interest in this berry, and the advantages of growing it. Even a few plants (from six to twelve) will supply a family of five with enough fruit during the season and, when they come into full bearing, some over to can.

THE middle-aged people of today are probably the last generation of Americans to be amazed that men have learned to fly higher, faster and farther than birds. The airplane has been developed within their lifetime, and if they have to take it on faith, as they do the radio, there is little wonder.

HERE is a new edition of an old, old favorite so well-beloved by so many children and light-minded adults that it has taken on the legendary air of Mother Goose rhymes. The first Edward Lear Nonsense Book was concocted for the delight of the children of the Earl of Derby, with whose family Lear was a favorite.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -Without leaving the bench, seven judges of the Ninth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals blocked today a move to deprive 70,000 evacuated Japanese-Americans of their citizenship.

DR. WILL DURANT is now working on the third volume of his monumental five-volume project, "The Story of Civilization," the first volume of which "Our Oriental Heritage," was published in 1935 and the second, "The Life of Greece," in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -William M. Leiserson, chairman of the National Railway Labor Panel, today appointed three emergency boards to investigate four wage disputes, including the differences between all Class I steam carriers and about 900,000 non-operating employes seeking a $450,000,000 wage increase.

Developments in the wave of scarce buying of apparel, which increased retail sales from 22 to 107 per cent in a single week, once again focused attention on the need of a government agency to foster civilian production and distribution.
Stocks staged a strong recovery yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Telephone and rail shares mounted to new highs in the second largest weekend session of 1943.

THERE is no overabundance of recordings of Debussy's unforgettable tone poem, La Mer. The domestic lists show a performance by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and now Columbia comes forward with a version for its catalogue by the Cleveland Orchestra under Artur Rodzinski (M-531, three twelve-inch records).

New York City's garment workers numbering more than 100,000 passed up their usual Saturday holiday yesterday to make a sizable financial contribution to American and foreign war relief agencies and domestic community services.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 20 -- German artillery and armored units are now holding off Allied advance elements around Ledinine and north of Foun Tatahouine, apparently helping the larger parts of Marshal Rommel's army to get set in the Mareth Line, twenty miles north.

THE Spanish Broadcasting Network" has a show for North America from 9.86 megacycles beginning at 8 P.M. English news of modern Spain is the main attraction. At 2 P.M. Madrid talks from the same channel for forty-five minutes with French, English and Spanish war bulletins.

Nearly 95 per cent of New York City's cooking is by gas. Next in order as fuel for the city's kitchen ranges come coal and coke, 2.8 per cent; electricity, 1.2 per cent; kerosene, 0.7 per cent, and wood, 0.3 per cent. Domestic cooking accounts for about half of the city's average daily gas consumption of 107,250,000 cubic feet.

THE standard portrait of Morse presents him as a bearded patriarch, his breast covered with decorations of the kind that he had once contemptuously regarded as "gewgaws that please the great babies of Europe."

AN unmistakable odor of orange drifted across the classroom in an up-State elementary school one morning a couple of weeks ago. The teacher's head came up and she surveyed the group without being able to locate the culprit.

WITH restrictions on transportation and labor problems curtailing the output of commercial farms, home-raised fruits will be doubly important. If, then, the Victory Garden is to make a substantial contribution to food supply, the gardens must be of sufficient size to raise real amounts for the family, and home gardeners may greatly increase yields by following certain rules.

Washington, Lincoln, Colin Kelly and Meyer Levin were hailed as exemplars of the true spirit of brotherhood in sermons by rabbis here yesterday, marking the observance of Brotherhood Week. Sergeant Levin was killed recently when a plane fell into the sea during a storm.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Feb. 20 -- Horse racing came back to Bay Meadows today in a war-tempered setting that saw some of the 6,750 fans reach the track by street car, horse-drawn vehicle, bicycle and on foot.

GUESSING just what the American home front will be like a year or eighteen months from today is the ticklish task that confronts Hollywood producers and writers now preparing pictures that will not reach theatres until 1944.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A new college training program designed to produce naval officers on a wholesale basis will be started about July 1, the Navy announced today. Selection of candidates will begin April 2.
In the mountains of Central Tunisia last week American soldiers had their first taste of Blitzkrieg in battles that may affect Allied grand strategy for months to come.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- The Germans have lately been transferring troops from Greece to the Russian front, according to a statement by Birger Persson, Swedish merchant sailor, who has just arrived here from Athens. The Stockholm Social Demokraten today prints the story of Mr. Persson, who landed in Athens from a Swedish wheat ship and was hospitalized there following an accident on board ship.

FRIEDRICH SCHORR will make his final appearance on the operatic stage next Tuesday night in the Metropolitan Opera House in one of his most famous roles, that of The Wanderer in "Siegfried." He will then conclude his thirty-first year on the lyric stage and his twentieth at the Metropolitan.

Jan Kiepura, the Polish tenor, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall which attracted an audience so large that the over-flow filled all the available seats on the stage. There was an unusually prolonged ovation for the singer when he first appeared, and enthusiasm ran high throughout a program exceptionally severe in its demands.

Three star badges for meritorius service to motor boating during 1942 were awarded at last week's annual meeting of the Regatta Circuit Riders Club at 420 Lexington Avenue, when Fred Brown, veteran regatta official, of Red Bank, N.J., was re-elected commodore.

The rush to buy subsided but very little in the wholesale markets last week, Kirby, Block Co. declared yesterday in its trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. In fact, it was stated, in the war production areas increases in sales continued at a "phenomenal rate," principally in women's apparel lines, the manufacturers of which were besieged with requests for immediate delivery which they were unable to fill.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 -- Two goals by Joe Benoit before he was led from the ice with a possible spine injury figured heavily in the Canadiens' 6-1 victory over the Rangers in a National Hockey League match tonight. The victory lifted Montreal into fourth place, 1 point ahead of the idle Black Hawks.
Sixteen young women repeated the oath yesterday that made them the first to enlist as privates in the Marine Corps Women's Reserve in the New York area.

The first effort by industry to curb delusions among consumers about new and greatly improved post-war products will be started soon, when refrigerator manufacturers institute an educational campaign to point out that 1942 models were the last word in refrigeration and that they are the types which will be first available in the post-war period.

GEORGE SANTAYANA worked on his first novel, "The Last Puritan," off and on for about fifteen years, completing it when he was more than 70 years old. When some one asked him why he had been so long at the job he explained that his was a solitary life in Rome, that he enjoyed the society of his characters and was in no hurry to send them away.

A hundred student nurses composing the largest class in the history of St. Vincent's Hospital were "capped" yesterday at ceremonies at the hospital presided over by Mgr. John J. Casey, secretary to Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.

Most of the events of this story take place during the weeks preceding Pearl Harbor, and the climax comes on the day of our entry into the war. Mr. Weaver, an American picture dealer with a good knowledge of the French language, is persuaded to undertake a job of short-wave broadcasting to the people of France.

Smith College will establish a Spanish House to be opened next Fall. Because of the large number of students taking Spanish and their interest in the plan, Washburn House has been chosen for the purpose. Located centrally on the old campus, Washburn was the third dormitory built by the college and was opened in 1878.
A Finnish communique broadcast by Lahti radio and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Opposition to the Coudert-Moffat bill, which would transfer authority to procure school supplies from the New York City Board of Education to the Department of Purchase, was expressed yesterday in a resolution adopted by the Board of Superintendents.

THE Broadway merchants of after-dark divertisement are offering three new shows this week. The first of these is the Hurricane's latest edition of "Wings of Broadway," opening tonight. In it will be Danny Rogers, comedian; the Carroll Sisters, dance duo; Bonnie Nielson, who also dances; the Radio Aces, and Peter Birch of the Fokine Ballet.

CANDY cases around town begin to have an empty look these days. But the huge demand of the armed forces does not entirely account for it. The chief cause of the candy shortage that may be coming is the difficulty, in this war, of procuring sugar and chocolate.
The first-aid packet carried by every soldier contains five grams of crystalline sulfanilamide and the directions to "open envelope, sprinkle evenly over wound before applying first-aid dressing."

A SEVEN-WEEK series of concerts will be given at Robin Hood Dell this Summer from June 21 to Aug. 6. Again the orchestra of ninety pieces will be chosen from members of the Philadelphia Orchestra. Prominent conductors are being engaged as well as many outstanding soloists.

A SALE devoted entirely to paintings, most of them by noted masters, is announced for Thursday evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. One of the most important items in the collection is a Renoir canvas entitled "Uncle Fillette Deminue," belonging to Mme. Bruna Castagna, the opera star.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The Chinese High Command announced today that Japanese forces, supported by bombers on at least one front, continued to push their offensives on four widely separated fronts west, south and east of Chungking and were making headway despite heavy losses.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Textile exporters expressed concern here last week about rumors that consideration is being given in official quarters to setting up a centralized lend-lease purchasing agency for all British Dominions and colonies, which would channel all requirements of those nations through this agency.

NEARING threescore and ten, Eugen Spiro, once leader of the Secession movement in Berlin and later forbidden by the Nazis to paint, is holding his first New York exhibition at Galerie St. Etienne. The show includes paintings executed during his long European career and now lent from private collections, as well as work done since his arrival in this country two years ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 -- Yale tonight defeated Navy by 44 -- 31 in an Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet. The losers took three firsts to six for the Elis. No records were broken. Alan Ford, Yale record breaker in several recent meets, switched to the 220-yard free style.

THIS is the story of a master "point-maker" whom many today acclaim as the dean of artisans now active in the upkeep of America's tremendously growing wartime recording industry. When you buy a phonograph record, or listen to a transcribed air program, chances are the wavering "needle" groove on the original or "master" recording was initially cut by a jewel point fashioned by this expert, whose sanctum is an obscure little workshop in this city.

WHEN the Japanese invaded Java their propaganda experts came prepared with a list of American motion pictures, which with crude application of the Nipponese touch could be used to disparage the white race in general and the United States in particular.

RASPBERRIES are a very useful and satisfactory home garden fruit in the States north of Washington, D.C. Their period of ripening extends from the close of the strawberry season in late June for at least a month and they provide -- when no other home-grown fruits except cherries are available -- an abundance of easily grown fresh fruit for dessert, jam and canning.

The eloquent appeal for greater aid to China made last week by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek came almost at the moment when dispatches from China announced the opening of a new Japanese offensive. Attacks have been launched at widely scattered points in North, Central and South China.

THE delta of the Sacramento River in California has not previously, I think, received much attention in fiction. Flat like all true deltas, only partially protected by levees, it stretches away in all directions, and yet in the far distance the end of the vista is often a range of mountains -- except for a narrow gap to the west.

Grover A. Whalen, former Police Commissioner and head of the New York World's Fair, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to serve as chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, succeeding James G. Blaine, whose resignation became effective on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration tonight banned all sales of dry beans, dry peas, lentils and dehydrated or dry soups, effective immediately, and added those products to the list of foods which will be rationed when rationing of canned foods starts March 1.

The Office of Price Administration, in response to representations by New York City officials that an emergency existed, gave the city permission last week to use part of the fuel-oil rations of public buildings that had kept well within their limit to heat other buildings whose rations were already exhausted, Louis Maier, deputy rationing administrator for New York County, said last night.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Interest in observance of Washington's Birthday here centers about tomorrow night's dinner in the Seven Seas Restaurant, Miami. Sponsored by Greek-Americans of the Greater Miami area, the dinner will aid the national drive in which Greek-Americans are pledged to sell $50,000,000 worth of United States War Bonds.

The statement of Major Gen. Ira C. Eaker on the pattern of the bombing offensive from Britain against the Nazis is interesting for a number of reasons. His disclosure that the score as between our Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers of the Eighth Air Force and the fighters of the Luftwaffe is four to one in our favor is of course heartening.

QUEBEC -- Members of the United States Winter sports colony in Quebec who may have heard a lot about snowshoeing but have never witnessed a field of runners in action will go to Three Rivers next Sunday, where an eight-mile snowshoe race for the St. Maurice Valley championship will be held.

FURTHER details of the Council for Democracy program, on which the Axis dictators will be put on trial, have become known. It will be entitled "The Day of Reckoning," and the first presentation, to be neard from 7 to 7:30 P.M. next Saturday on NBC (WEAF), will deal with one A. Hitler.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The practically unknown Aberman Athletic Club provided the greatest surprise of today's football games in Britain when it toppled Lovell's Athletic, 1 -- 0, in the English League cup qualifying competition.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuter) -Today's football results in Britain follow:
MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

A new and effective method of watering house plants and seed flats has been introduced. Not only is it intended to lessen the bother of watering the plant. It is also meant to improve the plant's growth. It is described as automatic. More accurately, it is as nearly automatic as it is possible to be, all things considered.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 20 (U.P.) -- The Tenth United States Air Force inflicted casualties and heavy damage in attacks on Japanese communications, transportation facilities and troop concentrations in Burma Thursday and yesterday, an American communique said today.

YOU go along listening to the radio, minding your own business and absorbing culture in small, easy doses as it emerges from your wireless set, and, suddenly, there it is staring you in the face or, rather, smiting you in the ear: a trend.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 20 -- Valentim F. Boucas, secretary of the commission in control of the Washington agreements with Brazil, yesterday made public a translation of his comment on the friction reported to exist among the United States bureaus in Rio de Janeiro, differing in part from the version published Feb 4 in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- Surging back from impending defeat three times, Harvard's battling hockey team failed to snap Dartmouth's hockey streak with a defeat tonight at the Arena, but the Crimson skaters did the next best thing. In an overtime Pentagonal League thriller, Harvard deadlocked the Green, 4 -- 4, thereby ending the winning streak that had extended through thirty-two consecutive games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, returning from a tour of combat areas, has reported that tests of a captured Japanese plane "exploded the theory that the Zero is a super-airplane."
AGAIN the National Academy comes to the fore with annual -- this time the 117th.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- A manual to assist manufacturers in organizing the record keeping and accounting required under the War Production Board's controlled materials plan will be available by the end of this month, it was announced today by Harold Boeschenstein, director of the plan division in WPB.

A drive to put the entire licensed personnel of the merchant marine in uniform -- to "dress up the industry" and at the same time identify deck officers and engineers abroad -- has been started by the War Shipping Administration, it was announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- The decrees of the past few weeks, particularly those affecting civilian mobilization involving compulsory labor service and the closing of "superfluous" department stores and smaller retail businesses in Germany generally, have added to the feeling of unrest and anxiety throughout the Reich, it is indicated in press reports from there.

A jury of artists and art teachers will select the prize winners in this year's Regional Scholastic High School Art Exhibit to be held at Macy's from March 1 through March 13, according to an announcement yesterday.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- City College's quintet lost to Niagara, 52 -- 43, tonight in Memorial Auditorium. The Beavers dazzled a small crowd with their sparkling play in the first half and left the floor at half-time with a 23-20 advantage, based on the fast break and superior speed.

ON the first page of new novel, "The Land I Live," Stephen Longstreet has David Ormsbee, his narrator, say: "It is the little people I understand -- those who stand around in baggy pants and look at one another."

Superior ball-handling and some spectacular shooting by Bob Mullens brought Fordham's basketball forces a well-earned 39-to-31 triumph over Manhattan last night in before a capacity crowd in the former's gymnasium.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- American Flying Fortresses and Catalina patrol bombers pounded the Buin-Faisi area of the Northwestern Solomon Islands for the second successive day, raining tons of bombs on the big Japanese seaplane base at Faisi, a communique from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.

Many articles describing guerrilla warfare in Yugoslavia have recently been published in the American press, but none of them containing as many details as the dispatches of your correspondent Cyrus Sulzberger.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 20 -- Standing at bay in the mountain passes back of Kasserine and Sbiba, American and British troops smashed two enemy "fingers" of infantry probing the new Allied front running along the Tunisian Grand Dorsal as General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander assumed command of the entire Tunisian land front.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- William D. Cox, wealthy New York sportsman, purchased the last-place Phils from the National League today. The price was not disclosed, but unofficial estimates placed it at about $230,000.

Education of youth in industrial problems and cooperation between leaders of industry and labor rather than "toleration" will make for industrial harmony, the Rev. William J. Kelley declared yesterday in his first interview as a member of the New York State Labor Relations Board.

HERE in this book, the first we have had for young people about beleaguered Russia, is made plain the spirit and the will which have turned back the tide of war against the aggressors. It is the story of a young Cossack, not too concerned with ideology, as ready to loaf as to work on the collective farm in the Ukraine, who was orphaned and made homeless by one of the first German bombs.

AN ADVANCED BASE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Feb. 10 (Delayed) -- The United States cruiser Chicago, already powerless from two torpedo hits the night before and being towed slowly, never had a chance as Japanese torpedo planes attacked again the afternoon of Jan. 30.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 20 (AP) -- General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, Deputy French Civil and Military Command in Chief, announced tonight that 5,000 political prisoners still interned in North Africa would be released or repatriated within two months.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Replying today to "carping critics" of the aid given to Russia, Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, gave impressive figures about supplies sent to the Soviet armies.

A charge that the White House was "thinking in political terms when it "commandeered" all radio time for the speech made by President Roosevelt on Lincoln's Birthday and the one he is scheduled to make tomorrow evening was made yesterday in a statement by the Republican National Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Some years ago Clare Boothe Luce, the playwright, who now is a member of Congress from Connecticut, went out to Hollywood to do some screen writing. The movie moguls promptly decided she ought to be a glamour girl on the silver screen.

OFF the coast of Georgia is a chain of semi-tropical islands that have been the playground of adventuring Spaniards, buccaneers and merchant princes. They are known as the Golden Isles of Gaule and their hunting preserves have provided rich living for succeeding settlers, who knew well the succulence of local tidbits such as turtles and turtle eggs, wild turkeys, ducks and the small wild pig prized by epicures.

However this war may end in detail, and however difficult and possibly circuitous our road to victory may still be, this much has already been decided: Another and perhaps the most formidable attempt in history by any one man or nation to conquer the rest of the world has again ended in failure.

The traditional celebration of Washington's Birthday, which begins today in the churches and will continue tomorrow in many halls and shrines, will be inspired this year by the valor of the country's armed forces again preserving the patriotism and ideals inculcated by the first President.

Lord Leathers, British Minister of War Transport, estimates that the combined shipbuilding volume of the United Nations in 1943 will exceed 14,000,000 gross tons, it was announced here last week by the British Information Services.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 20 -- Dartmouth's impressive basketball team, apparently back in the stride which has given the Green five straight Eastern Intercollegiate League titles, turned back Army today, 60 to 46. The Indians, in command through nearly all the game, sent statisticians scouring through the records, for their 60-point total was thought to be a record for this field house.
THIS year, when almost everyone is planning a Victory Garden, there should be kept in mind the fact that many fruits also are valuable as food producers; and ranking high among these are grapes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- In the first surface bombardment of Japanese bases in the Aleutians since last Aug. 8, American warships shelled enemy bases at Holtz Bay and Chichagof Harbor, on Attu Island, on Thursday, the Navy said today.
General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, recently expressed a clinching argument for increasing the size of the Army to about 8,200,000 officers and men by the end of this year.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: If you are ordering vegetable seeds be sure to specify second, or even third, choice of varieties, as stocks of some are running out. . . . Have you grown tuberous-rooted begonias for Summer color in shady beds and porch boxes? Order a few bulbs now to be started indoors as soon as received; or planted in the open later on.

TOMORROW we celebrate the birthday of a great patriot. There will be editorials and speeches. Everywhere portraits of George Washington will dominate, severe, cold, distant, forbidding. Will most of us be celebrating the man or the myth? How many of us have measured his real greatness or come close to the agonies and turmoils he suffered as a human being?

Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday that the Giants had signed two more players for the 1943 campaign. They are Van Lingle Mungo, veteran right-hander and former speedball king of the National League, and Joe Orengo, utility infielder, who also will attempt a come-back effort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Additional thousands of Federal employes can be released soon for military service through elimination of needless functions and positions and adequate preparation of other workers as replacements, the President's Committee on Occupational Deferment of Federal Employes reported today.

Traditionally there are two sides to every argument. In financial matters there usually are three: management, underwriters and investors. In the matter of the new proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, however, there appears to be only one side: the side of the company managements which dislike them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Rationing restrictions on recapping of passenger car and light truck tires with passenger-type camelback were removed today by the Office of Price Administration with the approval of the Rubber Director.

Former President Herbert Hoover told a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon that the starving peoples of Nazi-occupied Europe could be fed with South American foodstuffs, which could be carried in Swedish ships, financed by funds of the governments-in-exile and distributed under the supervision of neutral governments, so that the United Nations need not lose nor the Axis gain the any way.

First official details of the Board of Economic Warfare's new "decentralization agreement" for the control of exports to Brazil were disclosed here yesterday following the receipt of the official gazette of the Bank of Brazil. No announcement of the details of the plan have yet been made by the BEW and at the agency's offices here it was said that the project was "still being worked out."

Some improvement in the city's tin-can salvage situation, with a hope of preventing the stockpiling of unwashed tin cans from becoming a health menace, was promised yesterday by municipal and War Production officials.

A learn-to-swim campaign for merchant seamen will be started tomorrow at seven indoor pools in Manhattan by the city Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday. Cooperating in promoting the idea among the seamen are the United Merchant Seamen's Service and the Seamen's Church Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines told his countrymen today that their liberation from the Japanese was "certain" and urged them to continue all possible resistance to the invaders.

THE man with the closest view of what happens on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, or any other opera house, is the prompter. But he is not there merely for a close-up but to help leading singers and chorus. Like scores of other men and women, he works unseen to make the show possible.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the city's plans for a City Hall reception at 12:30 P.M. Tuesday to honor Vice Admiral Raymond A. Fenard, head of the French naval mission, and the officers and crews of the French battleship Richelieu and the cruiser Montcalm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Ways and Means Committee is believed to be trying to strike a compromise between simplicity and "principle" in its efforts to put the income taxpayers of the country on a pay-as-you-go basis in response to general and intense public demand.

DESPITE war-imposed restrictions for military purposes, Aerosphere 1942, the third edition of America's most ambitious yearbook dealing with the main fields of world aviation, is probably the best thing of its kind published in the world today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- No fewer than four Danish industrial establishments working for the Germans have been destroyed by fire or explosions attributed to sabotage in the last two weeks, according to reliable information reaching here tonight.

THAT the United States must shoulder a heavy burden of responsibility after the the present war is over seems obvious to Dr. Wertheimer, an Austrian diplomat and newspaper man now in exile and resident in this country.

Retail trade continued active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were crowded, accessory departments were active, and the demand for suits, dresses and coats was brisk.

An important program for the general betterment of the breed has been launched by the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England, one of the most active and influential specialty organizations in the United States. For twenty-one years it has run its distinctive specialty event, which has been won by many of America's greatest cockers.

ALTHOUGH it is only a trickle in comparison with the torrent of private automobiles that used to surge back and forth across the continent, long-distance motor travel is not yet completely dead in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The next Presidential election is more than twenty-one months away and the greatest war in history is raging, yet "fourth-term" talk permeates politically minded Washington like water seeping through limestone.

It was like old times at the University Club squash racquets courts yesterday as leading players of the United States and a half-dozen Canadian Army officers started competition in the national Red Cross tournament.

IN the interests of the projects conducted by the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York for the 20,000 service men who use the club's facilities each month, a gala concert will be given at Town Hall on the afternoon of March 14. There will be no public sale of tickets, subscription to the event to be obtained through invitation by a committee of sponsors.

The Boys Brotherhood Republic, the five-story building at 290 East Third Street on the lower East Side, founded ten years ago to teach youngsters self-government, came forward yesterday with an eleven-point program aimed at decreasing juvenile offenses and promoting better pupil-teacher relations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20 -- Trailing by seven points with five minutes to go, a courageous Harvard basketball team tonight staged one of the most thrilling finishes ever seen at the new indoor building to nose out Columbia, 53 -- 52, for its second victory in the Eastern Intercollegiate League competition.

HELEN SIOUSSAT is the ebullient young lady who is director of the department of radio talks for the Columbia Broadcasting System, a post which requires her to decide who shall or shall not have an opportunity to expound his views on a coast-to-coast network.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Federal Communications Commission approved tentatively today a merger of the Keystone Telephone System, the nation's last major competitive telephone group, into the Bell System. Keystone operates in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, and includes three companies with property value at $15,717,053, the price to be paid by the Bell companies.
LONDON, Feb. 20 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York reached Vatican City today after arriving at the Rome airport by airplane from Barcelona, Spain, the German radio reported.

The canned goods buying rush in preparation for point rationing and the preliminary one-week "freeze" of items to be rationed that went into effect throughout the nation at 12:01 o'clock this morning continued with increasing momentum in the New York metropolitan area up until closing time last night.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 -- President Roosevelt said tonight in a letter to The Post-Dispatch that "after long months of preparation, of 'holding on,' we have now turned the corner in the war."
DOING the family wash at home will enjoy a revival in the weeks to come, according to the joint authorities of the WPB and PAW -- Petroleum Administration for War.

Abraham Lincoln High, defending city champion, and Bayside, a favorite for this year's team crown, turned in easy triumphs yesterday as the P.S.A.L. team foil fencing competition began at Washington Irving High School.

ANOTHER group has been freshly formed and is now exhibiting: New York Artists Painters (strange sort of name, come to think of it). The group is composed of nine men who hold each other "in mutual esteem as creative artists."

Miss Elsie Houston, 40 years old, Brazilian soprano, was found dead yesterday afternoon in her apartment at 431 Park Avenue. Detective William Chaplain of the East Fifty-first Street station listed the death as an apparent suicide.

Six German enemy aliens, three of whom were at a secret meeting of Nazi party members and consular officials in Yorkville in February, 1941, at which a Luftwaffe ace described how he escaped from a Canadian internment camp, were arrested during the week-end in metropolitan New York by E.E. Conroy, agent in charge of the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- Valdina Orphan, who looms as the favorite for the $25,000 added New Orleans handicap a week hence, added to his reputation today when he toyed with six rivals in the Lecompte Handicap of a mile and a furlong at the Fair Grounds.

THE PUBLISHERS' CIRCULAR has discontinued the elaborate statistical tables of the last year's literary output which it formerly issued every January. The nearest approach to it now is a brief summary of the number of 1942 publications which is given by The Bookseller and is accompanied by comparisons not with 1941 but with 1939.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 20 -- On Feb. 15 the President of Finland, Risto Ryti, was re-elected for a term of three years by 269 votes out of 300 possible. In the opinion of competent observers, this vote was not at all representative of the "true feeling of Finnish public opinion."

AMONG the lethal ladies of stage and screen, the career of Katharine Hepburn is perhaps best documented. Newspapers are full of blurred photographs of Miss Hepburn sprinting from stage doors to waiting limousines.
BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 20 -- A "reactivization" of the German campaign to suppress Catholic worship in Poland is reported in a memorandum received here.

Aware of continued strength in securities, cotton traders became bullish near the close or the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, ignoring a new Congressional movement for the abolition of all crop controls, which had exerted a bearish influence during the early trading in the two-hour session.
THE bridge player dislikes guessing, and occasionally will accept a line of play which is mathematically inferior rather than stake his chances on guessing correctly.

For the first time in its history, New York University has leased a dormitory for the use of women students at its University Heights center. Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday the acquisition of the Campagna House in Riverdale as a residence for women recipients of the newly established Chance M. Vought scholarships in aeronautics in the College of Engineering.

The Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg was present at the Opera Victory Rally in tribute to Luxembourg and Belgium broadcast yesterday afternoon from the Metropolitan Opera House during an intermission in the performance of Gustave Charpentier's "Louise."

The oldest house flag in the American merchant marine, the blue spread eagle of the United States Lines, will complete half a century of sea service tomorrow, fifty years from the day it was broken out for the first time in New York harbor from the mast of the crack liner New York of the old American Line.

GUADALCANAL, Jan. 19 (Delayed) -- Private Leland B. Simpson, 22 years old, of Winnetka, Ill., decided yesterday that he "couldn't fight this war from a galley."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Pennsylvania's thirteen-game winning streak came to an end tonight when the Cornell quintet, by staging a second-half rally, triumphed in the Palestra, 35 -- 30, before 3,500 spectators.

Money in circulation in the United States is fast approaching the unprecedented level of $16,000,000,000. Only nine weeks ago it crossed the $15,000,000,000 level. In only four weeks of the last fifty-two has the volume declined and these declines were so small as to be inconsequential.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- A swift Soviet wheeling movement southwest of Kharkov put the Red Army tonight only thirty-six miles from Dniepropetrovsk, the power site keystone of Nazi secondary defenses in Southern Russia, it was disclosed in a special Moscow communique recorded here by the Soviet monitor.

ALMOST on the centenary, March 1, of the issuing of the first stamps of the Cantonal Administration which preceded the Swiss Confederation, there comes to the auction market one of the finest collections of a foreign country's early stamps ever publicly placed on sale in the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Prices of corn futures on the Board of Trade advanced last week to the ceiling level that was imposed by the Office of Price Administration on Jan. 13, and closing trades yesterday were at the maximum level, showing gains of 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel for the week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Higher temperatures in the Southwest have caused the Winter wheat plant to come out of its dormant condition but as yet there has been little growth, and additional surface moisture would be of benefit in some areas, it is reported.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Government tax experts were at a loss this week to discover why President Roosevelt chose in his letter to Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday to cite as an example of "gross inequity" the president of a corporation "engaged in the production of materials for the government" who received "a salary and bonus of $500,000 a year."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Displaying staying power and keen judgment of pace, Allison Merrill, the University of New Hampshire's former intercollegiate combined ruler, led two of his team-mates today in capturing the cross-country race, opening event of the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' twenty second annual Washington Birthday ski games.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Red Wings bounced into a tie for the National Hockey League leadership tonight by defeating the front-running Bruins, 4 to 0, before a record Detroit crowd of 14,119 at Olympia Stadium. The shut-out was the fifth of the season by Johnny Mowers.

In the first half of the week, prices continued to advance, reaching on Wednesday, by THE TIMES' averages, the highest for stocks since Oct. 8, 1941, and for bonds since Sept. 16, 1937. ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- The bodies of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Beyer of Boonton, N.J., were recovered late today from the ruins of the Lust Sanitarium and Rest Home at Tangerine, which was destroyed by an early morning fire.

Registration for point-rationing will begin in public and parochial schools of New York City and in schools of Northern New Jersey tomorrow. In New York City registration will continue daily from 3 to 7 P.M. through Thursday for housewives who are expected to apply for 6,000,000 War Ration Books 2.

Calling for "a complete about-face" by Mayor La Guardia on the necessity for the processing of all tin cans by housewives, Millard F. Bennett, former War Production Board tin salvage representative, said yesterday that tin salvage throughout the nation was being hampered because the Mayor had told housewives that it was not necessary for them to process the cans.
Last week was the first since Pearl Harbor during which no Allied or neutral cargo ship was announced as sunk by the enemy in the Western Atlantic.

Calling for the balancing of the city budget through drastic economy, Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday that a threat of increased taxes on real estate is implied in the administration's recent request for authority to levy such new taxes as it may determine necessary for its purposes.

Tuffy, a 4-year-old Russian brown bear, whose life is divided into periods of living in a cage in the rear of his owner's house at 146-32 231st Street, Rosedale, Queens, and appearing in vaudeville and carnivals as a roller-skating artist, suddenly decided to take a walk yesterday afternoon.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Feb. 22. (AP) -- Japanese planes bombed Buna, Allied-occupied town on the northeastern coast of New Guinea, yesterday, the Allied Command reported today. There were neither casualties nor damage.

James G. Blaine's resignation as chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office ends a year of conspicuous public service. When he took over the organization it existed largely on paper and was in many respects at loose ends. He has not only expanded it but has welded its various units into an efficient corps of willing workers.

The fifteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, which will be the next to the last, starting March 1, will see the last performance of "Goetterdaemmerung," fourth work in the only unabridged Ring Cycle of the season. Another feature of the week will be the first appearance this season of Rose Bampton as Elsa of Brabant in "Lohengrin" and of Nadine Conner as Sophie in "Der Rosenkavalier."

Half a day's pay will be asked of employes by the solicitors of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund, John H. Callen, chairman of the Employes Gift Committee, announced yesterday. He pointed out that American Red Cross pledge cards had been arranged to permit employes to budget their contributions conveniently over three to six weeks.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today that intercollegiate rowing, golf and tennis would be placed on a strictly informal basis here this Spring and that other Spring sports schedules would be shortened by at least two weeks.
The particular significance attaching to Washington's Birthday in wartime served as the theme for sermons delivered in many of the city's churches yesterday.

BRIG. GEN. JOHN REED KILPATRICK knows his boxing from his many years as president of Madison Square Garden. He also knows the art of war from his Army experiences. Hence it was a rather striking analogy which the old Yale Blue drew recently.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 21 -- Official announcement that the United States was interesting itself in the Indian situation, which centers in the fact that Mohandas K. Gandhi seems to be dying of his fast, came late today in a statement issued here by William Phillips, President Roosevelt's envoy with ambassadorial rank.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The stock markets have just experienced another very dull week. The turnover remains poor and the best that can be said is that prices have resisted the tendency to decline which usually accompanies a lack of business.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 113.3 on Feb. 9. This compared with 113.5 a fortnight before, 113.2 a month before, 108.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Two points from defeat in the fourth game, Germain Glidden of the Englewood Field Club unleashed a potent rally to defeat Charles Brinton, national champion from Philadelphia, and supply the highlight of yesterday's play in the national Red Cross squash racquets tourney at the University Club.

Robert Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, expressed confidence yesterday that the United Nations would win the war in 1944 or 1945, provided the Nazis were hit now and hit hard in the West while they were reeling from the blows administered by the Russians.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Jan. 28 (U.P. (Delayed) -- Ten warships, two floating drydocks and seven merchantmen were sunk at Casablanca and twelve merchantmen at Port Lyautey during the American invasion Nov. 8, Captain W.A. Sullivan, United States salvage chief, disclosed tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, Feb. 21 -- Loss of the United States submarine Argonaut, largest in the American Navy and probably the largest in the world since the French lost the Surcouf, was avenged within two hours by the sinking of two fat transports in the same convoy that attacked the Argonaut southeast of New Britain last month, it was revealed here today by Commander Leon J. Huffman, 44 years of age, of Tiffin, Ohio.

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY, in Tunisia, Feb. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- Even at war you can't get away from traffic policemen. A correspondent's jeep was speeding en route to a battle when a motorcycle drove up and the driver said:

In a letter to Vice President Wallace President Roosevelt declares his "unqualified opposition" to the McKellar bill, which would require Presidential nomination and Senate confirmation of all Federal employes receiving more than $4,500 a year. Cynics may dismiss the question as one involving merely a struggle between the President and the Senate for control of patronage.

Looking forward to point rationing, effective March 1, several readers have asked this column whether ration books belonging to a servant should be surrendered to the person in charge of the household. One woman, for example, explained that her maid "sleeps out," but eats virtually all her meals in the home of her employer.

The Rev. Dr. Harold A. Cockburn, officiating chaplain of the Royal Air Force, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, that "the only real peace that can be established and maintained after this war must be made by the common people and not by statesmen."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Loss of the United States submarine Argonaut and her crew was announced today by the Navy. A mine-laying submarine of 2,710 tons, which made her probably the world's largest since the loss of the French submarine Surcouf, the Argonaut has failed to return from patrol operations and "must be presumed to be lost," the Navy said.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Despite protests from State labor unions, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, who recently came near death in the service of his country in the South Pacific, will be a guest speaker before a joint session of both houses of the Legislature tomorrow night.

In a resolution deploring the activities of the American Council for Judaism, an organization recently formed and opposed to the principle of establishing a Jewish state, the National Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America declared yesterday at a meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel that to take a stand such as the council does "is to condemn the homeless Jews of Europe and elsewhere to lives of continued misery and woe."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Navy Communique 288:

LONDON, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- Simultaneously with the "abolition" of the demarcation line, the Laval government announced tonight that free passage would be permitted between the northern departments of Nord and Pas-de-Calais and the remainder of France, with the exception of the coastal and military zones where, presumably, the Germans have placed fortifications.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Thousands of women who, because of their age and household responsibilities, have so far escaped the industrial call-up will find themselves directed to part-time jobs by the Ministry of Labor when the government's latest manpower measure takes effect tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Labor-management committees in the steel industry were making a "tremendous contribution" to the war effort, Gordon Lefebvre, vice president and general manager of the Cooper-Bessemer Corporation, Grove City, declared today.

QUEBEC, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Eight of nine army medical officers and men who recently faced a general court-martial here on charges of irregularities in medical examinations of army recruits have been found guilty, Brigadier E.A. Blais, commanding Military District 5, announced tonight.

The public is continually urged to give books and magazines to the services, but the facilities for doing so are discouraging. For example: the barrel-sized container for such contributions, placed at a center of traffic in this town, is so seldom emptied that not only are magazines projecting from the slit but the lid is covered with accumulations which, as they increase, slip to, the ground.

While icy weather is detrimental to feminine complexions, ice apparently is not. Such, in any case, is the opinion of the concern that is introducing a new device that looks like a tiny tennis-court roller but is actually designed for skin toning.

Stravinsky, Debussy and Ravel made up the program given yesterday afternoon by Leopold Stokowski, conducting the NBC Symphony Orchestra. This modern Russian and French group of works was played in the studio at Radio City before an audience that included officers from the French ships now here, and at the end of the broadcast program Mr. Stokowski and the orchestra played in their honor the "Marseillaise" as the audience stood.

A wage conflict between the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society and the Musicians Union, Local 802, threatening the possible closing down of the Philharmonic Orchestra next season, was disclosed yesterday when Calman Fleisig, chairman of the orchestra's union committee, announced that the society has demanded that the season of 1943-44, beginning next October, be cut to twenty-four weeks at the present rates of pay.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Steel production last week remained at the substantially high tonnage level indicated by 99.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that this output will be equaled or exceeded this week.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Although a scheduled meeting of the British National party, just around the corner, was called off, more than a thousand Londoners crowded Lncoln's Inn Fields this afternoon and made plain their distrust of the Government policy that permits fascist groups to function in times like these.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 20 (Delayed) -- British Crusader and Valentine tanks pounded past me today at a crossroads near the battle line and made contact with the enemy. At the same time, bearded, begrimed Americans in dust-and-mud-covered medium tanks rumbled forward up a near-by road.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 22 -- Russian armies are threatening a 120-mile stretch of the Dnieper River from Kremenchug to Zaporozhe, and also are driving forward on three other main fronts for gains that promise them excellent chances of major triumphs for their twenty-fifth Red Army anniversary tomorrow, a High Command communique reported today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- A parade and a rally today marked a campaign to end absenteeism in Buffalo war plants and recruit 60,000 more workers to increase the city's arms production by $5,000,000 this year. The campaign seeks to shift thousands of workers from nonessential to war tasks and bring 30,000 more women into war work.

In the grim, dark days of 1931-32 there was a phrase coined -- "The Forgotten Man." Today the forgotten man is the married man up to 38 with children. He can't find out anything as far as his future plans go.

The patience of the Rangers was rewarded last night. Battered by every team in the National Hockey League with disheartening regularity since late December, the Blue Shirts finally managed to batter a sextet themselves.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- The Russian Army's striking power is growing daily despite the transfer of thirty-one more German divisions -- at full strength 465,000 men -- to the Eastern Front from Western Europe, Col. Gen. E.A. Shadenko, Vice Commissar of Defense, said today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 21 (U.P.) -- When the all-out Allied offensive against Burma begins, former cannibals of the Lisu tribe from the mountains on the Yunnan border probably will be fighting at the side of Chinese troops.
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Industrial accidents among women have increased by 192 per cent and among men by 42 per cent since the war began, Dr. Joan McMichael told a health conference in London today.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- With 1,054 on the benches, the Eastern Dog Club today opened its thirty-first annual all-breed fixture in Mechanics Building, the total entry being 1,154. This is a remarkable showing for a wartime exhibition, being only sixty fewer specimens than shown last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Far more drastic reductions in civilian consumption of canned, bottled, dried, dehydrated and frozen foods than had been generally expected will be effected under point rationing beginning March 1.

A team of four from Western Reserve University and the Cleveland School of Art was named yesterday as the winner in the seventeenth annual collaborative competition for students of architecture, landscape architecture, painting and sculpture conducted by the Alumni Association of the American Academy in Rome.
With so many suits being worn this Spring that they have become virtually a civilian uniform, short gloves have truly come into their own.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 21 -- German tanks and two battalions of infantry cracked the stubborn Allied defense yesterday and occupied the highly important Kasserine Pass, twelve miles from the nearest point on the Algerian frontier, as the second phase of the German offensive in Central Tunisia got under way.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Black Hawks, battling to stay in the running for a berth in the playoffs, regained fourth place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating Toronto, 5 to 0, while the Canadiens lost to New York.

The need for a large army -- an army about 8,200,000 strong -- is based fundamentally on the firm belief, carefully documented by all available studies, that an army of this size will be needed to insure victory.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh put the kick in the 1942 National Football League season by winning the punting championship for the third successive year, official statistics disclosed today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Japanese forces, trying to extend their grip along the Burma Road in Western Yunnan Province, attempted to cross the Salween River yesterday for the third straight day and again were driven back, the Chinese High Command reported today.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 110.7 to 111.0. Again most of the changes occurred almost entirely in agricultural prices. Advances in practically all commodities in the farm products index caused it to rise 1.2 per cent.

Payers of Federal income taxes are reminded by the Internal Revenue Bureau that personal, living or family expenses and capital expenditures are not deductible items in computation of the statutory net income, whereas all the ordinary and necessary expenses of carrying on any trade or business are deductible.

The directors of the Regional Plan Association announced their conclusion yesterday that the metropolitan area of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut "cannot take for granted the continued prosperity and progressive economic development of the region."

Unless New York consumers get a fair share of the meat supply entering the city their meat ration coupons will be meaningless because the meat just will not be available, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

Entries more than doubled at the opening of the third week of the Thomas Jefferson Bi-Centennial Essay Contest being conducted by the New York City school systems and THE NEW YORK TIMES, with participant schools standing yesterday at a total of 305.
The city's next air raid drill will be held "in a week or so" and will feature a "double-red" alarm, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

The Lower East Side yesterday had its second Sunday shopping spree. From Delancey to Division Street to the south and from Clinton Street to the Bowery thousands jammed the sidewalks. To the police and to casual observers native New Yorkers seemed to be in the minority.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Old-time grain speculators whose policy was "never to overlook a profit or take a loss" might hearken to a "voice from the tomb" and buy wheat now.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- Inability of men in the grain trade to guarantee time of shipment has curtailed business in Canadian oats and barley, although handlers say they would be able to do a very large business if they could assure the buyer that shipment would be made when needed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 21 -- Marking six months of war tomorrow, Brazil is far ahead in her defensive program. War industries are speeding up and the flow of raw materials to the United Nations is increasing.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- General Wladislaw Sikorski, Poland's Prime Minister, today accused Russia of dropping parachutists in Central and Eastern Poland to carry on political warfare and disclosed that his government had protested to Moscow "against foreign elements intervening in the internal affairs of the Polish state."

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- A controversy raging between the Congressional farm bloc and the Administration in regard to ceiling prices on agricultural products has stimulated interest in wheat, and the action of the market in advancing last week to the highest level since 1937 reflected trade opinion as to the outcome.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -Loss of life in the sinking of the destroyer leader De Haven was believed to have been comparatively small, as the vessel went down on the afternoon of Feb. 1 within easy rescue distance of Guadalcanal Island, it was pointed out today.

Ruth Terry, gifted mezzo-soprano from California, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Terry made known a rich, velvety voice, far above the average in quality and ably employed in interpretations displaying a decided feeling for the style and meaning of the German, Italian, French and English songs on a well-chosen program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A shortwave broadcast beamed to Italy today by Mayor La Guardia of New York and released here tonight by the Office of War Information appears to indicate beyond doubt that the famous Italian general, Annibale Bergonzoli ["Old Electric Whiskers"], and eight other high Italian military men are in the United States.
Four new films are scheduled definitely to open on Broadway this week, while the Capitol and the Rialto expect to decide today whether to continue their present attractions or bring in new pictures.
LONDON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the soviet Monitor:

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- The Board of Trade index of commodity prices at the end of January, using 1930 as a basis of 100, stood at 162.1, compared with 131.5 in December and 156.4 in January, 1942. This was a new wartime high, raising the aggregate increase since the beginning of the war to 65 per cent.

Playing against a strong team representing City College, the champions of the Marshall Club, defending their title in the Metropolitan Chess League, defeated the students in the first round of the annual competition at the Marshall Club by 7 -- 3 yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Allied planes, in a wide sweep of New Guinea and New Britain, dropped bombs on at least five Japanese centers yesterday, the Allied High Command reported today.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Through Bound, a fleet 3-year-old with a knack of breaking on top and staying there, bore the red and green silks of Mrs. A.R. Smith to a three-length victory today in the ninth annual renewal of the $1,500 Mayor Leo P. McLaughlin handicap at Oaklawn Park.

DALLAS, Texas, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The regional Office of Price Administration filed more than 100 suits today in Federal courts in Texas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Arkansas, Louisiana and Kansas against slaughterers, packers and meat dealers, charging black-market practices.

The woman office worker who in the last year has swapped silk for rayon, coffee for milk, and hamburger for fish is due for another readjustment. Today, meatless Tuesday, when she hikes herself up on her favorite drug store stool, she is apt to find even her canned fish "off to the war."

The increased costs of putting out your daily newspaper are reflected in a report issued through The Associated Press by the American Newspaper Publishers Association that more than half of the reporting papers now charge five cents a copy on retail sales.
The publication of the Official Table of Point Values emphasizes several facts about the new rationing program.

Our naval bombardment of the Japanese on Attu Island offers at once a reminder they are still entrenched in the Aleutians and a hope that their tenure may be shortened. It seems unlikely that we would have risked our ships in these foggy and treacherous waters if the enemy had an adequate task force in the vicinity to meet them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt warned the nation tonight that America still faces reverses and misfortunes in the war and declared that victory is not just around the corner, despite the great successes scored by the Red Army on the Russian front.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Yale University today announced that all Spring intercollegiate competition in track, tennis and golf had been abandoned and that all remaining Spring sports schedules would have to be revised to meet a classroom program speeded up in wartime.
Russia's Red Army was compared by speakers at the Hotel Commodore last night with George Washington's forces in the American Revolution; hailed as crushing tyranny to preserve freedom.

Throughout the city yesterday thousands of persons gathered to observe the 211th anniversary of George Washington's birth and to pay tribute to the memory of the country's first Commander in Chief at a time when this nation again is engaged in an all-out war for existence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UP) -- From the standpoint of lives lost the two sinkings reported by the Navy today ranked perhaps second only to last year's sinking of a British transport with the loss of about 2,000 lives, including some 1,500 Italian prisoners who were being transported from Africa.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 22 -- The Government of India issued today a White Paper purporting to place responsibility for last Summer's disturbances on Mohandas K. Gandhi and his Congress party as Mr. Gandhi's life seemed further to be ebbing away in his fast at Poona.

THE Dodgers and the Phils were playing an exhibition game in Clearwater and locker space was at a premium. So Fresco Thompson was assigned a few spare hooks in Babe Herman's locker. In shuffled the Babe, glanced at his locker-mate and growled caustically: "I don't like dressing with a .250 hitter."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 22 -- German occupation of at least a large part of the puppet State of Croatia was openly acknowledged today for the first time in an order by the German Commander in Chief in Croatia declaring that the entire territory south of the River Save had been placed under German military occupation.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22 -- Captain John Eusden paced the Harvard swimming team to a 40-to-35 victory over Army in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that a limited group of "play" shoes and some other types not worn on the street would be released from ration control Thursday, with the change applying to shoes which are in the hands of dealers or are manufactured before April 16.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- To British housewives the new American point-rationing system seems pretty soft. They somewhat enviously said today that they would take "a poor view" of any complaints by American women.

As the first part of their new coordinated advertising campaign to support the government's food program leading grocery manufacturers opened a series of newspaper insertions on Sunday to explain the point-rationing system to the public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- More than 850 Americans, most of them service men of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard, were lost early this month when enemy submarines sank two medium-sized combination passenger-cargo vessels in the North Atlantic, the Navy Department stated today.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Nine representatives of the wool industry were chosen today to confer with the Department of Agriculture on a proposal that it buy the entire domestic wool clip.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Members of the Ways and Means subcommittee assigned to find an acceptable system for putting income taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis expressed belief today that an agreement could be reached by the latter part of this week.

In addition to Captain Eddie Rickenbacker's "Seven Came Through," an account of the harrowing twenty-one days adrift in the Pacific, which Doubleday, Doran will issue March 19, Dutton has listed for release on the same day, "We Thought We Heard the Angels Sing," by Lieutenant Fames C. Whittaker, co-pilot and second in command on the ill-fated Flying Fortress.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- British submarines, ranging ceaselessly across Axis Mediterranean supply lines, have sunk two more enemy supply ships, probably sunk a large tanker and have damaged three other vessels, the Admiralty announced tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- War workers who stay away from their jobs "unnecessarily" were put tonight by Senator Truman of Missouri in the same deserter class with soldiers who leave their posts "in the face of the enemy."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- The Louisiana delegation in the House went on record tonight in opposition to the nomination of former Governor James V. Allred of Texas to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, embracing Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and Florida.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Thirty-three additional industrial plants have been selected for the Army-Navy production award, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- An oft-debated proposal to permit the Western Union Telegraph Company to absorb its rival, the Postal Telegraph Cable System, won final Congressional approval today when the Senate adopted it, 42 to 17.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Civilians who hope to eke out their food rations by eating out several times a week may find restaurants just as badly pinched.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek laid wreaths today on the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery and at the graves of George and Martha Washington on the 210th anniversary of the first President's birth date.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 22 -- Requiring 4,000 tons of newsprint monthly, and with stocks hovering around zero and the chances of new shipments slim, the Brazilian press, it was revealed today, must use a greater amount of national newsprint, which is three times more costly than the imported article and inferior in quality.
Leo Durocher, manager of the Dodgers, must appear for induction into the Army Monday morning.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 22 -- Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," in a letter declining appointment by Governor Ellis Arnall to membership on the State Board of Education, indirectly answered the often asked question whether she is writing another book.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Fore-seeing "little improvement" in the petroleum situation for the duration of the war, the Special Committee to Investigate Gasoline and Fuel Shortages urged today in a report to the Senate that a simpler rationing system be devised to replace the Office of Price Administration's "complex mechanism."

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A total of 330 National Football League players -- normal full complement of men on the ten league teams -- now is in the armed forces. Today Joe Stydahar, Chicago Bears' tackle, was sworn into the Navy with the rank of ensign and Joe Beinor, Notre Dame All-America tackle in 1938 and a member of the Washington Redskins last season, was sworn into the Marines.

Lovers of the great classic and romantic piano literature had a fair banquet spread before them last night by Oscar Ziegler, Swiss pianist, at Town Hall. The program was made up of great works by Beethoven, Michelangelo, Rossi, Bach, Mozart and Schumann, Mr. Ziegler apparently having wearied of the "moderns" which formerly were all too thickly interspersed among the older masters on his lists.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 22 -- Marcel Peyrouton, Governor General of Algeria, outlined the broad aspects of his serial economic reforms in a radio address today. He warmly praised the Allied armies in Tunisia and identified his regime with President Roosevelt's leadership in "the defense of human liberties."
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 22 (UP) -- The big American bombers that attacked Messina Harbor, Sicily, on Jan. 31 got a hot reception.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The text of the President's address as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Branch Rickey said today he had several men in mind for the job of managing the Dodgers this year. He added, however, he would take no step to choose the manager until Leo Durocher had been inducted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau said today he will proceed with plans to raise $13,000,000,000 in a new victory loan drive this Spring in the expectation that Congress will act promptly on legislation increasing the national debt limit to $210,000,000,000.

THERE have been two Ruth McKenneys. One of them, a humorist, has specialized in the family comedy of the "Sister Eileen" sketches. The second Ruth McKenney, contributor to The New Masses, has preferred to write about the industrial valleys of Eastern Ohio and Western Pennsylvania, usually from a highly conscious Marxist class angle.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb.22 -- The text of an address by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker at a joint session of the Legislature here tonight, follow:
