CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, stated today that enough food could be produced if the government would act quickly to accord farmers the same treatment that has been given war industries.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Yale's 300-yard medley and 400-yard free-style relay swimming teams today established world records for a twenty-yard pool. They swam for records and their only opposition was the clock.

The first contingent of a class of fifty women arrived at New York University yesterday to start tomorrow an eight-month course that will qualify them for positions as engineering aides in the Vought-Sikorsky Aircraft Division of United Aircraft Corporation's plant at Stratford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The apparent determination of Finnish leaders to seek peace with Russia as soon as the new Cabinet is formed, as reported by the Stockholm correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, conforms to expectations that long have been held here regarding the consequences of the Presidential election last Monday.

More than 20,000 civilians of Rostov were slaughtered by the Germans during their occupation of the city, the Moscow radio reported yesterday, according to a British broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
CAIRO, Feb. 22 -- Despite continued bad weather over most of the Mediterranean, British torpedo bombers attacked a convoy and damaged two enemy merchantmen yesterday near the western tip of Sicily.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie told the Arkansas Legislature today that farmers were ready and willing to make any necessary sacrifices to win the war, but that when the war was won they wanted the country returned to the citizens, because "they are tired of regimentation."

The St. John's basketball team never played more brilliantly or effectively than the Redmen did last night at Madison Square Garden against the highly regarded Georgetown quintet. St. John's romped to a 65-43 victory and moved a long stride toward a place in the national invitation tournament"

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- Electric Bond and Share Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to put surplus cash to work and to effect savings in preferred dividend requirements by employing $15,000,000 in the retirement of its preferred stocks.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Repulsed in three attempts on successive days to force a crossing of the Salween River in Western Yunnan Province, Japanese forces turned northward yesterday against Mangpeng, only to be intercepted by Chinese forces and engaged in bitter fighting, the Chinese High Command reported today.

Tuffy, a brown bear of Russian descent, 4 years old and a vegetarian, is a professional roller skater who has recently returned to Rosedale, Queens, after a season on the road. In spite of his seeming youth he is a seasoned performer, having rolled along since cubhood. Tempted by the genial air and sun of Sunday, he left his cage and started on a tour of the town.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- Champion Sirarno's Impertinent Lady, a beautiful specimen of the Kerry Blue terrier, tonight was awarded the best-in-show title of the thirty-first annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club in Mechanics Building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce joined today the ranks of advocates of the equal rights amendment, confirming and reiterating an interest in it the measure which dates back to its adoption by the National Women's party in 1923.

About 98.6 per cent of medical students have at least three years of college preparation and about 76 per cent have baccalaureate degrees. At its meeting of Oct. 27, 1942, the Association of American Medical Colleges expressed its willingness to accept two years of college preparation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 17, the Federal Reserve Bank reported today: Increases of $463,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $251,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and a decrease of $470,000,000 in United States Government deposits and increases of $232,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $137,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 21 (Delayed) -- The first thrust of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's finest re-equipped armored division was checked today by grimly fighting Americans of a veteran combat team that has participated in almost every major battle in Tunisia.

DENVER, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Miners, lumberjacks and ranchers of the snow-quilted Rockies who seldom scuffle their boots inside a grocery store were assured today of adequate "grubstakes" under the point-rationing system for canned foods.
Events tonight: Philadelphia Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; concert, Inter-Faith Brotherhood Week, choral groups, Town Hall, 8:30; Mendelssohn Glee Club, private concert, Waldorf-Astoria.
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

A thousand officers and men of the French battleship Richelieu and the cruiser Montcalm will be welcomed officially to New York today by Mayor La Guardia and other city officials. The exercises will include a parade up Broadway from the Battery and a reception at City Hall at 12:15 P. M.

The annual memorial mass of the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus was held yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral for those who have died in service and other deceased members of the order. Tribute was paid also to men and women in the armed forces.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of United States factories now devoted to the war effort will be dismantled and moved to Latin-American countries when the war ends, Eric Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said today in an interview.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 22 -- The Dartmouth basketball team strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League tonight when it overpowered Columbia, 70 -- 48, at the Alumni Gym. At the same time Whitey Myers took a 1-point lead over Walt Budko, Lions' center, in the league scoring race, registering 15 points while Budko accounted for 11.

" Random Harvest" will start its eleventh week at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, thereby establishing a new long-run record for the ten-year-old house. The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer screen version of the James Hilton novel was seen by 1,356,541 persons, who had paid $1,022,800, from its opening on Dec. 17 through Sunday night.

LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 23 -- Premier Joseph Stalin asserted today that the "Red Army alone is bearing the whole weight of the war" in the "absence of a second front in Europe," but declared that it had inflicted 9,000,000 casualties on the Germans -4,000,000 of them killed -- and that time was now working against Germany.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported today a net profit of $14,370,911 in 1942, an increase of $1,539,514 over the previous year. The 1942 profit was equal to $5.46 a common share.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Demands that the government cut loose from social and economic agricultural reforms and substitute what was described as a principle of abundance and higher price ceilings for a policy of crop control and benefits were made here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration, acting to meet the threat of skyrocketing prices for fresh vegetables as the result of the program for rationing of most processed foods, placed emergency price ceilings today on fresh tomatoes, snap beans, carrots, cabbage and peas.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 22 -- A German armored column leading a new and dangerous drive designed to split the Allied forces in Tunisia reached a point four miles southeast of Thala at about noon today after a morning of savage fighting against veteran British tank units.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 22 -- Pope Pius XII gave an audience to Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York for a third time this afternoon. The first two occurred Saturday and yesterday following the inauguration ceremonies of the seventh academical year of the Pontifical College of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- While the Navy listed the casualties in the two February ship sinkings as "known dead or missing," there was little hope that many of the missing could have survived the wintry gales and violent seas of the North Atlantic at this season.

The ten-story apartment house, with 120 suites, at 128 Fort Washington Avenue, northeast corner of West 164th Street, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Simon Bond and Leon Fromer, investors.

Charges of "defamation of character and jeopardizing of the livelihood of brother musicians" will be filed today against Dr. Artur Rodzinski, incoming conductor of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra for the 1943-44 season, by the orchestra's union shop committee with the Musicians Union, Local 802.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- The California Retail Merchants and Grocers Association authorized today a committee of five to meet with Governor Warren and present "a problem of confusion" in food- stuffs which, spokesmen said, had been accentuated by the new point- rationing system.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Ursula Parrott, the novelist, filed in Federal Court today a petition reciting that she was instrumental in uncovering the sale of narcotics to service men in New York.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) -- Before the war can be won, America "must learn to sacrifice as she has not yet begun to do," Francis B. Sayre, special assistant to the Secretary of State, declared today. He was one of five persons who received honorary degrees at founders' day convocation exercises commemorating the fifty-eighth anniversary of Rollins College here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Roosevelt spoke over the radio to Democratic gatherings; his visitors included Secretary Hull, with Under-Secretary Welles, Norman Davis, Myron C. Taylor, Dr. Isiah Bowman and Dr. Leon Pasvolsky, Secretary Stimson and William D. Herridge.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Commander William Right Hollingsworth received the Navy Cross this afternoon. The Navy's highest decoration was pinned on his lapel by Admiral Harold R. Stark.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The War Department announced today that one American officer was known dead and twenty-five members of the American and British air forces were missing in an Army transport plane last reported over the South Atlantic on Jan. 18.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Deplorable health conditions and widespread poverty were found by a Senate committee which has just returned from Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt conferred for an hour and a half today with Secretary of State Cordell Hull and five other foreign affairs specialists as rumors and reports involving Finland, Italy and India aroused speculation as to possible impending developments.

Extension of price controls to fresh fruits and vegetables, announced in Washington last night to forestall skyrocketing prices expected from point rationing of canned foods, will be discussed by representatives of the regional officials of the Office of Price Administration here and the food industry at conferences in this city Thursday and Friday.
LONDON, Tuesday, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:
Sir William and Lady Garthwaite of the Plaza have gone to Palm Beach for the remainder of the season.

Concern over "scare" buying by consumers and the growing difficulty of placing commitments for immediate delivery on apparel led to continued desperate efforts by retailers to get early shipment on outstanding orders, according to a summary of the week's activity prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- A Florida food producer declared today that "orgies" have taken the place of work among some of the farm laborers supplied growers by government agencies.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker indicated his opposition to a fourth term for President Roosevelt in an address which he delivered tonight to a joint session of the State Legislature in the Assembly chamber here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that three of its pictures now in the story preparation stage will be starring vehicles for George Sanders, who, on loan from this company, will next do "Appointment in Berlin" at Columbia.

Expecting a busy week and a drop of at least 15 per cent in sales, chain stores started yesterday on the gigantic task of marking every rationed item with its proper point value and retail selling price.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A joint statement by the War and Navy Departments disclosed today that military requirements for some fabrics may be reduced slightly this year. Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, said the cotton and woolen textile industries "have in general achieved the maximum rate of production on military fabrics that they are likely to be called upon to provide during 1943."

Spring's preview held over another day yesterday in New York. Seductive zephyrs called the townsfolk and strangers to open streets and the parks. At 9 A.M. the temperature stood at 44 (fifty two degrees higher than on the previous Monday) and by 4 P.M. it had mounted another fifteen points.

On every hand that eminent blue-pencil editor, Time, is busy revising plans. Our own Regional Plan Association is re-examining its original plan of 1929 for metropolitan development. World conditions have changed and are changing.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- From entirely reliable Allied sources it was learned today that the Soviet Union has forwarded a formal guarantee to the present Czechoslovak Government in London, promising to support the reconstitution of the pre-Munich frontiers of the Czechoslovak Republic.

The Argonaut is the sixth and largest American submarine lost in the war. Most missing undersea boats disappear in an endless silence. The Shark, Perch and Grunion went that way. But we know how the Argonaut met her end. She went down fighting and she was avenged.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 22 -- A Clipper flying boat arriving here on a flight from the United States crashed in landing on the Tagus River today. Four were killed and twenty missing of the forty persons aboard.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP) -- A pair of full sisters monopolized the winners' circle at the Fair Grounds track today.
Some of the resolutions adopted by the session of the North American Wildlife Conference last week at Denver reflect a trend of thought in matters of conservation during the wartime emergency.
An Italian High Command communique broadcast by the Rome radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Looking like the "bobcat" of old, Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia jumped back into the lightweight picture tonight by punching out an unanimous ten-round decision over Lulu Costantino of New York before 9,041 at Convention Hall.

National Distillers Products Corporation made net profits of $6,896,765, or $3.37 a share, in 1942, after all charges, including taxes, Seton Porter, president, said in his annual report mailed to stockholders yesterday. This compared with net profit in 1941 of $7,099,656, or $3.47 a share.

While the city's relief costs are cut by several million dollars in the proposed budget of the Welfare Department for the fiscal year 1943-44, the department could have cut another $10,000,000, in the allowances for its 271,600 relief recipients except for the abolition of the Federal Food Stamp Plan and other changes, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- A full-page advertisement in The Washington Post, "sponsored by Texans from every part of the State who admire courage and forthrightness of speech in public officials," called on government officials today for an explanation of why strikes, slow-downs and absenteeism are permitted in war industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Administering, in effect, a rebuff to President Roosevelt, who had voiced his "unqualified opposition" to the measure, a Senate Judiciary subcommittee decided today to report favorably on the McKellar bill, which would require Presidential appointment and Senate confirmation of all Federal employes receiving more than $4,500 a year.

Business jumped to bonanza proportions on Broadway yesterday afternoon, Washington's Birthday being traditionally the best matinee day of the year. Although last year there wasn't a ticket left in the brokers' racks after 2 P.M., yesterday some were still available at that hour.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Fighter planes of the United States Tenth Air Force carried out a destructive raid on Japanese headquarters at Sahmaw in Northern Burma on Saturday, starting more than thirty fires, a headquarters communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Representative McCormack of Massachusetts, majority leader in the House, today called "a deliberate falsehood" a statement by the Republican National Committee accusing President Roosevelt of "commandeering" radio time for talks on Lincoln's and Washington's Birthdays.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Limited supplies of live hogs for this season again forced prices to a new top of $15.80 a hundred pounds today. Not since Oct. 16, 1920, when live hogs reached a top of $15.90, has live pork commanded a better price.

The Rev. Gustave Dumas, dean of the Graduate School of Fordham University, announced yesterday that twenty-five assistantships and twenty-one scholarships for the scholastic year of 1943-44 would be offered in the school. Twenty-two of the assistantships are known as centenary assistantships in honor of the recent completion of Fordham's 100th year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Butchers are receiving only 40 or 50 per cent of their normal supplies of meat, Edwin F. Janssen, president of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers, estimated today. In some instances, he added, they were obtaining only 20 per cent of their 1941 volume.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN TUNISIA, Feb. 22 (Reuter) -- A meeting between the French garrison at Ben Gardane and the first Fighting French troops who crossed the Tripolitanian frontier into Tunisia with units of the Eighth Army took place today.

One of the major problems that the war has brought upon us is to find an answer to the universal demand for some sort of guidance in the building of a philosophy of life, G. Howland Shaw, Assistant Secretary of State, told the annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 22 (U.P.) -- A Stockholm dispatch, published today by The Daily Express, reported that on the northern front the Germans were preparing to evacuate Estonia, northernmost of the Baltic republics. The dispatch said that trains were leaving with heavy materiel, an apparent precaution in the event that a Russian advance on the Leningrad front compelled the Germans to evacuate Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 12 (Delayed) -- This is the story of American Rangers who raided Gafsa in the first job that these Commando-type troops did in Tunisia. Because of the official desire, to mystify the enemy, that the Rangers and the town not be mentioned earlier, the story has not been written before.

A heavy fog that hung over upper New York bay yesterday was responsible for a collision between the municipal ferryboat Astoria and the Cities Service oil tanker Missouri 300 feet off St. George, S.I., in which one passenger and a deckhand on the ferryboat were injured.
LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill, suffering from an acute attack of catarrh, was described by friends today as "the world's worst patient."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- President Rosevelt declared today that the Red Army and the Russian people "have surely started the Hitler forces on the road to ultimate defeat, and have earned the lasting admiration of the people of the United States."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Johnny Neal, 17-year-old Northwood School senior, today captured the jumping event in the twenty-second annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' Washington Birthday ski games. The protege of the three-time Olympian, Rolf Monsen, took the challenges offered by the 70-meter Olympic Hill in stride to lead a formidable field with a score of 140.5 points.

Members of the armed services who qualify for college varsity teams will have to meet the National Collegiate Athletic Association's normal eligibility standards in order to compete in N.C.A.A. championships, The Associated Press reports.

BOSTON, Feb. 22 -- With Albie Everts scoring twice and assisting in three other goals, Harvard skated to an 8-4 victory over the Army in its second Pentagonal League game in the past three days, at the Skating Club of Boston today.

Registration for War Ration Book 2 starts today. Those whose last names begin with the letters A to F, inclusive, will register between 3 and 7 P.M. in 700 public schools, 400 parochial schools and fifty schools of other types throughout the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- The proposed sale by Southwestern Public Service Company of two of its wholly owned electric subsidiaries in Arizona to James C. Tucker, an individual, for a base price of $775,000, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The arrest last week of thirty-three men charged with violating the Selective Service and Training Act was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here. Mr. Conroy said sixteen of those detained had neither registration nor classification cards.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22 -- Yale's hockey team routed its old foe, Princeton, 6 to 0, at the Arena tonight. The Eli skaters, who put up a fine defense throughout, scored twice in the first period, three times in the second and once in the last session.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 21 (Delayed) Pretty Barbara Brandon, 30 years old, of Indianapolis and Chicago, was looking for adventure when she joined the American Red Cross as an assistant field worker -- and she has been getting it.
ATLANTA, Feb. 22 -- "Planned confusion, created by bureaucrats in government" was condemned by Representative Eugene E. Cox of Georgia in a talk today to the Georgia Bankers Association.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The text of Premier Stalin's order of the day as broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The birthday of the man whose victories took the United States out of the British Empire found Tommies and Yanks talking over things today and agreeing that they were well satisfied at fighting together in this war.

In a hotel lobby, a white-helmeted air raid warden and a red-tufted, pancake-topped French sailor exchanged curious glances. In the ballroom American girls of French extraction, acting as hostesses, swung their partners (men from the battleship Richelieu) into a conga line.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- John L. Lewis has announced two steps which will add to the embarrassment of the bituminous coal operators whose agreement with the United Mine Workers is to expire April 1.

Curtailment of production in kitchenware in traditional metals has made glass pots, pans and casseroles volume sellers today, supplemented by stocks of earthenware and diminishing quantities of iron and enamelware. In retail stores the space ordinarily devoted to these items has been reduced in several instances.

Jane Courtland, who gave her first New York recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, plays the piano as one might expect a woman to do: with grace, gentleness and sustained lyricism. Miss Courtland is slight of figure and she does not look as if she could muster the strength to be a stormy virtuoso.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Urging our soldiers not to settle for "a cigarette, a thumbed ride or a cash bonus" when they return as veterans, Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education, called upon them today to consider the kind of world they are fighting for and to be sure to have a part in its realization.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- Princeton's basketball team turned back Yale tonight, 38 to 25, in the feature of a Washington's Birthday sports program. The Tigers were never in real danger in the Eastern Intercollegiate League contest, but Yale managed to provide real action through much of the contest and once during the second half climbed to within 3 points of Princeton.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Eight New Jersey war workers who dug into their minds for ideas on saving man-hours and critical materials received today WPB awards of merit.

General Emile Bethouart, chief of the military mission to the United States from the French forces cooperating with General Dwight D. Eisenhower, said here yesterday that the fighting in North Africa would be "very long and very tough."

OTTAWA, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King said today that, with the increasing tempo of the war, Canadians would face during 1943 a more severe ordeal than at any previous stage of the conflict.

WASHINGTON, Feb.22 -- Agreements similar to that worked out with Brazil regarding that country's imports from the United States have been concluded with ten other Latin-American countries, it was learned at the Board of Economic Warfare today.

TULE LAKE, Calif., Feb. 22 -- Twenty-seven American-born Japanese from the Tule Lake relocation center, near here, were in jail at Klamath Falls, Ore., and Alturas, Calif., tonight in connection with their alleged refusal to abide by regulations seeking to determine their eligibility for military service or for work in war industries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The hard going around Kasserine Pass, in Tunisia, has delayed for a bit the next experience American military commanders will have in governing a zone of occupation. And the distance is still long to the point where our generals will meet that problem in German-occupied Europe.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 22 -- New symptoms of increasing German nervousness at developments on the eastern front were seen by competent observers here in today's violent article by Dr. Robert Ley, Labor Front leader, attacking those Germans spreading jokes criticizing the government.

With the statement that "in war-time there is no justification for a white collar class as such or any other class if that class does not contribute directly to the war effort," Ralph A. Bard, assistant secretary of the Navy in charge of labor, declared yesterday that 3,000,000 of the 6,500,000 additional war production workers to be added to the nation's labor force in 1943 would be persons that hereto-fore had never done manual labor.
H. Sherman Howes of Boston won the national Red Cross squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22 -- Army's holiday sport program included morning and afternoon matches today. Harvard engaged the cadet basketball team in a morning affair, the West Pointers winning by the one-sided score of 72 to 40.

Your "Letters to the Editor" department carried on February 11 a statement from Louis Bromfield presenting an array of charges against the Government's management of the wartime food production program. Since his outburst is directed primarily against me, I would like to match some of his statements with the recorded facts:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- Detailed plans to split the globe into seven regions so that the Office of War Information may be able to aim its propaganda "with a rifle rather than a shotgun at definite overseas targets" were made public by the government agency today.

According to still unconfirmed reports from neutral European capitals, the Germans are already withdrawing ammunition and supplies from the East and are pouring trainloads of seasoned veterans through the French Pyrenees toward the Spanish frontier. Simultaneously, Berlin announces that Hitler has gathered around him "a group of men endowed with special powers by the Fuehrer for concentrating all their respective spheres for a victory of German arms."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 22 -- Suffolk County farmers are determined to increase crop production to aid the food for victory campaign at home and abroad, but the percentage has not yet been determined because a survey now under way by the United States Department of Agriculture has not been completed.

War production plants can usually avoid shutdowns because of shortages in certain critical materials by making minor revisions in specifications, Ralph A. Parker, assistant deputy regional director of the War Production Board, declared yesterday.

Housewives yesterday took inventory of pantry stocks against today's ration registration and turned up an odd assortment of forgotten provender. Also uncovered were lost household items and hidden treasure.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Nearly all Laborite Ministers met behind closed doors tonight to discuss where labor's vote on the Sir William Beveridge plan for social security had left them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration, with the approval of Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, set today a ceiling of $1.66 a bushel for top grades of soybeans, heretofore not under price control.

Pan American Airways, Atlantic division, with headquarters at La Guardia Field, North Beach, Queens, confirmed last night the crash of one of its flying boats, the Yankee Clipper, at Lisbon, Portugal. A statement by the company read:
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 22 (AP) -- An effort is being made to bring Greg Rice, America's great distance runner, to this country in August to race Eweden's world record-holder, Gunder Haegg.

Although overshadowed at the moment by unfavorable military developments, important political news is coming from North Africa. Yesterday's dispatches told of the appointment of General Rene Chambe, "a distinguished officer and writer with no Vichy connections," to the strategically important post of Secretary of Information and Propaganda in General Giraud's government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Asserting there is evidence of an "unwholesome intimacy" between Federal war agencies and "big business" interests, Senator Stewart of Tennessee asked the Senate today to "uproot the predatory, the irresponsible and the obstructive in this bureaucracy."

A Berlin broadcast, recorded by The Associated Press yesterday, said the Soviet offensive "has presumably passed its climax" and "there has been no further expansion of the success of the attacks made hitherto."
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- After a brief session this afternoon the Assembly adjourned until March 8, to which date the Senate recessed last week.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 22 (AP) -- B.C. Moise, president of War Materials, Inc., a $500,000,000 war-born Federal corporation organized last year to collect 5,000,000 tons of iron and steel scrap, charged Donald M. Nelson and the War Production Board tonight with "progressively blocking" its objectives from the day of its formation.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22 -- After a brief session this afternoon the Assembly adjourned until March 8, to which date the Senate recessed last week.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The stock markets here started the week quietly, with prices mostly lower. Further declines were recorded for home railway issues on profit-taking now that the dividends of all companies are known. Great Western and Southern deferred lost a half, and North Eastern preferred and deferred an eighth.

The quality of the fields in the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Saturday will not be affected materially by the number of athletes in the armed forces, if the list of entries for the short events announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, the meet director, is a true sample.

Under the patronage of Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Lady Halifax, the performance of "Manon" at the Metropolitan Opera House on the night of March 11 will aid the British War Relief Society's "Seeds for Victory" campaign for British victory gardens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox indicated at his press conference today that negotiations were in progress that might bring the French warships demilitarized at Alexandria, Egypt, back into the fight at the side of the United Nations.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- The Ways and Means Committee in the Assembly and the Finance Committee in the Senate reported out today, without any changes, Governor Dewey's budget amounting to $369,600,000. Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee announced that any change in the budget, in the way of correction, subtraction or addition, will be made in the Legislative Supplemental Bill, which customarily is passed the last day of the session.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount, the newcomer will be "Hitler's Children," an RKO adaptation of the Gregor Ziemer book, "Education for Death," produced by Edward A. Golden. . . . At the Roxy, the new offering will be Twentieth Century-Fox's "The Meanest Man in the World."

Eager housewives on a safari yesterday for fresh vegetables, now that canned goods have been frozen until March 1 and the lowly can-opener parked away as a casualty of war, found supplies plentiful but prices asked by retailers in most cases high.

Monday of last week was an infamous day and its memory should remain infamous. If there has been colder cold, there has been none so mean. It was unexpected and without warning. As you staggered over the ice, ears, nose, arms, legs, hands, your whole corpus was withdrawn from circulation.

The Southern Pacific transportation system made a reduction last year of $26,244,275 in its funded debt held by the public, A.T. Mercier, president, disclosed yesterday in the annual report. Public debt unmatured and held by the public was $677,851,750 at the end of the year.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 24 -- Russian troops have captured the big German base of Sumy, two other key towns and four adjacent railroad stations northwest of Kharkov to culminate a series of victories that marked an eighty-two-mile advance in seven days, Russian communiques announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Efforts to mediate the dispute between the railroads and the Big Five operating brotherhoods over the latter's demand for a 30 per cent wage increase with a minimum advance of $3 a day failed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt took sharp issue at his press conference today with those who have interpreted Premier Joseph Stalin's order of the day to the Red Army as implying that Russia will not continue the war after the Germans have been driven from Soviet territory.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- British Valentine and Crusader tanks fought in mist and mud today to prevent forty of the latest Mark IV and some massive Mark VI tanks of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's best armored division from cracking through and flanking the British First Army.

The Red Army has justified the policy of Joseph Stalin. Hitler's invasion of Russia under cover of the Nazi-Soviet agreement, made by the Soviet leader for the purpose of preventing such an assault, would have stamped that policy as the costliest of failures if the army and the people behind the army had not proved strong and ready enough, when the pact was broken, to stop the invader and put him on the run.

A testimonial luncheon for 700 members of the American Women's Voluntary Services, who have assisted in the sale of $10,000,000 in war bonds since December, 1941, at sixty-six Skouras theatres in the metropolitan area, was held yesterday at the Hotel Astor by the theatre chain.

Edward Bykowski, the pharmacist's mate on the U.S.S. Vincennes whose life was saved by Red Cross blood plasma after the sinking of the vessel in the Solomons, and a 23-year-old marine who recently returned from Guadalcanal, were guests yesterday at a pre-campaign luncheon of the Bronx Committee of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Feb. 23 -- Master Sergeant Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn youth who blasted the Japanese battleship Haruna as bombardier for Captain Colin Kelly, died the hero he had lived.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature took pains today to disclaim responsibility for the views on organized labor, expressed by Captain Rickenbacker in his address before a joint session of the houses last night.

A college basketball double-header, involving four local quintets, will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden, with Fordham engaging N.Y.U. and City College tackling Brooklyn College. The latter contest will open the show promptly at 8:15 o'clock.

Only six shows are promised for Broadway next month, an increase of two over last March. Beginning with Wednesday, March 3, comes Helen Hayes in "Harriet" at Henry Miller's. Now scheduled for the week of March 8 is "Men in Shadow," which opened Monday afternoon in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- As "a matter of military necessity" the War Department today assigned troops in Arizona to go into the fields near Phoenix and help pick the crop of long-staple cotton needed for making Army parachutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Representative Paul J. Kilday of Texas, who is rated by his colleagues as one of the ablest and most sincere members of Congress, told the House today that there has been a steady drain of confidence in the Selective Service System since it was placed under the supervision of Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The anti-aircraft "guns," which have pointed skyward for months from the roof of the Congressional Office Building, are made of wood and manned by "decoy soldiers," it was disclosed today.

WESTON, Conn., Feb. 23 -- The little white Town Hall that stands just back of historic Norfield Congregational Church in this village is soon to provide the setting for an experiment new in the present war, but historically derived from an old New England custom that served the nation in times of for mer peril.

George W. Dunn decided that, at the age of 72, he was too young to stay retired. And so, yesterday, he severed his connections with Sailors' Snug Harbor, on Staten Island, and in a short while he will be back in the engine room of a ship, where he had spent the better part of fifty years before retiring five years ago.

The news on the local baseball front yesterday concerned the Giants principally, and it was disquieting, to say the least. From St. Louis came an Associated Press dispatch to the effect that Big Jawn Mize, slugging first baseman, had been notified to report to his local draft board for a physical examination today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 18 per cent for the week ended Feb. 20, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Examiner said tonight that Dolph Camilli's signed conditional contract to manage the Dodgers already "reposes in (Branch) Rickey's inside coat pocket."

Randolph Godfrey Phillips of 36 East Sixty-seventh Street, has been apprehended for alleged failure to report for induction into the Army, and failure to inform his local board of a change of address, it was revealed yesterday. He was released in $500 bail last Saturday for grand jury action by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

New York City's housewives -- and husbands, too -- reported yesterday ahead of time to register for point rationing of canned foods as registration began throughout the nation. Waiting lines at registration places in public and parochial schools even before doors were opened ranged from a score to a thousand.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Yugoslav Government in London said today that the Germans, apparently fearing that Yugoslavia might be one of the points of an Allied invasion of the continent, had launched a major campaign intended to clear General Draja Mikhailowitch's patriot army from the plains areas and restore control of the main railways.

Gross sales of the National Biscuit Company in 1942 amounted to $167,788,071, an increase of 40 per cent over sales of $119,599,610 in 1941, according to the annual report signed by Roy E. Tomlinson, president. Sales volume of foreign subsidiaries was higher than in 1941.
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 24 (U.P) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Radio Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that the savings in manufacturing costs resulting from simplification of men's and boys' shirts and pajamas made according to the specifications of the War Production Board must be passed along to consumers.

The Board of Estimate approved unanimously yesterday a resolution authorizing the Board of Higher Education to spend $100,000 for renovation and maintenance of the former Hebrew Orphan Asylum building at 1560 Amsterdam Avenue, adjacent to City College, for dormitories for Army and Navy trainees assigned to the college.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- Air Vice Marshal Harry Broadhurst has succeeded Air Vice Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham as commander of Allied Air Forces in the Western Desert. He is a veteran fighter pilot with more than 600 operational hours to his credit and at the same time he is the youngest air vice marshal in the history of the Royal Air Force -- he is 37.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 23 -- In the course of providing services for Allied fighting men, the American Red Cross today is operating the biggest chain of "hotels" and "restaurants" in the Southwest Pacific. In New Guinea, Australia and at almost every place where American service men are to be found, the Red Cross is represented by a club or rest home that is part of the "chain."

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia is planning an official visit to the United States and Russia. In all likelihood he will leave for Washington late next month or early in April, flying from there to Russia.

The record and transcription companies formally rejected yesterday the plan of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, for settling the controversy over recordings, asserting that they could not accept such "a startling new kind of social philosophy" without the approval of Congress.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers scored three hits on a Japanese cruiser or large destroyer yesterday in a raid on the major enemy feeder base of Rabaul, New Britain, the United Nations Command announced today.

ELKTON, Md., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Stockholders of Triumph Explosives, Inc., whose plants were taken over by the Navy last October on charges of management irregularities which later resulted in Federal indictments, confirmed the new management today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The President held a press Conference after receiving a number of callers, including Norman Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, and Herbert H. Lehman, foreign relief and rehabilitation director, and received Prince Bernhardt of the Netherlands as a White House guest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Office of Defense Transportation warned today that some system of freight priorities in order to insure the production and movement of essential products might be introduced. An ODT announcement said that serious delays in the movement and delivery of bulk commodities by rail threaten to occur this year as the result of tight situations in the supply of open-top freight cars and railroad motive power.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- The American Power and Light Company was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to spend $10,000,000 to buy part of its outstanding debentures on the open market.

A directed verdict of acquittal was ordered yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato in the case of Dr. Maurice Rogalin, former principal of New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, on charges of third-degree forgery in connection with the disappearance of $18,000 of the school's general organization funds.

Unless immediate action is taken by the OPA to permit cotton yarn prices to slide up or down with raw material costs, maximum output for essential civilian needs may not be attained this year despite the promised leveling-off in military procurement, it was declared yesterday by textile producers.

A BOY, 13 years old, once flicked a pebble at a passing automobile near a Nebraska stream, and that is why Gilbert Dodds will be defending his mile title at the National A.A.U. track and field championships in Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Had that pebble not been thrown, Dodds might now be an unknown country preacher in some forgotten country town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- While the Navy Department told today of the sinkings of two enemy submarines, Secretary Frank Knox reported that sinkings of American ships had been fewer in recent months. He immediately warned, however, against any "foolish feeling of complacency," declaring that "the submarine, most emphatically, is still a very grave menace."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- While plans for the construction of a huge State ski development on Whiteface Mountain, as approved by public vote, must be held in abeyance until the war's termination, the authorities behind the project continue to do preparatory work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- When the Army ordered troops to pick cotton in Arizona, President Roosevelt indicated he hoped this action would still the clamor in Congress for the armed services to furlough all experienced farm hands.
ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- An important Allied convoy en route to this base fought off a prolonged attack by Japanese torpedo planes on the night of Feb. 17.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- Bing Crosby will star at Paramount in a musical, "All Around Town," based on an original screen play by Karl Tunberg and Darrell Ware, ahead of the previously announced "Stallion Road." Plans are for "All Around Town" to go into production in six weeks.

In one of the first programs suggested in the garment and allied fields for the post-war period, Samuel L. Deitsch of Deitsch, Wersba Coppola, Inc., and president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., last night outlined five major policies for the coat and suit industry.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Finland has called home her Ministers to the Vatican and Germany, it was revealed tonight. The belief gained in diplomatic quarters that a Finnish bid for a separate peace with Russia might be near.

In an unusual communication in memory of Thomas J. McGee, Acting Chief Clerk of his court, Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran suggested yesterday to his fellow magistrates that if they desired to attend the funeral mass for Mr. McGee tomorrow at Our Lady of Angels Roman Catholic Church, Fourth Avenue and Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, they postpone opening their courts from 10 A.M. until noon.

Noontime holiday crowds on Times Square are predominantly youthful. Day before yesterday the age level on Broadway between Forty-second Street and the Fifties was perceptibly higher. Young girls were more numerous than ever, or perhaps there seemed to be more of them because the young men were so much rarer than usual, for obvious wartime reasons.

Despite the fact that the 65,000 concerns capitalized at $100,000 or more set the pattern for all business today, within ten years the 1,000,000 or more small companies worth less than $10,000 will form the country's most powerful bloc, Arthur D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

With sales volume sharply restricted by the "freeze" on the bulk of processed foods, retail grocers yesterday asserted that the new price ceilings on fresh vegetables would be unworkable unless controls were placed on all producers of the items.

The President says: "I could not exercise the discretion invested in me by the Congress to adjust salaries without finding that it is a gross inequity in wartime to permit one man to receive a salary in excess of $67,200 a year while the government is drafting another man and requiring him to serve with the armed forces for $600 per year."

In your editorial "Featherbeds" you hit upon a situation which, if allowed to continue, may well destroy all that the people of this country have helped to build over the years. Those time-killing, job-stretching, cost-increasing practices are reprehensible at any time -- in peace or in war.

Although the Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled that annual reports of corporations to stockholders are not a part of the proxy statements, unless the company specifically requests it, Edgar M. Queeny, president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, says in his report for 1942 that he is abandoning "with reluctance" his practice of transmitting an informative and interpretative annual report covering all phases of operations.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Seeing a gloomy outlook for British shipping after the war, the annual report of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom, published today, forecasts that this country's mercantile marine, once the greatest in the world, will yield the leadership to the United States.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were forced down today 15 to 25 cents a hundred-weight by a heavier run than had been expected. The top dropped to $15.60 and most good butcher hogs sold at $15.40 and $15.55. The day's report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The annual report of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company for 1942 shows total admitted assets of $133,641,779, an increase of $3,970,295 over the 1941 figure, with premium income amounting to $52,054,582, an increase of $5,467,898.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 23 -- A mass exodus of Norwegians into Sweden is expected to be the first consequence of the decree issued by Premier Vidkun Quisling yesterday mobilizing Norwegian manpower.

Men and women prominent in the amusement world, who were going under the auspices of the USO Camp Shows to entertain American troops overseas; foreign correspondents and business men were among the passengers of the Yankee Clipper in the crash at Lisbon on Monday night.

From Brunswick, Me., has come the signed entry of an athlete upon whose individual performance may depend the outcome of the struggle for the national A.A.U. team championship that the New York A.C. and New York University squads are certain to wage at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

At least one group of sportsmen's clubs believes there is a role the average sportsman can fill. In the opinion of organized Rhode Islanders, those who fight for conservation of fish and game can easily become "public benefactors."

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23 -- A glimmer of hope for the life of Mohandas K. Gandhi appeared today in the fourteenth day of his fast. His physicians announced during the afternoon that "he appears comfortable" and there was "no appreciable change" in his condition.

One of the major mysteries of World War II developed to a tragic climax but left no satisfying solution when an assassin's bullet struck down Admiral Jean Francois Darlan. Now Dutton plans to present a study of the man which adopts the viewpoint that the late French leader was a much maligned and misunderstood patriot.

]Hrs. H. Dunscombe Colt gave a tea yesterday in her home, 470 Park ., to discuss final plans for the fashion show and tea dance to be given Friday at the Pierre for the Aalta War Relief Fund of the British War Relief Society.

Faced with the prospect that furniture might eventually have to be put on a priority basis at the expense of non-defense areas, the National Retail Furniture Association has sought to forestall such action by suggesting to the government a method for channeling production equitably among all retailers, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The hope was expressed by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, at a press conference today, that the Government of Finland would cease giving military aid on the side of Germany.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Hamilton Colket gave a dinner in their apartment in the Pierre last evening for the Rev. Jean de Geuser, chaplain of the Richelieu. The other guests were Mrs. Pitts Duffifield of Paris and this city, Miss Elizabeth C. Benoist of St. Louis, and Bishop John F. O'Hara, military delegate to the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Mayor Edward J. Kelly and George B. McKibbin, candidates respectively of the Democratic and Republican party organizations, were nominated for Mayor of Chicago today in one of the lightest primary votes in years, probably less than 50 per cent of the total registration of 1,784,324. Election day is April 6.

Declaring that the American people wished the press to have freedom to "tell the truth about the war, no matter how unpleasant it may be," Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan American Society, suggested yesterday that "sugar-coated war news" encouraged absentees at war plants, thereby slowing up work on the home front.

A new issue of $21,635,000 of bonds was awarded yesterday by the Lower Colorado River Authority through competitive bidding to Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc. The sale was made on a 2.92 per cent interest cost. White, Weld Co. entered the second highest bid, one of a 2.93 per cent basis.

Of all the hundreds of cities seized by Japan in the Pacific the great base of Rabaul on New Britain has proved to be the most expensive to occupy. As a town Rabaul was not worth much. Volcanic eruptions made it precarious as a peacetime capital. But its harbor gave it strategic value for the Japanese.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

BOSTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks spotted Boston's crippled and undermanned Bruins three early goals and then, sparked by the veteran Johnny Gottselig, cut loose with such a terrific attack that they pulled out a 7-5 victory tonight before 11,288 at the Boston Garden.

Bank credit, like industrial facilities, has undergone a rapid process of conversion from peace to war uses, with the decline in loans far exceeded by the expansion of bank purchases of government securities, accompanied by a corresponding rise in deposits, the Guaranty Trust Company says in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 23 -- Swift waters of the Tagus River today hampered workers attempting to lift the shattered wreckage of the Yankee Clipper and recover the bodies of twenty missing passengers and crewmen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, has called upon the press to help spread the appeal that "we stop fighting each other and start fighting the enemy."

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Indecision in the Legislature as to what should be done about the proposed constitutional amendment to lower the voting age for New York citizens from 21 to 18 years was shown on the Assembly floor today.

While newspapers have not experienced the rush by advertisers to contract for space, such as the magazines have gone through, it is now considerably easier to sell space, according to newspaper representatives. In addition, advertisers are more willing, apparently, to take longer contracts than in the past.

Advisory committees in fifty-two key transportation centers have been asked by the Office of Defense Transportation to make a survey of the operations of for-hire motor carriers engaged in both over-the-road and local carting in order to eliminate any wasteful truck mileage that can be found.

Catholic hospitals in the Archdiocese of New York have sent 642 doctors, 324 nurses and 293 non-professional workers into the armed services since Pearl Harbor, the health division of Catholic charities reported yesterday. These totals include fifteen general and eleven special hospitals.

News that play shoes are to be exempted from rationing tomorrow sent many New York shoppers into stores yesterday to check up on these heretofore lightly considered wardrobe items. A glance at stocks on hand revealed such likely items as all-leather toeless and heel-less pumps with leather soles suitable complements for all but the most formal afternoon garb.

Now that the point values of dried beans and peas and lentils have been published and you know all the facts concerning the new rationing system, you are probably wondering how you will budget your allowance during March. If you are like most women, your problem is complicated by the fact that you have just so much money with which to buy fresh vegetables and just so much time to spend in preparing them.

Strong opposition to the Coudert-Moffat bill to transfer the purchase of school supplies from the Board of Education to the city Department of Purchase was voiced yesterday by the law committee of the Board of Education in a report to be voted upon at today's board meeting.

The six-story and basement warehouse at 719-23 Greenwich Street, on a plot 56 by 92 feet, has been resold by Dewey Carver to an investor. The building is occupied by Daggett Ramsdell, manufacturers of toilet articles, who recently extended their lease on the property for an additional term of five years.

AT SEA OFF THE SOLOMONS, Feb. 2 (Delayed) -- That the Battle of the Solomons is not yet over is evident from the air attacks that, so far as those on naval vessels are concerned, have been pressed home vigorously and effectively by the Japanese.

After the sharp decline in the latter months of 1942, the demand for generators and motors spurted in December, according to the monthly indices released yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association. The index jumped 306 points to 700, a gain of 78 per cent, and was 319 points, or 84 per cent above the December, 1941, figure.

The loss of more than 850 lives in the sinking of two of our transport vessels in the North Atlantic will bring home to the American people as nothing else in this war has done the deadly menace of the German U-boat. This loss comes to us not in terms of tonnage, not in comparative rates of ship destruction but in tragic human terms.

CHUNGKING, Feb. 23 (U.P.) -- More than 400 Japanese have been killed in Central Hupeh Province, where Chinese routed enemy mobile units in the vicinity of Puchihkwan, a Chinese communique announced tonight.
The proud and undying strains of the "Marseillaise" rang out in City Hall Park yesterday to symbolize the rebirth of French fighting power, again allied in the cause of freedom.

Absence of any delivery notices on the maturing active month, a rarity in the cotton futures market, instigated yesterday a covering move. in the March position on the New York Exchange. Prices showed gains of as much as 29 points and rose to the highest level for any futures contract since 1929.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Prices of wheat climbed early today to the higest levels of the season on the Board of Trade, but the market ran into hedging sales and profit-taking, and with weakness in the basis for sales of cash wheat at Kansas City a considerable part of the upturn was lost in the later trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Senator Willis of Indiana today accused the government of "disgracefully and shamefully" multiplying its own use of paper while calling on newspapers and magazines to curtail their newsprint consumption.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23 (AP) -- An attempt to end the twenty-one day fast of Mohandas K. Gandhi, now in its fourteenth day, by a compromise between the Indian nationalist leader and the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithtow, failed today.

Mrs. Reginald F. Pearson of Summit returned yesterday from Lexington, Ky., after accompanying her daughter, Mrs. Frederic N. Cowperthwaite Jr., and her grandson, who will remain there whiIe Lieutenant Cowperthwaite Jr. is in training at a Signal Corps Supply at School.

That expert manipulation of fabrics and a keen sense of line can take the "restrictions" out of WPB regulations was illustrated yesterday afternoon when Chez Ninon presented its new Spring collections in its salon at 785 Fifth Avenue.

Thanos D. Skouras, a motion picture producer and exhibitor in Greece and nephew of the three Skouras brothers prominent in the American motion picture industry, has been executed in his native land by the Nazi occupation authorities because of "spectacular service performed in the interest of freedom for the subjugated Greek people.

Carroll Glenn, youthful violinist, scored a triumph last night at Carnegie Hall with the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, in the great Beethoven concerto in D major, Miss Glenn gave a fiery reading to the opening movement, Allegro ma non troppo, and evoked prolonged applause from the large, audience.
The five-story apartment building at 2247 Seventh Avenue was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the Lynar Realty Corporation through John J. Dickerson, Inc., brokers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Plans for breaking up the Middle West Corporation System and distributing about 60 per cent of the underlying properties to shareholders were disclosed today by Purcell L. Smith, president.

The stock market resumed yesterday its upward movement on a broad front as the railroad issues assumed the burden of the new push. Gains of more than 2 points peppered the list as trading on the New York Stock Exchange returned to a gait of more than a million shares.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt signed today a proclamation designating March as "Red Cross Month" and calling all men, women and young people of the country "to enlist in the army of mercy mobilized under the banner of the Red Cross and to contribute generously to the Red Cross war fund in order that the sum of $125,000,000, every cent of which is needed, may be raised promptly."

A program brimming over with provocative things in rare choral and instrumental music was presented at the Town Hall last night under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. A host of performers took part and the music ranged from the eleventh century to our own day.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that plans were being discussed for an exploratory conference of the United Nations on post-war world food problems of a permanent nature.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 22 (Delayed) -- An appeal to the United Nations to undertake practical measures to obtain the speediest salvation of the remnants of the Jewish populations of German-controlled Europe while there is still time, by threatening direct retribution, was the keynote of today's nation-wide mourning and protest.

A small exhibition that opened yesterday at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, is devoted entirely to "War Mothers." This is a series of terra-cotta figures by the American sculptor Bernhard Sopher, created, he says, to express his "reaction to the torture and inhumanity of war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (C.I. O.), said to represent more than 450,000 war workers in the largest electrical plants, proposed a wage adjustment formula today to cover the entire electrical industry and designed to complement the War Labor Board's "Little Steel" formula.

Albany County, N.Y., awarded yesterday $1,269,000 of bonds to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Phelps, Fenn Co. The bonds, issued for refunding, home relief and tax revenue purposes, will be due variously from 1943 to 1962.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The House Naval Affairs Committee reported favorably today the Johnson bill aimed at stopping absenteeism of civilian employes at Navy Yards, "an evil," the committee said, which was increasing and produced a "very plain, very stark, very ugly situation."
The twenty-seventh annual dinner of the Westchester County Realty Board will be held on Saturday evening, March 6, at the Biltmore Hotel in New York.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Details of the German Mark VI tank were given in London today.

Commander Vincent Astor, acting through his realty advisers while on duty with the Navy, has sold the land under the east portion of Ohrbach's Fourteenth Street store. The leasehold land figuring in the sale to investors is known as 42-44 East Fourteenth Street, running through to 43-45 East Thirteenth Street, measuring 45 by 200 feet.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 -- Fresh storm warnings on the inflation front were posted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as it disclosed that Americans, as individuals, saved more money in the fourth quarter of 1942 than ever before.

" At Home to Junior Officers," a place where Junior officers of our armed forces may relax in a homelike atmosphere, will hold a party Friday at headquarters, 28 East Thirty-sixth Street, Mrs. Junius S. ' lVIorgan, the president, said yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- The island of Jamaica, the largest and most valuable in the British West Indies and the site of one of the new United States Caribbean bases, today won from Downing Street acceptance of proposals for a new form of government based on universal adult suffrage and a bicameral Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board, announcing the names of persons aboard the Yankee Clipper that crashed at Lisbon yesterday, listed today six known surviving passengers and seven surviving crew members.

The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company, owned by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, showed net income, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday, for the company and its subsidiaries of $20,164,639 for 1942, an increase of $1,707,112, or 9.2 per cent over 1941.

WILMINGTON, Del., Wednesday, Feb. 24 -- More than a score of service men, mostly enlisted personnel of the Navy, were injured early today in a rear-end collision of two south-bound passenger trains of the Pennsylvania Railroad outside the Wilmington station.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- An assertion that Mayor La Guardia was personally responsible for the crime wave in New York City, notably the series of "muggings" that have been going on, was made in the Senate today by John J. Dunnigan, Democratic minority leader.

In the Winter battle on the southern part of the Eastern Front far-reaching aims of the enemy have been frustrated. Since he failed to break through the fully linked front of German troops on the eastern rim of the Donets industrial region he has tried to get into its rear by a wide sweep to the northwest.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 23 -- The total production of rubber in Venezuela will be about 100 tons for this season, which ends in April, and will probably reach 1,000 tons next season, which begins in October, the Minister of Agriculture, Rodolfo Rojas, said today.

The marriage here a few days ago of Sir Thomas Beecham, widely known opera and orchestra conductor, and Miss Betty Humby, young English pianist, was revealed yesterday. Sir Thomas, who is conducting this season at the Metropolitan Opera, obtained a divorce on Jan. 14 in Boise, Idaho, from Utica, Lady Beecham, on the ground of extreme cruelty.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals, who once did a booming business selling surplus players from their far-flung farm system, today put out a "help wanted" sign.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile, has postponed a projected trip to Moscow pending the outcome of what are described as "very delicate" negotiations over Russian-Polish problems.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Uncertainty regarding the war in Tunisia, plus that resulting from the Indian situation, had a quieting effect today on the stock markets.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Many persons who escaped to lifeboats in one of the torpedo-sinkings of two passenger-cargo ships that left 850 "known dead or missing" in the North Atlantic early this month were found frozen to death the next morning, Robert Weikart, 20-year-old Navy signalman, said today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 23 -- No official quarters of the city did much serious work today between 11 A.M. and 1 P.M., for Colonel N.V. Roshchin, acting Russian military attache, had sent gold-leafed invitations requesting the honor of the presence of every official in town to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Red Army.

Although sales of the Monsanto Chemical Company and its American subsidiaries last year increased 8.5 per cent to $69,146,999, the net income after taxes decreased 18 per cent from 1941, the annual report of Edgar M. Queeny, president, will disclose today to stockholders.
Warning that an under-nourished civilian population will not win the war, Daniel P. Woolley, city markets commissioner, urged yesterday a limitation of food distribution through lend-lease.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Wholesale egg prices were stabilized today by the Office of Price Administration with cents-a-dozen prices for sales of Grade B eggs to retailers, restaurants and institutions set at an average of 40 cents, but 41 cents in New York City, for March, April and May.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 23 No organized gambling exists in Yonkers and there has been no laxity by Yonkers and Westchester County officials in enforcing the laws against gambling, a Westchester grand jury said today in a presentment handed up to Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The White House is looking for a successor to Paul V. McNutt, director of the War Manpower Commission, it was reported today.

MARK VAN DOREN of the literary Van Dorens is a Pulitzer prize-winning poet, a perceptive and discriminating critic, a distinguished Professor of English at Columbia University -- and a disappointing novelist. An able and versatile writer with many fine achievements to his credit, he easily commands the respectful admiration of many readers who, with all the goodwill in the world, can find small merit in his fiction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A House naval subcommittee expressed the opinion today that a story published by The Akron (Ohio) Beacon Journal to the effect that some merchant seamen had refused to unload cargo on Sunday at Guadalcanal was based on a "broad general statement" by returned service men, with the writer "going far afield in drawing the inferences."

The United States Rubber Company reported yesterday for 1942 a net income of $8,381,011 after all current charges, including war losses of $15,487,414 and Federal and foreign income taxes of $11,600,409. This is equal to $1.82 each on the 1,739,092 common shares outstanding after allowing $8 a share on the preferred stock.
Baseball's war-wabbling minor league structure finally has become stabilized, with nine loops ready to start the season, The Associated Press reports.

Private Johnny Greco of the Canadian Army and Cleo Shans, California lightweight, will share the distinction Friday night of boosting boxing receipts at Madison Square Garden for the first six shows of the year beyond the quarter-million-dollar mark.

The Philharmonic Orchestra "shop committee" filed charges yesterday with the Musicians Union, Local 802, against Dr. Artur Rodzinski, incoming conductor of the Philharmonic, and wired to members of all other leading symphony orchestras in the country asking them to refrain from accepting posts with the Philharmonic "until we have won justice."

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- The United States must have an Army of 8,200,000, including officers, by the end of 1943 and a total of 10,800,000 in the armed forces, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said tonight in an address beore a dinner meeting of the Produce for Victory Committee of the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce.

Helen McCarey, 11 years old, was drowned and her sister, Catherine, 9, nearly lost her life last night in a strange accident in the four-room penthouse apartment occupied by the caretaker on the roof of the four-story Beth Hamedrosh Hagodol Synagogue at 610 West 175th Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Concern was expressed today by some Federal fiscal officials over the lack of clarification of Federal tax policy as the deadline for filing income tax returns draws near.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Louis Mongno, 62 years old, of 215 West Eighteenth Street, an ex-convict who was head of Brooklyn's so-called "Blue Limousine Gang" of hold-up men twenty-four years ago, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Martin Epstein in Brooklyn on a charge of stealing government property.

Leaders of the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths in this country and in England asserted yesterday that no lasting reconstruction of the world after the war could be effected unless the reform had its basis in religion.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's latest order of the day has revived and stimulated discussion of need for an immediate opening of another front across the English Channel, which died down for a while after the Allied landing in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Restrictions of wheat production were suspended today in one of a series of government moves designated to ease the food supply and price situation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 23 -- A German armored column thrusting toward Thala was battered to a standstill this morning by British tanks and American guns. The enemy was stopped four miles south of the town after twenty-four hours of the campaign's bitterest fighting.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins, Cleveland Negro, gained a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Anton Christoforidis of Geneva, Ohio, in the finale of Matchmaker Larry Atkins's light-heavyweight duration championship tournament at the Arena tonight.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation has completed arrangements for a revolving Regulation V credit in the amount of $150,000,000 to finance a large and rapidly growing production of war goods, it was announced yesterday by E.R. Breech, president.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 23 -- A group of American noncommissioned officers and enlisted men were gathered in a cafe that by tacit agreement has become their special preserve when two men dressed in British uniforms entered and began making insulting remarks.

Sharp retrenchment matched declining revenues on the New York Curb Exchange last year and held its net loss to $105,003, against $93,461 for 1941, according to the annual report yesterday. Before depreciation of $101,681 and amortization of telephone equipment of $4,695, the Curb had an operating profit of $25,255, compared with $57,312 in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Two former missionaries in India were arrested today when they attempted to picket the British Embassy in protest against the imprisonment of Mohandas K. Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru.

The Childs Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1942 after taxes a net profit of $125,515, equal to $3.36 a share on the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, in contrast to a net loss of $121,963 reported for the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Japanese outpost bases in the Solomon Islands and the Aleutians felt the weight of blows dealt by heavy American bombers yesterday, the Navy announced today. No United States planes were lost in either of the far-spread operations.

Two years ago the Medical Society of the County of New York appointed a committee to develop a plan to reduce the cost of blood transfusions and to make blood more generally available to the needy in these parts. Out of the committee's work came the remarkable Blood and Plasma Exchange Bank, which applies horse-trading principles with extraordinary efficiency, but of which few have heard.

Maxine Elliott, actress, who retired from the New York stage in 1920 to live at her Chateau l'Horizon near Cannes, France, left a net estate of $1,140,065 when she died there on March 5, 1940, it was disclosed yesterday when the estate tax appraisal was filed here.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 -- Stretching his winning streak to five races, Warren Wright's Louisiana derby favorite, Ocean Wave, carried 128 pounds to a one-length triumph in the $5,000 added Belle Grove Handicap before some 4,000 fans at the Fair Grounds today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Pope Pius received the secretaries of the Hungarian and Argentine Legations at the Vatican today in a continuance of conversations that, since the arrival of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, have given new impetus to rumors of a hope for a separate peace by the small nations of Europe.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 -- The eighteen-point proposal submitted by Margarito Ramirez, general manager of Mexico's National Railroads, for the reorganization of the entire network has been rejected by the Syndicate of Railroad Workers, which is now studying a plan of its own, according to a statement in today's press by Leoncio E. Ucha, a spokesman for the syndicate.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- In spite of the handicap of one of the heaviest snowfalls recorded for a long time in Central Russia and a paucity of communications, the Red Army is developing its attack on Orel in a manner that must now be causing the German command acute anxiety about the fate of this important base.

Further amendments to the WPE shoe industry order M-217 were predicted yesterday following three hurriedly called trade meetings arranged over the week-end following announcement of the amendment late last week.

Breaking many precedents, the first contingent of women who have received Chance M. Vought scholarships in engineering registered yesterday at the New York University Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics and took up residence at the Campagna Mansion in Riverdale.

In describing the results of the recent series of air raid tests, you give high praise -- and justly so -- to the Air Warden Service, the police, the firemen, the Fire Auxiliary Corps, and the City Patrol. Perhaps because they were not seen in public, you failed to mention one other service which was alert and prepared for immediate action even before the public siren sounded -- the Emergency Medical Service.

Women with dependent children were urged yesterday to refrain from accepting positions in war industries unless absolutely necessary, if it meant that their families would receive inadequate care. The advice was given at the opening by the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children of an information and counseling service for working mothers in the Fort Greene Health Center, 295 Flatbush Avenue Extension, Brooklyn.

The British Insurance Communications Office, to be known as BICO, will begin operations on Monday in order to provide for the transmission of insurance information to Great Britain under conditions which will prevent any data of a secret or informative nature from falling into enemy hands.
