WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Representative Merritt has set March 10 for a House military subcommittee hearing on legislation to place women physicians in the Medical Corps of the Army and the Navy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Yale's recent statement of its. wartime sports policy left the question of football up in the air, but an announcement today from the athletic department indicated that, if the game is to be played, there will be enough material at the university to put some sort of team on the gridiron.

About 25 per cent of the retail stores in New York City were reported without butter yesterday due to a damming of trade channels allegedly resulting from a recent Office of Price Administration order fixing ceilings at various trade levels.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill made it clear today that the Government of India would continue to hold in confinement Mohandas K. Gandhi, who now is expected by his doctors at Poona to live through his twenty-one-day hunger strike against detention.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal for the city's purchase of the plant and equipment of the Staten Island Edison Corporation at a price not to exceed $16,500,000 was rejected yesterday at an executive session of the City Council's finance committee at City Hall.
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Labor Minister Ernest Bevin, one of the Labor party leaders, has dared the party to expel him and declared that he would attend none of its sessions until the situation arising from the Laborite vote against the government on the Beveridge report is cleared up and the party's future stand defined, London morning newspapers said today.

HOLLYWVOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 -Francis Alstock, director of the Motion Picture Division of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, left tonight for Mexico City after conferences with Twentieth Century-Fox and RKO executives which are expected to result in the former company buying RKO's interests in "It's All True," which Orson Welles produced in Brazil and Mexico and over which Welles and RKO have been at loggerheads.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Adolf Hitler indicated tonight that he intended to force the occupied countries to join in a German war effort on a scale unprecedented in history and said he would not spare foreign lives in a struggle that was costing many German lives.

Timelessness is a quality Zoe de Salle developed in her custom-made clothes long before it became the necessity of today. Yesterday in showing her new Spring collection she emphasized this point again. Handsome fabrics, both imported and domestic, were selected for these long-wearing and satisfying clothes.

In a double attack upon the illicit use of gasoline ration coupons, the Office of Price Administration directed yesterday that the owners of automobiles not in use deposit their ration books with local rationing boards, and at the same time heard evidence against nine alleged black market operators.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -Governor Dewey continued his drive for help for the farmers of the State today by sending a telegram to Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, urging an increase in the steel allotment for farm machinery and repair parts for 1943.

Russia's great offensive has swept on toward Orel. But Orel is not the only point on the southern battlefront to watch. It is probable that the Germans are already preparing to give it up and to retire to the stronger defenses of Bryansk. The two areas of most significance in the Russian line are the little bulge toward Stalino and the huge bulge south of Kharkov toward Dniepropetrovsk.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Allied bombers forced a Japanese warship aground and damaged two other warships and a merchantman at Rabaul, New Britain, General Douglas MacArthur's communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Farm group demands for higher prices, rather than government "incentive" payments or other indirect spurs to war production, neared a showdown today as Secretary Wickard, Food Administrator, called for "a clear mandate from Congress immediately" for his program so that plans and planting could get under way.

CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 24 The bill amending the National Security Act by removing all restrictions on use of the militia outside of Australian territory was defeated in the House of Representatives this afternoon on a motion for the first reading, 34 to 29.

Fighting for a play-off berth in the National Hockey League race, the Black Hawks will tackle the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Windy City team has been engaging in a bitter struggle with the Canadiens of Montreal recently for possession of fourth place in the standing, the lowest berth that permits a team to qualify for the post-season competition.

Retail clothing sellers in the New York area, particularly stores selling women's apparel, were frankly upset yesterday by an unprecedented "buying spree" on the part of customers who have disregarded repeated announcements by the OPA that plans for rationing clothing are not imminent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24--Coming from behind with a thrilling second-half rally and a dynamic last-minute surge that dwarfed even its dramatic finish against Columbia last Saturday night, the amazingly unpredictable Harvard basketball team toppled the University of Pennsylvania, 57 to 56, tonight for its second successive one-point victory in five days in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
Admiral Sir Percy Noble, Royal Navy, head of the British Admiralty Commission in Washington, is at the Plaza.

Bullish forces struck with greater force yesterday as the stock market climbed to new highs on a volume surpassed by only one other session this year. Again it was the rail group that supplied the real energy for the advance, and several major carriers, absent from the rise of the previous day, caught up with the leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -Stanley (Bucky) Harris, who has spent twenty-three years in the major leagues as second baseman and manager or the Senators, Tigers and Red Sox, today received the job of rebuilding the last-place National League Phils.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The recommendations made by housing groups and the State Division of Housing that the use of the State housing bond authorization, amounting to $150,000,000, be made available now, so that a large-scale program of post-war housing can be worked out the coming year are scheduled for rejection by the Dewey administration.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Debate on the crime situation in New York City continued in the Legislature today, with Senator Coudert of Manhattan denying that Mayor La Guardia was in any way responsible for the many recent "muggings" and stating that, if anything, crime in the city has declined under the present administration.

It was a gala night last night for lovers of two-piano music at Town Hall, where Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, British team, who have been favorites here now for many years, presented several interesting new pieces, along with old favorites.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 24 -- Banged and battered to the breaking point by outnumbered, weary Americans who outfought them for ten days, Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's prize armored divisions are in full retreat. The German bid to smash the British First Army before tackling the Eighth has failed after coming within an inch of succeeding.

Independent wine bottlers in the Eastern area, principal suppliers to the market here, are facing complete discontinuance of their operations as a result of their inability to obtain supplies of wine from California, it was learned yesterday.

Formation of the East Side Committee on the Care of Children in Wartime was completed last night at a meeting in Public School 64, 605 East Ninth Street. One hundred and fifty persons, representatives of parents associations and executives of settlement houses and other organizations, attended.

The sight of French sailors and marines marching up Broadway through ticker-tape showers to be welcomed at City Hall and addressed by the Mayor in their native language was one of the most dramatic this town has seen in this war. It almost made one think that the surrender of June, 1940.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A haunch of musk-ox for the White House and a letter of thanks to President Roosevelt were the means emplayed by 200 grateful Greelanders to express their appreciation for relief brought by the United States Coast Guard to an Arctic community.

A sharp increase in the number of cowhides received from uninspected sources, as reported by the Tanners Council, was interpreted yesterday as substantial evidence that black markets in beef are flourishing in many sections of the country.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Robert K. Burns, chairman of the War Labor Board's advisory panel for the newspaper industry said the panel will be governed by policies and procedures of the WLB, and its findings will be filed directly with the national board.

" It took a horrible war to make us improve Pan-American relationships," said Joseph T. Mackey, president of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, who gave a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt for nine visiting journalists and publishers from Peru and Uruguay.

LONDON, Feb. 24--Prime Minister Winston Churchill has been suffering from pneumonia, it was revealed in a bulletin issued by his physicians tonight announcing a general improvement in the Prime Minister's condition. His temperature, however, is still reported high.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, former Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Spain, warned yesterday that the arrival here of General Juan Beigbeder y Atienza, former High Commissioner of Morocco and first Foreign Minister in the Franco Government, as an emissary of peace will be the signal for Germany to march into Spain.

Dr. Elvin H. Killheffer, chairman of the executive committee of the American Tariff League, gave a sixteen-point statement of the league's post-war program last night at its annual meeting in the Union League Club, Park Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Capturing seven of nine first places, the Fordham swimming team downed Manhattan, 45 to 30, yesterday in the Rose Hill pool in the Bronx. Paced by John Sormann and Jim Carrington, the Rams got off to an early lead and went on to register their second victory in nine meets.

In the good old days of vaudeville a sketch was always a part of the bill at the Palace and in the better houses on the circuit. When vaudeville was "revived" recently this feature was omitted. Beginning next Monday night, this lack will be remedied as far as "Priorities of 1943" is concerned.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Ever-growing shortages of restaurant and hard-to-get household equipment have brought a flood of requests for information concerning the Stevens Hotel furnishings auction from unusual sources, it was learned today.

Early adoption of a social security program "to implement the ideal of freedom from want" was urged yesterday by Dr. Eveline Burns, chief of the economic security and health section of the National Resources Planning Board.

Snooky, the City Hall cat who loves salmon and knows nothing about rationing, got a can of pilchards in the mail yesterday. They came from Slippers, a kind-hearted cat who lives at 47 Barrett Road, Lawrence, L.I., and loves salmon as much as Snooky does, but has turned to pilchards in the pinch.

While the favored N.Y.U. quintet floundered about the court, sagging right from the beginning, Fordham's basketball team romped to a topheavy victory in the battle of the Bronx at Madison Square Garden last night. The score was 65 -- 45 and the Rams were as superior as the margin indicates.
ALLIED HEDQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 24 (AP) -A communique:
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- After British medium and heavy bombers had blasted Palermo, United States Liberators smashed at the ferry terminal and huge railway junction at Messina yesterday.

In its busiest twelve months in ten years the Legal Aid Society, which provides free legal counsel for those who cannot pay for it, last year served 38,800 clients, including 5,661 service men or members of their families, Harrison Tweed, president of the society, reported at its annual meeting yesterday at 60 Pine Street.

The future of European Jews is inescapably dark, no matter how the present plans for rehabilitation and relief are carried out and despite the certain prospect of the winning of the war and the suppression of persecution, according to Moshe Shertok, chief of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine.

Appeals for eradication, of anti-Negro prejudice to prevent possible strife after the war were made yesterday by a Negro and a Jewish churchman at the second annual Conference on Religion in the Modern World, for which Columbia University was sponsor.

Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, speaking at the Mobilization Rally of the commerce and industry committee of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City in Manhattan Center yesterday afternoon, warned that the war would last at least until the Fall of 1944 and possibly through 1945 or even 1946.

After having been out of the realty market for more than a year, Isadore B. Geller, operator for more than thirty-five years, returned to active trading yesterday by purchasing from the 549-55 West 156th Street Corporation the six-stoy apartment house at that address.

Since fresh vegetables are not rationed, they will undoubtedly play increasingly important roles in wartime meals. Unfortunately, many of those grown in Florida -peas, snap beans and tomatoes, for example -- were severely damaged by the recent cold spell, so your selection is somewhat curtailed.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from a correspondent pointing out that the President's letter of Feb. 17 suggesting that a confiscatory war supertax be placed on all net income above a certain amount "from whatever source derived (including income from tax-exempt securities)" was interpreted by Secretary Morgenthau the next day as applying only to tax-exempt State and local securities, but not to wholly exempt Federal securities.

Triptyches executed for the use of chaplains with the armed forces -- work commissioned through the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy -- are being shown until Wednesday, March 3, at the gallery of Harry Bland, 45 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Representative Sabath, chairman of the House Rules Committee, got in the van of what he described as the "fourth-term-for-Roosevelt" movement today, but said he found the President not "very keen" about the idea.

Evening office hours have proved so successful for J.S. Bache Co. that the firm, now in the second week of the experiment, has decided to extend it to Detroit, Akron, Buffalo, Washington and, possibly, to Miami. This will give it nine or ten branches open one or two evenings a week. The firm has thirty-six offices in thirty-five cities.

A gathering of 300 attended the annual dinner of the rod and gun editors of the metropolitan area last night at Ruppert's. The sportsmen talked of better days when more time was devoted to fishing and hunting in a peaceful world.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Bringing to a climax one of the most hotly contested issues of the war, a Parliamentary select committee appointed to study and report on the question of equality of war injury compensation recommended that an end be put to discrimination against women and that payments be made on an equal basis to all workers, irrespective of sex or occupation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -The War Labor Board created tonight on a ninety-day trial basis a six-man, tripartite advisory panel for the newspaper industry which will make recommendations to the WLB on labor disputes and wage and salary adjustment cases.

" Hi-Ya Chum," a Universal comedy, will arrive today at the Palace. The Ritz Brothers, Jane Frazee, Robert Paige and June Clyde head the film's cast. The second-run "China Girl" is the associate picture on the double-feature program.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 24 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho urged the 18-year-old boys who were recently drafted into the Mexican Army to prepare themselves "in time for battle" today.

As of March 1, when the retail food stores throughout the country receive their first ration coupons from customers purchasing processed food, the country's commercial banks will experience a sharp increase in their ration-coupon accounts.

iVfrs. Lawrence Hart of the Ambassador gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Rocm of the hotel for her sister, l[rs. E. McLain Smith, to celebrate the latter's birthday. '=[Among the other guests were Mrs. Wesley C. Bowers, Mrs. Percy Chandler, Mrs. Guy Torrey, IVIrs. Robert N. Smither, Mrs. William Ottman, Mrs. Christopher Feigenspan, Mrs. Julian Wilson, Miss May Fairchild, Mrs. Lavender B. Dunlap and lVIrs. Lfilian Fuller.

The iron and steel salvage quota for New York and New Jersey for the first six months of this year is 1,422,000 tons, of which industries are to supply 911,000 tons, it was announced yesterday by R. Merrill Decker, regional chief of the War Production Board's industrial salvage branch.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 24 -- The Germans this week began the distribution of gas masks to civilians in Berlin, according to private advices received here. The issue is the so-called people's mask, for which every German had to pay at the beginning of the war but which he is receiving only now.

An additional 2,580,424 copies of War Ration Book 2 were issued yesterday in the city despite a shower that soaked many thousands of housewives and men waiting in line at public, parochial and private schools. This made a total of 4,584,734 books issued since registration for point rationing started on Tuesday and assured completion of the task of distributing the new books by tonight, according to Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.
A sort of cosmetic "Information Please" is in full swing at the make-up division of a Manhattan department store.
Sir Thomas Beecham, famous British conductor, warned yesterday against the present trend toward extending State control over music as well as private enterprise in general.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 24 -- Addressing war correspondents at his headquarters this morning, General Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, recently appointed Commander in Chief for the fiddle East, predicted that before long Tunisia would be cleared of Axis forces.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The Fighting French mission to North Africa, which will leave soon, will raise as one point in its negotiations with General Henri Honore Giraud unification of the Allied line in broadcasts to France.

Winston Churchill's health is a matter of deep concern to the free world. Last week he was reported to be suffering from catarrh, but the symptoms were highly encouraging. The patient's reaction was all that could be wished. Restive and cantankerous, he longed and cried for his familiar cigars. He was described as "the world's worst patient."

The American Car and Foundry Company announced yesterday that the dividend of $1 a share heretofore declared on the common stock will be mailed tomorrow to stockholders of record Sept. 24, 1941. Payment of this dividend was deferred pursuant to court order pending settlement of a suit brought by a preferred stockholder.

As a round of applause greeted the end of the Jay Thorpe Spring style offering yesterday morning, one was aware of having seen a very complete presentation of this specialty shop's style conception for wartime. It was in "the spirit of 1943" with no nostalgic backward looks.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -Navy communique 291:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A special ration board has been set up quietly to serve Senators and Representatives only, the Office of Price Administration acknowledged today.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (AP) -Honus Wagner, regarded by most baseball fans as the greatest short-stop of them all, reached his sixty-ninth birthday, today and received his thirty-second major league contract as coach of the Pirates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A disabled Army plane that was abandoned by its crew of six and two passengers in the air off the coast of Florida reversed its course and flew 2,000 miles, to crash in Mexico.
Frank C. Bals, one of Brooklyn's outstanding police officials, announced yesterday that he had sent his resignation as chief investigator to Acting District Attorney Thomas Cradock Hughes.

JUDGE: William Saroyan, you have been accused by the reviewer of having written a novel, "The Human Comedy," * about a type of boy that has never existed in this land of Huck Finns, Penrod Schofields and young Gene Gants. Do you plead guilty, not guilty, or do you enter a plea for leniency ?

As a result of the investigation made by Lieut. Col. William O'Dwyer, two more officers of the Spier Aircraft Corporation were arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court. Sigmund Spier, president, and Bernard Spier secretary, pleaded not guilty before Judge Franklin Taylor to charges of grand larceny.

Total admitted assets of the Jefferson Standard Life Insurance Company on Dec. 31, 1942, increased to $115,016,016 from $104,764,885 at the close of the previous year, according to the annual report made public yesterday.

To provide notification for unsecured creditors in the event that assets on which they rely for satisfaction are removed beyond their control, the National Association of Credit Men has drafted a model law covering accounts receivable, it was learned yesterday.

Deprived by the war of the opportunity to display formal gardens at the annual flower show, members of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., are preparing for the coming of Spring with a program for "Victory Gardens."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The President conferred the Congressional Medal of Honor on Major John L. Smith of the Marine Corps; met with the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, and received callers, including Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador, and Bishop J.W. Lina, chief chaplain of the Polish Army.

Four young Negroes in Brooklyn were sentenced yesterday to long terms in prison in Kings County Court after conviction before two judges on charges of assault. Each of the jurists in sentencing the men insisted that "mugging" of citizens must stop in Brooklyn.

Jacob Brenner, a lawyer, called yesterday as one of the State's principal witnesses in the General Sessions extortion trial of two former business agents of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Independent Union, testifed that when, on June 15, the defendants extorted $5,000 from his brother-in-law, a publisher, under threats of calling a strike of his employes, one of them referred to the money as "cabbage."

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs told a Carnegie Hall audience last night that Russia and America "must work together, respect each other, trust each other and labor together confidently in full and equal partnership." He spoke at a rally sponsored by the Greater New York Committee of Russian War Relief at which tributes were paid to the Red Army -just 25 years old -- and the Russian people.
LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces in Kiangsi Province have killed about 300 Japanese, the High Command announced tonight, but the communique indicated that the Japanese were making headway in their two-prong drive toward Changsha, vital Chinese base in Hunan Province.

ALAS and alack," said Al Schacht sorrowfully, "Three Rivers, Que., has seen the last of me for the duration. So has Billings, Mont., and Brewster, Ala. I'll do my clowning henceforth only in the big cities because the whistle stops are out."

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Senator William Bewley, chairman of the Senate Taxation Committee, announced today that a hearing will be held in the Senate chamber March 10 on all measures on the question of assessment review now pending before the Legislature.

Adjustments of $5,700,000 in the accounts of the International Railway Company of Buffalo were ordered yesterday by the State Public Service Commission, which found the railroad to be in a "sad" financial condition. Of the total adjustments found necessary, the company has already agreed to eliminate from its operating property accounts about $5,250,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The shadow of a fourth-term drive for the President is beginning to rest heavily over Washington. Since Washington runs the activities of the United States in the war, including the formulation of military strategy, this depressing fact is important.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A measure extending the Lend-Lease Act until July, 1944, was approved unanimously today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Few furniture manufacturers will be affected seriously by the reduction in the number of patterns to 35 per cent of those offered in September, 1939, as directed in the new order L-260, trade observers said yesterday. It was pointed out that most factories have already cut their lines by that much, or will have done so anyway by the time the order becomes effective, July 1.

The legal rule of standing by decisions has its uses and its merits. But when sticking to precedents means a kick to common sense, it is time to abandon it. The other day the House of Lords broke an ancient custom. A woman who made her own will left to her nephews and nieces "all the money" of which she died possessed.

Gluck's "Orpheus" Was presented by the Opera Department of the Juilliard School of Music last night in the Juilliard Concert Hall. The work was given in an English translation by Albert Stoessel, who conducted the performance.

DUBLIN, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- At least thirty-five girls between the ages of 4 and 18 years and an aged attendant perished today when fire swept a four-story orphanage at Cavan, sixty-three miles northwest of here. It was believed that additional victims still might be in the debris.

Point rationing will be explained to members of fifty Harlem church congregations following services next Sunday morning by women volunteer speakers appearing under the auspices of the Office of Price Administration. Announcement of this plan was made yesterday through the OPA Speakers Bureau, headed by Mrs. Charles Purcell.

How to rationalize buying by the public and discourage scare purchasing and hoarding is the major problem facing retailers in their advertising. Leading promotion authorities pointed out yesterday that several solutions have been advanced, without general agreement on any.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -Secretary Ickes asserted today that the Axis would make propaganda capital out of any move to oust Governor Tugwell of Puerto Rico, because such action would be viewed as undemocratic.

The demand for men's clothing by retailers, resulting from consumer scare buying following the shoe rationing order, started to reach proportions close to a boom this week, sellers reported yesterday. Manufacturers and buying offices asserted that there was a definite tone of scare purchasing in the reorders, which in some instances were centered on requests for Fall merchandise.

Squash racquets players of all classes gathered at the University Club last night for the handicap singles tournament starting under the auspices of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association for the benefit of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -A heavy flow of people into centers of war activity raised the civilian population of metropolitan counties 2.5 per cent in the 1940-42 period, the Bureau of the Census reported tonight.

Described as the "first work of its kind in any language," the Philosophical Library will publish next month a "Dictionary of World Literature," edited by Joseph T. Shipley in collaboration with some 250 authorities. The volume will be a survey of the forms and techniques of the various literary arts, their principles and problems, arranged in dictionary form for ready reference.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Feb. 24 -The bodies of Charles M. Lent, 54 years old, and his estranged wife, Mrs. Margaret Mura Lent, 46, both of whom had been shot, were found today in the bedroom of Lent's two-room apartment on Park Street here.

Retailers are not only responsible for adherence to the provisions of inventory control order L-219, but, in the view of the courts, are also responsible for any breach of contract for merchandise which may be cited as due to inventory control, according to interpretations and opinions in legal quarters yesterday.

International labor will demand "full and responsible representation" for the trade union movement at the peace conferences, to assure a world in which both power and responsibility are shared equally by all instead of being concentrated in the hands of a few, according to John Marchbank, general secretary of the National Union of Railwaymen of Great Britain.

LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A woman survivor of the Yankee Clipper crash here Monday night told today how the great flying boat apparently overturned just before it plunged into the murky Tagus River.

Philip Stein, 34 years old, and Sandra Stein, 23, a dancer, who said she was his common-law wife, were arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on charges of possessing a quantity of narcotics in their apartment at 64 West Seventieth Street last Tuesday night when Detectives John Cattrone and George Zegers of the Narcotics Squad visited the place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The House Appropriations Commitee rebuffed the Administration today by denying a series of requested appropriations. All told, $13,106,330 was cut from the estimates of the Budget Bureau.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Herbert Morrison, British Minister of Home Security, in a speech at Guildhall today urged the creation of some sort of "world association" to solve the world's post-war problems. At the same time he envisaged future international control of currency, commodities and commerce and the abandonment of those economic methods that in the past have produced "the scandal of poverty amid plenty."

A new issue of $2,500,000 city and county of San Francisco, Calif., tax anticipation notes was awarded yesterday to a syndicate of three San Francisco banks, comprising the Anglo-California National Bank, the Bank of America N.T. S.A., and the American Trust Company. The banks bid an 0.39 per cent basis for the notes, which are payable on May 10, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Lettuce and spinach were put under emergency price ceilings today by the Office of Price Administration. The agency made its regulation effective immediately to forestall sharp price advances in the small group of still uncontrolled fresh vegetables.

Conditions of war affecting availability, quality and transportation of bituminous coal have caused the Board of Transportation to relax the specifications on soft coal required for generation of electric power to operate the IRT and BMT divisions of the unified transit lines, it was disclosed yesterday.

With the arrest of four men, one of whom was described as the key man, the police announced yesterday that they had broken up a new policy ring before it could assume large proportions in the city. The budding racket was described as the "Antler Varied Action Treasury" by Deputy Chief Inspector Michael J. Murphy, in charge of Police Commissioner Valentine's Confidential Squad, which made the arrests.
Events today: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Haarlem Philharmonic Society of New York, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 11 A.M.

A suit to enjoin Noel Coward and John C. Wilson from continuing the production of the play "Blithe Spirit" at the Booth Theatre was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by John O. Hewitt, who declared that the play was "a plagiarism on plaintiff's play" written in 1928 under the title of "Spirits" and also known as "Husbands and Wives?"

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 25--The Red Army, surging westward over a 300-mile front in a race against Spring mud, was reported early today to have toppled several more Axis strongholds in the drive toward Poltava and Konotop, Ukraine rail junctions guarding the approaches to the Nazis' Dnieper River line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The War Department has "indefinitely postponed" its plan to use troops for picking long staple cotton near Phoenix, Ariz., it was reported to night at the War Manpower Commission and the headquarters of the Ninth Service Command at Salt Lake City.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 24 -- A sharp curtailment of its Spring intercollegiate, sports competition because of the war was announced today by the Middle Three group of colleges -- Rutgers, Lehigh and Lafayette.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The Port of New York Authority, despite reverses and disappointments since 1921 and the impact of the war, is in excellent financial condition and the pre-war policy of building strong reserves is reflected in the present soundness of its bridge and tunnel bonds, John J. Mulcahy, controller of the agency, told the Municipal Bond Club of Philadelphia today.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- German bread is now wheatless, it was learned today by the British Ministry of Economic Warfare.

Thirty-eight teams were listed yesterday by the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee as worthy for consideration to compete in the national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden March 18, 22, 27 and 29, The Associated Press reported.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Royal Air Force bombers have dropped more than 100,000 tons of bombs on Germany, the occupied countries and Italy since the war began, it was revealed today by a high Air Ministry official in an interview. He emphatically supported the United State Army Air Force's policy of daylight raids.

For the second successive year Adolf Hitler has been unable to attend the Nazi party's birthday celebration in Munich. The reason he gave yesterday was the same as the one he gave last year -- Russian trouble. There is not much more reason than there was last year to believe that he is dead, ill, insane or under restraint.

The tide of battle seems to be turning in Tunisia. The vanguard of the American invasion army was strung too thinly along the cold and desolate heights where the Germans struck last week, and for a few days it looked as if Rommel might succeed in his audacious thrust to split the Allied armies by a break-through at their weakest point.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Reliable informants said tonight that Finland's desire to get out of the war had reached the point where she had submitted a four-point separate peace feeler to Russia through Sweden.

Suggestions for the means of raising money for the Red Cross War Fund were made yesterday at a meeting of delegates from 770 schools, sponsored by the Junior Red Cross High School Council, at the New York Chapter Red Cross auditorium, 315 Lexington Avenue.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET, in the South Pacific, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, in a recent presentation of a Navy Cross, joined his senior officer in expressing the belief that battleships played a potent role in the war in the Pacific.

Your editorial commenting on the President's statement criticizing the McKellar bill relating to Senate confirmation of all positions in the Federal service paying $4,500 and over sets forth clearly the responsibility of the Executive and Congress in appointments to policy-determining positions.

Relay racing, ever an exciting feature of indoor track meets, is expected to play an important part in determining the winner of the National A.A.U. team championship at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Obviously, N.Y.U.'s chances to dethrone the perennial winner, the New York Athletic Club, depend on the fortunes of the Violets in the relays. The Winged Foot will have no representation in the relays.
In THE TIMES'S recent editorial, "The $25,000 Limit," there is a statement which shows that the writer did not read an article in the business section of THE TIMES of Feb. 19.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Gross revenues of the Ryan Aeronautical Company and wholly owned subsidiaries increased sharply in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1942, totaling $19,620,076. The net profit was $1.27 a share after all charges, T. Claude Ryan, president, disclosed today.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- In the stock markets here today gilt-edge issues remained steady.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -Ration allotments of processed foods for hotels, restaurants and other eating places were fixed by the Office of Price Administration today at slightly more than 50 per cent of their December trade.

Eight thousand large users of gas, including bakeries, hotels and industrial plants, have been notified by the Consolidated Edison Company that they may have their gas shut off on twenty-four hours notice if stocks of heavy fuel on reach a low enough point, it was learned yesterday.

A dispatch yesterday that was dated "Somewhere in New Guinea" told the story of the last moments of a brave and gallant life. Master Sergeant Meyer Levin, the Brooklyn boy who blasted the Japanese battleship Haruna as bombardier for Captain Colin Kelly, went down with a Flying Fortress, out of fuel, that plunged into a stormy sea.

Squash tennis players who haven't touched a racquet in years came out of retirement to join with a few of the remaining younger generation in the Red Cross tournament which started last night at the Yale Club under the auspices of the National Squash Tennis Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24 -- Prices of wheat turned upward shortly before the close of the market today on the Board of Trade on buying headed by professional traders. Many operators who sold on an early break started to cover their short lines when the market started upward and found offerings light.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -The New York Herald Tribune told the War Labor Board today that arbitrators improperly applied the "Little Steel" formula in a case affecting news and editorial department employes and questioned whether such a formula should be applied at all because of the nature of the salary structure for such employes.

Eighty longshoremen returned to work loading war supplies on a United Nations ship tied up at a South Brooklyn pier yesterday as a result of the conciliatory efforts of union delegates and the Brooklyn police.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Action to limit the manufacture of steel mill products to the minimum number of varieties which will satisfy current needs was taken today by the War Production Board. The board issued national emergency specifications for structural steel shapes, steel axles and forgings, mechanical steel tubing and rails and track accessories.

After values had declined approximately to the extent of the preceding session's gains, the cotton futures market rallied late yesterday upon receipt of a denial from the Department of Agriculture that it contemplates elimination of acreage controls on the staple.

Arguments favoring and opposing proposals that the New York Stock Exchange permit membership corporations were presented yesterday by Emil Schram, president, in a preliminary report. Members of the Exchange were asked to digest these and to submit their own views in writing as easly as possible, to guide action by the board of governors.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The text of Adolf Hitler's proclamation, read for him at a party meeting in Munich, as broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded here tonight:

A charge of suspicion of homicide against Benjamin Siegal, 48, of 443 Avenue S, Brooklyn, whose automobile struck and fatally injured an unidentified man at the Bowery and Broome Street several weeks ago, was dismissed for lack of evidence yesterday by Magistrate Charles E Ramsgate in Homicide Court.

In another "all cash" transaction the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee for the William Waldorf Astor estate, has purchased from the Mutual Life Insurance Company the well-known blockfront on the east side of Madison Avenue from Fifty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Street.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- The Red Army is driving a forty-mile-wide wedge into the Northern Ukraine on the borders of Poltava, Chernigov and Kharkov Provinces. The latter is now almost cleared of the enemy.

A blue-eyed, blond 3-year-old girl, who only knows that her name is Lorraine, was brought into the West Sixty-eighth Street police station yesterday morning after being abandoned by a woman at 152 West Sixty-fourth Street.

Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, reported yesterday that the company had a net income of $2,335,737 in 1942, after all operating expenses and other charges but before reservations of income in the amount of $1,032,000.

The nation's supplies of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oils showed declines last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. In the East the index of the institute covering these three oil products stood on Feb. 20 at 35.2, compared with 36.5 a week earlier.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- President Manuel Prado pledged Peru's entire strength and resources to the United Nations' war effort today, asserting that his nation adhered to the Atlantic Charter "because we believe in a society where there is neither oppression nor oppressed."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Air warfare flared up in the Solomon Islands in the past three days, with United States and Japanese war planes exchanging blows at ground objectives over a 500-mile area, and with one enemy raid far to the southeast on our advanced base area in the New Hebrides group, a Navy Department communique issued here today revealed.

Earl Browder thinks the case of the American people is not hopeless. "America still has the opportunity of striking decisive blows against Hitler and winning an honorable position in the victory by the side of the Soviet Union."
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 -- Mel Ott wiped a hand on the leg of his borrowed britches and mused today:

Louis Dieu, an importer from North Africa, has leased a large penthouse apartment in 100 Central Park South, through the Kempner Realty Corporation, which rented a suite in the same house to Robert Griffin.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 24 (AP) -- President Isaias Medina told a special session of Congress yesterday that approval of new petroleum legislation sponsored by the government would enable Venezuelan oil refineries to increase their daily output from 72,000 to 192,000 barrels within five years after the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- After a closed two-hour session of the Senate Judiciary Committee today, even the opponents of the McKellar bill, which would require Senate approval of all Federal appointees to posts paying $4,500 or more, conceded that the measure would be approved and its passage recommended to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Major John L. Smith, 28, Marine Corps flyer who has shot down nineteen Japanese planes, received the Congressional Medal of Honor today from President Roosevelt in the presence of Mrs. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Senator Ellender of Louisiana asserted today that "pure, simple and unadulterated politics" caused President Roosevelt to nominate James V. Allred, former Governor of Texas and a former judge, to the vacancy on the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals caused by the death of Judge Rufus Foster of Louisiana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Advocates of the Ruml plan voiced the belief today that sentiment against it in the House Ways and Means Committee was a boomerang in that each day of delay in the confusion over proposed alternatives meant more support for the plan itself.

Sir Walter Citrine, general secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, took exception yesterday to the report in THE NEW YORK TIMES that he had revived the proposal of the congress for American labor affiliation with the Anglo-Soviet trade union committee at a luncheon given in honor of the congress delegation, which he heads, by the American Federation of Labor at the Hotel Commodore on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Ammunition for fighting and not charity food is what China needs and expects from the United States, as the arsenal of democracy, and from other nations joined in battle against a common enemy, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States must make reciprocal air commerce agreement, with Great Britain and other foreign nations, and "the sooner the better," Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut told reporters today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Army chefs are concocting new dishes for the fighting men. It is the Quartermaster Corps' approach to victory by supplying more soldiers with more food which will last longer in less space and have a still higher nutritive power.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (U.P.)--A House military affairs subcommittee disclosed today plans for a complete investigation of Selective Service operations after Representative Harness of Indiana demanded that "desk heroes" and "draft dodgers" deferred for government and war industry jobs be turned out to fight.

Randolph Godfrey Phillips, who is seeking to oust the management of the United Corporation, public utilities holding company organized by J.P. Morgan Co., denied in a statement yesterday that he had been arrested as a draft evader and insisted that he surrendered to the United States Attorney here for "voluntary arraignment as a conscientious objector."
LISBON, Portugal, Feb. 24 (U.P.) -- Jane Froman said that when she had escaped from the sinking plane she had struggled to reach the surface "because I suddenly said I wouldn't give up."

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Feb. 23 (AP) (Delayed) -- Flying Fortresses can fly low indeed when occasion demands, and that's why a Japanese cruiser in Rabaul harbor got three big hits early this morning from a B-17 whose crew considered themselves extremely lucky to get back alive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -Defending the War Department's action in mounting dummy guns on Congressional office buildings, Representative Mahon of Texas said on the House floor today:

A trade union council of 150 labor organizations affiliated with the American Labor party was formed last night at a meeting in the Hotel McAlpin. The announced purpose was to campaign for strengthening of the party and to mobilize all labor unions in the State against "efforts of reactionary elements to destroy the labor gains of the past ten years."

The Treasury notified commercial bank depositaries here yesterday that it will make withdrawals from its government war loan accounts in these banks on next Monday and Tuesday. From the banks in the New York Federal Reserve District, the Treasury will withdraw $104,942,000 on each day.

It is the Adminstration's decision that we need an Army of 8,200,000 by the end of this year. The Navy, the Marines and the Coast Guard are planning for 2,600,000. This would make a total just short of 11,000,000 men planned for our armed forces by the end of 1943.

With his share of the profits from "Good Night Ladies," a Chicago fixture since April 12 of last year, Al Rosen will place in rehearsal on March 8 "Harem Scarem," which he describes as a farce-comedy, based on an idea by Fred Ballard and converted into play form by Milton Herbert Gropper.

SANTIAGO Chile, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace's home during the four days he will spend in Santiago will be the Palacio Cousino, a luxuriously furnished nineteenth century residence acquired from the municipality of Santiago. He will be declared "an ilustrious guest" and will receive several orders of honor.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal for city purchase of the Staten Island Edison Corporation and its municipal operation as a yardstick on rates for electric light and power was killed by the City Council yesterday on a roll-call vote of 16 to 7. Democratic members of the Council voted as a block to file the measure after defeating a motion by the Republican-Fusion-American Labor party coalition to defer action until the next meeting.

It was only a matter for the records, but the New York Rangers played as if all their chances of survival depended on their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night. Frank Boucher's blue-jerseyed skaters spared neither themselves nor the opposition as they blasted their way to a 7-to-4 triumph.

As the result of conferences during the past fortnight, but concerning which there has been no official announcement, it is likely that the New York State Racing Commission or the New York tracks will invite the OPA to scrutinize all automobile parking in the vicinity of the courses.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

If the Senate passes the McKellar bill in anything like its present form it will do a disgraceful thing. The McKellar bill is a naked grab for Senatorial patronage. As Senator Hatch points out, for the minor offices that it covers it would in effect transfer the nominative power from the President to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Outdoor sports would be cut to 18 per cent of their 1941 importance (measured by the amount of money spent for such recreation in that year) when and if the United States invokes the "bedrock" civilian economy outlined for James M. Byrnes, director of Economic Stabilization, by the Office of Civilian Supply in the War Production Board.

" The Moon Vine" will terminate its career at the Morosco tomorrow night, thereby increasing the week's closings to two. The other one, previously announced, is "Counterattack." Strenuous attempts to prolong "Counterattack" apparently were stymied by a demand by Columbia Pictures, backer of the production, for 6 per cent of the gross receipts in the event the play was operated by other interests, according to the attraction's spokesman.

From a reliable diplomatic source it is reported that the British Government, at the time the troops of General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery captured Tripoli, was approached by Italian military leaders intent upon extricating their country from defeat, invasion and social chaos.

A homey fireplace fashioned from hearts of oak and mahogany log shoring, picked up "somewhere on the high seas" by a British cruiser in need of temporary repairs, was the main object of interest yesterday at a preview of the new quarters of the Union Jack Club at 587 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-eighth Street.

Price ceilings on used machine tools will soon be cut 25 to 60 per cent through the operation of a table of equivalent values being drawn up by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned here yesterday. In addition to reducing the price to the user, the OPA is seeking also to widen the margin percentage wise between "as is" and rebuilt prices in order to stimulate rebuilding, it was said.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 25 -- Asserting they would not return to work until the company withdrew its request for a third deferment of one of its skilled employes, 650 miners at Montour No. 4 of the Pittsburgh Coal Company remained on strike tonight after halting mining of an estimated 4,700 tons of coal today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- United Nations bombers, winging for the fourth straight night across New Britain for attacks on shipping at Rabaul, possibly damaged a seaplane tender and three cargo ships, the High Command announced today.

The enlistment of private automobiles to transport war workers was urged yesterday by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, to meet the increasing shortage of equipment, some of which he described as "living on borrowed time."

SEATTLE, Feb. 25 -- Production of Flying Fortresses at two big Boeing Company plants was at a standstill for three hours today and was slowed down for a longer period by a mass meeting of the employes who threatened a nationwide demonstration of aircraft workers unless the War Labor Board ended its "delay" and satisfactorily met demands for wage increases.

With virtually every Wall Street bank and investment firm participating in the bidding, New York State awarded yesterday a new issue of $12,000,000 of grade crossing elimination bonds at an interest cost of 1.141 per cent, lowest in the State's financial history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 "(AP) -- The Senate confirmed former Senator Harry H. Schwartz of Wyoming today as a member of the National Mediation Board after an uproarious hour of debate between new Republican Senators and veteran Democratic members.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The American forces battling the Germans in Central Tunisia, with the assistance of a few units of British troops, have administered a "clean-cut repulse" to the enemy attackers who pushed them westward from Faid Pass, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House debated today the $6,298,530,435 first deficiency, appropriation bill, with indications that the fight for restoration of funds for the National Resources Planning Board and for child care for defense workers' children would come tomorrow.

Under existing law Lend-Lease expires on June 30. That the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives would recommend its continuation, as soon as the question came before it, could have been taken for granted; Lend-Lease is the kingpin of our whole war effort; without it the offensives of the United Nations in every part of the world would go to pieces.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Heavy seasonal losses in both employment and payrolls were reported by retail and wholesale firms in the State from the middle of December to the middle of January, according to an announcement by the Labor Department today.

One always comes away from a Sophie collection feeling stimulated. Her touch is sure, her sense of line accurate and her feeling for color highly developed. Sophie, who is Mrs. Adam Gimbel, gave wide play to her talents in her Spring and Summer collection of custom-made costumes, reviewed yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Feb. 25 -- This post's first Waac contingent -- 145 corps members and three officers -- passed in review here today for the first time, before Colonel John W. Downer, commander at Camp Upton and First Officer Cora Webb Bass of General T.A. Terry's command.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate, by a bandwagon vote of 78 to 2, adopted and sent to the House today the Bankhead bill to repeal the requirement, imposed by an Executive order of President Roosevelt, that all benefit, subsidy Sand parity payments made by the government to farmers be deducted in the setting of ceiling prices on agricultual commodities.

Price ceilings on fresh fruits and vegetables are "economically unsound and impossible," officials of the Office of Price Administration were told yesterday at a meeting at the agency's regional headquarters here in the Empire State Building.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Aided by a native-made cane adorned with real Japanese teeth, boxing's "man of the year," Corporal Barney Ross, kneeled humbly on American soil and kissed the ground today as he came home from heroic fighting on Guadalcanal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A new picture of America's growing military might was studied by Congress today with a disclosure that the Army contemplated an air force equal to the entire aerial strength of the Axis nations by the end of 1943, and a total overseas force of 4,750,000 men by the close of 1944.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, said today that he strongly approved a special ration board for Congressmen.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 25 -- The battered remnant of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's assault force has been swept off the Bahiret Foussana plateau into the Kasserine Gap's western end, where it is being attacked today by American and British tanks and infantry.

Bank clearings at the twenty-three principal cities of the country for the five-day period ended on Wednesday totaled $7,052,569,000, or 2.3 per cent less than in the preceding week, which also had only five business days, but was 26.5 per cent larger than the $5,576,131,000 volume of the corresponding short week a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Two more signed contracts were tossed into the hopper on Secretary Eddie Brannick's desk yesterday. The documents were forwarded to Giant headquarters by the veteran catcher, Gus Mancuso, and Infielder Connie Ryan.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 25 -- Pope Pius XII today received Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York in private audience for the fourth time. As usual, no hint of the subject discussed was divulged.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 25 -- For the first time in weeks Allied light and medium bombers supporting the British Eighth Army have gone into action against German forward positions by blasting at the enemy along the approaches to the Mareth Line.

More than 265 graduates of free American Women's Voluntary Services training courses in code and radio theory are now earning $2,000 and up in communications work for the armed forces. This announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Frances Peabody Mayer, director of radio classes at the Greater New York headquarters of the A.W.V.S., 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Polish Government declared tonight that it expected Russia to restore Poland's eastern frontier as it was before the Nazis crushed its defenses and the Red Army marched in from the rear, occupying the half that the Nazis did not have time to reach.

A Stork Club waiter who had accepted tips from the "care society" members who frequent that resort and used the money in betting on Hitler victories in the war, has been arrested and interned as an alien enemy, it was announced yesterday by E. E. Conroy, special agent in charge of Federal Bureau of Investigation offices here.

The annual report of the Washington Railway and Electric Company for 1942, made public yesterday by A.G. Neal, president, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $2,961,714, compared with $3,335,362 in 1941. These results, according to the report, exclude the company's equity in undistributed earnings of subsidiaries amounting to $736,815 in 1942 and $513,548 in 1941.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A bill providing for a pay-as-you-go policy for the New York income tax was introduced today by Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell, Manhattan Republican. It follows, to some extent, the Ruml plan for Federal taxation.

A new issue of $25,000,000 New York City revenue bills was sold yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to a group of New York City banks and trust companies by allotment. The bills dated Feb. 26, 1943, and due April 30, 1943, were awarded on an 0.55 per cent basis.
The M.A. Hanna Company, coal, ore, dock and water transport operators, had a consolidated net profit in 1942 of $4,254,663 after all expenses and taxes, it was reported yesterday.

Today's events: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Alexander Brailowsky, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; James Sykes, piano, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- "Magic schemes" emanating, from Washington to meet the food shortage are "little better than useless," Governor Dewey declared tonight in a radio speech in which he urged men, women and children to volunteer for farm work in order to boost food production in the State.

With the approach of the Red Cross War Fund drive of 1943, which will open with a radio broadcast by President Roosevelt, General Eisenhower and Admiral Nimitz on Sunday afternoon, New York synagogues will observe "Red Cross Sabbath" today and tomorrow, while churches will hold Red Cross services on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture assured farm State Senators today that abundant surplus grains were available to provide alcohol for synthetic rubber, after, a committee investigator complained of an apparent "conspiracy" in the War Production Board to prevent their use.

H. Everett Woodruff, railroad analyst and statistician for the New York Life Insurance Company, testified here yesterday, according to The Associated Press, in support of a plan for the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad. Earlier Henry J. Norton, executive officer of the road, had completed testimony at the hearing, conducted by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

An organization to raise funds to buy sports equipment, especially boxing paraphernalia, for service men at home and overseas was formed at a meeting held yesterday at the Twentieth Century Sporting Club headquarters. Mike Jacobs was elected president of the group, known as Boxing's Service Athletic Fund.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- These questions and answers are issued by the Office of Price Administration to clarify point rationing of processed foods:

IF Howard Cann had been assigned to a destroyer in the last war instead of the Battleship New Mexico, he probably would be a captain or an admiral in the Navy today instead of the head basketball coach at New York University.

Since there was extensive damage to the Florida crops of peas, tomatoes, snap beans and cabbage in the recent cold spell, supplies of these vegetables are comparatively light this week. Potatoes also were affected by the weather, one wholesaler reported.

HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman, commenting on recent reports abroad, denied tonight that the Finnish Government had entered into any negotiations for a separate peace with Russia.
Edgar Ansel Mowrer declared here last night that he had resigned as deputy director of the Office of War Information "with my ears still tingling from a recent rebuke."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- An intensive search was on tonight for Lawrence R. Kervan, 5-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence T. Kervan of 158 Edgemont Road in near-by Greenburgh, who has been missing since 5:30 o'clock this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Concerning fighting on other fronts, Secretary Stimson said:

Voluntary price reductions of $169,178,141 were made by the General Motors Corporation in war materials delivered to the government in 1942, it was announced yesterday by C.E. Wilson, president of the company. Total deliveries of war materials in 1942, after the cebates, were $1,913,464,090, almost five times the deliveries of $406,149,273 under the defense program in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Representatives of the United Greek Orthodox Churches in the Americas presented to President Roosevelt today the Grand Cross of the Holy Sepulchre containing a piece of wood described as a part of the cross on which Christ was crucified.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A hope that the United States and its courts would be kept free from hysteria during the war was voiced by Chief Justice Stone and Attorney General Biddle in extemporaneous speeches today before the annual Judicial Circuit Conference.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- The Moscow press today gives prominence to a Tass dispatch from Washington reporting a rebuke by President Roosevelt to an American radio commentator for interpretation of Premier Joseph Stalin's order of the day on the Red Army anniversary two days ago.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A United States Headquarters communique:

The building at 195 Avenue O, Brooklyn, containing two apartments and two stores, has been sold for cash by the Methodist Church Home for the Aged in the City of New York to John Terrana. The property is assessed at $13,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- During the week ended Feb. 24 member bank reserve balances decreased $176,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $107,000,000 in money in circulation, $70,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $15,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, and $2,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $10,000,000 in Treasury currency and $9,000,000 in reserve bank credit.

MONTCLAIR, N.J. Feb. 25 -- Appointment of Mercer C. MacPherson as director of community relations of the Montclair Savings Bank was announced today by T. Philip Reitinger, president, who said the bank is first among the mutual savings banks in the United States to create such an office.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Following is the prepared text of Governor Dewey's broadcast this evening:

The New York City that is to be rebuilt when the war is over will be a much more beautiful city, with lower buildings of more simple design and extensive landscaping that will lead to a feeling of lightness and flexibility that our present architecture does not exude, Harvey Wiley Corbett predicted last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Immediate reorganization, of the Office of Price Administration to eliminate "social and economic theorists" from its personnel was advocated today By Senator George, who said he feared that efforts to control inflation were approaching "a break down."

Charles R. Crane, world traveler, friend of Woodrow Wilson and former United States Ambassador to China, left a net estate of $4,130,391 when he died on Feb. 14, 1939, after having given away more than $13,329,000 in the quarter-century before his death.

A report made public yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers, based upon a comparative study of factory wage gains and cost of living fluctuations, declares that, despite a rise of 19 per cent in living costs in three years of war, the average factory employe has improved his living standard 41 per cent.
A public hearing will be held by the New York State Senate and Assembly Committees on Conservation in the Senate chamber at Albany, on Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

Stimulated by the Office of Price Administration order of Wednesday that owners of unused automobiles must surrender their gasoline ration books, a rush of motorists descended upon offices of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau in this city yesterday to buy 1943 registration tags.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Japanese drives in Hupeh and Kiangsi Provinces have been halted with heavy enemy losses, and other enemy offensives have failed to score except in the French-leased territory of Kwangchowan, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- War has brought to light the fact that the United States is not as well fed as it thought it was, in point of nutrition, not amount of food, Dr. Eugene C. Auchter, research administrator in the Department of Agriculture, said today.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi and other Congress party leaders under detention will not be released, Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, told the House of Commons today. He said there could be no justification for freeing men who had deliberately planned to paralyze India's defense at a most critical moment.

Victor by knockouts in his last two appearances in Madison Square Garden, Johnny Greco of Montreal, a private in the Canadian Army, will try to make it three in a row when he tackles Cleo Shans, sturdy Californian, in the star bout of ten rounds at the Eighth Avenue arena tonight.

An apartment of ten rooms and four baths has been leased in 770 Park Avenue by Oscar Burke, president of the Manhattan Soap Company. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens the agents.

Government purchase of all livestock as it is put on the market was proposed yesterday as a means of eliminating the growing black market in meats which is threatening to disorganize completely the packing industry. The suggestion was made by Samuel Slotkin, president of Hygrade Food Products Corporation, one of the "Little Four" meat-packing houses.

Alex Rose, State secretary of the American Labor party, declared last night that the Democrats must nominate a liberal candidate for President in 1944 or expect a national third party movement and a third party ticket, "organized to prevent monoply in government and dishonest political collusion."

The stock market was subjected frequently yesterday to tests for weak spots, but when profit-taking failed to discourage buyers or to undermine the list in any respect, prices resumed their upward movement with sustained force. While it was again the rail section that assumed the leadership, several other groups gave excellent accounts of themselves in the face of the selling pressure.

Your editorial of Feb. 21, "Airplanes and Maps," is to be commended for its general sense but is incorrect in stating that "You would never guess from a Mercator projection that San Diego, Calif., is no nearer Japan than Minneapolis or that the shortest route to Moscow from New York lies through Greenland."

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Prices of wheat went today into the highest ground since the 1928-29 crop year on both cash and futures. At the top they showed a gain of around 1 cent a bushel, with the deferred deliveries strongest. Profit-taking and some hedging checked the bulge and the finish on the Board of Trade was at gains of 1/2 to 3/4 cent for the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes asked today that the Vandenberg Senate bill to end the tenure of Governor Tugwell of Puerto Rico and to establish four-year terms for his successors, which is awaiting Senate action, be returned to committee for further consideration.

Hitler's convulsionary style is an old but still queer acquaintance. However it sounds or used to sound to German ears, to the non-German eye it has a look of disjointedness, solution of continuity, often of self-contradiction as well as of incoherence. In his latest piece he takes his favorite part as the darling of destiny.

Confidence increased here yesterday that the OPA will act favorably on the request of the couturier type of dress producers that they be granted severance from the provisions of MPR 287, following the return of the delegation from Washington, where it presented its case to the OPA.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Automobile rationing was liberalized today to make the country's stock of 240,000 new cars available for purchase by a wider list of persons.

A total of 6,688,884 copies of War Ration Book 2, to be used for the purchase of canned and processed foods and meat, was issued through public, parochial and private schools in New York City during the three-day registration period that ended last night at 7 o'clock, it was announced last night.
LONDON, Friday, Feb. 26 (UP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique broadcast by radio Moscow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Roosevelt, suffering an intestinal upset, canceled his engagements.

In his first appearance as chairman of the special gifts committee for the twenty-fourth annual appeal of the New York Catholic Charities, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who recently has been hospitalized for a general health check-up, reported yesterday that despite his indisposition he has been able to collect $13,969 as a "one-man committee."

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 25 -- German comment on Adolf Hitler's anniversary proclamation to the Nazi party stresses the emphasis placed by him on the Jews in Europe. A section of the Berlin press seizes on the Reichsfuehrer's denunciation of the Jews and makes it the outstanding feature in frontpage headlines and editorial comment.

In your issue of Feb. 23 you have an editorial in which you discuss the present need for physicians for our armed forces and the drain which the armed forces are making upon the medical schools in the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- About 15,000,000 more pairs of "durable" wartime shoes for civilians will be produced this year than last, although the overall production of shoes of all kinds will be nearly 100,000,000 pairs less than the 1942 record production, the War Production Board said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- in enforcement drive against black markets in meat has already brought about the indictment of 420 firms and individuals in New York and other large cities and will be continued "as long as necessary," the Office of Price Administration stated today.

All friends and admirers of the Atlantic Charter should carefully note your editorial of Feb. 17, "War-Weary Finland." For, as you say, "Finland might well become the test case of just what the Atlantic Charter means when applied to small nations."
MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- British troops, in their deepest penetration of Burma since their evacuation last Spring, have made a daring sea-borne raid far behind the enemy lines, it was announced today, and American fliers have destroyed at least six and probably eighteen Japanse planes from a strong formation attempting to attack a United States base.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A charge that New Jersey's railroads, through a "conspiracy" with Governor Edison, had obtained control of the State tax system was made tonight by Commissioner Frank H. Eggers, nephew of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, in the second of a series of addresses Stations WAAT, WTTM and over WFPG.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- Testimony that lack of meat had lowered morale and contributed to absenteeism and a heavy turnover of workers in bay area shipyards was given today to a legislative committee studying food shortages.

The General Sessions trial of Harry Waltzer and William Walsh, former business agents for the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Independent Union, on the indictment alleging they extorted $5,000 last June 15 from William Armstrong, president of Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc., under threats to call a strike of his employes, continued yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Feb. 26 -- The Red Army punched new holes in Nazi defenses on the approaches to the Dnieper River west of Kharkov and stormed and captured Mingrelsk, in the Western Caucasus thirty-three miles from the big Black Sea port of Novorossiisk, the Russians announced early today.

The most independent class of people in the world is the theatre public, or rather the public in the theatre. People otherwise submissive will not let themselves be coerced by prestige or authority or reasons of state when they have paid to see a show.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Canadian bombers carried out their greatest attack of the war last night on the German naval base at Wilhelmshaven and returned without loss after setting large fires in this third raid there within a week and the sixteenth on Germany this month.

The Philharmonic-Symphony program that John Barbirolli presented last night in Carnegie Hall opened with a thunderous burst when the orchestra gave the first New York performance of Llewellyn Gomer's transcription for many instruments of the introduction and fugus of the Bach unaccompanied sonata in C minor for the violoncello.

" Tu M'ami-Io T'amo" ("Her First Love"), an Italian-language film, will have its local premiere today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Heading the cast of the picture, which has no English titles, are Alida Valli and Amedeo Nazzari.
MOSCOW, Feb. 25 (AP) -- German claims concerning the number of Russians killed on the eastern front were denied in a statement by the Soviet Information Bureau distributed today.

Hospitals of the country may face a crisis as a result of food rationing, shortages of material and personnel and other effects of the war, according to members of the Hospital Bureau of Standards and Supplies, which held its annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel McAlpin.

With some English industries estimating that it may take them as long as three years to reconvert to peacetime production after the war is ended, Great Britain will not make the mistake this time of dropping all controls over industry as hastily as it did at the conclusion of World War I, Redvers Opie, economic adviser to the British Embassy, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

Dressing for dinner has reached its lowest ebb in years among New Yorkers, according to the dry cleaners, who say it must be because of the war. The same is true to an even more marked degree for wearing formal attire to Saturday night shindigs and Sunday soirees, judging by the shrinkage in the piles of fancy attire brought to the shops on Mondays, which used to be the banner day for the cleaners.

A new shortage of fuel oil, which may become as serious as the crisis of more than a month ago, is shaping up here, according to petroleum industry spokesmen who warned yesterday that there was "not one drop of oil" in reserve in the metropolitan area for civilian use.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A War Production Board order today cut to 2,200 the number of builders' hardware items which the war agency will permit to be manufactured. The current number of items is 3,500, to which level it was cut last December from a previous total of 27,000.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A British communique:

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- After hearing a government warning that butter rationing was inevitable, leaders of the dairy industry were preparing today to consider the invitation of the Office of Price Administration to offer aid in making such a program effective.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands is training the two eldest of her three daughters for the day when the royal family will leave Canada to enter a liberated homeland where their people have endured total war and alien occupation.

Life insurance companies of the United States purchased $3,650,000 of U.S. Government securities in 1942, more than twice the $1,600,000,000 of Federal bonds purchased in 1941, and more than three times $1,190,000,000 of government securities purchased in 1939, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP) -- An all-male jury heard evidence today that Ursula Parrott and Private Michael N. Bryan "appeared to be making love" in the rear seat of the novelist's automobile just before they sped out of a Miami Beach Army stockade.

With the arrest yesterday on burglary charges of a youthful band led by a 17-year-old messenger boy, the police believe they have solved a series of thefts in the last two months in the old Manhattanville section of the city of more than $10,000 worth of household furnishings, jewelry and clothing.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The British Government's plans for a twelve-year post-war building and town-planning program with employment for 1,250,000 men were outlined in a White Paper issued today.

The skier's bane, a combination of warm weather, rain and subsequent freeze, has brought about discouraging snow conditions, according to reports from the North last night. The belated "January" thaw, arriving shortly before the Winter's last holiday week-end, reduced snow covers up to two feet.

A choice collection of Revolutionary and early Federal Americana has been presented anonymously to Fordham University. It comprises 127 items -- books, newspapers, records, letters and manuscripts, among which are three of General Washington's orderly books of the Revolutionary War.
