Urging full production without any restrictions from labor, industry or agriculture as a solution of this nation's post-war economic problems, Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold criticized the emphasis that this country has put on social security in recent years and warned that future obsession with "security" will bring about economic collapse.

Because of the current Office of Price Administration "freeze" on all canned fish and meat, restaurant operators here have appealed to Mayor La Guardia for a temporary suspension of the "Meatless Tuesday" program, Miss Elsabelle Curtiss, executive secretary of the New York State Restaurant Association, disclosed yesterday.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Kasserine Pass, Tunisia, Feb. 25 -- Americans occupied Kasserine Pass this morning without firing a shot, moving in after a nightlong artillery barrage.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Dewey is discouraging all open movements to make him the 1944 Presidential nominee of his party.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission joined today in the petition of the North American Company to the Supreme Court of the United States that a writ of certiorari be issued to review the judgment of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in upholding the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Further sharp advances in prices for agricultural commodities, particularly grains, livestock, eggs and vegetables, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets up 0.3 per cent during the week ended on Feb. 20.
LINDEN, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A whistle wailed and the riveting, hammering and drilling stopped. Silence blitzed all sound as the entire day shift left machines and tools today at 1 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The United States can supply and equip an armed force of more than 11,000,000 men this year without resorting to the "bedrock" civilian economy outlined recently by the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the war board, told a press conference this afternoon.

Large space comprising a floor and a half in the Bond Building at 29 West Forty-seventh Street, has been leased by Ralph W. Biggs Co., makers of jewelry and surgical instruments. The lease was arranged by Cushman Wakefield, who also rented an office in the Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Avenue, for Eastern Offices, Inc., to J.T. Mitchell Hastings, manufacturer's representative from Boston.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Gangsters have established slaughterhouse "speakeasies" in the Philadelphia area to distribute meat on a widespread black market, according to George A. Casey, president of the National Independent Meat Dealers Association.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The war news from Tunisia and the improvement in Prime Minister Winston Churchill's health cheered the stock markets today. Home rails continued to harden and prices recovered all around.

MONTREAL, Feb. 25 (AP) -- In a thrill-packed finish the Canadiens scored a 4-to-2 victory over the Red Wings tonight to keep alive their hopes of entering the National Hockey League play-offs and prevent the Wings from breaking their first-place tie with Boston.

I have been for some time intensely interested in the program with which the British people, as individuals and as family groups, are fighting their critical food shortage. In spite of long hours of hard work -- now the common lot of men and women -- they till their allotted plots of earth in every city and town.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 20 were 32 per cent above the like week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 45 per cent for the week ended Feb. 13 over the corresponding week of 1942.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Notes in circulation as reported by the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday increased 2,536,000 to 917,447,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared here today that the country can meet and solve the serious manpower problem with womenpower, and added:

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25 -- The Department of Higher Education of the National Education Association, disbanded in 1927, was reorganized today and cast its support behind a movement to ask $100,000,000 from Congress "to save scores of educational institutions from bankruptcy because of war."

Ivy Litvinoff, English-born wife of the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, will have her novel, "Moscow Mystery," released in this country March 15 by Coward-McCann. Printed several years ago in England, the book never was distributed in this country.

The Publishers Association of New York City announced yesterday from its offices in the Times Tower that an arbitration award made last year for a new contract between thirteen members of the association and the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union, Local 2, providing for an increase of 50 cents a shift for the pressmen, had been sustained in full by the International Arbitration Board of the union and the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- Allied leaders in exile started warning their peoples tonight to refuse cooperation in Adolf Hitler's apparent plan to draw on a pool of 6,000,000 men and millions of women in occupied countries in an attempt to mobilize all European resources for the German war effort.

Exception was taken yesterday by the National Federation of the Fur Industry to the "bedrock" figure of the Office of Civilian Supply of $139,000,000 as the value of fur production at the manufacturing level in 1939 as erroneous and much below actual production of furs for that year, which the federation put at more than $213,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Congress was admonished today by a mother of two sons in the armed forces, Representative Frances P. Bolton, to stop bickering and face the stark realities of global war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- T.V. Soong's statements today were significant in the light of recent appeals made by his sister -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek -- for American planes, gasoline and heavy arms.

MOSCOW, Feb. 25 -- The outcome of the big battle progressing in the Western Donets Basin is not yet decided. Its center appears to have shifted during the past twenty-four hours from Krasnoarmeisk to the sector described as southwest of Kramatorsk.
WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY AT "NEW BROOKLYN," Tunisia, Feb. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- "Them Mark-Six tanks are bush-league stuff -- we're waiting for those krauts to trot out some Mark sevens and eights."

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- General Hsiung Shih-fei, head of a Chinese military mission, told a press conference today that the first thing necessary in the strategy of attacking Japan "is for the United Nations to get together and settle on some definite plan."

LONDON, Feb. 25 (Reuter) -- Reports from both Moscow and Berlin tonight indicated that German resistance in the Donets Basin had greatly stiffened in the last forty-eight hours. Germany is throwing fresh reserves, supported by large quantities of aircraft and tanks, into the Donets battle to keep open the "back door" at Stalino as long as possible.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, Feb. 25 -- General Boisseau, French military commander of the Oran divisional area, has been relieved by General Henri H. Giraud and transferred to a relatively unimportant command in Southern Algeria. General Boisseau, who was appointed by Vichy from Limoges, France, last September, commanded French troops at Oran when they offered bitter resistance to Allied forces in November.

The first negotiated peace between an Axis ally and a member of the United Nations seems at least a little nearer. The nations involved are Finland and Russia. President Ryti's reelection on Feb. 15 has been followed by a shift of policy and may have been conditioned upon such a shift.

An acrostic for rationing and against black markets, prepared by the New York City League of Women Voters, will be distributed at its consumer center informations booths opening at public markets March 1. Ten thousand copies are in preparation, according to an announcement yesterday from the league headquarters at 461 Fourth Avenue.
The Exchange will admit today to dealings the Southwestern Public Service Company's first mortgage and collateral trust 4 per cent bonds due in 1972.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
POONA, India, Feb. 25 -- Poona is a hopeful, cheery city today with even the attending doctors inclined to believe that Mohandas K. Gandhi has a good chance of surviving his twenty-one-day fast.

When the Americans landed in French Morocco last November, it now appears that they rescued General Emile Bethouart from a court-martial that was authorized to have him shot at dawn. He told about it yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, as an aside to his present mission of obtaining equipment for the French forces cooperating with General Dwight D. Eisenhower in North Africa.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussion, Federal income-tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- War Minister Sir James Grigg told the House of Commons today that a "flood" of American troops was pouring across the Atlantic and that he hoped Canadiafi forces in Great Britain, who had been clamoring for action, "won't have to wait much longer."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 366 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa since early November, 1942. Some of this list have recovered and returned to duty.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Before an honor guard of 100 fellow-marines, Private Albert A. Schmid, one of the outstanding heroes of the present war, received today the Navy Cross for extraordinary heroism in the fighting on Guadalcanal.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Americans will not go short of matches as a result of the war, but matches of all kinds will be shorter, the WPB stated today.

Earl J. Heseman has been elected president of Igleheart Brothers, Inc., Evansville, Ind., subsidiary of General Foods Corporation, to succeed Edgar A. Igleheart who becomes chairman of the board, it was announced yesterday by Clarence Francis, president of General Foods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Troops will not be used to pick the Arizona long staple cotton crop pending an investigation to determine whether a real emergency exists, Secretary Stimson told a press conference today.

Gifts totaling $249,713 have been received in the 1943 financial campaign of the New York City Young Men's Christian Association, it was announced yesterday at the final meeting of the drive's 300 workers at the Hotel Commodore. The goal was $245,598.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Representative Disney, foe of "government by directive," filed his bill today to raise the public debt, which carries as a rider a revocation of the President's salary limitation order, limiting all incomes to $25,000 net.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 25 -- More than 250 men employed by the New Jersey Shipbuilding Corporation of Perth Amboy, N.J., refused this morning to ride a five-car special commuter train of the Central Railroad of New Jersey on the ground the wooden cars that made up the train were not adequate accommodations.

Prices of cotton spurted yesterday from moderate losses to slight gains in late trading on the New York Cotton Exchange after passage of the Bankhead bill by the Senate. Under a flurry of replacement orders, active contracts, with the exception of the March option, which ended with a nominal loss of 8 points, closed 5 to 8 points higher than Wednesday's final quotations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Three studios are rushing scenarios on pictures with a contemporary Turkish background. Columbia announced today that it would produce a film under the title "Constantinople," a script for which is being written by Osso Van Eyss.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 25 -- In order that no one of the thirteen fraternities at Amherst College may suffer greater financial burden than any other during the unsettled conditions due to the war, a pooling arrangement has been devised by the office of fraternity business management calculated to equalize receipts from rents and expenditures for taxes, insurance, mortgage interest, etc.

New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System maintained their slender margin of excess reserves during the week ended on Wednesday, while banks in other parts of the country suffered a shrinkage in excess funds, according to the weekly figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A fight for control of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation will come to a head at the annual meeting of stockholders to be held at New Castle, Del., next Wednesday, when two rival slates, constituted respectively by G.M. Bellanca, founder and chairman of the board, and Lessiter C. Milburn, president of the company, will be voted upon.

A fight for control of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation will come to a head at the annual meeting of stockholders to be held at New Castle, Del., next Wednesday, when two rival slates, constituted respectively by G.M. Bellanca, founder and chairman of the board, and Lessiter C. Milburn, president of the company, will be voted upon.

War has invaded the quietude of scores of estates in the hills of Westchester County, out on Long Island's North Shore and in Northern New Jersey, converting their palatial residences into medical, rest and recreational centers for service men, their lawns into Victory gardens and their meadows into pasture land for beef and breeding cattle, a survey disclosed yesterday.

Another war casualty looms, though there is still hope that it may be averted. Just now it looks very much as if the Art Students League of New York would go on the rocks unless rescued financially by those who recognize and appreciate the solid worth of an institution that for sixty-eight years has functioned with progressive vigor at the heart of the local art world.

The steel industry of the United States, in the brief span of three years, has created more new steel- producing facilities than are now available to Japan, including all conquered territories, according to an announcement yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

An exhibition made up of recent accessions to the Brooklyn Museum's collection of prints and drawings opens today in the print gallery on the second floor of the museum and will continue through April 11. American and European artists are represented.

There are a number of reasons why today's National A.A.U. championship track and field meet in Madison Square Garden can be regarded as the high point of the season, even though the season is by no means finished.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Polish Government's National Council made a second claim tonight for restoration of the 1939 Polish borders. The council endorsed a resolution expressing a desire for cooperation with Russia, but declared in a statement:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The reassertion by the Polish Government in London yesterday of Poland's claims to her pre-war frontiers is believed here to have been provoked by numerous articles in the Russian and foreign press urging that Russia should receive wide control over disputed regions in Eastern Europe.

Manufacturers of dehydrated soups, concerned about the "costliness" of their products under the schedule of point values recently announced by the Office of Price Administration, are planning general changes in their customary package sizes, it was learned yesterday.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Bay Meadows, which suspended operations for one day today because of a jurisdictional labor dispute involving the mutuel clerks, was warned by the chairman of the State Racing Board tonight to keep going or quit for 1943.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in England, Feb. 26 -- From the cockpit of a plane that led an American air armada in its third attack on Germany today I watched bombs from Flying Fortresses and Liberators blast the docks at Wilhelmshaven, one of the Nazis' principal naval bases. It was the first time that reporters accompanied an American air raid in the European theatre.

DETROIT, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Ray (Sugar) Robinson of New York avenged the only defeat of his 132-fight career by getting up from the floor to outpoint tough Jake La Motta of the Bronx in a ten-round bout tonight at Olympia Stadium. Robinson was down for an eight count in the seventh.

Education is more closely involved in this war than in any previous one in history and it is likely that education will be improved as a result, rather than wrecked, according to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College. Miss Gildersleeve was a speaker yesterday at the annual session of the National Association of Principals of Schools for Girls, held at the Hotel Biltmore.

In modern warfare tanks replace the armored knights who charged ahead of medieval foot soldiers. Like the knights, the tank crews fight inside of steel jackets. Their success depends on the strength of their jackets, the speed of their mounts and the power of their stroke.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26 -- Mervyn Le Roy will direct and Walter Pidgeon will play Petronius in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Quo-Vadis," which will be made in technicolor, and will be the company's biggest undertaking of the year. The film is expected to cost more than $2,000,000 and calls for 176 speaking parts.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Major William G. Benn, one of the leading airmen under General MacArthur's command, has been listed officially as missing, it was announced today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 26 (AP) -- J.W. McCord, Fayette County Patrol Chief, said tonight it had been "definitely established" that the death today of John Edward Madden, 48, sportsman, polo enthusiast and owner of near-by Hamburg Place, 2,200-acre farm, resulted from a self-inflicted shotgun wound.

Under auspices of the consumer division of the Manhattan CDVO, of which Mrs. Nathaniel Singer is chairman, ten motion-picture "shorts" aimed at helping women help the war program, were previewed yesterday afternoon in the Board of Estimates room at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Distribution of 400,000 copies of a 32-page booklet describing the life of Thomas Jefferson will be one of the features of the bicentennial anniversary of the third President.

Marshal Hermann Goering is a great collector. He assembles shoes, uniforms, armor, pictures; especially pictures. Some of these are given to him. All are stolen from conquered nations. In his Bavarian castle he has canvases by the most famous names: Raphaels, Rembrandts, Titians, El Grecos.

LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 27 -- The Russians announced continuing gains in the thawing Ukraine west of Kharkov early today, but the Red Army's offensive apparently had slackened there, and German dispatches said the Russians had hurled great numbers of troops, including Stalingrad veterans, against Nazi central front lines.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Mortgage bankers of the nation today went on record as approving the Dirksen bill ordering the liquidation of the Home Owners Loan Corporation. Members of the board of governors of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, attending a "war and post-war clinic," adopted a resolution endorsing the plan to end the HOLC.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House passed today, with a minimum of controversy, the $6,298,289,435 first deficiency bill, of which $6,173,719,545 was in direct appropriations and contractual authority for the Maritime Commission.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Fort Monmouth's basketball team, victor in seventeen of thirty-one games to date, was eliminated by Camp Upton, Long Island, from the Eastern seaboard servicemen's basketball tournament in a first-round upset. The score was 43 -- 34.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The War Labor Board warned the protesting employes of the Boeing Aircraft Company in Seattle today that it would not proceed considering their case unless the men remained at their tasks, board members indicating that they would refuse to act with a "gun held at our foreheads."

Mrs. James. Christy Bell, in a quiet way, is conducting a one-woman drive in her neighborhood. Unlike some campaigners, she has her own comfortable brownstone house at 240 East Sixty-first Street as a working example of what she seeks in larger numbers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An estimate that American working and fighting forces must total 62,500,000, nearly half the population of all ages, by the end of 1943 led a Senate committee to the conclusion today that the "personnel bank account" appeared overdrawn by "several million men."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, has taken steps to break industrial bottlenecks by provisions to compel a manufacturer to accept an order, or to take work from one plant and give it to another.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

It will be illegal after tomorrow to operate a passenger car on a B or C ration or any commercial vehicle unless a tire inspection has been made at an official Office of Price Administration inspection station, the district OPA office warned last night.

Mrs. Harry Houdini, widow and former stage partner of the magician, who shortly before his death in 1926 entered into a compact with his wife to attempt to reach her from the spirit world, declared in her will, drawn April 29, 1940, that "I do not now nor did I at any time believe in spirit communication or spirit messages."
LONDON, Saturday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow and transcribed here by the Soviet monitor:

Yale's attempt to break into the winning column in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League met with failure again last night when the Elis were downed by Columbia in the Morningside Heights court before a crowd of 1,000.

I Vegetable farmers of the Eastern Seaboard unburdened their woes -- particularly manpower shortage and labor costs -- as they opposed price ceilings yesterday at a hearing before officials of the Office of Price Administration at the agency's regional office in the Empire State Building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Senators investigating the country's food production schedules and the farm manpower shortages complained privately today that they had been unnecessarily confused and hampered in their inquiries by conflicting testimony, much of it taken from key officials, and by what they described as apparently uncoordinated programs in the war effort.

The six-story apartment house at 181 Lenox Road, Brooklyn, has been conveyed by clients of J.K. Colman, attorney, to the 364 East Forty-ninth Street Corporation, represented by C.H. Fier. The buyer paid cash, above a first mortgage of $177,650 held by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank.

The suggestion in your columns that Cuba can spare war workers also suggests that our southern neighbors all have a surplus of manpower that can be used admirably to relieve the farm-labor shortage. Mexico alone probably could mobilize a million farm workers who are accustomed to farm work and could perform adequately simple farm tasks involving cultivating and harvesting crops.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Three packages containing 1,425,000 grains of quinine were turned over to the Army today as the contribution of 127 Jersey City druggists in response to an urgent appeal for the drug received by the Jersey City Pharmaceutical Association from the quinine pool of the War Production Board and the Defense Supplies Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Unofficial reports received here today from Cairo, Egypt, to the effect that Imam Yahya, ruler of Yemen -- a small Arab kingdom situated on the Red Sea coast between Aden and Saudi Arabia -- has ordered the arrest of all Germans and Italians in the country, interning them until the end of the war.

Despite prospective, merchandise shortages, some large department stores expect to continue newspaper advertising at the 1942 level, according to a survey made by field officers of the Department of Commerce in principal cities. Eight, including one large chain, reported an increase in their advertising.

Clothiers and manufacturers reported yesterday that their sales this week were slightly above those of the previous week despite the holiday. The demand in manufacturing circles was greater than supplies and continued to reflect heavy consumer buying in several sections of the country during the past few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Reporting a deficit of 6,000,000,000 board feet in 1942 lumber production, President Roosevelt directed Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, tonight to start at once "a program to stimulate lagging production of lumber and other forest products required for war and essential civilian needs."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- House leaders are planning a showdown on the floor on the Disney combination bill to raise the debt limit and revoke the President's salary limitation order.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- America's wartime aid to her allies came in for attention on Capitol Hill today, with Senators studying a government official's affirmation that England is selling lend-lease food for cash.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET in the South Pacific, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Navy task forces have found the top of the Coral Sea theirs without challenge. [The Coral Sea stretches from Northwest Australia and the Port Moresby area to the Solomons region.

Now that all commercially canned soups are rationed, you might do well to assemble your own homemade varieties, using fresh vegetables and perhaps a bit of meat. In doing so, you will save precious stamps for the processed foods that cannot be satisfactorily duplicated.

Federal petroleum officials, confirming the industry's estimate of the critical nature of the fuel-oil shortage, said yesterday that the next two weeks might tell whether there would be another period of severe hardship before the end of Winter weather.

A resumption of tax-exempt financing, together with the offering of a small issue of railroad equipment certificates, lifted the new investment market this week out of the doldrums of the preceding period. One railroad and four State and municipal bond issues aggregating $15,429,000 were offered to the public.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Leaders of Washington society flocked to the Shoreham Hotel tonight to greet Mme. Chiang Kai-shek at a reception arranged by the Chinese Embassy.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Eleven of the nation's best thoroughbreds, headed by the favored Valdina Orphan, who recently set a new track record at the Fair Grounds, were entered today in tomorrow's richest stake of the Winter, the $25,000 added New Orleans Handicap.

Paddy Joseph Annunziata, 30-year-old bus driver who had adopted a coy attitude toward war service, had his mind made up for him yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum. Since last July Paddy had been toying with the thought of entering the Coast Guard or the Army.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26 (AP) -- James J. (Jimmy) Collins, one of baseball's greatest third basemen and manager of the first team to win a world series, was reported in a critical condition tonight at Millard Fillmore Hospital, where he is ill of pneumonia.

The placing of ceiling prices on some fresh vegetables by the Office of Price Administration, the recent warm spell, the usual Spring planting and Victory gardening were said to be responsible for the greatest volume of business within the memory of seedsmen of this city, a canvas disclosed yesterday.
Sales of business buildings formed the bulk of property deals reported yesterday in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Preliminary reports indicate that twenty-four railroads reduced their debt by $330,000,000 in the first ten months of last year through payments from current cash without resorting to outside financing, Z.G. Hopkins, spokesman for the Western Railways Committee on Public Relations, reported today. A "very much larger" total will be shown when figures for all roads for the entire year are available, he said.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Adding his voice to steadily rising clamor for something to be done to combat social disease -- a subject hitherto discussed here only behind closed doors -- William Temple, the Archbishop of Canterbury, criticized the church as well as the government for failing properly to tackle the problem, which, he said, was fundamentally a moral one.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for 1942, made public yesterday by Clifford E. Paige, president, shows for the year a net income of $1,301,080 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $1.75 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A lithe Yale Sophomore, James Wyer of Cleveland, today provided an upset in the national intercollegiate squash racquets championships by defeating T. Decker Orr of Harvard, who hails from Bay Shore, L.I., in the semi-finals of the upper bracket, 15 -- 7, 8 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 12.

TORONTO, Feb. 26 -- The United States has decided to press for United Nations conferences on common aims now, without waiting for the end of the war, and "intends at once" to open preliminary talks with its Allies in preparation for such conferences.

Many of the heated defenses of intercollegiate contact sports in wartime miss the point. They call attention to the undoubted benefits of football and basketball to the relatively tiny band of players who represent their colleges in games with other schools.
" It is my impression, after talking with him, that Dolph Camilli is not interested in managing a ball club."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 26 -- A beaten Axis force, including some of the Wehrmacht's proudest regiments, streamed out of Kasserine Pass on to the Faid plain today, whipped on by shells from Allied artillery and tanks and harried by Allied bombers and fighters that kept up their relentless pounding of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's retreating columns.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 26 -- Rumors of important negotiations on the conduct of the war and possible efforts toward its mediation circulated from both Vatican City and Rome tonight with greater intensity and more veiled implications than at any time since Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York arrived at the Vatican.
I sincerely hope that the proposed War Department inquiry concerning Lieut. Col. John Hay Whitney will do him no injury as most persons in racing think he is a worthy man.

An over-all study of post-war problems, which will be based upon a preliminary "balance sheet" of favorable and unfavorable conditions that can be expected to prevail after the war, will be made by a committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Arnold Wood of the Princeton Club and G.M. Rushmore of the Harvard Club, headliners in squash tennis a few years back, met in the outstanding second-round match of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association last night.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 26 -- Now that Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel has failed in his initial all-out attempt to smash the British First Army before the British Eighth Army attacks him from the south in Tunisia, it is possible to review briefly the campaign involving chiefly Americans that has lasted over a month and has taught two major lessons.

Church bells will be rung at 1 P.M. tomorrow to mark the opening of the drive for what has been called "a great mercy fund." The day will be known as "Red Cross Sunday," which will be nationally observed. The bell-ringing will be at the request of the Red Cross Campaign Committee.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of China's generalissimo, will return on Monday to New York, where she recently spent weeks in a hospital, to be received with official ceremonies and to make her first public address here, at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- A force of 10,000 Japanese, supported by tanks arid planes, has been battling Chinese forces for twenty-four hours in Hupeh Province, the Chinese communique said tonight.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Charges of neglect of duty have been filed against hundreds of firemen off duty who failed to report to their assigned fire stations during the air raid drill last Saturday afternoon, Commissioner Patrick Walsh disclosed yesterday. The order to file charges was sent to all division commanders.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Differences between the Polish Government in London and Russia have reached the point where the British are prepared to take a hand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The War Labor Board laid down a bonus formula today for restoring the loss of regular earnings incurred by thousands of workers when the President abolished premium pay for week-ends and holidays.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said in a broadcast to Japanese-occupied Thailand tonight that Axis defeats "everywhere" foreshadow the final showdown with the enemy and that "once our offensive is launched from China the other Allies will deal crushing blows to the enemy."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- President Roosevelt directed Donald Nelson to set up a program to stimulate lagging lumber production. He had no engagements.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 26 -- The Waffen SS [the militarized branch of the Elite Guard] has been absorbed into the regular army as a concession to the generals now back in command of the Reich military operations, according to Berlin advices received here through private channels.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- George Bernard Shaw wrote today that the detention of Mohandas K. Gandhi was the most stupid blunder the government had "let itself be landed in by its Right Wing of incurable die hards."

Daniel J. Dowling, 63 years old, a practicing lawyer for thirty-three years, was sentenced by Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions yesterday to from eighteen months to three years in Sing Sing for looting the estate of a Supreme Court attendant with whom he had been on friendly terms since Dowling first began to practice in that court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Navy announced today fifty-five casualties, including four dead, eighteen wounded and thirty-three missing. This brings to 23,776 the total of Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard casualties reported to next of kin since Dec. 7, 1941. The grand total includes 6,674 dead, 4,498 wounded and 12,604 missing.

Right down to the chunky cookie jar on a diminutive corner commode, the French Provencal living room opened by W. and J. Sloane's in connection with the celebration of their 100th anniversary on Monday is true to its calling.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP) -- A defense motion for directed acquittal of Ursula Parrott, novelist, was denied today and the charge that she smuggled a soldier from an Army stockade moved toward a jury decision.

Caustic indeed was the letter from the Adirondacks that appeared in THE TIMES last Saturday concerning the continuance of baseball this year. It seems strange that opposition to the game's operation should come from the open places.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee cleared the way for action next week on a bill to curb absenteeism through "work or fight" legislation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, paid tribute to the press today for "invaluable assistance" in explaining canned-goods rationing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Negotiations for the acquisition of overseas bases which the United States may consider necessary after the war should be started now, Secretary Knox said today.

The corner store at 230 Fifth Avenue, containing about 18,000 square feet of space, has been leased by Harry Rothman, Inc., retail clothier. The new tenant commenced business at 64 Bleecker Street eighteen years ago and this is the first move the company has made.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Major R.H. Thornton, aviation expert and member of the Air Registration Board, advocated in a speech last night at a meeting of the Institute of Export international control of all post-war commercial trunk airlines in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The McKellar bill, which would require Senate confirmation of an estimated 33,000 governmental officials and employes in posts paying $4,500 a year or more, ran into competition today in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., Feb. 26 -- Twenty-eight buses, valued at $650,000 and representing two-thirds of the Public Service Coordinated Transport's carriers on a nine-mile run from this district to war plants at Camden, were destroyed early today in a fire that swept the company garage a mile and a half northeast of here.

Despite long and difficult supply lines and the lack of good ports in North Africa, American troops in that area and in England are being well taken care of and will continue to be supplied with adequate quantities of food, clothing and other essentials, Major Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, Quartermaster General of the United States Army, said yesterday.

When the seven-year term of Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Board of Education Commissioner from the Bronx, expired last May he was not reappointed. Mayor La Guardia permitted the appointment to lapse, and since then an anomalous situation has developed. While Dr. Bonaschi is entitled to remain temporarily on the board until he is replaced by a successor or is renamed, the Mayor has taken neither of these steps.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- Because they believe it offers them the best chance to shoot back at the Axis, six former members of the American Field Service, all of whom have been under fire on the western desert, have now joined the Indian Army after having completed their contract year with the A.F.S.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Labor members of the War Labor Board rebelled today against what they termed "dictation" of James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, in current wage disputes.

Mayor La Guardia will issue a proclamation at City Hall at 11:30 o'clock this morning, designating March as Red Cross Month, and will urge every one in New York to contribute generously to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund campaign, which is to start here and throughout the nation Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Congress learned today that industrial engineers have cut the production time on medium bombers from the 70,000 man-hours it required to turn out the first planes to 13,000 man-hours.

William Armstrong, owner of the Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc., told a General Sessions jury yesterday at the attempted extortion trial of Harry Waltzer and William Walsh, former business agents of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Independent Union, he paid $5,000 to the defendants to avert a threatened strike of his employes, although he was determined before that "not to pay a nickel" to them.

A large duplex apartment in 863 Park Avenue has been leased by Mrs. Margaret Sangster Van Deth, writer, through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc. The same brokers also rented apartment to Mrs. Maude Van Turk Taylor, in 37 Park Avenue; Siegmund Baruch, in 145 East Fifty-fourth Street; Claire A. Wolff, in 105 East Fifty-third Street, and Laura Harris Grabbe, in 8 East Fifty-fourth Street.

President Roosevelt was urged yesterday in a resolution adopted by members of the Citizens Con ference on International Economic Union in session at the Hotel Roosevelt to call a conference of representatives of the United Nations to plan post-war international economic cooperation "to lay the foundations for world stability and a lasting peace."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- More women are employed in a greater variety of jobs in cannon and small arms manufacture than in any of the other war industries the Department of Labor has surveyed, according to an analysis of employment of 11,000 women in eight plants.

Butter receipts at New York last week were 487,965 pounds below the total for the previous week, owning primarily, in the opinion of those in the trade, to the situation growing out of a recent order of the Office of Price Administration fixing ceiling prices, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A revised estimate of 130,982,277 for the civilian population of the United States as of May 1, 1942, shows a decline of .3 per cent or 340,859 persons, compared with the figures of April 1, 1940, the Census Bureau said today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The noon communique:

James Sykes, pianist, who had appeared several times previously in this city during recent seasons, gave a recital last night at the Museum of Modern Art. The program, devoted to music of the present century, comprised eight Preludes by Debussy; Copland's Second piano sonata; Schoenberg's Suite, Op. 25; Scriabin's "Satanic Poem;" Bartok's 'Improvisations on Hungarian Folk Songs"; Busoni's Fourth sonatina; John Verrall's "Theme and Variations," and items by Fernandez, Villa-Lobos and Vianna.

Boxers who win so-called "ad interim" ring titles may be champions in the localities where the "championship" bouts are held, but in New York State they will be just so many fighters while the real titleholders are away fighting a greater battle.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Aluminum Company of America closed its smelter plant temporarily today to prevent any reprisals by discharged strikers against a score of furnace tenders willing to resume ingot production.

Marshal Rommel's triumphant advances in Tunisia at the beginning of this week have been followed by a hasty and expensive withdrawal. Not only is the American base at Tebessa safe, but the Kasserine Pass has been cleared, top and bottom, and German units around Sbeitla are in danger of being cut off.

Gertrude Lawrence and her starring vehicle, "Lady in the Dark," commence their New York return engagement this evening at the Broadway Theatre after a highly successful road tour. Supporting Miss Lawrence are Eric Brotherson, Margaret Dale, Willard Parker, Hugh Marlowe, Richard Hale, John Leslie and Ann Lee.

Buoyed by indications of higher ceiling and parity prices, the cotton futures market resumed yesterday its upward trend, with five of the six active options establishing the best prices in fourteen years. The close on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net increases of 3 to 18 points above Thursday's final quotations as late realizing and hedging reduced slightly the session's maximum gains.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 26 -- A move to readjust priorities, ruling out all nonessentials and including only essential products to aiding the war effort, will be studied next week by a policy committee appointed to make recommendations to the United States and Brazilian Governments.
There has been much discussion about finding a method to stop absenteeism in war industries, but, like Mark Twain's weather, nobody has done anything about it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator, said today that a record-breaking cold wave on the East Coast last week was met "fairly successfully," with "no unforeseen serious effects on over-all supplies" of fuel oil, despite some difficult local problems.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique today:

The stock market was forced yesterday to labor through considerable profit-taking and despite rallying note in the afternoon the list closed mixed. Except for a few wide swings both up and down, the additions to values held at fractions.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Three leaders of the Chinese community in New York City offered to Governor Dewey today the services of 3,000 of their countrymen for full-time work on the farms as part of the program to increase food production in New York State.
The city's first "double red" air raid drill under the new Army signal system will be held on Tuesday, starting at 9 P.M., Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The Foreign Office tonight confirmed press reports that 100 Peruvian soldiers have occupied the site of Cerro Verde (Green Hill) in the Province of Loja. A detachment of Ecuadorean soldiers withdrew without resisting.

AT A UNITED STATES FLYING FORTRESS BASE in England, Saturday, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- American Flying Fortresses have just come back from an assignment to hell -- a hell 26,000 feet above the earth, a hell of burning tracer bullets and bursting gunfire, of crippled Fortresses and burning German fighter planes, of parachuting men and others not so lucky.
TORONTO, Feb. 26 -- Following is the text of the address delivered by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles at the convocation of the University of Toronto today:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- "The worst black market in meats in the history of the country" was reported today by the House Small Business Committee, which attributed it to inequitable policies of the Office of Price Administration and the Agriculture Department.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The United States was urged today to take its vast supply of gold coin and bullion out of storage vaults at Fort Knox, Ky., and enlist it in the fight against inflation by selling it to the American public for private hoarding.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- It was no accident that British and American medium and light bombers and fighter-bombers began to smash Nazi defenses and airfields around the Mareth Line at the same time that Allied planes from Northern Tunisian bases started a blitz on the Germans near Kasserine Pass.

William A. Irvin, national chairman of the National Safety Council's War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, returned to New York yesterday from New Orleans, completing a six-week tour of principal industrial cities that was made to promote and stimulate public and industrial efforts to prevent accidents.

LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Weary United States bomber crews reported "good bombing results" today in the daylight raid on Wilhelmshaven, despite Nazi fighter opposition that some pilots said was the heaviest they had encountered and intense anti-aircraft fire over the target area.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Jack Heintz, Inc., maker of airplane parts, is pouring 80 per cent of its net profits into a reserve fund to provide work for its 6,200 associates (employes) in the postwar readjustment period, William S. Jack, president, said today.

Duell, Sloan Pearce observed its third anniversary yesterday at an "open house" in its offices that served the dual purpose of exhibiting the firm's books and honoring, in absentia, Berry Fleming, author of "Colonel Effingham's Raid." Since 1940 a total of 196 books have been published with 139 writers represented.
Republicans here and there may still he heard muttering under their breath about the scandalous way President Roosevelt has been stealing the G.O.P. holidays and shoving Republicans off the air.

Even if it should be quickly settled, the strike of workers at the Boeing plants in Seattle and Renton is an ominous symptom. The company asserts that more than 97 per cent of the day shift employes "walked out" to attend a mass meeting and that only a small percentage of the 3 P. M. shift reported for work.

Responding to the call for war services on the home front, 16,105 New York boys, mostly in their twelfth year, joined the Boy Scout movement in 1942, according to an annual report of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, released yesterday.

Red Army Day was celebrated in Great Britain last Sunday, two days before the publication of Stalin's Order of the Day, so the speeches delivered on the occasion by Mr. Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, Mr. Oliver Stanley, Colonial Secretary, and Mr. William Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, could not have been intended as replies to the statement that Russia is bearing "the whole weight of the war."

At its interstate bridges and tunnels the Port of New York Authority has been checking up on the extent of observance of the share-the-ride program. Surveys were made for ten minutes out of every hour on selected days between 6 A. M. and midnight at the George Washington Bridge and the Lincoln Tunnel and for twenty-four hours at the Holland Tunnel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 570 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Southwest Pacific area since early November, 1942. Some have recovered and returned to duty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In a country-wide drive against State barriers which impede war traffic, the Office of Defense Transportation has proposed to the forty-four Legislatures in sessions this year an emergency transportation law, Joseph B. Eastman, director, disclosed today.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Fresh reports on the Japanese attempt to attack American air bases in Assam, India, yesterday disclosed that the score of the Tenth United States Air Force fighters was twenty-nine planes positively or probably destroyed.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 26 -- After inspecting today the plant of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation here and the Republic Aviation Corporation's plant in Farmingdale, members of the aviation committee of the Truman Senate Committee expressed satisfaction with what they had seen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Divergent Congressional comment greeted word from Barcelona today that America has been exporting oil, cotton, food and other supplies to Spain.
Members of the United States Coast Guard Auxiliary were informed last night that they would be expected soon to do longer tours of duty ashore and along coastal waters.

The petroleum industry found 1,878,976,000 barrels of new oil in 1942, or 493,497,000 more than the 1,385,479,000 produced last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The net increase raised the total known underground reserves of crude oil last Dec. 31 to 20,082,793,000 barrels, compared with 19,589,296,000 at the close of 1941.

A future world in which the Jeffersonian ideals of religious, political and economic liberty must be worked out for the individual in a society that is knit together by Jefferson's basic ideal of" the "dignity, individuality and independence of each citizen" was forecast by Supreme Court Justice Wiley B. Rutledge here last night.

BARCELONA, Spain, Feb. 26 -- America has been exporting considerable oil, cotton, food and other products to Spain, United States Ambassador Carlton J.H. Hayes said today, adding that oil products available in this country were "considerably higher than the present per capita distribution to the people of the Atlantic seaboard of the United States."

The General Electric Company received more than $2,000,000,000 worth of orders last year and shipped $1,000,000,000 of its products -- the bulk of which was for war purposes -- Gerard Swope, president, disclosed yesterday in reporting preliminary results of the company's operations for 1942.

SEATTLE, Feb. 26 -- In the face of a warning from the War Labor Board that it would not consider a case unless the workers involved "remain loyally at their jobs," aircraft union leaders went ahead tonight with plans for twenty-four-hour West Coast protest meetings next week if the board fails by then to meet demands for wage increases.
Stores are now preparing to receive applications for ammunition which the government is making available in limited quantities for pest and vermin control.

Today's events: "Die Walkuere," 2 P.M., and "The Marriage of Figaro," at 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Claudette Sorel, piano, Town Hall, at 3; Dusolina Giannini, soprano, and piano quintet in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Eugene Onegin," in concert form, Russian Opera Company, Town Hall, 8; "La Boheme," Salmaggi Opera Company, Mecca Theatre, 8:30; "Orpheus," Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:15.

The New York Victory Fund Committee, quartered at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is holding almost daily conferences with its field workers in preparation for the next Victory Fund Drive which is scheduled to start about April 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- A revised occupational bulletin issued today by the Selective Service System added commercial fishing to the list of essential activities, grouping it with agricultural services, which previously had been announced.

New municipal financing scheduled for next week will amount to $28,223,500, of which $24,914,000, comprising the bonds of seven local housing authorities in various parts of the country, will come up for award on Tuesday. Next week's volume compares with $23,865,380 this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $24,198,697.

The food situation "is becoming increasingly serious and will continue so as the war goes on," Dr. Archie Palmer, associate director of the Food Division, Office of Price Administration, declared here yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Lieutenant Marshall T. Ismond of Chicago, who was a lawyer before he joined the Navy last April, told today how, after his ship was torpedoed in mid-Atlantic in a gale, he and several companions drifted on a raft for nearly seven hours before they were picked up by a British vessel.

All the properties of the Consolidated Edison System will be owned and operated by the city "in the not far distant future," Mayor La Guardia prophesied yesterday, when asked for comment on the action of the City Council on Thursday in voting down his proposal to have the city buy and operate the electric light and power plant of the Staten Island Edison Corporation.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- In the stock markets here today gilt-edge issues closed steady, while home rails progressed further, Great Western rising to 59, London, Midland Scottish to 30 and Southern deferred to 22 1/4, each 1/4 better.

New York City's vast dress industry has taken up the cudgels for a minority group within its ranks. Paradoxically enough, members of the group, allegedly the "victims" of the latest Office of Price Administration curb on the industry, cater to a small and exclusive clientele.

Private Johnny Greco of the Canadian Army hammered his way to a decision over Cleo Shans, California lightweight, last night in ten rounds of uninterrupted slugging in Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 13,154 fans who paid $29,622 to see one of the most torrid ring battles local arenas have offered in recent years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- New members of Congress who took their seats only last month have been invited by president Roosevelt to a get-acquainted session at the White House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Spinners of carded cotton yarns were give notice by the Office of Price Administration today to stop the "wasteful and unnecessary operation" of putting more twist into yarn than called for by purchasers.

Scare buying of apparel continued heavy here this week, with the result that specialty shop sales increase will approach the gain of 61 per cent reported for last week by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Merchants, deploring the rush as unjustified, were hopeful that the crest of such buying has now been reached and that more normal purchasing for Spring is in the offing.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Moffat constitutional amendment, which would permit the Legislature to establish tax stabilization reserves and which was passed by the 1941 Legislature, was re-introduced today, with prospects uncertain. Passage a second time is required before it can be brought up as a State referendum in the Fall.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 26 -- Another step in the program that aims to provide suitable recreational facilities for all American soldiers in the Middle East is the Enlisted Men's Club, to be opened tomorrow at Alexandria under the auspices of the American Red Cross.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Passage of the Bankhead bill in the Senate by an almost unanimous vote late yesterday brought a wave of buying of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade and prices soared 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit, before profit-taking and hedging sales brought about a reaction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration soon will raise the ceiling price on soft wheat flour, the main ingredient for cakes, cookies and crackers, 60 cents a barrel in all States except the Far West and Northwest, it was disclosed tonight.

First official figures show that 703,316 books have bean collected in the 1943 Victory Book campaign up to Jan. 25, according to Edward L. Bernays, co-chairman of the national campaign board. Pointing out that the problems of transportation, collection and sorting prevented a more recent tally, he said local committee reports reaching him from throughout the country indicated there may be well over twice that number of books actually in hand.

Samuel Goldwyn's action comedy "They Got Me Covered," will have its long-deferred local premiere at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, succeeding "Random Harvest," which ends a record eleven-week engagement. The comedy stars Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour and features Otto Preminger, Edward Ciannelli, Donald Meek, Marion Martin and Lenore Aubert.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26 (AP) -- An American communique:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (U.P.) -- The House Banking and Currency Committee reported favorably today additional legislation to overthrow the existing farm parity price formula, imparting new force to the already strong Farm group's assault on this cornerstone of Administration price stabilization policy.
POONA, India, Feb. 26 -- Convinced that "God intends him to live," Mohandas K. Gandhi tonight concluded the seventeenth day of his three-week fast, still cheerful and mentally alert.
A great deal of controversy over the Ruml plan seems to be based on the so-called "forgiving" of a year's taxes. The following is offered in the hope of bringing further light on that point.

Claims of certificate holders for unpaid interest on 229 mortgage certificate issues of the Lawyers Mortgage Company will be computed at the reduced interest rate agreed upon between certificate holders and property owners under the Shackno act, and not at the original guaranteed interest rate, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday.

Specific ceilings for the standardized civilian styles to which the knit underwear industry will be limited after April 1, as outlined in WPB's order L-247, will be discussed here next week at meetings between manufacturers and OPA officials, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Twelve men and a woman were indicted by the Federal grand jury today of mail fraud and conspiracy charges involving an alleged $1,000,000 whisky scheme. One of the victims was George Brent, the film actor, who was said to have sold $5,000 worth of whisky warehouse receipts to the concern.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- American and Russian music was played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra today during unique ceremonies which paid tribute to the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Red Army and Red Fleet and featured the world premiere of an American symphony dedicated to the U.S.S.R.
As an ardent baseball fan since I was 8 years old, I would like to answer Robert Legier, who said baseball should be halted in his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday.

Blooms from the South and from local greenhouses in increasing quantities and varieties are brightening city flower shops. From South Carolina, for example, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets reported yesterday that daffodils that had been arriving at the rate of one to two thousand bunches daily, have reached a peak of 9,000.

The comprehensive articles of THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent C.L. Sulzberger on the situation in Yugoslavia and the interest which the Soviet Government shows in the Croatian-Serb dispute and in the civil war between the Partisans and the Chetniks recently have provoked much comment in the American press.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- American Flying Fortresses and Liberators pounded the German docks and U-boat lairs at Wilhelmshaven today while the British hammered the Nazis thrice at Dunkerque before dusk to round out twenty hours of what competent observers said was one of the greatest sustained aerial offensives of the war.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Spring training rosters show that the least of the American League's worries this year is a player shortage.

Operations of the Radio Corporation of America set new high records in 1942, withgross revenues aggregating $197,024,056, an increase of $38,328,334 over 1941, but net income for the year, due to higher taxes and increased operating costs, declined to $9,002,437 from $10,192,716 the year before, according to the company's annual report, released yesterday by David Sarnoff, president.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Despite the amount of "soy bean talk" in connection with the nation's better nutrition program, few soy bean products are available in stores as yet, representatives of the Agricultural Research Administration admitted today.

HARTFORD, Feb. 26 -- Madeleine Carroll, screen actress, was sworn in as a citizen of the United States today, her birthday. Wearing a large brimmed black hat and a grey sport suit and carrying a persian lamb coat on her arm, she stood in the front rank of 100 applicants for citizenship and listened intently as Federal Judge J. Joseph Smith administered the oath and briefly addressed the new citizens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Office of Price Administration has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate recent heavy buying runs on clothing stores on the theory that Fifth Columnists may have had a hand in promoting them.

THE Gabrilowitsch Memorial Series of the National Orchestral Association for this season will consist of two performances of a program composed of Schubert's "Mass in G" and Ropartz's "Requiem," to be presented Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall and repeated Sunday afternoon, March 14, in St. Thomas Church.

AN AMERICAN AIR BASE IN ENGLAND, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- It was Robert Post's generous nature and forthrightness as a reporter that caused him to be with the bomber squadron that caught the heaviest force of Nazi anti-aircraft fire and fighters over the target on the Wilhelmshaven raid.

SOMEWHERE IN BURMA, Feb. 23 (Delayed) (AP) --In the first raid of its kind in the Burma war theatre, a British water-borne force armed to the teeth landed by moonlight Feb. 21 thirty-five miles southeast of Akyab behind that Japanese stronghold and shot up the Burmese village of Myebom in Wild West style.

BRITAIN'S victory gardens, from which last year 180,000,000 pounds of vegetables were harvested, have provided the incentive for British War Relief Society committees here to initiate a new "Seeds for Victory" campaign with a benefit performance of the opera "Manon" on the night of March 11 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Apparently as the result of a flood of inquiries in Germany by anxious families of German soldiers, the German Army has made special arrangements to clear queries about the fate of those soldiers believed to have been on the Stalingrad front before that sector was cleaned up by the Russians, it was disclosed last night.

As a psychologist whose preoccupation in the last two years was the study of the human factors responsible for success or failure of price control and rationing, I would like to congratulate you on your recent editorial, "Psychology of Rationing," in which you emphasize that "intelligent rationing must take into account the psychology of consumers."

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 23 (Delayed) -- Since weather reports divulge critical military information, it is not possible here to identify the day when the sun shone in Chungking, but quite unexpectedly it did stare through the heavy cloud canopy one morning recently and the city of slime and nipping dampness began to dry out.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -La Salle's quintet scored a thrilling 51-46 victory over Long Island University tonight in the second game of a triple-header basketball program at Convention Hall.

IN one volume Henry Holt Co. has published "The Carolina Folk-Plays" ($3.50) and in addition one new play, "The Third Night," by Thomas Wolfe. All of these have been produced again and again by the Carolina Playmakers in their experimental theatre, the first State-owned in America devoted to native drama, at Chapel Hill and by acting groups in other sections of the country.

BEING a sentimentalist, Broadway sets up anniversaries so they look like the jewels in a crown. Being also a realist, it knows the practical value to be placed upon those periods of time, neatly spaced, which spell either an increasing success or a decreasing proximity to a lean and hungry Sheriff.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The British Government welcomes Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles' recent proposal for discussions of post-war problems, especially from the economic angle, authoritative circles said today.

Under Hunter College's new wartime curriculum, described by Dr. George N. Shuster, president, as "the best job done yet," students will receive specialized training to qualify them for war jobs. According to the new plan, instituted this term, each freshman, sophomore and junior will be required to complete a program of courses in any one of thirty-odd "war service training areas."

TORONTO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Chicago, suddenly throwing the scoring throttle wide open, fired three third-period goals to defeat Toronto, 4 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game. The result moved Chicago into third place, one point ahead of their beaten rivals.

THE annual dinner dance of the New York Southern Society will take place Friday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. William C. Bates is chairman of the entertainment committee and is being aided by Magruder Dent and John B. Glenn.

A wartime safety program to curb the rising trend of accidents in war plants, reduce off-the-job accidents, promote home safety and study the causes of absenteeism and the needs of women in industry was announced yesterday for the fourteenth annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

SEATTLE, Wash., Feb. 27 -- Aircraft workers at the Boeing Flying Fortress factories tonight won the backing of a majority of unions in the Seattle area, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in their demand for an immediate ruling from the War Labor Board on wage increases.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 27 -Princeton lost three players, one of them in the first half, on personal fouls, but had enough left to withstand a Cornell rally and win the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game here tonight, 41 -- 37. As a result, the Tigers took second place undisputed, breaking a tie with Penn.

TULAGI, Solomon Islands, Feb. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A 150-foot New Zealand patrol vessel depth-charged, shelled and rammed to the bottom a Japanese submarine twice her size last night in one of the fiercest naval duels of the Pacific war.

All over the country wartime marriages are taking place as increasing numbers of men join the forces. There's not always time for the girl to get the romantic dress she's dreamed about all her life; instead of walking up a long church aisle she may be married in a hotel near the soldier's camp.

IN a recent broadcast J.G. Wilson of Bumpus's expressed the wish that he could give the listeners some idea of the bustling activity which has gone on during the last three months, and is still going on, in bookshops throughout the whole country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Washington, city of changing scenes in the sense that administrators, "czars" and dollar-a-year men come and go with every sun, is no less a city of changing scenes in the physical sense.
AND we are like the owl -- only a little better off in that we can add more feathers to keep out the cold, while he, poor thing, is limited to the covering with which nature provided him.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 -- Marriage, a one-time cheap plater and the longest priced of the ten starters, carried the silks of R.A. Coward and C.L. Dupuy to a startling victory at the Fair Grounds today in the $28,000 mile-and-a-sixteenth New Orleans Handicap, richest race of the Winter.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -Despite the fact that he is forced to spend much time at his desk at headquarters, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied commander in this theatre, is becoming known as a "front-line general."

I HONESTLY believe that more people come to my dressing room than to almost any of my contemporaries. Girls and boys wanting advice as to how to begin a theatrical career, song writers, material writers, playwrights, but more than any of these, committees who are running dinners for their respective lodges.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- Heavy air attacks against the Mareth Line defenses and the airdromes intended to give them fighter cover continued yesterday.

SMALL irises offer so much bright beauty that a place may well be made for them even more than for the miniature dahlias, zinnias and chrysanthemums already well established in gardens. They have the exquisite velvety shades and markings of tall irises, and in addition most of the smaller ones carry an airy grace, even though their flowers are so large in proportion to their foliage.

Since the War Shipping Administration renewed its campaign to bring former seamen from their present shore jobs to fill urgent deficiencies in skilled sea jobs 363 licensed officers and 124 able seamen have registered with the WSA's recruitment and manning office at 45 Broadway, but only thirty-five of these were "new" men attracted back to the sea, according to figures compiled at the registration headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -Army casualty lists, now being issued almost daily by the War Department, reflect the increasing participation of American forces in the world struggle against the Axis.

Twenty-five word messages still can be sent to any country in the world except Russia under the auspices of the American Red Cross, Miss Frederika Farley, director of home nursing for the organization, declared yesterday.

Again featured by scare buying of apparel in fear of garment rationing, retail trade here showed substantial gains in sales. Rumors of impending rationing brought a particularly sharp peak in buying on Thursday, but volume for the week as a whole was heavy.

UP in the small settlement of Palisades, N.Y., which is not an amusement park but the seat of Rockland County culture, the members of the Presbyterian Church have found time from their daily chores to put on a promising religious program over the facilities of WFAS, White Plains (1,240 kilocycles), a lively outlet which belies its 250 watts of power.

Many householders who deposited their fuel oil coupons with their dealers last year and telephoned for replenishments as needed have come to the chill awakening that all of their Period 4 coupons are gone and their Period 5 coupons not redeemable for another two weeks, it was learned last night.

Preaching during the observance of Red Cross Sabbath yesterday, Rabbi Israel Goldstein, in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway, hailed the Red Cross as "the outstanding non-sectarian, or perhaps more accurately described, trans-sectarian, benevolence of our time."

The Work Projects Administration, variously pictured during its stormy career locally as a great social advancement by its proponents and as a gigantic boondoggling venture by outspoken critics, to all intents and purposes went out of business in New York City yesterday.

ERIC KNIGHT'S "Lassie Come Home" provides at least a partial solution to the present dearth of Hollywood leading men. It has none. The casting problem therefore was negligible, calling for a character actor, a boy and a dog.

Mayor La Guardia and his official reception committee announced yesterday the completion of plans to accommodate a record crowd in City Hall Plaza tomorrow noon to see and hear Mme. Chiang Kaishek, wife of the Chinese Generalissimo, All available facilities have been marshaled to handle this throug.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 27 -- American, French and British authorities are consulting on plans designed to break the present deadlock between General Henri Honore Giraud's regime and General Charles de Gaulle's French National Committee.

When the public hearing is held in the Senate Chamber at Albany on Wednesday to review various bills on conservation matters of interest to sportsmen there undoubtedly will be several with which the fishermen and hunters are not entirely familiar.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 -- World discussion of what Finland is going to do in the matter of a separate peace was enlivened considerably this week by the statement of a prominent Swedish Social Democrat, allegedly inspired by Vaino A. Tanner, Finnish Finance Minister and leader of the Social Democrats in that country, that the Finns were seeking a way out of the war at the earliest possible opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The War Manpower Commission promulgated today its regulations governing extension of the forty-eight-hour work week to thirty-two local labor-shortage areas and, nationally, to the lumber and non-ferrous metal mining industries, and at the same time indicated its belief that if the commission's program failed the responsibility would be that of Congress and not that of Paul V. McNutt, the chairman.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- A board of inquiry at the naval air training center here has found that the death of Lieutenant Edmund C. Stout, U.S.N.R., who was found dead of a gunshot wound at his home Thursday night, was accidental, Lieutenant Byrnes MacDonald, aide to the commandant, Rear Admiral George D. Murray, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt was reported by his friends tonight to regard the present upsurge of anti-administration sentiment in Congress as a temporary situation which would work itself out.

JOSEPH SCHILDKRAUT has acquired the old Jules Eckert Goodman play, "The Great Romancer," which was seen in London in 1937 but which apparently has never been offered in this country. The play, which starred Robert Morley in the British offering, is about the life and loves of the elder Alexander Dumas, and Mr. S. thinks it has the "flavor" of "The Firebrand," in which he was quite a success.
Mr. and Mrs. Seth Bliss Hunt have arrived from Houston, Texas, and are at the Weylin.

Still rated a possibility for a bid to the coming national invitation tourney, Manhattan's basketball team leaped back into the winning column in its home gymnasium last night by thrashing Brooklyn College, 41 to 30.
Behind the barbed wire of war prison camps throughout the world, captive fighting men are filling long, dreary hours by studying subjects ranging from elementary ABC to advanced university courses.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The following tribute to Robert P. Post, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who did not return from yesterday's bombing of Wilhelms-haven, was written by one of the officers at the station to which he had been assigned:

KHARKOV, Russia, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Kharkov, third city of the Soviet Union and the first of its size from which the Germans have been driven, today is an empty shell. It is a city of destroyed buildings, twisted steel girders and pocked streets, marks of sixteen months of German occupation and a final burst of vandalism as the Red Army closed in a little more than ten days ago.

The international executive board of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., has endorsed President Roosevelt for re-election to a fourth term, Samuel Wolchok, president of the union, announced yesterday.

FORCING cut branches into bloom is one of the easiest forms of indoor gardening and one of the most refreshing at this time of year, for the home as well as for the gardener. The branches of shrubs or trees are merely cut and brought into the house, where, after a short time, the buds or leaves will unfold for an inviting glimpse of Spring.

Heartily endorsed by President Leonard Carmichael and Vice President George S. Miller, the Army Institute has won the wholehearted approval of the Tufts College faculty, it was announced today. Tufts will cooperate to its maximum in the development of the educational program for men in the armed services and will give "full consideration" to the scholastic records of the men in the armed forces, attained during their period of service.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) -- In today's Wembley Stadium game Wales failed to recover from England's early attack before the huge throng, which was entertained during half-time by the release of pigeons of the armed services, including the famous Beachcomber, one of the winged emissaries used by Major Gen. J.H. Roberts, Canadian commander, during the Dieppe raid.
Supreme since 1932, the New York Athletic Club lost its grip on the National A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championship last night.
