DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 27 -- Reporting the first decrease of assets for the United Automobile Workers-C.I.O. in two years, George F. Addes, secretary treasurer, today urged the union's 778,659 members to approve a monthly "security assessment" of 50 cents a member for the duration of the war.

A FACT of tremendous significance which has not yet been widely perceived is that the children of the world are the people who are most greatly affected by this war. Much more than in any previous ordeal, they have been helplessly caught in the strife.

The Office of Price Administration made it clear yesterday that, while it wants every one who can do so to help increase the national food yield, it will not sanction the waste of gasoline or rubber by "Victory gardeners."

By announcing its intention of becoming a direct party to proceedings before the District of Columbia Public Utilities Commission on next Tuesday in a rate case involving the Potomac Electric Power Company, the Federal Government last week once again waved the "big stick" at the utilities.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 27 (AP) -- War workers "would show up just as well on Guadalcanal and New Guinea as the boys who are there, because they are just the same kind of Americans," according to Charles P. Taft, assistant director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Service.

A NEW method for making English language motion pictures more palatable to foreign audiences has been introduced by Walter Gould, foreign manager for United Artists. Using "The Moon and Sixpence" as a test case he has woven into the drama as an unseen character the voice of a Spanish narrator, identified in the opening sequence as a friend of the author, Geoffrey Wolfe, who relates the story of Charles Strickland.

Following a sustained drive lasting eight months to enlist clergymen, educators, social workers and civic leaders in support of the War Savings Bond program of the United States Treasury Department, more than 2,800 professional leaders of this State had responded favorably, according to an announcement yesterday from the associate administrator's office of its War Savings Staff at 20 Exchange Place.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, China, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Fifteen Air Medals were awarded today to veteran bomber crewmen of the China Air Task Force for "meritorious achievements while participating in aerial flights." One fighter pilot received a Silver Star, another got a Purple Heart.

A STRAWBERRY barrel is likely to draw only a laugh from a fruit grower, and even from the suburbanite who has a half-acre to plant to an orchard of dwarf fruit trees. But the strawberry barrel isn't wholly a joke, so far as fruit production is concerned, and it is decorative at all times, in any sunny place in the garden.

Even though they are alike in many respects, fundamental differences exist between the Army and Navy educational programs which are to go into effect on 500 or more American college and university campuses within the next few months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Senator McKellar, veteran Tennessee Democrat, has been battling for ten years for his bill to place higher-priced Federal employes under Senate control. Last week the possibility of final victory seemed nearer.

CLIFFORD C. FISCHER'S plans for a new Broadway night club are fast taking shape. The veteran theatrical producer and showman, who at one time had cabaret-restaurants operating simultaneously in New York, Paris, London and Miami Beach, reveals that he will open his club on April 16.

THE new laws of contract bridge, published on Feb. 19 but subject to adoption at any time before April 1, are receiving their first test in the annual Eastern States tournament which enters its second day at the Park Central Hotel today.

WHEN Lieut. Gen. Frank Maxwell Andrews was piloting a big plane across Africa on the way here from Cairo he circled an airfield somewhere en route, let down his flaps and brought the bomber in at a long glide, the wheels waiting to touch the earth. As is the case with every landing of a commercial airliner, those behind the cockpit tensed up a little, may even have held their breath.

To give the housewife as wide a choice as possible within any group of rationed commodities and to encourage the use of more plentiful foods in preference to the scarcer items, the government has worked out the point system, which becomes effective tomorrow. War Ration Book 2 will allow each person, including infants, 48 points during the first period, for most canned goods and processed soups, vegetables and fruits and dried beans and peas.

To hundreds of pedestrians who gathered in Rockefeller Plaza to witness the military ceremonial of retreat yesterday, the thirty-three members of the Fighting French lowering flags of the United Nations were just so many more men in uniform.

WHILE no formal announcement has been made at Washington, it is known that the Post-office Department is planning a series of stamps which will symbolize the future of nine now-subjugated European countries after the victory of the United Nations over the Axis powers.

I WISH my daughter wouldn't . . ." The mother of a teen-age daughter, completing the sentence, usually wishes that her child would not neglect to pick up after herself without being reminded; or that she would not adhere so meticulously to the herd rule -- "all the girls do it"; or that, if she must use lipstick at 14, at least she would not omit washing her face before applying it.

H.W. Pell of the Princeton Club, top seeded player, led the field into the quarter-finals of the Red Cross tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday on the courts of the University Club.

In the western theatre of war last week the hour of decision seemed near. Behind battle lines still flaring with the campaigns of the Winter mighty armies were gathering their strength for the struggles of Spring. The air was charged with expectancy. Soon these forces would be in motion.

Seton Hall Prep of South Orange, N.J., continued its domination of the prep school division, while Bishop Loughlin Memorial High's three-year reign as high school ruler was ended by New Utrecht of Brooklyn at the tenth annual national A.A.U. high and prep school indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- American Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers pounded the German naval base at Brest on the French coast today while Venturas of the Royal Air Force attacked Dunkerque in continuation of the greatest sustained air assault of the war on enemy installations from the North Sea to the Bay of Biscay.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- King George VI, Queen Elizabeth and an array of international dignitaries, including Admiral Harold R. Stark of the United States Navy, saw England defeat Wales at soccer, 5-3, before a record wartime sports crowd of 75,000 at Wembley Stadium today.

RED CURRANTS are delicious berries, far less grown and used than they deserve to be. However, once they are planted and the family finds out how good they are, how many their uses, they are sure to become a favorite and a stand-by in the fruit garden.

While we're on the subject of the 'teens, here's a point gleaned from Dr. Esther Lloyd-Jones, director of the Teachers College Guidance Laboratory. Speaking of the acute "awareness" of this age, she said that self-consciousness about a mother's looks -- her hair-do, her hat -- is part of it. Better play along, if one possibly can, is Dr. Lloyd-Jones's view; the young die a thousand deaths when mother is out of style.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The special subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee appointed a week ago to Work out a compromise pay-as-you-go tax plan will start consideration Monday of the withholding aspect of such a plan so that the bill drafting staff can get to work.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 28 -- Red Army troops battling forward west of Kharkov captured a number of large populated places in violent fighting yesterday, while Russian planes roared ahead to destroy eighteen German bombers on the airdrome at Zaporozhe on the Dnieper River bend, Moscow announced early today.

COLLECTORS of Chinese ceramic art have broadened their once-exclusive interest in the wonderful porcelains of the East to include the not so well-known earthenware and pottery. Less sophisticated and sometimes even primitive, these vases, jars and figures were made in country districts for home use, or for burial with the dead.

On July 1 next a new New York standard fire insurance policy will displace the present standard policy, adopted in 1918. It will simplify the text of the policy in many respects and provide a "streamlined" coverage designed to meet changed general conditions as well as temporary wartime problems.

John Barbirolli, Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave a program of unusual interest last night at Carnegie Hall. It opened with the first performance anywhere of Mr. Barbirolli's own free transcription of several movements from the set of twelve violin sonatas by Arcangelo Corelli, producing a composition in concerto grosso form for string orchestra in D major.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Edward Corsi, formerly relief administrator in New York City, as chairman of the State Industrial Board to take the place of Richard J. Cullen of New York City, whose term expired Jan. 1.

Trade buying near the close of business on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday converted a lethargic session into an active one and lifted the list of active futures to final net gains of 4 to 11 points, slightly under the day's best quotations.

DALLAS, Feb. 27 -- Baseball competes with the war effort and should fold up for the duration, Texas League President J. Alvin Gardner said today, labeling his league's suspension a patriotic sacrifice.
Retail trade continued active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Indications that the WPB has decided to speed up its textile-simplification program to conserve limited manpower and yarns, as well as to utilize available production time on essential civilian items, were seen last week by Worth Street mill representatives following announcement of the knit underwear limitation program which takes effect April 1.

THE Dutchman's breeches (Dicentra cucullaria) of our Eastern woodlands is a familiar plant of the Springtime. Although it is not grown as widely as our old garden favorite, the Bleeding heart (D. spectabilis), which is a native of China and Eastern Asia, no more beautiful plant for a partially shaded spot or rock garden can be found.

FROM exotic to home-made primitive and from ultramodern to ultra-academic ranged the exhibitions of the week. Action by leading retail organizations on a program by which American retailing can take the initiative and leadership in national and world affairs is urged by Harry W. Schacter, president of the Kaufman Straus Company, Inc., Louisville, Ky., in a statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES formulating the principles of the plan.

The Rev. Dr. Elmer A. Fridell, Professor of Homiletics and Practical Theology at the Berkeley Baptist Divinity School, Berkeley, Calif., was elected last week a secretary of the American Baptist Foreign Mission Society, with headquarters at 152 Madison Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

One and one-half-ton Army trucks, as well as administrative cars, are now being driven by the sixty-five members of the Motor Transport Service of the American Women's Voluntary Services, assigned to duty at the New York City headquarters of the Army Air Force, Eastern Procurement District, Materiel Center.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The community of interest and of activity in fields of scientific endeavor was cited here today by Dr. Harlow Shapley of Harvard College Observatory as a hopeful indication that international cooperation was "probably not too difficult in language, in economics and in political administration."

CENTURIES after the assimilation of the Israelites into the population of Assyria, or their absorption by that country's conquerors, the whereabouts of the lost ten tribes was made the subject of animated speculation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- If the "orphans" of prohibition expect to get rich on the "noble experiment" of World War II -- rationing -- they are not reckoning with the average American housewife.

The Brooklyn Baseball Club directors may have made a ten-strike when they named Branch Rickey president, but the Giants are not totally outdone, for yesterday they came up with a "spare," and his name also is Rickey.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Feb. 27 -Dr. Florence Whyte, widely known in educational circles as a teacher of foreign languages, was killed today in the collision of an automobile and a truck in a snow-covered highway in West Norristown Township. Her age was 60.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Feb. 27 -- Fisheries in the State of Parana controlled by Japanese have been declared a public utility. Federal Commissioner Manoel Ribas today expropriated the Japanese Fishing Company, which owns a substantial fleet of speedy launches and a score of large fishing boats, all operating from Paranagua.

SIDELIGHTS on a convoy -- the occupations and preoccupations of the men and all manner of lively incidents connected with the voyage -- are revealed in the straightaway sketches by Clifford Saber, currently on view at the Society of Illustrators.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of two Army mess sergeants, who, it is alleged, stole food from the Camp Kilmer commissary to gain favor of a New Brunswick tavern keeper, whose daughters were their "girl friends."

THIS textbook is a revision of the 1928 edition of "Industrial Engineering and Factory Management." Like the earlier edition, the book is one of broad orientation intended to precede any study of specialized subdivisions of the field.

SEVERAL sculpture shows became current last week. Of these one of the most interesting is that furnished by Bernard Sopher, at the Associated American Artists Galleries. His theme is "War Mothers." The event was described in more detail in our daily column of Wednesday last.

With one exception this column has unreservedly supported the pay-as-you-go plan proposed by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., and still prefers his plan to any of those suggested by the Treasury advisers, by members of the Ways and Means Committee, or by the public in so far as such plans have received public notice.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Nearly 3,400,000 persons had been executed or had died in prison in nine Nazi-occupied countries by the end of 1942, the Inter-Allied Information Committee of the United Nations said in a statement today.

Negotiations have been completed for the purchase by the United Light and Power Company System of the control of the Des Moines Electric Light Company and the Iowa Power and Light Company from the Illinois Iowa Power Company, according to information received here yesterday.

ALTHOUGH the Navy some time ago created camera combat teams for the purpose of providing adequate coverage on action at sea, it and the other branches of the armed forces as yet are often reluctant to let great events find their way onto celluloid.

The transfer of the United States Purchasing Commission to the Bureau of Economic Warfare follows a number of reports from Brazil of friction between the two agencies, which had provoked some comment from Brazilian officials.

VALLEJO, Calif., Feb. 27 -- The greatest medical problem confronting the hundreds of doctors who are operating on the wounded and treating the ills of American soldiers, sailors and marines in the South Pacific is the problem of supply, says a young surgeon who left for the war zone immediately after the Pearl Harbor attack and has just returned as a hospital patient.
CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (A.P.) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

BEATING the official Army Film Unit to the screen by the skin of its teeth, a commercial company -- gallant, independent little Ealing -- has produced the first deglamorized and soldierly picture about the war in the desert.

IN Thomas Jefferson the political philosopher has overshadowed the man in the public mind. The popular impression that he was cold cannot stand the test of scrutiny. True, he did not carry his heart on his sleeve nor admit the stranger instantly to his bosom. But such was his uncanny judgment of men that one penetrating glance, however cold, sufficed.

Claudette Sorel, ll-year-old French pianist, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. The talented child's playing was sensitive and clean. Her tone, if limited in power, was singing, velvety and under firm control.

This column, availing itself of earlier access to some departments of our Sunday paper by a day or so, has already clipped and filed for use Catherine Mackenzie's absorbing story in today's Magazine. It deals with changing fashions in Bringing Up Baby over a period of twenty-nine years.

The new point rationing system gives an advantage to those who can afford to eat in restaurants, or who have to do so because they live in rooms in which they can't cook. There is nothing to prevent any one of us, if he has the cash, from eating up his home allowance and then eating as many restaurant meals as he can hold.

Ten years ago this week the nation was gripped by the worst banking crisis in its history. In the dark March days a decade ago the country reaped the whirlwind of the speculative excesses of the previous ten years. Wall Street, as the financial nerve center of the nation, will not have much time this week under wartime pressure of business to give more than passing recollection to the grim events of 1933.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Feb. 27 -- A picture of Mexico's financial situation is contained in the annual report for 1942 just published by the Banco de Mexico. The report analyzes factors which began to exert their influence when the war in Europe broke out and which since have become more definite features of the economic life of the country.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Colonel Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, told Indiana Republican editors tonight that their party must swing away from the East in its search for leadership.

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 27 -- Berlin's displeasure with Rome's "frivolous attitude" in considering alleged Vatican efforts to mediate the war is reported to have led to the precipitate recall of Diego von Bergen, the German Ambassador to the Holy See, late this afternoon.
As a mariner and navigator I was much interested in your timely editorial "Airplanes and Maps" in the Feb. 21 issue.

America's best-known outboard driver, Fred Jacoby Jr., of North Bergen, N.J., who has won more national high-point scoring championships than any other pancake pilot, became captain in the Army Signal Corps last week.

GAS SAVING -- Officials of the Consolidated Edison Company estimate that in the present oil crisis domestic consumers save as much as a quarter of their normal consumption -an amount of gas requiring approximately 125,000,000 gallons of fuel oil a day to manufacture.

The opening up of new areas for commercial food production under a plan announced last week by major food chains and other distributors in cooperation with State colleges is part of a widespread program for increasing the food supply by eliminating former wasteful practices in the growing and distribution of foods, it was learned yesterday.

The first year of the war has seen an increase in community support and interest in local welfare institutions, George Z. Medalie, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, states in the federation's annual report, issued last week.

TO help the New York Red Cross Chapter meet its enlarged quota for surgical dressings, women's clubs are turning out in force, and two of them are opening special workrooms. Women's City Club members, and non-members as well, are folding dressings in the converted lounge, under supervision of Mrs. Stanley Isaacs, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, and Monday and Wednesday evenings.

A RECENT survey of our institutions enumerated more than 3,000 manuscripts by old European masters, brought over by immigrants in the past centuries, which are unknown and have never been appraised, edited or performed.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- An extensive program of boardwalk modernization will be completed by city officials this week preparatory to the official opening of the Spring season here. This resort, which entertained a record influx of Winter visitors, still offers about seventy-five hotels catering to civilians, with eighty more to be opened for Summer occupancy.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Approximately 500 employes of the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyards who had finished their shift were turned back at the entrance to the plant today in what General Manager J.M. Willis said was an action designed to combat "racing to the gates." All the men were suspended for a day, Mr. Willis added.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio and Wendell L. Willkie are the front runners at this stage for the 1944 Republican Presidential nomination.

AMBASSADOR GREW has told us that Japan in fighting China and the English speaking peoples is working against her own best interests. Ninety per cent of Japan's business was for years with English speaking peoples.

Sailors from the big battleship Richelieu and three other French warships undergoing repairs in American harbors are leaving their craft and trying to get to England to join General Charles de Gaulle's fighting forces, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -Driving hard from start to finish, Dartmouth gained its seventh straight circuit victory by overpowering Pennsylvania, 66 -- 43, before 5,000 persons at the Palestra tonight and strengthened its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League lead.

Consider the following facts: (1) Eleven countries, the United States, Canada, Great Britain, France, Belgium, Holland, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Australia, are the only ones on earth that have had democratic freedom long enough to know from first-hand experience what the blessings of a democratic society are.

We were quietly listening to the story of "Zero Hour" in the Western Desert. As our soldier guest told us how he watched the luminous face of his watch, we felt the tenseness of the last few minutes of waiting. Then the first rays of the morning sun began to touch the little elevation out in no man's land.

AT 4 A.M. on a black Winter night the Navy base was a cold and lonely spot. Several miles away the city was asleep, snug against the gusty dry wind that came out of the northwest. On the bridge of the destroyer an officer took a look overside and ordered: "Starboard engine stop; port engine a third back."

NOT long ago the United States air mails in New York received a small carton. It was about as large as a spool of thread, and weighed less than an ounce. The wartime need for more air mail space might have long delayed a larger package, but not this one, which was soon tossed into a convenient mail bag and forgotten.

President Manuel L. Quezon of the Commonwealth of the Philippines declared yesterday afternoon in a broadcast for the Victory Rally at the Metropolitan Opera House that Mme. Chiang Kai-shek was right in warning the people of this country against the idea that Adolf Hitler was the single most dangerous enemy of the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Governor Dewey issued today a proclamation setting aside the week of March 1 as Victory Book Week and appealing for books to be sent to the men in the armed forces. The proclamation read, in part:

The Garden Journal of the Air is now incorporated as a regular feature of the radio program "Other People's Business," heard Monday through Friday at 11 A.M. over WQXR. Garden problems are discussed and questions answered.

The University of Pittsburgh has considered earnestly how to use classrooms and laboratories most effectively for training young men and women to help win the war. The Army, the Navy and the War Manpower Commission have asked this university, along with other colleges and universities throughout the country, to get young people ready as soon as possible for the fighting forces and for war industry.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Nonresident taxpayers in New York State, whose State income taxes are deducted at the source by their employers, must file returns themselves by April 15 if they wish to obtain the benefit of the new exemptions recently voted by the Legislature, Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration today granted an increase of 60 cents a barrel in the price of soft wheat flour and announced a forthcoming ceiling on the price of soft wheat. Soft wheat flour is used largely for crackers, biscuits and pastry.

All who are familiar with conditions surrounding the teaching of English in our secondary schools are aware of the extraordinary confusion of aims existing in the subject. A report of a Harvard committee on "The Training of Secondary School Teachers -- Especially With Reference to English" suggests that English is one of the few subjects in which the tradition of liberal education can be kept for some 7,000,000 young Americans.

NOW and again a book appears which reminds Americans so strikingly, poignantly, of their indebtedness to the civilization of Europe that they are left wondering how the feeling of intimate comradeship with older peoples could ever have been forgotten.

In preparation for the New York City Red Cross War Fund drive which will get under way tomorrow as part of a national campaign, Mayor La Guardia yesterday proclaimed March as Red Cross War Fund month and called upon "my fellow-citizens" to take part in the campaign and to "give generously so that the quota of $12,920,700 set for the city will be quickly oversubscribed."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A new system of pricing retail cuts of pork is due to be revealed by the Office of Price Administration next Friday.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 -- In a statement published in the newspaper Novedades, Mgr. Luis Maria Martinez, Archbishop of Mexico, placed the full support of the church behind the war effort of the Avila Camacho government and appealed to Mexican youth to cooperate loyally with the authorities by complying with the military measures resulting from the situation created by Mexico's entrance in the war.

Soviet Russia, like every other country at war, has mobilized its scientists to solve war problems. Professor Alexander Baikov, vice president of the Academy of Sciences, has distributed a report on the scientific program for 1943, which we summarize in the following paragraphs:

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 27 -France faces the prospect of being without bread for a whole month. The truth is now out. For months past the Vichy government has been striving to dodge the issue. Today it call do so no longer. It continues to appeal to farmers and peasants to deliver every grain of wheat they may still hold and to suggest that the problem may soon be solved.

LONDON, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- Perfectly planned, perfectly timed and hammered home in almost ideal bombing weather, the R.A.F. raid on Cologne last night was believed to have blown wide open all the repair work on the industrial centers in which the Nazis had been engaged since the 1,000-plane assault last May.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Premier Joseph Stalin aroused new doubts about Russia's intentions and the whole future strategy of the war this week by saying that Russia was fighting not for conquest but to rid her territory of the German invaders.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Under cover of the Winter's heaviest rain in Central Tunisia, the Axis army continued its retreat toward a line held at the beginning of the ambitious German attack from Faid Pass on Feb. 14.
MR. PRATT'S heroes are apt to be timid, middle-aged men a bit on the myopic side, who blunder into extraordinary situations, like Mr. Limpet, who turned into a fish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- An increase of $4 a ton in the ceiling price of standard newsprint paper was announced today by the Office of Price Administration and the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 27 -- A number of Belgian airmen who have been training in South Africa have arrived in the Middle East to join South African Air Force squadrons, it was revealed today.

CHANGES in the museum field have been coming so thick and fast of late that the art world must experience difficulty in keeping abreast of them. The most recent of these developments concerns the modern section of the Chester Dale Collection, a considerable portion of which has been sent to the Chicago Art Institute on a basis of indefinite loan.
IF the season thus far has been slowish, what with the general readjustment which the war and its calling of dancers to the colors has made necessary, things are definitely looking up for the Spring.

In the 101-year history of the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra a concert has never been canceled. Only two have been postponed -- one when Abraham Lincoln was assassinated and the other when the conductor, Anton Seidl, died. Last week that record was in danger.

When a layman looks at a Flying Fortress he sees one sleek, streamlined machine. But, as Donald W. Douglas wrote recently, when an aircraft builder looks at the same machine he sees 110,000 separate parts, a goodly number of which were not made in the factory which assembled the plane but flown to the assembly line from some 6,000 plants scattered over the nation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The German Minister of Munitions, Professor Albert Speer, was reported today to have called an urgent conference of 140 of Germany's leading economic experts to discuss means of matching the flood of war materials being turned out by United Nations arsenals.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Treasury is about set for the biggest income tax collection task in its history.

WITH the week of preparation and freeze over, food rationing on the point system gets off to its muddled start tomorrow. Grocers operated at about 25 per cent of their normal volume during the "freeze" week.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Textile foremen and colorists employed in New York City and Northern New Jersey voted unanimously today to strike Tuesday in all dyeing and finishing plants which by that time have not signed a new contract.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA Feb. 27 -- Bitter fighting spread over the mist-shrouded hills and valleys of Tunisia's northern front today after British tanks and infantry had halted a series of sharp German assaults against important British positions yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at City Hall his complete support of the civilian defense program of Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh, under which firemen off duty must report, in case of air raid drills or actual air raid alarms, to their assigned firehouses.

THE art -- or business -- of perfumery is an admixture of poetry, practicality and nonsense. Strangely enough, even in wartime, these incongruous constituents remain. There is the poetry of far places -- exotic essences being shipped through battle-stirred waters to Bermuda, Nassau and the United States, where they sell for fabulous prices.

IT was a piece of good luck that Frederick Machetanz, described by Mr. Stefansson as one of his most valuable Alaskan correspondents, should have started in 1940 to make a plan and to assemble photographs for this volume.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 -- Declaring the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York had failed to carry out a commitment made a year ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission granted the bank today a limited extension until July 15 to dispose of certain securities before it will extend further the bank's request for an exemption from provisions of the Holding Company Act because of other security holdings.

New financing here in February consisted of eleven bond issues aggregating $76,947,000, the only new securities offered for public subscription. The total compared with thirteen bond flotations amounting to $160,901,000 in January and with offerings of twenty-four bond issues totaling $74,735,000 and two stock offerings aggregating $18,675,000 in this month a year ago.

Your editorial "Doctors and the Army" leads to the impression that the shortage of doctors is more acute than it really is. The fact is there are thousands of doctors who would gladly serve in some capacity who are politely told they're not eligible because they are over the age limit.

TWO weeks before the outbreak of war, Robert Henriques completed "No Arms, No Armour," a novel which, after three years and several readings, I do not hesitate to call great. It was at once a protest and a statement of faith -- a protest against the unyielding rigidity of the military mold, and an essential faith in the flowering of the human personality even in the most unpromising circumstances.

The first group of student soldiers to be assigned to City College under the Army specialized training program is expected to arrive at the college at 139th Street and Convent Avenue during the first two weeks in March, two weeks earlier than previously announced, it was revealed yesterday by Harry N. Wright, president of the institution.

IT is likely that the Metropolitan Opera Association will add two weeks to its regular schedule, besides giving two performances of "Parsifal" in Holy Week. The regular season ends March 13. The new schedule probably would be as follows:

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would discuss with appropriate Federal authorities the problem of the city's growing stockpiles of tin cans, which exceed the present capacity of the only detinning plant equipped to handle unprocessed cans.

RELATIVELY few Americans realize that, apart from all humanitarian considerations, a Federal law and Army regulations require the American Red Cross to render its many services to our armed forces wherever they may go. Today the American Red Cross faces the greatest task in its long history to furnish aid and comfort to our fighting men in the four corners of the world.

ATLANTA, Feb. 27 -- Ten months ago the site of the Bell Aircraft plant at Marietta, almost in the shadow of Kennesaw Mountain, was 3,000 acres of rolling ground, some under cultivation and much of it wooded or dotted with farmhouses.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Although wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner today within a range of 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel, there was considerable activity in the market on the Board of Trade here.

Warning against the application of any new kind of "Darlanism," as it might relate to Italy, through deals with disaffected Fascists, the Italian-American Labor Council asserted yesterday that there can be no compromise with Premier Benito Mussolini or his nine defeated generals now in this country as prisoners of war.

The discovery that a deficiency in biotin, nature's most powerful vitamin, greatly increases susceptibility to malaria, and that an adequate amount of the vitamin will increase resistance to the infection, is reported today in Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

William J. McGeory, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Westchester County, and Martin J. Parkinson, business agent of Westchester Local 137, International Union of Operating Engineers, A.F. of L., were arraigned yesterday afternoon before General Sessions Judge James G. Wallace on charges of having tried to extort $100,000 from a construction company handling an $11,500,000 job at the Delaware water aqueduct project.

IN all of New York City there is no place where the gloom of dimout hangs more oppressively than in the neighborhood candy store -- that barometer of the city's spirits. For the candy stores are wilting and dying by the thousand, "blitzed" by the war.
LONDON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A communique of the Soviet Information Bureau broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Thirty-two pairs remained in the running for the Eastern States contract bridge pair championship, and the Julian Goldman trophy that goes with it, after two qualifying sessions in the first day's play at the Park Central Hotel here yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 27 (AP) -Five American Mitchell Bomber crews shared in one of the most important attacks on Allied shipping in the Tunisian campaign when they scored hits on an oil tanker that was later sunk by planes from Malta, a spokesman for the Northwest Africa Air Forces said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (Science Service) -- Several new United States patents, among the 679 issued during the last week, might well be dedicated to Tantalus, the poor wretch in Roman mythology who could see, but not get, the good things he wanted to enjoy.

. . . A box of "Mendettes" for aluminum utensils. Little aluminum patches come equipped with a nut-and-bolt attachment that screws them firmly in place over the hole. Four in a box for 10 cents at many stores. . . .

IN celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Sorosis, leaders of women's units will join its members tomorrow in a birthday luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria, honoring the group's unique role in the women's club movement.

PAUL ROBESON is an artist who does his best work where his convictions are fully enlisted. There can be no question that they are so enlisted behind Songs of Free Men (Columbia M-534, four ten-inch records).

ILLUSTRATIONS of four pictorials issued by Greece reached New York last week. There is nothing in the inscriptions to indicate Greece is under Axis domination. Values, colors and designs are 2-drachmas green, historic stone and fabric windmill at Mykanos; 15d red-brown, ancient fortress near the Aegean Sea; 25d dark blue, a view in the city of Ydra, in Thessaly; 50d violet, the De Mateora Cloisters, which date back almost 1,500 years.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 27 -- Overwhelming Allied air power applied at precisely the right moment, combined with a series of deftly delivered counter-attacks by British tanks and American infantry and guns this week set the pattern for future operations on a grand scale in Tunisia.

" I'm a guttersnipe," said Marcia Davenport, the author of "The Valley of Decision." She talks rapidly and eagerly. "I'm a wharf rat. I was born in New York and I live overlooking the East River. I expect to go on living there because I must live in the city or I can't work, and near a large body of water or I can't function.

Stimulated by a demand that surpassed any previous short session in more than a year, the stock market pushed yesterday into still higher ground with gains of a point and more. Trading in low-priced issues monopolized the two hours of business on the Stock Exchange and brought the day's volume to 942,870 shares, with 662,000 shares dealt in during the closing hour.

Tomorrow begins the month that carries with it the promises of Spring, but also the darker portents of the Ides of March, and both are likely to prove of greater significance this year than ever in the past. For in a military sense this month marks the end of one war-year and the beginning of a new one.

THE Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, which for many years have staged educational exhibits at the New York Flower Show in Grand Central Palace, are this year offering to the public (in the absence of the flower show) a substitute in the form of a Garden Week, to be presented, in cooperation with THE NEW YORK TIMES, in the Times Hall, formerly the Little Theatre, at 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Representative J.W. Fulbright of Arkansas, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, who is a former professor and college president, was applauded heartily at the third annual meeting of the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace, at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, when he expressed the belief that a majority of the new members of the House of Representatives "are already eager to create a world organization to prevent war."

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- In all the confusion and lack of specific post-war planning now evident both in Washington and in London, a great fog has arisen concerning the all-important peace objectives of the Soviet Union, specially as regards the territorial claims.

STEFAN ZWEIG'S autobiography, finished before the author's tragic death in South America last year, will be released next month by Viking. The title will be "The World of Yesterday." . . . Professor Allan Nevins of Columbia has written a "reverse" side to his "Brief History of the United States" and "America: The Story of a Free People," prepared for British consumption, and undertaken for the British Ministry of Education.

The robins were not only out and around, early last week; they were bragging about it. And the cardinals were making quite a to-do. Dour observers said the robins probably had been here most of the Winter, and the cardinals certainly weren't newcomers. But they were exuberant at the unexpected touch of April.

UNDOUBTEDLY you are anticipating the start of point-rationing -- the program becomes effective tomorrow -- by wondering how best you can stretch your share of processed foods. Solution to the problem is advanced by the Office of Price Administration, which suggests four ways of getting along successfully on restricted amounts of tinned and bottled and frozen goods.

With Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne as guests of honor, the Studio Club of the Y.W.C.A., 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, will give an open house party this afternoon for men and women in the armed forces. Waves, Waacs, Spars, soldiers, sailors, marines and Coast Guardsmen have been invited to the fete, which will be featured by an informal entertainment program.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Allied forces chased Japanese forward elements back in the Wau-Mubo area of Northeastern New Guinea yesterday and the enemy left many dead, General Douglas MacArthur disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Mgr. John A. Ryan of Washington, director of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, writing in The Post-Dispatch tonight, said that Hitler, Mussolini, their chief associates and the Japanese war lords should be put to death by the United Nations as punishment for their crimes.

Penick Ford, Ltd., Inc., manufacturer of corn, sugar cane and maple products, reported yesterday in its annual report for 1942 a net profit of $1,608,087, equal to $4.36 a share. Earnings include a post-war credit of excess profits tax of $304,821. Excluding this post-war credit, 1942 earnings were equal to $3.53 a share.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- The Florida Winter tourist season now drawing to a close has been comparatively inconspicuous, but it has been a season nevertheless. There has been little or none of the usual fanfare, for the simple reason that neither visitors nor permanent residents were in a mood to place an accent on social diversions.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) -- Ursula Parrott was acquitted today of three charges growing out of smuggling Private Michael W. Bryan from a military stockade where he was a prisoner for being absent without leave.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 -- The Red Wings seized sole leadership of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the cellar-dwelling New York Rangers, 7 to 1, before 9,586 spectators at Olympia Stadium. Harry Watson and Carl Liscombe each tallied twice as Detroit established a new all-time club scoring mark for one season.

CRAIG WOOD never thought the day would come when he would enter a hospital eagerly and hope that the doctors might order an immediate operation. His back has been bothering him of late, however, and the National Open champion hospitalized himself this weekend to try to discover just what is wrong with his vertebrae.

WRITING with warm sympathy and the imagination which can re-create the past, Mrs. Lansing makes an outstanding figure and an extraordinary personality of the fifteenth century very much alive for readers of today.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- One of the dullest and most peaceful buildings in London these days is the musty old structure in Whitehall's King Charles Street bearing the simple sign "India Office." Any one who crosses its threshold with the expectation of finding himself in an atmosphere of tension arising from the latest developments in India can be excused if, upon finding none of these things, he things he has knocked at the wrong door.

IF H.L. Mencken had thought of it soon enough, he now says, he would, after calling his first autobiographical book "Happy Days," have called the second not "Newspaper Days" but "Happy Days II," and then have called the third of them "Happy Days III" instead of "Heathen Days" as he has done.

MR. SAROYAN'S first novel, long awaited but never really expected, is almost exactly what one would have expected if one had really expected a novel out of Saroyan. Though it is a fairly short novel, it succeeds, like his stories and plays, in being discursive.

THE author, a vice president and chief engineer of a leading aircraft corporation, has undertaken in this manual "* * * to enable men experienced in aircraft work to broaden their knowledge and to assist men without aircraft experience to acquire a knowledge of the materials * * * and the processes * * *."

BRITAIN has stopped inflation dead in its tracks; the United States hasn't. In Britain the cost of living has been pegged; in the United States it is advancing at the dangerous rate of 1 per cent per month. In Britain people are confident that prices will stay put till the war ends; in the United States there is greater inflationary danger now than at any period prior of the war.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 27 -Fordham brought its regular basketball season to a close today by defeating Army, 68 to 42. The score tells the story of the game, with the cadets after the first six minutes of the game simply unable to penetrate the Maroon defense and the New Yorkers breaking fast to drop in baskets from all over the floor.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- After more than eighteen months' fierce intermittent civil warfare in Yugoslavia, secret armistice negotiations between envoys of General Draja Mikhailovitch and certain partisan groups now are going on and there is a fair prospect of their success.

A half-ton of Axis propaganda was seized and seven German enemy aliens were arrested by Federal agents in sixty-four spot search raids in metropolitan New York yesterday and Friday night, E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Two new rebuffs for President Roosevelt are strongly indicated in the Senate, but the White House was authoritatively represented as not greatly perturbed over the current Congressional discord. Nose counts by Administration leaders indicate that a majority of the Senate is likely to support a modified version of the bill by Senator McKellar to require Senate confirmation of federal appointees paid more than $4,500 a year.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 27 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Star, in a dispatch from its Washington correspondent, said tonight that Wendell L. Willkie's candidacy for the 1944 Republican Presidential nomination would be entered in the thirteen States having primaries for selection of delegates to the national convention.
OTTAWA, Feb. 27 -- On Tuesday evening Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley will present to Parliament its fifth war budget.
THE armies of the Confederacy held many individualists, from "Extra Billy" Smith to Thomas Jonathan Jackson. But they had, perhaps, no more individual individualist among them than John Hunt Morgan.

Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York Racing Commission and also head of the Turf Committee of America, has been voted the man who did most for racing in 1942. The award came as the result of a vote by the members of the New York Turf Writers Association, who also honored Mrs. John D. Hertz, trainers Ben Jones and John Gaver and Jockey George Woolf.
Judge Edward R. Finch of the Court of Appeals announced last night that he planned to retire from the bench soon to return to private law practice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -Reporting "increasing evidence of the inadequacy of present controls," Secretary Stimson wrote the Senate Military Committee today strongly endorsing a bill providing for the compulsory control of manpower.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Aided by a grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the Library of Congress is prepared to begin the general distribution of records of American folksongs.

FRIENDS of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children will fill Henry Miller's Theatre Tuesday night for the benefit preview of "Harriet," the new play starring Helen Hayes and based on the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe.

HAPPILY timed to the rise in the birth rate, that famous bulletin of the United States Children's Bureau, "infant Care," is out in a new edition. At 10 cents a copy, and with annual distribution above the million mark, it is the nation's best seller. Several times revised, "Infant Care" has been in print since 1914.

WOMEN are bound to take a more active part this season in growing the food to fight the war because new labor will be so badly needed. The question whether there is enough labor on the farms to plant and harvest the crops and tend the livestock needed to meet the national food production goals is of intense public interest.

American eating habits last week were changing rapidly. The announcement of point values in the rationing of canned foods made it clear that civilians would get less than half their previous annual consumption. To a nation which is the world's greatest consumer of canned goods the new order meant a kitchen revolution.

WRIGHT FIELD, DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 27 (U.P.) -- The Army Air Corps reported today the development of a helicopter, a new type of aircraft having extensive possibilities as an arm for land or sea forces, as well as in civilian aviation after the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- While large supplies of short staple low grade cotton are on hand, United States supplies of the higher grade and longer staples of upland cotton are relatively small, the Department of Agriculture said today in a report on carryover and production of the last two seasons.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27--Harvard was master of both offense and defense throughout to beat Yale, 4 to 1, in the opening of the annual series between the nation's oldest collegiate hockey rivals tonight.

Robert Perkins Post had been a newspaperman during the last ten of his thirty-two years. He had worked with uncommon courage through the Battle of Britain. He had reported other world-shaping events: land and sea battles, tremendous aerial conflicts, startling political twists and changes, the fall of great nations.

GREENFIELD, Mass. NEITHER below zero weather nor the OPA ban on pleasure driving has been able to keep either performers or subscribers away from the concerts of the Pioneer Valley Symphony Orchestra.
Displaying its best game of the season, the City College quintet routed St. Francis last night on the Beavers' court, 58 to 46. City now holds a 21-to-1 edge in the series that started in 1921.

Mr. Byrnes's speech on inflation on Feb. 9 was notable, as your editorial pointed out, for its attempt to claim credit for effectively abolishing the now fantastic forty-hour week, while really doing nothing of the kind. It was just another example of the double-talk which sometimes seems characteristic of the New Deal.

More than 3,000 retailers organized as the New York State Food Merchants Association yesterday warned Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, that the "black market threatens the entire retail food distribution picture unless a practical attitude is immediately taken by Office of Price Administration pricing executives."

Recommendations that the United Nations organize, as a "continuing conference" to prepare a program for a better world based upon the principles of the Atlantic Charter, with a bill of human rights, disarmament of conquered nations, substitution of the concept of "trusteeship" for imperialism, and joint settlement of social, economic and political problems without recourse to war, were made yesterday in a 13,000-word report issued by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.
Certain inaccurate statements and implications contained in the letter of D.W. Bell, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, published in THE TIMES some months ago, should be clarified.

NOT "ships and shoes and sealing wax," but shoes and steaks and electric irons, puzzle the average consumer -- shoes, nutrition, home-repairs. Left alone with his ration book, he finds himself at sea. (The generic term "he" is used because it appears that men are more confused than women, or, at least, contrary to cliche, ask more questions.)

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- Undramatically, but none the less relentlessly, Hitler keeps up his war at sea. Air raids against strategic British cities have ceased for the time being but without surcease since the war began the Germans have been harrying Allied sea communications with their submarines, long-range bombers and mines.

Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said last week: "The submarine, most emphatically, is still a very grave menace. There is nothing on which to predicate any sanguine hopes for its early stoppage or cure."

HOLLYWOOD will pay tribute to the heroic resistance of the Russian civilian population against the Nazi invasion with at least three important pictures this year. The Samuel Goldwyn production of Lillian Hellman's "The North Star" is already under way; Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will launch its "Russia" this coming week and preparations are being made at Twentieth Century-Fox for the filming of the Konstantin Siminoff play, "The Russian People."

" EFN de Lawd has ever yit made a mistake, well, ain't nobody ever kotched him," says Mr. Bradford's black evangelist. "A heap er times hit do look like he kind er bit off mo'n he kin chew, an' a heap er times hit look like he got hisse'f way out on a limb.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- The Union of South Africa, with one eye cocked for its own future in the post-war world, is at the same time continuing to play a big part in the United Nations' effort to knock out the Axis, and there is a likelihood that the fighting "springboks" will play an even bigger part before the conflict ends.
A movement has been started in many States to relieve taxpayers of some of their burden by reducing or abolishing State income taxes for the duration of the war.

ELSIE DINSMORE, the Bobbsey Twins, and the Five Little Peppers would be staple soldiers' reading rations from Buna to Algiers had not the book-sorters on the 1943 Victory Book Campaign caught them and thrown them out.

READING "Congo Song" is very much like reading a movie -- a good, engrossing one. There is a fine exotic back ground -- a botanical station set high on a mountain slope in equatorial Africa, with the seething jungle below and snow-capped mountains beyond.

POONA, India, Feb. 27 -- We can see how much Indian polities centers around the frail old man who has been hovering on the edge of death for more than two weeks here in the Aga Khan's ugly Victorian building with its pretentious name of the Yerroda Palace.

Next Sunday the Providence County Kennel Club will make the experiment of putting on a dog show for the benefit of breeders and exhibitors under wartime conditions without the formalities and frills that usually accompany an all-breed exhibition.
Soil-starved city dwellers, whose acquaintance with chickens is limited to the pot and the eggcup, can appease their longing for the simple life of the country by visiting Macy's fifth floor.

LONDON, Feb. 27 -- At Fighting French headquarters in London there is a storm door which has painted on it "Sortie" and "Entree" and "Entrance" and "Exit." Everybody reads the signs, hesitates, then goes the wrong way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- In 1936, three years before her armies invaded Poland and precipitated the war in which the United States has become involved, Germany completed her final plans for the rationing program she was to invoke when the world conflict came.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Will President Roosevelt run for a fourth term? What are his chances for re-election if he does?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Thousands of workers in the Boeing plants on the Pacific Coast laid down the tools and left the machines by which the great Flying Fortresses are made in protest this week against the length of time it has taken the War Labor Board to pass on higher wage demands.

IN view of the internal rumblings in Germany caused by disasters on Russian battlefields and the renewed signs of uneasiness among Nazi party chieftains, the role of Heinrich Himmler and his ruthless secret police becomes more and more significant. Himmler, the man who looks like a village schoolmaster and acts like a fiend is different from most Nazi leaders; he tries to keep out of the limelight.

WITH this volume Mr. Hylander, who has already given us "Out of Doors in Spring," in Summer and in Autumn, rounds out the year. All four of these books are appealing and useful, but perhaps this latest volume has an especial value since it encourages us to realize that the outdoor Winter world, often thought to be dead and desolate, is very much alive and full of beauty and interest.

The four-year medical technology program offered by the Washington Square College of Arts and Science of New York University, in collaboration with three local hospitals, has been approved by the Council on Medical Education and Hospitals of the American Medical Association, Professor William McTavish, director of the program, reported yesterday to Dean Charles Maxwell McConn.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Admiral Wililam F. Halsey presented a Distinguished Service Medal today to the man whom he described as chiefly responsible for the rout of the Japanese fleet in the Battle of Midway -- Captain Miles R. Browning of Mountain Lakes, N.J., his chief of staff.

GUAYULE -- Several hundred tons of guayule rubber -- the first natural rubber to be produced on an industrial scale in the United States since Pearl Harbor -- is now being extracted for war needs by the Forest Service. The rubber is processed chiefly from an old plantation of guayale purchased by the government in the Salinas Valley of California.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A one-year extension of the Lend-Lease program was approved unanimously today by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs in a report which declared that the act has operated "with brilliant effectiveness" as "an essential part of our mechanism for waging war."

American and Canadian soldiers in Britain are beginning to influence the British way of talking, says Geoffrey Whitworth, director of the British Drama League. The league is making phonograph records to save what it can of "the traditional British accent." One would like to ask Mr. Whitworth, what accent?

Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin" was presented in concert form last night at Town Hall by Michel Kachouk's Russian Opera Company. Unlike Glinka's "Russlan and Ludmilla" and Dargomyzhsky's "Russalka," which preceded it in the company's current series, the Tchaikovsky work was not unfamiliar in this city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- A total debt reduction of $300,735,471 during 1942 by thirty-five Class I railroads was reported today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Expansion and clarification of the system under which the State takes over unclaimed moneys and property after a period of years is proposed in a series of bills to be introduced Monday night by Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee and Chairman Wicks of the Senate Finance Committee.

A new set of human values is being forged in the vast furnace of the war, and the teacher must be ready to train the young people of America to reorient themselves to a vastly changed world, Dr. Arthur S. Roberts, chairman of the Secondary Education Board, told 1,000 teachers yesterday at the board's eighteenth annual conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt directed the Navy Department today to return to private management tomorrow the plants of the Triumph Explosives, Inc., at Elkton, Md., which were seized Oct. 13 following Justice Department charges of "numerous instances of bribery in the Triumph Company management."

Furniture and other consumer durable goods may soon be channeled into areas of critical shortage by means of an entirely new method of controlled distribution, it was learned here last week. Under the proposal, as developed by the National Retail Furniture Association, retailers in these areas would receive preference ratings for replacing goods sold to migrant workers in order to offset the fact that manufacturers' allotments usually fail to take into consideration increases in population.

THE war has made it necessary that several hundred thousand young men must be trained as weather observers, navigators and pilots. Most of them entered the service unable to tell an aneroid barometer from a wet-and-dry-bulb thermometer.

Buying continued at a brisk pace last week in the wholesale markets, a reflection of sustained consumer purchasing, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 23 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Admiral Wililam F. Halsey presented a Distinguished Service Medal today to the man whom he described as chiefly responsible for the rout of the Japanese fleet in the Battle of Midway -- Captain Miles R. Browning of Mountain Lakes, N.J., his chief of staff.

The rubber is processed chiefly from an old plantation of guayale purchased by the government in the Salinas Valley of California.

The league is making phonograph records to save what it can of "the traditional British accent." One would like to ask Mr. Whitworth, what accent?

Unlike Glinka's "Russlan and Ludmilla" and Dargomyzhsky's "Russalka," which preceded it in the company's current series, the Tchaikovsky work was not unfamiliar in this city.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 -- Expansion and clarification of the system under which the State takes over unclaimed moneys and property after a period of years is proposed in a series of bills to be introduced Monday night by Chairman Moffat of the Ways and Means Committee and Chairman Wicks of the Senate Finance Committee.

Roberts, chairman of the Secondary Education Board, told 1,000 teachers yesterday at the board's eighteenth annual conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- President Roosevelt directed the Navy Department today to return to private management tomorrow the plants of the Triumph Explosives, Inc., at Elkton, Md., which were seized Oct. 13 following Justice Department charges of "numerous instances of bribery in the Triumph Company management."

Furniture and other consumer durable goods may soon be channeled into areas of critical shortage by means of an entirely new method of controlled distribution, it was learned here last week. Under the proposal, as developed by the National Retail Furniture Association, retailers in these areas would receive preference ratings for replacing goods sold to migrant workers in order to offset the fact that manufacturers' allotments usually fail to take into consideration increases in population.

THE war has made it necessary that several hundred thousand young men must be trained as weather observers, navigators and pilots. Most of them entered the service unable to tell an aneroid barometer from a wet-and-dry-bulb thermometer.

Buying continued at a brisk pace last week in the wholesale markets, a reflection of sustained consumer purchasing, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 27 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Tank-led reinforced German forces have driven back General Draja Mikhailovitch's forces during heavy fighting in the Bosnia sector between the Una and Sana Rivers, reports from Yugoslavia indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Gross national product in the fiscal year which ended on June 30 last topped all records, according to the annual report of Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones, released today. The year's total was $133,800,000,000 against $105,900,000,000 for 1941 and $92,800,000,000 for 1940.

Personnel shortages rank second only to the problem of obtaining merchandise, and retailers agree that difficulties in obtaining employes will remain acute in spite of a probable decline in sales volume as the year progresses, according to a survey of wartime personnel problems just completed by the School of Retailing of New York University.

On the eve of point rationing of processed foods, the Regional Office of Price Administration urged housewives yesterday to budget their coupons carefully and appealed to consumers and grocers to have "patience and understanding."

A NEW broom sweeps clean, they say, and such new brooms as Owner Bill Cox and Manager Bucky Harris certainly have plenty to sweep in their efforts to whisk the Phils into the pennant. They need a lot more at Philadelphia besides the franchise, Danny Litwhiler and good intentions. Baseball no longer is run from the top down as it was in the days of John McGraw.
MONTREAL, Feb. 28 (AP) -- On its last visit to Montreal of the National Hockey League regular season, Toronto outscored the Canadiens, 4 -- 2, tonight before 11,880 fans.

A program designed to obtain arbitration of grievances of the 27,000 employes of the city-owned transit system and a workable and enduring basis for collective bargaining between the city and the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., was adopted yesterday by a convention of 500 union delegates at Transport Hall, 153 West Sixtyfourth Street.

KHARKOV, Russia, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- German forces, occupying Kharkov in a sixteen-month reign of terror, systematically destroyed the city's educational and cultural institutions in an effort to reduce the Ukranian population to illiteracy.

The sixteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season, which will be the last of the regular season, beginning on March 8, will be featured by Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung," the fourth and last performance of the only unabridged Ring Cycle of the season.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Demand for hog products shows no signs of abating and brokers are of the opinion that the sooner rationing is inaugurated, the better it will be for all concerned.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Trading in corn futures on the Board of Trade here came to a halt late last week as persistent talk of a higher ceiling level caused sellers to withdraw from the market.

The farm is increasingly in our minds these days as point rationing begins and the tin can recedes into the distance. The city eye has always looked longingly toward the country. Now there is added reason to do so.

Entries in the Thomas Jefferson bicentennial essay contest closed yesterday with a total registration of 403 city high schools and seventh and eighth year elementary schools. This included a 100 per cent representation of the fifty-four senior public high schools in the five boroughs.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The Tunisian battles have taken precedence over all other developments in the war situation in the past week, so far as the stock markets are concerned.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- After starting heavily under the influence of discomforting news from Tunisia, Prime Minister Winston Churchill's disquieting illness and renewed fears about the Indian political situation, the stock markets in London took a decided turn for the better in the closing two days of last week and finished with sentiment more cheerful than at any other time in the past month.

Multitudes of individuals are saying what is the use in a time like this of respecting the old conventions, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor, in his sermon yesterday in the Riverside Church.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- The United State's Army school where American technicians teach British crews how to operate and maintain American arms also promotes Anglo-American friendship.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 28 -- Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, honorary president of the National League of Women Voters, issued a statement today through the Westchester League of Women Voters, opposing the equal rights amendment now before Congress.

Although the control of our fishing resources may sound like a remote topic, it is the concern of many and a subject upon which there is likely to be considerable discussion and some action before the war is over.

The American Red Cross turns to the American people today for the $125,000,000 it needs to carry on its work during the coming year. The appeal comes from the President of the United States, who by virtue of his office is president of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- How machinery set up for more efficient conduct of the war may serve in solving the problems of peace was pointed out today by William L. Batt, Vice Chairman of the War Production Board who made public the report on the first year's operations of the Combined Materials Board in directing the assignment and procurement of raw materials in the United Nations' war effort.

A New York pair, Jules Tilles and Abe Goldstein, won the Goldman Cup in the Eastern States contract bridge championship play at the Park Central Hotel last night, barely nosing out the favored pair of Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York and Charles H. Goren of Philadelphia.

The flags of the recently organized Army Ambulance Emergency Corps were blessed yesterday afternoon by dignitaries of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths at a ceremony in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

KEARNY, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Four destroyers, one named after a hero of the attack on Pearl Harbor, were launched here today, two at a time, by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company. They brought to five the number of destroyers launched this month at the yard of the United States Steel Corporation subsidiary.

The Nazi-controlled Kalundborg radio in Denmark reported yesterday that a bombing in which "four female members" of the German occupying forces were injured on Thursday was an "attempted assassination," but the broadcast did not name the intended victim.

SEATTLE, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Aircraft workers, sending telegrams blaming the War Labor Board for unrest, absenteeism and slowdowns, polished the last details of their twenty-four-hour a day protest meetings which will start in the morning.

All up and down the East Coast the First Fighter Command is broadcasting an urgent S O S for volunteers. Civilian workers, briefly replaced by Waacs; are needed again in aircraft warning centers from Maine to Florida, not only to chart the courses, of all planes in the vicinity and to be prepared for any emergency, but also to help in training Army pilots for fighting overseas.

The 250,000 persons on the rolls of the Department of Welfare, who have found the family market basket a little fuller in the last two years because of the Federal Marketing Administration's stamp plan for distributing surplus foods to low-income families, were reminded yesterday that they have until midnight on March 31 to use up the orange and blue stamps purchased during February.

The Red Cross, internationally known and respected now as a symbol of mercy, owes its beginning to the horror felt by Henri Dunant, a young Swiss, when he visited the battlefield of Solferino in the France-Austrian War in 1859 and did what he could to relieve the sufferings of the wounded Austrian, French and Italian soldiers there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared his opposition today to War Department plans for an 8,200,000man army in 1943, stating that war production would decrease and "this would be fatal."

The actual production of seagoing tonnage suitable for participation in the war, turned out by American shipyards in 1942, was 719 vessels with a carrying capacity of approximately 8,000,000 deadweight tons and measuring 5,341,378 gross tons, according to a review of the year's shipbuilding activities by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president of the American Bureau of Shipping.

The American Tobacco Company last year did the largest volume of business in its history, George W. Hill, president, declared in the annual report for 1942, being mailed to stockholders today. Consolidated net sales amounted to $442,152,203, an increase for American Tobacco alone of $71,800,853 over 1941, when consolidated sales were $336,638,665.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- Efforts by New York State to safeguard its $500,000,000 stake in the unemployment insurance reserve fund are discouraged by officials of the Federal Social Security System, it was reported to the Legislature today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 28 -- British Eighth Army guns continued to hammer the German positions in the Mareth Line yesterday, supplementing the aerial bombardment that continued to reduce the enemy's defenses and airfields. German guns replied, but not strongly.

If the air raid drill scheduled for 9 P.M. tomorrow is "satisfactory," the next one will be a "surprise," with no advance notice to the public, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in his weekly radio talk from City Hall.

Addressing 750 college students yesterday at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, Mayor La Guardia declared that it was up to the younger generation "to take over the sorry mess our generation has made of the world" and to correct the mistakes of the past.

Robert P. Post of THE TIMES was one of six American reporters who rode in the bombers that attacked Wilhelmshaven last Friday. He was in one of the bombers that did not come home. We do not suppose that he or his companions regarded their trip as a special act of courage.

Under the terms of the Geneva Prisoners of War Convention of 1929, the International Red Cross Committee is the official agency for gathering and forwarding information about prisoners of war to their home lands. Most of the belligerent countries, including Japan, have announced their intention of abiding by the convention.

In the United States and in Great Britain it seems to be taken for granted that this war is a Christian crusade, but it is well to remember that non-Christian peoples are to be numbered among our allies, said J. Hutton Hynd, leader of the St. Louis Ethical Society, addressing the morning service of the New York Society of Ethical Culture yesterday, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

After having been in the family for almost 200 years, the property at 113-15 University Place, northeast corner of Thirteenth Street, has been sold by the estate of William Remsen to the Westflat Realty Corporation, Jacob Freidus, president, for investment.

Continued "scare" buying at retail led to increased efforts to replenish stocks and to additional commitments on Fall merchandise, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- A bill establishing a State Youth Correction Authority to cope with the problem of rehabilitating the increasing number of youthful offenders who run afoul of the law by a "sharp wartime rise in juvenile crime" will be introduced tomorrow by Senator Desmond of Newburgh.

Increased taxes, the change-over to war production and reserves established to cover the change-back cut the net profit of the Chrysler Corporation in 1942 to $15,529,013 from $40,114,420 in 1941, according to the annual report, released yesterday. This is equivalent to $3.57 a share, against $9.22 in 1941.

Bacterial decay in rubber, demonstrated as possible in recent researches by Dr. Claude ZoBell of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, is probably inhibited by the action of two chemicals commonly used as accelerators of the rubber curing process, Science Service reports.

Soundly trounced by Fordham last week, the N.Y.U basketball team goes into action twice this week and for an opener the Violet will be confronted by anything but a set-up. Because on Wednesday night, at Madison Square Garden, Howard Cann's quintet will have to collide with St. John's, in the big game in this area.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- The Government of India disclosed tonight that it had considered entering into a direct mutual aid agreement with the United States as it submitted an estimated $830,000,000 war and civil budget.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The German High Command announced today the recapture of the important Russian railway centers of Lozovaya and Kramatorsk, below Kharkov, and the Red Army acknowledged "serious counterattacks" in this area, where the Russians had sought to drive south to the Sea of Azov and trap huge Nazi armies in the Donets Basin.
Assets of the Kansas City Life Insurance Company increased $7,685,168 during 1942 to a new high record of $138,522,397, the annual statement disclosed yesterday.
Sir George Bettesworth Piggott and Lady Piggott will return to the Plaza on Wednesday from Palm Beach, Fla.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Although most of the pre-war links that bound the Wall Street and London markets together have been snapped again as they were in the first World War, it is not without significance, especially in view of Wall Street's present revival, that London again is taking some interest in the doings of its New York counterpart.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Two hundred "government girls," the vanguard of a multitude destined eventually to occupy twelve government-built dormitories in this metropolitan area, are scheduled to move today into the first to reach completion, at Arlington Farms Va.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- B.C. Moise announced his resignation today as president of War Materials, Inc., the government agency organized seven months ago to salvage scrap for the war.
MOSCOW, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -While the French were being told today that the outlook for bread was "terrible," Chief of Government Pierre Laval was announcing the definitive construction of the "French militia," which is to be his Praetorian Guard.

THE list of Allied lost opportunities, political and military errors and miscalculations, gallant and inept campaigns foredoomed from the beginning by the prevailing policy of "too little and too late" is lamentably long. One of the most pitiful and the most strategically disastrous of them all was the Burma campaign. There nearly everything went wrong with such fatal persistence that no aspect of war's cruel calamity seems to have been absent.
