LONDON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Brig. Gens. H. S. Hansell Jr. of San Antonio, Texas, and Frank A. Armstrong of Asheville, N.C., flew with the American Flying Fortress and Liberator formations that dumped tons of bombs on Brest yesterday, United States Army Air Force Headquarters announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -Laird Cregar will be featured by Twentieth Century-Fox in a picturization of Mrs. Belloc Lowndes's story, "The Lodger." Originally published in 1913, it is a mystery yarn of London in the eighteen eighties.

The inflationary character of legislative developments last week resulted in cotton prices advancing to the highest levels in fourteen years. Net gains for the period were 22 to 37 points, or $1.10 to $1.85 a bale, with the distant options on the New York Cotton Exchange registering the sharpest advances.

ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 27 (Delayed) -- Premier Sukru Saracoglu and the Soviet Ambassador, Sergei Vinogradoff, dined with the British Ambassador, Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, and the Chinese Minister to Ankara, as guests of the American Ambassador, Lawrence D. Steinhardt, tonight.

The New Friends of Music's series of chamber music concerts in Town Hall for this season closed yesterday afternoon with a program performed by the Budapest Quartet with Luigi Silva, 'cello, as assisting artist. Three eighteenth-century works were presented, comprising the Haydn quartets, Op. 76, No. 4, and Op, 77, No. 1, and the rarely heard Suite, No. 5, in C minor, for unaccompanied 'cello, by Bach.

We must not be tripped up by the hope of any panacea in our approach to a just and durable peace, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton said in his sermon yesterday in the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

- 16-year-old junior at Samuel J. Tilden High School, Arthur Okun, was announced yesterday as the winner of three first prizes in tile Regional Scholastic High School Art Exhibit opening today at Macy's. The show includes 1,100 exarnples of art work by boys and girls in 140 high schools of Greater New York.

In an appeal yesterday for nationwide support of Victory Book Week,-which opens today, James Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said the United States now had the best educated _Army in the country's history.

Maintenance of war oil supplies and the nation's underground oil reserves are being threatened seriously by governmental policies affecting essential producing equipment and prices for crude oil and petroleum products, Henry M. Dawes, president of the Pure Oil Company, declared in the annual report to stockholders issued for publication today.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Like almost every other country in East Europe, the political differences of Czechoslovakia, both within and without that occupied land, are based on a cleavage in attitude toward Soviet Russia. These differences cannot be considered too great and, on the whole, the Czechoslovak Government here has managed to play an exceedingly clever diplomatic game.

NORTH CREEK, N.Y., Feb. 28 -A skiing event that for months has excited this Winter sports center was held today in superb snow conditions. The community's youngsters, whose brothers are in many arms of the service, particularly the "Fighting Mountaineers" at Camp Hale, participated in the first grade school ski "championships" with an enthusiasm worthy of international competition.

The housewives' introduction to the food rationing point plan this morning will be made as painless as possible. For the last week store and super-market personnel have been undergoing intensive schooling in the intricacies of the point system and charts and tables have been prepared.

After a plane trip from Florida, Lippy Leo Durocher, manager of the Dodgers, conferred yesterday with Branch Rickey at the club president's Bronxville home and said that he was all set to join the Army today, if wanted.

To be careless about or indifferent to religion is to undercut the foundations of our democracy and to be subversive of the best interests of the State, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, declared in a sermon there yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 28 -After six contests today that started the Spring series of sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club there was a first-place point tie between Jack Sutphen and his craft Rum Dum and Howard McMichael and his Ordeal.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced for the seventh consecutive week. The index is now at a new high level of 111.1, compared with 111.0 last week and 103.1 last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today attended services at Foundry Methodist Church, worshiping in the faith to which her illustrious father, Charles Soong, was converted in his youth.

In the spacious quarters of W. J. Sloane at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, the clock will be turned back today a hundred years to the firm's founding by William Sloane with a small shop at 245 Broadway.
LONDON, Monday, March 1 (U.P.) -- The midnight Soviet communique, broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Now celebrating its first anniversary, the Ecole Libre -- Franco-Belgian unit of the New School for Social Research -- deserves warm congratulations. During the past twelve months this unique institution has more than fulfilled its early promise of helping to keep alive the culture and the heritage of the old France at its best.

The long-predicted "round-the-clock" bombing of Germany is at last apparently under way. Bad weather may from time to time set the clock back. But Allied air superiority is now so great that henceforth we may expect a fairly regular schedule of American raids by day and British raids by night.

The twelve-story office building with stores at 1841-43 Broadway, northwest corner of Sixtieth Street, overlooking Columbus Circle, was sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to Leo Silver, the operator. The latter, who was represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, acquired the property in the name of Land Properties, Inc.
Newspapers will carry the major share of two advertising campaigns just released for Spring by Park Tilford, one on behalf of its cosmetics and perfumes and the other for Tintex tints and dyes.

Education of soldiers of the United States Army to respect the customs of Moslems in North Africa was commended in a sermon yesterday morning at the Congregational Church-in-the-Gardens, Ascan Avenue and Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, by the Rev. Franklin P. Cole.
Captain P.J. Deramond, commander of the French battleship Richelieu, with 100 of his officers and men, attended solemn high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The quite fabulous "Lady in the Dark" came back to town last Saturday night, installing her sparkling self and the colleagues of her dreams in the gigantic Broadway Theatre. At the popular prices now demanded and judging from past performances, there seems little reason to suppose they cannot all remain there until the next century or the end of the world, whichever is sooner.

March 1 to 6 will be Victory Book Week, the climax of the Victory Book campaign for interesting reading matter for the men of the armed forces. In one final effort to get the type of fiction and non-fiction the servicemen wish to read, the committee, under the sponsorship of the American Library Association, American Red Cross and the USO, has enlisted the aid of varied groups.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28 -- Americans will have taken "one more step along the totalitarian road" if they ever lose the right and ability to support as citizens such charities as the Red Cross, Wendell L. Willkie said in opening the Red Cross drive here tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- "The postwar world will be a grimmer place than most people realize and members of the British Government have no desire to escape the consequences of their acceptance of the Beveridge report in principle," Clement R. Attlee, Dominions Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister, declared at Ashton-under-Lyne today.

Introduced at Albany at the request of Mayor La Guardia, the CoudertMoffat bill to transfer the purchase of school supplies and materials from the Board of Education to the city's Department of Purchase needs careful study. Although the recent Herlands investigation disclosed "inefficiency and waste" in the schools supply bureau, the present bill is a doubtful remedy.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold to William Roberts the one-family house at 57 Atlantic Street, Jersey City, N.J., through the Equity Real Estate Agency and D.E.C. Somers, Inc.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The International Red Cross organization with headquarters at Geneva started an inquiry today, it was learned here, to ascertain the fate of Robert P. Post, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and members of the crew of the American bombing plane in which he was an observer, that was reported missing in the daylight raid Friday at Wilhelmshaven.

A modest, unassuming young man, known by sports fans the world over as the greatest pole vaulter of all time, accepted from Lawrence di Benedetto, president of the National A.A.U., the greatest award in amateur athletics -- the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy -- at a luncheon at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- The volume of steel orders last week went down slightly from the week before, and at some steel plants was running from 8 to 15 per cent under the corresponding January period. This did not mean, however, that backlogs were being reduced to any extent, because in most instances order volume was still in excess of shipments.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Steve Vassilakos, who, from his peanut vender's stand near a corner of the White House grounds, saw American Presidents come and go for more than thirty years, died today.

The stupendous total of 520,000,000 surgical dressings has been produced by patriotic women working in the production rooms of almost every one of the nation's 3,755 Red Cross chapters since the day of the attack on Pearl Harbor. Statistics are incomplete, but it is estimated that 2,500,000 women have taken part in this task.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, March 1 (U.P.) -- Allied planes, battering at Timor Island southwest of New Guinea, destroyed fourteen Japanese planes and probably destroyed nine more at Kupang yesterday, United Nations Headquarters announced today.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Black Hawks played the second-place Bruins to a 4-4 deadlock tonight before 16,261 in a National Hockey League game at the Chicago Stadium.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- On the eve of scheduled adoption by the Assembly of Governor Dewey's $369,600,000 executive budget, leaders of the Democratic minority in the Legislature charged today that the Republican fiscal program constituted an attempt "to hide the huge surplus" left by Governor Lehman and deny tax reductions this year for political purposes.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Seventy-six organizations representing fifty national and racial groups living in Manhattan's Lower East Side took part yesterday afternoon in a Unity Festival organized by the Lower East Side Defense Council and held in the Educational Alliance, Straus Auditorium, 197 East Broadway.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- The battle in the northwest region of the Donets Basin, which for prolonged violence surpasses any fought in Southern Russia since that at Kotelnikov, is still in progress and the issue still hangs in the balance.

MONTREAL, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Ration coupon banking -- designed to help large retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers of rationed commodities -- will begin tomorrow in branches of chartered banks throughout Canada. The system does not affect the individual consumers, but helps larger dealers in ration coupons by opening "ration coupon accounts" on books at the banks.

The Eastern League definitely will operate during the coming baseball season, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the circuit at the Hotel New Yorker. The only question concerned the number of clubs that will be in business, President Thomas H. Richardson said.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

A minimum of $1,000,000 for Russian War Relief during the year, "with the hope that this will be doubled," was pledged yesterday at the first anniversary conference of The Jewish Council for Russian War Relief, at the Hotel Commodore.

Millions of pints of human blood, freely given by patriotic donors who hope thereby to save the lives of wounded fighting men, are being collected by the American Red Cross at the urgent request of the Army and Navy, because medical officers have reported that dried blood plasma has proved to be the most important single medical tool that the war has produced.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 -- Legislative action in Washington last week carried cotton futures and spots in all positions to the highest levels since 1929. Marked strength in the forward positions, especially the new crop months, sharply narrowed the premiums of the near months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Continued activity by our planes in the Solomons yesterday resulted in bomb hits on a Japanese transport and corvette and the destruction of one enemy plane, the Navy reported today. Our loss was two fighter planes.

Already heavily burdened by wartime demands on its organization, the American Red Cross was also called upon last year to extend relief to the sufferers of more natural calamities than in any year since it began disaster relief work in 1881. It disbursed more than $1,500,000 in helping 130,000 persons affected by these disasters.

Accused of having stolen a large quantity of dairy products and foodstuffs from a Long Island grocery store and of having sold it to local grocers, four youths were arrested yesterday afternoon at Fifty-ninth Street and Eleventh Avenue and taken to the West Sixty-fourth Street station house to await action by the New York State Police.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in February was the largest in more than a year, despite only twenty-two business sessions, and the largest in six years for a corresponding month, or since February, 1937.

Despite the tremendous expansion of industrial production in the United States, net income of 710 leading corporations in 1942 showed an average decrease of 13 per cent from the preceding year, the National City Bank of New York reports in the March 1 issue of its survey of business and financial conditions.

Wherever American fighting men in considerable numbers are stationed, at home or in far-off combat areas, the American Red Cross accompanies them to provide for their welfare and recreation, to keep them supplied with little comforts and luxuries, and to help fight such deadly enemies as boredom, homesickness and flagging spirits.

The Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company last year purchased $6,419,000 of its prior lien mortgage bonds for retirement and to Feb. 5, last, had purchased an additional $1,942,000 of these bonds, Matthew S. Sloan, chairman and president, revealed in the 1942 annual report to stockholders.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday March 1 (AP) -- A communique:

Office of Price Administration inspectors concentrated their drive against pleasure drivers yesterday in the Northern New Jersey area, particularly along the highways leading to the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the George Washington Bridge.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Prices of oats advanced last week to the highest since 1929, May selling on the Board of Trade at 60 1/2 cents a bushel at one time, but the action of the market was largely a reflection of the upturn in other grains, as traders fear large quantities of Canadian grain will come into this country as soon as navigation on the Great Lakes gets under way.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Prices of wheat moved upward to new high levels since the 1928-29 crop year last week. The market jumped 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit, at one time, on Friday as the result of buying induced by the Senate's passing of the Bankhead bill by an overwhelming majority.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek is due in New York this morning to begin a four-day visit. The First Lady of China will be received officially by Mayor La Guardia and after a reception at City Hall, will pay a visit to thousands of waiting countrymen in Chinatown.

The following chart is printed today -- the first day of the first point rationing period -- in the hope that it helps you spend your stamps intelligently. It is suggested that it be used with the Official Table of Point Values for Processed Foods in planning how to budget points.

Sergeant Eugene List dominated yesterday afternoon's Philharmonic-Sympohny Orchestra concert led by John Barbirolli at Carnegie Hall with a brilliant and masterful performance of Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto for piano and orchestra in C minor, Opus 18.

Despite the heavy emphasis by the Treasury on sales of government securities to nonbanking investors, the commercial banks-of the nation in a single month in 1942 bought considerably more of these securities than they acquired during the whole period of the last World War, according to a report of survey of wartime banking released here yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc.

Dave (Doc) Livingstone, who leaves this week to enter the Canadian Navy, celebrated his final home appearance yesterday by getting three goals to help the New York Rovers down the Philadelphia Falcons, 7 to 5, in the star battle of an Eastern Amateur Hockey League double-header at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Top-ranking British Army generals and War Secretary Sir James Grigg indicated today that Britain's armies in three continents were poised and ready to strike a full-scale blow at the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration is considering a plan to provide supplemental rations of fuel oil for householders whose allowance soon may be exhausted through no fault of their own, an OPA spokesman said tonight.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- British bombers soared over the Continent today to round out four days of almost continuous Allied night and day air attacks and close February as the war's month of most devastating and intensified bombing of Nazi-occupied Europe.

A maternity mortality rate set by city welfare authorities as an "irreducible minimum" fifteen years ago already has been lowered, according to the latest figures from the Department of Health's bureau of statistics. For the first seven weeks of 1943, the rate per thousand births is recorded as 1.9, although the goal of health officials in recent years has been to reach 2.2.

POONA, India, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, nearing the end of his his twenty-one-day protest fast, amazed his doctors and friends tonight by his spectacular physical and mental resilience, and the belief prevailed that he would come through the fast safely.

Faced with the danger of being forced to shut down unless $20,000 is raised, the Art Students League of New York, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, held yesterday a mass meeting attended by 400 members and students at which $4,260 in cash was pledged and approximately $4,000 worth of paintings was donated.

Bishop William T. Manning, preaching yesterday morning at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth Avenue and Twentieth Street, asked for a better understanding of the church and urged his listeners to "stand fast in your faith" in these grievous days.

An army of 100,000 volunteers, backed by the cooperation of thousands of business concerns, will launch today the 1943 Red Cross War Fund campaign of New York City, which will seek to raise $12,920,700 here as the city's share of the national goal of $125,000,000.

The bootlegger of the prohibition era was "an ethical business man" compared with the black market operator, the food price chiseler and the others who take advantage of food scarcities to pile up profits for themselves, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly broadcast from City Hall

The coming peace must guarantee the four freedoms, plus complete equality for women, it was agreed yesterday by speakers at a discussion of "Problems of the Peace Table," presented by the International Federation of Business and Professional Women to mark its ninth annual observance of International Day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The story of gangland extortions from moving picture theatre workers in Chicago and the country generally through a conspiracy with members of the movie industry was told here today as a New York grand jury was reported to be delving into the gigantic racket.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A Royal Air Force statement today, explaining the new Northwest African Air Force set-up headed by Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, said that the best brains "of the Allied Nations have been pooled."

Nobody believes any more either that the World War will end everywhere at once or that it will be quickly followed by a definitive peace. This shift from the state of mind prevailing during the last war indicates as clearly as anything how American public opinion has changed.
One of these days a particularly punctual robin is going to appear in Central Park, the restaurants of Greenwich Village aill set their tables out on the sidewalk -- and then it will be Spring.

Composers sometimes say curious things and this, we thought, was manifested when Paul Hindemith was quoted yesterday afternoon at the broadcast of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conducting, in Radio City as having remarked that a composer when creating a piece of music should know what specific purpose he was writing it for, because the days of composing simply for the sake of composing were at an end.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, March 1 -- The German Foreign Minister, Joachim von Ribbentrop, flew to Rome late yesterday in an effort to prevent an extension of the present Italo-German "mediation crisis" in Vatican relations.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The Monterey, newest of the Navy's aircraft carriers, was launched here today at the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation just thirteen and one-half months after laying of the keel.

LONDON, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Any Americans inclined to grumble about wartime food restrictions may be interested to learn that they are probably eating better than Britain's royal family, which is lucky to have meat more than once a week.

March 1 is known to Koreans the world over as their Independence Day. Not that Korea is free, but on that date in 1919 the Korean people declared their independence from Japanese domination, set up their provisional republic and, though driven into exile by Japanese reprisals, have continued to work for independence ever since.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fighter planes have made destructive attacks during the past two days on Japanese objectives in a widespread area of Burma, concentrating their main blows against enemy transport, a British communique said today.

The reaction caused in financial markets week before last by the advance of Rommel in North Africa did not last. When the Allied troops successfully drove back the enemy last week the rise was resumed, both stocks and bonds going to new high levels in a series of "million-share markets."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Congress faces crucial tests, some possibly this week, on questions relating to pay-as-you-go taxes, the farm policy and absenteeism in defense plants.

A youth of twenty-one years, wearing the blue of the Coast Guard, walked casually into the Times Square Service Men's Center shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and suddenly discovered himself the center of a happily excited group. Momentarily abashed by the greeting, he became excited as any one when he found a $50 War Bond thrust into his hands.

Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, is in for a rough evening in Madison Square Garden Friday if past performances are fulfilled in his return bout of twelve rounds against Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgher who formerly held the world welterweight title.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Pyne, Kendall Hollister-Reynolds, Fish Co., established in 1909, will be known beginning today as Mallory, Hollister Co. General partners are Charles H. Mallory, Buell Hollister, George T. Adee, Albert W. Bianchi, Paul W. Havener, Ernest L. Jones, F. Malcolm Minor and William L. Strong Jr.

John Feeney, Irish tenor, gave a benefit recital for the Roman Catholic Church of St. Stephen of Hungary last night at Town Hall, assisted by the St. Jude Girl Choir of that church. Except for the three opening numbers, "Where'er You Walk," from "Semele," by Handel; "My Lovely Celia," by Monro, and "Widmung," by Franz, the singer's program consisted of Irish songs.

The Original Don Cossack Chorus and Dancers, under Serge Jaroff, gave their second New York concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. Again the ensemble attracted a large and enthusiastic gathering, which expressed its approval with ovations after all the offerings.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The scramble of retailers, faced with reduced supplies of merchandise, to find new products to offer their customers may yet develop into a bitter fight between store groups. Recent months have seen many retail chains and independents branching out into fields hitherto considered entirely alien to their line of business.

Volunteer nurse's aides may now be assigned to Army hospitals, under an agreement reached by the Army, the American Red Cross and the Office of Civilian Defense, according to announcement yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the OCD.

A new deal for all concerned has extended the life of "Counterattack" at the Windsor. Scheduled to close on Saturday, the engagement will continue at the same stand tomorrow night. Yesterday's performances were canceled and there will be none today.

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN AIR BASE, in North Africa, Feb. 27 (AP) -- With 180 flak holes in his plane, and both gunners wounded, Lieutenant Dave Bensley, 24 years old, of Alden, N.Y., flew his crippled A-20 low-flying bomber back to its base and a perfect belly-skid landing after strafing forty Axis trucks and other targets.
Five midtown theatres will present new films this week. The schedule follows:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 28 -- Hardhitting British veterans checked German attacks along the entire northern front in Tunisia and launched a counter-attack today in the Medjez-el-Bab area, where the enemy was making a bold bid to cut off the battered town that is the gateway to Tunis.

A program designed to solve the manpower problem on farms and in industry and to accelerate output in war plants was made public yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a report prepared by a special committee headed by Gilbert H. Montague.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Spartan war work is being done by about 400 women at the War Relocation Authority's ten isolated centers for Japanese evacuated from the West Coast.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 28 -To some extent this North African campaign has been the same sort of testing ground for the Americans that Spain was for the Germans. Put in another form, the lessons learned here can be of inestimable value for future and larger-scale movements. Failure to observe them will certainly lead to an unnecessary expenditure of lives and materiel, if not to serious trouble, in bigger campaigns.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Twenty-two additional industrial plants have been selected to receive the Army-Navy production award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work, Under-Secretaries Patterson and Forrestal announced today.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Japanese advances in Western Yunnan Province were admitted by the Chinese today in a High Command communique that also reported fighting in the Provinces of Kwangtung, Hupeh and Shantung.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Roosevelt asked the country today to contribute at least $125,000,000 to the Red Cross for its greatest crusade, "now that we are engaged in a war to decide whether all our concepts of mercy and human decency are strong enough to survive."

Dr. Lynn Stratton Abbott, in 118 E 54th St; Edward Robbins, in 60 Gramercy Park; Mrs. E. Norman Chamberlain, in 179 E 79th St; Claude E. Hamilton Jr., in 130 East End Ave, through the Gresham Realty Co -- Douglas Gibbons Co, brokers.

Their last visit to Madison Square Garden this season was a memorable one for the Red Wings as well as for the 14,857 fans on hand to see them beat the Rangers last night. Sparing the last-place sextet not at all, Jack Adams's scrappy crew romped to a 5-to-1 triumph and strengthened their hold on first place in the National Hockey League race.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Feb. 28 (U.P.) -- Difficult supply problems have hampered the American forces in Tunisia, but today fleets of trucks and American-operated railroads can carry more than enough to supply the forces that have gone to the front in the past two months.

The United States and Great Britain should heed the call of God and stand together to serve. His purpose, the Rev. Harold A. Cockburn, minister of St. Michael's Church, Dumfries, Scotland, declared in the morning sermon yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street.

On Nov. 19, 1941, the Australian cruiser Sydney, a flaming, shell-battered hulk, disappeared over the horizon after a chance meeting with what seemed to be a harmless merchantman cruising along in the South Pacific. The entire ship's company of 645 men vanished with the Sydney.
A German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The New York Federal Reserve District, which includes this State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., is by no means participating in the war boom to the extent achieved on the average by the remainder of the nation, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declares in its monthly review of credit and business conditions for publication today.

A subway strike in this city could never win. It might cause a lot of trouble. Every subway rider must therefore welcome the assurance of President Douglas MacMahon of Local 100, Transport Workers Union, that his organization contemplates no such action.

Hoarding of coupons for processed foods was reported generally on the first day of point rationing yesterday as cautious housewives tried to accustom themselves to the newest restrictions on marketing and hung on to their numbered tokens.

A speech delivered yesterday in Philadelphia by George W. Taylor, vice chairman of the National War Labor Board, is merely one more reminder that the Board has still not adopted any precise wage policy. Mr. Taylor begins with the Congressional declaration that the wages, prices and salaries which were prevailing on Sept. 15, 1942, are to be stabilized at these levels so far as practicable.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A major diplomatic struggle, which may affect the length of the war, is being fought in Washington.

Because various complaints have been received at the Department of Welfare from relief recipients that certain retail grocers have said they would not accept food stamps during March, Welfare Commissioner Leo Arnstein said yesterday that any such cases should be reported immediately either to one of the branch offices of his department or to the Federal Marketing Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles conferred half an hour today with Hjalmar J. Procope, the Finnish Minister. Mr. Procope brought Mr. Welles the text of President Risto Ryti's inaugural speech.

CHUNGKING, China, March 1 (AP) -- Chinese shock troops have recaptured the Kiangsi Province city of Fengsin and a half dozen towns in Kiangsu, while the Japanese maintained offensives in two other provinces, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Oklahoma City, with department stores sales for January 46 per cent above the same month of last year, led the nation in such gains, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Second in the list of cities showing gains was Wichita, with an increase of 39 per cent.

Major Gen. Kenryo Sato, director of the Military Affairs Board of the Japanese War Ministry, told a committee meeting of the Diet yesterday that United States Military strategy was bad, that United States officers had "an extreme deficiency" and that, besides, the American people were too "serious," the Tokyo radio reported, according to the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Decorations have been awarded to fourteen naval aviation officers, the Navy reported today, for skill and daring displayed during attack and patrol missions against the Japanese in the western Aleutian Islands.

The report of the Connecticut Light and Power Company for 1942, released yesterday by C.L. Campbell, president, shows a net income for the year of $3,586,506 after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $2.50 share on the utility's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $3,752,340, or $2.94 a share, in 1941.
An estimated 60 per cent of New York City's milk supply brought in by three large distributors would be unaffected by any shortage in tank trucks, a check yesterday showed.

Todd Shipyards Corporation will break today a new advertising campaign in ten cities where its plants or offices are located, in which Todd workers will tell why they are bending every effort to increase production and repair of ships.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (U.P.) -- American women may be wearing ersatz shoes soon.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 (AP) -- The Swiss telegraphic agency reported from Rome tonight that Vatican circles, speculating on the subjects of conferences between Pope Plus and Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, had sug gested that one of the aims might be a proposal by the Pope banning some forms of warfare.

Steve Vasilakos was one of America's most distinguished citizens. Few would have recognized his name and still fewer could have spelled it correctly, but most newspaper readers would have understood a reference to the picturesque Greek who sold peanuts on a corner just outside the White House.

For the second time yesterday Frank L. Kluckhohn, writing from Allied headquarters in North Africa, stressed what he calls the first lesson which the Americans have learned in actual battle. Our men must try to work in larger units.

The-prosecution finished yesterday presenting evidence at the trial in General Sessions of Harry Waltzer and-William Walsh, former business agents of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Independent Union, charged with attempting to extort $5,000 last Summer from William Armstrong, president of the Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc., under threats to call a strike of his employes although all were members of other unions.

LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- Fighting French headquarters said today it had received a document disclosing that the Germans obtained control of a small squadron of French warships stationed at Tunis through a threat to massacre all personnel down "to the last officer and man."

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -Attorney General Biddle said today that a Federal grand jury here had returned an indictment charging John Eoghan Kelly of New York and San Francisco with failure to register as a paid representative of the Spanish Government in violation of the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Renewals of strike actions in war industries prompted the introduction in the Senate today of two measures designed to prevent production losses through work stoppages during employer-employe disputes.

Uncle Sam does not want Lippy Leo Durocher. The 37year-old Dodger manager was rejected for military service because of a perforated right eardrum after being called for induction at 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 1 -- Now that General Sir Harold R. L. G. Alexander has taken over all land operations in this theatre, it is to be hoped that certain factors tending to disturb otherwise harmonious Anglo-American relationships will be eliminated.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Herbert Hoover replied here today to statements by Vice President Wallace and Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island that he had proposed limitation on the size of the Army and that if the country had heeded Mr. Hoover's advice in 1917 the first World War would have been lost.

Income tax returns must be filed on or before March 15 by every single person whose gross income from all sources was $500 or more in 1942 and by every married person living with husband or wife, if their combined gross income last year was $1,200 or more, it was reiterated yesterday by Captain William J. Pedrick and Joseph T. Higgins, collectors of internal revenue respectively in the Second and Third New York districts.
Mme. Chiang Kai-shek arrived in New York yesterday as a visitor of state, as the wife of the Generalissimo of the Armies of China.

Patrick J. Walsh, Fire Commissioner, estimated yesterday that owners of 275,000 of the 700,000 residence and business buildings in the city had not yet filed certificates of compliance with a local law requiring them to have on hand specified emergency fire-fighting equipment for use in incendiary air raids.
The courage that is China's swept the city yesterday as it carried Mme. Chiang Kai-shek through the ceremonies that marked her official welcome to the city.

LONDON, March 1 -- The stock markets opened the week on a cheerful note with the diamond and home railway sections particularly active. Generally the industrials remained firm with the stores group recording small gains.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- A registration statement covering $6,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures, due March 1, 1963, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc.

Mrs. Beatrice Houdini, widow of Harry Houdin, the magician, had returned to the Catholic faith, in which she was baptized as an infant, shortly before she died on a train on her way here from California, it was revealed yesterday by her sister, Mrs. Marie Hinson of 67 Payson Avenue, and a life-long friend, the Rev. Charles S. Bonanno of the Church of St. Vincent de Paul in West Twenty-third Street.

" The Human Comedy," Metro's screen adaptation of the William Saroyan story, will have its world premiere at the Astor this morning. Mickey Rooney is starred in the picture, which was produced and directed by Clarence Brown. Among the featured players are Frank Morgan, James Craig, Marsha Hunt, Fay Bainter, Ray Collins and Van Johnson.

Following four successive sessions of moderate advances and brisk trading, the cotton futures market yesterday became quiet and suffered moderate losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed with net losses of 10 to 17 points, near the day's low levels.

LONDON, March 1 -- The Dodger-Yankee world series of 1941, with all the heartbreaking connotations for the Brooklynites, had a faint echo in Hyde Park today when teams of American soldiers captained by a Bronxite and a Brooklynite clashed at softball for the benefit of a fascinated if bewildered crowd of British men and women.

No effective action to curb juvenile delinquency has been taken by city authorities, and conditions are such that the problem is being aggravated rather than relieved, it was charged last night by Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court.

Ed Kelleher, Fordham coach, told the basketball writers at their weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday that his chief aim at the moment was the mythical metropolitan championship, and that, so far as he was concerned, his Rams already had clinched that.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- In a decision affecting the buying of supplies for the armed forces, the Supreme Court ruled today that a State may fix minimum prices for milk sold to the Federal Government for use at an army camp on land belonging to the State.
. NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (AP) -- A communique of the United States Air Forces:

A special meeting of the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers Union has been called for 3 P.M. Friday at the Hotel Claridge to set the machinery in motion for a strike in the theatres operated by Lee and J.J. Shubert on Broadway and elsewhere.

LONDON, March 1 -- The arrival here of Major Gen. Harry C. Ingles and his appointment as Deputy Commander of the United States Forces in Britain, in succession to Major Gen. Russel P. Hartle, was announced tonight by Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, with whom General Ingles was closely associated in the Panama Canal Zone.
High school students now busily engaged in writing essays on Thomas Jefferson will have a chance to see Sidney Kingsley's notable interpretation of the great democrat today for a dime.

Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, and Fritzie Zivic, former welterweight titleholder, are scheduled to receive their preliminary physical examinations today at the office of the State Athletic Commission. In acordance with custom, Chairman John J. Phelan will supervise a thorough inspection of these ring rivals, who are to wage a twelve-round non-title bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

Emanuel Zetlin, violinist, formerly a member of the New York Symphony Orchestra under Walter Damrosch, more recently with the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, and, since 1938, a member of the Juilliard School faculty here, gave a recital at the New York Times Hall last night before an enthusiastic audience.

LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- British and Canadian bombers dumped more than 1,000 tons of explosives last night on the German submarine base at St. Nazaire, sustaining through the fifth day and night the greatest aerial offensive the world has ever known.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 -- Today marks what the controlled French press persists in calling the "suppression of the line of demarcation," whereas the only concession made by the Germans is that French nationals may cross it, unless Chief of State Pierre Laval's police considers them "undesirables."

Although William Zorach has been continuously active in the New York art world, his first one-man show in twelve years will be opened today at the Downtown Gallery. Fourteen examples of his work are included, ranging from "Hound" and "Cat" (glacial boulder, 1934-35) to the truly architectural pieces, such as "The Faith of This Nation Is Eternal" (white marble, 1939-42) and the "Quest," a monumental head in pentelic marble, just finished.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Declaring that he was determined to do everything in his power to make the voluntary system of recruiting workers for war industry a success, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, took issue today with those who favor the cumpulsory method proposed in the Austin-Wadsworth bill.

Within two weeks after the initial troop landings in North Africa the American Red Cross had its first recreation club operating there and now thirteen clubs are functioning in that area, it was revealed last night by Howard Barr, who directed the establishment of nearly fifty Red Cross clubs in Great Britain before he went to North Africa.
Despite uncertainty as to the extent of off-shore fishing this year, George Ruppert has announced that his salt water fishing contest will be continued.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Acting Secretary of War Patterson and Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, urged the Senate Military Affairs Committee today to disapprove legislation, sponsored by forty Senators, to defer automatically from the draft all farm workers.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A new process for compressing air out of dried foods so that three dozen eggs can be reduced to a one-pound package, was described to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to day by E.R. Stettinius Jr.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn ,department stores' showed an increase of 18 per cent last week over the comparative week of 1942, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The percentage of gain was unchanged from that of the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -The Supreme Court reversed today the conviction of eight members of the C.I.O. International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers who were accused of conspiracy to dynamite Tennessee Valley Authority power lines during a 1940 strike at the Tennessee Copper Company mines at Copperhill, Tenn.

Production of steel this week will be at 98.2 per cent of the present capacity of 1,731,662 net tons per week, based on the revision made by the American Iron and Steel Institute last week after determining that productive capacity on Jan. 1, 1943, was 90,202,660 net tons of steel per annum, a new high.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Acting at the insistence of William M. Jeffers, his rubber director, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, today amended his original order which provided that Mr. Jeffers, along with other WPB heads, report direct to Charles E. Wilson, recently appointed executive vice chairman of the WPB.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Office of Price Administration completed today its price control for eggs by announcing the fixed markups which retailers may use to establish their maximum prices.
The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year 1942 net profit of $17,366,841, after reserve of $4,947,510 for post-war contingencies.

Friedrich Schorr will make his farewell appearance at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight, singing the role of The Wanderer in "Siegfried." Helen Traubel will appear for the first time on any stage as Bruennhilde. She is the first American in forty years to undertake the role throughout the Ring.

Part-time employment of housewives in this city reached a new field last week-end with the appearance of an advertisement for Housewives "with any time to give to war work" to serve as Western Union messengers.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 83 by 98 feet at 4500-06 Hudson Boulevard, Union City, N.J., has been sold by the Philadelphia National Bank to Richard Underwood for $100,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The one-man report by Senator Green of Rhode Island, opposing any reduction in the Army's plan to have a total of 8,200,000 officers and men in uniform by the end of 1943, rests heavily on two bases which as yet are unsubstantial.

One event on the program of the twenty-second annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track championships at Madison Square Garden Saturday night that figures to be wide open is the 600-yard run. A total of seventy-three men from twenty-three colleges has been entered for this popular test, heats for which will be run in the afternoon, along with 1,000-yard trials.

Mrs. Emma Van Coutren, 60 years old, six of whose twelve children were reported last year to be in the armed services, now has worked the percentage up from one-half to three-quarters. Two of her daughters have joined the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps and a son who was turned down by the Navy is in the Army.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, issued a statement tonight asserting that the shipment of petroleum products from the Western Hemisphere to Spain was in line with the interests of the United States and "has had no effect whatever on the quantity of petroleum available to any consumers in the United States."

Your editorial "Airplanes and Maps" insists that the time has come to discard Mercator's map because "we cannot forever mislead children and even college students with grossly inaccurate pictures of the world." This is an unduly strong condemnation of a map projection which possesses unmatched advantages for precision navigation of both sea and air, everywhere except in polar regions.

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (AP) -- Fifty Japanese soldiers were killed and others captured in a light naval engagement off Ramree Island Friday night, when coastal craft of the Royal Indian Navy encountered two armed enemy launches heavily loaded with troops and ammunition, a British communique announced today.

Fifty-three persons were rounded up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last week for infractions of the Selective Service Act, but of these twenty-five agreed to mend their ways and were released, it was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, local F.B.I. chief.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A preliminary meeting of representatives of all the United Nations to consider post-war economic problems will be convened in this country at an undetermined date. Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, told his press conference today.

This is the second day of Victory Book Week, the culmination of the campaign to furnish the armed forces with books. It hasn't gone as smoothly and successfully as might have been expected. The reasons are a matter of speculation. There are other drives. The time and the news are full of excitements.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities according to the Federal Reserve System, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 24: A decrease of $573,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $509,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Senator Mead (D,N.Y.) advocated today the cancellation of the world series and all "all-star" baseball games for the duration to relieve the strain on the nation's transportation system.

Lieutenant Joseph J. Copeland, former Professor of Botany and Biology at City College, who joined the Army Air Forces last week, described in minute detail to a jury in General Sessions Court yesterday the appearances and characteristics of Plantago lanceolata, Panicum dichotimoflorum, Eleusine indica and other grasses that grow in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The War Production Board announced today that no priority ratings will be issued by that agency for civilian rayon cloth orders. WPB is now at work on a study of the possibilities of increasing the output or conserving the supply of rayon goods for civilians by simplifying rayon gray goods construction.

Compulsory registration of women over 18 years of age in New York State and inclusion of women over 50 years of age in the proposed National War Service Act of 1943 was recommended yesterday in a resolution submitted to the office of the State Industrial Commissioner by the New York State Women's Commission, headed by Professor Kathryn Starbuck of Skidmore College.

DETROIT, March 1 (AP) -- Randolph E. Paul, Treasury Department general counsel, said today that corporation taxes must be maintained at a high level so that business and industry would not escape their fair share of the war burden.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (By Mail) -A brain-probing machine based on similar principles to those of a submarine detector has just been announced here.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- A Soviet communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

W. J. Sloane opened its doors at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street yesterday morning to the beginning of its second century of business. Among the prominent visitors invited to share in a ceremony commemorating the store's centennial was Mayor La Guardia, whose place of business, City Hall, faced the first small quarters of the house-furnishings establishment.

G.P. Putnam's Sons announces the purchase of H.C. Kinsey Co., which was established in 1932. Harold C. Kinsey, president of the firm since its inception, will continue to act in an advisory capacity. Five books were listed for Spring publication and will be issued as originally announced.
Governor and Mrs. Sumner Sewall of Maine have arrived from Augusta, and are at the St. Regis.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Opposition to a general wage increase for 250,000 persons working for nine West Coast companies making aircraft frames was reported to be the majority sentiment of members of the War Labor Board, which met in special session late today to continue consideration of the recommendations made by Paul R. Porter, the board's referee.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- John K. Thompson, vice president of the Erie Railroad, told Interstate Commerce Commissioner Oliver E. Sweet today that the Erie sold $14,000,000 of its bonds in a private transaction because lack of time and uncertainty of a wartime market made it inadvisable to ask for competitive bids.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Special bus services provided by some race tracks, golf, beach and night clubs, baseball clubs, stores and apartment houses for their patrons were banned today by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Treasury's next big borrowing campaign -- the first major financing since the $9,000,000,000 flotation last November -- will be launched on April 12, Secretary Henry Morgenthau announced today. About its size he would make no definite prediction, merely reiterating his previous announcement that it would be at least $13,000,000,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 1 -- Hurricane fighter-bombers and ponderous Churchill tanks battered the German columns attempting to capture Beja and flank the British positions around Medjez-el-Bab, the key to offensive strategy in Northern Tunisia, today.

The Military Affairs Committee of the Senate will begin hearings today on the most important bill that has been brought before the new Congress since it convened two months ago. This is the National War Service Bill, which would impose upon every able-bodied man and woman in the United States the legal obligation "to render such personal service in aid of the war effort as he or she may be deemed best fitted to perform."

Establishment of a War Production Board test plan to aid small plants should start a flow of contracts to 893 distressed concerns in New York and Brooklyn within the next three weeks, Colonel Robert W. Johnson, vice chairman of the WPB and chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, declared here yesterday at a press conference.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Splitting five to three, the Supreme Court today rejected a government demand to upset a 22-year-old ruling limiting the Treasury's power to tax dividends paid in stock.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $225,000 Northumberland County, Pa., 1 1/4 per cent refunding bonds, due Dec. 1, 1944 to 1952. The price paid was 101.089. Reoffering will be made at prices to yield 0.60 to 1.00 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Mills were persistent buyers of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade and while the aggregate trade was somewhat smaller than late last week there was no material selling pressure. Closing sales were at the top with gains of 1 1/8 cents, the finish being within 7/8 cent of the seasonal high.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 1 (AP) -- A communique:

Textile converters and garment manufacturers were warned yesterday by the regional office of the WPB to stop illegal extension of A-2 priority ratings to fabrics not suitable for use in women's workwear as defined in the agency's Order M-207.

NORTH CREEK, N.Y., March 1 -- William G. Howard, superintendent of New York State's lands and forests and one of the East's pioneer skiers, has directed all forest rangers in the Adirondacks and Catskills to work with local and national ski patrolmen in the rescue of lost and injured persons.

It is highly encouraging to learn that the Army regards the tests of the latest Sikorsky helicopter model as sufficiently successful to justify it in placing a production order. Those who have urged the Army and Navy to exploit the possibilities of the helicopter have never thought of this form of aircraft as a substitute for the airplane, but rather as an auxiliary weapon of very important potentialities.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Juan Jose de Amezaga, who was elected President of Uruguay last Nov. 29, took oath of office before the General Legislative Assembly this afternoon and received from the hands of outgoing President General Alfredo Baldomir the badge of Presidential office consisting of a sash of Uruguay's national colors.

A resolution was adopted last night at the meeting in Madison Square Garden called by the American Jewish Congress and other Jewish and Christian organizations to demand practical action by the United Nations to rescue as many as possible of the Jews living in Axis-dominated countries.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The revolutionary effect of current and prospective discoveries and developments in pure science upon everyday living today and tomorrow was discussed in addresses today before the Science Talent Institute.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Joseph Cotten will have the lead opposite Deanna Durbin in the Universal star's forthcoming vehicle "Hers to Hold." He will be on loan from David O. Selznick, to whom he is under contract.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 1 (AP) -- Andy Phillip set a record of 40 points and Illinois scored a new Western Conference high total tonight in crushing Chicago, 92 to 25, to win the Big Ten basketball championship for the second straight year.

Clinton H. Crane, president of the St. Joseph Lead Company, announced yesterday that his company had bought 195,000 shares of capital stock of New Jersey Zinc Company from the estate of Edgar Palmer, late president of the zinc company, at $59.75.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Navy Communique 295:

At 2 o'clock yesterday morning the brothers Malone, who ran away from home last Tuesday, sprang from their sandbox hermitage at Thirty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue in Brooklyn. They were shrill with terror.

The importance of conserving space on cargo ships for war materials, through the use of V-mail instead of the heavier ordinary letters, was discussed yesterday at the information center of the Civilian Defense Volunteer office in Pershing Square by Walter Hoving, chairman of the board the United Service Organizations.

The stock market had yesterday its first 2,000,000-share session in more than a year, but prices inclined to weaken. The lower tendencies were apparent most in pivotal issues; the low-price and bankrupt sections continued to move upward in blocks of 1,000 to 10,000 shares.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Navy announced today seventy casualties in Navy forces, including five dead, fifteen wounded and fifty missing.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Ways and Means subcommittee assigned to work out a pay-as-you-go income tax payment plan approved tentatively today an over-all 20 per cent withholding levy upon wages and salaries to put an estimated 70 per cent of the country's 40,000,000 taxpayers on a current basis.

LONDON, March 1 -- The Russians announced tonight a crushing new Winter offensive in the Lake Ilmen sector south of Leningrad in which they said the forces of Marshal Semyon Timoshenko had captured Demyansk and 301 other localities and had beaten the Germans into a hasty retreat with 11,000 of the enemy killed or captured.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, March 2 -- One of the largest Japanese convoys yet sighted in the northeastern sector of the Southwest Pacific area was reported by the United Nations High Command today to be heading in the direction of New Guinea.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 1 -Miss Virginia Lee Hanna, 30 Years old, daughter of Charles Augustus Hanna, retired chief examiner for the New York Clearing House, died Saturday in Mountainside Hospital.

BALTIMORE, March 1 -- Forty-nine colts were named by the Maryland Jockey Club today as eligible for the fifty-third running of the famed Preakness Stakes at the Pimlico race course on Saturday, May 8.

Warning that the government cannot act to relieve all conditions of hardship incident to shoe rationing and production control, W.W. Stephenson, chief of the footwear rationing division of the OPA, declared yesterday that the shoe industry "must use its tremendous influence to get customers to buy as usual, according to availability by type and grade."

Fira Benenson is a magician. Out of little she has created much; she has utilized restriction for expansion and has transformed simplicity into super-elegance. In short, yesterday she offered the best collection of her career in the Salon de Couture at Bonwit Teller's.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Southern Railway Company and its subsidiary, the Cincinnati, New Orleans Texas Pacific Railway, today made application to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue equipment trust certificates.

BOSTON, March 1 (AP) -- Contracts for war housing projects in Rhode Island, Connecticut and Vermont aggregating more than $1,102,000 in value, were announced today by the Federal Public Housing Authority in Boston.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The French crew of a French ship at New Orleans was reported today by Representative James H. Morrison, Democrat, of Louisiana, to have gone on strike in protest against the "pro-Vichy attitude" of Admiral Georges Robert, the Governor of Martinique and Guadaloupe.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Roosevelt's visitors were Admiral Leahy and Ambassador Winant.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- The Ogden Corporation, successor in reorganization to Utilities Power and Light Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a voluntary plan providing for divestment of interest in all of its subsidiaries that are registered holding or public utility companies.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 1 -- Lieut. Col. Harrison J. Uhl, a resident of this city and formerly associated with the Standard Oil Company, died yesterday of injuries received in an accident at Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, according to word received today.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Dewey put his veto pen to use for the first time today, disapproving a bill to bar the use of the name of educational institutions without consent, because he felt it might have a "disastrous" effect upon academic freedom.

The brewing industry has voluntarily undertaken to reduce shipments to the West Coast by 25 per cent and to cut over-all freight car mile usage 10 per cent as of April 1, should such action be necessary as a means of conserving transportation facilities, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision holding constitutional a section of the 1935 Public Utility Holding Company Act requiring interstate gas and electric holding companies to limit their operations to a "single integrated" system.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 1 -- The Italo-German "crisis" over purported peace efforts ended dramatically today with the publication of an official communique at Rome announcing that Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany had been in the Italian capital for five days engaged in political-military talks "destined to form the Axis answer to the United Nations Casablanca conference."

There seems to be wide disagreement on what to do with us young fathers. Rightly enough, nobody's asking us what we think is best, but perhaps the following thoughts represent the feelings of many who are not yet in the services.

An entertainment, called an "After Supper Gin Rum-mage Party," will be given the night of March 13 at the Ritz Tower for the benefit of Irvington House Thrift Shop. Mrs. Clarence Millhiser and Mrs. Joseph M. Friendly are co-chairmen of the committee for the event, which will include divertissements by professional entertainers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 1 -- Recommendations by the War Production Board that the town of Greenburgh sound air raid alarms by using compressed-air whistles instead of special sirens were termed "ridiculous" this afternoon by Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy director of civilian protection for Westchester County.

LONDON, March 1 -- The only Slav country on the side of the Axis -- except such subject and sub-divided States as Slovakia and Croatia -- is Bulgaria, which finds herself in the paradoxical position of being at war with Britain and the United States whom she cannot fight and at peace with Soviet Russia with whom Reichsfuehrer Hitler would like to see her at war.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 155 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Immediate action by the United Nations to save as many as possible of the five million Jews threatened with extermination by Adolf Hitler and to halt the liquidation of European Jews by the Nazis was demanded at a mass demonstration of Christians and Jews in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Army and Navy fliers, operating over a wide area of the South Pacific, made a series of raids on Japanese strongholds over the week-end and, among other results, blew up a cargo ship believed to have been loaded with ammunition, a Navy communique announced today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 1 -- The report on recent increase of Japanese strength in the arc of islands northward of Australia, contained in today's communique of United Nations Headquarters in Australia, has again concentrated attention in Australia on the aims of Japanese military activity in the Southwest Pacific area in the next few months.

LONDON, March 1 -- While the first Norwegian clergyman to reach here from his homeland told today of some of his experiences with German storm troopers, reports in Norwegian circles indicated that Quisling authorities in Oslo had backed down in their controversy with the Lutheran Church to the extent of restoring the rights of some "discharged and exiled" clergymen.
Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor, in sentencing three muggers yesterday, called for the use of nightsticks by policemen. The muggers, all Negroes, received long prison terms.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Mayor La Guardia formally requested of the Legislature tonight permission for New York City to increase the rate of the city sales tax from 1 per cent to 2 per cent, and also to double the rate of general business and financial business taxes on gross income which have been supplementary to the sales tax in the city's emergency revenue scheme for a number of years.

The tradition of a New York recital seems to require a pianist to play major works of two or three masters and to end with a group of short, fairly recent compositions. In his second Carnegie Hall recital last night, Sidney Foster observed the routine during the first half, and introduced a brace of new compositions in the second

The Capitol Theatre will introduce a band-show and "in person" stage policy to supplement its film programs beginning March 11. The theatre discontinued its stage-show policy in August, 1935, when vaudeville presentations in motion-picture houses apparently had reached a low ebb.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 2 (U.P.) -- Russia's official news agency, Tass, charged in a Moscow broadcast today that Poland, in insisting on her pre-war frontiers, "does not wish to recognize the historical rights of the Ukrainian and White Russian peoples to be united with their national states."
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
LONDON, March 1 (U.P.) -- A special Soviet communique broadcast by Radio Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Lend-lease in reverse has reduced cash expenditures for the American Army in Great Britain to less than $25,000 a month, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

The housekeeper who once considered herself clever if she kept within a financial budget must now balance ration points as well. One way to do it, of course, is to buy plenty of the fresh things that require no stamps.
Heavy bombers of the British Royal Air Force raided Berlin last night, apparently in considerable strength, and started fires in the German capital.

Following up the recent statements of both President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill that the United Nations will now carry the war to the enemy, American and British generals and admirals announce that their armies, navies and air forces are poised to strike on all fronts.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Financing by electric and gas utility companies, reflecting the impact of the war, fell off more than 50 per cent in 1942, it was disclosed today in an analysis prepared by the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

HELSINKI, Finland, March 1 -- in a sober twenty-minute inauguration ceremony in the Helsinki Parliament today President Risto Ryti was sworn in for a second term as President of Finland. After the session the Cabinet resigned in accordance with Finnish parliamentary tradition and was asked by Mr. Ryti to remain until a new Cabinet has been formed.

Seth Sprague, cotton converter and president of F.A. Foster Co., Inc., dealers in drapery fabrics, left $6,732,891 as a trust "for the well-being of mankind," the income to be distributed among religious, charitable, scientific, literary and educational organizations, it was disclosed yesterday when the estate tax appraisal was filed here.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Bernard M. Baruch reiterated today his belief of nearly a quarter of a century, that it would be impossible and dangerous to attempt to draft labor for war work. He is convinced, however, that labor can be compelled to work or fight.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision holding that a person who sought exemption from military service as a conscientious objector is required to report for duty if his claim is denied by a draft board.
With its usual attention to imaginative detail, Stein Blaine held its Spring and Summer fashion show yesterday in its rooms at 15 West Fifty-seventh Street.
NEW DELHI, India, March 1 (AP) -- A British communique:

All the favored teams survived the elimination round in the opening play of the Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Cup at the Park Central Hotel here last night, and entered the first of the knockout rounds which will be played tonight. Of the starting field of eleven teams, three were eliminated.

LONDON, March 1 (U.P.) -- The visit to Rome of Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Foreign Minister, was regarded here as actually a step in a secret diplomatic war in which the question of a separate peace by Italy was the ultimate stake.

The city will hold its first "double red" air raid drill under the new Army system tonight, beginning at 9 o'clock, officials reminded residents yesterday. The blackout is expected to last for an hour.

For the past two months, railroad bonds traded on the New York Stock Exchange have been the most active for any similar period since 1937. A factor in this activity has been the heavy purchases by the railroads of their obligations for retirement.

H.W. Pell of the Princeton Club, top seeded player, was eliminated last night from the Red Cross tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, held in the University Club. He was the last seeded player left in the singles competition, and was -- 6 in the handicapping.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Supreme Court reversed today the conviction of George Sylvester Viereck, Nazi propagandist, on the technical ground that he was not compelled to report to the State Department any of his activities except as "agent of a foreign principal."

ALBANY, March 1 -- The Assembly passed tonight Governor Dewey's $369,600,000 executive budget after the Republican majority had defeated a series of Democratic attempts to reduce expenditures and take an additional $11,600,000 off 1943 State income taxes.

The Canada Life Assurance Company had $825,740,840 life insurance in force at the end of 1942, comparing with $815,470,716 at the end of 1941, according to a report made recently at the annual meeting of stockholders and policyholders.

Several women's organizations set up machinery throughout the city yesterday to help bewildered shoppers through their first day of point rationing. The need for their assistance was brought out in various anecdotes related at the end of a confusing day.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE, South China, Feb. 28 (Delayed) -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault was seated in an office marked "Commanding General, China Air Task Force," and feeling very chipper at an interview this morning.

After an inspection tour of three of the city's enclosed public markets yesterday, Daniel P. Woolley, Markets Commissioner, asserted that any hysteria over point rationing was "out of all proportion to the facts." He said the rationed processed foods comprised only 3 per cent of the average person's total annual consumption.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Supreme Court held constitutional today New York legislation regulating a cooperative system of fire insurance participated in by a group of wholesale grocers and canners.

The twenty-one-story store and loft building on a plot 59.7 by 77.4 feet at 135-39 West Thirty-sixth Street has been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to the Kaufman 36th Street Corporation, Samuel Kaufman, president.

LONDON, March 2 -- Although business on the stock markets was reduced in scale today, prices remained around yesterday's levels, with the exception of diamond shares and gilt-edge stocks, which recorded gains. In the first group De Beers advanced another 3-16.

Several hundred civil employes in "thirty to forty" city, State and Federal offices throughout New York City have begun stopping men who visit those public bureaus on business and have demanded to see the visitors' draft cards, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service director, disclosed yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 2 (UP) -- American fliers, working from bases in China and India, have made many battering raids on Japanese positions and supply lines in Burma and in Yunnan Province, China, and successfully bombed the famous Gokteik viaduct on the Mandalay-Lashio Railway, it was reported today.

The German High Command, in a communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press, acknowledged yesterday the German evacuation of Demyansk, whose recapture was announced by the Russians in a special bulletin Monday night.

PEACE planners are popping up like worms after a Spring rain these days. Journalists, economists, professors, students of foreign affairs, law and credit, diplomats, politicians in office and out of it and card experts all have their two cents worth they must throw into the general discussion and most of them have written "how to win the peace" books.

Which lasts longer, a cotton shirt or a steel plate? Answer: The shirt lasts a good deal longer, if the shirt is one of half a dozen handled with consideration by the laundryman, and if the steel plate is part of a General Sherman tank.

For two successive nights Madison Square Garden has been the scene of living drama, grander and more significant than any symbolic spectacle the artist's imagination could conceive. For what was presented there in two extraordinary performances was the tragedy of the world, that apocalyptic interplay of terror and of pity wherein the whole human race, humanity itself, is the protagonist.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Over the objections of five Federal agencies, the District of Columbia Public Utilities Commission decided today to limit its annual hearing on adjustments of electric power rates to whatever changes may be possible under the existing "sliding-scale" agreement between the District and the Potomac Electric Power Company.

Despite long hours on man-sized jobs, women war workers in the metropolitan area are finding time to spend an hour or two each day with their children, do their shopping and household chores and still have enough time left over for recreation.

City life went on through thirty-four minutes of simulated air raid conditions last night in a "double-red" blackout drill that progressed smoothly. The first audible blue signal sounded above the city at 8:56 P.M., the all-clear at 9:30 P.M.

William Merna, 40 years old, the Eighth Avenue bus driver who recently pleaded guilty in General Sessions to an assault charge in the attempt to kill five of his six children and himself by illuminating gas in their home at 2136 Amsterdam Avenue, because of his wife's absence for weeks, was released on a suspended sentence yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan.

MOSCOW, March 2 -- The operation carried out by armies under Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's Northwestern Command for the liquidation of the powerfully consolidated Demyansk salient met with complete success. It still remains to be seen whether it will lead to immediate developments.

The stock market exhibited yesterday decided calm in the face of further profit-taking, and after losses of as much as 2 points had been suffered, the forces for the advance reappeared and brought the list to only an irregularly lower close on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- For morale's sake, a Pennsylvania Representative told the House today, Congress should go on record as sanctioning wartime spectator sports and opposing undue curtailment, especially of baseball and football.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Secretary Wickard and economists of the Office of Price Administration were blamed today by independent packers for conditions from which, they held, "black markets" in meat have sprung up in many parts of the country.

Moving speedily to simplify output of civilian rayon fabrics, in order to extend limited production facilities into constructions that will serve as many essential end-purposes as possible, committees of the Textile Distributors Institute began a series of conferences here yesterday aimed at completing their recommendations by the end of this week, at which time they will be submitted to the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply in Washington.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Legislative action on Governor Dewey's $369,600,000 executive budget was completed today with the Senate voting unanimous approval after the Democrats vainly sought to amend the main bill to eliminate $6,600,000 in appropriations for highways.

Perhaps the most spectacular movers of the 1943 market have been the so-called "penny stocks," which in many cases have doubled and tripled their values since the turn of the year. In many cases, of course, leverage has been responsible: Shareholders see companies earning accrued interest and preferred dividends and possibly reaching points at which the common shares will be able to pay again.

The performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was also the occasion of Friedrich Schorr's leave-taking of the lyric stage. He appeared in one of his greatest roles, which is that of the Wanderer.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Ray Reinhart Schiff of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Gloria Induslauere of Ames, Iowa, were named as winners of the four-year $2,400 Westinghouse science grand scholarships which are the top awards of this year's talent search.
