LONDON, March 2 (U.P.) -- The 9,380-ton British cruiser Sussex sank a large enemy tanker in the Atlantic Friday after a United States Army Air Force Liberator bomber had sighted the Axis vessel, the Admiralty announced today.

Daylight boxing in the outdoors is one of the plans under consideration by Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. for the Summer of 1943. The veteran promoter revealed this yesterday, emphasizing, however, that the arrangement was contingent upon the available talent.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Representative Carlson of Kansas, a minority member of the Ways and Means Committee and original sponsor of the Ruml pay-as-yougo tax plan in the House, introduced today a bill embodying a modified version of the Ruml plan plus a 20 per cent withholding tax.

Joe Lordi of the New York A.C., national champion in 1941 and runner-up last year to Ensign H. Robert Reeve, led seven of the eight seeded contenders into the quarter-finals of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association last night.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- Following the most devastating Royal Air Force attack of the war last night, rescue and wrecking crews in Berlin were still at work tonight to restore order in the devastated areas, and it is believed that casualties will considerably exceed earlier estimates. The well-known St. Hedwig's Catholic Cathedral is said to have been totally destroyed, while incendiary bombs are reported to have damaged the former American and British Embassy Buildings.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Before this war is over, Secretary Knox declared today, "we'll utterly destroy the Japanese fleet."

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A system of uniform standards and procedures to govern the selection of enlisted men for participation in the Army Specialized Training Program was announced today by the War Department.

Six days of relentless round-the-clock bombing reached a flaming climax Monday night in the deadliest raid Berlin has ever suffered. The blast of 900 tons of explosive lighted fires visible 180 miles away. Many observers predict that these great raids are the premonitory thunder of a storm about to break over Western Europe.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 2 -- A decree issued by the Ministry of War today confirms reports circulating here last night to the effect that an agreement had been concluded to permit Argentina to supply arms, munitions and other war materials to Great Britain.

Last Wednesday this column presented a week's menus for a family of four, including two school-age children. These twenty-one meals were designed for simplicity and economy, and showed how the household's ration of processed foods might be managed.
LONDON, March 2 -- The Royal Air Force subjected Berlin last night to the worst bombing raid the German capital has ever had.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 -- At an airdrome camp behind the front of the British Eighth Army fliers and ground officers of the United States Middle East fighter group have organized an "after the war club" called Tripoli Twerps.

The Chicago Corporation, an open-end investment company, had at the close of 1943 net assets of $26,627,175, equivalent to $55.96 on each outstanding share of convertible preference stock, against $50.76 at the end of 1941, according to a report issued yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 (U.P.) -- Unconfirmed reports were current in diplomatic circles tonight that Pope Plus had been asked to assume the initiative in an effort to obtain agreements among the belligerent powers to refrain from the bombing of "open cities."

Through arrangement with Simon Schuster, which has consistently published Hendrik Van Loon's books, Dodd Mead is to undertake a series of short biographies written by Mr. Van Loon. The first will be one on Thomas Jefferson, to be released March 30.

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- A jurisdictional dispute between electrical workers of the American Federation of Labor and members of an independent union over the moving of a light pole fifteen feet crippled today construction work on the new synthetic rubber plant of the Koppers Company at Kobuta.

OTTAWA, March 2 -- Canada will be placed on a pay-as-you-earn income tax plan, according to an announcement made tonight by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley when he introduced the 1943-44 budget. "I am proposing," he said, "that beginning this year, 1943, the income tax currently collected at the source or paid in quarterly installments shall apply in respect of the tax to be assessed on the income of this current year."

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The War Labor Board was prepared tonight to hand down tomorrow a decision granting a general wage increase of 4.5 cents an hour to 30,000 Boeing aircraft workers and withholding a general increase from 220,000 employes of eight Southern California aircraft companies, but allowing to about half the number an increase of about 7 cents an hour to cover "inequalities."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (U.P.) -- Cornelius Warmerdam, holder of world outdoor and indoor pole vault records, has been sworn into the Navy as an ensign, it was revealed today. He will leave his teaching job at Piedmont, Calif., to report for a physical training program at Chapel Hill, N.C., March 28.

MIAMI, March 2 (AP) -- A.P. Kitchin, special agent in charge of the Miami office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced today the arrest of eleven men in connection with the theft and sale of $98,000 of securities. A long investigation was continuing, he said.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The meat situation in New York City was described as "terrible" today by Mayor La Guardia, who flew here to confer on the question with Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture; Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, and Marvin Jones, assistant to James M. Byrnes, Director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

Three teams strongly in the running for tournament berths and another which clings to the hope of being invited will go into action in the college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight, when New York University faces St. John's and Long Island University tackles Toledo.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Petroleum industry representatives told Secretary Ickes today that easing of restrictions on passenger car use might reduce overcrowding of public transportation.
Mrs. A.M. Sobel and Miss Ruth Sherman led twenty-seven pairs after the first session of the Eastern States contract bridge, championship contest for women's pairs at the Park Central Hotel yesterday.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES on the Tunisian Front, March 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Sixteen officers and men received silver stars and twenty-nine others were cited by their commanding general today for outstanding courage under fire in recent fighting in Tunisia as well as heroism during the American landing at Oran, Algeria, last Nov. 8.

Members of the Old Timers Post 188, Jewish War Veterans, raised $75,000 yesterday in the first two hours of their War Bond drive for $350,000 to replace the bomber on which Sergeant Meyer Levin, Flatbush hero, lost his life when the plane crashed into the sea near Port Moresby, New Guinea.

FOLKESTONE, England, March 2 (AP) -- One of the most violent cross-Channel artillery exchanges of the war raged for an hour tonight, with British and German big guns hurling salvo after salvo over the misty Dover Strait.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Retail prices for some brands of Scotch, bourbon and rye whiskies may rise 5 to 10 per cent in New York on Monday as a result of a new pricing regulation issued here today, the Office of Price Administration warned consumers.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 3 -- The Red Army, which has marched 400 miles in three months, continued to advance against the Germans on the three main fronts south of Moscow yesterday despite the mud of early Spring thaws and despite Nazi reinforcements rushed from the Netherlands to the front west of Kharkov.

TORONTO, March 2 -- The Maple Leafs lost a chance to take sole possession of third place in the National Hockey League and Goalie Bill Beveridge of the Rangers scored his first shutout of the season as New York walloped Toronto, 4 -- 0, before 9,221 spectators at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 27 (I.P.) (Delayed) -- The Chinese Government today is housing, feeding, and even providing personal servants for thousands of United States Army personnel in return for lend-lease aid.

Reporting that more than 80 per cent of the shoes now being made in England are of the "utility" type, B.J. Perkins of the Fairchild Publications said yesterday that if the American consumer's acceptance is as favorable as it has been in England "we are not going to have many complaints of standardization or about putting people in uniform."

The 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City had a total of $1,515,000 in hand last night toward its goal of $12,920,700, it was announced by Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the campaign. This sum, he said, represented part of the returns from the two first days of the drive and an accumulation of gifts made before it was officially opened on Monday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- The groundwork for German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop's discussions in Rome was laid in a meeting between Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini "somewhere in Germany" last Wednesday, it was learned from Rome tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, March 3 -- Amnerican Flying Fortresses and Liberators, flying through tropical storms, have scattered a fourteen-ship Japanese convoy, sinking two large transports ...

A shortage of half-pint paper containers for milk threatens the daily milk ration of 40,000 school children of the city unless school authorities and the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Administration can devise a substitute method of distribution by next week, it was learned yesterday. The beverage is distributed in underprivileged areas at a cost of 1 cent a container to the children.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -William M. Jeffers, rubber director, said today that the rubber program now is moving ahead smoothly under its new priority directive and that a small number of synthetic tires for civilians would be turned out by the end of this year, barring new obstacles.

In your editorial this morning you say that Mr. Morgenthau, in denying that there is any contract of moral commitment preventing the Federal Government from taxing income from State and local securities, overlooks the fact that an 1895 Supreme Court decision has been held to mean that the Federal Government has no power to tax such income.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The unceasing hunt of United States submarines for Japanese ships in Pacific waters has been rewarded by the sinking of four more cargo ships and a tanker and the damaging of two others, a transport and a tanker, the Navy Department announced tonight.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Several amendments to the State Banking Law were introduced today in the Legislature at the request of Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks. They were sponsored by D. Mallory Stephens and Pliny W. Williamson, heads of the Banking Committees of the Assembly and the Senate.

Dr. Carl M. White of the University of Illinois has been appointed Director of Libraries and Dean of the School of Library Service at Columbia University, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. Dr. White will replace Dr. Charles C. Williamson, who will retire on June 30 after seventeen years of service.
CHUNGKING, China, March 2 (AP) -A communique from the American headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stillwell.

Meats, cheese, butter, cooking fats and oils will be rationed, beginning April 1, through the red coupons in War Ration Book 2. The over-all allotment of meat and cheese for consumers will average one and three-quarter pounds a person a week, with cheese considered a substitute for meat. [1:1.]

"We have not received any application as yet for consolidation of the Saratoga meeting with one in metropolitan New York," said Chairman Herbert Bayard Swope of the State Racing Commission yesterday, "but we fear it is inevitable."

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Two Republican members of Congress joined tonight in a Treasury-sponsored radio appeal to the public to keep faith with America's fighting men by prompt payment of income taxes due March 15.

LONDON, March 2 -- U-boats remain the only threat to a United Nations victory and Prime Minister Churchill's statements regarding the menace are far too optimistic, Lord Winster declared in the House of Lords today in a speech demanding new methods to combat the submarine.

The Chinese Women's Association, 311 Fifth Avenue, made public yesterday a letter sent to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek last month, urging the establishment of an immigration quota for Chinese, under which members of that nation "would be accorded the same privileges enjoyed by our companions in ideology and arms."
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, March 3 (AP) -- A communique:
MOSCOW, March 2 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

The common stock dividend of 25 cents a share voted yesterday by the American Crystal Sugar Company represents a reduction from the 50-cent. payments made last year in April, July, September and December.

Out of this war period a definite style is emerging. It is one to be proud of. The past week has witnessed showings of the custom-made departments of several members of the up-town retail guild. The last of these specialty houses to show was Bergdorf Goodman, with a group of eighty-five costumes and forty hats. As is customary on such occasions Edwin Goodman, president, presided.

It is expected that a meeting will be held in this city on Monday at which officials of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service will discuss various matters of national policy on conservation during the war emergency, with a view of gaining the public's reaction.

LONDON, March 2 -- Andre Maroselli, French Senator and lieutenant colonel in the air force reserve, who has just escaped from his homeland with his 22-year-old son to join General Charles de Gaulle's forces here, asserted in an interview today that there should be an early Allied invasion, for France is ripe for such an onslaught.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,370, which compared with 68 in the preceding week and 1,236 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 511 as against 76 last Tuesday.

Net income of the Freeport Sulphur Company in 1942 amounted to $2,436,655, or $3.05 a common share, compared with $3,149,030, or $3.95 a share, earned in 1941, according to the annual report made public yesterday. The figures included the company's proportion of net income of the Cuban-American Manganese Corporation, $443,877 for 1942 and $657,862 for 1941.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente approved yesterday as fair, reasonable and adequate a settlement offer made by the Texas Oil Company, in a suit brought by minority stockholders of the Indian Refining Company, a subsidiary of the Texas Company.
THE TIMES editorial attacking the McKellar bill marks one of the few occasions when you have been illogical and have opposed the public interest.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Senator Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri, whose stand prior to Pearl Harbor was strongly non-interventionist, is weighing the pros and cons of a concurrent resolution certifying the support by Congress of an effective post-war system of collective security and the active participation of this nation in that system, including international military protections of the peace.

The prevalence of meningococcus meningitis, an epidemic disease with a high mortality rate, is much greater in New York now than in the last several years, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. So far this year, there have been 201 cases of this dread spinal illness and 36 deaths in the city, contrasted with 37 cases and 4 deaths at this time in 1942, and 16 cases and 5 deaths in 1941.
AN ITALIAN HIGH COMMAND communique broadcast by the Rome radio and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -A lend-lease agreement setting forth that the defense of Chile is vital to the defense of the United States was signed by the two nations today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The ban on pleasure driving in the Eastern States, which was imposed on Jan. 7 to set free available transportation facilities for fuel oil, will be lifted on March 22. That is the date on which the present three-gallon A coupon of Period Four expires.

The annual report of the Employers Mutual Liability Insurance Company for 1942 shows a net premium income of $26,912,901, including $22,269,765 workmen's compensation insurance, comparing with $21,025,675 and $17,046,690 respectively for 1941.

Five hundred and eighty thousand boys and girls of 14 and 15 years and 2,200,000 of 16 and 17 are working either full or part time in industry and agriculture, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Child Labor Committee, describing the effect of the war on child labor.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 2 (U.P.) -A complete revision of the Army aviation cadet program to extend the training for cadets to fifteen and one-half months instead of the present eight and one-half was announced today by headquarters, Fourth Service Command.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Buying of wheat futures by flour mills sent the May delivery of that grain on the Board of Trade today to the highest price in fourteen years and No. 2 red Winter wheat sold in the cash market at $1.68 1/2 a bushel, highest since 1928 and 36 1/2 cents above the government loan basis on the 1942 crop.

Three young marines, veterans of the Battle of Midway last June, described in interviews here yesterday what one feels sitting in the tail position of an American plane when it is outnumbered by a horde of Japanese Zeros and traveling through a sky black with flak.

New issues of bonds aggregating $24,914,000 were sold yesterday by seven local housing authorities in various parts of the country. Through competitive bidding, $19,712,000 of the bonds was awarded to a major syndicate headed by Shields Co., and another headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., Blyth Co., Inc., and Goldman, Sachs Co. received a total of $3,833,000.

President Horace Stoneham of the Giants received word from St. Louis yesterday that his first baseman, Big Jawn Mize, had been reclassified 1-A by his draft board and would be called for induction possibly within a month.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 2 (AP) -A communique:

Traders in cotton futures acted cautiously yesterday, as no new developments in legislation affected prices. In a thin market the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange overcame early losses, which ranged to 14 points, and closed with net gains of 3 to 8 points, except for the March position.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Austin-Wadsworth proposal for a National Service Act was pictured before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today as a measure which would make victory more certain by putting the national manpower program on a more orderly basis to insure the production of munitions and food essential to the support of the United Nations' armies.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 -- Work on Navy contracts was delayed at the Alameda shipyard of the General Engineering and Dry Dock Company today when, with one exception, the entire day shift of machinists, numbering 169, walked out as the aftermath of the expulsion of a workman by his union.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the Erie Railroad contended today that it was good business to arrange a quick sale of $14,000,000 of bonds for refinancing without competitive bidding.

Strong protest against Mayor La Guardia's proposal to raise the retail sales tax to 2 per cent was registered yesterday by a group of seventy-one trade and civic associations, which announced they would re-create the dormant Sales Tax Committee of 1,000 to mobilize public opinion against the measure.
OTTAWA, March 2 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Ilsley's "work-and-save" budget allows some income-tax relief to persons engaged in the war effort.
POONA, India, Wednesday, March 3 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's twenty-one-day fast ended in defeat and failure at 9 o'clock this morning [11:30 last night in New York].

Paced by classified and national linage, advertising in eight New York newspapers last month rose 12.5 per cent over the corresponding 1942 period, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The gain compared with a rise of 14.6 per cent recorded in January but that month had the advantage of an extra Sunday in comparison with 1942.

MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- In an interview granted to the press, the United States Ambassador, George Messersmith, stated today that the solution of the problem presented by the inefficiency of Mexico's national railroads was of primary importance to both Mexico and the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- The Burlington Mills Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement naming fourteen additional underwriters to handle its offering of 65,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock $100 par value.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo of the Armies of China, last night told an audience of 17,000 in Madison Square Garden and a nationwide radio audience that "we in China have bled for the last six long years" but "shall hold firm" in "struggling against wanton domination."
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The War Department announced tonight the names of 435 United States soldiers killed in action in various theaters of operations. Among the dead from New York were:

CENTRAL TUNISIA, March 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- "Fix me up quick, Doc, I want to get back in there," said the soldier with the raw machine-gun wound in his leg as American Army medical men worked over him in the gleaming white operating room of a hospital truck.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Creation of a War Finance Committee to direct the Treasury's record financing operation scheduled for April 12 and future government borrowing was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau. It will be headed by W.M. Robbins of Greenwich, Conn., who has been granted a year's leave of absence from his duties as vice president of the General Foods Corporation.

Most large concerns spent more than 1,000 man-days each last year in answering questionnaires and filing reports required by the government, while many spent more than 5,000, according to a report issued yesterday by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Decisions made informally several days ago at a meeting of the Post-War Planning Commission, representing the Legislature and executive branches, were disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The President canceled his press conference and remained in his living quarters, but saw several government officials.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Two special fact-finding panels today started digging into evidence presented by railroad workers and managements to back up their arguments in disputes over wages, the closed shop, and Diesel-electric locomotive operation.

Citations honoring five typical "War Service Scouts," one from each borough of the city, for their contributions to the war on the home front, were presented yesterday noon at the annual meeting of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- In the face of vigorous opposition from the War Department and the selective service system, the Senate Military Affairs Committee approved today and released for floor action the Bankhead bill for sweeping deferments of farm workers from the draft.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 2 (AP) -- President Risto Ryti in a surprise move today entrusted to the speaker of Parliament, Vaino Hakkila, the task of forming a new government.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 2 -- Twenty -- four hours after the Royal Air Force visited the capital of the Reich, the fires there had not yet been extinguished, according to all reports reaching Stockholm tonight. The raid was the heaviest yet experienced in Berlin and the destruction caused was such that, according to one report, "a large part of the population has no roof over its head."

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The declaration by former President Herbert C. Hoover that Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island had misrepresented his position on the desirable size for the Army in the last war remained unchallenged today.

For brilliant virtuosity, Vladimir Horowitz is unsurpassed among pianists today. He seems to have become the people's choice in his field. No one, certainly among his own generation of pianists, can match his drawing power today. One announcement was made several months ago of his Carnegie Hall recital scheduled for last night and it promptly sold out. Only the stage seats were held out, reserved for men and women in the services.
Following is the text of the speech of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek at the Madison Square Garden mass tribute meeting last night and broadcast over the Columbia and Mutual networks:

British rationing problems somewhat similar to those now facing the American housewife are explained by numerous charts, graphs and motion pictures in the latest addition to the "World at War" exhibition, which opens this morning at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

Marshal Timoshenko's advance below Lake Ilmen begins to unfold the full strategy of the Russian Winter offensive. The new drive scarcely comes as a surprise. Berlin acknowledged heavy pressure in this area more than a week ago. Moreover, it seemed likely that as mud and German reserves slowed the Russian advance in the south the Red Army would attack in the north if it still had the manpower to strike fresh blows.
NEW DELHI, India, March 2 (AP) -- A United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Aided by more than fifty Republicans, the Democratic House leaders chalked up its first legislative victory of the session today by defeating a Republican-backed move to form a standing committee on civil and commercial aviation.

LONDON, March 2 -- Britain's "back-room boys," who are responsible for the design of munitions, are constantly exerting themselves to compress into every ton of bombs the most highly concentrated ingredients of destructive power that modern science and human ingenuity can devise, Duncan Sandys, Joint Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Supply, said today.

What began in Germany as anti-Semitism, taking that form because German Jews were a small minority and could thus be attacked with perfect safety, developed long ago into a crusade of hell against all civilized people. In Hitler's world all persons who love freedom are now in the same predicament as the little group of good German citizens against whom the Nazi hoodlums first commenced operations.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 (AP) -- A United States Army Headquarters communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, March 2 -- Having obtained release from his Twentieth-Century Fox contract, Jean Gabin will be starred at RKO this Summer in a picture to be produced and written by Dudley Nichols and directed by Jean Renoir. No title has been given the Gabin vehicle, which is described as a story dealing with "the racial roots that go to make America."
LONDON,March 2 (UP) so-I viet idniglt oommuiqud broadcast by Mosco and recorded kere by tk Soviet monitor:

LOS ANGELES, March 2 (AP) -- The long and successful comeback campaign of Hammerin' Henry Armstrong came to an end tonight as Willie Joyce, Gary, Ind., speedster, outboxed him all the way to earn a decision in ten rounds. Both boys weighed 137 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Consumers will begin spending the red coupons in War Ration Book No. 2 on April 1 for meats, cheese, butter and cooking fats and oils, it was learned tonight. The Office of Price Administration has completed its plans for rationing meats and other commodities, and intends to invoke all the programs simultaneously.

The land and people of China, once so strange and so far away, seemed close at hand and familiar when Mme. Chiang Kai-shek rose to speak at Madison Square Garden last night. It was not merely that Mme. Chiang had a perfect command of our language. She had also a perfect command of ideas which are received with equal sympathy here and in China.

A new issue of 65,000 shares of the Burlington Mills Corporation's 5 per cent $100 par preferred stock will be offered today at $104.50 a share and accrued dividends from March 1 by a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and Kidder, Peabody Co.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Suggested ways in which retailers may ease the additional accounting burdens which point rationing places upon them were offered today by S. J. Dunaway, chief of the retail and wholesale trade section of the WPB.

About a year ago George Sylvester Viereck was convicted under the act of 1938 for not having reported his actions as a foreign agent fully and in compliance with the regulations made by the Secretary of State under the act. He was sentenced to pay certain fines and costs and to imprisonment for two to six years.
LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- A British Admiralty, Air Ministry and Headquarters for the European Theatre of Operations, United States Army joint communique:

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- A bill which would make labor unions subject, to prosecution under the 1934 Anti-Racketeering Act if they used violence to interfere with interstate commerce, was sent to the House by the Rules Committee today, probably to come to a vote next week.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company effected last year a net reduction of $24,876,956 in its debt, making a total decrease in the last five years of over $100,000,000, M.W. Clement, president, declares in the carrier's ninety-sixth annual report, issued for publication today.

LONDON, March 2 -- In order to insure the defenses of their European "fortress" against a United Nations attack the Germans are doing their best to keep Bulgaria oft tenterhooks with constant propaganda hints that Turkey is about to join the Allied side or is ready to take the initiative against the Bulgars at an opportune moment.

Net profit of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company, an affiliate of the North American Company, amounted to $3,894,027 for 1942, equal to 89 cents a share for 2,660,928 common shares after preferred dividends, against $2,851,335 or 50 cents a share earned in 1941.

Sprawling his tall frame across the General Sessions witness chair, William Walsh, former business agent of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Independent Union, testified in his defense yesterday at his trial with Harry Waltzer in the alleged extortion of $5,000 last Summer from William Armstrong, head of the Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP) -- With Bill Cowley, their star center, scoring all the goals, the Boston Bruins kept their faint National Hockey League championship hopes alive by defeating the top-place Detroit Red Wings, 3 -- 1, tonight before 12,952 at the Boston Garden.

It is the opinion of Emil Von Elling, the N.Y.U. track mentor, somewhere in the neighborhood of twenty points could annex the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor championship at Madison Square Garden Saturday night. It is also his belief that his Violets are capable of tallying thirty points.

Taking issue with the recent attack on progressive education made by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, the Public Education Association declared in a report made public yesterday that it was "indignant" that progressive education was being made the scapegoat for unrest and rising juvenile delinquency.
AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, March 2 -- Bearded American soldiers on Guadalcanal thought they were dreaming the other day when out of a hospital evacuation plane stepped -- a blonde.

LONDON, March 2 -- An increase of 8,000,000 in income tax receipts, as well as a rise of 9,000,000 in customs and excise receipts, was responsible for the fact that last week's total ordinary revenue was nearly 14,000,000 higher, at 91,879,898, than that of the preceding week.
The Museum of Modern Art has purchased a painting called "The Eternal City," which it considers "remarkably prophetic" of the coming doom of Mussolini and the fascist regime.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2 -- Manhattan registered its seventeenth victory today by subduing the Rutgers five, 55 to 41. Tom Tolan led the Jaspers with 19 points, while Freshman George Mackaronis was high for the Scarlet with 14. Manhattan was ahead at the half, 26 -- 20.

As fresh fruit and vegetable prices rose to the ceilings on the second day of point rationing of canned foods the wholesale produce trade warned yesterday of black markets and disclosed that farmers already were trying to identify shippers who have the highest ceiling prices.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, March 2 -- Forty-eight Japanese were killed and sixty-three were wounded by New Zealand military guards in a prison camp riot in which the Japanese attacked the soldiers with improvised weapons last Thursday, it was revealed tonight. Two New Zealand officers and five guards were wounded, One fatally.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (AP) -- The Louisiana and Kentucky Derby stock of Warren Wright's Ocean Wave received a jolt at the Fair Grounds today when the handsome Calumet charger took a length-and-a-half beating from Ben Whitaker's improved colt Pops Pick in the mile-and-seventy-yard Lake Catherine purse.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 2 -American troops have entered Sbeitla, with its tan stone Roman ruins, its olive groves and its battered, burned houses from which they were forced to retreat fourteen days ago.

The International Harvester Company, in its statement for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1942, issued by Fowler McCormick, president, disclosed a net income of $26,746,552, compared with $30,634,588 for the preceding fiscal year.

The plan whereby regional War Production Board offices will be authorized to issue preference ratings on PD-1A certificates to deliveries of materials valued at $100 or less, starting on March 15, will be of immeasurable assistance to war plants and will cut time of priority assignments from two weeks to one or two days, according to local WPB officials.

At Henry Miller's tonight Gilbert Miller will present Helen Hayes in "Harriet," a play by Florence Ryerson and Colin Clements which covers twenty-seven years in the life of Harriet Beecher Stowe, the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

LONDON, March 2 (U.P.) -- A Polish government shake-up, in which General Wladislaw Sikorski would be supplanted as Premier, may result from the suddenly revived Polish-Russian frontier dispute, diplomatic observers reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Lawyers for George Sylvester Viereck said today they would ask the Department of Justice to cooperate in speeding procedure to release Viereck from jail following yesterday's Supreme Court reversal of his conviction.

Arbitration of trade disputes with Latin America will be particularly important in the post-war world and already there are "danger signals on the horizon" indicating the need for such action under the changed conditions likely to exist after the abnormal war period is ended, Herman G. Brock, vice president of Guaranty Trust Company, declared yesterday.

LONDON, March 2 -- The Polish Government in Exile has received assurances from Britain that the latter adheres to the position adopted at the time the Russian- Polish treaty was signed -- namely, that the atmosphere of war is an unhealthy time to discuss the delicate problems of frontier adjustments.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 2 -- United States Army Air Force Liberators scored hits on the Massaniello mole adjoining the quays during a raid on shipping and dock facilities at Naples yesterday. Attacked by enemy fighters, they shot down one.
POONA, India, March 3 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi was "fed like a child at first because of his weakened condition," his doctors reported as he broke his fast today.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- The Russians today reported advances on the Kharkov, Kursk and Kuban fronts, a continuation of offensive fighting west of Rostov and local operations southwest of Voroshilovgrad. The Germans are resisting in all sectors and their counter-attacks are increasingly persistent.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 3 -- The air might of the Southwest Pacific Command continued today to hammer the Japanese convoy of fourteen ships which ventured out of Rabaul, New Britain, two days ago and which, latest reports indicated, was heading into Lae or Salamaua, New Guinea.

The millions of theatregoers who are expected to see the motion picture "Forever and a Day," which will be released here March 12 at the Rivoli Theatre, will be contributing indirectly to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- A veteran investment banker threw an Erie Railroad refinance hearing into confusion today when he offered to underwrite a deal already negotiated.

To women in men's jobs --standing at whirring lathes, worming inside the wings of future Flying Fortresses, gripping the cold handles of welding torches -- cosmetics have taken on a new and serious meaning.

BUCKNELL had the game won when Joe Daher stepped up to the mound for a four-inning relief trick one chill Spring day in 1934. He blazed in his fast ball with all of his old assurance in the sixth. A frame later some of the speed had departed and by the ninth his arm was dead.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Because of the cold weather which has prevailed in the Eastern States in the last six weeks, the Office of Price Administration has increased the value of the household fuel oil ration coupons for Period 5 in that area from eight or nine gallons to ten gallons. It has fixed the unit for commercial users at 100 gallons.

LONDON, March 3 -- The Association of American Correspondents, meeting in London today, adopted resolutions expressing regret over the reported death of Ben Robertson of The New York Herald Tribune and the loss of Robert P. Post of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who was reported missing after the United States raid on Wilhelmshaven in which he flew as an observer. The resolutions follow:

The War Production Board, which made public yesterday the number of collapsible tin tubes salvaged in January, said it could not understand why the collection had slumped in nearly every State of the union.

Under the new "decentralization" plan for exports, foreign traders may expect a marked decrease in the number of export licenses issued during 1943, Louis L. Horch, manager of the local offices of the Board of Economic Warfare, declared yesterday.

The unusually heavy buying of clothing subsided somewhat yesterday after Lord Taylor, one of the city's largest shops, challenged rumors of imminent rationing with an advertised wager of $5,000 that buying of clothes would not be restricted this year.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (U.P.) -- The United States today countered a German attempt at diplomatic blackmail by interning in this country former German and Italian diplomats who were captured at Algiers during the North African invasion.

William G. McLaughlin, an executive of the International Milling Company of Minnesota, with offices at 11 Broadway, Manhattan, has leased an apartment in 785 Park Avenue through N.A. Berwin Co. and Douglas L. Elliman Co.
There is no air of pessimism surrounding the Hartford office of Russell Hunter, Connecticut's State superintendent of fish and game, concerning the approaching thout season.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- A comprehensive study of industry's post-war problems, especially that of providing jobs for those who must leave war plants and the armed forces, will be made by a special subcommittee of the National Association of Manufacturers, John Airey, a newly elected director of the association, announced here today.

Further nation-wide declines were registered last week in stocks of both light and heavy fuel oil, but gasoline supplies increased sharply, according to the American Petroleum Institute. On the East Coast the index number covering gasoline, light and heavy fuel oils available for civilian use at the close of last week stood at 35.7, compared with 35.2 a week earlier.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 3 -- American and British forces, retracing the trail of their defeat of eighteen days ago, pushed farther toward Sidi bou Zid from Sbeitla, in Central Tunisia, and the British First Army began putting pressure on the Germans in the north after a sharp defeat of enemy thrusts, Allied Headquarters announced today.

The United States Steel Corporation has notified the New York Curb Exchange that it has offered by letter dated March 1 to purchase any and all outstanding shares of common stock of the Pittsburgh, Bessemer Lake Erie Railroad Company at any time to and including June 1 at $41 a share.
If July 1 is to be the date on which the new withholding tax goes into effect, advantage might be taken of it for a compromise solution of the pay-as-you- go problem.

When your Government says that food rationing is good for your health a person may be tempted to say that the Government is an interested party. But when your insurance company tells you that war thrift is good for you there can be no suspicion of motive.

The congregation of Riverside Church learned last night that the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick would be relieved of a large part of his pastoral duties about June 1 but would continue his Sunday morning sermons and Wednesday evening meetings.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 3 -- The "bloody assize" in Alsace -- the section of the German Supreme Court sitting there temporarily -- has moved from Strasbourg to Colmar after imposing several score death sentences. In Colmar, however, the penalties meted out were milder, nothing more than forced labor.

LONDON, March 3 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today there had been "relaxation" of the anti- Jewish restrictions in North Africa under the administration of General Henri Honore Giraud.

Vincent Sheean continues his story of a passionate liberal and humanitarian in "Between the Thunder and the Sun," to be brought out by Random House March 26. Described as a logical successor to "Personal History" and "Not Peace But a Sword," the new book begins with a picture of the European world that was dying in 1938-39 and extends through April, 1942. Mr. Sheean now is a major in the Army Air Force.
ALLIED HEADUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 3 (AP) -- A communique:

Among the spectators at Madison Square Garden Saturday night, following one event in particular, the two-mile run in the twenty-second annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. championships, will be the greatest two-miler in the country, Greg Rice.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A standardization of radio-set parts which will greatly reduce the number of types manufactured but increase the total produced was announced today by the War Production Board. According to Frank H. MacIntosh, assistant director of the board's radio division, it will enable owners of radios to keep their sets in repair for the duration, regardless of the firm which made them or the year in which they were made.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 3 -- Army was defeated by Yale today in a Pentagonal Hockey League clash, 7 to 2. George Burgwin was high man for Yale with three goals. It was the final game of the season for the cadets.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Germany and the countries under her direct administrative control will eat about as well this year as last, the Agricultural Department's Office of Foreign Agricultural Relations estimated today.
ALBANY, March 3 -- A possibility developed here today that Mayor La Guardia may go into military service, which will temporarily require him to give up the office of Mayor.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., March 3 (AP) -- The Mahoney-Troast Construction Company of Passaic received the Army-Navy "E" award today for construction of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation's Plant 7, a huge poured concrete structure in' Southern Bergen County devoted to production of aircraft engines.

Nine institutional users of coffee, chiefly restaurants and lunch counters, have been penalized by the Office of Price Administration for understating their coffee inventories in applying for the right to buy additional supplies, Sylvan Joseph, regional administrator, announced yesterday.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Feb. 24 (Delayed) -- Seventeen survivors from a British merchant ship torpedoed and sunk in the South Atlantic have arrived here after a twenty-one-day ordeal during which their lifeboat was alternately parched by the tropical sun and battered by storms.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, March 4 (AP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 2 -- Administration of justice in the Reich must adjust itself to the policy of the State, Dr. Otto Georg Thierack, Nazi Minister of Justice, declared in a public address in Cologne.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The President saw Postmaster General Walker and other Democratic National Committee members, Under Secretary Welles and Major Curtis Dall, his former son-in-law.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 3 -- The Indianapolis Council of Women, a civic club group, has sent to President Roosevelt and the Indiana Congressional delegation a resolution opposing "any attempt to lower the standards of education by eliminating any course which is regarded as essential by educators or by substituting nonessential courses for fundamental ones."
MOSCOW, March 3 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Mrs. A.M. Sobel and Miss Ruth Sherman won the women's pair title and the cup given by Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright yesterday in the Eastern States contract bridge championships in progress at the Park Central Hotel. The winners had led the field at the end of the first session Tuesday afternoon and their lead was never seriously threatened.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3 -- The New Jersey banking advisory board has under consideration a proposal to limit the total amount of loans secured by real estate, including Federal Housing Administration mortgages, which any State bank or trust company may hold at any one time to a percentage of its time and savings deposits, it was announced today.

Speaking at the Pershing Square Information and War Services Center yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Abdulkadir, a Javanese Princess, told how deeply impressed she was with the great work being done in this country by women in the Red Cross, civilian defense and similar organizations.

Carl B. Robbins, president of the Axton-Fisher Tobacco Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Louisville, Ky., that several attempts had been made to formulate a plan to deal with the company's problem of capitalization, stemming from large arrears of dividends on the preferred and Class A shares, and said the matter would have to be settled within a few months if the company was to meet its "sales demands."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Answers to some questions which housewives have raised since the start of point-rationing of canned, dried and frozen fruits and vegetables were given by the Office of Price Administration today as follows:...
ITHACA, N.Y., March 3 -- Cornell easily defeated Harvard, 63 to 43, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game today.

LONDON, March 3 -- Tiny Albania, which has the briefest independent history of any European nation and which has been constantly embroiled with her neighbors -- Greek, Italian and Yugoslav -- since she was liberated from the Ottoman Empire, is once again seeking to prepare her post-war liberation.

The recent decision of the United States Supreme Court affirming a lower court decision holding nontaxable the common stock dividends made by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in 1939 is expected ultimately to result in other companies ordering such distributions.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Enemy submarine sinkings of United Nations merchant ships will prove to be a "little higher" in February than in January, but the situation is still fairly good when compared with the rate of ship construction, Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said today.

In an apparent attempt to soften a staggering blow to the German people, Berlin itself announced yesterday the withdrawal from the Rzhev salient. The broadcasts were recorded in London by The United Press.

Failure to stop Harry Boykoff was the only flaw in the New York University basketball team's performance before 18,163 persons at Madison Square Garden last night and the damage that the 6-foot 9-inch sophomore did to the Violet cause was irreparable.

Mr. Krock reported from Washington yesterday that Senator Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri is giving serious consideration to offering a resolution which would put both houses of Congress on record in support of an international security system, bulwarked by military force, in which the United States would participate effectively.
NEW DELHI, India, March 3 (AP) -- A United States communique:

Commander Henry E. Rossell, U.S.N., retired, has been elected president and general manager of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company Of Philadelphia and Captain Garland Fulton, U.S.N., retired, has been elected a vice president, the company announced yesterday following action by the board of directors.

Eddie Brannick, secretary of the Giants, yesterday discovered the answer to one of his favorite old-time parodies -- "How ya gonna keep 'em down on the farm, after they've seen Broadway?" It was supplied by none other than Fiddler Bill McGee, who was first violin in the Cardinals' Mudcat band before he came up to do some relief pitching for the Giants commencing with the Spring of 1941.

LONDON, March 3 -- In submitting Royal Navy estimates to the House of Commons today, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, drew a realistic but encouraging picture of the progress of the war at sea.
After moving narrowly in dull trading, the cotton futures market yesterday closed mixed, 1 point lower to 4 points higher than Tuesday's final quotations, with the old-crop options relatively strong.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the new attraction will be "They Got Me Covered," a Samuel Goldwyn production released by RKO and starring Bob Hope and Dorothy Lamour.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who has been named by the Treasury as New York chairman of the newly created War Finance Committee, headed nationally by W.M. Robbins, yesterday appointed his committee, which will cover the Second Federal Reserve District.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Three new vice chairmen of the War Production Board were named today by Donald Nelson to strengthen the powers of Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman.
Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway, accompanied by Lieut. Col. N.R. Ostgaard, aide de camp, have come to the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria from Pooks Hill, Bethesda, Md.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 (AP) -- Fighter planes of the Tenth United States Air Force inflicted widespread damage on Japanese military installations in Northern Burma yesterday and Monday, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A majority of the War Labor Board granted to Boeing Aircraft workers today a general wage increase of 4.5 cents an hour. To this was added a wage adjustment bonus of $78.75 in cash or four war bonds having a face value of $100, plus $5.75 in cash.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Formal announcement of the programs for rationing of meat, cheese, butter and cooking fats and oils, beginning April 1, will be made by the Office of Price Administration within ten days, according to reports tonight.

Whether the massive air offensive that is pounding German cities, military establishments and industrial plants by day and by night is or is not a prelude to an Allied invasion of the European Continent, there is no doubt that it is creating havoc in both Germany's military economy and in German minds.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Proposals by Secretary Knox for a Navy 2,250,000-strong by July, 1944, and big enough to control the world's seaways, and a warning that one out of every ten Navy men might be killed or wounded were made public by the House subcommittee on naval appropriations today in finishing work on a new $4,000,000,000 supplemental naval appropriation measure.
LONDON, March, 4 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Perhaps no decree coming out of Washington since war began has stirred up more bitter antagonism and discontent on the seething farm front than Economic Stabilizer Byrnes's order for time and one-half costs to accompany the forty-eight-hour industrial week.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Tyler Brooke, 52, veteran musical comedy actor and film comedian, was found dead in his automobile in the garage of his home last night by his wife after she discovered a note indicating his intention to commit suicide.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced today that beginning July 1 Princeton would operate on a drastically altered academic calendar with four terms of equal length rather than two normal terms and a shorter Summer session.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island denied today that there had been any changing of dates in his recent quotation of a memorandum of former President Herbert Hoover on the subject of sending troops overseas in 1917.

" Since Gandhi's fast has so happily terminated, now is the time to forget the bitter past and to open negotiations between the Viceroy's Council and the Indian political leaders," Dr. S. Chandra-Sekhar, member of the All-India National Congress and a friend of Mr. Gandhi, told the Advertising Club of New York at the weekly luncheon yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 3 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant General Joseph I W. Stilwell, commander of U.S. forces in the Far East, and the Chinese War Minister, General Ho Ying-chin, returned today from a tour of Allied bases in India, heartened by the military regeneration of the two Chinese armies driven from Burma last Spring.

POONA, India, March 3 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's fast ended at 9:30 this morning. It was 8:30, however, to Mr. Gandhi, who, like most old-fashioned Indians, does not observe the government's daylight saving.

A shrine to the North American Jesuit martyrs was dedicated yesterday at Fordham University by the Most Rev. Bonaventure Broderick, Vicar for Religious of the Archdiocese of New York, before a thousand persons at the university church on the Bronx campus.

CHUNGKING, China, March 3 (U.P.) -- United States Army fliers, dealing new blows to the Japanese invaders of Yunnan Province, have obliterated an enemy base west of the Salween River and successfully attacked motorized concentrations, it was announced tonight.

LONDON, March 3 -- Currency arrangements and other post-war financial questions of common interest were discussed today at a conference under the chairmanship of Ralph Assheton, Financial Secretary, at which the Finance Ministers of Allied countries having headquarters in London and representatives of the French National Committee, the Dominions and the Governments of the United States, Russia and China were present.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The equal rights amendment was reported favorably today to the House Judiciary Committee by a subcommittee on which the major parties were equally represented.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Labor Committee will have a hearing soon on a bill for an annual appropriation of $6,000,000 to the Children's Bureau for maternal and infant care for families of enlisted men, Representative Mary T. Norton, chairman, promised today.

Hortense Monath, pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. Miss Monath's performances during the course of a serious and noble program reached their peak of achievement in an unfoldment, of the "Thirty-two Variations on an Original Theme" in C minor of Beethoven.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 3 -- Princeton virtually eliminated Penn from the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race tonight, winning by 48 -- 27 before 1,200 spectators in the university gym. The victory tightened Nassau's hold on second place and left the Quakers with only a mathematical chance of sharing the league crown.

General Emile Bethouart, personal representative in the United States of General Henri Honore Giraud, appealed last night for union among French factions until "the French people are free to speak" regarding France's future.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 4 -- The destruction of twenty-two ships in a Japanese convoy by Allied planes north of New Guinea yesterday was our fourth victory over the Japanese Fleet in the Pacific war.
CHUNGKING, China, March 3 (AP) -- A communique from the headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph Stillwell:
ALBANY, March 3 -- Virtual agreement was reached today on a program for the more extensive use of women and of minors of 16 to 18 in industry to meet the labor shortage created by the war.
Mme. Chiang Kai-shek was received by an audience of 3,000 Chinese yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall as First Lady of China, the wife of the Generalissimo of its armies.

COMMANDO-RANGER TRAINING STATION, Somewhere in Scotland, March 1 (Delayed) -- America's Rangers, the hard-hitting raid specialists whose existence first became known after their participation in the Dieppe raid last Aug. 19, have just done their stuff for the benefit of a visiting party headed by Major Gen. Russell P. Hartle, United States field commander for the European theatre, and including other high British and American officers of various branches of the service.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., had last year a net operating profit of $2,176,035 after taxes, contrasted to a loss of $487,613 in 1941, according to the annual statement submitted by Jack Frye, president, for publication today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- The International Hydro-Electric System filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to facilitate compliance with a "death sentence" order by merger of two companies into a newly formed corporation and the issuance of $13,968,000 in new bonds by the new company.

Deliveries in the hand-made glassware market have been made tighter by the placing of large orders by several department stores, which until now had been holding back their confirmations, manufacturers reported yesterday. Although immediate deliveries were requested, shipments on most lines of blown and pressed ware will not be made before six weeks or sixty days, it was said.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Muted colors set the theme for the "symphony" of fashion presented by Arnold-Constable yesterday at the weekly style show in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Like a symphony, the showing was divided into four parts: a group of clothes for country wear; a city group; a scherzo miscellany of clothes for bright Spring days, and a finale of simple up-to-the-minute evening dresses.

Floyd N. Dull, president of the New York Board of Trade, announced yesterday that petitions had been sent to Governor Dewey and legislative leaders urging increased subway fares and opposing additional city sales taxes. His statement followed a directors' meeting at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

The Sheen Vault Company of Brooklyn has leased 10,000 square feet of space at 1180 Randall Avenue, in the Bronx, from the John F. McGowan Marble Company. The property, formerly used for a marble works, will be utilized by the lessee for heavy metal work for war purposes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Rules Committee set the stage today for a clear-cut fight on the floor next week over "government by directive" when it granted an open rule for the Disney bill, which combines an increase in the debt limit with a revocation of the President's salary limitation order.

Two-million-share days on the New York Stock Exchange have not caught Wall Street off guard. A brief poll of houses of all sizes yesterday found none which did not close each of the two days "up to date," although the working day for the back-office staffs was generally ten or eleven hours.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE in South China, March 2 (Delayed) -- The Spring weather was glorious today, so Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chenault's China Air Task Force decided to irritate the Japanese a little on the other side of the Salween River in Yunnan Province near Burma.

In Africa the Red Cross is not sitting back in comfortable hospitals 100 or 200 miles behind the battlefront, but is at work within a mile, and sometimes less, of the actual fighting, it was reported yesterday by Lieut. Col. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who spoke at a rally of the Manhattan Women's Special Gifts Committee of the Red Cross War Fund of New York City.

Although they can't go anywhere themselves in the National Hockey League race, the Rangers remain an important factor in the campaign. Frank Boucher's skaters, hopelessly lodged in last place, nevertheless constitute a stumbling block for at least two teams who still retain hopes of qualifying for the post-season championship competition.

Let us hope that the war will not postpone immediate relief for Puerto Rico, whose pitiful condition has just been revealed again to Congressional visitors. That pitiful condition has existed since we took over the island from Spain.

A street-by-street, house-to-house canvass will be held Sunday in residential sections throughout the city from 3 to 7 P.M. under the direction of the Greater New York Committee of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign to round up worthwhile books for service men.

A $425,000 trust set up in 1929 for Representative Clare Boothe Luce by her first husband, the late George T. Brokaw, is not liable for any part of the $164,000 taxes assessed against his estate. Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The quadrennial pilgrimage of political groups to the White House to urge the President to run for another term began today. It is a little earlier than usual. Not until tomorrow will the President celebrate the tenth anniversary of his assumption of office, and so the pilgrims arrived a day before the true dramatic unities of politics prescribed their visit.

LONDON, March 3 -- The strategic Nazi central-front stronghold of Rzhev fell to the Russian Army today after a violent struggle in which 2,000 Germans were killed and enormous booty was captured, Moscow announced tonight in a special communique, which also told of a Red Army sweep in the south to a point only forty-five miles from the Bryansk-Kiev railway.

With due recognition of the fact that farm labor has become one of the most critical problems now before the country, we believe that the Senate Military Affairs Committee has made a serious mistake in recommending sweeping deferment for all farm workers from the draft.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- American troops without battle experience made the same errors in Tunisia that they had made in practice manoeuvres in this country, Lieut. Gen. Leslie J. McNair, commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, disclosed today, but he asserted that the lessons learned in Tunisia already were being used here in an effort to train "a more nearly mistake-proof Army."

LONDON, Thursday, March 4 -- The Royal Air Force, in its round-the-clock bombing offensive, struck at Germany or occupied territory every day in February and on twenty-six of the twenty-eight nights, establishing a new record for consistency.

The annual report of the Crane Company, manufacturer of valves and fittings, announced yesterday, shows for 1942 a net profit of $4,824,602 transferred to earned surplus. This is equal to $1.64 a share on 2,348,628 shares of common stock after allowing for preferred dividend requirements.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Overriding Presidential opposition, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary approved today and recommended passage of a much-amended McKellar bill which would subject 25,000 to 30,000 officials and employes of the government to Senate confirmation.
LONDON, March 3 -- This was a noisy night in London. The noise was occasioned by the German Luftwaffe's anticipated reprisal for the latest Royal Air Force attack on Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Navy officials reported today they had been "kidding" themselves in thinking that the peacetime physical training program, incluing varsity athletics at the Annapolis academy, would condition men for war.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 3 -- It rained copiously last night and today in the provinces of Buenos Aires and in the greater part of the cereal belt, which this Summer suffered a drought of unusual severity, lasting almost uninterruptedly since the end of November.

With any sort of luck in casting, a Spring presentation by John Golden of the Phoebe and Henry Ephron play, tentatively called "The Wife Takes a Child," is practically assured, Mr. Ephron said yesterday. Once held by Max Gordon and subsequently tested by John C. Wilson, the script now has a new third act Mr. Ephron, who manages the stage for "Junior Miss," probably will direct.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Clarence E. Doan, vice president of the Philadelphia Wool and Textile Association, said today that the Department of Agriculture was considering a plan to control the country's wool production by outright purchase of the entire 1943 supply at ceiling prices and rationing it to mills for war and civilian purposes.

A Coast Guardsman was killed last night when the fishing schooner America, inbound for New York, collided with an Erie Railroad tug named the Johnson City in the East River off Beckman Street, near the Fulton Fish Market.
Brisk snow flurries followed by slowly falling temperatures and fresh winds turned New York white and cold yesterday and the Weather Bureau forecast even more chilly weather for today.

Wanda Landowska arranged and put on an evening of exquisite music and musicianship at Carnegie Hall last night. Though she is quite capable of enchanting an audience all alone, she chose to call in a group of colleagues. With them she played a handsome sheaf of Bach and a delectable Mozart concerto.

Harry Waltzer testified as the closing defense witness yesterday in his General Sessions trial with William Walsh, his former co-business agent in the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Independent Union, in their alleged attempt to extort $5,000 last June from William Armstrong, publisher of the Armstrong Racing Publications, Inc., at 350 West Thirty-fourth Street.

A sparkling fourth-quarter rally sparked by Harry Johnson enabled Andrew Jackson to down Forest Hills, 32 to 27, and capture the Queens P.S.A.L. championship in the feature game of a Madison Square Garden scholastic basketball double-header yesterday.

There is a movement afoot -- it originated with the Office of Fishery Coordination of the Department of the Interior -- to increase the production of fish that are easily caught but ordinarily neglected. In explaining the plan, which is a wartime conservation measure, officials say that there are many varieties that are customarily weeded out of a haul and thrown back into the sea.

WAR, even in the best of circumstances, is nine-tenths waiting, which in itself is one of the worst tortures that can be inflicted on a human being. No more subtly pernicious punishment could have been devised by the Nazis than to keep the French soldiers incarcerated in German concentration camps after the signing of an armistice.
CHICAGO, March 3 -- Representatives of railroad labor presented arguments and statistics before two Presidential fact findings commissions today to support wage demands.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Nine air attacks, in which 1,000 bombs -- an estimated total bomb load of 500,000 pounds -- fell on Kiska, Japanese-held stronghold in the Aleutians, were carried out by United States aircraft during February, and American airmen maintained a combat superiority of 10 to 0 over Japanese planes, the Navy announced today.

SCRANTON, March 3 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, told the tri-district anthracite convention, which opened sessions today to formulate demands for a new wage contract for 80,000 hard coal miners, that the 600,000 coal diggers of the country were determined to obtain substantial wage increases regardless of the contention of government agencies that such increases would be "inflationary."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Ways and means of solving the plight of refugees from Axis-dominated countries without regard to religion or race are expected to receive intensive consideration from the British and American Government as a result of diplomatic exchanges between them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3 -- Columbia defeated Yale, 62 to 56, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League contest in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight, although the Elis led throughout the first half, at the end of which they had a 29-to-26 advantage.

The long-awaited regulation of the Office of Price Administration to relieve the "squeeze" on liquor retailers will have little immediate effect on current price levels in this highly competitive market, trade observers asserted yesterday. Despite the provision of the regulation which permits markups of as much as 20 per cent above net costs, effective Monday, there was no rush on the part of consumers to stock up and sales volume yesterday was only average.

The Ballet Theatre will return to the Metropolitan Opera House for a Spring season of twenty-nine performances under the auspices of S. Hurok beginning April 1 and ending May 2. Performances will be omitted during Holy Week, April 19-24, and also on April 8 and 9, when the company goes to Philadelphia.

Gandhi's fast has ended, and he is still alive. He has made his moral demonstration. The British too have made their demonstration. They have vindicated what is to the Western mind a principle. They have refused to swerve from an admittedly legal position under the coercion of a humanitarian appeal, even an appeal as moving as that of the life or death of a man as universally respected in India as Gandhi.

A monopolistic conspiracy alleged to increase substantially the cost of fresh fruits and vegetables to consumers while reducing the returns to farmers for these products was charged yesterday in a Federal indictment. The true bill, naming two associations, two auction companies, thirteen trucking corporations, twelve receiver corporations and sixteen individuals, was returned by a grand jury in Federal court here.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Assertions that "economic theorists" in the Office of Price Administration were responsible for the "critical" situation in canned goods were made by fruit and vegetable canners at a hearing before the House Committee on Agriculture today.

Patrolman Joseph F. Finnerty, who went berserk while patrolling his beat in the Bergen Street precinct on the night of Feb. 6, was declared insane yesterday when arraigned before Kings County Judge Franklin Taylor on a charge of first-degree assault.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Wheat futures moved up 3/4 cent a bushel early trading today on the Board of Trade, but buying by mills was not as aggressive and reports were current that much of the recent demand for flour had been satisfied.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Answering accusations that the Russian Government had committed a "bloody crime" by executing two Polish labor leaders, the Soviet Embassy said tonight that the two men, Henryk Erlich and Victor Alter, had been convicted as spies and subversive agents.

A national system of unemployment insurance, in which the funds of the forty-eight States and the territories would be pooled, was proposed yesterday by Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board.

Distinction rather than so-called "high style" was the aim and the achievement of the beautiful Spring fashion collection presented yesterday by Henri Bendel. Changes in living imposed by the war were evident in the simplicity of the clothes and their definitely for-the-duration quality in fabric and workmanship.

The unusual protest of Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb in General Sessions yesterday on the severity of a mandatory sentence Judge Owen W. Bohan was about to impose on Harry Rose, 49 years old, as an ex-convict, brought a prompt shift by the court from the mandatory five to ten years to two and one-half to five years.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, told a Senate investigating committee today that he would apply dollar-and-cents community-wide retail price ceilings to pork and beef to enable the housewife to help beat the black market.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 3 -- The slackening of discipline among German troops reported almost daily from Norway and Poland has now become apparent in Denmark. Tonight's reports from that country state that a group of recruits refused to sing "Wir Fahren Gegen England" [We Sail Against England].

TORONTO, March 3 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Gordon Conant of Ontario tonight announced acceptance of the resignation of Provincial Treasurer Mitchell Hepburn and in a letter to Mr. Hepburn indicated this action stemmed from disagreement with Mr. Hepburn's opposition to the Dominion Government.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 3 -- An attempt by Randolph Phillips of 36 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York, to bring about the ouster of the present management of the United Corporation, in which he holds 1,000 shares, apparently met with failure today at the annual meeting of stockholders.

In line with its growing tendency to relax some restrictions on the manufacture and sale of consumer goods, the War Production Board will release to the general public by April 1 a sizable portion of the mechanical refrigerators now frozen and obtainable only on a priority basis, manufacturers reported here yesterday.

Formal offering will be made today of five municipal Housing Authority bond issues aggregating $19,712,000 awarded on Tuesday to a syndicate headed by Shields Co. The offering syndicate announced yesterday includes the following:

Net profit of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in 1942 amounted to $6,480,908, equal to $4.63 a share for the common stock, comparing with $8,189,578, or $5.85 a share earned in 1941, according to the pamphlet report signed by George W. McRae, president.
ALGIERS, Algeria, March 3 -- Colonel Maurice Herviot has been replaced by Colonel Ferdinand Taillardat as Director of Public Security in the Morocco Provisional Government, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The rate of increase of the shipping strength of the United Nations, which may prove the decisive factor in the war, is still such as to limit the military blows that may be struck at the enemy in 1943, Sir Arthur Salter, head of the British merchant shipping mission in this country, told a press conference here today.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- The death on active service of Captain Stephen Haggard, 31, son of Sir Godfrey Digby Napier Haggard, the British Consul General in New York, was announced here today.

In perfect fighting condition and eager for action, Beau Jack, world lightweight champion, and Fritzie Zivic, former welterweight titleholder, yesterday concluded training for their twelve-round return bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

A joint meeting of representatives of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railroad Brotherhoods, held here yesterday to launch a drive for a $4,000,000 war relief fund, was hailed as a forerunner of a reunited labor movement throughout the country.

Felix Lantiat, a soft-spoken, retiring, gray-haired man who has been chef de cuisine of many famous hotels and clubs in the United States, has obeyed the urge to play some part in the war -- despite his 67 years -- by signing up as a steward in the merchant marine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 3 -- Philip Dorn and Donna Reed will be co-starred in a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer picture titled "Malta," which will pay tribute to the resistance of the people of that most-bombed island. The film will be produced by Joseph Pasternak from a screen play by John Wexley.

The first "V Emergency" flags, exempting trucks carrying war materials from the nation-wide speed limit of thirty-five miles an hour set by the Office of Defense Transportation to conserve rubber, will go into use in the metropolitan area today.

The suggestion is made by Bernhard Ostrolenk to import a million farm workers from Mexico to alleviate the shortage of manpower in our agricultural districts. It is a matter of public record, and was also stated by this writer in a broadcast a week ago, that since the Fall of 1942 great numbers of Mexican farm workers have been sent to this country.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 -- Machinists affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted late today to return to their jobs at the Alameda shipyard of the General Engineering and Dry-dock Company after a two-day strike which delayed construction and repair work under Navy contracts.
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh declared yesterday that all the 5,600 uniformed members of the Fire Department off duty when the air raid alert was sounded Tuesday night obeyed the departmental order requiring them to report to their assigned stations.

Citing the fine cooperation between Colin Kelly and Meyer Levin, Magistrate Charles Solomon in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday found a man guilty of disorderly conduct for reviling another of a different faith.

LONDON, March 3 -- After opening steady today the stock markets became dull toward the close of trading, business being on a small scale. Gilt-edge stocks held yesterday's small gains, but home rails eased fractionally, with Great Western losing 1/4 and London, Midland Scottish and Southern deferred each down the same amount.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Mrs. Roosevelt called on the imagination of Americans today to make fashionable and attractive the exigencies of wartime living. Gazing down on pillbox hats as she addressed the Washington Fashion Group, she advised that functional apparel become the mode, that in every way women take the short cut to victory, whether it be rationing or transportation.

Advertisers are still attempting unsuccessfully to get the OPA to rescind its rule that premiums given consistently with a product cannot be abandoned unless the product's price is reduced by the value of the premium. The one exception which OPA has made is in the case of tobacco products.
