PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- Louis B. Mayer's compensation of $949,765.84 in 1942 as managing director of production for Loew's, Inc., was $245,339.24 more than he received in 1941.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 3 (AP) -- Supply Minister John A. Beasley announced today that Australia had accepted the responsibility of feeding United States forces in this country and throughout the South and Southwest Pacific areas and said that he had authorized the purchase of $64,000,000 worth of provisions.

Among the 800 men asked to show their draft cards yesterday, second day of the city-wide check-up by public offices in behalf of selective service, there was one visitor at the State Motor Vehicle Bureau who had to search himself virtually down to the skin for ten minutes.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Container board mills were directed by the War Production board today to set aside 25 per cent of their monthly kraft and jute container board production for allocation by WPB to container manufacturers making V-boxes for the armed forces and lend-lease.

AT UNITED HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, March 4 -- A deadly, efficient armada of Allied planes has practically destroyed a powerful Japanese convoy in one of the greatest triumphs of the war, sinking or disabling all ten of its warships and all twelve of its transports, wiping out 15,000 troops aboard and downing fifty-five Japanese fighting planes, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Men in the Army are suffering less from Winter ailments than the civil population in some parts of the country, the Journal of the American Medical Association said today.
LONDON, March 3 (AP) -- A special Russian communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
CHICAGO, March 3 -- American League batters may find a highball refreshing this Summer -- that is, the kind they hit into the outfield.

Inflationary possibilities tinged the stock market to such an extent yesterday that the volume of shares traded rose to the highest since late 1941 and prices of various issues rose 1 to 2 points. Business continued heaviest in low-price stocks and in those with speculative possibilities, although the force of the trading drew the more standard shares into the advance.
LONDON, March 3 -- King George has become a part-time worker in a war factory, standing at a bench two nights a week turning out precision parts for Royal Air Force guns.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary Knox and Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told the House Naval Affairs Committee today that absenteeism was a mounting restraint on war production and urged legislative action to keep workers on the job steadily, including if necessary the cancellation of draft deferments for able-bodied "willful absentees," and fines or wage penalties for those not subject to the draft.

When the Russians struck toward Rzhev last Fall Hitler warned his commanders that its loss would be "equal to the loss of half of Berlin." Now he has given it up, after a hard fight that cost him heavily. This ends the last present Nazi threat to Moscow and marks the beginning of a German retreat in north Russia that may yet match the forced withdrawals in the south.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, March 4 -- King George and Queen Elizabeth dropped into an American Red Cross club in Northampton today and swapped small talk with American soldiers there.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter granted permission yesterday to minority stockholders of the North American Company to discontinue a suit for recovery of several thousand dollars allegedly lost by the company through payments made as political contributions in St. Louis several years ago by a subsidiary, the Union Electric Company of Missouri.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- The Red Army was reported today to be advancing in a southwesterly direction from Rzhev along the line of the enemy retreat, forcing the Germans to abandon lines on which a stand had been intended and beating back counter-attacks.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 4 (AP) -- A communique:

Service men's wives who come to New York to spend a leave with their husbands are fairly fastidious about their accommodations. Much of the confusion on Saturday nights could be avoided, hotels and organizations dealing with service men declare, by a little more cooperation.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Quota restrictions on sales of roasted coffee by roasters were removed by order of the Office of Price Administration today. The restrictions, originally scheduled to become effective Jan. 1 and since postponed, were intended to limit 1943 sales of roasted coffee by roasters to 75 per cent of sales during a corresponding month last year.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The citizenship case of William Schneiderman, secretary of the Communist party of California, will be reargued March 12 in the Supreme Court by Wendell L. Willkie and Solicitor General Fahy.

Carlton J. Hayes, our Ambassador to Spain, has disclosed rather startling information in an address delivered by him in Madrid on Feb. 26. He is quoted as saying that the quantity of petroleum products in Spain now is "considerably higher than the present per capita distribution to the people of the Atlantic seaboard of the United States itself."

Investors were advised to pay more attention to the wealth of information available on companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and not buy stocks merely because they look cheap, in a statement issued in Chicago yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the big market.

Once again the Allied forces in the Pacific have been able to score a victory that writes a new page in military history. Allied, principally American, planes have attacked a large Japanese convoy, and have annihilated it to the last man and ship in what the official communique describes as a "major disaster to the enemy."

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- On this, the opening day of the President's eleventh year in office, the Lewisites and the Davisites are moving their forces into position for another great battle, in which those bystanders, the public and the price-level, are likely to be the chief victims.

The board of directors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra takes full responsibility for the recently announced discharge of fourteen members of the ensemble, Marshall Field, chairman of the board, declared in a statement yesterday.

The first of a fleet of mercy ships bearing the flag of the International Red Cross will sail from Philadelphia next week with a cargo of food parcels and other gifts for American prisoners of war in Axis countries, and will proceed directly to Marseille under a safe conduct from both groups of belligerents, it was disclosed yesterday.

BOSTON, March 4 (AP) -- A single torpedo fired in the dead of night from an enemy submarine sent a cargo passenger ship to its grave in the North Atlantic with a loss of 678 lives in the greatest United States sea disaster since the war began, survivors reported today.

A voice over the Nazi radio helped make this week's double-alarm air raid test a success. The voice warned us that this and other cities "may not be safe a few months hence." Some of us needed this reminder. Some of us are like the man who dropped his life insurance: he had given it a fair trial for some years and hadn't died.

There is a certain financial district building which may not be named. It has as tenant a certain corporation which may not be named. The corporation is doing some kind of secret work for the government. One day this week a man from the Federal Bureau of Investigation happened in.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Because India in the opinion of United States experts could supply the entire Burma-China-India front if properly developed, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, stated today that $295,501,494 worth of goods had been sent to that country since March 11,1941.

Colonel Allan M. Pope, president of the First Boston Corporation, will head a group of seventy-five seasoned bond men who will act as instructors to perfect the sales organization for the April drive of the United States Treasury War Finance Committee, it was announced yesterday by Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee, which, with the War Savings Staff, will undertake the April campaign.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 4 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the United Corporation was recessed today until next Wednesday at 2 P.M. to permit the proxy inspectors to complete a tabulation of the votes polled by Randolph Phillips of 36 East Sixty-seventh Street, New York, and by the management in their contest for control of the concern.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussion, Federal income-tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

Returning from a four and a half month tour of many American camps, Carole Landis, motion picture actress, said yesterday that the morale of our troops was "extremely high." She arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic clipper.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 27 were 26 per cent above the same week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 33 per cent for the week ended Feb. 20 over the corresponding week of 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Discussions are well under way to obtain United Nations' agreement on post-war relief and monetary stabilization before the end of the war, it was learned today. Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, urged in an address at Toronto on Feb. 26 that such pre-peace agreements be reached.

MOSCOW, March 4 -- The horror and glory of Stalingrad's historic defense are remarkably recorded in the new Soviet documentary film shown here last night. The picture is composed of scenes photographed during the height of the series of battles.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- An inquiry into the causes of all Army and Navy plane accidents since the start of the defense program has been started by the Senate War Investigating Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The newspapers of the United States were hailed today by Representative Halleck of Indiana as "one of the most essential and vital factors in the winning of the war," and the House applauded.
Bill Cox, new owner of the Phils, conferred with President Ford Frick of the National League in the latter's office here yesterday, "but was not talking about the purchase of the club," Frick said.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A letter of congratulation has been sent by Secretary Stimson to Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Brooks Sr., of 477 Midland Avenue, Syracuse, N.Y., who have five sons in the armed forces.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 4 -- A telegram was sent to President Roosevelt by Prime Minister Mackenzie King felicitating him on the tenth anniversary of his Presidency and congratulating the United States "on the magnificent successes" of air and naval forces under United States command in the Pacific.

The disposition of several hundred pleasure-driving cases, where motorists' ration books had been taken by Office of Price Administration investigators or their license number reported to local rationing boards before the OPA called off enforcement of the ban on pleasure driving, was in doubt last night.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 4 -- A varied program for attaining physical fitness is being carried out in Westchester County for the benefit of men and women in war occupations, who plan to enter them or who want to be healthier to get more enjoyment out of life.

LONDON, March 4 -- Lord Beaverbrook, former Minister of Aircraft Production, demanded dive-bombers and transport planes for the British Army in a speech in the House of Lords today, and declared the government should start building them in this country immediately.

As the volume of business on the New York Stock Exchange again topped the two million-share mark, the stock market climbed yesterday into new high ground, but it had to contend with profit-taking near the close which reduced gains. A much better brand of leadership was apparent, and there was a noticeable let-up in trading in the "penny" issues, the recent extent of which had caused considerable concern in Wall Street.

WEST POINT, N.Y., March 4 -- In celebration of the 141st anniversary of the founding of the Military Academy the National Broadcasting Company network will present a program between 7 and 7:30 P.M. on March 13. During the event twelve Army generals may be heard, most of them talking directly from theatres of operations.

LOS ANGELES, March 4 --Union leaders from far separated sections of the Pacific Coast, converging here tonight for strategy conferences, voiced sharp criticism of the majority of the War Labor Board for its "unacceptable" wage award in the coast aircraft industry.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, testified today that "illegitimate absenteeism'' among shipyard workers was costing an estimated 100 Liberty ships annually. He endorsed legislation designed to curb absenteeism by requiring shipyard foremen to report to local draft boards the names of workers absent without sufficient cause, with a view to possible induction into the armed forces.

Five truckmen were arrested and 7,000 pounds of edible meat confiscated yesterday as Mayor La Guardia launched a drive to wipe out black markets in meat. Two of those arrested were subsequently found guilty of violating the Sanitary Code and fined $250 each for having improperly inspected meat in their possession.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Court of Appeals was asked today to rule whether the proposed merger of the Horace Mann and Lincoln Schools at Teachers College, Columbia University, would carry out the purpose of the General Education Board, doner of a trust.

Business must be prepared to provide jobs for 56,000,000 persons, 10,000,000 more than were employed in the pre-war period of 1940, Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development and president of the Studebaker Corporation, declared yesterday afternoon at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, at 65 Liberty Street.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered eleven major airlines today to show cause why they should not reduce passenger fares 10 per cent. The carriers have fifteen days to reply.

In request by the WPB yesterday that all textile mills adopt the 48-hour week brought comment from industry spokesmen here that a more realistic approach to the industry's manpower and price ceiling problems than the mere request to adopt three-shift operations is needed to eliminate threatened scarcities of textile products before the end of 1943.

LONDON, March 4 -- Viscount Cranborne made it quite clear in the House of Lords today that until Burma was reconquered and the Burma Road reopened China could not expect any improvement in the supplies being sent from Britain. From this essential objection the attention of the United States and British Governments would not be diverted, the government leader in the upper house said.

At a special meeting of the Board of Education yesterday the members voted approval of seventeen bills and disapproval of thirty-four others relating to educational matters now pending before the Legislature in Albany. No action was taken on five bills.

While his mother, who received word recently that her other son had been killed aboard a destroyer in the battle of the Solomons, wept softly in Bronx County Court yesterday, 21-year-old William Bryant and his co-defendant, James McDermott, 19, halted their first-degree murder trial and pleaded guilty to second degree murder in the death of Philip Hochman, who was killed in a hold-up in his grocery store last Aug. 4.

The Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, without previous experience in the field, has in the last two years become a leading volume producer of ordnance fire-control equipment, Harold W. Sweatt, president, declared in the annual report to stockholders issued for publication today.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
ALBANY, March 4 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals today held picketing an illegal means of prosecuting a jurisdictional dispute between rival labor unions.

Five of the six non-subscription concerts to be presented during the post-season of the Metropolitan Opera House, starting Monday night, March 15, have been announced by Edward Johnson, general manager. The opera and cast for the final performance will be announced later.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Classification of the editor of the Navy's official cook-book as a specialist -- "a technician just like experts on Diesel engines or ordnance" -- brought a protest on the floor of the House today from Representative Ditter of Pennsylvania.

Bank clearings for the twenty-three leading cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday rose 20.6 per cent over the total for the previous holiday week and 10.3 per cent above the $7,712,298,000 recorded in the corresponding week last year, according to the report yesterday of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, Feb. 7 (Delayed) -- In contrast with the arrogance shown by the Japanese when they are top dog, most Japanese prisoners are the most servile so-called members of the human race which can be imagined.

SCRANTON, Pa, March 4 -- The scale committee of the tri-district convention of anthracite miners, presided over by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, formally recommended in a report to the convention today that an increase of $2 a day be demanded for 80,000 Pennsylvania hard-coal diggers in forthcoming negotiations for a new contract.

The Canadiens of Montreal kept alive their chances of reaching the play-offs by handing the Rangers a 7-to-2 setback at Madison Square Garden last night. In fifth place in the National Hockey League race, the Flying Frenchmen still have a mathematical chance of climbing to fourth, thus qualifying for the post-season competition.

Outdoor enthusiasts, who have reveled in the finest snow conditions in many years this Winter, will enjoy superb skiing again for the next few days, generally speaking. Reports from the North yesterday indicated not only ample opportunities for running slopes and traills this week-end, but a prolonged season of Spring skiing in the mountains.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Selective Service Bureau disclosed today a broad liberalization of its draft-deferment policies for college students.
According to newspaper reports the Mayor was pleased with the efficiency of last night's air raid test. He also drew the conclusion that the public well understood the meaning of the various signals.
HOLLYWOOD, March 4 (AP) -- The movie academy award for the best motion picture of 1942 went tonight to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for "Mrs. Miniver," which starred Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon.

Rupert Thomas of Princeton, referee for the twenty-second annual intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track championships, will hold his seeding conference tonight, when final plans will be completed for the renewal tomorrow of the college championships in Madison Square Garden.

Shoe retailers will get further relief from the Office of Price Administration on merchandising problems created by the recent rationing order, in the opinion of trade leaders who held individual conferences with government officials yesterday and Wednesday, following the two-day conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association.

FRITZIE ZIVIC, the silent Pittsburgher, never says a word -- when he is asleep. How his vocal cords remain inactive for eight to ten hours a night is one of nature's deepest and most unfathomable mysteries. Heaven knows that they need the rest, but their reflex actions should be so acutely developed by this time that they should be making sounds even without any help from the former welterweight champion.

The Indian people can gain their freedom at the end of the war "either as a dominion inside the British Commonwealth, or, if they prefer it, as an independent nation outside," Malcolm MacDonald, British High Commissioner to Canada, declared yesterday in an address before the Rotary Club of New York at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- As the first step in the plan to put all meats under dollars and cents price ceilings and thus strike a blow at black markets, the Office of Price Administration fixed maximum retail prices today for the five most popular pork products and said that these and specific prices for other pork cuts would go into effect April 1.

Planning for the peace involves more than a set of blueprints covering frontier revisions, international trade relations, world organization for peace, domestic reforms directed to the building of a better world for the masses.
Two contract bridge teams of four began play last night for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy and the Eastern States team championship in the tournament in progress at the Park Central Hotel here.

LONDON, Friday, March 5 -- The Red Army has regained control of the Moscow-Velikiye Luki railway in its drive toward the Latvian frontier, has routed two more German garrisons below Lake Ilmen and is threatening to cut the main Nazi rail artery linking Bryansk and Kiev in the south, two Soviet communiques disclosed today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 4 -- Twenty-five pert American misses in the trim blue uniform of Army nurses have arrived in this theatre to undertake the hazardous task of acting as nurses on transport planes evacuating wounded from the front.

Three hundred members of the nursing profession yesterday heard Mrs. Walter Lippmann, national director of the Volunteer Nurse's Aide Corps of the American Red Cross, come out against the small salaries paid graduate nurses in hospitals.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The prospective allowance of 1 3/4 pounds of meat a week to individuals when rationing begins next month may be increased later in the year, officials said today.
Three players gained the semifinals of the Red Cross benefit tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Yale Club last night.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, March 5 (AP) -- The noon commnique:

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Further action is to be expected in the Southwest Pacific theatre, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, indicated today as he hailed the "brilliant victory" over the Japanese flotilla in the Bismarck Sea and asserted it constituted "a severe reversal for Japan and one that disrupts their plans for the coming campaign in the Southwest Pacific."

WASHINGTON, March 4 (U.P.) -- Rubber Director William H. Jeffers predicted tonight that the country would be over the hump of the rubber problem by midsummer of 1944, but until then it would be "scraping the bottom of the barrel."

New arraignments in the Children's Court division of the city's Domestic Relations Court last month showed an increase of 124 over February, 1942, jumping from 617 to 741, according to comparative statistics released yesterday by Justice W. Bruce Cobb.

Dr. Lawson G. Lowry, New York psychiatrist, in an address yesterday at a luncheon of the women's field army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, in the Hotel Commodore, said that Mme. Chiang Kai-shek's plea at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night against recrimination and hatred toward our enemies in the post-war reconstruction period might become a stumbling block in our efforts to build a world in which further wars would be impossible.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- On the tenth anniversary today of his first inauguration, President Roosevelt and about 250 leaders of the government's executive, legislative and judicial branches attended divine services in the East Room of the White House.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (U.P.) -- The Federal Trade Commission said tonight that it had issued a complaint charging P. Lorillard Company, Inc., Jersey City, with misrepresentations in its current advertising campaigns for Old Gold, Beech Nut and Sensation cigarettes and Friends Smoking Tobacco.

A report that Secretary of Agriculture Wickard is prepared to ask for an increase of 10 per cent in cotton production for the additional oil and cattle feed which will result induced active liquidation through commission houses in late dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, depressing the market to final net losses of 10 to 23 points, or 50 cents to $1.15 a bale.

The requirements proposed by the War Department for an Army of 8,200,000 officers and men by the end of 1943 were defended on the ground of necessity last night by United States Senator Robert R. Reynolds, Democrat, of North Carolina, chairman of the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, speaking at the eighteenth annual dinner of the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trades section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 4 (AP) -- American patrols recaptured Sidibou Zid and reached a point three miles west of Faid Pass, today as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel surrendered virtually all his costly gains in Central Tunisia and massed his armor in the Mareth Line where the British Eighth Army has wheeled up for a decisive assault.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Citizens Committee for the National War Service Act recommended to the Senate Military Affairs Committee today that the pending Austin-Wadsworth civilian manpower mobilization bill be amended to provide for the appointment of a Director of National War Service who would be subject to confirmation by the Senate.

There are several reasons why an increasing number of Congressmen turn more and more to the Ruml plan, or the essence of it, the more they see of the proposed alternatives. The Ruml plan would treat all taxpayers in the same fashion. It would permit them to get onto a pay-as-you-go basis immediately.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, March 3 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Brian O'Neill of New York, who was standing behind Major Ralph Cheli of Bethlehem, Pa., in a Mitchell bomber strafing a Japanese ship in the Bismarck Sea convoy today, said the Japanese "flattened out on the deck as if they were glued to it."

"Frankenstein Meets the Wolfman," a Universal melodrama produced by George Wagner and directed by Roy William Neill, will have its local premiere at the Rialto this morning. Bela Lugosi and Lon Chaney Jr. play the respective title roles. Ilona Massey, Patric Knowles, Lionel Atwill and Maria Ouspenskaya are among the supporting players.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (U.P.) -- Census Bureau figures given out tonight show that coffee stocks are scraping bottom, but importers hope the situation will improve this Summer. Stocks available for civilian use were reported at an all-time low, 1,103,752 bags of 132 pounds each, as compared with 1,474,190 bags on Dec. 31 and with the previous low of 1,363,990 on Nov. 21.
I was very much interested in reading the recent letter of Noel Grady describing the experiences of his wife in a war plant.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 4 -- Governor Coke Stevenson and trade union leaders have signed an agreement by which, on the one hand, there are to be no work stoppages, strikes, slowdowns or lockouts in Texas for the duration of the war; on the other hand, the Governor pledged that the State government will not interfere with industry or labor.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- All corporate offerings of securities in 1942 amounted to little more than one-third the total for 1941, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its statistical bulletin for February.

George J. Schaefer, treasurer of the special gifts committee for Catholic Charities in the archdiocese of New York, announced yesterday at the second report meeting of this group in the Empire State Club that a total of $80,416 had been collected so far in the 1943 drive, including $20,002 raised alone by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, general chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- With continued advances in prices for farm products, largely grains, cotton, livestock, fruits and vegetables, the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive index rose 0.3 per cent during the last week of February to the highest level since January, 1926, 102.7 per cent of the 1926 average.

In Washington, where he is appearing in the vaudeville show "Priorities," Willie Howard let it be known yesterday that he will be in the cast of "My Dear Public." For a year Irving Caesar has been concentrating on this musical comedy, which is now promised for Broadway in August.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 3 (U.P.) (delayed) -- "Lifeboats, debris and Japs were everywhere in the water and the sea ran red with Jap blood" -- that was the description of the destruction of a twenty-two-ship Japanese convoy in the Bismarck Sea given today by Second Lieut. Edward T. Solomon of Suffolk, Va.

An illegal combination aimed at raising and fixing prices on patent medicines, cosmetics and other items commonly sold in drug stores was charged in a Federal indictment yesterday to eleven trade associations and seventeen individual leaders of the industry.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 154 American civilians reported by the Department of State to be interned by Japan in occupied China. Their American addresses were not reported.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 4 -- Bombs, gasoline and food are being moved forward by truck, train and ship; tanks are put back into battle trim, and the narrow-gauge railway operates again all because of the Service Supply of the United States Army which is the new Libyan Service Command, supplementing its organization in the Nile Delta, Iran and Iraq.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The prospect of early agreement by a special subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee on pay-as-you-go taxation was increased today as two Republican Representatives expressed opinions on the delay in making a decision.

Some newspapers have quoted a remark made by an officer of the Richelieu to the effect that offers of money have been made to induce the men to desert to the Fighting French Navy. This is rather a nasty crack. The truth of the matter is that the Fighting French Navy offers two-thirds of the salary paid by the Richelieu.

ONE of the most remarkable men in America is the subject of an utterly bewildering biography published today. The biography is "There Is a River: The Story of Edgar Cayce,"* by Thomas Sugrue, a writer and book reviewer whose feeling toward his hero is one of adoring discipleship, not one of impartial scholarship and objective reporting.

Expanding war production by the Aviation Corporation and associated companies in 1942 resulted in deliveries aggregating $640,000,000, while the current backlog of orders placed with the group now exceeds $2,500,000,000, it was announced in the annual report for 1942, signed by Victor Emanuel, president.

Harry Waltzer and William Walsh, officials of the independent Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, were found guilty of attempted extortion at 10:45 o'clock last night by a jury in General Sessions Court before Judge John A. Mullen.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- A rush of general buying today at the opening of business on the Board of Trade carried all deliveries of wheat, oats and rye, except the May contract in the latter, to new seasonal high levels, and an upturn in corn was prevented only by ceiling prices.
A partial solution of the farm labor problem exists, even without any further legislation.

LONDON, March 4 -- Destruction by torpedoes and shellfire of seven more enemy vessels in the Mediterranean Sea was credited to the Royal Navy's undersea fleet in an Admiralty communique today. The vessels included one large, one medium and two small supply ships, a minesweeper and two tugs.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- As a result of an undertaking by the Canadian Government to furnish the United States with the 1,170,000 tons of wood pulp already pledged, plus an additional 107,000 tons within the next three months, there will be no further curtailment in the use of print paper in newspapers, magazines, books and commercial printing at least until after July 1.

Boston lettuce and spinach, which dropped 2 cents and a penny, respectively, are the only vegetables that moved downward in price during the week, according to the latest report from the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city finished the week ended on Wednesday with only $60,000,000 of excess reserves, lowest since Aug. 4, 1937. The figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed that the net decline in excess funds in the week was $55,000,000, with actual reserve balances declining $63,000,000, while reserve requirements were off only $8,000,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, March 5 -- The remnants of the Japanese convoy of twenty-two ships -- ten warships and twelve transports -- have been wiped out, the Allied High Command announced today. British, Netherland and Australian fliers as well as Americans received credit for the great victory.

CHUNGKING, China, March 4 (AP) -- A brighter picture of the military situation in China was given today by a Chinese Army spokesman. He said that Japanese drives in Kiangsu and Kiangsi Provinces had more or less failed, while in Western Yunnan the enemy's thrusts on the Salween front had been checked.

Even though the value of Period 5 fuel oil coupons, which become valid next Monday in this zone, has been fixed at ten gallons, as compared with eight gallons for the Period 4 coupons, homeowners who have burned all of their current ration may exchange 5's for 4's only on a coupon-for-coupon basis, Bronx County Rationing Administrator Adolph J. Chesley said last night.

The future supply of spun rayon for civilian use in knit underwear and in dress fabrics has become problematical because of new priority developments, it was reported yesterday by rayon spinners. Staple fiber used in such yarn, it was added, has been finding its way into special types of uniform fabrics in addition to supplying other priority needs.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on a refinancing program of the Erie Railroad ended today with attorneys far apart on the question whether the company's directors acted in the interest of stockholders.

The long-awaited debut of Hervey Allen's historical series, which in length will overshadow his 1,224-page "Anthony Adverse" by a wide margin, takes place March 25 when Farrar Rhinehart release "The Forest and the Fort." It is Book 1 of a panel of six novels that in time to come will be issued collectively as one tome to be known as "The Disinherited."

NEWARK, N.J., March 4 -- What is believed to be the severest penalty imposed so far on a filling station operator for a ration violation was meted out today to William E. Burke of Route 17, Carlstadt, N.J., who will be deprived of gasoline supplies from next Wednesday through Dec. 31, 1944.

COMMANDO-RANGER TRAINING STATION, Somewhere in Scotland, March 2 (Delayed) -- The Rangers here wallowing in the black mud of a country rich in traditions of the old Scottish clans all started their service with regular infantry units, in which they found insufficient excitement and action.

At the annual Judicial Conference Attorney General Biddle and Chief Justice Stone made remarks full of encouragement to all friends of impartial justice and civil liberties. Mr. Biddle said there had been no active sabotage in more than a year of war and that the fear expressed early in the war that it would make impossible the preservation of civil liberties has "almost disappeared."

LONDON, March 4 -- A strange and tragic accident, unique in this capital's air raid experience, happened last night. As a result of one woman's tumble down a short flight of steps leading to an air raid shelter at least 178 persons were killed and sixty injured.

Pain and uncertainty about the future are inevitable in any hospital, but in Army and Navy hospitals there are certain factors that tend to make the lot of the patients doubly difficult. The sick or wounded service man is usually far from home or friends. He has suddenly been removed from the disciplined pattern of group living and action to which he has been conditioned.

It was announced yesterday by the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound that the same procedure as in 1942 would be followed in regard to racing this year. A tentative schedule was drawn up by the executive committee, and with it was sent an inquiry to member clubs as to whether they intended to hold regattas.

ALBANY, March 4 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that James D.C. Murray, criminal lawyer, had the right to sue County Judge Peter J. Brancato of Brooklyn for libel. The court, in a four-to-three decision, reversed an Appellate Division dismissal of Mr. Murray's complaint.

Holders of War Ration Book 1 who failed to get their War Book 2 at the general consumer registration last week have another chance to do so today. Those who pass up today's opportunity may have to wait about thirty days before they can get their No. 2 books from local War Price and Rationing Boards, the District OPA office said last night.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- Among the dead was Oick Corbett, former bantaweight boxing champion of Britain and the Empire. Sixty of the dead were children.
LONDON, Friday, March 5 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

Tiny girls and matrons were included in the fashion parade at De Pinna's yesterday morning. This was not an occasion devoted solely to the tall and slim perfect size twelves. They had their place in the line of march as did the teen-age girl, but the laurels did not all go to them.

It was a preview and a review at the same time at Delman's Spring shoe showing yesterday for the press in his salon at Bergdorf Goodman. New styles created for Spring and many favorites still on hand, but having features that must of necessity be eliminated from now on, were grouped for envious inspection.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The War Production Board has authorized five new grain alcohol plants in the Middle West to cost about $10,000,000.

More than 1,200 notable Americans and the leaders of the Chinese community in the East attended a reception given by the Chinese Consul General, Yu Tsune-chi, yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, in honor of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the generalissimo of the armies of China.

The Office of Price Administration has definitely decided to test enforcement of its rules by the public, rather than to build up a huge enforcement staff, it was indicated yesterday at a discussion on price control, participated in by several OPA officials, at the afternoon session of the annual convention of the Wholesale Stationers Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Plans to accelerate the city's drive for women volunteers to work in Army Enemy Aircraft Warning Centers were announced yesterday by Grover Whalen, Greater New York CDVO chairman. An intensive ten-day recruiting campaign will start Wednesday with ceremonies at City Hall, which will be attended by Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, head of the Eastern Defense Command; Mayor La Guardia and other officers and civilians.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, Somewhere in England, March 4 -- Flying Fortresses from this and other American bases roared over Northwestern Germany this morning to pound the railroad yards at Hamm, among the most important in Adolf Hitler's entire domain.

LONDON, March 4 -- The stock markets were cheered today by the war news from Russia and the Southern Pacific, but there was not much of an increase in the volume of business. The approach of the "Wings for Victory" campaign restrained activity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Ted Lewis and his orchestra will be featured in a musical to be produced by Irving Briskin at Columbia, under the title "When My Baby Smiles at Me," a song the orchestra leader helped popularize. The film story will be based on Lewis's career.

Two rarely performed works were featured on the program of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. One was Scriabin's "Prometheus" and the other the Debussy "Fantasie." Nadia Reisenberg appeared as piano soloist in both of these offerings.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to be at a new high record, while holdings of United States Government securities decreased $131,339,000 during the week.
MOSCOW, March 4 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported losses of 12,625,000 in government securities and 9,604,000 in private deposits. Notes in circulation totaled 922,468,000, an increase of 5,021,000, the fifth consecutive week to show a gain.

Another war problem that is worrying some of New York's parents, wives and sweethearts came to light yesterday -- the problem of writing the kind of letters that men far away in the armed services may be proud to receive.

When William McChesney Martin Jr. of this city went into the Army as a private nearly two years ago it looked as though some talent was being wasted. Mr. Martin had not only made many friends in town but he had risen at 31 to be president of our local Stock Exchange. He seemed to be a good executive, and an Army private does not get much executive work to do.

Beau Jack, lightweight champion of the world, will go out of his class for the second time in a month to meet Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh veteran who once held the welterweight championship, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The pair met in February, and Beau Jack corralled the decision in a ten-round fight.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Reversing the lower courts, the Court of Appeals decided today that Alice Jones, divorced wife of the late Leonard Rhinelander, was entitled to $3,600 a year from the estate of Philip Rhinelander, father of Leonard, under the terms of an agreement.

The Borden Farm Products Division of the Borden Company notified last night Dr. C.J. Blandford, administrator of the New York Milk Marketing Area, that it would be unable to supply half-pints of milk today to 67,000 children in 162 New York City schools for lack of paper containers. The containers of milk are sold in the schools at 1 cent each.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ALBANY, March 4 -- The calm which exists in the legislative halls toward the end of the work week was disturbed today as members, particularly those from New York City, realized that a coup had been executed under their noses in the recent bill, now law, which gives a leave of absence to Mayor La Guardia should he enter the Army.

In view of the discussions about a change to a pay-as-you-go income tax plan, I wonder whether the Treasury would not feel it appropriate to make a statement about the method by which it intends to treat Treasury tax certificates.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE in South China, March 4 -- (Delayed) -- The boys inhabiting the Ricebowl are reading bulletins about North Africa and wondering when their turn will come. To many the time is beginning to seem long, and the distance seems stupendous.

Captain Fitzroy, the late Speaker of the House of Commons, was of aristocratic and even royal descent, as his name testifies. In that office he showed a dignity and impartiality which its traditions command. To be eligible a man must not be too prominent in his party.

A new issue of $9,000,000 of City of Seattle (Wash.) 3 1/2 per cent municipal transportation system refunding revenue bonds will be placed on the market today by a nation-wide banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.; Blair Co., Inc., and Dean Witter Co.
The four-story eight-family apartment house at 424 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, has been bought by the Clelia Company from Maria Sorrentino.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (U.P.) -- Pilots of a single United States Army Air Force group destroyed 129 Japanese fighter and bombing planes during the New Guinea campaign, the War Department announced today.

Nazi shock troops were declared in a German High Command communique yesterday to have stormed Slavyansk, fifty miles north of Stalino, in a Donets Basin offensive maintained despite impending rain and mud.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Representative Taber of New York accused the Office of War Information today of disseminating propaganda for a fourth term for President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Great Britain has given sanctuary to 100,000 refugees from Europe, and her colonies are providing refuge for even more, the British Information Services reported today.

Wendell L. Willkie personally intervened with the Soviet Government on two occasions in behalf of two Polish labor leaders who were executed recently in Russia for alleged subversive activities hampering the war effort against Germany, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Football coaches and athletic directors of the Western Conference will meet tomorrow to rearrange gridiron schedules for 1943 in the interest of saving railroad mileage and to make room for games with service teams.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Aircraft production in the United States reached the 5,500 mark in February, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, revealed today in reporting a general increase in the output of munitions and armament.

The report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for 1942 shows total assets of $994,726,523 at the close of the year, comparing with $862,608,194 at Dec. 31, 1941, reflecting mainly an increase in current assets from $388,819,038 to $511,613,297.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 212 United States soldiers and twenty-one officers wounded in action in the Alaskan, European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Some interesting stories will be told about the new fishing kit for emergency use that the United States Navy, Army, Coast Guard and Maritime Commission have adopted, for months of study and preparation have resulted not only in the selection of an all-round outfit to weigh three pounds when packed, but also a set of fishing instructions unique in the history of angling.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 4 -- British and German infantry fought today for the small Northern Tunisian town of Sedjenane, which, despite its size, is a keypoint on the northerly road to Bizerte. The Germans started their attack in some strength yesterday, fighting their way, despite heavy casualties, into the village, which lies on the Mateur-Tabarca Road north of Beja.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 4 -- Civilian mobilization, ordered from Berlin, is to be extended to all of France, although it will not openly be called by that name. There is every indication that this is the price Chief of Government Pierre Laval must pay for greater facilities across the line of demarcation for both passengers and mail.

Robert L. Stott, chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, will not be a candidate for re-election, he revealed yesterday. On the board of governors without a break since 1935, he wishes to devote himself more fully to his own brokerage business.
NEW DELHI, India, March 5 (AP) -- A United States Tenth Air Force Headquarters communique:

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo of the Chinese Armies, said in a press conference at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that China's miiltary need was for planes and munitions. China has the manpower to manage them, she declared.

LONDON, March 5 -- According to information received by United Nations military circles, a fundamental reshuffling is now taking place in the German Army that is believed designed to cover the eventual -- if not already effected -- abandonment by Adolf Hitler of the post of supreme commander of the army on the Eastern Front.

" Excessive" purchases of processed foods by the government and hoarding by millions of private families are responsible for the high ration point value of canned and dried foods, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., declares in a bulletin mailed yesterday to its 3,000 members, including the large grocery chains.

George A. Burrows, 38-year-old Negro cook, who is wanted in Gulfport, Miss., for shooting two employes of the Edgewater Hotel, where he also was employed, dropped to his knees in Felony Court yesterday and begged Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio not to send him back to Gulfport because "they'll lynch me."

Threats voiced by Calman Fleisig, one of the fourteen musicians whose contracts are not being renewed for next season by the New York Philharmonic Society, that the other members of the orchestra would not renew their contracts unless the discharged men were reinstated and that they might even organize their own orchestra as a rival "New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra," were ignored by the management yesterday with a terse: "No comment.''
LONDON, March 5 -- London newspapers today published dispatches reporting that a powerful concentration of German warships had been assembled in the Trondheim area of Norway.

Tentative plans to convert Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, into a music and art center for presentation of opera, concerts, plays and ballets at popular prices were discussed last night in Mayor La Guardia's office by a committee representing all phases of the musical and dramatic arts.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The campaign to end absenteeism in war plants of the country steadily increased in force tonight, with new proposals introduced into the House calling for a curb of liquor sales in factory areas and the induction of workers who persisted in staying away from their jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Control of the importation of coffee brought in by rail from Mexico, Guatemala and El Salvador and of the shipment of syrups by that route to producers of soft drinks here was taken by the War Production Board in an order today changing orders M-63 and M-63-A, which control imports into the continental United States.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of fifty-seven United States Army enlisted men and fifty-four officers missing in action in the European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 5 -- Cadet Johnny Doolittle, Army middleweight ring artist, led the United States Military Academy to four victories in a slam-bang opening of the Eastern intercollegiate championships tonight in Syracuse University's Archbold Gymnasium.

LONDON, March 5 -- The first step in the government's post-war rebuilding plans was announced by Ernest Brown, Minister of Health, today when he told a meeting of local authorities to go ahead and buy up building sites sufficient for a one-year housing program.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- The task of accommodating sixteen teams in football schedules originally designed for nine was so big a task that directors of the Western Conference worked all day today without reaching a solution.

Services in the churches tomorrow will be in preparation for Ash Wednesday, which falls next week. Easter will occur on April 25, the latest possible date. It was last so in 1886, and before that not in more than one hundred years, and it will not occur this late again until after the year 2013.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- American airmen bombed four Japanese air bases in the Solomons yesterday, while earlier the Japanese made a futile raid on Guadalcanal Island, the Navy announced in a communique today. On Tuesday bomb-carrying Curtiss P-40 fighters swung over Kiska in the Aleutians and bombed Japanese positions with hits on the enemy camp area.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Representative Flannagan of Virginia, who is a farmer, reported to the House today what he called the latest suggestion of the WPB "Wonder Boys."

LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- Polish and British authorities are trying to mitigate Poland's dispute with Soviet Russia over post-war boundaries. However, reports that General Wladyslaw Sikorski, the Polish Premier, had taken disciplinary action against anti-Soviet extremists in his own ranks were denied.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The new Cabinet of Finland is composed of representatives of five of the six Finnish political parties, and it gives the harassed little nation caught between Russia and Germany a coalition or national government that can be expected to try to solve her difficult problem in foreign affairs in the manner best suited to Finland's national interests, it was pointed out at the Finnish Legation today.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Absenteeism among women working in war industries is twice as great as among men, according to Secretary Perkins.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 5 -- British Churchill tanks and infantry rolled back another German attack in the Sedjenane area today after throwing the enemy out of that tiny town yesterday and there are strong indications that the German offensive along the northern front is petering out.

The annual dinner dance of the New York Southern Society took place last night in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Chairman of the entertainment committee was William C. Bates, who was assisted by Magruder Dent and John B. Glenn.

A quarrel between Sir Thomas Beecham, British orchestra and opera conductor now in this country, and the Columbia Recording Corporation reached Supreme Court yesterday with the filing of papers in a suit by Sir Thomas for $600,000 damages and for an injunction to restrain the company from manufacturing and selling certain phonograph records made by him with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Janet Fairbanks, soprano, gave a recital devoted to songs by contemporary American Composers in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night. In addition to items heard here previously by Paul Creston, Theodore Chanler, Paul Bowles, John Sacco, Charles Naginski and Mary Howe, the elaborate list contained twelve songs accorded their first performance in a public concert in this city.

A fleet of 5 capital ships, 7 aircraft carriers, 25 cruisers, 94 destroyers and 44 submarines, with a swarm of accompanying merchant cruisers, corvettes, minesweepers, trawlers and drifters, all under a United Nations flag, would be a heart-stirring sight in any of the earth's troubled waters.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 5 -- The disaster Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's air force has meted out to the Japanese Laebound convoy is another striking example of the effectiveness with which air power can be used in Southwest Pacific warfare.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association asserted today in a brief filed with the Supreme Court that a municipality was forbidden by the Constitution to impose a license tax "as a condition precedent to the dissemination of information and opinion."
College athletes, the backbone of any track meet, will have Madison Square Garden all to themselves tonight in the twenty-second annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor championships.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Praising President Roosevelt's record in peace and war, Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania told the Senate today that there was "no American tradition which says that a good President cannot serve four terms in the White House."

Because of the great number of books turned in during the past two weeks and which still pour in to collecting centers throughout the nation, the 1943 Victory Book campaign, originally scheduled to end today, will continue indefinitely, Norman Cousins co-chairman of the national committee, announced yesterday.

A Louisville, Ky., lawyer, C.W. Grafton, is announced as the winner of the $2,000 mystery-story prize posted by Collier's Weekly and Farrar Rinehart in an effort to encourage new writers. Judges were Mary Roberts Rinehart, the editors of the magazine and the publishing firm.

At the meeting at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night in honor of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek the fact was referred to that Perry opened Japan's trade to the world. Although 17,000 gathered to honor China and to bring her nearer to us the fact of who opened China's trade to the world was not mentioned.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Lieutenant Colonel Elliott Roosevelt answered to Congress today the criticisms of himself and brothers made by Representative Lambertson of Kansas, who said they were being "coddled" and remove from combat zones because of possible danger.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Up to the first of March, 1288 new stock corporation had been formed in the State, but the total fell 614 short of a year ago, when 1,902 were chartered, Secretary of State Curran revealed today.

The records of the Metropolitan Opera Association for the season of 1942-43 will show an increasing number of young Americans taking roles that in former years were entrusted almost exclusively to Europeans of special training and experience in such parts.
The letter by H. Leland Jackson published in THE TIME last Saturday pertains to a situation which demands immediate attention.

The possibility that more than half of the established whisky brands will soon disappear from the shelves of retailers as a result of the traders' unwillingness to handle the brands under the small mark-ups permitted by the new regulation of the Office of Price Regulation was seen yesterday by trade observers here.

Spring flowers are reaching their peak in variety and quantity this week, offering fragrance and color in abundance for city apartments and corsages for every taste and purse limitation. Low temperatures of the week have not encouraged flower fanciers, with the result that florists now have ample stocks for week-end table decoration and for brightening coat lapels.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Perfection of a simple and inexpensive method of preserving vegetables by dehydrating them in the oven of a kitchen range was reported today by the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, which credited the process to Miss Honore O'Brien, home service consultant in its Evanston office.

The United States, despite all Adolf Hitler can do to stop it, is definitely delivering the goods to the Soviet Union. After riding in American trucks and jeeps, seeing American bombers and fighters, eating American sugar and lard in remote corners of Russia, one cannot doubt that a large part of the supplies we promised the Red Army is reaching its destination.

Professor Arthur B. Lamb, dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences of Harvard-University, received the 1943 William H. Nichols medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society at a joint dinner meeting last night of the New York section land the Society of Chemical Industry at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 5 (AP) -- A communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The warning issued on Thursday by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, against overindulgence and indiscriminate purchasing of securities solely on the basis of their "cheapness" appeared yesterday to have acted somewhat as a corrective in the stock market.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 471 United States soldiers who are prisoners of war of the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

Rapid depletion of cold storage reserves of poultry since the first of this year has raised a threat of a poultry shortage here and is causing great concern in the meat trade. Among some dealers there is fear that Army and Navy authorities may requisition a substantial part of the remaining storage holdings to insure adequate supplies for their own needs, a step that would further curtail the amount available for civilian consumption.

While Roman Catholic Dioceses in various parts of the country announced yesterday relaxation of the requirements of fasting and abstinence during Lent, and in some cases for the whole year, because of the food shortage, regulations for Lent for the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn, as printed in the dioscesan papers, show no change in the usual proscriptions.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The recent meetings of General Francisco Franco, head of the Spanish state, with his cabinet were concerned solely with internal political questions, according to definite reports that have been received here.

William J. Stelmack, 35 years old, of 651 West 188th Street, accused in testimony of having induced customers of a brokerage house where he had been employed to invest in worthless stock at his own over-the-counter concern at 70 Pine Street, was found guilty of grand larceny in General Sessions yesterday afternoon.

Gallant old Fritzie Zivic just didn't have what it takes to overcome youth, inexhaustible stamina and unquenchable spirit last night in the ring at Madison Square Garden, and for the second time within a month the former world welterweight champion went down to defeat at the hands of Beau Jack, the former shoeshine boy who is world lightweight titleholder.

Special concentration camps have been set up in Germany for "several thousand" soldiers and sailors court-martialed on such charges as refusing to put to sea in submarines or to return to the Eastern Front after leave, the Russian news agency, Tass, said in a Geneva dispatch reported yesterday to the Office of War Information in Washington.
In the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge, at Pier 32, East River, the old city ferryboat Brooklyn is making her last contribution to the cause of water transportation.

More than thirty department stores in New York banded together last year in a voluntary drive designed to teach the public how to conserve merchandise, William H. Howard, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., declared last night in a broadcast over Station WMCA sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

The annual report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for 1942, made public yesterday by Earle J. Machold, president, shows for the year a consolidated net income of $5,250,933 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

Never have I read a more narrow-minded letter in your sports pages than that written by Robert Legier. There is not one point in Mr. Legier's letter, calling for a halt in professional baseball, that cannot be proven erroneous in one way or another.

The one publicized result of the recent Axis parleys in Rome was the return to Italy of the Italian divisions on the Eastern front. Ordinarily this would have given great satisfaction to the people, for of all the campaigns into which they have been led the war in Russia is the most unpopular.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

I HAVE a strange apple tree in my yard with a trunk that looks like a two-handled jug. Several Winters ago the rabbits girdled the bark. To save the tree I made a bridge graft out of two sucker shoots, which effectively carried the sap from the cambium layer below the girdle to the cambium above it. The two sucker shoots have replaced the old trunk; they are now tough and sturdy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 5 -- Dr. Cauby de Araujo, president of Panair do Brazil, subsidiary of Pan American Airways, was absolved of charges of treason yesterday by a military court.

The city's drive to wipe out black markets in meat will continue without let-up, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at City Hall as a Brooklyn dealer was fined $200 for having uninspected meat in his possession and warned that future offenses will bring jail sentences.

The War Production Board entrusted the new "Victory Model" ash can yesterday to the mercies of the janitor, but asked him to treat it gently because it wasn't as strong as the one he used to bounce on the pavement.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday approved contracts for a ten-round bout between Sammy Angott, former world lightweight, and Willie Pep, featherweight titleholder, in Madison Square Garden, March 19, for the Boxing Service Athletic Fund, Inc.

Once again the New York Stock Exchange has managed to close a business year with a gain in cash despite a severe operating loss. In 1942 the net loss was $815,972, including depreciation charges of $548,191 and a loss of $69,402 on final liquidation of New York World's Fair bonds.

LONDON, March 5 -- The victims of Wednesday night's shelter disaster will be considered the same as the victims of a bombing, the government assured survivors today. Herbert Morrison, the Home Secretary, promised a thorough inquiry into the mishap that took 178 lives.

LONDON, Saturday, March 6 -- Smashing stubborn Nazi resistance southwest of Rzhev in the central front sweep toward the enemy anchor at Smolensk, the Russians have freed 102 localities in two days, a Soviet communique disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (U.P.) -The House unanimously approved a $4,267,197,983 supplemental naval apropriation today, leaving unchanged an appropriation committee reduction of $192,803,017 which included a cut in the allotment for expanding personnel.

Eleven small issues of new municipal securities aggregating only $1,076,000 are scheduled to be awarded next week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's total of $30,225,000, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $24,868,119.

Senator Desmond's bill to establish a New York State Youth Correction Authority, designed to give humane and understanding treatment to the 7,500 or more youths between the ages of 16 and 21 who are found guilty of criminal offenses in this State each year, is a forward-looking measure.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, March 6 (AP) -- Straggler groups of the 15,000 Japanese troops spilled into the Bismarck Sea by the sinking of a twenty-two-ship convoy have been searched out bobbing on the sea in lifeboats and mopped up by Allied planes; the High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- American housewives will have an official representative among the policy makers of the Office of Price Administration, one who will supply the average homemaker's viewpoint before regulations affecting homes are drafted and will help explain the orders to women of the country once they are issued.
BOMBAY, India, March 5 -Strenuous efforts to save something from the wreck of Mohandas K. Gandhi's fast are being made in Bombay and elsewhere by Hindu political leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Roosevelt nominated former Representative John M. Houston of Kansas to be a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The government prepared tonight to raise the ceiling price of corn from $1 to $1.08 a bushel, Chicago basis, as representatives of feeders and feed processors asserted that an acute shortage of market supplies of the grain imperiled the production of milk, beef and poultry products.

Yesterday a seat on the New York Curb Exchange was sold for $5,000 -- no very amazing figure as money values go these days, but double the preceding sale, which took place on Feb. 18, and in sharp contrast to the prices of $750 and thereabouts that ruled less than two years ago.

COMMANDO-RANGER TRAINING STATION, Somewhere in Scotland, March 3 (Delayed) -- Private Ernest L. Martin of Martinville, Va., drove a jeep like a man who knew what he was doing, but every so often the jeep seemed a little bit ahead of him.
What would you do, the volunteer was asked, if there was an air raid? Would you run home to see if your two babies were safe, or would you go straight to the registration bureau?

Industry recommendations for simplification of civilian rayon apparel fabrics, requested last Tuesday by the WPB for the purpose of conserving dwindling yarn supplies, have been submitted on behalf of fabric converters supplying the women's underwear, linings, blouses, corsets and brassieres and men's sportswear manufacturing trades, it was announced yesterday by Allen Snyder of the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply.

I have been an ardent follower of trace and field for more than three decades and must say that last Saturday night at the National A.A.U. indoor championships witnessed more records that never will be written, into the book than at any time during these past years.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5 -- Awards of fellowships for 1943 -- 44 to nine Vassar College seniors and three alumnae, one of them a member of the college faculty, were announced today by Professor Mary L. Sague. Four of the fellows will study medicine, two will prepare for teaching, and the others will pursue advanced study in chemistry, food production, religion, classics, history and mathematics.

Many firms and individuals contributing to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund have multiplied by many times their gifts of 1942, Chester M. Colby, general chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday, making public the comparative figures to date.

ALBANY, March 5 -- In January 36.8 per cent more women were employed in all manufacturing industries in the State than in January, 1942, the State Labor Department reported today. Of this number 21.9 per cent more were employed in New York City and 51.8 per cent more in other parts of the State.

Berlin received its heaviest load of British bombs this week on the day that Germany was celebrating the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Luftwaffe. The whole center of Berlin was turned into a bonfire such as no German had ever imagined on German soil. Perhaps there were some Berliners who remembered Hermann Goering's promise that no enemy bombs would ever be dropped on the Fatherland.

A contract bridge team composed of Mrs. A.M. Sobel, Howard. Schenken and Peter Leventritt of New York, and Charles H. Goren and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, won the final match of five days' play for the Curt H. Reisinger team-of-four cup in the Eastern States contract bridge tournament here last night by 5,079 points.

LONDON, Feb. 20 (By Mail) -- The Paris weekly Semaine reports a sharp rise in the French marriage rate, which is attributed to special inducements in ration cards and to a revolutionary change in the traditional French custom.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (U.P.) -- The Russian Embassy indicated today that the Soviet Government would not accept the pre-1939 Polish boundaries of Polish Ukraine and White Russian Ukraine in any final border settlement after the war.
LONDON, March 5 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan stated tonight that an independent investigation had satisfied that the sponsors of the $44,000,000 Florida barge canal had promised too much in contending that the waterway could be completed within ten months and that, with its aid, oil shortages in the East could be alleviated next Winter.

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- In a denouncement of outlaw strikes, Daniel J. Tobin, international president of the A.F.L. Teamsters' Union, declared today that union members joining walkouts in defiance of their officers should be classed as enemies of the government.

ALBANY, March 5 -- Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic minority leader, said today that he had advance knowledge of the bill, now law, giving Mayor La Guardia the right to go into the Army without losing office, and that his fellow-Democratic members approved of the measure, and still did.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Roosevelt nominated today John M. Houston, former Democratic Representative from Kansas, to the place of Dr. William M. Leiserson as a member of the National Labor Relations Board.

Widespread consumer acceptance of chemically treated textiles in the post-war era as a result of superior performance achieved by such products in military services was predicted here last night by Dr. Hugh H. Mosher, director of textile research for Onyx Oil and Chemical Company.

Full silvers brought a top price of $112 at the sale conducted for the account of the American National Fur Breeders Association yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth, Inc. Other top prices at the auction were: New color phases, $164; three-quarters, $58; one-halfs, $35; one-quarters, $25, and one-eighths and darks, $15.
LONDON, March 5 -- The stock markets here ended the week today on a firm note. Gilt-edge stocks were quiet, Brazilian and Japanese issues improved among the foreign bonds, and home rails hardened.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- In announcing today that it had bought "Kingdof of the Dead," an original story by Al Martin, Columbia becomes the third major studio in as many weeks to schedule so-called "horror" pictures for immediate production.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, appearing yesterday before the City Council committee on State legislation, analyzed and defended his recent report to Mayor La Guardia recommending that the power of the Board of Education to purchase school supplies be transferred to the Department of Purchase.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 5 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur assured New Mexico relatives today that every effort would be made to save the surviving members of the 200th and 515th Anti-Aircraft Regiments who fought in the defense of Bataan in the Philippines.

The yardstick of good nutrition -- a translation into kitchen language of the daily dietary allowances recommended by the National Research Council -- has been revised in keeping with the recent revolutions occurring along the food front.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 5 -- Rutgers University's decreasing undergraduate body received another heavy blow today when the university received word that the members of the Enlisted Reserve Corps unassigned at Rutgers, who reside within the geographical area of the Second Service Command will receive orders for active duty within the next week or ten days.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A new type of warcraft, speedy and deadly, and equipped with all anti-submarine weapons known to science, is flying the American flag ready to battle undersea raiders, Secretary Knox disclosed today.

The National War Labor Board hands down hundreds of decisions. It is merely one of scores of Federal agencies handing down a deluge of decisions. Partly because of the sheer number of these rulings, but more because the country's interest is mainly absorbed in the course of the war on the military front, few of these rulings receive the attention or analysis that they would in more normal times.

Apparently unperturbed by recent comments that the Yankees had not signed a single player who was a regular on last year's champion team nor had either a pitcher or catcher in the fold, President Ed Barrow remained silent on the matter until yesterday.

SCRANTON, March 5 -- Without a dissenting vote or modification, the Tri-District convention of the United Mine Workers, representing 80,000 anthracite miners in Pennsylvania, at its concluding session today approved the report of its scale committee recommending that the union seek an increase of $2 a day for the hard-coal diggers in negotiations for a new contract.

Even before the outbreak of hostilities it was evident that blood banks were necessities. They are here to stay. So long as they remained under the control of the Red Cross and the great hospitals there was little danger of passing along infectious diseases when transfusions were received.

After an ownership of eighty-five years, the estate of Mary A. Noe has sold the four-story apartment house at 578 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-eighth Street, to an investor. The property is assessed at $35,000, and was sold through Henry B. Root, Inc.
MOSCOW, March 5 (AP) -- The Soviet mid-day communique:

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Steel once earmarked for peacetime products but now lying idle in plants is being located and put to war use at the rate of more than 70,000 tons a month, A. Oram Fulton, assistant to the director of the War Production Board's steel division, reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Office of War Information, which insists it has the right to release government information pertaining to the wartime food program, has started an investigation to determine how newspaper men obtain information from other sources.

The food crisis makes it imperative that we maintain and foster our existing natural resources in fish and game, opposing vigorously the tendency to deplete these without adequate measures for replacement.

Net income of Republic Steel Corporation in 1942 declined 29 per cent, to $17,154,000, while net sales rose 8 per cent to a new high record of $521,110,000, and provisions for Federal taxes on income rose 1 1/2 times, to $67,875,000, according to the pamphlet report issued yesterday by T.M. Girdler, chairman, and R.J. Wysor, president.

" Harriet," which was forced to cancel its Thursday and Friday evening performances when Helen Hayes, the play's star, contracted laryngitis after the opening on Wednesday night, will resume this afternoon at Henry Miller's Theatre, it was announced yesterday by the offices of Gilbert Miller, sponsor of the attraction.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5 (AP) -- Rounders, Irish-bred 4-year-old from Emerson Woodward's Valrdina Farms, galloped to an eight-length triumph in the $5,000 added Andrew Jackson Handicap at the Fair Grounds today and set a track record of 1:50 3-5 for the mile and a furlong.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Reports were current tonight that the OPA was preparing for a "showdown" with the Department of Agriculture over the matter of the fixing of ceiling prices on live cattle and hogs.

Jacob Migden, 33 years old, was sentenced yesterday to serve five to ten years in State prison by Bronx County Judge Lester W. Patterson on his plea of guilty to second-degree attempted assault in connection with the slaying of Irving Penn on July 25, 1939.

I read with interest the recent article by Richard Lee Strout in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine on "How We Can Lick Inflation." Mr. Strout like a number of commentators and experts on this subject, lays great stress on the generally increased buying power of the American public and quotes over-all figures that run into billions.

Once again the rights of free Americans have been invaded and their constitutional protection disregarded by Federal agents, according to reports appearing in some newspapers and heard over some radio stations. This in the Maryland Free State, where those rights and protection are so zealously guarded by the people.

LONDON, March 5 (UP) -- Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, new chief of the German Navy, may be planning to send the German surface fleet into action despite the fact that he has denuded it of its best men for his submarines and has ripped the naval command to pieces, naval quarters reported tonight.
