Hugh E. Moffett, third engineer on the cargo passenger ship that was torpedoed in the North Atlantic with a loss of 678 men, announced yesterday that he would ship out again as soon as possible "but this time I'm going to get on a ship that's going to warm waters -- I hope."

The New York Conservation Department has advised Mel Rosch secretary of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, of Westchester's quota of trout to be planted in the country's lakes and streams before April.

" l{andom Harvest" established an all-time high for attendance and receipts during its elevenweek. starid at the Radio City 2fusic Hall ended Wednesday night by playing to 1,548,082 persons for a gross of $1,152,800, it was learned from the management yesterday.

Moving through the second half with a relentless pressure that speed and adept ball handling gave them, Manhattan's basketball team broke the resistance of a game but outclassed City College five in Fordham's gymnasium last night and ended the best season any Jasper team has had.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company last year reduced its funded debt by $18,266,000, leaving the system's total funded debt in the hands of the public on Dec. 31 last at $304,964,749, according to the company's report for 1942, made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- A new program to train more than 10,000 weather experts has been started by the Army Air Forces.

TRENTON, March 5 -- New Jersey's public bus transportation system faces imminent collapse because of the deterioration of equipment and the shortage of manpower, unless "immediate steps" are taken by the Federal Government to alleviate the condition, Joseph E. Conlon, president of the State Public Utility Commissioners and Coordinator of Transportation under the State's defense setup, warned today.

An additional 136,118 copies of War Ration Book No. 2 were distributed yesterday through public, parochial and private schools to consumers who failed to get their point-rationing, books last week, the Office of Price Administration district office announced last night.
The Title Guarantee Trust Co. has sold the following Brooklyn properties:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Reports that Swedish sailings to Latin America have been canceled were confirmed today by Sumner Welles, acting Secretary of State. He declined to give any details or comment on the development. It is assumed here that the sailings have been interrupted on account of the German U-boat campaign in the South Atlantic.

A warning that gas attacks may be made on States along the Eastern seaboard was voiced yesterday by Major John L. Cummings of the Army's chemical warfare school at Amherst, Mass., but he cautioned that the public should not be frightened by the effects of chemical warfare.

The 1942 assets of the State Insurance Fund, non-profit underwriter of workmen's compensation insurance, amounted to $74,781,904, a record high, Lieut. Col. Nicholas W. Muller, executive director, said in his annual report made public yesterday.

Suspension of the forty-hour work week until six months after the war, as a means of relieving the manpower shortage, was urged yesterday by Senator Albert W. Hawkes of New Jersey, in an interview at the Hotel Commodore, preceding a luncheon of the Retail Stores Division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews at which he was the principal speaker.

The Penetone Company of Brooklyn has bought the two-story factory building and boiler house on a plot 216 by 95 feet in Hudson Avenue in Tenafly, N.J., from the Cleansel Corporation. The property was held in excess of $50,000. Joseph P. Day was the broker and the J.J. O'Connor Organization, co-broker.

Trade and commission house buying, mostly of a replacement nature in the old-crop months, won back yesterday all of the preceding session's losses in the cotton futures market. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange spurted to final net gains of 11 to 22 points, or 55 cents to $1.10 a bale, under thin volume.

A Youth Court, designed to protect wayward boys between the ages of 16 and 19 years from the handicap of a criminal record, was convened in the Bronx yesterday by Special Sessions Justice Frank J. Oliver. The proceedings were conducted privately and the names of the offenders were not divulged.

Absenteeism in factories, whatever the cause, is no more justified than it is in Congress or in the field of management and capital, where it is also prevalent. Absenteeism is an indictment of the whole American people, who are not yet face to face with the grim realities of total war.

THE Far Westerners call it the "straddle jump which certainly is a nicer sounding term than the "belly roll," its more common designation. But whatever it's called, it is high jumping in real earnest. This new-fangled form of clearing a bar gets a man up higher, but has a distinct disadvantage in that it generally dumps the leaper on the top of his head, never a preferred landing spot.
The sale of eleven properties in Queens and Nassau Counties was reported yesterday by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. They are:

LONDON, Saturday, March 6 -- The Royal Air Force sent its big bombers on their tenth consecutive night raid over the Continent during the night and repeated blasts along the French coast were heard on this side of the Channel.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- War and post-war demands for trained personnel will be the subject of this year's annual conference of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations which will open two-day sessions here April 9.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 5 (AP) -- The fight waged by Dickie Laswell, an ailing six year old boy against disease and the Axis -- has won the recognition of tile Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today revised contracts between twelve airlines and the Railway Express Agency, Inc., which will terminate the express agency's exclusive right to handle air express business and will eliminate provisions that air express rates may not be lower than twice the rail express rates.

LONDON, March 5 -- Replying specifically to "a great volume of friendly criticism and disinterested advice" from the United States, Colonel Oliver Stanley, Colonial Secretary, declared at Oxford today that he was much more interested in what Britain thought of the empire than in what the United States thought of it, and rejected any scheme for international administration of the British colonies after the war.

The decisive Allied victory in the Bismarck Sea is, among other things, fresh evidence of Japan's increasing weakness in the air; for the Japanese convoy which we destroyed obviously lacked adequate air protection. This fundamental weakness in Japan's armor has been more and more apparent, as the war in the Far East has developed.

UNITED STATES ARMY AIRFORCE HEADQUARTERS, Canal Zone, March 5 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Robert Hunter of Rayne, La., and Second Lieutenant Allen H. Elward of West Lafayette, Ind., lost their lives Wednesday after their planes met over Panama Bay and they parachuted to the sea.

Numerous flotations of housing bonds and the marketing of the first industrial issue since October raised the total of new securities offered for public subscription in the current week to $35,220,000 for eleven bond offerings, the largest weekly figure in nearly two months. The total compared with $15,429,000 for five issues in the preceding week and with $51,201,000 for six flotations in this week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A bill providing for removal from office, and other stiff penalties, for officials who use or authorize the use of government-owned automobiles for other than government business, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Byrd, chairman of the Joint Congressional-Departmental Committee, seeking reductions in Federal expenditures.

The five-story building on the northwest corner of Mt. Eden and Walton Avenues in the Bronx, containing fifty apartments and eight stores, has been sold by a client of Samuel Goldstein through M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company. The property is assessed at $200,000 and is fully rented.

Varsity sports at the Naval Academy at Annapolis will continue under full sail through the war, in the opinion of Captain J.E. Whelchel, former football coach and now athletic director. The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Senate was warned by its Military Affairs Committee today that the prospects for a food crop this year as large as was grown last year, were "almost hopeless of realization,''' although the war production goals called for an increase of at least 8 per cent.

A net profit of $4,506,801 was reported for the year 1942 by the Burroughs Adding Machine Company in its annual report announced yesterday. The profit, which includes $196,000 in dividends received from foreign subsidiaries, is after deducting $7,400,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $400,000 reserve for contingencies.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The crushing American victory over the Japanese in the Bismarck Sea was a superb demonstration of perfectly planned and executed teamwork in the air and was comparable to the Battle of Britain and the Battle of Midway, Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, announced today.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- A little buying of wheat by flour mills caused an advance of around 3/8 cent a bushel in the price of that grain in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, but the support was not aggressive and increases in hedging pressure and profit-taking, combined with weakness in rye, caused a sharp break from the top.

Convicted pleasure drivers who have not yet paid gasoline coupon "fines" to local rationing boards need not do so under a sweeping interpretation of the OPA's new "honor system" in regard to essential driving of passenger cars, announced yesterday by the regional Office of Price Administration here.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Addressing the Executives Club of Chicago today, President Everett Case of Colgate University laid down four "basic specifications" for the nation's new tax program with the warning that "so far as this war is concerned we have only begun to tax."
AT UNITTD NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, March 6 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A special subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee tentatively approved today by unanimous vote a plan that could put taxpayers on a current collection basis, but which did not achieve that objective because subcommittee members decided to refer the controversial question of cancellation or "forgiveness" to the full committee.

The purchase-prize winners of the Artists for Victory exhibition recently held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are being exhibited during March in Gallery C-30 at the museum. Fifteen of the sixteen purchase-prize paintings are shown, the exception being Jack Levine's "String Quartet," which has been lent to the Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 5 -- A new Finnish coalition Cabinet was formed this afternoon by Professor Edwin J. Linkomies, Rightist member of the Diet and one of its vice speakers. He chose as his Foreign Minister Sir Henrik Ramsay, a ship owner of Scottish descent who has not previously been prominent in politics.

The papers are full of war maps showing the tides of battle. War charts show the economic and industrial battlefronts. Oddly enough, the two most important war graphs of the last fortnight were never published.

A bill specifying equal pay for equal work has been prepared by members of the New York City Women's Trade Union League and will be introduced in the Legislature Monday. The announcement was made yesterday by Miss Pauline Newman, vice president of the league, after plans to recommend a similar bill had been abandoned by the Women's Advisory Commission of the New York State Department of Labor.
The boundary lines of the Senatorial districts in New York County under the proposed legislative reapportionment were under consideration yesterday by legislative leaders in Albany.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 -- A small British naval craft, operating in waters supposedly controlled by the enemy, intercepted five Japanese Supply vessels in the Mayu River near the Burma port of Akyab on Wednesday night and captured one of the ships and took prisoners, a British communique announced today.

Tuesday afternoon at 2 o'clock the delegates to the American Kennel Club will gather at the offices of the national organization for their annual meeting. During the afternoon the board of directors also will meet and will elect officers for the year.
Discovery of a small, invisible star, the "silent partner" in a revolving unit with two large, bright stars, is announced in the Astrophysical Journal.

LONDON, March 6 -- Seven members of the crew of one of the Flying Fortresses that were lost after the bombing of Hamm, Germany, Thursday were saved after crashing in the North Sea, it was announced tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, March 6 -- Charles T. Fisher's Amber Light, under perfect handling by the veteran Johnny Longden, administered a heart-breaking nose defeat to Warren Wright's highly favored Ocean Wave in the $15,000 added Louisiana Derby, first major 3-year-old special of 1943, before some 8,000 fans at the Fair Grounds today.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt and Corporal Barney Ross of the Marine Corps, former lightweight boxing champion of the world, who was one of the heroes of Guadalcanal, will be among the speakers at a rally of Red Cross War Fund volunteer workers in Madison Square Garden on Monday evening, March 15.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, March 7 (AP) -- Three Japanese light cruisers were among the twenty-two ships lost by the enemy in the sinking of the Bismarck Sea convoy by Allied planes, the High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A gift of books, manuscripts and objects of art of Tibet has been made to the Library of Congress by Mrs. William W. Rockhill of Litchfield, Conn., from the collection of her late husband, who was Minister to China from 1905 to 1909.

THE well-known reward of building a better mousetrap has been demonstrated at Harvard in the splendid Houghton Library which was dedicated a year ago. In his first annual report William E. Jackson, the director, observes that the returns ever since have been most gratifying.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, laid out OWI's foreign propaganda for all to see today, said that it was dwarfed by similar Axis activity and to Congressional critics replied that to read into the American publications any political angles was "utterly misleading."

WALTER HUSTON was the obvious choice for the role of Ambassador Joseph E. Davies in the picturization of "Mission to Moscow." For one thing, Mr. Huston has an ambassadorial look about him. He stands well over six feet, has an, impressive head of graying hair and his manners are as indigenously American as apple pie.

Apparently convinceed that the trading of ten-share units on the main floor gives the public a better market and results in an adequate increase in volume, the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday to change the trading conditions of fifty-nine issues.

WHILE traveling around the country with a production the size of "Lady in the Dark" is not without its problems in wartime, it is also a lot of fun. It is very seldom that one feels as a star is supposed to feel.

IN his new volume, Mr. Leacock turns a penetrating and caustic eye on the gentle art of the writer. A generous man, he offers advice to readers and writers alike, and as an author not altogether unknown his advice is both judicious and shrewd.

Courses to prepare women college graduates to become supervisors of radio inspectors were announced yesterday by the United States Civil Service Commission here. Men college graduates whose draft status indicates indefinite deferment may also be eligible.

BOSTON, March 6 -- Yale's hockey team notched one of the major surprises of the collegiate season tonight at the Garden by humbling Harvard's powerful skaters, 4 to 2, in a Pentagonal League contest, thereby evening their series at one -- all. Harvard won the opener last week.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 6 -- War dampened the ardor of carnival revelers here tonight. The crowds were small and forlorn and the streets were bare of hotdog, peanut, beer and soft-drink stands.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, struck out at his press conferenee today at Nazi propaganda that seeks to spread the impression in Latin America that the United States is seeking permanent footholds in the American republics to the south by making a sweeping denial and declaring that this government has no intention of holding permanently military bases that have been established in the Western Hemisphere during the war.

A week ago New York University accomplished a feat never before achieved by a college indoor track and field team when Emil Von Elling's squad won the National A.A.U. championship. Last night at Madison Square Garden the Violet athletes accounted for another unprecedented attainment in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. meet.

AN amazing amount of adventure is crammed into this double romance. One expects a couple of scrambled love stories, which are here in generous tangle, but the secret service and the commando raids are an extra measure of excitement and suspense.

In the belief that intelligent incentive systems in war production plants can contribute more to a solution of the manpower problem than any other step, the War Labor Board will within the next sixty days adopt a definite policy approving incentives, Austin M. Fisher, labor relations consultant to about fifty plants, predicted here yesterday.

The University of Delaware swimming team triumphed, 50 to 25, over Manhattan in a dual meet at the Park Central Hotel pool yesterday afternoon. Both teams closed their campaigns as Delaware registered its fifth victory in seven starts.

Twenty-two members of the first and second teams were honored at the seventeenth annual All-Brooklyn scholastic football luncheon tendered by Abraham Straus yesterday in the Gallatin Room of the Brooklyn department store's West Building.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Both before and since Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's tank assault against the American lines in Central Tunisia -- the first large-scale clash between Nazi and American land forces in this war -- the Berlin radio has beamed to North Africa programs designed especially for the American troops there.

James King Sons, Inc., Manhattan contractors, builders of the Halloran General Hospital at Willow Brook, S.I., biggest Army hospital in the United States, received the Army-Navy E yesterday after noon at ceremonies in the auditorium of the institution.

Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder, announced here yesterday that the Kaiser Company has arranged to buy all the stock of Fleetwings, Inc., currently engaged in the manufacture of aircraft for the Army at plants in Bristol, Pa. Fleetwings also manufactures component aircraft assemblies for other aircraft companies.

A GREAT Saga Humane is now being enacted before us. We are at present so close to it and so much part of it that we do not see the entire panorama. But in time all the legends and tales of our conflict will no doubt be collected and arranged in a work more vast and varied than even Balzac's "La Comedie Humaine."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- Yale Went down to a 55-to-38 defeat in opening the annual basketball series with Harvard in Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight. The outcome marked the Elis eleventh straight Eastern Intercollegiate League setback as they closed their home season.

During the last six months of 1942 war contracts flowed into the city four times as rapidily as in the preceding two years, according to a report made public yesterday by Commissioner George A. Sloan of the city's Department of Commerce. The report declared, however, that New York manufacturing plants, despite this acceleration, were still operating less than one full shift every forty hours and the unemployment problem was still present.
PAT CORCORAN, a bulbousnosed. Runyonesque character who has been conducting sight-seeing tours around New York City for the past twenty years, is amazed by the great anomaly.

MR. GOZZOLI was a man of about 65, skinny, unshaven and despondent. He was sitting up in bed in a snarl of sheets and blankets, grumbling and sighing to himself. As I approached he eyed me with weary hostility, the sighs and moans increased in tempo and he began to sway from side to side in anguish.

One psychologist tells us, with amusement, that all is not loss in the behavior and play patterned on the war. When her 5-year-old is exasperated and would like to say to her mother, "You're a dope," she gets it out of her system by saying, "Hitler's a dope!"

IN this persuasive and moving novel, J.H. Wallis presents a shocking picture of religious bigotry in New England -- specifically of the inhumanity of the Gentile toward the Jew. He shows in this story of the persecution of Abraham Pein how such inhumanity, inflamed by jealousy and prejudice, can defeat even our American justice.

ALGIERS, March 6 -- The repeal of the Vichy laws of 1940, which are still in effect in French North Africa, was predicted today by sources close to the regime, who say that this step is "inevitable" pledge of allegiance to the Atlantic Charter by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief.

" TILDA," Mark Van Doren's new novel, is a tale contrived out of fancy, a story which holds reality mainly through virtue of the poet's art. Robert Nathan is a master of this genre of writing; in many ways, Tilda will recall the "Portrait of Jennie."

OMAHA, Neb., March 6 -- They couldn't use Max Coffey in the Army, so he decided to do the next best thing. He quit his job as head of the newspaper's war desk and rented an Iowa farm, where he is going to milk cows, grow corn and produce pork to feed hungry soldiers and meat-rationed civilians.

ACCORDING to Hitler and the Japanese undoubtedly agree with him even the greatest spirit can be liquidated by a rubber truncheon. For merely one more time Hitler is wrong, and has been proved wrong. But what are the sources of strength that the spirit feeds on when confronted by the man with the truncheon ? What images, what beliefs, what memories, offer some best shield against the blows ?

THE things that we did in the Far East that we should not have done, and the things left undone that we should have done, are the theme that runs through Vanya Oakes's book. The folly of the white man in the East was that he could not see, his perceptions too dulled by the ease of life in the East and the artificial shelter that the privileges of a superior caste gave him.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 1,252 American soldiers held prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

Two conscientious objectors from New York City, Louis Krawcyzk of 995 Freeman Street, the Bronx, and Stanley Thomas Murphy of 14-45 163d Street, Beechurst, Queens, yesterday entered the twenty-second day of a voluntary fast by which they hope to obtain their release from the Federal prison at Danbury, Conn.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 6 (AP) -- The International Railway Company, which operates bus and trolley service in Buffalo and other Niagara frontier cities, has severed its contract ties with Mitten Management, Inc., of Philadelphia, as directed by the Public Service Commission.

SHORT-WAVE reception, which has been none too good in recent months, should be improving soon, according to Sir Edward Appleton, the English scientist and one of the foremost authorities on the relation between sunspots and radio transmission conditions.

New Jersey's formative plans call for some special experiments regarding deer. Many States have had their own ideas, conducted their research along special lines so that deer populations might be maintained satisfactorily from the standpoint of size of herd as well as for the general public welfare.

Danish newspapers have been banned in Norway, according to a Stockholm broadcast to North America heard yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission. The Stockholm radio quoted the Swedish newspaper Dagens Nyheter as commenting: "There is much written on and between the lines in the Danish papers.
Associated Press Correspondent The Soviet Union, which is regarded abroad as the stormy petrel of the United Nations, still does its best to get along with its Allies.

Aircraft shares and low-priced issues paced the market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The close was irregularly higher on the day, with most prices at about the best levels of the recovery movement. Volume of 787,800 shares was the third largest in more than a year for a half day and compared with 942,870 in the previous two-hour session.

NUTRITION -- From March 25 to 27 the Medical College of Virginia will conduct a symposium on wartime nutrition. Among those on the program are Dr. W.W. Sebrell ("Nutrition in Changing World"), Dr. Lydia Roberts ("Making Nutrition Vital"), Dr. V.P. Sydenstricker ("Rationing as It Affects Nutrition"), and Brig. Gen. J. Fulmer Wright ("Living Under Rationing").

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 6 -- New York University's quintet spurted twice in the second half to crush Rutgers today, 75 -- 57, for its seventeenth victory. The Scarlet ended its season after winning seven and losing nine games.

SELWYN JAMES has certainly let the cat out of the bag with "South of the Congo." It was time somebody did it, although the cat was on a fair way to creeping out for itself in the press -- not in headlines, but in little items such as: "Seven natives killed in Pretoria. . . . Sabotage of power lines" . . . etc.
Action on the schoolboy track and field front took place at the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School gymnasium and at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
WELLESLEY, Mass., March 6 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek came back to her alma mater tonight and is housed in Tower Court, a Wellesley College dormitory where she lived in her senior year.
IN October, 1937, the British Minister of War, Leslie Hore-Belisha, addressing the House of Commons announced solemnly, "Colonel Blimp is dead."
LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- A communique of the Soviet Information Bureau broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet Radio monitor:

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Library of Congress and the National Gallery of Art are planning a joint celebration and special exhibitions in honor of the bicentennial of the birth of Thomas Jefferson April 13. President Roosevelt heads the committee of honorary sponsors.

Hundreds of thousands of pounds of crude rubber will be saved and crystal-clear plastic noses and transparent enclosures for military aircraft will flow to assembly lines without interruption because of a new adhesive developed by duPont chemists.

BY way of Lisbon comes information regarding stamps issued last year by Norway. On the occasion of the "Nasjonal Samlings" (National Congress) assembling on Sept. 26, a 20-ore plus 30o-semi-postal commemorative was issued for the benefit of soldiers' widows, the design being a likeness of Vikdun Quisling.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The Midsouth is swinging into its high season with business ahead of last year in many areas as the usual Spring group is augmented by persons returning from Florida. In the next two months sports will center round the horse, now more than ever king of the region.
Setting: Typical small college town, complete with campus scandals and a football coach named Paul Y. Wiznowsky.

Before it is too late for the textile industry to produce enough yarns and fabrics needed for next Fall and Winter's essential civilian apparel, some impartial government executive or agency may have to decide whether it helps the war effort for the OPA to stifle any production or distribution skills during 1943, merely to simplify that agency's task of policing price ceilings, textile men declared here last week.

MEXICO CITY, March 6 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho saw his own horse win the second race today as a crowd of 43,805, largest in Mexican sports history, welcomed racing to Mexico City after a twenty-five-year lapse.

Following complaints by spokesmen for the food distribution industry that "excessive" purchase of canned foods by the government and private hoarding had been responsible for high ration point values, reports persisted yesterday in official and unofficial circles that additional hoards of government food were being released to ease the civilian pinch.

LONDON, March 6 (U.P.) -- The Germans are using machine guns on youths who refuse to bow to the new order, it was asserted today. Young men conscripted for military service by the Germans in Luxembourg revolted in the railway station just before their departure for Germany, the Ministry of Information said, and "machine guns were turned upon them, resulting in a great loss of life."

In the discussions here regarding overtime payments and the length of the working week it is astonishing that almost no attention has been paid to the British system of "payment by results." It deserves the most serious study by employers, workers and our Government.
LONDON, March 6 (Reuter) -- Today's football results in the British Isles follow:

ALBANY, March 6 -- Three proposals for changes in the State income tax law, two offered by Senator Wicks and Assemblyman Moffat, as members of the Governors unofficial committee studying tax reform, will be submitted to the Legislature Monday.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Russian reports that Red Army vanguards are outpacing the enemy retreating southward and southwestward from Rzhev, curling around to trap his columns and stifle small groups of tanks and tommy gunners left to ambush the Russians, indicate that substantial successes may be expected on this front.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Outlining the tremendous gains made by the Navy toward becoming the "four-dimensional" fighting force necessary for the waging of total war, Secretary Knox revealed today that most of the 5,675,000 tons of new warships would be in active service in 1945, two years ahead of schedule.

ERNA FERGUSSON, author of several books on Latin America, has returned from Chile with a vivid, stimulating book of fact, narrative and comment about that country. The book is timely; people in this country have long thought of Chile as an old friend of the United States and one of the three most important countries of South America.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 138 United States soldiers missing in action and 175 wounded in the European, North African and South Pacific areas. Of this total seventy-one were commissioned officers.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Time now to get those vegetable seeds started, if it hasn't already been done -- cabbage, broccoli, cauliflower and lettuce..... Unless you have a hotbed it's just as well to wait another week for tomatoes, peppers and eggplants..... If rotted manure is available, a generous mulch applied now to rhubarb plants and asparagus will help give them a quick, strong start as the ground thaws out.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 6 -- In the chain of island bases northward from Australia the Japanese for the last few months have been busily, urgently, preparing for the next phase of the Pacific war. Hard-driven Asiatic laborers recruited from the lands that lie under the hard Japanese conquest have been sweating at the construction of new airfields, roads, docks, jetties, barracks and warehouses.

A small section of the City College campus was transferred yesterday into a military objective to be shielded from theoretical enemy bombers as members of the college's camouflage course gave a demonstration of their work. The objective consisted of a machinegun and a trench mortar, protected by a garnished net twelve feet square made of wire and cord.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (Science Service) -- Andrew J. Higgins, New Orleans boat builder, has taken out Patent No. 2,312,548 on a type of wooden boat hull construction designed to impart greatest strength with maximum economy of materials. A feature of the construction is a series of longitudinal stringers, converging toward bow and stern.

Our objective in entering the war was to attain a lasting global peace under humane conditions of life. To obtain this objective, defeat of the enemy is not enough. The urge to war must somehow be discouraged. We know no infallible remedy today. We can only choose between past tried alternatives.

It is extremely difficult for us, living here in comparatively peaceful surroundings, to comprehend what is and has been taking place in Europe among those unfortunate peoples whom the Nazis decided to eliminate. One of Hitler's strongest assets has been that, from the first, he stunned us with the incredibility of his acts.

THE months which changed Hawaii from the secure, serene Paradise of the Pacific into a war-torn outpost hold contrast enough, drama enough, to tempt any novelist. For Mrs. Mackay they are also stuff of personal experience.

EVERY woman her own handyman! This is the immediate prospect as the possibility of being able to take up the telephone and call in a service man to do minor repairs dwindles to the vanishing point. Off to the wars are marching the plumber, the carpenter, the electrician -- the few who have not long since been called.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A House appropriations subcommittee has slashed by more than 50 per cent the funds sought by the Agriculture Department to recruit farm labor and has ordered revisions in the program, it developed tonight -- a new move to shape Administration plans to Congressional views.

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM has not been invited to conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for a good many years, and it has devolved upon a record company to bring ensemble and conductor together.

Convinced that higher ceiling and parity prices on farm products are inevitable, cotton traders yesterday supplied fairly good demand for the new-crop options on the New York Cotton Exchange, lifting them to their best closing prices in a week.

JUST because some of the materials and gadgets to which we are used are not at present available and others can be had only in modified or even in ersatz forms is no reason for letting the rooms of the home or of one's apartment acquire that woebegone wartime look.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Conflicts between Congress and the executive branch over policies and prerogatives are not new, but the one currently generating steam has potentialities ranging beyond its predecessor because of the tremendous war and post-war issues involved.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- After two days of trying to arrange football schedules to meet a curtailed travel program and to accommodate service teams, Western Conference coaches and athletic directors adjourned today with a general pattern in mind but in agreement that finishing touches must be worked out individually.

A former United States Army captain who admitted at a court-martial shortly after the first World War that he had come to this country as a spy for Germany was among ten enemy aliens arrested here this week-end, E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced yesterday.

New York's indoor track and field season, highly successful this Winter despite the war, will end Saturday when the New York Chapter, K. of C., holds its twenty-fourth annual games in Madison Square Garden.

Sustained consumer buying in practically all "cost of living goods," particularly apparel and various soft goods except home furnishings, again brought substantial gains in retail sales here last week. Despite unfavorable weather conditions early in the week, the increased in volume of department stores was put at around 20 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Senator Murray, chairman, and Senator Capper, a member of the Senate Committee on Small Business, are not impressed by letters received from fifty-four Federal departments and agencies outlining their impression of their responsibility toward small business.

MEMBERS of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States are asking their friends to take "Pot Luck" with them this week in a novel fund-raising campaign which will be initiated tomorrow as "Cook Book Week."

A rising tide of juvenile delinquency was forecast yesterday by Stanley P. Davis, executive director of the Community Service Society, unless immediate steps are taken to help children whose family relationships have been disrupted through the absence from home of fathers because of the war.

In spite of the large known underground reserves of petroleum recently estimated by the American Petroleum Institute at twenty billion barrels, the United States will face a serious shortage of oil within two years unless steps are taken soon to develop additional reserves and also to reduce consumption of oil by using coal for fuel wherever this is possible.

Local officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation issued yesterday a warning to all men subject to training under the Selective Service Act that they were required to carry at all times their registration and classification cards.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 6 (AP) -- The grand slam scored by General Douglas MacArthur's airmen against the most ambitious Japanese sea-borne attempt to reinforce bases in New Guinea was the result of months of preparation to meet just such a threat.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Farmers will be permitted to increase their allotments for the planting of cotton in 1943 by 10 per cent, Secretary Wickard, head of the Department of Agriculture, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- An official of the War Production Board retorted with rhyme for rhyme today to the attack made in the House yesterday by Representative Flannagan of Virginia against "the wonder boys" of the WPB.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce called today for immediate action toward meeting postwar problems, saying "the preservation of the American way of life is one issue which we cannot afford to postpone until it reaches the crisis stage."

THIS first book about plants, intended for very little children, is so exceedingly simple that one wonders whether they will gain from it anything more than they presumably know already from observation; namely, that plants grow in the earth, with their leaves above ground in her effort to eliminate details the author-illustrator has over-simplified her drawings until they tell practically nothing at all.

THAT children need in wartime the things children need at any time -- including the presence of adults they can love and trust -- is a view this reporter shares. There is nothing new to report about these needs. But we return to the subject because (1) a recent scientific gathering offered some interesting sidelights on it, and (2) we hear that mothers who stay at home with their children need an encouraging word.

DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- A manpower utilization committee has been formed by the Automotive Council for War Production. Created in anticipation of manpower shortages, its function will be to obtain the fullest use of men in the car industry's war production plants.

Dr. Frans E. van der Gugten, chief medical officer of the Netherland Shipping Committee, who was named recently to take charge of a new merchant marine polyclinic at 61 Broadway, said yesterday that work on the institution was progressing rapidly and that it would be opened to serve Netherland seamen in about two weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Air Medal has been awarded to Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding general, Army Air Forces.

AFTER a year of America's participation in the war there is evidence that the slogan, "flowers for morale," which florists used after Pearl Harbor, was not the mere "gag" that some people thought. Not only has the demand for flowers in general held its own, but there has been a marked rise in certain flowers' popularity.
HAVANA, March 6 -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight filled the vacancies in the Cuban Cabinet, thus ending the crisis that has existed for the past three months.

Set these facts against last week's spell of the shivers:

CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army, with its huge consumption of gasoline and munitions as well as water and food, was able to travel from El Alamein to Tunisia, because the British Army Service Corps has managed to provide it with 2,400 tons of war materiel daily.

To meet a war-created demand for well-trained nutritionists in public health and social welfare agencies, Simmons College, with the cooperation of the Harvard School of Public Health and a group of Boston community organizations, has announced a program leading to a master's degree in public health nutrition to be offered in the academic year beginning next September.

THE flame and smoke of battle have hardly faded on the active fronts of this war before the agile and untiring correspondents on the scene have their cable dispatches singing on the wires and are ready to settle themselves to the serious business of putting their experiences in book form.

THE problem of the survival of the liberal arts in wartime has been much discussed of late and from many points of view. Closely bound up with it is the problem of the survival, as well as the immediate utility, of the arts with which this department particularly concerns itself.

Under the auspices of the Medical Society of the County of New York a Blood and Plasma Exchange Bank has been established which is all that its name implies. Whole blood, plasma (the pale, straw-colored liquid in which the red cells float), or dried plasma now become as negotiable as checks.

WHEN the finals of the national amateur figure-skating championships are held tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden the occasion will be a gala benefit for the American Flying Services Foundation, which, since its inception in 1941, has been engaged in a national project to "keep 'em flying."

THE annual Hurok Spring season of ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House will find the Ballet Theatre alone in residence this year, with some twenty-nine performances scheduled between the formal opening on April 1 and May 2.

HERMAN ULLSTEIN was one of five brothers who ruled the greatest publishing house of Europe only a few years ago. He left his native country, stripped of his whole fortune by the Nazis because of his Jewish descent.

To facilitate prompt settlement of war production contracts and thus speed reconversion to peacetime output when hostilities cease, it is proposed in the current bulletin of the National City Bank that the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission set up a division of audit and accounting to function during the war, with the definite objective of facilitating post-war settlements and cooperating with contractors for that purpose.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 6 -- The race for the Republican Presidential nomination has taken on new interest with Governor Dewey of New York bowing himself out and Wendell Willkie bowing himself in.

The Maple Leafs will make their last appearance of the National Hockey League season in this city when they oppose the Rangers at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although the Rangers are going nowhere fast, their showing in recent games has been comparatively satisfactory, and a crowd of more than 13,000 is expected to see them try conclusions with the Toronto skaters.

THIS is a really good book with a Cape Cod setting. For people who have such a fondness for the Cape that they can enjoy anything about it, there is a happy fellow-feeling for its hills and dunes and long flat stretches, its bayberries and pines and cranberries and bush-studded sands, its shore birds and winds and changing colors, and always the sea.

INSURANCE companies deal in drama and consequently should have dramatic histories. The business of inspecting a subject to be insured, getting the policy signed and collecting the money is prosaic enough, but the pay-off comes after fire and flood, tornado and shipwreck -- or even broken glasses.

Mayor La Guardia spoke at the Yugoslav Victory Rally at the Metropolitan Opera House broadcast over the Blue Network yesterday afternoon in an intermission between acts at the performance of "Aida." Other speakers were Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Ambassador to Washington, and Bogoljub Jevtitch, former Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia.

FAR beyond diminishing oil coupons lie certain other indications that Spring is at hand. As the commuters rush these evenings for buses and trains they rattle with packages of seeds, and out at their homes a few unwise crocuses already are sticking their heads through the last quarter inch of ice.

TWO veterans of the New York art world furnished outstanding shows in last week's rush of highly diverse group and one-man exhibitions. It will come as something of a surprise to his many admirers that William Zorach, despite continuous activity, has not had a show of his own since 1931.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee predicted tonight that "beyond the shadow of a doubt" the committee would approve next week a measure to curb absenteeism among war workers, but he said he would fight any move to tack a dry rider to the bill.

TWO current exhibitions of antique American crafts demonstrate how fundamental in our culture is that mechanical skill which is now important in our war production. At the Folk Arts Center, 670 Fifth Avenue, are hand-wrought wooden ware and ingeniously pieced patchwork quilts; at the H.F. Sachs Galleries, 63 East Fifty-second Street, is an array of antique hand-made tools.

LESS well-known than its Fall-flowering relative, Hydrangea paniculata, the Hedge Hydangea (H. arborescens grandiflora) is, as its name indicates, a large-flowered, woody shrub, with leaves and florets characteristic of the Hydrangea family.

HONOLULU, March 6 -- Correspondents with American land and sea forces in the South Pacific are, in effect, "grounded" by an order of Admiral William F. Halsey, commander in that area, banning all civilians from air transportation within his command except in cases "governed solely by military necessity."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 6 (U.P.) -- Allied sea power has broken the back of the Axis and will win the war in the end, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, supreme Allied naval commander in this theatre, said in an exclusive interview today.

THERE was a map on the front page of this newspaper a few days ago. It was a map of Berlin with a circle indicating the section of the city which had been pulverized most by an R.A.F. raid. Memories flowed swiftly at the sight of it because this reporter had lived within that circle during the 1936 Olympic Games.

I have followed with interest Hanson Balowin's discussion of manpower problems with special reference to size of the Army. He has given valuable information and made some important points, but neither he nor any other supporter of the Administration's mass army policy has yet answered questions which the public has a right to ask.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 6 (AP) -A Swiss telegraphic agency dispatch from Vichy said today that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs there had adopted a series of decrees stripping dissident French officials, including diplomats, of their functions.

Referring to the article in THE TIMES of March 1 voicing Mrs. Catt's opposition to the equal rights amendment to the Constitution, it was my grandmother, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, who called the first Woman's Rights Convention in Seneca Falls in 1848.

The occupational surprises of a mailman are inclined to be numerous and varied but none in recent months had a more startling effect than what happened to David Koller, 30-year-old letter carrier, of 1450 Thwaites Place, the Bronx, when he opened a mailbox around 6:45 A.M. yesterday at Twelfth Street and Third Avenue.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., March 6 -- Her long, golden curls are only a memory to 11-year-old Anita Hoch berg new, but she has a tangible reminder that they have gone into the nation's war effort every time she looks at the living room wall. A framed certificate from the Bendix Aviation Corporation hangs there, attesting to the fact that Anita's fourteen-inch tresses are being used in the precision instruments that go into warplanes.

STATE and local government support or assistance for orchestras is spreading. A bill to make possible State tax support for the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra was approved last week by the Indiana Senate. It had been passed by the House after being amended so as to put the final decision for levies on local tax authorities.

Although no formal commitments had been made yesterday to the Yacht Racing association of Long Island Sound for championship dates by the various clubs, it was ascertained from committee chairmen that they will be made known this week, and the prospect appeared to be that the sessions will be approximately the same as last year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 6 -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel struck today at dawn against the British Eighth Army south of the Mareth Line. In the first fighting, which was still continuing tonight, General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's forces destroyed twenty-one enemy tanks without loss.

LONDON, March 6 -- The Red Army scored its third major victory in a week today by capturing Gzhatsk, 100 miles west of Moscow and the nearest point to the Soviet capital in the Germans' crumbling hedgehog defense system on the central front.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 6 -- That the total mobilization of German manpower is meeting serious objection from the population was revealed today in the German press, which reported that "many persons of both sexes have already been sentenced to long terms of imprisonment for general unwillingness to work."

Stressing the importance of international cooperation in the post-war world, Dr. Carl J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament and of the League of Nations Assembly, declared yesterday that education can play an important part in building a lasting peace after victory is won.

NEWARK, N.J., March 6 -- Three small steel fabricating plants in Northern New Jersey were forced to close today when their employes, estimated at 100, all members of Shopman's Local 545, International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Iron Workers, A.F. of L., walked out in protest against President Roosevelt's Executive order setting time-and-a-half pay for the sixth day of work.

THE punning title gives only the faintest hint of the amusing combination of Broadway wisecracks and Walden wisdom within. Thoreau's remarks remain as quotable as when he first wrote them, as Mr. Hybolates Hoolock and his audiences discover, and Hoolock had taken the advice literally.

Short-wave station KGEI, in San Francisco, and Fulton Lewis Jr., commentator, received last night the first annual Alfred I. du Pont awards at a dinner held at the Hotel St. Regis. The awards, each carrying citations and $1,000, were for outstanding service in the field of broadcasting.

STRATFORD, Conn., March 6 (U.P.) -- The first cross-country flight of a two-place Army helicopter, from Stratford to Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, covering 761 miles in 16 hours and 10 minutes flying time, was disclosed today by Air Force, service journal of the Army Air Forces.

ALTHOUGH it is in no way comparable to "Dragonseed" -- nor to any of Mrs. Buck's more considerable novels of Chinese life and character -- "China Sky" is a swift, smooth, compelling tale with many of the aspects of a thriller, founded on that solid structure of knowledge which one expects from Pearl Buck.
LONDON, March 6 -- A question that is constantly being asked is whether the strategic bombing of Germany can win the war. The obvious answer is that nobody knows because it hasn't ever been tried.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The War Labor Board announced today it will no longer issue statistics on strikes in war industries.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- There have been Russians this week talking like Annie in John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down," not certain whether it was the war that brought the bad weather or the bad weather the war.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 6 -- Salvatore (Toots) Mirabito out-pointed Maryland's Len Rodman for his thirtieth consecutive victory tonight, ending one of college boxing's greatest careers by capturing the Eastern Intercollegiate Association heavyweight title for the third time, as his Syracuse University ringmates walked away with team honors.

THE distinguished diplomatic gifts and spectacular showmanship of Queen Victoria's great Prime Minister, Benjamin Disraeli, has obscured the luster of his father's fame who, nevertheless, was a writer of ability.

THIS novel, published in France some years ago under the title "Les Javanais," shares its basic characteristics with a great many first novels. It is a consciously expressionistic book, concerned with intricate, never quite definable emotions rather than dramatic passions.

LATIN-AMERICAN countries supplied the bulk of the past week's information regarding recently released or forthcoming stamps. Dispatches from the capitals of Bolivia, Chile, Costa Rica, Cuba, Ecuador, Honduras, Paraguay and Peru tell of more than fifty postal items, most of them associated with history, industries, agriculture and charity.
The Allstate Insurance Companies, automobile insurance affiliates of Sears, Roebuck Co., showed that premium writings of the companies gained $363,279 last year to $7,200,480 on Dec. 31, 1942.

A GRAND Opera Festival will be held by the Essex County Symphony Society, Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, president, May 4-9, at the Mosque Theatre, Newark, N. J. The festival will replace the outdoor symphony concerts presented by the society for the last seven years at the City Schools Stadium of Newark, which have been abandoned until after the war because of dimout regulations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -With Chink Crossin, Davis and Jack Colberg repeating their earlier-season performances against Columbia, Pennsylvania notched a hard-fought 58-49 victory over the Lions in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at the Palestra tonight before 1,000 spectators.

THAT lively old lady of 80, Mrs. Caroline Meigs, gets married in this, the fifth or sixth of Elizabeth Corbett's Meigs novels. No doubt you remember Mr. Horace Cunningham, her youthful and persistent suitor.

THE use of okra is not, perhaps, as well understood in the North -- for some reason -- as in the South. When used at all, it is apt to be cooked as a vegetable by itself, under which conditions it has a glutinous quality which is not very pleasant.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 6 (AP) -- With Keo Namaka setting a new Big Ten record in the 440-yard free style race, Ohio State won the Western Conference swimming championship tonight, and ended Michigan's four-year reign as titleholder.

SO brief is the span of the nation's second city that there are men living today who remember the men who made Chicago what it is today. Ernest Poole, born on a quiet, tree-shaded street in Chicago some sixty years ago, has known many of the ruthless go-getters who transformed it into a great business metropolis.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, which two weeks ago passed the problem of pay-as-you-go taxation to a special subcommittee after being unable to agree itself, today found itself with the toughest part of that problem right back in its lap.

Herbert Hoover's appeal for immediate measures to feed the starving children of Europe has fallen into a void of silence. Why? I have read or heard no convincing argument against it. It has merely been allowed to fade out into oblivion. And this I, for one, hold is regrettable and will one day be regretted.

HOUSTON, Texas. THE annual Azalea Trail program will be held again this year in Houston, Texas, on March 13 and 14, under the sponsorship of the River Oaks Garden Club. Including visits to homes in the vicinity whose gardens are outstanding -- with azaleas in full bloom -- the program will make available information concerning fruit and vegetable growing.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Two large Japanese destroyers were sunk by a United States naval task force of light surface units in the central Solomons last night (Solomons time), the Navy announced today. No American vessels were lost.

ONE year has passed since Edward Raquello, the motivating power of the war production training committee of the American Theatre Wing War Service, announced to the theatrical profession his plan to harness the available manpower of the entertainment industry for the nation's war production.

GRUBBY, a little boy who does not like soap and water, discovers that none of the animals (except the pig) will play with him or let him pet them, as long as he is so dirty. When he asks for advice as to how he is to get clean, he is told successively that he must take a dust bath like the pigeon, lick himself like the cat, curry-comb himself like the pony.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -T.P. Wright, civilian aeronautical engineer, emerged today as a key figure in aircraft production.

The Chancery Office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that there would be no change in the usual Lenten regulations or in the rule of fast and abstinence on Fridays because of food rationing re strictions. The statement explained that the action of other dioceses in relaxing the Lenten restrictions had not been followed here because the required condition of serious hardship is not yet present in this area.

There is ground for encouragement in the report of William A. Irvin, chairman of the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, after his visit to fourteen cities and many factories in the interest of a full enlistment of industry in the drive to prevent accidents that are hampering the war effort.

THE familiar conception of New Jersey as a thoroughfare to somewhere else, or as a bedroom for Manhattanites, is briskly disputed by Mr. Wildes in his account of the twin rivers that dominate the northern part of the State.

Director. American Institute of Public Opinion THE regular and systematic effort to measure and to report public opinion on a national scale is now entering its eighth year in the United States, its seventh year in England and its second year in Canada, Australia and Sweden.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- London reports of a powerful German warship concentration in the vicinity of Trondheim, Norway, received considerable credence in American naval quarters today. Speculation centered on the possibility that the German High Command planned a surface campaign as well as an undersea offensive against supply lines to Britain and Russia this Spring.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- The General Executive Board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has refused to permit a sympathy strike against the R.R. Donnelley Sons Company to support the efforts of Chicago printing trades unions to organize the Donnelley plant, which has always remained an "open shop."

Members of the New York City Fire Department, who voted a month ago against additional duty during air raid drills, completed a second vote on the subject last night at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

For the citizen who says, "If the government wants the tin cans so bad, let it wash 'em and squash 'em itself," our Professor Ensykle has prepared material for a leaflet setting forth the joys to be derived from complying with Uncle Sam's request in the matter.

DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- The soaring Red Wings moved two games from clinching the National Hockey League championship by defeating the Black Hawks, 5 to 0, before 11,460 spectators at Olympia Stadium tonight.

YOUNG matrons and debutantes of recent seasons are serving on a junior committee, headed by Miss Mary Ann Travers, whose members are aiding in the arrangements for the card party and tea in behalf of the Catholic Big Sisters to be held on Tuesday afternoon at Sherry's.
AMERICANS who had never seen the tropics until a few months ago are today beating the Japanese at his own game, the grim hide-and-seek of jungle war.

WE are often told, in accents of lamentation, that the art of letter-writing is dying out. Its decease, however, seems to be a slow process. Not long ago we had the Holmes-Pollock letters, which certainly showed no sign of the decrepitude of this art.

THE old desert island story is done up very smartly here, with all modern touches. Instead of a shipwreck, a plane is smashed up. There is sparkling snow instead of sandy beaches, and timber wolves take the place of tropical dangers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Mr. Roberts, who was known throughout the world as an authority on structural steel and bridge work, once was described by the late Judge Elbert H. Gary, chairman of United States Steel, as the "greatest practical steel man in the world." He was the last member of the original board of directors of United States Steel.

The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, assisted by the Collegiate Chorale, Robert Shaw, director, presented the first of the two concerts of its Gabrilowitsch Memorial series for this season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

Despite losses of manpower, the nation's commercial banks are faced with a growing and complex list of new demands for special services. Under present wartime conditions they are called upon to invest heavily in government securities and to lend to war industries and also to sell war bonds to the public.

Joe (Muscles) Medwick's signed contract was received yesterday by Branch Rickey, and along with the document, according to the president of the Dodgers, came "the most pleasing letter I have had in all my years of correspondence with Joe Medwick."

WITHIN the last six months Mexican movie production has reached a high mark unequaled in its history. People in the local movie trade give seven reasons for this expansion. First, national products have assumed new importance since this country's declaration of war.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Two manufacturers and four civilian employes of the quartermaster depot here were arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on charges of bribery in connection with bids to furnish mosquito netting and raincoats for the Army.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh announced yesterday that 500 new firemen would be needed to replace a like number who have left city service to join the armed forces. He said he had asked Harry W. Marsh, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, for a new list of eligibles.

A NEW center for volunteer workers opens tomorrow at 587 Fifth Avenue, where the New York Women's Division of the United Seamen's Service has established headquarters under the chairmanship of Mrs. Herbert Scoville.

OF all shade-loving plants, the tuberous begonia, which makes a fresh start each year from a dormant tuber, is perhaps the most brilliant in color and the most varied in flower form. Its bright blooms will bring gayety to those shady stretches on the north side of a house where nothing but ferns seem to thrive, or will add a fresh grace to a shady rock garden where late Spring flowering has altogether vanished.

The more victories the Allied nations win in European 1943 the less food the American people will have. That is our paradoxical situation as ration coupons become as essential as money for the transfer of food from retail shelves to the consumer.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- The rapidity with which the Red Army is exploiting its seizure of Rzhev by overrunning the northeastern corner of the Vyazma-Gzhatsk salient now seriously threatens the extensive area between the Smolensk-Vyazma railroad, which is the spine of the salient, and the Rzhev-Velikiye Luki railroad, now Russian-held.

Ethelbert Smith has caught himself frequently thinking of late about the old eighteenth century maxim that the King can do no wrong. Like a good many other familiar quotations Ethelbert Smith finds the words usually invoked in a sense just the opposite from the real meaning.

GEORGE JESSEL, author and actor, is writing a play, too, which is not to be confused with his autobiography just finished. He calls the play, "Company in the Parlor," and its locale is a New Orleans bordello. Sam Carlton is helping Mr. Jessel with the script.

HENRY PRUNIERES is a French musicologist whose influence in France and out has been wide. He has immersed himself in the study of old music, especially French, and one of his most notable accomplishments was the editing of the complete works of Lully, the composer, who was the favorite of Le Roi Soleil.

It is usually assumed that modern science, which produced long-range artillery and the bursting bomb, flamethrowers and poison gas, tanks and, above all, the airplane, has made war more horrible than it was in the past. In a sense it has. There is no doubt that the impact of mechanized warfare on the individual soldier's psychology is far more terrifying and requires greater moral and physical stamina to withstand than ever before.

THE central figure in Mr. Massie's new novel is a madman, so it is not strange that the book itself is tinged with madness, which makes it fascinating and at times almost repellent. It is the story of a young man named Egan Borthwick, a graduate of Oxford, who goes to a small English town to receive a special type of religious instruction in Greek.

HANOVER, N.H., March 6 -- Dartmouth clinched at least a tie for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title tonight by downing Princeton, 52 -- 33. With two games left, the Indians have to win only one to take their sixth straight championship outright.

THE story of the Acadians -- something most of us are dimly acquainted with through juvenile memories of "Evangeline" -- comes to us in this decade with an unexpectedly modern ring. There was a time not so very long ago when such things seemed to belong to medieval history.

Present regulations covering the establishment of price ceilings on "new" brands of liquor are likely to be discontinued by the Office of Price Administration, in line with the issuance by the agency last week of the long-awaited "relief" order for liquor retailers, trade observers asserted yesterday.

WITH the current interest in vegetable growing augmented by recent activities within city limits, and the appointment of various committees to "do something about it," the city dweller who happens to possess a bit of land is wondering what steps he can take to supplement the lean supply of rationed vegetables and canned products.
LONDON, March 6 -- Great Britain launched today a campaign in which it is hoped to raise in one week 600,000,000 freely loaned by its people toward "Wings for Victory."

The twelfth annual conference of the National Association of Seamen's Welfare Agencies will open here Thursday at the Hotel New Yorker. The meeting will be held in conjunction with the Eastern Regional Conference of the National Conference of Social Work.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Revision of the Civil Service Law, and a new method of civil service administration were recommended today by the Hollowell legislative committee which has been investigating the subject for more than a year. It did not urge action at the current session of the legislature, however, but postponement of the complete revision until next year.

THE welcome which their hitherto unknown Great-Aunt gave Tenny Crepps and her older brother, Budge, was far from effusive when they arrived for a first visit on her farm, but her totally unexpected gift of a broken-down canal boat was a promise of a happy Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A special committee consisting of Bernard M. Baruch, James F. Byrnes, Admiral William D. Leahy, Harry L. Hopkins and Judge Samuel I. Rosenman has been holding secret hearings on manpower problems for the last week at the White House, and is expected to submit its survey and recommendations to President Roosevelt within a few days.

An old building, a small faculty and a none too ample supply of money might mean that a school could do little to further the war effort. Yet many schools, such as Hamilton Central School in up-State New York, with these difficulties and with no Army camp or defense industry near by to pace a war program, have developed set-ups which could give ideas to many city schools.

THIS is a provocative little book on the beasts, birds, insects and plants which may be seen when the traveler takes, not the main traveled routes where trucks and buses run, but the quiet roads that go past farms and rocky pastures, follow streams, or wind among rocky hills.

Norman Thomas, leader of the American Socialist Party, attacked Premier Joseph Stalin in a radio talk over Station WJZ and the Blue Network last night for the recently disclosed execution by Soviet authorities of the two Polish Jewish Socialist leaders, Henrick Ehrlich and Victor Alter.

Irene Jessner and Nadine Conner were heard for the first time in the respective roles of the Marschallin and Sophie at last night's fourth and final performance this season of Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier," at the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Jessner sang the Marschallin's music decidedly well.

JANET, at 30, was regarded by her seven younger brothers and sisters as a settled old maid. The pretty mother of the family, stigmatized as frivolous (with all those children?) by the author, had run off with another man when the youngest was quite small and was never heard of again.

THE American public receives regular reports about the concert life in Great Britain, and particularly London. It has learned with profound admiration of the vision and inspiration of Myra Hess whereby Londoners have been provided on every day since the Fall of 1939 with the best music.

ALTHOUGH a committee composed of members of the boards of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Berkshire Symphonic Festival and the Koussevitzky Music Foundation were formulating plans for continuing the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., this Summer, it has been decided to temporarily suspend its activities, owing to war conditions, according to an announcement made by Serge Koussevitzky, founder and director of the school.

OFFICERS of the armed services will be honored guests at the Spring dance of the Senior Assemblies to be held March 27 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Of the two escorts permitted each girl, one must be an officer.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6 -- Harvard's swimming team showed its best form of the season today, upsetting favored Dartmouth, 44 to 31, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet.

THIS novel is the story of Beulah Land, a section of river plantation country in North Carolina, over the eight years of time bounded by the arrival and departure of a stranger. The inhabitants include river gentry, sharecroppers and Negroes, and their in-betweens; and their lives when we meet them are intimately known and intimately related, one with all the others, according to the ways of the country.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A mounting succession of events and preparations for events have convinced observers here that politics, and 1944 politics in particular, has begun to dominate the minds of public servants whose concentration should be on fighting the war. One aspect of the situation is that the appoinments of Congressional lame ducks to offices that call for special talents and nonpolitical thinking are actually on the increase.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- In a letter addressed to the Judiciary Committees of the House and Senate, the Congress of Women's Auxiliaries of the C.I.O. expressed today "the strongest possible opposition" to the Equal Rights Amendment.

THE fifth in the series of fortnightly supper dances being given in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Theatre Wing Supper Club will take place next Saturday night. The parties are given for the benefit of the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc.

IN his attack last week on the Office of Civilian Supply for talking shortages one minute and calling people traitors the next for the natural reaction of hoarding, Representative Shafer of Michigan noted the elimination of monuments and tombstones in the recent OCS "Bedrock" report.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, March 7 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Navy disclosed tonight that a single American submarine had sunk thirteen Japanese ships -- ten cargo vessels and three warships.

THE late Alexander Woollcott, for all his sweeping judgments, was not too proud to admit an error. Eight years ago I heard him broadcast the famous poem by Edna St. Vincent Millay, whose last lines he read thus: My candle burns at both ends,

The Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, under the local leadership of Grover A. Whalen, summoned art to the aid of home defense yesterday and took over the bare west wall of the lobby of City Hall for a mural painting symbolizing the work of the CDVO and bearing quotations from George Washington and Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The War Labor Board is facing a national crisis over wages. This is apparent in the outcry from organized labor following the board's decision this week in the West Coast aircraft case and in the recent packing-house workers' case.

Readjusting their curricula to meet urgent war needs, women's colleges and universities throughout the country are now adopting accelerated programs, offering to capable students an opportunity to complete the regular four-year course in three years or less. At the same time, however, these colleges are insisting that their status as liberal arts institutions remain unchanged.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Carlos Chavez, Mexican conductor, directed the National Symphony Orchestra in an invitation concert for the Pan American Union tonight in the Hall of the Americas of the Pan American Union Building.

Operations last year of the Coca-Cola Company and its subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $23,267,446 after deductions for Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to the annual report for 1942, announced yesterday.

ACCORDING to the prophets, purple-lipped Cleopatras will not be in vogue this coming Spring. The arbiters of style (both in frocks and in faces) predict a season of gay, brave colors, sometimes saucy, sometimes soft, but as wholesome and as fresh as a daffodil.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 6 -- "Tell us your troubles, soldier," might well be the motto of the Red Cross girls now serving in the Middle East, for there are few problems that these competent, helpful women are not called upon to consider and try to solve.
Setting: Victory Swops and blackouts form an up-to-the-hour background for some highly illegal goings-on in Dalton Center, Mass.

POULTRY is returning to the backyard of the American home. The interest of city and urban people in these domestic birds is growing by leaps and bounds, and they are asking for information on how to start and manage a small flock of poultry.

Three American Army officers have been the first foreign observers to witness actual combat operations of the Soviet Army. The group, headed by Brig. Gen. Patrick Hurley, former Secretary of War, visited the desperately contested Don-Stalingrad front early in December, traveling close behind a fast-moving Red Army as it sliced its way southward. Later the same official group went into the Caucasus to another sector of this gigantic Winter offensive operation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 6 -- Yale defeated Princeton's swimmers, 42 -- 33, today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League Meet. The victory was the sixth straight in circuit competition for the Elis and it gave them first place. The setback was the first in seven league starts for the Tigers.

NEVER did I think that my American accent and an ability to play a fair game of bridge would make a wartime career for me. But here I am in England talking my head off just because American doughboys, although definitely fond of the British, are lonely for people who say "can't" instead of "cawn't."

Manufacturers made every effort last week, particularly in apparel and accessory lines, to fill the large volume of orders now booked and found it necessary to refuse additional business due principally to lack of piece goods, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
" LISTEN, brother," said the sergeant, "when we get back in there against those 'Krauts' we're gonna be just twice as good. You know why? Because we know this thing ain't no fool's game now."

MUCH confusion and resentful criticism in some quarters have been engendered by the announcement that the contracts of fourteen of the present members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, including that of the concertmaster, will not be renewed next season.

ONCE again the welcome list of books for young people, compiled by Mabel Williams, Supervisor of Work With Schools. New York Public Library, and her Book Committee, makes its annual appearance. The books on the list are those suggested for the reading of the older boys and girls who, as they reach high school age, become users of the adult department of the library.

MOST writing is done against time -- all writing, indeed, in the sense that even the most leisurely author has only one life in which to work. But most writing is also done against space. For my sins and to my modest profit I once condensed a handful of assorted novels from 90,000 words or thereabout to 30,000 each.

Hundreds, and probably thousands, of business men who have sacrificed their own business interests to work for government agencies without salary and under an expense reimbursement agreement will have to pay Victory taxes on their expenses, according to a ruling of the Internal Revenue Bureau, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, March 6 -- What threatens to be one of the most delicate and disturbing problems that will confront the United Nations, and especially the United States and Britain, after this war is won has already come into the forefront of the news at a time when the finish of the conflict is not even in sight.

CHUNGKING, China, March 6 (AP) -- A flareup of fighting west of Hupeh was reported today by the Chinese High Command communique, which also announced action in the Hupeh-Honan border region and in the Inner Mongolian Province of Suiyuan.

THE Atlantic patrol north of the fortieth parallel is a cold patrol. It is a bitter, desolate, lonely vastness where the wind is high and the sea is wild. Yet this is the ocean we fight for, the ocean we struggle to maintain. It cannot even be called beautiful, for the days are bleak and stormy and the nights are black and hostile.

THE best news in civilian radio affairs in weeks came a few days ago from the office of Frank A. McIntosh, civilian radio division chief in the War Production Board, Washington.
