It was the long-awaited announcement of the actual production of the new revised list of 114 radio tube types needed to keep home receivers operating during the war.

IN a little essay in the February issue of "Stand By," the American Federation of Radio Artists magazine, Robert J. Landry of the Columbia Broadcasting System wisely observes that "when the history of this war comes to be written considerable credit will be due to the so-called radio documentary programs, those lectures in dramatic form on the nature of our enemies, on the magnitude of our problems, on the challenge of our future."
ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, Feb. 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieutenant Quentin Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, N.Y., 25-year-old son of Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt, has been wounded in action on the Tunisian front.

Edward Kilenyi, now a corporal in the Army Air Corps, who has been hailed, perhaps somewhat prematurely, as "another Paderewski," made his debut with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night. The young pianist played one of the Paderewski triumphs of other days, Liszt's Concerto in E flat major, No. 1.

ALBERT LEA, Minn., March 6 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Della True, 34 years old, confessed today that she killed the two youngest of her seven children to save them from the taunts of their schoolmates. The children were heartbroken, she said, because their playmates teased them about their tattered and worn clothing.

THE scene of this better-than-average school story is a co-educational country boarding school. "Boys' End" and "Girls' End" were quite separate in many ways, but the students met in classes and shared the outdoor activities and the social events of the year.

CHUNGKING, China, March 6 -Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's new book, "China's Destiny," lists wartime tasks and proposes a ten-year plan, including the construction of 12,500 miles of railways, 137,000 miles of highways, 220,000 automobiles, 12,000 transport planes and a tremendous increase in technical education aimed at training 2,000,000 technicians.

THE OWI's Overseas Motion Picture Bureau is swinging into a film production program through which it hopes to counteract in foreign lands the impression that the United States is a country of gangsters and cattle-rustling cowboys.

The transportation of ship officers and seamen from vessels at anchor in the harbor waiting for berths or waiting to leave port has developed to such proportions that it is now "a huge business" requiring reorganization to avoid ship delays, it was disclosed yesterday.

MRS. CHARLES E. MITCHELL will give a reception Tuesday afternoon at her home, 1 Sutton Place South, for members of a special box committee organized to advance the sale of subscriptions for the violin recital to be given by Fritz Kreisler on the night of March 22 at Carnegie Hall, proceeds from which will go to the American Red Cross War Fund.

The steel industry began the present year with a supply of 3,831,000 net tons of scrap steel in stock yards adjacent to its plants, or about four and one-half weeks' supply at current levels of consumption, according to a survey made by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

LAWS governing the scoring at contract bridge are always of more interest to bridge players than any other laws of the game. The 1943 laws, which are already being used at most clubs and will be standard for all bridge games on April 1, make only two changes in the scoring table.

THE family was having a lazy, happy Sunday, with late breakfast (waffles, maple syrup and the bacon Jim broiled with such gustatory skill), a neighbor dropping in and Doody making plans for Peg's first Christmas vacation from college.

THIS is a French officer's war prison notebook. On the jacket the publisher says "We do not know who Marcel Haedrich is. We know that the name he uses is not his own. * * * We believe he must already have fame as a writer. * * * "

ON this page is a collection of recipes -- some of them are suggestions rather than exact formulas -- relating to point rationing. The first group deals with preparing fresh vegetables simply and (in most cases) speedily; the second, with serving fresh fruits simply and speedily; the third, with stretching processed foods.

A total of 110 3-year-olds, including Count Fleet, 1942 juvenile champion and world record-holder, has been named for the sixty-ninth Kentucky Derby, to be run May 1 at Churchill Downs in Louisville for a $75,000 added purse. Thus Col. Matt Winn, who has made the Derby internationally known, has the ingredients to perpetuate his horse race, one of the richest in the world.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Navy communique 301:
LONDON, March 6 (U.P.) -- Seven American airmen -- two of them wounded -- from a Flying Fortress have been rescued from the North Sea after an eight-hour battle with icy winds and 40-foot waves.

LAST October Gilbert Miller was talking with Ina Claire about doing Turgenev's "A Month In the Country," which hasn't been seen hereabout since the Theatre Guild put it on for seventy-one performances thirteen years ago come St. Patrick's Day.

A SERIES of five lectures on "The Home Victory Garden" will be sponsored by the Flushing Garden Club beginning tomorrow. The sessions will be held at the Methodist Episcopal Parish House, 136-45 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, at 8 P.M. Admission is free and the public is invited to attend.

Consolidated Railroads of Cuba and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the three months ended on Dec. 31, last, a net income of $1,581,278 after charges and taxes, compared with $450,135 in the corresponding quarter of 1941 and $326,525 in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, 1942.
BALTIMORE, March 6 (AP) -- The Liberty ship William Osler, named for the Canadian physician who died in 1919, was launched today at the Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyard.

MANY of the plants growing wild in the field, garden and yard are wholesome and nutritious and may be eaten cooked or raw. If picked when young and tender, these wild plants make delicious cooked greens and piquant, leafy Spring salads.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A new type of currency was introduced to American shoppers this week, and, despite the forebodings of government experts, the average housewife mastered its intricacies within twenty-four hours.

PERSONS going to picnics and fairs and other fun spots reached only by special bus will either have to give them up for the duration or walk. For the ban to be placed on special buses on March 15 by the Office of Defense Transportation will affect these along with race tracks, golf and beach clubs, baseball grounds and stores.
LONDON, March 6 -- Cup soccer games today drew the largest crowds of the season in both the Northern and Southern English Leagues.

TO the Riobamba, Linton Well's East Fifty-seventh Street retreat, goes the distinction of offering the week's most ambitious entertainment program. For Mr. Weil, ever solicitous to please the fickle seekers of nocturnal diversion, has engaged three -- not one -- personalities to grace the confines of his establishment, beginning next Thursday evening.

LONDON, March 6 -- The Royal Air Force loosed upon Essen and the great Krupp arms works at that Ruhr city at least 150 two-ton bombs last night in the course of a "very heavy and concentrated" raid, as the Air Ministry described it. The raid cost fourteen of the several hundred bombers employed.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- New high prices for the season were established today on the Board of Trade by oats and rye following an announcement that the government contemplated raising the ceiling price of No. 3 yellow corn to $1.08 a bushel, or full parity, other grades to sell at customary premiums or discounts. This is 6 1/2 cents above the current permissible maximum.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The necessity for curtailing as much as possible the use of castor, citicica and tung oils, because there is no relief in sight from the critical supply situation in these raw materials, was stressed at a meeting here of government officials with representatives of the oleo resinous and tower oil coating industry last week.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 6 -- Gustavo Abaunza, Under Secretary of War and Interior, has resigned and Juan Lopez Moranda has been appointed Under Secretary of Interior. Major Carlos Telleria, Governor of Bluefields, has been named Under Secretary of War.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 6 -Navy defeated Army today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League swim meet, 46 to 29. Cadet Bill Glynn was outstanding, winning the 220 and 100 yard free-style races.

Enthusiasts for the across-Jersey canal between Sayreville on the Raritan River and Bordentown on the Delaware River see as a progressive step in their efforts the announcement that the House Committee on River and Harbors will hold a hearing Tuesday morning at 10:30 o'clock.
THIS is Gladys Swarthout of the Metropolitan and WABC-Columbia's "Family Hour," on the subject of popular songs and operatic arias:

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP) -- Prices of hogs held nominally steady today, although the undertone was weak. As only 500 head were placed on sale, there was no real test of the market. The nominal top was $15.75 a hundredweight. However, hogs generally advanced about 25 cents during the week, the $16 hog appearing for the first time since October, 1920.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (U.P.) -- Queues of customers before meat markets today underlined forecasts of imminent serious food and farm labor shortages in the Far West which will affect both civilians and the armed services.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Meeting on Tuesday with Prentiss Brown, Director of the Office of Price Administration, ten members of the Senate Finance and Banking Committee will suggest sweeping changes in the policies and practice of the organization he heads.

The words of H.G. Wells's prophetic pre-war title accurately described what has been happening around the world during the past seven days. We are surely seeing "the shape of things to come." In the South Pacific General MacArthur's land-based planes have wiped out a large Japanese armada bound for New Guinea, a decisive victory that may have halted finally the enemy's southward thrust.

Premier Hideki Tojo told the Japanese House of Representatives yesterday, in response to a resolution "urging that the strength of the nation's fighting power be increased," that 1943 would be an important war year for the Japanese nation.

AS any one who saw "Flying Tigers" or "How Green Was My Valley" must know, Anna Lee has a cool, liquid voice, reddish hair and the sort of complexion possessed only by babes and English women -- at least if one believes the Yardley ads. Miss Lee also has legs; among her other charms, the legs are by no means to be overlooked.

A DIGEST of helpful hints for the radio writer has just been issued by the Office of War Information, which sets forth some of the pitfalls into which the pencil pushers are apt to stumble and offers a few suggestions that would seem adaptable to peacetime radio, too.

TORONTO, March 6 (AP) -- Toronto moved into undisputed possession of third place in the National Hockey League standings tonight by battling Montreal to a 2-2 deadlock before 11,766 fans. The result left the race for the last two playoff berths still obscure with less than two weeks of the regular schedule to play.

PORTLAND, Me., March 6 (AP) -- One at a time, the thirty-eight men in the crew of the 319-foot Boston collier Hartwelson leaped into the Atlantic and were rescued by the Coast Guard early today as the raging sea pounded their vessel apart on Bantam Rock, five miles south of Newagen.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6 -- The tall cadets on the basketball team of the Military Academy were too fast on tip-offs and rebounds today for the midshipmen of the Naval Academy, and the Army won the annual contest with the Navy, 56 to 45.

A post-war vocational guidance bureau, established by British prisoners of war in Sta lag VIII-B, Germany, is being extended to all other camps in that country where Britons are held, through the cooperation of the War Prisoners Aid of the Y.M.C.A.

The heavy drone of big four-engined bombers resounded last week over Adolf Hitler's "Fortress Europe." The Germans, who initiated large-scale bombing of big cities, were being blasted in the greatest air assault in history. It began in January with a few heavy raids. Since then the rain of metal and high explosive has grown in intensity.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Michigan returned to the Big Ten indoor track supremacy tonight after an absence of two years, setting a record by sweeping up 53 1/2 points for the most complete domination in the meet's thirty-three-year history.

The only unequivocal report received from Washington during the past week on the income tax situation is that the 1942 return must be filed on or before March 15, accompanied by payment of the first installment of at least one-quarter of the tax.

Runner-up for the women's senior title for the past two seasons, Miss Gretchen Merrill of the Skating Club of Boston gained a slight lead for the crown as the 1943 edition of the national figure-skating championships opened yesterday at the Iceland rink atop Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 (U.P.) -- Queues of customers before meat markets today underlined forecasts of imminent serious food and farm labor shortages in the Far West which will affect both civilians and the armed services.

LONDON, Monday, March 8 (AP) -- A few German raiders flew up the Thames Estuary early today to drop heavy explosives in the Greater London area and put the capital under an alert for the second time in a week. London's anti-aircraft guns put up sharp fire.

The first American hearing in concert form of Serge Prokofieff's "epic cantata," "Alexander Nevsky," for chorus, solo voice and orchestra, took place at the concert given by Leopold Stokowski and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, with the assistance of the Westminster Choir and Jennie Tourel, contralto, yesterday afternoon in Radio City.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, or the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott, pastor of the historic First Presbyterian Church, Passaic, N.J., is apt to win the 1943 Moderatorship of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., the highest office in that denomination, it was disclosed yesterday by their friends.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- A curtailed Spring exhibition schedule, sharply reduced from last year's slate of 260 games, was announced today by the American League.
Trailing by three goals at the end of the second period, the Rangers rallied to go ahead of the Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 7 (AP) -- The A.F.L. Aeronautical Mechanics Lodge 1,125, in a vote of acclamation at a mass meeting, today urged President Roosevelt to order the Army and Navy to "take over" the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation plant.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Feb. 27 to March 5 are given in the appended tabulation:

Women with the armed forces are more "highbrow" and serious-minded in their reading tastes than are the men in the services, it was said yesterday at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Room 112 was opened as a Book Canteen two weeks ago.

Tonight's events: "Don Giovanni," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; flute recital by Rene Le Roy, with Chamber Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:45. Admiral Raymond Fenard, chief of the French Naval Mission, and 100 of the crew of the Richelieu will be guests of Mr. Le Roy at a supper and dance in Town Hall after the recital.

Americans in the armed forces are the best ambassadors this country ever sent abroad, the Rev. Dr. Michael Coleman, formerly acting vicar of All Hallows Church, London, and now Canon Missioner in the Diocese of British Columbia, said in a sermon yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
The news you read from the Soviet Union is as accurate as any that can be given from a great country at war.
The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin warned yesterday against national isolationism, declaring that it is as hostile to Christian brotherhood as any aggressive imperialism we fear in allies or foes.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The War Manpower Commission paved the way today for resumption of the drafting of men over 38 years old by ordering local Selective Service Boards to abolish the 4-H classification.

ALBANY, March 7 (AP) -- Four hundred weary war plant workers snatched a few hours' sleep tonight on the hard floors of the Massena Town Hall, stranded by a gale-driven snowstorm that crippled a large section of up-State.

A spokesman for General Giraud, speaking to the people of occupied France from Radio France in Algiers, declared yesterday that by March 1 the Germans had completed a reorganization of the laws and government of Alsace and Lorraine that amounted to "out-and-out annexation."

The first Sunday since the Office of Price Administration substituted the honor system for policing of the ban on pleasure driving saw little if any increase in passenger car traffic in the metropolitan area.

Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, in his annual statement to stockholders issued for publication today, reported that 1942 sales and income before taxes were the largest in the history of the company. The net income after taxes and reserve for contingencies came within a few dollars of equaling the record net income figures established in 1941.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Complete change of the emphasis of New York City's educational system, in curriculum and direction, was urged today by the Rapp-Coudert committee investigating the city's school system.
LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The remarks of Professor Moulton and Dr. Virgil Jordan at the recent dinner of the Economic Club of New York on paying for the war, as reported in THE TIMES, while on the whole excellent, are in part not clear and convincing. They seem to assume that paying for the war can be postponed to a later time.

A sparkling, graceful performance by Miss Marcella May and James Lochead Jr., representing the Skate and Ski Club of San Francisco, yesterday ended the East's grip on the senior dance title as the three-day national amateur figure-skating championship meet continued at the Iceland Rink atop Madison Square Garden.

A BRILLIANT behemoth of a book is published today. It is a novel truly majestic in theme and epic in scope that falls far short of its great aims in its actual execution. Nevertheless it is more vital, more intellectually exciting, more truly noble in its passion for human dignity than any work of fiction I have read in a long time.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch remains as both War Minister of the Yugoslav Government in Exile and field commander of guerrillas battling Axis occupation forces within that nation, a statement issued on behalf of "authorized Yugoslav circles" said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 7 -- British Eighth Army troops were reported tonight to be hurling back wave after wave of German tank assaults with heavy enemy losses as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel strove desperately, but so far in vain, to crack their positions before the Mareth Line.

Dorothy Maynor gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of Hampton Institute and Lincoln University. For the event the soprano had prepared a comprehensive program covering a wide range of styles and demanding interpretive gifts of no mean order for its proper performance.

CLEVELAND, March 7 -- Ch. Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds, Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., and handled by John Goudie won his fifteenth best-in-show award tonight, taking chief honors at the twenty-seventh annual all-breed show of the Western Reserve Kennel Club.

CAIRO, March 7 -- Squadron Leader Lance Wade of Tuscon, Ariz., veteran American flier who joined the Royal Air Force at the beginning of the war, got one of five enemy planes that were shot down in one day on the Southern Tunisian front without loss to Allied pursuit planes.

The six-story store and loft building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 24 Bond Street has been purchased by an investing client of Irving T. Wolfson through the Charles F. Noyes Company. It is assessed at $17,000 and was bought by the seller in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Argument in the first case of a conscientious objector of the Second World War to be put to the Supreme Court was tentatively set for an early date as the court calendar was mapped out over the week-end.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Members of the Legislature from the metropolitan area voted on important measures last week as follows:
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, March 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Complete and intensive courses in the cultivation of "victory gardens," from preparing the soil, planting and transplanting to canning and storing, will be offered by speakers at "Garden Week" to be presented by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES from March 15 through March 18 at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Mayor La Guardia appealed to housewives yesterday to process all tin cans, if it is possible, before putting them out for the Department of Sanitation's weekly collection for detinning.

A surprise air raid drill that will provide the most severe test to date of the city's civilian defense establishment will be held soon, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. Plans for the drill await only the approval of the Army and the State civilian defense agency, he said.

Some little concern has been expressed -- all on the good-natured side -- over the possibility that the war may have an effect on the English language. Geoffrey Whitworth, director of the British Drama League, is reported in an Associated Press dispatch to be wondering about the influence of American and Canadian accents on the speech of British children.
The cure for absenteeism lies not, as your correspondent Robert Routh indicates, in penalizing absentees, but in removing or weakening the underlying causes of absenteeism.

Commending "the fortitude and patience" of the Chinese in his sermon yesterday morning, the Rev. Fred Robert Tiffany, preaching at the Richmond Hill Baptist Church, 114th Street and Ninety-first Avenue, Queens, said that "the amazing faith of those people in present day life, who have been denied the privileges of liberty, life and the pursuit of happiness, is something to marvel at."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 7 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce, acknowledging an invitations from President Roosevelt to visit the White House March 10 with other freshmen legislators, wrote the President today that "while we feel that our cause is safe on the battlefronts, we are deeply alarmed by the many disquieting and even explosive circumstances that face us on the home front."

Investigators of the Office of Price Administration have been directed to make no search of homes for hoards of canned foods unless extreme violations are reported and then only with a search warrant, Walter Gellhorn, regional attorney for OPA, District 2, disclosed here last night.

The members of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, to which nearly all members of the Fire Department belong, have voted almost two to one to continue to perform "V duty," Vincent J. Kane, president of the association, announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 7 -- The third and most dangerous phase of the large-scale German delaying action in Tunisia has opened with Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's attack on the British Eighth Army.

Wartime restrictions are reflected in altered buying habits of the public, especially in the furniture field, where a trend toward investment in better grades of pieces is becoming evident. Because of government regulations on manufacturing, the type preferred now is the one that will last for the duration.

Long before the outbreak of hostilities the National Gallery of London, one of the great art museums of the world, laid plans for the protection of its many precious works from German bombs. The bulk of the collection was transferred in ten days before Sept. 3, 1939, to country houses and halls.

Consolidated net profit of the United Aircraft Corporation for 1942 was $17,096,841, or $5.95 a share on the common stock after preferred dividends, comparing with $16,721,381, or $6.29 a share for the common stock, in 1941, when no preferred stock was outstanding, according to a report issued for publication today.

A joint conference of the Association of New England Community Chests and Councils and the Mid-Eastern Regional Conference opened yesterday at the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of Community Chests and Councils, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Buying by consumers was well maintained in January, with sales of all retail stores totaling $4,481,000,000, 3 per cent more than in January of last year, according to Department of Commerce estimates released today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 7 (AP) -- A communique:
Miss Marilyn Sahner, a national champion, and Miss Florence Schmitt, 12-year-old Women's Swimming Association star, won titles in the London Terrace pool yesterday.

LONDON, March 7 -- Thousands of Londoners, and American soldiers, too, from a crowd of about a million pushing through Trafalgar Square, bought savings stamps today and plastered them on two 500-pound bombs in the Square "for delivery to Hitler."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 7 -- The famous white whippet bitch with the slate-gray patch and slate-marked ears, Champion Flornell Glamorous, tonight took the highest honors at the twenty-seventh annual All-Breed Show of the Providence County Kennel Club in the Elks Auditorium.

In an effort to meet the problem of intensified competition from other forms of transportation after the war, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, in his report for 1942 to stockholders, released for publication today, reveals that the road has created a research council composed of officers of the company "whose individual qualifications and official responsibilities particularly fit them for the assignment."

Sonnets have been addressed to the beauty of English women's skin -- the pallor of face, the creamy softness of hand. But in latter years the women of Britain have been a bit too engrossed in the saving of their figurative skins to pay much attention to care of their literal ones.

Singing informed with the amount of soulfulness and inner warmth Rosel Benda, New York soprano, brought to her work at her debut recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall is rarely encountered nowadays. The depth of expressiveness with which "Ewig war ich," from Wagner's "Siegfried," or a song like Brahms's "Die Mainacht" was delivered, and the spontaneity of feeling that imbued every measure of them, made them exceptionally impressive from the interpretive point of view.

UPPER DARBY, Pa., March 7 -- About 100 women and children comprising twenty families will move from Kentucky to the Eastern Seaboard this week as part of one of the largest mass migrations in recent American history, J.H. Wood, regional director of the Farm Security Administration, made known today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 7 (AP) -- Cancellation of the Notre Dame-Stanford football game, scheduled here Sept. 25, was announced tonight by Al Masters, Stanford athletic director, after a telephone conversation with Head Coach Frank Leahy of the South Bend, Ind., university.

In the presence of both his old and new congregations, the Rev. Dr. J. Wilson Sutton, formerly vicar of Trinity Episcopal Chapel, conducted his first service yesterday morning as rector of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 128 West Sixty-ninth Street, near Broadway.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

NEW DELHI, India, March 7 (AP) -- Increasing evidence that the Japanese in the Asiatic theatre are refusing to come out and fight in the air was reported by Brig. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell, commander of the United States Tenth Air Force, at a press conference today in which he summarized February operations in India, Burma and China.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 7 -- Passive resistance in France to Chief of Government Pierre Laval's "collaboration" with Germany is developing to such an extent that young men and girls, fearful of being sent to Germany for forced labor, are purposely falling down the stairs of their homes in the hope of breaking an arm or leg.

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday the resignation, effective next Monday, of W. Francis FitzGerald, chairman of its impartial grievance committee since it was established about a year ago. He will enter the banking field.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The Legislature enters the "stretch" in its adjournment drive this coming week.
Sacrifice for spiritual victory should be the keynote of Lenten self-denial, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

When Rzhev fell to the Russians it was inevitable that they should also capture Gzhatsk, the nearest point to Moscow on the entire German front. Now they are closing in on Vyazma, the southern anchor of the Rzhev salient. Obviously this whole great bulge is crumbling.

Long after the lights went out at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, wherever track fans gathered the chief topic was not the runaway victory of N.Y.U. in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. carnival. The Violet success was expected, even though its unprecedented point total was not.

The George Marion Jr. musical, "Early to Bed," will go into rehearsal about April 5, Richard Kolmar said yesterday. Present plans call for it to open May 6 at the Shubert in New Haven, whence it will go to Boston the next Monday, May 10.

Mrs. A.M. Sobel and Edward Hymes won the Eastern States contract bridge mixed pair championship last night, rounding out a record week for Mrs. Sobel. In the tournament, which started Saturday, Feb. 27, she won three of the four championships and finished second in the fourth.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The war Department announced today award of the Air Medal for meritorious service in the South Pacific to these Air Corps enlisted men:

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 7 (U.P.) -- Police ended a street fight today between members of the International Association of Machinists (A.F.L.), arriving in town for a protest meeting against the War Labor Board, and Socialist pamphlet distributors, who were chased two blocks through the business district.

LONDON, March 7 -- A group of Danish boys, imprisoned for sabotage, carried out one of the most audacious plots in occupied Europe. Their story was told in "Denmark -- Fight Follows Surrender," which will be published Tuesday by the Danish Council of Information Office.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, March 8 -- American and Australian air success in the destruction of the Japanese fleet in the Bismarck Sea was achieved with air inferiority. We put 136 aircraft into last week's battle, compared with 150 by the Japanese.
LONDON, March 7 -- Music, said Captain Arthur B. Hunt, who ought to know, is a weapon.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 -- Steel ingot output throughout the country last week is estimated at 98.5 per cent of the newly established capacity figure as of Jan. 1, this year. This is equivalent to 99.5 per cent of rated capacity based on the figure used before the revisions were made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- Paramount has announced that it is negotiating for Katharine Hepburn to portray Cornelia Otis Skinner in "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," the recent best seller by Miss Skinner and Emily Kimbrough, both of whom are collaborating on the script with Sheridan Gibney.

Desperate efforts to replenish declining retail inventories continued last week, with buyers seeking both to place new orders and to expedite delivery of old ones, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Two flags that are to stand permanently in the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of Christ the Consoler in Bellevue Hospital were blessed there yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.

The policy committee of the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, president of the union, representing 450,000 bituminous coal miners, will begin sessions at the Hotel Roosevelt this morning preparatory to opening negotiations for a new agreement with soft coal operators of the Northern Appalachian region on Wednesday.

Oxford University Press, not the least deterred by the paper problems the war has brought upon publishers, will issue March 25 a new revised edition of "The Book," the story of printing and bookmaking, by Douglas C. McMurtrie. The new volume is a completely rewritten version of "The Golden Book," which ran through four editions when first printed in 1927.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Soaring prices for hogs, with a top of $16 a hundredweight, the best since 1920, resulted last week in packers suffering a further squeeze owing to the ceiling prices on lard and other hog products, and what trading there was in the latter commodities was at the maximum levels permitted under government regulations.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 7 (U.P.) -- American-made Consolidated Liberator bombers, whose sting has proved so fatal to the enemy that fighter escorts are unnecessary, tonight were revealed to be doing virtually all the long-range strategic bombing from the Middle East of Axis Central Mediterranean communication lines.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, March S (U.P.) -- Allied medium bombers yesterday battered the Japanese base at Tual, in the Kai Islands, 90 miles south of the western end of New Guinea, causing heavy damage and starting many fires, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

An urgent plea to provide sanctuary for the Jews "whom Adolf Hitler has doomed to die in his human slaughterhouses in Eastern Europe" was made yesterday afternoon at the fifty-eighth annual convention of Hias, the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, in the Hotel Astor.

College basketball enters its final week of the campaign, except for tournament competition, with a Madison Square Garden double-header Wednesday night as the highlight. This twin bill will send St. John's against St. Francis and N.Y.U. against C.C.N.Y. St. John's and N.Y.U. are in the running for tournament bids.

CHUNGKING, China, March 7 -- After being subjected to furious Chinese counter-attacks, Japanese troops on the west bank of the Salween River have started a general retreat, the Central News Agency reported from Tali today, adding that "many strategic points have been recovered by the Chinese."
Some anglers have expressed a desire to know what sort of fishing instructions accompany the kit that is to be issued by various branches of the armed services along with life-saving equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (U.P.) -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, reported tonight that huge quantities of raw materials had been supplied to Russia for its munitions industry in addition to "many thousand" planes, tanks and guns and other equipment for its fighting men.

ATLANTA, March 7 -- One soldier died and thirteen are believed to have been drowned in an accident during night manoeuvres in the storm-tossed Gulf of Mexico off Florida, the Army's Fourth Service Command announced today. Five, including two officers, were rescued.
Ten days later than last year because of necessary wartime revisions, but with the opening date, April 21, only one week later than in 1942, the National League baseball schedule was released today.
Stay-at-home New Yorkers were subjects yesterday of a treasure hunt.

The Permanent Court of International Justice has exerted great influence on international law since its creation in 1920, Dr. Manley O. Hudson, a judge of the Court and Bemis Professor of Law at Harvard University, asserts in this month's issue of International Conciliation, publication of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, released yesterday.

RAMONA ALLEN had spent the Summer skating in London and it was time for her to return home. This pert 15-year-old miss will be whirling about in Madison Square Garden at the finals of the national figure skating championships tonight, but quite a bit happened, between her London and New York appearances.

As the first week of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund appeal drew to a close yesterday, Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the campaign to raise $12,920,700 in this city toward the national goal of $125,000,000, received word that before the end of this month New York City would become the leading center for preparing Red Cross food packages for prisoners of war.

LONDON, March 7 -- The stock markets here have experienced another quiet but cheerful week, News from the various fronts has had a gently stimulating effect on sentiment with particular stress laid on the utter rout of the Japanese armada in the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- America's growing air strength in the South Pacific was employed over the week-end in three raids against the Japanese, in which five enemy strongholds were pounded.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Board of Economic Warfare formally announced today adoption of a plan whereby the other American governments are to cooperate in selection of United States exports of commercial goods southward in the hemisphere.

Although four of the best chess players in the country headed the Marshall Chess Club team in the third round of the Metropolitan League tournament, the champions were held to a 4-4 tie by the West Side Y.M.C.A. Chess Club yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 (AP) -- A British communique:

Camargo Guarnieri, Brazilian composer, was honored last night by the League of Composers at the Museum of Modern Art with a concert of his works presented by distinguished soloists and chamber-music performers. These included Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera and before that of the Paris Opera Comique; Arnaldo Estrella, Brazilian pianist; Joseph Schuster, 'cellist; Leonard Bernstein, pianist; Samuel Dushkin, violinist, and Beveridge Webster, pianist.

The repertory season of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman added another chapter to its record last night by presenting on its new bill down at its little Sixteenth Street Studio Theatre Mr. Weidman's latest comedy decoction, "And Daddy Was a Fireman."

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Expectations that the ceiling prices on cash corn and futures would be raised soon, probably around 8 cents a bushel, resulted in very little trading in that grain last week on the Board of Trade. The only business in futures was a few sales of July at the maximum permitted figure.

WELLESLEY, Mass., March 7 -- Overcome by the emotion of her return after twenty-five years to her alma mater, Madame Chiang Kai-shek nearly collapsed as she began a speech to the Wellesley student body today.

Following a dozen million-share days in February, the stock market on three days of last week crossed two million shares -- a daily activity not reached since 1941. Both stocks and bonds reached the highest average of 1943 to date, railway shares in particular going on Thursday to the highest since November of 1939.
Seven new films, including a French importation, will have local premieres this week. The schedule follows:
MOSCOW, March 7 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique:

CHICAGO, March 7 - New seasonal high prices for cash oats and futures were established last week, the former bringing the top price since 1928 owing to limited offerings and a continued good shipping demand.

As a result of rationing, you will undoubtedly be using the stove a good deal in the weeks to come -- preparing more fresh vegetables than the processed ones that are virtually ready to serve, and conjuring up dishes that will stretch a limited quantity of meat.

A new concept of business obligations to provide information for "customers" was seen by agency men in the 1,000-line copy recently carried in seventy-five newspapers throughout the country by the Bendix Aviation Corporation. The customers are taxpayers of America, since Bendix now produces only war material for planes, tanks, jeeps and other fighting equipment, and its output is running twenty times its pre-war rate.

SEATTLE, March 7 (AP) -- Japanese war lords have been using a foreknowledge of the labor unrest in the Pacific Coast aircraft industry in their propaganda efforts against the United Nations, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd told a mass meeting of Boeing workers today.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The second-class mailing privileges of "The Militant," a weekly publication printed every Saturday in New York, have been revoked by Postmaster General Walker on the ground that it has attempted "to embarrass and defeat the government in its effort to prosecute the war to a successful termination."

The Rev. Doushan J. Shoukletovich, the rector, and the parishioners of St. Sava's Serbian Orthodox Church held their initial service yesterday morning in their new house of worship, the former Trinity Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, west of Broadway.
Mrs. George Wadsworth of Buffalo, who had been at the Plaza, left yesterday for Hot Springs, Va.

LONDON, March 7 -- Thousands of words have been written about what the women of Great Britain, Russia, China and the United States are contributing toward achieving a common victory. How about the women of Germany? Are they doing less, as much or more now that there is total mobilization of all women from the age of 17 through 45?

Although net sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation in 1942 amounted to $562,451,639, almost one-third greater than the $431,049,646 in 1941, net profits after taxes and reserves were $12,221,852, or $1.95 a share, against $12,334,734, or $1.97 a share, earned in 1941, according to the annual report signed by L.A. Van Bomel, president, released for publication today.

Two thousand Brooklyn civilian defense volunteers, many of them in the uniforms of their services, gathered yesterday afternoon in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, to be sworn into the newly organized Citizens Service Corps and hear addresses by Mayor La Guardia and Grover Whalen, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

Out of the war laboratories are coming many developments that will lead to better living in a peacetime world. Vistas of some of the paths which these developments will take were opened before the Science Talent Institute in Washington by Dr. Hugh L. Dryden, president of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, and Dr. Joseph Slepian of the Westinghouse laboratories.
The Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 111.1 to 111.3 in the week ended March 5.

Steps will be taken at once to provide the city with "the largest, most modern primary terminal market in the entire country," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. The capital outlay budget for 1943 will be amended, he said, to pave the way for engineering and architectural plans for the project so that construction may be started as soon as possible.

Voicing New York City's determination to make every effort to bring down meat prices and to make "tough going" for the "rash-hogs" of the "black market," Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall announced yesterday that the Commissioner of Health today would embargo "a certain food item" which he declared had been placed on the market to circumvent Office of Price Administration regulations and to reap higher prices.

CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- The National Hockey League-leading Red Wings scored two goals in the third period tonight to tie the Black Hawks, 3-to-3, before 16,670 fans, largest crowd of the season here.

ALGIERS, March 7 -- The regime of General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief, formally severed all connection with Vichy and Marshal Henri Philippe Petain tonight when General Giraud declared in a statement to the press that "a decree signed in Vichy has no effect in French Africa."

Despite a two-day upturn at the close of the period, the cotton futures market lost ground last week as continued indecision as to pending farm legislation discouraged trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts showed net losses of 5 to 12 points in contrast to gains of 22 to 37 points in the preceding week.

LONDON, Monday, March 8 -- Capturing towns and villages at the rate of three an hour against stubborn enemy resistance, Red Army shock troops are sweeping on toward Vyazma, last bastion of the great German offensive line that for seventeen months had threatened Moscow, Russia reported today.

With twenty-two penalties called -- high for the season at Madison Square Garden -- and not one fight, the Rovers were humbled by the Coast Guard Cutters, 5 to 2, in an Amateur Hockey Association play-off game yesterday. A crowd of 9,000 watched the hard-fought contest.

After nearly a year of careful investigation and analysis the subcommittee of the Joint Legislative Committee, headed by Senator Coudert, has concluded its survey of administrative and financial problems found in the New York City school system. This report, clear, comprehensive and sound, marks an epoch in local school history.

NEW ORLEANS, March 7 -- Testimony of Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown before the Senate Agricultural Committee Friday on abandonment of farmers' incentive payments, a statement by Secretary Claude W. Wickard that same day that farm acreage probably "cannot be increased over last year," and persistent price-fixing against textile orders, combined to halt a sharp spill in cotton futures after midweek.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The weather was heavy over New Britain Island last Monday and when Lieutenant Walter Higgins of Fort Worth, Texas, spotted a break in the clouds, he decided to take his heavy Liberator bomber down for another "look-see."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 7 -- Marshal Rommel has lost heavily in his big attack, intended as a surprise. He threw into the fight all the Mark IV and huge Mark VI tanks at his disposal, including many belonging to Col. Gen. Dietloff von Arnim, the German commander in the north.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The $25,000 salary ceiling and the farm labor draft deferment issues, two of the many disputes concerning Administration policy which have marked the course of the new Congress, seemed shaping up for a showdown in both the House and Senate this week.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The following is an official summary of the report of the New York City subcommittee of the Joint Legislative Committee on the State Education System:

VADUZ, Principality of Liechtenstein, March 7 -- Unmindful of war drums beating against its frontiers, the diminutive Principality of Liechtenstein, counting 11,102 persons who occupy sixty-five square miles of fertile land, lustily acclaimed its sovereignty today as its ruler, Prince Franz Josef II, took unto himself a spouse in the thirty-seventh year of his life and the fifth of his reign.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Regional branches of the Office of Price Administration may adjust the maximum prices charged by individual sellers of fresh lettuce, spinach, carrots, green peas, snap beans, tomatoes and cabbage where the ceilings are higher or lower than others generally prevailing in a given region and are likely to disrupt normal distribution, the OPA announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (AP) -- The former triple boxing champion, Henry Armstrong, marked up another victory in his sensational comeback campaign, knocking out Tippy Larkin, Garfield, N.J., welterweight, in the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout at the Civic Auditorium tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (AP) -- Big bombers of the Tenth United States Army Air Force, joining the Royal Air Force's assault on Japanese bases in Burma, have sunk or damaged three Japanese cargo ships in Rangoon River, started a huge fire in Moulmein and damaged the approaches to the vital Myitnge Bridge south of Mandalay, an air force communique said today.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, said today that news of important American aid was being kept from the Russian people and he suggested that Russian authorities sought to give the impression that Russia was fighting the war entirely alone.

Declaring that teen age girls in their last two years of high school could render invaluable service to the civilian defense effort by helping to care for young children, the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volun teer Office announced yesterday the opening of a "Junior Service in Child Care" course.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Despite indications that the petroleum supply situation is becoming progressively worse rather than better, the Office of Price Administration said today that householders pinched for heat due to circumstances beyond their control would be allowed supplementary fuel oil rations beginning next week.

THE weather may be a military secret but it is no secret that recent developments have temporarily steeped the countryside in snow and both the Giant and Yankee offices in gloom. Branch Rickey is probably chuckling to himself over in Brooklyn. As far as Brother Branch is concerned it can snow right up to opening day and his Dodgers will be getting in shape at the cavernous West Point field house.

The Food Industry War Committee, set up by food trade groups to assist in the promotion of the nation's wartime food supply, yesterday opened its permanent offices in Washington, D.C., it was announced by Clarence Francis, chairman.

After an absence of more than a year, the Frigidaire division of General Motors will resume advertising next month when it launches a new service campaign in newspapers, national magazines, as well as home economics and business papers.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The White House asserted today that Representative Clare Boothe Luce, Republican of Connecticut, had sent a political reply to a social invitation.

The suggestion by one of your correspondents, Harold J. Fishbein, relative to relieving the near-famine in farm labor by the organized diversion of thousands of men rejected by the armed services "for minor physical defects, or in the 38-45 age group not now engaged in war industries," seems to me to merit official study.

The war industries need engineers and skilled technicians, the Army and the civilian population need doctors. But we cannot employ refugee engineers and technicians in responsible positions or permit refugee doctors to practice unless they are citizens. This is as it should be.

This is the motto the Camp Fire Girls have adopted for the battle against waste they are waging this month by way of celebrating the thirty-first birthday of their organization. The recruits for this battle, called "Thriftees," are making a spirited attack on the home, salvage and war bond fronts.

Slowly but successfully a new France is being built on the sands of Africa. The order issued by General Giraud on March 7 repudiates the authority of the Vichy regime not only for North Africa but for all of France, and therewith forms a document which, for the import which it carries, is unique in its military terseness.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Ways and Means Committee today adopted the recommendations of a subcommittee for a 20 per cent withholding tax to become effective July 1, but rejected the revised Ruml plan, largely on a partisan basis.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Disclosing that the War Manpower Commission plans a monthly survey of industrial absenteeism, a spokesman for the agency today opposed legislation requiring that employers report to local draft boards the names of workers absent from the job without good cause.

The United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine's 1943 campaign has been endorsed by President Roosevelt in a message to William Rosenwald, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland and Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairmen of the unified drive in behalf of the Joint Distribution Committee, United Palestine Appeal and the National Refugee Service, the appeal announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 8 -- In a rather quiet opening day of the stock market South African gold and development issues continued strong under the lead of Blyvoors, which reached a new high at 52s 6d. Diamonds showed a sustained buoyancy, with DeBeers preference rising a quarter and the deferred an eighth.

Ash Wednesday, ushering in tomorrow the forty days of the penitential season, will be more widely observed here this year than ever before, churches of various Protestant faiths holding many services. The wider observance is due to the war and the fact that so large a part of the world is almost literally in ashes.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 9 (AP) -- A communique:

On the strength of his victory in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. test over the same distance, Bob Stuart, Fordham ace, yesterday was named as the fifth starter in the famed Casey 600, one of the feature races on the program of the annual Knights of Columbus track meet at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

RENO, Nev., March 8 (AP) -- Private Jacob Webb, descendant of the late Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, was convicted by a special Army court-martial today of impersonating an Army officer, being absent without leave and breaking arrest, and was sentenced to six months at hard labor.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- As the Navy's Liberator bombers continued to scour the South Pacific area and pressed home four new attacks on Japanese positions, the question of United States strategy in the section stemming northward from Guadalcanal became a subject of increased interest in naval circles here.

Cook County, Ill., which includes the city of Chicago, plans to market a new issue of $6,700,000 of tax anticipation warrants, it was learned yesterday. It is planned to sell the issue on Friday. Further details of the financing are to be made known soon.

No plant of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company was shut down for a single day due to disputes among employees or between employees and management, nor for lack of scarcity of materials, A.W. Robertson, chairman, and George H. Bucher, president, disclosed in the fifty-seventh annual report to stockholders issued for release today.
DELAWARE, Ohio, March 8 -- The text of Vice President Wallace's speech to the Conference on Christian Bases of World Order was as follows:

Paramount Pictures, Inc., in its report covering the year ended on Jan. 2, 1943, issued yesterday, estimated its earnings at $14,525,000 after interest and all charges including reserves for contingencies and Federal normal and excess profits taxes.

It was a close-up of millinery in more ways than one that was given yesterday morning at Bloomingdale's. In the Custom Hat Box -- it is so tiny that one feels as if one were sitting comfortably inside of a bandbox -- Lil Picard explained her Spring and Summer hats as she exhibited them.

With the arraignment of three hotel men yesterday in Special Sessions on grand jury informations accusing them of turning three midtown hotels into houses of prostitution, it developed that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had ordered a drive on vice.

CHUNGKING, China, March 8 (U.P.) -- Chinese successes along a 150-mile front in Western Yunnan Province were announced tonight in a communique that reported a Japanese retreat in one sector and the repulse of enemy drives in others.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Roosevelt has signed an Executive Order providing for setting up governmental agency committees to pass on draft deferment for all Federal employes and prohibiting government workers in the future from individually requesting deferment on occupational grounds.

Pleased by the decision of city firemen to continue to perform "V duty," Commissioner Patrick Walsh said yesterday that he would make every effort to see that the "V duty" program was administered equitably and that he would take all possible measures to make the work easier for the men.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Oats and rye paced the grain markets to higher levels today on the Board of Trade, the former going into new ground since the 1928-29 crop year. Oats at the top was up around 1/2 cent a bushel, with commission houses good buyers, but profit taking and Northwestern pressure brought about a reaction and final sales were unchanged to 1/4 cent lower.

Joe Lordi, former national amateur champion from the New York A.C., and R.H. Berger of the University Club of St. Louis reached the final round of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association last night at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Retail sales in most independent businesses except department stores increased 3 per cent last January over January of 1942 but decreased 31 per cent from December of 1942, while department store sales were up 4 per cent over January of 1942 but down 51 per cent from December of 1942, the Department of Commerce reported today.
CHUNGKING, China, March 8 (UP) -- A Chinese communique:

From California yesterday came word to the Dodgers' headquarters that allayed some of the worst fears of President Branch Rickey. Dolph Camilli notified the executive he would be back on duty at first base during the 1943 campaign.
LONDON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

MOSCOW, March 8 (AP) -- Admiral Standley in the course of his press conference statement today to the effect that he did not think the Russian people were being told the complete story of United States aid to Russia, said:

SARASOTA, Fla., March 8 -- The Ringling Circus has gone old-fashioned and the modernistic trappings of recent years have been toned down or abandoned for this year's tour in favor of old-time features.

Urging WPB and the OPA to foster a "working partnership" with trade associations to achieve mutual objectives and to offset attempts to undermine these governmental agencies through charges of bureaucracy, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, last night called for recognition of trade groups as a vital wartime link between government and industry.

A typical war worker presented a scroll to the armed forces of the United States yesterday through Captain Eddie Rickenbacker bearing 7,000 signatures of workers at a Los Angeles ordnance plant, their wives and children in a pledge against absenteeism and loafing.

The Tokyo radio, in a broadcast recorded by The Associated Press, quoted an Imperial Headquarters communique yesterday as saying the Japanese had lost two destroyers and five transports in the Solomons-New Guinea area between Feb. 16 and March 5.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Legislature gave final approval tonight to the constitutional amendment which would wipe out the present bar against voters in New York City from voting in elections if they have moved from one borough to another in the four months period preceding election day.

Visits from front-line soldiers at war plants are among the best production stimulants England has found in reaching the highest per capita production of the Allied Nations, James T. Chirurg, advertising analyst, reported yesterday.

Allocation of orders to meet a strong demand for a substantially reduced volume of playthings was the rule as the American Toy Fair opened yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin and 200 Fifth Avenue under the auspices of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A.

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- March 8 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace cautioned farmers today to be "on guard so as not to let fair-weather friends destroy the Triple A machinery or public sympathy for the farmer's cause."

Sales of New York and Brooklyn' department stores showed an increase of 13 per cent for the week ended March 6, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain in sales of 21 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- At her press conference today, Mrs. Roosevelt said that while the election of the President to a third term was due to the war, it did not follow that history would repeat itself, and she deplored as premature and unfortunate speculations at this time regarding a fourth term.

DOVER, N.J., March 8 -- If it had not been for Picatinny Arsenal here there would have been available no ammunition except that for small arms when the Japanese struck at Pearl Harbor, and the United States would have had no shells for its guns.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Not very long ago it seemed that the post-war structure of the world was occupying too little of the legislative mind. Now it almost appears that the subject is occupying too much of the thought of Congress, with the war yet to be won and a more fundamental subject still unclarified: what Congress will do to support this post-war structure if established.

The constitutionality of the Emergency Price Control Act of 1942 and the broad powers enjoyed under it by the Office of Price Administration were challenged yesterday in federal courts in Brooklyn and Newark by attorneys representing clients accused of having violated OPA rulings.

Absenteeism in the production of war essentials can be reduced to a minimum by the introduction of multiple shifts of eight hours each, in place of the present long hours and seven-day week. This was among the highlights of a recent study made by the New York State League on Economics and forwarded to Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Committee, which is now holding hearings on absenteeism.

Something Arcadian and "old world" comes to the mind in reading the story, telephoned to this newspaper yesterday, of the marriage of the Prince of Liechtenstein and an Austrian countess. His principality is one of the smallest of sovereign European states. It has an area of sixty-five square miles, a population of 11,000.

A man who thought the best disguise for a draft evader was the uniform of an Army lieutenant was listed yesterday by E.E. Conroy, local Federal Bureau of Investigation chief, as one of fifty-two men arrested for violation of the Selective Service Act.

After months of preliminary sessions and discussions representatives of thirty important women's organizations, together with a number of individual leaders invited to join them, will meet on Friday at Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, to seek ways of utilizing their joint strength "to make of the United Nations an enduring reality."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Testimony taken before closed sessions of a special Senate Appropriations subcommittee investigating shortages of farm manpower showed, upon release today, that Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, asserted a month ago that the pool of unmarried men eligible for military service was "practically exhausted."

LONDON, March 8 -- French guerrillas, goaded by increased Nazi demands that threaten to complete the draining-off process of the nation's manpower, attacked the Casino in Lille with grenades and killed twenty-three German officers, it was disclosed at Fighting French headquarters here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 124 United States soldiers wounded and sixty-nine killed in action in the Alaskan, Asiatic, European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas. Next of kin of personnel of this list live in thirty-four States, the District of Columbia and Canada.

Rene Le Roy, the flutist, who seldom gives a program which is not a fortunate departure from conventionality, gave a concert of chamber music last night in Town Hall which featured his own instrument, but centered upon music by ensemble groups, in the shorter forms, and in little-known aspects.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The statement of Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador to the Soviet, in Moscow today that the Russian people were not being told by their government of the aid furnished by the United States came to Washington as a bombshell and remained as an enigma.

There is much discussion going on today regarding the broad outlines of the terms of peace to be imposed upon Germany after the Axis has been decisively beaten. Roughly speaking, these terms will be predicated upon two basic ideas which at some points coincide, but at others are mutually exclusive: (1) Justice to the nations and people who have been wantonly attacked by the Germans.

The stock market faltered a bit yesterday, especially in the more standard issues, although trading continued at a fast pace in some low-priced shares with fractional additions among those heaviest traded. Despite the fact that business was the second lightest in two weeks, volume topped the million-share mark for the tenth consecutive full session.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 8 (AP) -- The Notre Dame football team will meet the Great Lakes team next Nov. 27, it was announced today, subject to the approval of the faculty board in control of athletics.

The OPA administrator for District 2, Walter Gellhorn, may have relieved some nervous housewives by his statement that reports of forcible entries of OPA agents into one or more Baltimore homes have been grossly "distorted." Mr. Gellhorn states that the investigators are not to enter homes to check canned-food hoards unless they have search warrants, which will be resorted to only in extreme cases.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The government ban on bakery-sliced bread was removed today. Housewives who have risked thumbs and tempers slicing bread at home for nearly two months will find sliced loaves back on the grocery shelves tomorrow in most places.

MEXICO CITY, March 8 -- The four months old struggle between the management of Mexico's National Railroads and the syndicate of railroad workers for control of the network seems to be nearing an end as Pedro Garza, president of the convention of the workers assembled in Mexico City, said that the syndicate had completed a plan of reorganization which it will submit to President Manuel Avila Camacho tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Dr. Herman B. Baruch, brother of Bernard M. Baruch, War Production Board head in the first World War, has been appointed chief of the Board of Economic Warfare's representatives in Brazil, it was learned today, and will soon leave to take up his duties in that country.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 8 -- The Gremlins, that species of trouble visible only to pilots, were blamed today for the strange flight of an airplane at a flying field here yesterday, after the small pilotless ship took off, reached an altitude of 2,000 feet and then nosed over and plunged into the near-by Cumberland River.

THIS column's March choice for its own personal Book-of-the-Month-Club-for-Peace-Planners is "Darkness and the Deep,"* a novel by Vardis Fisher about prehistoric man. The choice is not prompted by sardonic motives; modern man has changed considerably for the better since paleolithic times. But man still remains a bundle of contradictions, and peace planners who fail to reckon with the bloody past of the race will simply discover they are talking not to posterity but to themselves.

Last Friday burglars broke into Lebold De Francisco's butcher shop at 1103 East Gun Hill Road, the Bronx, found the cash register locked and carried it off. Behind a billboard in a lot at Boston Road and East Gun Hill Road they broke it open and found $162 in the till.

Although it was reported yesterday at the Ritz that "New Faces of 1943" would give its last performance there on Saturday night, Leonard Sillman, producer of the revue, said there was a chance of continuing, depending on this week's business.

TRENTON, N.J., March 8 -- Hudson County veterans of the first World War "invaded" Trenton today for the second time within recent months, the purpose this time being to protest to Governor Charles Edison against his failure to reappoint Common Pleas Judge Alexander F. Ormsby.

Additional data mailed to stockholders of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation by both sides in a proxy contest to be resolved at the annual meeting in New Castle, Del. on Saturday center around the bank borrowing by the company in 1941, it was noted yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) -- Johnny Hutchinson of Philadelphia and Maxie Shapiro of New York fought almost a duplicate of their bout three weeks ago when they battled to a draw tonight at the Arena.

DELAWARE, Ohio, March 8 -- Vice President Wallace, asserting that a decision would be made this year or next "whether to plant the seeds for World War No. 3," declared today that unless the Western democracies and Russia come to a "satisfactory understanding" he feared such a conflict would be inevitable.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Air Medal has been awarded to twenty-three members of the Army Air Forces for meritorious achievement in the air in the South Pacific, according to a War Department announcement today.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., March 8 -- Otto D. Meyer, 33-year-old married man of this community, has to use a magnetic earphone device to hear and is minus the trigger finger of his right hand, but that did not deter Army doctors at Newark from passing him as fit for service and ordering him to report for duty Thursday at Fort Dix, N.J.
A German High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Total assets of national banks rose to $55,000,000,000 last Dec. 31, more than $10,000,000,000 above the level of June 30, 1942, Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 8 -- Brig-Gen. Everett S. Hughes has been named deputy theatre commander in charge of all administrative affairs affecting United States forces in the North African Theatre of Operations, the Allied commander, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, who has been mentioned frequently as a potential Republican Presidential nominee, tonight urged renewal of the lend-lease program and extension of the reciprocal treaties as preliminary steps toward participation by this country in "a government of the United Nations of the World."

LONDON, March 8 (Reuter) -- The German radio tonight reported a renewed and powerful Russian offensive against the German Army corps west of Orel, launched by four rifle divisions, a rifle brigade and three tank brigades and supported by 150 artillery batteries, fifty salvo guns and numerous planes.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- The United States Ambassador, Admiral William Standley, in a conference with American and British press representatives today, expressed con cern that the lack of publicity in the Soviet Union to war supplies of American origin might affect opinion in Congress during the pending discussions of the LendLease Act.

TRENTON, March 8 -- "Sometime I'm glad I am only the Governor and not a housewife," Governor Charles Edison told members of the New Jersey Press Association here today in an address complimenting newspapers for their part in the war.
BOSTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Eastern Racing Association today voluntarily closed the 20,000-automobile parking spaces at the Suffolk Downs horse racing track for the 1943 season.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 8 -- Elections for the Danish Parliament will be held March 23, it was officially reported from Copenhagen tonight. Germany had opposed the elections, and the change in mind must be regarded in connection with the new tactics adopted by the German representative in Denmark, Dr. Werner Best.

BOSTON, March 8 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek told thousands of Bostonians tonight that a newspaper today paid China the greatest tribute it can have when it said that Chinese citizens in America behaved in a manner worthy of Chinese and American citizens.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The detailed description of the Eighteenth to Twenty-third Senate Districts, which are the six new districts set up in Manhattan in the reapportionment bill, is as follows:

The Uniformed Firemen's Association seems to have surprised itself by voting nearly two to one in favor of continuing the unpaid eight-hour periods of "V duty," established by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh as a standby precaution against enemy air raids. The vote rescinds action taken by the U.F.A. a month ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 8 -- Because of Governor Dewey's opposition at this time to general tolls on Westchester County park-ways, the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted 40 to 1 today to seek withdrawal of a bill now before the State legislature that would enable the county to levy the tolls.

A prophecy uttered by the light-hearted and ingenious H.I. Phillips when food rationing first came to America did not go far astray. He predicted that American young men contemplating marriage would choose girls with small appetites and preferably non-users of coffee.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 8 -- The British Eighth Army has broken Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's major offensive and forced him to retreat under aerial pounding to the momentary safety of the Mareth Line, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture and Food Administrator, was disclosed today to have warned a Senate subcommittee investigating food and farm manpower shortages that "we are approaching pretty rapidly" a level of nutrition such as they have in Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The War Production Board today ordered the cotton-textile industry to simplify constructions of a specified list of fabrics in a move to increase production.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- Pravda today gives prominence to the new Polish-language newspaper Free Poland, published in Moscow by an exclusive Polish group.

LONDON, March 8 (U.P.) -- An estimated 2,000,000 persons turned out today to see London's biggest parade since war began -- a procession of 4,000 men and women of the armed and civil defenses observing Wings for Victory Week.

Various committees working for the success of the benefit performance of "Harriet" on the night of March 25 at Henry Miller's Theatre for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies will meet this week.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 8 (Reuters) -- An atmosphere of what is called "near panic" prevails in Warsaw, Poland, according to a report to a Swedish newspaper today.

William H. Hintelmann, Rumson, N.J., broker, has purchased from Johnfritz Achelis and G. Herbert Semler, executors of the estate of the late John Achelis, a tract of seven acres in the estate. It adjoins on the south Mr. Hintelmann residential property.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- American Fortress and Liberator bombers renewed the offensive against the U-boat menace by daylight today by hammering the key enemy railway points of Rennes and Rouen in France, shooting down more than a score of German fighter planes, in the first concentrated operation by Allied air units since Saturday.

With the aid of a flow of gifts that are double, triple or quadruple the contributions made by the same donors a year ago, the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City reached a total of $2,508,917 yesterday as the campaign to raise $12,920,700 toward the national goal of $125,000,000 entered its second week.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 8 -- What I have just seen and heard during a 10,000-mile trip over the Southwestern Pacific area enables me to understand apprehension expressed in authoritative quarters lest world reaction to Allied victory in the Bismarck Sea prove too enthusiastic and optimistic.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Russians continue to meet successes on the central front south of Lake Ilmen and on the border of Northern Ukraine west of Sievsk, nearly 100 miles southwest of besieged Orel. In the Donets Basin important battles are progressing southwest of Voroshilovgrad.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- OPA released today the following answers to cover a number of questions asked by housewives on the processed foods rationing program:

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 8 (U.P.) -- Vance C. McCormick, Democratic National Chairman in 1916, called today on President Roosevelt to take steps immediately to halt fourth-term discussions, warning that "nothing but damage to the successful prosecution of the war can possibly result."

Civilian industries will lose 3,200,000 workers to war jobs this year, Dr. William Haber, director of the bureau of program planning and review of the War Manpower Commission, told the American Public Welfare Association, one of the participating groups in the National Conference of Social Work meeting yesterday in the New Yorker and other hotels.
Will you let me add a few words to your deserved and graceful tribute to the late Captain Edward Algernon FitzRoy, Speaker of the House of Commons?

The cotton textile industry thus far has met virtually every objective demanded of it, Colonel Robert T. Stevens, chief of the Textile and Clothing Branch, Procurement Division of the Quartermaster General's Office, told the second National Conference-Forum held last night at the Biltmore Hotel under the auspices of the New York Cotton Exchange.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- MetroGoldwyn-Mayer will produce "Nine Marines" from an original story by Robert Hopkins. It will be divided into nine episodes, each of which will have individual writers and directors. To be produced by Edwin Knopf, the picture will dramatize the thoughts of nine Marines facing death while engaged in a rear-guard action.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Without dissent the Supreme Court upset today Texas court convictions of two members of the Jehovah's Witnesses on charges of distributing literature in violation of municipal ordinances. The court ruled that the convictions abridged constitutional rights of freedom of religion and speech.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 -- Utah Power and Light Company, part of the Electric Bond and Share Company holding company system, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan providing for the eventual dissolution of two subsidiaries and the issuance of $44,000,000 of bonds in a refunding program.
ALBANY, March 8 (AP) -- The Assembly approved 120 to 20 tonight and sent to the Governor a bill continuing the moratorium on mortgages for another twelve months.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Legislation to permit merger of the Western Union Telegraph Company and Postal Telegraph, contingent upon approval of a consolidation plan of the Federal Communications Commission, was signed today by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Navy announced today forty-two casualties, including four dead, one wounded and thirty-seven missing. They bring to 24,163 the total of Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard casualties reported to next of kin since Dec. 7, 1941.
