The board of trustees of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, meeting last night in the federation building, 71 West Forty-seventh Street, named George Z. Medalie, former United States ttorney, as president of the federation for his third consecutive term.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Office of War Information is supporting an appeal to President Roosevelt from a draft board ruling which put Kay Kyser, orchestra leader, in Class 1A, it was disclosed tonight.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday the appointment of seven agricultural representatives to the area manpower committees that were set up throughout New York State last month.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 8 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

LONDON, March 8 -- Sweeping down on a strongly fortified and desperately held German stronghold in a swift pincers movement, the Russians have taken Sychevka, forty-two miles north of Vyazma, killed 8,000 of its garrison and captured an enormous store of spoils, a Russian special communique announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Senate (Truman) Committee Investigating the War Program called in three shipbuilders from Eastern and Gulf ports today and asked them to disclose and pass on to the industry in general their secrets, if any, for attaining record production of naval and cargo craft.

Simultaneously with the arrival here of Jimmy Bivins, Cleveland light-heavyweight, yesterday came word that Corporal Barney Ross, one of the marine heroes of Guadalcanal, would be in a ringside seat Friday night at Madison Square Garden when Bivins clashes with Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight, in a return bout of ten rounds.

The Midtown Gallery, 605 Madison Avenue, is celebrating its eleventh anniversary with a group exhibition that opened yesterday, to continue through April 3. Founded in 1932, this gallery, directed by Alan D. Gruskin, has devoted itself altogether to work by American artists.

Four jurors had been chosen yesterday for the first-degree murder trial of two men in the alleged "rub-out" shooting of a gambling "overlord" more than nine years ago when General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen ordered adjournment until today.

One of the privileges of an American Vice President derives from his constitutional lack of executive power. He can say what he likes, for the simple reason that he cannot do what he likes. Hence Henry A. Wallace can be the prophet of the Roosevelt Administration without in any way committing that Administration to a course of action.

Dr. Ira Gabrielson, chief of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and prominent leaders in various fields of conservation were in accord at a meeting held at the Yale Club yesterday that no tags of being "unpatriotic" should be attached to any one who elects to go fishing or hunting on vacation, so if doubt ever existed that these are not recreational sports of consequence it may be dispelled.
NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Army Air Force communique:

In order to make full use of the wide variety of equipment operated in the rayon weaving industry the WPB's forthcoming synthetic fabric simplification program should not be so rigid as to prevent maximum output for civilian needs, it was declared yesterday by rayon fabric suppliers.

LONDON, March 8 -- With new laws just passed in Norway, under which the Department of Trade was given power to take control of all industries, the Germans can liquidate or concentrate them in accordance with the needs of German war economy.

Commenting on the report of the Rapp-Coudert Legislative committee, urging changes in the administration of the city's public school system, school officials yesterday criticized the findings, but also agreed with parts of the report.

i 1V[rs. Tho .nas Leiter of Washing-i ton has joined her mother, Mrs. Philip G. Gossler, at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting will give a dinner tonight in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW DELHI, India, March 8 (AP) -- Technical Sergeant Adam R. Williams, 23 years old, of Morganton, S.C., who helped in the American raid on Japan last April 18 and later became the outstanding top-turret gunner in the China Air Task Force, was headed back to the United States today, grinning from ear to ear.

When the late Professor Hans Berger of Jena came forth with his discovery that the brain emits electric waves which can be recorded and used to diagnose epileptic states and tumors there was a chorus of skepticism. One of the skeptics was the distinguished neurologist E.D. Adrian of Cambridge.

Although confronted with a bearish development in the confirmation of an earlier report that the Department of Agriculture would request farmers to increase their cotton acreage by 10 per cent, the cotton market held steady yesterday, resuming the moderate upward movement begun at the close of last week.

Eleven thousand tons of steel have been made available for the war program in the last month by manufacturing companies in New York State and New Jersey north of Camden, it was announced yesterday by the Regional Office of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- A warning that China might be forced out of the war by a lack of supplies was voiced today at the opening of House debate on extension of the lend-lease program for a year.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- New prices for synthetic rubber, 2 to 20 cents a pound lower than previous levels, were set today by the OPA in agreement with Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and William M. Jeffers, rubber director. Prentiss M. Brown, OPA director, who announced the new prices, added that according to information received from Mr. Jeffers most of the synthetic rubber produced this year will be required for military products.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 3: A decrease of $402,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and increases of $176,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $167,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Greg Rice, one of the greatest of modern distance runners, cracked his own world indoor record for the two-and-a-half-mile run in the feature event of the tenth annual Catholic University track meet tonight.

A new issue of $6,000,000 of twenty-year 3 per cent debentures of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Incorporated, will be offered publicly today at 103 3/4 and accrued interest by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers and Glore, Forgan Co.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, March 9 (U.P.) -- Ninety-two survivors of the twenty-two-ship Japanese convoy sunk by Allied planes in a three-day running battle in the Bismarck Sea last week have been killed or captured after they reached shore in New Guinea, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 334 enlisted men and two officers who are prisoners of war of the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 8 -- The prefect of Milan has ordered storekeepers to stay on the job despite Allied air raids, dispatches reaching here today said. The order followed a lashing by Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia, of storekeepers who had fled from Milan to escape the bombings and thus prevented workers from buying supplies.

The General Foods Corporation, in its annual report to stockholders signed by C.M. Chester, chairman, and Clarence Francis, president, shows sales last year increased to $231,506,460 from the previous year's volume of $180,358,903.

River Edge House at 33 East End Avenue has been sold by the 33 East End Avenue Corporation, P. Grassi, president, to Charles A. Frueauff through Charles G. Keller Co., brokers. It is a twelve-story building and contains seventy-five apartments.

The proposed construction of a second pipe line from Texas to the Philadelphia-New York area progressed another step yesterday when Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, formally applied to the War Production Board for materials for its construction.

Because of a prior claim on his services by the Army, William Bellard, 18-year-old graduate of the Samuel J. Tilden High School, will not be able to use for the duration an art scholarship he won yesterday at the Regional Scholastic High School Art Exhibit at R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

A legal technicality in language used in loans made by the Household Finance Corporation resulted yesterday in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter canceling the notes and chattel mortgages given by three borrowers, and in the filing of another suit demanding the wholesale cancellation of all of the company's outstanding loans and a general return to borrowers of all money paid to the company on loans in the last three years.

Chile, which has broken off diplomatic relations with the Axis, soon will be formally in the war, and Argentina will follow as soon as a new President is elected -- ten months hence, Bernardo Ibanez, president of the Chilean Confederation of Labor and Deputy in the Chilean Parliament, predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Young women employees of the government who are leaving literally by the hundreds are not doing so because of the reasons often attributed to them, such as loneliness, poor housing and lack of recreational opportunities, it was reported in a recent study of the Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Long-awaited dollars-and-cents price ceilings for rayon stockings, designed to save women $50,000,000 a year in hosiery bills, were ordered today by the Office of Price Administration Standards for top- grade stockings to lengthen their life also-were established.

Local directors of athletics, seven in person and two by proxy, yesterday voiced approval of the resolution adopted a week ago by the Basketball Writers Association favoring formation of a court league. However, each man qualified his remarks, pointing out difficulties that are certain to arise.
Not only civilians but the armed forces are suffering from the meat shortage, it was disclosed yesterday, simultaneously with the start of a Federal drive against "black markets." [1:1.]

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Reports that no food had gone from this country to the French West Indies island of Martinique since the landing of Allied forces in North Africa on Nov. 8 were confirmed today by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- "It is with mingled feelings of regret, disappointment and humiliation," Representative Rankin of Mississippi commented today in a speech in the House, "that I rise to defend Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information against the charge of attempting to elect President Roosevelt to a fourth term.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (U.P.) -- The suspension of food shipments puts a strain on Martinique's economy, since the island has been dependent on American food for years. The suspension will not cause starvation but it will reduce living standards to a bare subsistance level.

LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's secret police were reported today to have arrested thirty-four persons on Feb. 25 at the Military Academy in Charlottenburg in one of a series of raids described as apparently designed to block any rightist or monarchist coup by those tiring of Herr Hitler's conduct of the war.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The first legislative reapportionment bill in twenty-six years was introduced in the Legislature tonight, following a week-end drive by Governor Dewey to whip some Republican recalcitrants into line. The Governor won his battle, according to all information available tonight.

Staving off Miss Dorothy Goos's remarkable but belated bid, Miss Gretchen Merrill, 17-year-old pride of the Skating Club of Boston, annexed the women's senior singles title in the feature of the concluding session of the three-day annual national amateur figure skating championships at Madison Square Garden last night.
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- A communique of the Soviet Information Bureau broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 9 (AP) -A communique:

A poll of thirty-one writers, broadcasters and track and field officials yesterday revealed that fourteen men selected Gil Dodds as the probable winner of the Columbian Mile, featured test on the annual Knights of Columbus carnival at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

Anthony Christian, who for a time was one of the highest paid privates in the Army, what with his own $50 a month and $162 a month dependency money for his wife and eleven children, is out of the Army and running a fish-and-chips shop at 37-10 Ditmars Boulevard, Astoria.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 9 (AP) -- Manuel Ortiz, world bantamweight champion (National Boxing Association version), is a 1-to-2 favorite to retain his title over fifteen rounds tomorrow night against the man he won it from, Lou Salica of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 10 -- Axis sources early today described the devastation of Nuremberg, South German industrial city, in a raid by several hundred British and Canadian bombers Monday night as greater than that inflicted on Rostock and Luebeck when those Northern Reich towns were laid waste by the Royal Air Force last year.

A mishap, described by the Army as "an unfortunate misunderstanding of signals, not the fault of the New Jersey civil-defense officials," turned a projected State-wide test blackout there last night into something of a fiasco.

The United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission announced yesterday that 1,000 war jobs in Bridgeport, Conn., requiring no experience awaited New Yorkers able to pass a physical examination and prepared to work on any shifts, day or night.

A $50,000 damage action brought against License Commissioner Paul Moss by Triangle Publications, Inc., because of the commissioner's ban on sale of racing sheets on news stands last Fall, was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck.
Savings banks and insurance companies figured in most of the Manhattan real estate sales reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Mr. Roosevelt's recommendation of home rule for Puerto Rico came on the heels of reports of hunger and want in the tropic isle which has been under the American flag forty-five years. Two million United States citizens are crowded on the island.

MOSCOW, March 9 -- United States Ambassador William H. Standley's strictures on Russian domestic policy concerning the press reveal a tendency to misinterpret the Soviet attitude toward the Allies, the persistence of which is likely to lead to future misunderstandings.
CHUNGKING, China, March 9 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Eight wholesale butchers who had admitted charging more than the legal rates for meats were sentenced yesterday to serve terms in jail and fined a total of $33,300. The fines were calculated to wipe out all illicit profits made in the defendants' "black market" dealings.

The difficulties of waging a coalition war have again been brought into sharp relief by the statements of Vice President Wallace and Ambassador Standley throwing the spotlight of publicity on one of the fundamental problems facing the United Nations -- namely, the relations between Russia and her allies.

Motion pictures not only keep the home fires burning but also light them all over the face of the civilized world, Charles Francis Coe, vice president and general counsel of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America declared at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

In peacetime she took pot-shots at squirrels, rabbits and woodchucks, hunting with her husband in the deep woods of Pennsylvania. Wartime finds Mrs. Ruby Barnett, 41-year-old grandmother, firing Garard rifles, machine guns and carbines at the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, doing her best to score an indirect hit on Hitler.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Fifty shells every minute, day and night -- or a total of 1,932,000 high explosive projectiles -- were turned out by American ordnance manufacturers in February, Robert T. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War reported today.

Now that Lent is here you may find yourself resorting to meat substitutes with even greater frequency than you have in the recent past. Accordingly there follows a brief report of available alternates for steaks and chops, along with some scattered suggestions on how to prepare them appealingly:

A nationwide campaign to enlist more adult volunteer workers in Girl Scouting was officially opened last night, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, as honorary president of the Girl Scouts, said the organization was preparing young girls to be useful in their communities in wartime.
THE reserve starter had been having a bad night and the sprinters were jittery on their marks. Barney Ewell trotted back after a recall and plaintively asked: "Hey, where's that fat man?"

In line with its policy of the last two years under which outstanding debenture indebtedness has been reduced materially, the North American Company took steps yesterday to redeem an additional $3,000,000 of its 3 3/4 per cent debentures due in 1954.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Administration decided today to put a one-year limitation on the power it intends to grant to the La Guardia government in New York City to double the rate of the city sales tax, and the taxes on general and financial businesses.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- Figures on the number of Frenchmen and Germans killed in France in the past seventy-two hours were lacking here, but a French spokesman said the total of Nazi dead alone might exceed 200.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 9 (AP) -- The German press, which, with the Italian press, has been trying recently to build a picture of differences, if not outright antagonism, among Britain, the United States and Russia, seized today on the declarations by Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Admiral William H. Standley, the American Ambassador to Russia.

The long awaited corrective influences struck the stock market yesterday with sufficient force to bring one of the sharpest reactions in a year, but support for the advance steadied the list in the afternoon and extreme losses were reduced.

That government regulations will result in new fashion trends in shoes as much as they have in clothes was forecast by I. Miller yesterday in a special showing celebrating the concern's fiftieth anniversary in the shoe business. Simultaneously it was announced that the company was making parachutes for the armed forces.

The volume of business in dollars transacted last year by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation increased 6 per cent over the record volume of 1941, according to the annual report of H.F. Atherton, president, issued for release today.

Last of the double-headers before the national invitation tournament, tonight's double-barreled action at Madison Square Garden will present St. John's against St. Francis and New York University against City College, with at least one tourney berth at stake.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Total business inventories, although whittled down by record-breaking purchases and by the huge material requirements of expanding war production, still remained at the near-peak level of $28,300,000,000 at the end of December, the Commerce Department reported today.

ON THE NORTHERN TUNISIAN FRONT, March 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- The British smashed a two-pronged attack against their northern positions on the Mateur-Tabarka Road, near Tamera, today in fighting in which only thirty to forty yards separated the battling units at some places.

Governor Edison of New Jersey has made a remark that will be as bright as the sun when many executive messages and documents have been dumped into the furnace. "Sometimes I'm glad I'm only the Governor and not a housewife." He purposely understates. He's glad always, not sometimes.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 10 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique, as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

WASHINGTON, March 9 -Among persons experienced in the ways of statecraft and politics it is taken for granted that the Under-Secretary of State, Sumner Welles, consulted the White House before announcing today that Admiral William H. Standley, the United States Ambassador to Soviet Russia, spoke yesterday without previous conference with or reference to this government.

In the ring of Madison Square Garden, where he waged so many sterling battles before entering the more serious fight, World War II, Corporal Barney Ross on Friday night will receive the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque, awarded to him by the Boxing Writers Association of New York.

Northern Appalachian bituminous coal operators will be officially notified of the wage demands formulated by the policy committee of the United Mine Workers at a joint meeting at 10:30 A.M. today in the Hotel Biltmore, which will open negotiations for a new agreement.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 9 -- An important feature of the three-year program for the A.B. degree recently adopted by Vassar College will be the participation of all students in the household work of the college, according to Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar.

ALGIERS, March 9 -- Changes in the regime of General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief, may be expected to follow the meeting of General Giraud's War Council, which is in session today. The changes are expected to affect General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, General Giraud's deputy for civilian affairs, and Governor General Charles Nogues of French Morocco.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, March 10 (AP) -- Forty-seven Japanese planes have raided Wau, New Guinea, the United Nations base some thirty-five miles southwest of Salamaua, the High Command announced today.

A memorial exhibition of work by the distinguished marine artist, Frederick Judd Waugh, who died l in 1940, opened with a private view t yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries. Beginning today the exhibition may be visited by the ublic.

LONDON, March 9 -- Continuance of the recent high level of Exchequer returns for the last three weeks of the current financial year will enable the Chancellor of the Exchequer to record "a surplus over his estimate for the year," it is stated.
The Bankers Trust Company of New York won yesterday the award of $500,000 of Worcester, Mass., revenue anticipation notes, dated March 10 and due Nov. 13. The bank bid an 0.39 per cent basis.

A good deal has been said about absenteeism during the past few weeks, and the subject also cropped up at the round table discussion which was conducted by Dr. Ira Gabrielson, Unite States Fish and Wildlife Service head in New York the other afternoon.

ALBANY, March 9 -- The Williamson bill permitting either party to a marriage to obtain an injunction in the courts to prevent the other party from getting a divorce in another State on grounds not recognized in New York State was passed today in the Senate on a slow roll-call by a vote of 27 to 11.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 9 -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters has made it clear that the Southwestern Pacific Command does not regard Japanese air power as diminishing, at least in this war theatre. A headquarters spokesman said today:
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Chicago's 1943 racing season of 157 days was squeezed into three centralized tracks today, leaving Lincoln Fields and Arlington Park idle.
Intersectional college football games definitely are on the way out for the duration.

LONDON, March 9 (Canadian Press) -- Recurring reports that the British Royal family was finding time to don overalls or smocks and turn out war material are not true, it was learned authoritatively today.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The pressure being exerted on Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner in Martinique, through the halting of American food shipments to the island is the result of his refusal thus far to cooperate with the United States through some affirmative program that would facilitate the conduct of the war by the United Nations, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- Sir Alexander Korda, producer and co-owner of United Artists, will leave here within two weeks to take charge of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's British production in a deal which Metro, in its official announcement today, describes as "the most important merger in the history of British-American film production."

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -Warnings against any governmental attempts to "weaken the press" or interfere with its freedom of expression were sounded today by Senators Brooks of Illinois and Wiley of Wisconsin.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -Corporate simplification and geographical integration proceedings were instituted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Peoples Light and Power Company and its five subsidiaries.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Feb. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- It may be in a tent under a mango tree in New Guinea or in a modern clubhouse in some Australian city, but wherever it is, the American Red Cross is the "big brother" -- and sister, too -- of American soldiers and sailors in the Southwest and South Pacific.

Under the new decentralization program recently announced by the Board of Economic Warfare, the Lend-Lease Administration will act as the principal claimant agency for importers in the British Empire countries, it was disclosed yesterday by Captain W.G. Coventry, controller of the British Ministry of Supply Mission.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The complaint of Admiral William H. Standley, American Ambassador to Russia, against the alleged concealment from the Russian people of United States war aid to the Soviet Union, was said by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, at his press conference today, to have been "without prior consultation or reference to this government."

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- In a speech closing his career as anti-trust prosecutor, Thurman Arnold declared tonight that economic forces on the home front were struggling not for profits but "for domination of industry after the war."

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -The city of Jersey City and several other New Jersey communities told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that a report by Examiner R.N. Trezise recommending authorization of a ten-cent fare on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad from Jersey City to downtown New York was "obviously" in error.

MILWAUKEE, March 9 -- The furniture industry will have difficulty surviving after additional restrictions on use of metal go into effect next Monday and present war contracts are completed a few months hence, Frank S. Whiting, vice president of the American Furniture Mart, Chicago, said here today at the annual convention of the Wisconsin Retail Furniture Association.
The first round of the Battle of Tunisia is over and Rommel has lost it. Now he is digging in behind the Mareth Line.

The classic man-tailored suit took the center of the stage yesterday at the luncheon hour in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Knize, whose smart shops in London and Paris were visited by many Americans before the war, was the exhibitor.

Statements on United States relations with Russia such as those recently made by Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Admiral William H. Standley, our Ambassador to Moscow, "can do only harm," Wendell L. Willkie said yesterday in asking for an appreciation of Russia's viewpoint and rational statements of American post-war attitudes toward the Soviet Government.

Unless the WPB takes immediate action to modify the effects of shoe rationing on manufacturers of children's machine-made types retailing between $1.29 and $1.98, consumers will be deprived of approximately 75 per cent of the 25,000,000 pairs made annually by this branch of the industry, Benjamin Seligman, counsel of the Stitchdown Shoe Manufacturers Association, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In the face of the week-end directive of Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, holding workers on farms to overcome food shortages, the Senate, by an almost unanimous vote today, called up for action its Military Affairs Committee's bill prescribing sweeping and mandatory draft deferments for all men working on essential crops and commodities.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Senator Murray and Assemblyman Wood introduced today a bill, emanating from the Ives Committee on industrial and labor relations, which would broaden the powers to grant dispensations, during the war emergency, from the laws regulating the hours of women and children in industry.

Daniel Spencer Moran, dealer in bogus securities, who in past years has always emerged unscathed from his numerous brushes with Federal investigators, unexpectedly pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions when being tried for the theft of $5,100 in securities from the young widow of a prosperous interior decorator.

Because of illness, President Dudley P. Rogers was unable to preside yesterday at the annual meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club held at headquarters of the government body of purebred dogs. In his absence, Harry I. Caesar of this city was chosen chairman and also presided at the meeting of the board of directors.

The First Catholic Mission Church of the Congregation of the Holy Cross in Bertram, Texas, erected by the Rev. Daniel M. Gleason, in memory of departed comrades of the New York Police Department, has been completed and dedicated, according to word received yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

There is urgent need for the American people to practice rigid "war thrift" to check rising living costs and ease the critical manpower situation by helping to curtail demand for nonessentials, according to the annual report of Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (U.P.) -Nelson A. Rockefeller, as coordinator, is expanding to a considerable extent the functions of the Office of Inter-American Affairs which operates in the Latin-American republics.

As always, the fighting in China in the last month has been too confused to follow; but, as always, accounts can be struck after a period. Just how many offensives the Japanese army had under way in various parts of the country is not clear, but it is clear at least that none of them has come to anything.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 9 (AP) -- The destroyer escort Hopping was launched in the Norfolk Navy Yard today, the vessel being sponsored by the widow of Lieut. Comdr. Hallsted L. Hopping, who was killed in aerial action in the Pacific a year ago.

The imminent induction of more heads of families into the armed services makes it probable that Congress will reopen the question of allowances to dependents of service men "to secure the necessary men with a minimum of hardship," Watson B. Miller, assistant Federal Social Security Administrator, declared last night before 850 social workers.

Following a suggestion made by the paper industry some weeks ago, the Department of Agriculture this week started a campaign through their county agents to increase the supply of pulpwood coming from farmers. First step was the issuance by the department's Forest Service and Extension Service of pamphlets to be distributed to farmers in the Northeastern States and in the Lake States.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter dismissed summarily from the bench yesterday a suit brought by a borrower from the Household Finance Corporation "on behalf of" all the company's 100,000 borrowers, to compel the company to cancel all its outstanding $15,000,000 in loans in this State and to return to borrowers $50,000,000 estimated to have been paid back to the company on loans in the last three years.

Apathy toward the Red Cross and other phases of our war program is the result of the fact that our people do not wet understand the true horrors of war, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker declared last night at a nurses' recruitment rally at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

The testimony of two small boys, one the victim of an automobile accident, resulted in the holding of a motorist yesterday in Homicide Court for trial in Special Sessions on an assault charge, although he insisted he was not aware he had run over the boy, John Mulhern, 10 years old, the son of a policeman, of 431 East Seventieth Street.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs came from behind twice to strengthen their National Hockey League play-off hopes by gaining a 5-5 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,112 at the Boston Garden.
Rear Admiral and Mrs. Henry Hughes Hough of Washington have come to the Weylin for the remainder of the season.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- At the age of seven months, the War Department's auxiliary of 43,684 women soldiers or Waacs seems about to receive a favorable committee report that it be taken into the Army with a simple restriction, that members be ineligible to receive allowances for dependents.
A German communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Activities along the local baseball frontier, which soon is to break out in its first frost-bitten wartime Spring training campaign, continued to move yesterday at an accelerated pace.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Plans for testing students for admission to the Army Specialized Training Program, with examinations to be conducted at colleges all over the country on April 2, were made public today by the War Department.

LONDON, March 9 -- Shares of South African gold mining companies remained the center of attraction today in the stock markets. With the market short, renewed buying sent Kaffirs further ahead Blyvoor jumping to a new high price of 54s 6d.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -Juan Francisco de Cardenas, Spanish Ambassador, was reported today to have protested to the State Department against publication of Thomas J. Hamilton's book, "Appeasement's Child: the Franco Regime in Spain."

LONDON, March 9 -- An official American account of aid to Russia was broadcast by the Soviet domestic radio tonight -- just a full day after United States Ambassador William H. Standley had complained in Moscow that the Russian people were not being told the full story of help provided by lendlease.

LONDON, March 9 -- Amid ceremonial conventions dating back some 600 years, Colonel Douglas Clifton Brown, 63-year-old Conservative M.P. for Hexham, Northumberland, became Speaker of the House of Commons today, succeeding the late Captain Edward Algernon Fitzroy, who died March 3. Colonel Brown had been deputy speaker since 1938.
The don't-tell-it prescription of the Navy fliers who patrol the South Atlantic on anti-submarine duty apparently keeps them from telling even their wives.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9 -Harold Clark's Riverland won his first purse in seven local attemps this Winter when he defeated some fast sprinters in the $5,000 added Mardi Gras Handicap, feature of the card ushered in a fifteen-day Victory meeting before 3,500 at the Fair Grounds today.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- A total of 16,690,595 feet of hardwood lumber was inspected during February, according to the National Hardwood Lumber Association. Most of the wood inspected has been allocated for use by the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission and the Lend-Lease administrator.

JERUSALEM, March 9 -- Taking over its third hotel in the Middle East, the American Red Cross received from the United States Army Special Services in the Levant this week-end fully equipped spacious premises in Tel Aviv for the use of enlisted men on leave.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (U.P.) -Authoritative sources reported tonight that price control officials were preparing to place a ceiling on live hog prices at about $15 a hundred pounds, Chicago basis.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy the newcomer will be "The Young Mr. Pitt," a Twentieth Century-Fox release starring Robert Donat, Robert Morley and Phyllis Calvert. The production was made in England under the direction of Carol Reed.

CHUNGKING, China, March 9 -The activities on China fronts continue to corroborate the picture of tentative Japanese attacks in all sectors designed to explore the strength at different points of the line and, in the case of Yunnan, to prevent effective Chinese concentration for an attack on Burma.

When our country first entered this war, men in engineering institutions were faced with the problem of how we could best serve our country. Should we take up arms, or would we be of greater service if we kept to our studies? We were strongly advised by the leaders of our armed forces that we would be of greater value as engineers than soldiers.

LONDON, March 9 -- Five more Germans have been killed as guerrilla activity increases in France, according to Fighting French headquarters here. Resistance has flared up strongly, the de Gaullists believe, because of Adolf Hitler's apparent intention to drain France of all effective manpower.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- By April 1 V-mail will be in "full operation" in North Africa, according to the Army Postal Service. In the last two months this space-saving form of correspondence with service men overseas has risen from 350,000 letters a week to more than 1,000,000.

The 1943 Salvation Army campaign for $525,000 has brought $426,665, it was announced yesterday at the final-report luncheon in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway. Campaign officials explained that substantial gifts had been received each year after the close of the formal campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Existence of a secret "off-the-record" agreement which would prevent the Kaiser shipyard dispute from being arbitrated, signed by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations peace committees, was disclosed today.

The annual report of the B.F. Goodrich Company, signed by David M. Goodrich, chairman, and John L. Collyer, president, announced yesterday that in 1942 more butadiene-type synthetic rubber had been produced in the plant being operated by its affiliate, the Hycar Chemical Company, than in all other plants in this country.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Representatives of nearly a score of New York City religious, fraternal and veterans' organizations clashed today with spokesmen for the State Council of Churches at a hearing before the joint legislative Codes committees over bills legalizing bingo.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- While the Navy announced today a continuation of the daily air raids on enemy bases within striking distance of Guadalcanal, Secretary Frank Knox asserted at his press conference that the Japanese were having "increasing difficulties" with their lines of communications in the Pacific theatre as Amercan positions grew stronger.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 (U.P.) -- An American Kaiser-built merchant ship, manned by navy gunners and merchant seamen, fought a bloody twenty-five minute battle in the South Atlantic with two enemy surface raiders, sinking one and seriously damaging the other, the United States Maritime Service disclosed today.

With the exception of Siam there were no additions in 1942 to the list of countries in default on their external debt, according to the sixty-ninth annual report of the British Council of Foreign Bondholders, copies of which were made available here yesterday by Ernest F. Barry, representative in the United States for the council.
LONDON, March 9 (Reuter) -The German-controlled Vichy radio said tonight that more than 100 persons were killed in a raid by United States bombers on a town in Brittany yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Increased hedging sales against cash grain weakened the wheat market today on the Chicago Board of Trade. With a lack of aggressive support, wheat futures closed 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower than yesterday. Kansas City was down 1 1/4 cents.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -The President had no announced appointments.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, announced today the resignation, effective July 1, of John Hamm, senior deputy administrator of OPA, which he joined in its early days as chief aide to Leon Henderson, with whom he had been associated in the Russell Sage Foundation.

LONDON, March 9 -- Politically and diplomatically Greece's emigre government has held together rather well, compared with some of its colleagues from Eastern Europe. Its general tendency has been to bury the hatchet in old party feuds and to avoid tender international questions in order to get on with full prosecution of the war effort.

Forty thousand persons listened and watched in emotional silence in Madison Square Garden last night to two performances of "We Will Never Die," a dramatic mass memorial to the 2,000,000 Jews killed in Europe. The memorial was staged to stir the Allied nations to stop the slaughter of a people by the Germans.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -Two young men who objected to service in a work camp as well as in the Army are being tube-fed at the Federal penal institution at Danbury, Conn., because they went on a hunger strike after commitment Feb. 12.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, announced today a policy of lowering ceiling prices on products of industries which have reduced their unit costs by expanding production.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A bill covering $6,280,000,000 to authorize $4,000,000,000 in cash and $2,173,000,000 in contract authority for the Maritime Commission for the financing and construction of 2,161 additional cargo ships was approved today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -Grace George will make her first film appearance in James Cagney's first independent United Artists production, "McLeod's Folly," from the Louis Bromfield novel.

The six-story apartment house at 100 Avenue P, in the Kings Highway section of Brooklyn, was sold by the 100 Avenue P Corporation, represented by W. Rosmarin, attorney to an investing client of J.K. Colman, attorney.

DETROIT, March 9 -- The War Manpower Commission moved today to stabilize employment and obtain more workers for the Ford Motor Company's Willow Run bomber plant. In the face of a high labor turnover at the plant its employment estimates have been revised upwards by 30,000 workers to meet stepped-up production called for by the Army to supply more Liberator bombers.

A call upon advertising to initiate an educational campaign dealing with the critical food situation was made by speakers last night at the annual advertising and government dinner of the Advertising Women of New York at the Hotel Biltmore.

Instead of saving consumers 5 to 25 cents per garment, as visualized by the OPA, the new prices now in effect for simplified styles of men's nationally advertised dress shirts have resulted in reductions of only 1 to 4 cents, compared to prices that were in effect prior to March 1, it was announced here yesterday by Cluett, Peabody Co.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Hawaii will have a ceremonial "restoration day" tomorrow when martial law is to be modified to permit eighteen agencies of government to pass from military to civilian control, Joseph R. Farrington, Hawaii's Delegate to Congress, said tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 9 (AP) -- Major David M. Jones of Winters, Texas, under whose leadership the was tactically introduced into the North African war theatre, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today for "extraordinary achievement while participating in aerial flight."

LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP) -One of the nation's outstanding intersectional football rivalries became a war casualty today when cancellation of the Notre Dame-Southern California game for 1943 was announced.

Mrs. Monroe R. Lyeth, in 105 Park Ave; Harold E. While, in 434 E 52d St; Mrs. Alice M. Choate, in 21 W 58th St; Lieutenant Philip Winston, in 126 E 54th St, through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton -- Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, brokers.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to enact legislation providing for the election of the Governor of Puerto Rico by the people of the territory.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 9 -- The Army's Jersey City Quartermaster Depot, which spent $300,000,000 last year in supplying troops at home and overseas with equipment needed for living and fighting, is increasing the size of its purchases this year tremendously.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Governor Dewey was reported today to have enough votes in the Senate, where the legislative reapportionment bill comes up first, to pass it with the help of a mere handful of Democrats. This help seems likely to be forthcoming.

If I had a tendency to grumble because of food shortages or because at times I couldn't get my favorite cigars, I have now been permanently silenced by your correspondent, Drew Middleton. In his article on our troops in North Africa, your issue March 7, Mr. Middleton describes the confidence and high morale of our fighting men.

"Men in Shadow," a war melodrama by Mary Hayley Bell, an English author and actress, will open this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Morosco, under the sponsorship of Max Gordon. Roy Hargrave, who is featured, directed. Joseph Fields helped revise the script for presentation in this country.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 9 -- The Africa Corps was reported to be falling back deep inside the Mareth Line tonight, after having lost fifty tanks and hundreds of men in its frustrated week-end offensive, and French forces were developing a serious threat to the enemy's right flank with the seizure of Tozeur, on Chott Djerid.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Redemptions of war bonds are slowly creeping up on sales as the income-tax deadline approaches.

The 1,133 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $72,961,678,106 par value as of Feb. 27, had a total market value of $71,346,452,852, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Jan. 30, there were 1,132 issues, aggregating $72,880,365,437 par value which had a total market value of $71,038,674,932.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 10 -- Russian forces have been thrown back up to eighty miles, with the loss of eight important bases on the Kharkov-Dnieper-Donets front, by a counter-offensive into which the German High Command has thrown twenty-five divisions totaling possibly 375,000 men, a Russian communique said today.

At every international disarmament conference held since 1919 it has been admitted that civil and military aviation are inseparable not only because long-distance passenger planes can be converted into bombers, but because they have frequently been used to widen spheres of political influence rather than to improve friendly intercourse.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 9 -- Drill with gas masks and exposure to tear gas are the latest items on the curriculum of the Waves at the naval training school at Smith College.

Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation voted yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share for payment on March 29. The current dividend reflects the intention indicated in the company's interim report to stockholders issued on Sept. 1, 1942, to pay smaller interm dividends from time to time, when and if conditions justify, rather than to pay on an annual basis, which had been the practice of the corporation, the company states.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- In a sharp challenge to the growing movement to limit induction into the Army in order to provide a larger labor pool Secretary Stimson bluntly declared tonight that agriculture and industry were not yet keyed for all-out war and warned that to tamper with the size of the Army might prolong hostilities and needlessly cost the lives of thousands of young Americans.

No reapportionment bill can be perfect. There will always be some politics in it and some compromise between the principle of population and the principle of space. The question must be whether the proposal is a move toward perfect fairness or a move away from it.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,266 as against 1,370 in the preceding week and 1,152 in the like period of 1942, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 569 which compared with 511 last Tuesday.

We hope that when the House of Representatives votes today on the continuation of Lend-Lease it will give this most important war measure its complete approval, with no strings attached to its endorsement.

LONDON, March 9 -- Richard K. Law, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, told the Croydon Rotary Club tonight that he could see no reason why the world should face a third World War twenty years hence, referring to Monday's speech by United States Vice President Henry A. Wallace.

Max Cohen, who, as the treasurer of the Students General Organization at New Utrecht High School, pleaded guilty last June to taking $17,921 of the organization's funds, received yesterday a sentence of one to five years in Sing Sing from Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein.

In the March 4 issue THE TIMES published a report on the joint meeting of representatives of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railroad Brotherhoods to launch a drive for a $4,000,000 war relief fund. You stated that the beneficiaries included the Red Cross, U.S.O., British, Russian and China Relief.

Mayor La Guardia and three generals attached to the Army Air Forces are among the speakers scheduled to attend the formal opening of a recruiting drive for volunteers for the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service of the Army under the sponsorship of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at noon today in the Council Chamber at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Service bar pins for war workers, similar to those granted by the Army and Navy, were urged on the Truman committee investigating war activities today by two manufacturers as a means of combating absenteeism and as rewards for outstanding production records.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 9 (AP) -Counsel for the stockholders protective committee of the $1.60 preferred stock of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation said today that the stockholders feared a plan for reorganization of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, parent of the former company, might encounter obstacles and be delayed.
LONDON, March 8 (AP) -- Today's Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Russia's inclination to keep aloof from the rest of the United Nations has for many months been a patent fact. Conte di Cavour, the great Italian statesman of the nineteenth century, used to exclaim when the French Emperor Napoleon III showed some reluctance to comply with his requests: "Italia fara da se [Italy will act on her own]."

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek was ordered by her physicians to rest for a week at her quarters at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel after returning in a state of physical exhaustion yesterday from a weekend visit to Wellesley College and Boston, L.K. Kung, her secretary general, announced last night.

BALTIMORE, March 9 (AP) -Dispatch by the Maryland Office of Price Administration of investigators to private homes in Baltimore to check rationed food stocks had the approval today of the national price administrator, Prentiss M. Brown, and the regional OPA attorney, Walter Gellhorn.

After capping a four-day upturn with a rise early in the session to the best prices since 1929, surpassing the fourteen-year record levels made two weeks ago, the cotton futures market yesterday receded moderately under liquidation and selling by New Orleans operators, but rallied in late dealings on trade price-fixing.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The prepared text of Secretary Stimson's radio address on "The Size of the Army" was as follows:
LONDON, March 9 -- Widespread reductions in cargo-risk insurance rates, as a result of Allied counter-measures against U-boats, were announced today by the Institute of London Underwriters.

This week-end will afford the public its last opportunity to visit the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street. The doors will close permanently at 5 o'clock Sunday afternoon. The current attraction is the memorial exhibition of sculpture by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, founder of the museum.

Joseph Szigeti is not the kind of violinist who relies invariably on the Beethoven, Mendelssohn, Brahms or Tchaikovsky violin concertos for his appearances with orchestra. He is willing to explore areas of concerto composition that are relatively neglected.

In an effort to bring about the most equitable allocation of limited magazine advertising space, a special committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies met recently with representatives of the Association of National Advertisers and yesterday recommended to publishers a number of steps.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek appeared on the Wellesley campus in slacks and it was all over with the college taboo on women in trousers. Very few laws or prohibitions in all history have been so quickly put out of business. Even the Boston Tea Party must have been a considerably longer affair.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Care of children whose parents are employed in war industry was put before the Legislature today by Assemblyman Moffat of Manhattan, in a bill to direct the State War Council to adopt and carry out rules to make a program effective.
Max Berger, 145 1/2, Bronx, won a clean-cut decision from Saverio Turiello, 148, West Side, in the main ten-round bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before 3,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Ways and Means Committee virtually scuttled pay-as-you-go taxation this afternoon as it prepared to vote tomorrow on what Chairman Doughton described as little more than the present tax collection system, amended to put into force a 20 per cent withholding tax.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A new method of scheduling machine tool deliveries is established by general preference order E-1-B as amended today by the WPB director general for operations. The changes are confined to the scheduling of deliveries on purchase orders from "service purchasers" as defined in the order.

Although most manufacturers and distributors of women's rayon hosiery were inclined to defer final judgment yesterday on the OPA's new MPR 339, which takes effect April 15, pending further study of the order, at least four major possibilities were discussed in the trade, as follows:
ANKARA, Turkey, March 9 (U.P.) -- A new Turkish Cabinet, headed by Premier Shukru Saracoglu and involving six-changes in the thirteen Ministries, was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House Labor Committee ordered today a general investigation of absenteeism in industry and called Secretary Perkins as its first witness at hearings to start late this week.

The New York Chapter of the Society of Residential Appraisers will hold its March dinner-meeting tomorrow at the Building Trades Employers Association restaurant, 2 Park Avenue. Cleveland Rodgers, a member of the City Planning Commission, will be the speaker.

PITTSBURGH, March 9 -- The C.I.O. United Electrical Radio and Machine Workers of America, representing 450,000 war workers, bought a page of newspaper space today to advance its plan to effect a stabilized wartime economy by proposing to forego, on certain conditions, "the general cost of living wage rise that would be negotiated during the next few months when our contracts are expiring."

The Western and Southern Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati had the largest growth in its history in 1942 and expects a further substantial increase in 1943, according to Charles F. Williams, president, who announced yesterday insurance of $1,173,678,440 in force at the end of last year, a gain of $91,055,922 for the year.

J.P. Morgan, 75-year-old chairman of the board of the famous banking house of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., at the "Corner" of Wall and Broad Streets, and son of its founder, the late J. Pierpont Morgan, suffered a cerebral stroke during an attack of heart trouble a week ago last night and is critically ill at Boca Grande, Fla., it was disclosed yesterday.

As the Federal Government continued in the courts its crusade stamp out black markets that are cutting into food supplies of the armed forces and lend-lease as well as civilian consumers, Roy F. Hendrickson, director of the Food Distribution Administration, declared here yesterday that the nation's tremendously increased wartime buying power and the withdrawal of breed cattle from market also were responsible for the growing food shortage.

Two companion volumes containing speeches and writings since Pearl Harbor of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek will be issued by John Day on April 13. The Generalissimo's book, to be called "All We Are and All We Have," contains his important pronouncements with a bearing on the war made between Dec. 7, 1941, and Nov. 17, 1942.

The recent decision of Washington and Ottawa officials that further curtailment of newsprint is unnecessary at present is supported by "an exhaustive and independent investigation" of the newsprint supply, made by the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the organization disclosed yesterday.

Directors of the Celanese Corporation of America, and the corporation, filed motions in Supreme Court yesterday to dismiss for legal insufficiency a part of the complaint in a stockholder's suit brought by Seymour Bayer for recovery of $1,350,000.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce told the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today it had been "unable to find any representative body of business men or citizens" of the State favorable to construction of a trans-State ship canal.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- An R.A.F. communique:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, March 11 -- Five Japanese merchantmen have been bombed and two heavily damaged by United Nations planes in the Southwestern Pacific, the High Command announced today.
Reviewing the career of the late Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, former associates yesterday praised his "vision" and contribution to the progress of aviation.

Efrem Kurtz was the guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, and Efrem Zimbalist was the soloist, playing the Beethoven violin concerto. Mr. Kurtz arranged a program which, for Philharmonic-Symphony patrons, was principally of novelties.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The House passed today by a vote of 407 to 6 the bill extending the Lend-Lease Act for another year. At the same time the Senate Foreign Relations Committee unanimously approved a similar bill. The Lend-Lease Act would expire June 30, and the present policy of aid to the United Nations required the extension.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Ways and Means Committee voted by 16 to 9 today to continue the present year-behind income-tax collection system with the addition of a 20 per cent withholding tax for wage and salary earners beginning July 1.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A crew of enlisted men who stuck to their word and stayed with their ship after all their officers were wounded brought their Flying Fortress bomber back home today from an aerial battle against nine Japanese Zero fighters over Gasmata New Britain, where four of the enemy planes were downed and a fifth damaged.

Pork supplies moving through normal trade channels for civilian use here are running about 43 per cent behind last year, Department of Agriculture figures disclosed last night as the Meat Trade Institute, Inc., predicted that recent action by the Office of Price Administration in fixing uniform retail prices would have no effect on the supply situation.

OTTAWA, March 10 -- One hundred officers and men from the French battleship Richelieu and other French warships are now at Halifax, N.S., Major Gabriel Bonnaud head of the Fighting French delegation in Ottawa, announced today.

Employers who provide services for workers are not "coddling" their employes, but rather increasing efficency, "and that is the sort of thing that is cutting down absenteeism," Charles P. Taft, assistant director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, asserted here yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 10 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

LONDON, Thursday, March 11 -- Russian armies are closing their grip on Vyazma and in the bitter fighting on the Kharkov-Donets front they have smashed sixty-six German tanks in twenty-four hours in repulsing the enemy's twenty-five-division counter-offensive, Russian communiques reported today.

Columbia Grammar School, preparing for the defense of its title in the eighteenth annual swimming meet of the Athletic Association of Private Schools, led in the number of qualifiers yesterday as preliminaries were staged in the Columbia University pool.

A private view of paintings and drawings by Augustus John will be held Sunday evening at the American British Art Center. The exhibition will open to the public on Monday, closing on April 17. "The exhibition is due," according to an announcement from the gallery, "to the war in Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A comparison of the National Resources Planning Board's report with that submitted recently to the British Parliament by Sir William Beveridge indicates that while the two documents have some aspects in common the American report goes beyond the British proposals in several major respects.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The President sent to Congress the report of the National Resources Planning Board on post-war planning; accepted a bust from the Order of Ahepa; filled several appointments and received new members of Congress.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Scattered hedging pressure and spreading between the market here and Kansas City and Minneapolis, especially the latter, gave the wheat market an easier undertone on the Board of Trade today. While there was fair buying in the way of short covering and support by commission houses on resting orders, the close was 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel lower than yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- A new plan for the sale by the Twin State Gas and Electric Company of its electric and gas business in New Hampshire and its electric properties in Maine to the Public Service Company of New Hampshire for $4,048,977 in cash, adjusted, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

JOHN T. WHITAKER is no Summer soldier, no sunshine patriot. For years, as a correspondent in Europe, he warned his American readers that war was coming. An impulsive and generous Southerner, he felt ashamed to be an American and a citizen of the democracies when Czechoslovakia was being sacrificed at Munich to the exigencies of "peace in our time."

A mushrooming of the number of small-scale truckers, resulting from the Office of Defense Transportation's tire conservation program, has brought about an "uneconomic situation," ODT District Manager H. Carroll Wall disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress submitting two reports of the National Resources Planning Board was as follows:

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- Threats of an imposition of ceiling prices on live hogs brought about a slump of around 50 cents a hundredweight today, with the extreme top of $15.60 paid sparingly in early rounds. Most late sales were 35 to 50 cents below yesterday's averages. Cattle and lambs were about steady.
JACKSON, Miss., March 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's sons in the service are "fighting men and they are tough," one of the first Navy seabees to land on Guadalcanal reported today.

The trouble with women -- in the opinion of those who concoct cosmetics for these unreasonable creatures -- is that they expect all good things to come in pretty packages. This esthetic insistence is all very well in peacetime, but in these days of priorities it presents a rather ticklish problem.

The belief that Finland "would like to get out of the war but doesn't know how" was expressed here yesterday by Stanton Griffis, motion-picture executive, who returned on a Pan American clipper from a six-month tour of Finland, Sweden, Spain, Portugal and England.

A stockholder's action filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Seymour Bayer against the Celanese Corporation of America, makers of yarns and fabrics, to recover $1,350,000, accuses the board of directors of spending $1,000,000 to further the career of Jean Tennyson, radio singer and wife of the president of the corporation, Camille Dreyfus.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate agreed late today, after two days of debate, to make a voting choice at 2 P.M. tomorrow between a bill which would require a minimum of essential food production by a farm worker to keep him out of selective draft call and one which would grant mandatory, blanket deferments on occupational grounds.

Federal immigration officers yesterday were conducting a quiet hunt in New York for French sailors from various units of the French Fleet, now in harbor, who have jumped ship. Last night twelve had been taken into custody and removed to Ellis Island for investigation.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Dewey asserted today that Federal agencies, attempting to devise means of caring for children whose mothers are at work in war industry, were engaged in "a struggle for power" accompanied by "carloads of publicity," with the result that "not one child in this State has yet received aid."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Use of refrigerator cars for the shipment of beer from the Midwest is prohibited except under special circumstances under terms of an order issued by the refrigerator-car division of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Luggage, with a gain of 70 per cent, led all sections of department stores in this Federal Reserve district in percentage of sales increases during January, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Formal demands for a basic wage increase of $2 a day and a minimum wage of $8 without exception were presented by the United Mine Workers yesterday at the opening of negotiations for a new agreement with operators of the Northern Appalachian re gion at the Hotel Roosevelt. The current two-year agreement covering 450,000 soft coal miners expires March 31.

CHUNGKING, China, March 10 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have made new crossings of the Yangtze River in Southern Hupeh Province, but on the more vital Yunnan front Chinese forces have recaptured several towns west of the Salween River and the enemy there is retreating "in confusion" after suffering heavy losses, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

The new index of the American Petroleum Institute shows that gasoline and fuel oil stocks on the Atlantic Coast last week reached an all-time low. At the close of the week, the index, based on the average normal stocks for 1940-41 adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, stood at 32.5, compared with 35.7 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, when the current downward trend started.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 10 (AP) -- A representative of the Real Estate Board of New York today demanded action by the Legislature on pending legislation to provide for assessment review without court action, declaring taxpayers' organizations "are fed up with delays."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate (Truman) Defense investigating Committee listed "three basic weaknessess" today as responsible for almost all of the failures and shortcomings of the war program.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (U.P.) -- The Office of War Information made first draft deferment requests for seven other radio entertainers besides the orchestra leader Kay Kayser, it was learned today, but the agency no longer is pressing for favorable rulings in the cases.

The American Women's Voluntary Services started yesterday its demonstrations of different phases of point rationing to housewives by means of a mobile kitchen, staffed with a driver, three cooks and an interpreter. At its first stop at Tenth Street and First Avenue in the morning, it was surrounded within twenty minutes by women of all nationalities on their way to market.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau broadcast yesterday a nine-State alarm for the 12-year-old son of a member of the British Purchasing Commission. The boy disappeared from his home at 110 East Eighty-fourth Street Monday morning after leaving a note in French telling his mother not to worry, as he was going to Phoenix, Ariz.

For the last quarter of a century the American Red Cross has been developing a strong, socially constructive program among the youth of the land. The American Junior Red Cross is the organization of the Red Cross in the schools. In time of peace it has fostered qualities of leadership and cooperation, as well as such valuable special skills as swimming, life-saving, sewing, manual training and home nursing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 10 -- British protests against the building in Sweden of fishing boats for the German firm of Hugo Stinnes as craft that London considered would be used as minesweepers were declared "entirely unfounded" by Foreign Minister Christian E. Gunther when he replied today to a question in Parliament.

Despite increases in taxes and operating costs, earnings of the Climax Molybdenum Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries in 1942 were substantially above those of 1941 according to the annual report to stockholders.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 10 -- Princeton clinched second place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by checking Harvard, 40 -- 25, for its eighth victory in eleven circuit starts.

All of the 1943 advertising of the Westinghouse Electric Appliance Division will be devoted to the job of helping win the war as well as to building good-will, according to Roger H. Bolin, advertising manager of the division at Mansfield, Ohio. The program, in which magazines will be used as the major medium, has been divided into three parts.

The stock market duplicated yesterday its performance of Tuesday, with the morning hours dominated by further profit-taking and losses reduced in the final period on renewed buying. Business was much smaller in volume with dealings on the New York Stock Exchange under the million-share mark for the first full session in more than two weeks.

" Sons o' Fun" will not be required to leave Broadway on March 27 after all. This was made official yesterday with the announcement that the revue will be transferred from the Winter Garden to the Forty-sixth Street on March 29.

The second week of continuous bombing of Germany closed with the war's most devastating raid on Munich, birthplace of the Nazi party. On twelve of these fourteen days Allied planes have been shuttling over the borders of the Reich in mass formation, to drop a heavier load of explosives than has ever fallen on any nation in an equal period of time.
LONDON, March 10 (U.P.) -- King George personally decorated four American fliers recently at an investiture at Buckingham Palace, it was disclosed today.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 10 (AP) -- Shifty little Manuel Ortiz left no doubt who is the undisputed world bantamweight boxing champion by scoring a technical knockout over Lou Salica of Brooklyn in the eleventh of a scheduled fifteen-round bout tonight.

Scattered trading involving dwellings, apartments and lofts in Manhattan yesterday included the purchase by an investor of the five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 608-14 West 177th Street, west of St. Nicholas Avenue, from Ruth Kuperschmid and Helen Petziner.
The "open season" to which members of the Board of Education have been subjected lately led their president, Ellsworth B. Buck, yesterday to voice his resentment in verse.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Colonel Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, has asked the Secretaries of War and Navy, the chairman of the Maritime Commission and the director of Treasury Procurement to inform him to what extent contractors working for them have let subcontracts as Congress wants them to do.

" Mr. Winkle Goes to War," the recent novel by Theodore Pratt, published by Duell, Sloan Pearce, has been purchased by Columbia Pictures for immediate production, the publishing company announced yesterday. Mr. Pratt, the author, will go to Hollywood to work on the script for the film.
In order to meet the need of lodging for enlisted men who come to New York on leave, there seems an opportunity for the New York branch of the Federation of Churches.
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, March 10 (U.P.) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said in the House of Commons today that Britain welcomed a suggestion by the United States that discussions be held to deal with the problem of war refugees.

Undefeated in nine meets, Columbia's Bill Vessie, newly crowned intercollegiate high-jump champion, will face his strongest opposition on Saturday night, when the curtain will be rung down on the local indoor track season at Madison Square Garden with the staging of the annual Knights of Columbus carnival.

It is stated in some quarters that the Administration is laying plans to block by parliamentary manoeuvring an open floor test in the House on adoption of the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan. The Administration may attempt to provide, it is said, that only those amendments acceptable to the Ways and Means Committee can even come up fop a House vote.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 107 United States Army officers and enlisted men missing in action in the European, Middle East, North African, North American and South Pacific areas and of 236 missing at sea in the North Atlantic.

Milk distributors in New York and vicinity were authorized last night by the Office of Price Administration in Washington to increase the price of home-delivered milk a half cent a quart, effective today. The Borden Company immediately announced it was putting the increase into effect and others were expected to do likewise.

LONDON, March 10 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace's proposal that a satisfactory understanding be reached by the Western democracies and Russia before the war ends received strong endorsement today from most of the influential sections of the press in Britain, which already has a twenty-year treaty of collaboration with Russia.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the Kansas City Southern Railway Company, issued yesterday, showed that on Dec. 31 the road had current assets of $15,742,788, including cash of $4,106,289, and current liabilities of $13,458,083, of which the largest item was accrued tax liability of $4,760,316.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii March 10 -- Rear Admiral Charles A. Lockwood, new commander of the Pacific Fleet Submarine Force, made his first formal appearance in his new post today to present awards to ten officers and men of the Pacific Fleet at the submarine base here.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today clearing up ambiguities between the Office of War Information and the Office of Strategic Services over the problem of psychological warfare.

The focus of fashion is so definitely on suits and hats this Spring that Oppenheim Collins has rearranged and redecorated one whole floor for the display of these two items. Yesterday evening the new suit shop and millinery salon were opened for a preview with a brief and well-selected fashion show.

In preparation for next week's heavy turnover of funds incident to first-quarter income tax collections, with the accompanying temporary heavy strain on the commercial banks, the Treasury is borrowing heavily from the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System to meet its current needs, instead of withdrawing funds from the commercial bank depositaries.

Prayers for the safe return of members of our armed forces were voiced throughout the nation yesterday at Ash Wednesday devotions opening Lent. Churchgoers thronged Protestant and Roman Catholic houses of worship all day starting at 7 A.M.

The protest against absenteeism in war industries is a natural and proper one, but it has led some persons to over-simplify the issue. The Johnson bill, requiring employers to report to draft boards the names of employes absent without good cause, is an illustration.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Oliver E. Carruth of Falls Church, Va., was notified today of the death of his brother, Private Max I. Carruth, 45, at Camp Truax, Army Air Field at Madison, Wis.
CHUNGKING, China, March 10 (U.P.) -- A communique:

BOCA GRANDE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- J.P. Morgan rallied today from the heart attack that has caused great concern to his associates. The latest word from the sick room of-the 75-year-old financier in a cottage at the Gasparilla Inn was of "a slight but definite improvement."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Formal exception to an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's recommendation that the Hudson Manhattan Railroad be allowed to increase its fare from 8 to 10 cents between Jersey City and Hoboken, N.J., and Hudson Terminal in New York City, was taken today by Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, in a brief filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.
City Hall rang loud with speech and song yesterday as the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office opened a ten-day drive for 2,500 women volunteers for the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 10 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering has been in Rome since Saturday, according to private advices that official circles in Italy and Germany neither confirmed or denied tonight.

Depressed by the report that the Commodity Credit Corporation next month will release some of its cotton stocks to the yarn trade for use in the manufacture of twine, the cotton futures market yesterday declined moderately on commission-house realizing.

The 1942 annual report of the Philadelphia Electric Company, made public yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $16,496,672, a decrease of $2,195,569, or 11.7 per cent, from the net of $18,692,241 reported for 1941.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Amendments to the milk marketing order for the metropolitan New York area will be considered Tuesday at a joint State-Federal hearing to be held at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn, State Agricultural Commissioner Holton V. Noyes announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 10, (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 194 United States Army personnel, 116 United States Navy personnel and thirty-six United States Marine Corps personnel held as prisoners by the Japanese Government in Taiwan, Manila and Java.

NEW DELHI, India, March 10 (U.P.) -- American fliers have blasted an important bridge near the enemy base at Myitkyina, Burma, while the Royal Air Force made a highly successful raid last night on the Irrawaddy River center of Prome, and continued to harass Japanese troops that infiltrated behind the British lines north of Akyab, it was announced today.
