WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Office of Price Administration has not intended to give the public the impression that a ban has been put on civic club luncheon meetings, club suppers and similar gatherings, Paul M. O'Leary, deputy administrator in charge of rationing, asserted today.

MEXICO CITY, March 10 -- The Syndicate of Railroad Workers today accepted the main suggestions proposed several months ago by the management of the national railroads for reforms designed to render more efficient the entire system through the elimination of abuses, waste and lack of discipline.

A small but active religious sect known as Jehovah's Witnesses figures again in two unanimous decisions handed down by the Supreme Court of the United States. In both opinions, the one written by Justice Black, the other by Justice Reed, local ordinances restraining the Witnesses from passing out handbills on the streets were declared invalid.

Victories by Benjamin Franklin High of Manhattan and James Madison High of Brooklyn that placed their teams in the city P.S.A.L. semi-finals featured a basketball triple-header yesterday afternoon in Madison Square Garden.

William D. Miller, for many years with Underwood Elliott Fisher Company, has joined John Underwood Co., manufacturers of carbon paper, typewriter ribbons and inks. He will be in charge of the export department.

ALRANY, March 10 -- Reorganization of the State Post-War Planning Commission so that it would be a much smaller group has been recommended by Governor Dewey. The proposal stirred interest because, as presented to the commission at a meeting held yesterday, it involved the dropping from membership of Robert Moses, president of the State Council of Parks, along with several others.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The comprehensive recommendations combined in the National Resources Planning Board's "cradle to grave" social security program, transmitted by President Roosevelt to Congress today, were based on the nation's experience with its social security program over ten years and on the ability of the national economy to cope with and remedy the inadequacies revealed by the board's study.

AHMEDABAD, India, March 7 (delayed) -- The shadow of Mohandas K. Gandhi lies over this great textile mill center where he lived for fifteen years and in behalf of whose workers he made one of his earliest and mot successful fasts.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Royal Air Force struck with explosives and fire deep into the heart of nazism for the second straight night with a 500-ton blockbuster and incendiary attack on Munich last night and followed it up this afternoon with extensive fighter sweeps over France.

LONDON, March 10 -- George Hall, financial secretary of the Admiralty, gave the House of Commons further cheering news today about anti-U-boat warfare, He was replying to demands by Emanuel Shinwell, Laborite, for a more aggressive policy in the anti-submarine war, more modern aircraft for the Fleet Air Arm and the construction of still more fast merchant ships.

CHUNGKING, China, March 10 -- The creation of a China Air Command of United States Forces under Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault was announced in a communique issued today from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters.

It is impossible to dissociate what is happening in French Africa from what is happening in metropolitan France. The French at home, more cut off from the world today than they were last year, walled in as they never have been in their history, must hear echoes of the changes being made day by day in Algeria and Morocco.

WITE THE AMERICAN FORCES, on the Central Tunisian Front, March 10 (U.P.) -- There's another Teddy Roosevelt bouncing into battle at the head of American troops -- this time in a jeep called "Rough Rider."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A stone bust of President Roosevelt, executed by Walter Russell, New York sculptor, was presented to the people of th United States today by the Order of Ahepa, an organization of Americans of Hellenic ancestry, at a ceremony in the White House.

The effective date of the new export program, under which the Lend-Lease Administration will act as the "claimant agency" for importers in the British Empire countries, will be April 1, it was announced yesterday by the British Ministry of Supply Mission.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- The Winter battles on the Russian front now have reached their highest pitch. From the approaches of Leningrad to the Northern Donets, the armies are grappling in snow and mud. The attrition is enormous. Neither side is sparing its strength.

Barney Ross, former world light- weight and welterweight champion, will be in this city tomorrow as Corporal Barney Ross of the United States Marine Corps, but with fighting his main objective, nevertheless.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A hint that the current rate of draft inductions may be speeded up came today in a statement from Charles P. Taft, assistant director of the office of defense health and welfare services, that all 3-A registrants may be inducted by midsummer.

LONDON, March 10 (U.P.) -British light coastal forces, in two encounters with German vessels off the Netherland coast last night, damaged three ships and inflicted considerable damage on others, the Admiralty announced tonight.

A program having as its objective the alleviation of pricing difficulties of fur wholesalers under the OPA will be presented at a general meeting of the Fur Wholesalers Association of America within the next ten days and shortly thereafter will be put before the OPA, it was stated yesterday by Joseph Kruskal of Kruskal Kruskal, president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, March l0 -- Indications today were that the government was disposed to let the furor subside over the Moscow press conference of Admiral Williana H. Standley, American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, after an explanation had been received from the Ambassador.

The annual report of the Prudential Insurance Company of America made public yesterday, showed that holdings of obligations of the United States and Canada increased $478,000,000 in 1942, bringing the total of such investments to $1,732,809,000 at the year-end.

Because of the war people "seem to be living for the present moment, ignoring the past and scarcely daring to think about the future." This appraisal of the public state of mind is made by the New York Public Library in its annual report for 1942, issued yesterday.

Development of a new catalyst that may step up the quality of high-octane gasoline to the point where it would give 23 to 35 per cent more power to supercharged aircraft engines or mean a 13 to 30 per cent increase in the yield of aviation gasoline base stock from given crudes was announced yesterday by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc.

At her recital last night in Town Hall, Edna Bockstein, pianist, gave a program in which works of Bach, Chopin and Liszt were contrasted with contemporary compositions. The latter included Shostakovich's sonata, Op. 12, granted its initial New York hearing; Wagenaar's First sonata and three short pieces by Leon Erdstein, Henry Brant and Eda Rapoport, which were accorded their premieres.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Education approved at its regular meeting yesterday the Coudert bill now pending before the Legislature to give the Superintendent of Schools more power and at the same time to change the Board of Superintendents into an advisory body.

A background to New York City's schools, and even more important than that very important subject, is New York City itself. More striking than any other figure or set of figures in the Rapp-Coudert report on school reorganization is the estimated number of children in the whole public school system two years from now.
Dr. Wei Tao-ming, the Chinese Ambassador, and Mme. Wei are at the Towers of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Major Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Work Administrator, made this comment today on the statement of Governor Dewey regarding child care:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The first revision of ration points for processed foods will be made tomorrow when the Office of Price Administration is expected to announce lower values for dried beans, peas and lentils. These three products now have a value of eight points a pound.

A potato shortage rapidly approaching the famine stage threatens New York City as a result of transportation difficulties and black market dealings in this staple food, a survey of the trade disclosed yesterday. [1:4.]

ALBANY, March 10 -- A bill granting tax exemption to that part of the Metropolitan Opera House property not used commercially, similar to the one vetoed by former Governor Herbert A. Lehman two years ago at Mayor La Guardia's insistence, was introduced in the Legislature today.

A general wage increase for theatrical house and company managers and press agents was ordered yesterday by Professor Paul F. Brissenden of Columbia University, who arbitrated the agreement between the Association of Theatrical Agents and Managers and the League of New York Theatres.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, on the Tunisian Front, March 7 (Delayed) -- General Sir Bernard L. 1VIontgomery told the British Eighth Army, in a personal message at the beginning of Marshal Erwin Rommel's attack, that the enemy was crippling himself and "it will then be our turn to attack him."

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 10 (U.P.) -- Man o' War, a symbol of turf superiority for more than two decades, will be retired from stud duty immediately, it was announced today. The most famous racer in American history is quartered at the Faraway Farm of his owner, Samuel Riddle, near here.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 10 -- Amplifying his statement before the recent transport inquiry that the agreement with the United States on bases was a dead letter as far as the Americans' postwar use of motor vehicles was concerned, Sir Stanley Spurling declares that as a result of discussions in Washington it was definite that the Americans would have the use of motor vehicles after the war to operate their bases satisfactorily.

The recent news that two more war correspondents, Ben Robertson and Robert Post, are among the dead and missing once more brings into sharp focus the shining heroism of our newspaper men. According to the last available figures, more correspondents have been casualties of war in proportion to their numbers than any group of war workers, all fighting units included.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold to Eduardo Chifari the one-family house at 7818 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, through Slomka Bros. and the Messina-Realty Company. The parcel is assessed at $4,800.

Colonel Douglas Clifton Brown, Deputy Chairman and Speaker of the House of Commons since 1938, has been chosen Speaker. He is an experienced Member, having served since 1918, with the exception of a month or two. He knows the ropes. He can call a substitute to the chair without saying anything about it to the House, a natural but modern rule.

The report of the Rapp-Coudert committee on the New York school system should receive the thorough consideration that the importance of its subject-matter demands. The natural interests that millions of parents have in the education of their children, no less than the huge investment in capital equipment and annual payrolls that the city schools represent, should insure such consideration.

The International League, in common with the majors, will open its sixtieth consecutive season a bit later but still with a full quota of games, according to the 1943 schedule, just released. The usual 154 games are carded for the campaign, which will have its regular opening on April 22 and close on Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Harrison E. Spangler, Republican National Chairman, welcomed today "the presentation of a large number of brilliant and competent Americans as candidates for the Presidency" and added:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today two reports of the National Resources Planning Board designed to guarantee a private or public job for every able-bodied person and suggesting major changes in the economic system, including larger government participation in private industry and a share in management by labor.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (U.P.) -- Pint-sized Basil D. Izzi, 20-year old naval gunner who was rescued with two Dutch seamen after eighty-three days adrift on a raft in the South Atlantic, today told how he and his fellow survivors used their toes as bait to lure sharks into a rope noose.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Plans of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to build a large "white-collar" housing development in the Lower East Side were discussed on the floor of the Assembly this morning, in connection with the Mitchell bill giving greater incentive to insurance companies and banks to invest in so-called urban redevelopment projects.

HANOVER, N.H., March 10 -- The Dartmouth basketball team, playing its final home game of the season today, rolled over Pennsylvania, 70 -- 34, to clinch its sixth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League title.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In a peace gesture toward the War Production Board and other agencies, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Services of Supply, disclosed today that he had ordered his military and civilian aides to abstain from engaging in "the battle of Washington" and to avoid any "useless bickering which turns our blood into bile."

LONDON, March 10 -- The Nazi regime "must be destroyed forever," Lord Simon told the House of Lords today in a speech replying to a demand by the Bishop of Chichester that, for the sake of those who were resisting Germany and those in occupied countries, the British Government make known, before their western offensive begins, with what elements the Allies would collaborate.

Apartment houses in the Washington Heights, Dyckman and Inwood sections drew many of the new tenants whose names were added yesterday to the rosters of the buildings by managing agents. Numerous rentals also were closed in buildings on the East Side and in Greenwich Village.

The New Jersey blackout mixup of Tuesday night was still unsettled yesterday as a new source of muddle arose -- the question of whether blank anti-aircraft ammunition would be fired during a forthcoming test.
Complete programs for the Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning April 1 have been announced by S. Hurok.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- The rescue of four United States fliers from the Amazon jungles after one of them, taking a million-to-one chance, had drifted down the turbulent Caqueta River on a flimsy raft to summon help, was disclosed today.

MOSCOW, March 10 (AP) -- Two days after the statement by Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, that the Russian people were not being properly informed of American lend-lease aid to the Soviet Union, Izvestia. Soviet Government newspaper, printed on its back page today an article supplied by Tass from New York and based on an article by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., American Lend-Lease Administrator, in the American Magazine.

MOSCOW, March 10 (U.P.) -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, conferred with Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff Molotoff this afternoon at the Kremlin, two days after his complaint at a press conference that American aid to Russia had not been sufficiently acknowledged.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- In his radio speech last night, after asserting that the greatest blow "to our hopes of a complete final victory" would be any reduction in the planned size of the Army in 1943, the Secretary of War, Mr. Stimson, said that a General Service Act would make it possible to attain the plan without weakening the home front below the point where such an Army could be effectively supported.

A British naval officer was burned to death and the brother of a New York banker was seriously burned early yesterday morning when the Hotel Delmonico apartment in which they were sleeping caught fire.

Opposition to a proposed 10 per cent increase in rates by a group of motor carriers until the Interstate Commerce Commission can investigate the necessity for such a rise was voiced yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York at the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., Woolworth Building.

Housewives have embarked on a new kind of hoarding -- of points in their War Ration Books No. 2 -Commissioner of Markets Daniel P. Woolley declared yesterday. Without consumer points, the grocer will not be able to replenish his stocks and thereby still another shortage will be created, he said.

Reviving the efforts of minority stockholders of Wickwire Spencer Steel Company to bring about the sale or merger of the company, the investment firm of Allen Co. has sent out a request for proxies to be voted in favor of such a policy at the annual meeting to be held here on March 25.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, sentenced to die for the slaying of Joseph Rosen, a Brooklyn storekeeper, asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its recent refusal to review their convictions as members of the Brooklyn murder ring.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Although the War Department would prefer to have women doctors serve the Army through the Waacs, it will not oppose suggested legislation to commission them as medical officers, Lieut. Col. C.J. Hauck, liaison officer for the Chief of Staff, testified before a House Military Affairs subcommittee today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, March 11 (AP) -- A communique:

HALIFAX, N.S., March 9 (Delayed) -- A gunner from the French battleship Richelieu asserted today that when crew members learned of the Allied invasion of North Africa and demanded to be sent to fight against the Germans thirty of their number were interned and their officers called them "damned fools."

Featured by heavy gains by apparel chains because of the wave of scare buying in fear of rationing, sales of leading chains and mail order companies showed an average advance of 11.2 per cent in February, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente granted judgment yesterday in favor of Emil K. Ellis in the latter's suit to compel the city to pay his fees and expenses as counsel to the City Council Committee that investigated the Municipal Civil Service Commission and its former chairman, Paul J. Kern.

Gunder Haegg, the Flying Fireman from Sweden who recently smashed nine world track records within three months, will come to the United States this Summer for a cinder path campaign against America's best, it was disclosed last night, The United Press reported.

While the United Nations are talking about future frontiers, the post-war world and responsibility for a possible third world war, the Germans are concentrating all their efforts on winning this war first. They have launched a counter-offensive in the East which has already thrown the Russian armies back nearly 100 miles over hard-won territory and again threatens the key city of Kharkov.

Estimating New York State's potential labor supply of women at 1,500,000, the Women's Advisory Commission of the State Department of Labor presented a report yesterday with recommendations designed to speed recruiting and training of women for the war industries of the State and for postwar planning to aid women in industry.

Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota declared last night at Columbia University that collaboration with Fascist forces in North Africa, Spain, Italy and Germany on the grounds of military expediency might endanger the cause of peace and democracy after the war.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- Following upon Ambassador William H. Standley's statement that the Soviet Union was insufficiently publicizing United States help, this correspondent made a hasty check around Moscow this morning and had several opportunities to probe the Russians' knowledge as to the origin of American supplies here.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for the Jacksonville Gas Corporation's $5 par common stock, and will act also as exchange agent for the company's bonds, debentures and notes under the reorganization plan.

Angelo Nicholas, an admitted pander, was sentenced to two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing yesterday in General Sessions, a short time before the manager of a midtown hotel was convicted in Special Sessions of operating his place as a house of prostitution and public menace.

CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- The Army plans to commission during 1943 6,900 physicians, 3,000 internes and resident doctors from hospitals, 4,800 dentists and 900 veterinarians, according to the Journal of the American Medical Association.

Doings along the local baseball frontier again veered slightly to the negative side yesterday. At least they did for the Giants, who, during the course of the afternoon, had to concede the loss of still another player because of wartime conditions.

" The situation is desperate during dimout, hours," Magistrate Anna M. Kross commented yesterday in Homicide Court when she discharged a taxicab driver on a technical charge of homicide. The driver had been arrested after the fatal injury of Corporal Robert E. Thompson, 30 years old, of Camp MacQuaid, Calif., at Madison Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, at 2 A.M. March 7.

LONDON, March 10 -- Sir William Beveridge, author of the controversial plan for universal social insurance, declared today that when he went to the United States he would continue his studies of his major preoccupation now -- how to avoid post-war mass unemployment.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -Here are major questions arising on the compromise tax plan as approved today by the Ways and Means Committee and the answers based on a committee explanation:
LONDON, March 10 -- Gunmen attempted to assassinate Marcel Deat, arch -collaborationist and close colleague of Pierre Laval, last night in Central France, the Paris radio reported tonight.

National champion in 1941 and runner-up last year to Ensign H. Robert Reeve, Joe Lordi of the New York A.C. carried off the honors in the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association last night.

The business of buying and preparing fresh vegetables and fruits -- activities that become increasingly familiar as the point rationing of processed foods continues -- is complicated this week by the fact that supplies are scant. Reasonably priced suggestions are few, according to the Department of Markets, which reports that the list or good buys includes bunched carrots, iceberg lettuce, beets, apples and oranges.

In the first forty days in which insurance on money and securities has been available at the War Damage Corporation, $1,245,000,000 of business has been written, including $1,102,000,000 on securities and $143,000,000 on money, with premiums estimated at $350,000, according to the money and securities group of the WDC.

Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, informed stockholders in the annual report issued for release today that sales last year increased 25.6 per cent over the previous year and that earnings were also higher despite the fact that taxes were nearly twice as much.

Columbia concluded its basketball season last night by losing to Cornell, 59 to 51, before a capacity crowd of 1,200 in the Morningside Heights gymnasium. The Lions' defeat gave them a season's record of five victories and seven setbacks in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

WASHINGTON, March l0 -- The South Pacific's small-scale version of round-the-clock bombing was continued yesterday with intensified and particularly effective raids the Japanese air field at Munda, as well as attacks on other points, the Navy announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The War Labor Board emphasized today that it would review wage awards of arbitrators only on the question of whether the award was compatible with the national wage stabilization program.

Anibal Almodovar, the 21-year-old Puerto Rican who has been in fear of the electric chair since he was convicted two weeks ago of strangling his young wife in Central Park, became violent yesterday in General Sessions as Judge George L. Donnellan sentenced him to be put to death in Sing Sing in the week of April 19.
St. John's earned a berth in the forthcoming national invitation basketball tournament last night by overwhelming St. Francis, 50 -- 34, before 14,185 persons at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -Freshmen legislators drank beer or soft drinks and chatted with President Roosevelt at the White House tonight at a gathering which was generally interpreted as a conciliatory gesture from the Administration toward Congress.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The findings and recommendations of the National Resources Planning Board on security, work and relief policies are as follows:

Contributions of $75,000 from the United States Steel Corporation and $40,000 from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation were announced yesterday by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City.

HONOLULU, March 10 -- Formal restoration to civilian authorities in Hawaii of all powers in local government except those affecting military defense of the islands was effected today at a joint session of the Territorial Legislature in the throne room of Iolani Palace, the former seat of Hawaiian Kings, now the capitol.

Miriam Winslow, who has danced here only with a partner heretofore, last night gave a solo recital at the New York Times Hall. The program was most expertly presented, the waits between numbers were brief, the costumes excellent, and the lighting carefully planned.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins asserted today that absenteeism among war workers can best be combatted by correcting the cause for the stay-aways rather than through a Congressional act.

THE bright-eyed, rosy-cheeked youngsters of other years who reported eagerly at training camp for major-league tryouts have given way this season to older men. Some of the rookies are distinctly on the ancient side, and the explanation of it is simple even if the French language expresses it best. C'est la guerre.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 10 -Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio is for "cooperation" in international affairs. He talked about this and the New Deal for two hours this afternoon without defining "cooperation" but at least he threw a little light on a dark corner in the 1944 Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -Japan has declared unacceptable an American proposal for an exchange of Japanese and United States nationals on April 1, but has left the door open for possible favorable action later, the State Department announced in a statement today.

Cablegrams from Generals Henri Honore Giraud and Charles de Gaulle, expressing their thanks for the city's "Freedom for France Day" welcome on Feb. 23 to the crews of French warships in American waters were made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

A copy of the report of the Commission to Investigate Fish and Game Conditions in Connecticut has arrived and the members censure both the Board of Fisheries and Game and the Fish and Game Committees of past Legislatures.

LONDON, March 10 -- Business on the stock markets here was restricted again today by the "Wings for Victory" and also by the war news from Southern Russia. Gilt-edge stocks dropped fractionally, the 2 1/2 per cent Consols at 82 I-16 and local loans at 96 11-16, being each 1-16 down.
LONDON, Thursday, March 11 (U.P.) -- The midnight commmunique as broadcast by Moscow:

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The War Production Board said today that beauty products were now selling more rapidly in the United States than before the war and that the generous supply of cosmetics might have to be reduced at least to the "normal" level of 1939.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 10 -- Patrols of Allied tanks and infantry probed the Axis front in Tunisia yesterday, seeking an avenue of attack in the rough rectangle in which Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel and 200,000 Axis troops are caged.

The organization of an Anti-Sales Tax Committee, representing 50,000 New York City business enterprises, and a call for a meeting to devise ways and means of fighting the proposed increase of the city sales tax from 1 to 2 per cent, were announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor and chairman of the new committee.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the first week of March to a new peak, 102.9 per cent of the 1926 average. Further gains in prices for grains and for fruits and vegetables largely accounted for the advance.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The establishment of a United Nations government as "a definite continuing organization," which would emphasize human rights rather than nation's rights, was urged tonight by Governor Stassen of Minnesota at the United Nations forum on the problems of creating an enduring peace after the war.

Three midtown theatres will present new films today. At the Rivoli the new attraction will be "Forever and a Day," an all-star drama of English life from the Napoleonic era up to the present featuring such players as Ida Lupino, Herbert Marshall, Roland Young, Anna Neagle, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Merle Oberon, Ray Milland and C. Aubrey Smith.

A declaration by John Buckley, president of Local 853, United Auto Workers, a C.I.O. affiliate, favoring either Army or Navy control of two plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, was endorsed by a cheering crowd of 1,800 employes who met early yesterday at the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, Myrtle and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn.
CHUNGKING, China, March 11 (U.P.) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -A charge that members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, headed by Harry Bridges, were practicing an "organized slow-down" on West Coast waterfronts was on the record today through the medium of a legislative committee hearing.

There are at least two approaches to the serious problem of absenteeism in war production plants on which management and labor can cooperate even before recourse to legislation. Both appeal to the patriotism of war workers. One holds out the incentive of recognition for services faithfully performed.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association disclosed yesterday through The Associated Press the results of a survey of daily newspaper criculation rates in the nation, showing that 690 newspapers reported increases in one or more classifications in 1942, while the remaining 475 of the 1,165 replying said no increases had been made.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Russian Ambassador, Maxim Litvinoff, speaking at the lease-lend luncheon today, said he had no statistics on just what part American aid has played in Russia's war along a 2,000-mile front, but as an example he cited an air-force regiment of the Red Army which, "using nothing but Airacobras (Bell P-39 canon-firing American fighter planes), has been given the title of a Guard regiment for its distinguished services."

Mrs. Jean Rhein Crisswell, 36-year-old mother of five children, described to a blue-ribbon jury in General Sessions court yesterday how she and a gunman had stalked Harry Nichols, Williamsburgh gambling overlord, for eighteen months before he was shot down in the Essex Street subway station of the B.M.T. on Sept. 26, 1933.

Purchase of the brick edifice of the Kent Street Reformed Church, near Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, by the congregation of the St. Elias Roman Catholic (Greek rite) Church, 724 Leonard Street, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday. The transfer will take place after Easter.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Dewey signed today the JanesArchinal bill extending the mortgage moratorium to July 1, 1944, retaining the provision for 1 per cent annual amortization of principal. He also approved the Janes bill extending for another year the moratorium on deficiency judgment actions in mortgage foreclosures.

Reports that the Army will assume control of the Civil Air Patrol within a week center attention on the lesser known but important phase of volunteer activities. This nation-wide network of private planes was started more than a year ago in the shadow of a virtual double-dare from the Army to succeed.
President Roosevelt, in a letter made public yesterday, congratulated and praised the Girl Scout movement, which marks its thirty-first anniversary today.
A Finnish communique broadcast by the Finnish radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- An attempted Japanese comeback in the skies over Guadalcanal in the Solomons, where American forces are enjoying air superiority, has cost the enemy four planes, the Navy Department reported today.

The post-war security program outlined by President Roosevelt was hailed yesterday by leaders in the field of social work as a plan that would carry out objectives they have sought for years. It was seen also as "an effective stimulus to the war program" that would hasten victory.

Dr. Elgin Groseclose, author of "Ararat" and "The Firedrake," has arrived safely in the Near East to take up his duties as Treasurer of Iran, his publishers, J.B. Lippincott, announced yesterday. Dr. Groseclose is in Iran as a member of the Millspaugh Mission.
Mrs. William Moore Shackford of Peacedale, Far Hills, N.J., is at the Plaza.

In preparation for the Presidential campaign next year representatives of the American Labor party, which now exists only in New York State, will meet Sunday evening in Philadelphia with leaders of both branches of labor to organize a Labor party in Pennsylvania.
UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, March, 12 (AP) -- A communique:

At a "Wings for Victory Week" celebration in Trafalgar Square in London yesterday Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden took the salute at a march-past of the Allied air forces, headed by a United States band, the British Information Service here reported.

Does the Foreign Exchange Control Board ever review its own work? Is the adverse exchange rate with which Canadians are burdened something that must be put up with until the Four Freedoms are established?

Further tightening in the civilian cotton yarn supply was reported yesterday by spinners, who said they have been advised to prepare for new invitations that may be issued shortly by the Army Quartermaster for about 60,500,000 olive drab undershirts.

An interesting sidelight on the decision of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to open certain areas in off-season and permit hunting so that crop damage might be limited has been furnished by Dr. Ira Gabrielson.
" Keep 'em sailing" was the slogan at the gathering of the members of the Cruising Club of America last night at the New York Yacht Club.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 11 -- Germany's air force is equipped and ready to strike back and strike hard in retaliation for Anglo-American attacks on civilian populations of the occupied areas and German cities, it was officially announced in Berlin tonight.

Russell S. Randall, former Mayor of Freeport, L.I., and Francis Levett, a garage owner of Freeport, entered pleas of guilty before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on an indictment charging them, together with Laurence Crici of Inwood, L.I., with conspiring to violate OPA regulations through illegal possession and sale of gasoline ration coupons.

For the first time we are getting detailed Axis admissions of heavy damage from Allied air bombing. Previous Nazi propaganda had credited enemy pilots only with an ability to hit hospitals, schools, churches and historic monuments. The Italians first acknowledged some military damage.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Navy communique 306:

Throngs of taxpayers crowded into the offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue here yesterday. Some were gay, some were grim, and some wore the expression that might follow a reading of the line, "All hope abandon, ye who enter here."
A German High Command communique broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

Trading in cotton futures was very quiet yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange business in active contracts was done within a narrow range, with the close at net losses of 4 to 6 points as commission houses in late dealings liquidated near-month holdings.

CHUNGKING, China, March -- The Japanese have captured Hwajung, important center in Northern Hunan Province, in a drive southward across the Yangtze River apparently aimed at Changsha, strategic Chinese base ninety-five miles southeast of Hwajung, a Chinese communique announced tonight.

Another of the big crowds that have jammed Madison Square Garden on boxing nights recently is due at the Eighth Avenue arena tonight, when Tami Mauriello, making probably his last ring appearance before going into the Army, and Jimmy Bivins of Cleveland will come together in the feature ten round bout.

A property in Greenwich Village changed hands for the first time in thirty-seven years when Lena Dunlap sold the six-story apartment building at 27 West Eleventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, to the Redan Corporation. There are twelve suites of six and seven rooms each in the building, which is on a plot 40 by 103.3 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $35,000.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Montreal's Canadiens, who had come from behind here twice before this season to tie Chicago, did it again tonight to stay at the heels of the Black Hawks in their fight for a qualifying berth in the National Hockey League play-offs.

The annual report of the Union Electric Company of Missouri, made public yesterday by J.W. McAfee, president, shows a net income of $7,763,000 for 1942 after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.39 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $8,232,000, or $2.67 a share, in 1941.

CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Sarah Rasof, mother of Barney Ross, bought a new hat this afternoon -- a pert little black one with a veil and an assortment of colored ribbons bunched in front. Then she was whisked out to the airport in a limousine, with Mayor Edward J. Kelly holding her hand all the way.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Air Commodore H.N. Thornton, British Air Attache Washington, said yesterday that German airplane production has passed its peak and the German Air Force is stretched to the utmost. That is why it has been unable to retaliate on Britain.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- The history of the German counter-offensive in the Eastern Ukraine, which led up to the present great battle on Kharkov's approaches, was recounted in some detail in the army newspaper Red Star today. It shows that the Germans failed to trap the main Russian forces because of heroic rear-guard actions fought by armored units that had been in the van of the advance toward the Dnieper River.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Despite German claims of huge losses inflicted on American troops during the North African setback, incomplete reports indicate that, between Feb. 14 and 20, United States casualties were 59 men killed, 176 wounded and 2,007 missing, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson disclosed at his press conference today.

Bituminous operators of the northern Appalachian region organized in the Appalachian Joint Wage Conference spoke an emphatic "no" yesterday in reply to the major demands of the United Mine Workers, including an increase of $2 a day in basic wage rates and the proposal that some 50,000 minor bosses be included in the agreement being sought as successor to the contract expiring March 31.

Unable to get enough meat through regular trade channels at OPA price ceilings for the inmates of its institutions, the city is buying livestock in the country and having it processed in packing plants, officials disclosed yesterday.

The annual report of the American Sugar Refining Company, issued for publication today, reveals a consolidated net income of $3,783,196 for 1942, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.41 a share on the common stock. In 1941 the consolidated net income was $5,417,513, or $5.04 a common share.

Three outstanding civic organizations -- the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, the Bronx Chamber of Commerce and the Sixth Avenue Association -- came out yesterday against the proposed increase in the city sales tax from 1 to 2 per cent.

The Victory Garden Department of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office opened a two-week round-up drive for victory gardeners last night by holding a special rally at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at which speakers emphasized the importance of growing victory gardens in the metropolitan area to meet the food needs of the population.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 11 -- An Eighth Army column thrusting north forty miles west of the Mareth line in Tunisia repulsed attacks by German tanks and infantry at Ksar Rhilane yesterday.

Support of the Dwyer Criminal Identification Bill, that would authorize arresting officers to make blood grouping tests of all those arrested and charged with a felony or certain specified misdemeanors, was urged yesterday by Dr. Alexander S. Wiener, serologist to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner of this city.

Fields for the intercollegiate basketball tourneys to be played in Madison Square Garden later this month were completed yesterday with Manhattan College and Washington and Jefferson accepting bids to the national invitation fixture and N.Y.U. gaining a place in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Eastern regional event.

Continued simplification and liquidation of the United Light and Power Company system in conformance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was promised yesterday by William G. Woolfolk, president of United Light, in his 1942 annual report to stockholders.

A youth who had been reared in an atmosphere of poverty and another who lacked parental control, according to probation reports, received sentences yesterday in Bronx County Court for the holdup killing of Philip Hochman in his grocery store last Aug. 4.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -Backers of the Ruml pay-as-yougo tax plan took heart tonight, and began to predict a victory in the House after Representative Martin, Republican leader, and his steering committee threw in their support.

After an ownership of only a few days, Henry Goelet, operator, has resold to an investing client of Abraham Sobil, lawyer, the nine-story loft and store building at 133-35 West Twenty-fifth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. The building occupies a plot 50 by 98.9 feet and is reported to be fully occupied at a gross annual rental of about $21,500.

Buyers returned yesterday to the stock market with considerable zest, apparently satisfied with the results of the three-day corrective interlude. Values on the Stock Exchange were bid up more than a point in a long list of representative issues, with even larger additions in isolated spots.

With the announcement that seven more players had signed contracts, Branch Rickey, at his weekly press conference, yesterday appeared more than reasonably assured that this phase of his tasks as head man of all the Dodgers could be considered well in hand.

The German High Command, in a communique broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded by The Associated Press, said German forces had driven the Red Army closer to Kharkov and that "the battle is still being waged at the northern and western edges of the city."

Corporate taxpayers have been relieved of the necessity of filing records of all increases and decreases of wages or salaries in connection with their 1942 income and excess profits tax returns, according to a telegram from the Bureau of Internal Revenue received yesterday by the Controllers Institute of America.

The burning ambition to become a United States Marine Corps aviator, which has been uppermost in the mind of Alexander G. Carlson, 20-year-old former resident of Lima, Peru, since he was old enough to read, moved a step nearer realization yesterday when he was sworn into the corps by Major Harry V. Miller at Marine Recruiting Headquarters, 299 Broadway.

AT SEA WITH THE SOUTH PACIFIC FLEET, March 7 (Delayed) -- Another installment of the hell owed the Japanese was paid early yesterday morning when two task forces of the United States South Pacific Fleet steamed in to put a nutcracker of gunfire on the Vila and Munda airfields.

Workers from all branches of the entertainment world will gather at 3 P.M. today at the Winter Garden to honor colleagues who died in the service of their country and pay tribute to those now engaged in all phases of the war effort.

The public will have a chance to see an exhibition of some of the art work that is entertaining American soldiers when the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opens on Wednesday a display of original drawings and photographs made for Yank, the weekly newspaper published by the War Department for enlisted men.

NEWARK, N.J., March 11 -- Further evidence of the high regard in which the Marines hold Colonel James Roosevelt came today from Sergeant James P. Alverson, who is in the South Pacific with the Marines.
An "overseer" of world affairs, including relations between nations, was supported last night in the Town Hall debate by Sir Norman Angell, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The names of Major Gen. George S. Patton Jr., commander of the First Armored Corps in North Africa, and Major Gen. Carl Spaatz, commander of the United States Army Air Force in the Northwest Africa area, both highly decorated pioneers in their respective fields, were sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt, who nominated them for promotion to the temporary rank of lieutenant general.

The eighty-ninth anniversary of the birth of Andrew Furuseth, pioneer in the unionization of merchant seamen, will be observed today in United Seamen's Service convalescent centers, hotels and clubs in this country and abroad, according to an announcement yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the organization. Mr. Furuseth died in 1938.

The mandatory use of low-beam automobile headlights under an experimental police regulation has reduced traffic accidents and deaths almost 50 per cent, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine when he ordered the rule made a part of the permanent wartime traffic code.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- The Princeton University Press Club, undergraduate organization that since 1900 has been the only source of Princeton news in the nation's press, will suspend for the war at the end of this week, Robert C. McGiffert, '44, of Easton, Pa., its president, announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The War Labor Board adopted today a short-cut procedure for regional boards to speed up action on the wage applications of small employers and for the first time authorized increases by regional boards to correct "substandard" wages.

LONDON, March 11 -- Since Dec. 20 at least 532 German officers and men have been killed by the guerrilla movement in France, it was revealed here today, with the accompanying disclosure that determined French patriots have organized to the extent of issuing formal communiques, which they sign "High Command, French Guerrillas and Partisans."
The pay-as-you-go plan for reform of the income tax, as proposed by Beardsley Ruml, is at present again in the focus of interest.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -President Roosevelt signed the bill extending the Lend-Lease Act; his visitors included Senator Kilgore, Dr. Charles E. Merriam and George F. Yantis of the National Resources Planning Board, Elmer Davis and Emil Schram.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 170 United States soldiers held prisoner by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The State War Council has approved a $15,000,000 program for the care of children of women working in war industry, one-third of the cost to be borne by the State.

Opposition to the proposal that the New York Stock Exchange permit members to be incorporated does not appear to be developing. What comment there is on the projected move, which now is before the membership for suggestions before definitive action by the board of governors, appears to be either disinterested or mildly favorable.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 6 were 14 per cent higher than the same week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 26 per cent in the week ended Feb. 27. For the latest four-week period sales were up 29 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A sweeping attack on government procurement officials for their "opposition and indifference" to the use of smaller plants in the war program was presented to the Senate today by its Small Business Committee, headed by Senator Murray of Montana.

STONY BROOK, L. I., March 11 -- At least two persons win vouch for the authenticity of this story of a mallard duck's mates freeing it from an arrow, and of the bird flying away, apparently little the worse for an archer's aim.
DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings clinched the National Hockey League championship tonight by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 to 1, on Don Grosso's goal with four minutes to play.
The immigration authorities at Ellis Island are today the uneasy custodians of twelve sailors of the French Navy who want to fight the Germans in any sort of craft without any further delay.

Bank clearings of the twenty-three principal cities of the nation totaled $7,414,311,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, or 19.1 per cent above the $6,226,900,000 recorded in the comparable week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. They were, however, $1,086,453, or 12.8 per cent less than in the previous week, which had the benefit of first-of-the-month settlements.

In studies designed to show the current deficiency in certain types of farm equipment, the De Laval Separator Company, one of the largest manufacturers of cream separators and milking machines, yesterday urged that the concentration programs affecting these products be abandoned and that separator production be boosted sharply.

A new issue of $40,000,000 New York City short-term revenue bills was sold yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, by allotment, to a group of twenty-three of the city's banks. The bills, which are dated March 12 and mature on May 3, 1943, were sold on an 0.55 per cent basis.
MOSCOW, March 11 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 -- Renewing his attack on labor "racketeers" and political incompetents who, he said, slowed up the war effort, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker called tonight for the establishment of a new union, a union of the people of the United States who would forget the money and political angles of this war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Pierre Aumont, French actor, whose first American film part is the lead in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's recently completed "Assignment in Brittany," will be starred in that company's "A Thousand Shall Fall," a story of French captured soldiers after the fall of France.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Small quantities of food shipped to the children of France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Norway under adequate guarantees and International Red Cross supervision will give no help, direct or indirect, to the Axis economy, Howard E. Kershner, director of the International Commission for the Assistance of Child Refugees, said today in disclosing that a new appeal has been made to President Roosevelt on behalf of starving children in Europe.

Announcement that the Office of Price Administration has lowered point values for certain dried vegetables was received with satisfaction in the food trades yesterday, although it was pointed out that unless such reductions are made retroactive on replacement purchases considerable hardship is likely to result.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The financial condition of American cities is improving under war conditions, Joseph M. Cunningham, deputy controller of New York City, said today in an address before a conference of the Central States group of the Investment Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, was the luncheon guest of President Roosevelt in the White House today. He said afterward he had told the President the present stock market was a healthy, not an excited one.

Columbia University lost its serenity yesterday when 2,000 students from elementary, junior high and high schools stormed the campus for the opening of the nineteenth annual Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention.
An optimistic outlook for continuation of tournament competition in 1943 was seen yesterday by Holycombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- On the second anniversary of the enactment of lend-lease, President Roosevelt signed into law today a Congressional resolution extending for one year the material aid under which our allies benefited during the first two years in airplanes, tanks, guns, munitions, food, shipping, ship repair and other services to the extent of $9,632,000,000.
The twelve-room house at 924 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to a client of Michael P. Curnin, Inc., brokers, for occupancy.

PORTLAND, Me., March 11 -- Stockholders of the Portland Ogdensburg Railway received today an offer of the Maine Central Railroad Company to exchange Portland Ogdensburg first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds due Nov. 1, 1953, guaranteed by the Maine Central, for their stock at the rate of a $1,000 bond for each forty shares.

Although many New York buildings are so constructed as to withstand fairly successfully any type of bombing, a large number of others are acutely vulnerable even to incendiary bombing, James McCawley, editor of The United Roofer and secretary of the United Roofing Contractors Association, declared yesterday.

With meat supplies so short that some butcher shops are reported closing at 2 P.M. daily and with canned goods moving slowly under the point rationing system, a movement to have all food stores remain closed all day on Wednesdays has been started by the Greater New York Retail Grocers Conference.

ALBANY, March 11 -- Passage of the Todd-Murray bill relaxing to some extent labor standards for industries connected with the war effort or the maintenance of the domestic economy was assured today when Governor Dewey stated that it received the approval of the State War Council.

MOSCOW, March 11 (U.P.) -- Russian newspapers, despite space restrictions of the war that confine them to four pages, gave lengthy treatment today to developments that have followed the complaint by United States Ambassador William H. Standley, that Russia had not properly acknowledged American aid.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Guy T. Helvering, Internal Revenue Commissioner, ruled today that the wife of a member of the armed forces serving outside the United States must file a separate return by March 15, reporting her taxable income, but may reserve the right to file a joint return with her husband when he comes home.

Business organizations were urged yesterday by Walter Hoving to take the trouble to adopt plans necessary for the employment of the blind and other handicapped people. Speaking at the Thirty-sixth Annual meeting of The Lighthouse, headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, Mr. Hoving said:

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Midwestern bankers won at least a moral victory today in a struggle with New York financiers when the Interstate Commerce Commission threw out the Erie Railroad's plan to sell $14,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent bonds to Morgan Stanley Co.

S. Philip Licht, former treasurer of Wagner Memorial Lutheran College on Grymes Hill, Stapleton, S.I., and a former well-known Staten Island banker who was scheduled to go to trial in the Richmond County Court at St. George, yesterday on a first degree grand larceny indictment, pleaded guilty.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A statement that the Allies must land in France this year or "it may be too late" was made today by J.C. Fernand-Laurent, long a Parisian member of the Chamber of Deputies and editor of the newspaper Jour, who escaped from France in December and is visiting Washington.

PRETORIA, Union of South Africa, March 11 (AP) -- One of Reichfuehrer Hitler's ace saboteurs, Sydney Robey Leibrandt, a former South African policeman and Olympic boxer who became a lance corporal in the German parachutist corps and eventually was landed by U-boat for destructive purposes in this country, was convicted of high treason today and sentenced to death.

One of the reporters in a bomber that attacked Wilhelmshaven last week brought back with him, among other impressions, a bit of advice for men in his trade. "It was not until then that I realized a truth that should be communicated to every student of journalism: a good deal of experience is needed to qualify as a competent aerial observer."

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 11 -- The World Journal here, in a front page editorial today, nominated Governor Rexford G. Tugwell eulogistically for Admiral William H. Standley's post in Moscow, but Tugwell supporters discounted it.

In the first of three programs under the direction of Doris Humphrey at the Humphrey-Weidman Studio Theatre in West Sixteenth Street, Jose Limon last, night proved his right to be ranked among the top line of American dancers.

The Argentine Government has barred five radio broadcasts of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, which is headed by Nelson A. Rockefeller and which has for its principal purpose the improvement of relations between the United States and Latin America, it was learned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -Diversion of men and materials to construction of a $187,000,000 ship canal across New Jersey during the war was opposed today by, the Port of New York Authority.

PATERSON, N.J., March 11 -Members of the Dyers and Finishers Employers Association rejected today demands for wage increases and other concessions made by the Federation of Dyers, Finishers, Printers and Bleachers of America, C.I.O.

Mounting shortages in nearly all kinds of textile and notions items have resulted in a decline of as much as 25 to 35 per cent in weekly billings, it was reported yesterday by wholesale distributors. Paradoxically, it was said new orders received have shown as high as 100 per cent gain over the like week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, reported to Congress today that lend-lease aid from the United States to its Allies from March, 1941, through Feb. 28, 1943, amounted to $9,632,000,000, of which $4,430,048,000 went to the United Kingdom, $1,825,600,000 to Russia and $157,805,000 to China.

With the final arrangement of the relay features, the Knights of Columbus Games Committee announced last night the completion of plans for tomorrow night's track meet in Madison Square Garden. It will close the metropolitan indoor season.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The House defeated today an attempt, apparently backed by the Administration, to obtain a separate vote on the part of the Disney bill revoking the President's salary-limitation order, and proceeded to thresh out on the floor throughout the afternoon "the solemn question" of "government by directive as against government by law."

Magazines are beginning to show the effect of the space-buying boom generated by the paper curtailment order which went into effect the first of the year. March issues of monthly magazines showed a 6 per cent gain over the corresponding 1942 issues, while February weeklies were up almost 30 per cent in linage.
John Nicholson, in 48 W 52d St; Lewis Lefkowitz, Herbert F. Zuhr, in 21 E 14th St; Sumner L. Benedict, in 11 W 14th St -- Carstens Linnekin, brokers.

LONDON, March 11 -- Viscount Cranborne, Lord Privy Seal, revealed in the House of Lords today that the British Government had "a secret report" drawn up three weeks ago by a special committee headed by Lord Brabazon, which made certain recommendations designed to safeguard this country's civil aviation interests after the war.

The national campaign of the War Dog Fund, organized to raise money for the purchase of young, trainable dogs for service with the Army and Navy, was assisted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Ellen Hardin Walworth Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Directors of the Creole Petroleum Corporation and of the Lago Petroleum Corporation have under consideration a proposal for consolidating their properties and operations, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by C.H. Lieb, president of both companies.

ANKARA, March 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Adolf Hitler in the past few days has sent notes to all his Southeast European allies setting forth details of Germany's new "total war effort" and demanding that these allies should make similar efforts, according to information received in diplomatic quarters here and disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- High government officials have reached a final agreement that the total personnel of the armed forces should number 10,800,000 men and that this goal could be reached before the year ends, it was disclosed tonight.

While banks in other parts of the country gained excess reserves, those of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $35,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of only $25,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday by the weeky report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- This has been a week of triumph for the Lend-Lease Administrator personally, and for the organization he has built up, as well as for Lend-Lease itself. Future historians, noting that Mr. Stettinius was drafted from the top rank of the biggest kind of big business by the New Deal, doctrinal foe and harsh regulator of that economic group, may find his career a paradox and make a search for its causes.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (U.P.) -- The Navy revealed today that it has begun operating blimps from bases far removed from the Continental United States in an extension of its air war against submarines.

Organized labor already has pledged more than three times as much to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City as the contribution of approximately $150,000 it made last year, yet solicitation for this years fund is not half completed, according to a joint statement released yesterday through war fund headquarters, 130 West Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Friday, March 12 -- The Berlin radio today broadcast a D.N.B. news agency dispatch reporting that the Germans had evacuated Vyazma, great base on the eastern front salient southwest of Moscow.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 11 -- Allied fighter bombers operating from behind the Eighth Army positions yesterday destroyed more than twenty enemy vehicles, downed five Axis planes and helped French forces defeat Nazi units engaging them.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate, by a vote of 49-32, killed today legislation which would require farm workers to produce minimum quantities of essential food or fiber, as individuals, to be deferred from the selective draft.

LONDON, Friday, March 12 (AP) -- A force of heavy bombers so large that it took nearly an hour to cross the English Channel headed for somewhere on the German occupied continent last night as the Royal Air Force kept hammering away at the Axis to soften them up for an expected invasion thrust.

A very interesting Brueghel exhibition opens to the public today at the Metropolitan. At first it may seem a little strange, in that no actual work by the great sixteenth-century Flemish artist is included. That, however, is readily explained.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Six distinguished Flying Crosses and thirteen Air Medals have been awarded to Army Air Force members in the Southwest Pacific by Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of the Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific Area, the War Department announced today.

LONDON, March 11 -- Although they are not required to pay an income tax until about three months after the war or after they return from foreign service, many American soldiers in this theatre have already gone to work on the necessary blanks and are getting rid of the obligation rather than take advantage of the indefinite period of grace.

Miss Gloria Callen of the Women's Swimming Association retained her title in the 100-yard backstroke event, which was one of the five Metropolitan A.A.U. championship tests on the program at the Downtown A.C. last night. Miss Callen beat her clubmate, Miss Betty Shields, by a length, with Miss Barbara Earing of the St. George Dragon Club third. Miss Callen's time was 1:11.9.

CHICAGO, March 11 (U.P.) -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, proposed tonight a 30 per cent withholding tax to meet half of the nation's war spending and strengthen the economic structure against inflation.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- The Russians, maintaining their rapid advance in Smolensk Province, are converging on Vyazma. They were reported fifteen miles from the strategic town this morning and were advancing westward and southwestward from Byelyi, the key to communications in a region of extensive forest and marshlands.

Moscow has been quick to answer Admiral Standley's complaints. Not only did the Soviet news agencies immediately broadcast the latest reports of lend-lease aid to Russia; they even published accounts of the criticism itself. The latter procedure is so unusual that it should dispel misgivings over the effect of the Ambassador's indiscretion on the Soviet Government.

ALBANY, March 11 (U.P.) -- The Public Service Commission told Governor Dewey and the Legislature today that no power shortage was imminent in the metropolitan New York area, but that the picture for up-State New York was vastly different.

TRENTON, March 11 -- State Senate President George H. Stanger, Cumberland County Republican, did not disqualify himself as a member of the Legislature when he accepted employment as counsel to the New Jersey Milk Control Director, Arthur F. Foran, the Court of Errors and Appeals ruled today.

Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw gave a dinner last night at River House before the benefit performance of "Manon" at the Metropolitan Opera for the British War Relief Society. In the party were Mrs. Henry Pierrepont Perry, Mrs. J. Robert Rubin, Mrs. Frederick Ecker, Mrs. Edward R. Tinker, Mrs. Julius W. Noyes and Mrs. Robert Dickey.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Members of a House committee investigating draft deferments of government workers directed their inquiry today at the Office of Price Administration and attacked David Ginsburg, 30-year-old general counsel of the OPA, because he is being considered for an Army commission after having been deferred from the draft as an irreplaceable official.

The offices of the regional Office of Price Administration in New York are at work drafting a new set of temporary price ceilings for seven major vegetables, it was reliably learned last night. They will announce them in the very near future.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The unprecedented sum of $13,000,000,000 is to be borrowed from the people and the banks of the United States in April, it was stated today by Secretary Morgenthau. This compares with $12,000,000,000 borrowed in December, a record at the time.

BOCA GRANDE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- The condition of J.P. Morgan, 75-year-old financier, who has been seriously ill here for more than a week, took a turn for the worse today and grave fears were expressed by his close associates.
Walter H. Pringle, president of the National Federation of the Fur Industry, yesterday characterized as "without foundation" the report that the OPA was suspending ceiling prices on furs.

LONDON, March 11 -- The only answer to the U-boat campaign is more escort vessels and, what is even more important, sufficient aircraft patrol ever a very wide area around convoys during the day, declared Admiral George P. Thomson, chief press censor, speaking at Manchester today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The National Catholic Welfare Conference has established War Relief Services, an organization to aid in postwar reconstruction, the Most Rev. Edward Mooney, Archbishop of Detroit and chairman of the administrative board of the conference, announced today.
In his address delivered at the Conference on Christian Bases of World Order, Vice President Wallace made many statements that are confusing -- none more so than the following:
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Navy announced today thirty-five casualties in Navy forces, including two dead, three wounded and thirty missing.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- Small mill buying and commission house support gave the wheat market a stronger undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, bullish sentiment being helped by reports that Eastern bakers and other interests had purchased 300,000 barrels of flour overnight.

DETROIT, March 11 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation obtained a remarkable confession from 22-year-old Barbara Brown today, how she cleared Detroit streets of more than 2,000 service men by telephone last night.

The two reports of the National Resources Planning Board that the President has forwarded to Congress are enormous in bulk and profoundly disappointing in content. Neither of these programs puts first things first. Neither shows genuine evidence of careful thought.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Consumers, Congress and industry are to have a "court" of appeal in Washington before which to put their criticisms of price and rationing policies and procedures.

Four boys on their way to the Kips Bay Boys Club for a swim last night were struck by an automobile as they attempted, arm in arm, to cross Second Avenue near Fifty-third. One was killed, two others injured seriously and the fourth escaped with bruises.

There are plenty of good, clean hotel accommodations available for service men, provided they go north of Fifty-seventh Street, Mayor La Guardia was informed yesterday in a telegram from a joint committee of hotel men, headed by Paul Stockhammer.
LONDON, March 11 -- The stock markets here remained today under the restraining influence of "Wings for Victory" Week, and gilt-edge issues were easier and home rails declined.

Secretary Stimson's radio speech of March 9 should put an end to criticism or even discussion of the size of the American Army. He speaks with "authority and not as the Scribes." All the points raised in your leading editorial on Feb. 26 are answered definitively.

Apartment dwellers, particularly in outlying parts of the Bronx, who have been carried by private bus between their doorstep and the subway station may have to walk soon unless the Office of Defense Transportation finds the distance involves real hardship, it developed yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, March 12 (AP) -- Forty Japanese planes raided Oro Bay below Buna in New Guinea and fourteen were shot out of action, the Allied High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Authority to start rationing of meats, cheese, edible fats and oils (including butter) and canned fish "on or before April 1" was given the Office of Price Administration tonight by Secretary Wickard. Details of the point rationing program under which Prentiss M. Brown will conduct the rationing will be made public in twenty-four hours, OPA officials said.
Secretary Wickard directed the OPA to start rationing meat, butter and cheese on or about April 1. [1:1.]

Tentative plans for a huge oceanarium or aquarium, to be constructed after the war on a site owned by the city adjacent to the Coney Island Boardwalk, just west of Seaside Park, and to house the nation's most comprehensive exhibit of marine and fresh-water life, have been made by the city and the New York Zoological Society, it was disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- An attempt by the Associated Electric Company to buy in privately $2,222,000 of its own bonds at half the face amount was opposed strenuously by the Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission today as an unprecedented scheme lacking a rational basis.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Members of Congress took widely diverse views today on the two reports of the National Resources Planning Board sent to them yesterday by President Roosevelt.

Regardless of what is done in Washington in the pending tax discussion, Federal income-tax returns must be filed in person or by mail on or before midnight March 15. The returns must be filed with the appropriate collector of internal revenue for the district in which is located the legal residence or principal place of business of the person making the return.

The House vote of 407 to 6 and the unanimous vote of the Senate in favor of extending the Lend-Lease Act another year are notification to all concerned that though differences of opinion as to many issues do exist in this country, there is no substantial difference of opinion as to the need for prosecuting the war.

It was a sparkling show with globe-encircling themes that took possession of the luncheon hour in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel yesterday. Dramatized fashions kept a buzz of excitement and a ripple of applause going for its half hour duration.

In an ingenious attempt to evade capture; an undersized hold-up suspect took refuge yesterday among the 100 worshippers in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-second Street.
r,y, 12 I -- The midnight communiqug a,s l broadcast by Moscow:

Election to Phi Beta Kappa of thirty-four students of the University College of Arts and Pure Sciences of New York University was announced yesterday. Eighteen of the students are members of the class of '43, and sixteen are from the class of '44.

Elias A. Cohen, a large owner of real estate in the downtown area, yesterday extended control of a holding in the center of the shipping industry by purchasing the eighteen-story Importers and Traders Building, on a plot 45 by 115 feet at 24 Stone Street, running through to 59 Pearl Street.

The second warm spell of an unusually snowy Winter has made the outlook for good skiing this weekend somewhat discouraging. The Weather Man brought six to fifteen inches of new snow to the North Country last week-end, but he has sent the temperatures rising since with the result that wet and soggy surfaces are to be found on most slopes and trails.
LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -An aerial combat looks "just like a dozen bees in a tightly sealed jar."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 11 (AP) -- City Judge Henry W. Clement sentenced George Tahamont of 364 Emerson Avenue to ten days in the Union County Jail today on a charge of drunk and disorderly conduct after Tahamont had testified to losing three days' work in the last two weeks at a war plant.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 11 (AP) -- The Saratoga Springs Chamber of Commerce has urged Governor Dewey to support "racing as usual" at the Spa this Summer, contending a meeting could be held "without violating essential OPA and ODT regulations.''
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 11 (AP) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 11 -- While in Paris the French police are rounding up young men to ascertain whether they are liable for compulsory labor either in France or in Germany, other Frenchmen are throwing bombs at German soldiers and sailors. There is reason to suppose that both events are directly related.

Eggs are indeed a boon to housekeepers in these critical times, for they are plentiful at present and will increase in supply until May and June, the peak of their season. One authority estimates that this year's production, which is running far ahead of estimates, tops that of last year by 10 to 12 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Numerous textile yarn and fabric mills have advised the WPB textile, clothing and leather division that they are planning new operating schedules to increase production -- some by longer hours and some by more shifts -- Frank L. Walton, director of the division, said today.

THE big fellows return to Madison Square Garden tonight, and nothing quickens the pulse beat of the average fight follower as much as the spectacle of a pair of heavyweights doing reconstruction jobs on each other's features. Tami Mauriello and Jimmy Bivins are the villains in Mike Jacobs's newest production and, as usual, it will be performed before another full house.

LONDON, Friday, March 12 (AP) -- Outnumbered Russian troops killed 1,200 Germans and destroyed thirty-six tanks yesterday in the violently unfolding third battle for Kharkov, but a midnight Moscow bulletin spoke ominously of an "unequal engagement" and said "the Germans are bringing up more fresh reserves."

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 8, under the headline "Dr. Coffin Backed for Church Post," there is a most unfortunate implication. This arises from the following paragraph [quoting a supporter of the Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott]:

Mrs. Jean Rhein Crisswell had undergone four and one-half hours of cross-examination yesterday as a State witness in the General Sessions first-degree murder trial of two men, alleged to have ordered the shooting of Harry Nichols, a Williamsburg gambling "overlord," on an East Side subway station more than nine years ago, when she collapsed in the witness chair.

New municipal financing next week will amount to $2,918,500, representing the requirements of twelve communities throughout the country, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $8,776,000 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $23,258,907.

Columbia Grammar, defending champion in the eighteenth annual swimming meet of the A.A.P.S., last night retained the title with a team total of 35 points in the finals of a two-day meet in the Columbia University pool.
The menus appearing today -- the third set in a series that dates from the start of point rationing -- are built, first of all, around foods that are generally available and comparatively cheap.

Representatives of thirty major women's organizations and a number of individual women leaders yesterday formed a new women's organization to work for "full American participation in international organization." The action was taken at the end of an all-day meeting held at the instigation of an Interim Planning Committee of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A "sales-minded" executive of national reputation is being sought by the Office of Price Administration to serve as second in command to Prentiss M. Brown, Administrator.
