He would take the place of John Hamm, deputy administrator, who served under Leon Henderson but submitted his resignation early this week.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 12 -- The military crisis on the Eastern Front has not yet been mastered and German thoughts must converge on the Winter that is to follow this Spring and Summer, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, warned readers of the magazine Reich this week.

THE advancing years have slowed down Frank Brennan to such an extent that the impressionable impresario of tonight's Knights of Columbus track meet believes his Columbian Mile will be run in only 4:06. There was a time when the frank Frank used to forecast "a four-minute mile or under." That was always said with cigar clenched firmly in teeth, a visionary look in the Brennan eyes and a grandiloquent wave of the right hand.

LONDON, March 12 -- Evidence of official British Government information regarding dissatisfaction among Reichsfuehrer Hitler's satellite allies came today in a speech at Croydon by Dingle Foot, parliamentary secretary to the Ministry of Economics Warfare, when he said:
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- The deal that sent First Baseman Nick Etten from the Phillies to the Yankees several months ago may be canceled, it was disclosed today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12 -- That the peril to neutral ships in the South Atlantic from Axis submarines does not apply to Argentine vessels is implied by the declaration of an Argentinian naval attache here. Germany broadcast a few days ago that all ships in inter American trade would be sunk.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 12 -- About 125 newspapers and 1,000 other periodicals in Germany will disappear for the duration of the war to release their journalists and printers, many of whom have been exempt, for military service or work in munitions factories, it was reported from Berlin tonight by the S.T.B. news agency.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Curiosity about what has happened to Adolf Hitler went up another notch today when Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said the State Department had received unconfirmed reports that the Riechsfuehrer was suffering from a complete breakdown.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday approved the proposed ten-round bout between Henry Armstrong, only boxer in the history of the ring ever to hold three championships at the same time, and Beau Jack, world lightweight title-holder, in Madison Square Garden, April 2.

Assessed valuations of real estate in New York still are too high, despite the reduction effected from $19,000,000,000 to about $16,000,000,000 in recent years, in the opinion of Henry Breuere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank.

CLEVELAND, March 12 -- Thousands of war plant workers in the Cleveland area are assuming a "come-and-get-me" attitude toward the income tax collector, Frank F. Gentsch, collector of internal revenue, said today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 12 (AP) -- A communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Harold Lloyd's first production under his Columbia contract will be "Mr. Winkle Goes to War," from the novel by Theodore Pratt, who will come to Hollywood to write the screen play. The humorous story deals with a 44-year-old inductee in the Army with the 18 to 19-year-old class.

To meet the constantly growing wartime demand for Girl Scout troops, particularly in industrial and Army camp communities, the Girl Scouts of America yesterday opened a nation-wide campaign for group leaders. Announcement of the appeal coincided with the organization's thirty-first anniversary and was launched following a two-day board meeting at its national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Byrd committee recommended today that the Department of Agriculture immediately discontinue the lending activities of the Regional Agricultural Credit Corporation through which Secretary Wickard recently offered farmers $225,000,000 in one-year, 5 per cent loans for the production of war crops.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- No official clarification was available here today regarding the status or future of the twelve sailors from the North African part of the French Fleet who are held at Ellis Island or of others who have been leaving those ships to join the Fighting French section of the French naval forces.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12, -- In order to readjust its transmission system to make up for the conveyance of part of its Texas property to the Defense Plant Corporation, the Houston Gulf Gas Company has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to revamp its financial obligations to the First National Bank of Boston.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- Woodrow (Porky) Dumart was a one-man team when a bomber squadron commanded by Wing Commander Henry Carscallen of Hamilton, Ont., won the Royal Canadian Air Force Hockey championship of northern England.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12 (AP) -- Lawreence D. Bell, president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, predicted today in a letter to stockholders that 1943 production of both new and improved models of Airacobra fighters and ordnance devices will greatly exceed that of 1942."

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Point rationing of meats, cheese, edible fats and oils (including butter) and canned fish will start at 12:01 A.M. Monday, March 29, the Office of Price Administration said today.

Upon reading of the passing of Jimmy Collins, I recalled a play I saw this great third baseman make at the Polo Grounds that somewhat indicates the shrewd and quick-thinking ability of the old-time ball players. They certainly majored in keeping their minds and eyes on the game.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Invincible in seven dual meets this season, Navy's well balanced squad launched a strong bid for additional prestige today as the thirty-ninth annual Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championships opened in the Palestra at the University of Pennsylvania.
Signing of ten new leases in the Buchanan apartments, at 160 East Forty-eight Street, was announced yesterday by Henry Weiner, trustee, through Pease Elliman, agents.

Babies arriving on the present upswing in vital statistics, may be born amid the grim realities of war, but when it comes to naming them, their fathers and mothers follow an old established custom: Romantic names for the girls, true and tried names for their sons.

Warning them that all their tasks will not be "glamorous," Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon-General of the Public Health Service, yesterday told 239 members of the first class of merchant marine pharmacists mates ever graduated in the country to remember while on the high seas that they have not yet the skills of experiencd physicians and surgeons.

LONDON, March 12 -- Examination today of air reconnaissance photographs taken after the United States Eighth Air Force's daylight raid on the important U-boat base of Lorient, France, on March 6 proved conclusively the deadly accuracy of the aim of the American bombers equipped with the uncanny Norden bomb sight.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Shipments of petroleum products from the United States to Spain during the last two years, the House was informed today, totaled 245,118 metric tons (roughly 1,942,000 barrels) and were made with the understanding that the products would not leave Spanish territory.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (U.P.) -- Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information, in the first of a series of analyses on the war situation, said tonight that Germany was waging tactical offensives in Southern Russia and Tunisia in the futile hope of preventing the Allies from launching their grand offensive.

With five of the seven categories registering gains, total advertising linage in newspapers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records rose 8.7 per cent last month over the corresponding 1942 period. This increase brought the two-month gain to 7.2 per cent.

The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound will set dates for the Summer championship series regattas of the various member clubs at a meeting listed for March 31, it was made known yesterday. The session will be held in the New York Yacht Club.
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

RZHEV, Russia, March 12 (U.P.) -- American and British fighters, bombers and tanks are playing a part in the powerful Red Army offensive on the central front, Colonel Yacoff Dimitrieff, assistant chief of staff lieutenant with Lieut. Gen. Kolpahky's army, which recaptured Rzhev, told American and British correspondents tonight.

As the Germans hurl reinforcements into the third great battle for Kharkov, it is natural that a new demand for a second front in Europe should arise in Moscow. The Nazis are still being driven back in the center, but their strong counter-offensive in the south proves that the Winter retreat was not voluntary or "according to plan."

WASHINGTON, March 12 (U.P.) -- The American Government is determined to stop sailors from leaving the French Battleship Richelieu and other French warships now in United States ports, an authoritative source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 173 United States Army officers and enlisted men wounded in action in the European, North African and South Pacific areas.

I wish to take issue with your editorial conclusion of March 6 that the so-called youth correction bill is a forward-looking measure. It is, in so far as it seeks to strip the courts of this State of their sentencing power, a revolutionary step in the wrong direction.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

Another 144 families living in the vicinity of the recently established training center for women at Hunter College in the Bronx will have to move to new homes to make way for the expanding women's Navy groups. This was announced yesterday after Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe had signed an order condemning apartment buildings at 2745 Reservoir Avenue, and 2824 and 2845 University Avenue, for use by the Navy.

AS a novelist, Walter Duranty is a good familiar essayist. His "Search for a Key"* breaks every rule of the fiction writer's craft, yet it pulls the reader along in the wake of a lot of good conversation about everything under the sun. Mr. Duranty is an Englishman, a newspaper correspondent, and a man who hurt his leg badly in an accident.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 12 -- Reports from the Haute Savoie frontier tell of the spread of tension and disorder aroused by the Vichy government's recruiting of labor for Germany. A report from Annemasse states that of 800 youths summoned by the authorities only 150 appeared and fewer than a dozen accepted jobs in Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt said today that the burden of planning now the social and economic cushions for protecting the country against the slacks and let-downs of the postwar period rested entirely on Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary Ickes, the Petroleum Administrator, said today that East Coast petroleum supplies reached an all-time low mark during the week ended March 3. He added, however, that by using petroleum products carefully it would be possible to squeeze through the heating season.
BOCA GRANDE, Fla., Saturday, March 13 -- The manager of the Gasparilla Hotel said today that J.P. Morgan, famed international financier, died at 3:10 A.M.

The Rev. Richard Pitman Mallery, for the last five years pastor of the historic Reformed Church, Walden, Orange County, N.Y., has accepted a call to the pastorate of the First Church of Kew Gardens, Reformed, in Queens. He and his wife and two little sons will move down to Kew Gardens Monday and he will be formally installed at 4 P.M. Sunday, March 21.

Joseph Rabushka, 14-year-old violinist from St. Louis, made his first appearance on the concert stage in a recital given last night at Town Hall. The natural, unspoiled boy made known a genuine gift for his chosen instrument, and played with a poise and security all the more remarkable at an initial performance.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, British West Indies, March 12 -- Conditions on the island of Martinique are described as "too terrible" by George Lardaux, a former citizen of the French possession, who has just reached here with his wife and 8-month-old child.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange jumped last month from 579,394 to 663,750 shares, the largest total reported since May 31, 1939. Neither figure included short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which changed hardly at all between the settlement date of Jan. 29 and that of Feb. 26.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Unusually heavy air raids against the Japanese entrenched on Kiska Island in the Aleutians have been carried out by United States aircraft operating in the North Pacific area, a Navy communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt suffered a severe rebuke from the House of Representatives today for alleged "usurpation" of legislative powers when, by a vote of 268 to 129, it passed the Disney bill to raise the debt limit, with a rider to revoke the President's order limiting salaries to $25,000 net.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The White House announced the arrival of Anthony Eden in Washington; President Roosevelt conferred with a group of Representatives, met the Cabinet and held his press conference; his visitors included the Norwegian Minister and Trygve Lie, T.V. Soong and Secretary Ickes.

Silas Wegg, the literary man in "Our Mutual Friend," charged Mr. Boffin so much an hour for reading aloud out of Gibbon's "Decline-and-Fall-off-the-Rooshan Empire." But it was agreed that on occasions when Mr. Wegg was moved to drop into poetry the fee should be higher, because of the greater strain on the vocal organs, said Mr. Wegg.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Loyd Converse, 42, who walked all night through a blizzard in subzero weather in order to get to work and then put in an extra shift, received congratulations today from Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Permanent maximum prices were fixed on corn by the Office of Price Administration today, covering the country's largest farm crop at every stage of distribution from the farmer to retail dealers. The permanent maximums are about the same as the temporary "freeze" levels imposed Jan. 11, last, to curb soaring corn prices.

A new plastic, Thermo-Cast, which aircraft companies using it predict will eventually increase plane production by 50 per cent, was demonstrated yesterday by its developer, Dr. James M. Church, Professor of Chemical Engineering, at a meeting of the Columbia Scholastic Press convention in McMillin Academic Theatre.

The Nutrition Foundation, Inc., organized last year, has authorized grants for research totaling $148,550 for 1943, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, president of the foundation, following a meeting of the board of directors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Liquidation and stop-loss selling developed today in the grain markets on the Chicago Board of Trade and wheat broke nearly 2 cents a bushel and rye more than that amount before short covering was able to stem the tide.

Flowers are literally turning green this week-end, according to the New York State Department of Markets. Flower shop windows will be filled with "a bit of Irish" between now and March 17. Customers may take their choice of emerald-toned carnations, gardenias or sweet peas for the traditional wearing of the green or to decorate the mantel vase.

After hearing a personal appeal by Senator Thomas C. Desmond for support of his bill pending in the Legislature to provide $150,000,000 in State loans now to communities for post-war public housing, representatives of fourteen civic and welfare organizations adopted yesterday a resolution favoring the adoption of the measure or a similar one.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- During the ten years since the "bank holiday" of 1933, the banks of the United States have recovered to the strongest asset position of record and are ready to meet any war demands that may be made, it was announced officially today.

Margaret Bourke-White, widely known photographer and author of "Shooting the Russian War," will describe her experiences covering the American Expeditionary Forces in North Africa this morning at Town Hall. Miss Bourke-White was rescued recently from a raft in mid-Atlantic after having been afloat for three days after the torpedoing of her ship, en route to North Africa.

Many small fruit and vegetable stores, stand holders in City Markets and peddlers are complaining of difficulty in getting fruits and vegetables from wholesale dealers who appear to give preference, so far as their supplies are concerned, to chain stores and large retailers, the Department of Markets reported yesterday.
Oscar Tschirky had a faraway look in his eyes yesterday as silent waiters in the Waldorf-Astoria offered cocktails and dainties at the party marking his fiftieth anniversary as host of the hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- For the second time in five months Wendell L. Willkie urged the Supreme Court today not to cancel the citizenship of William Schneiderman, secretary of the Communist party of California. Solicitor General Fahy insisted upon upholding revocation of Mr. Schneiderman's naturalization in 1927.

The temporary authorization for the balance of this month by the Office of Price Administration of an increase of one-half cent a quart in price of home-delivered milk in the metropolitan area calls attention once more to a serious problem. Milk, in its various forms, has been widely accepted as the most nearly perfect food.

Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, president and general manager of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday a net profit of $1,885,503, or $3.28 a share for 1942, comparing with $1,609,706, or $2.81 a share, earned in 1941, an increase of 16.7 per cent.

The stock market erased yesterday what losses had remained from the corrective period, and, stimulated by a volume that approached 2,000,000 shares, prices rose fractions to 2 points. Assured by no less an authority than Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, that the market was in "a healty condition" -- a term which he used in reporting to President Roosevelt -- buyers reentered the market in force.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that it was opposed to an increase of the city sales tax to 2 per cent, declaring that the $41,000,000 in budgetary needs claimed by Mayor La Guardia actually stands reduced to $18,500,000 because of savings already accrued.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Though repulsing a succession of powerful German attacks on Kharkov's southern defenses, the Russians have been forced to yield ground west of the city, where their positions were stormed by waves of tanks, closely followed by infantry, according to today's reports.
TRENTON, March 12 (AP) -- Three women serving sentences for murder are among 480 prisoners seeking paroles at the April term of the New Jersey Court of Pardons.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, arrived in Washington tonight for momentous conferences on war and post-war problems with President Roosevelt, Wendell L. Willkie and other leaders.

BOSTON, March 12 (AP) -- Jack Shewchuk, big defense man who enlisted in the Canadian Army last week, rejoined the Boston Bruins during today's practice session and thrilled them with the announcement that he had received a short furlough.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A 5 per cent increase in planting allotments for burley, flue-cured, fire-cured and dark air-cured tobacco is expected to be announced soon by Agriculture Secretary Wickard.

The world's largest biscuit bakery was honored for its war production yesterday when the National Biscuit Company plant at 425 West Fifteenth Street was presented with the Army and Navy E pennant for excellence. In a large room on the second floor of the plant, which is the largest manufacturing unit in Manhattan, 4,000 employes gathered for the ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt said today at his press conference that he planned to confer in a few days with Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific and hero of the Bismarck Sea battle.

The conference of representatives of the United Mine Workers and bituminous operators of the Northern Appalachian region called to negotiate a new agreement affecting 450,000 soft-coal diggers adjourned at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday until Monday amid threats of a strike from spokesmen for the miners.

Our city sales tax was instituted to relieve hardships arising from local unemployment during the depression and was borne patiently for this reason, although it placed a burden on business to collect it, led to the establishment of a considerable bureaucracy to check it and was often a nuisance to the public.
OTTAWA, March 12 -- Air Force headquarters today gave a detailed description of the Lindholme rescue gear and said it soon would be in use on the east and west coasts of Canada.

LONDON, March 12 -- For the second time in a week, American heavy bombers today attacked the railway and supply center of Rouen, France, following a heavy night assault by the Royal Air Force on Stuttgart, industrial and communications point in Southwest Germany.

A group of nine projects, including reconstruction of the northeast corner of Central Park, development of a ten-acre athletic field in the Bronx, installing boating facilities at a basin for small craft off Inwood Hill Park and the building of six playgrounds in various parts of the city are called for in contracts on which the Park Department opened bids yesterday.

Reapportionment of the State's Senate districts, long overdue, seemed to be placed in double jeopardy yesterday when a conference of Democratic legislative and county leaders of the metropolitan district held that the bill before the Legislature was unconstitutional.

An indication of the cost of the social insurance phase alone in a post-war security program was given yesterday at the closing session of the National Conference of Social Work in the Hotel Pennsylvania. An extended social insurance plan, it was estimated, would involve payroll contributions of 10 to 12 per cent.

The preliminary report of Postal Telegraph, Inc., for 1942, released yesterday, shows that the communications system had a net loss of $4,209,209 last year, after operating expenses, depreciation and other charges. This compared with a net loss of $3,037,900 in 1941.

Leading all the way, La Salle Academy's speedy five captured the city C.H.S.A.A. basketball championship last night by beating Mount St. Michael High, 47 to 37, in the final play-off at the Fordham University gymnasium last night.

The campaign to obtain $12,920,700 here for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund has advanced to the point where a report of progress will be made at the meeting Monday night in Madison Square Garden, it was announced yesterday by C.M. Chester, general chairman of the campaign.

Inspired by a day containing more than a hint of Spring and a sportsman's magazine containing photographs of fishermen in action on lake and stream, John Curasamo, 13 years old, and Frank Cinque, 14, left the troutless precincts of the Gowanus Canal yesterday for the rushing streams of the Catskills with fishing rods on their shoulders and hope in their hearts that they could get there by thumbing rides.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A coalition of Democratic and Republican Senators swamped Administration efforts today to get funds for a high school "Victory Corps" headed by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and for the care of children of working mothers on the ground that Congress had not authorized these projects.
CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -- The largest field of the indoor track season -- 421 athletes from twenty-four colleges and twelve universities -- will compete in the fifteenth annual Tech Relays tomorrow.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Waiter struck from the court calendar yesterday an injunction suit brought against Police Commissioner Valentine to restrain him from prohibiting the taking of photographs in night clubs. The suit was brought by Richards Hassen Enterprises, Inc., which was later joined as a plaintiff by the C. E. and M. E. Concessions Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt, who twice this year has endorsed the principle of pay-as-you-go taxation, struck out at his present conference today against the most popular pay-as-you-go plan, the one originated by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, as primarily benefiting persons with large incomes.

A dispatch from Chungking says that work has begun on a Chinese translation of the Encyclopaedia Britannica. This announcement is interesting for a number of reasons, of which not the least is the fact that both dictionary and encyclopedia are Chinese inventions.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold nine properties in Brooklyn, according to the John J. Mattia Realty Corporation, broker in the sales. They are as follows: the four-family house at 421 Third Street sold to A. Cona, O.F. Peterson, co-broker; the three-story building at 91 St. Marks Avenue, to Attilio Piccirillo, Louis Bacotti, co-broker; the three-story building at 299 Seventh Street to Angelo Assante.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, March 13 (AP) -- The noon communique:
" When I came down here I found the younger women so active and quick. Now I can keep up with any of them."

PHILADELPHIA March 12 -- Four members of the Jehovah Witnesses and three other men were sentenced to five years in a Federal penitentiary today in Federal court here on charges of violating the Selective Service Law.

HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., March 12 -- William Harrison Woodruff, who resigned because of ill health as director of the New Brunswick Division of the Rutgers University College a year ago, ended his life by hanging today in the cellar of his home at 125 Graham Street, here, according to Coroner Raymond J. Sheenan.

The New York Victory Fund Committee, of which Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is chairman, and of which Perry E. Hall, on leave of absence from Morgan Stanley Co., is executive manager, laid the groundwork yesterday for the preliminary organization campaign to be conducted before the new war loan drive begins April 12.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12 (U.P.) -- An enemy submarine torpedoed and sank an American merchant ship in the mid-Atlantic late in January, survivors reported upon arrival here. All crew members and passengers of the medium-sized cargo vessel survived the early morning attack.

Existing stocks of rayon hosiery should be exempted at once from the OPA's new regulation No. 339 to prevent unjustified markdowns as well as waste of manpower that would be needed to affix the required markings on each pair, it was declared yesterday by leading producers and distributors.

The lawn of the Charles M. Schwab estate, occupying a square block at Riverside Drive from Seventy-third to Seventy-fourth Street, for years one of the show places of New York, will be dug up next week to make three victory gardens, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Vernon Lamson, landscape architect, chairman of the Victory Garden Council of the Greater New York CDVO.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -- The Soviet mid-day communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Track and field addicts will have their last fling of the Winter tonight when the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, holds its twenty-fourth annual meet in Madison Square Garden. Director Frank A. Brennan, in his exhortation to hurry, hurry to the box office, says it also may be the last Garden meet for the duration.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 12 (AP) -- Three youthful Naval gunners told today about a two-week lifeboat voyage that carried them and seventy-four other survivors 1,200 miles after their medium-sized American freighter was sunk by a submarine.

A woman who kidnapped a month-old baby from her carriage near 65 West 104th Street yesterday afternoon abandoned the child early today in the vestibule of a five-story tenement at 156 West Sixty-second Street. The baby was unharmed, but hungry.

The nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it had received forty-one suggestions for its draft of a slate for the annual elections in May. Of most interest was the suggestion of Robert P. Boylan, former vice chairman, for the soon-to-be-vacated post of chairman of the board.
With baseball's belated training season now only forty-eight hours away, there was no end of bustle and to-do yesterday in the offices of the three local major league clubs.

In observance of Lent, which began last Wednesday, twenty churches of different Protestant faiths west of Central Park will participate in a "United Preaching Mission" beginning tomorrow and continuing for the five successive Sundays in the penitential season.

With the number of taxpayers calling at offices of the Collectors of Internal Revenue in this area well over the 100,000 mark yesterday, tax officials were still able to report last night that their staffs were taking the unprecedented flood of work in their stride. Joseph T. Higgins and Captain William J. Pedrick, collectors in Manhattan, reiterated their request, however, that returns be mailed in, by check or money order.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Controversy and debate tangled the Senate today as it attempted to rush to passage draft deferments for farm workers and finally plans for action this week were abandoned.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 12 -- The Rommel forces have been defeated in the battle of Ksar Rhilane, southwest of the Mareth Line in Tunisia, and are in retreat. Patrols of Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc's French column which, it develops, fought beside the British in the battle, are advancing on the heels of the retreating enemy, who is being pounded by Boston bombers and strafed by Spitfires.

LONDON, March 12 -- Following recent French guerrilla activities, the French National Committee under General Charles de Gaulle today broadcast from London a new call to the French people to "oppose by obstruction and sabotage" attempts to send French workers to Germany.

CHUNGKING, China, March 12 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces in Northern Hunan Province have pushed forward from the recently captured city of Hwajung, a Chinese communique announced tonight. Front dispatches said the invaders were throwing strong reinforcements into their drive on strategic Changsha.

Retail trade here was active this week, but the percentage of gain over a year ago continued to narrow. Department store volume was estimated at about 10 per cent above the comparative week of 1942. This would tend to support the view that scare buying is tapering off, but on the other hand, merchants pointed out, the increase is on top of high March figures a year ago.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- With a grin, President Roosevelt opened the doors wide today for speculation that he might be planning a war strategy conference with Premier Stalin of Soviet Russia.

Nine women and three men had been chosen yesterday as the jury for the trial in General Sessions of William Gardner, a 21-year-old Negro garage attendant, charged with the robbery and rape of a woman resident of Tudor City, when Gardner told his lawyer, Edward T. Tighe of the Voluntary Defenders, he wanted to plead guilty.

A number of artists have contributed pictures to be sold for half the usual price at the Fiesta of the United Nations, to be held next week-end for the benefit of the American Red Cross War Fund, at the galleries of the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

" Let's Face It!" the successful Herbert and Dorothy Fields-Cole Porter musical show, will close its run after next Saturday's performance, it was learned yesterday. It opened Oct. 29, 1941, closed for a month's vacation last Summer and, when it departs, will have given 547 performances.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The War Production Board announced today that in halting the construction of equipment for the production and purification of butadiene at three refineries it had acted on a recommendation by Rubber Director William M. Jeffers.

LONDON, March 12 -- The first concrete step toward the elimination of those divergencies of viewpoint that have impaired Allied unity in the political and diplomatic spheres was taken by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden on his journey to Washington.

LONDON, March 12 -- The "Wings for Victory" campaign kept the stock markets quiet again today, as all efforts are being put forth to make it a complete success. Gilt-edge stocks were firm nevertheless, and the war loan 3 1/2 per cents rose 1-16 to 105 1/2.

Westchester County will have three tons of trout released in its waters within the next two weeks, and the first lot is to be taken care of tomorrow, according to word from Melville C. Rosch, secretary of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association.

Liquidation, either of long hedges or of long speculative accounts, caused the cotton futures market to lose ground yesterday, but trade covering on the dip exercised a steadying influence. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed near the day's low levels at net losses of 1 to 5 points, the fourth successive day that the market ended moderately lower.
CHUNGKING, March 12 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique:
LONDON, March 12 (AP) -- A later Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt declined to comment today on the Moscow statement of Admiral William H. Standley, the American Ambassador, that the Russian people were not being told the extent of American lend-lease aid to Russia.

The United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association's action at its recent meeting designating a committee to visit Army and Navy leaders and urge the sport's inclusion in training camp athletic programs strikes me as a good idea.

Rebuilt steel baby carriages, which have been requested by some consumers in preference to the "victory" wooden type, have been selling in many of the smaller stores at prices far in excess of original cost, it was reported yesterday.

The United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association's action at its recent meeting designating a committee to visit Army and Navy leaders and urge the sport's inclusion in training camp athletic programs strikes me as a good idea.

Rebuilt steel baby carriages, which have been requested by some consumers in preference to the "victory" wooden type, have been selling in many of the smaller stores at prices far in excess of original cost, it was reported yesterday.

Industrial and railroad financing offset an absence of tax-exempt issues in the market for new investments here this week. Two flotations, one an industrial and the other a carrier loan, aggregating $7,960,000 were offered for public subscription, compared with eleven emissions, most of them tax-free, totaling $35,220,000 in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (U.P.) -- Japan is permitting lend-lease shipments from the United States for use against her Axis partner, Germany, to move in Russian ships unmolested across the Pacific and past her back door into Siberia, it was disclosed today.

Working mothers with young children to care for will not be much interested in a controversy between Albany and Washington over the delays in grants of Federal money for childcare centers. They will be very much interested in the decision arrived at in Albany to allocate $5,000,000 of State funds for this purpose.

New York sports fans welcomed Corporal Barney Ross home from Guadalcanal last night in Madison Square Garden and made an anti-climax of a heavyweight boxing bout that was spectacular in its own right.

Since the Red Cross movement was born out of the boundless compassion and energy of Henri Dunant it has been first and foremost a nursing service for the wounded in battle. When that youthful Swiss visited the battlefield of Solferino in 1859 he was aghast at the appalling neglect of the suffering men left by the armies.

Instances multiply alarmingly of fatal and other serious accidents to pedestrians and motorists in the streets of the city due to the special hazards of the dimout. A boy and two men were killed on one night this week in two accidents which appear to have been directly attributable to the bad conditions of visibility in the streets.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Roosevelt reaffirmed and emphasized a policy of the United Nations today by endorsing at his press conference the broadcast of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to Japanese occupied Thailand on Feb. 26 assuring the Thai people that China and her allies had no territorial ambitions there.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 12 (AP) -- Eight squads will send their star contestants into the Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championships in the Rutgers University pool tomorrow, but Coach Jim Reilly of the home team says the race for the team title is between Rutgers and undefeated Temple University.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator Hill of Alabama told the Senate today that David Ginsburg, general counsel for the Office of Price Administration, whose prospective commission in the Army is under Congressional criticism, never asked deferment from the draft.

Three to four times the normal number of shoes are pouring into repair shops these days, as the public, feeling the sobering effects of rationing, is rediscovering shops that will restore ill-fitting or worn pairs to their wardrobes. Since that pinch old styles and scuffed leathers are brought in to be renovated or remodeled and to provide their owners with footwear over and beyond the three new pairs the law allows.

There has been an increase in the aggregate short position on the New York Stock Exchange, indicating that some investors feel that the current advance has proceeded too far without a major reaction -- but indicating nothing else. Safeguards about the market now prevent bear raids.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Mayor La Guardia, who has been away from his office all week, except for two hours on Wednesday, is suffering from a streptococcus infection of the throat, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, disclosed yesterday, confirming an announcement by Lester B. Stone, the Mayor's executive secretary.

At the same time that Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley declared that the Live Poultry Market -- source of the annual $60,000,000 kosher poultry trade -- was in danger of closing because of price difficulties and acute shortages, his department yesterday haled before a hearing some seventy-five alleged price-ceiling violators.
Few Congressional committees have ever fumbled a job so badly as the House Ways and Means Committee in dealing with the pay-as-you-go proposal and the problem of a withholding tax.

LONDON, Saturday, March 13 -- The Red Army captured Vyazma and killed 9,000 Germans yesterday in the powerful central front sweep toward the Nazi anchor of Smolensk, but in the south Moscow announced another withdrawal in the critical third battle for Kharkov, which the Germans said was the scene of a bitter street struggle.
TORONTO, March 12 (AP) -- Gaye Stewart of the Toronto Maple Leafs was named the National Hockey League's outstanding rookie of the season tonight. He will receive the Calder Trophy.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 12 -- "It need not necessarily take a tougher girl to make a marine than it does to make a Wave," admitted Major Edward Hutter Hurst of the United States Marine Corps, commanding officer of the new marine contingent which is arriving tomorrow at Mount Holyoke College.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, March 13 (AP) -- Allied airmen scored a direct hit on a 7,000-ton Japanese merchant ship and shot down four of eight intercepting enemy fighters at Ambon, on the island of Amboina, north of Australia, a communique said today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) -- Bayridge, idle since last September, clattered to a half-length victory today in the six-furlong Solomons Purse for 4-year-olds and upward at the Fair Grounds, returning $20.80 for $2.

ATLANTA, March 12 -- The United States Fleet today is many times more powerful than before the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor and "the torrent of power is steadily growing," Secretary Knox said tonight in an address in the Atlanta Auditorium as part of a bond rally.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 12 -- "It need not necessarily take a tougher girl to make a marine than it does to make a Wave," admitted Major Edward Hutter Hurst of the United States Marine Corps, commanding officer of the new marine contingent which is arriving tomorrow at Mount Holyoke College.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, March 13 (AP) -- Allied airmen scored a direct hit on a 7,000-ton Japanese merchant ship and shot down four of eight intercepting enemy fighters at Ambon, on the island of Amboina, north of Australia, a communique said today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) -- Bayridge, idle since last September, clattered to a half-length victory today in the six-furlong Solomons Purse for 4-year-olds and upward at the Fair Grounds, returning $20.80 for $2.

MONTREAL, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian shipments of newsprint in February amounted to 222,383 tons and were 42,238 tons, or 16 per cent lower, than in the corresponding month in 1942, the Newsprint Association of Canada announced today in its regular monthly report.

Barney Ross was the particular idol of New York's boxing public last night. The former lightweight and welterweight champion of the world, now a corporal in the United States Marines, stepped into the ring at Madison Square Garden to the accompaniment of as sincere and moving an outburst of cheering as has ever been heard there.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Dewey today appointed Archie O. Dawson as a Moreland Commissioner to investigate conditions at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens where an epidemic of amoebic dysentry already has caused the death of several mental patients.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Following is the official list of foods that will and will not be rationed under the new meats-cheese-fats program:

WITH meat, cheese and other rationing to start in another two weeks, food distribution is the trouble spot in the retail situation. Shortage and point rationing of canned goods have already reduced volume to critical levels, and dealer mortality is rising sharply.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Although Sophomore Chink Crossin broke the Palestra record for a Penn player by scoring 23 points, the Red and Blue lost its closing Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game to Princeton tonight, 49 -- 45, before 3,000 spectators, including six alumni classes in reunions.

The new Naval Training School, Women's Reserve, the Bronx, which took over the facilities of Hunter College last month and received its first "boots" Feb. 14, will turn out its first class of Waves and Spars next Tuesday, the Third Naval District announced yesterday.

THE job of riding herd on the Roosevelt Administration's first maverick House of Representatives is, appropriately enough, that of a Texan, Sam Rayburn. "Maverick" is a Texas cattle term meaning "unbranded." Mavericks are not necessarily unruly, but they are no man's personal property until he can prove ownership or hogtie and mark them with his own brand.
The unprecedented rush to pay Federal income taxes continued here yesterday as record-breaking receipts of money and mail were reported by the local district collectors of internal revenue.

WAR today is a catastrophe which will leave its mark upon the population for generations. Until this century, wars were generally localized; the areas affected rarely extended beyond the countries engaged. The populations of the warring nations were only remotely affected.

SCOUT cars and light tanks forming our reconnaissance units have reported that enemy tanks are moving in our direction about twelve miles away. From a 2,000-foot peak, representing one side of a mountain pass, you are about to witness the climax of an eight-day tank battle.

The leading editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 12 impressively demonstrated the folly and destined failure of Hitler's program of world conquest, but the citation of the Medes and the Persians as confirming evidence and the affirmation that Darius as well as Hitler "left behind him a trail of blood and destruction and then disappeared" was an unfortunate slip.

LONDON, Sunday, March 14 -- German troops gained fresh ground in the flaming fight for Kharkov, a midnight Moscow bulletin announced today, and Russian field dispatches frankly termed the situation "serious" as the Nazis threw hundreds of tanks and thousands of infantrymen into an assault on three sides of the Ukraine citadel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 13 -- Russian airmen are enthusiastic over American fighter planes, particularly the P-39 Bell Airacobra, and are "performing great feats with them," it was stated here today.

FOR the benefit of those who are looking for an exemplary character to set before the young it must be stated now that Web Adams was not a model pupil nor son, although his parents seem to have been fond of him.

FOR use on mail in Eritrea the British occupation authorities in that former African possession of Italy have overprinted "M.E.F." (Middle East Force) on the following contemporary stamps of Great Britain: 1-penny, 2p, 2 1/2 p, 3p, 5p, 6p, 9p, 1-shilling and 2sh6p in the regular postage series and 1/2 p, 1p, 2p, 3p and 1sh postage dues.

LONDON, March 13 -- The village of Aldenham, in Hertfordshire, where J.P. Morgan had extensive land holdings, mourned today the passing of the banker.

THE school children of China have a popular couplet, "Ts'ang Chieh made characters and Ts'ai Lun made paper." Although the Chinese characters are supposed to date back to 2700 B.C., it was A.D. 105 when the eunuch Ts'ai Lun officially reported to the Emperor the results of researches in papermaking.

CHUNGKING, China, March 13 (AP) -- Difficulties between the Japanese and the owners of the Italian liner Conte Verde, Lloyd Triestino of Trieste, are holding up further repatriation of Americans from Japan, a Chinese who has just arrived from Shanghai said today.

The body of J.P. Morgan, last of a race of financial Titans, was on its way North for burial last night from Boca Grande, Fla., where the banker died yesterday morning at 3:15 o'clock. He was 75 years old.

THE interesting as well as disconcerting feature of this novel is that it isn't really a novel. The publishers announce it as "the story of a man who made it his main purpose to discover the meaning of life," and the author, in a brief foreword, gives a similar explanation.

Several weeks ago Greg Rice was asked when he thought he would be ready for his peak effort of the year. It would be some time in March, he replied. Last night at Madison Square Garden the mighty mite from South Bend proved to the satisfaction of a crowd of 15,000 persons at the Knights of Columbus meet that not only was he ready but near his peak.

JUST as a teacher regards a classroom of students as having basic similarities but a need for individual consideration, so the wise gardener regards that broad plant classification -- the annuals. True, he may sow them all outdoors about May 1 and, faithful to their horticultural definition, they will all come into bloom the same year; but treated so they will be incapable of fulfilling their finest possibilities.

What does it really prove when we say that a man is ahead of his time? In the matter of discovery and invention we can understand how a man can be ahead of his time. The new truth which he reveals is not listened to.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be anxious over the Administration's lack of a tax plan to combat the popular Rural plan or the Carlson bill. The President expressed disapproval of the Ruml plan yesterday, but offered no substitute.

America's post-war social security plan, drafted by the National Resources Planning Board and transmitted by President Roosevelt to Congress this week, was hailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday as an example of applied democracy.
Setting: A California estate bordered by a mysterious wood.
LONDON Sunday, March 14 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Absenteeism slows war production; it does more harm, says Secretary Knox, than strikes. So it comes in for hard words. In times of peace the philosophers are inclined to defend it. They argue that the right to be absent, the right to be a self-determined scamp instead of a regimented coolie, is one of the inalienable rights of a free people.

WITH a bow to the war needs for transportation, a number of women's organizations have made drastic changes in plans for their 1943 conventions. Most of these gatherings will resemble only dimly the gala events of pre-war years when delegates by the thousands journeyed from all parts of the country to participate in business and social sessions that made dramatic finales to the season.

THERE are very few non- Chinese writers who have the art of conveying colorful Chinese thought in the English language. Arthur Waley is one of these. He is, in fact, unique, because he not only captures the delicate form made possible only by the use of our ideographic language but he successfully weaves it into the tapestry-like pattern of his own writing.

WHEELER BECKET, conductor of the Youth Concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will direct seventy members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a series of three symphonic concerts for high school students on Thursdays, April 1, 15 and 29, at 3 P.M., in Hunter College Auditorium.

THE Metropolitan Opera ballet is to present Laurent Novikoff's new arrangement of the Dance of the Hours from "La Gioconda," along with "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," on Saturday afternoon as part of the regular opera bill.

AROUND noon last Aug. 19 I drew the blackout curtains in the Hotel Savoy in London. Sun streamed in and laid sharp patterns on the green rug. Through open windows I heard the steady hum of hurrying two-way air traffic in the blue sky.

Against a background of reminiscences of the great blizzard of 1888, James A. Farley, chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee, declared yesterday that the war would end soon if President Roosevelt and his associates were aided and their burdens lightened.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The visit of Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, has proved to be the most successful "good-will" appearance by an American in Argentina since the start of the war, in the opinion of observers here.

The Regional Office of the War Production Board announced yesterday that beginning tomorrow it will exercise its recently granted authority to assign preference ratings on PD-1A applications for restricted materials in amounts of $100 or less.

The strongest, most powerful military force in Africa is the British Eighth Army. Its veterans, drawn from all parts of the British Empire and from France, Poland and other conquered countries, have been hardened by defeat, tempered by victory. Behind them lie two and a half years of tough campaigning on the blazing Libyan deserts.

The proposed tax program of the C.I.O. was attacked yesterday by Dr. Willford I. King, authority on economics and statistics, who said the plan "almost exempts from Federal taxation four out of every five persons engaged in earning money."

Russia was the center last week for major events in the global war. A new turn of military fortunes on the Russian front coincided with signs of a new turn in Allied diplomacy concerning the Soviet Union. While Germans for the first time in months were striking hard blows at the Red Army, attention in Allied capitals was focused on the vital problem of relations between Russia and the United States.

LONDON, March 13 -- Although the food situation in Greece is now definitely better, thanks to outside aid, the occupation is becoming stiffer in other ways. Axis troops are receiving new reinforcements to meet the threat of the United Nations' attempt to liberate the Balkans in a second front effort, and new chains of fortifications are being worked on.

APPROPRIATELY, timed to provide information on some of the more popular types of antique ceramics is a small exhibition at the Newark Museum, "The Story of European Porcelain." Just now figurines, plates and bowls from the famous European potteries are being sought, say antique dealers and auction men, by both collectors and home decorators.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Nine French passenger liners with a total gross tonnage of thousands of tons in excess of the Normandie, and twenty-two French freighters, the gross tonnage of which exceeds that of seventeen "Liberty" ships, have recently been added to the inter-Allied shipping pool.
An Italian communique, broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALGIERS, March 13 -- The first economic consequences of the North African mobilization have appeared in Algiers, where the sale of meat has been suspended and the Economic Council of Algeria has protested the Army's requisitioning of motor vehicles and freight cars necessary to the carrying on of the country's agricultural economy.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- With rationing of meats and fats set to begin March 29, Prentiss M. Brown, the Price Administrator, appealed today to housewives not to buy or hoard in panic and expressed confidence in the cooperation of the country's 600,000 storekeepers.

A radical change in current export trade practices and the probable curtailment of the total volume of shipments was seen by foreign traders last week as a result of the disclosure of the new control system under which "unlimited licenses" are to be discontinued.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 13 -- In the defense of the "Fortress of Europe" which the Axis is now perfecting, France is to be the western bastion. This fact serves to explain what is taking place there, whether or not it comes to the knowledge of the outside world.

IN recent years many of our native dogwoods have been quite seriously affected with a deformity caused by the feeding of the larvae of mycodiplosis, a small midge. The deformities are known as club galls and occur mostly on the young, succulent growth.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in England, March 13 (AP) -- American Flying Fortresses, with a big Allied Spitfire escort, today roared over the Channel for the second straight day and bombed the railroad yards at Amiens, behind the French coast. Then in thick cloud cover they fought a stiff battle with German fighter planes on their way back.

Stimulating new fashion ideas are lining up for Spring. Most of the style interest is concentrated above the waistline, since the narrowness of the skirts forbids much variation of silhouette. The casual cardigan, for example, has become a part of smart town dresses. One designer has found a way of giving interest to crepe dresses, and sheer woolen ones too, for that matter, by making them with half tunic peplums.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The proposal which Democratic and Republican Senators will put before President Roosevelt tomorrow urging that the United States start a permanent organization with its Allies stems from weeks of conferences among leading Senators.

The United Nations are engaged in a global war to stop the aggression of the totalitarian states, which have embarked on a career of conquest to impose their system on the world and organize it in their own image. The totalitarian states will be defeated; but it has often happened in the past that the ideas of the vanquished have conquered the conquerors.

The report for 1942 of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $46,140,121 after taxes, depreciation, retirements and $2,000,000 reserved for contingencies, but without consideration of a post-war refund of $2,681,145 on excess profits taxes.

SPRING TONICS -- For the possessor of a home in the country (or a home anywhere, for that matter), the coming of Spring is an introduction to feverish activity. It is not all a season of unadulterated joy -- filled with sunshine and daffodils.

AFTER an absence of almost two years, Dwight Fiske, the supper club comic who can fit droll stories to piano accompaniment, returns to New York's night life this week. Mr. Fiske has been signed to display his piano elegancies at the Versailles for a period of four weeks, commencing Wednesday evening.

MONTREAL, March 13 (AP) -- Montreal kept a slim chance of edging into the National Hockey League play-offs by gaining a 6-6 deadlock with the Black Hawks tonight. The Canadiens, two points behind Chicago, have two games left, as do the Hawks.

SHOULD your child go to nursery school? It is a question for parents themselves to decide, on the basis of the child's age, health and temperament and the set-up at home -- including freedom to run up and down without bringing complaints from the people downstairs.

NEW HEALER -- British chemists have discovered a new sterilizing drug. Its name is Diamidinodiphenoxypropaned Ihydrochloride, which has been mercifully shortened to Propamidine. This new drug sterilizes injuries, such as burns, that have persisted for months.
For the first time in 115 years the St. Patrick's Day Parade next Wednesday will include in its ranks an outside organization. The exception is the Red Cross and the reason is the war.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Endorsing the post-war program of the National Resources Planning Board, submitted to Congress Wednesday by President Roosevelt, the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined today in a call for prompt action to put its provisions into effect.

A DAINTY Summer-flowering bulb, the ranunculus, while widely used in the South and West and long a florist's favorite, is not so well known to Northern gardens -- probably because of its somewhat tender nature.

For the year 1943 the Bennington College community will become largely self-supporting as far as food is concerned. On the hundred acres of farm land comprising part of the college property students, faculty and staff will produce most of the meat, poultry, garden vegetables, potatoes and apples necessary to supply a community of 400 people throughout the college year.

THERE are few more irritating literary tasks than that of making a good sea story out of the journal of a New England shipmaster of the early days of the Republic, days when New Englanders went to China and the South Seas, to India and the Spice Islands, on voyages bold and even foolhardy.

The Northeastern Vegetable and Potato Council, meeting yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker, went on record as declaring that price ceilings on perishable vegetables were impracticable of application. It adopted a resolution opposing their application at shipping points, which reportedly is the intention of the Office of Price Administration in making permanent ceilings effective.

IT is significant that although this country is severely limited in the variety of foods which in peacetime is enjoyed in plenty and, owing to the exigencies of war, has had to tighten its belt and content itself with a very dull diet indeed, the general health of the people is good.

Ten major league clubs will start work tomorrow in baseball's "close-to-home" training season, with six more to follow within the next few days. The complete list of camp sites, which were restricted to an area bounded by the Potomac River on the south and the Mississippi on the west, follows:

The havoc wrought by bombs and fire in Great Britain, and the necessity of starting off newly married couples with some sort of equipment for setting up housekeeping, have resulted in a serious problem. The solution worked out by the government includes a distinct new type of utility furniture, constructed with a minimum of material, but made fairly rugged and serviceable.

Low-priced issues again led the market and the two-hour session on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the second most active in more than a year. Stocks were firm and closed with mixed changes on volume of 829,830 shares, a figure topped only once since Dec. 27, 1941.

LIKE many another man of talent, Shepard Traube cooled his heels for quite a long time in this world before the honors due him were finally paid off. To be sure, Mr. Traube had often sensed his own abilities, but somehow whenever it seemed that the triumphal march was about to begin, he fell by the wayside.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 13 (AP) -- Penn State and Temple dominated the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League championship quest today as each team carried off three individual titles in the annual post-season competition.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- While the newly formed Smith committee of the House was being flooded with complaints that the War Labor Board is using its emergency powers to entrench organized labor in all industries, Senator Wiley and Representative Howell, the latter a member of the Smith committee, announced they would introduce bills on Tuesday to create an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Small Business.

In light trading, the cotton futures market yesterday rose to final net gains of 5 to 20 points, or 25 cents to $1 a bale, on the New York Cotton Exchange, as a moderate amount of replacement buying in the old crop months found offerings very limited.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The accusation that the Russian Government was keeping its people in ignorance of the aid sent them by this country, made in Moscow by American Ambassador Admiral William H. Standley, coincided this week with Vice President Wallace's prediction that "in case we double-cross Russia," we shall make another world war problem.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A statement by Donald M. Nelson that war production would reach its peak next Fall, cutting the demand for workers, was studied today by Senators concerned over the manpower problem.

Extraordinary facility at the keyboard was disclosed by Richard Korbel, 8-year-old pianist of this city, at his debut recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The child's playing of a program devoted to works by Bach, Scarlatti, Schumann and Debussy was remarkable in its control of tone, command of a wide range of dynamics, and technical skill.

Unmindful of the snow swirling down Forty-second Street's canyon, and singularly hopeful that even a journey of less than sixty miles assuredly, would bring sunshine and warmth, New York's baseball leaders yesterday set themselves resolutely to the task of launching perhaps the most bizarre "southern" training season the national pastime ever has known.

General MacArthur has sent Lieut. Gen. Kenney, his air commander, to Washington. The capital expects General Kenney to ask for more planes. It would be surprising if his trip had any other purpose, for certainly General MacArthur has made it plain that he would like to have greater air strength.

The report of the Allied Products Corporation for the year ended on Dec. 31 shows a net profit of $1,067,026, after providing $100,000 for contingencies, Federal normal income taxes of $137,500 and an excess profits tax of $3,543,300, after a deduction of $393,700 for the post-war refund.

RICHARD STRAUSS, according to recent reports from Germany, has left his lovely home in Garmisch, in the Bavarian Alps, and has chosen Italy as his place of refuge. Undoubtedly, in his new abode he is seeking peace after the disappointments he suffered.

NEW ORLEANS, March 13 -- Riverland, the big black gelding that beat both Alsab and Whirl-away last Fall in less than a week, returned to top form today with a victory over four of the best thoroughbreds at the Fair Grounds in the $5,000 Fort Jackson Handicap.

IN a patriotic move to advance the work which the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York is conducting for thousands of enlisted men in the armed forces of this nation and its Allies, committees representing the service club have extended invitations to the public to attend the gala all-out concert to be given under their auspices at Town Hall on the afternoon of March 28.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A program designed to bring relief to live poultry dealers and country dressers is nearing completion and will be announced soon, a spokesman for the Office of Price Administration said today in reply to reports from New York that the live poultry market there was threatened with a shut-down because of a shortage of poultry.

Delegations from twenty-eight Eastern colleges, each representing one of the United Nations, will hold a "model United Nations Conference" at Hamilton College, Clinton, N.Y., Tuesday through Friday, to consider a program for "the establishment of a just and stable world order."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Office of Price Administration made it possible today for persons living in areas remote from grocery stores to buy the canned and dried goods they need. Sheepherders, fishermen, forest rangers, lumbermen and others will get ration coupons to cover their requirements.

Sholem Asch has delivered the manuscript of "The Apostle" to his publishers, Putnam's and translation of the book into English is going forward. Publication is planned for late September of this year. Mr. Asch, now at his home in Stamford, Conn., is already at work on another book.

Steel experts of the Administration stand ready to controvert, at the drop of a hat, any further charges that a shortage of steel is, or has been for many months, a factor retarding or restricting the building of merchant ships under the war effort.
ALMOST to a woman, those who are experiencing point rationing for the first time want to know the answer to this question: What is the wisest way to spend the blue stamps in War Ration Book No. 2?

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- With the filing deadline only two days away, Treasury officials pre dicted today that Internal Revenue collectors throughout the country would be snowed under by an avalanche of income-tax returns and money over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A resolution recommending that the United States take the initiative in calling a conference of the United Nations to work out their wartime and post-war problems will be offered in the Senate on Tuesday by two Democratic and two Republican Senators, it was learned today.

Within the last year or two numerous critics have attacked the New York City School system, charging that it had become cumbersome and even outmoded in its practices and procedures. Economy-minded spokesmen held that a thorough overhauling to remedy inefficient policies was in order.

World War I was eleven years ended; passions had died down and out of sober reflection, the world, as after every great conflict, found much truth. Every one who wrote about "All Quiet" said it was a powerful preachment against war, a classic pacifist document, and I admit that it was.
CHICAGO, March 13 -- Major league hitters today envisioned improved averages after a three-man committee voted to put the "jack rabbit" back into the standard baseball.

BOSTON. IN spite of the dimout, which makes theatregoing something of an adventure, and restrictions on automobile driving, which count for a good deal in this city of suburbanites, Boston has been having a profitable season.

COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY announces that a course in Victory gardening will be given at Nevis, the Hamilton arboretum and gardens, Irvington, N.Y., on seven successive Mondays beginning March 22. Professor Hugh Findlay will direct the lectures, which are to include such subjects as soils, fertilizers, planting, harvesting and storing.

"During the last week I have passed through so many thrilling scenes that I am unable to describe them in regular order," the more literate but still inarticulate Private Benjamin Franklin Scribner wrote home to New Albany, Ind.

WASHINGTON, March 13 Three major warplane producers, whose output for the Army and Navy is trailing far behind expectations, are being quietly pressed by the Truman committee to improve their manufacturing methods and get out more planes -- or else!

FEDHALA, French Morocco, March 13 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis I. Spellman of New York said mass today at a plain, hastily built wooden altar in a small French cemetery over the grave of the first American chaplain killed in the second World War.

ALGIERS, March 13 -- The speech scheduled to be made by General Henri Honore Giraud tomorrow is regarded by French and Allied political circles as the most important that he has made since he became French Civil and Military Commander in Chief, for it is expected to include four important points that emphasize his regime's intention to align itself with the democratic ideology.

Practical clothes for a "topsy-turvy" world, where the day's activities sometimes go far into the night, were displayed yesterday by Martin's Department Store at a fashion show at the Waldorf-Astoria during an Adelphi College Alumni bridge. Helen Reed was guest commentator.

But as if to discredit such a dull start in life, it was rumored she had been plucked from a lonely cabbage to attain miraculous stardom in "The Song of Bernadette."

WOMEN who have long taken an active interest in the Child Education Foundation have arranged a theatre party in behalf of that organization's scholarship fund, to be held on the night of April 7 at the performance of "Men in Shadow," at the Morosco Theatre.

The Ides of March call the bird dog enthusiast into the field and stubble with his veteran of proved ability on quail and pheasant, together with youngsters who still have much to learn before they will be entered for competition in field trials or taken out for hunting in the crisp days of Autumn.

Formation of an opposition proxy committee for the coming annual meeting of stockholders of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation was announced yesterday. The committee has been formed by William H. Danforth, a large holder of Columbia Oil common stock, although he is not one of four nominees suggested for election to a new board of directors.
LONDON, March 13 (U.P.) -- French patriots and Italian soldiers are locked in bloody combat in the rugged, eastern French border district of Haute-Savoie, reports from Switzerland said today.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers, last year's winners of the Football League War Clip, bowed out of the 1943 competition for the cup today in the first round as Britain's soccer fans became cup-tie conscious.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- After a year's experience with government price "control" of meat, Packingtown, a city within a city on Chicago's south side and the world's greatest purveyor of that important item in the nation's daily diet, is having trade difficulties as a result of wartime government regulations.

With slightly more than half its goal achieved, the Forest Hills-Kew Gardens "Buy-a-Bomber" campaign enters this week the closing half of its drive with the prospect of exceeding its quota, the campaign committee, headed by John L. Bates, C.S. Coleman and Frank Robertson, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- War Department officials said today that 252 principal war contracting firms listed two days ago by the Smaller War Plants Corporation would shortly receive a questionnaire from the War and Navy Departments, the Maritime Commission and Treasury Procurement Division requesting full information about the extent to which they have subcontracted their orders as desired by Congress.

LONDON, March 13 -- Reiterating his confidence in a United Nations victory, President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, who is generally acclaimed as one of the shrewdest statesmen in Europe, told a London audience tonight that the war had at last reached its final period of operations and "the day of reckoning is drawing near."

Ducks were on the river the other morning, wild ducks heading north and forced down by the fog. A few days earlier another flock of them could be seen against the sunset, eager wings beating northward in the chill of evening. No doubt those who watch for airplanes have seen them in the dawn sky, too, and started at the sight; for wild ducks on the wing in the half-light look alarmingly like something else.

UNTIL ten years ago Wyoming enjoyed the reputation of having been the last State in the Union to receive its initial visit from a printing press. About that time Douglas C. McMurtrie, tireless historian of local incunabula, discovered the existence of a diminutive newspaper, The Daily Telegraph, published at Fort Bridger, in what was then Utah Territory, late in June, 1863.

As a result of the flood of amendments and revisions in procedure under the Controlled Materials Plan within the last few weeks, fear was expressed by some business men last week that the program would be so emasculated by the efforts to simplify paper work that the entire plan would collapse.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Consumer demand for dresses, coats and suits and sports wear was good, with accessories meeting a brisk call.

PROVIDING a groundcover for a steep embankment is a problem to many gardeners -- and a serious one where soil washes away after each rainfall. It is impossible to grow grass in such locations -- or, if grass will somehow thrive, it is a real task to keep it cut.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 13 -- There are strong indications that Marshal Erwin Rommel will throw the pick of his German forces against some section of the Allied line in another desperate attempt to stave off his inevitable defeat at the hands of the British, American and French forces massing to strike in Tunisia.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe denied yesterday a motion by Sir Thomas Beecham, British orchestra conductor, for a preliminary injunction against the Columbia Recording Corporation, to stop the manufacture and sale of certain recordings he considers defective.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13 -- Victory-starved Yale, which had been used as a door-mat by the other teams in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League this season, perpetrated a major upset by nosing out Harvard, 44 to 43, for its only victory in twelve circuit starts at the new Harvard indoor building tonight.
The second year of America's participation in the war finds Spring football practice a casualty in the East, but intercollegiate sports show no alarming signs of giving up the ghost at this time.

Associates paid tribute yesterday to the late J.P. Morgan as a public-spirited citizen, as an able financier and as a friend.

Cabinet members, Congressmen and representatives of England, Russia, China and other foreign nations sampled the new compressed dehydrated food at a luncheon given recently in Washington by the Lend-Lease Administration to mark the second anniversary of the passage of the lend-lease act.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 13 -- The special session of Congress today passed bills governing the petroleum industry, including a substantial increase in royalties. President Isaias Medina Angarita signed them at noon, putting them into effect.

LONDON, March 13 -- Signs are multiplying that the great Anglo-American bombing offensive against Germany that was promised last Summer soon will become a reality. Squadrons of Flying Fortresses and Liberators that have proved their ability to do pin-point daylight bombing while beating off Nazi fighters are being built up to the strength planned for them a year ago.

On the plains of Russia the Red Army last week continued its grim endeavors. Its aim, as always, was to sap the strength of Adolf Hitler's war machine. Its successes were no longer being measured in vast stretches of regained territory. In places it battled desperately to hold what it had won.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, March 14 -- Allied war planes have pounced upon yet another Japanese convoy thrusting toward New Guinea -- this time composed of five merchantmen and three destroyers -- and have damaged two ships in an initial attack, the High Command declared today.

THE American Red Cross War Fund of New York City will receive the proceeds from a novel series of exhibitions entitled "Sinner to Saint," dubbed by its creator, Brryman Ridges, as a "Georama, or a world of things seen," which will open with a preview on Tuesday afternoon at 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will continue there daily until April 6.

Commodore A.F. Jenkins of the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department will convene a meeting of his skippers Thursday evening at 6 o'clock at the city clubhouse, Central Park South. The regional Office of Defense Transportation served notice yesterday on twelve private bus lines, which carry apartment dwellers in Queens, Brooklyn, Manhattan and Yonkers, to end operations by tomorrow.

Governor Dewey will be urged tomorrow to extend his investigation of Creedmoor State Hospital to all the State's mental hospitals by the Association for the Improvement of Conditions in State Mental Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A new channeling system that is quietly revolutionizing the printing telegraph art is known to engineers as "Varioplex" and to the public as "Telemeter." It is the invention (Patent No. 2,313,238) of Philo Holcomb Jr. of Great Neck, N.Y.

A continual occupational deferment plan under Selective Service, affecting all merchant seamen in active service, will be placed in effect tomorrow by the Recruitment and Manning Organization of the War Shipping Administration, it was announced yesterday by Marshall E. Dimock, director.
ALBANY, March 13 (AP) -- A sharp increase in farm workers' wages, due to an acute help shortage and a continued rise in farm prices, was noted today by the State Agriculture Department.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Elated but not made over-confident by the recent crushing victory of the Bismarck Sea, United States military leaders here have become increasingly aware of the role that air power may play in the sprawling ocean-island theatre of the Southwest Pacific, where the enemy's bases are far more numerous than ours and where ships and men cannot move safely unless control of the skies is assured.

BUFFALO, March 13 -- The Joint Commission on Holy Matrimony of the Protestant Episcopal Church made public today two canons, as tentatively drafted and submitted to diocesan committees for study, which on one hand would liberalize the position of the church on the remarriage of divorced persons, and on the other hand would reestablish the family unit rather than the individual as the basic factor in parish life.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Lend-lease was 2 years old this week and the virtual unanimous approbation it received as Congress extended its life until June 30, 1944, indicated that it had done an important job well.
