Ostensibly, the setting is Europe in this century, with a glance in the end at wartime America. Yet the author's vast knowledge and historical perspective lead the reader back through the whole structure of Western civilization.

The twenty-first symphony of Nicolai Miascovsky, who is a man of many symphonies, opened the program of Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. This is an unconventional and appealing work; not unconventional in its harmonic fabric, or in any particular detail of instrumentation, nor yet in some novel manner of development of the ideas.

A luncheon, at times sounding like a football game with ten competing cheering sections, was held at the Hotel Commodore yesterday to wind up the three-day session of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association convention.

IN World War I the woman-power of this country, industrially speaking, was equal to the algebraic X, the unknown quantity. No figures existed by which to measure its height, extent or significance. In World War II statistics galore, carefully compiled in the interval between, certify the feminine battalions as the greatest single pool of potential workers, trained and untrained, skilled and unskilled, at the service of Uncle Sam.

THE National Theatre Conference is about to release another play for the colleges on its extensive circuit. It's a dramatization by Elizabeth McFadden of a short story known as "Moab's Vineyard." Under the title of "He Signed His Name," the play will have its first presentation April 8 at Indiana University, where it will be offered for five performances.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Dr. Howard Hawkes Mitchell, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Pennsylvania since 1921 who joined the faculty thirty-two years ago, died today of a coronary thrombosis at his home in suburban Merion. His age was 58.

Some phases of the work being done by the American Red Cross at home and abroad will be given dramatic portrayal in the pageant part of the program of "The Red Cross at War" rally at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night to initiate the Manhattan block canvass of the organization's city-wide campaign for $12,920,700.

LONDON, March 13 -- Four noted Norwegian athletes, including the three Ruud brothers, known both in Europe and America for their skiing performances, have been placed in a concentration camp for participating in an unsanctioned sports event, the Norwegian Telegraph Agency reported today.

But the leader of the squadron would go east of San Francisco because he would naturally follow the shortest route.

Behind barbed wire entanglements more than 6,000,000 men are now leading the hard lives of prisoners of war. The International Red Cross Committee, the neutral intermediary for the observance of the Convention, reports that in general its terms are being obeyed.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (Science Service) -- Seeds have assumed an importance out of all proportion to their size, as Victory Garden planting is urged even upon city dwellers, and crop prospects are debated daily in Congress. Means for making each seed more efficient, covered by newly granted United States patent No. 2,313,057, therefore, take high rank position in the week's news of inventions. Patentee is Albert C. Fischer of Chicago.

A GOOD flower holder deserves good care to keep it in its best condition. In other words, it should be cleaned as often as it is used and kept in a special place when not in use. Most important of all, the holders, especially the needle-type holders with the lead base, should not be kept in a drawer filled with everything from can openers to corkscrews, as they are likely to become damaged.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Royal Air Force dropped more than 1,000 tons of bombs on Essen last night. This afternoon, while fires still were raging there in the Krupp works, United States heavy bombers, flying the daytime schedules of the pro-invasion aerial offensive, attacked Axis rail installations just behind the vulnerable French coast.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today that if the "numerous desertions" of French sailors from their warships in American harbors continue, "the vessels will be left so understaffed that they will be virtually immobilized."

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- In response to requests by the War Manpower Commission, the Office of Civilian Supply has begun a survey of the service trades of Connecticut labor areas as the start of a country-wide study with a view to restricting their use of materials and manpower to essential needs so that these may be freed for straight war purposes, but also to guarantee that these essential needs will be met.

TORONTO, March 13 (AP) -- Toronto surged from behind with a third-period offensive to suppress the Red Wings, 3 -- 1, tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens, all but clinching a berth in the four-team National Hockey League play-offs which open next week-end.

ATLANTA, March 13 -- An experimental plan to make full and prompt use of the idle facilities of small manufacturers in the seven Southeastern States of Region 4 was discussed here this week by procurement officers of the armed forces and members of the Regional War Production Board.

UP to a little while ago, it looked as though the sports announcer would have to begin memorizing joke books instead of record books and hock their field glasses for musical instruments. Sports seemed the same doghouse as the gasoline station for the duration, what with the armed services grabbing off athletes and transportation difficulties putting a crimp in intersectional matches.

THROUGH an auditorium filled with hundreds of chattering college girls there rises a sigh of admiration and then a questioning murmur as two women, one in khaki, one in navy blue, and two men a soldier and a sailor, walk onto the stage.

PHYLLIS FENNER is a person who likes to laugh. You know that because this collection has obviously been made by one who has not only worked with children, but by one who has shared with them her own personal enjoyment of droll tales.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Chavez of New Mexico, who is the only Spanish-descended member of the Senate, said today that he found considerable opposition in Puerto Rico recently to his suggestion that English be made the basic language medium in Puerto Rican schools, and that Spanish be taught only as a grammar subject for those who wished to take it.

The upward trend in living costs for low-salaried workers continued in February with a rise of 0.4 per cent, according to the monthly survey of the Division of Industrial Economics of the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday.

FOR about four decades the late G. William Riegl collected stamps while he was postmaster at Bethlehem, Pa. Only a few persons were aware of his interest in philately. He entered office about the turn of the century.

A RECENTLY completed four-reel film produced by the Canadian National Film Board has created an unusual stir among exhibitor groups. It is called "Not the Gates of Hell," and like all the board's "World in Action" series was edited and written by Stuart Legg.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 13 -- James H. Shea, lawyer and banker, died at the home of a sister, Mrs. Alice Lawler, here last night after a long illness. His age was 79.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico -- A sightseeing tour of the wartime shopping fronts of Mexico's larger cities finds business almost as usual. A visitor fresh from a country of shortages and rationing can hardly believe his eyes when he finds just about everything for sale.

AT all seasons women progress steadily toward equality or identity with men, but a war gets them ahead faster. In the last conflict they came on by leaps and bounds. What they are doing now is worth watching.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Requests for American Red Cross aid to service men and former service men and their families have increased from a national average of 500 a day before Pearl Harbor to more than 4,000 a day, that agency stated today, adding that this had necessitated an increase in its "home service staff," both paid and volunteer.

MOSCOW, March 13 (AP) -- The Russian people read official Russian appreciation of American lend-lease aid for the first time today when Moscow's newspapers gave prominence to a statement made by Ambassador Maxim Litvinoff in Washington on the second anniversary of lend-lease two days ago.

WICHITA, Kan., March 13 -- An apartment owner here was permanently restrained today from evicting tenants or collecting more rent than regulations of the Office of Price Administration permit as a decision by a three-judge Federal statutory court brought the first major test of rent control to a close.

Governor Dewey yesterday gave New York racing its green light for 180 days of 1943 competition, within the framework of the war effort, when he approved and made public the report of his executive assistant, James C. Hagerty, one of whose recommendations was that the Saratoga dates be run off in the metropolitan district.

WHEN the editor of The Observer sent Cyril Connolly a dozen new volumes of poetry for review, there arose in the recipient's mind an image from Walt Disney's "Fantasia" -- the procession of dying giant lizards blindly searching for water in the dried-up river-bed, and dropping dead one by one.

ONE of Orson Welles's major ambitions is being realized these days -- he has achieved in his Mercury Productions a gathering of citizens with manifold talents, each of whom doubles, and sometimes triples, in brass. No single-threat man himself, the 26-year-old figures that all his associates should get in on the fun.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 13 -- Rutgers scored 61 points to win for the third straight time the Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship tonight. The Scarlet captured five of seven individual events and both relays.

INFORMATIONAL books with a war twist occupy a prominent place on many publishing lists this Spring. The steady public demand for explanation in lay terms of what life is like in the Coast Guard or the Signal Corps has made for systematic extensions of these "service" series to include most of the civilian or industrial war jobs.

Hockey will bid adieu to the New York scene tonight when the Rangers tackle the Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. Although the Blueshirts have two games more to play after tonight to round out their National League schedule, the contests are to be staged on the road.

THIS last volume of Elinor Wylie's poems will have many facets of interest for her following. Her writing life was not long, just eight years of the Nineteen Twenties, but what an excitement she and her poetry caused!

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Here are brief sketches of the five men who accompanied Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, on his flight to the United States for conferences on problems growing out of the war:

MOSCOW, March 13 (AP) -- In all Soviet villages and towns occupied the Germans have engaged in open brigandage and plunder, a Russian communique charged today. The destruction in Vyazma was heavier than elsewhere, it added, declaring all cultural institutions and historical monuments in the town had been ransacked and destroyed.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 13 -- Protestant and Catholic Churches in the Netherlands, in an open letter to Arthur Seyss-Inquart, the Reich Commissar, followed by a Catholic pastoral letter read from all Catholic pulpits on Feb. 21, have registered another energetic protest against "the State's encroachment on freedom of worship," mass mobilization of Netherland youth for German war industries and persecution of religious minorities.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (U.P.) -- The Navy, graphically stressing the heavy toll paid by the Japanese for their vain attempts to drive United States forces out of the Solomons, disclosed tonight that sixty-four enemy ships have been sunk during the islands campaign, against only thirty-two United States vessels lost.

CABBAGES and their kin -cauliflower, sprouting broccoli, Brussels sprouts, kohlrabi, Chinese cabbage, turnip, rutabaga, kale, collards and mustard -- are known as the cole crops. All of them are much more hardy than many other garden vegetables, and may be planted about a month earlier in the Spring than beans, tomatoes and the melons.

THE cost of transferring "Lady in the Dark" to celluloid will reach at least $3,000,000, according to Mitchell Leisen, who is directing the picture for Paramount, with Ginger Rogers starred in the Gertrude Lawrence role. Originally the budget for the Technicolor film was set at $2,300,000.

ONE of the arresting things about this authentic Civil War narrative by a young soldier who fought for three years with the 100th Indiana Volunteers is the fact that it is published by a university press of the Deep South.

IN a short and well-illustrated book, Captain Jerome teaches the rudiments of piloting, as far as can be done in a text. His approach is very straightforward. He has arranged the material in the form of eighteen flying lessons.

MOSCOW, March 13 -- Less than six weeks ago the German High Command seemed to be preparing for the evacuation of all Nazi positions on the left bank of the Dnieper River between Kremenchug and Zaporozhe.

THOSE wood-lot owners who have wondered if their property would ever be worth the taxes now appear to be in possession of an enviable asset that can easily provide a supplementary cash income or its equivalent.

NEWCASTLE, Del., March 13 -- With Giuseppe M. Bellanca apparently successful in his attempt to regain control of the board of directors of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation, the deferred annual meeting of the stockholders was recessed this afternoon until this evening to permit a tabulation of the proxies.

An overall standardization of cost accounting procedure, as has been suggested in some industry management and government quarters, would be impossible so long as variations exist in the uses to which cost information must be put, Dr. R.P. Marple, director of the research and technical service department of the National Association of Cost Accountants, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Secretary Henry L. Stimson, Republican elder statesman who allowed himself to be drafted for war, raised his authoritative voice this week to insist that the United States must have an army of at least 8,200,000 men.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Reductions in utility rates in this State during 1942 were smaller than in previous years, the Public Service Commission reported today to Governor Dewey and the Legislature, but they over-balanced increases in rates by more than $200,000.

VEGETABLES are rightly in the foreground of gardeners' minds this year, but as Spring comes on we could not, if we would, ignore the bright promise of the first daffodil. We still have room in this generous country of ours for at least a few of our favorite flowers, and to young gardeners this handsome book offers stimulus as well as information in planning and planting a flower garden.

THOSE wood-lot owners who have wondered if their property would ever be worth the taxes now appear to be in possession of an enviable asset that can easily provide a supplementary cash income or its equivalent.
Setting: The Old West meets Broadway at Central City's (Col.) annual play festival.

DURING the last several weeks the Tokyo radio has been conducting an "educational campaign" in which it accuses the United States Office of War Information of spending millions to "befuddle and bemuse" the Japanese mind.

NEARLY every gardener will plant tomatoes in the Victory Garden this Summer. Most of them will be the red-fruited varieties. Many persons, however, who like sliced tomatoes for fresh salads take pleasure in serving different things. They may have an eye for color, or like a mild-flavored fruit.

Americans learned last week the details of the new meat rationing program that will go into effect on March 29. Secretary of Agriculture Wickard estimated that the average weekly ration would be two and a quarter pounds, a half pound less than per capita consumption last year and still a quarter pound more than what the OCD has figured as "bedrock" requirement.

" WHO'S who on the Postage Stamps Costa Rica" was released last week by the Pan American Union, Washington. Written by Albert F. Kunze, director of the Latin-American Stamp Section, it is the sixth in the series of biographical booklets which the Union is publishing for the information of collectors.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Congress is extremely unlikely at this session to adopt any of the proposed social security proposals embodied in the National Resources Planning Board's report submitted by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The War Department gave out today the names of 168 United States soldiers and seven army nurses held prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

The thunderous roar of greeting Corporal Barney Ross, Guadalcanal Marine hero, received in the ring at Madison Square Garden Friday night had its echo yesterday in the announcement that Boxing's Service Equipment Fund to supply athletic paraphernalia, particularly boxing equipment, to Army, Navy and Marine training stations, had been enriched $1,100.

MOUNT ABU, Rajputana, India, March 9 (Delayed) -- Maharajas and industrial magnates, Brahmins and low-caste Hindus come in a steady stream to this spot, which is one of the holiest in India. Since prehistoric days there have been temples here and the hillsides are dotted with stone huts or caves where holy men have taught their disciples.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Opposition to the Hampton-Brady bill, which provides for the reorganization of the State Commission of Correction, has been voiced by the Prison Association of New York, it was disclosed today. The Prison Association, founded in 1844, is composed of private citizens interested in the proper maintenance of penal institutions in the State.

EDGAR CAYCE, like Joan of Arc, had a winged vision in early youth. The result is the amazing and at the same time disappointing story told in this book. Whatever else may be said about the story, one is convinced in reading it that Mr. Cayce is not a charlatan, and that Mr. Sugrue, a New York newspaper man and author, has written what he honestly believes to be the truth.

OURS is a singing nation, one which works and plays and marches to new tunes and to old ones which never seem to wear out. How right it is, then, that now when our songs of freedom touch the spirit with such poignancy we should know where they came from and how they were written.
LONDON, March 13 (Reuter) -- The text of the memorandum from the French National Committee to General Henri Honore Giraud:

BUFFALO, March 13 -- Following are the texts of the Canons of Marriage and on the Relationship of the Church and Family, as tentatively drafted and submitted to the diocesan committees by the Joint Commission on Holy Matrimony of the Protestant Episcopal Church:

THE new laws of contract bridge, which become effective on April 1 and are already being used by many clubs and tournaments, cover calls out of rotation with far greater detail than did the 1935 code. In particular, they make a distinction between a call out of rotation when it is the offender's partner's turn to bid, and any other call out of rotation.
THIS is the story of one of the little ironies of international warfare.

JUDGING from the advance sale of tickets to the Garden Week lecture course opening tomorrow morning at Times Hall, the interest in flower arrangement, despite the war, shows no sight of flagging. Up to the present writing mote tickets have been reserved for Flower Arrangement Day (Wednesday) than for any other day during the week.

The British Government has started to carry out an agreement made with the Netherlands in 1941 to replace some of that country's merchant marine losses with British tonnage, having transferred two ships to the Netherlands flag in the United States and turned over several others in England, it was disclosed here yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- Corn futures advanced 1/8 to 4 1/8 cents a bushel and the cash article declined 1 to 5 cents generally today on the board of trade as operators attempted to adjust themselves to the new price ceilings announced late yesterday by the Office of Price Administration.

CALIFORNIA is taking a cruel revenge upon Chicago. As if in retaliation for the city's steadfast rejection of all plays which depend upon Hollywood stars or acting, California has fastened upon the midland metropolis two sun-born dramas that threaten to be everlasting.

SOLDIERS of our Army who have been training, many of them, for two years are now on battlefronts all the way from New Guinea to North Africa. And that makes a deal of difference in the way the soldiers feel who are still training. But many hundreds of thousands of our soldiers are still training and many more hundreds of thousands will presently be training.

THE fans resented him and the players resented him. He was booed and jeered with such heart-wrenching persistency that his brother murmured: "If I ever play major league hockey, I won't start in with the Rangers." All this happened ten years ago, but the 20-year-old boy of 1933 has become in the interval the darling of the gallery gods and the best-liked athlete in the circuit.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- This is the month for the maple sugar harvest in the Berkshire and Pioneer Valley towns. Even if snowdrifts still block the woodland trails and the north wind spells continued cold weather, cobwebs are being whisked from the old-fashioned wooden buckets; spigots are being cleansed and evaporators overhauled.

A team of three experts in the Kenny method of treating infantile paralysis left yesterday by plane for Buenos Aires, Argentina, where they will aid in fighting an epidemic of the disease that has been raging for several months, it was announced by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

THE world is now in the midst of a military phase of the atr age. The flying machine which the Wright brothers thought of as a vehicle for the sportsman is now a weapon of death and destruction that is changing the congealed ideas of military men everywhere.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- An "escape hatch" in the floor of the latest combat tanks and a suspender made of webbed pistol belts for removing helpless men through upper hatches and turrets are new features adopted for the succor of wounded crewmen from tanks.

WHAT appears to be a transformation -- and a profitable one -- has been taking place among this town's leading publishers of popular music: They have gone seriously into publishing of more elaborate music.

HITLER'S god is a malignant deity who is not interested in the distinction between good and evil but only in the distinction between Germans and "inferior peoples." Such is the picture of the hidden religious side of National Socialist Germany.

A metal-sprayer wearproofs wooden core boxes and foundry patterns against the abrasive action of sand. It contains an electrically heated melting pot in a compact housing with a gun handle for air pressure control. When a low fusing alloy in the sprayer is melted, compressed air sprays the molten metal on the surface to be wearproofed.

UNLESS there is notice to the contrary, most camps for boys and girls in the Eastern States will open as usual this Summer, and railroads (unless conditions change sharply) will provide necessary transportation.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asserted today that some recent decisions of the War Labor Board, "not consistent with its general policies," were "a direct blow against war production."

As part of the seagoing services' drive to enlist 50,000 women in the Waves, Spars and Marine Women Reserves this year, 300 women in the uniform of the Navy League will launch a drive to aid the recruiting tomorrow. On Tuesday they will open the first of twenty booths where eligible women can fill out official applications.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, began his official conversations on problems of the war and the peace at an informal meeting with President Roosevelt in the White House this evening.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Sunday, March 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:

As part of the seagoing services' drive to enlist 50,000 women in the Waves, Spars and Marine Women Reserves this year, 300 women in the uniform of the Navy League will launch a drive to aid the recruiting tomorrow. On Tuesday they will open the first of twenty booths where eligible women can fill out official applications.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, began his official conversations on problems of the war and the peace at an informal meeting with President Roosevelt in the White House this evening.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Sunday, March 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:

COMMANDO tactics, modified for young women who spend their days behind a desk or a counter, will be taught as a climax to the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. physical fitness course, now being given to three evening groups.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 13 (AP) -- A communique:

The present session of the New York State Legislature has been one of the quietest in the memory of veteran Albany observers. It has had none of the color and fireworks that marked the two decades in which the State elected Democratic Governors and Republican Legislatures.

The present session of the New York State Legislature has been one of the quietest in the memory of veteran Albany observers. It has had none of the color and fireworks that marked the two decades in which the State elected Democratic Governors and Republican Legislatures.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 13 -- Allied war planes assaulted the Axis from the Sicilian channel to the Mareth Line positions yesterday, while tanks, guns and men of the American, British and French forces nassed on the perimeter of the Germans' African bridgehead, ready to deal out or ward off great strokes or deal blows.

ALTHOUGH the radish is not the most important of vegetables, it deserves, for several resons, the gardener's careful consideration. First of all, it may be used, because of its quick maturity, as a companion, a succession or an interplanted crop, thereby adding to the production of the area, at practically no expense, except for a little seed and labor.

Unlike most popular books on aviation, which seek only to awaken an interest in flying, "Air Pilot Training" is designed and written to help air-minded youngsters get a pilot's license. Bert A. Shields, an experienced and able pilot, instructor and author, set out to write a book which would contain all the information necessary to pass a written examination for a private or commercial pilot's license.

WEST POINT, March 13 -- Commanders of American troops from Australia to the fighting front in North Africa paid tribute tonight to the role of the Military Academy in training the country's new Army and leading it against the enemy.

Parents have a stake in the kind of care a child gets when he goes to nursery school, according to Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the Bureau of Child Hygiene. How about the health precautions -- such as facilities for isolating a child should symptoms of communicable disease turn up?

THERE has been no particular dearth of tokens indicating war's immediate influence on contemporary art. Again and again, since and preceding Pearl Harbor, exhibitions have touched upon or stressed this very thing, so that I am nonplussed by one correspondent's writing in to say that "the artist who is really sincere in painting war pictures doesn't have a remote chance of getting into a show."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 13 (AP) -- Residents of this Northern New York town whose incomes depended largely on accelerated trade during the race meeting today accepted the closing of the Spa track philosophically -- "our first interest is the return of our boys from the front."

ARTURO TOSCANINI, who was taken ill in Philadelphia recently, has recovered and returned to his home in Riverdale here. The concert he is scheduled to give with the NBC Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis on March 24, the day before his seventy-sixth birthday, will be held as planned.

FOR those who admire Robert Schumann's Quintet in E flat for piano and strings, Op. 44, the news this month is good. The Busch Quartet and Rudolf Serkin, pianist, have made a new recording that takes rank, despite certain shortcomings, as the most satisfying available of an endearing work.

Based on results of industry's first year of experience with renegotiation of war contracts, adjustment officials anticipate that Congressional action will be sought by industry groups to amend the renegotiation law in at least three major respects, it was learned here yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 14 (AP) -A communique:
I am puzzled by the continued calls in the newspapers and over the radio for officers in the Waves, Spars and Marines.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Officials said today that they were pleased by the speech made in Algiers by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa. They thought that it expressed a liberal attitude toward the political issues in Algiers, which is constitutionally a part of the French Republic, and that this attitude would have its effect in France herself.
Vegetable growers in the vicinity of New York voiced alarm yesterday over the OPA ceiling price system, which they said threatened the city's year-round supply of fresh foods. [1:1.]

Contrary to pressure from many other labor organizations for wage increases for their members, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., of which Sidney Hillman is president, announced yesterday that it would not ask for a general wage increase for 125,00 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry throughout the country when current agreements are renewed May 1 and May 15.

ALGIERS, March 14 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman told the American soldiers and sailors in North Africa that the war aims of the United States are "strictly defensive against alien, totalitarian world orders," in a speech broadcast today to the armed forces here.

Hundreds of mothers needed in war industries are finding the answer to their problems of child care through two information and counseling services set up by the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children. Directors of the program report a variety of complex family situations in which experienced counselors have been able to help.

GREGORY SPILLETT was haunted by a gleam in the sky, a mysterious flash of white, fleeting glimpses of an aerial being that soared like a rocket into the empyrean. If he could only examine it closely, if he could only catch it and hold it for a few moments, he felt he would ask for nothing more.

Two young singers received Metropolitan Opera Company contracts and the Metropolitan took options on the services of two others at the closing program last evening of the eighth annual Metropolitan Auditions of the Air series, broadcast over Station WJZ and the Blue network.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Taft asserted today that the free enterprise system could solve the problem of post-war unemployment and maintained that further consideration of social security legislation should be postponed until after the war.

Twelve Sundays, an equal number of Saturdays but only one holiday are included in home dates assigned to the Yankees for the 1943 championship season, according to the official American League schedule released for publication today.

SOME fifteen years ago the late J.P. Morgan was sailing his thirty-footer, the Phryne, in Long Island Sound off Larchmont. The second leg of the race was a run to Matinecock Buoy, a scant half-mile from the Morgan estate at Glen Cove. Suddenly the wind flattened out into a dead calm as the Phryne drifted helplessly in the grip of the tide.
Spring fever, feminine gender, involves the sudden desire to rush downtown and invest in something frilly.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was the principal speaker yesterday at a communion breakfast in the Hotel Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue, attended by 300 lay chairmen of the annual drive of the Catholic Charities in the New York Diocese.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -Formation of a Labor party in Philadelphia in preparation for the 1944 Presidential campaign was urged tonight by Dean Alfange, who was the candidate of the American Labor party for Governor of New York at the last election.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The highly political question of legislative reapportionment remains the only really controversial item on the calendar of the Legislature as the 1943 session enters its twelfth and penultimate week.

If the city is not permitted to double its present 1 per cent sales tax in order to balance its 1943-1944 budget, and no substitute sources of revenue are provided, it may have to close its museums and libraries, shut down one of its colleges and change the assignment system of its firemen and policemen, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Oats sold early last week on the Board of Trade here at the highest prices since the 1928-29 crop year, only to break sharply later on announcement that no permits would be required for the movement of grain via the Great Lakes during the early part of the coming season of navigation.

The 1942 annual report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $8,773,669. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 19 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $10,441,266, or 33 cents a common share, in 1941.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 14 -- The Spring series of dinghy sailing was carried on in smooth water at the Larchmont Yacht Club today, with Arthur Knapp, in his Popcorn, and Jack Sutphen, in his Rum Dum, tied at 56 points after seven races.

Frederick W. Teichmann Jr., 15-year-old son of the pastor of Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church, 153d Street, east of Broadway, was stabbed several times at 9:45 o'clock last night by a gang of Negro youths who set upon him and two girl companions at 147th Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, as they were walking home from a church meeting.

After giving its thirty-sixth performance on Saturday night, "This Rock," starring Billie Burke, will vacate the Longacre. The play, written by Walter Livingston Faust, opened here Feb. 18 under the sponsorship and direction of Eddie Dowling.

DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs clinched third place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the champion Red Wings, 5 to 3, before 11,958. The Leafs thus meet Detroit in the play-offs next week.

The Texas Corporation reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $35,060,001 after charges, taxes, depreciation, depletion and a reserve of $12,000,000 for possible losses arising out of the war. The net income was equivalent to $3.22 each on the 10,975,626 capital shares.

A committee of 250 leading trade union leaders, representing both A.F. of L. and C.I.O. unions, and headed by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday that a mass meeting to protest the execution in Soviet Russia last December of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, Polish labor and Socialist leaders, would be held at Mecca Temple on the evening of March 30.

So far as the East is concerned, the 1943 indoor track and field campaign was brought to a successful conclusion with the staging of the Knights of Columbus meet at Madison Square Garden last Saturday night. Two carnivals remain, but these will be at Chicago and Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) -- The Navy stated today that American planes had carried out seven attacks the past two days against Japanese positions in the Aleutians and the Solomons without losing a single United States plane.

An increase of 243,548 lines in New York department store advertising for February, compared with the like month a year ago, is shown in the compilation of Media Records. Main store total was 2,341,257 lines, a gain of 237,173 for the month, while basement advertising amounted to 180,998 lines, an increase of 6,375 lines.

Finishing strongly after a scoreless first period, the Brooklyn Hispanos defeated the Philadelphia Americans by 3 -- 1 in the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup soccer series before 6,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

The Rovers collided head-on with misfortune yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Not only did they suffer their fifth straight setback and their fourth in a row in the Amateur Hockey Association play-off series, but they also lost Cliff Wiest, star center of the first line.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 -Labor leaders closely associated with Philip Murray president of the C.I.O., asserted today that the War Labor Board, by its decision on Saturday in the Oliver Iron Mining Company, apparently has abandoned the "Little Steel" formula for regulating wage rates, which has been under constant attack by the C.I.O., A.F.L. and the Railroad Brotherhoods since it first was promulgated last Summer.

With the coal operators having spoken an emphatic "no" to the demands of the United Mine Workers for a wage increase of $2 a day and a minimum of $8 a day and with only seventeen days left before the expiration on March 31 of the agreement affecting 450,000 bituminous miners, conferences will be resumed this morning between the union and operators of the Appalachian region.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- Referring again to fighting "in the region of Kharkov" the Russians announced this morning the expulsion from their lines of a German wedge, the destruction of nine tanks and the killing of about 500 men.
CHUNGKING, China, March 14 (U.P.) -- A communique:

There are a lamentably few men in high places today with definite land unshakable convictions for which they will stand "come wind or weather, hail or high water," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday on "A Manly Man."
Sales of apartment houses over a wide area formed the bulk of realty trading reported over the week-end in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -President Roosevelt and six Democratic and Republican Senators, in an unusual Sunday conference lasting ninety minutes, agreed today on the general principle that there should be international cooperation backed by military strength to prevent future aggression after the Axis powers are defeated.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -Mrs. William Jackson Clothier, who heads the women's section of the Volunteer Port Security Force of the Coast Guard with the rank of lieutenant, looks upon her new job as a "great opportunity" in the war effort.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 14 -- Vichy was reported tonight to be fearful of using armed force to round up Frenchmen to be sent to Germany as conscripted workers, and was said to plan to try persuasion for some time yet. Should that fail, Vichy will seek to starve out those who have "taken to the bush," particularly in Savoy, near the Swiss border.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- A plan for transfer of the management of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation to Henry J. Kaiser, Pacific Coast shipbuilder who recently entered the aircraft field, will be laid before the Brewster board of directors at a meeting at 1 P.M. Tuesday at the offices of the company in Long Island City.

Following is the text of yesterday's address to the Alsace-Lorraine Society by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, as recorded and translated by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Four new films are scheduled to have local premieres during the week. The openings follow:

Not in many years have the relations between Congress and a President been as strained as they are today. The rejection of the Flynn appointment, the numerous investigations and denunciations in Congress of administrative agencies, the rebuke which the House has just given to the President in passing the Disney bill are symptoms of this strain.

Though it looks and tastes much like cocoa, the concentrate newly arrived in local stores contains no chocolate whatsoever. Rather, it is composed of a curious combination of ingredients that includes dehydrated soy beans, wheat germ, deep-sea kelp, mint leaves, rhubarb, spinach, carrot, celery and skim milk.

LONDON, March 14 (AP)- A Fighting French spokesman declared today that General Giraud's speech "brings Giraud closer to the view of General Charles de Gaulle and the French National Committee if he means what he implies."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 14 -- Eight Dodger players, shepherded by Mel Jones, new road secretary, along with Coach Johnny Corriden and Ted McGrew, chief scout, reached the end of their travels today ready to start this most bizarre of all training seasons.

MOSCOW, March l4 -- An article in Red Star, the army newspaper, estimates the total Italian losses on the Soviet front at 175,000, of whom 60,000 were killed, 69,000 wounded and 46,000 taken prisoner.

CHUNGKING, China, March 14 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces in Yunnan Province are retreating toward their main base at Tengchung after having been driven from several more points west of the Salween River north of Burma, while in Central China the enemy has made no progress during the past twenty-four hours in his drive southward across the Yangtze River, the Chinese High Command announced today.

NEW CASTLE, Del., March 14 -Sufficient strength to elect at least four and possibly five of the seven directors of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation was polled by Giuseppe M. Bellanca, chairman of the board, in a contest with the present management that was not decided until early today.

LONDON, March 14 -- General Henri Honore Giraud's speech today impressed the Fighting French here as representing an advance over Casablanca to the extent that the French Civil and Military Commander in Chief of North and West Africa expressed his faith in the democratic institutions of republican France -- a matter on which, until now, the de Gaullists have frequently complained that General Giraud refused to take a stand.

Calling our "naive trust in Japan" an example of the "false optimism of the western world," Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, preaching the first in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, said we are being "naive" again "in the hope and trust we have in certain other nations of the world."
A Finnish communique as broadcast by the German radio and recorded by The United Press:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Ida Lupino will be starred with Paul Henreid in the Warner Brothers picture "In Our Time," starting March 29. The picture, based on a radio narration by Robert St. John, deals with the romance of a refugee after the Warsaw bombing, and a British aviator.

DES MOINES, March 14 -- The American people will be able to maintain at least the minimum nutrition diet of 3,000 calories a day a person in 1943, but will fall from 5 to 60 per cent below their 1942 consumption of some foods, a survey of State and Federal Government officials indicated today.

The Mayors of the six municipalities on Long Beach Island in Ocean County, N.J., have sent a petition to Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and director of the gas and oil problems of wartime America, that contains some concrete and interesting suggestions.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -The American Farm Bureau Federation made public today a program for stimulating food production which would entail no "additional funds from the Federal Treasury."

Twenty Protestant churches in the area west of Central Park initiated yesterday a "united Lenten preaching program" where similar sermons on "God's Message to Man" were delivered from the various pulpits. Planned as a cooperative movement to reach the entire section west of the park, the program was expected by its originators to serve as a guide for other urban areas.

Once this season the Rangers bowed to the Black Hawks by the humiliating score of 10 to 1. It was the most one-sided defeat suffered by any team in the National Hockey League this season, and the Hawks crowed, while the Rangers could do little but vow revenge.

The Office of Price Administration's "honor system" for motorists collided yesterday with a balmy Sunday, bringing about an increase in passenger car traffic of from 30 to 75 per cent in the metropolitan area.

Moscow, March 14 (AP) -- In fine humor and hoping to be received by Premier Joseph Stalin soon, Admiral William H. Standleyexpressed pleasure today at the recent publication in the Soviet Union of several statements of Edward R. Stettinius Jr., lend-lease administrator, on United States aid to Russia.

The Board of Education made public yesterday a memorandum denying the possibility of an annual saving of $500,000 in school expenses as estimated two months ago by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in a report to Mayor La Guardia.

The elemental problem of getting sufficient food under rationing difficulties to protect New York City's millions against actual hunger will be discussed by representatives of 2,500 grocers at a special meeting this evening at the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce, 169 East Eighty-sixth Street.

James B. Finger, in 1200 5th Ave; Claire E. Petiguat, in 137 E 60th St; Mara Sernberger, in 2 E 75th St; Mrs. Frank Wilks Brooks 3d, in 124 E 84th St; Ralph Guterl, in 44 E 92d St -- Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker.

For many persons the religious struggle of youth was to get rid of dogma, break its intellectual bondage and achieve spiritual freedom, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday.

BOSTON, March 14 -- Petroleum Administrator Harold L. Ickes today put a ceiling on optimism for New England motorists and for householders who burn fuel oil. He again urged conversion to coal burning, held out no hope of increased supplies of gasoline for pleasure driving, and said that next Winter might even find the East Coast oil situation worse than it had been this Winter, if Army and Navy requirements proved heavier.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., March 14 -- In an opinion that may have important future bearing on the corporate structure of holding companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission enunciated today for the first time a set of principles governing service companies and their relation to holding companies and operating subsidiaries.

LONDON, Monday, March 15 -The German High Command said in a special communique last night that Kharkov had been re-taken by an enveloping movement from north and east, but the midnight Red Army communique referred only to desperate fighting in the Kharkov area, to the north and in the Izyum-Donets area, to the southeast.

Three thousand persons joined yesterday afternoon in a "salute to the Red rny of Soviet Russia" in Manhattan 'Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. The rally was sponsored by the nationalities division of Russian War Relief. Twenty-five sections, including Hungarian, Czechoslovak, Italian, German, Finnish, Greek and Belgian, participated.

Leopold Stokowski and the NBC Symphony Orchestra presented two novelties yesterday afternoon which were beautiful and were stunningly played. They were settings by Morton Gould, young American composer, of Chinese and Russian military songs.

New York does more than any other city in the United States to provide diversion, entertainment and sleeping accommodations for service men, despite recently published reports to the contrary, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Major league baseball players, augmented by some home town talent, easily defeated a Sarasota Army Air Base nine today, 9 to 4.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Monday, March 15 (AP) -- The command noon communique:
LONDON, March 14 (U.P.) -- The Russian midday communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio:

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Reports that ceiling prices might be placed on hogs soon resulted early last week in a sharp break in the market, but the decline resulted in farmers refusing to sell freely and part of the loss was recovered later.

The Regional Plan Association urged yesterday the immediate passage of the Hampton-Mitchell bill amending the Redevelopment Companies Law as a means of speeding the reconstruction of slum areas with private capital as soon as war conditions permit.

LONDON, March 14 -- London's great savings effort, the "Wings for Victory" campaign, took precedence last week over all other financial activities, although the results should have a stimulating effect on sentiment and possibly pave the way for some revival of the stock markets now that diversion of such huge sums from ordinary investment channels has ceased.
The day the world fully realized its danger from Germany, having meanwhile allowed it to grow to gigantic dimensions, was March 15, 1939. On that day THE NEW YORK TIMES wrote:
A German communique as broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The United Press:
Following is the text of the address delivered yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman to the American armed forces in North Africa, as recorded here from radio broadcast:

A blanket increase of $4.50 a week for 5,000 inside employes of 169 milk companies and a fiftyfour-hour week with overtime provisions for 8,000 drivers and garage workers were recommended yesterday by Ralph Seward, impartial chairman of the milk industry, in a report to the National War Labor Board.

Red Cross offices throughout the city reported yesterday a heavy demand for tickets for the big "Red Cross at War" rally in Madison Square Garden tonight, which will serve as a mid-month climax point in the city-wide drive to meet its quota of $12,920,700 toward the national goal of $125,000,000 for the Red Cross.

LONDON, March 14 -- While the United States' social security plan has aroused much interest in London financial circles, comments as yet are restricted. This may be because it covers a much wider field than the Beveridge scheme and because it is as yet lacking in detailed proposals.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Wartime conditions have not only slowed the State's railway grade-crossing elimination program but have increased the number of gradecrossing accidents, it was revealed today in the annual report of the Public Service Commission which will be submitted to Governor Dewey and the legislature tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 -- A rise in the volume of new steel orders, an increase in raw steel output and the existence of some confusion as the steel industry and its consumers swung into the Controlled Materials Plan featured news of the steel industry last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 14 -- Far-reaching repercussions of Vice President Henry A. Wallace's speech become most evident this week-end both in the highest Turkish circles close to the reformed government of Premier Shukru Saracoglu and in the alert, well-informed Turkish press, as well as in foreign diplomatic quarters in the Anatolian capital.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Stockholders of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, without dividends since 1931, are not likely to share in the road's wartime prosperity, at least in the immediate future, J.L. Beven, president, indicated in a letter sent to stockholders today.

Today is the day. While clerks in the offices of the Collector of Internal Revenue yesterday struggled with huge heaps of mailed income tax forms, taxpayers labored, too, against the deadline of midnight tonight.

" We are living in the most critical moment of history that this earth has ever seen. Let us ask God for His help and strength that we may do our part, whatever our part may be," Bishop William T. Manning, in his sermon yesterday morning, advised a confirmation class of twenty-two and the congregation of the Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

The Phillips Petroleum Company and its subsidiaries in the annual statement for 1942, for publication today show, after all charges, reserves and taxes, a net profit of $13,129,458, equal to $2.95 each on the average number of shares outstanding.

Exhortatory prodding from Washington and obvious shortages in the pantry will produce a good many more gardeners this year than there have ever been before. They may even produce the silent gardener, but this remains to be seen.

While awaiting action by Congress in respect to pending agricultural legislation, traders in cotton futures last week continued to withhold large-scale forward commitments. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the period with irregular price changes, showing an advance of 16 points to a decline of 2 points, following net losses of 5 to 12 points in the preceding week.

Heavier taxes and heavier costs, despite operation at 103 per cent of capacity and a gain from 3,887,335 to 4,548,844 tons in annual production, cut the net profit of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation from $15,499,983, or $10.85 a common share, in 1941, to $10,141,690, of $4.49, last year.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 14 -The Giants took this pine-studded resort by storm today when a gathering of 1,200, headed by Mayor William W. Curtis, greeted Manager Mel Ott's squad of players on their arrival to launch their wartime Spring training campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Senator Taft of Ohio objected today to what he termed the "commandeering" of all United States radio stations by Elmer Davis, chief of the Office of War Information, for the dissemination of "propaganda broadcasts."

Marked progress in production of natural rubber, Manila hemp, roselle, rotenone, rice, cocoa and other strategic and essential crops was reported yesterday by the United Fruit Company in a document that covers eight months from July of last year and deals with efforts to replace, in ten countries of Central and South America, the raw materials from which this country was shut off by the Japanese invasions of Malaya and the Netherlands Indies.

The United States Maritime Service has just leased part of the former Otto H. Kahn estate near Huntington, L.I., for use as a preliminary radio school, the War Shipping Administration announced yesterday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTEKS in Australia, Monday, March 15 (AP) -- Two more Japanese ships in the eight-vessel convoy off Wewak, in Northern New Guinea, have been hit, including a destroyer, a communique said today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -Congress will be occupied chiefly this week with taxes and farm labor. The House Ways and Means Committee will have ready tomorrow a draft of its composite tax plan -- which its opponents contend is no plan at all -- and it is expected that the bill will reach the House floor toward the end of the week.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 111.3 to 111.55. The increase in the general level was due to higher prices for farm products and some industrial commodities.

All is in readiness for the sixth annual national invitation basketball tournament which will start at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. The list of eight teams, completed last week, includes three local quintets, St. John's, Fordham and Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A Navy flier was attacked by thirty-one Japanese warplanes and received eleven wounds, but lived to tell the story.

Reflecting the continued urgency of war requirements, the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company, Ltd., established a new high record for annual tonnage of ore mined and metal products in 1942, as it did in 1941, according to the annual report released for publication today by R.H. Channing, president.

With civilians being required to take a rationing notch in their belts, the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command is doing its share to conserve food without stinting the healthy appetites of soldiers in training.

It is impossible to overestimate the importance of the conferences now taking place in Washington between President Roosevelt and Anthony Eden and their respective aides, for their results will go far in determining the future order of the world. The foundation for that order was laid down at the conference between Mr. Roosevelt and Premier Churchill which produced the Atlantic Charter that is the basic covenant among the United Nations.

The past year was one of the most active in the history of the Jewish Hospital, with 17,978 patients being hospitalized, 1,067 more than during 1941, it was reported last night at the forty-first annual meeting at the hospital, St. Marks and Classon Avenues, Brooklyn.

President Roosevelt's recent message to Congress, submitting proposals for post-war economy and a program of social security "from the cradle to the grave," was hailed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as an "emancipation message to Congress that will take its place alongside Lincoln's proclamation."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 14 -- Like the characters in a well-known Italian play in search of an author, the men in charge of Finland's destiny today are in search of a policy. In response to the well-nigh general desire of the Finnish people to get out of the war, Finnish statesmen are groping for a formula, but so far have found none likely to satisfy both Finland and her Russian adversary.

Formation of "layette clubs" in local sewing centers is keeping pace with the city's zooming birth rate. Service men's wives, many of them with no source of income apart from their monthly allotments, comprise a substantial proportion of the membership.
LONDON, March 14 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

NEWARK, N.J., March 14 -- The New Jersey State C.I.O. Industrial Union Council, at its conference on "Health and Recreation Needs for Workers in War Time," demanded today that Captain Eddie Rickenbacker give "factual proof" to a committee proposed by Representative Mary T. Norton (New Jersey Democrat) of his charges "laying the blame for absenteeism at labor's door."
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -The War Department reported today the names of 257 Army personnel held prisoners of war by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands.

ALGIERS, March 14 -- Frenchmen gained new confidence in their great tradition of "liberty, equality and fraternity" today when General Henri Honore Giraud announced the broad principles on which democratic government would be speedily reintroduced to French North Africa and promised the people of metropolitan France that their government would be reconstituted under the laws of the Third Republic once victory had been won.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 14 -- The Yankees were billeted in this snow-flecked resort tonight, awaiting the summons tomorrow to their first workout of 1943.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Dewey tonight ordered Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, to go to Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens and to take all steps necessary to end the epidemic of amoebic dysentery there.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 14 -- Allied forces have taken up the offensive in Northern Tunisia, frontline dispatches disclosed today, while fighting in the area of the Mareth Line appeared to be developing into an artillery combat between Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's Axis troops and the British Eighth Army.

LONDON, March 14 -- The official statement that Great Britain and her principal allies are engaged in discussion of post-war currency problems has aroused the greatest interest in financial London, which already, is visualizing the restoration of the gold standard or something very closely resembling it.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Dewey tonight ordered Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, to go to Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens and to take all steps necessary to end the epidemic of amoebic dysentery there.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 14 -- Allied forces have taken up the offensive in Northern Tunisia, frontline dispatches disclosed today, while fighting in the area of the Mareth Line appeared to be developing into an artillery combat between Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's Axis troops and the British Eighth Army.

LONDON, March 14 -- The official statement that Great Britain and her principal allies are engaged in discussion of post-war currency problems has aroused the greatest interest in financial London, which already, is visualizing the restoration of the gold standard or something very closely resembling it.

Sergeant John F. Bartek has lent the American Bible Society the copy of the Bible that he and Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and their comrades read at their daily prayer meetings while they were afloat in a rubber raft on the Pacific last year.

ALGIERS, March 14 -- Frenchmen gained new confidence in their great tradition of "liberty, equality and fraternity" today when General Henri Honore Giraud announced the broad principles on which democratic government would be speedily reintroduced to French North Africa and promised the people of metropolitan France that their government would be reconstituted under the laws of the Third Republic once victory had been won.

The fourteen winning essays qualifying for the finals in the three divisions of the Thomas Jefferson Bi-Centennial Essay Contest being conducted in New York City by THE NEW YORK TIMES will be judged by Dr. George M. Wiley, Associate Commissioner, and these four other officials of the New York State Education Department:

James Mill's letter of march 8 seems to misinterpret Dr. Virgil Jordan's speech as reported in your paper of Feb. 26. To quote from the report, Dr. Jordan explicitly said: "* * * but we should not imagine, whatever our income bracket, that by this we are shifting any of the cost (of the war) to posterity."

In the first half of last week, the stock market declined, but recovered on Thursday and Friday. Bonds were strong, reaching at the week-end the year's highest average. War news was perhaps less favorable. The President's message of Wednesday, reviving, with no reference to their expense, domestic policies of the "New Deal" order, was not reflected in the market, where it seemed to be felt that Congress would not accept the proposition.

Net sales of Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended with January were $635,006,979, a slight dollar increase over the previous record of $632,708,657 established in the preceding year, although the volume of merchandise sold declined, Sewell L. Avery, chairman, reported in the annual statement issued for release today.

The Marshall Club gained another point in the senior division of the annual competition for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday, defeating the visiting North Jersey team, 7 1/2 -- 1/2.

Memorial services will be held here and in other parts of the country today for fifty-four dead or missing members of the Merchant Marine Cadet Corps. The corps was established five years ago today to train young men to become officers in the merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -Tomorrow midnight is the zero hour for America's income tax army, 40,000,000 strong.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- There was a marked let-up last week in reports of dry weather in the Southwest, as that area received considerable snow which furnished surface moisture and checked deterioration in the outlook for the crop.

CHUNGKING, China, March 10 (Delayed) -- A recent arrival from Nanking said today that the Japanese there had commenced a huge drive to collect silver and copper coins and other metal for scrap that would "practically sweep Central China clean of native capital and resources."
Opposition to the Murray-Todd bill, pending in Albany, which would extend and amend the War Emergency Dispensation Act, is now being registered in Albany by a score of local organizations.

LONDON, Monday, March 15 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force's Whirlwind fighter-bombers renewed the Allied attack over the German-held French coast yesterday, battering enemy airfields at Abbeville and Maupertus, and British fighters swept over Northern France, destroying at least two Nazi planes.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, who did all their scoring during a blistering second-period attack, prolonged their National Hockey League play-off hopes by holding the late-storming Bruins to a 4-4 tie tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden. The line-up:

The consumer scare buying of apparel that was set off last month by the rationing of shoes appeared to be under control last week, and this was reflected by more sober trading at wholesale, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Establishment of a permanent ceiling price on corn by the Office of Price Administration is regarded by grain traders as having further complicated an already acute situation, and few operators expect that the present ceiling can be made operative except for a brief period.

MOSCOW, March 14 (AP) -- Soviet Russia's long Winter is nearly over. It was a very mild Winter, the natives say, nothing like last year, when the mercury rested in sub-zero zones of the thermometer for days at a time.
Opposition to the Murray-Todd bill, pending in Albany, which would extend and amend the War Emergency Dispensation Act, is now being registered in Albany by a score of local organizations.

LONDON, Monday, March 15 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force's Whirlwind fighter-bombers renewed the Allied attack over the German-held French coast yesterday, battering enemy airfields at Abbeville and Maupertus, and British fighters swept over Northern France, destroying at least two Nazi planes.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, who did all their scoring during a blistering second-period attack, prolonged their National Hockey League play-off hopes by holding the late-storming Bruins to a 4-4 tie tonight before 10,000 at the Boston Garden. The line-up:

The consumer scare buying of apparel that was set off last month by the rationing of shoes appeared to be under control last week, and this was reflected by more sober trading at wholesale, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Establishment of a permanent ceiling price on corn by the Office of Price Administration is regarded by grain traders as having further complicated an already acute situation, and few operators expect that the present ceiling can be made operative except for a brief period.

Knowledge of every branch of the theatrical business must have come to Alex A. Aarons early in life, for he was a son of Alfred E. Aarons, who spent fifty years in the theatre, principally in association with Klaw Erlanger. The father, who died in 1936 at the age of 71, is said to have originated the modern system of booking road shows.

The National Urban League for Social Service Among Negroes announced yesterday that it had launched its eleventh vocational opportunity campaign, to continue through Sunday. Its purpose is further to stimulate the use of Negro manpower in the war, according to Julius A. Thomas, director of the league's department of industrial relations, and this year the part that Negro womanpower can play in providing an adequate labor supply is being emphasized.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Although trading in cash corn proceeded more smoothly here today on the Board of Trade, there is a great deal of confusion in some of the terminal markets and in the country regarding new price ceilings and regulations that were announced Saturday.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Opposition to the legislative reapportionment bill crumbled completely tonight on the eve of the vote as the strength of the Democratic organizations in the Bronx and Brooklyn was thrown to the Republican-sponsored measure.

Railroad shares broke sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of the long-awaited Supreme Court ruling which upheld the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan for reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific.
The two five-story apartment houses containing forty-two apartments at 95-103 West 163d Street were sold by the H.W. Wilson Company to an investing client of J.P. McCann, broker.
The westerly half of the twentieth floor in 39 Broadway was leased to the Parry Navigation Company, Inc., through Carl A. Leasenfeld, broker, and the Fred F. French Management Company, agents.

There will be only two Broadway openings next week as the result of the postponement of "The Family" from March 23 to March 30 at the Windsor. The other productions still scheduled to arrive next week are "Apology" on Monday, March 22, at the Mansfield, and "Richard III," Wednesday, March 24, at the Forrest.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering terminated a nine-day "incognito" visit to Rome this afternoon, returning to Germany in his armored train, according to private reports from Italy tonight.

A hospital plan for needy circus troupers was announced yesterday by the Circus Saints and Sinners Club, 292 Madison Avenue, composed of business men, theatrical persons and government officials. The original purpose of the organization was to provide a home for aged troupers.

If this world's blessings were evenly distributed every American soldier overseas would receive about twelve letters a week. The average soldier gets that many, out of the fifteen to twenty million sent out by Army postal service every seven days. But we all know that there is no average soldier, any more than there is an average citizen.

Charges of a secret agreement between the governments of the United States and Great Britain by which American chemical exporters are prevented from competing with British products in certain Empire colonies were made yesterday at a meeting of foreign traders held under the auspices of the New York Board of Trade in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

How do President Roosevelt and Mr. Churchill know that Spring is at hand? Because of any number of things. Because the Australian authorities are expecting a Japanese offensive and want more airplanes.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- In the face of widespread Congressional opposition to definite commitments at this stage of the war, the four sponsors of a Senate resolution calling for setting up by this country of a detailed program of closer immediate and post-war United Nations collaboration decided today, after conferring with Senator Connally, Foreign Relations Committee chairman, to introduce their measure tomorrow for a showdown.
An Italian High Command communique broadcast by Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The value of 1942 shipments aggregating $302,492,000 was about four times that of 1941 sales of $73,745,000 and three times the highest Annual volume ever before attained by the American Locomotive Company, William C. Dickerman, chairman of the board, declared in the forty-first annual statement issued to stockholders yesterday.

]earts aglow with memories of glorious deeds by the Irish from Brian Boru to Colin Kelly, the wearers of the green will march up Fifth Avenue tomorrow by the thousands to the lilt of Celtic laughter and the music of Hibernian bands.
LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

BERNE, March 15 (AP) -- German Elite Guard and regular troops were reported tonight to be rounding up Frenchmen for forced labor by house-to-house raids in Lyon and other districts, in some cases seizing Frenchmen and shipping them off to Germany by freight carloads without allowing them to communicate with their families.

Taking sharp issue with plans recently outlined by the Board of Economic Warfare for the disposition after the war of commodities accumulated by this country in foreign countries, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange charged yesterday, in an open letter to Vice President Henry A. Wallace, that such plans will bring about the "strangulation" of our normal peacetime methods of doing business.

CHUNGKING, China, March 15 (AP) -- The Chinese press declared today that the Japanese Premier, General Hideki Tojo, wished to make Wang Ching-wei, head of the puppet Nanking government, a virtual quartermaster-general for the exploitation of Chinese resources and manpower in the Pacific war.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Vice President Wallace is leaving "early this week," with the actual time of departure an official secret, upon a good-will and information-seeking tour which will take him to seven Latin-American republics.

Funeral services for J.P. Morgan will be held at 10 o'clock this morning, attended by his immediate family, friends and close business associates, in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square, from which his father was buried in 1913.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, March 16 (AP) -- The noon communique:

MOSCOW, March 15 (Reuter) -- Germans have special units whose job it is to carry out such orders as that recently given by the commander of the 337th German Infantry Division -- "in case of forced retreat destroy and burn all towns and villages."

ALBANY, March 15 -- A special report of Elliot V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks on the operations of trust companies and trust departments of banks was presented to the Legislature tonight, covering operations for the past twenty years.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Increases of $313,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $199,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and $811,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $248,000,000 in United States Government deposits.
CHUNGKING, China, March 15 (U.P.) -- A special communique:

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 15 -- The Governors and representatives of twelve Midwest States recommended to the Federal Government today that agriculture be recognized as an essential war industry with guarantees of adequate labor and machinery to meet the 1943 goals for record food production.

ALBANY, March 15 -- February receipts of the Motor Vehicle Bureau were nearly $13,500,000, up $6,000,000 from the same month in 1942. The State Tax Commission said an unexpected last-minute rush for the 1943 strips swelled the February receipts, while the first day of February set a new record for a single day's business.

Price ceilings alone will not curb inflation, in the opinion of members of twenty-eight national organizations who have joined in a plea for informative labels on clothing and other products. Leaders have collected 15,000 signatures on petitions stating their case and are seeking an audience this week with Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, to discuss this means of linking price to quality and thereby circumventing hidden price increases.

Now that the Nazis have recaptured Kharkov it is a forceful reminder that the Russian armies, for all their spectacular Winter victories, are no more invincible than the German armies with which Hitler set out to conquer the world. The Russians cannot win this war alone.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull today warmly commended General Giraud's speech in Algiers Sunday.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 15 -- If batting practice comes, Spring can't be far behind.

MONTREAL, March 15 (AP) -- Captain Clarence Alvin (Duke) Schiller, 43 years of age, internationally-known pilot of the Royal Air Force Ferry Command and colorful veteran of numerous mercy missions, was killed yesterday in a crash at Bermuda that also took the lives of an unannounced number of his crew.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The proposal to give the vote to the youths and girls between the ages of 18 and 21 has been rejected by the Assembly's Judiciary Committee.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Keeper of the Flame," which will arrive at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. The film, which was produced by Metro and co-stars Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy, was directed by George Cukor.

New York's thousands of trout fishermen, looking forward to the first Saturday in April, will find their favorite streams well stocked with brooks, browns and rainbows on the opening day of the season, according to the announcement released today by the New York State Conservation Department.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A list of thirty-eight industrial establishments selected to receive the Army-Navy production award was announced today by the Under-Secretary of War, Robert P. Patterson, and the Under-Secretary of the Navy, James V. Forrestal.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Awards of Air Medals to officers and enlisted personnel of the Air Forces for meritorious achievements while participating in more than 200 hours of anti-submarine patrol flight during 1942 were announced by the War Department today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- Cold nights in the open, lack of organization and the ban on crossing into Switzerland are inducing the surrender of many French youths who had taken to the bush in Savoy to escape compulsory labor in Germany, it was indicated today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 15 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek had luncheon at the Bear Mountain Lodge here today with Dr. Li Yu Ying, president of the Chinese National Academy, and returned to New York in the evening after strolling about the grounds of the lodge and the adjacent Bear Mountain Inn during the afternoon. Dr. Li lives at the lodge.

The Italian High Command declared in a communique broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press yesterday that the liner Empress of Canada, laden with troops, had been sunk in the Atlantic by an Italian submarine.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The plan to double the rates of the New York City sales tax and business taxes hit a serious obstacle today when it was disclosed that Democrats in the State Legislature and in the City Council will act as a unit in opposing the measure.

Yesterday's last-minute rush to make quarterly income tax payments created no disturbance in the New York money market. Rates remained easy, thanks to the advance preparations made by the monetary authorities. It is estimated that ten days to two weeks must elapse before the Treasury is able to put all of the income checks through for collection.
MOSCOW, March 15 -- Although the Russians have been forced to withdraw in the Kharkov region, violent fighting continues between powerful German armored forces and Russian artillery and infantry.
A seven-room penthouse apartment in 55 East Eighty-sixth Street has been leased to B.M. Kaufman through Duff Conger, Inc., agents, by Francis R. Jaffin, broker. Other rentals follow:
