In one of the first utilizations of the recently enacted proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Austin Agnew, retired member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Shippee Rawson, is seeking to force the management of the American Ice Company to make "radical" changes in its financial policy.
I fully concur with your views as stated in your editorial of March 3, "Finland as a Test Case."

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Sweeping reorganization of the Office of Price Administration including a house-cleaning of young lawyers, was foreshadowed tonight by Prentiss M. Brown, OPA Administrator. The move is expected to start in earnest within two months.

The seventh annual faculty art show opened yesterday at University Hall, Columbia University. Oils, water-colors, prints and wood carvings by members of the teaching and administrative staffs are included. The exhibition will continue through Monday.

Various aspects of the Navy during this war will be discussed at the Booksellers League dinner tomorrow at the Hotel Brevoort. Speakers will be Gilbert Cant, whose "Ameria's Navy in World War II" will be published by John Day on May 27; Edmund Gilligan, author of "The Gaunt Woman" (Scribner); Lt. Comdr. Paul W. Townsend, who recently returned from active duty in Africa, and John Hersey, author of "Into the Valley" (Knopf).

The sharp gains in population which the Pacific Coast is enjoying will be retained permanently to a large degree, Emmil Brisacher, president of Brisacher, Davis Van Norden, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 3 per cent in sales last week as compared with the corresponding week of 1942, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 15 -- The problem of "who's on first," which has been vexing the Giants ever since it became reasonably certain that Johnny Mize soon would be indicted into the Army, was partly solved today even before the squad had completed its first workout of the year.

OCALA, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Louise Hampton Wartmann was married here today to Lieut. Gen. Brehon Burke Somervell, chief of the Army's Services of Supply, whom she had known since he was a West Point cadet.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops in Western Burma have suffered heavy losses in unsuccessful attacks on British positions north of the strategic port of Akyab, it was announced today, and the Royal Air Force and the Tenth United States Air Force struck heavily at the enemy over the week-end in widespread operations that cost them five planes.

The Hotel Waldorf-Astoria and Oscar Tschirky, its famed host, jointly observed their fiftieth anniversaries at a dinner last night. Since March 15, 1893, the Waldorf and Oscar have been home and host to generations of visitors from all parts of the world.
"OUT of the kindness of my heart I gave him a ten-pound note," said Tom Keane, puffing contentedly on his curved pipe. "And that's all he got out of the race."
MLWAUKEE, March 15 (U.P.) -- Johnny Maras, 15 years old, who spent a few months in the Army, is under arrest on charges of desertion.

Planning the home garden, canning its produce and organizing community gardening were discussed yesterday at the first of the Garden Week course of lectures presented by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 15 -- Chemists and bacteriologists in the laboratory of the California Quartermaster Depot, who help guard the health of the American soldier in Western Army camps and on Pacific battlefronts, gazed with lost appetites the other day at an unfamiliar can of food.

A rise in milk prices to cover increased labor costs involved in a wage award to 5,000 inside plant employes of 169 milk companies in the metropolitan area was urged yesterday by R.E. Coffey, chairman of the New York-New Jersey Milk Distributors Committee, representing the majority of the companies.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Paid vacations for productive war workers as a method of minimizing absentees was advocated today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 15 -- A German blow at the Allies' sea supply route along the Algerian coast was frustrated yesterday when British Spitfires drove back eight Heinkel-111 torpedo-bombers, destroying one and damaging several more.

Shaken by loss of confidence in ultimate enactment of the Pace bill, the cotton futures market fluctuated nervously yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in very dull trading, values dropping to final net losses of 5 to 19 points as demand proved particularly scant near the close.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 16 (UP) -- The Soviet Monday midnight communique broadcast by Moscow:

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Edward J. Flynn, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said after a conference with President Roosevelt today he thought there were "too many people in the United States who are fighting the President instead of fighting the enemy."

LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- Admiral Erich Raeder, deposed former head of the German Navy, was at odds with the High Command over demands for carrying on intensive submarine warfare too far from home, it was said today in a Tass [Russian news agency] dispatch recorded here by the Soviet monitor.

Continuation of the "penny milk" program by which 261,000 children in the city's schools are enabled to buy a half pint of milk at lunch time for a cent was assured yesterday by an agreement among the Board of Education, milk handlers and the American Can Company.

Three owners of gasoline service stations in Queens were found to have been illegally purchasing gasoline ration books to provide extra service for customers, in hearings yesterday in the offices of the American Arbitration Association, 15 West Forty-eighth Street, by the Regional Office of Price Administration.
PITTSBURGH, March 15 (AP) -- The Pirates received word today that Outfielder Eddie Stewart and Aldon Wilkie, southpaw pitcher, would not report for training.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Production of cotton fabrics last year topped the 11,250,000,000-yard mark, establishing a new record for output, the textile, leather and clothing division of the War Production Board announced today. Last year's production figure was 7 per cent greater than the preceding year's and fully one-third larger than in 1939, the last year for which final census of manufacturers' figures are available.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Appointment of a labor advisory committee in the War Production Board's steel division was announced today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB. This was done to achieve closer cooperation of labor and management for the increasing of steel production, he explained.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 15 -- United States medium bombers, escorted by British and American fighters, raided enemy positions near Mareth yesterday. Other American fighters carried out sweeps over the forward area. Neither formation encountered any opposition and Axis air activity in general was reported to be on an extremely small scale.

We see by the papers that a four-masted schooner is getting ready to sail from this port. The mere mention of her is enough to carry antiquarian memories back to South Street and its show of bowsprits and figureheads. These four-masters were a well-known family once.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 15 -- The Export-Import Bank has given Brazil credits totaling $150,000,000, its president, Warren Lee Pierson, said in Sao Paulo, according to a correspondent of the newspaper Globe.

NEW DELHI, India, March 14 (Delayed) -- That Mohandas K. Gandhi has lost by his fast with every one except his Hindu followers is even more obvious in New Delhi than in Bombay. It ranks as a great mystery, with nobody really understanding quite what he wanted to do or knowing what he can do next.

CHUNGKING, China, March 15 -- The week-old Japanese drive in Northern Hunan Province has "completely collapsed" under a furious Chinese counter-attack that recaptured at least seven towns during the past twenty-four hours and inflicted heavy casualties on the enemy, it was announced today.

Dartmouth's Indians, who continued their rule of the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League for the sixth consecutive year, carried their domination right into the 1943 All-League team, chosen for The Associated Press by the coaches of the league's seven quintets.

The unusual spectacle of a mother and daughter putting on a joint style show held the luncheon audience in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel spellbound yesterday. They not only looked but listened as Florence Reichman and her daughter, Rejean, carried on a lively and enlightening dialogue about the styles being presented.

NEWCASTLE, Del., March 15 -- Giuseppe M. Bellanca regained control of the board of directors of Bellanca Aircraft Corporation late tonight at the conclusion of the annual meeting of the stockholders, but, through an adroit manoeuvre by the incumbents, failed to elect the officers.

Award of a new tissue of $129,500 town of Cheektowaga (N.Y.) Drainage and Sewer District No. 5 bonds, dated April 1, 1943 and due from 1944 to 1963, was made yesterday to C.F. Childs Co., Inc., and Sherwood Co. The bankers jointly bid 100.137, naming the interest rate as 1.80 per cent.

PANAMA, March 15 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, arrived here yesterday from Colombia after completing a tour in South America as chairman of the United States National Committee of the Inter-American Development Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Roosevelt received, among other callers, Mayor Erastus Corning of Albany, N.Y.; Edward J. Flynn and Jonathan Daniels.

The wave of "muggings" spread to the Bronx early today when a woman, on her way home from work, was set upon by a handbag thief, and when she refused to give up her purse, was stabbed and seriously wounded in the right side of the chest with an icepick, which pierced her lung.

Minority holders of first refunding mortgage bonds of the Third Avenue Railway will ask Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy today to restrain the Third Avenue Transit Corporation from paying approximately $275,000, interest which is payable April 1 on the junior adjustment income bonds.

Archie O. Dawson, Moreland Act Commissioner, yesterday temporarily suspended his investigation of the Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens to allow Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Commissioner of Health, to make an extensive inspection there.

LONDON, March 15 -- Only a small amount of business was transacted in today's stock market, where the tone generally was firm. Gilt-edged issues showed a firmer tendency on the success of "Wings for Victory Week."

Bowing to the inevitable arrival of the income tax deadline last midnight, hundreds of thousands of Americans paid up yesterday and did it with notable good grace. The collectors' offices at 110 East Forty-fifth Street and the Custom House, each of which had been receiving 50,000 visitors a day, were more crowded than ever.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court, reversing itself, agreed today to review the convictions of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone, alleged members of Murder, Inc., whose last hope of escaping execution had seemingly ended.
ALBANY, March 15 -- A bill making alimony payments a proper deduction in calculating State income tax went to Governor Dewey today for signature after unanimous approval by the Senate.

The draw for the opening round in the Eastern play-offs for the N.C.A.A. basketball championship, which is to start at Madison Square Garden on March 24, was made yesterday at the weekly meeting of the Basketball Writers Association at Toots Shor's restaurant.

More cotton for stronger stocking tops is the War Production Board's answer to the women's hosiery problem. To prolong the wear of rayon stockings, WPB announces that British cotton yarns, which are imported in the gray state, are being mercerized in this country.

The "realistic team-work" between the War Department and industry has brought a substantial amount of war work to New York City in recent weeks. George A. Sloan, Commissioner of the City Department of Commerce, declared yesterday at a luncheon given by the Army Ordnance Association at the Hotel Commodore, prior to a preview of an ordnance exhibit in the Chrysler Building.
NEW DELHI, India, March 15 (AP) -- communique:

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- With American fish production at virtually its lowest ebb and falling steadily below even normal demands despite efforts to increase it as requirements of the Army and Navy and the United Nations grow, protests have been received here against British restrictions on the taking and purchase of fish in Bahaman waters.

Though the President endorsed the principle of pay-as-you-go taxation at a press conference on Jan. 8 and again in his annual budget message, in which he asked Congress "to put our taxes as far as feasible on a pay-as-you-go basis," he now declares himself to be opposed to the Ruml plan.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 16 -- Aerial action against Japanese shipping north of Australia flared into a series of blows yesterday led by a furious assault on three medium-sized Japanese transports filled with troops. Allied planes heavily damaged two of the transports with direct bomb hits, setting fires, and long-range fighters raked the troop-packed decks, killing many.

TRENTON, N.J., March 15 -- Governor Charles Edison charged today that State Senator Harry Runyon of Warren County had demanded appointment as judge of the Common Pleas Court and served notice he would confirm no one else for the place.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 15 (U.P.) -- The Germans have checked a British attempt to improve the Allied defense positions in the Tamera area of northern Tunisia in a sharp week-end battle that broke the rain-enforced lull, field reports said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Walter Wanger will produce for Universal a film tribute to the Second Marine Raider Battalion, under the title "Gung Oh," the battle cry of the raiders in action at Makin and Guadalcanal, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 172 United States soldiers missing in action in the European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, served a formal ultimatum yesterday upon the bituminous operators of the Appalachian region that 450,000 soft coal diggers would stop work if a new agreement granting the union's demands for a wage increase of $2 a day and other changes was not reached by midnight March 31, when the current contract expires.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- United States fliers continued their stepped-up aerial offensive in widely separated areas of the Pacific front over the week-end, damaging enemy planes in the Aleutians and destroying a Japanese ship in the New Georgia group.
Beauty-shop owners and operators of the nation were called upon yesterday to play their part in the war by setting up salons in every war plant to increase production and combat absenteeism.

With six cities and Puerto Rico represented, Philadelphia led the list of thirty-one survivors with eight boxers as the Eastern competition in the 1943 Golden Gloves tournament of champions began last night at the Ridgewood Grove S.C. in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Employers need not seek approval of the War Labor Board to bring wage or salary rates up to 40 cents an hour, it was announced by the board today as part of its program to simplify procedure and speed the handling of small wage and salary adjustment cases.

As the climax of the biggest rally of the 1943 Red Cross war campaign, announcements that New York City already has raised $5,107,000 toward its goal of $12,920,700 and that the nation as a whole has pledged $50,000,000 of the $125,000,000 sought by the Red Cross brought storms of applause last night from an audience of Red Cross volunteer workers that filled Madison Square Garden.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 15 -- Fourteen strong, the Yankees opened training today at the Asbury Park High School field.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 16 (AP) -- British and German planes traded aerial blows across the English Channel last night, the Royal Air Force striking first at a Nazi air field in France and the Germans retaliating with raids on the northeast coast of Britain.

Official notification from Washington raising the age limit for nurses to 45 years for Amy duty is expected to create a rise in enlistment here, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday. Notification was given to headquarters here by Lieut. Col. Florence A. Blanchfield, acting superintendent for Army nurses.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A recruiting agreement whereby neither French group would permit accessions from the armed forces of the other without its consent will be one goal of the meeting soon to take place at Algiers between General Henri Honore Giraud, Civil and Military Commander in North Africa, and General Georges Catroux, representing General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, it was understood here today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 15 -- Milton M. Unger, Newark attorney, applied before Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays here today for a fee of $301,000 for his services in obtaining for preferred stockholders of the American Car and Foundry Company $2,399,540 in dividends as a result of a successful suit by Oscar B. Cintas, former Cuban Ambassador to the United States.

The most recent pronouncements of both General Giraud and General de Gaulle come very close to agreement on principles. The final unification of all Frenchmen in their common struggle for the liberation of France has now become a matter of national discipline and of the ability to subordinate personal ambitions and doctrinaire purposes to the common good of France and her allies.

The post-war era will see another global war of gigantic dimensions against an invisible army of countless billions of disease-carriers against which defense measures must be undertaken immediately. This was the keynote yesterday at the all-day session of the National Conference on Planning for War and Post-War Medical Services, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the auspices of the Carlos Finley Institute of the Americas.

A conference of New York State vegetable growers has prepared a report giving views on price ceilings of farmers in the fresh fruit and vegetable producing areas of the Northeast and North Central States. The report will be sent immediately from Albany to members of the New York delegation in Congress, to high officials of the Office of Price Administration, the Department of Agriculture and the Office of the Director of Economic Stabilization.

CHUNGKING, China, March 15 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the newly formed Fourteenth United States Army Air Force in the Chinese war theatre, said in a speech today that after a long period of waiting he could see the day approaching "when we can have equality in arms and then superiority" over the Japanese.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 15 -- The American people will hesitate about agreeing to any limitation of their sovereignty at the peace conference, Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today at the Midwest Governor's conference.

ALGIERS, March 15 -- The resignation of General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, Deputy Civil Commander in Chief of French North Africa, was accepted today by General Henri Honore Giraud, his superior, according to reliable French sources here. This step marked the start of the long-awaited reform of General Giraud's regime, aimed at bringing it into line with the democratic principles expounded by General Giraud yesterday.

A notable exhibition of paintings and drawings by the British artist, Augustus John, opens today at the American British Art Center. A dozen canvases and some thirty drawings, including examples in wash, pencil, charcoal, pen-and-ink and sanguine, are from the artist's studio and to these have been added five paintings and three drawings on loan from American collections.

Your paper today carried a news article about a proposal to build an aquarium in Coney Island to replace the old Aquarium, formerly in Manhattan. The plans properly call for a building superior in all ways to the old and inadequate Aquarium.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 15 -- State tax cuts exceeding $80,000,000 during the next biennium, the largest slash in the State's ninety-three-year history, have been recommended to the California Legislature by Governor Earl Warren to help offset increased Federal taxation.

LONDON, March 15 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, has made public his readiness to receive General Charles de Gaulle, the Fighting French leader, in an attempt to achieve world-wide French unity, it was disclosed today as General de Gaulle renewed his offer to negotiate an agreement with General Giraud to the same end.
A German High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A proposed order stipulating the amount of meats and other foodstuffs that restaurants may serve to a diner is under consideration in the Department of Agriculture, it was learned today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 15 (AP) -- "Snow White," an American Mitchell bomber that few unscathed for thirteen missions over German strongholds in Tunisia, came back from her fourteenth raid with more than 500 holes in her trim figure.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Reorganization plans drawn by the Interstate Commerce Commission under the Federal Bankruptcy Act for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad and the Western Pacific Railroad were approved today by the Supreme Court in opinions interpreted by railroad lawyers as vital to other such programs.

Joint action by business, labor and the government will be vital in shaping the planned economy that will extend far into the post-war period, Walter G. Baumhogger, president of the United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation, said yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 15 -- The recapture of Kharkov by the Germans will enable bomb-scarred, windowless Berlin to celebrate its traditional "Heroes" Memorial Day" next Sunday in slightly better mood than if the ceremony had been held last Sunday, as originally planned.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Jobbers and dealers in stove pipe and elbows were urged today by the plumbing and heating division of the War Production Board to place early orders to relieve the shipping situation in the Fall, Pipe and elbows will undoubtedly be scarce next Fall and the demand will probably be greater because of increased conversion of oil heating units to coal operation in fuel-rationed States, is was said.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, conferred separately today with Vice President Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of State Cordell Hull, secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, Sir Arthur Salter of the British Merchant Shipping Mission, and Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister.
PORT WASHINGTON, Wis., March 15 (AP) -- The story of a young sailor who came to their home and posed as their son for two days and then disappeared was told today by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Meisnest.

Highly interesting day assignments as plotters, filterers and tellers -- workers who chart the movements of friendly as well as possible enemy aircraft -- await 2,500 women volunteers in the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service, the Army announced yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- If a heavy bomber lands its bombs on one ship in a single bombing run over a convoy, that is considered good bombing, but in the attack last night on eight Japanese ships thirty miles northwest of Wewak, Flying Fortresses did better than that.
DES MOINES, Iowa, March 15 -- Following is the text of an address by former President Herbert Hoover at the Midwest Governors' Conference here tonight:

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, said today that the OPA would attempt to hold prices down, but added that "we will be doing well if we hold the rise in the cost of living to one-half of 1 per cent a month."

LONDON, Tuesday, March 16 -- The Russians officially acknowledged last night that the Red Army after days of fierce fighting had evacuated Kharkov, rail hub of all Southern Russia, and both German and Russian dispatches indicated that the powerful Nazi counter-offensive still was pressing viciously on a broad front from Kursk to the middle Donets River, below and beyond Kharkov.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The newest Senate move to consolidate the war and post-war programs of the United Nations in advance of victory ran into trouble at once for several reasons. It takes in too much territory. It was publicly sponsored -- by Senators Hill and Hatch, Democrats, and Ball and Burton, Republicans -- without that preliminary spade-work which must be done in all such projects.

H.L. MENCKEN is still doing business at the same old stand. And it is still a good business. The latest Mencken package is called "Heathen Days,"* a book that continues to exploit the vein of reminiscence that he tapped in "Happy Days" and "Newspaper Days." The only difference between this book and its predecessors is that Mencken has begun to skip about in time.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The OPA told housewives today to expect no change in the number of points to be allowed them in the processed-food rationing period which is to start March 25 and continue through April 30. The total will remain at the 48 points fixed for the initial rationing period, which started March 1.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 15 -- The United States must strengthen its food production for a long war and help the United Nations in the momentous post-war task of policing the world and planning now for a peace which would remove economic barriers and disarm the aggressors, former President Herbert Hoover said today.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conducting, gave an unusual program at Carnegie Hall last night, described as "Women in Music." Following the opening selection, the Gluck-Wagner Overture, "Iphigenia in Aulis," every number employed a woman as soloist.
Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway have arrived from their home in Bethesda, Md., and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

DETROIT, March 15 -- The Office of Price Administration has taken off "the boxing gloves and put away the police whistle as enforcement weapon" and has adopted a humanization policy of seeking public cooperation for price control and rationing, Lou R. Nixon, deputy OPA administrator in charge of information, told representatives of the National Association of Better Business Bureaus today.

" Air Force" today starts a seventh week at the Hollywood Theatre ... Beginning second weeks today are "The Young Mr. Pitt," at the Roxy, and "It Ain't Hay," at Loew's Criterion. ... "Hitler's Children" enters its forth and finnal week today at the Paramount.
Loft buildings figured in most of the Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday. Several investors thus extended their holdings in this field.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 16 -- Deeds of gallantry, as well as unusual occurrences, are becoming almost routine on the Tunisian front. But two Airacobra pilots, Lieutenant Paul Christie, 22 years old, of Redmond, Ore., and Flight Officer Martin D. Frain, 23, of Chicago, had a somewhat outstanding experience.

AN ADVANCED ALASKA BASE, March 16 (AP) -- The fact that Dutch Harbor, the Navy's Alaskan stronghold, did not suffer a Japanese surprise attack such as hit Pearl Harbor was due in considerable measure to the creation of two fake salmon packing companies.

The purchase of war bonds in denominations of $25 to $50,000 will grant admittance to a concert to be presented on Easter Sunday, April 25, by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, with Vladimir Horowitz, the maestro's son-in-law, as piano soloist.

MOSCOW, March 16 -The fighthug now is shifting from Kharkov toward the Northern Donets River. The Russians have followed up the announcement of their evacuation of Iharkov with an official eport of the failure of a German. attempt to force a water barrier in the neighborhood f a large unnafned I place'

Three or four years ago a soldier or sailor in uniform was a fairly rare sight on New York streets. Now, of course, he isn't. Still, he is in a minority. To get the full force of what the mobilization of millions means one has to go to one of those small communities on the verge of great camps where it is the civilian who is in a minority.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Under an agreement which precluded an outbreak of debate and possible immediate floor controversy the Senate received today the newly projected five-point program calling for the establishment now of a United Nations organization to consolidate definite post-war action with the prosecution of the war.

A tableau vivante of Red Cross work by young Latin-American women will be given at an entertainment entitled "Star-Spangled Latin-American Night" tomorrow evening in the auditorium of Hunter College for the American Red Cross War Fund Drive. Miss Maria Cecilia Lynn heads the concert committee and Senora Maria de Aya of Colombia and Mme. Eurico Penteado of Brazil are vice chairmen. Representatives of twenty Latin-American republics are serving with them in behalf of the event.

Nearly two hundred holders of 5 per cent debentures of the Childs Company, which will mature on April 1, received yesterday a gloomy picture of the prospects that face them if substantially all the outstanding debentures are not deposited under the company's plan of exchange by the maturity date.

Headed by President Holcombe Ward, representatives of the United States Lawn Tennis Association met with officers of the West Side Tennis Club last night to work out plans for the national amateur grass-court championships.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, continued his official conversations here today and will be the guest of Maxim M. Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, at luncheon in the Russian Embassy tomorrow. Presumably this will afford him an opportunity to make observations on his activities and impressions since arriving here and so prevent any uncertainties from arising in the minds of the Russians concerning the objectives of his mission.

Providence, R.L, awarded yesterday $2,000,000 of unemployment relief bonds to a syndicate comprising Phelps, Fenn Co., Graham, Parsons Co., the Equitable Securities Corporation, Coffin Burr, Inc., Arthur Perry Co. Inc., A.G. Becker Co., Inc., Donald-Coolidge Co., Martin, Burns Corbett, Inc., and Crouse, Bennett, Smith Co. The bankers bid 100.91 for the bonds, which are dated April 1, 1943, and will mature from 1944 to 1963.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (AP) -- Mrs. H.P. Bonner's War Barn, who recently broke a long losing streak, continued the winning habit today by trimming five other veteran sprinters in the $1,200 Optimist Club Handicap of six furlongs at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- According to authoritative sources, President Roosevelt's special manpower committee will submit a report tomorrow expressing confidence that the United States can muster and support armed forces totaling about 11,000,000 by the end of 1943 and still carry on record munitions and food production programs, but only if better methods of mobilizing manpower are adopted.
A communique recorded from a Berlin broadcast by The Associated Press:

BOSTON, March 16 -- The Boston Bruins, with the second-place playoff berth clinched, completed their regular National Hockey League season by overwhelming the lowly New York Rangers, 11 -- 5, tonight before 8,885 spectators at the Boston Garden.

Hesitancy enveloped the cotton futures market again yesterday, restricting price variations and limiting volume. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed with irregular price changes, 1 point lower to 8 points higher than Monday's final quotations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- The Allen Electric and Equipment Company was denied permission today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw its common stock, $1 par value, from listing and registration on the Detroit Stock Exchange because of the company's alleged failure to notify properly its stockholders of their right to present their views to the SEC.

The five-story apartment building for forty-six families at the southwest corner of Boston Road and East 167th Street, known as 1133 Boston Road, has been sold by the I.F.W. Realty Corporation to Louis Berdiansky, Ethel Hoffman and Mollie Kosheff for cash above a first mortgage of $112,364.

MADRID, March 16 (AP) -- A law was published today over the signature of General Francisco Franco making all "crimes and transgressions that have clear repercussion in public life" equivalent to rebellion and subject to military trial, with the death penalty.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, who has warned bituminous operators of the Appalachian region that 450,000 miners would stop work if their demand for an increase of $2 a day is not granted by April 1, assailed President Roosevelt's expanded social security program yesterday as "Utopia" and declared that wage increases now would be more practical.

Mothers of children under 14 years old "can perform their best service to the country by close control of their own children to steer them away from delinquency, rather than by working in war factories," John R. Ellington, special adviser on criminal justice for youth of the American Law Institute, told members of the Child Study Association of America at a conference yesterday in 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

John Gurney, young American bass-baritone of the Metropolitan Opera, invested the program of his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night with remarkable freshness. The make-up of his program should be a lesson to singers who can find little but the timeworn arias and songs that parade across an endless expanse of recitals.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,158, which compared with 1,266 in the preceding week and 1,228 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's buyer registrations numbered 418, as against 569 last Tuesday.

An unexpected move by the American Light and Traction Company whereby the utility holding company attempted to elect two directors to the board of the Detroit Edison Company failed yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Detroit utility.

Net sales of Standard Brands, Inc., and its domestic subsidiaries last year increased 21 per cent to $144,358,009 from the 1941 volume of $119,563,282, James S. Adams, president, declared in the annual report to stockholders, for publication today.
LONDON, March 16 (AP) -- The midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 -- British infantry swarmed up a ridge in the Sedjenane area of Northern Tunisia yesterday without encountering enemy resistance and French artillery fire dispersed an enemy armored-vehicle patrol near Gafsa, in the central sector, but elsewhere there was little land activity.

The four and twenty blackbirds that were baked in a pie in the Mother Goose jingle were nothing compared to the $1,000 worth of pigeons that a Chinese laundry man baked in his pie at the bargain rate of two for a quarter. But Mother Goose's birds survived the baking, while Tom Lee's helped ease the food shortage and thereby dished the Army out of a number of carrier pigeons.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Stepping back into the controversy over dried coffee grounds, President Roosevelt showed at his press conference today a hand-written recipe in a translation of "Epicurus's Morals" brought to him by Mayor La Guardia of New York.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 16 -- Prentiss M. Brown, head of the Office of Price Administration, declared here today that if the increases in wages for coal miners demanded by John L. Lewis were granted the fight of the country against inflation would be lost.
NEW DELHI, India, March 16 (AP) -- A communique:

The United Fruit Company in its forty-third annual statement, for publication today, shows for 1942 a net income of $11,934,583 before addition to reserve for contingencies. The net was equal to $4.08 each on the 2,925,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

Carrying their fight for survival under price regulations directly to the Federal Government itself, organized groups of retail food distributors yesterday undertook to convince local government agencies that Office of Price Administration rules had produced "maldistribution," had opened the door to the black market operators and food speculators, and were leading to inflation.

American and other United Nations service men now in the hands of the Axis soon will receive food packages prepared by the New York Prisoners of War Packing Center. Opened by the Red Cross on Monday without fanfare the center at 39 Chambers Street already has turned out 8,000 packages.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 17 (U.P.) -- Mosquito bombers of the Royal Air Force attacked railway shops at Paderborn in Western Germany in daylight late yesterday, an Air Ministry communique said today.
Real estate trading in Brooklyn and Queens reported yesterday involved a broad variety of properties, with small dwellings in the majority.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 17 -- The Red Army rolled the Germans back on the important front west of Moscow yesterday, driving to within fifty miles of the powerful key Nazi base of Smolensk and capturing scores of populated places, but to the south, in the strategic Donets Basin below Kharkov, Russian troops were locked in a great defensive battle against strong German tank and motorized infantry forces.

OTTAWA, March 16 -- A draft measure to provide compulsory nation-wide health insurance at a cost of $260,000,000 and a report that has the benediction of the government showing how a minimum maintenance income could be secured to every family at a cost of $1,000,000,000 a year were submitted today to the House of Commons Committee on Social Security.

It is quite simple, said the Chinese historian Hi-Ho-Hum in the preface, how he came to write his "History of American Fascism Between 1920 and 1933." One day about the middle of March, 1943, our Chinese savant was reading a speech by an American labor leader named.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The first legislative reapportionment bill since 1917 was voted today by a reluctant Legislature. A combination of the Governor's power over patronage and the decision of New York City Democratic leaders to support the measure for intra- party reasons brought overwhelming majorities for the measure in both houses.
Variety marked the showing of Spring and Summer fashions from Jane Engel at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton. Styles for matrons as well as young girls were presented.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt talked today with three men high in New York political circles -- former Governor Alfred E. Smith, Mayor La Guardia and Michael J. Kennedy, Tammany leader.

Plans to bombard Mayor La Guardia and members of the City Council with oral and written protests against the proposed doubling of the city sales tax were made yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The number of civilian employes in the Executive branch of the Federal Government rose during 1942 from 1,620,900 to 2,810,900, a net increase of 73 per cent, and the Federal payroll went from $247,379,409 to $470,334,353, an increase of 90 per cent during the twelve-month period.

A 7 per cent wage increase was awarded yesterday to 3,000 workers in the bakery and confectionery industry by former Mayor James J. Walker, who acted as arbiter in a wage dispute between the Specialty Bakery Owners of America, Inc., and Locals 579, 164 and 51 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union, A.F. of L. The increases, amounting to 75 cents a day, are retroactive to Nov. 15, Mr. Walker said.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America appealed yesterday to the governments of the United States and Great Britain to consider offering financial assistance to Jewish refugees who have escaped to neutral countries from Nazi-held territory, and the possible establishment of temporary places of asylum for those evacuated from Europe.

Tonight's events: "Faust," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; Louis Kaufman, violinist, Town Hall 8:30; Robert Goldsand, pianist, Beethoven Sonatas, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; Festival of American Music, Museum of Modern Art, 8:15; Composers Press Concert, Haubiel Studios, 853 Seventh Avenue, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 133 United States Army personnel killed in action in the Alaskan, Asiatic, European, North American, North African, South Pacific and Southwestern areas and in the Philippine Islands.

The resolution sponsored by two Democratic and two Republican Senators, which advocates a specific program of closer immediate and post-war collaboration among the United Nations, is a highly encouraging sign. It indicates that leading Senators are aware of the inescapable role that the United States must play now and after hostilities if we are to win not only the war but the peace.

The suggestion advanced by a representative of a group of 3,000 retail grocers that the food shortage might be alleviated by a relaxation of the liquor law compelling taverns to serve food was received warmly by many tavern owners yesterday.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The Assembly ratified today a constitutional amendment which ignores the concept of merit or qualifications in the Civil Service and substitutes for experience the fact that a member of the Civil Service is a discharged veteran, or a volunteer fireman.

Willie Pep, the featherweight champion, who is to meet Sammy Angott, former lightweight ruler, in a non-title ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night, was a surprise arrival here yesterday. Pep previously had asked and received permission to work out at Hartford, Conn., but changed his mind and decided to complete his training here.

An enthusiastic audience attended the second day of Garden Week yesterday in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. The four-day forum is sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund Drive.

LONDON, March 16 -- Baron Bruntisfield, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of the Admiralty, told the House of Lords today that Axis warships, exclusive of submarines, destroyed since the war began totaled three battleships, one pocket battleship, six aircraft carriers, thirty-one cruisers, 157 destroyers and torpedo boats, four surface raider and 104 miscellaneous craft, including mine-sweepers and other small boats.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (U.P.) -- The Navy announced today that casualties in the United States Merchant Marine between Feb. 1 and 28, 1943, had totaled 288 dead and missing.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Roosevelt will intervene "at the proper time" and make the fateful decision as to whether John L. Lewis's mine workers are to have a wage increase, and if so how much.

ALBANY, March 16 -- Seasonal expansion of the clothing industries and continued activity in war plants were factors in increases in factory employment and payrolls from mid-January to mid-February, according to the State Labor Department.
MOSCOW, March 16 (AP) -- A communique:

An "unfreezing" of existing inventories in hands of both large and small business when they cannot be efficiently taken for war work was advocated yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., as one of three steps designed to assist small business.

In one of the major upsets in years in a village election in suburban counties, the Home Rule party yesterday defeated the Economy party at Freeport, L.I. The latter had controlled the affairs of the town for ten years.
CAIRO, Ill., March 16 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals learned today they might lose their Captain Jimmy Brown to Uncle Sam.

An application to restrain the Third Avenue Transit Corporation from paying interest on April 1 on the junior adjustment income bonds of the Third Avenue Railway was referred yesterday to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins by Justice Aaron J. Levy, before whom the case was called.

Recent Congressional attacks upon David Ginsburg, general counsel of the Office of Price Administration, have been so outrageous, so irresponsible and so damaging to a brilliant career that simple justice requires them to be answered.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Asserting that the government's attempt to stabilize prices and living costs had failed, the American Federation of Labor members of the War Labor Board petitioned the board today to scrap its "Little Steel" formula and make effective a "realistic wage policy."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 -- The smashing initial success, the bitterly fought retreat over fifty-five miles of broken ground and finally the stubborn counter-attack, followed by a skillful enemy withdrawal -- these are the main phases of last month's battle from Faid Pass to Thala and return.
LONDON, March 16 -- The necessity of post-war equality for all the United Nations was stressed today by Count Edward Raczynski, Polish Foreign Minister, in a statement to the Polish National Council.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved in principle today the amendment offered to the Disney Bill in the House by Representative Wolcott, Michigan Republican, and instructed a subcommittee to bring in a bill on Friday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 16 -- Denying Vice President Wallace's charge that National Socialism was aspiring to rear a "master race" that would perpetuate war, Dr. Otto Dietrich, the German Press Chief, declared in a public speech that the Third Reich disavowed all imperialistic tendencies or aspirations for world domination.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Holders of B and C gasoline-ration cards will be eligible to buy pre-Pearl Harbor and "victory" tires to take the place of any of their tires worn beyond the recapping stage, the Office of Price Administration announced today
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, March 17 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- War Department spokesmen indicated today that the all-soldier musical, "This Is the Army," would not be seen again on" the stage in this country after its filming in Hollywood is completed, but no confirmation was available of the persistent reports that the troupe would be sent to England.

LONDON, March 16 -- Prices on the stock markets moved today within narrow limits and business remained restricted. There was hardly any movement among gilt-edged stocks, and home rails were featureless.

CHUNGKING, China, March 16 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops pursuing the enemy in the Hupeh-Hunan border area of Central China have recaptured two more towns south of the Yangtze River and are threatening the important Japanese-held city of Hwajung from three sides, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- American housewives are going to have to decide whether to have one luscious steak a week or spread their ration coupons over a lot of different kinds of meat which won't have such a high point value.

Several leases of floors in manufacturing buildings in Manhattan were reported yesterday by Adams Co., brokers. The firm negotiated a lease on a floor in 121-23 East Twenty-fourth Street to J.A. Maurer, Inc., manufacturers of motion-picture and photographic equipment, and through the J.D. Robilotto Company, a floor in 108 West Eighteenth Street to La Siga Manufacturing Company, makers of cigars.

Insisting that it was a "typographical error" that identified Harry Bridges, San Francisco maritime labor leader, as a "West Coast Communist leader" in last Saturday's issue of The Daily Worker, a spokesman for the Communist publication at 50 East Thirteenth Street, refused to discuss the slip further yesterday.

The stage now appears to be set for a meeting between Generals Giraud and de Gaulle for a final composition of their remaining differences. It is to be hoped that neither personal ambitions, doctrinaire considerations nor Gallic punctilio will be permitted to interfere with a unification of all Frenchmen in the common struggle for the liberation of France and the victory of the United Nations.

Amendment of a Federal-State order regulating the handling of milk in the New York metropolitan marketing area would increase the cost to local consumers and divert milk from the market here, Sol Pincus, assistant commissioner of the Department of Health, charged yesterday.

Arthur Cardinal Hinsley, primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Great Britain, died in England at 7:20 A.M. today, London time according to a Reuter broadcast report, recorded here by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Navy communique 311:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 16 -- General Henri Honore Giraud's radio broadcast from Algiers two days ago has produced a great impression on French listeners, according to private advices, because of his allusion to Alsace and Lorraine, the two provinces lost after the War of 1870 and recovered after the first World War.

From Memphis has come a letter written by Nash Buckingham, Tennessee sportsman, setting forth some views on the highly interesting and important topic of shells for the next hunting season. Mr. Buckingham has been interested in conservation and the outdoors for a long time, and has been quoted before on this subject.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Combined action by all divisions of the food industry is imperative at once if the country is to be spared "the tragedy of near-famine in war time," Clarence Francis, president of General Foods, Inc., told the new Food Industry War Committee at an emergency meeting today.

ALGIERS, March 16 -- Jean Rigaud, Secretary of Political Affairs, followed General Jean-marie-Joseph Bergeret into political limbo today as General Henri Honore Giraud's campaign to cleanse his regime of anti-democratic elements quickened.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 (UP) -- The United States pays out about $15,000 a month to repair damage and ease ruffled feelings occasioned by the occupation of North Africa.

LONDON, March 16 -- Viscount Cranborne, speaking for the government today, reiterated Britain's desire to help China to her utmost in a speech in the House of Lords, but he was unable to give any definite commitment that this country would not attach any restrictions to its loan to China which is at present pending.

Philadelphia will have six representatives and New York three in the finals at Madison Square Garden tonight as a result of competition in the semi-finals of the Eastern section of the Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament sit the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, March 17 -- A persistent search by Allied fliers has revealed no further trace of the three Japanese troopships that were attacked by Netherland and Australian planes Monday afternoon just outside of Dobo in the Aru Islands, off Western New Guinea.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 (AP) -- The British have maintained their positions unchanged through a day of fierce Japanese attacks and British counter-attacks northwest of Rathedaung, twenty-five miles north of Akyab in Burma, a British communique said today.

The opening of the former White-law Reid home at 451 Madison Avenue as the Women's Military Services Club for members of the women's auxiliaries of the United States armed forces was announced yesterday.
When so many great plans are cooking to make this a less annoying world, how about ending one small and ancient New York nuisance -- the numbering of avenue houses?

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- Beardsley Ruml, author of the pay-as-you-go income tax collection plan bearing his name, told the Commonwealth Club today that the country did not want a tax on savings right in the midst of widespread efforts to get the public to buy more war bonds.

The American Meat Institute will run a full page ad in newspapers from coast to coast tomorrow to combat black markets, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of food advertisers and agencies with officials of the OPA, OWI and Advertising Council in Chicago.

Sir Thomas Beecham conducted a small orchestra last night in the second of the series of five serenades "of rare music, ancient and modern" at the Museum of Modern Art. The feature of the evening was a "Little Suite" composed by Sir Thomas for this concert and based on music from three of Handel's operas, "I1 Pastor Fido," "Ario Dante" and "Rodrigo."

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Should recent history be repeated John L. Lewis, failing to obtain from the coal operator or the established government agencies either his U.M.W. wage demands or a satisfactory compromise, will call a strike. He will then be induced by the President, on the promise of a special arbitration committee, to order the miners back to work, and the special committee will make an award satisfactory to Mr. Lewis.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Tom C. Clark of Dallas, Texas, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be an assistant Attorney General, succeeding Thurman Arnold, in charge of the Department of Justice's anti-trust activities.

The stock market was bogged down again yesterday by further liquidation in the "penny" railroad issues on the Stock Exchange as a result of the United States Supreme Court's decision in the case of the Milwaukee Railroad. Selling was not as widespread nor as intense as on Monday, but values of carrier securities adjudged as having no place in recapitalization plans approached the vanishing stage.
The American Abstract Painters are holding their seventh annual exhibition at the Riverside Museum (Riverside Drive and 103d Street). It opened to the public yesterday and will remain until April 25.

A new comedy by F. Hugh Herbert, "Kiss and Tell," will open tonight at the Biltmore under the auspices of George Abbott, who also directed. The players featured in the cast are Jessie Royce Landis and Robert Keith; others include Joan Caulfield, Judith Parrish, Richard Widmark, Tommy Lewis, Lulu Mae Hubbard, Frances Bavier. Robert White, John Harvey, Paula Trueman, Walter Davis, Calvin Thomas, Robert Lynn and James Clement (Lane) McCaffrey. John Root designed the settings.

Reports concerning the shortage of potatoes continue. Yesterday, for example, a survey conducted by the Department of Markets revealed that some retailers are voluntarily rationing their customers to five pounds an order. The spokesman for a big chain store said his company was experiencing difficulty in procuring all it needs.

LONDON, March 16 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's first day back in the arena of political warfare after his recent illness was enlivened by a flurry over a letter on the North African situation written by his son, Captain Randolph Churchill, to a London evening newspaper and published a few days ago.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, March 12 (Delayed) -- A remarkable instance of Allied cooperation between ground and air forces, as the result of which a strong German contingent completely failed in its purpose of disrupting the British Eighth Army's plans, is still tile subject of elated conversation among the Fighting French.

Housewives shopping for vegetables and farmers who grow them in this region want the same thing from the Office of Price Administration -- a price system that will enable grocers to put a large sign over their vegetable stocks showing retail ceilings -- a leading Eastern grower declared here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, March 16 -- Officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers (C.I.O.) said tonight they would request a Federal investigation of the operators of Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyard, Inc., subsidiary of the Bethlehem Steel Company and makers of Liberty ships, after three shifts of male electric bridge crane operators walked off their jobs in protest against the use of women as bridge crane operators.

LONDON, March 16 (U.P.) -- Martial law was reported to have been declared tonight throughout the Savoy area of Eastern France, where French guerrillas were holding out in the mountains against Vichy's national police and Italian and German regulars.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, March 16 -- The Women's Army Auxiliary Corps sent out today another company of young women to release soldiers for front-line duty. It was the nineteenth class to go into the field from Fort Des Moines since the Waac was organized in July, and as one of the girls said this afternoon, "We're definitely out of the powder-puff stage now."

Hundreds of thousands of men, women and children wearing the traditional ribbon of emerald green or the shamrocks of the "old country" will line both sides of Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street to ll0th Street today to witness the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade, in honor of Ireland's patron saint.

A check for $11,000 was presented yesterday by the Chinese National Press Association to J.B. Powell, former editor of The China Weekly Review in Shanghai, at his bedside in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he is now recuperating from beriberi and gangrene that cost him his feet as a result of brutal treatment he received in a Japanese prison in Shanghai.
CHUNGKING, China, March 16 (U.P.) -- A communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 16 -- Germany's great industrial city of Essen, pounded heavily by the British Royal Air Force in two large-scale raids this month and many before, was pictured as a scene of widespread devastation today by German newspapers reaching here.

ALGIERS, March 16 (U.P.) -- The French North African regime tonight ordered all public pictures, posters, statements, signs and slogans bearing the name or picture of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State in Vichy, removed starting tomorrow.

St. Patrick died 1,450 years ago today. Honor, reverence and affection for him do but grow as the centuries pass. To the piety of this commemoration and the old memories of descent that it stirs is added this year a proud sorrow for the men of Irish origin in the armed forces that have died nobly for their country.

There were no financial arrangements involved in Kaiser management taking over the potentially great Brewster aircraft works yesterday. There was no sale of stock or assets, no rental, no fee basis of operation. The active control has been vested in the Navy ever since the Van Dusen management was installed ten months ago, when the shares of principal stockholders were placed in a voting trust, which remains unchanged.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Four more Japanese vessels, including a destroyer and a large transport, have been sunk and three other ships damaged by United States submarines operating in the Pacific and Far East, a Navy communique, announced tonight.

Arthur Meissner, an alien born in Germany, was arrested last night on charges of forgery and perjury growing out of the fact that since 1937 he had posed as William Jocher, an American-born citizen, and that under that pretense he was appointed a patrolman on the city police force on March 1, 1937.

Vacancies in "old-law" tenement houses in Manhattan of the type generally occupied by wage-earners and low-salaried families have increased sharply in recent months, according to the fifth annual survey of such properties conducted by the Real Estate Board of New York.

For distinguished service, to track and field, Emil Von Elling, veteran N.Y.U. coach, yesterday was voted the Track Writers Association Merit Award for 1943 at a meeting at the Paramount Hotel. Von Elling was the unanimous, choice and will be the first to receive this type of plaque.

Degrees of Doctor of Medicine were conferred yesterday on sixty-eight graduates by the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, at its eighty-third annual commencement exercises, held in Hosack Hall of the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 16 -- Bill Dickey, veteran catcher, today held the questionable distinction of being the Yankees' only official holdout.

The Brooklyn Lodge of Elks, No. 22, has leased the basement space in 22 Court Street, formerly occupied by a restaurant, as its new quarters, and will move to that building before April 1 from its clubhouse at 150 South Oxford Street.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Elevator men admitted today that they are making little effort to fill Eastern orders for cash corn pending further developments in regard to the new price ceilings and regulations announced by the Office of Price Administration.

Although many of them were soaked by the rain, 25,000 volunteer workers began ringing doorbells throughout Manhattan yesterday as the borough-wide block canvass for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund got under way. Its goal is to raise at least $1,000,000 toward the city's quota of $12,920,700 in the national campaign for $125,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House today debated a bill proposing to appropriate $26,100,000 to finance distribution of farm workers to areas most needing them, and it heard rebukes to the Farm Security Administration for alleged efforts to promote unionization of farm workers.

Warning against pushing customers around and misrepresentation of quality of merchandise in the wartime upswing in retail trade, I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, declared yesterday that customer good-will should not be sold short in the intensive struggle to get goods and sales people.
In its new master plan for all and sundry, the National Resources Planning Board has not overstrained itself figuring the cost.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- A $60,000,000 bond refinancing program and a voluntary proposal for compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, filed by the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- An appeal is being made to the Office of Defense Transportation and the Office of Price Administration to relax official pressure against trade shows, it was revealed here today with the report that representatives of the American Furniture Mart, Merchandise Mart and the Chicago Association of Commerce are in Washington discussing the situation with heads of the government bureaus.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- George Marshall, who directed Paramount's "Star Spangled Rhythm" will direct that company's 'Tour Angels" which will go into production within four weeks featuring Dorothy Lamour, Fred MacMurray and Betty Hutton.

On the question of the relation of the United States to the post-war world the young people in this country are doing some anxious thinking. This is brought home to any one who has the opportunity to listen to them talk among themselves -- especially in those moments, not solemn but clear-sighted, when they go forth or come home from the wars.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The President conferred with Basil O'Connor and a group of British film actors, Mayor La Guardia, Michael J. Kennedy, Tammany leader, and Alfred E. Smith, and held a press conference.

In THE TIMES of March 9 I find a headline "Poles in Moscow Launch New Paper." It is apparent from the text of the dispatch that the paper is a Russian bolshevist paper printed, in Polish by the Russian imperialist bureau of propaganda.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Speculation as to the identity of the Chicago merchandising executive chosen by Federal Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown to be his senior deputy administrator, replacing John E. Hamm, whose resignation is effective July 1, was general in Office of Price Administration circles here today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Conferences of far-reaching significance have been in progress in Washington between high-ranking United States, British and Canadian officers to map an anti-U-boat campaign, and "complete agreement" has been reached on the best way to combat the menace of the Nazi underwater fleet, the Navy disclosed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 16 -- Putting a price on the pursuit of higher education in Holland, Anton A. Mussert, Nazi leader, and Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Reich Commissioner of the Netherlands and Belgium, today ordered Netherlanders wishing to attend colleges or specialized faculties to sign a written pledge to refrain "from any sect of conscience or honor" directed against the occupying authority.

The secret German radio, "Gustave Siegried Eins," yesterday quoted Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein, former German commander in the Crimea, as saying that "Tunis will be our second Stalingrad," according to a broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York.

Edward L. Shea, president of the North American Company, warned yesterday that the future of the private utility industry in this country was in jeopardy unless the Federal Government and taxing authorities gave serious consideration to the inequitable tax burden currently being borne by the utilities.

The Studio Theatre, an experimental theatre affiliated with the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, has suspended operations for the season, it informed Actors Equity Association yesterday. Lack of funds was given as the reason by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School.

Postponement of the effective date of OPA's new women's rayon hosiery regulation MPR 339 will be sought at a conference to be held today in Washington between officials of that agency and a special committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association headed by Lew Hahn, general manager of the organization, it was announced here yesterday.

Jose Limon and the Humphrey-Weidman Repertory Company have scheduled three extra performances of their program of American dances staged by Doris Humphrey at the Studio Theatre, 108 West Sixteenth Street. Originally announced for only three presentations last week, the program will be seen also on March 20 and 27 and April 3.

OTTAWA, March 16 (Canadian Press) -- Assurance of a minimum standard income in the face of all the risks of life is the basic idea of a plan for social security in Canada laid today before a special House of Commons committee by Pensions Minister Ian Mackenzie.

THE gun cracked for the end of the basketball game. Referee Bill Grieve stuck his whistle in his pocket, picked up his sweater from the timer's bench and headed for the showers. A stranger introduced himself and, as a result, Bill Grieve is one of the crack American League umpires today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Ways and Means Committee virtually completed work today on the bill it has prepared in lieu of the pay-as-you-go measure it set out to write about two months ago. The bill probably will be introduced tomorrow.
Jackie Cooper, 150, of Brooklyn, scored a technical knockout over Johnny Morris, 161, of Yonkers at the Broadway Arena last night in the scheduled eight-round main bout before 4,000 fans.

A million Manhattan income taxpayers, the overwhelming majority of them filling their obligations for the first quarter only, paid $600,000,000 by the deadline at Monday midnight, it was indicated last night.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 16 -- The lean, lanky lad with the sloping shoulders seemed to have springs in his shoes as he strode out to the pitcher's box. He warmed up quickly -- a fast ball, a hook, a change of pace -- then settled down to the business at hand, helping his baseball club win the General Headquarters base section championship.

CENTRAL TUNISIA, March 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Streamlined little American armies known as "combat teams" and able to fight their own battles without aid from other forces are proving highly valuable on the African front. The armored forces call these self-contained fighting units "combat commands" and the infantry calls them "combat teams," but they do essentially the same thing -- specific jobs such as those carried out by a Navy task force.

Henry J. Kaiser, already a legendary national figure because of the scope of his shipbuilding and production ventures in the last two decades, yesterday was elected chairman of the board of Brewster Aeronautical Corporation with the formal approval of the Navy.

The wave of muggings continued yesterday as a Bronx housewife was attacked and stabbed by a Negro youth who was captured a short distance away and who admitted three similar crimes in the last two weeks. Two indictments were handed up later in the day on two of these cases.

LONDON, March 16 -- Emphatically praising reciprocal lend-lease between the United States and Great Britain and the cooperation given by the authorities in this country, W. Averell Harriman, lend-lease representative, said in an interview today that 3,517,000 tons of supplies, including food and equipment, had been obtained in Britain for the United States forces up to last Dec. 31.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 16 -- The Dodgers became assured of a lot of Grade A catching this season when Mickey Owen, who caught 133 games last year, checked in early tonight with his contract signed and ready to go to work tomorrow. Owen had accepted terms in Brooklyn earlier in the day.

The Regional Office of Price Administration put a damper yesterday on any hopes Manhattan's cliff-dwellers might have had for getting a little more gasoline to motor to the country this Summer to care for patriotically inspired victory gardens.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek has received $310,000 for war relief work in China since her arrival last November in the United States, according to a representative at the Waldorf-Astoria. Hotel where China's First Lady is now resting. Checks and cash are still pouring in daily.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- A series of transactions involving the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and four of its subsidiaries, designed to create special capital surplus for the latter concerns, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Association Press, publishing department of the Young Men's Christian Association, and Fleming H. Revell Company announce arrangements for publishing new Association Press books of general trade interest under the joint imprint of the two houses.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Willard L. Thorp, economist and trustee of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, has been approached by the War Production Board to take a post as vice chairman in charge of the Office of Civilian Supply, according to a report tonight.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 (AP) -- A communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 (AP) -- A communique:

The question whether the mutual saving banks in this State should continue to insure their deposits through their own mutual fund, established for that purpose in 1934, or through the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will be one of the principal topics at the annual midwinter conference of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York on Friday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, March 16 -- Oliver Stanley's speech at Oxford on March 3, in which the Colonial Secretary replied to American criticism of British policy and rejected any scheme for a post-war international colonial administration, drew some criticism in the House of Commons today. So did "ill-in-formed" American Senators and Pan American Senators and Pan American Airways, the latter as a potential tyrant in the West Indies.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 16 -- Floridian weather of the previous twenty-four hours walked right out on the Giants today when rain sprayed this pine-studded resort, soaked the ball field and wiped out whatever outdoor training Manager Mel Ott had in mind.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 16 (U.P.) -- It takes ten tons of equipment to land one American soldier in North Africa and a ton and a half a month to keep him going.

Even in large cities, where storage space is at a premium, home-canning is expected to undergo a renaissance this year as a means of conserving food supplies. Accordingly, attention is directed toward a device that enables one to convert commercially packed glass containers into jars for preserving fruits and vegetables.
LONDON, Thursday, March 18 (AP) -- The Russian Midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LOS ANGELES, March 17 (AP) -- The Pacific Coast Conference, as now constituted, is out for the duration, and the four California members, Stanford, U.C.L.A., Southern California and California, most likely will schedule home-and-home football games next Fall.

LONDON, Thursday, March 18 -- Allied escort vessels and the Royal Air Force have destroyed at least three enemy submarines and probably damaged many others in a seventy-two-hour running fight with a U-boat wolf pack which the Admiralty described as "one of the greatest battle of the Winter between naval escorts of a convoy and U-boats."

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 17 (AP) -- The power of the Federal Government to borrow money "is not subject to restriction by the laws of this or any other State," United States Attorney George L. Grobe said today in a proceeding involving the devolution of war bonds.

A former officer of the German State Police who tried to enlist in the German Army but has openly declare that he would never help the United States to fight the Axis has been apprehended by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, E.E. Conroy, local F.B.I. chief, announced yesterday.
DETROIT, March 17 -- Nearly 7,000 workers in the aircraft engine division of the Ford Motor Company were back at their jobs today after a wildcat strike interrupted production yesterday.

The congregations of St. Luke's and St. Matthew's Episcopal Churches, Brooklyn, have merged and will attend services together starting Sunday as the Episcopal Church of St. Luke and St. Matthew, worshiping at St. Luke's edifice, 520 Clinton Avenue, near Fulton Street, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $10,361,210 after charges, taxes, depreciation and reserves, equal to $3.31 each on the 3,302,897 capital shares outstanding, compared with $10,918,820 or $3.31 a share in 1941.

WEST SAYVILLE, L. I., March 17 -- Twenty-six inductees, soldiers and Coast Guardsmen and a civilian were injured here this morning when five cars of a Long Island Railroad train jumped the tracks. Three of the inductees, en route to Camp Upton, suffered broken bones.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 17 -- General Douglas MacArthur walked in at the wind-up of the regular noon press conference for accredited war correspondents at the Southwest Pacific Headquarters today and marked the anniversary of his arrival in Australia from the Philippines by talking with newspaper men for more than two hours.

IN THE SWISS ALPS, March 17 -- Absorbing a lesson from the disaster of the Austro-Hungarian Army of Dec. 13, 1916, when some 9,500 men were killed by avalanches during an overnight march, the Swiss Army has based a part of the defense of its inner line on the controlled release of snow slides at various strategic intersections.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- An increase of 28 per cent in February as compared with February last year in the sales of independent retailers was reported today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. Dollar sales in February were 5 per cent higher than for the preceding month.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- By a vote of 50 to 24 today, the Senate passed the Bankhead-Johnson bill requiring blanket deferment from military draft call of registrants engaged "substantially full time" in producing or harvesting crops and commodities deemed essential to the war effort.

LONDON, March 17 -- Emphasizing the crippling effect of the American-British air offensive on Axis war production, an important Royal Air Force commentator asserted today that it was "very important" to get the greatest possible number of United States bombers here to give their crews actual combat experience in order to establish the unquestioned Allied air superiority that is essential for any second-front operations.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- To conserve roadbuilding machinery as well as materials and manpower, the WPB today withdrew a blanket authorization which had permitted road departments to begin highway construction jobs provided no critical materials which had been acquired after May 6, 1942, were used.

Eight mothers, most of them busy on war jobs, sat down last night to a dinner prepared by fourteen girls, ranging in age from 8 to 13, who are learning homemaking in special classes at the Young Women's Christian Association branch at 501 West Fiftieth Street.

Anti-aircraft guns operated by remote control, trench mortars, ammunition and other ordnance were displayed here yesterday to the public at an exhibit sponsored by Major Gen. Levin H. Campbell Jr., chief of Army Ordnance.

The continuance of American lend-lease aid, which aggregated more than eight billion dollars through last year, has also continued and increased the burden on the War Shipping Administration of handling and dispatching a vast quantity of war and other cargoes moving to our allies and the areas of combat.

BOSTON, Mass., March 17 (AP) -- Representative Hamilton Fish of New York declared in a speech here today that he was in favor of demanding from the British Government "outright possession of all the islands from Bermuda to South America for use as strategic air and naval bases."

The sharp decline last week in oil supplies on the East Coast to the lowest level in recent years is not so important as it would have been a few weeks or months ago. The heavy consuming period for light fuel oil is near an end and the industry now may use a greater part of the transportation available to it for bringing in gasoline.

The Broadway news this morning quite clearly may resemble only the purr of a cat which has eaten the family steak and is lying grinning before the fire; for last evening the George Abbott of "What a Life," "Three Men on a Horse," "Room Service" and all those other good ones, brought to the Biltmore Theatre a comedy called "Kiss and Tell."
CHUNGKING, China, March 17 (U.P.) -- A communique:

LONDON, March 7 -- Radioman third class Charles Kelley of the United States Navy comes from South Boston, and his father, Tom, comes from South Boston too, but before that, the Kelleys came from County Galway and they knew the difference between a shamrock and a four-leaf clover.

LONDON, March 17 -- The French National Committee announced tonight that General Charles de Gaulle, its chairman, would leave soon for Algiers to confer with General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa.
