Flowers blooming in the windows of Fifth Avenue's leading stores brightened the way for the marchers in yesterday's parade. A greeting to Spring, they formed part of a floral show for a city deprived of the annual event at Grand Central Palace.
Chelsea, Mass., announced yesterday that it will open bids today on a new issue of $700,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be payable on Nov. 5.

The position taken by the American Federation of Labor members of the War Labor Board is untenable. They demand that the Board "arrive at its own decisions on wage matters by the democratic process of majority rule" and that the Board accept no "dictation by any person or Government agency."

Makers of packaged cereals, which are one of the few food items in ample supply, are taking advantage of the meat shortages to promote the use of cereals as meat extenders. A new campaign for Quaker Oats, in which recipes feature the product as ideal for such use, will break this month.

The joint scale committees of United Mine Workers and the Northern and Southern coal operators made "very considerable progress" in executive sessions here yesterday but failed to reach any agreement on the $2-a-day wage increase and other demands of the miners.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 17 -- The Allied air force maintained its offensive against Axis communications during the past twenty-four hours.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The New England Power Association was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to eliminate from its holding company system four subsidiaries with investments aggregating $150,000,000 and to provide a means of dissolving a fifth subsidiary.

NEWARK, N.J., March 17 -- Criteria for women doubtful whether they can fill war production jobs were outlined here today by Major Howard J. Lepper, area director of the War Manpower Commission, in appealing for more women to enter war industries in Newark, Perth Amboy, Elizabeth, Somerville, Paterson and Bayonne.

Only one person at Creedmoor State Hospital is now actually ill of amoebic dysentery, although thirty-five to forty patients and employes of that institution for the insane are still isolated so as to prevent an epidemic, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, City Health Commissioner, reported yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister Shukru Saracoglu expressed the thorough sympathy of the Turkish Government with the Allied cause, in a policy speech today, and later won a unanimous vote of confidence from the Grand National Assembly.

Military and civic leaders joined yesterday with members of the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in the religious observance at St. Patrick's Cathedral of the feast of the patron saint of the archdiocese. Two thousand persons attended.

The Eastman Kodak Company set new high records for sales and operating income in 1942, according to the fortieth annual report to stockholders signed by F.W. Lovejoy, chairman, and T.J. Hargrave, president, and made available today.
ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, March 17 -- Rumors were current throughout the islands today that a Senatorial investigation of conditions here was to be expected.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (U.P.) -- Senator Gillette of Iowa, said today that he had been informed by the War Production Board that "some 100" distillers of industrial alcohol are facing a shutdown within forty-eight hours because no corn is available.

High-powered Creighton and Toledo, topnotchers from the Middle West, rule favorites to defeat their Eastern rivals -- Washington and Jefferson and Manhattan, respectively -- in the opening games of the national invitation basketball tourney in Madison Square Garden tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP) -- Tragic Ending, making his first start for the Millbrook Stable, which had claimed him from the Coldstream Stable for $4,000 a week ago, easily led a field of high-class platers in the St. Patrick's Day Claiming Stakes at the Fair Grounds today.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation, meeting in San Diego, Calif., and of Vultee Aircraft, Inc., meeting in Wilmington, Del., voted yesterday overwhelmingly in favor of a merger into a single company to be known as the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The projected post-war food conference of the United Nations may be held within two months, members of the Pacific War Council said today after a meeting in the White House with President Roosevelt. Dr. Walter Nash, the New Zealand Minister, said no date had been set because discussions were continuing over matters of organization.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The President saw Lieut. Gen. George O. Kenney and Major Gen. Richard K. Sutherland and met with the Pacific War Council.

Philip K. Wrigley, president of Wm. Wrigley Jr. Co., has sent a letter to the secretary of the company, for distribution among stockholders with the proxy statement for the forthcoming annual meeting, describing to the last detail his stock ownership and financial relationships with the company.

Truancy is the beginning of delinquency and crime is on the rise in Harlem, according to Herman H. Moskowitz, district supervisor of attendance of the Board of Education, District 16, which covers the Harlem area north of 130th Street. Mr. Moskowitz has been in the bureau twenty-eight years.

Despite some disappointments and some disquieting remarks by the chiefs of the Spanish state, this country's policy toward the Spanish Government is one of hopeful conciliation. We have allowed some useful supplies to pass the blockade, our President has expressed the desire for closer relations after the war, and our Ambassador has even gone a little out of his way to praise the Franco regime.

IT was with some misgivings and not too much confidence in the success of the project that Madison Square Garden authorities assigned eight dates to Ned Irish the first full season he introduced basketball to the arena. Within the next fortnight there will be eight nights devoted to the dribble diversion alone, which indicates how rapidly the sport has grown.

MADRID, March 17 (AP) -- General Francisco France told the new Cortes today that the objectives of the World War had changed with the entry of Russia and that the struggle was now "a war to the death" that might last six or eight years.

With traders still holding much business in abeyance until some settlement is reached in the political and legislative questions now at issue, the cotton futures market progressed yesterday through another featureless session and closed at best levels in a week as late trade and local covering orders found offerings scarce.

LONDON, March 17 -- German broadcasts said tonight that the British Eighth Army had launched its long-awaited offensive against a broad front of the Mareth Line and implied that German and Italian troops had given ground at some points in heavy fighting.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- The American League disclosed today that its number of baseball players in the armed forces now had reached 144, a figure that exactly equaled the league's service roll during all of World War I.

The cracking and sinking of the big tanker Schenectady at Swan Island shipyard in Portland, Ore., in January, was due in part to a lack of uniformity in the quality of steel used in the hull and to the departure on the part of the shipyard personnel from recognized fundamentals of good welded construction for the laudable purpose of speeding up construction.
MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) -- The midday communique:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 17 -- Things seem to move with surprising alacrity in this streamlined baseball training season. Where, in happier and more leisurely days, it might have taken several weeks to arrive at the same conclusion, it seems to have taken Manager Mel Ott only a matter of forty-four hours to reach the decision today that Babe Barna is not likely to supply the answer to "Who's on first?" for the Giants this year.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- "Work or fight" legislation aimed at war plant workers who habitually lay off the job without good cause was approved by the House Naval Committee today, 17 to 9. Before approving the bill the committee revised it in some particulars.

New Hampshire is the latest of the Eastern States to announce the intention of its conservation authorities to carry out, for this year at least, its full program of fish stocking. This is a marked indication of hopefulness for the Spring season.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (U.P.) -- Award of the Distinguished Service Medal to Brig. Gen. Bryant E. Moore of Ellsworth, Me., who led the first American Army troops in action against the Japanese on Guadalcanal, was announced today by the War Department.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- American naval surface vessels and Navy and Army aircraft have subjected Japanese bases at both ends of the vast Pacific front to heavy punishment, the Navy disclosed today.

Stocks of oil products on the East Coast moved into new low ground last week. At the close of the period, the new index of the American Petroleum Institute, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil supplies, stood at 29.9, compared with 32.5 at the close of the previous week and 58.3 on Nov. 7 last, when the current downward trend started.

With the entrance of RCA Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America into a priority plan for post-war purchases of theatre equipment, this type of "layaway" plan for industrial equipment and supplies is broadening steadily, it was indicated yesterday.

Philip A. Hines, who resigned as deputy city clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau last Sept. 3 after being accused of improperly accepting gratuities for performing marriages, lost yesterday in Supreme Court in his legal fight to compel the city to pay him the $3,500 pension refused by the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- J.K. Galbraith, Deputy Price Administrator, told a livestock delegation today that he believed the Federal Government must impose "ceiling" prices on live hogs and other live meat animals.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 17 -- Owen Vincent Madden, known two decades ago as Owney Madden, who in the Prohibition era had Broadway and its tributary streets for his "territory," became a naturalized citizen today.

Word of the award of a silver star for gallantry in action in New Guinea to Dr. Rafael R. Gamso, 31 years old, had been received by his brother, Hyman W. Gamso, 1 University Place, deputy county clerk of New York County, it was learned yesterday.

Formation of a fur industry advisory committee is expected to be announced shortly by the OPA, it was stated yesterday by Avery T. Salter, executive secretary of the National Federation of the Fur Industry. Walter H. Pringle, head of the federation, and Mr. Salter conferred recently with Bernard F. Haley, chief of the textile, leather and clothing division of the OPA, who outlined the requirements for setting up the advisory committee.

Dozens of industrial firms in widely scattered sections of the country are fostering the planting of victory gardens by their employes and are assisting them to grow vegetables, berries and fruit, as a result of a series of meetings held during the past few weeks at the headquarters of the National Victory Garden Institute, 598 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, March 17 -- How the Allies are successfully conducting their economic relations with Spain, not only to obtain resources for themselves but also to keep them from the Axis, was outlined today by a spokesman for the Ministry of Economic Warfare.

Although sales of the Douglas Aircraft Company rose last year to $501,781,985, from $180,940,110 in 1941, its net earnings from sales and cost-plus-a-fixed-fee contract billings were 39.7 per cent below the previous year, Donald W. Douglas, president, declared in the annual report to stockholders for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, 1942, issued yesterday.
A German communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A breakdown on the home front by the end of this year unless drastic measures are promptly taken to maintain essential civilian supplies was predicted today by Senator Maloney in a report to the Senate on behalf of its Small Business Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- After lunching at the Russian Embassy with Maxim M. Litvinoff, the Soviet Ambassador, Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, visited the White House at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, accompanied by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Arturo de Cordova instead of Fred MacMurray will have the co-starring name role with Dorothy Lamour in "A Medal for Benny," Paramount has announced. Now in "Hostages," de Cordova will appear in "Frenchman's Creek," with Joan Fontaine, before the John Steinbeck story.

Two sets of amendments to the recent vegetable price ceilings were promulgated formally yesterday by Sylvan Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration. One set limits the number of wholesale mark-ups that can be made and the other makes five additional varieties of the seven price fixed vegetables subject to ceilings.

Demonstrations of floral beauty won the applause of a large audience yesterday at the third day of "Garden Week," sponsored jointly by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund.
BALTIMORE, March 17 (AP) -- The Glenn L. Martin Company announced today its answer to chronic absenteeism and loafing at its huge airplane factory -- an ultimatum to "work or get out."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, March 18 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, March l7 -- Eric A. Johnston, President of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, returned tonight from a 20,000-mile airplane trip to seven Latin-American countries and will report to President Roosevelt that they do not want "A South American WPA," financed by the United States Government but would welcome American capital and management into joint, cooperative private corporations.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- All staff members of the office of War Information were ordered by Elmer Davis, the director, today to avoid anything which could be construed as partisan poetical activity.
The old Murray Hill Hotel, eight-story red brick landmark of the Grand Central zone, was sold yesterday to the Pershing Square Building Corporation, headed by Samuel D. Leidesdorf.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- House leaders set the stage today for four days of debate next week on the question of pay-as-you-go taxation after Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, introduced the committee's bill which rejects tax forgiveness.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, declined today to call off the strike of his union, in effect since Aug. 1 against the recording and transcription of music for radios, phonographs and juke boxes.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A motion by Senator Greenberg, Brooklyn Democrat, to discharge the Senate Finance Committee from further consideration of his bill allocating another $150,000,000 for public housing in the State was defeated today by a straight party vote.
LONDON, March 17 -- The March 10 editorial of The Times of London on post-war Anglo-Soviet relations, which has attracted attention in the United States, read as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The unprecedented story of how a thin-skinned Coast Guard cutter fought a wolf pack of Nazi submarines, pounding five with depth charges, then sailed into a sixth and sank it, was revealed tonight by the Navy Department.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was asked today by its public utilities division to compel the $1,000,000,000 Cities Service Company to strip itself of all its properties except its Mid-Continent Gas System and the Cities Service Gas Company.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, March 17 (Reuter) -- It was disclosed today that Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, discussing the future of the Jewish people with a representative of South African Jews recently, had said that his mind had turned to the idea of a confederation of States in the Near East -- a confederation of States in the Semitic countries.

Thirty thousand wearers of the green marched up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth Street to 110th Street through steady rain drip yesterday in honor of St. Patrick. Several hundred thousand of the faithful, umbrella-shielded, cheered from the curbs.

TRENTON, March 17 -- State Finance Commissioner Frank E. Walsh began today a "treasure hunt" within State departments to offset declining revenues and was told of nearly $1,000,000 in claims held by the Highway Department and Department of Commerce and Navigation.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the State Assembly, by voting down the Moffat bill that would have given the City Council power to double the present 1 per cent sales tax, had made it impossible for him to submit by April 1 a balanced budget for 1943-44 without either raising the basic tax rate 20 points or curtailing city services and shutting down some city institutions and departments.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Basic gasoline rations for East Coast motorists were slashed by half today by order of the Office of Price Administration. Beginning with the new ration period next Monday, motorists who have been allowed twelve gallons of gasoline a month will have to get along on an average of six.
A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique, broadcast from Tokyo and recorded by The United Press in New York:

Three midtown theatres will present new films today. At the Radio City Music Hall the attraction will be "Keeper of the Flame," a Metro screen adaptation of the I.A.R. Wylie novel starring Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy. George Cukor directed the romantic drama, which features Richard Whorf, Margaret Wycherly, Horace McNally, Donald Meek, Frank Craven and Darryl Hickman.
NEW DELHI, India, March 17 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

Feeling sappy though seedy, even a bit rakish on warm sunny days, your Topics of the Times column of March 15, with its gardening monologue, came as the answer to a maiden's prayer. And in wartimes a "maiden's prayer" carries with it even more urgent heartthrobs than in days of peace and moonlight.
LONDON, March 17 -- The stock markets remained subdued today and prices sagged for want of support. Home rails weakened and Argentine rails were dull.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, March 17 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace and his party on a Latin-American air tour landed at Al-brook Field today while a fighter escort buzzed overhead.

PITTSBURGH, March 17 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, warned today that the country faced a critical transportation problem and hinted that the civilian population might be compelled to obtain priorities in the not too distant future in order to travel at all.

NEW DELHI, India, March 17 (U.P.) -- India-based American fliers made widespread raids during the past forty-eight hours on enemy objectives in Burma, while in the jungles north of the West Coast port of Akyab British troops stood firm against attacking Japanese units attempting to bend their lines, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Actual receipts of individual income taxes on March 15 were only $246,850,735, a decrease of $145,623,247, compared with March 16 of last year, which was the last day for filing 1941 returns.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The House Rivers and Harbors Committee acted today to brush aside any parliamentary technicality which might obstruct a bill authorizing construction of a ship canal across New Jersey to complete the Atlantic intracoastal waterway.

A trained and uniformed women's corps of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office who completed two months training in military drill, with special training in handling crowds, will receive their colors today at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
CINCINNATI, March 17 (U.P.) -- James A. Farley tonight called for equality of sacrifice in prosecution of the war and intimated that politics should be shelved until next year.

The screams of a 23-year-old night club singer at 2:30 A.M. yesterday as she was being forced into a hallway near 159th Street and Amsterdam Avenue led to the arrest of Norman Smith, 16-yearold Negro of 450 West 164th Street.

Army and Navy officials of a large delegation of experts from South and Central America, who have been touring this country to study mutual problems of hemispheric defense and of speedy achievement of victory, were the guests last evening at a reception at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, following a tour of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn during the day.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- In formal recommendations made tonight the Food Industry War Committee, ending a two-day session, pressed demands that the government adopt a program for a "business-like" handling of the food production and distribution problem.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 17 -- The third day of Yankee training went into history today and natives and camp followers still are waiting for the familiar crash of bat on ball.

At Tuesday's press conference Mr. Roosevelt offered a curious piece of evidence given him by Mr. La Guardia to support the latter's theory of coffee-making. It purports to be a copy of an inscription on a blank page of a translation of Epicurus printed in 1656. It is a recipe on how to use "Copha," a form absent from the Oxford Dictionary:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 17 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, March 17 -- The commander of a training battalion who is said to have ordered his men to salute with a "hi-de-hi" and a "ho-de-ho" has been relieved of his post.
W.D. Hancock, in 145 E 52d St, through the Carpenter Realty Corp.; William D. McAdam, Miss Michelle C. Parker, in 139 E 35th St -- the Tishman Realty and Construction Co, broker.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Even in advance of any committee consideration of the resolution introduced yesterday by four Senators for the setting up of a United Nations organization to combine definite post-war action with the fighting of the war, the Senate received today an amendment proposing restrictions upon such an international body.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, sent to Congress today recommendations by the Social Security Board which he said envisaged "the ultimate attainment of a unified social security program which will sustain individual initiative on the part of American workers and their families while providing a bulwark against all major risks to those whose livelihood depends on work."

Evidence of widespread irregularities in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Act, with stories of padded doctor bills, overcharges and kickbacks, involving physicians, lawyers, licensed representatives and referees, was presented yesterday at the opening hearing of an inquiry under William F. Bleakley, Moreland Act Commissioner.

Former Judge William H. Hastie, who resigned as civilian aide to Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson in protest at alleged racial discrimination in the armed services, has won the Spingarn Medal for 1942, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, March 18 (AP) -- The Allies dropped 392 bombs in a heavy attack yesterday on the big Japanese naval base at Rabaul, New Britain, Allied Headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- While no official clarification was available here today regarding General Giraud's action in continuing the Vichy Government's abrogation of the Cremieux decree of 1870, informed circles among both French groups here said that the effect was to place Arabs and native Jews in Algeria on an equal footing by eliminating the privileges that native Algerian Jews had enjoyed since 1870.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- After reporting to President Roosevelt at the White House today, Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, General Douglas MacArthur's air commander in the Southwest Pacific, declined to comment on the nature of their discussions, but cautiously implied a confirmation of the belief that he is here to urge more planes for the Southwest Pacific theatre.

Although taxes were $18,650,000 larger, earnings of the J.C. Penney Company for 1942 increased over those in 1941, according to the annual report of E.C. Sams, president, issued for release today. The net profit after all charges and taxes was $18,058,136, equal to $6.58 a share on 2,743,984 shares of common stock, compared with $17,128,104, or $6.24 a common share, the year before.

Producers and wholesalers in the New York area admit without exception that voluntary systems of allocating scarce merchandise to retailers "are full of headaches" and that many special adjustments have been necessary, Carl H. Henrikson Jr., regional business consultant of the Department of Commerce, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Downtown Textile Credit Group in the Arkwright Club.

The problem of adequate civilian medical care will become increasingly acute in 1943, with 11,000 more doctors entering the armed services, Dr. Frank H. Lahey, former president of the American Medical Association and now chief of the procurement and assignment division of the War Manpower Commission, yesterday told a convention of the American College of Surgeons in the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 17 -- A seeming dampener on hopes expressed in various quarters for an early attempt to establish a second European front was felt in today's utterances by Viscount Cranborne, Government leader in the House of Lords, who warned that there was nothing so dangerous as a premature attack.

Louis Kaufman, violinist, formerly a member of the Musical Art Quartet, who, for a number of years, has been actively engaged in recording scores for important film companies in California, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. In addition to the Tchaikovsky concerto, the Brahms sonata in D minor and a Desplanes-Natchez "Intrada," the program contained five contemporary American offerings which received their first New York hearings.

Headed by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt as honorary chairman, the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace took final shape yesterday during a daylong conference at headquarters of the Young Women's Christian Association at 600 Lexington Avenue.

The four-story factory and warehouse building at 258,-260 and 268 Gold Street, corner of Tillary Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold by the estate of Helen Barnutz to Celia Dorfman for investment. The property is 185 by 100 feet and was assembled by the sellers over a period of years.

CHUNGKING, China, March 17 (U.P.) -- The Japanese retreat in Central China grew today as Chinese troops, pushing swiftly northward toward the Yangtze River, recaptured five more towns and launched their climatic assault on the enemy-held city of Hwajung.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek must find one gift for Chinese relief particularly interesting, both in size and in source. The amount is the respectable figure of $100,000. The donor is a labor union, the International Ladies Garment Workers.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Both houses of the Legislature drove through long calendars today, with the Assembly in session more than six hours. The day started with the Lower House adopting an adjournment resolution which would end the legislative session on Friday, March 26, at 4 P.M.

Reports from both sides agree that the big Allied push to throw the Axis out of Africa is at hand. Berlin announces that the British Eighth Army has started a large-scale offensive against the Mareth Line. The increased Allied air, artillery and patrol activity along the whole Tunisian front is taken to indicate that the offensive will not be limited to that spot.

American flying equipment in North Africa is as good as that of the German Luftwaffe, if not better, and our pilots are "infinitely superior to the Hun," Colonel J.S. Allard, a veteran flier of World War I, who now serves under Major Gen. James Doolittle with the Twelfth Army Air Force in Africa, declared yesterday.

One of the largest contributions yet received by the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City was announced last night at a dinner at the Union League Club, at which William Edward Cotter, chairman of the chemical division of the fund's commerce and industry committee, disclosed that the Union Carbine and Carbon Corporation had given $100,000.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- A strong undertone developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Reports from Washington suggesting quick action by the House on the Steagall bill which would prohibit the Office of Price Administration from including benefit payments in computing ceiling prices on agricultural products brought in fairly aggressive buying, and while there was profit-taking on the upturns the close was about the top.

The urgent need for additional space for its engineering department has led the aircraft division of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of Hagerstown, Md., to open a branch office here, J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the company, announced yesterday.

In its annual report for 1942, made public yesterday, the Transit Commission declared that it was "primarily responsible," since its creation in 1921, for saving the city's transit riders, on a conservative estimate, "the surprisingly huge sum of $1,000,000,000."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 -- Through Jose W. Agusti, owner and editor of Noticias Graficas of Buenos Aires, a group of Argentine journalists said here today that thinking citizens of Argentina expected the United States to "take and keep the leadership of the whole world after this conflict and to make sure this will be the last war."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- After ruling out all attempts to amend the measure, the House passed today by a voice vote the bill appropriating $26,100,000 for recruitment and transportation of farm laborers for areas where the situation is critical.

Ralph Seward, impartial chairman of the milk industry, has recommended considerable increases in wages and overtime payments -- including retroactive payments from Oct. 25 -- for 13,000 inside employes, drivers and garage workers handling milk. Present earnings of milk drivers and garage workers average $53.57, and of inside workers $41.84 weekly.

Stocks were reduced further in value yesterday on the Stock Exchange by selling pressure, but general retreats of a point were whittled to fractions in a belated move toward recovery. The market spread over a wider variety of issues than in recent sessions, although the bulk of the business continued to be in low-priced shares.

With some 650,000 income tax returns still to be tabulated, and $130,000,000 estimated as the amount to be realized in these returns, Collectors of Internal Revenue in the Second and Third Districts here reported yesterday that they alreday had banked sums equal to the total for the first quarter of last year.

More than fifty of the twentieth century French paintings from the Chester Dale collection will soon be placed on indefinite loan at the Chicago Art Institute. This group includes world famous examples by Picasso, Braque, Derain, Matisse, Utrillo, Vlaminck and other leaders of French modernism.

Thomas W. Lamont was elected yesterday chairman of the board of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., succeeding J.P. Morgan, who died last Saturday. Announcement of the election was made after the regular meeting of the board. Russell C. Leffingwell was chosen chairman of the executive committee of the bank, succeeding Mr. Lamont in that post.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A complaint that the Controlled Materials Plan announced by the War Production Board last November was making it difficult or impossible for most war manufacturers to fulfill their allotted production schedules has been made by the Automotive Council for War Production, representing automobile manufacturers, in a letter to C.E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed unqualified opposition today to the Austin-Wadsworth National War Service Bill as threatening the creation of "slave-labor" conditions in America.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate passed today a bill directing local Selective Service boards to defer from the draft farmers working substantially full time to produce essential crops:

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Five Japanese soldiers were the only survivors out of the 15,000 aboard the twenty-two ships sunk by American forces in the recent Bismarck Sea engagement, Elmer Davis, Director of War Information, stated at a press conference today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 17 -- "I would say," remarked Lippy Leo Durocher today when surrounded by a group of inquisitive scribes during a lull in his exercising in the West Point Field House, "that Les Webber will be the Dodgers' number one relief pitcher this year."

Thousands of invitations by telegram and letter from American and Chinese individuals and organizations, including the Governors of eight States, had been received here by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek as China's first lady prepared last night to leave for her transcontinental tour today, it was revealed by a spokesman.

AT THE FRENCH FRONTIER, March 17 (AP) -- Vichy police and German Elite Guards, in further efforts to frustrate the flight of youth from forced labor for the Germans, made wholesale arrests today of French villagers who fed the refugees in the Haute Savoie mountains.

Arthur Meissner, burly German alien who has been a city policeman for the last six years under the name of an American seaman he formerly worked with, William Jocher of Philadelphia, was held in $2,500 bail in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of voting illegally last November.

New York, Philadelphia and Puerto Rico shared honors in last night's final bouts of the 1943 Golden Gloves Tournament of Champions at Madison Square Garden. Each district took two championships as the amateur boxing tourney, sponsored annually by the News Welfare Association, came to a close before 18,796 spectators.

One might think there would be no more dancing in France, but there is. There is dancing in the French Department of Creuse, southwest of Vichy, where the Central Massif drops westward, and there are rain and mist on the hills. There is what the Prefect of Creuse, reported over the Vichy radio, describes as "clandestine dancing." The Prefect of Creuse cannot drive out the Nazis who are robbing and murdering his people.

Japan's loss of merchant tonnage between the attack on Pearl Harbor and March 1 of this year was estimated here last night by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox as 1,857,000 gross tons out of an original tonnage of 6,369,000.

Much civilian air mail for overseas destinations is being transported by ship instead of by airplane because of inadequate air transportation, it was disclosed yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman. Military necessity may even cause overseas civilian air mail to be eliminated entirely, he added.

LONDON, March 17 -- Slipping into Floroe Harbor, in Southwestern Norway, early Sunday morning, light coastal forces manned entirely by men of the Royal Norwegian Navy made a successful attack on enemy shipping lying in the roadstead without loss to themselves, the Admiralty announced today.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The State Assembly defeated today, by a wide margin, the bill to permit New York City to increase, by local law, the city sales tax and the special taxes on business. The measure got only 50 affirmative votes, 26 short of the required majority, and 79 were adverse votes -- an upset for the legislative leadership that surprised even the Democratic opponents of the measure.

The preliminary annual report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for 1942, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $5,647,637 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was an increase of $2,744,044 over the net of $2,903,593 reported for 1941.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Much of the railroads' present record-breaking volume of traffic is only temporary and when the war is ended they will go back to other forms of competition, Dr. J.H. Parmelee, director of the Bureau of Railway Economics, told a Presidential fact-finding board today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 17 -- Three local boys fired with an Urge to do their bit for Uncle Sam put their St. Patrick's holiday to good use today by traveling from one end of this city to the other and disregarding adult rebuffs until their persistence finally got them a promise of farm work on neighbors' victory gardens.

LONDON, Thursday, March 18 -- Russian troops have regained ground at one point in the savage Donets River battle below Kharkov, captured dozens more hamlets in the sweep toward Smolensk and driven new holes in Nazi lines near Lake Ilmen, Moscow announced today.

DES MOINES, March 17 -- Governor B.B. Hickenlooper today made public a telegram received from a Storm Lake business man and farm owner who outlined some of his problems. Some of these were discussed at the Governor's recent farm conference.

LONDON, March 17 -- The Battle of the Atlantic still remains a cause of "continued anxiety," Britain's First Lord of the Admiralty. A.V. Alexander, told the House of Commons today in the course of a debate in which he crashed his fist down on a dispatch box while he was defending himself against charges of complacency and vanity.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews has announced plans for the first nation-wide observance of a Religious Book Week from March 28 to April 3. In cooperation with the Council of Books in Wartime, the conference has prepared a list of books, including those of the three major faiths in the United States, designed to stimulate the reading of religious books. The list has been distributed to 6,000 libraries throughout the country.

Unable to get enough dressed poultry for a government order through regular channels, local officials of the Food Distribution Administration invoked yesterday for the first time their powers to establish sales priorities to make sure their needs were met promptly, John F. Conaboy, New York area supervisor of the FDA, disclosed.
Many leases of business and manufacturing space to garment firms and companies in allied lines of trade were reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Acceptance of the gift of the Lessing J. Rosenwald Collection of Prints, drawings and rare books was announced today by the National Gallery of Art and the Library of Congress, where selections from the collection will be placed on exhibition during April.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 17 West Seventeenth Street has been purchased for investment by the Lou-Gren Realty Corporation, Jerome Greene, president, from Sara B. Rosen, it was announced yesterday.

In the driving rain of the March afternoon, as I waited under my umbrella on a Fifth Avenue corner for the lights to signal right-of-way for cross-town vehicles and pedestrians, I was admiring the black-bronze statue effect of the traffic policeman's waterproof-garbed figure at the middle of the intersection.

CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP) -- Elections of A.T. Lowmaster of Richmond, Va., to the new position of executive vice president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and of Frank D. Beale of Cleveland as vice, president in charge of operations of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, which is controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio, were announced today by the railroads.

Music is to be included in the Pulitzer awards this year, along with journalism and letters, according to an announcement by Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of Columbia University. Heretofore the only recognition of merit in the field of music has been a scholarship awarded each year to some promising young composer, to help him in continuing his studies.

Whether the order of the Petroleum Administrator for War reducing by 40 per cent the fuel oil rations for industrial use for the first quarter of this year will be extended after April 1 will "depend upon conditions prevailing at that time," Federal officials said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Navy communique 314:

LONDON, March 17 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, discussing the future of the British Empire in the House of Commons, today said that "the government is convinced the administration of British colonies must continue to be the sole responsibility of Great Britain."

The nation's home front took on some added strength last night when four classes of women and girls received certificates for the completion of various courses in home nursing and first aid. The special ceremonies were held in the auditorium of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, 331 East Seventieth Street.

A "Fiesta of the United Nations," including national folk songs and dances, short dramatic presentations and exhibitions and auctions of native art and craft objects, will be held for the benefit of the American Red Cross War Fund at the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow through Sunday, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Nobile Giacomo de Martino, Italian Ambassador to the United States in 1928, was proved a good prophet through the publication today by the State Department of two volumes of "Foreign Relations of the United States" for that year.

WILMINGTON, March 17 -- The present management of the United Corporation, after defeating an attempt by the Securities and Exchange Commission to prevent a resumption of the annual meeting of stockholders because of alleged proxy irregularities, was returned to power this afternoon by an overwhelming majority.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur should receive more sea support for his land operations in the South Pacific, Vice Admiral John Wills Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District and Western sea frontier, said today.

FORT DIX, N.J., March 17 -- Although deprived of its orchestra by a union ruling, the Philadelphia Opera Company went ahead tonight with a performance of "Die Fledermaus" by Johann Strauss at this post and was warmly received by an all-soldier audience.
